snippets.title: Day 1: The Blind King's Question
snippets.sanskrit:
धृतराष्ट्र उवाच |
धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः |
मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ||१||

सञ्जय उवाच |
दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा |
आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् ||२||

पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम् |

snippets.transliteration:
Dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca:
Dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ
Māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kim akurvata sañjaya

Sañjaya uvāca:
Dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṁ vyūḍhaṁ duryodhanas tadā
Ācāryam upasaṅgamya rājā vacanam abravīt

Paśyaitāṁ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīṁ camūm
Vyūḍhāṁ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
verseTranslations: Dhritarashtra said: "O Sanjaya, assembled on the holy field of Kurukshetra, eager to fight—what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?"
Sanjaya replied: "Having seen the Pandava army arranged in battle formation, King Duryodhana approached his teacher Drona and spoke."
"O Teacher, look at this great army of Pandu's sons, arranged by the son of Drupada—your wise disciple."
snippets.commentary:
Think about this for a moment: the Bhagavad Gita doesn't begin with Krishna. It doesn't begin with Arjuna. It begins with a blind man asking a question from his palace, miles away from the battlefield.

Dhritarashtra couldn't see. But his blindness wasn't just physical—and that's precisely the point.

The day before this war, the sage Vyasa came to Dhritarashtra and offered him something extraordinary. "I can give you divine sight," Vyasa said. "You can witness everything that happens on this battlefield."

Dhritarashtra's response? "No, thank you. I'm comfortable as I am. But if you're offering, give it to Sanjaya instead."

*I'm comfortable in my blindness.*

How many times have we said the same thing, in different words? We don't want to see what's really happening in our marriage. We don't want to acknowledge what that habit is doing to us. We'd rather not look too closely at how we're living our lives. Chosen blindness feels easier than facing difficult truths.

The Gita begins here because this is where most of us begin—not wanting to see.

Now look at the first words Dhritarashtra speaks: *"Dharmakshetre Kurukshetre"*—at the field of Dharma, at Kurukshetra.

He calls it Dharmakshetra. The field of righteousness. He knows. Somewhere deep down, Dhritarashtra knows exactly which side represents Dharma in this war. He's not confused about right and wrong. He simply can't bring himself to act on what he knows.

This is one of the Gita's earliest teachings, tucked into its very first line: knowing what's right is not the same as doing what's right. Dhritarashtra knew. He just couldn't act.

There's something else hidden in this verse—a single word that reveals everything about why this war is happening. The word is *"Māmakāḥ"*—mine.

"What did *my* sons and *Pandu's* sons do?"

But wait. Weren't they all grandsons of the same man? Weren't the Pandavas also descendants of Kuru? Why aren't they all simply "Kauravas"?

Because Dhritarashtra couldn't see them that way. *My* children versus *their* children. *My* family versus *those people*. This is how he saw the world. This is how the world always divides itself before it goes to war.

We do this too, don't we? My team versus their team. My community versus outsiders. We draw these lines constantly, and then we wonder why there's so much conflict. The Gita is pointing at something fundamental here: this *mine versus yours* thinking is the seed from which all conflict grows.

In verse 2, the scene shifts to the battlefield. Sanjaya begins his narration, and immediately we see something curious: Duryodhana, the mighty king with the larger army, is nervous.

He had eleven akshauhinis—massive military divisions. The Pandavas had only seven. By any calculation, he should win. Yet look at what he does: he rushes to his teacher Drona, not to the commander Bhishma, and starts anxiously pointing out the enemy's strengths.

Why would someone with such an advantage feel so unsettled?

Because numbers aren't everything. Duryodhana knew, in some part of himself, that he was on the wrong side of this fight. He had stolen a kingdom. He had tried to kill his cousins. He had humiliated Draupadi in open court. All the military might in the world couldn't quiet that knowledge.

This is something worth sitting with: when you're doing the right thing, you can face challenges with a certain peace. When you're not, no amount of external advantage makes you feel secure. Duryodhana had everything going for him—except the one thing that would have given him real confidence.

And then comes verse 3, where Duryodhana speaks to Drona. On the surface, he's just pointing out the Pandava formation. But listen to his words more carefully: "Look at this army, arranged by the son of Drupada—*your wise disciple*."

There's an accusation buried in that phrase. *Your* disciple. The one *you* taught. Duryodhana is essentially saying: "This is your fault, teacher. You trained them. You gave them the skills they're now using against us."

This is how it works when we're not willing to own our choices. We blame the teacher, the parents, the circumstances, the system—anyone but ourselves. Duryodhana never once stopped to ask: "How did my own actions lead us here?" Instead, he looked for someone else to hold responsible.

There's a deeper teaching embedded in the structure of these opening verses that often gets overlooked. Notice how Vyasa, the author, chose to begin the text. He could have started with Krishna's teaching. He could have opened with some grand philosophical statement about the nature of reality. Instead, he begins with a question born from anxiety.

Dhritarashtra asks: *"Kim akurvata"*—what did they do? He's desperate to know. He can't bear the uncertainty. And this desperation reveals something crucial about the nature of attachment.

When we are deeply attached to an outcome, uncertainty becomes unbearable. We need to know. We check our phones constantly. We ask the same questions over and over. We cannot rest until we have information that confirms or denies our hopes and fears.

Dhritarashtra is not simply curious about the battle. He is terrified. His whole sense of security—the kingdom he helped his son steal, the dynasty he hoped to establish—depends on the outcome of this war. No wonder he's asking questions before a single arrow has been fired.

The Gita begins this way to show us something about ourselves. How much of our mental activity is driven by this same anxious need to know? How much of our day is spent checking, confirming, seeking reassurance?

Swami Chinmayananda used to point out that Kurukshetra was not just any battlefield—it was considered sacred ground. The name literally means "field of the Kurus," the ancestral dynasty. But it was also called Dharmakshetra because it was a place where great sages had performed austerities and spiritual practices for generations.

There's a profound symbolism here. The battle for dharma—for right living—doesn't happen in some pristine spiritual environment away from the mess of life. It happens right here, on the same ground where our ancestors walked, where our family dramas play out, where the stakes are highest and the relationships most complicated.

You don't get to choose a convenient time and place for your spiritual growth. The battlefield finds you. It might be your workplace, your marriage, your relationship with your aging parents, your own health crisis. The question is never "how do I avoid the battle?" The question is "how do I face it with clarity?"

Consider also the role of Sanjaya in these verses. He's the narrator, the one with divine sight, granted by Vyasa. Throughout the Gita, Sanjaya reports what's happening on the battlefield to the blind king.

Sanjaya represents something important: the possibility of true seeing. Unlike Dhritarashtra, who chose blindness, Sanjaya accepted the gift of vision. He can see the truth, and he reports it faithfully, even when that truth is painful to hear.

Every one of us has access to our own inner Sanjaya—that part of us that knows the truth, that sees clearly, that isn't fooled by our rationalizations. The question is: do we listen to it? Or do we, like Dhritarashtra, prefer to remain comfortable in our blindness?

The Gita is, in one sense, an invitation to become our own Sanjaya—to develop the capacity to see our lives clearly, to witness our own dramas with some degree of objectivity, to tell ourselves the truth even when it's inconvenient.

One more thing worth noting about these opening verses: the emotional tone. There's urgency here. There's anxiety. There's blame. There's defensiveness. The battlefield hasn't even begun, and already we see the full range of human reactivity on display.

This is intentional. The Gita doesn't pretend that we come to spiritual teaching from a place of calm readiness. We come to it desperate, confused, looking for someone to blame, terrified of what might happen. We come to it exactly as Arjuna will come to it in the verses ahead—overwhelmed and unable to function.

And that's okay. That's the starting point. The Gita meets us where we are.

Finally, let's consider the setting of these opening verses from a practical perspective. Here is Duryodhana, about to fight the most important battle of his life, and instead of focusing on strategy or inspiring his troops, he's complaining to his teacher about the enemy's strengths.

This is what anxiety does to us. It makes us focus on threats rather than possibilities. It makes us rehearse worst-case scenarios. It makes us seek validation for our fears rather than courage for our actions.

Duryodhana had assembled the greatest army the world had ever seen. He had legendary warriors on his side—Bhishma, Drona, Karna, Ashwatthama. He had every material advantage. And yet here he is, fixated on what the other side has, unable to appreciate his own resources.

We do this constantly. We have health, relationships, skills, opportunities—and we obsess over what we lack. We have support systems and capabilities—and we fixate on the obstacles. This is the Duryodhana mind at work, and it never leads anywhere good.

The antidote isn't positive thinking or denial of real challenges. The antidote is clarity—seeing what we actually have, what the situation actually requires, and acting from that clear seeing rather than from anxiety and complaint.

That's the journey the Gita will take us on. But it starts here, with recognizing where we are: blind like Dhritarashtra, anxious like Duryodhana, looking for someone to blame. Only when we see this clearly can we begin to move beyond it.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses invite us to examine the Dhritarashtra within ourselves. Notice how he uses the word "Mamakah"—mine—creating an immediate division between "my sons" and "Pandu's sons," even though both groups are equally his nephews and part of the same Kuru dynasty. This week, observe where you draw similar lines in your own life. Where do you say "my team" versus "their team," "my community" versus "outsiders"? The Gita suggests that this "mine versus theirs" thinking is the very seed from which all conflict grows.

Consider also the profound symbolism of Dhritarashtra's chosen blindness. When Vyasa offered him divine sight to witness the battle, he refused, preferring the comfort of not seeing. Ask yourself: What truths am I choosing not to see in my own life? Is there a difficult conversation I'm avoiding? A habit whose consequences I refuse to acknowledge? A relationship truth I'd rather not face? Like Dhritarashtra, we often find comfort in blindness—but the Gita reminds us that this comfort comes at a terrible cost.

Finally, notice how Duryodhana, despite having the larger army (eleven akshauhinis versus seven), rushes nervously to his teacher Drona to point out the enemy's strengths. This reveals a profound truth: when we know deep down that our cause is not righteous, no amount of external advantage brings real security. Reflect on areas of your life where you feel anxious despite having "everything going for you." Could this anxiety be pointing to a misalignment between your actions and your deeper sense of what is right?

snippets.title: Day 2: The Warriors Assembled
snippets.sanskrit:
अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि |

धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् |

युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् |
snippets.transliteration:
atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjunasamā yudhi .

dhṛṣṭaketuścekitānaḥ kāśirājaśca vīryavān .

yudhāmanyuśca vikrānta uttamaujāśca vīryavān .
verseTranslations:
Here are heroes, mighty archers, equal in battle to Bhima
and Arjuna, Yoyudhana (Satyaki), Virata and Drupada, of the great car (mighty
warriors).

"Dhrishtaketu, chekitana and the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit
and Kuntibhoja and Saibya, the best men.

"The strong Yodhamanyu and the brave Uttamaujas, the son
of Subhadra (Abhimanyu, the son of Subhadra and Arjuna), and the sons of
Draupadi, all of great chariots (great heroes).
snippets.commentary:
We'll be discussing Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 1, Arjuna Vishada Yoga—the Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. In our scriptural system, there are two types of scripture, divided into two major categories. One is called Shruti. The other is called Smriti.

Shruti means "heard" and Smriti means "remembered." The scriptures considered "heard" by the great sages in their contemplation, in their inspired moments, and then given out to the world, are considered Shrutis. Based on those scriptures—the truths found in Shruti—the systems, laws, customs, and traditions of society were developed; these are called Smritis. Shrutis are typically considered as Prasthana Trayi. There are three legs of Shruti. One is the Upanishads, which we have all learned.

They come at the end of the Vedas. Vedas generally describe all types of sciences which are utilitarian or material in nature—things one can use in his lifetime. But at the end of the Vedas, there are dialogues between students and teachers. They are called Upanishads. They deal with the fundamental questions we all ask, knowingly or unknowingly: Who am I? Is there someone who has control over my life, and what is my relationship with that controller?

So these are dialogues between students and teachers, set in the serene environment of Himalayan valleys. Both students and teachers are highly evolved seekers. The teacher is a realized master who has gone through his Sadhana and realized the truth. The student is also a highly evolved seeker who has gone through Sadhana and is now finding his final answers.

The truths in Srutis are immutable. Rather, they cannot be changed over a period of time, from one age to another. The Shruti does not change. The truths revealed in Srutis do not change. Smriti, on the other hand, are the laws created by society, by the leaders of the society. The lawmakers in the society are adaptable to the new environment in the society.

So the two mains we hear about are Parasara and Manusmriti. Mainly manusmriti is the one which we hear most, we heard most about. In fact, if I'm not mistaken, the laws in India before independence and somewhat after the independence were structured based on Manusmriti. Laws for Hindus were Hindu laws and they were based on Manusmriti. And laws for Muslims were based on Syria. So the Manusmriti was considered the code of conduct for the society.

As we know, we don't apply Manusmriti as-is in our society now. Even in India, the laws have changed, society has changed. The basic structure may remain what Manusmriti says, but many things we have updated to fit our current needs. On the other hand, the facts revealed in Shruti are unchangeable. It is something like mathematics—I can use mathematics in my life from childhood to old age, depending on my own needs, and I'll interpret mathematics accordingly.

But the fundamentals of mathematics do not change. 2+2 remained 4 when I was in kindergarten; it still remains 4 when I'm an old man and consider myself a wise person. The spiritual tenets in Shruti are like those rules—unchangeable. They remain constant no matter how you look at it or try to prove it. But the application of those laws can change according to society. The way I used mathematics in my childhood is different from how I used it as a high school student, then as a college student, and then as a professional.

My applications are different based on my own situation. So Smritis are like those adaptable sciences which we can update as we go along in our society. The fundamentals of Manusmriti may remain the same, but the application is completely changed in our society now. So there are three aspects of the Shruti: the Upanishads as we talked about, Brahma Sutra, and third is Bhagavad Gita. Bhagavad Gita is considered an Upanishad by itself.

Therefore, at the end of every chapter we say "Upanishadsu Bhagavad Gita." It's considered an Upanishad by itself because it reveals the truths found in Shruti. But the uniqueness of Bhagavad Gita is that it is also considered Smriti—it's a combination of Shruti and Smriti. Therefore it has a unique place in Prasthana Trayi.

In Prasthana Trayi, if you just learn Upanishads, they are transcendental. They transcend my day-to-day life, telling me what the ultimate truth is and how it relates to me. And they are set in a very serene environment, as I said before. Bhagavad Gita, on the other hand, is set in a completely different environment. It's still a dialogue between a student and a teacher.

But here the student and teacher are not a great master and a lowly seeker trying to understand. They were two friends—a dialogue between two friends, two cousins. One was great, but he did not act like one when it comes to his friendship. So it's a dialogue between two equals, set in an environment completely different from Himalayan valleys—it's on the battlefield. Some commentators think that the whole Mahabharata was written by Bhagavan Ved Vyas.

To have a platform for Bhagavad Gita, he had to have a proper background to convert it into a scripture that can guide mankind. The entire Mahabharata, which is a hundred thousand verses as we now know it, originally started out as a book called Jaya with only 24,000 verses. But it did have Bhagavad Gita in it. Bhagavad Gita is the central crown jewel of Mahabharata. Mahabharata became the greatest epic of all times for Hindu culture, for India, and for the world because of Bhagavad Gita. Remove Bhagavad Gita and Mahabharata becomes another story of a Kuru clan.

At the same token, remove Mahabharata and Bhagavad Gita becomes merely poetry, something similar to Upanishads. They have a symbiotic relationship. Mahabharata converts Bhagavad Gita into a Smriti which can be used in day-to-day life. Mahabharata gives us the background of human society—human conditions, human aspirations, human shortcomings. It is generally said that Mahabharata contains all human situations. If you don't find a situation in Mahabharata, it does not exist.

You may find any situation from Mahabharata in other works of art, but not the other way around. So Mahabharata sets the stage, and we all know the story—the cousins Kauravas and Pandavas were fighting for their rights, and Duryodhana said he's not giving even a square inch of land, even though rightfully Pandavas were the claimants for that kingdom. The war is about to begin, and we are now going to see a dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna.

In the first chapter, called Arjuna Vishada Yoga, there are no great philosophical revelations, so one should not seek philosophical explanations in Chapter 1. Bhagavan Shankaracharya in his Gita Bhashya does not start his commentary until verse 11 of Chapter 2. He didn't think it was worth his time to talk about Chapter 1 and the first 10 verses of Chapter 2.

But for us common folks, context is very important. Without context, we lose the meaning of what we are discussing. Chapter 1 gives us the context for the dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna.

Krishna and Arjuna are the two main characters in this dialogue, but there are two other people involved in Bhagavad Gita: Dhritarashtra and Sanjaya. Dhritarashtra, as we know, was the King of Hastinapur. Duryodhana and the other Kauravas were his sons, and he could have avoided this war by just his own declaration—but he did not. He was blind from birth and therefore was not considered worthy of being king. But because of the situation with Pandu, the younger son, he was made the caretaker king, and Duryodhana became the effective king—like MBS in Saudi Arabia.

Duryodhana was the one actually making the decisions, and he obviously was not going to give up the kingdom he had already been enjoying for so many years. When the war is about to begin, Dhritarashtra is still sitting in the palace because he's not taking part in the war, but he's curious about what's going on. He knew that the Kaurava side has 11 Akshauhini Sena and the Pandavas have 7—so 11 plus 7 is 18. You will see that 18 is the magic number: there are 18 books in Mahabharata, the war lasted 18 days, and there are 18 chapters in Bhagavad Gita.

Apparently one Akshauhini has 21,870 chariots, the same number of elephants, three times that of horses, and five times that of foot soldiers. If you take any of these numbers and add their digits, they will add up to 18. Take 21,870 and add up the digits—it adds up to 18. Multiply that by three, and the digits add up to 18 again. Multiply by five—same result.

If you do the math, there were about 4 million people on that battlefield. Now, I've never been to Kurukshetra, so I can't tell you it's large enough to hold 4 million people. But according to this calculation, about 4 million soldiers were ready to fight. The war is about to begin. Dhritarashtra knew that his side is much stronger—11 Akshauhini versus Pandava's 7.

But he also knew who is on the right side and who was on the wrong side. That gives you a little pause in thinking about what is going to happen. He wanted to know what's going on, and he had an opportunity. The day before, Bhagavan Vyasa stopped by his palace and said, "You really need to see what's happening, and I can give you divine vision so that you can see it." But he said, "I'm comfortable in my blindness. I really don't want to see."

"But if you are really kind enough, give it to my minister Sanjaya." So Sanjaya got the Divya Drishti, the divine vision. Now, we do not know how all that happened. Maybe Sanjaya was on the battlefield and reported back. But it is believed that Sanjaya had this divine vision—not only could he see things happening on the battlefield, but he could also see what's going on in people's minds. He can hear, he can see, and he can perceive.

Therefore it's called Divya Drishti—he has much greater capacity than an average person. Ati Drishti means he can see even further than a normal person. Dhritarashtra knew that Sanjaya can see everything. So the very first verse starts with "Dhritarashtra Uvacha." Notice that Bhagavad Gita did not start with "Krishna Uvacha" or "Bhagavan Uvacha" or "Arjuna Uvacha." It started with Dhritarashtra, the blind king. These characters are there in Chapter 1 and in Mahabharata.

So we can identify with the situation. I may not be able to identify with Arjuna, but I can probably identify with Dhritarashtra as a father. Maybe I have done something that Dhritarashtra did, and therefore suffered.
snippets.reflection:
These verses enumerate the mighty Pandava warriors: Yuyudhana (Satyaki), Virata, Drupada, Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the King of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, Shaibya, Yudhamanyu, Uttamaujas, Abhimanyu, and the sons of Draupadi—all described as "maharathas" (great chariot warriors). Notice that Duryodhana is reciting this list not to his commander Bhishma, but to his teacher Drona. This reveals his anxiety: he's essentially saying, "Look at all these students you trained who are now fighting against us." When we feel insecure about our position, we often seek validation from those we hope to influence.

Reflect on times when you've enumerated your competitors' strengths to someone whose loyalty you questioned. Perhaps before a presentation, you listed all the reasons the other team might win, hoping for reassurance. This is the Duryodhana pattern—anxiety masquerading as assessment. The Gita shows us that true security doesn't come from counting resources or comparing strengths, but from alignment with dharma.

Consider also the teaching embedded in Bhagavad Gita's structure: it is both Shruti (revealed scripture revealing eternal truths) and Smriti (remembered wisdom applicable to daily life). Unlike the Upanishads set in serene Himalayan valleys, this dialogue unfolds on a battlefield between two friends and cousins. What battles are you facing right now in your workplace, family, or inner life? The Gita meets us not in some ideal spiritual environment, but precisely where we are—in the midst of our conflicts, confusions, and competing loyalties. How might you bring the wisdom of scripture to your own "Kurukshetra" today?

snippets.title: Day 3: The Great Heroes
snippets.sanskrit:
अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम |

भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः |

अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः |
snippets.transliteration:
asmākaṃ tu viśiṣṭā ye tānnibodha dvijottama .

bhavānbhīṣmaśca karṇaśca kṛpaśca samitiñjayaḥ .

anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā madarthe tyaktajīvitāḥ .
verseTranslations:
"Thyself and Bhishma, and Karna and also Kripa, the victorious
in war, Asvatthama, Vikarna, and also Bhurisrava, the son of Somadatta.

"And also many other heroes who are ready to give up their
lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled
in battle.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 1, Arjuna Vishada Yoga—the Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. As we discussed before, this is a chapter which gives us the context for the dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna. Bhagavad Gita is part of the Prasthana Trayi, one of the three legs of our philosophy: the Upanishads, Brahma Sutra, and Bhagavad Gita. Bhagavad Gita has a unique place, as we have discussed—it is not only a Shruti because it reveals the Brahma Vidya, but it is also applicable for day-to-day living and social order. Therefore it is also considered Smriti. In that context, we're seeing Chapter 1 as a study in how different people react to the same situation.

We started this Bhagavad Gita with Dhritarashtra's query to Sanjaya: "What's happening at the battlefield?" Dharmakshetra, Kurukshetra, Mamakaha, Pandavaschain. The very first thing we notice is how Dhritarashtra thinks—this world is divided into mine and yours, mine and the rest of the world. "Mamakaha"—mine, and Pandava's. This is the central issue we deal with in philosophy: in our Advaita philosophy, the root cause of all our problems is duality. This duality—I as an island by myself, and the world out there—creates friction between I and the world. The very first indication, the first word, tells us where we stand.

We are in the Dhrutrastra Sthiti. We see this world as I, mine and rest. And then as we further go into the chapter we see Sanjay's narration. Sanjaya starts his narration with what is Duryodhan doing? So we are seeing now the world from Duryodhan's perspective, same situation. The two armies are facing each other.

War is about to be started. We all know the background of why they are there very elaborately. The Mahabharata describes what happened before we came to this point of two armies facing each other. Now Duryodhana is looking at the situation. He sees it from a very different perspective: Is this winnable or not? Am I in a winning position or a losing position?

The same situation—as we'll see further in the chapter—Arjuna looks at very differently. He looks at it as whether it's right or wrong to be here. So it gives us various perspectives on how we look at our lives. When we face any situation, depending on our own mental condition, we look at it that way. Swamiji used to say the scriptures are nothing but the mirror of our mind. Every time we read the scriptures, we see our own reflection in it. So we have seen that Sanjaya first says that, looking at the Pandava army, Raja Duryodhana went to Drona and told him thus.

And then he described what he told Drona. First of all, as we know, the commander-in-chief on the Kaurava side was Bheeshma; on the Pandava side, Drishtadyumna, Drupada's son. So if Duryodhana had any question, doubt, or concern, he should have gone to Bheeshma and said, "Let's make sure we are in a winning position." But instead, he goes to Drona, his teacher. It seems he felt there was a soft spot. Drona is as powerful as Bheeshma and Arjuna in terms of his prowess in warfare.

Not only that, all other people who are the great warriors on the other side are Drona's student. So he is now questioning whether he will be at his best when Drona fights this war. It seems therefore he goes to Drona and tells him look at the army on the Pandava side.

Reflect on your own patterns of seeking reassurance when facing challenges. Do you enumerate your "assets" to others when you're actually trying to convince yourself? Do you subtly question the loyalty of those around you, revealing your own insecurity rather than any real deficiency in them? This week, notice where you're seeking external validation for decisions you've already made internally. When you find yourself listing your strengths or resources to others, pause and ask: "Am I strategizing, or am I managing my own anxiety?" The difference matters. True confidence comes not from counting what's on your side, but from knowing your cause is aligned with dharma.

snippets.title: Day 5: The War Begins
snippets.sanskrit:
ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः |

ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ |

पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः |
snippets.transliteration:
tataḥ śaṅkhāśca bheryaśca paṇavānakagomukhāḥ .

tataḥ śvetairhayairyukte mahati syandane sthitau .

pāñcajanyaṃ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṃ dhanañjayaḥ .
verseTranslations:
Then (following Bhishma), conches and kettledrums, tabors,
drums and cow horns blared forth quite suddenly (from the Kaurava side)
and the sound was tremendous.

Then, also, Madhava (Krishna) and the son of Pandu (Arjuna),
seated in the magnificent chariot, yoked with white horses, blew divine
conches.

Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya, and Arjuna blew the Devadatta,
and Bhima (the wolf-bellied), the doer of terrible deeds, blew the great
conch Paundra.
snippets.commentary:
We are now discussing Chapter 1, Arjuna Vishada Yoga—the Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. In the first 12 verses we have seen so far that Dhritarashtra is very anxious to know what's happening with his sons and Pandu's sons. "Mamakaha Pandavaschaiva"—so in the very first verse we see the cause for this war. Dhritarashtra was the guardian after Pandu died for Pandu's sons. When you assign a guardian to take care of children, that guardian is responsible for their welfare and well-being and to protect their interests. That's the job of a guardian. Dhritarashtra, being the Emperor and the uncle of Pandu's sons, was assigned to take care of them.

It was Dhritarashtra's duty to treat Pandu's children as his own, because he was the guardian. But we clearly see how he had a distinction in his mind between his sons and Pandu's sons. "Mamakaha Pandavaschaiva"—that is the cause for this conflict in life. We see that conflict occurs only when someone is not doing his or her duty. Conflicts are there because someone assigned a duty is not doing it, whether it is you or the other. Therefore you also have "Dharmakshetra Kurukshetra" here.

The goal for this war is to establish Dharma again—to re-establish Dharma. Conflict occurs because there is a violation of Dharma somewhere. Who is responsible? One has to figure out.

In the next 11 verses, we have seen what's happening with three of them. Dhritarashtra was very anxious to know what's going on because he obviously wasn't really sure. Duryodhana, in a similar situation, has his own doubts about the loyalty of his own people and generals. He knew for sure that his cause is not validated by all the great generals in his army; he cannot feel comfortable.

They are completely loyal to him. Their loyalties may be divided. They are on my side because of their employment, that they are employed by the kingdom but their hearts may be on the other side. It is quite well known that Arjuna was Drona's favorite student. Bheeshma liked Pandavas more than the Kauravas, so he wasn't sure. So the cause of anxiety which we see here is my own failure to follow my own Dharma.

So all these 12 verses tell us that conflict only occurs when Dharma is violated, and your peace of mind is shattered only when Dharma is violated. When you don't follow your Dharma, your mental peace will be disturbed. We see in Duryodhana that he's suffering from anxiety, and his first target was Drona, because it was quite obvious that Drona has a soft corner for Arjuna and the Pandavas. We have seen his behavior—he enumerates who are on their side and our side, whether our army is enough or not enough. Now we are seeing Bhishma. Bhishma, being the guardian of Hastinapur's throne.

No matter what the situation, he had the duty to keep the army motivated. He realized that if he leaves this situation any longer, not only is Duryodhana going down, but he's going to bring everybody else down with him—Drona and whoever else he is addressing. So in verse 12, he said "Tasya Sanjanayan Harsham"—to cheer them up to fight this battle. "Simhanadam vinadya ucchaih shankham dadhmau pratapavan." He roared like a lion and then blew his own conch.

So we have discussed last time the declaration of the war. Bheeshma has also come to the conclusion that this conflict can only be settled by this war. Dharma can only be established by just fighting this war. And therefore let's get it done. So he blew his own conch. And now we see the reaction, Quick response from everybody.

As soon as Bheeshma blew his own conch, everybody else blew their own conches. There was a great sound—everybody playing their kettledrums and cow-horns. Now, there is a reason why armies used to carry those kettledrums. We also know that sound has its own effect. When you go to a disco, the beats, as the yoga teacher will say, will activate your Muladhara chakra—they will make you dance whether you want to or not. As soon as the beat starts, you start dancing.

So the sound has its own effect in changing your mental makeup. So this great sound will put you into frenzy to do something. So that as soon as the leader has announced that we are ready, everybody else supported and said we are ready too. We have seen the response by the army. Now here interesting thing to note is Bhagavan Vedvyas does not enumerate all the Kauravas generals who blew their conscience. But he does enumerate the Pandavas Tathahas, Swetaihi Hayehi, Yukte Mahati, Syandanesh, Titao, Madhavah, Pandavah, Chayeva, Divya, Sankam, Pradhadvatuhu.

The very first response comes from Madhav seated in the great chariot yoked by white horses. Pandav Arjun Pandu's son. Pandav here is Arjun Divya, Sankhopra, Dhatma. They believe their own divine conscience. Bhagavan Vedvyas didn't say first. Drishtadhamna did that because he was the chief of the army.

Yudhishthir not an Arjun Madhavah. The one person who was really keen in establishing Dharma in Aryavarth was Krishna. He has concluded that this conflict cannot be settled. All the arrogance of Kauravas and their mistreatment to the people will only stop if they are stopped in their tracks. The only way to stop them is to have this war. So the first response actually came from Madhava, Krishna, who had decided he's not going to take up arms himself.

He said, "I'm not fighting." So sometimes without fighting directly, you can still fight the battle. The lesson to be learned here is you don't have to be always actively making noise. You can very silently win the war. Both Madhava and Pandava Arjuna blew their own divine conches. Bhagavan Vedvyasa seems somewhat biased here. He didn't say the conches on the other side were divine, but he specifically said the Pandava conches were divine.

What this means is their cause was divine—to fight this war. Their cause was not driven by their own arrogance or self-interest. Their cause was driven by establishing Dharma. In your own life, when have you needed to sound your voice first, not because of your position, but because of your clarity of purpose?

snippets.title: Day 7: Arjuna Surveys the Field
snippets.sanskrit:
स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् |

अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान् कपिध्वजः |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṃ hṛdayāni vyadārayat .

atha vyavasthitāndṛṣṭvā dhārtarāṣṭrān kapidhvajaḥ .

hṛṣīkeśaṃ tadā vākyamidamāha mahīpate .
verseTranslations:
That tumultuous sound rent the hearts of (the members of)
Dhritarashtra's party, making both the heaven and the earth resound.

Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra’s party standing
arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of
Pandu, whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following
to Krishna, O Lord of the earth.

Arjuna said: In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O Krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence.
snippets.commentary:
We are now discussing Chapter 1, Arjuna Vishada Yoga—the Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. In the first 18 verses, we have seen the situation with Dhritarashtra, the situation with Duryodhana, how Bhishma reacted, and how the Pandavas reacted. What we are basically seeing here is that anytime someone speaks, we can see his mental state. Unless somebody speaks, we will not know what's going on. So up till now, through the very first verse, we have seen Dhritarashtra's state of mind.

Dhritarashtra's state of mind is "Mamakaha Pandavah"—his world is divided between mine and others. Even his own brother's children, whom he has raised, he does not consider to be "mine." So we know now that this division in our mind—this duality of "I and mine" versus the world outside of me—creates the conflict. All the conflicts, as we have discussed, are there because of this sense of duality and because of not following our own Dharma. Had Dhritarashtra followed his Dharma, we wouldn't have this war.

Bhagavan Ved Vyas is now painting the picture of how different people are situated in this Mahabharata. As we have heard many times before, all the characters and situations we encounter in life are already there in the Mahabharata. It is said that if it is not in Mahabharata, it is not worth even knowing or mentioning. The situations we encounter in our life are already depicted somewhere in Mahabharata. So up till now, we have seen that Dhritarashtra said what he wanted to say, and we know that his world is divided into "mine" and "Pandavas."

That's how he saw the world. Then we have seen Sanjaya narrating what's happening on the battlefield. Sanjaya was the most loyal advisor to Dhritarashtra. He would obviously never go against Dhritarashtra or do anything to hurt him. As we know from Mahabharata, even when Dhritarashtra left for the forest after the war, Sanjaya went with him. He was there until they were caught in the forest fire.

I think Dhritarashtra asked him to leave, so he leaves and saves himself. But Dhritarashtra and Gandhari decided they were not going to leave. He was there till the end of his life. But Sanjaya was not a yes-man. As somebody said, if you hire the next guy, don't hire a yes-man—you will be in trouble.

So Sanjaya was a loyal advisor but not a yes-man. Therefore he gave the narration of what's happening as he saw it. As we have seen, first he describes how Duryodhana acted in that situation. He wasn't fully confident. He was evaluating the strength of each army, whether it's good enough or not good enough. And then we have seen that Bhishma declared the war and the Pandavas responded.

But the leader of the Pandavas responding was not one of the General but Madhava himself. The Krishna himself responded first. Krishna had already decided there is no other way but to fight this war to settle the score. So Krishna responded and all Pandavas followed enthusiastically. So you can see that the Pandavas are enthusiastic and confident about their own ability and in their cause. It also gives us an indication.

As long as you are sure about the cause of your pursuits you will be confident. And then we have seen the reaction from Gaurava's side which Sanjay narrates. It's not that we are adding anything here but he never said anything about what happened in the Pandavas side. He only said what's happened on the Dhritarashtra side. And he said this great sound which reverberated between the earth and the sky made the hearts of the people in Dhritarashtra army shiver. He didn't say that for the Pandavas.

This gives an indication that if you're not sure about your cause, any obstacle will make you unsettled. You will not be sure whether this is the right thing to do or not. On the Pandava side, Sanjaya has not given that indication. He saw only the enthusiastic response to Bhishma's call for the war. So we can take a few lessons from here. As long as you're sure about your pursuits, no matter what obstacles arise, you will be confident and you will pursue your path towards your goal.

If you're not sure, even the smallest obstacle will make you rethink: Is this the right thing to do? Am I really putting my energy in the right place? Will I be able to win in this situation? Bhagavan Vedavyasa through Sanjaya's narration is painting this picture of how things work. When we are facing this battle of life, after everyone has expressed their opinion by blowing their own conch, each one has to have their own opinion in life. No matter what other people have said. "Shankhan dadhmuh prithak prithak"—each one has to say "I support it" or "I don't support it."

So one who is not saying anything, we know that he's on the fence. But each one gave their own opinion that they support this pursuit. On the Pandava side we are seeing enthusiastic support; on the Kaurava side, Sanjaya wants to give the correct report to Dhritarashtra because he is the king. And maybe Bhagavan Vedavyasa had a little bias because he had tried in the beginning to stop this war by convincing Dhritarashtra in a last-ditch effort. But it obviously did not work. So verse 19 says: "Sa ghosha Dhartarashtranaam hridayani vyadarayat, nabhas cha prithivim chaiva tumulo abhyanunadadayan"—that tumultuous sound which reverberated between the sky and the earth rent the hearts of Dhritarashtra's army.

Verse 20: "Atha vyavasthitan drishtva Dhartarashtran Kapidhvaja, pravritte shastra sampate dhanuhu udyamya Pandava." Sanjaya now focuses on Arjuna. We have learned from Mahabharata that Sanjaya had this unique vision—not only could he see things, but he could also read people's minds and see things beyond normal perception. In fact, before this war starts, Sanjaya's vision was tested by Bhagavan Vedavyasa and Dhritarashtra. Sanjaya described distant lands which he had never visited before—the people, the culture, and all the fauna and flora of those lands. So he had this great ability to see things which are not within normal perception.

So now he's focusing on Arjuna, describing what Arjuna is doing and saying. Thus having seen the Kaurava army arranged in formation, Kapidhvaja—Arjuna's chariot was called Kapidhvaja because his emblem on his flag was Hanuman. Hanuman was very devoted to Bhagavan Ramachandra, and he said, "In any age, at any time, wherever there is Rama, I will be there."

Krishna being Rama's incarnation, Hanuman is always there when Krishna is involved in a battle. So Arjuna's chariot is called Kapidhvaja. Thus, having seen the Kaurava army now arranged in formation, with all the weapons ready to be discharged—"Dhanuhu udyamya"—he picked up his bow, getting ready. Here Sanjaya addresses Dhritarashtra as "Mahipate, O Lord of the Earth." Having seen all this, Arjuna said this to Hrishikesha, Krishna. "Arjuna uvacha"—now Arjuna speaks. Anytime somebody speaks or opens their mouth, we know what's going on in their mind.

That's why we have this fear of public speaking. Because as long as I keep my mouth shut, you don't know what's going on. Am I a Democrat or Republican or Independent? But as soon as I open my mouth, you know. These days you can also tell what channel someone's watching—MSNBC or Fox News. So up till now, Arjuna has not said anything.

He just blew his conch. So we know he is very confident, very enthusiastic. I wouldn't call him arrogant—I would call him very confident in his pursuit, in what he is going to do, and in his ability. He picks up his bow—ready, I am ready and capable. And then he said: "Arjuna uvacha, senayoho ubhayoho madhye ratham sthapaya me Achyuta"—O Achyuta, place this chariot in the midst of the two armies, right in the middle. He addresses Krishna as "Achyuta"—one who never wavers from his position.

Swamiji reminds us here that this is the iconic image we have of Krishna and Arjuna in the chariot. This reminds students of the Upanishads of the parable of the chariot in Katha Upanishad: this body is the chariot and the atma is the rider. Buddhi is the charioteer, the mind is the reins, and the senses are the horses. The sense objects create the path on which the chariot moves. The senses are running on that path, the mind is the reins.

In the hands of Buddhi, along with the senses, the rider—the ego—becomes the enjoyer. The ego is the rider and the senses are drawing this chariot towards the sense objects. As long as that Buddhi is pure and in control, the chariot will be in control. If the Buddhi is not purified, it will let the senses go in the wrong direction. So here Arjuna tells Krishna to put his chariot right in the middle of the two armies.

Because "Yavat etan nirikshey aham yoddhu kaman avasthitan, kairmaya saha yoddhavyam asmin rana samudyame"—I want to see who are desirous to fight in this battle. I want to make sure that I know whom I am fighting. It's basically due diligence. Anytime we have to go for an interview, the first thing someone might ask is, "Neil, did you find out who we're competing against?" I said I never asked that question because half the time they don't give that answer.

But we are very curious to see who we are competing against. I'm sure Arjuna knew, but he wanted to make sure. Let's see on the very first day who is there. Verse 23: "Dhartarashtrasya durbuddhe yuddhe priya chikirsava"—I want to see those who are assembled here to fight, wishing to please in battle the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.

We now see Arjuna's state of mind—very confident, and he has great animosity toward Duryodhana, calling him "evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra." He also knows that the people who are there are not fighting a righteous battle—they just want to please Duryodhana. That's why they are there. Because Duryodhana has the power, he is the person in charge of the entire empire.

And they want to be in his good graces, in his good books. Therefore they are there. So let me see who those people are whom I'll be fighting. It's basically as simple as that. That's what we have seen so far.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 19 reveals a crucial psychological truth: the tumultuous sound from the Pandava side "rent the hearts" (hridayani vyadarayat) of Dhritarashtra's army. When you're uncertain about your cause, even the opponent's confidence becomes threatening. The Kauravas had more soldiers, more resources—yet their hearts were shaken by sound alone. This shows how inner doubt magnifies external challenges.

Notice also the contrasting states of the two sides. Sanjaya reports no heart-rending fear on the Pandava side—only enthusiastic response to the call. As Swamiji teaches, when you're sure about your purpose, obstacles don't destabilize you. When you're not sure, even small setbacks cause doubt. Reflect honestly: in your current challenges, are you more like the confident Pandavas or the anxious Kauravas?

Then comes Arjuna in verse 20-21, described as "Kapidhvaja"—one whose flag bears Hanuman. This isn't just decoration; Hanuman promised to be present wherever Rama (and his incarnation Krishna) fights for dharma. Arjuna, supremely confident, picks up his bow and commands: "Achyuta, place my chariot between the two armies." He addresses Krishna as "Achyuta"—the one who never wavers. But here's the irony: Arjuna himself is about to waver profoundly. The one who calls on the Unwavering One is about to demonstrate just how much humans can shake. This week, notice when you invoke stability and certainty in others precisely because you sense your own approaching instability. Sometimes our strongest declarations of confidence come just before our deepest crises of doubt.

snippets.title: Day 8: Between the Armies
snippets.sanskrit:
यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान् |

योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः |

सञ्जय उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
yāvadetānnirikṣe.ahaṃ yoddhukāmānavasthitān .

yotsyamānānavekṣe.ahaṃ ya ete.atra samāgatāḥ .

sañjaya uvāca .
verseTranslations:
Arjuna said: In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O Krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence.

For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight,
wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana (the son of Dhritarashtra).

Sanjaya said: Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna, having stationed that
best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies.

He's basically giving us the mental status of each main character in this conflict. We've seen Dhritarashtra first, then Duryodhana, then Arjuna. We have also seen that Arjuna told Krishna to take his chariot and place it in the middle of the two armies. What we have seen so far is that both Arjuna and Duryodhana have strong egos.

One had negative qualities associated with the ego, the other positive qualities. That's the only difference. Therefore we see Arjuna commanding or giving an order to Krishna: "Place my chariot in the middle of the two armies." How do you know that Arjuna had a big ego? We also see in Mahabharata that Arjuna was the one who objected to competing with Karna. He said, "Sutaputra—I will not compete with him."

When they had this competition, that's what Duryodhan gave Karna kingdom of Angadish. So he became Angaraj Because Duryodhan see an opportunity having someone equivalent to Karna Arjuna in his own side. That's how Arkarna became Duryodhana's best friend. Yotsamana avekhse aham. I want to see ya eta itra sama Gataha the people who are gathered here. Dhartra rashtra syedurbuddehe yudde priyachi kir savah.

Those who are gathered here just to please this evil minded Duryodhana. The very words shows his anger, hatred and his own ego. At this point he sees the army on the other side is one homogeneous mass of evil. Because their leader is evil, Duryodhana is evil and all who are gathered on that side are just there to please Duryodhana there is no other motive. Arjuna can see this is the entire army. On the other side is nothing but people with evil intentions.

They are either themselves an evil or they're just supporting evil for whatever the personal gain or whatever the personal opinion. And now we hear from Sanjay. He gives a very unbiased commentary. He is a commentator just like our news. People claim that all always give is the news. We are not news ourselves.

We are not putting our coloring. Sanjaya, Vaacha, Evam, Uktva, Hrushikeshah, Guda, Keshena. This is what told by Arjuna to Hrishikesha. Hrishikesha is the one who has the control of the senses. That's one interpretation. Other is the one who has the short hair Gudakesha, one who has the control over sleep on his conquered sleep.

Swamiji says that there is no real proof in Mahabharata in Arjuna's biography that he has conquered sleep. The Western scholars said they won with the hair in bundles. Hair in style bundles. Obviously in India we have not seen that hairstyle. But here we can see the African Americans have hair in bundles. So it's possible that Vedvyas Bhagavan is just saying what they look like and not have this deeper meaning.

We have a tendency to find deeper meaning in everything we see in our scriptures. In my first year of architecture there were simple tasks like design a handle for a window or a doorknob. And then we obviously made very complicated designs because otherwise how are you going to impress your teacher? So we have a tendency to complicate things and see deeper meaning than what is actually there. It is possible that Bhagavan Vedavyasa simply described how these two people looked. So, having been thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna responded.

Oh, Bharata Bharada here is addressed to Dhritarashtra because he was the king of Bharatkand. It has been said that Kuru dynasty was the first to organize the society in a statewide society. So Bharata, you are the king of this Bharat Khan Senayoho Ubhayoho Madhya Sapayitva Rathautamam. So we have the confirmation from Sanjay that Krishna followed the order thus ordered by Arjuna. Krishna placed the chariot in the middle of the two armies. Bisma Drona, Pramukhataha, Sarve Samcha, Mahikshitam, Vacha Partha Pasheta, Samavetaan, Kurunithi.

He put it right in front of Bhishma and Drona. He could have put it right in front of Duryodhana instead. And then Krishna spoke the first words uttered by him in Bhagavad Gita. This is the only time we hear Krishna's words indirectly through Sanjaya, otherwise we hear his direct words as "Sri Bhagavan Uvacha." But here Sanjaya reports what Krishna said to Arjuna: "Pashyaitan—make sure you see all the Kurus who are gathered here."

Look at Vishwa and Drona and other kings, but also see all the gurus gathered here. Because what was Arjuna's intention? He just wanted to see who are against him. He wanted to see who are gathered here to please this evil Duryodhana. He very clearly said, that's all I want to see. I want to make sure that I understand who I'm fighting with.

Therefore Krishna put him right in front of the Bhishma Dranada. It's not a homogeneous mass of evil that you're facing—once you wipe out that evil, things won't simply be well and good. There will be problems, there will be side effects. This is how we sometimes think we'll save the world. We believe that if we eradicate the evil from this world, everything will be fine. But we have learned in recent years that eradicating anything doesn't solve the problem unless the root cause is eradicated.

Just eradicating the other side completely will not solve the problem. It may create more problems, but you have to be prepared for that. You should know what you are dealing with. Therefore he put Arjuna's cherry right in the Bhishma and Drona because they are clearly not part of evil. But the more important he said, see all the Kurus who are gathered here. Arjuna himself was a Kuru.

He was the descendant of the Kuru dynasty. Both Gauravas and Pandavas are descendants of Kurt dynasty. Up till now we have heard Arjuna referring to Kaurava as Dhartrastranam, Dhritarashtra's sons. His animosity was against Dhritarashtra's son, not against Kuru. Therefore, in the previous time when Arjuna has fought with even Bhishma, there was not really big problem. Basically protecting Virat's kingdom and he fought with Bheeshma.

He didn't have any problem fighting with Bheeshma before. Obviously he didn't try to kill him, but we couldn't kill him anyway. But this time Krishna says, look at all the Kurus. Don't only look at Dhrutrastra's putra. He gives him instruction indirectly. Make sure that you are aware that all your family members are involved on both sides in the next two verses.

Tatra apasyat, sthitan, parthah, pitru, Nathaha, pita, Mahan, acharya, matulan, bhrartran, putran, patran, sakimsthata. So now he is obviously observing on both sides that he doesn't see just the evil and good divided by the line. This is what we do in our life. We divide this world of liking and disliking with an imaginary line in my mind that if I can avoid this which I don't like, the world will be nothing. My life will be nothing but pure happiness. Well, we tend to forget that those are intertwined with each other.

The world which I like and world which I don't like, they intertwined with each other. So some of us in elections are party line voters because we clearly see that this side is a side of good, that side is side of not so good. It's only when you find out that the world is not as clearly divided into good and evil as we like to think. In our childhood we had it's very simple who are bad people, who are good people, cowboys and Indians. But world is not like that. Krishna wants to make sure the Arjuna understands that.

There is also another implication which we heard from lots of commentators that as we have seen that Arjuna's words indicate he has a big ego. Big ego doesn't mean the person is necessarily bad. Good people have big egos. Artists have big egos, architects have big egos. It's actually said in our profession, unless there are any Gita, it's generally said in our profession that you can't have two architects in the same room. Their egos are so big that no room in this world is large enough to contain two egos of the two architects at the same time.

I learned hard way that when we collaborate with other firms, two architects collaborate with each other and it's a lesson in humility. I was fortunate enough to get this lesson very early on in my career when I came here. So when I was in Dallas, when I first came and working with a very large firm, WZMH somewhat specialized in high rise. And we were collaborating IM Pei, an international architect and he was a design architect. WZMH was just basically an architect of record. So I asked my boss, I said Mark, we are capable to design this project and we had the relationship with the developer, why do we have to bring in Im Pei in the mix?

And he said, Neil, 100% of zero is still zero. If you want the whole enchilada, but you're not going to get it. He said you didn't get anything. Is it better to have a portion of an enchilada to devise a situation where at least you have a portion of the pie? So by myself I won't get that project. By themselves, they won't get the project.

Well, let's compromise and say look, we can share this and we have to control our ego. If we share this, then we both get something out of it. So the people with big egos are bipolar in nature. So they go from supreme courage to complete vulnerability in one moment. If they see the world from this side, they will be very courageous. And when they see the competition, they see their own shortcoming.

They will break down very easily. So Krishna saw that Arjuna is overconfident. He thinks he's the best archer in the world. He has fought Bismar before. He has done all these people. There is nothing which can stop me from wiping out this sea of evil which I see in front of me.

But he had to be brought to his senses and brought to humility so that he is really prepared to fight this war. So Krishna said, now look at the Bisma, Drona, all other kings and all the crews, all the Kurus include all the people on his side as well. Now Arjuna sees all the people and individually recognize what his relationship with them. Tatra, Apasyat, Parthaha, Pitrunatha, fatherly relatives, Pita Mahan, also grandfatherly relatives, Acharyan, teachers, Mathulan, maternal relatives, Bratan, Putran, Pautran, Sakimstatha. Both sides he says people who are like his sons and also his grandsons, friends, Tatha, Swasuran, Sruhada, Chaeeva, also in laws, the people who are close to you. Now we have confirmation then not only he looked at the Kaurava's army, he also looked at Pandava's army.

He saw all the people who are dear to him, close to him, related to him. There is no indication he sees evil here. He didn't say oh, I also see Duryodhani. All he saw is the people who are related to him, were closer to him, were dear to him. And therefore he says Krupaya Pariya Vishtaha, Visidantam Idam Abravit. He thus sorrowfully filled with deep pity said this Swamiji says that Sanjay is actually generous in calling him as a deep pity Swamiji actually says that he may be broken down by his own insecurities.

Now he realized that the world is not divided into evil and good, but a mixture of both on all sides. Things which we consider evil and lots of good in it and things we consider good has some evil in it.
snippets.reflection:
In verse 23, Arjuna reveals his current mental state: "I wish to observe those assembled here to fight, wishing to please the evil-minded Duryodhana (durbuddhi)." Notice the anger and contempt in these words. To Arjuna, the enemy is a "homogeneous mass of evil"—Duryodhana is evil, and everyone supporting him is simply trying to "please" this evil person. This black-and-white thinking is comfortable but incomplete.

Then Krishna does something profound in verse 24-25. Arjuna asked to see those "wishing to please Duryodhana." But Krishna parks the chariot right in front of Bhishma and Drona—the two men who least fit that description. These aren't sycophants seeking favor; they're noble warriors bound by complex dharmas. And Krishna says: "Pashya etan—behold all these Kurus gathered here." Not "Dhritarashtra's sons," but "Kurus"—Arjuna's own clan, including those on his side.

This is the master therapist at work. Krishna doesn't argue with Arjuna's assessment; he simply expands his field of vision. Reflect on where you might be viewing your challenges through an oversimplified lens. Who are the "Bhishmas and Dronas" on the other side of your conflicts—people who aren't simply evil but are caught in their own complex webs of duty and loyalty? When we reduce our opponents to caricatures, we lose the ability to understand the true nature of our situation. What would it mean to truly "see the Kurus"—to recognize that those opposing you might share your lineage, your values, even your dilemmas?

The clear line between "us" and "them" dissolves. What seemed like a righteous battle against "evil Duryodhana" now reveals itself as a civil war within one family.

Arjuna, the greatest archer in the world who just commanded Krishna confidently, now sees reality differently and begins to crumble. His previous confidence wasn't based on comprehensive understanding but on a simplified view of the situation.

Reflect on moments when your certainty suddenly collapsed upon seeing a situation more completely. Perhaps you were confident about a decision until you truly considered its impact on everyone involved. Perhaps you were sure about a course of action until you recognized the faces on the "other side." This isn't weakness—it's the beginning of wisdom. snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the classic symptoms of what we might today call a panic attack or nervous breakdown. Arjuna reports: "Sidanti mama gatrani" (my limbs are failing), "mukham cha parishushyati" (my mouth is parched), "vepathush cha sharire" (my body trembles), "romaharshas cha jayate" (my hair stands on end). His Gandiva—the legendary bow he has mastered—slips from his hand. His skin burns. He cannot stand. His mind reels ("bhramativa cha me manah").

Notice that these verses move from physical symptoms (verse 29) to functional collapse (verse 30). The greatest warrior in the world, who just moments ago commanded Krishna with confidence, now cannot even hold his weapon. This is the psychosomatic reality of overwhelming emotion—when the mind is shattered, the body follows.

The Gita begins with this honest portrayal because transformation requires acknowledging where we actually are, not where we wish we were. Arjuna doesn't hide his breakdown; he describes it in detail. Swamiji reminds us that within each person are all the characters of Mahabharata—we have our Dhritarashtra (willful blindness), our Duryodhana (grasping attachment), our Bhishma (rigid adherence to rules over principles), and yes, our Arjuna (paralysis when facing difficult truths). Reflect this week on moments when you've experienced your own version of these symptoms—the physical manifestations of being overwhelmed. Rather than judging these reactions, recognize them as the starting point for deeper wisdom. What situations cause your "Gandiva to slip"? What truths make your mind reel? The Gita's message begins here: the admission of our vulnerability is the doorway to receiving teaching.
