Notice how Krishna responds to Arjuna's despair - not with sympathy, but with a "gracious smile." This smile is significant: it reflects the perspective of one who sees beyond the immediate drama to eternal truths. Krishna's first teaching strikes at the root: "Why grieve for those for whom no grief is due, and yet profess wisdom? The wise grieve neither for the dead nor the living." Then comes the revolutionary declaration: "There was never a time when I was not, nor thou, nor these princes were not; there will never be a time when we shall cease to be."

This is not mere philosophy but a complete paradigm shift. We spend our lives believing we are temporary beings who will one day cease to exist. Krishna says the opposite is true: we are eternal beings who have always existed and always will. The body changes from infancy to youth to old age, but the "I" experiencing these changes remains constant. This same "I" will continue through the change called death.

Contemplate today: If you truly accepted that you are an eternal being temporarily wearing this body, how would it change your relationship with fear? With loss? With death itself? When you worry about aging, illness, or mortality, pause and ask: "Who is it that is aware of these changes? That awareness - is it also changing?" Notice that the witness of change itself remains unchanged. This is the beginning of Self-knowledge.

snippets.title: Day 21: The Soul is Eternal
snippets.sanskrit:
देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा |

मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः |

यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ |
snippets.transliteration:
dehino.asminyathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā .

mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ .

yaṃ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha .
verseTranslations: As the soul experiences in this body infancy, youth and old age, so finally it passes into another. The wise have no delusion about this.
Those external relations which bring cold and heat, pain and happiness, they come and go; they are not permanent. Endure them bravely, O Prince!
The hero whose soul is unmoved by circumstance, who accepts pleasure and pain with equanimity, only he is fit for immortality.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And so far we had seen that just in the beginning, right away, as soon as Bhagavan started his discourse, he came out without waffling about what is the truth. He says, you and I are imperishable. So are all these people which you see them around you, all these kings. A complete paradigm shift for a normal person who considers himself to be perishable. I was born at one time and I'll die at other time.

In between is my life. So I'm a perishable entity. Bhagavan said, no, neither you nor I are perishable. There was never a time that you did not exist, or I did not exist, or all these people around you did not exist. The existence is permanent. I may not exist in the same form and state.

I'm existing today as I existed as a child before and I'm existing as an old man now, but still I exist for that I. There is no non existence. So that's a complete paradigm shift and without any explanation. Bhagavan said, the first thing you should know is you're imperishable. And then he goes into the explanation, because he realized that at the stage Arjuna is in, simple advice like "this is your action, these are your duties, you should do this" is not enough.

Forget about what they did in the past. It's not going to work. This is a disease which has to be cured at its root cause. The root cause of all the disease or all the problems we have is the desire and attachment which is born out of my ignorance about what the reality is. If I'm deluded by this world and my relationship with it, the only way you can cure it is to cure the root cause of it.

Therefore, Bhagavan Buddha said, cure the disease of desire and everything will be cured. No matter how much we help somebody, as long as the root cause is not cured, it will be a band-aid solution as we call it. In architecture, even though the term is borrowed from medicine, we also call it a band-aid solution. You want to fix it permanently? Well, let's demolish this building and build a new one. Bhagavan realized that just telling Arjuna what is his duty now and what will be right for you is not going to help.

Let's start from the beginning. What is your problem? You are afraid that you will be killing these people? Well, you are incapable of killing these people because they are imperishable. The other day our Dr. Chinmayananda Lothe was trying to tell us how indestructible his glasses are. He said, "You know, the one good thing about these glasses..." -- and by the time he finishes the sentence, they broke into two pieces! His whole demonstration of indestructibility fell apart right in front of him. "Boy, I need new glasses now." So sometimes what we consider imperishable turns out to be perishable; things we consider indestructible turn out to be quite destructible. So in this life, what I consider is my security blanket, which I consider to be imperishable.

Because I think I'm in control. I have taken care of everything. The things which I rely on as dependable may turn out to be undependable. So from Arjuna's point of view, he was depending on his teachers and his grandfather -- he thought his family, his dynasty, his culture all depended on them. And Bhagavan said, that may not be true in the way you think.

However, what is true is this: you are indestructible, and they are indestructible at the core of their being. Then he says, why don't I feel it that way? Dehino Asmin Yatha Dehe Kaumaram Yauvanam Jara. The classical example we use all the time: just as I have changed from my existence as a child to young man to an adult, and I still remain the same. The feeling which I have as I is exactly same today as it was when I was a young man and when I was a child.

I always see other people as old people. I never see myself as old. It's a very strange phenomenon -- I don't know whether anybody can vouch for this. I can tell you, I never feel I'm old. I actually feel the same way as when I was young: "I can do that!" I look at others and think, these people are old, they cannot do it. Then I realize that person is actually younger than me. You know, Swami Dheerananda used to come to Richmond. They would say, "Swamiji, let me take your bag." And he would say, "Moonkanish, forget it! I'm much younger than you are."

I have more strength than you do, so don't worry about my bag. But we always feel at the core, core of our heart were indestructible. The same person as I was when I used to have all the real strength. That's why the middle aged people go to play the sports which they are supposed not to play at their age. I want to play cricket. I really like cricket because I used to play cricket when I was 20 years old.

Well, you try that today. Then after about two or three games, you realize that that's not the thing you should be doing at the age of whatever you are today. So at the core of your being there is no change. Change is happening in the outside existence which you have, which is your body. Just as you have changed from a young age to old age. The same way this self will move from one body to another.

He introduces the concept of reincarnation right away. In the first verse he said you're indestructible; in the second verse he says this death is nothing. These are shock treatments to somebody whose mind has gone into a complete delusion. They can't see the reality as is. And as all these psychiatric treatments used to be shock treatment, you have to jolt him out of that state. Basically, Bhagawan is giving a shock treatment.

We are all deluded by our own reality. Our own security blankets our own thinking about what is right and wrong. And he said, starts from this you are imperishable. You will continue to exist in one form or another. Therefore, in any culture, and particularly in ours, suicide is never prescribed. Suicide does not solve anything -- it exactly takes the same mental problem you have to the next stage of life. You're just running away from your problems. Swamiji used to say, if you are unhappy here, if you say, I am so unhappy in us, I am going to go to India and then I will be happy. You will be exactly same unhappy person in India. Except the place will change. As long as the internal climate you are taking with you, things are not going to change for you.

So you have to change your internal climate. Bhagavan gives you a shock treatment. First: you're imperishable, not perishable. Secondly: death is not going to change anything fundamental -- you will start all over again in a new body. And then he addresses the question: why then do we feel what we feel in our day to day life?

These changes in my life keep occurring -- some are pleasant and some are unpleasant. The answer is in the verse: Matra Sparsaha Tu Kaunteya Sita Ushna Sukha Dukhadaha. Here is the simple analysis of how your experiences are defined. When your senses come in contact with sense objects, it gives rise to the experience of pleasure and pain, heat and cold. No two people feel the same way about the climate.

Somebody in the room, it's too hot. Neil, can you check another person say I'm perfectly fine, don't touch it. Meena will say it's too hot and also no, it's too cold. And she will say it's too cold. I say no, it's too hot. I think our thermostats work differently.

Internal thermostats. So the experience of heat and cold depends on two things. Outside world which has obviously this condition, but also my sensitivity. My senses, its own sensitivity decides whether it is pleasant or unpleasant. Swamiji's classical example of the cigarette smoker: a cigarette gives one person a heavenly experience. I'm a reform smoker, so I know exactly what I'm talking about.

When I was in college and when we are in the dining hall, not interested in meal, when can I finish there and go and have a cigarette outside? That was more enjoyable. The cigarette after the dinner or lunch or any time. Then the lunch itself or dinner itself. Same cigarette gives a repulsive reaction from somebody else. Now I'm a reformed smoker, so I'm the worst one and I can't really tolerate even the smell of cigarette.

We have one smoker in my office. Every about an hour he goes out, smokes and come back. And then he feels obliged. Every time he goes out there he needs to say something to me and I say, well, you go away. I really don't want to talk to you right now because you're smelling cigarettes all over my office. The same object which gives pleasure to someone, gives pain to someone.

What it tells you is object has no capacity to give a pleasure or pain. It is your senses which decides which is pleasurable or painful. So Bhagavan said, matras parsaha tu kaunteya sita ushna sukhdukh daha. This context between the senses and sense objects are the cause of all the experiences you have. So if you remove yourself from the senses because you don't think you are your senses, then these experiences are not yours. Experiences of my car are not Mine.

So my experience of my eyes, I consider mine and I consider my eye to be me. But I don't consider my glasses to be me. My glasses are not me because I can go to lens craft and get it done in one hour. I know that my eye, I cannot. I have to rely on Santa Ramji and his colleagues to say, make sure that it's functioning well because of that attachment, that identification with the eye which makes me feel it is me. But one says this identification with your senses, that your senses are.

You transfer all those experiences to you, whether it is heat or cold, pain or pleasure. So understand, these are not your experiences. These are the experiences of these senses when they come in contact with sense objects. And it depends on your sensitivity, your sense of you will feel whether pleasure or pain. My mother, I remember she can pick up the burning charcoal and then put it. I said, don't you need it?

He said, no, I'm fine. Now I can't even pick up the hot cup of tea because her fingers are numbed by all those cooking. He can pick up charcoal and put it in. When we came to this country, you had to get the fingerprinting done at the airport because you come on a green card. Well, obviously they have a green card. They make your fingerprint, put it on a green card, sealed it in their plastic and give it.

That's a green card, sir. Meena comes after me. The guy tried and tried and tried and tried and couldn't get a fingerprint done. Sir, I'm sorry, but your wife probably have to go to the downtown in Houston to get this fingerprint done. We don't have capability to take a fingerprint. I said, what's the problem?

He said, because her ridges are all worn out from the chemicals she uses while doing dishes. So we may have special machine in downtown Houston which may be able to do it, but we can't do it.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna offers a profound analogy in verse 13: Just as the soul experiences infancy, youth, and old age within this body, so it passes into another body at death. "The wise have no delusion about this." We accept the daily changes of our body without confusion about our identity - we do not grieve when our childhood body "dies" into our adult body. Similarly, the transition from one lifetime to another is simply a continuation of this natural process of change.

Verse 14 introduces the teaching about sensory experiences: "Those external relations which bring cold and heat, pain and happiness - they come and go; they are not permanent. Endure them bravely." Notice that the same experience - hot weather, for instance - can be pleasant to one person and painful to another. This proves that the pleasure or pain is not inherent in the object but depends on our own senses and their sensitivity. Understanding this frees us from being enslaved by circumstances.

Today, practice observing your reactions to pleasant and unpleasant experiences with this awareness: "This sensation is the result of my senses contacting an object. It is temporary. It will pass." When something uncomfortable happens - physical discomfort, an annoying situation, disappointing news - remind yourself: "This too shall pass." And equally, when something pleasant occurs, recognize its temporary nature without clinging. The one "who accepts pleasure and pain with equanimity" is declared fit for immortality. What would it mean to "endure bravely" the fluctuations of your day?

snippets.title: Day 22: The Real and Unreal
snippets.sanskrit:
नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः |

अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् |

अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः |
snippets.transliteration:
nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ .

avināśi tu tadviddhi yena sarvamidaṃ tatam .

antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ .
verseTranslations: That which is not, shall never be; that which is, shall never cease to be. To the wise, these truths are self-evident.
The Spirit, which pervades all that we see, is imperishable. Nothing can destroy the Spirit.
The material bodies which this Eternal, Indestructible, Immeasurable Spirit inhabits are all finite. Therefore fight, O Valiant Man!
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. This is the knowledge about our true self. So verse 11 through 30 give us the Upanishaddic definition of what the self is all about. So Bhagawan starts with telling Arjuna that you should start looking at this world very differently. It is something like for any corporate planning there is short term planning and a long term planning. So there are some things you have to look at it from short term planning.

You have to get these things done during this quarter, but then you also have to look at it on a long term basis what will be in next 10 years. So Bhagavan says that right now we are looking at the world from a very short narrow perspective which is limited to this life. But this life is not the end by itself. This life is nothing but just a fraction of your own existence. So he starts with saying, you are worrying about these people. They are not worth worrying about.

No relatives of yours or friend of yours you should worry about whether he is dead or alive. It was a very shocking declaration to Arjuna, why shouldn't I be worrying about my own kith and kin? When you look at it from this narrow perspective, it will seem that something is good or bad. But we have learned that good and bad is a relative perspective. So what is maybe good in a short term may not be good in a long term. That's why we have come across two terms.

Prayas is pleasant temporarily. Shreyas is good forever. That which is always good is Shreyas. That which is temporarily pleasant is Prayas. So the situation I see may be pleasant for now -- from Arjuna's point of view, running away from this battle is pleasant. Less things to worry about, but it's not pleasant in the long run.

You can allow these criminals to continue doing their crimes and this non Aryan like behavior, as Krishna puts it, the way these people are behaving is not fit to be an Aryan. Therefore to establish Dharma of Arya Bhart, it is your duty as the Kshatriya to fight this war. That's basically Krishna's message here. So he said, you shouldn't be worrying about them. But then he starts from the widest perspective saying the existence for any being is eternal. We are eternal beings.

There was never a time where you were not there, or I was not there, or these kings were not there. So we are all eternal beings, immortal beings. We consider ourselves to be mortal. So that's basically the paradigm shift for Arjuna and all of us. How to look at our life. There will be a narrow perspective.

There is a relative reality. When there is a ice cube in my glass, it has this relative reality. The ice cube is very solid. But if I wait long enough, that ice cube will be gone. There will be just water. Water relatively has a longer existence than ice cube.

Ice cube is a very short term existence. I, as an intelligent being who use ice before, I know that that if I really want to use this ice, I have to use it as quickly as possible. Otherwise the ice will go away. There won't be any ice. So if I want to say you have to look at this situation from a wider perspective, that these people cannot be killed. And therefore he said, just as they have progressed from one existence to another, you have progressed one existence to another in your life.

From a childhood to adulthood and to old age, you will also migrate to the new state of existence. Deha Antara -- transferring from one body to another -- will not be any different from your migration from childhood to adulthood. Therefore, wise person who has understood this fundamental truth will not get confused. One who has understood the widest perspective of existence, he will not be worried about a small change in existence. When you understand water and ice, and the ice becomes water, you don't get upset.

Maybe you have to put it back into the freezer if you want more ice in the ice cube tray. So we know that the existence is permanent. Bhagavan says, but there may be a temporary consequences of me dealing with this world. Those experiences in my life create Sukha and Dukha. Matraha Sparsaha Tu Kaunteya -- When sense organs come in contact with sense objects, it will create an experience.

That experience, depending on the qualities of your sense organs, will be either pleasant or unpleasant. One experience which is pleasant to me may be unpleasant to somebody else. Jumping from 50ft on a bungee jumping is pleasant to somebody. It will not be pleasant for me. Same experience can give two different experiences to two different people in the same set of circumstances. Depending on his own equipment, depending on my mind if it is rainy outside it may be unpleasant.

But if I'm a farmer or a gardener, it may be a pleasant experience. The bhagawan said, matrahas parsaha tu kunteya sita ushna sukh dukadah. They give these experiences of sukhendukha. They are nothing but perceptions of your mind. And therefore he said, taam titiksha bharad. You have no other choice.

Whether it's pleasant or unpleasant, you must bear them. Know that they are temporary. They have beginning and an end. And therefore, even a pleasant experience -- don't get too excited or too elated, because it will also come to an end. Every other day we hear about recession and then the next day we hear about no, no, the market is going to keep going.

How long? We know for sure there will be a recession sometime. We just hope it will not be before I retire, that's all. So every experience has a beginning and end. While we are experiencing, if we remember that, that this is a temporary experience, we will not get too invested in that experience. We get too invested in their experience. That's where we get either too excited or elated or too depressed.

The right way to live is to bear them all -- pleasant and unpleasant. And then Bhagavan now defines what is the nature of the self. So other day I also had a new revelation about the ownership of this building. So my condo administrator came to me as a Krishna to explain to me what I own and what I don't own. We obviously all of you know that Meena and I own this building. So we always say, well, we own this building.

Everything outside parking lot is common area. We own this building. There was clear understanding the last about 14 years we owned this building or 16 years we owned this building. The other day we had a water damage. Hot water heater broke and it was just spraying out water all over the bathroom. So I had to obviously call.

I actually called fire department because I didn't know what to do. By the time fire department came, the guy who was cleaning the carpet, he figured out there is a shut off valve outside. He shut it off, everything was fine. But when I reported it to our condo guy, he said, well, I'll come down Neil and check it out whether there's any damage in the attic. He walked through my attic. He found that we were storing old drawings and files in our attic.

We have storage trusses. He said, Neil, I don't want to be a pain in your neck, but you're not supposed to store anything in an attic. He said, why is that? He said, because you only own building from your ceiling to the top of the floor. The attic does not belong to you. I said, who owns the attic? He said, the condo association.

I said, are you serious? They say, yeah, yeah, you only own from the ceiling to the floor. They said, what about below the floor? He said, that also condo association. He said, what about outside? He said, you only went from the inside face of your exterior wall to the other side interior face of exterior wall.

I said, who owns the exterior walls? The condo association. So I said, who owns the building? He said, Neil, you own the space within the exterior walls, the ceiling, and the floor. I said, so nothing concrete which I can call a building is mine? He said, no, none of that is yours.

You as a condo owner only own the space. Do you mean to say the condo association tomorrow can decide that they want to take the roof away because they own the roof and then they take the four walls away? Yeah, technically they own. Now, how about the ground below? They own the ground below too. All you own is space within four walls, floor and a ceiling.

They say, okay, you try to remove that. I'll tell you, demarcate my space from outside space, inside space, because my condo is just the space. You can remove floors, wall and ceiling as condo owner association. You won't be able to take this space away because I own this space. Now, that's a completely different way to look at this condo ownership. First of all, the bank has the mortgage on this space, so I owe them money. And when I want to sell something, I only own the space. There is nothing tangible which I can say I own outright. But technically, free and clear, what I own is just the space inside this building. Even though it has no value by itself -- without the walls, floor and ceiling, the space has no practical meaning. The space is defining the value of the conditioning, but the conditionings are defining the limitations of the space.

Bhagavan said to Arjuna that you have to start looking at your relationship to your teacher and your grandfather in a very different way. And therefore he says, avinasi tu tadviddhi en sarvam idam tatham. So what is my relationship with that self which is residing in all these beings? If all these beings are immortal, but they can get killed. What is getting killed and what is immortal? So Bhagavan now defines the relationship between the perishable and imperishable.

The Imperishable is the one which is the essence of any being. Any being is called a being as long as the consciousness is functioning through him. I am who I am as long as I'm alive. Without that consciousness, it is nothing but a dead body. The dead body is not Neil Bhatt. But he said that which you call your relative Bhishma and Drona.

That essence is Avinashi. It cannot be destroyed. Tadvidi, know that the essence of a being with whom you have a relationship with is indestructible. It is not limited to that person. This is a complete paradigm shift for most of us who have never thought about it. I have always thought that my self is residing in me and your self is residing in you and herself is residing in her.

They're all kind of nice little packages of selves, you know. And we are interacting with each other. That which makes your friend your friend is actually indestructible. Your cousin, your cousin is indestructible. Your teacher, teacher indestructible. But that essence is not limited to him.

Everything is pervaded by that essence which you call yourself, which you call your friend's self, which you call grandfather's self. Anything that you can think of, anything they can perceive. Your world perception may be as grand as the entire universe. Anything that you can think of in a sarvam idam tatham, it is all pervaded by that self.
snippets.reflection:
These verses contain one of the Gita's most essential teachings: "That which is not, shall never be; that which is, shall never cease to be." This distinguishes between the Real (Sat) and the Unreal (Asat). The Real is that which exists in all three periods of time - past, present, and future - without any change. The Unreal is that which appears to exist but has no permanent reality, like a snake seen in a rope or ice that melts into water. The body and all material forms belong to this changing, temporary reality.

Verse 17 declares: "The Spirit, which pervades all that we see, is imperishable. Nothing can destroy the Spirit." This all-pervading Spirit is not limited to your body or mine - it is the same consciousness expressing through all beings, like electricity manifesting as light, heat, and sound through different appliances. Therefore, Krishna concludes in verse 18: "The material bodies which this Eternal, Indestructible, Immeasurable Spirit inhabits are all finite. Therefore fight, O Valiant Man!"

Apply this teaching today by examining what you consider "real" in your life. Your possessions, relationships, status, body - which of these will exist unchanged forever? Now consider: What remains constant through all the changes of your life? That unchanging awareness is your true Self. When you feel threatened or anxious, ask: "Is it the Real or the Unreal that is threatened?" The Real cannot be harmed; the Unreal was never truly yours to lose. How does this shift your perspective on what you fear losing?

snippets.title: Day 23: The Soul Cannot Kill
snippets.sanskrit:
य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम् |

न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्

वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम् |
snippets.transliteration:
ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaścainaṃ manyate hatam ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate ||2-19||

na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ .

vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enamajamavyayam .
verseTranslations: He who thinks that the Spirit kills, and he who thinks of It as killed, are both ignorant. The Spirit kills not, nor is It killed.
It was not born; It will never die, nor once having been, can It cease to be. Unborn, Eternal, Ever-enduring, yet Most Ancient, the Spirit dies not when the body is dead.
He who knows the Spirit as Indestructible, Immortal, Unborn, Always-the-Same, how should he kill or cause to be killed?
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And as we have seen, this is a self unfoldment for the one who has not understood himself. Arjuna has not realized the reality of his own self. Therefore all this confusion. So rather than just giving him a temporary advice of what is right at this time, help to dispel his myth about the nature of the self and give him the right knowledge. So the verse 11 onwards, we had been discussing the nature of this self.

And the first thing we have heard from Bhagavan is that the self which you and I considered mortal is actually immortal. That the first declaration very bold. We don't find it very bold because we grew up with it. It was somewhat embedded in our psyche. However, if you imagine your own experiences of your life and your own viewpoint towards life, it's extremely revealing. It is completely different than all my experiences so far.

All my life I consider this life to be mortal. Therefore there's fear of death. And now Bhagavan says this life is immortal. Your self which considers you as you. That which makes me feel I. That feeling I, which is not related to this body, not this mind, not this intellect.

Therefore I always say my body, my mind, my intellect, that entity he calls this mind is, Bhagavan says eternal is imperishable. That's the first declaration. The second, as we have seen, is the explanation of what this mortal life is all about. How does it relate to that immortality? He said the immortal self keeps taking different states of existence as the embodied one. Just as within this body there are changes occurring, when this body becomes no longer useful for that embodied one, he moves on to find another body. That change is no different than my growing from baby to young man to old man and then dying.

So the idea or the concept of reincarnation is introduced right away in the second verse of that discourse. Now this is something we do find very controversial. Swamiji used to say, "One thing good about my profession is I can bluff all my life and never have to prove anything, and nobody can catch me." That's because this is nothing you can prove objectively -- it is a subjective science. Subjectively, it can be proved. All our sages and all the prophets of the world have time and again confirmed the nature of this self.

But it cannot be transferred that knowledge to you in an objective manner. Therefore it is called self unfoldment. Therefore it can only be prescribed how to feel it, how to experience it. If I had been to Hawaii and I can give you all kind of explanation, I can write all kind of essays. But the only way will experience it when you yourself go to Hawaii. So therefore this knowledge can only be experienced.

So the concept of reincarnation can only be inferred by our experiences and cannot be experienced or proven objectively in the scientific sense. And as we had discussed, all of us do come into this world with very different backgrounds, situations and circumstances. And if Bhagavan was all compassionate and equal to all of us, he probably would have created a standard situation for all of us to come in -- same set of parents, same situation, everybody given the same amount of money upfront, and now go do whatever you need to do. But that does not happen.

That does suggest that we may have been carrying some baggage from before we started this journey. I may be carrying some abilities before I started this journey. So it neatly ties together the observations we have in this world -- different people having different abilities right from birth, different tendencies -- suggesting that they must have had different experiences prior to this existence. So the diversity of situations for all the newly born in this world is somewhat explained by this concept of reincarnation.

The third question is: why do I then feel this sorrow and happiness in this world? If my self is immortal, why am I not experiencing it?

And it is explained by Matraha Sparsha Tu Kaunteya -- the senses, when they come in contact with sense objects, depending on the sensitivity of the senses, make me feel either pain or pleasure. All these experiences, whether painful or pleasurable, are time-bound and finite. Therefore, you bear them or enjoy them, but know that they are going to pass. So that explains our situation and how to deal with this life. And then Bhagavan came to the conclusion: Naasato Vidyate Bhavaha.

That which is unreal has no existence. It may be the figment of my imagination. In my perception there is an existence a snake which I am seeing in a rope. In a classical example, snake does have real existence for the one who is seeing the snake. But in reality the snake has no existence. Because it is asat before my delusion and after my delusion is over.

That snake has no existence. Therefore it is asat that is impermanent. No real existence, but a perceived existence that has no real existence. There is no being for the unreal to come into existence. And for the real there is no non existence. The real, which is myself, has no question of non existence.

Therefore I say, there was never a time when this king were not there or you were not there. That I in I and you in you and he in him and see in her always existed will exist. Bhagavan said in a different form. Gold continues to exist; the form continues to change. The form of a gold bar is temporary.

At the whim of the owner or the whim of the artist, the goldsmith, that will change and that is impermanent and. And therefore it does not have a real existence. What is real is the gold existence. So we learned that that which is real never cease to exist. That which is unreal truly have no existence other than in my perception. This room space truly has no existence other than its own conditioning.

There is nothing called room space really exist here other than the space exists here. But I create room space in my perception because of the walls, floor and ceiling. The mortality is for this walls, floor and ceiling. I can remove them anytime I want as an owner. Or somebody may decide to destroy it for other reason. But that can never change the nature of the space within this space was here, is here and will be here.

So for the space's perspective, there is no mortality from the conditioning perspective. It never really had any real existence other than a relative reality. So therefore, Bhagavan says, avinasi tu tadviddhi iena sarvam idam tatam by which this entire Jagat is pervaded. There is existence everywhere. I exist, you exist, she exists, he exists, chair exists, tree exists. So everything where we see, we consider it in existence.

That existence in its purity is all pervading. Everywhere I see there is some existence of something that all pervading existence. Bhagavan says Avinashi is indestructible. A form of an existence can be destroyed. Existence itself cannot be destroyed. A table can be destroyed, but the material of the table will remain in some form.

Craig is trying to make a table out of now. The table does not exist right now other than his imagination. But the wood does exist because he said, I have this. I Will buy this and do that that would exist. Table only exist in his imagination. But with his imagination he can bring the form into existence.

And it will exist as long as its time is. And then somebody will say, this is not good enough and it will be destroyed. So the form has the mortality, not the existence itself. Know that the all pervading self which makes all the existence possible is indestructible. That also does not exclude you and I. You and I are part of this ever existing, all pervading being.

And we have in detail, seen in self unfoldment and thought about. This body is nothing but the food modified. It was something else. It became food for me, it became my body. It will become food for some other entities, creatures, worms, whatever, or fertilizer. Because Hindus get cremated.

So it will be fertilized. Vinasam avya yasyasya nakastyan kartum arhati. There is none who is capable of destroying this imperishable self. No matter how much force I can apply to this building. I can have bulldozers, I can destroy this building, but cannot destroy the space. Space was here, is and will be here.

None has any capability to destroy this space. Because this space is all pervading, ever pervading. No one has any capability to destroy the space. The self in me, Bhagavan said, is similarly imperishable. And therefore no one has the capability to destroy that. So if you consider I can destroy somebody's self, you are mistaken.

Or somebody thinks they can destroy myself, they are mistaken. Therefore, Gandhiji said, you probably can destroy my body, but you will never be able to win over my soul. Somebody can kill you, but you cannot kill the self in you, the ideals in you. The message which you leave behind. Nityasya uktaha sharirnaha. So what is destructible?

These bodies of this embodied one is destructible as an end. This conditioning of this unconditioned space is destructible. Space which is all pervading, ever existing, remaining as is. But it has taken up this conditioning, this conditioning which I see as room space is destructible. And it has its own end. It is own beginning and own end.

Therefore, there is a little plaque in every office building or new commercial building. Say create and such, such and such occupancy, such and such. It says when it was created it does not have a death date. But we know for sure that this building will not be here 500 years from now mortgage companies have figured out the life of your building, typically 30 years. Therefore they give you 30 year mortgage. Because average life of a building in this country we consider 30 years.

So by the time you depreciate the building at the end of 30 years, the value is zero. Now I have to reconstruct what we call it is a adaptive reuse. And we spent as much money, not as much, probably more money than it took them to build that building and just completely change it into something new warehouse before. Now I'm creating office building into it. But it will never exist in the same fashion forever. It continues to change.

For that imperishable one's bodies has end. This conditioning of the room we have said is room, walls, floor and ceiling. In my case it is my body, mind and intellect. They have end but not the self. Those are the conditioning taken upon by the imperishable self. Anasi Nah or pramayashya.

But that entity which you consider yourself, I consider myself. And he, she herself is Anashinaha indestructible, a prameyashya also incomprehensible. That's the problem we have. We just cannot comprehend the self without its conditioning. Imagining a space without conditioning is impossible. No architect can imagine or no designer can imagine a space.

So for me to consider a space, I have to create conditioning in my mind. Therefore, even to conceive the space outside, I can only imagine it in reference to something -- the building across the parking lot, the trees, the sky. Space itself cannot be grasped by the mind without some conditioning.
snippets.reflection:
These verses deliver a startling truth: "He who thinks that the Spirit kills, and he who thinks of It as killed, are both ignorant. The Spirit kills not, nor is It killed." This challenges our fundamental assumptions about death and violence. The eternal Self cannot be the doer of any action, including killing, nor can it be the recipient of any action, including being killed. Actions happen at the level of body-mind-intellect, not at the level of the true Self.

Verse 20 is one of the most quoted descriptions of the Self: "It was not born; It will never die, nor once having been, can It cease to be. Unborn, Eternal, Ever-enduring, yet Most Ancient, the Spirit dies not when the body is dead." Notice the paradox: the Self is both "eternal" and "most ancient" - it transcends time altogether. And verse 21 poses the logical question: "He who knows the Spirit as Indestructible, Immortal, Unborn, Always-the-Same, how should he kill or cause to be killed?"

Today, contemplate this: If your true Self was never born and will never die, what exactly do you fear when you fear death? The body will certainly perish - but that is not you. The mind will dissolve - but that is not you either. Try this exercise: imagine yourself as the space within a room. The walls can be painted, damaged, or demolished, but the space itself is untouched. You are like that space - forms come and go within you, but you remain unchanged. How does identifying with this unchanging Self rather than the changing body-mind alter your relationship with mortality?

snippets.title: Day 24: Like Changing Clothes
snippets.sanskrit:
वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय

नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः |

अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च |
snippets.transliteration:
vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro.aparāṇi .

nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ .

verseTranslations: As a man discards his threadbare robes and puts on new, so the Spirit throws off Its worn-out bodies and takes fresh ones.
Weapons cleave It not, fire burns It not, water drenches It not, and wind dries It not.
It is impenetrable; It can be neither drowned nor scorched nor dried. It is Eternal, All-pervading, Unchanging, Immovable and Most Ancient.
snippets.commentary:

I call the Bhagavad Gita cliff notes for the Upanishads, or a Reader's Digest version of the Upanishads. Upanishads are very abstract to understand. So Bhagavad Gita is putting this knowledge in an understandable manner for us. Something which cannot be explained, inexplicable, the nature of the true self. Bhagavan is making an effort for us to understand.

So so far we have understood from Bhagavan that the self is imperishable, immutable and immortal. And it is all pervading. So myself and yourself are not two different selves. The same self expressing through different bodies, different instruments. Just like Swamiji uses the classic analogy of electricity. Electricity is one, its manifestations are many.

So in this building right now we see electricity, light, also see the heat from our heater. Both are only expressed in the same energy which is electricity. So you and I are different people, but we are the manifestation of the same entity which I call myself and you call yourself. So we had been discussing this verses where Bhagavan gave us several analogies for us to understand. One of them says: just as in this body we grow from baby to child to young adult to adult and then to an old man, when this self changes this body, it will still be the same kind of change.

It is no different than the change which you encountered effortlessly. I grew effortlessly from young adult to adult into an old man. And to make us understand, we have seen Vaasansi Jirinani ya tha Vihaan. So why do I change this body? He said, because this body is no longer appropriate to fulfill my Vasanathan desires. If my goal is to go from here to D.C. but if my car is not good enough, I have to buy another car or change another car, borrow, rent another car, which is more appropriate for that.

So because now this body is getting old and non functional that I change the body. Bhagavan has explained the concept of transmigration. Why person goes from one body to another which we have seen in the last verse which is vasansi ji yathavi haya navani gruhanati naroparani tatha sari raani vihaaya jirinani annyani sanyati navani dhi. It is as simple as that. Because this body is old. Just as when the old clothes are no longer useful, I buy new clothes, I change into new clothes.

When this body is no longer useful or not appropriate, I move on to the next one. Then coming back to explaining the nature of the self. The next two verses describe the self in a manner which we can understand. Swamiji explains here that something which is inexplicable can only be explained in terms of what is explainable. There is a word in Sanskrit: Upadesha. Upadesha literally means "near place" -- a place near to what I am trying to indicate. Because I cannot transmit my knowledge into your mind or intellect. But I can point out and then you will understand yourself to make it your own knowledge. So if I had been to Hawaii and you have never been to Hawaii, and I have to explain to you what Hawaii feels like or looks like, all I can do is compare it to a place which you have been to. So I might say, "Have you been to the Bahamas? Yes? Well, Hawaii is something like the Bahamas." So I can only explain things which you have not experienced by using the parameters of what you already know. So Bhagavan here now explains the nature of the self using examples which we understand. The verse says: Na Enam Chindanti Sastrani, Nainam Dahati Pavakaha, Na Chainam Kledayantyapah, Na Shoshayati Marutah.

Everything in this world I see is destructible. There is nothing that I know which does not get destructed. The destruction is the nature of this world. But the destruction can occur in various ways depending on the nature of that thing or being. So things which are grosser can be destroyed by grosser instruments. Nayanam chindanti sastrani Sastrani Weapons or any kind of instrument which can cut axe or a sword which can cut something.

But sword can only cut something which is as gross or more grosser than the sword. It cannot cut something which is subtler than the sword. So sword can cut object which is Solid, it cannot cut water which is liquid. Because water is subtler than sword itself. Therefore sword cannot cut it. So the implication is the self is subtler than any solid material you see in this world.

Therefore it cannot be cut by weapons. Nayanam Chandanti Sastrani na enam Dahati Pavakaha Fire cannot burn it. Fire can burn everything, but it cannot burn space. Space is subtler than fire and therefore fire cannot burn space. So in the world of manifestation Prakriti we see the five great elements. The earth the grossest and space is the subtlest of all.

So as the things get subtler, the grosser material cannot affect it. Nayanam Dhati Pavakah so the fire can burn everything, but not something which is subtler than fire. Therefore the self must be subtler than fire. Na chanam kle dian ti apah Water cannot wet it. Water can only wet something which has space in its structure -- interstitial space. Cotton can get soaked because between cotton fibers there is space in between. If there is no space, water cannot wet it.

Steel, it cannot soak that. So it is even subtler than water and wind cannot dry it. The dehydration only occurs if there is a moisture available in that object. Our body can get dehydrated because we know it is what 80% water. If there is no water in it, it cannot be dried. Water is only there if there is an interstitial space in between the structure.

The point is: something which is subtler than the instrument of destruction cannot be destroyed by that instrument. So all the things which we know in this world are basically destructible because they're grosser than the instruments that can destroy them. Including my mind and intellect. This body get destroyed because it is gross body. It is made up of five elements. So all elements go back to where they come from.

Think of it this way: we borrow a book from the library. At some point we have to return it. It does not belong to me. I just borrowed it from the library. Same with elements which make my body, mind and intellect are borrowed from Prakriti. Therefore I have to return them when I'm done with it.

The next verse defines this self as Acchedya. So now we have understood: because it cannot be cut, it must be non-cuttable. It cannot be burnt; it's non-wettable; it is non-dryable. And therefore because it cannot be destroyed by any means that we have known. The conclusion is Nityaha permanent. Something which has no destruction has to be permanent.

If something is permanent and indestructible, that means it is subtler than all means of destruction. And if it is subtler than any means of destruction that I know, it has to be all pervading. Therefore it is sarvagataha, all pervading. All pervading literally means it is subtler than anything I can comprehend through my senses. Everything which I can comprehend is finite.

Everything that is finite has its own self, life. But something which is permanent has to be beyond my sense perception. And therefore it is all pervad. If it's all pervading, it has to be firm because there is no place to move. If I am all pervading in my chair, then I cannot move. But if I am sitting on a bench and I am the only one, I can move around on that bench.

Sthanu also can be movable -- a tree is stable at the base, but it's moving at the top. Many people do not know that high-rise buildings also move in the wind. When I first started designing high rise buildings, I come to realize that the movement can be as much as several feet. Buildings which are hundred and something stories, so people get seasickness.

Some people are very sensitive to movement. Most of us do not notice it, but those who are sensitive to movement feel seasickness because the building literally moves in wind. So when we design it, we have to make sure all parts are basically movable. So all the windows and all that which you see. But from my perspective, the building is stable because my perception doesn't go as far.

The building is stable at the base but moving at the top. Therefore, the next verse says Achalah -- not only stable, but unmovable, simply because there is no place for it to move. If I'm all pervading, there is no other thing that can exist. So right now, only thing which I can think of, all space, is all pervading. Out of the five great elements I see, the other four are relatively finite. Matter has its own limitations.

The fire has its own limitations. Air has its own limitations. Water has own limitations. Space is all pervading. From my perspective right now, wherever I think there is space, therefore I can move the parts of this building. Now, these days, with the historical preservation, they sometimes insist that you cannot destroy this building.

But then some developer wants to buy that land because of great value. Then they will come in and say, we will take this building and put it somewhere else. We can take the whole building from the foundation up, put it in another county, another country. Even so, space does not move. When the building moves, space does not move. I can move my car from one place to another, but the space within the car does not move simply because space is unmovable.

If space is everywhere, there is no place to go. But everything else moves in the space where space is the subtlest of all the elements of Prakriti. The self is even subtler than the space, all five elements. Therefore it has no place to go. Therefore it is achalam, Sanatanah, eternal or ancient. Sanatana means it's not something new, it's not something new that we have invented.

If it were something new, a new concept that we have figured out, then there will be another time when somebody will make it not valid. New research will occur -- so for a while they say coffee drinking is not good. Then they came back and said, no, coffee is actually good for you. If you drink at least X number of cups of coffee, then you don't get Alzheimer or at least your brain will function well. That was a great solace to me. Okay, okay, I'm with.

So it keeps changing. If there's something new, it has all probability of getting invalid. But he says it's a Sanata. It's ancient, it's eternal. Before the time that you can think of, anything you can think of in past, it is beyond that. Therefore it's sanatanah.

It is unmanifest, Achintya -- it cannot be thought of. It cannot be grasped by my thinking instrument. So everything I try to understand, everything I comprehend in this world is actually by my intellect to understand it. When it comes in my comprehension, it has limitations. Everything I can comprehend is finite.

I can think of elephant, I can think of buildings. All that I can think is finite because they are manifest. The self is unmanifest. Manifest is something I can perceive through my senses.
snippets.reflection:
The famous "garment" analogy in verse 22 makes the abstract teaching tangible: "As a man discards his threadbare robes and puts on new, so the Spirit throws off Its worn-out bodies and takes fresh ones." We change clothes without any sense of losing our identity - the new shirt is simply more appropriate for our current needs. Similarly, the Self changes bodies when the old one can no longer serve its purpose. This reframing transforms death from a terrifying end into a natural transition.

Verses 23-24 describe the Self's indestructibility using the five elements: "Weapons cleave It not, fire burns It not, water drenches It not, and wind dries It not." Weapons can only cut something grosser than themselves - they cannot cut water. Fire can only burn something less subtle than itself - it cannot burn space. The Self is subtler than the subtlest element, hence nothing in the material world can affect it. It is "Eternal, All-pervading, Unchanging, Immovable and Most Ancient."

Practice this contemplation today: When you change your clothes, pause and notice - did "you" change? When you cut your hair or nails, did the essential "you" diminish? Now extend this: when your body ages and changes, when cells die and are replaced, when moods shift and thoughts come and go - what remains constant through all these changes? That constant witness is what these verses point to. Spend a few moments simply being aware of being aware - this pure awareness is what cannot be cut, burned, wetted, or dried.

snippets.reflection:
These verses complete Krishna's philosophical argument by addressing both the spiritual and practical perspectives. Verse 25 declares the Self to be "Unmanifest, Unthinkable, Immutable" - beyond the reach of our senses and even our thinking mind. "Wherefore, knowing the Spirit as such, thou hast no cause to grieve." The Self cannot be objectified or known as an object of knowledge; it is the very subject that makes all knowing possible.

But Krishna also addresses those who may not accept the immortality of the Self. Verse 26 says: "Even if thou thinkest of It as constantly being born, constantly dying, even then... thou still hast no cause to grieve." And verse 27 delivers the practical truth everyone must accept: "For death is as sure for that which is born, as birth is for that which is dead. Therefore grieve not for what is inevitable." Whether you believe in an eternal soul or not, grieving over what is certain and unavoidable is futile.

This teaching offers a powerful practice: Identify what you are currently grieving over or anxious about. Ask yourself: "Is this within my control, or is it inevitable?" If it is inevitable - like aging, change, or eventual death - then grieving is a waste of precious life energy. If it is within your control, then take action instead of worrying. The Stoics later echoed this wisdom: concern yourself only with what is in your power. Today, sort your worries into these two categories and release those that belong to the inevitable.

verseTranslations: The end and the beginning of beings are unknown. We see only the intervening formations. Then what cause is there for grief?
One hears of the Spirit with surprise, another thinks It marvellous, the third listens without comprehending. Thus, though many are told about It, scarcely is there one who knows It.
Be not anxious about these armies. The Spirit in man is imperishable.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed discussion on Chapter 1, Arjuna Vishadha Yoga, in which we have seen our conditions in this world. Arjuna Vishada Yoga represents our life where we are trained all our life for something. We have certain ideals and certain duties which we have held very dear to us. This is the very goal of my life. But then sometimes the situation overwhelms us, which makes us confused about what is right and what is wrong. And at that point our mind starts giving us wrong indications of what is right and what is wrong.

And we come up with all kinds of arguments about why I shouldn't be doing my duty, why I shouldn't be doing what I thought all this time that this is right for me. And these arguments are sometimes so convincing that we convince ourselves, saying "this is the voice of my antaratma, my inner conscience." However, it is just the blabbering of my mind, because I have not really established myself in my own true self. So this is not advice from Krishna, the consciousness in me, but rather my mind coming up with a defensive mechanism for why I shouldn't be doing this -- just because I'm overwhelmed by the situation.

So we have seen in the last few verses of chapter one, Arjuna put forth a very brilliant argument about why he shouldn't be fighting this war. First he says, from my personal point of view, I shouldn't be fighting this war. To kill my own kith and kin looks very logical -- why should you be killing your kith and kin? When that argument didn't seem to be convincing Krishna, because he didn't have an approving reaction, Arjuna realized -- well, those kith and kin are standing right in front of you to kill you. So that didn't seem like a very logical argument, he goes to the next level and says the war itself is very evil.

Any war is evil because in war men will die -- many men will die, which is obvious. And therefore it will upset the entire equilibrium of society by destroying family units. When a man dies in the family, obviously the family loses the head of the household. Now the women will be unprotected. And when the women become unprotected, they will do things which are not according to their dharma, because they have no protection. And when that happens, the whole system will be out of balance, giving rise to Varna Sankara -- intermixing of social classes -- in the next generation.

And that will completely upset our system, where the lineage of a father to the son in the same tradition will be giving oblation to the Pitrus. So the whole system will be completely destroyed according to Arjuna. Again, this makes a lot of sense, that war is evil. Everyone knows war is not something which is to look forward to, but war is inevitable sometimes to protect the society, protect the dharma. So Arjuna makes all the arguments he thinks he can make against fighting this war, and then he sits down in his chariot.

In the last verse, which we have seen, Sanjaya described that after making his argument, Arjuna didn't see any reaction from Krishna, so he drops down and throws his weapons away. That means he does not even have a mental capacity to hang on to himself. So the next chapter which we are entering into, called Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. Yoga of Knowledge, in the line of the knowledge of the Sankhyas. As Swamiji describes in his commentary, in our system there are six schools of thought, six different lines of philosophy, each one taking a slightly different route from the others. Sankhya is one of them. Sankhya is supposed to be the most logical thought, almost as scientific as the modern sciences.

It's a very logical approach to what is reality, what is truth, what is my essence, and what is the ultimate reality. It takes a very logical approach, and as we have seen in Logic of Spirituality, it takes you through who am I and what is my self. Then where did I come from? Where we have seen anything which we see is an effect of a cause. When I see a book here, it's an effect. The cause is somebody who knew how to write the book, how to print the book, and how to put it together.

The book is in front of me. So there are causes to cause any reality. I exist, I'm an effect. There are causes which cause me to be in this effect. Those causes are broadly defined as an efficient cause and a material cause. Someone who knew how to create me in this effect.

And someone also had the material to create me. Someone who knew how to create this book and someone also the material to create this book. So the knowledge is called efficient cause and the material is called material cause. These two have to come together for any effect to come into existence. And we can trace back all of that. And who had this efficient cause and material cause, both of them, to create this universe and me.

And we trace it back to one entity who had the knowledge to create this universe and also had the material to create it. The efficient cause we call God -- God has the knowledge to create this universe, including my own self. He also had the material to create this universe and myself. Then where did that material come from? At the end of our inquiry, we come to the conclusion that the material could not have come from anywhere else but from His own self, because nothing else existed before this universe was created -- only that one singularity which we call God. And that God had the knowledge.

The only material available to him was his own self. So out of his own self is created this universe. So my own self also cannot have come other than from his own self. So myself and his self is one and the same. My self is nothing but the reflection of his self. Thus logically concluding that Myself cannot be separate from his self because his self is immortal, imperishable, Myself also cannot be perishable or mortal.

Now, the Sankhya philosophy here is not put together verbatim, but its flavor and essence were taken here by Bhagavan Vedvyasa, also called Badarayana, in the Uttar Mimamsa school of thought -- which is theistic, as Swamiji says -- which accepts the reality of the one eternal self called Brahman, and also accepts the reality of this world and its relationship to Brahman.

Thus, in Bhagavad Gita from Chapter 2 onward, we will see the synthesis of all three paths of realization explained in the Vedas: Bhakti Yoga (path of devotion), Karma Yoga (path of action), and Jnana Yoga (path of knowledge). Bhagavad Gita puts all three yogas together as a comprehensive path of realization. It's Pravritti Vada -- you have to actively engage in this world, and then achieve the ultimate happiness you're seeking, with freedom from all the bondages and limitations you have superimposed on yourself. So in this second chapter, the teaching begins with Sanjaya's assessment of what's happening there.

Chapter 2, verse 1 says Sanjaya Vacha tam tatha krupaya vistam asrupurna kulekshanam Vishidantam Idam Vakyam Uvacha Madhusudhana, Madhusudana Krishna. And we have seen the Madhusudana one who is the slayer of the demon Madhu. In the Puranic story, these are all demons Krishna has slain. But philosophically, the demon Madhu represents that which seems very sweet to me in life but is not good for me -- that which is Preyas but not Shreyas, that which seems pleasant but is not truly good. Madhusudana is the slayer of that. When my intellect is awakened, I realize this may seem good to me, but is not good for me.

So Lord Krishna, Madhusudana, said this to the one who was completely overwhelmed by pity and despondency, his eyes full of tears, agitated. Arjuna had presented his case for why he shouldn't be fighting, and he was obviously expecting that Krishna would say, "Well, let's not fight this war." But the reaction that came in the next two verses is completely shocking to Arjuna. O Arjuna, where does this weakness of heart come upon you?

Which is Anari Jistham only practiced by those who are not civilized like you. Because Arya is the civilized one, Anaria is the uncivilized one according to their social order. One who is not civilized, who does not know the value of dharma, value of performing his own duties. Once a duty is assigned to me, I have assigned myself as taking upon that role, then it becomes imperative that I perform that duty. Once I decide that I want to be a husband, all the duties of husbands are now superimposed on my and as long as I want to be a husband, I have to perform all those duties that the civilized man's law. Once I decide I want to be a father, all the fatherly duties are assigned to me and there is no escape for me to perform those duties.

That's a civilized way of living. So once I have decided I'm going to be the general of this army, the leader of this society, then all the duties assigned to me as the leader of this army and leader of this society, I have to perform those duties. Now when I'm trying to shirk away from those duties. That is Anaria jistham. Only those who are not civilized will do that. They will be those deadbeat dads.

They are not civilized. They do not know that their duty is to pay whatever the alimony for their children. So only the uncivilized one will do that. So Bhagavan said, where does this Anaria jistham, weakness of your heart, which is not allowing you to do your duty, come upon you, which is a kirtikaram? It's not going to give you a good name. You may have all the good arguments to not do your duties, but once you don't do your duties, it's not going to give you a good name, not going to make you famous.

That how he ran away from his duties, you know, and this is because of the weakness of your heart. When you were thinking correctly, you knew what your duty is because you are the leader of this army and you knew what to do is to fight the enemy which is standing in front of you. You have not asked for this war. You didn't decide that this is the right thing to do. But the others in in their evil thoughts have decided to fight this war. Now it is your duty to lead your army into this war.

So this is not something Krishna approves of -- running away from your duty. Therefore, in the next verse he says: this is what you should be doing.
