His training and achievement in life have been such that enemies tremble to stand in front of him.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 28 presents a humbling truth: "The end and the beginning of beings are unknown. We see only the intervening formations. Then what cause is there for grief?" We witness only the middle portion of existence - a being's appearance in this world - without knowing where it came from before birth or where it goes after death. Our grief arises from the illusion that this visible portion is all there is.

Verse 29 acknowledges the rarity and wonder of this knowledge: "One hears of the Spirit with surprise, another thinks It marvellous, the third listens without comprehending. Thus, though many are told about It, scarcely is there one who knows It." This is not discouraging but realistic - Self-knowledge is not easily attained. Many hear these teachings as mere philosophy; few truly realize them. And verse 30 brings closure to the argument: "Be not anxious about these armies. The Spirit in man is imperishable."

Today, reflect on your relationship with this teaching. Do you hear it with "surprise" - as something new and intriguing? Do you think it "marvellous" - intellectually fascinating? Or do you "listen without comprehending" - the words going in but not transforming your life? The gap between hearing about the immortal Self and knowing it as your lived reality is the journey of spiritual practice. What would it take to move from intellectual understanding to direct experience? Consider that every moment of genuine self-inquiry - asking "Who am I?" and waiting for the answer - brings you closer to that realization.

snippets.title: Day 27: The Warrior's Duty
snippets.sanskrit:
स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि |

यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् |

अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि |
snippets.transliteration:
svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na vikampitumarhasi .

yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam .

atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi .
verseTranslations: Thou must look at thy duty. Nothing can be more welcome to a soldier than a righteous war. Therefore to waver in this resolve is unworthy, O Arjuna!
Blessed are the soldiers who find their opportunity. This opportunity has opened for thee the gates of heaven.
Refuse to fight in this righteous cause, and thou wilt be a traitor, lost to fame, incurring only sin.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen in the chapter that Bhagavan explained to Arjuna his situation from various perspectives, not just one perspective, that this is my idea, you should do this. But he gave him various perspectives. The first perspective, spiritual perspective, from the highest perspective, from the spirit's point of view that the self is immutable, imperishable. So that's the highest perspective. Then it came down to the society's perspective.

And see, from a society's perspective, you as a Kshatriya has duty to protect the society from evil. If you see that evil is occurring in the society, we rely on the Kshatriya just like we rely on our armies to protect ourselves. Our army cannot become pacifist at the last minute. From that perspective, this is the best opportunity you have to perform your art and perform your duty. So society's perspective, he gave his opinion that this is still what you should be looking at. Then came down the individual's perspective.

There we have seen Bhagavan said, if you give up, you run away from your duty, then you will incur sin. He has looked at the issue from various perspectives and came to the same conclusion that Arjuna should fight this war. So in the process, Bhagavan also taught us the art of persuasion. To persuade somebody who is bent upon doing something other than what we think is right for him, just giving your opinion that "look, you are doing something wrong" is not going to work. The only way that works is when you give him a three dimensional view of his situation, give him the view from various perspectives, look at it from various points of view and then the person will be able to see it correctly, then you will be able to persuade him. This can also be applied to looking at any problem or situation.

Say you come across a situation where you got a job in another town -- that's best for you. From your professional perspective, well, that's great. But if you take the decision just based on that, it may or may not be right. So you have to look at it from various perspectives. First you say, well from a professional perspective it seems like that job will give me more opportunity to go further in my career. Then you see it from family's perspective.

Will my family be comfortable relocating from this town to another? Will they be able to adjust as easily as they are adjusted here? Then lastly, you also have to see what the school district is in that new town. Is it as good or better in that town? And if you come to the same conclusion from all three of them, then relocation is the great idea. Take the job and move or you will find that you will end up commuting just like most of our friends do who work outside Richmond in Washington or or other places.

So any problem or situation cannot be viewed from just one perspective. And you can come to right decision or you can convince someone. So this art of persuasion is to give somebody a three dimensional view of a situation and then come to the conclusion. In this case, Bhagavan came to the same conclusion from all perspectives. From a spiritual, from a society's perspective, from individual Arjuna must fight this war. What typically works best is when it comes to me, I can see from my perspective that it is right.

So therefore Bhagavan put more stress on his individual situation. So we have seen that he's saying tathaha swadharma kirtim hitva papa vapsyasi. If you give up your duties, you will incur Papa. And this obviously is very dreaded word in Hindu society that you will incur papa. So that obviously worked probably more effectively. But you had the background of other two perspectives that this is right, this is the right thing to do from all perspectives.

So Bhagavan pursue that point of view a little further and says, bhayat ranat uparatam mansante tvam maharathaha isam chatvam bahumatah bhatva yasyasi lagavam. So all these great warriors who are gathered here on our side and on the other side, they have very high regards for you. Because of your valor and your prowess. Even your enemies are unwillingly accepting that you are one of the best warriors. It is not easy to confront you. You are the one who has achieved the pasupatastra from Lord Shiva himself.

Obviously there's a story that Arjunaya goes for tapas to please Lord Shiva. And in the end he ended up fighting with Lord Shiva himself. But Lord Shiva was so pleased that he revealed himself that I am not just the hunter which you are fighting, but I am Lord Shiva. Here is the Pashupadashtra. And as the Purana says, the Pasupatastra is like ultimate weapon. It can destroy the entire universe in no time.

So you are the one who has such a prowess that you can destroy everybody in no time if you really choose to. However, you cannot use any weapon irresponsibly. Just like our nuclear weapons. You may have capability but you may never use it. He said those people, they will then think that you ran away from this war because of fear. Even though that may not be reality but that's how you will be viewed by your peers and your enemies.

They will belittle you, they have high respect for you. And they will say I don't know what we were thinking. This guy turned out to be not really what we thought he is going to be. It's not something very comfortable for you if that happens. So the next verse says: not only will you disappoint your friends, relatives, and the people who are relying on you in society, but there are also Ahita people -- those who are not your well-wishers, your enemies who wish you would go away. They will be telling stories about your cowardice. All kinds of Bahun Avachya Vadaan -- things which we cannot repeat on national TV. That kind of talk, they will be talking about you. So please think about it.

Ninantaha, tava, samaratyam. They will be cavilling at your prowess. That I think it was all big hype. It was all made up stories that he is such a great warrior. I don't think he had those qualities. And if that's happened, what is more painful than that?

That nobody will ever realize that you ran away because you thought that killing your cousins and your teachers is not a right thing to do. But they will think it's a fear of war, fear of defeat which made you go away. So don't think this is going to be easy. If you go away -- well, in any deal we make, you have to come up with a win-win situation. The only way the deal gets closed is when a client thinks I can provide the most appropriate services and I think this is the right project for me -- then only do we sign a contract. If either party doesn't think it's right, nothing happens.

You have to come up with a win-win situation where both parties will have a good outcome. Now in this case, looking at our own situation, any decision I take from the options available to me -- I should feel comfortable that it will be an acceptable situation for me. So Bhagavan now uses that final trump card and says if you die, you will go to the hero's heaven. So there is a special section of heaven which is reserved for these great heroes who die on the battlefield.

It's like the GI Bill, these great privileges in heaven for the heroes who serve their country, serve the society, in the process they die. You can think about the health care workers who lost their lives in this battle against Corona. So our scripture says there is a special section in heaven to reward them for their valor and their courage. Hatova Prapsesi Swargam Jitwava Bakshishe Mahim. If you die, you go to the heaven for the heroes. If you win, you will lead the kingdom on this earth.

This is a no-brainer for you. There is no way you can lose -- fight and die, or fight and win. Either way, you come out ahead. So there is nothing to think about. Here the only good decision is fight the war. Therefore he says, Tasmat Utthishtka Yudhaya Krutan Nishayah.

Therefore O son of Kunti, get up with a resolve to fight this war. So this is like a conclusive statement from Bhagavan. In the beginning Arjuna asked him and said, give me which is shreyas for me. And we have come across the word shreyas and prayers before. That which is always good. It may not feel good, but it is good for me.

Preyas feels good but is not good for me. And Arjuna, in no uncertain terms, asked Bhagavan: tell me what is good for me and I will do it. Now Bhagavan says Utthiste Kamanteya, get up with the resolve to fight this war. So that was the conclusive advice from Bhagavan. And then Bhagavan now introduces the concept of Karma Yoga. You have to act in this world and there will be consequences of your actions.

You are part of this world. This Sansa and this Sansar is not homogeneous experiences. The experiences are varied. Some are conducive, some are not conducive. You will fight the war. Outcome is not guaranteed.

The experience will not be as you predict. It may be something different. But you have to treat whatever you face with an equal state of mind. You have to treat them alike no matter what the outcome is. Because you are enjoying the ride in this world. The next verse now introduces the idea of how to transform Karma into Karma Yoga.

Same action, but changing the mental attitude, becomes Karma Yoga. It says: Sukha Dukhe Same Kritva Labha Alabhou Jaya Ajayou, Tato Yuddhaya Yujyasva, Naivam Papam Avapsyasi. We came back to Papa again. In verse 33 he said Tatah Svadharmam Kirtim Cha Hitva Papam Avapsyasi -- You will incur sin if you abandon your duty. Here he says Tatha yudhaya yujyashwa na evam papam avapshasi.

You will not incur any sin. But the condition is Sukha Dukhe Same Kritva -- you should treat pleasure and pain alike. It's more like being an observer. It does not mean that you react to pleasure and pain in the same way, but you treat them alike as an observer, maintaining equanimity.

For example, when someone thinks "I should have a cup of coffee," the one who is thinking about having that cup of coffee -- that's an observer. That observer should be neutral, treating anything which comes with equanimity. Sukha and Dukha operate at the mental level -- these are my experiences. When I experience something, there will be a mental reaction saying "this is conducive" or "this is not conducive, not good."

Then there's profit and loss, which operates at the intellectual level. Am I making profit by doing this or I'm losing something? Here is my intellect. I actually thought I'm gonna get this but I didn't get that.

And therefore this is a loss or this is a profit. So that's at the intellectual level. Finally both Jaya and Ajaya victory or defeat is at the physical level. I tried to gain something, I did not gain it. I competed against several firms to get a project. That's a real reality, the physical reality that I don't have that project anymore.
snippets.reflection:
Having established the spiritual foundation, Krishna now addresses Arjuna from the perspective of Dharma - righteous duty. "Thou must look at thy duty. Nothing can be more welcome to a soldier than a righteous war. Therefore to waver in this resolve is unworthy" (verse 31). This is Swadharma - one's own duty based on one's nature, training, and role in life. Arjuna is a Kshatriya, a warrior; protecting society from adharma is his sacred responsibility.

Verse 32 presents the opportunity positively: "Blessed are the soldiers who find their opportunity. This opportunity has opened for thee the gates of heaven." Far from being a curse, facing this battle is actually a blessing - a chance to fulfill one's highest duty. But verse 33 warns of the consequences of abandoning that duty: "Refuse to fight in this righteous cause, and thou wilt be a traitor, lost to fame, incurring only sin."

Apply this teaching by identifying your own Swadharma. What is your unique role, given your nature, skills, training, and circumstances? Are you fulfilling it, or are you wavering at a critical moment? Remember that Dharma is contextual - what is right changes based on time, place, and role. A soldier's dharma differs from a monk's. Today, ask yourself: What is the "righteous battle" I am being called to fight? Where am I being asked to step up but holding back due to fear or attachment? What opportunity for growth or service am I treating as a burden rather than a blessing?

snippets.reflection:
Krishna now appeals to Arjuna's sense of honor and reputation. "Men will talk forever of thy disgrace; and to the noble, dishonour is worse than death" (verse 34). This is not about ego or pride, but about the practical consequences of abandoning one's duty. Verse 35 adds: "Great generals will think that thou hast fled from the battlefield through cowardice; though once honoured thou wilt seem despicable." Those who respected Arjuna will lose that respect. His enemies will mock him: "Thine enemies will spread scandal and mock at thy courage. Can anything be more humiliating?" (verse 36).

Notice Krishna's masterful teaching approach: He presents the same conclusion - that Arjuna must fight - from multiple angles. First the spiritual perspective (the Self is immortal), then the duty perspective (Swadharma), and now the social perspective (honor and reputation). This three-dimensional view helps Arjuna see clearly from all angles. A decision supported by spiritual truth, aligned with duty, and acceptable to society is more likely to be correct.

Today, apply this multi-perspective analysis to a decision you are facing. How does it look from the spiritual perspective - what is most aligned with your highest Self? From the duty perspective - what does your role and responsibility demand? From the social perspective - how will your choice be perceived, and can you stand behind it? If all three perspectives point in the same direction, you have strong guidance. If they conflict, examine which concern is truly valid and which might be fear or attachment in disguise.

snippets.title: Day 29: Victory or Heaven
snippets.sanskrit:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् |

सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ |

एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु |
snippets.transliteration:
hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm .

sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau .

eṣā te.abhihitā sāṅkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu .
verseTranslations: If killed, thou shalt attain Heaven; if victorious, enjoy the kingdom of earth. Therefore arise, O Son of Kunti, and fight!
Look upon pleasure and pain, victory and defeat, with an equal eye. Make ready for the combat, and thou shalt commit no sin.
I have told thee the philosophy of Knowledge. Now listen and I will explain the philosophy of Action, by means of which, O Arjuna, thou shalt break through the bondage of all action.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen in the chapter that Bhagavan explained to Arjuna his situation from various perspectives -- not just one perspective saying, "this is my idea, you should do this." He gave him various perspectives. The first was the spiritual perspective, from the highest point of view: the self is immutable, imperishable. So that's the highest perspective. Then it came down to the society's perspective.

And see, from a society's perspective, you as a Kshatriya have a duty to protect the society from evil. If you see that evil is occurring in the society, we rely on the Kshatriya just like we rely on our armies to protect ourselves. Our army cannot become pacifist at the last minute. From that perspective, this is the best opportunity you have to perform your duty. So from society's perspective, he gave his opinion that this is still what you should be looking at. Then came the individual's perspective.

There we have seen Bhagavan said, if you give up and run away from your duty, then you will incur sin. He has looked at the issue from various perspectives and came to the same conclusion that Arjuna should fight this war.

So in the process, Bhagavan also taught us the art of persuasion. If you want to persuade somebody who is bent upon doing something other than what we think is right for him, just giving your opinion -- "look, you are doing something wrong" -- is not going to work. The only way that works is when you give him a three-dimensional view of his situation from various perspectives. Look at it from various points of view, and then the person will be able to see it correctly. Then you will be able to persuade him. This can also be applicable to looking at any problem, any situation.

You come across a situation where you got a job in another town, that's best for you. From your professional perspective, well that's great. But if you take the decision just based on that, it may or may not be right. So you have to look at it from various perspectives. First you say, well from a professional perspective it seems like that job will give me more opportunity to go further in my career. Then you see it from family's perspective.

Will my family be comfortable relocating from this town to another? Will they be able to adjust as easily as they are adjusted here? Then lastly, you also have to see what the school district is like in that new town. Is it as good or better? And if you come to the same conclusion from all three perspectives, then relocation is a great idea. Take the job and move -- or you will find that you will end up commuting just like most of our friends do who work outside Richmond in Washington or other places.

So any problem or situation cannot be viewed from just one perspective. And you can come to right decision or you can convince someone. So this art of persuasion is to give somebody a three dimensional view of a situation and then come to the conclusion. In this case, Bhagavan came to the same conclusion from all perspectives. From a spiritual, from a society's perspective, from individual Arjuna must fight this war. What typically works best is when it comes to me and I can see from my own perspective that it is right.

So therefore Bhagavan put more stress on his individual situation. So we have seen that he's saying tathaha swadharma kirtim hitva papa vapsyasi. If you give up your duties, you will incur Papa. And this obviously is very dreaded word in Hindu society that you will incur papa. So that obviously worked probably more effectively. But you had the background of other two perspectives that this is right, this is the right thing to do from all perspectives.

So Bhagavan pursue that point of view a little further and says, bhayat ranat uparatam mansante tvam maharathaha isam chatvam bahumatah bhatva yasyasi lagavam. So all these great warriors who are gathered here on our side and on the other side, they have very high regards for you. Because of your valor and your prowess. They are unwillingly accepting your enemy, unwillingly accepting that you are one of the best warriors. It is not easy to confront you. You are the one who has achieved the pasupatastra from Lord Shiva himself.

Obviously there's a story that Arjunaya goes for tapas to please Lord Shiva. And in the end he ended up fighting with Lord Shiva himself. But Lord Shiva was so pleased that he revealed himself that I am not just the hunter which you are fighting, but I am Lord Shiva. Here is the Pashupadashtra. And as the Purana says, the Pasupatastra is like ultimate weapon. It can destroy the entire universe in no time.

So you are the one who has such a prowess that you can destroy everybody in no time if you really choose to. However, you cannot use any weapon irresponsibly. Just like our nuclear weapons. You may have capability but you may never use it. He said those people, they will then think that you ran away from this war because of fear. Even though that may not be reality but that's how you will be viewed by your peers and your enemies.

They will belittle you. Right now they have high respect for you, and they will say, "I don't know what we were thinking. This guy turned out to be not really what we thought he was going to be." It's not something very comfortable for you if that happens.

So the next verse says: not only will you disappoint your friends and relatives and people who are relying on you, the society.

But there are ahitha people who are not your well wishers, you know, enemies who wish that you go away. He said they will be telling stories about your cowardice. All kinds of, you know, Bahun, vadish, shanti or vachevadas. Things which we cannot repeat on national tv. That kind of talk, they will be talking about you. So please think about it.

Ninantaha, tava, samaratyam. They will be cavilling at your prowess. That I think it was all big hype. It was all made up stories that he is such a great warrior. I don't think he had those qualities. And if that's happened, what is more painful than that?

Nobody will ever realize that you ran away because you thought that killing your cousins and your teachers is not a right thing to do. They will think it's a fear of war, fear of defeat, which made you go away. So don't think this is going to be easy if you go away.

And then, in any deal which we make, you have to come up with a win-win situation. The only way a deal gets closed is when a client comes to me and thinks I can provide the most appropriate services, and I think this is the right project for me -- then only we sign a contract. If I don't think it is right, or he doesn't think it is right for him, nothing happens.

So you have to come up with a win-win situation where both parties will have a good outcome. Now in this case, if you are just looking at your own situation, any decision which I take out of the options available to me, I should feel comfortable that it will be an acceptable situation for me. So Bhagavan now uses that final trump card and says: if you die, you will go to the hero's heaven. So there is a special section of heaven which is reserved for these great heroes who die on the battlefield.

It's like the GI Bill, these great privileges in heaven for the heroes who serve their country, serve the society, in the process they die. You can think about the health care workers who lost their lives in this battle against Corona. So here our scripture says they have a special Saxon in heaven to reward them for their valor and their courage. Hatova Prapsesi Swargam Jitwava Bakshishe Mahim. If you die, you go to the heaven for the heroes. If you win, you will lead the kingdom on this earth.

This is a no-brainer for you. There is no way that you can lose, one way or the other. Fight and die, or fight and win -- both ways you come out ahead. So there is nothing to think about. Here the only good decision is to fight the war. Therefore he says, Tasmat Utthishtka Yudhaya Krutan Nishayah.

Therefore O son of Kunti, get up with a resolve to fight this war. So this is like a conclusive statement from Bhagavan. In the beginning Arjuna asked him and said, give me which is shreyas for me. And we have come across the word shreyas and prayers before. That which is always good. It may not feel good, but it is good for me.

Preyas, on the other hand, feels good but is not good for me. And Arjuna, in no uncertain terms, asked Bhagavan: tell me what is good for me and I will do it. Now Bhagavan says Utthiste Kaunteya, get up with the resolve to fight this war. So that was the conclusive advice from Bhagavan. And then Bhagavan now introduces the concept of Karma Yoga. You have to act in this world and there will be consequences of your actions.

You are part of this world. This Sansar is not made up of homogeneous experiences. The experiences are varied -- some are conducive, some are not conducive. You will fight the war. Outcome is not guaranteed.

The experience will not be as you predict. It may be something different. But you have to treat whatever you face with an equal state of mind. You have to treat them alike no matter what the outcome is. Because you are enjoying the ride in this world. The next verse now introduces the idea of how to transform Karma into Karma Yoga.

Same action, changing the mental attitude becomes Karma yoga. It says Sukhdu KE samy krutva alabha jaya jayo Tathaya yujaswa na evam papam avapsyasi. We came back to the papa again. So in verse 33 he said that Tathaha swadharma kirtim chahitva papam awapsyasi. You will incur sin if you abandon your duty. Here he says Tatha yudhaya yujyashwa na evam papam avapshasi.

You will not incur any sin. But the condition is sukha dukkha samay krutva sukhyana dukkha. You should treat them alike. It's more like an observer. It does not mean that you react to Sukhanidukha in the same way but you treat them alike as an observer. It's like that to me.

One part of me says, "I think I should have a cup of coffee." The one who is thinking about me having a cup of coffee -- that's the observer. See, that observer should be neutral. He should be treating anything which comes alike. Sukha and Dukkha operate at the mental level -- my experience. When I experience something, there will be a mental reaction: "this is conducive" or "this is not conducive."

Then there is profit and loss -- that operates at the intellectual level. Am I making a profit by doing this, or am I losing something? That's my intellect at work. I actually thought I was going to get this, but I didn't get that.

And therefore this is a loss or this is a profit. So that's at the intellectual level. Finally both Jaya and Ajaya victory or defeat is at the physical level. I tried to gain something, I did not gain it. I competed against several firms to get a project. That's a real reality, the physical reality that I don't have that project anymore.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 37 presents a win-win scenario: "If killed, thou shalt attain Heaven; if victorious, enjoy the kingdom of earth. Therefore arise, O Son of Kunti, and fight!" Either outcome is favorable when one acts from duty with the right attitude. This removes the paralysis of "what if I fail?" - both success and failure have their rewards when the action itself is righteous.

Verse 38 introduces the transformative attitude of Karma Yoga: "Look upon pleasure and pain, victory and defeat, with an equal eye. Make ready for the combat, and thou shalt commit no sin." This equanimity (Samatva) is the key that transforms ordinary action into yoga. And verse 39 transitions to the practical teaching: "I have told thee the philosophy of Knowledge. Now listen and I will explain the philosophy of Action, by means of which... thou shalt break through the bondage of all action."

Practice this today by choosing one challenging task and approaching it with equanimity. Before beginning, consciously decide: "I will give my best effort, and I will accept whatever outcome arises with equal composure." Notice the difference this makes - without attachment to results, you can focus fully on the action itself, making you more effective. At the day's end, reflect: Did viewing success and failure equally allow you to act more freely? Did releasing outcome-attachment reduce your stress and increase your engagement? This is the beginning of Karma Yoga in daily life.

snippets.title: Day 30: The Yoga of Action
snippets.sanskrit:
नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते |

व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन |

यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः |
snippets.transliteration:
nehābhikramanāśo.asti pratyavāyo na vidyate .

vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana .

yāmimāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ pravadantyavipaścitaḥ .
verseTranslations: On this Path, endeavour is never wasted, nor can it ever be repressed. Even a very little of its practice protects one from great danger.
By its means, the straying intellect becomes steadied in the contemplation of one object only; whereas the minds of the irresolute stray into bypaths innumerable.
Only the ignorant speak in figurative language. It is they who extol the letter of the scriptures, saying, There is nothing deeper than this.'
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have discussed up to the verse 30, the knowledge of Sankhya, the knowledge about your own self. What is the nature of the self? And then now I'll teach you the Buddhi Yoga. I'll teach you the Yoga of how to implement this knowledge in your life. Buddhi Yoga, Intelligent way of living.

And then Bhagavan said, the way to work in this world is to have equanimity. Equanimity comes from your understanding of what you are getting into. If you understand the field of actions, the nature of the field of actions, the equanimity comes easily, naturally. If you do not understand the field of action, then obviously you will have difficulties. And we have used the example of roller coaster. That one who is standing in the line with all the enthusiasm, he knows what is the nature of the roller coaster.

He anticipates the ups and downs and twists and turns. That's the thrill of riding a roller coaster. If there were no ups and downs and twists and turns, there is no fun in a roller coaster. The more twists and turns, the more enjoyable it is -- then you go back and stand in line again. So if you enter this Sansar with the expectation that there will be ups and downs, twists and turns -- Sukhaduka, Lava Alabha, Jaya Jaya.

Well that's the thrill of living in Sansar. So at the end of this life we'll come to the conclusion that that was pretty thrilling ride. Well, let's do it all over again. That's Kurupunar Janma. We'll stand in line again in that Sansa. While we are on that ride we forget that this is what we signed up for.

That's where problem comes. So Bhagavan said keep that in mind that these are natural and this is what you signed up for. The goal of life is to realize your true self. Which is what Bhagavan said I taught you in the first portion of this discussion. Now I want to tell you how to use that knowledge to realize that ultimate truth, the self, the nature of yourself. Bhagavan Ved Vyas discusses what is the difficulty we have in understanding our Darshan Shastras.

So we have basically discussed in the beginning there are six schools of thought and the school of thought which is based on the previous portion of Veda called Karmakanda. So all Vedas are divided into four parts. There are the mantras, then Brahmanas, then Aranyakas, and then Upanishads. The philosophy which is more centered around Karmakand. The Brahmana portion is called Purva Vimansa. We have discussed before, in Purva Mimsa, the goal of life is to reach heavens.

And in heavens then you will have supra sensuous experiences to make you feel happy. Every good action we perform will create merits. You accumulate enough merits so you can go to Swarga. And in that Swarga, then you will have these enjoyments. When you exhaust your balance of your merits, you will come back again, work again for the more merits and go back to Swarga again. But that's the goal of life in Purva Mimsa.

And therefore the society in general placed more emphasis on collecting merits and various ways to do yajnas and rituals. So the means of rituals was supposed to be to purify your mind and intellect so you can become single pointed. But the means became the goal in the society and they completely missed the boat. So now we see the criticism from Bhagavan Ved Vyas that how we have missed that boat as a society. And we have seen time and again in history of India that these philosophers and the great thinkers have come to realign the religion back to its goal. So this spiritual aspect becomes available to all people.

So it seems that during Mahabharata time the spiritual aspect of the goal was not available to most people. People were stuck into the rituals. So Bhagawan Vedvyas criticizes those people who had been misguiding the generations. So he says in verse 42 yam imam puspitam vacam. Those people using the flowery language are unwise. The unwise people are using flowery language.

The language used in Brahmana portion of Bhagavadas. He said, they make it sound like that is the goal. Those description rituals are for you to purify your mind and intellectual. But here they have made it sound like that is the goal. This is what you should be doing. Then it became so elaborate and society was so indulgent into it, that average person was afraid of the word yoga or Yajna.

Because in each ritual it has been said that if you don't perform it correctly, you will incur sin -- there will be an adverse effect. So you have to have an expert to tell you how to do it. And each ritual became so elaborate, describing what type of bricks to be used, how the bricks are to be arranged for the yajna. So an average person was afraid of the word yajna or yoga, with the fear that "if I do something wrong, rather than accumulating merits, I'll accumulate demerits."

Therefore, Bhagavan in the previous verse has given us this assurance: this yoga, this Buddhi Yoga, when you perform it, there is no danger of any adverse effect. And even a little practice -- you don't have to be an expert.

You don't have to perform it to a level where you become a master. Even the starting of a little effort will not go in vain. So it's a complete contradiction to what was prevalent in ritualism. In ritualistic practice, you have to do it correctly; if you don't do it correctly, there will be an adverse effect. Here Bhagavan said, no, no -- there is no adverse effect in this Buddhi Yoga, there is no adverse effect.

You perform your actions in this manner with equanimity of mind and you will be liberated from all your karma bandana, the bondages of actions. So now Bhagawan is criticizing the people who are using flowery language to make people confused about what is right and what is wrong. And he said Veda Vadharathaha. They take great pleasure and using the words of Vedas Na anyat asti ITI Vadhi Naham. They say there is nothing other than this, other than this, other than this Karma Kanda, other than this rituals, other than to accumulate merits and go to heaven, there is nothing else there. Completely missing the boat.

The goal of life is to achieve that oneness with yourself, understanding the self. Kamatmana Swarga Paraha. Because they're desirous of achieving Swarga. So the Swarga became the ultimate goal. They said that Veda says that Karmakand, you should be doing all these karmas. When you do, you will accumulate merits and you will go to Swarga.

So Swarga became the goal of life. Swarga Paraha Janma, Karma Falla Pradha -- which promises new birth as the renewal of their actions. You will come back again, you will have more enjoyments, and you go to Swarga again. Kriya Vishesha Bahula -- and there are all kinds of rituals. They don't have one single goal. They also do not follow one single path.

There are so many desires and so many goals. So now you can say that even though this criticism is for the Karmakanda, if you look at our lives, it is exactly that we are all Karma Kandis. We do all kinds of actions to achieve all types of different results, different accomplishments and achievements. Kriya vi says Bahula. They are engaged in too many different types of activities, too many different types of rituals. Bhoga Aishwarya gatimprati.

Because we want to achieve the Bhoga and Aishwarya -- enjoyments and power -- that became the goal of life, then and even now. We have no one single goal, and therefore we are not focused. And therefore we cannot achieve what we think is our birthright, which is happiness. Because we have lost ourselves into all these Kriyas. Bhagavan Ved Vyas criticizes those people who have preached that the goal of life is to go to heaven to elevate your standard of living. Now we have come to conclusion that no matter what status you have in the society, what achievement you have, what accomplishment you have, your problems remain the same.

Whether you are working at the lowest rank of the society or you are the highest rank of the society, basic problems which we face, which makes us unhappy, remain exactly the same. So this Bhogaira Aishwarya is not going to give us what we are ultimately looking for, which is happiness. And Bhagawan continues the criticism. Bhogeswarya prasaktanaam taya apruta cheta sam. Their intellect is taken away. They have lost their rational intellect -- the ability to discern what will give them happiness.

Because they are Bhoga Aishwarya Prasaktana -- engaged in enjoyment and power. This fixation with enjoyment and power, with raising the standard of your living, has made us lose the goal of life: that we want to be happy. It is pure and simple. Vyavasayatmika Buddhi Samadhau Na Vidhiyati. Those who are engaged in this variety of activities to achieve varieties of goals cannot have the single-pointed mind, the single-pointed intellect, to achieve their oneness with self.

That oneness with yourself is the only means to achieve happiness. The conclusion of Vedanta so Bhagavan Ved Vyas who wrote the Brahma Sutra as Rishi Badaraya, crystallized this knowledge of Upanishad, saying that the goal of life is to achieve the oneness with your true self. Once you realize your true self, all that which you're seeking, all your life will be yours. Peace and happiness will be your birthright. So far we have learned from Bhagavan the ultimate truth which is revealed in Upanishads. That is Brahma, Satya, Jagat, Mithya, the Atma, Satya, Deha Mithya.

That which is permanent is Satya. That which is superimposed on the permanent is Mithya. For example, if somebody is wearing a Halloween costume, a child is wearing a Halloween costume and you ask, is that you, Medha? And she said, no, I'm a witch. That which is Mithya, Medha is Satya. Because Medha is permanent, which is the superimposition.

I dropped it like a hot potato. The hotness is superimposed on potato. Because that's not potato's inherent quality, that's an incidental quality superimposed on a potato. Potato borrowed that heat from boiling water or microwaves. That is not inherent in potato. So that hotness, that hot potato is Mithya.

Coronavirus is Mithya. Because the coronavirus by itself has no real activity, it cannot do anything. It's only when there is a host, it manifests as infection. So Bhagavan taught us that this Deha is Mithya. But you, the Atma is satisfied. And therefore Arjuna, you should fight this battle of life.

But how to fight is then we learnt in the last verse which is Sukhadu khe samy Krutva la Balabha Jayajayo Toto Yudhaya Nayvam Papam, Ovaps that having that equanimity of mind to all these pairs of opposites, Sukhadukha la Balab Jaya Jaya. And then you engage in your life, in your actions, and you will not incur any sin. Now this seems fairly absurd advice. Because how can you be same for Sukha and Dukkha? Dukkha is going to upset me and Sukkah is going to elate me. But Bhagavan said no, this is a reality which if you understand, then you will be able to practice it.

So for example, if you Go to theme park and you see the people lining for roller coaster ride. So all these people are lining up enthusiastically. They know the nature of roller coaster. They have figured out roller coaster is made up of ascents and descents, twist and turns. Knowing fully well that this is the nature of roller coaster.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 40 offers tremendous encouragement: "On this Path, endeavour is never wasted, nor can it ever be repressed. Even a very little of its practice protects one from great danger." Unlike ritualistic practices where incorrect performance brings adverse effects, in Buddhi Yoga even small efforts yield lasting benefits. No sincere spiritual effort is ever lost - this is a powerful reassurance for seekers worried about "doing it wrong."

Verse 41 distinguishes focused wisdom from scattered thinking: "The straying intellect becomes steadied in the contemplation of one object only; whereas the minds of the irresolute stray into bypaths innumerable." Having one clear goal creates focus; having many competing desires creates confusion. And verse 42 begins a critique of those who miss the deeper purpose of scriptures: "Only the ignorant speak in figurative language... saying, 'There is nothing deeper than this.'" They mistake the means (rituals for purification) for the end (Self-realization).

Examine your own life for scattered focus. How many different things are you pursuing, hoping each will bring fulfillment? The teaching suggests that this multiplicity itself prevents happiness. Today, try this: identify your single most important goal - not your many wants, but your one true aim. How would your day look different if every action was aligned with this one purpose? Also notice if you are confusing means with ends anywhere in your life - pursuing money, status, or pleasure as goals in themselves rather than as potential means to a deeper fulfillment.

snippets.title: Day 31: The Vedic Ritualists
snippets.sanskrit:
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम् |

भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम् |

त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन |
snippets.transliteration:
kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām .

bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām .

traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna .
verseTranslations: Consulting only their own desires, they construct their own heaven, devising arduous and complex rites to secure their own pleasure and their own power; and the only result is rebirth.
While their minds are absorbed with ideas of power and personal enjoyment, they cannot concentrate their discrimination on one point.

The Vedic Scriptures tell of the three constituents of life - the Qualities. Rise above all of them, O Arjuna, above all the pairs of opposing sensations; be steady in truth, free from worldly anxieties and centered in the Self.

Well that's the thrill of living in Sansar. So at the end of this life we'll come to the conclusion that that was pretty thrilling ride. Well, let's do it all over again. That's Kurupunar Janma. We'll stand in line again in that Sansa. While we are on that ride we forget that this is what we signed up for.

That's where problem comes. So Bhagavan said keep that in mind that these are natural and this is what you signed up for. The goal of life is to realize your true self. Which is what Bhagavan said I taught you in the first portion of this discussion. Now I want to tell you how to use that knowledge to realize that ultimate truth, the self, the nature of yourself. Bhagavan Ved Vyas discusses what is the difficulty we have in understanding our Darshan Shastras.

So we have basically discussed in the beginning there are six schools of thought and the school of thought which is based on the previous portion of Veda called Karmakanda. So all Vedas are divided into four parts. There are the mantras, then Brahmanas, then Aranyakas, and then Upanishads. The philosophy which is more centered around Karmakand. The Brahmana portion is called Purva Vimansa. We have discussed before, in Purva Mimsa, the goal of life is to reach heavens.

And in heavens then you will have supra sensuous experiences to make you feel happy. Every good action we perform will create merits. You accumulate enough merits so you can go to Swarga. And in that Swarga, then you will have these enjoyments. When you exhaust your balance of your merits, you will come back again, work again for the more merits and go back to Swarga again. But that's the goal of life in Purva Mimsa.

And therefore the society in general placed more emphasis on collecting merits and various ways to do yajnas and rituals. So the means of rituals was supposed to be to purify your mind and intellect so you can become single pointed. But the means became the goal in the society and they completely missed the boat. So now we see the criticism from Bhagavan Ved Vyas that how we have missed that boat as a society. And we have seen time and again in history of India that these philosophers and the great thinkers have come to realign the religion back to its goal. So this spiritual aspect becomes available to all people.

So it seems that during Mahabharata time the spiritual aspect of the goal was not available to most people. People were stuck into the rituals. So Bhagawan Vedvyas criticizes those people who had been misguiding the generations. So he says in verse 42 yam imam puspitam vacam. Those people using the flowery language are unwise. The unwise people are using flowery language.

The language used in Brahmana portion of Bhagavadas. He said, they make it sound like that is the goal. Those description rituals are for you to purify your mind and intellectual. But here they have made it sound like that is the goal. This is what you should be doing. Then it became so elaborate and society was so indulgent into it, that average person was afraid of the word yoga or Yajna.

Because in each ritual it has been said that if you don't perform it correctly, you will incur sin -- there will be an adverse effect. So you have to have an expert to tell you how to do it. And each ritual became so elaborate, describing what type of bricks to be used, how the bricks are to be arranged for the yajna. So an average person was afraid of the word yajna or yoga, with the fear that "if I do something wrong, rather than accumulating merits, I'll accumulate demerits."

Therefore, Bhagavan in the previous verse has given us this assurance: this yoga, this Buddhi Yoga, when you perform it, there is no danger of any adverse effect. And even a little practice -- you don't have to be an expert.

You don't have to perform it to a level where you become a master. Even the starting of a little effort will not go in vain. So it's a complete contradiction to what was prevalent in ritualism. In ritualistic practice, you have to do it correctly; if you don't do it correctly, there will be an adverse effect. Here Bhagavan said, no, no -- there is no adverse effect in this Buddhi Yoga, there is no adverse effect.

You perform your actions in this manner with equanimity of mind and you will be liberated from all your karma bandana, the bondages of actions. So now Bhagawan is criticizing the people who are using flowery language to make people confused about what is right and what is wrong. And he said Veda Vadharathaha. They take great pleasure and using the words of Vedas Na anyat asti ITI Vadhi Naham. They say there is nothing other than this, other than this, other than this Karma Kanda, other than this rituals, other than to accumulate merits and go to heaven, there is nothing else there. Completely missing the boat.

The goal of life is to achieve that oneness with yourself, understanding the self. Kamatmana Swarga Paraha. Because they're desirous of achieving Swarga. So the Swarga became the ultimate goal. They said that Veda says that Karmakand, you should be doing all these karmas. When you do, you will accumulate merits and you will go to Swarga.

So Swarga became the goal of life. Swarga Paraha Janma, Karma Falla Pradha -- which promises new birth as the renewal of their actions. You will come back again, you will have more enjoyments, and you go to Swarga again. Kriya Vishesha Bahula -- and there are all kinds of rituals. They don't have one single goal. They also do not follow one single path.

There are so many desires and so many goals. So now you can say that even though this criticism is for the Karmakanda, if you look at our lives, it is exactly that we are all Karma Kandis. We do all kinds of actions to achieve all types of different results, different accomplishments and achievements. Kriya vi says Bahula. They are engaged in too many different types of activities, too many different types of rituals. Bhoga Aishwarya gatimprati.

Because we want to achieve the Bhoga and Aishwarya -- enjoyments and power -- that became the goal of life, then and even now. We have no one single goal, and therefore we are not focused. And therefore we cannot achieve what we think is our birthright, which is happiness. Because we have lost ourselves into all these Kriyas. Bhagavan Ved Vyas criticizes those people who have preached that the goal of life is to go to heaven to elevate your standard of living. Now we have come to conclusion that no matter what status you have in the society, what achievement you have, what accomplishment you have, your problems remain the same.

Whether you are working at the lowest rank of the society or you are the highest rank of the society, basic problems which we face, which makes us unhappy, remain exactly the same. So this Bhogaira Aishwarya is not going to give us what we are ultimately looking for, which is happiness. And Bhagawan continues the criticism. Bhogeswarya prasaktanaam taya apruta cheta sam. Their intellect is taken away. They have lost their rational intellect -- the ability to discern what will give them happiness.

Because they are Bhoga Aishwarya Prasaktana -- engaged in enjoyment and power. This fixation with enjoyment and power, with raising the standard of your living, has made us lose the goal of life: that we want to be happy. It is pure and simple. Vyavasayatmika Buddhi Samadhau Na Vidhiyati. Those who are engaged in this variety of activities to achieve varieties of goals cannot have the single-pointed mind, the single-pointed intellect, to achieve their oneness with self.

That oneness with yourself is the only means to achieve happiness. The conclusion of Vedanta so Bhagavan Ved Vyas who wrote the Brahma Sutra as Rishi Badaraya, crystallized this knowledge of Upanishad, saying that the goal of life is to achieve the oneness with your true self. Once you realize your true self, all that which you're seeking, all your life will be yours. Peace and happiness will be your birthright. So we had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And so far we have seen that Bhagavan gave us the knowledge of the Sankhya which is teaching us that this self is immortal, this body is mortal.

At the death of the body, this ego continues its journey, taking along with it the mind and intellect and its tendencies. Based on those tendencies, that ego will continue to exist in various states of existence which we call Janma. Knowing this, that the self is only immortal. If your goal is to have infinite happiness, your goal should be to identify with the self and not with the ego. And to do that is to live your life now with that clear understanding that I am the manifestation, the supreme self, and not the ego, which is identified with this body, mind and intellect, and that way of thinking and acting. Accordingly, he called it Buddha Yoga.

That's a Buddha Intelligent living, as we call it, knowing fully well what is my goal and how to achieve it, then I put it into practice is the intelligent way of living. So that's called Buddhi Yoga. Keeping in mind, my goal is happiness and nothing other than happiness. Whatever gives me happiness, I will do it. But on our way, we have taken the means for the goal, therefore the means to get happiness, which is to acquire things, to accomplish things. We consider now that to be our goal.

That's where the problem is. Then he said, why this happens because we have taken the wrong advice from the wrong people. So he criticizes the pundits who had been propagating the words of Vedas. And he said that they use this flowery language and promise all the pleasures and all the lordship here and hereafter. What we call it is Swargalok, that you do this and you will achieve this. So we have this, you know, basically quit for whatever the word is quit for Kuro, type of an arrangement where you do this and you will get this.

And he said they use this language which is so enchanting to you that you get caught up in that.
snippets.reflection:
These verses continue the critique of those who pursue religious practices for worldly ends. Verse 43 describes those who "construct their own heaven, devising arduous and complex rites to secure their own pleasure and their own power; and the only result is rebirth." Their religious activity is driven by desire (Kama) for enjoyment (Bhoga) and power (Aishwarya) - essentially using spiritual means for material ends.

Verse 44 explains why this approach fails: "While their minds are absorbed with ideas of power and personal enjoyment, they cannot concentrate their discrimination on one point." A mind scattered across many desires cannot achieve the single-pointed focus needed for Self-realization. Then verse 45 gives the solution: "Rise above all of them, O Arjuna, above all the pairs of opposing sensations; be steady in truth, free from worldly anxieties and centered in the Self." The three Gunas (Sattva, Rajas, Tamas) and the pairs of opposites (pleasure-pain, gain-loss) must be transcended.

Reflect honestly: Are your spiritual practices aimed at genuine transformation, or are they subtly seeking worldly benefits - health, prosperity, success, recognition? There is nothing wrong with these things, but if they become the goal of spiritual practice, we miss the point entirely. The teaching also applies beyond religion: whenever we pursue multiple goals simultaneously, pulled by various desires, we lack the focus to achieve what truly matters. Today, examine what you are really seeking through your activities. Can you identify one overarching purpose that would give meaning to everything else?

snippets.title: Day 32: Beyond the Vedas
snippets.sanskrit:
यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः सम्प्लुतोदके |

कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन |

योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय |
snippets.transliteration:
yāvānartha udapāne sarvataḥ samplutodake .

karmaṇyevādhikāraste mā phaleṣu kadācana .

yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā dhanañjaya .
verseTranslations: As a man can drink water from any side of a full tank, so the skilled theologian can wrest from any scripture that which will serve his purpose.
But thou hast only the right to work, but none to the fruit thereof. Let not then the fruit of thy action be thy motive; nor yet be thou enamored of inaction.
Perform all thy actions with mind concentrated on the Divine, renouncing attachment and looking upon success and failure with an equal eye. Spirituality implies equanimity.
snippets.commentary:
We are now discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen that Bhagavan gave the knowledge of Sankhya. The Sankhya Darshan is Gina Darshan. It takes us step by step what the reality is. From verse 11 through 30 he gave us this Tankhya Darshan, the Gnana Darshan. Then he said that now I'll teach you the Buddhi Yoga which is the application in your life, how to overcome the Prakruti.

So Sankhya Darshan says that Purusha and Prakruti are two separate entities. When Purusha gets involved with Prakruti, then all these problems start. The five kleshas start -- ragadvesha, etc. So Yoga Shastra says how to overcome this entanglement with Prakriti. That Yoga Shastra, Bhagavan says, I will now teach you. But Bhagavan coined a new word: Buddhi Yoga -- Yoga which is established in wisdom.

So Bhagawan is basically now teaching Arjuna the Yoga Sastra in a very simple format that we all can understand. Arjun, I can understand. We all can understand. We have touched upon a landmark verse in Bhagavad Gita -- verse 47 -- which is the most quoted verse in Bhagavad Gita. Most people quote this verse but only quote the first half of it.

You will hardly ever hear anybody quoting the entire verse. So the first line everybody is very familiar which says Karmanye vadhikarathe ma faleshu kadaa. And we quote that as if that's the instruction in reality, that is the statement of fact. The first line in that verse is statement of fact that you have only control over your actions, you do not have control over the fruits of actions. That's a statement of fact. All of us who can think about it will agree with that, that I can act or the results will come.

I'm not the Karma Falada. Somebody else is either the world Bhagavan whoever you consider, but that's not you. But you do have control over actions. The second line is actually the prescription. The second line is the advice which says Maa karma fala hai turbuhu. Never engage in any action with the expectations of the results.

It's advice for us to be wise about how we act. You will never be able to guess what the results will be. You will never have control over them. There is no reason for you to invest your energy into it. Most of our energies are wasted in regrets of the past or in anxieties of the future, and then we have less enthusiasm in the present.

So Bhagavan said, therefore, therefore, never engage in action with a result in your mind. And then the last portion of that verse is mate Sangahatu akarmani. And never get attached to inaction by fear of failure or not having any clear direction. You do not want to get engaged in inaction. Instead it become tamasic. So basically the advice Bhagavan has given is very clear.

Engage in action without any expectations. Many commentators said this is where you change from prayers to shrayas. So all Kamya karmas are for prayers. That which is going to be pleasant for me. Those actions which are not driven by the expectation of the fruits will lead you to Shreyas. Because you will be only focusing on the action itself.

So Bhagavan has given a clear direction and clear statement of the reality we live in. And now in the following verse, Bhagavan clearly demonstrate how one can engage in this activity. Yogastha Kuru Karmani. Establish yourself in yoga. How to practice this Gnana Darshan, this knowledge of the true self. As I said, there are two entities for Sankhya.

Purusha who is always pure. Chaitanya but inactive. Prakruti which is inert but active. Prakriti does not have the consciousness but it is very active. And Purusha which is pure consciousness but inactive. When these two get entangled with each other, then the confusion starts.

Maharishi Patanjali's Yoga Sutra said that Yoga Chitta Vritti Nirodha -- Yoga is to stop the modifications of your Chitta. The Chitta is like a mirror; it reflects the pure consciousness. But there are Chitta Vrittis -- modifications which create this confusion. Basically the functions of Chitta in our day-to-day life include: Pramana (right knowledge), Viparyaya (contrary knowledge, wrong knowledge), Vikalpa (doubt), Nidra (sleep or Tamas), and then Smriti (memory).

These five modifications of Chitta create flickering in our Chitta. They do not let the consciousness reflect purely. Once these Vrittis are negated, the Purusha is reflected through the Chitta in its pure form -- that is basically what the Yoga Shastra says. But this is very complicated for an average person to understand. So Bhagavan is now clarifying this in very simple terms which you and I can understand and try to practice. Yogastha Kuru Karmani: you have to establish yourself in yoga, then act outside.

If you are not established in yoga then actions will be haphazard. They will be driven by the results. Then obviously there will be all the side effects which come along with it. Sangam tyaktva Dhananjaya Swamiji points out this is the most important part of this verse and most people leave that out. Sangam tyaksva act in this world by establishing yourself in yoga and without any attachment. So even attachment to actions themselves in is detrimental.

If I get too attached -- "I have to do this, I need to do this" -- then it will be problematic. There may not be an opportunity for those particular actions. In other words, you should perform the actions which are appropriate, necessary, and available in that environment, and not insist on the particular actions you're attached to: "I will only do this but I will not do anything else." In olden society in India, a Brahmin could only do certain work. He could not do menial work.

And I know in times where there was not enough work, people suffered because they would not say, "I will do this other work if my usual work is not available." Bhagawan said: don't get attached to actions. Whatever actions are available and appropriate, engage yourself in them. No attachment to what type of actions I'm performing -- I also have to establish myself in yoga.

Now, when an average person hears the word yoga, he gets really frightened. "You want me to become a yogi?" He will say, "Oh no, no, I don't want to become a yogi."

I have my own life to live. I want to say: no, no, that's not what Yoga is all about. Yoga is something different. So what Maharishi Patanjali says as Chitta Vritti Nirodhaha, Bhagavan puts in a very different way which is very palatable to us. He said: Siddhi Asiddhi Samo Bhatva -- become even-minded to success and failure. Once again, going back to the previous verse, success and failure come from past actions.

The success and failures which I am experiencing now are actually results of my past actions. I have no control whatsoever on them anymore. I should have gone to medical college and I would have been a doctor and made more money and I'd be considered a frontline worker right now. I cannot change that. And therefore, whatever the results I'm facing right now, whether I consider them to be success or kind of failures, I should be even minded, take them as they are without attaching my likings and dislikings. Siddhi Asiddhi Samo Bhutva Samatvam Yoga Uchate -- the very first definition in Bhagavad Gita about Yoga: Samatvam Yoga Uchate. We will see more definitions, and therefore this chapter is so important.

These next three or four verses starting from 47 are so loaded with meaning -- they compress all the wisdom of Sankhya and Yoga into these few verses -- that we have to pay a lot of attention to understand them. Bhagavan said Siddhi Asiddhi Samo Bhatva: in a sense, do not pay attention to what you are getting because of your past actions. Treat them equally, with Prasada Buddhi. Engage in your present actions. Do not let your present actions get affected by the Siddhi or Asiddhi which you are facing right now. Samatvam Yoga Uchate -- the balance of mind is Yoga. So we go back to what Maharishi Patanjali said.

Yoga Chitta Vritti Nirodha. When Chitta is agitated by all these Vrittis -- right knowledge, contrary knowledge, memories, Nidra, Tamas -- all those Vrittis are creating impurities in Chitta. That Chitta is then not available to reflect the right knowledge, the right reality of who I am.

Bhagawan said Samatvam Yoga: this balance of mind which does not get affected either by the past or by anxiety of the future, which does not lose any enthusiasm in the present or in your current actions -- that is Yoga. Once you are established in this, your actions will bear right results.

In the next verse, how to look at the situation: Durena Hi Avaram Karma Buddhi Yogat Dhananjaya. Actions which are prompted by desires are far lower than Buddhi Yoga. Bhagawan is using a very unique term -- Buddhi Yoga. Buddhi Yoga is Yoga of wisdom, an intelligent way of living, establishing yourself in Buddhi.

So again, we have discussed before that Chitta is a thinking entity. The thinking entity has several functions. We know the three functions are Manas, Buddhi, and Ahankar. The Ahankar is always constant -- the "I" feeling is always constant. When that thinking entity is in doubt, it is mind.

Sankalpa Vikalpatmaka Manah. But Nischayatmika Buddhi -- Buddhi which is decisive: "this is right, this is the truth, and this is what I should be working on." Once you establish yourself in that Buddhi, that wisdom of what is right and what is wrong, and you are not in that doubtful situation -- that is Buddhi Yoga. When Chitta is in that Nischayatmika mode, it's Buddhi. So Bhagavan said, engage yourself in Buddhi Yoga. That Buddhi Yoga is far better than Karma.

And here Karma is only Kamya Karma. Desire prompted actions. Karma Khanda, all the actions all the way up to the desire to get Swarga is all Kamya Karma. Therefore all actions perform for those results. Bhagwan said anytime. Even though they may be the highest form of actions to achieve the best possible state of living or living standard, they are far lower than Buddhi Yoga.

Buddhau Sharanam Anviccha -- take refuge in Buddhi. This also reminded me of "Buddham Sharanam Gacchami, Dhammam Sharanam Gacchami, Sangham Sharanam Gacchami." I take refuge in Buddha, in the wisdom of Buddha. Here Bhagavan says: take refuge in your own wisdom. Buddhau Sharanam Anviccha. Kripanaha Phala Hetavah -- those who are working in this world to get conducive results, or to get the fruits of their actions all the way up to reaching the heavens.

They are Kripanaha -- unfortunate misers. The translation is "wretched." Kripana means miser. A miser is always unfortunate because he never gets to enjoy his own wealth. He has all the wealth but can't enjoy it, so he's wretched. Those unfortunate people -- and that includes all of us who are working for the fruits of actions.

They are very unfortunate because they will never be able to enjoy fruits of their actions. They will always be in misery, either regretting the past or anxious about the future. They will never be living in present. They are always living in future or in past. They both are hypothetical situation. There is no past that I have experienced and there is no future that I have seen.

Anytime I experience, it is always present. Bhagavan says those people are really unfortunate misers who waste their energies into past and in future and completely ignores the present. O shantihi shri gurubyonamaha harihio. So we had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And so far we have seen that Bhagavan gave us the knowledge of the Sankhya which is teaching us that this self is immortal, this body is mortal.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 47 is the most famous verse of the Gita: "Thou hast only the right to work, but none to the fruit thereof. Let not then the fruit of thy action be thy motive; nor yet be thou enamored of inaction." This is not advice but a statement of fact: we control our actions but not their results, which depend on countless factors beyond us. The prescription follows: do not let results motivate your action, and do not use uncertainty of results as an excuse for inaction.

Verse 48 gives the positive instruction: "Perform all thy actions with mind concentrated on the Divine, renouncing attachment and looking upon success and failure with an equal eye. Spirituality implies equanimity." The definition "Samatvam Yoga Uchyate" - "Equanimity is Yoga" - transforms our understanding of spiritual practice from something done on a meditation cushion to a quality of mind maintained throughout all activity.

Today, choose one action - perhaps your work, a conversation, or a household task - and practice Karma Yoga with it. Before beginning, consciously set your intention: "I will do this to the best of my ability, as an offering, without attachment to the outcome." During the action, stay focused on the task itself rather than imagining future results. Afterward, accept whatever comes with equanimity. Notice: Does releasing attachment to results make you more or less effective? More or less peaceful? This is the laboratory where the Gita's teaching is tested.

snippets.title: Day 33: Yoga is Skill in Action
snippets.sanskrit:
दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय |

बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते |

कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः |
snippets.transliteration:
dūreṇa hyavaraṃ karma buddhiyogāddhanañjaya .

buddhiyukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte .

karmajaṃ buddhiyuktā hi phalaṃ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ .
verseTranslations: Physical action is far inferior to an intellect concentrated on the Divine. Have recourse then to Pure Intelligence. It is only the petty-minded who work for reward.
When a man attains to Pure Reason, he renounces in this world the results of good and evil alike. Cling thou to Right Action. Spirituality is the real art of living.
The sages guided by Pure Intellect renounce the fruit of action; and, freed from the chains of rebirth, they reach the highest bliss.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter two. We had been discussing verse 47 onwards, most quoted verse in Bhagavad Gita, which is Karmani Vadikarastha. Between that verse 47 and 53, Bhagavan gives us concisely and succinctly how to live life. Because those scriptures give advice about how to live your life. Sometimes Hinduism is called way of life. So from verse 47 onward, we basically have seen is what is the reality of my life?

Reality of my life is: I am a living being, a conscious being, and therefore activity is what makes me who I am. I must be active. However, I must understand that the only thing which is in my control is my actions. The result of my actions are not in my control simply because there is infinite world out there that is the field of my actions. When I act in this field of my actions, the other forces affect the result of my actions which is not in my control. So I must keep the goal very high, which gives me the directions of my actions. So the goal gives us direction.

Bhagavad Gita did not say don't have any goal. It says Karmaniyeva adhikara ste ma faleshukadachan, not the fruits of action. It did not say don't keep any goal or don't plan anything in your life, just continue so keep the goal in your mind and then work accordingly. So the goal gives me direction in which direction I should put my actions. If I'm going from here to New York, I know one thing, I have to drive northward on 95, that my goal is to go to New York. It gives me direction which way to go, so I don't drive south.

What it does not give me is what I will encounter on my way while I'm driving. I can generally predict that because I'm driving at 70 miles an hour. New York is 400 miles from here, therefore it takes me all of that, but it does not give me all the other information which affect my reaching New York. Previously we didn't have any way to predict what's going to happen on the way. So we have to rely only on our general judgment. And there was some traffic news broadcast which says what is the traffic pattern today?

Then we have now the gps. We're trying to add more and more ability to predict what is going to affect my travel. My GPS also tells me there is traffic congestion 25 miles from here and it will last for 8 miles. May delay for 15 minutes. So would you like to take a detour? Every time I try to follow my GPS agna to take detour, I'm actually more delayed than the 15 minutes that GPS predicted.

Because GPS does have some information but not all information. It had information on my main route but didn't really have all the information detour we have to take. So I figured out that I better stay on the same course which I have started and decided. Because the Karma Phala is dependent on not just one factor but many factors which we may not have control over right now or we do not have control over the Bhagavan. Therefore you should not be worried about the Karma Phala because it is not in your hand. Karma is your right, that's in your control.

Find a direction, find a goal in life. Find a direction and work accordingly. Karma Phala may not be because what's going to encounter while you're working, you will not know. And therefore he said ma karma fala hatu bahu. Therefore do not make the fruits as the motivator. We'll reach New York in six hours.

Because I'm driving at 70 miles an hour, that should not be the motivating force of my driving. My motivation is I need to reach New York and it is in north. Therefore I'm driving northward. I will deal with whatever comes in my way. If I have to take a detour, I'll take a detour. But I will reach New York.

I don't know, but I will reach there. But never get discouraged and say, oh, there is a lot of traffic today. Ma sanghatu akarmani. Do not get attached to inaction because you predict there may be a lot of obstructions on your way. So this is the prescription given to us. Have a goal, find a direction and then continue working.

Do not worry about what you will encounter. So the next verse says Siddhi asiddhi samo bhatva Yogastha kurukarman. Establish yourself in yoga and then work. I don't go to yoga classes. Panditji keeps telling me, but I keep avoiding. So now I can't do anything about it.

Yogastha kurukaraman established into a state of mind where this Siddhi Asiddhi does not affect you. I have to go to New York but right near the Ashland there's a huge traffic jam. That doesn't make me to make a U turn and come back home. Goal is to go there somehow to find a way to get over this. Therefore he said siddhi asidhi samo bhatva. Whatever comes in your way, take it equally.

This is still part of your life. So the yoga is samatvam Yoga uchade. So I should be establishing yoga. I say it's very simple. Keep your mind even in whatever situation you encounter. In other words, keep.

Keep that goal still in your mind. Don't let that obstruction in your way discourage you. Your goal is to achieve that infinite happiness. Don't get discouraged. Success and failure are part of your life because it is guaranteed that sometimes you will succeed, and most of the time you will fail. We used to track the statistics -- what is our hit rate on our proposals? For a while I did that because I was trained by my previous employers to track the hit rate.

Verse 49 declares: "Physical action is far inferior to an intellect concentrated on the Divine. Have recourse then to Pure Intelligence. It is only the petty-minded who work for reward." Working merely for results is called "inferior" not because results do not matter, but because fixation on them diminishes both our peace of mind and our effectiveness. The term "Kripanaha" (misers or wretched ones) describes those who work only for fruits - they never truly enjoy even the success they achieve because they immediately start worrying about the next goal.

Verse 50 gives another powerful definition: "Spirituality is the real art of living" (Yogah Karmasu Kaushalam - Yoga is skill in action). When the mind is equanimous and focused, actions become efficient and skillful. Think of any peak performance - an athlete in the zone, an artist in flow - the common factor is complete absorption in the action without anxious thinking about results. Verse 51 describes the fruit of this practice: "The sages... freed from the chains of rebirth, they reach the highest bliss."

Test this teaching practically: recall a time when you were fully absorbed in what you were doing, not worrying about how it would turn out. Notice the quality of that experience and the quality of your work. Now recall a time when you were anxious about results while working. How did that affect both your experience and your output? The Gita promises that skillful action naturally arises from equanimity. Today, experiment with bringing this focused, result-detached awareness to your tasks.

snippets.reflection:
Verse 52 describes a sign of progress: "When thy reason has crossed the entanglements of illusion, then shalt thou become indifferent both to the philosophies thou hast heard and to those thou mayest yet hear." At a certain stage, the seeker no longer needs to accumulate more information - they have moved from learning about truth to experiencing it directly. The teachings that once seemed so important become stepping stones now left behind.

Verse 53 describes the goal: "When the intellect, bewildered by the multiplicity of holy scripts, stands unperturbed in blissful contemplation of the Infinite, then hast thou attained Spirituality." The mind that was once confused by competing philosophies and practices becomes still and one-pointed. Then in verse 54, Arjuna asks the practical question that opens the final section of the chapter: "How can we recognise the saint who has attained Pure Intellect... how does he talk, how does he live, and how does he act?"

This question is crucial for us too. Having heard the theory, we want to know what it looks like in practice. Reflect today: Do you know anyone who embodies this teaching - someone who seems consistently peaceful regardless of circumstances, who acts with skill and dedication yet without visible anxiety about results? What qualities do you observe in them? Also ask: What would it look like if you had crossed "the entanglements of illusion"? How would your daily life be different? Let this vision inspire your practice.

snippets.title: Day 35: The Stable-Minded One
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः |

यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

duḥkheṣvanudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ .

yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehastattatprāpya śubhāśubham .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: When a man has given up the desires of his heart and is satisfied with the Self alone, be sure that he has reached the highest state.
The sage, whose mind is unruffled in suffering, whose desire is not roused by enjoyment, who is without attachment, anger or fear - take him to be one who stands at that lofty level.
