He who wherever he goes is attached to no person and to no place by ties of flesh; who accepts good and evil alike, neither welcoming the one nor shrinking from the other - take him to be one who is merged in the Infinite.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter two, Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen that this chapter is divided into four segments. In the first few verses, Arjuna says, "I am Navirsheshya. I don't know what to do. You tell me without any option what is good for me." Second, we have seen how Bhagavan responded. He said, you shouldn't be worried about anything that is happening in this world simply because what you see happening is temporary.

There's nothing in this world which is permanent, because all your experiences are the senses coming in contact with the sense objects. That which you are worried about -- yourself -- is immortal. There is no death for it, there is no birth for it. So is the case for his self, her self, my self. Therefore there is no worry about the self. Everything else is temporary.

So why worry about that? That was the knowledge part. And then he said: how to practice that? Now, just knowing that does not make your life easier. Just because I went to Gita class does not make my life easier on Monday through Friday. What you should do is act just like you were acting before -- but establish yourself in yoga.

Yoga is the equanimity of mind. When you establish your mind in equanimity, things will continue to change outside, but I will remain the same in dealing with them, whether they are conducive or inconducive. Samatvam Yoga Uchate -- equanimity of mind is Yoga. When do I know that my mind is equanimous? When you become skillful in your actions.

When your actions become crystallized and precise and efficient, you should know that you have established yourself in Yoga. Samatvam Yoga Uchate and Yoga Karmasu Kaushalam. So one is the definition, and there is actually a test. If your actions are haphazard, even though you think you are in yoga, you are not. Because a yogi's actions will be all precise and dexterous.

Many times in my life I have seen this. Swami Chinmayananda says something that seems absolutely ridiculous, that it's not going to happen. Somehow it all falls into place. When I think from my logic, it should not work at all. But for him, if he says this should happen by this time and you should do this -- it happens. Because he has the mind of a yogi who can see through how to get things done.

Mine is the mind of a Bhogi who cannot see how this can ever happen. So Bhagavan said, that's your test. Yoga Karmasu Kaushalam. When we practice something over and over and over again, we become so efficient. I used to practice music. My teacher said, keep practicing.

You will get it before you even know when you got it. You will never know the exact moment when you mastered it. But then you will know what is the Madhya Sapta, the Mantra Sapta, the Taar Sapta. Practice makes you perfect. Once you achieve that art, you don't have to make any effort. Like driving -- that's Karmasu Kaushalam. I don't have to make any effort.

I don't even think about it while driving. Because I have achieved Karmasu Kaushalam, I am established in the yoga of driving. Therefore, Bhagavan says, that's what equanimity of mind means. But we come to this conclusion very quickly that this is not possible -- this is just for yogis like Swami Chinmayananda and Buddha and Mahavir, not for us. So the question arises: okay, if that's the case, how do we know that someone is established in yoga?

So Arjuna asked the question about this Prajna which is Sthita -- whose intellect is steady. We saw the definition: Samatvam Yoga Uchate. Once one's intellect becomes steady, he becomes Sthita Prajna -- because that Prajna is not changing no matter what the outside situation is. It may be very dark in this room, but I know it is daytime. Because my prajna is sthita in the knowledge that it is daytime right now. Even if you turn off light, even if there is clouds outside and it becomes very dark, I still say it's daytime. Because I know it is daytime. Because my prajna is completely sthida in that knowledge. The knowledge which Bhagavan gave in the first section that you are not the mortal being, you are the immortal being. Your self is immortal.

Everything else is just passing experiences. Once that knowledge takes place in the intellect, no matter what happens in my life, it does not change my understanding of that fact. If that happens to somebody who establishes himself in that knowledge, what is the description of such a person? How would I know such a person? So Arjuna in verse 54 asked that question.

Sthita Prajnasya Ka Bhasha Samadhisthasya Keshava. We know Samadhistha -- one who is established in Samadhi. Sama + Dhi: Buddhi which is steady. We use this word Samadhi in a very metaphysical way, but Samadhi is simply a firm conviction that this is the reality. In one Upanishad class we were told that you are in a complete state of Samadhi right now -- of your body consciousness.

Nobody has to remind me who I am. No matter what situation changes. Outside, it is dark, it is light. If everybody's here, nobody's here. This is me that never changes. You can convince me, if you are persuasive enough that this class does not exist.

I am just hallucinating. "Neil, you need some help. You are hallucinating. You're talking to yourself." It's possible that I will believe that and will start seeking advice. But you can't convince me that I don't exist.

No matter how confused I am, you can't convince me that I don't exist. But what Bhagavan is saying is that this self is actually immortal, not this body. So therefore you shouldn't be worried about death. Your samadhi should be in this immortality. So Arjuna asks: Bhagavan, how would that person who is established in the samadhi of his immortal self behave? His intellect is so steady that no matter what happens, he never loses that connection with that Samadhi.

What is his description? To speak, Bhasa is describing. That's why the language is called Bhasha. Because we describe what we think through our speech. So what is his description of such a person? Swami Chinmayananda used to get this question all the time.

Swamiji, are you realized? Swamiji, there is a conundrum here. If I tell you that I am realized, then what would you say? He tells everybody he's realized. Now if Swamiji says I'm not realized, why am I wasting time with you? If after all this, you are not realized, what am I going to get out of you?

So there is no way to find out one is realized or not. Only another Realized person will know who this realized person is, one who is a good singer. If somebody sings, he knows he's a good singer. For us, everybody is a good singer. But one who really knows music, he knows when the other person is doing well or not. So Arjuna said, how would I know that such a person exists?

Or this can be achievable. Give me some description, give me some idea. And now all I can do is judge people by how they behave, right? I can't really go into their mind and say they are established in samadhi, but I can see from their behavior. Therefore, the second line says, sthita dihi Kim Prabhasheta Kim Asita Vrajeta Kim. This is indicative of knowing how a person with that level of establishment in Yoga will be behaving in this world.

How does he walk, how does he sit? Prabha cheta talk Kim Asita. How does he sit down and how does he walk? Basically, in indicative words, to know what would be his outward behavior. Now our problem is, once we know the outward behavior, somebody says, somebody will be sitting like this, somebody will be talking like that, somebody will be doing like that. Now we are trying to see that in a person and then basically come to the conclusion he is not.

Because he is not fitting into my description of how Sthita Pragna should be a muni. He should be sitting. So our idea of muni is sitting in Himalaya somewhere who is completely secluded from people, not interacting with people, not getting emotionally upset or emotionally charged with any situation. So we'll say, Swami Chinmayananda, I don't know. Swamiji still gets angry. And it says that Vitaraga Bhayakrodha is still angry.

The answer was, if I go to the ocean and try to see the ocean in a wave, and if I only see the characteristics of the wave, only thing I will see is the wave. Only never see the ocean in the wave, the wave its own characteristics. If I'm focusing on those characteristics, I only see wave in it. But if I see that the wave is nothing but the ocean rising and falling, I will see the ocean in it. So Arjuna wants to know, how do I know that a person like that exists? Tell me some description, give me some idea.

How will he behave in any situation? This is more like that bracelet these Christians have for the teenager, says wwjd what would Jesus do? This was, I think, a brilliant idea. Whoever came up with that, the teenagers, when they are in a dilemma, in some peer Press in school or whatever. What should I do when everybody's asking me to smoke? But my parents say you're not supposed to smoke.

He said, look at that person. WWJD what would Jesus do in this situation? How do I know what to do in a situation I'm encountering? How would a realized person would act in this situation? So the answer comes in the following verses till the end of the chapter. What a realized person will do in different situations.

Once your mind is steady, your excellence will be effortless. And then you will know in each situation how to react to that situation. Things and beings outside will continue to remain exactly as they are. As the Prakriti says, constantly changing. How would I react will change if my mind is equanimous. So that's basically the gist of this question.

So the answer is Prajahati Yada Kaman Sarvan Partha Manogatan. The first thing: who has given up all the desires? Sarvan Kaman Manogatan is the operative word -- desires born out of my mental agitations. One who gives up all the desires born out of the mind. What is our primordial desire? To be happy. I want to be comfortable and happy.

But out of this primordial desire to be happy, all other desires have come into this one. If I didn't have that desire to be happy and be okay with any situation, it looks like the guy is going to be a stone. A dead person who has no reaction to anything good or bad. It can only happen when I die. After I die, people can kick me. I'm fine, put me and throw me in a well.

I'll be fine because I'm not there. But while I'm leaving, I'll be very careful. So they say, is that person be any different than all of us? However, he will be different from you in this following manner. Prajahati Yada Kaman Sarvan Manogatan. Right now I have decided that when I fulfill all these desires, I'll be happy. A realized person does not have those desires.

That does not mean that he does not become thirsty and won't have the desire to drink water. Actually, Swami Tejomayananda and others categorize all the desires and say: these desires which you can fulfill easily, don't even bother about them. Why are you suffering? That's not the Manogatan desires we are talking about.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna's answer to "What is a Sthitaprajna (person of steady wisdom)?" begins here. Verse 55: "When a man has given up the desires of his heart and is satisfied with the Self alone, be sure that he has reached the highest state." The key phrase is "Manogatan" - desires born from the mind, meaning fabricated wants rather than genuine needs. The Sthitaprajna is "satisfied with the Self alone" - finding completeness within rather than seeking it from external accomplishments or possessions.

Verse 56 describes behavioral signs: "The sage, whose mind is unruffled in suffering, whose desire is not roused by enjoyment, who is without attachment, anger or fear - take him to be one who stands at that lofty level." This is not suppression of emotions but their natural absence when one is fulfilled within. Verse 57 adds: "He who wherever he goes is attached to no person and to no place... who accepts good and evil alike, neither welcoming the one nor shrinking from the other - take him to be one who is merged in the Infinite."

Examine your own desires today. Which are genuine needs and which are "Manogatan" - fabricated by your mind, perhaps influenced by advertising, social comparison, or habit? Notice which desires, if fulfilled, would still leave you wanting more. The Sthitaprajna has discovered that no external acquisition brings lasting satisfaction - only recognizing one's inherent completeness does. As a practice, spend time today simply being - not doing, not acquiring, not accomplishing - and notice if you can touch a sense of sufficiency in that simple presence. This is the beginning of being "satisfied with the Self alone."

snippets.title: Day 36: Withdrawing the Senses
snippets.sanskrit:
यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः |

विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः |

यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः |
snippets.transliteration:
yadā saṃharate cāyaṃ kūrmo.aṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ .

viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ .

yatato hyapi kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ .
verseTranslations: He who can withdraw his senses from the attraction of their objects, as the tortoise draws his limbs within its shell - take it that such a one has attained Perfection.
The objects of sense turn from him who is abstemious. Even the relish for them is lost in him who has seen the Truth.
O Arjuna! The mind of him, who is trying to conquer it, is forcibly carried away in spite of his efforts, by his tumultuous senses.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter two, Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. We have seen so far that in verses 47 and 48, Bhagavan has given clear instruction about how to act in this world. Bhagavan said, Karmani eva adhikaraste ma phaleshu kadachana ma karma phala hetur bhur ma te sango'stv akarmani. Your right is only to act, never for the fruits -- never work for just getting the fruits, and also never get attached to inaction. But then he gave us a very positive message about how to act in this world: Yogastha kuru karmani sangam tyaktva Dhananjaya, siddhi asiddhi samo bhutva samatvam yoga uchyate.

Very clear instruction: establish yourself in yoga. And then he defined yoga for us -- Samatvam Yoga Uchate, the balance of mind is yoga. You establish yourself in that state of mind where it is balanced. And then Sangam tyaktva, without any attachment, you act in this world. Siddhi asidhi samo bhatva be equal to success and failure. That is the total instruction for Karma Yoga.

If we remember just these two verses, then we have learned the entire message of Bhagavad Gita. Then people like us will say, "Is that really all? Is this a watered-down version Bhagavan is giving me?" And Arjuna probably felt the same way. So he uses two very familiar terms in the discussion of yoga -- terms Arjuna probably learned during his time at the Gurukul: Prajna and Samadhi. These two terms are elaborately described in Yoga Sutra. He uses those words in asking his questions.

You see, if that is the case -- if just balancing the mind is yoga -- then what are all these discussions about yogis who spend their lifetime practicing yoga? In Ashtanga Yoga, Samadhi comes at the final stage after years of practice. So he wanted to know: are we talking about the same yoga? So he asked Bhagavan: Sthita pragnasya ka bhasha samadhisthasya Keshava, sthita dhi kim prabhaseta kim asita vrajeta kim. In other words, he said, "Okay, if that's the case, can you please explain to me what is the description of Sthita Prajna?"

Prajna means Consciousness. So Aitareya Upanishad says Prajnanam Brahma. We learned this in the four Mahavakyas -- this is the first Mahavakya. Consciousness is Brahman. Prajna is pure consciousness. One who is established in that is the Sthita Prajna.

One who is clearly identifying with the consciousness and not identifying with this BMI (Body, Mind, Intellect) is the Sthita Prajna. Arjuna says: if that is the case, can you please explain to me what is the description of that Sthita Prajna who is established in pure consciousness? And how is he Samadhisthasya -- established in Samadhi, constantly in the state of Samadhi? Samadhi is effortless awareness. Right now, we have effortless awareness about our own self as this limited being -- no effort is required for me to recognize "this is me."

For that Sthita Prajna Yogi, no effort is required to realize that he is pure consciousness. Sthita Prajna who is established in Samadhi who recognizes that his self is nothing but consciousness. Describe to me that person. Is it same as what you described as Samatam Yoga? Uchad Sthita Dhi Kim Prabhasyeta Asyata Vrajeta.

And what will be his behavior? Will he be different than what you and I see everybody else doing? So he wanted to clarify that we are talking about the same state of Sthita Prajna achieving through this Karma Yoga. This yoga which Bhagavan said is as simple as: continue doing what you are doing, but change your attitude -- you are not doing it for the fruits, but because it ought to be done. And then whatever the results come, accept them as Prasad. I will accept them whether success or failure, without having any judgment of my own.

So Bhagavan responded, the next verse which we have seen is verse 55. Bhagawan simply says Prajahati yada kaman Sarvan Parthumanogadan. One who gives up all the desires from the mind. In other words, he empties the mind. Atmaniyeva atmane tusta. One who is satisfied in the self by the self is Sthita Prajna.

It is as simple as that. One who has no desires, one who has completely emptied his mind, is a Sthita Prajna. So Bhagavan responded to Arjuna's question and described the Sthita Prajna. Very simple: one who has completely emptied his mind and is content, satisfied by the self in the self, is a Sthita Prajna -- which is not different from what Yoga Sutra describes as Yoga Chitta Vritti Nirodha. Yoga is the cessation of activities in Chitta.

This agitation in Chitta. As we have seen, Chitta is basically the total sum of mind, intellect, and Ahankar. When mind is not functioning with desires, intellect is not judging, and there is no sense of "I the doer," then there is no Chitta Vritti. In the same way, Bhagawan said that when you empty your mind completely of all desires, then you become Sthita Prajna. The next question Arjuna had was then explain to me how will he behave in this world?

Bhagavan said Duhkheshu Anudvigna Manah -- he will not be agitated by Dukkha. His mind will not agitate when Dukkha comes, because he already anticipated that living in this world, Dukkha is bound to come. As Bhagavan Buddha figured out: Dukkha exists -- that's his first noble truth. Second, there's a cause for Dukkha, and if you remove the cause, Dukkha goes. So the Sthita Prajna, knowing this reality, remains undisturbed -- Duhkheshu Anudvigna Manah.

His mind doesn't agitate with Dukkha because it is something natural in this world. Sukesu vigathas pruhaha. When he encounters a conducive situation, he does not create more desires to experience that again and again and again, which is a typical case in our situation. Something which you like, you want to keep repeating it. Something which you don't like, we want to avoid it. Vitaraga Bhayakrodha when he becomes without any attachment, fear and anger.

So Bhagavan in these two verses already described what Arjuna asked for what is the description? Sthita Pragna is one without any desires in his mind. This is Sthita Pragna that simple. And secondly, how will he behave in this world? Well, he will behave very differently than a common man will behave. Common man gets agitated when Dukkha comes and gets all attached to Sukkah.

Contrary that this Muni will not be agitated by Dukkha and he will not long for this Sukkah to keep coming over and over again because he knows that that's not reality. It does not happen that way in this world. The remaining verses in chapter two basically elaborate on his answer. So Bhagavan is now elaborating on the description of Sthita pragna. Yaha Sarvatra Anabhis Neha Tattat prapya subu Asubham. So first thing he said.

Ya Sarvatra Anabhi Snaha. He is everywhere without Sneha. He avoids Sneha everywhere. Well, this doesn't sound good to us. Sneha is something we live for in our vernacular language. This word is very, very pleasant.

In Dear, Sneha is in olden days. I remember when I was a little kid. The letter writing was the only means of communication. We'll start with Bhai Rajesh, Tatha Anya Snehi Jana in Gujarati, Brother Rajesh and all others. All the people I'm attached to in the family Richmond Ni Yad from Richmond Nilkanti is remembering you all because I'm attached to you. So Snehi Jan I have attachment to.

Bhagavan says he is Yaha Sarvatra Anabisneha. He is not attached to anyone. So it's not a negative connotation. What it really means is he is equal to all. There is no partiality that I like this person. But I don't like that person.

I mean indifferent to that, to that thing and attached to this thing. When I'm attached to everything then there is no differentiation between one or the other. I am attached to all limbs in my body. So it's not that I am attached to my right hand more than my left hand. Therefore he said Yasarvatra Anabhis Nehah. There is no partiality.

Bhagavan is equal to all because Bhagavan knows that this is just Me everywhere. In the same way, the Muni who is established in pure consciousness knows that there is no other reality than consciousness alone. Consciousness is Brahman. That Brahman is all-pervading, and the basis for all things and beings is consciousness. If I am that consciousness, there is no reason for me to get attached to one thing over another. Then Subham and Asubham will keep coming from Prakriti. It will go on as Prakriti is designed. So Subha and Asubha comes. When Subha comes, he does not congratulate himself. Again we have a problem here. Well, this is what we leave for we want congratulations. When something good happens, does this mean that I will not congratulate my son or a grandson or granddaughter who graduates from high school or college and celebrate? He does not go himself.

See, we typically congratulate ourselves when we succeed in something. Something good happens to us. I did this just before the great crash. I sold all my equity. We congratulate ourselves. Muni never congratulates himself.

Tat prapya subham na abhinandati. When Subham comes, he does not congratulate himself and say, good job, Neel. He knows that everything is possible because this consciousness is functioning through me and this world is functioning as per the laws of nature. And laws of nature include law of karma. I had done something good. Something good came to me.

When Asubham comes, he does not hate himself. Our problem is either we like ourselves or we hate ourselves. It's not congratulating others to encourage our children, encourage our friends, encourage our relatives when they succeed. It is not that we tell them not to do something which is going to hurt them. They don't going to embrace things which are going to hurt. Don't go into a mass rally to get coronavirus infection.

I don't hate coronavirus. That's not the intent. Intention here is to say when I continue to congratulate myself when I succeed and I hate myself when I fail, that has to stop. If my mind is empty, then this will not happen. Tashya prajna pratishtita. Such a person is established in consciousness.

Prajna, as we have seen, is pure. Consciousness is prajna. The higher form of awareness is prajna. This is another way of looking at it. That that person will be always happy in whatever is happening. Neither he is congratulating himself nor is he hating himself.

Success and failures come because of my past actions. I may have made mistakes. I may have done something good. Things are going to keep happening. Yada samharte kurmu angani iwas sarvasah. He lives a very intelligent life.

He does not put himself in danger, just as a tortoise detects danger and withdraws all its limbs under its shell to protect itself. He does not make himself vulnerable to perceived threats. When a Muni perceives there is a threat of getting attached to sense objects, he withdraws his senses. If something has a likelihood of getting me attached, I withdraw my senses from that. So there is no real reason for us to challenge ourselves and say, "Let me see if even in that adverse situation I can maintain my composure."

So instead of meditating in my room where I have established myself, I'm going to go and meditate in a bar? Even though everybody is enjoying themselves, but I'll be meditating? Well, that's not a very smart way to live. Bhagavan said: the one who lives an intelligent life avoids things which are dangerous -- dangerous to my state of mind, which will agitate my mind. I may get attached, then I will have fear, and then I will have anger.

I would rather not get into that situation.
snippets.reflection:
The famous tortoise analogy appears in verse 58: "He who can withdraw his senses from the attraction of their objects, as the tortoise draws his limbs within its shell - take it that such a one has attained Perfection." The tortoise does not destroy its limbs; it simply withdraws them when needed for protection. Similarly, the wise person does not eliminate the senses but learns to withdraw them from potentially harmful engagements.

Verse 59 distinguishes mere abstinence from true transcendence: "The objects of sense turn from him who is abstemious. Even the relish for them is lost in him who has seen the Truth." Willpower-based abstinence leaves the desire intact; true wisdom removes even the craving. And verse 60 offers a realistic warning: "The mind of him, who is trying to conquer it, is forcibly carried away in spite of his efforts, by his tumultuous senses." Even sincere seekers find their senses overpowering at times.

Practice sense-withdrawal today in small ways. When you feel the pull to check your phone, eat when not hungry, or engage in some habitual indulgence, pause and "withdraw your limbs" - simply choose not to act on the impulse and observe what happens. Notice: Does the urge intensify and then pass? Can you be comfortable with the sensation of wanting without fulfilling it? This builds the muscle of pratyahara (sense-withdrawal). Also observe if some desires have naturally fallen away in your life - things that once seemed essential but no longer interest you. This is the "relish being lost" that comes from growth.

snippets.title: Day 37: Mastery of Senses
snippets.sanskrit:
तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः |

ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते |

क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः |
snippets.transliteration:
tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yukta āsīta matparaḥ .

dhyāyato viṣayānpuṃsaḥ saṅgasteṣūpajāyate .

krodhādbhavati sammohaḥ sammohātsmṛtivibhramaḥ .
verseTranslations: Restraining them all, let him meditate steadfastly on Me; for who thus conquers his senses achieves perfection.
When a man dwells on the objects of sense, he creates an attraction for them; attraction develops into desire, and desire breeds anger.
Anger induces delusion; delusion, loss of memory; through loss of memory, reason is shattered; and loss of reason leads to destruction.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. As we have seen, this chapter is in four parts and we are in the last part which describes the characteristics of a man of wisdom, a perfect person who has learned how to live in this life intelligently. This segment is called Sthita Prajna Lakshana -- basically a virtual role model created for us by Bhagavan Krishna, showing what a perfect person should be, how he acts in this world, and how he conducts himself. Bhagavan gave a very succinct definition of a Sthita Prajna.

The one who has emptied his mind of all desires, one who feels complete, he does not feel incomplete and therefore he does not have to acquire anything or accomplish anything to feel complete. So the person who has emptied his mind of all desires, he becomes Vita Raga Bhayakroda. He becomes devoid of any attachment, fear or anger. So that's basically a simple definition of a man of perfect wisdom, that he has no desire, he feels complete, he has no attachment, and therefore he has no fear and no anger. And then Bhagawan also described that what is that steady wisdom? What is that steady Buddhist which can make person achieve this state of having no attachment, fear and anger.

And he said that one who does not get affected by any happening, whether conducive or unconducive -- he does not get agitated by unconducive happenings, and he also does not get carried away by conducive happenings. Conducive experiences do not create longing in him, and unconducive experiences do not create any grief or agitation in his mind. So this is basically a state of constant enthusiasm. He's constantly enthusiastic about living his life in a perfect state of mind.

Reminds me of my last boss, basically when I left my last office and started NBG architecture. He was a unique person, full of energy. Anytime I'll go to him and say, dan, we have a new project. He'll get excited, tell me what to do. He'll be always encouraging. But the unique thing was When I go to him and tell him that Dan, you know, we have a problem in this project.

And somebody's going to file a claim against us for errors and omniscience. Some of the things which we always dread to go to your boss and tell him because he will be disappointed. How can you do this, Neil? On the contrary, Dan will be all enthusiastic. Okay, if that's the case, let's do this. Call such and such person.

Let's make sure we do this enthusiasm in both cases I found very unique. He will not get upset because we have now a potential claim against us. But he will get all excited and say let's make sure that we are prepared to deal with it. I will never forget that. And it's now 20 years since I left the job. He now became the head of the entire organization which has 2100 people.

That shows what a person who can maintain his enthusiasm in all situations can achieve. In my own life, I've seen people achieving that. For one said that such a person, his intellect is steady. He does not get affected. His enthusiasm for acting in this world is not affected by the experience he is experiencing. So number one defined a role model.

A man of perfect wisdom. So we come to the conclusion if we achieve that state, we got it made. We don't have to do anything after that. Bhagavan said, no, you have to be very careful. So then Bhagavan gives us a warning that be aware that your senses are very powerful. Indriyani Pramatini, Harati Prasabham Manaha.

It can take away the tranquility of mind. Because the very nature of senses is to go out and get impressions of all the objects. So what we know about objects is not really the actual nature of the object but what we have perceived about that object. That is the nature of senses. Those perceptions created on my mind. If my mind is not careful or it's not under the control of my intellect.

Then it will get carried away again. And then it will lose its tranquility. So Bhagavan said, be careful. Therefore, a man of perfect wisdom moves around in this world like a tortoise that whenever it senses danger, withdraws all its limbs. So the man of perfect wisdom does not give up this world of plurality. He has to live in this world, but he lives with his senses under control of his mind. The mind is under the control of the intellect, and the senses are under the control of the mind. That is basically the state of perfect wisdom, as Bhagavan describes it. So he moves around in that fashion. That is what we have seen in the last two verses. And it says everything starts from constant contemplation on sense objects -- Dhyayato Visayan Pumsah. That is the root cause of all my troubles.

When I constantly think about something, it becomes my nature. And once I attach myself to the world of finite objects, I'm going to assign my happiness to that object. I have now mortgaged my happiness to the world of objects. And therefore now I have to acquire them, because my happiness is mortgaged with them. Bhagawan said that is the ladder of fall. It starts with thinking about something, which creates attachment.

That attachment creates desires. The desires unfortunately creates anger. Anger created delusion. That delusion created loss of intellect. And loss of intellect gets you destroyed. So this is the fall which we have seen.

So that means I have to work with the root cause of my problem is Bhagavan Buddha in his Arya Satya. He says, the first Sathya is that Dukkha exists. There is Dukkha in this world. The second one is that there is a cause for Dukkha. And what is the cause for Dukkha? Desire is the cause for all Dukkha.

So Bhagavan says the same thing here. Dhyayato visayan pumsah -- contemplating sense objects is the cause for all the problems. So how do I live in this world? The next three verses describe how to avoid this danger, how to avoid falling from this ladder of fall.

It says Raga Dvesha Viyuktaihi Tu Visayan Indriyaih Charan Atma Vashyaih Vidheyatma Prasadam Adhigacchati. So, countering that tendency of thinking about objects and then getting attached to them and falling into that trap, he said: the man of wisdom has now realized, as we discussed last time, that attachment is a mental phenomenon. Because my mind gets impressions from the world of objects, it gets attached. Detachment, on the other hand, is a very intellectual pursuit. Knowing fully well that this attachment is going to create sorrows for me, I try to detach myself from those attachments. How do I detach myself?

Bhagavan says Raga Dvesha Viyuktaihi -- one who is devoid of likes and dislikes. Bhagavan has given us a pointer on how to become that. He said Tani Sarvani Samyamya Yukta Asita Matparaha. In verse 61 he said: here is the key. You will not be able to control your senses unless you have a higher goal. Turn your mind towards the higher goal. If that higher goal is engaging your mind, then the impressions coming from this world are not going to disturb it. When we are engrossed in doing something we are not aware of what's happening around us. Yukta, Asita, Matparaha. Have me in your mind all the time. Now that again sounds really ridiculous. Goal to have that my mind is always focused on Bhagavan.

Therefore I cannot think of anything else. No -- actually, once you realize that, then nothing exists other than Me. Everything you see, you should see Me. Once I see all the objects are nothing but manifestations of the God. The impression of that object on my mind will be more divine than a finite image of that object. If you start seeing me in all things and beings then you will be able to control your mind.

If I see Bhagavan, the supreme being, in all things and beings, then the question of likes and dislikes really does not come. I cannot have one part of Bhagavan I don't like and another part of Bhagavan I like. That's truly not possible. We like everything about that being. Even his shortcomings -- we enjoy his shortcomings.

But a person we don't like -- even his good qualities we don't enjoy. So once we identify with that supreme self, all his manifestations we will enjoy them all as they are. Because we will not have any judgment about an individual manifestation. So Bhagavan says Sachapa Raga, Dwese Viuktahi. Person who has become devoid of likes and dislikes.

Visayan Indre Charan. He moves around in this world of objects. Because there is no escape from this world of objects. We are part of this world and we have to live in this world. What do we want to achieve? We have to achieve within this world.

But how we act in this world is up to us. So I said one who is devoid of likes and dislikes. He is moving around with Atma Vashyahi, Vidhey Atma. He is self restrained. He is not getting carried away by one experience or the another. Vidheyatma, his self control.

Prasadam Adhigacchati. He achieves that final result. And as we have discussed Prasad many times before, we are used to the word Prasad -- after every puja we have Prasad. That Prasad is always sweet, because it represents the fruits of all my good actions, sweet results. Here the result is tranquility of mind -- the mind is not getting any impression which is negative.

No matter what impression comes from outside, the mind sees a divine impression, and therefore it is in a state of tranquility. That is the Prasad -- that's the final reward. Then nothing can upset my mind. Bhagavan said such a person achieves Prasadam -- that final tranquility of mind that no experience can disturb.

So Bhagawan says: get out of likes and dislikes, see Me in everything, and then your mind will be constantly focused on Me. Prasade Sarva Dukkhanam Haanih Asya Upajayate -- this is where we started. I want to learn Bhagavad Gita because I need to get rid of all my Dukkhas.

I want to get Bhagavan's Kripa because I want to get rid of all my sorrows and unhappiness. Bhagavan says there is a way to do it, and it is not My doing -- it is your doing. You have to do it yourself. When you control your mind, when you get out of likes and dislikes, then you will get the Prasad of your own actions -- the tranquility of mind. That tranquility of mind actually removes the cause for all your sorrows. Bhagavan Buddha said there is Dukkha, and there is a cause for Dukkha. All you have to do is remove the cause, and then you achieve that Kaivalyam. Prasade Sarva Dukkhanam -- by this Prasad, all Dukkhas get destroyed.

Prasanna Chetasah Ashu Buddhih Paryavatishthate -- and for the one who is of tranquil mind, Chitta becomes Ekagra (one-pointed). As we have discussed, Chitta is a mirror which is reflecting all the impressions from outside. When all these impressions are divinized by my focusing on the divine self who created this cosmos out of his own self, the Chitta reflects nothing but the definitive reality.

As we have discussed before in this logic of causation: if this world exists, there must be a Creator. The Creator needs to have two causes -- efficient cause and material cause. He is the efficient cause because he knew how to create this world, but he also needed material, and the material is nothing but his own self.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 61 gives the positive practice: "Restraining them all, let him meditate steadfastly on Me; for who thus conquers his senses achieves perfection." The key is "Matparaha" - having a higher focus. Senses cannot be controlled merely through suppression; they need a superior attraction to draw them away from lesser objects. Focusing on the Divine provides this superior attraction.

Verses 62-63 present the famous "ladder of fall" - the progression from contemplation of sense objects to complete destruction: "When a man dwells on the objects of sense, he creates an attraction for them; attraction develops into desire, and desire breeds anger. Anger induces delusion; delusion, loss of memory; through loss of memory, reason is shattered; and loss of reason leads to destruction." Each step follows inevitably from the previous: thinking leads to attachment, attachment to desire, unfulfilled desire to anger, anger to confusion, confusion to forgetting what is truly important, and this to the destruction of discrimination itself.

Trace this progression in your own experience. Think of a time when you became irrationally angry. Can you trace it back through desire and attachment to repeated contemplation of some object or outcome? Notice how anger clouds judgment and makes you forget your values and priorities. The teaching is clear: the problem starts with where you place your attention. Today, notice what you spend your mental energy contemplating. Is it building desire and potential frustration? Or is it supporting peace and wisdom? Attention is the beginning of the chain - guard it well.

snippets.title: Day 38: Peace Through Discipline
snippets.sanskrit:
रागद्वेषविमुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् | (or वियुक्तैस्तु)

प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते |

नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना |
snippets.transliteration:
rāgadveṣavimuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran .

prasāde sarvaduḥkhānāṃ hānirasyopajāyate .

nāsti buddhirayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā .
verseTranslations: But the self-controlled soul, who moves amongst sense objects, free from either attachment or repulsion, he wins eternal Peace.
Having attained Peace, he becomes free from misery; for when the mind gains peace, right discrimination follows.

Right discrimination is not for him who cannot concentrate. Without concentration, there cannot be meditation; he who cannot meditate must not expect peace; and without peace, how can anyone expect happiness?
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. As we have seen, this chapter is in four parts and we are in the last part which describes the characteristics of a man of wisdom, a perfect person who has learned how to live in this life intelligently. This segment is called Sthita Prajna Lakshana -- basically a virtual role model created for us by Bhagavan Krishna, showing what a perfect person should be, how he acts in this world, and how he conducts himself. Bhagavan gave a very succinct definition of a Sthita Prajna.

The one who has emptied his mind of all desires, one who feels complete, he does not feel incomplete and therefore he does not have to acquire anything or accomplish anything to feel complete. So the person who has emptied his mind of all desires, he becomes Vita Raga Bhayakroda. He becomes devoid of any attachment, fear or anger. So that's basically a simple definition of a man of perfect wisdom, that he has no desire, he feels complete, he has no attachment, and therefore he has no fear and no anger. And then Bhagawan also described that what is that steady wisdom? What is that steady Buddhist which can make person achieve this state of having no attachment, fear and anger.

And he said that one who does not get affected by any happening, whether conducive or unconducive -- he does not get agitated by unconducive happenings, and he also does not get carried away by conducive happenings. Conducive experiences do not create longing in him, and unconducive experiences do not create any grief or agitation in his mind. So this is basically a state of constant enthusiasm. He's constantly enthusiastic about living his life in a perfect state of mind.

Reminds me of my last boss, basically when I left my last office and started NBG architecture. He was a unique person, full of energy. Anytime I'll go to him and say, dan, we have a new project. He'll get excited, tell me what to do. He'll be always encouraging. But the unique thing was When I go to him and tell him that Dan, you know, we have a problem in this project.

And somebody's going to file a claim against us for errors and omniscience. Some of the things which we always dread to go to your boss and tell him because he will be disappointed. How can you do this, Neil? On the contrary, Dan will be all enthusiastic. Okay, if that's the case, let's do this. Call such and such person.

Let's make sure we do this enthusiasm in both cases I found very unique. He will not get upset because we have now a potential claim against us. But he will get all excited and say let's make sure that we are prepared to deal with it. I will never forget that. And it's now 20 years since I left the job. He now became the head of the entire organization which has 2100 people.

That shows what a person who can maintain his enthusiasm in all situations can achieve. In my own life, I've seen people achieving that. For one said that such a person, his intellect is steady. He does not get affected. His enthusiasm for acting in this world is not affected by the experience he is experiencing. So number one defined a role model.

A man of perfect wisdom. So we come to the conclusion if we achieve that state, we got it made. We don't have to do anything after that. Bhagavan said, no, you have to be very careful. So then Bhagavan gives us a warning that be aware that your senses are very powerful. Indriyani Pramatini, Harati Prasabham Manaha.

It can take away the tranquility of mind. Because the very nature of senses is to go out and get impressions of all the objects. So what we know about objects is not really the actual nature of the object but what we have perceived about that object. That is the nature of senses. Those perceptions created on my mind. If my mind is not careful or it's not under the control of my intellect.

Then it will get carried away again. And then it will lose its tranquility. So Bhagavan said, be careful. Therefore, a man of perfect wisdom moves around in this world like a tortoise that whenever it senses danger, withdraws all its limbs. So the man of perfect wisdom does not give up this world of plurality. He has to live in this world, but he lives with his senses under control of his mind. The mind is under the control of the intellect, and the senses are under the control of the mind. That is basically the state of perfect wisdom, as Bhagavan describes it. So he moves around in that fashion. That is what we have seen in the last two verses. And it says everything starts from constant contemplation on sense objects -- Dhyayato Visayan Pumsah. That is the root cause of all my troubles.

When I constantly think about something, it becomes my nature. And once I attach myself to the world of finite objects, I'm going to assign my happiness to that object. I have now mortgaged my happiness to the world of objects. And therefore now I have to acquire them, because my happiness is mortgaged with them. Bhagawan said that is the ladder of fall. It starts with thinking about something, which creates attachment.

That attachment creates desires. The desires unfortunately creates anger. Anger created delusion. That delusion created loss of intellect. And loss of intellect gets you destroyed. So this is the fall which we have seen.

So that means I have to work with the root cause of my problem is Bhagavan Buddha in his Arya Satya. He says, the first Sathya is that Dukkha exists. There is Dukkha in this world. The second one is that there is a cause for Dukkha. And what is the cause for Dukkha? Desire is the cause for all Dukkha.

So Bhagavan says the same thing here. Dhyayato visayan pumsah -- contemplating sense objects is the cause for all the problems. So how do I live in this world? The next three verses describe how to avoid this danger, how to avoid falling from this ladder of fall.

It says Raga Dvesha Viyuktaihi Tu Visayan Indriyaih Charan Atma Vashyaih Vidheyatma Prasadam Adhigacchati. So, countering that tendency of thinking about objects and then getting attached to them and falling into that trap, he said: the man of wisdom has now realized, as we discussed last time, that attachment is a mental phenomenon. Because my mind gets impressions from the world of objects, it gets attached. Detachment, on the other hand, is a very intellectual pursuit. Knowing fully well that this attachment is going to create sorrows for me, I try to detach myself from those attachments. How do I detach myself?

Bhagavan says Raga Dvesha Viyuktaihi -- one who is devoid of likes and dislikes. Bhagavan has given us a pointer on how to become that. He said Tani Sarvani Samyamya Yukta Asita Matparaha. In verse 61 he said: here is the key. You will not be able to control your senses unless you have a higher goal. Turn your mind towards the higher goal. If that higher goal is engaging your mind, then the impressions coming from this world are not going to disturb it. When we are engrossed in doing something we are not aware of what's happening around us. Yukta, Asita, Matparaha. Have me in your mind all the time. Now that again sounds really ridiculous. Goal to have that my mind is always focused on Bhagavan.

Therefore I cannot think of anything else. No -- actually, once you realize that, then nothing exists other than Me. Everything you see, you should see Me. Once I see all the objects are nothing but manifestations of the God. The impression of that object on my mind will be more divine than a finite image of that object. If you start seeing me in all things and beings then you will be able to control your mind.

If I see Bhagavan, the supreme being, in all things and beings, then the question of likes and dislikes really does not come. I cannot have one part of Bhagavan I don't like and another part of Bhagavan I like. That's truly not possible. We like everything about that being. Even his shortcomings -- we enjoy his shortcomings.

But a person we don't like -- even his good qualities we don't enjoy. So once we identify with that supreme self, all his manifestations we will enjoy them all as they are. Because we will not have any judgment about an individual manifestation. So Bhagavan says Sachapa Raga, Dwese Viuktahi. Person who has become devoid of likes and dislikes.

Visayan Indre Charan. He moves around in this world of objects. Because there is no escape from this world of objects. We are part of this world and we have to live in this world. What do we want to achieve? We have to achieve within this world.

But how we act in this world is up to us. So I said one who is devoid of likes and dislikes. He is moving around with Atma Vashyahi, Vidhey Atma. He is self restrained. He is not getting carried away by one experience or the another. Vidheyatma, his self control.

Prasadam Adhigacchati. He achieves that final result. And as we have discussed Prasad many times before, we are used to the word Prasad -- after every puja we have Prasad. That Prasad is always sweet, because it represents the fruits of all my good actions, sweet results. Here the result is tranquility of mind -- the mind is not getting any impression which is negative.

No matter what impression comes from outside, the mind sees a divine impression, and therefore it is in a state of tranquility. That is the Prasad -- that's the final reward. Then nothing can upset my mind. Bhagavan said such a person achieves Prasadam -- that final tranquility of mind that no experience can disturb.

So Bhagawan says: get out of likes and dislikes, see Me in everything, and then your mind will be constantly focused on Me. Prasade Sarva Dukkhanam Haanih Asya Upajayate -- this is where we started. I want to learn Bhagavad Gita because I need to get rid of all my Dukkhas.

I want to get Bhagavan's Kripa because I want to get rid of all my sorrows and unhappiness. Bhagavan says there is a way to do it, and it is not My doing -- it is your doing. You have to do it yourself. When you control your mind, when you get out of likes and dislikes, then you will get the Prasad of your own actions -- the tranquility of mind. That tranquility of mind actually removes the cause for all your sorrows. Bhagavan Buddha said there is Dukkha, and there is a cause for Dukkha. All you have to do is remove the cause, and then you achieve that Kaivalyam. Prasade Sarva Dukkhanam -- by this Prasad, all Dukkhas get destroyed.

Prasanna Chetasah Ashu Buddhih Paryavatishthate -- and for the one who is of tranquil mind, Chitta becomes Ekagra (one-pointed). As we have discussed, Chitta is a mirror which is reflecting all the impressions from outside. When all these impressions are divinized by my focusing on the divine self who created this cosmos out of his own self, the Chitta reflects nothing but the definitive reality.

As we have discussed before in this logic of causation: if this world exists, there must be a Creator. The Creator needs to have two causes -- efficient cause and material cause. He is the efficient cause because he knew how to create this world, but he also needed material, and the material is nothing but his own self.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 64 presents the positive alternative to the ladder of fall: "The self-controlled soul, who moves amongst sense objects, free from either attachment or repulsion, he wins eternal Peace." Note that the solution is not avoiding sense objects (impossible in worldly life) but engaging with them without Raga (attraction) or Dvesha (repulsion). The key is "Vidheyatma" - one whose self is disciplined.

Verse 65 describes the reward: "Having attained Peace, he becomes free from misery; for when the mind gains peace, right discrimination follows." Peace enables clear thinking, which reinforces peace - a virtuous cycle. But verse 66 warns of the opposite spiral: "Right discrimination is not for him who cannot concentrate. Without concentration, there cannot be meditation; he who cannot meditate must not expect peace; and without peace, how can anyone expect happiness?"

This teaching creates a clear roadmap. Start with reducing likes and dislikes - practice equanimity toward pleasant and unpleasant experiences. This enables concentration. Concentration enables meditation (sustained focus). Meditation brings peace. Peace brings happiness. Today, practice engaging with something you typically dislike or avoid with an attitude of neutrality - not forcing yourself to like it, just dropping the active dislike. Similarly, engage with something you typically crave with a bit more detachment. This "Raga-Dvesha Vimuktaihi" (freedom from attraction and repulsion) is the practical beginning of the path to lasting peace.

snippets.title: Day 39: The Wandering Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते |

तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः |

या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी |
snippets.transliteration:
indriyāṇāṃ hi caratāṃ yanmano.anuvidhīyate .

tasmādyasya mahābāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ .

yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī .
verseTranslations: As a ship at sea is tossed by the tempest, so the reason is carried away by the mind when preyed upon by straying senses.
Therefore, O Might-in-Arms, he who keeps his senses detached from their objects - take it that his reason is purified.
The saint is awake when the world sleeps, and he ignores that for which the world lives.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. Bhagavan gave us a roadmap for our journey from ignorance about ourselves to the knowledge of the Supreme. We have seen this step by step. How can I come out of this ignorance about myself? Right now I consider this body as me, this mind as me, this intellect as me. Ideas such as "I think, therefore I am" create attachment to my mind and my intellect.

And this body serves as my vehicle for all my experiences in this world, which creates attachment to it. Therefore I consider the death of this body to be my death. I have not seen anybody coming back after he dies, so I conclude the death of this body is my death. But Bhagavan said, dehino'smin yatha dehe kaumaram yauvanam jara tatha dehantara praptir dhiras tatra na muhyati. Just as you have seen changes in your life from childhood to youth to old age, you should not be confused by the transition to another body.

You have seen in your journey various states of existence. You existed as a child, as a youth, and also as an old man. Now he said, you're not confused by that, that does not delude you. These experiences which are different from each other has never confused you, who you are. You always consider, this is me. When I say I, it remains same no matter what state I was in, whether I was a child, a young man or an old man.

Since those changes in this life did not confuse you about who you are, the change to another body also should not confuse you. This is a hypothesis for us now because we do not have direct experience of it. But the idea of reincarnation was introduced to us: that this life is not the only life. You lived many lives before, where you created all your vasanas and tendencies. I have a tendency to be artistic, somebody else has a tendency to be athletic, another person is more intellectual. Where are all these tendencies coming from? Bhagavan said these tendencies come from your experiences in past lives, before you were even born in this body. And then he basically said that this journey is one of activity. In this journey you have to be active all your life. Then the question is: how do I act in this world? Bhagavan said, sukha duhkhe same kritva labha alabha jayajayau, tato yuddhaya yujyasva -- with a balanced mind you should act in this world. That's basically simple advice Bhagavan gave. Samatvam Yoga Uchate. Create balance in your mind in all the various experiences you're experiencing. And then you will be on your path to your destination. Your destination is to find perfect happiness.

Bhagawan said you will find that if you act in this world with a balanced mind. Then my question is: how do I keep a balanced mind with varied experiences in my life? And Bhagawan said Yukta Asita Matparaha. Keep an overarching goal which encompasses everything -- all your experiences, all your feelings, and all your thoughts.

Then you will be able to balance your mind. If you have an overarching goal, then that goal becomes the destination. The goal will be reflected in all your experiences. We have all experienced that when you are in love, when you are fixated with one object, you see that in everything. When you fall in love, you see that person.

In all other persons you see -- "that must be her, that must be him." Because my mind is so overpowered by that goal that I see everything in it. When I become a father or mother for the first time, in all children I see my child. Then when I first become a grandfather, I see my granddaughter and grandson in all children. Because whatever is taking over your mind, you will reflect that in all your experiences.

If your mind is focused on Me, if I am your supreme goal, then I will be reflected in all your experiences. Everything I see, I will see His manifestation. Everything I hear, I will hear His voice, His flute in that sound. So everything will become divine. The experience may be anything, but now my mind will not assign any value other than a divine value to it.

Bhagavan said Yukta Asita Matparaha -- but to become Yukta, to be established in that union, Bhagavan says Tani Sarvani Samyamya, you must control all your senses. Vashe hi yasya indriyani -- one who has the senses under control. Tasya prajna pratishtita -- his wisdom is steady. What he's seeing is what is truly there to be seen. When my wisdom is steady and my mind is balanced, I'm seeing reality. If my wisdom is not steady, if I assign different values to different things based on my likes and dislikes, then my wisdom is not steady.

The result of that would be that I will not have any Sukha, I will not be at peace. So the last verse which we discussed says Nasti buddhir ayuktasya. One who has no overarching goal is Ayukta. Yukta is one who is identified with the supreme goal. My supreme goal should be having Sukha and no Dukkha. That overarching goal in my life is to avoid Dukkha and have only ultimate happiness. That happens when you are identified with the supreme self. Bhagavan says, the one who is not identified with the supreme goal is Ayukta. He has no fixed goal, so anything will become his goal. Whatever experience I have, I'll be attached to it, and then I will not know where my happiness truly lies. It is something like when I was in India or in Africa -- there were only a few choices, like two or three: Kesar, Pista, or Kajudraks ice cream. When I went to Law Garden in Ahmedabad, the choices were very clear, not really a big question mark. But I come here and Baskin Robbins has 31 flavors. Now how do I know which flavor is best? If I taste all 31 of them, by the time I get to the 31st flavor, I forget what the first flavor tasted like. I would have to start all over again. So I really have no clue where my happiness lies.

Because every time I taste something, I think that's it. And then I say, but there are 30 other flavors. I need to try them also. Maybe there is one better than this. So Bhagavan said, one who is Ayukta -- who does not have this fixed goal of what he is trying to achieve -- he will not have any Buddhi. Nasti buddhir ayuktasya. He does not have the wisdom to know what his goal is and where his happiness lies. He also does not have any firm identification; his identification shifts from one goal to another. In one who is not identified with one goal, how can there be any peace? His mind is agitated. Even when I'm achieving something, I think, "This may not be it. There may be other things which other people are getting that I'm not getting. I should be going after them. I may be missing out on something." So Bhagavan said, na cabhavayatah shantih.

One who does not have identification with his goal has no Shanti. And ashantasya kutah sukham -- for the one who is agitated, where is happiness? We all know this: when the mind is agitated, there is no Sukha. Sukha I only experience when there is no agitating thought in my mind. Swamiji used to say: "I" minus "I want" equals happiness. As long as there is "I want," there cannot be any happiness. As long as I'm wanting something, there cannot be any peace in my mind, because there's agitation -- "I don't have it. I must be doing something which is not right. Or I may not be doing something which I should be doing now." Those thoughts create ashanti.

Such a person cannot have Sukham. If your goal is to achieve Sukha, you need to quieten your mind. And then Bhagavan explains why it is very important that you start with controlling your senses, which we have seen earlier. Dhyayato visayan pumsah -- if I let my senses get impressions of the sense objects, then I keep thinking about them, and then I'll fall down that ladder of fall. So it says Indriyanam hi charatam yan mano'nuvidhiyate -- if my mind follows the wandering senses. Senses are involuntarily going out and getting impressions of the objects they are contacting. If I keep my eyes open and see outside the window, there will be an impression of what's outside. But what I actually see depends on the disposition of my mind. For example, I see my friend Omi Narayan every day posting pictures of birds or flowers on his Facebook. But when I look outside, I see buildings. I say, "Well, that guy's house looks nice, but I think it could have been designed a little better than this." So the disposition of my mind is to see the built world, not the natural world, even though we're both looking outside. The senses are involuntarily going out there and getting impressions of these sense objects.

It is the mind which creates meaning from those impressions. Indriyanam hi charatam -- these wandering senses go out, and if the mind follows these wandering senses, getting attached to each object it perceives and wanting to keep thinking about it, then tadasya harati prajnam -- it carries away his wisdom. Now he obviously does not have the discrimination to know what is right and what is wrong for him, what to accept and what to reject. A picture is worth a thousand words, so Bhagavan gives this image: just as a boat on the waters with no controller, no boatman, just a boat by itself -- it will be tossed by the wind.

Wherever the wind takes it, it will go. There is no fixed destination. If your mind follows every object which is perceived through the senses, then it will be tossed from one object to another. It does not have a goal and therefore it does not have any destination. My destination was happiness, but I lost my way because I have not fixed my destination. I do not know where to go. I am just driving but do not know where I am going. And then Bhagavan says Tasmad yasya mahabaho -- therefore, O Mighty-Armed. Bhagawan gives Arjuna a little boost of courage: you are capable of doing this, of controlling your senses. Nigrihitani Sarvashah Indriyani Indriyarthebhyah. Therefore, one who has controlled all his senses from the sense objects -- Tasya Prajna Pratishtita -- his wisdom is steady.

This is a very difficult verse to understand because we think it is impossible -- impossible to not have any perception of this world outside. The very job of senses is to perceive the world outside. If my mind is completely inert and is not getting any impression, then I'll be basically a dead person. Swamiji says, "If that's the case, if you're not perceiving anything, just let us know and we'll do your last rites." So if that's what it means, it is not possible for us to do that.

The very nature of senses is to get impressions in the very nature of mind is to get attached to those impressions. But what I will see as my mind depends on the disposition of my mind. If I have already fixed a goal that my goal is to have ultimate happiness and therefore I have to fix my mind on the ultimate self, then I will see the manifestation of that self in everything which I hear, I taste, I touch. So the people who are bhakta, when they listen to music, they see Krishna Bhakti in it. To them the music is for achieving God's Bhakti. Otherwise I sing film songs and it has different emotions in it.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 67 uses a powerful image: "As a ship at sea is tossed by the tempest, so the reason is carried away by the mind when preyed upon by straying senses." Without mastery over the senses, even a wise person's discrimination can be swept away. The senses wander naturally toward their objects; if the mind follows them, wisdom is lost like a rudderless boat in a storm.

Verse 68 restates the requirement: "He who keeps his senses detached from their objects - take it that his reason is purified." And verse 69 offers a striking paradox: "The saint is awake when the world sleeps, and he ignores that for which the world lives." What ordinary people consider most real and important (sense pleasures, worldly success), the sage sees as relatively unreal - like being asleep to the deeper truth. Conversely, what the sage is awake to (the Self, the eternal) seems like nothing to ordinary perception.

This is an invitation to examine your own "sleep" and "wakefulness." What consumes your attention and energy? Is it what the verse calls the world's concerns, or something deeper? Try this contemplation: Imagine looking back at your current life from your deathbed. What that you now pursue will seem important then? What will seem like sleep-walking through life? The sage is awake now to what will matter then. Today, try to stay "awake" to what is truly significant amid the distractions that normally capture your attention.

snippets.title: Day 40: The Ocean of Peace
snippets.sanskrit:
आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं

विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः |

एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति |
snippets.transliteration:
āpūryamāṇamacalapratiṣṭhaṃ samudramāpaḥ praviśanti yadvat .

vihāya kāmānyaḥ sarvānpumāṃścarati niḥspṛhaḥ .

eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati .
verseTranslations: He attains Peace, into whom desires flow as rivers into the ocean, which though brimming with water remains ever the same; not he whom desire carries away.
He attains Peace who, giving up desire, moves through the world without aspiration, possessing nothing which he can call his own, and free from pride.

O Arjuna! This is the state of the Self, the Supreme Spirit, to which if a man once attain, it shall never be taken from him. Even at the time of leaving the body, he will remain firmly enthroned there, and will become one with the Eternal."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. We are coming to the end of chapter two, and we will be discussing the last three verses today, then we'll move on to chapter three, Karma Yoga, the Yoga of Action. What we have learned so far in chapter two is essentially the whole summary of Bhagavad Gita -- all the ideas and the basic philosophy of Bhagavad Gita are summarized in chapter two. The most important verse in the first section was verse 7, where Arjuna said, karpanya doshopahatah svabhavah -- my nature is overwhelmed by the taint of miserliness or weakness, and I do not know what is right and wrong for me. I don't know what is my Dharma.

Dharma sammudha chetasah -- my Buddhi does not tell me right now what is my right Dharma at this time. Shishyas te'ham -- so he admits: I need guidance. I need someone to tell me what is right. Therefore, tell me definitively, without any wavering, what is right for me. So the first section gives us a condition we sometimes face in life: we are completely overwhelmed by the situation and we cannot see what is right and wrong for us. But where we differ from Arjuna is that our ego doesn't give us that humility to say, "I'm completely confused, I am your student, please guide me." Even at the point of confusion and delusion, we try to hang on to our ego and try to solve our problems ourselves. And therefore we can't see how to get out of this problem.

Because we are in the problem, we need to surrender to someone who can see it from outside, have complete faith in his advice and guidance, and say, "I'm going to follow whatever you tell me, just tell me." But what we typically do is carry our ego to whoever we are seeking advice from. We say, "Look, okay, but what does he know? My problem only I know." That's why we fail to get the benefit of advice. So Bhagavan did not say anything in chapter one because he didn't see that Arjuna was ready yet. Swamiji says, giving advice to the wrong person at the wrong time can do more harm than help. If somebody is not ready to take the advice and you say, "Let me tell you, my son" -- he has to be ready before you can tell him what is right for him. So the first thing we have seen is that when you reach a point of complete confusion in your life, you have to surrender. In this case, if nothing else, surrender to your own conscience, which is Bhagavan, and say, "Give me guidance."

Tell me, I don't know. My intellect cannot come to the conclusion of what is right or wrong. And then we have seen all the guidance Bhagavan gave. He first changes Arjuna's paradigm of what he thinks he is. You are not who you think you are. This limited being which you have considered yourself to be is not really you. This is just your equipment. This body, mind, and intellect which I currently consider to be me is actually nothing but my equipment. So if I can realize that this is something which is mine and cannot be me, then I will be able to realize who I truly am and get the benefit of that wisdom. So Bhagavan changed his paradigm and said: you are that imperishable being. And then we have seen the explanation -- just as you change your clothes, you will change the body as well, but you remain the same.

Just as you changed from childhood to youth to old age, from this life you'll move on to the next life. The advice given by Bhagavan in verse 38 is how to live life: Sukha duhkhe same kritva labhalabho jayajayau, tato yuddhaya yujyasva naivam papam avapsyasi. Here is how you should live your life: not a life of inaction, not a life of complete detachment from your duties, but complete detachment from what's happening to you. Have that understanding that all things are transitory, finite in nature and in time-space. So sukha duhkhe same kritva -- you remain the same whether experiencing sukha or duhkha. I will still experience them differently -- one will be pleasurable, one will be painful. But I experience both while keeping in mind that this is just a passing phase, a finite experience.

How do I keep my balance? Victory and defeat in our life -- we are constantly winning and losing. We're winning an argument, we are winning a negotiation, we are losing a deal. Marketing people teach you that everyone is selling something. You may not consider yourself a salesman, but you are selling something to somebody -- selling your idea to your spouse about which vacation to take. You have to sell your idea first. So you're constantly selling and marketing and winning and losing in life, and you need to keep your balance. Just as you don't really get upset when you lose your argument within the family -- sometimes we do, but you're not supposed to because you understand we are still one family -- in the same way, when I lose or win out in the world, I should have the same equanimity. Others are going to win sometimes. The law of probability tells me I cannot have 100% success. As I told you, in our industry we ask, what is the hit rate -- how many proposals are submitted and how many have we won? Now that hit rate is not really entirely dependent on you; it's partly the law of probabilities.

I know if I submit 10 proposals, I'll win at least one of them. It is a law of probability. So I have to be prepared nine times to be disappointed that somebody else was better than me. But that one time when I win, I'm so ecstatic -- "I am the best." The other nine times, I will be miserable. But no -- you have to be the same in all 10 times. Bhagavan said the operative word is: you just engage in this battle of life. You can't run away from it. And there's a guarantee -- you will not incur any sin in doing your duty with this attitude. No matter what the outcome is, you are not incurring any wrong impressions on your mind. And then the last section we have seen is the Sthita Prajna. In the end, Arjuna said, if someone achieves this, how do I recognize him? So verse 55 gives a short definition: prajahati yada kaman sarvan partha manogatan, atmany evatmana tushtah sthitaprajnas tadochyate.

How do I become that person who is in a blissful mood all the time? Because you are saying yuddhaya yujyasva -- you want me to engage in the battle. Typically what we say is, "This is too painful an environment. I need to leave this environment." Bhagavan said no, you can't leave. It's part of your duty. You have to engage yourself in this battle of life and still remain equanimous, stable, blissful. How? He said Prajahati yada kaman sarvan manogatan. He didn't say to give up all desires. Desires cannot go away completely. Manogatan means fabricated by my mind -- something which I really don't need but I think I have to have.

One thing I learned in all the training we go through in the corporate world -- one of the trainings I did was "Negotiate to Win." They have an exercise about Honest Abdullah's shop in Pakistan, and you are an American tourist going to negotiate for an antique piece. The first thing the American does is say, "Oh that's great, I got to have it." Once Abdullah hears "I got to have it," he knows he's got you, and then he's going to start from the highest price he can imagine, then come down slightly, and you think you have done well. But if you're from India, what do you do? "Well, I really don't need it, but I think, you know, I'm here." Meena and I went to India last time at one of these historical places, and she said, "I can buy it, but I don't really have space for this in my bag, so I can't really buy it. But if you give it to me for this price, I'll buy it." The guy said, "So if I give you the lower price, you'll have space in your bag?" She said, "No, I can only buy -- okay, I don't have space in my bag." So we worked the other way around: "I really don't need it, but if you want to give it to me at that price, okay." So this is Manogatan -- desires fabricated by my mind. If I give up all the desires which are fabricated by my mind -- not my genuine needs -- that's the key. I have a desire to fulfill my needs: I'm thirsty and I want a glass of water, that is one thing. But if I have to buy a Perrier just because it's a status symbol, well, that's my Manogatan desire. So Bhagavan said that if you give up all the Manogatan desires and just be happy with whatever you come across.

Atmany evatmana tushtah. Fulfilling my desires is not giving me happiness or joy -- it is just fulfilling my needs. But I am always satisfied in myself, by myself, with who I am and where I am. Atmany evatmana tushtah sthitaprajnas tadochyate. That is the definition of Sthita Prajna. Not that he is not working in this world, or that he is a sanyasi in the Himalayas. He is working in this world but is satisfied in himself, where he is. He is not getting jealous by reading Forbes magazine -- "All these people are making all this money and what am I doing here?" When I am not disturbed by the outside world, that outside world cannot create unnecessary desires in my mind.

Then I am a Sthita Prajna. So we have gone through the whole characteristics of the Sthita Prajna -- he works in this world in a very intelligent way. That's an intelligent way of living. He does not live life in a chaotic way, whereas we live life somewhat prompted by our instincts. We go to the mall with no plan to buy X, Y, or Z. But just because I'm there and I see something, I keep saying, "Maybe I need that, maybe I should have that because it's on sale." That's because I never really defined what will make me happy. So what does the Sthita Prajna do? He lives an intelligent life. He does not expose himself to those temptations. As soon as he sees there are temptations, he withdraws his senses, like the tortoise. So he's always protecting himself from getting undue impressions which are not necessary. And that's how he lives an intelligent life, maintaining his state of equanimity. And then the last four verses tell us the difference between us and him. Right now I'm completely aware of the world of objects. And there are myriads of objects in this world. And I'm seeking happiness in those objects, constantly planning how can I get happiness from them.
snippets.reflection:
The chapter concludes with the beautiful ocean analogy in verse 70: "He attains Peace, into whom desires flow as rivers into the ocean, which though brimming with water remains ever the same; not he whom desire carries away." The ocean receives all rivers yet remains unchanged - full but not overflowing, deep and still. Similarly, experiences and desires come to the sage but do not disturb his fundamental peace. He is already full.

Verse 71 summarizes the path: "He attains Peace who, giving up desire, moves through the world without aspiration, possessing nothing which he can call his own, and free from pride." Three qualities: Nishprihaha (without craving), Nirmamaha (without "mine-ness"), and Nirahankaraha (without ego). And the final verse 72 declares: "This is the state of the Self, the Supreme Spirit, to which if a man once attain, it shall never be taken from him. Even at the time of leaving the body, he will remain firmly enthroned there, and will become one with the Eternal."

As Chapter 2 ends, reflect on its complete teaching: You are not the body but the eternal Self. Perform your duty without attachment to results. Cultivate equanimity toward pleasure and pain. Control the senses through higher focus. Free yourself from the tyranny of likes and dislikes. Become like the ocean - full within yourself, receiving all experiences without being disturbed. Today, choose one of these teachings to focus on. Which resonates most with your current situation? That is your entry point into the practical wisdom of the Gita.

snippets.title: Day 41: Why Action?
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |
