व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṃ mohayasīva me .

śrībhagavānuvāca .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna questioned: My Lord! If Wisdom is above action, why dost Thou advise me to engage in this terrible fight?
Thy language perplexes me and confuses my reason. Therefore please tell me the only way by which I may, without doubt, secure my spiritual welfare.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: In this world, as I have said, there is a twofold path, O Sinless One! There is the Path of Wisdom for those who meditate, and the Path of Action for those who work.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter two, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge, in which we have seen that in the beginning Arjuna was confused about his duties. He wanted to act according to his Dharma, but he wasn't sure what is his Dharma. So he argued first that maybe I should not take part in this war because I don't want to be the cause for all the consequences of this bad war. And then obviously he put for all his arguments, seeking endorsement from Krishna, that yeah, that's the right thing to do, let's stop this war. You run away and we'll be fine. Well, Krishna did not endorse his ideas and actually asked him to do his duties as the commander of the army, the Kshatriya.

To explain why Arjuna should fight, Krishna gave him a true thumbnail picture of who we are and how you should look at the world. So in the beginning he told him about what the self is, that this self is immutable, imperishable, only the body dies, and therefore you should not grieve about anybody dying. And then he continued telling him why he should continue his duty in this world. But then Arjuna asked, is there any person who can be such established in this knowledge that he is equanimous? In the end we have seen that a man of a steady wisdom, how he lives his life in a very intelligent way, that he does not get affected by all the attractions of this objective world. So he always keeps his senses under control and remain equanimous mentally in all situations.

And therefore Bhagavan said, you go ahead and act in this world, keeping your mind and intellect equanimous in all situations. Now this seems very simple and clear to us, but Arjuna, who was truly in that dilemma of what is right, I want to do my Dharma, but I don't know which one is right. This whole discourse about what the self is all about obviously did not make it very clear to Arjuna. So the chapter three, titled Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action, now elaborates upon what is action and how you should work in this world. You have to work in this world because we are all working. But if we find out how to act, maybe we can have better results, because right now we act in this world with mixed results.

Sometimes we are successful, most of the time we are not. Most of the time the results come completely contrary to what we think we should be getting out of our actions. So this chapter teaches us how to act in this world so our actions can be very effective. So the karma becomes Karma Yoga. Therefore this chapter is very very popular. Some of the great commentators have said the Gita is all about Karma Yoga.

It teaches you how to act in this life one way or other. It is a very important chapter for all of us because all of us are trying to figure out how to work in this world because we will not be able to avoid working in this world. So the chapter opened with Arjuna's question just as we all have. We all ask this question and say, yeah, this is great. In the Gita class we talk about all this -- desirelessness and actionlessness -- and then go back to your workplace on Monday morning and try to tell that to your client. From our perspective it does not work.

I actually just heard that Mina watches this course in the morning, so I get the benefit. When I'm passing around, I overhear stuff. Deepak bhai from Dada Bhagavan -- they have a question-answer format. So somebody asks, "Deepak bhai, when I am trying to focus more on this Prateekraman and spirituality, I lose my motivation to make progress in my job. Should I focus more on this or focus more on my job?" Deepak bhai said, "So what's your name, sir?" My name is Janakbhai.

Janakbhai, let Janakbhai make the progress in the job, and you establish yourself in spirituality. In other words, you need to separate yourself from what's happening in this world with you. You become a sakshi-chaitanya, a witnessing consciousness. Basically, when you take the role of Janakbhai as an employee, you have to work as an employee very effectively. When Janakbhai is in spirituality, Janakbhai has to establish himself in spirituality. But this answer is confusing, and Janakbhai can say, "Deepak bhai, tell me one thing -- you are not helping me here. Janakbhai is one, and you are telling me to be two different Janakbhais!" This is not Janakbhai's newly minted question. This question Arjuna had 5,000 years ago. So he said, Jayasi Chit Karmanaste Mata Buddhi Janardina Tatkim Karmani Ghore Maam Niyo Jayasi Keshava. You just discussed in detail what is right and what is wrong, what is better and what is not so good, what is higher and what is lower. In last chapter he says Durena hi Avaram Karmaha Buddhi Yoga Dhananjaya. Krishna in last verse clearly says that Karma is inferior to Buddhi Yoga.

In the beginning he propagated, you should go and fight for all these good reasons. Then he came back and said, you achieve the Buddhi Yoga. Buddhi yoga knowledge about what is your true self. Arjuna said, that's what I was trying to do. I want to run away and meditate. If you consider that Buddhi is better than Karma, you say it very clearly.

In last chapter in verse 49, the Durenahiyavaram Karmaha Buddhi Yoga Dhananjaya. So therefore you said engage yourself in a Buddhi Yoga. You clearly told me that Tatkim Karmani Ghore mam. Then why are you asking me to fight this war? This is like a person interested in physics who wants to find out what light is all about. If I ask a Mahatma like Sid Carey, who is a physicist, "Tell me, sir, what is light?"

And he said, light can be a particle or a wave. I said, what do you mean? Is it a particle or a wave? Please don't confuse me. He said, no, both are right. Except that you have to rise yourself to a level in your understanding to understand both viewpoints.

He said it depends on the observer. Observer can decide it's a particle or it's a wave. So Bhagavan said, karma is necessary, but Buddhi Yoga is also necessary. One is superior than other depending on where you are. Vya Mishrena Vakhena Buddhim Moha Yasi Evame. This mixed Mishrena you are going the two mixed messages.

You are speaking from both sides of your mouth. One side saying go fight the war, that's okay, kill those people. Other side says, establish yourself in Buddha knowledge. This is confusing my intellect. These statements have already confused my intellect. Tad Ekam Vadanishchtya.

Therefore obviously I am your Srishya. I already told you I am your Shishya. You tell me what is good for me. So don't go into this great arguments about which one is better. Tell me one thing that will be the best for me which will be Shreyas which is good for me. As you are saying shres and prayers.

Something which is pleasant but may not be good for me -- but something you tell me, it may not be pleasant, but tell me this is good for you. And I already told you, I surrender to you. I will do whatever you tell me.

And then comes the whole of Chapter 3, Karma Yoga. Bhagavan said, Sri Bhagavanu Vacha. Now Bhagavan is elaborating on what Karma is all about. Loke Asmin Dvividha Nistha Pura Prukta Maya Anaga -- don't get confused.

There is not only one path in this world. Loki Asmin -- in this world. Dvivida Nishta -- I have established two paths. Because you need to give people alternatives. You have to have choice. Pura Prokta Mayan -- right from the beginning, I established two paths.

This is the first time, as lots of commentators say, that Bhagavan comes out clearly and says, "I'm not Vasudeva Krishna. I am the Supreme Lord." That right from the beginning of this world, I established two paths. So you always had two options available from the day one. The day I forgot myself as who I am.

From the day I forgot that I am the Supreme Being and taken up this identity as me, this limited being, I had two paths available. My loka started with the very first thought that I am this limited being. And Bhagawan says there are always two paths available. It is like I'm going to New York. My goal is to reach New York, and just around the Delaware, there are two paths. One goes to the New Jersey Turnpike, another is 95 going through Philadelphia and all that.

I get confused and say which way I'm going. Well, I have two paths available. I can go through the 95 and I still reach New York. And I can go through New Jersey Turnpike and I'll still reach New York. So Tupa is always available to me. Gnana Yogina Sankhyana for those who are established in contemplation, those who are contemplative type.

For them Gnana Yoga Yoga of Knowledge, Karma Yogi and a yoginand. Those who are action oriented. For them Karma is established. Two paths are available to us. Either you have to work through your way to your goal or realize how to get there quickly. If I realize the New Jersey Turnpike will be quicker and I'll take quicker path.

If not, I'll work my way through Route 95, going through the smaller towns and traffic, but both will lead me to the destination. There is also something similar in our Indian system of marriage. In the Indian system, I say, well, if you want to get married, you have two paths. I'm not sure what is there now. Either you can have a love marriage.

You fall in love, find somebody and then get married. Or arranged marriage -- find somebody, get married, and then fall in love. Both ultimately culminating into what? One starts out by knowing first who I want to marry. Knowledge occurs to me -- that one I like -- and then I get married. But then I work towards how to live together, what marriage is all about.

All that takes place after marriage. Meena said, I never knew your true swaroopa till I got married, even though we were dating for three years. On the other hand, you get married to somebody, you work through an arranged marriage. Then you have to fall in love with her. The ultimate goal is to identify. Right now, my identification is with this limited self.

My goal is to identify with the supreme self. So identification has to change. When identification occurs, it becomes love. When I start identifying, then only I can love somebody. I cannot love someone I never met. So I have to first know someone to fall in love with her.

As Swamiji says, you fall in love, you rise in devotion. So to love someone, you have to know the person. So to love the divine, you have to know the divine, that bhakti. Eventually you're trying to achieve the Bhakti Yoga. That's your goal, to have devotion for the Lord. But I cannot devote to somebody whom I do not know.

I love God, but I don't know who. That is not possible. So I have two paths to achieve that devotion. When I get the knowledge that who I am, that I am not this limited self, contemplating on who I am not, and I get the knowledge who I am, then I'll identify with that self.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna's confusion in these opening verses mirrors our own daily struggle: we hear teachings about inner peace and detachment, yet Monday morning arrives and we must engage fully in the world. Like Arjuna, we often feel pulled between two paths - the contemplative life of wisdom and the active life of responsibility. Krishna's response reveals a profound truth: both paths lead to the same destination. The question is not which path to choose, but rather which path suits your nature at this stage of life.

Consider your own life today. Are you someone who naturally gravitates toward reflection and study (Jnana Yoga), or do you find fulfillment through action and service (Karma Yoga)? Neither is superior - they are simply different routes to the same summit. The key insight is that you cannot escape action by merely refusing to act. Even sitting still involves the action of sitting. The real question is: how will you act?

Take a moment to identify one area where you feel confused about what is right - perhaps a decision at work, a family obligation, or a personal choice. Instead of seeking one "correct" answer, ask yourself: What does my unique nature (swabhava) call me to do? What path - action or contemplation - feels more aligned with who I am right now?

snippets.title: Day 42: Action vs Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते |

न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् |

कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् |

na karmaṇāmanārambhānnaiṣkarmyaṃ puruṣo.aśnute .

na hi kaścitkṣaṇamapi jātu tiṣṭhatyakarmakṛt .

karmendriyāṇi saṃyamya ya āste manasā smaran .

I love God, but I don't know who. That is not possible. So I have two paths to achieve that devotion. When I get the knowledge that who I am, that I am not this limited self, contemplating on who I am not, and I get the knowledge who I am, then I'll identify with that self.
snippets.reflection:
These verses expose one of the most common spiritual traps: the pretense of renunciation. Krishna warns against the "mithyachara" - the hypocrite who outwardly restrains his senses while inwardly dwelling on sense objects. How often do we physically step away from temptation while our mind continues to feast on it? The person who refuses to eat cake but spends hours thinking about it has not truly renounced anything. The struggle has simply moved from the external to the internal realm.

The teaching here is liberating: you cannot achieve freedom from action (naishkarmya) by simply refusing to act. The qualities of nature - sattva, rajas, and tamas - will compel you to act whether you wish to or not. Even breathing, thinking, and sitting are actions. The path to liberation lies not in suppression but in transformation of how we act.

Today, honestly examine one area where you may be practicing this spiritual hypocrisy. Perhaps you have given up a habit outwardly, but your mind still gravitates toward it. Or maybe you have withdrawn from a responsibility while telling yourself it is "detachment." True renunciation is internal - it means engaging fully with life while remaining mentally free. Ask yourself: Where am I restraining my body while my mind runs wild? What would it look like to act fully in that area while cultivating genuine inner detachment?

snippets.title: Day 43: The Superior Path
snippets.sanskrit:
यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन |

नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः |

यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः |
snippets.transliteration:
yastvindriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate.arjuna .

niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ karma jyāyo hyakarmaṇaḥ .

yajñārthātkarmaṇo.anyatra loko.ayaṃ karmabandhanaḥ .
verseTranslations: But, O Arjuna! All honour to him whose mind controls his senses, for he is thereby beginning to practise Karma-Yoga, the Path of Right Action, keeping himself always unattached.
Do thy duty as prescribed, for action for duty's sake is superior to inaction. Even the maintenance of the body would be impossible if man remained inactive.
In this world people are fettered by action, unless it is performed as a sacrifice. Therefore, O Arjuna, let thy acts be done without attachment, as sacrifice only.
snippets.commentary:
So far we have seen the dilemma of whether to work in this world or renounce actions. We have discussed many times that action -- which is an interaction between I and this world -- creates impressions. These impressions on my mind create tendencies, these tendencies create desires, the desires create actions. And then the cycle starts all over again. The more I act, the more I interact with this world. That interaction will have this cause and effect relationship.

This cycle seems like never ending cycle that I can never get out of this. And the whole purpose of all this studies is to get out of this cycle. So obviously Arjuna is confused whether he should act by fighting this war or renounce all these actions and go to Himalaya. So that's where we started the chapter. In the last verse, we have seen Bhagavan say Niyatam Kuru Karmatvam -- a very firm prescription. You must do all your ordained duties.

Niyatam Kuru Karmatvam Karma Jayahi Akarma Naha Because Karma is superior than inaction. Action is superior than inaction. So very simple, very clear that what you should do in life is do your ordained duties. And, and we have seen in last discussion, the ordained duties are. Daily duties which we can't really escape. Brushing your teeth, taking bath, going to work, all these Nitya Karma, there's nothing special about it.

Nobody is going to congratulate you every morning for brushing your teeth, unless you are a little three-year-old child. Then there is Naimittya Karma, which are the special duties -- when something is required by your family, your community, your society, your nation, then you have to perform those duties. You're not doing those duties every day. On special occasions you're required to participate. Either you have a voluntary army or a draft. If you're not volunteering on your own to protect your country, there will be a draft.

You have to draft you because that's required a special duty. So Bhagavan says Niyyatam Kuru Karma Tvam. Niyata Karma includes both the Nitya and Naimittya -- that means there is no escape from any duty. Swamiji gives the example that your friend is sick and he needs your help. At that time you can say, "I am very busy." You can, but that means you are shirking your duty.

You are not doing your part. So Bhagawan very clearly says Nidham Kuru Karma Thomas Karma Jyay or Karmanaha Karma is anytime better than inaction. Action is anytime better than inaction. Sari Yatra Apicha Tena prasiddayat or Karmanah. By inaction you can't even sustain your body. We can understand that even to sustain my body, I have to act.

And therefore action is prescribed here. So now we are still in the conundrum. On one hand we want to liberate ourselves from this bondage and other hand we have to act. So it looks like catch 22. So the next four verses, as Swamiji says, are laid out as the overall scheme of thing as the Creator has created how to act and how to be liberated from your actions, not bound by your actions. Also, when this world is created, there should be a plan for sustaining it.

So the whole plan is laid out in the next few verses. And I obviously had been listening to Swamiji from the Cold War era. Swamiji used to say, "Don't blame me or don't put me in jail because it sounds like I'm a communist or a socialist. Krishna is the socialist, not me." Where Krishna now lays out the whole path of socialism in the next four verses, Swamiji says there is no real socialist nation on this planet, because even in communist countries, there are people who are just in it for their power.

That's not what the socialism is all about. So the next four verses lay out the whole plan of sustaining this universe and you being a part of that universe. How you can participate but not get bound by your actions. So the next verse says, Yajnar Thaat Karmano anyatra Loko Ayam Karma Bandanaha. Actions other than those performed for the Yajna are binding Loko yam in this loka in this world. This Loka is bound by Kun, cause and effect.

Everything in this world is bound by cause and effect. There is nothing in this world that is free from cause and effect. Therefore, we give this standard example. If I see something in this room, it's an effect. If I see a table in this room, it's an effect. And I cannot say that this table has no cause.

Where did this table come? Kneel and say, we are chinma mission, we don't want to do anything. And table appears here. Obviously nobody will believe me because you know I bought it from somewhere. Even if I didn't buy it, I stole it from somebody. So buy, borrow or steal.

Only three ways we can acquire things. Table is in effect, so it must have a cause. This cause has two aspects, efficient cause and a material cause. Someone who knew how to make this table is the efficient cause carpenter and the material cause, the wood which was required. So having this relationship of cause and effect, this table comes into existence. So in this loca everything is bound by cause and effect.

So if you act, there will be an effect. So you will be bound by this cause and effect. If you are acting for your own desires, for your own betterment, for your own good only. But if you are working for the betterment of the whole society, for the cosmic order, then you are bound by one thing. So yajna karmano van Yatra, actions performed for the Yajna. Obviously we know culturally that it's a ritual of offering sacrifices in the fire.

But the original meaning, the significance of Yajna in the Vedic period, was to propitiate the deities who are in charge of these elemental forces. As an observant person, we realize that there are two aspects of my success. One is my own efforts, but then also the environment in which I'm putting my efforts. I may be a very hard-working farmer, but if there is no rain, obviously I will not have any success. So I know that something other than me is participating in my success. That's what we call Devam.

That's something destiny we call it. So these phenomenal forces are the ones I don't have control over. One year there is a lot of rain, the other year there is a drought and third year there is just appropriate rain. How do I control that? There must be some controller who decides this. That controller we call deva.

Maybe there is a controller who controls this rain, a deva. So if we appease those devas, it will be good for the whole society and there will be rain for the whole society. This yajnas were the cooperative endeavor to appease the deities of phenomenal forces. So the purpose was to have a common good where everyone can benefit in the community. Therefore you hear the story about in Bhagavad, Krishna lifting the govardhan parvat. You know how it all started.

Krishna was a reformer. Everybody was doing yajna to Indra. Krishna said, "Why are you offering this Yajna to Indra? Indra is not doing anything for you. These cows are supporting you. This Mother Earth is supporting you."

Let's have Yajna for the cows and lay Yajna for the earth. That's from Mother Earth. Mother Cow, they are supporting us, not Indra. So Indra got mad and then the whole story goes he sent all the storms and hurricanes and typhoons or whatever. And then Krishna protects them under the Govardhan Parvat. Even though he was holding it, everyone else was supporting it with their sticks.

And then in the end what do we have? Because of the rain, there's so much food that when all the rains subsided, everybody said let's have a party. Everybody brought their own food. So there was Annakut. There was like the mountain of food. So if you think that potluck was started in America, Krishna started potluck from that Govardhan Parvat there.

So the whole idea is that we have a capacity to work together for the common good. When we work together for common good that include my good also. But not just my good, but everyone else's good as well. Those actions are considered Yajna actions. Bhagavan says all the actions performed in that spirit are not binding. You may be acting in your profession, but if you're only acting for the salary, then that's a selfish action.

But acting because you are improving other people's lives -- by participating as a doctor, as an engineer, you're making the society better and making everyone's life easier -- that's Yajna action. Actions performed in the spirit of Yajna are non-binding. All others are binding. So here is your escape hatch.

You can continue doing whatever you are doing. Just change the attitude that I'm not doing it for myself, I'm doing it for the greater good. Whether I'm an architect, a doctor, a housewife, a mother, everything I'm doing is not just for me but for the overall good of the society, the community, the cosmos, the universe. So Yajna Karmano Anyatna Loko Yam Karma Bandanah Tadartam Karma Kantaya Mukta Sangha Samacharah. Therefore here is the clear advice. Perform actions in the Yajna spirit for Yajna without any attachment.

Perform your actions. Nothing you have to change in your life. Purely your attitude towards your actions. I'm doing these actions because it will help the Entire society. Therefore we have this now new awareness about green buildings, green society, energy savings. None of this is new -- we had it in our culture.

Therefore when I go for my presentations on this green initiative, I say well, I never had to learn because it comes from my culture. We respected the mother earth, we respected nature because we understood those Vedic people understood the value of nature and our participation. Therefore Bhagavan says Tadartam Karma Kaunteya -- act for the Yajna. Therefore act for Yajna only, Mukta Sangha, without attachment. Not having the attachment that I am the doer. I am the only one who can do this.

Because you are just a part of the whole society. You are not an island by yourself. By yourself you are worthy of doing nothing. Just simple act of me coming to this class, I cannot do by myself. So many people have to do so many things. Police have to make sure that there are no crimes on the road.

Roads are clear, the traffic is properly regulated. BMW has to make a car so I can drive a car. Gas companies have to put the gas in the gas stations. All that when it all come together, I can make the simple move from my house to within center if I recognize that. Bhagavan said you are Mukta Sangha. You are detached from your actions.

Sahayagnaha Prajaha Srishtva Purow Vacha Prajapati. How did all this start? Bhagavan says the Creator, when he created this universe, knew that he has to sustain it. If we create something and we do not know how to sustain it -- say we start a business -- we need to know how to sustain the business. If you start any endeavor or create any creation, you have to make sure you maintain it, you sustain it.

So you have to have a plan for that. You have painting artists create. You have to have a plan for how you are going to protect it, where you are going to display it, how to preserve it. So there is always a plan for sustaining something when you create it. Therefore, in Hindu trinity there is a creator, a sustainer and a destroyer.
snippets.reflection:
Here Krishna introduces one of the Gita's most transformative concepts: Yajna, or sacrifice. The word transforms our understanding of action entirely. Actions performed for selfish gain bind us to the wheel of karma, creating an endless cycle of cause and effect. But actions performed as Yajna - as an offering to the greater good - do not bind. This is the escape hatch Krishna offers: you need not change what you do, only the spirit in which you do it.

Consider the profound statement: "Niyatam kuru karma tvam" - do your prescribed duty. Even maintaining the body requires action. You cannot survive without eating, and eating requires the action of procuring food. The question is never whether to act, but how. When you work only for salary, you are bound by that transaction. When you work recognizing that your profession serves others - that the doctor heals, the teacher enlightens, the architect creates shelter - the same action becomes Yajna.

Today, take your most mundane task - perhaps cooking a meal, answering emails, or commuting to work - and consciously reframe it as Yajna. Ask yourself: How does this action serve something larger than my personal gain? How can I offer this task as a sacrifice rather than perform it as a transaction? Notice how this shift in attitude, without changing the action itself, changes your experience of doing it. The action remains; the bondage dissolves.

snippets.title: Day 44: The Wheel of Creation
snippets.sanskrit:
सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः |

देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः |

इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः |
snippets.transliteration:
sahayajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā purovāca prajāpatiḥ .

devānbhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ .

iṣṭānbhogānhi vo devā dāsyante yajñabhāvitāḥ .
verseTranslations: In the beginning, when God created all beings by the sacrifice of Himself, He said unto them: Through sacrifice you can procreate, and it shall satisfy all your desires.
Worship the Powers of Nature thereby, and let them nourish you in return; thus supporting each other, you shall attain your highest welfare.
For, fed, on sacrifice, nature will give you all the enjoyment you can desire. But he who enjoys what she gives without returning is, indeed, a robber.'
snippets.commentary:
So we are now discussing Chapter 3, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. We typically evaluate before getting into any sphere of activity: What are my limitations? If I want to take a particular major in the university, am I good at mathematics, or am I good at science or arts?

Once I decide what my limitations are, then I say how I can develop my capabilities in that field. And then that becomes the field of my choice. So in Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan in chapter two, give us our limitations. That Karmaniyeva adhikarahte ma faleshukajana. Our limitation is to act in the present only. And we have no control over the fruits.

So that's our limitation Bhagavan has given us. Therefore, Bhagavan said that do not worry about the fruits. They are not in your capabilities. You never get attached to inactivity. You focus on your actions. And then for development of my capabilities, then Bhagavan said, Yogastha Guru Karmani, establish yourself.

Yoga is nothing but the balance of mind, equanimity of mind. So once you know your limitations that I have no control over the fruits, but I do have control over my actions, then I have to now become more efficient in my action. And therefore Bhagavan said that Yoga Isthaha. Establish yourself in Yoga, you guys. Develop balance of your mind while acting. When your mind is imbalanced, there is no way you can act efficiently.

So once you establish the equanimity of your mind, then Yoga, Karma, Sukhaoshalam, that will be the result. You will become very efficient in your actions. You will be very dexterous in your actions if you can balance your mind. So your job is only to balance your mind no matter what the situation is. Because you will be acting in this world in myriads of situations. Situations are not in your control.

They will be controlled by the world of phenomena, the world outside the people of the world. You have no control over that. But you have to continuously act. Because you cannot stay without any activity. You cannot change the situation. But you can change the way you perceive and work in this activity.

In one of these TV serials, I heard a very interesting line: if you cannot change the Paristhiti, then change your Manasthiti. And I thought it's a very profound statement. If you cannot change the circumstances outside, you can at least change your mental reaction to them. Manasthiti, the state of your mind you can change because you cannot change the situation outside. The Bhagavan said Samatvam Yoga Ucha de balance of mind in all situations.

Now that I have learned how to work efficiently, I need to know what is the field of my activity and what spirit I should be acting. So the last verse we discussed is Yajnarthaat Karmano Anyatra Loko Yam Karmabandana Tad Artam Karma Kauntiya. Bhagavan has now given us the field of activity: Yajna is the field of your activity. And we have defined Yajna as cooperative activity for the greater good -- dedicated action, sacrifice. So Yajna is basically people coming together in a spirit of sacrifice.

Each one sacrifices something of his own for the betterment of the community. So Bhagavan said, that's the field and the spirit. If you act with all the capabilities you have developed by that samatvam, employed in Yajna -- Lokoyam Karma Bandanaham -- actions performed other than for Yajna are binding. We know that action is bound by its own reaction. By the law of physics, Newton taught us in high school at least that action and reaction are equal and opposite. Anytime there is an action, there will be a reaction.

So the action is bound by the law of Karma. My actions are bound by law of actions. So I'm bound by the result of my action. Once I perform action, I have no control over the result. And as the actor I will be affected by the result. So my action will have a reaction from the world.

That reaction is now the effect of the cause which was my action. Now the reaction from the world when I react to becomes another cause for the reaction by the world. So that chain starts the chain of cause and effect. Once I start the chain, I will be the only one who can break is I who can stop that chain by not reacting to the reaction of my action. So if I do not react to the fruit of my action, then I'll be able to break the chain of that action which I started. Therefore, Bhagavan said Yajna Anyatra Lokoyam Karma Bandana -- actions which I'm performing for gaining something, benefiting from my action, are all binding.

All actions are binding. But if I am performing action not for me but for the greater good then I'm not really expecting anything particularly for me and therefore there is no reaction from me and I'll stop that chain reaction. That's why Bhagavan said the karmas performed in Yajna are non binding to you as a person. Those karmas will be binding to the community for which you have performed that Yajna. Those karmas will be binding to the group of people benefit from those actions but not you personally. So Bhagawan says therefore Yajnaartaat Karma, Kauntiya, Mukta Sangha, Samacharah without attachment, now you attach yourself into it.

That I'm doing this so that the community will benefit. That will also benefit me. That attachment will again bind you. But if you are not attached to your actions in the first place and then to the results in the second place then you are completely free. So Mukta Sangha sam acharaha perform those actions. And then the next verse now says that this is the universal design.

This is not something Bhagavan said I came up with just to give you this advice. This is the original design, universal design, how this universe should function. The next verse says Saha Yagnaha, Prajaha, Srushtva, Pura uvacha. Prajapati said that I created Yajna and Prajaya at the same time. So Praja here is all beings. It is now narrowed down to human beings.

Because everything in this world other than human beings working in compliance with the laws of nature, everything is cooperating and complementing each other except when it comes to human beings. We have free will and we become the disruptors if we are not working in this spirit of Yajna. So Bhagawan said, when I created Praja, I also create a Yajna with it. There is a creative force in nature. That creative force is evolving things. And when it comes to a level of evolution that you can function on your own, Prajapati says, I have created Praja but I also created the spirit of Yajna with it.

By this you shall prosper. But I'm giving you means to support yourself, means to prosper yourself. This is your milch cow. This is your Kamadenu. And we obviously all know about the mythology of Kamadhenu the sacred cow which is capable of fulfilling all your desires. So in mythology the cow came out of churning of ocean and it is also described as a cow's body with human female head and bird's wings.

So it is basically combination of all beings. The this Kamadenu is all beings. The birds and animals and human beings all working together can fulfill any desire. In this case your Yajna is the Kamadenu. This cooperative spirit and the actions performed in Yajna are capable of giving you whatever you desire. When I created Praja, I created spirit of Yajna.

We know that everything in this world has to be working together. And every one of us have to contribute our own share for the betterment of the community. So if I am living in Hendrico county and enjoying all the services Hendrico county offers, I have to contribute my part as paying taxes. If every citizen decides that I'm not going to pay my taxes, there won't be any services after a while. So Bhagavan said, you do your part, but if you work in this cooperative manner, you shall prosper. You will get anything you desire by this Yajna.

And the next verse says Devan Bhavayat vanena te Deva Bhavayantu vaha parasparam Bhavayantaha Sreiyah param avapshata -- Bhagawan explains how this cycle works. Cherish the Devas with this Yajna. You nurture Devas with your cooperative actions. Because your existence in this universe is not that of an island. You as an individual, as you consider is not really an individual. You're just part of the big whole.

And in this universe everything is connected to everything. And therefore if each part is not working in a right manner, which we call it Dharma Chakra, if that's not working, then there cannot be any progress. There cannot be any evolution. Deva Bhavayatan -- we have discussed Deva before. Deva etymologically means "that which is shining." So you know, in a vernacular language you have Diya, Deepak.

So Diva is that which is shining in human beings. Our senses are shining. Our senses illuminate the world outside. So these senses can only work if I nurture those senses. So for me, even the individual to function properly, I have to nurture my senses. Then the same senses will nurture me.

Deva Bhavayantuvah, those Devas will then nurture you. You nurture Devas and Devas will nurture you in an individual level. If I take care of my senses, then my senses will nourish me. At the universal level, the phenomenal forces are considered devas. So in our mythological stories, The Devas are 33 Karod Devas or 33 Koti. The 33 great elements are the devas.

Somewhere in his commentary, Swamiji has listed those Devas -- 8 Vasus, 12 Rudras, etc. In other words, everything in this world is important. Unless every element of this universe is taken care of, the universe cannot function as it's supposed to. Everything in the universe is working as per the laws of nature. The human beings have to be disciplined. And now, in today's situation, we all know about climate change, the green movement.

We know that world would have worked perfectly fine if we have not created the problem with the environment. Anytime I want to get something out of the environment, I have to make sure the environment is not affected. But which is where we are failing. I actually read a very interesting theory on Facebook or WhatsApp -- the theory was that the coronavirus had come out because of the 5G network. The presenter was so convincing, and he related all the coincidences, saying when electricity was invented, then we had this great flu, and all the pandemics were related to the development in electricity and how we use it. And the latest is this 5G.

And the Wuhan was the main center of that 5G. Now there may not be any basis in this theory, but one thing is entirely possible, that if we do not use the natural resources with understanding, then it can create disasters which we have not anticipated. The global warming, we are all now experiencing the results of them. So here Bhagawan said, you take care of the nature and nature will take care of you. How can I as an individual take care of the nature? Bhagavan said, if you act in the spirit of Yajna, that every action that you perform, if you analyze and see that it is for the greater good and not just for me.

As Ezra Plate says, we will produce more than we consume, we will give more than we take. If I have that attitude of Yajna, the sacrifice, I'm sacrificing my actions for the greater good. Because you are cherishing Devas and those Devas, those phenomenal forces will then cherish you, will nurture you.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the cosmic design of mutual nourishment. When Prajapati created beings, he also created Yajna - the principle of cooperative sacrifice. The message is striking: this spirit of giving was not an afterthought but was embedded into creation itself. The Devas (cosmic forces or our own senses) and humans exist in a relationship of mutual support. We nourish the Devas through our offerings, and they nourish us in return. This is not mere ritual - it is the fundamental operating system of existence.

The verse's warning is equally powerful: "He who enjoys what nature gives without returning is indeed a robber." In our modern context, this speaks directly to how we engage with our environment, our community, and our own bodies. When we take from the earth without replenishing, when we benefit from society without contributing, when we use our senses without caring for them, we become thieves in the cosmic order.

Reflect today on the balance of giving and receiving in your life. Consider your Devas - your senses, your environment, your community. What have you received from them today? What have you offered in return? Identify one relationship where you have been more of a taker than a giver - perhaps with nature, with a colleague, or even with your own body. How can you restore balance through conscious offering? Remember: the Yajna is your Kamadhenu, the wish-fulfilling cow. When you give in the spirit of sacrifice, all your legitimate desires can be fulfilled.

snippets.title: Day 45: Food and Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः |

अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः |

कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yajñaśiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarvakilbiṣaiḥ .

annādbhavanti bhūtāni parjanyādannasambhavaḥ .

karma brahmodbhavaṃ viddhi brahmākṣarasamudbhavam .
verseTranslations: The sages who enjoy the food that remains after the sacrifice is made are freed from all sin; but the selfish who spread their feast only for themselves feed on sin only.
All creatures are the product of food, food is the product of rain, rain comes by sacrifice, and sacrifice is the noblest form of action.
All action originates in the Supreme Spirit, which is Imperishable, and in sacrificial action the all-pervading Spirit is consciously present.
snippets.commentary:
So we are now discussing Chapter 3, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. We have seen so far that Bhagavan says: Sa Yagnaha Prajaha Srushtva Pura Uvacha Prajapati Anena Prasavishyadhvam Esha Vah Twishtakamadhu. In the beginning, when Prajapati created beings (Praja), he also created Yajna. So we are right now concerned about Praja. Praja means human beings.

So the Lord of Praja is Prajapati. The one who propagates progeny is Prajapati. So from that perspective all parents are Prajapati. So we are Prajapati for our Praja, for our children. So what we do for our children is not that we have given them life or created their existence, but we also have to create sustenance for them. So what we do is we give them education.

Then say this education will be your milch cow. Use this education to get whatever you want. Prajapati is mentioned in Hiranya Gharba Sukta in Dhruva. So the Rig Veda says that previously there was nothing but Hiranyagarbha. So Hiranya Garbha is something like the condition before the Big Bang. All the potentiality but no reality.

So there is a singularity or the potentiality but no reality. So that Hiranya Garbha then out of its own potential, its own creative urgent, creates a mind. This is also mentioned in Brihadaranya Upanishad and Chandogya Upanishad. Brihadaranyak Upanishad describes this Hirinyagarba. Thus he says, first there was nothing but death and hunger. There won't be Yajna. There is no communal projects. So when you do communal project, the unit is an individual action.

Karma Brahma Udbhavam. Now this is where I think it gets slightly complicated, as various translators have translated it very differently. The other translation I have seen which says Veda Karma is possible because of Veda. In other words, Veda instructs you how to act in this world.

Without that, there is no individual action. So it's a Karma Brahma Udbhavam with the know that Brahma Aksala Samudbhavam and that Veda or that Brahma is possible because of that imperishable Brahman, that imperishable self, then uncaused cause of all things, then imperishable Brahman is the root substratum for all that is happening. snippets.reflection:
These verses present one of the most beautiful cycles in the Gita: beings arise from food, food arises from rain, rain arises from Yajna, and Yajna arises from action rooted in Brahman. This is not mere poetry - it is a profound ecological and spiritual truth. Nothing exists in isolation. The all-pervading Brahman is eternally present in every sacrificial action, meaning that divinity is not distant but intimately woven into the fabric of daily life.

The teaching about eating is particularly instructive. The sages who eat the remnants of Yajna (yajna-shishtashinah) are freed from all sins, while those who cook only for themselves consume sin. This transforms the simple act of eating into a spiritual practice. When we see our food as prasad - the blessed remnant of cosmic cooperation involving sun, rain, earth, farmers, and countless beings - we eat with gratitude rather than entitlement. When we eat only to satisfy our own cravings, we disconnect from this sacred cycle.

Before your next meal today, pause to trace the journey of your food. Consider the rain that nourished the crops, the earth that held the seeds, the people who grew, transported, and prepared it. Recognize the all-pervading Brahman present in this cycle. Then eat as one receiving prasad from a Yajna, taking only what you need and with full appreciation. Notice how this awareness transforms not just your eating but your sense of connection to the web of existence. Ask yourself: In what other areas of life am I taking without acknowledging the vast network of support that makes my existence possible?

These verses present a striking contrast between two ways of living. One who does not participate in the revolving wheel of Yajna, who lives only for sensory gratification (indriyarama), is said to live in vain (mogham jivati). The word "mogham" is powerful - it means wasteful, futile, purposeless. But the one who meditates on the Self, who is content within (atma-triptah) and satisfied by the Self alone (atmanyeva santushta), has nothing left to accomplish. For such a person, neither action nor inaction has any personal motive.

This teaching invites us to examine the purpose behind our daily activities. Are we running on the hamster wheel of sensory pleasures - seeking the next meal, the next entertainment, the next acquisition - or are we contributing to the cosmic wheel of mutual nourishment? The indriayarama (one who delights in the senses) may appear successful by worldly standards, but Krishna declares such a life to be "aghayu" - sinful or unwholesome.

Today, observe your activities through this lens. At the end of the day, ask yourself: How many of my actions today contributed to the cosmic wheel of Yajna? How many were purely for sensory gratification? This is not about guilt but about awareness. Then contemplate: What would it feel like to need nothing, to be "atma-tripta" - satisfied within myself? Even if that state seems distant, can you identify one moment today when you felt complete without needing anything external? That glimpse is your guide. Cultivate it, and the desperate pursuit of sensory pleasure will naturally diminish.

snippets.title: Day 47: Work Without Attachment
snippets.sanskrit:
तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर |

कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः |

यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः |
snippets.transliteration:
tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara .

karmaṇaiva hi saṃsiddhimāsthitā janakādayaḥ .

yadyadācarati śreṣṭhastattadevetaro janaḥ .
verseTranslations: Therefore do thy duty perfectly, without care for the results, for he who does his duty disinterestedly attains the Supreme.
King Janaka and others attained perfection through action alone. Even for the sake of enlightening the world, it is thy duty to act;
For whatever a great man does, others imitate. People conform to the standard which he has set.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga and so far we have seen that act you must, because that is the nature of the Prakriti and you are part of the Prakriti. And Prakriti is maintained by each other's actions. And since you are part of that, you have a duty to perform your part in the Prakriti. How long do I have to continue performing these actions? Bhagavan said, as long as you are identified with the Prakriti. As long as I consider this body, mind and intellect to be me, I have to continue performing Niyata Karma, the karmas that are ordained by the roles which I take as part of this Prakriti.

So when I say this is me and now I take the role, I have duties to be performed. But when I get out of this identification with this Prakriti which is right now, this body, mind and intellect and identify with the self, then there is no action. Bhagawan says for such a person, one who is reveling in the self is satisfied with the self. For such a person there is no action because he does not have anything to gain which he not have gained already. Once I get out of this identification with the limited self and identify with this supreme self, there is nothing to be gained, nothing to be competing against, and nothing that I have to do to achieve what I'm trying to achieve right now, which is a complete bliss and a complete happiness. Because that the very nature of the self, the very nature of the self is Sat chit and Ananda.

Right now I'm trying to get out of this mortality. I'm 66, and my life insurance goes till 80. It will be better if I die before 80, because all these premiums I have paid all this life will be in vain if I die one day after 80. So I can see my mortality. People ask me, when are you going to retire? I say I have no plan.

But then I say, I am already 66. In the next 5 years I will be 71 -- will I be able to function? So whether I like it or not, I am bound by mortality. And what I'm trying to do is overcome that mortality. I'm seeing myself as mortal. I'm trying to become Sat -- ever existing.

I always find myself to be not knowledgeable enough. I don't know everything that I need to know. So I'm constantly in the quest for learning more and more and more -- that is Chit. The very nature of the self is all knowing. So there's nothing more to be known. And right now all I'm trying to get out of is the unhappy unconducive situation.

So I will be in Ananda once I realize that's my true nature. As long as you're identified with this Prakriti, you have to be bound by the laws of Prakriti -- that every constituent part has to function to make the Prakriti function. And therefore as long as you identified with the Prakrutti, you have to do your part. Once you identify with this self, none of the laws of Prakrutti are applicable to you. Prakrutti will sustain by itself. That's not your responsibility.

Because you say, "Okay, I'm satisfied with the self and I don't act -- then who will?" That's the one question everybody has. Who will do all these things which are happening in this world? He said, that's not your problem. Prakriti will take care of itself. You are in trouble right now.

You are in pain right now of this unhappiness. You want to get out of it. Once you get out of this identification, you have nothing else to do. There is no action for such a person. Say, till that time what am I supposed to do? Asaktaha Karya Samacha.

Till that time, you continue working, performing all your Niyata Karma. Except right now you are performing with attachment -- "People will recognize me, at least if I do something for my family, my family will say you're doing good" -- I'm doing it out of attachment. He said, just do without attachment. Continue doing what you are doing. Except Asaktah Karma Samachara, you do all your action without attachment.

With that minor adjustment in what you are doing, you will achieve that perfection. Many people in the past, Janak Adayah Janak and others Karma Nai vahi samsiddhaha, they have achieved this just by performing their actions diligently without any attachment. And they achieve the perfection. So could you, so should you. And then he said, now if I have come to the conclusion that I have done everything, that I really don't have to achieve anything, then what should I do? Still continue to act in this world, at least for the Loka Sangraha, for the welfare of the society.

Once I come to the conclusion that I have achieved everything I have achieved, you continue to contribute your contribution to the society, for the welfare of the society. That's because the same poison which you have right now, of your own ego, once you take that and dilute it, right now this ego is identified with this limited self. I call me this body, mind and intellect. I take this ego and dilute it with a larger arena, it will lose its bite. At a 1985 camp, at the end of it, there was a question-answer session. Somebody asked Swamiji, Swamiji, do you have ego?

What could be the answer? Swamiji, of course I have ego. He said, without ego, how can I control all of you? And now what we think is, if he has ego, I have ego. So what is the difference between you and I? Why am I wasting my one week and all these dollars to come here and spend time here?

He reinforces this with the powerful example of King Janaka, who achieved perfection (samsiddhi) through action alone while ruling a kingdom. Janaka did not retreat to a forest; he governed, made decisions, faced challenges - yet remained internally free. This is the gold standard of Karma Yoga.

snippets.reflection:
In these verses, Krishna speaks in the first person as the Supreme Lord, offering His own example as the ultimate teaching. "Na me parthasti kartavyam" - there is nothing in the three worlds that I must do, nothing unattained that I need to attain. Yet "varta eva cha karmani" - I am ever engaged in action. If the Lord of the universe, who has nothing to gain, continues to work tirelessly, what excuse do we have for inaction?

Krishna's reasoning is profound: if He were to stop working, the world would fall into chaos (sankarasya cha karta syam). The laws of nature - gravity, thermodynamics, the cycle of seasons - operate without a single day's rest because the cosmic intelligence behind them never takes a holiday. This is not labor as we know it; it is effortless, joyful engagement. The sun does not strain to shine; it simply expresses its nature.

Today, contemplate what it would mean to work as Krishna works - with nothing to prove, nothing to gain, yet fully engaged for the welfare of all. Notice how much of your work stress comes from attachment to outcomes or the sense that you must accomplish something to be worthy. Now imagine working without that burden - acting from fullness rather than lack. Choose one task today and approach it as Krishna approaches His cosmic duties: with total engagement but zero anxiety about results. Ask yourself: If I had already attained everything I needed, would I still do this work? If yes, do it in that spirit. If no, examine why you are doing it at all.
