The Prakriti will only follow the laws if I am there to support these laws. Sankrasi Chakarta Syam Upahanyami Imaha Prajaha. This teaching connects to our dharma and duty, which we sometimes find difficult because of our cultural burden and the complexity of the caste system inherited from hundreds of years.
snippets.reflection:
These verses contain a crucial teaching for anyone who has gained spiritual understanding: do not disturb the minds of others who are still attached to their actions. The wise person (vidvan) should work alongside the ignorant (avidvan), performing the same actions but with a different inner attitude. This is not hypocrisy - it is compassion. Abruptly telling someone immersed in worldly pursuits that "all action is bondage" may paralyze rather than liberate them.

The revelation in verse 27 is equally important: "Prakriteh kriyamanani gunaih karmani sarvashah" - all actions are performed by the gunas of Prakriti (nature). It is only the ego-deluded person (ahankara-vimudhatma) who thinks "I am the doer." This is a fundamental shift in perspective. You are not the doer; the qualities of nature - sattva, rajas, and tamas - are interacting with each other. Your body-mind is an instrument through which these forces operate.

Today, practice observing your actions as the play of the gunas rather than the products of "I." When you feel energetic and clear, recognize sattva at work. When you feel driven and restless, see rajas. When you feel dull and resistant, observe tamas. Instead of saying "I am lazy" or "I am productive," try saying "Tamas is predominant right now" or "Rajas is active." This subtle shift dissolves the grip of ego on action. Also, consider: Is there someone in your life who is earnestly engaged in their work, even if with attachment? Rather than correcting their philosophy, can you inspire them by your example of engaged yet detached action?

snippets.title: Day 50: Understanding the Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः |

प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु |

मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा |
snippets.transliteration:
tattvavittu mahābāho guṇakarmavibhāgayoḥ .

prakṛterguṇasammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇakarmasu .

mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi saṃnyasyādhyātmacetasā .
verseTranslations: But he, O Mighty One, who understands correctly the relation of the Qualities to action, is not attached to the act, for he perceives that it is merely the action and reaction of the Qualities among themselves.
Those who do not understand the Qualities are interested in the act. Still, the wise man who knows the truth should not disturb the mind of him who does not.
Therefore, surrendering thy actions unto Me, thy thoughts concentrated on the Absolute, free from selfishness and without anticipation of reward, with mind devoid of excitement, begin thou to fight.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Actions. And so far we have learned that act we must because we are part of this Prakriti. The Prakriti functions because each individual constituent parts work with each other. Just as we have seen in a cycle of rain during the summer, the ocean water becomes clouds and then clouds become rain and the cycle continues. So there is a cycle in this Prakriti which is dependent on its constituent parts, the Prakriti. This manifest world works because each constituent part work with each other.

We being part of this Prakriti, we have our own duties and we need to fulfill their duties. So the advice is perform all your ordained duties, duties which come with the roles which I take in my life. I take a role of a father, role of a husband, role of an employer, an employee, a son. Whatever role I take, I should perform those actions. So once I understood that this is a part of my duty, I have to continue acting. But then I have come to realize that these actions create bondage.

The bondage of actions and reactions, the reward and punishment. So how do I get out of this? Bhagwan said, act without attachment. If you act with the sense of doership, you are responsible for your actions. And therefore either you will get the credit for it or a punishment for it. So act without attachment and you will not be bound by your actions.

And then the next thing we have seen is that even though I consider that I have nothing more to do now I have achieved everything I need to achieve, it will still continue to act because other people are following your example. As human beings, we have tendency to follow others to act in our life. We need some role model, we need some guidance, we need some standards. And those standards are other people whom I consider to be my role models. I follow them and I become role model for others. And therefore, at any given time I should be acting in appropriate manner.

So others who are following me get the right role model standard to act for themselves. Once I considered that I'm not attached And I'm working. I'm working for the Loka Sangram, for the welfare of the society. Bhagawan said, even you can look at my own example. As the Creator, I have nothing to gain in these three worlds. But I continue to work as the law giver and law enforcer in this universe.

This universe is never without laws. There are no weakens in our natural laws. Law of physics doesn't stop functioning because now it's the leap year on 29th of February. I don't know what to do. There is no exception in nature because the Creator remained as the lawgiver and law enforcer in this universe. So we want to look at I as the Creator.

Even though I have nothing to gain, I continue to work. Because if I do not work, this world will cease to exist. The cycle of creation, maintenance and destruction continues because the Creator continues to support it. That substratum which creates the substratum for this universe is always present in the universe to function. I, as the part of the Parakrati, should follow that lead and do the same. Continue to act even when I don't consider that I have anything to gain just for the welfare of the society.

Even when you consider that other people are acting with attachment. Now I have come to the conclusion that the best way to act in this world is one. Do my duties as ordained by my roles I play, but act without attachment. So have no attachment to your actions and perform actions. But I know that the world is not made up of all those detached sannyasis. The people needs motivation for them to act.

Their motivation may be the goals they want to achieve in their life, their attachment to their actions, their passions. I, as the Gnani, have a responsibility to make sure that they don't get confused by this high philosophy. So the next verse says, Na Buddhi Bhedam Janayed Agnanam Karma Sanginam. It's a great responsibility on a person who has achieved knowledge that with my knowledge I don't confuse others. You know, in our Gita class, the one common thing we hear is, "I'm more confused now than I was before I came to this class." The more you know, the more you realize how much you don't know.

And that's a biggest responsibility in the part of the wise person. To guide the society in a right manner so that people don't take the wrong message from your advice. One person was an alcoholic, so his father or teacher wanted to give an example and said, "Let me show you what alcohol does to you." He takes a glass of alcohol, puts a little worm in it, and the worm obviously after a while dies. "Did you see what happened?" "Yes, yes, I understood what happened."

"If I drink alcohol, all the worms in my stomach will die!" Another person was trying to find out where the brain of a cockroach is. He was a researcher, obviously. "I'm going to find out where the brain of the cockroach is in his body." So he puts food in front of the cockroach; the cockroach runs towards the food. So he figures out the cockroach does have a brain.

Now let me find out where the brain is. He breaks one leg -- the cockroach limps towards the food. It still has a brain; it was not in that leg. He breaks another leg -- it still limps towards the food. So the brain was not in that leg either. He breaks the last leg, and the cockroach can't move towards the food. He says, "I figured out the brain was in the last leg which I broke."

From your observations and conclusions and the advice that you hear, unless you're prepared for that, you may come to the wrong conclusion. So it's the great responsibility on the teacher and the wise people to guide the society appropriately without confusing them. Nabuddi Vedam Janayat Agnaram Karma Sanghi naam. The ignorant people who are working in this world with attachment -- you should not create confusion in their minds so they stop working. There was a time when some philosophies made people give up everything and become a sannyasi or a monk. Is that the real goal of life? Well, after all is figured out, society just cannot function like that.

If all the young people become sannyasis, who would support the Social Security for people like me who will be retiring? We need people to work so you should not unsettle them. Josayat Sarvakarmani Vidhvan Yuktaha Samacharan For a Vidhvan person, the one who is knowledgeable and is Yukta who is balanced. He knows how to motivate people. And if they are working with an attachment, encourage them to work. Joshayed Sarva -- somehow engage all of them in actions so that activity doesn't stop.

Because if they are acting, there is a chance that sometime they will understand what is the right way to act. Swamiji gives an example that if I am driving in a wrong direction, if I stop driving, I will never reach the right destination. But if I continue driving and then ask somebody and find a direction, then continue driving, I will reach my destination all the time. The operative word is "driving." As long as I keep driving and then correct my direction, I'll find the destination. So it is up to us not to confuse our children.

People who listen to us and say this is of no value. What are you going to gain in life? And that's not the way to guide the society. So for anybody who has the criticism that Hinduism teaches pessimism -- it teaches action consistently, all throughout your life. There is no discussion of retirement here. Bhagavan says, please make sure as a Vidvan person that all people are engaged in actions, because activity is the signature of nature.

Prakrutehe kriyamanani gunaihi karmani sarvasah. Then where is this confusion coming between the one who is acting with an attachment, one who is acting without an attachment. Why the one acting without an attachment is more efficient. One with acting with an attachment is less efficient. The reason for me to act without attachment is not to detach myself from what's happening but to become more efficient in what I'm doing. The more I get attached, the more

My mental energy will be dissipated into the worries about what will come out of my actions. That I will be employing one third of my energy into what may come out of my actions. One-third of my energy goes into what happened last time when I did this, and only one-third of my energy is available for the present. "The last proposal I did, I did not win it. Am I going to win this one?" That will take away my complete focus on what needs to be done. Therefore detachment is necessary so that I focus on the present only and function fully in it. But where is this confusion coming for me where I get attached to my actions and it says this ignorance about how the world works. The actions in this world are working by their own nature. Prakrutehi kriyamanani gunehi karmani sarvasah. All actions performed in this universe are performed because of the gunas of the prakriti of the objects. But I on the other hand think I am the doer.

Ahankara removed atma out of my ignorance by my ego. Karta aham ithimanyate I think I am the doer. Even though guna gunesuvarthantaha -- the gunas interact with the gunas -- we are not islands by ourselves. We cannot function by ourselves. If everybody moves away from this town and I am the only one left, for a few days it will be very fun because I could walk into Starbucks, nobody can stop me, get a cup of coffee myself, go to the food aisle and get whatever grocery I want. After some time, there won't be anything to do for me, because there's nobody else doing anything for me.

I am surviving because other people are doing their part. Therefore I'm functioning as I'm functioning. Once I come to that conclusion -- that things are working because these constituent parts of this Prakriti are working with each other -- then I will not develop the ego that I am the doer. I go to the lab, take hydrogen and oxygen, put them together, and they become water. Now I say, "I created water." No, no, Neil -- hydrogen and oxygen acted on each other and they behaved as per their qualities to create water.

You are just a mere agent to put them together. So you are not the doer. You are just a Nimitta, Matra, Ahanka, ra, Vimu, dhatma, Karta, ahamiti many. He starts thinking that I am the doer. Whereas the actions are performed by the Prakruti by its own nature. Everything in this Prakriti has sattva, rajas and Tamas.

The basic ingredients in each thing. Those ingredients when they come in contact with each other they function according to their own nature. So two atoms come together. No atomic scientist to do engineered to do anything. Those atoms will act with each other according to their own gunas. Prakrutehe guna, Sammudaha, sajante guna, karma.

So one who is ignorant about this nature of Prakriti in the Gunas of Prakriti he gets attached to the actions. When I do something and then I get success. I'm now attached to my actions. Because I think I achieved this success. I forget that what I submitted as my project There are about 18 people in my office has to work on it.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 30 is one of the most complete instructions on Karma Yoga in the entire Gita: "Mayi sarvani karmani sannyasya adhyatma-chetasa, nirashir nirmamo bhutva yudhyasva vigata-jvarah." Surrender all actions to Me, with mind fixed on the Self, free from desire, free from the sense of "mine," and fight without the fever of anxiety. Every element of this instruction is practical: offer actions to the Divine, keep awareness on your true nature, release craving for results, drop possessiveness, and act without mental agitation.

The phrase "vigata-jvarah" (without fever) is particularly evocative. Fever represents the restless, burning anxiety that accompanies attachment. When we are attached to outcomes, we experience the fever of anticipation, the fever of worry, the fever of disappointment. Krishna prescribes action without this fever - calm, steady engagement with whatever needs to be done.

Today, before you begin your work, pause and consciously offer your actions to something greater - God, the universe, the welfare of all beings. Set your intention: "These actions are not for my ego's gratification but are offered as service." Throughout the day, check in: Is there "fever" in my work? Am I anxious about outcomes? When you notice the fever rising, remember: "Guna guneshu vartanta" - the qualities of nature are simply interacting with the qualities of nature. You, the witness, are untouched. Then return to action with renewed calm. In the evening, reflect: How did working with this attitude change my experience of the day?

snippets.title: Day 51: Following This Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः |

ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् |

सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि |
snippets.transliteration:
ye me matamidaṃ nityamanutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ .

ye tvetadabhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam .

sadṛśaṃ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛterjñānavānapi .
verseTranslations: Those who always act in accordance with My precepts, firm in faith and without cavilling, they too are freed from the bondage of action.
But they who ridicule My word and do not keep it, are ignorant, devoid of wisdom and blind. They seek but their own destruction.
Even the wise man acts in character with his nature; indeed, all creatures act according to their natures. What is the use of compulsion then?
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. So we have seen in last few verses. Bhagavan says that Prakrute, he, kriyamanani, gunaihi, karmani, sarvasa, all actions are performed by Prakriti. Ahankara, vimu, dhatma, karta, aham ithimanyade. But the one who is deluded by ego, he thinks he is the doer. So this is something Bhagavan is trying to clarify, which we have learnt in chapter two, that Purusha is the enabler.

Prakriti functions when Purusha and Prakriti come together. But all actions belong to Prakriti. There is no activity in I, the Purusha that we consider our own self, the I which last time we talked of will and free will. German philosopher Schopenhauer wrote a book called the World as Will and Representation. So this will is the force which enables the Prakriti to represent itself. So here we are saying the actions are performed in Prakrut.

There is something similar to the situation in my house, where there are several gadgets which generate heat, light, sound, and pictures, which make the house lively and livable. But all this equipment is only functioning when it's electrified. So if a bulb somehow gets this ego that "I am the one who gives light," then the electricity as the guru can come and tell that bulb, "No, no. All activities are performed by the equipment, but not because of themselves -- because of the electricity functioning through them." But activity does not belong to electricity. Whether the bulb is not functioning well, or is dim or bright --

that does not belong to the electricity; it belongs to the bulb itself. See, the bulb is getting jealous -- "That other bulb is brighter, and I am dimmer, and I have to do something to be brighter." All that belongs to Prakriti. But once it's first of all know that you are not the doer. Your dimness or brightness belongs to the equipment and not to you, the electricity.

Ahankara Vimudhatma Karta Aham Iti Manyate -- he thinks that he is the doer. But one who knows the reality, the truth about the gunas and Karma -- Tattva-vit Tu Mahabhaho Guna Karma Vibhagayoh -- he knows the gunas of the Prakriti: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas, and their functions. The function of Sattva is existence and knowledge.

Rajas is activity and Tamas is inertia. They have their own gunas, things which are made up of these three gunas in Prakriti. They function according to those gunas and permutation combinations of those gunas. Guna Gunesajjade Knowing that the qualities of my senses and the sense objects outside, when they come together, when the activity takes place, as we have seen last time, that the senses create sensation on the mind, the sensation creates the perception in mind. That perception conception of that object, that conception of that object. If it is in line with my tendencies, then it creates action.

If it is not in line with my tendency, I won't even pay attention. There are so many sensations come to me, but I am only aware of those I am paying attention to. And I am paying attention to those only which are in line with my tendencies. So Bhagavan says, Guna Guneshu Vartan Tah. My guna is this limited being and the guna of the objects outside, they are acting with each other, but I remains uninvolved. So the verse we have seen which is almost a summary of Karma Yoga in two lines.

Bhagavan says how to practice Karma Yoga. Mai sarvani Karmani Sanyasya Adhyatma Cheta Saha Nirasi Nirmamo Bhatva Yidyaswa Vigatha Juraha. Renouncing all actions in me with mind centered on yourself. It's like that electricity guru telling the bulb, "You offer all your light to me. It is me who enables you to give light. You just focus on your own self."

What is your reality? Nirasi Nirmamo Bhatva. You do not have any expectation what will come out of me. So don't consider your past achievement is yours. All that was happening for that bulb is because of electricity. As long as electricity is functioning, whether it was giving a good light or a bad light or it was performing according to the expectation of the home owner or not.

All that is because of the electricity. Whatever is coming out of you as actions, devote all of them to me, the enabler. So here the me, as Bhagavan said, is Your own self, your true self which is limitless. You are binding it into your own limitedness. You offer all your actions to me and do not have any expectations. Do not dwell in future.

What will happen in future? Will my actions generate good results or not? Will I achieve something or not? All that you leave to the Karma Phaladata, the giver of fruits, and remain Nirmamaha. All you accomplished in the past is also past. We have a great tendency, most of the older cultures especially, to dwell in the past and say we used to have a great culture.

Look at our culture in Mahabharata. Look at our culture in Rama's time. That doesn't really matter. What are you doing right now matters. Your culture right now. Are we the most cultured people on this planet?

Do we have the right values or are we corrupt people? That matters what we are doing right now, not what we did in the past. Not we may do in the future. So Bhagawan said Nirasi Nirmama Bhutva Yudhyasva Vigata Jwaraha. You engage in your activity. Inactivity is not an option for you.

You engage in your activity without having these agitations in your mind which is like a fever will rob your energy. This agitations about what will I get in the future and what are my accomplishments in the past. Forget about all of that. Become completely healthy to function in present. That's basically a summary of Karma Yoga. Act in present, do not worry about the future.

Do not regret what you did or did not do or accomplish in the past. And engage yourself in actions. Devote all actions to the enabler, the self in you. You can only act as long as you are living. You will not be able to act when you die. After your death, there is no activity for this limited body.

So therefore offer all your actions to the enabler, the consciousness, your own self. And then Bhagavan says, Yeme Matamin, this is my opinion whether you like it or not. But I'm telling you, this is my Eme Matamidam Nityam Anuthisthanti Manavah. Those people who follow these teachings of mine. This teaching which I have just taught you, the Karma Yoga, how to act in this world, Offer your actions to the Supreme Self, the supreme will. Our desire is to live.

So there is a will to live, a will to act. Free will is something when I have more choices and I can choose one of them, that's a free will. If I have a Desire to play outside as a child. But my mother said that you have to do homework. Well if I can decide it's a free will. But if my mother decides then no, no.

You can go out to play right now but do your homework. That's not a free will. So Bhagavan says that you have free will. You have a very narrow window of free will. Either you can choose my teachings of how to act in this world, or you can follow other opinions about how you can get happiness through your actions. So we do have a concept in the last time we argued about whether we have concept of free.

We do have a concept of free. We call it Purushartha Purushasthana Prarabdha. Prarabdhdha is something I have no control over. There is no free will there in Prarabdha. The situation I'm facing is because of my past actions. Those past actions go as long as I can think about my existence.

This life, previous life, life previous to that, whatever that is. That's Prarabdha situation is presented to me by my Prarabdha. The way I act in this situation is my Purushart. I don't have a complete free will that I can do whatever I want Because I can't change the situation. But I do have free will to act within the circumstances. See, will of an individual is always limited.

A complete free will is the universal will. The will of God as we call it in our religious terminology. Universal will is free. I have a limited free will and I can exercise that free will. So Bhagawan said those who exercise their narrow free will to follow my teachings Eme matamidam nityam Anuthisthati Manava who constantly follow my teachings. Sraddhavantaha Anusuyantaha muchante tiyapi Karmabhi.

Those who follow my teachings with Shraddha without raising trivial doubts it is my opinion that they will also achieve the liberation from Karma Naiskarma Siddhe. They will achieve the final goal. So here couple of things we can look at. What Bhagavan is saying is that you may have your own doubts whether this is really workable. This Karma Yoga we had been talking about. Act without any expectations.

Don't have any regrets about what you achieved all the way. Unless I have a passion to achieve something. If I have a fire in my belly to go and get it how am I going to get it? Unless I have this passion to achieve and I'LL do anything to achieve it based on my tendencies. Bhagawan said, put all this thing aside. Don't raise those trivial doubts in your mind.

If you subside those trivial doubts in your mind and have Sraddha, have faith that this will work and then you follow all the time. Nityam, Anuti, Sthunti, Manava. Those people who practice, practice that narrow free will to take my advice and have faith in it and follow, they will also be released from all karma, all actions, all sorrows, all unhappiness. We may have heard before, before Gita came along, there were so many other maths as we have discussed there Sat Dashara, Samari, Swarvadi, Samarani, Swarvadi. Some say going to heaven is the only goal. And others say the liberation is the goal.

There are so many Mata. But I say Krishna says this is my Mata. You may think this is so simplistic. People say to achieve the Samadhi, Yogi has to practice for a long period of time. And you are saying Samatvam Yoga, Uchathe, just a balanced mind and you're done. So you may have lots of doubts.

But if your faith in my teachings and follow, you shall achieve that nice karma. So we have discussed many times this word Shraddha. Is it the blind faith that Krishna cannot be wrong, that I have to follow him whether I like it or not? We have come across several definitions of Shraddha. One Swamiji gives in Vivekachudamani.

He says, my belief in what I do not know, something I do not know. I do not know whether Bhagavan exists or not. That's my belief that yes, there is a superior power. Even though I do not know what that power is right now. But I have believed that I may come to know sometime. If I work at it diligently, I will come to know that power, that supreme power.

What I believe in is Shraddha. If I have a belief in something which I do not have direct knowledge of right now, the faith that I will come to know -- then my belief is correct. Swamiji says that's Shraddha. That's Swamiji's definition. But Shankaracharya's definition is: Guru Vedanta Vakya Adishu Vishvasah Shraddha -- my trust in the words of my teacher and scriptures.

Scriptures in a sense, the books of knowledge which I have trusted. Upanishads, Vedanta, Bible, whatever you consider book of knowledge, if you have trust in that, that's Sraddha.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna presents here a clear choice with clear consequences. Those who follow His teaching with shraddha (faith) and without anasuya (fault-finding) are freed from the bondage of karma. Those who reject it, carp at it, or fail to practice it are declared "nashtan" - lost or destroyed, deluded in all their knowledge. Strong words, but Krishna speaks them to emphasize that this is not mere philosophy to debate but a practical path to follow.

The teaching on shraddha deserves special attention. Shraddha is not blind faith but trusting confidence - the willingness to act on a teaching before you have fully verified it through experience. It is like trusting a doctor's prescription before the medicine has cured you. Without this initial trust, no experiment can begin. Equally important is being "anasuyanto" - free from the tendency to find fault, to argue, to resist. This does not mean uncritical acceptance, but rather an open, receptive attitude that allows the teaching to work.

Examine your relationship with these teachings today. Do you approach them with shraddha - a genuine willingness to experiment and experience? Or do you find yourself arguing, doubting, finding reasons why they might not work for you? Notice that Krishna does not ask for blind belief but for sincere practice. He says "anutishthanti" - those who follow, practice, live by these teachings. Today, choose one principle from Karma Yoga - perhaps acting without attachment to results, or offering your work as Yajna - and practice it with full shraddha, suspending your inner critic for just one day. Let your experience, not your arguments, be the test.

snippets.title: Day 52: Likes and Dislikes
snippets.sanskrit:
इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ |

श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāgadveṣau vyavasthitau .

śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt .

arjuna uvāca .
verseTranslations: The love and hate which are aroused by the objects of sense arise from Nature; do not yield to them. They only obstruct the path.

It is better to do thine own duty, however lacking in merit, than to do that of another, even though efficiently. It is better to die doing one's own duty, for to do the duty of another is fraught with danger.
Arjuna asked: My Lord! Tell me, what is it that drives a man to sin, even against his will and as if by compulsion?
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of actions. In other words, we are trying to understand how can I transform my actions which are binding me right now into liberating entities right now, every action I do, I am bound by results which are either good or bad. And this cycle continues. How can I transform this cycle of acting and reacting into liberating me? The goal is that the more I act, the more liberated I become. But right now, the more I act, the more bound I am -- the more I seek happiness, the more I collect unhappiness. As we discussed last time, the Sukha is something which is defined by absence of dukkha.

As long as I have dukkha of any kind, sukha cannot be experienced. 99% of my body is very healthy except my heart. snippets.reflection:
These verses address one of life's most frustrating experiences: knowing what is right but being unable to do it. Arjuna's question in verse 36 resonates across millennia: "What is it that drives a person to sin, even against their will, as if compelled by force?" We all know this experience - the diet we break, the angry word we speak, the commitment we abandon. It feels as though some force within us overpowers our best intentions.

Before answering, Krishna identifies the real obstacles: raga and dvesha - attraction and aversion, likes and dislikes. These are not external enemies but internal tendencies embedded in our relationship with sense objects. They are "paripanthinau" - obstructers on the path. And then the powerful teaching on swadharma: "Shreyaan swadharmo vigunah" - better is one's own dharma, though imperfect, than the dharma of another well performed. Even death in one's own dharma is better, for another's dharma is fraught with fear.

Today, map your raga-dveshas in one area of life. What do you find yourself irresistibly attracted to? What do you instinctively avoid or resist? These are your specific obstacles. Do not fight them directly - that only strengthens them. Instead, acknowledge them: "This is raga operating. This is dvesha arising." Then return to your swadharma - your own natural path of action. Ask yourself: What is truly MY work, my calling, my nature? Am I pursuing it, or am I chasing someone else's dharma because it looks more glamorous or profitable? Remember: "Paradharmo bhayavahah" - another's path is dangerous. Find your own, and walk it imperfectly but authentically.

snippets.reflection:
Krishna's answer to Arjuna's question is direct and unsparing: "Kama esha krodha esha" - it is desire, it is anger. These two, born of rajas (the quality of passion and activity), are the great enemies. Desire is called "mahashana" (all-devouring) and "mahapapma" (greatly sinful). It cannot be satisfied - like fire, the more fuel you add, the more it blazes. This is the force that compels us to act against our own wisdom.

The three analogies in verse 38 are particularly instructive. Desire covers wisdom like smoke covers fire (easily dispersed), like dust covers a mirror (requires some effort to clean), and like the womb covers an embryo (requires time and natural development to reveal what is within). These represent sattvic, rajasic, and tamasic levels of covering. Some desires are light veils that a moment of clarity can disperse. Others are accumulated dust requiring sustained effort. The deepest ones are like the womb - they will only release through a natural process of maturation and cannot be forced.

Examine your desires today using these three categories. Which desires in your life are like smoke - easily recognized and dispersed with a little awareness? Which are like dust on a mirror - requiring consistent effort and discipline to clear? Which are like the womb - so deeply embedded that only patient spiritual growth over time will transform them? Do not be discouraged by the deeper ones; even recognizing them is progress. For today, focus on one "smoke-like" desire - something you can see clearly is not serving you. Can you let even a small breeze of wisdom disperse it? Remember: you are not trying to destroy desire entirely, but to stop feeding the fire that makes it your master.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. All of us realize that we are defined by our actions. You meet a new person, the first thing you do is obviously judge the person by the way he looks and way he dresses and way he talks and way he acts. But the million dollar question we ask is what do you do? And whatever response comes, you will either enhance your judgment about that person or you will reduce the judgment which you have made by just outward appearance. You know, long time ago, when I first joined Chinmaya Mission in Houston, I met a person in a class called Rambhai.

Rambhai -- in Gujarat, it's a pretty simple name. So well, very old fellow, he looks also very modest, in conversation also. He actually came to me because he thought I was asking some smart questions in the class. So he obviously already had a better judgment of me. I'm making the judgment just based on what he looks like.

And then I finally asked, "Rambhai, what do you do?" He said, "I'm a structural engineer. I'm a research engineer, so I don't do normal building structures. I'm basically a researcher." The more I talked to him, I found out the guy has about three PhDs in structural engineering. He was actually awarded a PhD when he was in his undergraduate class.

He was doing his BE when he found a flaw in the way structural engineers for high-rise buildings -- like 15 or 80-story buildings -- calculate the structural load. He found the flaw in that theory while he was in his undergraduate class. As soon as I heard that, for me, Rambhai became a completely different person. I always remember that when I judge somebody, is he not another Rambhai? So actions we know are very important, but not all the time. We can act appropriately.

Even knowing that my actions will describe me, will define me, we don't really do everything right in our life. So we have gone through the whole chapter about what right action is, how actions work, what is the right way to act. But in the end, the question came back, as Arjuna asked: even though sometimes I know what is right, I can't do what is right. Papam Charati Purushah -- we have cultural baggage when we say Papa.

We consider something sinful in a sense, something only the sinners do. As we have defined in our discussion in Vedanta, that which creates a negative impression on my mind is a Papa. That which binds me more and more to these limitations is a Papa. That which liberates me is Punya. That which puts a positive impression on my mind, which encourages me, inspires me is Punya. That which dejects me and depresses me is Papa.

When I'm depressed and go through all that, I'm going through hell. So Papa leads me to hell. So what is it that puts me in this misery of life? Even though sometimes I know this isn't the right thing to do. And most of the time, at least in my life, I can tell you most of the time when I took wrong decisions or did wrong things, I already had the inkling in my heart that this may not be a right thing to do. But we did it anyway.

Because everybody says it's okay. My mind says, "If you don't do it, you will be left out," whatever it is. But we did it anyway. So you say, Atha Kena Prayukto Ayam Papam Charati Purushah Anichchhann Api -- he doesn't want to do it, but Baladiva Niyojitah -- as if he is compelled by some force which is not allowing him to do what he thinks is right.

Kama Esha Krodha Esha Rajoguna Samudbhavaha -- not really a big revelation to us, but still, we never make the connection. When we do something wrong, we immediately transfer the blame to somebody else. "I shouldn't have done it, but what can I do? Circumstances are like that. I wouldn't have been angry had he not pushed my buttons." We right away transfer the blame to others and kind of redeem ourselves: "I'm actually a nice guy, and I normally don't do that."

But because of that, we have no chance to improve. What this basically says is: you have a chance to improve. Realize what the source of your mistakes is. There is Kama Esha Krodha Esha -- it is your own desire and anger which led you to do what you thought was not really right. Rajoguna Samudbhavaha -- these are born of Rajoguna, the quality of activity and passion. Going back to actions: they are very important.

I need to how to act. Same activity, if it is not done properly will lead me to desire and anger. Then that will lead me to commit wrong actions. Therefore it is even more important how to do the right actions. So first thing we have seen is do for the greater good. Do without attachment.

That part is very important. That attachment creates karma and Krodha that attachment created the desire and anger. As you'll learn in the second chapter, the constant thinking of something creates attachment. That attachment then creates desire. Then that desire creates the anger. The same thought is transforming from constant thought to the desire to the anger.

And then buddhi nasha. So Bhagavan said kama erudesa mahasana Mahapatma. Once you are overwhelmed by that flow of thoughts, you can't really get out of it and you continue to commit wrong thing. We have seen all the Hindi movies -- when he starts with stealing a loaf of bread and then he becomes a great Amitabh Bachchan-style angry young man. Once you are in that frame of mind and do not know how to get out, it will just take you further in that direction.

So what is it that I knew something is not right and this is right, but I cannot what is it that's clouding my right thinking? So the next verse says dumena abriate vahanihe. Just as the fire is covered by smoke, fire is there, but there is smoke. Where there is a smoke, there is fire. Smoke cannot be there without fire. But I can't see the fire because the smoke smoke is veiling that fire.

Yatha darshao malena cha. Just as mirror is covered by dirt, mirror is there. But I can't see the reflection. Anytime you take a shower, if your bathroom doesn't have good exhaust, the mirror will be covered with water vapor. You won't be able to see your reflection till you wipe it off. And just as the embryo is covered by the placenta, the womb --

Tatha Tena Idam Avrutam -- by that, this is covered. What is covered? Wisdom. By what? By Kama and Krodha. Three examples are given. As Swamiji says, in our scriptures unnecessary repetition is not allowed.

Therefore, Bhagavan ved Vyas would give three examples. Just one simple idea. That knowledge is covered veiled by something. It gives that the veiling of various categories. Just as we have seen everything in three categories, veiling is also of three categories. Sattvik, rajastic and tamastic.

The first is Tume na vriya te bhanehe. Fire is covered by smoke, but it's very thin veil. A little breeze will remove that smoke and you will see the fire. It's like a sattvic veiling. My desire to do good for the society, my desire to do good for my family, I may get trouble for that, but there was sattvic desire. And then when I realize that society really doesn't need my help or I'm not capable of doing it, that desire will go away.

That's still availing. Sattva still binds you. By the happiness it gives you. The sattvic desires are still bonded, the golden chain, but still a chain. But it can be removed easily with little knowledge, little brushing up of what is right and wrong, it can go away. The next, just that dust covers the mirror.

This is a rajasic desire. I want to achieve this, I want to acquire this. Those don't go away with little breeze. You literally need some physical actions to remove the dust from the mirror. It requires a little more effort. You have to really have the resolve that I need to get out of this desire.

Then only you can get out of it. Just by shining a little knowledge. Coming to Gita class Sunday morning doesn't take away Monday morning. I need to get that because it's a Yatha Darsho Malayana. So it's a rajastic desire which is veiling my knowledge of what, what to do and what not to do, what is right and what is wrong, what is truth and what is untruth, what is permanent and what is temporary. That wisdom which I have is veiled by this desire.

Yatha Ulbena Avrito Garbhaha -- as the womb covers the embryo. We know, and at least men can infer, how difficult it is for the embryo to mature and come out. It's not something which can be done lightly. It takes its own time and maturity. And then whatever the pain you have to go through to reveal what the truth is, which is the baby. So when my desires are tamasic for the sensual pleasures, then those do not, even with firm resolve, just goes away. It really requires a long term discipline which you have to mature yourself out of that.

A child cannot get rid of their desire to play with toys. He has to mature out of that. So those are stronger, deeper desires which you just have to give time, letting nature take its own course. Just like animals evolving -- Swami Purushottamananda told me that on the lap of Mother Nature they don't do any karma, so they don't have any Papa or Punya. They don't have any baggage of this is right and this is wrong.

Mother Nature gradually takes care of them. So if you are in that category, let the time take its own course. Let the Bhagavan take care of it. Tena idam Avrutam that Kamayesha Krodhayasa is veiling this knowledge. Next was now defined what this and that is Avrutam Gnanam Etena Gnanino Nitya Vayrina Even a wise person's knowledge and for all practical purpose. Vedanta says we are all wise people.

Actually at the core of our being we know we are sat chit Ananda. But this wailing is stopping me to realize that. So Avrutam Gnanam this knowledge which is instinctively mine that who I am is veiled by Nitya Vereena. These constant enemies which are present in my mind Kamaru pena kaun the analayana cha this constant enemy present in my mind in the form of Kamarupa in the desire no matter how hard I try to get peace of my mind and we constantly sing my gimme vaidauri Santi Apnea Santi is what we are looking for all our life. But Santi we never got. Because this constant enemy is right there.

He's not leaving me alone. Other enemies you can leave, but this enemy is within you. It's not something you can fulfill one time and be done with. Desire is like that -- it's not that you fulfill it once and you're done. Duspurena -- insatiable.

You can put a little ghee in the fire and say, "Now we are done with it" -- but the more you put ghee, the more it flares up. So in other words, this is a losing battle for us. We already know that the more I feed my desire, the more it is going to flare up.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna now reveals where the enemy resides: "Indriyani mano buddhir asya adhishthanam" - the senses, mind, and intellect are the seats of desire. Through these instruments, desire deludes the embodied soul by covering its wisdom. This is strategic information for the spiritual warrior. The enemy operates through our own equipment - our senses that perceive, our mind that desires, and our intellect that rationalizes.

The hierarchy presented in verse 42 is crucial: the senses are powerful, but the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and superior to the intellect is "He" - the Self, the Atman. This tells us where to make our stand. If we fight desire at the level of the senses, we are fighting at the outermost fortress where desire is strongest. If we retreat to the mind, we have better ground. At the intellect, we have strategic advantage. But established in the Self, we are beyond desire's reach entirely.

Today, practice this strategic retreat in real-time. When you notice desire arising, first observe: Where is it operating? Is it at the sense level (craving what you see, hear, taste)? At the mind level (emotional wanting)? At the intellect level (rationalizing why you should have it)? Then consciously move inward. From the senses, retreat to the mind: "This is just a sensation." From the mind, retreat to the intellect: "Is this truly good for me?" From the intellect, retreat to the Self: "I am the witness of all this - complete, lacking nothing." You may not fully establish in the Self, but even momentary contact with that deeper identity weakens desire's grip. Practice this hierarchy of withdrawal whenever desire arises today.

snippets.title: Day 55: Karma Yoga
snippets.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना |
snippets.transliteration: evaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā saṃstabhyātmānamātmanā .
verseTranslations: Thus, O Mighty-in-Arms, knowing Him to be beyond the intellect and, by His help, subduing thy personal egotism, kill thine enemy, Desire, extremely difficult though it be."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 3, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. In Chapter 2, Bhagavan had given us indication about who we are at the core of our being. That the self that I think I am is not the Self, but my self is imperishable, everlasting, all knowing and ever blissful. And it is contrary to my own experience. So it becomes a hypothesis for me. It's not my knowledge right now that the self is all pervading, everlasting, ever blissful.

My life is completely contrary to that. So Bhagawan says, that's because of your ignorance about yourself. So once I remove that ignorance, then I should be able to know the knowledge. That's basically our hypothesis right now. But my effort to know that is not very fruitful so far. So we have to accept that there is a limitation for me to know.

Even all Western scholars and philosophers have come to the conclusion that there is a limit for the rational thinking to get knowledge. Immanuel Kant said, I have to limit my reasoning to make room for faith that there is God or there is a Creator of this universe. And you can postulate a theory, but it does not become my knowledge. You have to rely on faith. Our scriptures say you don't really have to rely on just faith, but you can experience that if you follow certain path, then you will be able to know this. In fact, our scripture says it is your birthright to know this knowledge.

And you will know that when not guaranteed. So you have to make efforts. Efforts means activity, and activity as we know, has its own limitation. So in the beginning of this chapter, having been taught by Bhagavan Karmani, Eva di Karaste Mahphale Shukadachana, your right is only to act, never the fruits of actions. And therefore Yogastha kuru Karmani, establish yourself in yoga and then do your actions and you shall come to know this knowledge. But Arjuna obviously was not convinced that this activity is going to get me anywhere.

So obviously he asked that question. If you think then I have to establish Myself in yoga which is basically sit down, meditate and become a yogi. Then why are you asking me to engage in this war which is a terrible act? Why don't you tell me the act and can lead me to a greater understanding? So Bhagavan basically clarifies: Loke Asmin Dvividha Nishtha Pura Prokta Mayanagha -- in this world, two paths are created right from the beginning. Gnana Yogena Sankhyanam Karma Yogena Yoginam -- for people with Sankhya Buddhi, the contemplative intellect, the path is Gnana Yoga. This means contemplating on the fact that I am not this body, I am not this mind, I am not the intellect. "Then who am I?" is basically Gnana Yoga. And Karma Yogena Yoginam -- those who are active in this life, for them it is Karma Yoga. So basically, Bhagavan transformed Karma into Karma Yoga. And we have seen that Bhagavan has given five pointers.

Two we get in chapter two. You should not have the fruit in your mind as the goal for your action and establishing Yoga. Perform your all actions. Bhagwan says there are two parts. But for you Karma Yoga is good. Where you are in the station of your life, Karma Yoga will be much better.

There are three paths we typically talk about. Karma Yoga, Gnana Yoga and Bhakti Yoga. Karma and Gnana I have control over. At least I can make my efforts in them. Bhakti I can only get by God's grace. To fall in love is not something in my hand.

When you fall in, there is no choice in love. Bhakti is love for divine and it is choiceless. It only comes by the grace of God. Therefore Bhagawan said, start with Karma Yoga. That Karma Yoga will lead you to knowledge about God. The Bhagavan said, activity is involuntary for all beings.

Na Kaschit Kshanam Api Jatu Tishthaty Akarmakrit -- but you should act in this world by controlling your senses and without any attachment. So Bhagavan said, when Prajapati created this Praja, he also created Yajna at the same time. To sustain this Praja, Yajna was created. So we worry about our children: how would they sustain themselves when we are not there?

So we have to make them independent. How do you make them independent? By this education you shall earn your living. So focus on your education. That's how we do as parents. Prajapati did something similar -- Prajapati created Yajna, cooperative activity where you work with nature.

This cooperation between the beings in nature will yield results which will sustain this praja. So then we have seen a cycle in this Prakriti Annad Bhavati Bhutani, Prajanyatamna Sambhavah. And in the end says Karma Brahmod Bhav that the unit of this cycle is action. All that is happening in this Prakriti is happening because of activity in the Prakriti. And this activity is only possible at an individual level. At an individual level, if we act, then this activity becomes a communal activity, a national activity, a global activity.

But at an individual level you have to act. Then Bhagavan said, this ability to act comes from that Brahman, the supreme consciousness which is functioning through you. As long as I'm alive, I can act. So Bhagavan said, know that this activity is based in your consciousness and therefore you continue activity without any attachment. Because activity is to acquire something I don't have and preserve what I have. But if I come to a conclusion that I have acquired everything I want, should I continue to act?

For the Loka Sangra, for the preservation of the community, of the society, of this universe, you have to continue working. Look, I have nothing to gain, but I continue to work. If I don't act or work, then there will be a chaos in this cosmos. To avoid this chaos, the Sankarasyacha Kartashyam I will become the cause for this chaos in this world and therefore I continue to work. And then he comes to his final advice in verse 30 where he says, Mai Sarvani Karmani Sanyasya Adhyatma Chet Nirasi Nirmama Bhutva yudhiya, you offer all your actions to me. In this one verse, Bhagavan has given us a complete method of Karma Yoga.

Act you must but act in a manner of Karma Yoga. Now what is Karma Yoga? He said, when you act with that attitude that I'm offering all my actions to the Supreme Lord. Because we have seen in that natural cycle that acts, activity at my level is only possible because I am a conscious being. That life in me, that consciousness in me is not different than the consciousness which is all pervading. Therefore I should offer all my activities to that supreme consciousness.

Nirasi Nirmama Bhutva -- without any desire for a particular result from my actions. And Nirmama means not thinking anything is mine; even this ability to act is not my own. This ability to act is God's gift to me. I did not do much to prepare that this type of body. I will have this type of mind, I will have this intellect developer. Well, this was given to me as my instrument and I'm now just using them.

If I have better equipment than some other person, it's not something that I have done in this life, at least. So Bhagavan said, Nirashi Nirmamo Bhutva -- you become desireless and without any sense of "mine." Therefore, you should act according to your own dharma. Wherever you are, whatever station you are at in your life, you should act according to that, because you don't really have any choice but to act according to that. I can't suddenly wake up one morning and say, "I really don't want to act as an architect anymore."

You know, this business is not doing well for me. I'm going to become something else. Well, I don't really have an ability to change right away. So Bhagavan said, Swadharma Nidhanam, Sreyaha Paradharmo Bhya Vah, you act according to your own dharma, according to your own Prakriti. Because to act like someone else is very dangerous. It may seem easy right now, it may seem glamorous right now, but because it is not your nature, you will fail eventually and you will not make any progress.

So therefore, he said, even a wise person is also bound by his own Prakriti. When a wise person is not free from his own nature, he also acts according to his own nature. Except that he does not consider that as his own nature. He considers this the nature of my body, mind and intellect. I offer all that I do to the Lord who is making me do that. You are bound by the Prakriti because you are part of Prakriti.

Your Prakriti is basically who you are at this point and therefore know your nature and act accordingly. In Arjuna's case, he said, you are a Kshatriya. You are a prince who is responsible to protect others. And now you are in front of this enemy army. Your job is to fight this war. In whatever station of life I am in, I should act accordingly.

Prakriti works by likes and dislikes. I have created likes and dislikes by my experiences in the world of objects. Some experiences I like, some I dislike. These likes and dislikes reside in my senses, in my sense perception. Some sense perceptions were pleasurable,

some were painful. They are your obstructions, and therefore avoid them. If that is the case, just tell me: what is the force which makes people commit sins against their own will? Knowing this is not right, I commit that act and then I come to suffer for it. So Bhagavan said, Kama Esha Krodha Esha. In the end, it came down to this: my likes and dislikes are the root cause of how I act.

If I overcome my likes and dislikes then it will be much easier for me to act in a rational manner. Why I have not been able to do that is because of the Kama and Krodha. This likes and dislikes create desire. That desire creates anger. This Kama is the root cause of all my problems. So Bhagavan said, therefore consider them to be your enemies.

This desire and anger are veiling my true nature. We started a journey from I do not know my true self and therefore all my problems in life. If I know my true self, I'll be almighty, all pervading, omniscient, omnipresent. That knowledge has been veiled by this Kama and Krodha. Therefore Bhagavan said Avrutam Gnana Methina. Now this Gnana is the Gnana of myself.

Avruttam Gnanameti na Gnanino Nitya Vairina bhai. This knowledge is veiled from even a wise person. Kama Rupena kaunteya duspuraynanalynacha Kama desire. It is insatiable like a fire. And therefore Bhagavan says, Indriyani Mano Buddhih Asya Adhishthanam Uchyate. To fight the enemy, you have to find his location.

The location of my enemy is Indriyani Manah Buddhi Senses, mind and intellect are this desire's residences. I identified where this desire resides. It deludes the embodied by veiling his wisdom. A simple fact Bhagavan said is this desire is veiling your wisdom about your own self. And therefore this desire is your enemy. The desire is residing in your senses first by the sense perception.

This perception creates the conception of that object and then I have desire to acquire that object. If I can't acquire the object of my desire then I'm angry. This desire and anger is veiling your true self. And therefore, Tasmat Tvam Indriyany Adau Niyamya Bharatarshabha. Don't let this enemy come into your house. Once it enters your house, you are in trouble.

Therefore you have to lock your doors, have a security system.
snippets.reflection:
The final verse of Chapter 3 is Krishna's battle cry: "Jahi shatrum mahaabaaho kaamarupam durasadam" - O mighty-armed one, slay this enemy in the form of desire, difficult though it is to conquer! The path is clear: knowing that the Self is beyond the intellect ("evam buddheh param buddhva"), steady yourself in that Self ("samstabhya atmanam atmana"), and destroy desire. This is not suppression but transcendence - rising to a level of identity where desire cannot touch you.

The word "durasadam" (difficult to overcome) is important. Krishna does not promise an easy victory. Desire is indeed a formidable enemy - it has been with us since beginningless time, it operates through our own instruments, it is insatiable and ever-renewing. But "mahaabaaho" - mighty-armed one - you have the strength for this battle. The strength comes not from willpower but from knowledge and proper positioning. Established in the Self, you are invincible.

As Chapter 3 concludes, take time to integrate its teachings. The chapter began with Arjuna's confusion about action versus knowledge, and ends with a call to action - "jahi" (slay!). The entire arc of Karma Yoga is here: you must act, but act as Yajna; work in the world, but remain established in the Self; engage with the gunas, but know you are beyond them; face your desires, but slay them from the vantage point of your true identity. Today, choose one desire that has been troubling you. Rather than fighting it directly, ask: From where am I fighting? Can I establish myself, even momentarily, in that which is beyond the intellect - my witnessing awareness - and from there see desire as something that arises and passes, unable to touch who I really am? This shift from battleground to observation deck is the essence of victory.

snippets.title: Day 56: Divine Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः |

स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

evaṃ paramparāprāptamimaṃ rājarṣayo viduḥ .

sa evāyaṃ mayā te.adya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: This imperishable philosophy I taught to Viwaswana, the founder of the Sun dynasty, Viwaswana gave it to Manu the lawgiver, and Manu to King Ikshwaku!
The Divine Kings knew it, for it was their tradition. Then, after a long time, at last it was forgotten.
It is the same ancient Path that I have now revealed to thee, since thou art My devotee and My friend. It is the supreme Secret.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Renouncing Karma in Knowledge. We have completed discussion on chapter three, Karma Yoga. In Karma Yoga we have seen how to act in this world so that we are not bound by our actions. But our goal actually in life is to become actionless, to retire from my activity. So if somebody says, "Why, Neil, you are working so hard?" -- well, I am working hard to become actionless in my retirement. And how do I want to achieve that? If I can become financially independent so that I don't depend on the outside income. As long as I'm dependent on outside income, I have to keep working.

I need to generate income from outside sources, so I'm continuing to work. The harder I work, obviously the more conflicts I create and more situation which makes me unhappy. More I think I'm controlling the situation. The situation controls me. So what I want to do is to create a situation where I don't have to work with the outside world for my well being.

That's what we call retirement. So that's why we have this 401k and IRA and all of that. That will make me independent. Once I'm financially independent and I don't depend on my outside income, then I can do what I want. Every year I took a cruise, and I realized that most of the population of the cruise is above 55 -- 80% of the people were senior citizens.

So all the programs were geared towards senior citizens. So I was actually pitying all the young people who were there like in minority. I want to do what I want to do. So the goal is always to be actionless, that I don't want to interact with this world. In the last chapter we learned exactly the same thing. For all these activities it says Yahatu Atmaratiyeva: everyone has a duty to act in this world according to their own dharma, according to the roles they are playing. It comes with all the Niyata Karma, all these ordained duties.

So you have to continue doing your duties. But there is Only one exception. One who is atmaratihi who is reveling in himself. He's not dependent on anything or anybody outside to be happy. Atmatruptastamaanava who is self content. If I'm reveling in myself, I'm self content.

Atmani evacha santushtaha tasya kariyam na vidyaday -- the only time you have no duty to act, to do any work or any action, is when you meet this condition. Atmaratehe -- full of yourself. Not a right way to put it, but you get the idea. So you have no real need to depend on the outside world. Once you are not depending on the outside world, there is no question of having a conflict with it. It's only when we are dependent on them that we have conflict.

I am dependent on my employees. My employees are dependent on me. We constantly have conflict. "You are not coming on time. You didn't do what I thought you were going to be doing."

He feels the same way: "Neil, you are not doing what I thought you were going to do for me." Because we are dependent on each other. If I am not dependent on them, there is no conflict. We have a project at Dominion and it's really going nowhere because we are updating the auditorium. The CEO of the company will be at the first meeting there on the 23rd.

And the project is supposed to be complete end of March. It is not completed now. We don't know whether it's going to complete on the 23rd. So they're working overtime hours because the CEO is going to be there, they call me up, they call everybody. Obviously we blame everybody else who contracted into this. "Why did you specify this, Neil?" They say, "Something which comes from Japan," all this good stuff. So I asked the guys, "Did you always have this problem?" The guy who's in charge at Dominion said, "The only time I don't have a problem is when I don't depend on anybody. When I do work myself, that's fine. But otherwise, I have to depend on the contractor. I have to depend on you."

We all know for sure: when I don't have to depend on other people, then I'm free. He has no employees to worry about. His structural engineer was a one man firm and did very well, because he's not dependent on his employees. He knows what he can do, what he cannot do, and he can promise accordingly.

In my case, I have to depend on 15 other people when I promise what they're going to do. So in our life we have figured out that the only way to be free is not to be dependent on anybody. At the same token, my happiness right now is mortgaged to this world outside. They determine whether I can be happy or not. So Bhagawan said that the goal of life is to become actionless. I'll become actionless when I'm not dependent on others for my happiness.

So we learn that Yahatu Atmaratihiva, one who is reveling in himself, atmatrupta satisfied by his own self, atmaniyevacha Santustah is content by himself. Then he does not have to do anything. But the same token, I have to continue to work in this world. So I need to understand what is the way I can stop acting. And this chapter, the title says Gnana Karma Sannyasa. When the knowledge occurs -- what is happiness? What is it that I'm seeking? -- then all actions I can renounce. So now we are further taking our discussion on actions to next level. We understood that I need to act in a manner that I'm not attached to the actions. And also I should be acting in a way that it is good for everyone, that is for the greater good. Then I will not be bound by my actions.

But how do I reach to that point? I need to have the knowledge. My actions without knowledge obviously are not producing the result which I need to produce. So the next level of discussion in the actions is now how do you achieve that state where I have the knowledge? So the chapter titled Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga Bhagawan doesn't even wait for Arjuna to ask any question. He comes out and gives him his version of what we're going to do next.

Sri Bhagavanu Vacha Imam Vivasvate Yogam proktavan Aham Avyam Vivasvaan Manavai Praha Manohu Isvakave Abravit said, I'm now going to teach you the yoga which is imperishable. That knowledge has never become outdated. We used to learn something probably in last century about driving a horse buggy. In this century we are learning how to drive car. It will become invalid pretty soon if these guys are all successful. We used to put a lot of emphasis on handwriting, at least architecture.

Our whole life in the architecture school was how nicely I can write. It's called architectural script. We spent all our life to perfect our handwriting. Nobody writes anymore. You can't differentiate my drawing from anybody else. We used to take great pride in that.

Even if there is work left and there is not enough time, and somebody says, "Can I help you, Neel?" -- I want to make sure that nobody else's handwriting is on my drawing. Because once somebody says, "Oh, that's Neil's drawing," I don't want somebody else's handwriting on it. But now all drawings look the same, no matter where they come from, because it's all computer.

So the skills which we were learning, which was so dear to us is no more valid. But one said this yoga is not like that, it's universal. It was always valid in the past, it's valid now and it will be valid forever. Ivam Vivasvate Yogam Proktava vyam I taught this yoga to Vivaswan and then Vivaswan Manavai Prah Vivaswan then taught in turn to the Manu. The Manu in dint taught to Manu Isva kavet. He is now making sure that you understand that this is not something I just made up suddenly.

This is an imperishable yoga. This knowledge is imperishable. It's applicable at any given age. So it starts with that. This knowledge is so ancient. It starts with the beginning of this creation.

In our world, the creation started with Sun. We at least know from our high school science that this earth came out of Sun. And then obviously all the development in the earth is because of that solar energy. So our source at our level is Sun. We don't have to go any further than that. So he said, even when the sun was created, this knowledge was there.

So Vivaswani -- for the first time, as Swamiji says, Krishna comes out as "I am the Lord." In this conversation, the Creator, the knowledge giver, is saying this knowledge was always available from the beginning of this creation. So I gave it to the first created entity, the Sun. That Sun gave it to his son, which is Manu. From our puranic point of view, Viva Swan was the original entity. Manu was his son, and then the whole progeny starts and we end up here.

In this class I taught to Lord sun who is the originator of our world. Then he in turn taught to his sons. Obviously we always pass on our knowledge from us to our children. That's why we start teaching the little kids. And yesterday we were in the park and Medha always like to swing. The only way to stop her is say we're going to count one to hundred.

So in 100 you have to come down. That's okay, we start 1, 2. And she said no, we're going to count in Spanish. So she starts -- uno, dwe. Okay, after that what? Meda, after that what?

Because she has to tell us now. She knows because of Dora the Explorer. So we teach our children what we know. So Bhagavan said that Lord's son taught to his sons what he knew, this imperishable yoga. Then Manu in turn taught to his son. So Ishvaku, Ishwaku, we all know from Ramayana is the ancestor of Rama of the Sun Dynasty.

Sun Dynasty came from this lineage, whether we like this historically or not. But that's how the Puranas describe our lineage. The point here is very simple: right from the beginning of our ancestry, this knowledge was available to people. And those people passed it on from one generation to another through the leaders of the society. The leaders obviously in those days were kings.

They were the people who were leading the society. So if you read historically, Manu led these people from wherever they were to land which was safer and more fertile. Actually, Professor Bargha said that Noah is the same as Manu, because in Sanskrit Manu is "Manu-hu." The people in the Arabic world only kept "Nu." They dropped the "Ma," and then "Nu" in the western world became Noah. So if you read the story of Noah's Ark, it is very similar to what we have in our Puranas about the Great Flood.

So we know that there's some connection somewhere where some ancestor left some land which was not very conducive and was flooding all the time, and led his people to somewhere safer. So he led his people to this. So he's our ancestor Manu Adi Manu. And whether he was the first human being is left to your imagination. We know for sure that he was the first Aryan king in this lineage of the Aryan kings who ruled Arya worth for ages.

So he said the first person to know this knowledge in this lineage, Manu. Manu in turn will give it to his sons. He came to Ishwaku who was the ancient king of Solar dynasty.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses of Chapter 4 reveal something profound: the wisdom Krishna shares with Arjuna is not new but imperishable (avyayam), passed from teacher to student since the beginning of creation. This knowledge was given first to Vivaswan (the Sun), then to Manu, then to Ikshvaku, forming an unbroken chain of transmission. Consider that you too are part of this lineage of seekers. The fact that this teaching has survived millennia, passed through royal sages and philosopher-kings, suggests it addresses something fundamental about human existence that transcends time and culture.

Krishna reveals this supreme secret to Arjuna because he is both a devotee (bhakta) and a friend (sakha). This teaches us that spiritual knowledge is not merely intellectual but relational. Ask yourself today: Who are my spiritual teachers, formal or informal? Am I approaching this wisdom with the humility of a student and the openness of a friend? What ancient wisdom traditions have been passed to me through my own family, culture, or chosen path?

As a daily exercise, identify one piece of timeless wisdom you received from a parent, grandparent, or mentor. Reflect on how this "imperishable knowledge" has helped guide your actions. Consider how you might pass on such wisdom to others, becoming a link in the chain yourself. The goal of this teaching is to become actionless at the core, not dependent on the outside world for happiness, but reveling in your own Self (atmaratih).

snippets.title: Day 57: Action in Inaction
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन् |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

ajo.api sannavyayātmā bhūtānāmīśvaro.api san .
verseTranslations: Arjuna asked: My Lord! Viwaswana was born before Thee; how then canst Thou have revealed it to him?
Lord Shri Krishna replied: I have been born again and again, from time to time; thou too, O Arjuna! My births are known to Me, but thou knowest not thine.
have no beginning. Though I am imperishable, as well as Lord of all that exists, yet by My own will and power do I manifest Myself.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga Yoga of Renouncing actions in Knowledge. So so far we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita that the sole goal of any being is happiness. And happiness we have seen is defined as absence of unhappiness. As long as there is unhappiness somewhere, I cannot be happy. Just like as we have seen, the cold is defined as absence of heat is cold. Darkness is defined as absence of light is darkness.

Happiness is defined by lack of unhappiness. So my true nature is actually happiness. But the infusion of unhappiness creates this state which I call going back from happiness to unhappiness. When there is no unhappiness, I am happy. But if even one thing is wrong, no matter how many other things are going well in my life, it just won't let me focus on the good.

In Sastra it's called Kakadrasti. A crow is flying over a garden and everything is beautiful underneath. But the crow is not focusing on the beautiful flowers. He is focused on a carcass lying in that garden. That's where he goes. So our Kakadrasti --

We don't focus on what is right in our life, we focus on what is wrong in our life. So we have to get out of this habit of seeing what is not right in my life. So what we try to do is keep searching for happiness rather than avoiding unhappiness. The search of happiness leads us to believe that my actions will get me to happiness. So we act in this world to achieve happiness which is already with us. But these actions also lead me to results which are unhappiness.

So therefore we have seen in last chapter, Arjuna's question is Atha KE na prayuk toyam Papam Charati Purusha. There is no one in this life who really wants to become unhappy. And still we end up becoming unhappy by our own actions. So actions are at the root cause of whether I'm happy or unhappy. Therefore we need to understand what actions are all about. The one thing we learnt is I cannot live without actions, because action is the very nature of my own being.

Nature is part of Prakriti. It is one of the attributes of Prakriti is action Rajas. And as I am part of Prakriti, as this body, mind, intellect is part of Prakriti, action is a very signature of my being who I am. So actions I cannot avoid that's given. Now, how can I avoid actions which give me unhappiness? Well, when I am performing actions, there is not a single action I perform because I want to be unhappy.

"Well, let me do something that makes me unhappy. Let's see how it feels." There is no curiosity about unhappiness. I really don't want to know. But I still end up being unhappy. That's because I'm not understanding what actions are all about.

So we learnt in chapter three what actions are all about. The first thing we learnt is Yajnaarthaat Karmano, Nyatra Loko Yam Karma, Bandanaha. All actions are binding. If they are not performed for the Yajna, for the spirit of common good, then they are binding. If I am doing it for myself, they are binding. When those actions are binding, I'll be bound by the results.

In a sense, I really don't know what the results would be. They may come back as conducive results and I'll be happy or they come back as unconducive results and I'll be unhappy. So now I am in a conundrum. I want to act because that's what's going to make me happy. But also I'm not quite confident that my actions will make me happy. Because I have no control over my actions.

So there got to be a way to get out of this conundrum of acting and reacting and then acting again. So Bhagavan said yes, there is a yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge. Once the knowledge takes place that I am not the actor, you will be released from this bondage of actions. Because you are not performing the actions, you cannot be bound by it. So that is Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga. Yoga of renouncing actions in knowledge.

When knowledge takes place that I am not the actor. Guna Gunesuvartantaha Ithimatva na Sajjadhai. We learned that in chapter three. Once I figure out that the actions are only taking place at the Prakriti level -- by my qualities, qualities of my body, mind and intellect, and qualities of the rest of the universe -- when they come in contact with each other, they react with each other. Like hydrogen and oxygen: when they are two independently standing, there is no water.

When they come together, they create water. We also work in this world the same way. By ourselves we are not reacting to anything. As soon as we come in contact with another being or an object, we react. There was sometimes we had good chemistry with him. What do you mean good chemistry?

I like him with no reason. Guna Gunesuvaratanta. I detect Gunas in him or her. Maybe a physical, mental, intellectual, something which I like. I tell people how I got into hotel designing business. Very first limited hotel.

I had designed full service hotels in my life before I came to Virginia. But then I was looking for some work. Somebody says there is an Indian community. They design lot of mid level hotel. He said no, no, you're a big time, not small time. So the first guy they introduced me was in Charlottesville.

They said, "How about you come down here?" Because one thing I figured out: I can win people over if I'm in front of them -- on the phone and in writing it's harder. But if I'm in front of him I can probably have a better chance. So I go down there, talk to the guy, and then he said, "Where are you from?" I said Surat.

"My parents actually come from Randeh." "Oh, where is Randeir?" In the end of the day, we never talked about what I know about architecture. They said, "You are my architect now because your ancestors come from Randir. Let the architecture sort out by itself. You are my architect."

Something we find common. So therefore these actions are all bound by Gunas. But we consider it to be ours. The Bhagawan said that one who is understanding this he will not be attached to his actions. He doesn't get attached. But how do I get to that point that I don't get attached.

I have to have knowledge who I am. So this chapter starts with Bhagavan said that I taught this yoga to Vivaswan. Then the Viva swan taught to Manu. Then Manu taught to Iksvaku.
