And thus by lineage the knowledge was passed on to generation to generation. But now because the long time has passed the knowledge is lost.

When were Vivaswan and Manu alive? And you are now telling me that you taught them? We have discussed that Vivaswan and Manu, from a genealogical point of view, are Krishna's ancestors. Vivaswan's son was Manu, who at the time of Pralaya saved his family and seven Rishis. Manu's son was Ikswaku. So Vivaswan taught his son Manu.

Manu taught his son Ishvaku. And Isvaku, we know, is Rama's ancestor who established the kingdom in Ayodhya. Somewhere about 36 generations later, Rama comes. One of them was also the ancestor of Krishna. Somewhere in the 60th generation, Krishna comes. So Arjuna is saying: you are telling me that you taught all your ancestors?

So then Bhagavan said Bahuni me Vyati Thani Janmani Stavacharjuna Tani Aham Veda Sarwani Natvam Vedaparam Tapa. This is not the only life that you and I know, Arjuna. You know me in this life as Krishna. But I have taken so many births before and so did you. The only difference is I know them all. This is a very bold presentation of concept of reincarnation.

It was not that it was not introduced before. It was introduced in chapter 2. Vasamsi Jinini Yatavi Haya Navani Guru Nathi Naroparani we have already seen that this self is immutable, imperishable. It just takes one state of existence to another depending on. We know from our study of Bhagavadya by Karma actions. Our actions create experiences in this world.

These experiences create tendencies. These tendencies create likes and dislikes and desires. And to fulfill those desires we take a next state of existence. My desire was to become a rock star. Then obviously I learned music and then march on that path. So desire leads us to where we are today.

But you see, we won't remember how we got here. The one who is very aware of this transitory nature of things, he will remember all of them. See, some of us are very good at remembering dreams. All of us remember dreams, right? Some of my dreams, even ones I had in childhood, I still remember. They either still scare me or still fascinate me.

But I don't remember all my dreams. If I was more aware and enlightened about keeping myself connected to my dream world, then I would remember all my dreams. See, right now I'm only connected to my waking world, and sporadically I'm connected to my dream world. So I remember some dreams here and there, but not all of them. In the waking world, I think I remember everything. Then somebody says, "But Neil, you did this?"

No, I don't remember. I forget almost everything she says I did. She said, "You did this for some reason." Women are very historical. They remember everything. From the day I met Meena till today, she remembers everything that I did not do right.

And I don't remember any of that. But you remember what she didn't do, right? So we have very, what you call it is a convenient memory. But at least I'm connected to the waking world. If I'm disconnected, then I will have to have a psychiatric evaluation because I don't remember who I am and all the good stuff. Now imagine: if I'm connected to the waking world, and if I'm also connected to my dream world, and then also my deep sleep, then I will remember everything.

But for that I have to be a third party, not involved in it. Imagine there is a recording device which is recording everything going on in my brain. It will record everything. See, that's why when we see some recordings of our own childhood, we get fascinated. "Did I look like that?" So we have a memory which is very specific to time and space.

The time and space we are in. This is what remember as the reality. But if there is some way we can connect all our realities then we will have a complete view. Bhagawan said that you and I both have the capability to know that. But ignorance about who I am has created a smaller memory. The more I identify with the localized situation,

the more I will forget about my greater situation. Some of my friends still write me every year, and I have forgotten most of them, because my nature is to identify with wherever I am now. I'm in Richmond. These are my friends and my family. The more I identify with Richmond, the more I'll forget my friends in Northern Virginia and Houston and Nairobi and Zambia and India. But some people remain connected because they never fully belong to where they are.

They may ask somebody and say, what are you doing? We go to Northern Virginia every weekend. We have all our friends there. They are not connected here, they are more connected there.
snippets.reflection:
When Arjuna questions how Krishna could have taught Vivaswan who was born ages before, Krishna reveals a profound truth: "Many births have passed for Me and for you, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you know them not" (bahuni me vyatitani janmani tava charjuna). This teaching on reincarnation invites us to consider the continuity of our existence beyond this single lifetime. Just as we remember some dreams vividly while forgetting most, our connection to past experiences depends on our level of awareness. Krishna, being fully aware, remembers all; we, identified with our limited selves, remember only fragments.

The key distinction Krishna makes is that while we take birth compelled by unfulfilled desires (vasanas), He manifests by His own free will (atma-mayaya), presiding over His own Prakriti. Though unborn (ajo) and imperishable (avyayatma), He appears in creation by choice, not compulsion. This teaches us that our bondage comes from identification with limited circumstances, while liberation comes from recognizing our true nature as the unchanging witness.

Today, reflect on your patterns of attachment and desire. What recurring themes appear in your life that might point to deep-seated tendencies (vasanas)? Practice expanding your sense of identity beyond your current circumstances. Just as people who keep connected to friends from different cities never feel fully "local" anywhere, consider: are you so identified with your present situation that you have forgotten your larger Self? Try maintaining awareness of yourself as the witness who observes all experiences rather than the one caught up in them.

snippets.title: Day 58: Types of Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत |

परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम् |

जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः |
snippets.transliteration:
yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānirbhavati bhārata .

paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṃ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām .

janma karma ca me divyamevaṃ yo vetti tattvataḥ .
verseTranslations: Whenever spirituality decays and materialism is rampant, then, O Arjuna, I reincarnate Myself!
To protect the righteous, to destroy the wicked and to establish the kingdom of God, I am reborn from age to age.
He who realises the divine truth concerning My birth and life is not born again; and when he leaves his body, he becomes one with Me.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation of Action in Knowledge. We have seen so far that in chapter three, Bhagavan has taught Arjuna Karma Yoga. In that he said that you should perform actions for Yajna Yajnarth Puru Karmani. Then he also said, asaktah Sattattam Karma Samajaraha. Perform all your actions without attachment. And he said, yogastha Guru Karmani, establish your Sulmi Yoga and they perform your actions.

So these are the three requisites or three path. Three ways of performing actions Bhagavan has indicated to Arjuna and he called it Karma Yoga. How you can continue performing your actions in this world as required by roles you are taken. The art of performing action called Karma Yoga. Bhagavan Seth was taught to the royal sages, the philosopher kings, right from the beginning. Right from the beginning of the creation.

This knowledge was given to Lord sun, who is considered to be in this case, the original ruler of this universe. He then gave it to his successor. His successor gave it to his successor. And this knowledge was passed on one royal sage to the another, one philosopher king, to another philosopher king. You know, kings were not just simply the rulers, but they were also established in Dharma. They were established in the knowledge.

But this knowledge was lost over a period of time. And therefore I have given it to you again today, and you shall also be able to use it. But then Arjuna asked, how can that be possible? Because you are under my contemporary, how you could give this knowledge to Lord Son. And in that response we all learned how the reincarnation works. So Bhagavan said, bahuni me vyati Thani Janma ne tava Charjana.

Oh Arjuna, you and I have gone through many, many Janmas, many, many iterations of our existence. The only difference, he is saying that I know them all and you do not know any. That's because you take birth. I, as a Jiva, take birth, compelled by my own vasanas. My unfulfilled desires. I take a new instrument to fulfill my vasanas which I have not fulfilled yet.

If I have no vasanas, no desires, there is no reason for me to take birth. In other words, there is no action required if there is no desire. I don't need to buy a car if I am never going to travel. People in New York City, most of them don't buy car because they are not going to use car. It's not economical for them to bike. They don't need that equipment.

People like us, we need that equipment. Because there is only way we can travel from one place to another. We have desire to travel. The equipment needed is a car. Therefore, I'll buy a car. In the same way you are driven by your own vasanas, take another birth.

But in my case, there is no need for me. But I take birth by my own free will because I have a desire. And that is what Bhagavan has basically said. Why he takes that divine birth. He said, yada yada hi dharmasyagnanir Bhavati Bharata abyuthanam adharmashya tad atmanam srujami ham. The desire may be noble, it may be good or bad.

But unless there is desire, there cannot be any action swimming in Bhagavan's part also from Ishwara's point of view also he has a desire to set the creation right. When he sees that the Dharma is declining in his own creation, as we have seen in Vedantic discussions, then Bhagavan creates this universe out of his own self. The Creator is the efficient cause, knows how to create. He also knows how to maintain it. But the material he used to create this universe, his own self, he has created this universe out of his own self. So he is all pervading in this universe.

And he has created this universe out of his own will. Maya when he sees that his own creation, there is a decay of Dharma. Dharma we have seen in several discussions before is the law of being. That which makes a thing or a being what it is is its Dharma. If that Dharma is declining, a thing or being is not functioning as it should be, then it needs to be corrected. So here Bhagavan said, when in the society, just as an individual has a Dharma, the society also has a Dharma.

Human beings have their own Dharma. At the basic core level, a human being is a rational animal. He is differentiated from all other animals by his reasoning power. So he can act rationally, he can think rationally. If human beings stop acting rationally, then Dharma is decayed. If they start acting irrationally, I will say Dharma is decayed for human beings, for that society.

So it's been current condition, the Dharma of democracy is that everyone has the right to vote or right to give opinion. When that Dharma is violated, then democracy is decayed and somebody has to come and correct it. So in this case, Bhagavan said, whenever there is a decay of Dharma, when I see that things are not performing as per Dharma, then it has to be replaced, corrected, and the order should be restored. To give you an example from my own observation: the Dharma of a steel beam under a bridge is to provide the tensile strength to that bridge. Because that beam can bend and come back to its own position -- that is the Dharma of steel. When the steel is corroded, it's still steel, but it's corroded steel.

That steel does not have the tensile strength which was required by that beam, and therefore it needs to be either repaired or replaced. Whoever is responsible for that bridge may be paying no attention to that beam. But now that he has observed the decay, there's a danger of the bridge collapsing. Well, he has to manifest himself as the corrector for that steel beam. So he said, yada yada, hi Dharma Siglanir Bhavati.

Whenever Dharma has decayed, that things or beings are not acting according to their own Dharma. Abhiuthana Madharma and the rise of Adharma Adharma, which is contrary to his own Dharma. Human beings are supposed to be rational. They are not acting rationally. They are no different than any other animals. Society has to be just.

If the society is not just, obviously it is not a society. If there is a chaos in the society, whoever is responsible for their society has to restore the order in the society. It becomes a just society again. Bhagawan said, that is my desire when I take birth by my free will. So we have seen that we are under the spell of Maya. Therefore, we are deluded by ignorance.

Ignorance is veiling my own self. I do not see who I am. I continue to change my vehicle from this body to another. But that's driven by my vasanas. Ishwara is in control of Maya. The whole creation is created by his own Maya out of his own self.

When he sees this creation is not performing as per his design, he has the desire to set it right. Paritranaya Sadhunam Vinashaya Chaduskritam, Dharma, Sansthapa, Narthaya, Sambhavami, Yuge Yuge. Time and again I manifest myself as one of my own creation and then set the order correct so that the things which are working as per Dharma are protected, and those which are not acting according to Dharma either need to be corrected, rehabilitated, or replaced. So in the same example of my steel beam under a bridge, there are several steel beams under that bridge. Those are providing the tensile strength to that bridge.

People don't pay much attention. Corroded beams we see all the time. When we see extensive corrosion under that bridge, then whoever is in charge says, "We need to do something." Well, let's figure out which beams we can restore and which we have to replace, so that the overall strength of that bridge is restored back to where it should have been.

Dharmasansthapa Narthaya -- for society to function as it was supposed to have functioned, as a just society, then I have to come and restore order: remove those who are poisonous and cannot be rehabilitated, rehabilitate those who can be rehabilitated, so that those who are practicing Dharma are protected and society functions as it was supposed to before the decay started. In verse nine, he says, Arjuna.

Here is another method Bhagavan gives us to achieve that state of knowledge. Right now I am under the spell of Maya and my knowledge is veiled by my ignorance. There are several methods. We have seen Gnana Yoga, Bhakti Yoga, Karma Yoga. He said that in Karma Yoga, you can perform your actions as we have discussed. Or you can just observe a divine person acting in this world selflessly, recognize how he does it in his divine manifestation, and then find the same divinity within you. You will establish yourself in your own real self, which is your own atma, your own consciousness. As we have discussed, there is nothing in this world which is not a manifestation of Bhagavan, of Brahman.

And therefore you and I cannot be different from Avatara. In our culture we have this Dasha Avatara, but actually that's just the popular version of it. Some Puranas have 24 Avataras, some have 36. There are numerous descriptions of Avatara, because Avatara means "the one who descends" -- Avatarati ITI Avatara. You and I also have descended from our highest position of all-knowing self to very limited knowing self.

From these limitations, I want liberation. Bhagavan said, even by observing others, so we create role models in our life, from them we learn. And if I can create the highest role model which has demonstrated how a person established in his own self acts in this world. Bhagawan said, you can also get liberated just by recognizing how a divine incarnation functions. Janma, Karma, Chame Divyam Evam yo Vittita tv. One who knows in essence what is the purpose of a divine Avatara and how that divine being functions in this world.

Therefore we learn Ramayana, therefore we recite Bhagavad Gita. We are trying to learn from them how Lord Rama acted in his life. If we can understand that, Bhagavan says, then when you give up this body -- if I understood in my life how Rama functioned, what was his motivation to act the way he acted, what was Krishna's motivation -- then I will also find that same self in me through my own contemplation, my own observation of my own self: that this is not me. The demands of my body, my mind, intellect are not really me. I am something other than that.

Having understood this by learning from my own role models, when I give up this body, I don't have to take the birth again. So Swamiji explains here that in previous descriptions in scriptures, the idea was deathlessness. But then the later portion of our scriptures describes birthlessness instead. Death is obviously something to be afraid of -- therefore don't get infected by coronavirus, social distancing, all of that. Death is the one thing you are worried about.

But somehow we are going to die anyway, coronavirus or no coronavirus. The very thought that I will start all over again -- I have come all this far, from learning ABCD to whatever, went through kindergarten, then high school, then college -- and I have to start all over again.
snippets.reflection:
These verses contain the famous promise of divine intervention: "Yada yada hi dharmasya glanir bhavati" - whenever Dharma declines and Adharma rises, the Lord manifests to protect the righteous, destroy wickedness, and re-establish Dharma. This is not merely about cosmic events but applies to our inner life as well. Just as a gardener tolerates a few weeds but eventually must restore order, the divine principle within us rises to correct imbalance when we stray too far from our essential nature.

Dharma here means the law of being - that which makes a thing what it is. When a steel beam loses its tensile strength through corrosion, it has lost its dharma and must be repaired or replaced. Similarly, when we deviate from our own authentic nature, life itself creates situations that call us back to alignment. The teaching also reveals that one who truly understands the divine birth and actions (janma karma cha me divyam) becomes free from the cycle of rebirth. This is not mere intellectual understanding but a profound recognition that transforms one's entire being.

Today, examine where in your life Dharma may be declining - where are you not functioning according to your true nature? What corrective forces have appeared to guide you back? Also reflect: Bhagavan says He comes "paritranaya sadhunam" - to protect those practicing Dharma. What good thoughts or intentions within you need protection from being overwhelmed by negative tendencies? Trust that when you sincerely seek to follow Dharma, the inner voice of guidance will strengthen and rise to support you. The goal is birthlessness (aja) - to exhaust all desires so completely that no new birth is needed.

snippets.title: Day 59: The Sword of Wisdom
snippets.sanskrit:
वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः |

ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम् |

काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः |
snippets.transliteration:
vītarāgabhayakrodhā manmayā māmupāśritāḥ .

ye yathā māṃ prapadyante tāṃstathaiva bhajāmyaham .

kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṃ siddhiṃ yajanta iha devatāḥ .
verseTranslations: Many have merged their existences in Mine, being freed from desire, fear and anger, filled always with Me and purified by the illuminating flame of self-abnegation.
Howsoever men try to worship Me, so do I welcome them. By whatever path they travel, it leads to Me at last.
Those who look for success, worship the Powers; and in this world their actions bear immediate fruit.
snippets.commentary:
Chapter 4 Gnana Karma Sannyasi Yoga of Ending Karma in Knowledge. We all want to retire, but there is no real practical way to retire. You always do something. You can only retire mentally. So when you don't take your actions to be work, you retire, then you enjoy this. So when we change our mental attitude about our actions, then you retire from the actions.

So the only way Bhagavan says to end your actions because these actions are binding and I want to get out of this bondage. He said, you have to get rid of your actions. You have to retire from your actions. And the only way to retire is in the knowledge of who you are and what actions are all about. So in chapter three we have seen Karma Yoga and see how to gradually liberate yourself from your actions by changing your attitude towards actions. And now you say, well, how can I then completely relieve myself of this burden is to realize who I am.

So this chapter talks about what is the nature of the self. Ajaha Pisan Avya Yatman. I yourself, Ajaha Unborn, Avyatma, immutable, imperishable. That's the real nature of mind. Bhutanam Isvaropisan. I am the lord of all beings.

All beings are beings because of my presence in them. I am who I am and you are who you are. And the donkey is who donkey is. Because that life which is pulsating through them, the presence of that omnipresent self makes people who they are and beings who they are. That's why he is the lord of all the beings. Lordship is someone who has a control over my life is my lord in feudal system.

The guy who owned the estate was a lord. Even today he's a landlord and a renter. He has the control over your property. Therefore he's a landlord. So he is the Bhutana Mishurabeesan. Prakrutin swam this tyre.

You and I come into existence because of the Self. But because of the Maya we think we are individual egos, we are the individuals. But someone who has a complete identification with himself, he realizes this is just an appearance. It's just an illusion that I have taken a limited form. So the difference between us and the Avatar is we think we are limited. Avatar knows all the time.

His role in this life is limited. So Krishna can say, I am unlimited. He knew his role in this life, but he never bound himself with his role. He said that presiding over my prakriti, I come time and again to regulate Dharma. Hi Dharma Siglanir Bhavati. Dharma itself is a self regulating principle.

You don't really need to do anything about Dharma water. You don't have to train water to seek its own level because it's self regulating. My Dharma is also self regulating. So when I get out of my Dharma, I cease to be what I was. I'll become something else. When I came to this country, there were no jobs for architecture because I came in 82 and there was a recess in time.

So there were no jobs. So people said, Neil, the best thing you can do. And I was in Houston at the time, so the oil economy was still tail end of it. The best thing, if you can become a pipe designer, pipe drafting, pipe drafting. Pipe drafting is a lot of money. So compared to architecture, you do pipe drafting, all those pipes for the oil company, you will make more money.

And I said, no matter how much money there is, I won't be able to do it. That's my Dharma to design building. I can't design pipes. I may have to suffer through unemployment. As long as I don't get a job, I'll do something else. But by very nature, I'm an architect.

I have to design buildings. And then I finally somewhere I worked for some contractor. I think you will do very well if you continue in the contracting. I left the job right away. He is going to deviate me from my Dharma. So what is your Dharma if I stop being an architect or stop designing buildings?

I'm not an architect. It's as simple as that. So Dharma is a self regulating principle. To remain who I am, I have to remain in that Dharma. As soon as I deviate from that Dharma, Dharma itself, eliminate me from that existence, stop practicing architecture, I'll be eliminated from architectural societies, architectural communities, all the architectural duties and responsibilities. I'm not something else.

So Bhagwan says, yada yada, Hi Dharma Seglani R. Bhavati. In this world, a role is assigned to each thing and being. If they deviate from the Dharma, I will eliminate them. As the regulating principle, to be the agency that does this, I will take Avatara. I will be a catalyst to make the change for those who are deviating from the Dharma. To eliminate from that society, that community, that part of this universe.

Abyutthanam, adharmasyatadhatmanam sujam. When there is a rise of Adharma, a lot of people are thinking that this is Dharma, but actually it's Adharma. So when that happens, when Dharma is misunderstood by beings and people, as the last time we have discussed, it's only for human beings because we have free will that we can deviate from our Dharma. We can be vegetarians and also can be non vegetarians. We don't know whether we were designed as vegetarians or not. Elephant knows he is designed as vegetarian.

Lion knows he is designed as carnivore. Because of our free will, we deviate from our Dharma when it becomes unbearable for the society. Swamiji used to say that you also, you know, surjami aham. During springtime, you see, when there are few weeds in your garden, you see, it's okay. You don't pay much attention to it. Then gradually your yard becomes filled with weeds.

Then less grass and more weeds. Then one Sunday, you put on your yard work clothes and say, I need to take care of this. You will tolerate it to a point. Let the weeds have good time. And then one Sunday you say, no, this is it or the protection of the grass. Vina Sahaja duskritam all the way.

So time and again you, as the Lord will come and set your yard right. Bhagawan said this, in my yard, I have to do the same thing. Paritra Naya Sadhunam Vinasaya. Somebody asked Swamijuman. They say, but if that's the case, why Bhagavan is not coming now? He said, Bhagavan clearly says Paritra Naya, Sadhuna.

If lesser evil is fighting with greater evil, Bhagavan has nothing to do with it. Let them figure it out how to kill each other. They will eliminate each other automatically. Bhagavan doesn't have to interfere. It is only that evil is not letting the good practice good. Then only Bhagavan comes.

In our case, it's a lesser evil fighting greater evil. It's still evil in the end. Therefore, he said, Bhagavan doesn't have to come yet. Dharma Sasthapanaarthaya. To establish Dharma again. As I said, it's a self regulating principle.

It will time and again it will reset Dharma so that the cycle will continue as it was designed. We take our car once in a while for tune up and wheel alignment. We tolerate it to a point. When it starts making noise while you're driving, I need to take it to the garage and calibrate it. So that is a self regulating principle to calibrate itself. Because time and again it gets out of its alignment.

And Bhagawan said, I as the self. I created this universe out of my own self, out of my own Maya. And I let it run through its own laws. The laws of nature are self regulating. So we don't have to control whatever the law of gravity and all that. We don't want to get up in the morning.

Let's make sure the law of gravity is working. Otherwise how I'm going to go down to the staircase. Because suddenly if I try to go down, I start flying into the ceiling. So I have to be very conscious that law of gravity is working every day. No, we don't have to. But my own behavior I have to regulate.

Because I have free will. I can be doing right. I also can be doing wrong. My free will is guided my mind and intellect and my mind and intellect can deceive me in doing something which is not right. I say I should not be doing this. But the mind will put an argument and say no.

Other people are doing it. So what's wrong in it then? Everybody's doing it. Cheating on 1040 because other people are doing it. I come to think that it's okay. But my conscience tell me it's not right.

But my mind and intellect will say that's okay. And that's what I suffer. So Bhagawan says, that's why I have to time and again rise in your own heart as your own inner voice. If I have few good thoughts which are still trying to direct me toward the right path, but many bad thoughts are avoiding me to exercise my right to follow the good thoughts, then that voice will rise in my heart. Because at least those good thoughts were propelling me to find what is right. So that's what Bhagawan said.

I will rise in your heart as your avatar. And that will redeem you from the Wrong that you are going to do, when will that happen? Janma Karma Chame Divyam evam yo Vidya Takvatah -- when you will realize that in its essence, I am the divine being, that this life is divine, given to me for learning to rise out of limitations. Once I realize what is the real truth, what is my real nature, then when I get out of this existence, when I exhaust all the vasanas and karmas of this existence, I will not take a new birth. If last time I experienced something and that was not really enjoyable, I somehow suffered through that experience. But then what will I do next?

I don't want to go there again ever. Because I realized that this is a painful existence. It is when we go back and forth I enjoyed some but suffer some. So let me go for the enjoyment in the bargain I also suffer. So that's why we have Punarabi Janamam Punarapi Maranam because our attachments are taking us back to that existence Even though we suffered through it we forget at times that there will be sufferings also attached to this pleasures. But once I realize my divine nature is omnipresence and omnipotence, I will get out of this Punarjanma.

So Tektvadeham Punarjunmati Saharjuna -- he comes to being my own self. The technique is now given, and we have discussed before that the root cause is attachment, and its byproducts are Raga, Bhaya and Krodha. Raga (attachment) is the root cause; Bhaya (fear) and Krodha (anger) are the byproducts. Once I realize that's the root cause, if I start getting out of attachment, fear and anger will not be there.

He said therefore the goal is to get rid of attachment. But I can't get rid of attachment unless I take refuge in something higher. Maam Upa Sri Tah -- one who takes refuge in "me." Then that "me" is the "I" that I keep reciting all my life.

If I take refuge in my "I" and do not rely on my body, mind and intellect to give me the peace and happiness which I am seeking, then I will be liberated. Liberated from attachment. Once I am liberated from attachment, I will be liberated from fear and anger. Bahavogna Tapasa Puta Madbhavam Agatha -- again we have to be reminded: you are not the guinea pig.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the path to liberation through the purification of attachment, fear, and anger (vita-raga-bhaya-krodha). Many have attained the divine state by taking refuge in the Lord and becoming purified by the fire of knowledge (jnana-tapasa puta). The root cause is attachment (raga), with fear and anger being its byproducts. Krishna teaches that by releasing attachment and taking refuge in the higher Self (mam upashritah), one becomes free from these binding emotions.

The beautiful verse "ye yatha mam prapadyante tams tathaiva bhajamy aham" reveals the universal nature of grace: however people approach the Divine, in that very manner does the Divine respond. All paths ultimately lead to the same destination. However, those seeking quick, measurable results in this world worship various powers and deities, because worldly success is easily visible and attainable. The challenge is that attachment to these results creates further bondage.

For daily practice, identify the primary attachments driving your actions today. Are you pursuing something because of genuine dharma or because you seek quick, visible results? Notice when fear or anger arise - trace them back to the underlying attachment. Practice the teaching "mam upashritah" - taking refuge in your own higher Self rather than in external outcomes. Ask yourself: Can I remain in my authentic nature (like an architect who refuses to design pipes because it is not his dharma) even when external pressures push me otherwise? When you find yourself attached to outcomes, remind yourself that the Self within is actionless, unborn, and Lord of all beings (bhutanam ishvaro'pi san).

snippets.title: Day 60: Divine Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः |

न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा |

एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः |
snippets.transliteration:
cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ .

na māṃ karmāṇi limpanti na me karmaphale spṛhā .

evaṃ jñātvā kṛtaṃ karma pūrvairapi mumukṣubhiḥ .
verseTranslations: The four divisions of society (the wise, the soldier, the merchant, the labourer) were created by Me, according to the natural distribution of Qualities and instincts. I am the author of them, though I Myself do no action, and am changeless.
My actions do not fetter Me, nor do I desire anything that they can bring. He who thus realises Me is not enslaved by action.
In the light of wisdom, our ancestors, who sought deliverance, performed their acts. Act thou also, as did our fathers of old.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We had been discussing chapter four, Jnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation of actions in Knowledge. This is all about knowledge, all about what the real I is. So far in chapters two and three, Bhagavan has been saying that what I consider to be "I" is not the real I, but that which is permanent, that which is Ajaha (unborn), that which is immortal -- that is me. Chapter three talked about Karma Yoga: how do I act in this world and not get bound by those actions? Chapter four continues that same theme: how do I act in this world but not get bound by my actions?

So the first thing Bhagavan says, Ajaha PI, I am unborn. He clarifies first that let's keep in mind that what's the theme of our discussion? Our theme of our discussion is from chapter two onward is I am unborn. Avya Yatma Immutable. There is no change ever takes place in the self. The supreme self which is all pervading.

Swamiji gives a commentary here that in the early part of Vedic literature there was a great emphasis on immortality. No death, deathlessness. He said that in the later part of this Vedic literature they switched on to Aja. Unbornness, birthlessness. So all of our stories about the Devas are looking for nectar Amrit. There is always a fear of death.

Over a period of time they realized it's not the death you should be worried about, it is the birth you should be worried about. As long as there is birth, there will be death. Only way you can overcome death is by not having birth. That's where it all started, because of my birth that I am now afraid of death. If I achieve the birthlessness, deathlessness I already achieved. So therefore Bhagavan clarifies very first declaration in this chapter is Ajaha Apisan, I am unborn.

No mutation ever takes place in myself. Now obviously Bhagavan is speaking from the highest perspective of the all pervading self. But we have also seen that our own self is no different than his self. This room space is no different than the space outside. Before this building was built, this space was nothing but the continuation of the space outside. I created this conditioning called walls, floor and ceiling.

Now this same space is part of the universal space, but I consider it to be a separate room space. So all the qualities of the space outside still remain intact in the room space. But in my perception, they're conditioned by the walls, floor and ceiling. In my own existence, it is something similar. The self which is all pervading in my own self are exactly same.

The qualities attributed to the Supreme Self are also valid for my own self. So the first thing is Ajahapi son. I am unborn as the Supreme Self. Therefore my own self is also unborn. No mutation ever took place. Space never get contaminated by or affected by bad designs.

We design buildings, not all of them are good. So we jokingly say the doctors bury their mistakes. What do we architects do? We put it out there for the world to see every time we pass it. Who the heck designed this thing? But the space in a good building or a bad building are not affected by an architect's design.

It remains immutable, imperishable. This place was not brought from Hanover County. It will never be transported back to Hanover County. So he said, I am unborn. Therefore you are unborn. No mutation ever took place.

But Bhutanam Isvaropi son. But I am still the Lord of all the beings. Beings are beings because of my presence. And they are created out of my Maya. It is my Maya which created this universe out of my own self. There was no other material available to Bhagavan when he created this universe other than his own self.

But if you say there are other material existing, he is limited. He is no more unlimited. So if he is unlimited, you have to accept that there was no other material ever available to him to create this universe. And therefore the material he used to create this universe is nothing but his own self. That self, he says, is immutable. No change ever took place in it.

Only in your perception. Out of your ignorance. Out of my ignorance, I create my world and identify with this body, mind and intellectual. Just as we walk into this room, we identify this space with this room and say, this room is too low, Ceiling is not too good. Neeli should have made some ceiling or higher. Because we are affected by the conditioning, our perception affected by the conditioning.

Same way Bhagavan said that Bhutana mi swopishan. All beings are who they are because of my presence. This room exists because of room space. Just walls, floor and ceiling does not make the room. The heart of this room is the space in the room. Without space, there is no room.

Without self, there is no being. So Bhagavan said, I am Isvar. I am the Lord of all beings. However, this universe I have put forth according to its own dharma. Maya has its own Dharma. Sattvarajas and Tamas, those gunas and Dharmas are inherent in this universe.

And when there is a decay of this Dharma, when those Dharmas decline, I as the Creator, will set it back. I will participate actively in the creation. To set the creation back to as I design, time and again, we renovated my building. I designed something. After a while it gets deteriorated. We just change carpet in my front room.

Because when I designed in 2004, I had a perception what the room looks like. Over time, the carpet got soiled. I have to the architect again and say, change the carpet. Now it looks the way I have thought in my mind before. So Bhagawan said the same way, I come back again. Yadayadahi Dharma seglanir Bhavati.

When the essential Dharma of this universe gets out of line, then I take active participation. Just as I took active participation in creating this universe. I'll set the universe back to its Dharma. Paritra naya Sadhunam, Vina saya chaduskritam. Whatever went out of Dharma, I will eliminate. And then whatever is in line with Dharma and protect it.

So the Dharma principle will be restored. And as I said, Dharma is a self regulating principle. As soon as you get out of your Dharma, you lost your existence. As soon as sugar loses its sweetness. If you put sugar on frying pan and it becomes black, and now you put in your mouth, it's not sweet. It lost its existence because it's lost its Dharma.

You won't call it sugar anymore. So Bhagavan says, as soon as the Dharma gets out of line, the thing or being loses its existence. I destroy them by very fact that the Dharma is lost. So he said, therefore I come back again and again, every time. So I assure you that my creation will always remain as I have designed. The will of Dharma makes it function.

And then he said that every being still has to continue working. All beings who are working, they're working in my path alone. No matter what I am doing or you are doing, she is doing, he is doing -- everybody is functioning because of that consciousness in them. They are living beings. Dead, Einstein cannot invent anything. As long as they are alive, they create.

And whether I am going in the right direction or wrong direction in terms of my goals in life, as long as I take the support of my consciousness, it will allow me to go in the direction which I think is appropriate. That is because of the equipment that I have.

The equipment which I have will decide what direction I will take. My mind, my intellect, my body will determine what actions I am taking and what direction I will take. Whatever my desires are. Therefore Kanksutta Karmanam Siddhi Ijanti IHA Devataha. Because we want success in this life. We want success which is miserable success.

Something which I can show people and say this is what I did in last 4 years, 5 years, 10 years. So what we'll do is something. If say this is some pie in the sky type of a goal, I don't really pursue it. I want to pursue something which is I can show the result to the world. In this world getting results of your actions are easy and measurable and showable. Therefore Bhagavan says Kangsadha Karmanam Siddhi Ijanti Ihadvattaha.

Therefore we pursue those senses. Because I think I will get the results which I can enjoy. The whole goal I have is to enjoy the fruits of my actions. I do not want to perform any action which I already know. There is no result for it. If I know that I can keep working in this company and they won't ever promote me or will ever recognize my work.

What is the normal advice? You better leave this company or find someplace else where you work and get results. So my fruits of actions are driving me. Therefore people are pursuing different paths based on what they think will give them those results. My field is different than yours, and your field is different than hers. Next verse says Chaturvarnam Mayasrishtam Guna Karmaha Vibhagashah Kartaram Aphima Vidhi Kartaram Avyam.

This is not a social commentary on Indian caste system. This book was not written to have a commentary on whether a caste system is right or wrong. This book is a commentary about yourself. It's a self development book. Gita was not written for you to learn and then teach other people. Gita was designed for you to learn yourself and make progress.

Now I don't know why I am putting these efforts in this field and not Going in. Why did I go to architecture school? I should have been smart enough to figure out that time that I should be there. Medical or maybe some business or Wall street type of commerce. Nobody wanted to go in commerce. In my days, MBA wasn't even invented.

I think it was there but nobody knew. Nobody ever told me, Neil, you can be mba. So only three options. I had you become a doctor. That's your first choice. Second was a chemical engineer, the second choice.

And third, either electrical or civil engineering. After that, no choice really. After that, BA, BA, BCom -- no value. Nobody told me that if you go to Commerce, Neil, and become a Wall Street banker, you'll be much better off than becoming an architect. Why did you follow what you followed?

Chaturvananyamaya Sristam Guna Karma Vibhaga Saha. Looking at the mental moods of people, you can say that the entire human race can be divided into four classifications.

And Bhagwan says I created them. I'm taking full responsibility. Don't think that it was by accident that people are different from each other. Guna Karma Vibhaga Sah. They need to be complementary. This society cannot function.

If all want to be architects, there won't be any clients. If I want to play a cop and robber game, somebody has to be the cop and somebody the robber, right? To play the game, I have to have both characters. To make this universe function, I need all the ingredients needed for this universe. To make the human race function, I need all types of people to make human society possible.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna declares that the four-fold order of society was created by Him according to the natural distribution of qualities (gunas) and actions (karma). Yet immediately He adds: "Though I am the author of this, know Me as the non-doer, immutable" (tasya kartaram api mam viddhy akartaram avyayam). This is a profound teaching on the nature of the Self - actions take place, creation happens, yet the Self remains actionless. Just as space is not affected by good or bad architecture within it, the Self remains untainted by whatever occurs in body, mind, and intellect.

The key to freedom lies in understanding "na mam karmani limpanti na me karma-phale spriha" - actions do not taint Me, nor do I have desire for their fruits. Without desire for results, there can be no attachment, and without attachment, no bondage. This is not about the four castes of Indian society but about the four types of mental temperaments found in every society and within each individual. We each have qualities suited for different roles, and living according to our natural disposition (svadharma) is the path to harmony.

Today, reflect on your own natural temperament and tendencies. What type of work aligns with your inherent qualities? Are you forcing yourself into roles that contradict your nature, like trying to make a lecture hall into a concert hall? Practice viewing your actions as Krishna describes His own: you are the apparent author, yet at your core, you remain the actionless witness. When you catch yourself anxious about results, remember that the sufferer and enjoyer is only the ego - the body, mind, and intellect. The Self within you, like space within a room, remains forever free and unchanged.

snippets.title: Day 61: Action in Inaction
snippets.sanskrit:
किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः |

कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः |

कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः |
snippets.transliteration:
kiṃ karma kimakarmeti kavayo.apyatra mohitāḥ .

karmaṇo hyapi boddhavyaṃ boddhavyaṃ ca vikarmaṇaḥ .

karmaṇyakarma yaḥ paśyedakarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ .
verseTranslations: What is action and what is inaction? It is a question which has bewildered the wise. But I will declare unto thee the philosophy of action, and knowing it, thou shalt be free from evil.
It is necessary to consider what is right action, what is wrong action, and what is inaction, for mysterious is the law of action.
He who can see inaction in action, and action in inaction, is the wisest among men. He is a saint, even though he still acts.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Renouncing Actions in Knowledge. It's all about knowledge. It's all about Karma. So the first thing we have seen in this chapter is where Bhagavan gave his identity: my nature is that I'm unborn. And because his nature is Ajaha, the nature of myself is also Ajaha -- unborn.

But as long as I am in this life, that will continue performing actions. So also I need to understand actions. Bhagavan said that this world is created by me and it is regulated by Dharma. It is regulated by the laws of nature that we know. The laws of nature have no exceptions and therefore they're self regulated. Nobody has to vouch over law of gravitation.

Nobody vouch over the laws of thermodynamics. And you can rely on them. Only time the people deviate from the Dharma is when they have free will. The human beings are the only one who have free will. So when they deviate from that Dharma, Bhagavan said, I manifest to make that Dharma aligned again. So we can say at the micro level, when I will deviate from my Dharma, the situation will teach me to come back to my Dharma.

You learn a lesson by your own actions, by your own situations. And then as long as there are good thoughts, as we have seen, it says Paritranaya Sadhunam Vinasaacha Duskrita. At the macro level, you can say the whole human society in micro level, when there are good thoughts, are overwhelmed by the bad thoughts in my mind. But one thing, as long as you hang on to the good thoughts, I will manifest in your mind and take care of all the bad thoughts so that the good thoughts will thrive and then you will be able to do what is right for you. Well, then the question obviously occurred: why can't everyone understand what is right and wrong? Bhagavan said, because in this world it is easier for us to find the results of our actions, so we pursue our senses and pursue the deities of our senses.

In other words, we try to get success out of our actions. And that's miserable and enjoyable. I can see that I have done something and I got these results. So then we get more and more attached to those actions. That's where the problem starts. So the whole chapter is all about how to detach yourself from your own actions.

Therefore he said that this yoga I have taught to Vivaswan. And then he taught to Manu and the Manu taught to Eswaku. And thus all those Rajasis knew what is right, how to act in this world. So you are liberated. So you're not bound by your actions. But over a period of time that is lost.

So people are all got then attached to the actions. Everybody is trying to put more importance in what I have accomplished and achieved. And that's how you are judged by the society, by yourself. And they say that's what the problem is. So I'm teaching you this yoga which will liberate you from that. And then he said, obviously all people are not made equal.

Chatharuvanyam Maya Guna Karma, vi Pagisah that in any given society the people are four types. And as we discussed last time, no matter how hard you try, you will not be able to justify that. Bhagavan meant the four caste system universified. There are not four types of colors, Chatruvand. Four types of people of different colors I have created. So these were about the skin colors.

Obviously there are no four types of skin colors in our society. Or you can look at it this way. The colors are associated with Satvaraja and Tamas as white, red and black. And then they have added the yellow as the Vaishya. Then it's one of the commentary I have read says, okay, if that's the case, if it was a skin color, all whites are Brahmins, all red Indians are Kshatriyas, all Mongolis. People who are yellowish are Vaishyas and all dark people are Shudras.

That's not true either. So these are the colors of your mind. These are the colors of one's mental textures. See, the people in this world come with four different mental textures. And depending on the Guna and karma, they are divided into the four classification. Any given society at any given time that I am the author of them.

In other words, they exist because of me. But I'm not involved in. I didn't create them. They are by themselves have their own gunas and karmas. So even though I Act, I do not participate in that. As this self, as the supreme Self, there is no creation.

All exists is himself as one single entity. And therefore what is created is in perception only. So he said, even though I am the author of Jatir Vraniam, I am not the responsible party. And then we have seen that he said the Namaam Karmani limpanti Namay karmafulasproha. Why I am not attached to that? Because I am not Karma Falas proha.

You only get attached when you have Karma falasproha. From the self's perspective, he does not have anything to gain. So at macro level, the Bhagavan has nothing to achieve and therefore he has no desire. As long as you have no desire, you cannot be bound by it. At a micro level, all the desires are at my intellectual and mental level only myself is not participating in it. As the self, I'm completely detached from my actions.

So the actions are performed at the body level, are taught as the mind level desired at the intellectual and mental level. So these sufferers are also mind, body and intellect only. My actions are not right physical level, I suffer through physical level. At a mental level, I suffer through mind and suffer through intellect when they are wrong. But the self is not attached. Therefore the Namam Karmani Limpanti self is not affected by any actions, good, bad or ugly.

Just as our analogy of space, the quality of the space inside the room is exactly the same as outside the room. This space, no matter how I try to contaminate it, will not be affected and will not change its characteristics. Because it remains exactly same as the universal space outside. So myself in me is also in the same manner is not getting affected by my actions. Ithima yo Vijayanarti Karma Vihen NASA badhya. The one who knows this then my accents are only binding my body, mind and intellect.

Therefore the enjoyers and sufferers are nothing but the body, mind and intellect. At the ego level only, the self is not participating and not suffering. One who knows that Karma bhi NASA Badhyate actions do not bind them. Many people in the past, your ancestors knew this. And they continue to perform actions as required by their duties and the roles they've taken. But knowing that core of their being is not affected by these actions.

They lived very successful life and liberated themselves. And therefore I'm now advising you that you should also do this. Because one thing is clear. You cannot live without actions. Action is a signature of life. As long as you're alive, you have to perform actions.

When actions stop that's your death. Only in death you will be actionless. Action you must perform. But you need to change the attitude towards action. So you become actionless. You as the core of your being is not participating in these actions.

So you align yourself with the one which is not participating. Not align one which is fighting this battle. That's how you will become actionless. Goal is to become liberated from actions. One way to liberate from action is to become actionless. If I don't drive, Meena and I always argue you have a lot of traffic tickets.

Look at me, I've only got one or two. Compare the amount of miles I drive and compare the mile you drive. Then put a probability on every hundred thousand miles you drive or 10,000 how many tickets you got and how many tickets I got. So one way to not get a ticket is what? But you can avoid that. Because you can't come from your home to the class without driving.

So driving is unavoidable. So somehow you have to avoid getting tickets of other means. So action is unavoidable in life. So getting bound by the action is also unavoidable. But there may be other means to not getting attached is not identifying with the one who is acting. Then when you disown your relative who is doing something bad, you are no more attached to the actions.

As long as you are relating to that. I am part of that organization which is doing something wrong. You are bound by that. You detach yourself from that. You are just a witness now. So there must be another way of detaching ourselves from actions.

Our Sastra says there is a way. The concept Saksi Chaitanya. Just as when I am watching other people witnessing what other people are doing, I am not getting affected. Because I am just witness. You are doing some two people are fighting. I cannot be blamed for that fight the same.

If I start seeing my actions as a third party then I will not be bound by my actions. It's called Saksichaitanya. So the next verse says Kim Karma Kim Akarma IDHI kavayo ABHI atramo hita ha. And as Swami explains, even in our day to day life we call Kavi a poet as a Kavi in our vernacular languages. But Kavi with the name of a Rishi was a great Rishi who has written so many of these. You know Richas in Vedas.

So after that, even the other Rishis, other people who were wise, were also called Kavis. The word Kavi became a connotation for a very wise person. A wise person is supposed to know what is right and what is wrong. But he says karmas are so complex that even wise people do not know what is action and what is inaction. They get confused, deluded by that.

See, in this world, if we look at the relationship of cause and effect, everything in our universe works on cause and effect. So this universe is a very predictable universe.

There is nothing in this universe which cannot be predicted as long as you know all the factors which are acting on that action. So when you send the Mars, whatever the Yan as long as you calculate all the forces and act on that correctly and perfectly, it will land exactly as you plan. If you don't know one factor which is affecting it, you will not be able to predict where it is going to land. So if you know everything about how the world reacts to actions, you will be able to predict what the results would be. Not very difficult in theory. But it is difficult to know how many things will affect my actions in this world.

I submit a proposal and I think I have done everything I know. So the result should be this. What I don't know is what the other people are doing, what their proposals would be like and therefore I cannot predict. Therefore I shouldn't be worried about what will come out of that. Therefore I said the nature of action in action is so complex because so many factors affect the result. They even get confused when they try to predict what will happen.

Tate Karma Pravakshami -- therefore I am going to tell you what Karma is, not what Karma Phala (the fruits of action) will be, but what the nature of action itself is.
snippets.reflection:
These verses address one of the most profound puzzles of spiritual life: "Kim karma kim akarma iti kavayo 'py atra mohitah" - even the wise are confused about what is action and what is inaction. Krishna promises to explain this mysterious subject, for understanding it liberates one from all evil. The teaching culminates in verse 18: one who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is the wisest among people, a true yogi who has accomplished all actions (kritsnakarmakrit).

What does it mean to see inaction in action? When you become so skilled at something that your mind and intellect are no longer effortfully engaged, the action becomes automatic - like driving a car after years of practice. The deeper teaching is that the Self is always inactive; only the body, mind, and intellect act. Conversely, apparent inaction can be the most powerful action - like a supervisor whose mere presence makes workers productive, or a political leader whose decision not to act shapes history. By not acting, you are still doing something with consequences.

Today, observe your actions throughout the day. Notice which activities engage your full mental effort and which flow naturally without strain. When driving, walking, or doing routine tasks, recognize that "you" (the witnessing Self) are not truly acting - it is the conditioned body-mind operating. Also notice where you are not acting - and what effect that inaction is having. Are there good intentions being overwhelmed by neglect? The wise person understands that the nature of action is gahana - deep and mysterious. Results depend on countless factors beyond your knowledge or control. Focus on performing right action with the understanding that the Self is always the non-participant witness (sakshi chaitanya), and you will find freedom even while engaged in intense activity.

snippets.title: Day 62: Types of Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः |

त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः |

निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः |
snippets.transliteration:
yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāmasaṅkalpavarjitāḥ .

tyaktvā karmaphalāsaṅgaṃ nityatṛpto nirāśrayaḥ .

nirāśīryatacittātmā tyaktasarvaparigrahaḥ .
verseTranslations: The wise call him a sage, for whatever he undertakes is free from the motive of desire, and his deeds are purified by the fire of Wisdom.
Having surrendered all claim to the results of his actions, always contented and independent, in reality he does nothing, even though he is apparently acting.
Expecting nothing, his mind and personality controlled, without greed, doing bodily actions only; though he acts, yet he remains untainted.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? So we had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of renouncing actions in knowledge. Not physically renouncing actions, but renouncing attachment to them through knowledge. How to not identify with your actions. So far we have seen that Bhagavan said Ajaha -- I am Ajaha, I'm unborn.

Therefore he is also Amara. Therefore he is deathless. One who has no birth cannot have any death. So because he is Ajaha, he is also Amara. And not only that, but he says, I am a Karmaha, I am actionless, I am birthless, I am deathless, also actionless. So at the macro level he says, I'm not participating in anything that you consider is happening.

It is only happening because of my presence. But I am not actively participating in it because I don't have any desire to get anything out of it. There is no desire for Karma Phala of these actions, therefore I am not involved in it. Even the action is taking place because of his presence. But because he is not involved in it, with any desire to gain anything out of it, he is actionless. Same thing applies at a micro level to our self, which we constantly call it I that I am, I am.

But then everything we say after that I am, that I is not involved in it. I am working, I am speaking. So all the words which we attach to I and am that existence, I is not involved in it. So Bhagwan says, who is involved in that action? Then the one who consider that to be the actor is involved in it. That I, when I say I am eating, that's a physical act, so the body is involved.

Then when I say I like what I eat, my mind is involved. And then my intellect says, this is pretty nutritious, so I'm going to get some benefit out of it. My intellect is involved. Whatever gets involved, that's the one which is bound by its results. So once the I is not involved as the actor and therefore remains Actionless. That which gets involved will be bound by the actions and therefore has to receive the results.

So my body is involved in my physical act. So more exercise I do or less exercise I do, more I eat or less I eat will show up in my body. When I go to my doctor, he figures out that you may not have been doing this or you may not be watching your diet. Because my lab results tell him exactly. All that tells him what I had been doing. So the body is bound by its own actions.

Whatever the grudges and complexes I carry, they will show up in my mental attitude. So the mind is bound by what mind does. Then what I learn or not learn will show up at my intellectual level. So this body, mind and intellect are bound by these actions. Till I get attached to that body, mind and intellect, I am not involved and actionless. But as soon as I identify with this body, mind and intellect, I become the doer.

And that doer is, aham, the ego. Once the ego is formed, that ego becomes the enjoyer and sufferer of these actions. So now who are we trying to really liberate right now? Not the body, not the mind, not the intellect. Ego is the sufferer and enjoyer. That ego is trying very hard to redeem itself.

Achieving a state where there is no unhappiness, there is no sorrow and there is no death. So that ego is trying very hard to achieve that by actions. Because it can only attach itself to the body, mind and intellect. And therefore it says, let me achieve this. I can achieve security by accomplishing things and acquiring things. Or I can achieve deathlessness by finding all the latest cures about or anti aging drugs, whatever that is.

And it's failing miserably. No matter how hard I try, I think I'm not aging. But other people say, Neil, you look little old now. My nephews and nieces. Kaka, now you look a little tired. And what do you mean?

We are trying very hard to achieve what we are trying to achieve through the means available to us right now. But we are not getting there. So Bhagavan said, the only one way to achieve is you disassociate yourself from actions. But actions cannot stop. So say that you have to achieve that knowledge where you start seeing inaction in actions. Actions are being performed.

The only entity which is inactive in this is my self. My self is not taking any part; my consciousness, just because it is there, makes all three function -- the body, mind and intellect. Swamiji uses the example that a supervisor really doesn't do anything. On a factory floor, the supervisor is not operating machines, but his presence makes all the work go on. If he's not there, work will be all over the place.

I give my real life example a lot of times. I used to work in India in an architect's firm, and my boss used to come to the United States every two years or so to renew his green card. During those four to six weeks he was here, we would have a complete vacation. We all go to work every morning just as when he was there. We try very hard to work for about half an hour. And then somebody will say, "You know, Neil, did you know this?"

And he will start a topic and then everybody get involved. We have about six, seven people in the same room. That topic will go on till lunchtime. Then we realize, oh God, we haven't done anything. Well, let's have lunch. And then after that we can work something.

And that will go on till about four weeks. And when we realize that one week my boss is going to come back, we start suddenly putting something on a paper which looks like we had done some work. In the end, there was no real work done when he was not there. And as soon as he comes, everything goes back to normal. We are working, just as the supervisor's presence makes all the workers work. But the supervisor really doesn't do the work himself.

He doesn't sit down and start doing what he was supposed to do. His presence make it work. But he is not participating in your activities the same way the self is not participating, but the very presence of the self, the consciousness make people work. But because right now my identification is with the workers, all the drawbacks and the quality of the workers become my qualities. But if I identify with that self who is actionless, then I'll see myself as actionless too. Karmani Akarma Yahya Pashet -- one who sees inaction.

Action only takes place when my ego gets involved. When I was in Zambia, it was so difficult to get a driver's license because the test was about 20 times more difficult than what you go through here. And without a driver's license you can't do anything. So you are so keen on getting a driver's license, you work so hard, and your mind and intellect are both involved in driving so intensely. Last week I told somebody, "You know, I'm trying very hard to remember everybody's name."

And she said, don't try too hard. That was the problem -- I was putting too much mental effort into it. So when I'm trying too hard to drive the car, it's very difficult. But now when I drive, I don't consider that as a real action requiring effort because my mind and intellect are not intensely involved while I'm driving -- it has become automatic. So Bhagavan said, when you do that, you reach a level where all your actions you see just as what you see, you're driving, you are literally removed. You have your mind and intellect are free to think about other things. Karmaniya, Karmaiya, Pashet, Karmani, Chakarma Yaha.

Not only that, but even though it seems inaction, but action is taking place. By not acting also you are doing something which is affecting you. Sabuddhiman, Manusheshu. Out of all these people who consider themselves intellectuals, such a person is a wise one. Sabuddhima and Manish Yeshu, he is a Buddhiman. He is a true intelligent person who figured out that actions are taking place at the level of body, mind and intelligence, not at my self level.

Sahayuktaha, Such a person is Yogi. He is connected Yogi, one who is connected with the self. As we have seen at a macro level, the supreme self, the God is everywhere, is omniscient, omnipotent and omnipresent. At micro level, myself is omnipresent, omniscient, omnipotent. In my this body, mind and intellect. When I see that is myself, I'm connected with that self.

So Sai Yuktah, Krishna Karmakrit and such a person knows how to act. In this world we are all acting but at a very lesser capacity. I think they say you are only using the 1/10 of the capacity of your brain. Our brain has so much capacity, but we are only using it at a very micro level. Bhagwan said, if you then think about how capable you are when you connect to your higher self, then when you act, your actions will be perfect. Krishna, Karma, Krita, Such a person know how to perform real actions.

It actually says how to become efficient in life by connecting with your higher self. And then the next few verses actually give the prescription for how to connect to that higher self. So now we have learned what the issue is. The issue is that I consider myself to be a mortal being who has birth, who is acting in this world and suffering. Bhagavan said, no, no, you're birthless, you're deathless and you have all the capacity to work in this world -- you just have a wrong identification. So yes, we hear this word Samaram in our vernacular language.

When there is some event taking place -- Samaram. For whom are all events taking place in his life? Kama Sankalpa Varjita -- there should be Kama Sankalpa Varjita. Kama means desire. Sankalpa is translated here as planning; I would say determination. What are we determining?

I want to do this and I want to get out of this. So first I have a desire. I want to make million dollar, then make a plan. How am I going to make a million dollar? That plan is based on what I'll get a million dollar out of it. So all my actions are first starts with the desire, then I have a plan to achieve that particular results out of that action.

And therefore I'm bound to fail. Because first of all I have not figured out whether what I desire is really appropriate for my capability. And secondly, whether the plan I'm putting together action I'm putting together or capable of achieving it. Because only thing available to me as I said in this world is knowledge of my actions. I do not have knowledge about how the world is going to react to these actions but I'm still determining what the results would be. Therefore there are more unknowns than knowns in my actions. There are more chances of failure than success.

So: do not have any desire and do not have any plan to get something out of it. Kama Sankalpa Varjita. Gnana Agni Dagda Karmanam -- I am acting in this world, but all my actions are burnt with the fire of knowledge. The knowledge that this body, mind and intellect are limited in their capabilities. But the self which is involved in these actions is only a Sakshi Chaitanya -- a witness -- and he is not affected by any of these actions.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the qualities of a true sage (pandita): one whose every undertaking is free from desire and selfish planning (kama-sankalpa-varjita), whose actions are burned in the fire of knowledge (jnanagni-dagdha-karmanam). Such a person, though apparently acting, does nothing at all (naiva kinchit karoti sah), because they have surrendered attachment to results and remain ever content and independent (nitya-tripto nirasrayah). The culmination is verse 21: expecting nothing, with controlled mind, abandoning all possessiveness, performing only bodily actions, one incurs no sin (kilbisham).

The teaching here addresses the fundamental error: we identify with the doer and therefore become bound by results. The ego is the sufferer and enjoyer, not the Self. When we act from desire (kama) and planning for specific outcomes (sankalpa), we plant seeds that must bear fruit. But when actions arise spontaneously from our nature without personal agenda, they leave no karmic residue. It is like the difference between a new employee desperate to impress versus a master craftsman who simply does excellent work because that is who they are.

For today's practice, before each significant action, pause and ask: What desire is driving this? What outcome am I planning and attached to? Practice "tyaktva karma-phalasangam" - releasing attachment to results before you begin. Notice how this changes the quality of your engagement. When you finish an action, practice letting it go like a post-it note that leaves no mark. The sage acts only at the bodily level (shariram kevalam karma) - meaning the deeper Self is uninvolved. Can you act today with your body and skills fully engaged while your inner witness remains detached, content, and free?

snippets.title: Day 63: The Sword of Wisdom
snippets.sanskrit:
यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः |

गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः |

ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yadṛcchālābhasantuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ .

gatasaṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthitacetasaḥ .

brahmārpaṇaṃ brahma havirbrahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam .
verseTranslations: Content with what comes to him without effort of his own, mounting above the pairs of opposites, free from envy, his mind balanced both in success and failure; though he acts, yet the consequences do not bind him.
He who is without attachment, free, his mind centered in wisdom, his actions, being done as a sacrifice, leave no trace behind.

For him, the sacrifice itself is the Spirit; the Spirit and the oblation are one; it is the Spirit Itself which is sacrificed in Its own fire, and the man even in action is united with God, since while performing his act, his mind never ceases to be fixed on Him.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasi Yoga. Yoga of Renouncing actions in Knowledge. So far we have seen that actions are necessary, but actions are also binding. My ultimate goal is to get happiness only way I feel happiness. I'm completely liberated from my limitations and here I am acting in this world and actions are binding. So what is the prescription?

What is that one yoga which will liberate me from these limitations? So in the beginning Bhagavan said, this is the yoga which I taught from time immemorial to people. And people have been benefited by this by practicing this yoga to release themselves from these bondages. So I'm going to teach you again and see, the technique is very, very simple. You have to end all your actions in knowledge that you are not the actor. It is as simple as that.

Right now we are taking burden upon ourselves of something which does not belong to us, a responsibility which does not belong to me. I'm taking upon myself which is to control the Karmaphala. My constant goal in life is to get the desired results. That's why we plan five year plan, three year plan. People ask me all the time, Neil, what's your plan? I say, what do you mean what's my plan?

I'm talking about retirement. What's your plan for retirement? You have to plan out retirement in a particular manner so that then I can enjoy the retirement. So we plan our actions, keeping the final results in mind, which is Karma Phala. Karma Phala by very nature is not in my hand because I'm not the Karma Falada. The rest of the world is the Karma Falada.

I act and the world react and that burden on me is binding me. Bhagawan said, once you realize that you are not the actor, the one who you think you are. This body, mind and intellect is not the one who you try to satisfy. The one which is seeking happiness is someone other than your body, mind and intellect. One who wants to be liberated is someone other than your body, mind and intellect. So he starts out by giving his identity, say Ajaha, a peace on Abhyatma.

I myself is unborn, deathless, immutable, and also do not take part in any actions. And therefore the karmas don't bind me. The actions which I don't take part in, they cannot bind me. Bhagavan said, at the macrocosm I am the all pervading Brahman who is infinite, unborn, deathless. And at the micro level Atman has the exact same quality. So at the macro level he is Brahmandu, all pervading, Almighty, all potent, omniscient God.

At a macro level is Myself which I constantly refer. I is nothing but his own Self. We have logically deducted in our discussion that this world cannot be separate from Him. Because when he created this universe, the cosmos, the Brahman, no other material available to him other than his own Self created out of his own Self. And therefore you and I and this world cannot be any separate from Him. But that understanding when it takes place that this room space is no different than the space outside, then all the limitations of the room space will be gone.

So right now the room space thinks it's limited by its wall, floor and ceiling, and it is suffering from its limitation. "I want this room to have a higher ceiling." These limitations are also nothing but his own manifestation. If God is omnipresent, where is my body, my intellect, my mind? They are also part of Him. There is only one material available to him to create this universe, which is his own self.

So he created out of his own self. And now I'm trying to liberate his self from these limitations which are also part of his self. It is like a cup which is made up of ice is immersed into water. So the water outside the cup is also water. Water inside the cup is also water. And the cup itself is nothing but water.

But the crystallization creates identification of name and form and shape. The ego is that crystallization of the shape of a cup. When it melts, it will be all water. So Bhagavan said, once you start realizing that the self you are trying to liberate is already liberated, it is not taking part in any of your actions and therefore it is not bound by it. But you are now identifying this self with this limited body, mind and intellect, with his name, forms and colors. And therefore you are reflecting all its limitations.

So he said, now you start contemplating on it and then live your life. We have seen that how to live life is Vitaraga Bhayakrodha -- without any attachment, without any particular desired fruits of actions which I had been trying to achieve, which are not in my hand.

According to your swadharma. We have learned Swadharma. This body has its own Swadharma. Mind has its own swadharma. Intellect own swadharma. Just go with that flow.

If I try to make this hall into a concert hall, I'll be disappointed. It does not have any of the qualities of a concert hall. I try to have a music party and then I say I don't sound good here. Because the hall does not have the quality to have the acoustics of a concert hall. As long as I live with the limitations of this room, I'll be happy with this room. As soon as I get out of my expectations of what this hall can do.
