I'll be disappointed. Bhagavan said, follow your Svadharma and do actions without any attachment, without any particular expectation of the fruits of actions. So the last verse, the 22nd, describes the state you should be achieving to be perfectly happy.

The stage which you have to achieve is Yadruchanthusthaha. Content with whatever comes to you without effort. That sounds a little tricky to understand. It does not mean that you didn't put in your efforts. But it means: without conniving and manipulating to control the results, without scheming so that everything will fall in place exactly as you want.

That's not going to happen. The results are not in your hand, no matter how smart you are. Therefore, you act according to your dharma. Then whatever comes -- without manipulating outcomes -- you accept contentedly. You put your efforts.

You realize that was according to my efforts. Move on to the next step. Yadruchala va santoshta Dvanda Athitaha. Of course we know that there are times that will be conducive. At time the fruits will be not conducive. I expected something.

I was targeting to achieve this. But I end up getting this. So that's going to happen. That's a given that the law of nature that things will be different every time, same effort. You put two different times, get two different results. Last time I said this and everybody was very excited.

And this time I said let's do this. And nobody is excited. So the world will be like that. Therefore, you will be buffeted between hope and dejection. Vimatsaraha without envy. Now this sounds very difficult.

But it is the only way you can be happy, because as you have seen in our analogies, somebody will always be a little better than me no matter how high I go. I saw on CNBC someplace that the most difficult group of people to plan retirement for is millionaires. It's easier for someone in the hundred thousand range. They can project how many times your current income you need for retirement. It's easy for a guy making $60,000 a year. Guys making $10 million a year -- they're very difficult.

You see, it's very difficult as you go higher and higher to achieve that perfection. Bill Gates -- if you tell him he needs an income seven times his current income to retire, he will never be able to retire. So Bhagavan said, Vimatsarah: do not judge your situation by comparing with the other person. You do not know his situation. Every time I see Facebook, I get very depressed because everybody else in the world seems so happy.

I'm the only one who has all these responsibilities and problems. Do not compare your situation with others. That's where the envy comes. I stopped reading Fortune and Bloomberg and Newsweek because it depresses me. Vimatsaraha -- Bhagwan said, the only way to be happy is not to compare your situation with others.

Sama Siddhava Siddha, we know success and failure. It's a relative term. But you decided what success is and you did what failure is. You remember that whatever really came is what you really deserved. Swamiji used to say, you don't get what you desire, you get what you deserve. Sama Siddha ashidhav krutvapi nani badhyata.

He never gets bound by any actions he performs, good, bad or ugly. Because once you perform actions you're done with, there's nothing you can do about it. So whatever comes back, you say, okay, next move, let's go to the next one. So you see, that's the state you need to achieve. And it seems very difficult, but it is truly, I'll tell you, it is the only way you will be happy. When you get closer to that state, it may not be exactly as you imagine in your mind what yogi should be.

But at some level, you have to achieve this to be happy. So next verse says, gatha sangasya muktasya gnana avasthi da cha yajnaya acharataha Karma Samagram Praviliyate. Our goal right from the beginning was not to be bound by my actions. My actions should be always pristine and come with the results which are complete. So I will never have to be reacting to it. So I don't want to be bound by my actions.

So the first goal we have said is Gata Sangasya. Attachment to your actions. Whose actions will be as perfect as they need to be to achieve the goal which we established in previous verse. One who is not attached to his actions. See, once I'm attached to my actions -- I had an interview, I thought I did the best in my interview.

Then this happens all the time. When we go for an interview, we come back and they select us. How can they select him? I think we were the best team. Give us the feedback. All of them are qualified.

But what did we not do? You did everything right. But we thought the other day I was a little better than you are a little more appropriate for this project. But we are so attached to our actions. We think that our actions are the most appropriate. Should get the result I am looking for.

But once I perform action, I should not be attached to Gata Sangasya. We are detached to your actions. Once you perform actions and move on, you are liberated from it. You feel free because you are not thinking about it. Gnana Avasthita Cheta Saha. But this thing only came because I'm established in knowledge.

I have learned over and over and over again. The results are not in my hand. Once that knowledge takes place that no matter how better I do, results will never be in my hand. Same presentation you make one time and you are the best. And next time they will say you are the lowest. Gnana Vastyatchiyata Saha.

His intellect is established in the knowledge that only control I have is on my own actions and not on the results. Yajnaya Acharataha Karma. Therefore he is acting for only one reason.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 22 presents the state we must achieve for perfect happiness: content with what comes without scheming (yadriccha-labha-santushtah), beyond the pairs of opposites (dvandvatitah), free from envy (vimatsarah), balanced in success and failure (samah siddhav asiddhau). Such a person, though acting, is not bound. Verse 23 shows the method: being free from attachment (gata-sangasya), liberated (muktasya), with mind established in knowledge (jnanaavasthita-chetasah), acting only for yajna - such a person's karma completely dissolves (samagram praviliyate).

The profound verse 24 reveals the ultimate vision: "Brahmarpanam brahma havir brahmagnau brahmana hutam" - the offering is Brahman, what is offered is Brahman, the fire is Brahman, the offerer is Brahman. When one sees this unity, even while acting, one remains united with God (brahmaiva tena gantavyam). This is like ice immersed in water - the cup, the water inside, and the water outside are all the same substance. The crystallization creates apparent separation, but upon melting, all is revealed as one.

Today, practice contentment with whatever comes naturally from your efforts, without manipulating results. When comparing yourself to others (a major source of suffering), remember "vimatsarah" - you do not know their full situation. What looks like success on social media hides struggles you cannot see. In your actions today, practice the Brahman vision: see the instrument of action (your body), the effort expended, the field of action, and the actor as expressions of one reality. When you fail or succeed, maintain "samah siddhav asiddhau" - equal-mindedness. Ask: If I truly believed that everything involved in my action is Brahman, how would I approach this task differently?

snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Enunciation of action in Knowledge. So far we have seen that chapter two defined what Yoga is and then told Arjuna that Yogastha Guru Karmani, you perform actions rooted in Yoga. And then Bhagavan defined what yoga is. Samatam Yoga Uchate, equanimity is Yoga. That was the simple but very powerful definition Bhagavan gives it.

Samatam Yoga Uchate, equanimity of mind is Yoga if your mind is balanced in all situations, whether conducive or unconducive. Bhagwante Dutch Yoga. But then how do I translate that into my daily life? So Bhagavan said Yoga Karmasu Kavushalam, dexterity in your actions is Yoga. If you are performing action without any anxiety, then obviously there will be effective actions. And if this anxiety about the fruits of actions is not there, then your actions will be effective.

Bhagavan says that's the sign of you being establishing Yoga. Bhagawan dedicated chapter three for defining Karma Yoga. So we have seen in chapter three what Karma Yoga is. Karmas are binding because they are bound by the law of causation. It is bound by the law of cause and effect that if I perform an action that will be the cause and there will be effect which is a reaction from the world and I'll be bound by their reaction. How to mitigate that causation is Karma Yoga.

So chapter three Bhagavan dedicated to define what Karma Yoga is. And in a simple term in verse nine, he said Yajnarthaat Karmano Anyatra Loko Ayam Karma Bandanah. Any action which is not performed for Yajna is binding in this world. So the simple definition of Karma Yoga is when I perform action for Yajna, then it is Karma Yoga. And we have then defined Yajna. Yajna is any action which is performed for the greater good is Yajna, any action which is performed for my selfish gain.

Is binding action, Karma. Any action which is performed for the greater good is Yajna. Yajna, Loko, Ayam, Karma, Bandanah. Any action which is performed for the selfish motives, if I am at the center of the result, it is for me that's a selfish motive. And therefore Bhagavan said, you're bound by that action. Whatever the reaction comes from the world of your action, you're bound by that.

You have to enjoy it or suffer it. But if it is performed with a greater good, then you are not bound by it. You perform action and your story ends there. Whatever results come out, the world will suffer or enjoy. So we have defined Karma Yoga in chapter three. Chapter four is now centered on the word Yajna.

So in chapter three, we have learned what Karma Yoga is, is to perform actions in the spirit of Yajna. But what yajna is is now defined in chapter four. And then chapter five will take that a step further. And what sannyasa is, this chapter is labeled Renunciation of Action in Knowledge. So I'm now renouncing my actions and not mine by thorough understanding that I'm not the doer. In other words, I'm not capable of doing anything unless I'm enabled by all others.

All others in this world have to do so many things for me to do even the smallest act of drinking tea. When I come to understand that I am not the sole one in charge of my action, then my ego will diminish. And then I come to understand that the ego actually has no real part in the consciousness which is enabling it to perform action. So Bhagavan said, that is how I renounce my action in knowledge. When I renounce my actions completely, I become a sannyasi. When I have no sense of agency, I am a sannyasi.

So this concept of Karma Yoga is defined in three chapters. First, define Karma Yoga. And then we will learn what is Sannyasa. So far in chapter four, we have learned what is action, what is inaction. One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction. He's the person who sees things as they are.

There are times when I'm acting, but it's of no consequence. And there are times I'm not acting, but there are great consequences of my not acting. That itself is a great action. We have seen last time that Mitch McConnell not bringing legislation to the floor is inaction. But it's the greatest action he performs -- by not doing anything. Similarly, there are times we don't do anything.

If we don't perform our duty, it's an inaction. But that's a great action performed by us which will have the consequences. So you'll learn what is inaction? The one who sees through inaction and action. He knows what actions are. And then we have seen the characteristics of a sage.

We have seen similar Characteristics in Chapter 2 in Sthita Prajna Lakshana. The last section of Chapter 2 define what a man of perfect wisdom is. So the last verse we have seen. Yadruchalabhasantustaha Dhwandvati Taha Matsyara Sama Siddha asiddhavcha Krustva nani badyate. Who does not get bound by the action? A man of perfect wisdom.

What is perfect wisdom? What is action and what is inaction? One who has learned this art of action. Such a person is from our perspective. He is acting feverishly. Swami Chinmayananda was the most dynamic person I knew.

He was acting all the time. But none of his actions ever bound him. Because Sama Siddhi Asiddhavcha same in success and failure. You take a project and you have great goals. Sometimes you succeed and sometimes you don't. But if you don't take the success and failure to your heart then you are a yogi.

But therefore those actions do not bind you. He is happy with whatever comes naturally. I perform my actions. What comes to me, I accept as Prasad. I do not question why me and why not me. I am not getting result.

Other people are not doing anything but getting all the credits. But once a one who does not think in those terms, he is happy. Yadrucha Lava Santustha. He gets whatever without any anxiety. He is happy with that Dvandvati Tah. He is beyond the pairs of opposites.

In other words, he is not affected by the pairs of opposites. Pairs of opposites are very much in this world. There are days which are cold and there are days which will be very hot. But if I know how to deal with both of them then I am a happy person. How do I compare myself whether I am successful or not? By comparing myself to others.

If I see others are not as successful as I am then I consider myself successful. But I think I am not as successful others. Then I consider myself a failure. That's how we judge ourselves. Our gauge is not inside. Our gauge is outside.

I don't judge by my own height, I judge by other side. Other people are taller than me, therefore I'm short. Other people are shorter than me then I'm tall. When we change who I am Bhagawan said V Matsyara There is no envy. Everybody is who that person is. Such a person Sama Siddha, Siddhav, Krustvapin Nani Badyate he does not get bound.

So we have seen the definition of perfect person in the verse 23 really ties all that together in half a line. What a person of perfect wisdom is Gatha Sanghasya whose attachment is gone devoid of attachment that the first quality of a sage that he has no attachment to anything. He lives in the present environment, in India, in Egypt, in Iran Wherever I find myself, I find myself comfortable. Bhagawan says that's because no attachment. Gatha Sanghas is devoid of attachment in any situation. If I feel comfortable, that means the word of attachment Muktasya this liberation only comes if I have no attachment.

One with no attachment is always free. We are bound by our own attachments. The bondage which I feel in this world is my own creation. I myself decided that I am a tattoo. My family, my children, my profession, my possessions I'm bound by them. I feel myself incomplete without them.

I have bound myself and only I have the capability to liberate myself. When I liberate myself from these attachments, I avoid these attachments. Muktasya he becomes Mukta liberated. But this is only possible if Gnana Avasthita Cheta Saha whose mind, whose Chetana whose Chitta is established in knowledge Knowledge about who I am and who I am not. If I know my true self that I am not this body, mind and intellect, the limited being, this body and intellect are my equipment. But I am something other than this.

All the attachments of the body, all the likes and dislikes of the body, of the mind, of the intellect belong to them only and not to me the self. Such a person will be devoid of attachment. Because he is devoid of attachment he will be liberated. So what is important is the knowledge. Knowledge about your own self. So I may get this glimpse of my true self in meditation.

But it's not going to last forever. I'll come back to my day to day life and have to work in this world. River Bhagawan said Yajna Acharatah Karma Samagram Praviliyate Then I'll still be working in this world. But for Yajna Going back to the verse in chapter three, Yajna tat Karmanu annytra lokoyam Karmabandana. Now that I have no attachment, I will be working, but only for the Yajna for the purpose of helping the community, helping the society, helping everyone around me. All his Karma will be dissolved.

In other words, there is no after effect, there is no rebound effect, there is no cause and effect relationship to his actions. He is not performing for himself. The next verse defines what Yajna is. Brahmarpanam Brahmahavehi Brahmagna Brahmanahutam Brahma Eva Tena Gantavyam Brahma Karma Samadhinaha we have seen that everything in this world, if it is manifestation of the same entity, the Brahman, then obviously you and I cannot be any different from Brahman himself itself, herself. Brahman is the reality. Everything else is just a projection on the Brahman.

I cannot be different from my own Lord. Because if God created this universe out of his own self, there is nothing in the universe which is other than Bhagavan God Ishwara Brahman. Therefore he says any action that liberated sage of perfect wisdom performed, he sees that it's happening in the Brahman by the Brahman, in the self, by the self. Very famous metaphor of Yajna used here to explain Yajna. In the Vedic time the Yajna was very central ritual. So in that central ritual you, you have fire invoked.

A deity is invoked and something is offered to the deity through that fire in the fire by the devotee. So Brahma Arpanam, Brahman is the instrument of offering the ladle which is used in the Yajna to pour the ghee, the ladle itself in nothing but Brahman alone. It is the manifestation of the same reality. So Brahma Arpanam, the means to act is Brahman. In my case, the means to act is my body, my organs of actions. They are nothing but the manifestation or the representation of Brahman only Brahma Havihi.

What I am offering in that fire, what I am offering is my efforts performing actions that's only enabled by Brahman only. So Brahma Havi, the instrument is Brahman. What is offered is also Brahman. Brahma Agna in the fire of Brahman. So in my case the body which enables me to act in this world is expression of Brahman. My efforts to act in this world is also Brahman.

The field of action in which I am putting my efforts is also Brahman. All is Brahman.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce various forms of yajna (sacrifice) that yogis practice. Some worship the devas (divine powers), offering sense objects to the senses while remaining detached witnesses. Others perform Brahma Yajna, offering the limited self into the fire of the higher Self. Verse 26 describes sense-control yajna - either restraining the senses from their objects, or restraining the mind from being affected by sensory input. Verse 27 speaks of offering all sense activities and vital energies in the fire of self-restraint, kindled by wisdom (jnana-dipite).

The teaching builds on what Chapter 3 established: "Yajnarthat karmano anyatra loko yam karma-bandanah" - any action not performed for yajna is binding. The purpose of all these yajnas is antahkarana shuddhi - purification of the inner instrument (mind and intellect). We cannot directly control our spiritual awakening, but we can prepare the vessel. As the teaching says, one who is devoid of attachment is always free (gata-sangasya muktasya), and such a person sees all beings as residing within their own Self.

For daily practice, choose one form of yajna to focus on today. For Deva Yajna: practice witnessing your sense experiences without getting involved - let the world offer itself to your senses without you grasping. For Brahma Yajna: before acting, remember that your limited self is an expression of the unlimited Self, and offer your effort to that higher reality. For sense-control yajna: pick one sense (perhaps sight or taste) and practice restraint - not harsh suppression, but mindful non-attachment. Notice throughout the day: are you the one going to experiences, or are experiences coming to you? The sage sees the world offering itself to the senses while they remain the uninvolved witness.

verseTranslations: And yet others offer as their sacrifice wealth, austerities and meditation. Monks wedded to their vows renounce their scriptural learning and even their spiritual powers.
There are some who practise control of the Vital Energy and govern the subtle forces of Prana and Apana, thereby sacrificing their Prana unto Apana, or their Apana unto Prana.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasiyog Yoga of Renunciation of Action in Knowledge. So we had been discussing Karma Yoga in last chapter and in chapter two, Bhagavan says the Karmani Eva Adhi ka Rasthi Mafula that your right is only to act, but you have no right for your fruits of actions. So for us to understand that concept, we have to understand what action is. So we have learnt in this chapter what action is, which then relates to what we learned about Karma Yoga. In the last chapter where we have seen that Bhagavan said Yogastha Kuro Karmani Sangam tyaktvadhananjaya. That's the essence of Karma Yoga.

Do not expect any fruits of your action. Establish yourself in yoga and then without any attachment perform actions in this world is Karma Yoga action I must perform, but I must perform in this manner and for what I should perform action. This chapter in verse nine says Yajnar Tat Karmano anyatra Loko Yam Karma Bandanaha. All actions other than those performed for Yajna are binding Tadartam Karma Kanthya. Therefore, perform actions for Yajna alone, Mukta Sangha Samacharaha without any attachment, with equanimity of mind. So the final advice we have seen is perform actions for Yajna.

We learnt in verse 24 then that Yajna is to understand that everything that is involved in my action is nothing but Brahman alone. There is no difference between the hunter and hunted. It's all manifestation of Brahman alone. Say Brahmarpanam Brahma have Brahma Agna Brahma hutam. Using this metaphor of Yajna, we have learned that everything involved in this Yajna, the four things involved the instrument, the offerer, the deity and the offering itself. So these four items Bhagavan said, that is nothing but Brahman alone Brahma Eva Samadhi Nah, it's only going to the Brahman alone.

This is the renunciation of action, in knowledge. Having this knowledge that all actions are performed because in and by Brahman, by the power of Brahman, Bhagawan said that's Yajna. So then next few verses we learn the 12 types of yajnas we have seen so far 10 of them from verse 25 onward. So in verse 25 we say deva Yajna and Brahma Yajna. Deva Yajna is that when I see that all that is happening in my experience all the sense perceptions are only happening. The offerings of the sense object to the senses, the devas.

Therefore I remain detached from those experiences. Every experience I see is only happening between the sense objects and the senses. I am just a witness of what's happening that Deva Yajna. Then we say Brahm Yajna. When I offer my limited self to my higher self. When I realized that my limited self is nothing but the expression of the higher self, it was never separated from its higher self.

As we have seen, the room space and outer space is always one and the same. Remove the room space remains where it is. My conditioned self remained where it is after my death. It was here before my birth. So that's Brahm Yajna. That understanding firm in your mind, constantly keeping at the back of your mind in all your action.

Then sense control, that's another type of Yajna. Either control your senses so that they don't wander around or mind control. Senses may bring any information but mind does not get attached to it. That's the mind control. Self restraint by controlling all the senses it's self restraint. So that's another Yajna we have seen.

And in the last verse which we have discussed there are five Yajnas we have seen. Dravya, Yajna, Tapa Yajna Yoga Yajna, Swadhya Yajna and Jnana Yajna. So the life of charity. Everything that I have is for charity. Dravyajna is not just giving you one check every year during tax time. But it is something which I offer that everything I have is for the greater good.

Nothing belongs to me. What I have acquired from this world, this Prakriti, I have to give it back to the Prakriti. What I have borrowed from this Prakriti, this body, mind and intellect, they also don't belong to me. They are just lended to Me for my experiences, that type of attitude, Dravya Yajna then Tapa Yajna austerities for the self control. When I perform certain disciplines, that's tapa Yajna then yoga Yajna, various upasanas and sadhanas. All these Yajnas are for the purification of my mind and intellect for the Antakarana Shuddhi.

As a seeker of happiness, my job is only to purify my internal instrument. Rest will happen automatically by God's grace. The Bhagavan is partial to his Bhakta. Oh now he's praising me all the time. It is the very nature of yourself. Just like I think that Yogi Berahur said the the more I practice, the luckier I get.

My preparation made me worthy of getting that opportunity. So here yoga is the upasana I prepare myself. Then the next one is swadhyaya. Reflecting on your own self introspection. Who I am is this body me, this mind me, the intellect me, the accomplishments me. That's basically is the swadhya Yajna.

And then we said Gnana Yajna, Yoga of knowledge, offering your ignorance, consciously trying to get out of the veiling of this mind is Gnani Yajna. Our learning Bhagavad Gita falls into the Gnani Yajna. The last two yajnas, the Pranayama and Pratyahara. These come from Patanjali's Yoga sutra, Ashtanga Yoga, eight parts, the Yama Niyama Asana, Pranayama Pratyaha, fourth and fifth steps of Ashtang Yoga, Pranayama Pratyah. So verse 29 says Apane Jhuvati Pranam Pranay Apanam Tatha Apare Prana Apana Gati Ruddhwa Pranayama Prayanaha. Those who are expert, they are engaged in pranayama.

They perform this pranayama in various ways. There is not one method; there are various ways. It says Apane Jhuvati Pranam. So Apana is the outgoing breath -- and even this book says outgoing breath.

I read Bhagavan Sankaracharya's Bhashya and it says Apana is the incoming breath, which contradicts some other sources. I checked some other books and some agreed with Sankaracharya's Bhashya: Apana is incoming breath (Ap-Anaha is incoming) and Pra-Anaha is outgoing. But whichever interpretation you follow, the essential meaning of the verse does not change -- it's about controlling the breath. Let's say Apane Jhuvati Pranam -- some offer outgoing breath into the incoming breath, and Prana Apanam Tadapara -- some offer the incoming breath into the outgoing breath.

In other words, two diametrically opposite practices in pranayama. Pranayama, as we have seen, is the control of all the vital energies. But at the core of it is the control of breath, which is actually the word Svasa. If you read Patanjali's Yoga Sutra, he does not use the word Prana here. He says Svasa (incoming) and Prasvasa (outgoing). But the overall technique is also called Pranayama.

By controlling your breath, you control your pranas. All the other functions of the pranas which right now I have no control over. So even when I am in a deep sleep, all my organs are functioning properly. My heart, my brain, my liver, my kidneys. Because the conscious mind has no control over this organ. You can imagine if the conscious mind has to control these organs, then we will all be in lots of trouble.

But conscious mind has no control over these organs or they are free of conscious mind. And therefore it functions all three states of my existence. That waking, dream and deep sleep. But the yogis have found ways to control these functions by the conscious mind. This is called pranayama. Their observation was that as the state of my mind change, my breathing changes.

So if I can control my breathing, I may be able to control all my pranas and all my mental thoughts. So the techniques devised was to control breath. Panditji used to say that we have finite number of breaths to take in this life. If you take faster breathing, you have a shorter life. If you have slower breathing, then you have a longer life. So people who are calm, normally quiet, and have control over their breathing -- they live longer lives. People who are very excitable and constantly get agitated and excited, their breathing goes faster and they live shorter lives. I have no knowledge about that. But this is what the Yoga Sutra basically says: control your breath so that you are regulating your breath.

Many, many years ago when we were in Dallas, Texas, we took a course in Pranayama and Raja Yoga. One of my friend's father, Mr. Haris Raja, was a disciple of Swami Muktananda, and he gave us pranayama training.

We used to have that in early morning at 6:00. And that's a part of Raja Yoga. So the yogas which we have seen, the pranayama, are performed in three different types of tradition. One is the Shiva Yoga. Vignana Bhairav is the book from the Kashmir Saivites. And you see on TV this Shiva yogicant and he said that by controlling the breath, you can control all your systems.

There is no need for any medication. We can control everything by controlling breathing. Then, popularly, what we know about yoga in this country is Hatha Yoga. Hatha Yoga is basically the first three sections of Ashtanga Yoga: Yama, Niyama and Asana. We focus more on the third step, which is Asana. But the Yoga Sutra says you should not start Pranayama until you have mastered Asanas.

So Asanas are very important, and once you master the Asanas, then you do Pranayama. Many teachers I have come across say Hatha Yoga is very good, but it can also be dangerous if you are not under the guidance of a trained teacher. Be careful, have a good teacher, then you can practice. Raja Yoga, on the other hand, is considered safer and subtler. What Pandit Ji used to teach is also Raja Yoga.

And what we learned many, many years ago, that's also Raja Yoga where basically the breathing is controlled by nine mudras. They call it remote controls. Now obviously there is no scientific study done on why that works or does it work. But all the yogis have said that they do work. So it's a apana jhuvati panam prana apanam tatha apare prana apana gatirandhwa pranayama prayanaha. Those who are expert, they engage in this pranayama.

And in Bhagavan Sankaracharya's Bhashya, I learned that the first technique of apane jhuvati pranam is called purak. We often talk about purak, Rechak and Kumbhak. Sankaracharya said these three are described here. The first one is called purak -- when you are offering incoming breath into the outgoing. Then another is called rechak -- offering outgoing breath into incoming breath.

And then pranapana gati ruddhva -- restricting the flow of air is called kumbhak. This has to be practiced in a serial manner. So Mr. Raja used to write articles in Times of India. Those articles were published into a book. In that he said that the goal of pranayama is our normal breathing is about 16 breaths in a minute.

The goal is to reduce them to four. So in one minute there are only four breaths. He recommends in his book -- and what he taught us back in the '80s -- 5 seconds for inhalation, then 2 seconds of inner Kumbhak (retention), then 7 seconds of exhalation. Because, he said, the air has expanded due to body temperature, so it takes longer to exhale than inhale. That makes 14 seconds.

Then you hold the breath for one second outside before taking the next breath, and you start the cycle again. That makes 15 seconds. So there are four breaths in a minute.
snippets.reflection:
These verses enumerate additional forms of yajna: Dravya Yajna (offering wealth/possessions), Tapo Yajna (austerities for self-control), Yoga Yajna (various spiritual practices and upasanas), Swadhyaya Yajna (self-study and introspection), and Jnana Yajna (the sacrifice of ignorance through knowledge). Verses 29-30 describe Pranayama - the control of vital energies through breath regulation - and Pratyahara - control of diet and withdrawal of senses. All these practitioners understand the principle of yajna, and through it their impurities are washed away (yajna-kshapita-kalmashah).

The teaching emphasizes that there is no single path that fits everyone. Human beings come in various combinations of sattva, rajas, and tamas, so numerous methods exist - "scattered at the mouth of Brahman" as Krishna says later. Dravya Yajna is not merely writing an annual charity check but cultivating the attitude that nothing truly belongs to you. What you borrowed from Prakriti must return to Prakriti. The discussion of Pranayama (control of breath) shows how controlling the subtle can affect the gross - by regulating breath, one can influence all pranas and mental states.

For today's practice, honestly assess which yajna suits your current temperament. If you are naturally generous, practice Dravya Yajna with awareness. If you are disciplined, try Tapo Yajna. If intellectual, focus on Swadhyaya and Jnana Yajna. If you have time, practice simple pranayama: try breathing with a rhythm of 5 seconds inhalation, 2 seconds retention, 7 seconds exhalation, 1 second pause before the next breath - this slows breathing to about 4 breaths per minute, calming the mind. Whatever practice you choose, remember the purpose: purification of the inner instrument so that knowledge may dawn. The method matters less than sincere, sustained effort aligned with your nature.

snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sanyasa Yoga for renouncing actions in knowledge. So far we have seen that Bhagavan said that I am going to tell you a secret knowledge, having known which you will not have to know anything else. And this is nothing new. I had been teaching this from the beginning of time how to end your actions. That's the goal, to end my actions. But right now I'm not finding any means to end these actions.

Bhagavan said that one who develops the knowledge that the self is not the doer can get out of this cycle of actions and reactions. The cycle continues: I act, the world reacts, that becomes actions for the world. When I react to that reaction, it becomes my actions, and the action-reaction cycle continues. He said, once you get out of this notion that I am the doer, you will be out of this cycle of doing and reacting, suffering and enjoying.

So in verse 14 he says namaam karmani lin panthi Namay karmafulesh prahaha ithimam yo vijayanathi karma bihin NASA badhyadhya. He is not bound by any actions. One who knows me as Namam Karmani limpanti Karmas do not bind me, they do not attach to me. I don't get attached to the karma in Namay Karmafula. I do not have any desire for the Karma Phala that I is the self in me. I think I have all these desires.

Well, that I does not have any desires. My mind has desires, my intellect has desires, and also my body has desires. It feels a little hot. My body tells me, let's make it comfortable. So all these things which I think I have karma falas pruha or the desire to enjoy is at either the body level, at the mind level or the intellect level. At the self level there is no desire.

The one who knows himself as the one has no attachment to action. Self never gets attached to any action. Neither that self has any karma falas pruha. One who knows this as his own self in this manner he does not get bound by any actions. Another question is how do we get to that point? So in verse 23rd, the technique is Gatha Sangasya.

He has given up all attachments. He works in this world but does not get attached. He said the attachment to the world is like a post it notes. As long as it is there, it is attached, you remove it. It does not leave any mark on their wall. Gatha Sangha says no attachment.

You can take it from here and put it here. And take it from here, put it here. It will get attached to whatever but not leave any mark. Gnana Vasthidha Saha. So he's free, he's not attached. And his intellect is organized by the knowledge that the self is not having desire for any fruits of actions, neither it is taking part in any actions.

Yajnaya Charathaha Karmaha. And therefore he is constantly acting in the spirit of Yajna for the greater good. All the actions which are taking place are only taking place for the greater good, not just for my selfish desires. Karma sama Grim pravely. That's how all the karmas will get destroyed for that person. He's not having any sense of identity with his actions.

Then we have seen that this Yajna can be performed in various ways. But what should be the Yogi, the one who has mastered this art of performing actions in Yajna, his attitude. There are two ways he said. The first one he says is Devam Evapare, Yajnam Yogi, Nahapariupa Sataya. Some yogis will perform all their actions working in this world, experiencing this world as the world is offering its objects for the perception of his senses. World's offering to the senses.

It's not him going to the world, world coming to him. That's how he never gets attached to him. Because he is not really going out to the world. World is coming to him for his perception. So all the perception comes and goes, but he never gets attached to any one of them. That's the one way other.

Brahma Agnavare Yagnam Yagne Eva Upa Jihuvati. Others will sacrifice the self by the self. And the next verse is Brahmarpanam Brahmavi. Everything that is happening is happening by the self alone. So now that when I'm working in this world, I'm offering myself which I consider to be myself right now is my sense of perception. Sense organs of actions in the service of the self, the greater self.

So now everything which I'm doing is offering to the self by myself. The limited self offering its own self for the service of the self. In this attitude, when he works in this world, he's also not getting attached to any actions because he obviously is not really performing any actions for himself. So both are the various ways the Yogi sees this world. Either this way where the world is offering to himself, or he is offering himself to the greater self. Both are the techniques with which he can continue working in this world, but not getting attached to the actions.

And then we have seen that the agnas can be performed in 12 different ways. The fire you have to kindle for this yajna is not the physical fire, but the fire of your self restraint. So Samyama Agni, he's going to start with kindling first his fire of restraint. That restraint first can be at this sense level, sensual perceptions he limits to a point where he does not get attached to them. So restraining the senses is the first method we use it. The second method is the mental restraining the perception.

So whatever the perception comes, he obviously restrain its impression, does not let that perception leave any impression on his mind. So it's a mental level. And the next level of yajnas we have seen is the intellectual level, Swadhyaya Yajna. I constantly reflect on what is the truth about myself. Constantly asking question, who is it that tells me that I am doing this? So that's swadhya yajna at the intellectual level, which is we call gnana yajna.

Then Bhagavan also enumerated that there are other yajnas as well. But all of them we have seen is performing yajnas in the mental level. By kindling the fire of restraint, restraining of the senses, restraining of the mind, or restraining the intellect into the inquiry of what is the self. We have seen there are other methods available. There is not really one method fits all we know because human beings are made in various different permutations and combinations. Sattva, rajas and Tamas, whichever is most conducive for me, I should be practicing.

But the goal is to perform actions in Yajna spirit. That's basically the goal. Evam, Bahvida, Yajna, Vitatha, Brahmana, mukhe. Thus there are many yajnas lying at the mouth of Brahman. These are not the only yajnas that can be practiced. But there's a limitation for the poet -- he cannot enumerate a list of thousands of Yajnas.

There are many methods available to you. Vitatha Brahmanamukha -- they are scattered at the mouth of Brahman, at the gate leading to Brahman, at the threshold of perception of the Brahman. There are many paths which are leading towards that that will open the door for you. So any of that, whatever path I take, as long as I have taken the correct path towards my goal, that goal will be available to me. Karma Janaan Vidhi Taan, Sarvaan Evam Gnatva Vimoksha Se.

But know that all those paths are born out of actions. In other words, you cannot sit back and relax and say things will be done and someday I will have a realization. It requires your self-effort. No matter which path you take, there is no easy shortcut. All of them require you to put your own self-effort to get there. Karma Jan Viddhi -- there is not a single path where you just stay relaxed and it comes to you.

Actions are very much essential in each part. Actions are the binding force right now and I'm trying to get out of it. Actions are the only means available to me to get to Brahman. As long as I put my self efforts on a right path. Bhagavan says Vimoksha Se you will achieve the moksha. As long as I take the right route to go to New York.

Whether I take 95 north through the New Jersey Turnpike or go via Route 95 through Philadelphia -- as long as I know that this path is leading towards my goal. Just sitting down here thinking about it, I will never go to New York. But putting my efforts into it -- Tan Sarvan Evam Ganatwa Vimoksha Sey -- they're all going to take you to the same goal as long as you put your self-effort in a diligent and honest manner.

So the next verse says Sreyan Dravyam Yagnath Gnana Yajnaha Parantabah Sarva Karma Ahilam Partha Gnane Parisamarpiate -- which path should I take? He said the Gnana Yajna is clearly better than the Dravya Yajna.

This is not an indication that this all the various paths which are described as one is better than other. All paths are gonna lead you. As long as you put your self efforts in a clear understanding what my goal is will get you there. However, the culture in the environment may mislead me. Me just writing a check to the Hindu Center -- I think that I have earned some punyas. Bhagavan says that Dravya Yajna will get you very little, because the whole intention behind writing the check makes that check what it is worth to you, not to the Hindu Center.

The Hindu Center gets the same value. I write a check for $101 -- the $101 they can cash. But whether that gives me value is all about my intentions. What efforts did I put in, with what intentions, with what understanding -- that will determine my reward. Therefore he says Sreyan Dravyam Yagnath Gnana Yajnah Paramta.

Whatever your perception of that offering, as long as the knowledge does not take place, that offering does not get you much. Therefore knowledge is superior to the physical act of performing Yajna. I may be exercising, but not with a clear understanding of what I'm trying to get out of it. Then obviously it won't have the same result as exercising with a clear goal. Disciplined actions with a clear plan, clear knowledge of what this action should yield -- that will get you much greater results.

And you go to American Fitness. Do you have a trainer? I don't have a trainer. Why do I need a trainer? That trainer will give you this gnana. Which exercise will be better for you?

I may be putting lot of efforts but in a wrong direction. Yesterday we were at somebody's house and somebody took out of the list of what food does not goes with what. In the end we said if you follow this, we will not be able to eat anything. He said parotta should not be eaten with dahi yogurt. So Punjabis are all gone! See, even that knowledge, if it is put in the right context, may have some value.

Obviously the whole of our Ayurveda is about parhej. You have to regulate your diet, and then you don't need other medication. But just doing upavas without thinking may actually make me sick.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 31 declares that those who partake of the nectar remaining from yajna attain the eternal Brahman, while those who perform no yajna find no happiness even in this world, let alone the next. Verse 32 reveals that many types of yajna are spread before Brahman's gate, and all are born of action (karmajan). Knowing this, one becomes liberated. Verse 33 makes a crucial distinction: "Shreyan dravyamayad yajnat jnana-yajnah" - the sacrifice of knowledge is superior to material sacrifice, for all actions in their entirety culminate in knowledge (sarvam karmakhilam partha jnane parisamapyate).

This teaching clarifies that while many paths exist, knowledge (jnana) is the ultimate goal toward which all other practices lead. Writing a charity check has value, but the intention and understanding behind it determines its true worth. The same external action performed with different levels of awareness produces vastly different results. Like having a trainer at the gym who guides your efforts optimally, knowledge directs and elevates all other practices. Without understanding why you are doing something, even sincere effort may be misdirected.

For daily practice, evaluate not just what you do but the knowledge underlying it. Before any spiritual practice - whether charity, discipline, or study - ask: What am I trying to achieve? How does this lead toward self-knowledge? Just as the teaching says all paths are "karma-jan" (born of action), your own efforts are indispensable. There is no shortcut where things happen without your participation. Today, choose one practice and examine the knowledge component: What do you understand about why this works? What are you still confused about? "Evam jnatva vimokshyase" - knowing thus, you shall be liberated. Make your practice conscious, not mechanical.

snippets.title: Day 67: The Sword of Wisdom
snippets.sanskrit:
तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया |

यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव |

अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः |
snippets.transliteration:
tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā .

yajjñātvā na punarmohamevaṃ yāsyasi pāṇḍava .

api cedasi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpakṛttamaḥ .
verseTranslations: This shalt thou learn by prostrating thyself at the Master's feet, by questioning Him and by serving Him. The wise who have realised the Truth will teach thee wisdom.
Having known That, thou shalt never again be confounded; and, O Arjuna, by the power of that wisdom, thou shalt see all these people as if they were thine own Self, and therefore as Me.
Be thou the greatest of sinners, yet thou shalt cross over all sin by the ferryboat of wisdom.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga Yoga of renouncing action in knowledge. So we have seen in the beginning of chapter three, Bhagavan had said that there are two paths always available for a seeker to seek the ultimate knowledge. The Gnana Yogi in a Sankhyana Karma Yoga yogina. For the yogis, the Karma Yoga and for the Gnani, the Gnana Yoga. So chapter three we discussed Karma Yoga.

This is where one needs to start. Bhagavan Saha that if you are engaged in this world of activities, in this rajasic world of activities, then it will start with Karma Yoga. And Karma Yoga simply says act with the balanced mind without expecting any particular fruits of your action and act efficiently. That's basically Karma Yoga. Remain balanced in any situation. Do not react overly in any situation.

Bhagawan said, you start with that. Purpose of that is to purify your mind and intellectual so that you can function very efficiently in this world. But what type of action I should be performing in that manner was described in chapter four. In the beginning, Bhagawan said, you should know what is karma and what is akarma. You should know what is vikarma, what is akarma. So you should have some basic gauge to decide actions are appropriate or not appropriate there.

Bhagavan said that when you reach a point where action seems inaction and inaction seems action, you now come to understand what action is all about. And how do I get to that point? Bhagavan said, Yajnaar Thaat Karmano Anyatra Lokwayam Karma Bandana. You get bondage from your action in this world because you are acting in this world as an individual trying to compete with the rest of the world. It's creating sorrows and unhappiness and fears and greed and jealousy. That's because this concept of duality that I am an island by myself, the world is out there to get me.

Bhagwan said that you overcome by performing your Actions in the field of Yajna. Yajna is something you're not doing for yourself. You're sacrificing something for greater good. So if you go to Hindu temple and Panditji is doing Havana, every mantra start with Idhamna Mama, this is not mine. Up till now I thought this is mine. But right now I'm offering it for the greater good in the holy fire.

Something I always thought is mine -- I offer it as no longer belonging to me. That is what we call charity. The money which I thought is mine, I write a check and send it to a non-profit organization. I say, "Now it is not mine, it is yours. You do whatever you need to do." So that's the act of Yajna.

Yajna is to sacrifice something which you thought is yours. But you came to the conclusion that really does not belong to me. I heard one of the CNN executive retiring and he said learn, earn and then return. Learn the knowledge, how the business works. Then earn, make money and then return. Return back to the community.

And that's what most of us one way or other do. Because we have seen that when a person dies, he cannot take anything with him. He acquires things, thinks they are his own, and then eventually gives up, leaves everything here and goes away. So Bhagavan said that you have to understand this concept even while acting in this world. Therefore you have to act in the spirit of Yajna so that you come to realize the oneness. Once you perform this, you will get the Brahmajnana. I have this translation of Gnaneshwar Maharaj's Gnaneshwari.

This chapter is actually titled in Gnaneshwari as Brahma Yajna Prasantsa Brahmajna Prasansa Nama Chaturtha Dhyayah. So here we say Gnana Karma Sanyasi Yogana. There are books I have seen which simply says Gnani Yoga. So chapter four is about knowledge. Knowledge about your own self and how to get it. So the two paths which Bhagavan had initially described that is always available right from the beginning of this universe for a seeker to realize the truth is Karma Yoga.

And then Gnana Yoga, Karma Yoga. When you are not ready yet, very Rajasic, perform Karma Yoga. But then ultimately you have to have Gnana. The knowledge, what it is all about, why my actions are not my actions. And when I come to realize, it becomes inaction. It's no longer any action which is belonging to me.

So in verse 33 we say, Sarvam karma akhilam Partha gnane parisamapyate. Bhagavan came to that final statement saying, O Partha. All the actions, good, bad and ugly that you had been performing or you think you had been performing once you know the knowledge, they get all dissolved once you achieve their knowledge. What is their knowledge? He said we would learn that. Brahma arpanam Brahmahavihi Brahma agno Brahmahutam.

Everything that I perceive in this world that I consider to be something other than me is also not different than me. The same entity which makes me who I am, the very same entity makes the world of plurality what it is. Once I come to that conclusion, Bhagavan said, Sarvam karma akhilam grana parishama pyyade. All actions which I am either very proud of or very afraid of that I may have to pay for them. Those actions all will get resolved. So in last verse 34, Bhagavan said, the only way to get it is to someone who has realized this knowledge.

I can only learn something from someone who has experienced it. If I am dreaming and suffering in my dream, only other waker can see that I may be going through a nightmare and awake me. Are you having a nightmare? Another dreamer cannot do that. Another dreamer who is also dreaming his own dream. He cannot wake me up from my dream.

Only a waker who is not dreaming can see that I am having a nightmare and can wake me up. So Bhagavan said, go to a guru. You may not call them a guru -- you may give them another title. But go to someone who has experienced this knowledge, someone who has experienced this truth that there is no duality in this world. The world is the manifestation of the same reality.

That duality is created out of my own ignorance about the nature of this universe. In Prakriti there is multiplicity. Prakriti itself is one entity. But in that there is multiplicity. Just as I as one person. But I have multiple limbs which has different parts and different functions.

But I know that all these limbs are nothing but me. And therefore there is no conflict ever. My right hand is not fighting with left hand and left hand is not fighting with my right hand. Because there is a unity of thinking. And that knowledge, you can only get it from a great person who has realized this Tadviddhi Prani pati ne pari prasnayana sevaya. You have to put your own efforts.

You can't really get it just by thinking about it. You have to put your own efforts with that humility that you do not know. Right now, what I know is creating more conflict for me, creating sorrows, unhappiness, fears, jealousy, greed -- all of that. Because I think the world is out there to get me and I need to take care of myself. So once you know -- Tadviddhi Prani Patena Pari Prashnena -- by inquiring what is real and what is unreal, what is my true self and what is not my true self.

Sevayah -- by serving the teacher. Upadekshyanti Tegnanam Gnaninah Tattvadarsinah. And if you find that person -- if you are sincere, you will find such a person -- that teacher will point you in the right direction, will give you the direction on how to find your own self. You have to find yourself, but you will find a guide to get to your destination. Now, is this something I'll know one time and then forget?

There are a lot of things I have learnt before but have now forgotten -- that is of no great value. "Neil, do you know calculus?" I learned it in my college days but I know nothing about it anymore. Bhagawan said no, this knowledge is different. Once you know it, you will never get confused like this again. You are right now confused about whether to fight or not to fight this battle.

Knowing that knowledge, you will never get confused again. Bhutani Ashena Drashasi Atmani Athomai. That is because right now my problem is that I see that world is competing with me and therefore I'm getting confused about how to protect myself. And that's what is creating confusion. In Arjuna's case, his own people are there and he has to kill them. He has no problem killing others, only his own people.

He's worried about killing them. But once this sense of "I and mine" is dissolved, you will not have any problem. Two people facing each other in a dark alley are afraid of each other because one doesn't know who the other one is. So they hide from each other because they think the other person is out there to rob me. But once they realize that other person is my friend then all the fears are gone. So that identification is the unifying factor.

Bhagawan said, once that identification takes place -- Atmani Athomai -- you will see that all beings are in your own self. The self which I consider my own self is not limited to this body, mind and intellect. It is all-pervading and encompassing everything. That teacher will make you realize that your self is that supreme self where everything is contained. And you will see that in me -- "me," Bhagavan said, meaning Krishna himself.

You will see in God all the beings. That's nothing but your own self. When this takes place, all the fears will be dissolved, all the negative tendencies of your mind will dissolve, and you will be free from all the problems that belong to you.

So Bhagavan said Apiched -- now I come to the point of gauging my own capability. Am I capable of achieving this? And 99 times out of 100 we come to the conclusion: that's for the sannyasis, that's for somebody else, not for me.

It may be, but I don't know whether I'm going to get it in this lifetime or not. Don't worry about the lifetime. Because you do not know what your lifetime is. This life is not the only existence you have. Bahuni, me, Vyatitani, Janmani, Tawachaljani. You and I have spent many, many lives before we never perished and we will be there forever.

So therefore time is not of any consequence here. Neither your own qualification. If you consider yourself the best among sinners -- even criminals have categories, the best and the worst, from a stupid criminal to the most intelligent criminal. All the jewel thief movies I used to love in my younger days.

Because jewel thief is not an ordinary person, he is so intelligent. If you consider that you are the worst of sinners, then also it does not exclude you. Because sin is nothing but the other aspect of karma. If it is utilized in a proper field, it becomes merit. If it is in a wrong field with a wrong attitude, it becomes sin. So all you are doing up till now is what you consider your sins is you're applying your ability to act with a wrong attitude.

Those attitudes and the consequent experiences are creating negative impressions on your mind. Therefore you consider yourself a sinner. But you cannot be a sinner, because you are part of that pristine reality.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 34 prescribes the method for gaining knowledge: "Tadviddhi pranipatena pariprashnena sevaya" - learn it through prostration (humility), questioning, and service to those wise ones who have realized the truth (jnaninas tattva-darshinah). Verse 35 promises that having known this, you will never again fall into confusion, for you will see all beings in your own Self and in Me. The powerful verse 36 offers hope even to the greatest sinner: "Api ched asi papebhyah sarvebhyah papa-krittamah" - even if you are the worst of sinners, the boat of knowledge will carry you across all evil.

The teaching emphasizes that spiritual knowledge cannot be gained through intellect alone - it requires a relationship with a realized teacher and one's own sincere effort. Just as only a waking person can awaken someone from a nightmare (another dreamer cannot help), only one who has realized the truth can guide us out of our confusion. The three elements - prostration (humility), questioning (sincere inquiry), and service (devoted practice) - form the complete approach. Once this knowledge dawns, duality dissolves; you see all beings as your own Self because they truly are.

For today's practice, cultivate the three elements of learning. Practice humility by acknowledging what you do not know - your current knowledge is creating your confusion and suffering. Formulate genuine questions about what is real and unreal, what is your true Self and what is not. Serve the teaching through dedicated practice, not just intellectual study. Reflect on verse 35's promise: if you truly knew that all beings are in your Self and in God, how would you treat the people you encounter today? And take heart from verse 36 - whatever you consider your "sins" are merely actions performed with wrong attitudes. Your true Self, part of pristine reality, cannot be a sinner. The boat of knowledge can carry you across any ocean of past mistakes.

snippets.title: Day 68: Divine Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन |

न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते |

श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः |
snippets.transliteration:
yathaidhāṃsi samiddho.agnirbhasmasātkurute.arjuna .

na hi jñānena sadṛśaṃ pavitramiha vidyate .

śraddhāvā.Nllabhate jñānaṃ tatparaḥ saṃyatendriyaḥ .
verseTranslations: As the kindled fire consumes the fuel, so, O Arjuna, in the flame of wisdom the embers of action are burnt to ashes.
There is nothing in the world so purifying as wisdom; and he who is a perfect saint finds that at last in his own Self.
He who is full of faith attains wisdom, and he too who can control his senses, having attained that wisdom, he shall ere long attain Supreme Peace.
