What is their knowledge? He said we would learn that. Brahma arpanam Brahmahavihi Brahma agno Brahmahutam.

Everything that I perceive in this world that I consider to be something other than me is also not different than me. The same entity which makes me who I am, the very same entity makes the world of plurality what it is. Once I come to that conclusion, Bhagavan said, Sarvam karma akhilam grana parishama pyyade. All actions which I am either very proud of or very afraid of that I may have to pay for them. Those actions all will get resolved. So in last verse 34, Bhagavan said, the only way to get it is to someone who has realized this knowledge.

I can only learn something from someone who has experienced it. If I am dreaming and suffering in my dream, only other waker can see that I may be going through a nightmare and awake me. Are you having a nightmare? Another dreamer cannot do that. Another dreamer who is also dreaming his own dream. He cannot wake me up from my dream.

Only a waker who is not dreaming can see that I am having a nightmare and can wake me up. So Bhagavan said, go to a guru. You may not call him a guru. You may give him another title. But go to someone who has experienced this knowledge, experienced this truth that there is no duality in this world. The world is the manifestation of the same reality.

That duality is created out of my own ignorance about the nature of this universe. In Prakriti there is multiplicity. Prakriti itself is one entity. But in that there is multiplicity. Just as I as one person. But I have multiple limbs which has different parts and different functions.

But I know that all these limbs are nothing but me. And therefore there is no conflict ever. My right hand is not fighting with left hand and left hand is not fighting with my right hand. Because there is a unity of thinking. And that knowledge, you can only get it from a great person who has realized this Tadviddhi Prani pati ne pari prasnayana sevaya. You have to put your own efforts.

You can't really get it just by thinking about it. You have to put your own efforts with that humility that you do not know. Right now, what I know is creating more conflict for me, creating sorrows, unhappiness, fears, jealousy, greed -- all of that. Because I think the world is out there to get me and I need to take care of myself. So once you know -- Tadviddhi Prani Patena Pari Prashnena -- by inquiring what is real and what is unreal, what is my true self and what is not my true self.

Sevayah -- by serving the teacher. Upadekshyanti Tegnanam Gnaninah Tattvadarsinah. And if you find that person -- if you are sincere, you will find such a person -- that teacher will point you in the right direction, will give you the direction on how to find your own self. You have to find yourself, but you will find a guide to get to your destination. Now, is this something I'll know one time and then forget?

There are a lot of things I have learnt before but have now forgotten -- that is of no great value. "Neil, do you know calculus?" I learned it in my college days but I know nothing about it anymore. Bhagawan said no, this knowledge is different. Once you know it, you will never get confused like this again. You are right now confused about whether to fight or not to fight this battle.

Knowing that knowledge, you will never get confused again. Bhutani Ashena Drashasi Atmani Athomai. That is because right now my problem is that I see that world is competing with me and therefore I'm getting confused about how to protect myself. And that's what is creating confusion. In Arjuna's case my people are there and I have to kill them. I have no problem killing others, only my people.

I'm worried about killing them. But once in this I and mind, once dissolved, you will not have any problem. Two people facing each other in a dark alley are afraid of each other because one doesn't know who the other one is. So they hide from each other because they think the other person is out there to rob me. But once they realize that other person is my friend then all the fears are gone. So that identification is the unifying factor.

Bhagawan said, once that identification takes place -- Atmani Athomai -- you will see that all beings are in your own self. The self which I consider my own self is not limited to this body, mind and intellect. It is all-pervading and encompassing everything. That teacher will make you realize that your self is that supreme self where everything is contained. And you will see that in me -- "me," Bhagavan said, meaning Krishna himself.

You will see in God all the beings. That's nothing but your own self. When this takes place, all the fears will be dissolved, all the negative tendencies of your mind will dissolve, and you will be free from all the problems that belong to you.

So Bhagavan said Apiched -- now I come to the point of gauging my own capability. Am I capable of achieving this? And 99 times out of 100 we come to the conclusion: that's for the sannyasis, that's for somebody else, not for me.

It may be, but I don't know whether I'm going to get it in this lifetime or not. Don't worry about the lifetime. Because you do not know what your lifetime is. This life is not the only existence you have. Bahuni, me, Vyatitani, Janmani, Tawachaljani. You and I have spent many, many lives before we never perished and we will be there forever.

So therefore time is not of any consequence here. Neither your own qualification. If you consider yourself the best among sinners -- even criminals have categories, the best and the worst, from a stupid criminal to the most intelligent criminal. All the jewel thief movies I used to love in my younger days.

Because jewel thief is not an ordinary person, he is so intelligent. If you consider that you are the worst of sinners, then also it does not exclude you. Because sin is nothing but the other aspect of karma. If it is utilized in a proper field, it becomes merit. If it is in a wrong field with a wrong attitude, it becomes sin. So all you are doing up till now is what you consider your sins is you're applying your ability to act with a wrong attitude.

Those attitudes and the consequent experiences are creating negative impressions on your mind. Therefore you consider yourself a sinner. But you cannot be a sinner, because you are part of that pristine reality.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 37 uses the powerful metaphor of fire: "Yathaidhamsi samiddho 'gnir bhasmasat kurute" - as a blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, so does the fire of knowledge burn all karma to ashes. When different materials are burned, they all become one undifferentiated ash; similarly, knowledge dissolves the distinctions between "good" and "bad" karma into the unity of Brahman. Verse 38 declares nothing is as purifying as knowledge (na hi jnanena sadrisham pavitram iha vidyate), and the one perfected in yoga finds it within their own Self in time. Verse 39 gives the three requirements: faith (shraddha), devotion to the goal (tatparah), and sense-control (samyatendriyah). With these, one attains knowledge and quickly reaches supreme peace.

The teaching addresses both the power of knowledge and the practical requirements for gaining it. Faith (shraddha) means trust that the destination exists - like trusting that Hawaii exists before saving for the trip. Tatparah means burning desire - like the fire in the belly that makes one champion prevail over another equally skilled competitor. Samyatendriyah means discipline - the controlled, sustained effort that transforms aspiration into attainment. Without all three, the journey stalls.

For daily practice, assess honestly where you stand on these three requirements. Do you truly have faith that a state of lasting peace exists and is attainable for you, not just for sannyasis and saints? Do you have the burning desire (tatparah) to reach it, or is it just an interesting intellectual idea? Are you exercising the discipline (samyatendriyah) that moves you toward the goal, or do desires constantly pull you off course? Remember that the timing is not entirely in your hands - "kalena atmani vindati" - in time, one finds it in the Self. Your job is to keep marching on the path, trusting that the purifying fire of knowledge will eventually burn away all that obscures your true nature.

snippets.title: Day 69: Action in Inaction
snippets.sanskrit:
अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति |

योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम् |

तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः |
snippets.transliteration:
ajñaścāśraddadhānaśca saṃśayātmā vinaśyati .

yogasaṃnyastakarmāṇaṃ jñānasañchinnasaṃśayam .

tasmādajñānasambhūtaṃ hṛtsthaṃ jñānāsinātmanaḥ .
verseTranslations: But the ignorant man, and he who has no faith, and the sceptic are lost. Neither in this world nor elsewhere is there any happiness in store for him who always doubts.
But the man who has renounced his action for meditation, who has cleft his doubt in twain by the sword of wisdom, who remains always enthroned in his Self, is not bound by his acts.
Therefore, cleaving asunder with the sword of wisdom the doubts of the heart, which thine own ignorance has engendered, follow the Path of Wisdom and arise!"
snippets.commentary:
So far in Bhagavad Gita and in our discussion about Vedantic philosophy, we have learnt that Brahman is pristine, imperishable, immutable and without any attributes. That Brahman, which is all pervading, nothing exists outside Brahman. So there is no good or evil which is beyond Brahman, outside of Brahman. And if Brahman is all pervading, then obviously the good and evil, as I perceive, must be residing within the realm of Brahman. But these are two contradictory assertions. One, Brahman is all pervading, pristine, and there is no good and evil.

There is no happiness and sorrows in Brahman. At the same token, if the happiness and sorrows do exist in my life, then this happiness and sorrows must be existing outside of Brahman. When I make that assertion, I make Brahman limited. Because now that realm of happiness and sorrow is outside the realm of Brahman, which makes Brahman limited. Either there is happiness and sorrow in Brahman, or there is no happiness and sorrows. And Brahman remains pristine, unborn, imperishable, untainted.

So that is the quest of our life. So then we have looked at how I experience my life and what is my relationship to Brahman. So we have seen that Brahman expresses as Purusha and Prakriti, matter and energy, mind and matter, consciousness and matter. When I think about consciousness, I'm conscious of everything, but not about my own self. So this Purusha remains untainted. The Prakriti, it seems, goes through changes.

This Prakriti, which is the manifest world, has plurality. And that's where we see changes. World, as I knew yesterday, does not exist today. It has already changed. So it seems Prakruti is going through changes. So we have learned that Prakruti has three Gunas, Sattva, Rajas and Tamas.

These three Gunas, when they are in equilibrium, there is no phenomenal world. When my three Gunas in my self at a micro level, are in equilibrium, there is no experience which I call deep Sleep. In deep sleep there is no Sattva, there is no Rajas, pure Tamas and everything is in equilibrium. And therefore I do not experience anything. So there is no phenomenal world when these three gunas are in equilibrium. It is only the touch of consciousness when I wake up from my deep sleep that the world of phenomena comes in place.

So I must make a journey from that world of Brahman which is pristine to the world of phenomena which I experience. So the world of my happiness and sorrows are within the phenomenal world. So Bhagavan in Sankhya Yoga told, you will experience this bliss if you lose your identification with this individual being that you consider yourself to be. And for that he said, you have to purify your internal instrument. The instrument which you have to experience the world outside is mind and intellect. I am experiencing the world outside through my mind and intellect supported by my senses.

River Bhagavan in chapter three gave us a simple method of Karma Yoga to purify your mind and intellect. Right now has come to the conclusion that my happiness outside in this world and I need to acquire it. That notion is creating this conflict with this world. And therefore I'm working hard in this world. Actions are motivated by my desire to achieve that state of perfect happiness. All my actions right now are either to get happiness or avoid unhappiness.

So Bhagawan said, you are motivated by your quest for happiness. All you have to do now is find out where your happiness is. He said that the happiness lies within yourself and you need to find it. The senses are creating sense experiences, as we have discussed, and my mind gets deluded by Moha -- attachment. When I see something which I like, I get attached to it, then I want to acquire it.

And if I can't acquire it, then I get angry. So Bhagavan said, you have to purify your mind and intellect, and therefore start with Karma Yoga. Perform your actions because you're motivated to act in this world. But just change your attitude towards your actions. Your actions should expand your identity. Your problem on one side is that your identity is so limited -- to yourself, to your body, to your mind, to intellect. You need to expand it more and more.

If you come to the conclusion that everything that is happening in this world is perfect, then you have less complaint about this world. If Brahman is perfect, then Purusha has to be perfect. And if Purusha is perfect, Prakriti has to be perfect, because Purusha and Prakriti are nothing but the expression of the same Brahman. One cannot be imperfect while another remains perfect. If Brahman is perfect, his creation also has to be perfect.

So Brahman plus Maya, as we have discussed is Ishvara. If Ishvara is perfect, his creation also has to be perfect. If I take that notion that this world is perfect then the imperfections which I see has to be because of my own ignorance. My complaint about this world is about its imperfection. It is not as perfect as I would like it to be to make me perfectly happy. Bhagavan said, when you change your vision, your drishti, then you will be able to see that this world is perfect.

Everything is in this world is the necessity. Without that the world will not function. The world will function perfectly for you if you start seeing it as perfect. So that journey was Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. To expand my identity, more I work for the greater good, more I identify with that greater good. Then achieve that sense of belonging to that greater self.

So Bhagavan said, you perform Karma Yoga. To perform Karma Yoga, Bhagavan has given us Yajna. And Bhagavan says, once you perform this Yajna diligently, you will achieve knowledge. That knowledge is not outside of you but within you. You already know yourself, but right now it is veiled by your identification with your limited self and your sense of duality between the world and you. That knowledge will remove that veil.

So what we have seen in last few verses is it says Yatha e Dhansi, Samidha, Agnihi Basma Sat Gurute. Just as blazing fire burns everything to ashes, now there is no duality left in that fuel. If you put fire in different things, the wood and something else and paper, all that has duality before. Once it becomes ashes, they all become one. Gnana Agnihi, Sarvakarmani, Basma Saat Kurute Datta. The knowledge about yourself will burn all your actions which you consider either good or evil.

All of that will merge into one. In this world there is nothing but the same entity. And therefore there cannot be too many different things. Everything has to be the expression of the same entity. I don't identify myself as my mind is separate and I am separate. So at my level I say my mind and body are one and the same.

My present is nothing but an imaginary line between my past and future. Past and future are not two separate entities but continuum of my own self. So Bhagavan said that knowledge will burn all your Actions just as when I wake up from the dream, all the actions in the dream are resolved. No consequences of any bad, good or ugly actions in my dream. So Bhagavan said, in your understanding all actions will burn to ashes. Nahi Gnane Sadrusam Pavitram Iha Vidyate -- there is no greater purifier of your own actions than the knowledge that you are not the doer.

This world is functioning as Bhagavan has designed. Once you know that everything in this world is perfect, that it is as it must be and I am a part of it, then this knowledge will purify all the impurities in your mind which are creating this confusion. There is no greater purifier. I try my best to purify my experience, make it all good, but it is not really working. Once you know this knowledge -- that your self is nothing but an expression of the supreme self -- all your actions will be dissolved and you will be purified of all your sins.

Tatsvayam Yogasansiddha Kalena Atmani Vindhati -- the person who is established in Yoga (and we have seen the definition of Yoga before) is one whose mind is completely balanced, who does not get affected by any situation. Why? Because he has stopped seeing the world as good and evil, has stopped seeing the world as "I versus the world." His mind is completely balanced. Yoga Sansiddha Tatsvayam -- he himself will recognize this truth in his own self in time to come. It will not happen overnight, not because, as Swamiji says, "some guru put his hand on me." But it will happen because I made the effort to purify my mind and intellect by gaining the knowledge about who I am.

That journey may take time. But it will happen. Is it a year from now? We don't know. But it will happen. Your job is to keep marching on the path of Karma. Use the methods which are available in Sastra.

All these yagnas which we have seen. Bhavan said, at the mouth of Brahman, there are many such yajnas are available. In other words, there are so many paths. Whichever path is the most conducive for your own situation, you should take that. But your responsibility is to walk that path and not just know about it. So Bhagawan said, Saddhavan Lavateghnana now for that to take that path, first of all you have to have faith that there is something which I can achieve.

That destination is available. If I want to go to some fictional place, there is no chance that I will ever reach there no matter how hard I try. A fictional city created in some fictional novel -- I think people have tried to find Sherlock Holmes' home. We all know Sherlock Holmes is a fictional character and therefore everything described is somewhat fictional.

But people still go to London to find Sherlock Holmes' home. That's a fictional destination. If I know Sherlock Holmes did not exist, then his home cannot exist, and there is no chance for me to find where he lived. But if I know the destination I'm looking for exists -- there is Hawaii on this planet, and I can go to Hawaii if I make efforts and save enough money and take my journey. If I have that faith, that Shraddha -- Bhagawan Sankaracharya says, Guru Vedanta Vakya Adisu Vishwasah -- if I have trust in what my teachers have told me, that H2O makes water, then someday I can go into the laboratory, make it happen, and experience it myself.

But if I think this formula is wrong, that what my teacher is teaching me is wrong, then I will never get there. That Shraddha is trust in what I have learned from others through their experience. I trust that there is a destination where pure happiness lies.

Tatparaha Sanyat Indriyaha Labhate Gnanam -- one who is Tatparaha, who is anxious, who wants to go there. Not only do I know about Hawaii, but I have an intense desire to go there. We have heard that in Wimbledon, both players are equally prepared and equally capable.

One who wins is the one who has the fire in his belly: "I need to win this match." That anxiousness, that burning desire to achieve it. Tatparaha. Sanyat Indriyaha -- I may have faith that there is a destination, and I may also have this great desire, but I am not disciplined. I want to be a great athlete but I have no discipline. So these three -- if I cultivate them, I have faith that there is a state where I can be perfectly happy, and I want to get there.
snippets.reflection:
The closing verses of Chapter 4 issue both a warning and a call to action. Verse 40 warns: the ignorant, the faithless, and the doubter are destroyed (ajnas cha ashraddadhanas cha samshayatma vinashyati). For the one who doubts, there is no happiness in this world or the next. Verse 41 contrasts this with the liberated one: who has renounced action through yoga, whose doubts have been severed by knowledge, who is self-possessed (atmavantam) - such a person is not bound by action. The chapter culminates in verse 42's stirring command: "Tasmad ajnana-sambhutam hritstham jnanasina atmanah chittvainam samshayam yogam atishthottishtha Bharata" - therefore, with the sword of knowledge, cut asunder this doubt born of ignorance dwelling in your heart. Take refuge in yoga. Arise!

The three enemies named - ignorance (ajna), faithlessness (ashraddhah), and doubt (samshaya) - are interconnected. Ignorance breeds doubt; doubt undermines faith; and without faith, no sustained effort is possible. The "doubt dwelling in the heart" (hritstham samshayam) is the fundamental uncertainty about whether liberation is real and attainable. Krishna's solution is dramatic: take up the sword of knowledge and cut it away. This is not passive acceptance but active, decisive action.

For your closing practice with Chapter 4, examine the doubts dwelling in your own heart. What fundamental uncertainties prevent you from wholehearted commitment to the spiritual path? Write them down. Then consider: are these doubts born of genuine inquiry or from ignorance and lack of experience? Recognize that doubt itself is not the enemy - samshaya that leads to inquiry is healthy. But chronic, paralyzing doubt that prevents action is destructive. Today, take one concrete step to "arise" (uttishtha) - whether through study, practice, or service. The chapter's teaching is complete: through Karma Yoga purify the mind; through Jnana Yoga understand who you truly are; through Yajna act for the greater good. Now, armed with the sword of knowledge, arise and fulfill your dharma!

snippets.title: Day 70: True Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

jñeyaḥ sa nityasaṃnyāsī yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna said: My Lord! At one moment Thou praisest renunciation of action; at another, right action. Tell me truly, I pray, which of these is the more conducive to my highest welfare?
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Renunciation of action and the path of right action both lead to the highest; of the two, right action is the better.
He is a true ascetic who never desires or dislikes, who is uninfluenced by the opposites and is easily freed from bondage.
snippets.commentary:
We completed chapter four and started discussing chapter five. Chapter four was Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation of actions in Knowledge. Now chapter five is called Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation of Actions. Some of the books only title it Sannyasa Yoga -- basically, Yoga for renunciation or true renunciation. And the word "true" is very meaningful here, because renunciation can be of many types.

And we have been discussing what is true renunciation. Chapters one and two give us the background and the insight into the nature of the self. Chapters three and four talked about Karma Yoga, Yoga of action. So our journey is from inertness, which is the true nature of this body. In Prakriti everything is inert, and our body is nothing but part of this Prakriti. So the very nature of our self is inert.

Given a choice, what we want to do is nothing. So what are you doing this weekend, Neil? And my answer is nothing. I really don't plan anything. The real joy is not doing anything. So that's our basic nature is inertia, inertness.

So inertia is our nature, and therefore the danger is that we may fall into tamas. The first quest is to whip yourself up into rajas, to start doing activity. You can't do activity unless there is motivation. What is the motivation? My desires, my goals. To acquire and accomplish -- that is the motivation. It is very, very important to have motivation.

So all my activities are driven by my motivation, which is desires. From inertia I have to go to desire-prompted activities. That's where I do things, accomplish, and achieve. But then I have to rise above those, because I realize that's not the end -- that's the means to go to the end. So the next goal is to have desireless activities, which is the Yoga. We have seen that Yoga is activity performed keeping the greater good in mind. The Yajnas -- twelve different types of Yajnas described in the last chapters -- are meant to prompt ourselves into a level of activity which will purify our mind and intellect.

And why are we purifying our mind and intellect? To get to the next stage where we can realize who we are -- the self. So that's meditation, Dhyana, contemplating on your own self. It's a journey from inertia to realizing yourself. Chapters three and four prepared us for desireless activities, Yajna. As we said, the definition of Yajna is activity which I do for the greater good.

Keeping the good of the entire society, the community, the cosmos, the universe, humanity in mind -- that is my Yajna. There are twelve different methods we have learned. Now, once I have learned the art of action, I have to go beyond actions. The next two chapters, five and six, focus on how to transcend actions. As we have seen, when I drop attachment to something, I transcend that. The standard example is when I was a child, I was attached to my toys.

And as I grow, the attachment to those toys drop. You can't give a 12 year old a balloon on their birthday like you gave them at age three. With my little Maida, I can see the difference between what I could give her six months ago and now -- she's constantly changing, saying "oh no, I don't want that. That's a baby's toy." Just six months ago she was playing with it, now she's outgrown it. So you transcend as you attach to higher and higher things.

So if you attach to the higher, then the lower drops off. When we attach to the activity, Tamas drops off. When I attach to the desireless activities, the desires drops off. And now I have to go beyond that. So the next two chapters. Chapter five makes a bridge between contemplation, the Dhyana and the yoga which is activity actions.

So therefore it's called Karma Sannyasa Yoga -- renouncing actions. The first few verses start with Arjuna's question. Now this confusion is not really anything unique. Even the most ardent students of Bhagavad Gita constantly get confused about the goal of life -- whether Sannyasa is good or Yoga is good. Let me clarify the two terms we have defined before: egoless action, giving up the sense of doership, is Sannyasa. If I give up the agency -- the "I am the doer" -- it's Sannyasa.

But if I give up the enjoyership -- that I am the enjoyer of the fruits of my actions -- then I am a Yogi. So Yoga requires Tyaga, giving up the fruits of actions. Sannyasa requires complete renunciation of myself as this limited being, as the doer. But this is not very clear to most of us. So Bhagavan puts this question in Arjuna's mouth, which we have all universally asked. Sanyasam Karmanam Krishna punar yogam Chasansashi Yat shreya etayoho ekam tanme bruhi sunis chitam. We go and ask this question all over.

Tell me one thing that I can practice. Don't confuse me with all this elaborate discussion about what is right and what is wrong. Just tell me should I go and do this or not? Sanyasam Karmanam Krishna punar yogam chasansi. You are praising Sannyasa because we have seen several verses in last four chapters which says offer everything to me, just do actions for me. All of that basically means I have to renounce actions.

So it says Sanyasam Karmana sansasi. You are praising renunciation of action, giving up actions at the same time. And also you are praising Yoga. You spent the whole chapter describing what Yoga is. So now you tell me what is good for me. Yat sreya ethayaha ekam tanmi bruhisoneshitam.

Don't give me two options. As I told you before, options really create confusion. When I was in Nairobi to buy a car, I had to register your name, just like in India it used to be. I think they changed it since, but I'm talking about the 80s. In India also, to get a car you had to register yourself, and after two or three years your number comes. Nairobi was the same way.

My boss told me that Neil go and buy a new car. The company used to give me a car and an old car. I was so excited I went and told my friends. My boss told me buy a new car. They all started laughing. I said why are you guys laughing?

He said new car means next couple of years then you may get it. I said no, no no, I need it now. He said there is no way you're going to get a new car. You register then a number will come. But I was so determined I need a new car. My boss told me you can get a new car, I'm going to get it.

So I used all my influences -- told all my friends, all my networking contacts, all the business people I knew. They finally found one car from a remote-area agency where there was one car available. You know, they allocate quotas to different agencies, and in the remote area there was no one to buy cars, so it was available. We bought the car from the remote area and drove it back to Nairobi. And I was so proud that I got a car. There was not even a question of which car it is -- whatever it is! It was actually called the Ford Laser.

None of you may have ever heard here Ford Laser. It is actually Mazda Trivanti, made in Japan for Ford company. I didn't even ask them what does that mean. They actually told me it's actually Mazda but it's Ford. New car, that's all I need. And I was so proud and happy.

And after about eight months we decided to come to United States. I had to sell the car. So my boss said, you go and sell the car. I said, are you sure? Yeah, you sell it to whoever there. I realized why he wanted me to have a new car.

Selling a car fetches more money than what I paid for, because cars are scarce. Somebody has a new car, people are going to pay a premium. So I sold that car for probably one and a half times what I bought it for. The company made a profit on me in eight months. I used the car and gave a profit to it. Then I come here, and the very first week I realized I can't survive in this country without a car.

So I told my brother in law, we need to go and buy a car, let's go and register it. You don't need to register. I said when can we go and buy a car? He said, over the weekend we will go. I said are you sure that we're going to wait till the weekend? He said, yeah, yeah, that's right, over the weekend.

The weekend comes and he tells me, let's go. So we first go to one dealership -- a Ford dealership -- and there are cars as far as my eyes can see. And he said, you can take any car from here. I said, are you serious? Tell me which one I should take. He said, this is just one dealer. We're going to then go to Chrysler, then we will go to GM, and then we will go to all the Japanese cars.

You tell me which car to buy and I'll buy it. But I'm not used to this. If you don't have a choice, that's the best situation you are in. When I started my firm, I did not have too many choices -- that was the best situation. When I had choices, I could never decide. So Arjuna is in the same situation.

He said, with all these choices, can you tell me what is good for me? So at least now we know that Arjuna has come from not doing anything. He wanted to run away from his actions. He is now ready to do actions. He realized that doing right action is what is necessary here. But he does not know what the right action is.

That's where we are all. We all want to do right things in life. It's just that we sometimes don't know what the right thing is. Therefore now Bhagavan says, Sanyasaha, Karma Yogastha, Nistreyaha Sakarao Ubhav -- both Sannyasa and Karma Yoga are good. Both lead to Sreyas, the bliss which I'm seeking, the peace which I'm seeking in life constantly.

If I do this, then all my life will be peaceful -- that's what we think. And so I continue to work towards my goals, and in the process I actually create more agitations. As I told you before, probably in this class, when I started going to Chinmaya Mission many, many years ago -- since I was a teenager -- we took Bhajans, and there is one verse that comes: Baalahatavat Krida Sakthah, Taruna Hatawat Taruni Sakthaha, Bruddha Tawat Chinta Saktha. I never understood it fully. Bala Tawat Krida Saktha -- easy.

When I was a little child I was engaged in toys, you know and plays. No problem understanding. I understood it clearly. Mine is a love marriage so I understood the Taruna Tawat part -- being engrossed in romance. I thought to myself, by the time I'm 50 and my son is 25, I should be completely at peace, right? Since I have only one son, all my family responsibilities will be over. So why this Vriddha Tava Chinta Saktha -- why would old age be filled with worry? snippets.reflection:
Arjuna's question in verse 1 mirrors our own confusion: should I renounce actions or engage in them? Krishna's answer reveals a profound truth - both paths lead to the same goal, but Karma Yoga is more accessible for most of us. Today, notice when you feel torn between "doing" and "not doing." Are you seeking to escape responsibility, or are you genuinely ready to transcend action? The true sannyasi described in verse 3 is one who "neither hates nor desires" and is "free from the pairs of opposites." This freedom comes not from avoiding life, but from engaging fully without attachment.

Consider this practice: Choose one routine task today - cooking, commuting, or working - and perform it with complete presence, without mentally labeling it as pleasant or unpleasant. When you notice yourself wishing the task were different, or congratulating yourself for doing it well, gently return to the action itself. Ask yourself: "Can I do this without needing it to be over? Can I act without becoming the 'doer'?" This is the essence of what Krishna calls Karma Yoga being superior - it transforms every moment into spiritual practice, preparing the mind for the deeper renunciation that comes naturally with purification.

Let me clarify the two terms we have defined before: egoless action, giving up the sense of doership, is Sannyasa. If I give up the agency -- the "I am the doer" -- it's Sannyasa.

But if I give up the enjoyership -- that I am the enjoyer of the fruits of my actions -- then I am a Yogi. So Yoga requires Tyaga, giving up the fruits of actions. Sannyasa requires complete renunciation of myself as this limited being, as the doer. But this is not very clear to most of us. Tell me one thing that I can practice. Don't confuse me with all this elaborate discussion about what is right and what is wrong. Just tell me should I go and do this or not? All of that basically means I have to renounce actions.

So it says Sanyasam Karmana sansasi. You are praising renunciation of action, giving up actions at the same time. And also you are praising Yoga. You spent the whole chapter describing what Yoga is. So now you tell me what is good for me. Yat sreya ethayaha ekam tanmi bruhisoneshitam.

snippets.reflection:
Verse 4 delivers a striking rebuke: "Only the unenlightened speak of wisdom and right action as separate, not the wise." How often do we create false divisions - spiritual life versus practical life, meditation versus work, sacred versus mundane? Krishna declares that one who truly establishes himself in either path gains the fruit of both. The division exists only in our confused minds. Verse 6 adds a crucial warning: "Without concentration, renunciation is difficult" - we cannot skip the preparation that Karma Yoga provides.

Today, experiment with seeing your work as your spiritual practice and your spiritual practice as your work. When you sit to meditate, bring the same diligence you bring to important tasks. When you engage in daily responsibilities, bring the same awareness you cultivate in meditation. Ask yourself: "Where am I creating artificial separations between the 'spiritual' and the 'worldly'?" Notice if you postpone inner peace until retirement, vacation, or some future condition. The sage meditating on the Divine, as verse 6 describes, does not wait for perfect circumstances - he finds the Divine in every circumstance. Can you bring this unified vision to just one hour of your day?

snippets.title: Day 72: The Liberated Soul
snippets.sanskrit:
योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः |

नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् |

प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि |
snippets.transliteration:
yogayukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ .

naiva kiñcitkaromīti yukto manyeta tattvavit .

pralapanvisṛjangṛhṇannunmiṣannimiṣannapi .
verseTranslations: He who is spiritual, who is pure, who has overcome his senses and his personal self, who has realised his highest Self as the Self of all, such a one, even though he acts, is not bound by his acts.
Though the saint sees, hears, touches, smells, eats, moves, sleeps and breathes, yet he knows the Truth, and he knows that it is not he who acts.
Though he talks, though he gives and receives, though he opens his eyes and shuts them, he still knows that his senses are merely disporting themselves among the objects of perception.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter five, Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of True Renunciation. So the chapter opens with Arjuna's question, which one is better? You had been praising Sannyasa. At the same time you are asking me to engage in action. Both are reaching the same goal. Whether you start with Karma Yoga or a Sannyasa, it will take you to the goal which you are striving all your life, that is finding a permanent bliss.

Right now, it seems my life is filled with agitations and unhappiness. No matter how hard I try, I can't get out of agitations. Even when I think I'm doing something with good intentions, it creates agitations. As the Rolling Stones say, the road to hell is paved with good intentions. We do think we are doing it with good intentions. We end up in a very uneasy situation.

So how do I get out of it? One side, I think if I continue working harder and harder, I'll get to the point where there will be bliss. That's our retirement plan, isn't it? I want to work hard and work hard so I can get to a blissful retirement. Or say, I'm so tired of this agitations and unhappiness, I should give up everything and not get involved in anything. That's typically what we go through in our life at various stages of our life.

And that's basically Arjuna's question. Bhagavan said no -- intelligently engaging yourself in either Karma or renouncing Karma will get you the same goal. However, for you, Karma Yoga is clearly better. You are not at a state to renounce actions. As Swami says, I can only renounce something which I have. I can't renounce and say I have given up Hanover County.

I don't own Hanover County. I can't renounce Hanover county. Or I give Hanover county donation to Chinmaya Mission can't happen. I have to have something to renounce. So if I have worked very hard in the field of my actions, then only I can retire from actions. If I never engage myself into actions, there is nothing to retire from.

The man who never worked in his life -- how can he retire? If you're not working Monday through Friday, there is no weekend. All seven days are weekend for you. So Bhagavan says the first thing is you have to engage yourself in actions. You start with Karma Yoga, apply yourself into actions. And you start out your actions in life first with desire-prompted actions: I want to achieve this, I want to accomplish this, I want to get this -- and that will get me to happiness.

Then he realized that that's not getting me anywhere. Then started desire less actions. Bill Gates obviously started out with a lot of desires, built the biggest company, want to put PC on every home and build the largest company. And he did whatever is stuck to make the Microsoft the biggest company. Now what he's doing is desireless actions. He's giving up all the money he has earned.

He's engaging himself actively into his foundation to better people's lives. So I start out to get happiness through my desire-prompted actions. Then I graduate from desire-prompted actions to desireless actions. From desireless actions only can I graduate to agency-less action -- giving up the sense of "I am the doer." Moving from selfish action to selfless action is a journey, and Karma Yoga is the means to achieve that.

So Bhagavan said that only the people who do not understand this journey will think that Karma Yoga is different from Sannyasa, or that Gnana Yoga is different from Karma Yoga. But one who establishes himself in one will get the result of both. Once I establish myself in Karma Yoga, my mind and intellect will purify and I will achieve that bliss. Likewise, when I realize that I'm not this limited being, that I am not the doer, then I'll achieve the same bliss. So Yat Sankhe Praapvyate Sthanam Tad Yogi API gamma te -- whatever is reached by the knowledge that I am not this limited being can also be achieved by performing Karma Yoga.

So the one who sees that this is the same path leading to the same goal -- Yapasyati Sapashyati -- such a person realizes what the true destination is. What is the true journey? Sanya Sastamaha Baha Dukham Aptama Yogatah. If I start renouncing things before achieving things, it's very painful. I haven't even gained anything -- how can I renounce anything?

So first step to make myself worthy of giving up. If I start giving up without achieving anything, I want to make a Donation of a million dollar. But I have only hundred thousand dollars in my bank. It's going to give me more pain. If I achieve the level well, I can start giving up. Bill Gates could not have given up his money before Microsoft was built, right?

So for one who wants to renounce before achieving anything, it's very painful. Therefore, don't start thinking about giving up actions before you accomplish actions. Yoga Yukta, Munihi Brahman Achiranadhi Gacha Diprama. Once you establish yourself in Karma Yoga -- which is selfless action, Niskama Karma -- moving from desire-prompted action to desireless action, it is very easy to give up after that. Then Sannyasa comes very naturally to us.

See, therefore, in the Varnashrama system, you start with Brahmacharya, which is the life of a student.

Then Grihasthashram -- you have to engage yourself in activity, achieve things, produce things, do whatever it is to support society, your family, your community. Then Vanaprastham -- gradually retreat from all activity. Not suddenly, but gradually start giving up the powers to your juniors, your sons, whoever you consider. And then Sannyasa -- you have already taken yourself out of action to a point where it's very easy to exit. So you see, once you establish yourself in desireless actions, it is very easy to achieve that peace which you are looking for.

Yoga Yukto Visuddhatma, Vijitatma Jitendriyaha, Sarva Bhuttma Bhutatma Kurvanapi Na Lipyate.

Once I establish myself in desireless action and I want to take Sannyasa, that Sannyasa does not mean that I will not be acting in this world. Outside, I'll be working in the world. But now the actions don't bind me. Yoga Yukta -- once one has established himself in Karma Yoga and the art of action. When I was learning music, obviously it's so painful to do the Sa-Ra-Ga-Ma, the Sargam.

Once you establish in that, it's very easy. So once you master anything, it's very easy to perform that action. So to perform these actions in a right way, Bhagavan said is without desire. You perform the same action without desires. Right now it is very difficult for me. Because everything is prompted by my desire.

I want to achieve this. So all this is creating agitations. Once I'm out of agitations then it is very easy for me to give up. So these are the qualifications Yoga Yuktah Once we established in how to perform actions. Visuddhaatma Vasudhatma. Your internal instrument is purified.

Mind and intellect is now purified. So it sees things as they are. And we are not polluted by my desires. Right now the reality is colored by my desire. If the market is going up, we are all very happy. And the interest rates are at zero level.

Great for a businessman. But the guy who is retired and relying on investment income -- he is suffering with a 0% interest rate for so long. For a person surviving on investment income, 0% interest is a disaster. For a person borrowing money to leverage his business, that's great. There's never been a better time in this country than the last few years. So it's all colored by my desire.

But the one who is not involved in both, he sees that as a normal occurring. This is how the world works and there's nothing to rejoice or regret about it. Vijay Tatma who has a control over his self in this case is ego. Who has a control over his ego. He knows that these things are happening. I'm just doing my part.

Jit Indriyaha -- one who has control over the senses. Indriyas are there for a purpose and they have their own reasons to be there. And I have control over what I see, what I hear, what I touch, what I taste. I have control over it, not my senses.

Sarva Bhuttma Bhuttatma -- now this is the real test of a Sannyasi. Once he starts seeing that the self in me is the self in all beings.

Myself and yourself and his self or herself are not various selves. One self manifesting as me, you, he, she, it. When that reason comes, Bhagavan says Kurvan API na lipya dhai. He can do whatever he wants in this world but not affected by it. We are affected by our actions because we think I've done good, that means I'm going to get something out of it. I've done bad, I'm going to get punished by it.

All these things are because of my desires. But once I have transcended the desires -- see, when two children are playing and both are your children, who wins and who loses is not a problem. Serena Williams and Venus Williams -- at one time they were both in a Wimbledon final. To their father, what does it matter which daughter is going to win?

Guaranteed, he is happy either way -- otherwise he is jumping up and down in his chair. Whether his daughter is going to win or not, if I start seeing myself in everything, then whoever is winning or losing is all me winning and me losing. Therefore, Bhagavan always says, you are not suffering alone -- I'm suffering with you. When I suffer, he suffers at the same time. You know, different Puranas say that somebody did this or Bhagavan had the pain. It's symbolic.

But if I pervade everywhere in my dream, even the one who is suffering and one who is enjoying, both are me. So Bhagavan said, when I start seeing that Kurvanna pina Lipyade, then whatever I do is not affecting me. So the following three verses say the attitude of a person who has achieved that level of accomplishment and seeing things as one. How that Sanyasi so is now a realized person. He has seen that the one self pervades everywhere and I am no different than it. His attitude will be Naiva kinship, Karomi Ithi, Yuktah, manyya tattvavit.

Here is the qualification or the description of a self-realized master -- Tattvavit -- who knows in essence what the reality is all about. There is no plurality as we see it. The perception of plurality is because I have confined myself to this limited identification. I am one person when I identify this body as me. But when I represent a family or a company -- when I say I'm from Google -- I represent Google.

The entire Google pervades in me. The whole power of that company I exude when I say I am from Google. I remember I used to work for large companies. So when I go to Austria or someplace, I'm not Neil Bart. I'm representing wzmh, one of the largest companies. When I take out my card and say I'm Neil Bart, wzmh.

I'm not presenting my qualifications -- I'm presenting the qualifications of my company. Then I left the company, started NBJ architecture with four people. Now I have to say I am who I am. It changes your perception when you expand your identification. So one who has expanded his identification to the entire universe -- for him, Naiva kinchit karomi, "I am not doing anything."
snippets.reflection:
These three verses paint a remarkable portrait of the liberated soul in action. Verse 7 describes one who has "realized his highest Self as the Self of all" - and crucially, "even though he acts, is not bound by his acts." Verses 8 and 9 then enumerate the full range of human activities - seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving, sleeping, breathing, talking, giving, receiving, even opening and closing the eyes - and declare that the wise one knows "it is not he who acts." This is not philosophical theory but a lived experience: the recognition that "his senses are merely disporting themselves among the objects of perception."

Practice this contemplation today: As you go through your activities, periodically pause and observe. Who is seeing? Who is hearing? Notice that the eyes see automatically, the ears hear automatically - you, the awareness behind it all, are simply witnessing. When eating lunch, notice that taste happens, chewing happens, swallowing happens. Can you locate the "doer"? This is the attitude of the tattvavit, the knower of Truth mentioned in verse 8. The goal is not to become passive or disconnected, but to recognize your true position as the unchanging witness while the body-mind instrument continues its natural functions. Even now, as you read these words, who is reading? Abide as that which knows.

snippets.title: Day 73: Inner Peace
snippets.sanskrit:

Having abandoned the fruit of action, he wins eternal peace. Others unacquainted with spirituality, led by desire and clinging to the benefit which they think will follow their actions, become entangled in them.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter five, Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation of Actions. So far we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita that the self which I consider myself is not the real self. We learnt in chapter two, Sankhya Yoga. So the entire quest in our life is to reconcile this paradox we have. We consider ourselves to be a limited being. But Bhagavad Gita says, you are not the limited being.

So how do I remove this paradox? How do I change this paradigm with which I'm functioning right now as an individual limited being, and identify with that unlimited supreme being? That's basically the goal of the rest of the teachings of Bhagavad Gita. So in chapter three, Bhagavan said, you can start with Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. Act you must, but act in a way that does not bind you, so that you can free yourself from this conditioning. You act in this world without an expectation for the fruits, because you are not in control of the fruits.

Right now I consider myself to be completely separate from this world, and I'm competing with this world. Bhagavan said, unless you give up this identity of your own, you will not be able to realize your true identity. The Upanishads tell us that the world which I see is finite, but that supreme is unlimited, infinite, Almighty, all-knowing. But for me to perceive that is very, very difficult. So therefore we chant this: Om Purnamadhah Purnamidam Purnath Purnamuddhachate Purnasya Purnamadaya Purnamavashate. It says that from that infinite came this infinite which I see as infinite.

Jagat, this Prakriti, is also complete and infinite. That from which it came, the supreme Brahman, is also infinite. That is infinite. This is also infinite. The world I'm identifying with is also infinite, even though it seems finite. Even though I see myself as a finite being in a world that appears finite -- it's not finite, it's infinite. And if you take this infinite out of that infinite, what remains is still infinite.

In other words, there is no separation between the world which I perceive and the real self. There is no separation between my limited self and that supreme self. But ignorance is creating this dual vision, and I need to remove that. So the first step is: when you act in this world, see this unity and don't expect any results from your actions. That will relieve you from the anxiety of the fruits of actions. And then chapter four said there are not really two separate entities. Both came from the same singular entity, and therefore act for the betterment of the entire Jagat.

The Jagat that you consider your own world -- maybe your own family, maybe your own community, maybe your own nation. Work for that without expecting that your actions will bear particular results; that will free you from anxiety. And now in this chapter, we are learning how to renounce this sense of agency -- that "I am the doer."

So Bhagavan started this chapter saying you can reach that same goal by renouncing actions and also by performing actions. Renouncing actions in the knowledge that I am not the doer will take you to that place where you can identify with your supreme self. But performing actions in this world without any expectations will also lead you to that state, by purifying your internal instrument, which right now is conditioned by this limitedness that you have taken upon yourself as your own.

Bhagavan said both are one and the same. Yatsangkhi prapyate sthanam tadyogi apigema. That place which is reached by contemplation on the very fact we learnt in chapter two -- that I am not this mortal being, I am that immortal being. If I contemplate on that statement and come to the conclusion that that's the truth, I change my identification from this limited self to the higher self. That's the path of Sankhya -- contemplating on that great statement Tattvamasi, "you are that." But if that's not in my capability right now, Bhagavan said, tat yoge API gammade.

By performing this Karma Yoga, you can also achieve that same state, the same result. And therefore you should start with Karma Yoga. Because contemplation without preparing your mind for the contemplation is pretty painful. In other words, it will not bear any good result. And then you will be frustrated. And then you will say, I don't think this has any value.

So rather than engaging yourself in Something you're not capable of, engage yourself in purifying your mind and intellect. The yogi who has achieved the state of purification, he knows that naiva kinchit karomi ITI yuktaham manyate tattvavit. One who knows the essence of the self, that that which feels like my limited self is nothing but the supreme self. It is my own ignorance that I'm identifying with the limitations and therefore I feel limited. One who has recognized that truth by establishing himself in yoga or by contemplation, he knows that naivakinchitkarami I am not doing anything. Everything is performed by indriyani indriyarthesu vartanta ITI dharayan.

He clearly sees that what I perceive as activity performed by me is nothing but senses reacting with sense objects. And we can clearly see through our normal observations that my sense of taste will indulge me into eating more sweets, and that will show up on my body. So it is the sense objects and senses reacting with each other. Or I may consider myself to be a very wise person with control over my intellect and mind, but just one substance from this world called alcohol -- if I indulge in it, all my wisdom and sanity will go away and I will act like an average idiot.

So we know that these sense objects have clear effect on my behavior, a clear effect on how I think. And therefore I have to come to the conclusion that indriyaani indriya teshu vartnantah, the senses are indulging in activity with the sense objects. So all the activities, all that which is good and how that is bad is nothing but purely the interaction between the senses and sense objects. And we have seen sabdas parsa rupa rasa gandha, the five sense objects, and kshutra thvaka chakshuhu rasana grana, the five senses we have, you remove one, then the world of that sense will go away. If you remove all five, the world of objects which I perceive will go away. So therefore Bhagavan says, Brahmani adhaya karmani sangam tyaktva karotiyah.

So now, I am not at the level of that Yogi who clearly sees "naiva kinchit karomi" -- I am not doing anything. He does not have this confusion that I have. I think "I am doing this, I have done this, I have not done this" -- he does not have that confusion. He is like the ocean which sees its own waves and sees that he, as the ocean, is not involved in the activities of the waves. The waves are the water reacting with the wind, creating these waves on the surface.

But at the bottom, the ocean is standing still. They say Brahmani Adhaya Karmani Sangam Tyaktva Karutiyah. The phrase "Sangam Tyaktva" comes, as Sid pointed out last time, in this verse, and then "Karma Phalam Tyaktva" in the third verse. This word "Tyaktva" is constantly coming in our discussion. Anytime we see the word Tyaktva, it clearly means we are already attached. It means "give up, abandon."

I can only do that if I have something which I have to give up. So this clearly says that Sangam Tyaktva I am already attached. It's given that I'm attached to this world. I'm attached to this body, I'm attached to this mind, I'm attached to my intellect. No matter how hard I try, I keep identifying with who I am. As this limited being.

The idea that I am the doer does not go away very easily. Therefore, Bhagavan said, there is a method to get rid of that. Your mind has a tendency to attach, and if you don't give it an alternate, you will never be able to give up your attachment. So the alternate: Brahmani Yadhaya Karmani -- you offer all your actions to that supreme. That supreme which is complete. There is no place for you to be there as an individual.

If that supreme is all-pervading, all-complete -- if I'm all-pervading in my chair, there's no place for somebody else to be here. If that supreme is all-pervading, there is no place for me as a little ego to be there. And therefore, offer all your actions to that supreme. Brahmani Yadhaya Karmani, Sangam Tyaktva -- first you have to detach yourself from this attachment.

So by attaching yourself to Brahman, you offer all actions to him. Right now I'm bound by all my actions. I get success and I get elated. I get failure and I get dejected. When I get dejected and disappointed, it creates a negative impression in my mind -- that is the sin I'm incurring. So now the exercise for you, Bhagavan said, is this: because you are not at that level of a Yogi, you offer all your actions to him. Continue working, but think that you are not working for yourself -- you are working for him.

Whatever the results come, that will be his loss or profit, not yours. This analogy comes in our scriptures all the time. Just as lotus leaf is in the water, but does not get moistened by the water, it comes out of water, goes back into the water, decays in water, but during its lifetime it never gets moistened by the water. The same way you came in this world, you live in this world. You will die in this world. But while living, you don't get attached to the world by attaching yourself to Brahman.

So here is the technique Bhagavan has given for giving up the sense of agency, for those of us who are still at a level where we think that we are the doers. Kayana, Manasa, Buddhaya, Kaivalay, Indriyahiyapi, Yogi nahakarma, Karvanti, Sangam tyaktva atma sudaye. Again the words "Sangam Tyaktva" -- by giving up attachment, because right now I am attached. That fact has to be acknowledged first, and then we can say what is my next step. It is like Alcoholics Anonymous.

The first step is to admit that I'm an alcoholic. See, the first step is to admit that I am attached to this world -- to my body, my mind, my intellect, and my senses. Therefore, now I should recognize that I am not the one instigating all these activities. The activities are done by my body, because the very nature of the body is to function. Manasa -- by my mind, because the very nature of mind is to go out and get attached. Buddha -- my intellect, because the very nature of my intellect is to think what is right, what is wrong, what I have experienced, what I have not experienced. And my senses -- the very nature of the senses is to go out and get impressions from the world outside. Those impressions, now reported to the mind, create impressions on the mind.

Those impressions on the mind create perceptions in my intellect, and then I become the doer of the activity. But once I detach myself from all of this -- Kaya, Mana, Buddhi, and Indriya -- they are independent of me. They are acting according to their own nature. But I, the consciousness, the self, am not involved in it. Yogi Naha, Karma, Kurvanti, Sangam tyaktva atma sudaye.

So here clearly Bhagavan gives us the goal. The goal is the purification of the internal instrument Atma.
snippets.reflection:
The lotus leaf analogy in verse 10 offers a powerful image for daily life: living in the world without being stained by it, just as the lotus remains in water yet never gets wet. Verse 11 reveals the purpose of this detached engagement - "atmasuddhaye," for the purification of the self. This is not passive withdrawal but active purification. Verse 12 then presents the clear choice: one who abandons the fruit of action "wins eternal peace," while one driven by desire "becomes entangled."

Today, offer your actions to the Spirit as verse 10 instructs. Before beginning any task, silently acknowledge: "This action is offered to the Divine. The results belong to the Divine." Notice how this shifts your relationship with the work. The recurring phrase "sangam tyaktva" (giving up attachment) appears twice in these verses - acknowledge that you are currently attached, and that is precisely why this practice is necessary. Like Alcoholics Anonymous begins with admitting the problem, spiritual growth begins with acknowledging our attachments. Track your inner state during one significant activity today: Are you performing it for purification (atmasuddhaye) or for personal gain? The quality of your inner peace will reveal the answer. Can you be like the lotus - fully present in your environment yet untouched by its turbulence?

snippets.title: Day 74: True Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी |

न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः |

नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः |
snippets.transliteration:
sarvakarmāṇi manasā saṃnyasyāste sukhaṃ vaśī .

na kartṛtvaṃ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ .

nādatte kasyacitpāpaṃ na caiva sukṛtaṃ vibhuḥ .
verseTranslations: Mentally renouncing all actions, the self-controlled soul enjoys bliss in this body, the city of the nine gates, neither doing anything himself nor causing anything to be done.
The Lord of this universe has not ordained activity, or any incentive thereto, or any relation between an act and its consequences. All this is the work of Nature.
The Lord does not accept responsibility for any man's sin or merit. Men are deluded because in them wisdom is submerged in ignorance.
snippets.commentary:
So now we know that in my life, actions are necessary, but they're also my assets. My actions are my assets. Well, Neil, how did you accomplish what you accomplished? All that I have done -- went to architecture school, then worked for all these years for very little pay. My actions are my assets, but my actions are also a liability. So my actions are both the assets and the liabilities.

And what we try to do is leverage the assets and renounce the liabilities. When you file bankruptcy, what are you trying to do? You're renouncing your liabilities. But at the same token, you have to renounce your assets as well. You know, a very good recent example -- HDL, a very well-respected, fastest-growing company, thousands of employees and millions of dollars of investment. They filed for bankruptcy. Not only their bad deeds and their debt they have renounced, but the assets also they had to renounce -- just got sold for like 32 or 37 million dollars.

There were probably hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of investment. Bhagavan said that when you file bankruptcy on your liabilities, you have to also renounce your assets. So if I give up this sense of agency for both my good actions and bad actions, then I'm free. No assets, no liability.

So Bhagavan said that one who takes the doership has to suffer through the merits or the sins of his actions. The Yogi, while working, realizes that he can't give up the agency, but he gives up the fruits of actions.

Whatever will come out, I'll accept. Because I'm not the Karma-Phaladatta -- I'm the actor. I have the capacity to act, empowered by the Lord as my consciousness. But I have no control over what comes out from the world. The world is the Karma-Phaladatta. When I practice architecture, all the efforts I put in -- I can't give myself a project.

Somebody else has to give me a project. So the Karma-Phaladatta is somebody other than myself. Now in our Puranic sense, we think that the Karma-Phaladatta is Bhagavan -- that Bhagavan is keeping score of what good deeds you have done, what bad deeds you have done. Therefore, when we go to the temple, what do we ask for? Bhagavan, maaf karna. Bhagavan, Bhagavan hoge.

We don't say, "You remember what good deeds I have done -- I'm in control, don't worry about it, Mr. Bhagavan." Just "Bhagavan, maaf karna." So whenever we are in trouble, we ask Bhagavan to forgive us for all of our bad actions. But when it comes to success -- "I'm a self-made man. Came to this country with $8 in my pocket."

When I left India, the only thing I could take with me was $8. That was the total foreign exchange the Indian government allowed for people who leave India. So most of us came with $8 in our pocket. Your problems, Bhagavan -- you take care of it. But Bhagavan said, look, neither can I take care of your problems, nor can I give you credit for what you have done. Because all these actions which you are performing are in the realm of Prakriti.

Not in the realm of the self. Bhagavan is functioning in the realm of the self. So the verse which we will be seeing today says Nakartrutvam nakarmani lokasya srajati prabhuhu. This is completely in contrast to what we have believed all along -- that Bhagavan is the controller of all that I do. See, every time I make a mistake, I just say, what can I do?

Bhagavan has made me like that. Bhagavan put me in this situation. And that's a good comforting thought. That look, I'm not doing anything wrong. Bhagawan is putting me in this situation. And also we have this Puranic idea that Chitragupta is writing this book.

When you die he will just open up your account and say look, what good deeds you did. What bad deeds you did. Well, looks like your balance is pretty good. Well, it looks like your account on the negative side so it will go to hell. So we thought that somebody is taking care of all these things. So we always have this comfort zone that Bhagavan is actively participating in my life and he is guiding me or he is maneuvering me to what I am doing.

But now this Verse says Bhagavan says, I'm not doing anything. Nakartrutvam Nakarmani not the doership or the actions are created in this world by Prabhu. One who is a Prabha is a Prabhu. The Lord, one on which my life depends, is my Lord. The Lord is the one who sustains my livelihood. So my Lord is the one on whom my life depends.

So he's the Lord of my being, my consciousness. As long as I'm alive, I am who I am. As soon as the consciousness leaves me, I'm no longer who I am. That dead body -- you won't call it Neil Bhat. You will get rid of it as quickly as you can. Because I am who I am because of the consciousness in me.

So here Bhagavan says, Nakaratrutvam Nakarmani -- nothing in this world is created by the Lord of your being, my consciousness. The self which I call myself, you call yourself, he calls himself, she calls herself -- it is not forcing you to do anything. It's not creating any actions for you. It's also not creating any sense of agency for you. It's not taking any part in anything which you're doing.

Then where does this idea of me doing things come from?

It comes from your identification with the conditioning of yourself. Navadvare puree dehi naiva kinchit karomi iti -- the verse says it is the embodied one in this nine gated city who thinks "I am doing." The self says, "I am not doing anything." But the one who identifies with this nine gated city becomes the doer. And that identifier is my ego that says this is me.

The ego is the doer because he is the identifier with the conditioning. So Bhagavan said, the self, I, the Lord of your being is not forcing you to do anything nor am I creating any actions for you. He's also not the one who is actively sitting down with his supercomputer and saying Neil did this. He's completely out of this business. He simply says, let nature take care of it. Everything that is happening to me is happening because of the way I acted according to my nature -- the nature of my body, the nature of my mind, the nature of my intellect -- and then the nature of the world, what object I have acted upon, and at what level of physical abilities.

If I punch a guy who is 6'5" and about 300 pounds, what do you think the reaction would be? According to his Prakriti, according to my Prakriti -- Svabhavastu Pravartate. So Bhagavan said, in this world, actions are performed by the very nature of the beings -- the very nature of my body, mind, and intellect. And the Karma Phala coming to me is also dependent on the nature of the world. I always say, I may be the best architect on this planet, but if there is no work outside, no matter how much effort I put in, will there be any result?

Because the world is completely devoid of that need. But if I put my effort into a field where there is a need compatible with my ability, then I will get results. So what is happening? The Karma and Karma Phala are not dependent on whether Bhagavan thinks I'm a good guy or a bad guy. "Well, give Neel some projects."

He takes Gita class on Sundays. My clients don't care whether I take Gita class or Bible class. They only care whether I can design their buildings effectively. So Svabhavastu Pravartate -- everything in this world is guided by the laws of nature. Bhagavan says, I as the Prabhu am not involved at all.

So please don't count on me. This is a big shocker for all of us. We always thought that no matter what bad I did, as long as I go to the temple, the coconuts I offer will take care of it. So Bhagavan said, I do not take part in any of that. Na Adatte Kasyachit Papam -- I do not take sins from anybody.

No matter what bad I do, Bhagavan says, it does not affect me at all. Na chaiva Sukritam Vibhuhu -- and also I don't accept any good deeds. "Aap khud hi karaho, Bhagavan, you don't do anything for me." I don't accept anything.

I don't accept any of your good deeds or bad deeds. That self which is all-pervading is not affected by any good deeds or bad deeds in this universe. Myself, my consciousness, which I consider my Prabhu -- because I cannot sustain myself without him -- the same self is also Vibhu, all-pervading. So right now I'm burdened by my sins.

In a sense I'm burdened by what things I have done wrong in my life. I wish I had done this. I wish I had done this. I wish I had not put money in the market before it crashed. I wish I had bought Apple stock when it came out 25 years ago or whatever. But one said, but it's not affecting me.

The self in me is not tainted by my sins, my bad deeds, or my good merits. So with all the good deeds and bad deeds happening in this world, we constantly ask this question: Why does Bhagavan let this happen? What is this ISIS doing? And tsunami, and all these terrorists, and all these things happening.

Is he sleeping at the wheel? He said, no, I really have nothing to do with it. Everything is happening as per the nature of the Prakriti. Once I have created the Prakriti, it is governed by its own laws. We know the laws -- Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas.

These laws, in their permutations and combinations, create this world of plurality. The world of plurality interacts with itself according to its own gunas and creates its own results. But I stay out of it. Once you create the laws of the game, the referee only judges the player based on the rules of the game -- not whether he thinks someone is a nice guy or a bad person. You have to play by the rules of the game.

Once I sit in my car and turn the ignition, the car does not know whether a nice person has turned the ignition or a bad person. It will go by how the laws of thermodynamics work in the engine. So Bhagavan says, I do not really accept any good deeds or bad deeds. Then why are we not seeing this? Why are we not seeing that all these things happening are very natural -- that they are happening exactly as they should? The world is perfect, as Dan used to say all the time.

The world as is is the way it should be. But I constantly think this world is not appropriate. I don't know why everything is so messed up. You know, it's a chaos. But once I know it's not a chaos, it's the cosmos, it's not a chaos. Things are exactly happening in your life as it should happen.

Because of what you did so far, things will happen in your future exactly as you build your future. But then I am completely confused about these laws of the game. I'm actually participating in a game without knowing the rules of the game. Basically, that's the problem. If I start playing football without knowing what the rules are, I'm going to be crushed. That's exactly what is happening with me right now.

So Bhagawan says, why that is happening? Agnane Abrutam Gnanam this knowledge about the self is covered by the ignorance.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 13 introduces the striking image of the body as a "city of nine gates" - the two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, mouth, and two lower openings. The self-controlled soul "enjoys bliss" dwelling within this city, "neither doing anything himself nor causing anything to be done." Verses 14-15 deliver perhaps the most challenging teaching: the Lord does not create our sense of doership, does not ordain our actions, and does not accept responsibility for our sins or merits. "All this is the work of Nature." Our confusion arises because "wisdom is submerged in ignorance."

This teaching demands deep reflection. We habitually blame God when things go wrong and take credit when things go right. Today, examine this pattern in yourself. When you succeed, notice the thought "I did this." When you fail, notice the tendency to blame circumstances, others, or even the Divine. Verse 14 states clearly: "svabhavastu pravartate" - it is your own nature, the interplay of body, mind, intellect with the world, that creates results. The Lord is like the sun - it enables all activity without participating in it, without preference for what grows in its light. Can you take full responsibility for your life while simultaneously releasing the ego that claims ownership? Sit with this paradox today: everything is happening according to natural law, yet you are not excused from the consequences of your actions. How does this understanding change your relationship with your choices?
