तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः |

विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि |
snippets.transliteration:
jñānena tu tadajñānaṃ yeṣāṃ nāśitamātmanaḥ .

tadbuddhayastadātmānastanniṣṭhāstatparāyaṇāḥ .

vidyāvinayasampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini .
verseTranslations: Surely wisdom is like the sun, revealing the supreme truth to those whose ignorance is dispelled by the wisdom of the Self.
Meditating on the Divine, having faith in the Divine, concentrating on the Divine and losing themselves in the Divine, their sins dissolved in wisdom, they go whence there is no return.
Sages look equally upon all, whether he be a minister of learning and humility, or an infidel, or whether it be a cow, an elephant or a dog.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter five, Karma Sannyasa Yoga. So far we have seen that Bhagavan said Karma Yoga is clearly better for you, because Sannyasa may be more difficult to pursue for one who has not developed the quality of na dveshti na kankshati -- who does not hate or does not even desire. For such a person, Sannyasa is not really easy to practice.

Therefore, Karma Yoga -- Yoga Yukta Bhava, become Yoga Yukta. Yoga Yukta Bhava is to develop the art of performing actions for the greater good, not for myself. And the technique given to us in this chapter says: while you are performing all your actions, constantly think that you are not doing anything. Pralapan, vishrujan, srunan, svashan -- even when you are breathing, seeing, hearing, touching, think that you are not doing that. Someone other than what you think you are is doing it.

So that's the technique given to us: constantly, while I'm acting in this world, I should see that something else is doing it. What is that something else? Well, we can clearly identify that everything we do is either my body doing it, my mind doing it, or my intellect doing it. The observer who is observing this activity is someone other than body, mind, and intellect. So constantly see yourself as the witness of your own activity. Just as when we witness other people and say, "I know he's doing well, he's not doing well, I think he's wrong or he's right" -- but we are not involved in it. We are constantly judging other people from our vantage point, our perspective.

If we start developing a practice where we can do the same thing for ourselves, we will clearly see what is right and wrong for us. When we do something wrong, if we step out of that activity and see it, we'll see whether that was right or wrong, and the next time we can correct it. So the technique is given to us: constantly watch yourself as a third-party observer in all the activities you do.

And then the last few verses we had been discussing, where Bhagavan comes out and says Nakartrutvam lokasya Prabhu -- the Lord is not creating any sense of doership.

The ego which I have right now saying this is me and I am the doer. I am the enjoyer and I am the sufferer. Bhagawan said, I really have nothing to do with it. So please don't blame me. I did not create this ego for you. It is the very part of the Prakriti that these activities are going on.

Your body, mind and intellect are nothing but part of the Prakriti. You identifying it created this ego. But I am not the creator of your ego. You now have the responsibility to get rid of the ego yourself. Nakartruttam na karmanis Lokas. The Lord who is the Lord of my being is not responsible or not the creator of this ego.

That sense of "this is me, that's not me, nobody else could have done it without me, this cannot function without me" -- Bhagavan said, I'm not putting that in your head. I'm not creating this sense of agency, nor am I creating any actions. In other words, the Lord of my being is beyond the world of activity.

And we know this world of activity -- at the Prakriti level. Activity is taking place at the level of Prakriti, this world of plurality, the world where I exist and you exist and the world exists. For any activity to take place, you need two things.

When there is an actor and an object of activity, then only does activity take place. If there is no duality, no activity takes place. That's why when you are alone, you get bored. By myself, what can I do? I need somebody to play with. That's why solitude is so difficult for us to practice.

We want a life where everything is going on. But Bhagavan said, in reality there is no duality when it comes down to the core of your being -- yourself, myself, his self, and her self are one. So at that level, no activity is ever taking place. Therefore he says, I am beyond this activity. I am not creating doership, and I am not creating actions.

We constantly blame Bhagavan for things not going right for us. When things go right, "I put all the efforts and got it." When things go wrong, "Bhagavan is not looking after me these days." He said, I am completely away from your activity. I am not in the business of marrying your actions with the fruits of actions.

I'm not taking stock about what Papa I had done or Punya I had done. It's entirely up to you and the world you're working in to figure out the transactions and what is the results of the transactions. Because I created this Prakriti out of my own self by my Maya. In the previous chapter we have seen it clearly stated that I am working in this world out of my own Maya. Ajo'pi san avyayatma bhutanam ishwaro'pi san prakritim swam adhishthaya sambhavami atma-mayaya -- by my own Maya, by presiding over this Prakriti, I work in this world.

snippets.reflection:
Verse 16 uses the powerful image of the sun: "Surely wisdom is like the sun, revealing the supreme truth." Just as the sun does not create light but simply is light, wisdom does not create the Self but reveals what was always present, hidden by ignorance. Verse 17 describes those who meditate on the Divine going "whence there is no return" - their sins "dissolved in wisdom." Most remarkably, verse 18 declares that sages "look equally upon all" - whether a learned Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, or an outcaste. This sama-darshana (equal vision) is the hallmark of realization.

Today, practice sama-darshana consciously. As you encounter different people - colleagues, service workers, family members, strangers - can you perceive the same consciousness animating each form? The verse deliberately contrasts extremes: the highest (learned Brahmin) with the lowest (outcaste), the large (elephant) with the small (dog). This is not about ignoring differences at the practical level but about recognizing the same Self wearing different costumes. When someone irritates you today, pause and remember: the same awareness that looks out through your eyes is looking out through theirs. When you admire someone, remember: that same light shines in the person you find difficult. This practice of "equal seeing" is not sentimental but precise - it targets the root of our judgments and preferences. Can you maintain this vision for even five minutes continuously?

snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the liberated state with increasing precision. Verse 19 declares that those "whose minds remain always balanced" have "conquered their earth-life" even while living - because "the Supreme has neither blemish nor bias." Verse 20 describes one who "is not elated by pleasure or depressed by pain." And verse 21 reveals the secret: "He finds happiness in his own Self" because his "heart does not yearn for the contacts of earth." This is not suppression but genuine fulfillment - one who has found the inner spring no longer thirsts for external waters.

Practice "sthira-buddhi" (steady intellect) from verse 20 today. When something pleasant happens - a compliment, good news, a small success - notice the tendency to become elated. When something unpleasant occurs - criticism, inconvenience, frustration - notice the tendency to become disturbed. In both cases, return to center. Ask yourself: "Does this event add to or subtract from my essential being?" The answer is always no - you remain the same awareness whether praised or blamed. Verse 21 points to the deeper practice: finding "sukham" (happiness) within the Self rather than in "bahya-sparsha" (external contacts). Today, set aside even five minutes to simply be - not meditating on anything, not seeking any experience, just resting as awareness itself. Notice if there is a subtle contentment that requires nothing. This is "akshaya sukham" - the inexhaustible happiness that depends on nothing external.

snippets.sanskrit:

verseTranslations: The joys that spring from external associations bring pain; they have their beginning and their endings. The wise man does not rejoice in them.
He who, before he leaves his body, learns to surmount the promptings of desire and anger is a saint and is happy.

snippets.commentary:
We are discussing chapter 5, Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation. Renunciation is always about anything that we think we are possessing -- in this case, our actions. We think our actions are our own, and therefore renouncing those actions is the renunciation. So far we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita who we are as limited beings. As we had discussed many times before, the first six chapters of Bhagavad Gita describe "tvam" in that Mahavakya "Tat Tvam Asi" -- "That Thou Art." "Thou," the "you," is what we have learned so far. In chapter one, we encountered the situation which we encounter in our daily life.

A common man facing day-to-day situations which never come clean-cut as black and white, good or bad, happy or unhappy. They always have complexity which makes me confused about what is right and wrong, which action to take. So we have seen Arjuna's situation. He cannot see whether there is good in fighting the battle or running away from it. Fighting the battle is going to create some collateral damage, as we have seen recently in Afghanistan. Some people who I really respect and revere may also get hurt or killed.

And that happens in our life all the time. So the first chapter describes our situation as we face it in life today. The second chapter told us that what we think we are is not who we are. So there is a paradigm shift for us. We consider this self to be this limited me -- this body, mind, and intellect. And at the end of my journey in this life, this self will be destroyed.

But the self that I truly am will never be destroyed. Death will be only for the body. So that's a paradigm shift for us. Now, understanding that still does not give me what to do next. So the third chapter gave us the instruction about how to work in this world in an efficient manner. Two things it told us.

One, it says Swadharma Nidhanam Shreya, Paradharma Bhayavah. Act according to your own nature, your own Prakriti, because that's where your welfare is. Your good is in acting according to your nature. Paradharma Bhayavah -- others' Dharma may seem very noble, very excellent, but you cannot follow that because that's not your Dharma. Act according to your Dharma, and act for the greater good -- not just in a selfish manner for your own good, but in a way that helps the greater community. We called it Karma Yoga.

The art of acting in this world in a way that purifies my mind and intellect is called Karma Yoga. Then chapter four says, once you have learned how to act outside in this world, now you have to renounce these actions which you consider yours. Even while I'm practicing Karma Yoga, I still think "I'm practicing Karma Yoga." So there is still agency involved -- "I am doing it." The fourth chapter says you have to now renounce these actions in knowledge -- knowledge which you already learned in chapter two.

That is, the self which I consider the self is not the real self. What I consider the self is actually the equipment belonging to the self -- body, mind, and intellect. So in chapter four it says: learn this knowledge about the self and renounce these actions, understanding that these actions belong to the Prakriti, to this body, mind, and intellect -- they do not belong to me, the self. That's chapter four.

Chapter five -- we started seeing Karma Sannyasa. Now, how to really gain this Sannyasa which we talked about in chapter four?

So we have this detailed instruction about how to think, how to adjust our attitude towards actions. And the first thing it said is, think that you are not doing anything. And then it says, Brahmani Yadhaya, Karmani, Sangam, Tyaktva Karutiyah. The person who devote all his actions to the Brahman, that universal self, not just myself as the limited self, but I am doing it for that greater self. Then he does not incur any sin. He does not incur any negative impression on his mind.

Our problem is we take our actions so personally that somebody says, neel, you are not doing well. We get hurt right away. Right away it tells me that this person is not respecting me and it starts putting the negative impression. So the next time when I have to do that, I'll be thinking twice, should I be doing it? Will people appreciate it or will it not be appreciated? So that negative impression will not be on the mind of a person who is not doing it with this limited ego.

Because to him, action is an action, the result is a result. So he has no impression on his mind. So such a person will act in this world like a Padmapatra, the lotus leaf which remaining in the water coming out of the mud does not ever get tainted by any of that. Water falls on it, it rolls off. So that's the technique given to us in this chapter. In such a person who is constantly thinking about his self as the greater self will be liberated from these limitations.

And then we have seen: how will such a Yogi behave in this world once he gets to that level? Bahyasparseshu Asaktatma -- he is unattached to the contacts outside. Sa Brahma Yoga Yuktamatma Sukham Akshayam Ashnute -- we are constantly seeking unlimited happiness. We are not seeking limited happiness, though we think we are happy if we get some limited happiness.

Green card, Green card, Green card. Once I have it I won't ask for anything more. But I know the next thing I'll ask is -- now I got the green card, maybe I need to find the right person to get married. So people say take a vacation for three weeks from your job, go to India to find a bride. And they say, "Neel, I can't do it in three weeks because my parents have lined up so many girls to meet."

But I think I still need some more time. Can I get two more weeks of vacation? And then it continues. We are seeking unlimited happiness. And Bhagavan said there's only one formula that works. Sua Saktatma is unattached to the context outside in this world.

Sa Brahma Yogi Yuktatma -- such a person is a Yogi. He is one with the Brahman, connected with the Brahman. And all of this seems very difficult to practice. So the next verse says, remember -- what is there if I am going to avoid all these pleasures in my life? What is the fun of living life?

When I was a teenager, we used to have this joke: when you go up to Chitragupta, he will ask what you did with your life. So we have to justify -- if you didn't experience anything, what did you do? Go back, experience all that, and then come back. So we think, if I don't experience any pleasure in this world, what is there to live this life for? They say, well, you can experience all these pleasures.

Remember, Ye hi samsparshaja bhoga dukha yonaya -- these pleasures coming out of contact with the objects in the world outside have a limited capacity; they are actually a womb of unhappiness. So unless you are careful, you will realize that these pleasures are Adi and Antavanta -- they start at one point in time and will end. So you don't get Ramate, don't get engrossed in them. You experience the pleasure and move on.

It's not that it's a nice day, I'm saying no, I mean this is not good. I mean how can you have a nice day? How can I enjoy nice day? Gita tells me it's all Adiyanta Vanta. But when there's a nice day, enjoy it. But next day when there's not nice, don't complain.

That's all it says -- not that you are going to complain about why we don't have nice days, why he's not controlling the climate. We know this is the reality of life. The next three verses tell us why one should be detached from these contacts outside, and how. Shaknoteehaiva yaha sodhum prak shareera vimokshanaat, Kama krodh udbhavam vegam, sa yuktaha sa sukhi naraha.

The happy person definition is here. We are very happy, elated. I read on Facebook somewhere that may your life be as happy as it seems on Facebook. Because we know that that's not the reality, right? We are not putting all the garbage from our life on the Facebook. So Sukhi who is truly sukhi, not who appears to be happy.

We all appear to be happy from the other person's point of view. "Neel, you're doing very well." Only Neel knows how he is doing, right? Bhagavan said, Shaknoti hi evaha yaha sodhum prak shareera vimokshanath -- before this body disintegrates, who can withhold the vega, the power, the udbhavam, that force which is generated in my mind by Kama (desire) and Krodha (anger)?

It did not say you will not have Kama or Krodha. Vega is the operative word here. When it is flowing peacefully in a serene manner, it is the most enjoyable thing, right? People enjoy the river. Some of our friends have houses right on the river. And we all go in envy and say James river.

When a storm was predicted, people were preparing. But the James River, when it is flowing peacefully, there is no problem. It gives peace and happiness to anybody. Our mind is like the river. When it is flowing in a peaceful, serene manner, it takes you towards happiness. When do we think about inspired projects or inspired actions? When we feel happy. When we are calm and happy, then we say, let's do this.

When I am upset, no matter how good an idea is put in front of me, forget about it. So the mind has to be serene and flowing in an appropriate manner towards its goal. Then only can peace and happiness come. But when this uninvited guest -- the flood -- comes, it will be manifold, uncontrollable, and anything that comes in its way will be destroyed. Bhagavan said that Kama and Krodha, when that desire is so powerful that you are rushing towards the object of desire and whatever comes in your way you want to destroy --

That's anger. That Vega should be withheld. A person who can withhold the force of Kama and Krodha in his mind is Yukta -- he is the one who is connected with his own self. He will then be happy in all situations, because he has control over the flow of his thoughts. Mind, as we have learned in Tattva Bodhi, is nothing but the flow of thoughts.

One thought does not make a mind. The second thought creates the genesis of mind. Then more and more thoughts -- the second thought gives rise to the third, the fourth, and the fifth in the same direction. Thoughts flowing in one direction create a focused mind. As long as the mind is flowing toward the right destination in a disciplined manner, it creates happiness. When my desires are all over the place -- I want to be a billionaire, and then I also want to become a wise person, and then I also want to be a sports personality -- then I'm torn all over and creating disaster.

A person who develops this capacity before this body disintegrates -- because after that you don't really have any chance -- this is your chance to create discipline in your mind. Such a person is Sukhi Naraha. The verse says "Yo Antaha Sukho" -- one who finds happiness within.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 22 delivers a sobering truth about worldly pleasures: "The joys that spring from external associations bring pain; they have their beginning and their endings." This is not pessimism but precise observation - every contact-born pleasure is inherently temporary, carrying within it the seed of its own ending. Verse 23 then offers the practical challenge: master "the promptings of desire and anger" before death. Verse 24 reveals the reward: one who is "happy within his Self" and in whom "the inner light shines" attains "Eternal Bliss and becomes the Spirit Itself."

Today, observe the adi-antavanta (beginning-and-ending) nature of pleasures. When you enjoy your morning coffee, notice it begins, peaks, and ends. When a pleasant conversation lifts your mood, watch how the feeling fades. This is not to become joyless but to see clearly - as verse 22 says, "the wise man does not rejoice in them" because he knows their nature. The more profound practice from verse 23 is working with kama (desire) and krodha (anger). Notice that the verse says to "surmount" their "promptings" - not eliminate desire and anger, but master their vega (force). When desire arises today, can you feel its pull without being swept away? When anger flares, can you experience its heat without acting from it? This mastery, Krishna promises, leads to the state of verse 24: antah-sukha (inner happiness), antar-arama (inner rejoicing), and antar-jyoti (inner light). Even a glimpse of this inner fullness changes everything.

snippets.title: Day 78: True Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः |

कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम् |

स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः |
snippets.transliteration:
labhante brahmanirvāṇamṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇakalmaṣāḥ .

kāmakrodhaviyuktānāṃ yatīnāṃ yatacetasām .

sparśānkṛtvā bahirbāhyāṃścakṣuścaivāntare bhruvoḥ .
verseTranslations: Sages whose sins have been washed away, whose sense of separateness has vanished, who have subdued themselves, and seek only the welfare of all, come to the Eternal Spirit.
Saints who know their Selves, who control their minds, and feel neither desire nor anger, find Eternal Bliss everywhere.
Excluding external objects, his gaze fixed between the eyebrows, the inward and outward breathings passing equally through his nostrils;
snippets.commentary:
We are discussing chapter 5, Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation. Renunciation is always about anything that we think we are possessing -- in this case, our actions. We think our actions are our own, and therefore renouncing those actions is the renunciation. So far we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita who we are as limited beings. As we had discussed many times before, the first six chapters of Bhagavad Gita describe "tvam" in that Mahavakya "Tat Tvam Asi" -- "That Thou Art." "Thou," the "you," is what we have learned so far. In chapter one, we encountered the situation which we encounter in our daily life.

A common man facing day-to-day situations which never come clean-cut as black and white, good or bad, happy or unhappy. They always have complexity which makes me confused about what is right and wrong, which action to take. So we have seen Arjuna's situation. He cannot see whether there is good in fighting the battle or running away from it. Fighting the battle is going to create some collateral damage, as we have seen recently in Afghanistan. Some people who I really respect and revere may also get hurt or killed.

And that happens in our life all the time. So the first chapter describes our situation as we face it in life today. The second chapter told us that what we think we are is not who we are. So there is a paradigm shift for us. We consider this self to be this limited me -- this body, mind, and intellect. And at the end of my journey in this life, this self will be destroyed.

But the self that I truly am will never be destroyed. Death will be only for the body. So that's a paradigm shift for us. Now, understanding that still does not give me what to do next. So the third chapter gave us the instruction about how to work in this world in an efficient manner. Two things it told us.

One, it says Swadharma Nidhanam Shreya, Paradharma Bhayavah. Act according to your own nature, your own Prakriti, because that's where your welfare is. Your good is in acting according to your nature. Paradharma Bhayavah -- others' Dharma may seem very noble, very excellent, but you cannot follow that because that's not your Dharma. Act according to your Dharma, and act for the greater good -- not just in a selfish manner for your own good, but in a way that helps the greater community. We called it Karma Yoga.

The art of acting in this world in a way that purifies my mind and intellect is called Karma Yoga. Then chapter four says, once you have learned how to act outside in this world, now you have to renounce these actions which you consider yours. Even while I'm practicing Karma Yoga, I still think "I'm practicing Karma Yoga." So there is still agency involved -- "I am doing it." The fourth chapter says you have to now renounce these actions in knowledge -- knowledge which you already learned in chapter two.

That is, the self which I consider the self is not the real self. What I consider the self is actually the equipment belonging to the self -- body, mind, and intellect. So in chapter four it says: learn this knowledge about the self and renounce these actions, understanding that these actions belong to the Prakriti, to this body, mind, and intellect -- they do not belong to me, the self. That's chapter four.

Chapter five -- we started seeing Karma Sannyasa. Now, how to really gain this Sannyasa which we talked about in chapter four?

So we have this detailed instruction about how to think, how to adjust our attitude towards actions. And the first thing it said is, think that you are not doing anything. And then it says, Brahmani Yadhaya, Karmani, Sangam, Tyaktva Karutiyah. The person who devote all his actions to the Brahman, that universal self, not just myself as the limited self, but I am doing it for that greater self. Then he does not incur any sin. He does not incur any negative impression on his mind.

Our problem is we take our actions so personally that somebody says, neel, you are not doing well. We get hurt right away. Right away it tells me that this person is not respecting me and it starts putting the negative impression. So the next time when I have to do that, I'll be thinking twice, should I be doing it? Will people appreciate it or will it not be appreciated? So that negative impression will not be on the mind of a person who is not doing it with this limited ego.

Because to him, action is an action, the result is a result. So he has no impression on his mind. So such a person will act in this world like a Padmapatra, the lotus leaf which remaining in the water coming out of the mud does not ever get tainted by any of that. Water falls on it, it rolls off. So that's the technique given to us in this chapter. In such a person who is constantly thinking about his self as the greater self will be liberated from these limitations.

And then we have seen: how will such a Yogi behave in this world once he gets to that level? Bahyasparseshu Asaktatma -- he is unattached to the contacts outside. Sa Brahma Yoga Yuktamatma Sukham Akshayam Ashnute -- we are constantly seeking unlimited happiness. We are not seeking limited happiness, though we think we are happy if we get some limited happiness.

Green card, Green card, Green card. Once I have it I won't ask for anything more. But I know the next thing I'll ask is -- now I got the green card, maybe I need to find the right person to get married. So people say take a vacation for three weeks from your job, go to India to find a bride. And they say, "Neel, I can't do it in three weeks because my parents have lined up so many girls to meet."

But I think I still need some more time. Can I get two more weeks of vacation? And then it continues. We are seeking unlimited happiness. And Bhagavan said there's only one formula that works. Sua Saktatma is unattached to the context outside in this world.

Sa Brahma Yogi Yuktatma -- such a person is a Yogi. He is one with the Brahman, connected with the Brahman. And all of this seems very difficult to practice. So the next verse says, remember -- what is there if I am going to avoid all these pleasures in my life? What is the fun of living life?

When I was a teenager, we used to have this joke: when you go up to Chitragupta, he will ask what you did with your life. So we have to justify -- if you didn't experience anything, what did you do? Go back, experience all that, and then come back. So we think, if I don't experience any pleasure in this world, what is there to live this life for? They say, well, you can experience all these pleasures.

Remember, Ye hi samsparshaja bhoga dukha yonaya -- these pleasures coming out of contact with the objects in the world outside have a limited capacity; they are actually a womb of unhappiness. So unless you are careful, you will realize that these pleasures are Adi and Antavanta -- they start at one point in time and will end. So you don't get Ramate, don't get engrossed in them. You experience the pleasure and move on.

It's not that it's a nice day, I'm saying no, I mean this is not good. I mean how can you have a nice day? How can I enjoy nice day? Gita tells me it's all Adiyanta Vanta. But when there's a nice day, enjoy it. But next day when there's not nice, don't complain.

That's all it says -- not that you are going to complain about why we don't have nice days, why he's not controlling the climate. We know this is the reality of life. The next three verses tell us why one should be detached from these contacts outside, and how. Shaknoteehaiva yaha sodhum prak shareera vimokshanaat, Kama krodh udbhavam vegam, sa yuktaha sa sukhi naraha.

The happy person definition is here. We are very happy, elated. I read on Facebook somewhere that may your life be as happy as it seems on Facebook. Because we know that that's not the reality, right? We are not putting all the garbage from our life on the Facebook. So Sukhi who is truly sukhi, not who appears to be happy.

We all appear to be happy from the other person's point of view. "Neel, you're doing very well." Only Neel knows how he is doing, right? Bhagavan said, Shaknoti hi evaha yaha sodhum prak shareera vimokshanath -- before this body disintegrates, who can withhold the vega, the power, the udbhavam, that force which is generated in my mind by Kama (desire) and Krodha (anger)?

It did not say you will not have Kama or Krodha. Vega is the operative word here. When it is flowing peacefully in a serene manner, it is the most enjoyable thing, right? People enjoy the river. Some of our friends have houses right on the river. And we all go in envy and say James river.

When a storm was predicted, people were preparing. But the James River, when it is flowing peacefully, there is no problem. It gives peace and happiness to anybody. Our mind is like the river. When it is flowing in a peaceful, serene manner, it takes you towards happiness. When do we think about inspired projects or inspired actions? When we feel happy. When we are calm and happy, then we say, let's do this.

When I am upset, no matter how good an idea is put in front of me, forget about it. So the mind has to be serene and flowing in an appropriate manner towards its goal. Then only can peace and happiness come. But when this uninvited guest -- the flood -- comes, it will be manifold, uncontrollable, and anything that comes in its way will be destroyed. Bhagavan said that Kama and Krodha, when that desire is so powerful that you are rushing towards the object of desire and whatever comes in your way you want to destroy --

That's anger. That Vega should be withheld. A person who can withhold the force of Kama and Krodha in his mind is Yukta -- he is the one who is connected with his own self. He will then be happy in all situations, because he has control over the flow of his thoughts. Mind, as we have learned in Tattva Bodhi, is nothing but the flow of thoughts.

One thought does not make a mind. The second thought creates the genesis of mind. Then more and more thoughts -- the second thought gives rise to the third, the fourth, and the fifth in the same direction. Thoughts flowing in one direction create a focused mind. As long as the mind is flowing toward the right destination in a disciplined manner, it creates happiness. When my desires are all over the place -- I want to be a billionaire, and then I also want to become a wise person, and then I also want to be a sports personality -- then I'm torn all over and creating disaster.

A person who develops this capacity before this body disintegrates -- because after that you don't really have any chance -- this is your chance to create discipline in your mind. Such a person is Sukhi Naraha. The verse says "Yo Antaha Sukho" -- one who finds happiness within.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 25 lists the qualifications of those who attain Brahma-nirvana: "sins washed away, sense of separateness vanished, self subdued, and seeking only the welfare of all." Notice especially "chinna-dvaidha" - the cutting away of duality, the sense that I am separate from you and from the world. Verse 26 adds that for those free from desire and anger, "Eternal Bliss exists everywhere" - not just in meditation but in all directions. Verse 27 then begins the technical instruction for meditation: excluding external objects, fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, and equalizing the inward and outward breath.

Today, work with "sarva-bhuta-hite ratah" from verse 25 - being devoted to the welfare of all beings. This is not merely doing good deeds but a fundamental shift in orientation from self-centered to all-inclusive. Ask yourself: "How would I act differently if I truly felt the wellbeing of everyone around me as my own?" Let this inform your choices today. For a more contemplative practice, experiment with the technique in verse 27: sit quietly and bring awareness to the space between your eyebrows, the ajna chakra. Without straining the eyes, let attention rest there gently. Then notice your breath - can you make the inhalation and exhalation equal in duration and smooth in quality? This pranayama practice, equalizing prana and apana, naturally calms the mind. Even five minutes of this practice demonstrates verse 26's promise: when desire and anger subside, peace reveals itself as already present, surrounding us "abhitah" - on all sides.

snippets.title: Day 79: Action and Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः |

भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yatendriyamanobuddhirmunirmokṣaparāyaṇaḥ .

bhoktāraṃ yajñatapasāṃ sarvalokamaheśvaram .
verseTranslations: Governing sense, mind and intellect, intent on liberation, free from desire, fear and anger, the sage is forever free.
Knowing me as Him who gladly receives all offerings of austerity and sacrifice, as the Mighty Ruler of all the Worlds and the Friend of all beings, he passes to Eternal Peace."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 5, Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of True Renunciation of Actions. We are coming to the concluding part of chapter five -- the last three verses. We have seen previously that Bhagavan said the one who develops qualities appropriate to merge with Brahman, he merges with Brahman. Yah Antaha Sukhaha Antahramah Tatha Antah Jyotihi Evayaha, Sahayogi Brahmanirvanam, Brahma Bhutodi Gachade. These are the qualifications one must develop if he wants to attain that eternal liberation, to merge with the supreme Self.

If he wants to achieve the final goal of complete liberation, he needs to understand that this finite being is not capable of attaining that. He has to leave attachment to this finite being -- this body, mind, and intellect -- which is running outside seeking happiness. That idea, that happiness lies outside in the world, has to be renounced. And he has to develop qualities where he becomes satisfied within his own self. Yaha Antaha Sukhaha -- who finds his happiness within himself. Ya Antahramaha -- who revels in his own self. Antah Jyoti --

He reveals his own existence. I do not need anyone to convince me that I exist. Verification is required for everything else -- whether I'm smart, whether I'm powerful, whether I achieved anything, am I an architect or not. I need verification for all of that. But whether I exist? I need no verification.

I know the self -- it is self-emerging knowledge. One who relies on that, one who identifies with that -- Sahayogi Brahmanirvanam -- he loses his limited self. He loses his identity in that greater identity. As we have seen in our analogy, when a small company merges with a big company, the small company's name goes away and it becomes one with the larger company. Labhante Brahma Nirvanam, Rishayah Kshina Kalmashaha. But to achieve that, you have to become Kshina Kalma -- without any impurities of mind. Those who have purified themselves of all sins, they achieve this Brahma Nirvanam.

They dissolve themselves into Brahman. And we have seen that sin is nothing but the agitations in my mind. As long as I want something out of this world, it's a desire. And as long as I don't have it, I'm incomplete -- that creates agitation. If I acquire it, I want to preserve it.

That creates another agitation. I accomplished all that. I have this bank balance in my 401k. It seems I'm set for my retirement of what happens if the market collapses and I lose everything. So there's always fear of preserving what I have and also an anxiety about what I have not accomplished. One who is without this agitation in his mind, whose mind is purified, he attains that ultimate truth.

He becomes one with that supreme self. Chinna Dvaidha -- he does not see the duality. Up till now I have lived my life as an island. The world is outside, competing with me, and I have to get my happiness out of it. So I'm constantly in battle with this world as an individual. If that individuality is dissolved, if I expand my identification -- as we have seen before, right now my ego is concentrated in my limited self which I call myself.

If I can expand my ego to include others -- my identification. At a small level, we all do that. We identify with our family, we identify with our friends, our community, our nation. Therefore, when Brazil was not doing well with coronavirus, we were not that upset. But when India is not doing well --

We are all very disturbed. Because of identification. I have expanded my identification from just me to the country where I was born and raised, and also the country where I live. Chinna Dvaidha -- they have expanded their identification to include everything. Yatatmanaha -- one who has control over this limited self. Once I identify with the world, then my purpose becomes seeking the welfare of all beings.

So these are the qualifications of the person who wants to achieve liberation -- the Mumukshu, who is desirous of Moksha. One who is happy the way he is does not need anything to do with this. But one who is not happy with the condition he is in and wants that liberation -- for him, these are the qualifications he has to achieve, that he has to strive for.

And then the next three verses -- the last three verses -- are actually introductory verses for the next chapter. Swamiji explains that in Sanskrit literature it is very common for the author to introduce a subject at the end of a chapter so that you are ready for the next chapter. It's like in Gujarati magazines -- the story gets very interesting and then it ends and says the more interesting part will be in the next edition. Bhagavan is also using a similar technique. He's introducing meditation in these last three verses.

These verses are more like sutras, very succinct. The entire process of meditation and the goal is described. It says Sparshan krutva bahir bahyan, chakshushcha iva antare bhruvoh, prana-apanau samau krutva nasa-abhyantara charinau. Here, the entire technique of meditation is given. The first instruction is Sparshan krutva bahir bahyan -- keep all the sense objects outside, outside of your perception.

So don't let the senses bring the information from outside of the sense objects which then creates these impressions on your mind. You shut off that mechanism of bringing all those impressions from the outside. This is something like if you have an old style camera which has a Kodak film in it. If you open the shutter, whatever is inside the image will come inside to the lens. And then the film is like your mind. So the film will capture the impression on it.

So there are two ways you can avoid taking any picture. One is you don't open the lens at all. I have done it before -- forgot to remove the cap. I kept clicking but nothing appeared on the film because the lens was covered. Kathopanishad says you should fold your senses into the mind.

The senses are turned inward; they are not looking outwards. Then there is no experience from outside. Or keep the experience outside only -- don't let it influence your mind. And focus your gaze at the juncture of your eyebrows. Now that you have turned your gaze inside, you have to focus on your mind.

So now the mind is focused, laserized. There are good explanations about the scientific and medical implications of focusing between the eyes. But from a yogic perspective, we are focused on the Ajna chakra. In our bodies we have six chakras. In some traditions there is a seventh chakra, the Sahasrara chakra, also called Brahmarandra. That's your exit point when you die, if you are a Yogi.

Bhagavan says here, focus on your Ajna chakra. The Ajna chakra is also called the third eye. In our literature, Shiva had a third eye -- the eye of wisdom. This third eye or Ajna chakra is associated with the subtle body, the mind and intellect. So rather than focusing on the world outside, now you focus on the world inside -- on your mind and intellect -- and turn them towards this chakra, which is a connection between you and the supreme. Bhagavan said, Chakshushcha eva antare bruvaha.

Focus your attention between the two eyebrows, at the Ajna chakra. It also corresponds to the pineal gland in your physiology. That is why we have a bindi in our culture at that point, and why the Yogis put Chandan tilak to keep that Ajna chakra protected.

Prana Apanau Samau Krutva -- equalizing the prana and apana. We also learnt in chapter three, I think it was verse 29, which says they offer the Prana into Apana or Apana into Prana. One of the Yajnas is this Prana-Apana Yajna, which is basically Pranayama with retention and breath control.

The Rishis developed this great technique after noticing that the mind affects breathing. So if I use that knowledge -- that there is a connection between my mind and my breathing -- I can control breathing to control my mind. This whole elaborate science of Pranayama was developed based on this principle. So here it says, make Prana and Apana equal. When there is no imbalance between the two, the mind also becomes balanced and controlled.

I have read Dnyaneshwar Maharaj's Dnyaneshwari, and it explains this beautifully: combine the power of Prana and Apana together and direct it towards your Sahasrara Chakra. The energy which is right now used for maintaining this body gets equalized so that the body is maintained with very minimal energy, and the rest is focused towards your Sahasrara chakra. According to yogic tradition, we have a connection with our greater self through that chakra. So Bhagavan says, balance your Prana and Apana -- Nasabhyantara Charinau -- which flow through your nostrils.

Yat Indriyaha Manaha Buddhi Munihi Moksha Parayanaha. If you are desirous of liberation, if the goal is to achieve liberation, then you have to make this preparation throughout your life. It is not something where you get up one morning and start meditating. Bhagavan Buddha did not get up that morning under a Bodhi tree and say, "I need to meditate and achieve enlightenment." He had to work all his life to achieve that enlightenment. This is the practice that controls my organs, my senses, my Manas (mind), and my Buddhi (intellect).

This cannot happen overnight, as we know. It is also not going to happen just because you decided to do so. It's a constant practice without any gap. Eknathi Swaran used to say that if you miss a day in meditation, it takes a week to make up. If you miss a week of meditation, it takes a month to make it up. If you miss a month, it takes a year to make it up.

So it's a constant practice to control your organs, control your mind, control intellect. Now we are all doing it. So it's not something which is not in our control. We control over organs in a sense. We don't behave in an inappropriate manner in the public. We also control our mind.

Sometimes we feel like doing something, but we realize it's not the right thing to do. So we control our mind. We control intellect too. Sometimes we get fancy ideas, but then we think, no, that's not the right thing. We do have capabilities. Except our goal is different in using that capability.

We're trying to achieve something from this world. Here it says Moksha Parayanaha -- those who are Mumukshu, those who are desirous of liberation, they use this capability to control mind, intellect, and body in achieving that liberation. Vigata Icchha Bhaya Krodhaha -- this is only possible if you're without desire, fear, and anger. We know that our life is basically nothing but a permutation and combination of these three. Either we are desirous of getting something, or we are fearful that we may not get it, or we are angry.

That's because my mind is right now turned outside, seeking happiness. If I realize that happiness does not lie outside -- the world of objects has no capability to give me happiness. As we have seen, every object which gives me happiness has equal capability to give me unhappiness. If that's true, they actually cancel each other out. It is like particles which have a negative and positive charge -- they cancel each other out and disappear.

These objects are illusory. They do not have the essential thing which I am seeking -- happiness.
snippets.reflection:
The final two verses of Chapter 5 bring the teaching to its culmination. Verse 28 describes the sage who is "governing sense, mind and intellect" and is "free from desire, fear and anger" - such a one is "forever free." Verse 29 then reveals the key to eternal peace: knowing the Divine as the receiver of all sacrifices and austerities, as the "Mighty Ruler of all the Worlds," and most beautifully, as "the Friend of all beings" (suhridam sarva-bhutanam). This friendship of the Divine is not a sentimental notion but a recognition that the deepest reality is not indifferent to us but intimately connected.

Today, contemplate the three aspects of the Divine in verse 29. First, "bhoktaram yajna-tapasam" - the Divine receives all our efforts, sacrifices, and disciplines. Nothing is wasted; every sincere effort is received. Can you offer your day's work with this understanding? Second, "sarva-loka-maheshvaram" - the Divine is the sovereign of all worlds. This removes the burden of trying to control outcomes. Third, and most transformative, "suhridam sarva-bhutanam" - the Divine is the friend of all beings, including you. Meditate on this: the ultimate Reality is not a cold, impersonal force but a presence that wishes you well. How would you live differently if you truly felt befriended by existence itself? The chapter concludes with the promise: knowing this, one "passes to Eternal Peace." Today, let this friendship be your foundation - approach each moment knowing you are supported by the deepest reality, that the universe is not hostile but hospitable to your awakening.

snippets.title: Day 80: The Practice of Yoga
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव |

आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

yaṃ saṃnyāsamiti prāhuryogaṃ taṃ viddhi pāṇḍava .

ārurukṣormuneryogaṃ karma kāraṇamucyate .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: He who acts because it is his duty, not thinking of the consequences, is really spiritual and a true ascetic; and not he who merely observes rituals or who shuns all action.
O Arjuna! Renunciation is in fact what is called Right Action. No one can become spiritual who has not renounced all desire.
For the sage who seeks the heights of spiritual meditation, practice is the only method, and when he has attained them, he must maintain himself there by continual self-control.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter five. Now we'll be discussing chapter six. Swami Chinmayananda says meditation is not a verb, it's a noun. It is a state to be achieved, not something you do. What you do is actually called contemplation. So what we have seen in Bhagavad Gita so far is the conclusion of the first set of chapters, and we are coming to this culminating chapter, Dhyana Yoga, which will indicate the state we have to achieve.

So we have discussed many times that Bhagavad Gita is divided into three distinct sections, each having six chapters. According to Anandagiri, who was a 13th century head of Dwarka Mutt, Bhagavad Gita is an exposition on the Mahavakya Tattvamasi. The Mahavakya is a statement which connects the lower to the higher, the jiva to the Paramatma. Tattvamasi is a Mahavakya from the Chandogya Upanishad. Bhagavan Ved Vyas wrote Bhagavad Gita. Then Bhagavan Sankaracharya wrote a Bhasya on Bhagavad Gita, and then Anandagiri wrote a Tika on Sankaracharya's Bhasya. There he says this Bhagavad Gita is an exposition on Tattvamasi -- "that thou art." There are other opinions about what Bhagavad Gita is and how it is divided. Madhusuddhan Saraswati, a late 16th / early 17th century Advaitic scholar, said that Bhagavad Gita is divided into three parts: Karma Yoga in the first six chapters, Bhakti Yoga in chapters seven through twelve, and Gnana Yoga in chapters thirteen through eighteen. Swamiji also points out that there are others who believe the first six chapters relate to the Karmakanda in the Vedas.

The next set of six chapters relates to the Upasanakanda, and the last six chapters relate to the Gnanakanda. However, Bhagavan Sankaracharya does not make any such distinction in his Bhasya. He simply says the spiritual evolution described in Bhagavad Gita follows a progression. First, you act in this world with hankering for the fruits -- you are working with expectations.

So in the first stage -- Hato va prapsyasi swargam, jitva va bhokshyase mahim -- what do you have to lose in performing any action? You shall achieve either heaven if you die, or the kingdom on this earth if you don't. When you're expecting a result, that's your motivation. The second stage is to act without any hankering for the fruits of action, which we have seen as Karma Yoga. And then the third stage in the spiritual evolution is the integration of the mind with Upasana.

The last stage, he says, is realization -- acquiring the knowledge. So far, what we have seen is this: in chapter one, we have seen the confusion of an ordinary person of this world, which we all are. We want to act in this world and get the right results, but we do not know what actions are right. That's our confusion. Arjuna Vishada Yoga explained that through Arjuna's condition. Chapter two gave us the philosophical perfection of the Upanishads.

The highest knowledge of the Upanishads was given out right away as the goal. Bhagavan Krishna didn't expect Arjuna to understand immediately, but he presented that knowledge of perfection -- that this self is immutable, imperishable. At the end of the chapter, we also saw the characteristics of a man of perfection, a wise person: how would he act in this world? Once you achieve the state of perfect wisdom, you will have a balanced mind. Then chapter three gave us the path of Karma Yoga, the method of self-integration of our mind and intellect.

That's the second stage. First you act with the desire for the fruits. Then you act without desire or expectation for the fruit. So that's chapter three. And chapter four actually gives the various means, Bahiranga, Sadhana, the external aids, how to perform Karma Yoga. So we have seen many Yajnas in chapter four.

Then chapter five gave us a technique. Even while working in this world without any expectations, there will be some impact on your mind. To avoid that, chapter five gives you the path of Renunciation: you give up the sense of agency for your actions while performing actions selflessly. You must also renounce your sense of doership. That's what we saw in chapter five. Renouncing the sense of agency is Sannyasa Yoga, the Yoga of Renunciation.

And now all that knowledge, if you have been practicing diligently, then Bhagavan said, you are ready for Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. Swamiji says it's a yoga of contemplation. Meditation is a state to reach. Contemplation is way to achieve that. So that is Dhyana Yoga. So you have to prepare yourself with Karma Yoga to get to Dhyana Yoga.

So the chapter literally opens with that statement. Anashritah Karmaphalam karyam karma karoti yah -- one who performs actions without depending on the fruits of actions. Sa sannyasi cha yogi cha, na niragnir na chakriyah -- such a person is a sannyasi and a yogi. Bhagavan is now relating both yoga (which can be viewed as Karma Yoga) and sannyas as one and the same.

The ultimate result is one and the same as long as you perform Karma Yoga without any expectation for the fruits. This is basically clarification. Because we carry baggage of our culture. We see sannyasi as somebody who has given up all activities, one who is completely inactive from a society's perspective. He does not have a job, he does not have a family, he has no relationship, he has given up everything. Sannyasi is the one who renounced everything.

All means of making a living, all possessions, all relationships, including possession of his body. When somebody takes sannyas, he actually performs his own last rites. He then wears the saffron robe. He's not doing anything. But Bhagavan said, outwardly that person may have taken sannyas, but if he has not given up the fruits of actions, then he's not a sannyasi. Akriyah -- he seems inactive, but that does not mean he is a sannyasi. Niragnir means one who does not have fire. This fire comes from our Vedic culture where every householder will have a fire in his house. Because fire is necessary for your day to day cooking, but also for the religious rites. All the religious practices or upasanas were done through fire, yagnas, homas. So they used to continually keep fire in the house because they didn't have this instant matches or lighters. So they'll keep a fire burning in the house so that when they need fire, they can use that to light bigger fire. So person who is a householder will always have fire in his house.

The sannyasi gives up that responsibility of carrying fire. He doesn't need to cook anymore, nor is he performing any religious rites or traditional pujas. Bhagavan clarifies this: a person may have given up the grihastha ashram.

But if he is not at that mental level, then he is not a sannyasi. If he has not renounced his sense of agency and the fruits of actions, then he is not a sannyasi. The clarification is that sannyasa is a state of mind -- a state of renouncing the sense of agency. The one who is a yogi is also a sannyasi; the sannyasi is also a yogi. In the next verse, Bhagavan says: Yam sannyasam iti prahuh yogam tam viddhi Pandava -- O Pandava, that which is said to be sannyasa.

Sannyasa is renouncing the sense of agency. Prahuh yogam tam viddhi Pandava -- so that sannyasa is also yoga. Because without becoming a yogi, one cannot become a sannyasi. Na hi asannyasta sankalpah yogi bhavati kashchana -- without renouncing Sankalpa, one cannot become a yogi. Sankalpa, Swamiji says, is a difficult word to translate in English.

But expectations -- na hi asannyasta sankalpah yogi bhavati kashchana. One who has not given up expectations cannot become a yogi. One who has not given up the fancies of the mind cannot become a yogi. Swamiji elaborates on what Sankalpa is. It is confusing for us because in our culture, in our vernacular languages, in our religious practices, you always do Sankalpa before you start any puja. Panditji will say, "do Sankalpa."

So Sankalpa also means termination, taking a vow. When I decide that this action, I'm doing it for this reason, that's a sankalpa. I'm going to be regular in my exercise every day. I'll go for a walk every day as we do on a. I guess a New Year's Eve, a resolution. Because you have a goal in mind, you have a result in mind. But Bhagavan says that this Sankalpa should be given up if you want to become a yogi.

Because Sankalpa is directed toward a future result, which is exactly contrary to Karma Yoga. Karma Yoga is not to expect any results. Sankalpa is to expect a result in the future and then work towards it -- there is nothing wrong in it. But the human mind is such that Sankalpa does not remain constant. We all know that every resolution we make on New Year's Eve, by the time that month is over, we have forgotten about it and moved on to some other Sankalpa. The nature of our mind is to make a Sankalpa for the future.

But the action can always be performed in present. And before we start that action in present, we move on to the next Sankalpa. We want to do something else. So we never reach a goal. Because the goal is constantly a moving target that the fancy of our mind. So to stop that one has to give up Sankalpa.

One has to learn how to give up this fancy of a mind. And I heard that you have to learn how to give up Sankalpa to get Sankalpa Siddhi. Sankalpa Siddhi means you're determined to get something, you work towards it, and you get it. So if you make a Sankalpa for something unattainable -- like Moksha, liberation -- then first you have to learn how to give up the other fancies of your mind. Give up all the other fleeting Sankalpas and just work toward that one Sankalpa of liberation. Then you can reach that. So learn how to give up minor Sankalpas so you can achieve Sankalpa Siddhi for the ultimate goal. Bhagavan here says that no one can become a yogi who has not given up Sankalpa. He is already a renouncer.

He has given up Sankalpa. He is a sannyasi and therefore he is a yogi. So yogi and sannyasi are one and the same. Then the Gita tells us who should practice what -- who is capable of inactivity and who should perform actions. We have already seen that inactivity is not an option for us. It's not possible for any living being to be inactive.

But inactivity is the goal. We want Nishkarma Siddhi -- we want to retire from our day-to-day pursuits. So he says: Arurukshoh muner yogam karma karanam uchyate -- Karma is the means for a seeker, a muni who wants to ascend to yoga, who wants to become a yogi but is not a yogi yet. The one who has control over his mind is a yogi.

For one who wants to control his mind but whose mind is not yet in control, Karma is prescribed. Remember, we have started a chapter called Dhyana Yoga. So we expected that Bhagavan would just talk about Dhyana -- how to meditate, what to do. We thought we were done with Karma Yoga.

Now let's focus on Dhyana Yoga. But Bhagavan really puts Karma Yoga at the highest level here and say unless you have practiced Karma Yoga and achieved the results of the Karma Yoga which is the control of the mind, purification of the mind, the next step is not really for you.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses of Dhyana Yoga reveal a profound truth: true renunciation is not about giving up external activities, but about releasing our grip on expected outcomes. As Krishna declares, "Anashritah karmaphalam karyam karma karoti yah" - one who performs obligatory actions without depending on the fruits is both a sannyasi and a yogi. This challenges our conventional understanding of spiritual practice. We often believe we must retreat from life to find inner peace, but the Gita insists that real yoga happens in the midst of action, when we learn to work without the anxiety of results.

Consider your own relationship with Sankalpa - those overarching desires and resolutions that constantly shift and change in your mind. How many New Year's resolutions have faded by February? The teaching here is not to eliminate all goals, but to recognize when your fanciful mind is creating endless moving targets that keep you perpetually chasing rather than arriving. Today, examine one activity you perform regularly. Can you do it with full attention and care, yet without mentally leaping ahead to what you hope to gain from it? Notice how giving up expectation paradoxically brings more peace to the action itself.

Ask yourself: Am I still climbing the ladder of yoga (arurukshu), requiring the discipline of Karma Yoga? Or have I reached a place of inner stillness (yoga-rudha) where the mind naturally rests? Be honest - most of us are still climbing, and that is exactly where we should be applying selfless action as our practice.

snippets.title: Day 81: Meditation
snippets.sanskrit:
यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते |

उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् |

बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः |
snippets.transliteration:
yadā hi nendriyārtheṣu na karmasvanuṣajjate .

uddharedātmanātmānaṃ nātmānamavasādayet .

bandhurātmātmanastasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ .
verseTranslations: When a man renounces even the thought of initiating action, when he is not interested in sense objects or any results which may flow from his acts, then in truth he understands spirituality.
Let him seek liberation by the help of his Highest Self, and let him never disgrace his own Self. For that Self is his only friend; yet it may also be his enemy.
To him who has conquered his lower nature by Its help, the Self is a friend, but to him who has not done so, It is an enemy.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Contemplation and Meditation. In the first five chapters, we have seen that Bhagavan defined the word Yoga. In chapter two, Bhagavan defined Yoga: Samatvam Yoga Uchyate -- Yoga is the balance of mind. And then he said, Yogah karmasu kaushalam -- Yoga is dexterity in action. That was given as the goal.

Yoga is to balance your mind. Your mind should be balanced in all situations, and that's your goal. Then the next three chapters -- 3, 4, and 5 -- give two techniques to achieve that yoga of balancing the mind. The first is Karma Yoga: do not depend on the Karma Phala. Giving up expectations for results is the technique we call Karma Yoga. The other technique is giving up the sense of agency, which is called sannyasa.

These two techniques represent two different modes. One promotes actions, but without any expectation of the fruits. The other promotes inaction -- giving up the sense of agency is giving up actions. "I am not doing anything." So for an average person, it may seem contradictory.

One promotes actions, the other promotes inaction. Also, culturally we have seen that a Karma Yogi is engaged in actions, while a sannyasi has given up all actions. He gives up his job, he gives up his family. Even in olden days, a grihastha was required to perform certain rituals daily. As we have seen, he keeps fire burning in his house all the time because he needs it for performing the rituals. But once he becomes a sannyasi, he is not required to perform any of those actions.

So in the narrow sense, the Karma Kanda says that a grihastha is required to perform ritualistic actions and a sannyasi is not. We have seen these two opposite sides of the same coin, seemingly contrary to each other. That can create confusion in our mind: is the tyagi or yogi better, or is the sannyasi better? Therefore the chapter opened with a clear declaration from Bhagavan: Anashritah karmaphalam karyam karma karoti yah -- sa sannyasi cha yogi cha. Bhagavan once again extols Karma Yoga as the very means of achieving this balance of mind.

One who performs actions without depending on the fruits of action is both a yogi and a sannyasi, because sannyasa cannot be achieved -- nor can yoga be achieved -- by merely renouncing actions. Both achieve the same goal of samatvam, the balance of mind which we are looking for. Therefore: Yam sannyasam iti prahuh yogam tam viddhi Pandava -- know that sannyasa is the same thing as what they call Yoga. One who has not given up Sankalpa cannot become a yogi. But depending on your progress in the evolutionary process of reaching from the lower to the higher, you can choose one or the other.

So in the third verse we have seen: Arurukshoh muner yogam karma karanam uchyate. If you're still not there, if you're not established in Yoga, then Karma is the means. If I can't balance my mind, I know that I can lose balance when a situation occurs which is not conducive. When things are going well, I act very rationally.

It's only when things are not going right that I become irrational. The irrationality, Bhagavan says, shows that you have no control over your mind. The situation is affecting you, and you blame the situation. But the root cause is that you have no control over your mind. The mind is taking away the peace in your inner self. Therefore Bhagavan says, keep doing actions without expectations.

That's your exercise. Continue working on that. Yogarudhasya tasyaiva shamah karanam uchyate -- but one who has balanced his mind, one who has achieved the state of yoga, for him shamah (quiescence of mind) is the means. The mind has no desire, no thoughts of achieving something. He doesn't become thoughtless, but he does not have any goal of achieving something he does not have, because he feels complete.

All our plans for achieving things are because we feel incomplete. Without my car, I'm incomplete. So the things that make me feel incomplete, I try to acquire from the outside world. When you feel incomplete and you have to get something out of this world -- that's the power of Sankalpa. In your mind you create a situation.

You really create a scenario that if I have this then I will feel complete. If I come here on any kind of student visa or H1 visa only if I can get green card then everything will be solved. Once I get green card, things will be perfectly fine. That becomes a Sankalpa, an overarching desire. Now, who is considered to be Yogarudha? One who has balanced his mind, who now has control over his mind. Here is the litmus test: not getting attached to sense objects does not mean I do not use sense objects.

But I use them for utility. I feel thirsty and I drink water. I feel hungry and I eat food. But I don't get attached to them. And I have to have this amras every day. That's an attachment.

Enjoying mango juice is not a problem. Getting attached to the taste is the problem. So Bhagavan said, one who doesn't get attached to sense objects -- he uses them for whatever utility they provide for maintaining his life, but doesn't get attached to them. If they are not there tomorrow, he will still be the same person. This part is even more difficult.

We can probably get detached from sense objects, but getting detached from my own actions is harder. Therefore we have discussed many times before: retiring is not that easy. Giving up something which I've been doing all my life is difficult. I know it very well because I'm not retired yet. It's very difficult to give up actions which you are performing and getting used to them.

Those actions define myself. The first thing that comes out of your mouth: "I'm an architect" -- because that defines who you are. That's your profession. "Oh, I'm a son of such and such." Well, that's your relationship. We continue this inquiry of defining ourselves, and we miserably fail in the end, because everything we use to define ourselves is some kind of relationship, some acquisition, some position -- but not really who you are. That Bhagavan says is attachment to your actions. You call yourself an architect because you're attached to your profession. You call yourself a father because you're attached to your relationship with your. Those attachments are to my actions, not to the sense objects. I'm not attached to my son.

I'm attached to my actions, my profession. That's attachment to action. But someone who has given up that attachment -- that does not mean he does not have relationships or doesn't work. He considers that as part of this world where he has to function. Sarvasankalpa Sannyasi.

These words come time and again, and therefore we obviously have to understand them as thoroughly as we can. The word Sankalpa comes in our culture all the time. As we discussed last time, when you go to do puja, Panditji will ask you to make Sankalpa -- "this puja, I'm doing it for such and such." The Sankalpa is Samyak Kalpana.

The word samyak literally means overarching, encompassing everything. That is Samyak Kalpana. When there is an overarching desire in my mind -- "I want to get this" -- that's Sankalpa. It is a firm determination that my happiness lies there and I must get it. So Panditji says, when you are doing a puja, you must do Sankalpa, Samyak Kalpana: "By doing this puja, I shall get this." Our mind does that Sankalpa all the time.

The only problem is it continues to change. Bhagavan said this mind has the capacity to jump from one Sankalpa to another, and that creates a variety of desires. In the Mahabharata, there's a statement which says: Kamah, janami te mulam -- "O desire, I know your roots. Your roots are Sankalpa. I know that you are born out of Sankalpa," the desire which is defining me.

The Upanishad also says the self is nothing but the identification with desire which I consider to be me. The Mahabharata says: "O desire, you are born from Sankalpa. Therefore I will never think about you, and you will be destroyed along with your own roots." If I don't have Sankalpa, I don't give rise to desire.

Then there won't be any desire. And I can kill the desire. Sarva Sankalpa sanyasi. Therefore, the word Sarva Sankalpa is constantly changing. We constantly change our overarching desire. Today this is what I want to achieve, and then tomorrow it changes.

Unless we curb that urge to create new Sankalpas, I cannot become a sannyasi. So he said, Sarva Sankalpa Sannyasi -- one who has given up all Sankalpas. Yogarudha ta duchyate -- that person is considered established in Yoga. If I feel complete, I will not have a desire to achieve anything overarchingly. I will have needs and I'll fulfill my needs.

I need water because I'm thirsty. I need food because I'm hungry. I need a job because I need to make a living. Those are normal things we do. But when there is a Sankalpa -- "this is what I need to get so that I feel happy" -- Bhagavan says that one who gives up that sense of Sankalpa becomes Yogarudha.

If you find yourself in that situation where you have no desire to achieve anything, Bhagavan said you are Yogarudha at that point. Shamah karanam uchyate -- for such a person, inactivity is the means. In fact, from the scriptural point of view, the time comes when you have to stop your activity. Swamiji says here it is a sin not to act when you are required to act, but it is also equally dangerous if you continue acting when you're not required to act.

And therefore we used to have those ashrams: Brahmacharyashram, Grihasthashram, Vanaprasthashram, Sannyasashram. You have to reach a point in your life where inactivity is your goal, and then start working not for the self but on the self. Uddharet atmanatmanam na atmanam avasadayet. It seems like there are two "me."

One is the "watching me" and one is the "working me." The watching me is constantly deciding what needs to be done. It is what we call our own conscience -- we feel this is right. But then my pragmatic thought says, "No, that may not be very useful, so let's go and do that instead." This watching me is my higher self.

Consider that which has a clear vision of what is right and what is wrong, constantly watching me. "I think I should have a cup of tea." There are two "I"s -- one who thinks, one who wants the cup of tea. This watching me is the one who can guide you. And Bhagavan said, Uddharet atmanatmanam -- let your lower self

-- the working me -- be raised out of this sansar, this jagat which is constantly changing. Raise that lower, working self by the help of the watching self. Then my own conscience can help me get out of the sorrows of day-to-day life, if I become friends with it, if I listen to that voice. Na atmanam avasadayet -- don't let this working me drown in this world of sorrows and day-to-day rut. Atmaiva hi atmano bandhuh -- that watching me can be my friend, if I allow it to be my friend.
snippets.reflection:
"Uddhared atmanatmanam" - lift yourself by your own self. This powerful instruction from verse 5 reveals that within you exists both the problem and the solution. There is a "working self" caught in day-to-day struggles, and a "watching self" that observes with clarity and wisdom. That inner voice of conscience, so often drowned out by the noise of desires and fears, is your higher self ready to guide you upward. The question is: which self are you listening to?

The teaching about the self being both friend and enemy is startlingly practical. When you have mastery over your senses and mind, the same higher self that could drag you into deeper confusion becomes your greatest ally, empowering every positive step. But when you lose control - when "I want that coffee right now" overrides your better judgment - that same powerful self enables your downfall. It is like the fuel in a car: in a controlled vehicle, it takes you where you want to go; in an out-of-control vehicle, it powers the crash.

Today, practice noticing the two selves in operation. When a strong desire arises - for food, for approval, for a purchase - pause and observe. Is this the restless lower self demanding satisfaction, or a genuine need? Then consciously invoke the watching self: "What would my wisest self advise here?" This simple practice of self-observation, done repeatedly throughout the day, is the beginning of making the higher self your friend.

snippets.title: Day 82: The Restless Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः |

ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः |

सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु |
snippets.transliteration:
jitātmanaḥ praśāntasya paramātmā samāhitaḥ .

jñānavijñānatṛptātmā kūṭastho vijitendriyaḥ .

suhṛnmitrāryudāsīnamadhyasthadveṣyabandhuṣu .
verseTranslations: The Self of him who is self-controlled, and has attained peace is equally unmoved by heat or cold, pleasure or pain, honour or dishonour.
He who desires nothing but wisdom and spiritual insight, who has conquered his senses and who looks with the same eye upon a lump of earth, a stone or fine gold, is a real saint.
He looks impartially on all - lover, friend or foe; indifferent or hostile; alien or relative; virtuous or sinful.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions on how to live. We experience life's vicissitudes without a so-called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. So last time we have seen that the advice from Bhagavad Gita is: raise yourself by the self, don't let the self fall. We all really know in life that the only one who can truly help oneself is one's own self.

Only my own efforts will raise me out of the situation I'm in. But the connotation here is: raise your lower self by the higher self. The self in me which remains constant throughout all these changes of birth and death -- as we have seen in chapter two -- is imperishable, immutable, untaintable. Let that self raise your lower self, which is suffering right now by its own limitations. I can't stand limitations because my true nature is limitless. So the only thing I can do is let my higher self raise my lower self to the same level. Raise yourself by yourself.

Don't let yourself fall. Don't let your lower self go even further down. And that's because it says the higher self is a friend of the lower self. When this lower self is conquered by the higher self, when the lower self starts identifying with the higher self, recognizing its existence, there is something beyond my this day to day life which I live. There is something beyond the life which I consider started at my birth and will end at my death. When I start recognizing this and make that higher self a friend of this lower self, I'll be able to pull the lower self out of its present state of misery.

But it said the same self, higher self, can be the enemy of the lower self. If my ego fails to recognize that there is something beyond my this limited self, then the same higher self will act as if it's enemy because it will let you go down further and further into this misery. By empowering you to do the wrong thing. Higher self will empower you to do whatever you wish you to do. If the ego goes down into the lower and lower plane of existence, it will be empowered by the same higher self. Just as a car out of control is empowered by the same gas which is in the tank which was making it go straight on the road in a controlled fashion.

The same gas will power a disastrous wreck. So the advice was clearly: raise yourself by the self. But to do that, you have to have certain qualifications. You have to make efforts to raise your lower self to a worthiness where it can start working with the higher self, start identifying with the higher self. The verses which we discussed -- 7, 8, and 9 -- describe the state of Yogarudha.

One who has become master of his lower self is Yogarudha. We have seen two stages: Arurukshu and Yogarudha. For someone who is desirous to gain control over his mind, body, and intellect, the advice was karma karanam uchyate -- keep working in this world with selfless motivation and you will achieve that.

But once you reach that state where you have that control, then shamah karanam uchyate -- at that point, contemplation and meditation become the means to reach the higher level, to achieve the goal of eternal happiness. We want to get out of the limitations. I want to be happy all the time. Bhagavan said it is absolutely possible, but only when you identify with the higher, not the lower. You are the manifestation of the higher.

But my identification right now is with the lower. As long as I don't identify with the lower, its limitations cannot affect me. It is like when you go to the science museum or some place where there is funny mirror are there. I stand in front of it and I look like I have bloated 10 times than what I am today. Well, as long as I don't identify that image in the mirror, I am fine. Everybody goes in a funny mirror and laugh at it.

Because they are not identifying with the image they see in the mirror. They clearly identify with the self standing in front of the mirror. That's why they can laugh at it. But anyone who identifies with that distorted reflection cannot laugh. Our situation, Bhagavan says, like we are looking at ourselves in this funny mirror and looking at this miserable self. And now we are in misery.

But one who identifies with the real self standing in front of the mirror -- the higher self which makes this lower self possible -- is without any miseries. So the one who has achieved that sense of balance over himself has now become Yogarudha. What will he gain? That is what we learned.
