In the last three verses it says: Jitatmanah prashantasya paramatma samahitah, shitoshna sukha duhkheshu tatha mana apamana yoh. Where do our problems lie? In the three levels we have seen here.

Physical condition is not comfortable -- the room is too hot or too cold. At the body level, I can be uncomfortable. At a mental level, I feel this is a good time or I don't have a good time -- things are not working out for me. Then there is mana apamana yoh -- honor and dishonor. Intellectually, I feel that people are respecting me.

I have achieved something -- or dishonor, they're not respecting me. All these are causes for pleasure and pain in life. But one who has achieved that Yogarudha state -- one who has recognized the existence of the higher self in him and started aligning himself with it -- for him, Prashantasya Paramatma: his self remains equanimous in all situations because he is not identifying with them. We wrongly understand that one who has achieved this state will not turn on the thermostat, because "so what if it is uncomfortable."

Well, that's sheer foolishness. If I have the facility to adjust the temperature to my level of comfort, then I should do it. People used to ask Swami Chinmayananda all the time: "Swamiji, you talk about all this detachment, but when you come, people pick you up in Lexus and BMWs and Jaguars. Why don't you go with somebody who has a broken car?" Swamiji says, "My friend, I'm a swami. That doesn't mean I'm completely stupid."

As long as there is a more reliable and comfortable vehicle available, why should I choose one which is completely unreliable and uncomfortable? That's a common sense. It has nothing to do with attachment or detachment. So we wrongly perceive that the person who has achieved this state has to suffer, that only then is he considered a true yogi. But the teaching simply says the self in him, the higher self, is prasantasya -- always at equanimity.

It is not disturbed by outside happenings. Whatever is happening at the body level, I see clearly that it is happening at the body level and let the body deal with it at its own capacity. Whatever is happening at the mental level, I see clearly and let the mind deal with it. Whatever happens at the intellectual level, let my intellect deal with it at its own capacity. But I, the self -- the core of my being -- never get shaken by these happenings in this world.

That's why I always say there are no riots when it's 102 degrees outside in Richmond. We didn't have people throwing stones at Richmond City Hall. When the temperature hit 102 degrees, we expected that this can happen in summer. Deal with it with the best situation we can create. So we all turned down our thermostat and let the air condition run as best as it can. But we didn't get upset, we didn't have anything to complain to because we knew that it is something beyond my control.

When a yogi becomes one with his higher self he sees all the occurring at the mental level, the physical level and the intellectual level occurring at the lower level of existence. But higher self is not involved and does not get attached to it. It's not affected by any of this thing. So that's his fulfillment. Having become Yogarudha, he is no longer disturbed by small things which used to disturb him before. Previously, when it was hot, we complained all over the place. Whenever things were not conducive, we complained. Now I can take it as it is and look at it as a transitory phase happening in my life, in my existence, and not get disturbed by it. The next verse says: Gnana vignana truptatma kutasthah vijitendriyah, yukta iti uchyate yogi sama loshta ashma kanchanah. This is the verse I never understood when I was growing up. I have been learning Bhagavad Gita since I was about 18 years old, and I would think: what is my attitude in life if I become sama loshta ashma kanchanah -- equanimous toward a lump of clay, iron, and gold?

Well, that means I have lost all kind of judgment in life! But it really doesn't say that. In your day-to-day transactions in this world, you do make differentiation between the usefulness or value of one thing or another. But it does tell me that one who has achieved understanding, one who has the knowledge -- Gnana -- one who has learned from others, from books, from teachers, from listening, has received the knowledge. But that knowledge remains bookish until I apply it and make it my own. That becomes Vignana.

That's what science labs are for. You learn in the classroom that H2O is water. Then you go to the lab and make it on your own with two molecules of hydrogen and one of oxygen, and say, "That's water!" Now I'm absolutely convinced. That's now my wisdom.

Vignana visishtagnana. That only comes with self experience. Experimenting what I have learned in my own life, I get wisdom. That's why I didn't understand when I was 18. Now at 62, it is very clear, okay? Because I have gone through the experimentation of it in life.

So it says Gnana Vignana Truptatma Kutastha. Kutastha, I think, comes from the anvil in the smithy shop. The blacksmith is hammering something on that anvil -- both are made of iron. But the one changes its shape while the anvil remains the same. So Kutastha means one who remains unshaken by whatever is happening.

One who has control over his senses -- Yukta iti uchyate -- such a person is called fulfilled, harmonized, one who has achieved the sense of his self. Sama loshta ashma kanchanah -- he sees the lump of clay, the iron, and the gold as the same. He sees each at its original value.

What is the value of gold? What is the value of my house? Well, we put this place for lease or sell or whatever. So what is the value? Well, I may want anything I want.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the remarkable equanimity of one who has conquered the self: unmoved by heat or cold, pleasure or pain, honor or dishonor. But as Swamiji wisely clarifies, this does not mean the yogi refuses to adjust the thermostat or chooses discomfort when comfort is available. The point is not to suffer needlessly, but to ensure that the core of your being - your inner peace - is not disturbed by external fluctuations. When it is 102 degrees outside, you may feel the heat, but you need not lose your mental equilibrium over it.

The phrase "sama-loshta-ashma-kanchanah" - seeing equally a lump of clay, a stone, and gold - puzzled many seekers in their youth. Does wisdom mean losing all discrimination? Not at all. In practical transactions, gold is still more valuable than clay. But the wise person recognizes that the value is assigned, not inherent. Gold cannot give you lasting happiness any more than clay can. This understanding frees you from the tyranny of constantly chasing "more valuable" objects, believing they hold the key to your fulfillment.

Reflect today on three categories of disturbance in your life: physical discomforts (heat, cold, illness), emotional fluctuations (good times, bad times), and intellectual wounds (feeling respected or disrespected). Which category most easily disturbs your peace? This is where your practice should focus. The goal is not to become insensitive, but to see clearly that these fluctuations are happening at the level of body, mind, or intellect - not at the level of your true self, which remains the unchanging witness.

snippets.title: Day 83: The Supreme Yogi
snippets.sanskrit:
योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः |

शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः |

तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः |
snippets.transliteration:
yogī yuñjīta satatamātmānaṃ rahasi sthitaḥ .

śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiramāsanamātmanaḥ .

tatraikāgraṃ manaḥ kṛtvā yatacittendriyakriyaḥ .
verseTranslations: Let the student of spirituality try unceasingly to concentrate his mind; Let him live in seclusion, absolutely alone, with mind and personality controlled, free from desire and without possessions.
Having chosen a holy place, let him sit in a firm posture on a seat, neither too high nor too low, and covered with a grass mat, a deer skin and a cloth.
Seated thus, his mind concentrated, its functions controlled and his senses governed, let him practise meditation for the purification of his lower nature.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter six, Dhyana Yoga Yoga of Meditation. In first five chapters we learned about ourselves. We learned the terms Yogi and sannyasi. So in this chapter we've learned so far that the one who is acting in this world without depending on the fruits of actions is a yogi and also a sannyasi. Because a sannyasi cannot be a sannyasi unless he has given up all the sense of agency. A Yogi cannot be a yogi until he gives up all the Sankalpas Sarva Sankalpa Sanyasi.

So both reach the same state of becoming equanimous to all the happenings around them. And Bhagavan said, the one who has not yet achieved the state of Yoga, Arudha. So we are seekers, the seeker. The prescription is to selfless actions. Karma Karanam Uchathe. But one, you are established in Yoga then Shamah Karanamuchate then controlling your mind is your pursuit to achieve the higher level.

How do I know that I have become established in yoga? Once you get detached from your actions and also the sense objects -- when you are completely detached from the world of objects and the world of your activities -- in other words, you are functioning but not having that attachment to it. When you achieve that state, Sarva Sankalpa Sannyasi, there are no aspirations to achieve anything or to accomplish anything. That seems like a pretty dangerous state of mind. But in other words, you know what needs to be done and you will be doing it, but without any anxiety about what will come out of it. When you reach that state, then you are Yogarudha.

But how do I get to that point? Bhagavan said, let yourself lift yourself. Let your higher self lift this lower self to a level where they both become aligned with each other. Right now my identification is with the lower self, which we have defined as my body, mind, and intellect. This limited being I consider to be me in all my pursuits. I try to achieve happiness through this limited being. But being limited, it is limited.

It cannot achieve infinite happiness. But I miss that equation: something finite cannot achieve anything infinite. I am constantly pursuing infinite happiness, infinite bliss, an infinite state where there is no sorrow, using equipment which is finite. Once you align yourself with that higher self which is infinite, you will achieve your goal. So let your higher self lift your lower self to a level aligned with it. And then came the caution: that higher self can be your enemy or a friend.

Depending on whether I have control over my self, my senses, my mind. If I have no control over mind and senses, higher self enable me to do whatever my lower self wants to do and then it will be a disaster. So now the higher self is acting as an enemy because it's allowing me to do things which are not good for me. So once I have understood that the higher self is there to enable me to achieve higher goals and align with it, it will become my friend. Once I have achieved that state, what will happen? We have learned that then one becomes in a state of equanimity.

His self remains same in a Sita, Ushna, Sukhada, Kamana or Pramana. At the level of physical being, at the level of mental being or intellectual being. My connection with the higher remains the same. In other words, that I do not identify with what's happening with my body, mind and intellect. I continue to identify with my higher self which remains as a witness to what's happening. Therefore it is not getting affected.

When I see that things are happening to people around me but I am not affected, then I am a witness. I heard a long time ago a definition of recession and depression: when your neighbour gets laid off, it's a recession. When you get laid off, it's a depression. As long as I'm not affected,

It's a good topic to talk about. So as long as I don't identify with what's happening, it does not affect me. So as long as my self is constantly identifying with the higher self, whatever happening at the physical level, mental level, intellectual level, it does not get affected. Then he will also become one with all beings in their relationship. Gnana Vignana Truptatma Kutastha Vijitendriyah Yukta iti uchyate Yogi Sama Loshta Ashma Kanchanah. He sees everything in the physical world as essentially the same.

He knows that there is no inherent value in anything. Value is what I assign the value to. As long as I know this is a million dollar Diamond. There is a value because I can sell it. But if I do not know what their value is, it is no different than a costume jewelry. So values are what I assign to it, the world assigned to it.

But there is no inherent value in anything or being. That's the person with the alignment of the higher self. Then we are saying that even in his relationship, Suhan, mitra, Hari, udasin, madhyas, all different types of people we deal with in our life. Some are friends, some are foes, some are indifferent, some are relatives. But we see them all equally. In other words, they are all manifestation of the same self.

So this is the state described of a yogi. But we are not at this stage. The prescription is: continue doing selfless actions for the purification of your mind and intellect. When the internal instrument becomes pure, you start seeing your connection with the higher. That inner voice which is so feeble right now, you'll hear loud and clear. How to get there is what the next few verses tell us -- a detailed description of the practices one can follow. Now, last time we had this discussion about whether meditation is for yogis only or for anybody.

And there is a question about whether we understand what meditation is. Meditation is the final state. If you take Patanjali's Yoga Sutra, there are eight different stages before you get to the state of meditation: Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, and Samadhi. We have to go through all these different steps to get to a level where we are ready for meditation. But that does not mean you don't have to start somewhere.

You have to start at some place, wherever you are in your journey, one step at a time. And then you have to discipline yourself, which is where Yama (restraint) and Niyama (observance) come in. In anything, what really matters is constant practice. When I used to work for large companies, the marketing people, before you go for a presentation, would say, "Let's have a rehearsal." Some of us would feel, "I've been doing it for years, why do I have to practice?"

They say, no, no, Neel, do the rehearsal one time and we are done. Practice, practice and practice some more. Then only you will be able to present it flawlessly when you go there. So in anything, practice, practice and practice some more is the key. Most of us will say, I tried that. And when obviously it's not working for me.

But how long have you tried? A couple of days. Obviously there is no way to judge what you can achieve if you continue to practice. But how you practice is just as important. We sometimes say that somebody has 10 years of experience, but it may be one year of experience repeated ten times. He never progressed beyond the very first year.

Whatever he learned, he keeps doing for the next 10 years and says, "I have 10 years of experience." So you have to learn how to start in the right manner and then make progress. The next three verses teach us how to start that journey. Yogi yunjita satatam atmanam rahasi sthitah, ekaki yata chittatma nirashih aparigrahah. This is the description of how the yogi should live, in one verse.

Now, the yogi who has established himself is yogarudha. He has already gone through the other things we have talked about. He is not attached to the world of objects. He is not attached to his activities. He reached that state. Now he wants to attain that final connection with the self.

So he said, let the yogi try constantly to keep the mind steady. Probably half an hour a day. So what about the next 23 and a half hours is I let my mind go wherever it wants to go. So what would be more prominent on your mind? The one which you've done in 23 and a half hours or the one you did for half an hour? Of course, the 23 and a half hours will be predominant on your mind.

What will be the nature of your mind, what you do for next 23 and a half hours? So the goal here is to open all 24 hours should be the same. Let the yogi try constantly. Keep the mind steady. Remaining in solitude. Remaining in solitude.

Mentally in solitude. You may be in a marketplace, but your goal always remains. How my mind is connected, myself is connected. Swamiji gives a standard example of mother in a child. A mother with an infant child. Child may be in the next room and she is in a kitchen and she is doing whatever she is doing.

But her mind is completely attuned to the child. Even the slightest noise she will recognize. In those days they didn't have those monitors we have here so that you can put a monitor all over the house. But her mind is so tuned to that baby that other people can't hear. Because mind is constantly focused on where the baby is and what it is doing. A yogi becomes like that he may be doing whatever but his mind is constantly aligned towards his self and the conditions given which will allow him to do this.

He doesn't consider himself bound by attachment to all the people around him. Yata chittatma -- he is balanced in his chitta and atma, the self and the thinking entity. Nirashih -- without any asha (expectation). This is where we get lost, thinking "this is maybe not for us; I have too many things to accomplish." But nirashih means he does not seek anything to accomplish outside in the world for his happiness. He may be accomplishing a lot, but that accomplishment is not going to give him anything more for his connection to his higher self.

He's constantly focused on his connection. Therefore he has no other desire -- getting this or that out of this world will not make him more fit to achieve supreme happiness. Aparigrahah -- without possessions. All my possessions are of no value when it comes to my understanding of myself. I may be a billionaire, but happiness cannot be bought with billion dollars. What I'm seeking is infinite happiness.

I have come to the conclusion anything which is finite is not going to give me happiness. Therefore, acquiring things to get happiness. I have come to the conclusion is not a good idea. I may acquire things for other reason. To support my body, my mind, my intellect, my relatives, my friends. For them I'm doing this.

But not for me to get happiness. I'm not buying happiness by acquiring things. That clear idea is in my mind. My possessing thing is not going to give me happiness. I have come to the conclusion that I have tried this before.
snippets.reflection:
These verses offer the first practical instructions for meditation: sit alone in a secluded place, control the mind, be free from desires and possessions. But the instruction "rahasi sthitah" - remaining in seclusion - is not merely physical. A mother with an infant in the next room is fully engaged in her tasks, yet her mind is constantly attuned to her child. Similarly, the yogi may be in a crowded marketplace but maintains mental seclusion - an inner focus on the self that is undisturbed by outer activity.

The condition "nirashih aparigrahah" - without expectations, without possessions - challenges us deeply. We tend to believe that acquiring things will make us complete. "If only I had a green card, everything would be solved." But once achieved, new incompleteness arises. The yogi has reached the profound realization that possessions cannot purchase peace. This does not mean abandoning all material support, but rather abandoning the delusion that material acquisition leads to lasting happiness.

Today, examine your relationship with your meditation practice itself. Are you treating it like 30 minutes carved out from the "real" 23.5 hours of your day? The teaching here is that meditation should gradually infuse all 24 hours. Start by choosing one regular activity - eating breakfast, walking to your car, brushing your teeth - and practice it with the same quality of focused awareness you would bring to formal meditation. This is how the practice expands from the cushion into life.

snippets.title: Day 84: The Practice of Yoga
snippets.sanskrit:
समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः |

प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः |

युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः |
snippets.transliteration:
samaṃ kāyaśirogrīvaṃ dhārayannacalaṃ sthiraḥ .

praśāntātmā vigatabhīrbrahmacārivrate sthitaḥ .

yuñjannevaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī niyatamānasaḥ .
verseTranslations: Let him hold body, head and neck erect, motionless and steady; let him look fixedly at the tip of his nose, turning neither to the right nor to the left.
With peace in his heart and no fear, observing the vow of celibacy, with mind controlled and fixed on Me, let the student lose himself in contemplation of Me.
Thus keeping his mind always in communion with Me, and with his thoughts subdued, he shall attain that Peace which is mine and which will lead him to liberation at last.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We had been discussing chapter six, Dhyana Yoga Yoga of Meditation. We have so far understood that the yogi is trying to achieve a state of mind where he is not attached to either the sense objects or his actions, and he does not have any grand plans for the future. To achieve this state of mind, one obviously has to turn one's gaze to the inner self and stop letting the mind run out to the outer world.

The nature of the mind is obviously to go after the sense objects because it is receiving the information from the senses, senses, reports to the mind. And mind wants to go out and analyze those experiences in the world of sense objects. For this mind to train to turn inward is the training of meditation. And we have seen that Bhagavan has given a clear instruction of how to start this practice. Obviously anything which we are doing and we want to change it, you have to make it a practice, a habit. I heard somewhere that if you do something seven times, it becomes a habit.

And I have personally experienced that if I get up one day at 6:30 and it seems too early the next day, I try a little harder and still get up at 6:30. And then after a while that becomes my normal routine that I'll get up at 6:30. So the mind gradually gets used to what we do in a routine manner, or we do it repeatedly. My mind is a flow of thoughts. In whatever direction we turn it, that's the direction the mind will start flowing into. Right now the mind has been trained since my birth to go out to the outside world and gather information whether that experience is conducive or not conducive, whether it is a pleasant or unpleasant experience.

And my happiness or unhappiness right now is defined by my experiences which are either conducive or unconducive, pleasant or unpleasant. Dhyana Yoga is the practice to turn this mind away from this outer experiences and experience the inner self. So so far we have seen that the instruction is given that having lived the life of a selfless activity. In other words, I have now changed my priorities in my life. Where whatever I'm doing, I will be thinking about the greater good. Then I will think about not only practicing this art for making money or making my living, but also how good I can make the others lives.

My clients will be using these buildings. Whether have I improved their lives. And that will be my motivation in practicing my art. If I train my mind to think that way for everything I do, my activities start becoming more selfless than selfish. More and more I practice my selfless activities. My mind becomes purer and purer and seeing the world outside.

But I have yet not trained itself to turn inward to see what is the experience of myself. And that's where the meditation come in place. So the instruction we have seen in last few _Verses_ it says such. Establish a place of your own meditation which is steady and firm. Naati uchritam naati nicham that it is not too tall, not too low. And once I've established my place of meditation, I've become comfortable on that asana.

And I sit down with my folded legs or any other position which is most comfortable. The whole goal is to make my body so comfortable that my mind does not run towards discomfort of my body. My mind gets used to sitting at that place and realizing that now is the time to contemplate and meditate. I'm training my mind. I'm programming my mind that once I sit down at this place, it is time to meditate. So the next instruction was, what do I do once I sit down?

I sit down, I close my eyes lightly. And then the instructions say tatra ekagramana kutva. Then focusing the mind at a single point, Yatachatta indriya kriyah. That controlling the senses. I'm not letting my eyes to see, my ears to hear, or my skin to feel any touch. And I will be practicing this for the purpose of atma vishuddaye, for purifying my internal instrument.

I keep this goal in mind at the seat of meditation. That I am doing this for my internal the purification of my internal instrument. Antakarana, my mind and intellect, the operating system of myself, which is my mind and intellect. So the next three _Verses_ gives us further instructions into what would be the most appropriate posture to achieve that. So the verse 13 says, Samam kaya shirogrivam dharayan achalam sthiraha. I sat down, I closed my eyes, but I'm trying to focus my mind and I feel the weight of my body.

It's slouching me down and slumping me down and that distracts me. I have never understood this before. I joined Chinmaya Mission and started hearing and learning about meditation. But I heard Swamiji saying that the most comfortable position will be to sit erect. If you want to sit at the seat of meditation, not only that you have to have a right, right seat, but you have to right posture so that you can sit without any stress and strain or having any discomfort in your body in the posture which is most natural, most natural posture. I now understand this as an architectural principle: if I have a straight column, it will have less stress because I'm transferring all the load on that column straight down to the earth. But if I have a bent column with a load on the second floor at the top of it, that column will have more stress and strain. And I have to design it in a way that it has more reinforcement and all different type of calculations to make sure that the column remains in place. It's a simple fact in structural knowledge: if I have a straight column, it requires less strength because there is less strain from the load imposed on it. This actually applies to our body too, because our body is nothing but a structure, just like any building. When we are sitting down and our backbone is bent, it puts more stress on it to keep itself in place. That stress and strain eventually transfers to my mind, which starts thinking about how to become comfortable.

So I need to create a posture which is the most natural in nature is to have a straight column. My backbone should be completely straight. So therefore it says Samam kaya shira grivam. Keep the head, neck and the body in a straight line. It's an observation by our rishis that this is the most comfortable position for our self, our body. It will less strain if you work on your posture and all the time make sure that you are sitting straight.

You will realize it is the most comfortable position, and you can sit in it for a longer period without feeling any stress on your body. This comes straight from Bhagavad Gita: Samam Kaya Shirogrivam -- having your body, neck, and head in a straight line. Dharayan Achalam -- hold it without moving.

Once again, let's go back to my own architectural training. If I have a column with wind load applied on it and it is moving in the wind -- I learned to my surprise when I started working on high-rise buildings that all high-rise buildings actually sway in the wind, just like a tree moves in the wind.

We typically think the buildings are stable and they don't move. But all buildings move just like a tree would move in a wind. So in a high rise building which are about 50, 60, 70 stories tall or more, they literally move in a wind just like a tree would move. And I even have heard that people get seasickness on the, on the top floors of high rise, those who are very, very sensitive to movement. Because at the top floor, if you are in a hundred story building or 110 story building and you are on a 110th floor, the movement may be in feet. You know, the building moves several feet from one side to another.

And people who are sensitive, most people don't, may not feel it. But some people who are very sensitive start feeling their movement, they develop something similar to seasickness. So if the column is straight, no other force is applied on it, and it's not moving, it has the least stress. But on a high-rise building that will move in the wind, the engineer has to calculate that movement and design for those forces so the column remains steady under wind load. He has to add more reinforcement and strength to keep this column intact under those conditions.

So once more: our backbone, when it is moving, experiences more stress and strain, and eventually that transfers to our mind. If I want my mind completely relieved of any disturbance, I need to relieve it from any stress coming from my body. So Bhagavan says Dharayan Achalam -- hold this posture of having the head, neck, and body in a straight line, firmly, without moving. That does not mean a stiff posture where I'm trying not to move, but naturally achieving that firmness in a most relaxed manner.

Now I have the seat, I've sat down on it, I've held my body in a firm position, my posture is corrected, my backbone is completely straight. How do I control my mind?

At one point I'll have to give my mind something to think about, something to focus on. The next line says: Samprekshya nasikagram svam -- gaze at your own nose tip. Somebody will say, "But Neil, my eyes are closed. How am I going to gaze at my nose tip?" Well, you're not really seeing; you are trying to focus on it. With your eyes closed, focus your mind at the tip of your nose. You are not seeing it, you are imagining it.

Focusing your mind at the tip of your nose. Dishash cha anavalokayan -- without seeing in the other directions. Our mind has a very imaginative nature. When you close your eyes, the first thing the mind does is, "Well, I can't see now, but let me imagine what's around me. What if I look to the right? What must be happening?"

Would I look on the left? What must be happening? What could be behind me and what could be ahead of me? This nature of imagining things, we need to stop my mind to do. Therefore I'm trying to focus my mind at the tip of my nose and not letting it go in all other direction. So the verse 13 has told us how to sit erect, hold the body firm then gaze at the tip of your nose with your eyes lightly closed and not let the mind try to imagine what's on the other side.

In the next verse say this.
snippets.reflection:
The instruction "samam kaya-shiro-grivam" - keep the body, head, and neck in a straight line - contains profound structural wisdom. Just as a straight column in a building carries weight with minimum stress while a bent column requires extra reinforcement, your spine when erect allows you to sit for extended periods without strain. The body becomes so comfortable that the mind forgets it, freeing attention for the inward journey. This is not rigid stiffness but natural alignment - relaxed yet upright.

The practice of gazing at the nose tip with eyes gently closed addresses our mind's imaginative nature. With eyes closed, the mind immediately begins constructing images: What is happening on my left? What is behind me? By focusing attention on a single point - the nose tip - we give the restless mind an anchor, preventing it from wandering in all directions. The instruction "dishash cha anavalokayan" - not looking in various directions - applies to mental wandering, not just physical seeing.

The promise of verse 15 is extraordinary: "Shantim nirvana-paramam mat-samstham adhigacchati" - the yogi attains supreme peace that resides in Me. This peace we seek so desperately in the external world simply does not exist there. It is like riding a roller coaster and wishing it would stabilize - the nature of the roller coaster is movement. True stability is found only by stepping off onto solid ground. Today, practice sitting in correct posture for just five minutes, focusing on the breath at the tip of your nose, gently returning when the mind wanders. This small practice, done consistently, is the doorway to that supreme peace.

snippets.title: Day 85: Meditation
snippets.sanskrit:
नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः |

युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु |

यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते |
snippets.transliteration:
nātyaśnatastu yogo.asti na caikāntamanaśnataḥ .

yuktāhāravihārasya yuktaceṣṭasya karmasu .

yadā viniyataṃ cittamātmanyevāvatiṣṭhate .
verseTranslations: Meditation is not for him who eats too much, not for him who eats not at all; not for him who is overmuch addicted to sleep, not for him who is always awake.
But for him who regulates his food and recreation, who is balanced in action, in sleep and in waking, it shall dispel all unhappiness.
When the mind, completely controlled, is centered in the Self, and free from all earthly desires, then is the man truly spiritual.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We obviously have been discussing the Yoga of Meditation. We went through several chapters with the Karma Yoga, then culminating the Karma into Wisdom and then Sannyasa Yoga. And now we are saying Dhyana Yoga, the Yoga of Meditation.

We have so far seen that all we are doing is for Atma Shuddhi -- the purification of my internal instrument. My mind and intellect are the internal instrument, and that's the only task I have as a seeker: to purify my mind and intellect so that my real self will shine through. Then I will realize who I am -- the peace which I had been seeking all my life.

Bhagavan said in the last verse we discussed that you will then achieve Shantim Nirvana Paramam Matsanstham Adhigacchati. In verse 15, it said: having gone through this Yoga of meditation -- how to control your mind, how to sit still, control your body, control your senses, control your mind, and then focus on yourself, focus on Me as your supreme goal -- you will find that peace which you had been looking for all your life. That peace resides in Me, the supreme self.

The peace I'm seeking in this world does not exist in this world. And therefore me seeking the peace in this world is something like if, let's say for there is a one weekend at King's Dominion, there is a free ride that you can take as many rides as many times, no tickets needed or no attendants are going to stop you from taking that ride over and over again. We go on that roller coaster ride because this is a great chance. I know it's a lot of fun and here it is that there is no restriction. How many times I can take it. So I go on the roller coaster and while I'm going through the roller coaster, I'm constantly thinking, well, if this thing can stabilize, I'll really feel good about it.

Boy, it is going up and down. I can't even predict when it's going to go up and when it's going to come down. If it just stabilizes, I'll feel good about it. But because of my desire to have this fun, I'm not getting off the roller coaster. And after all, I get so engrossed into this, I don't even realize when it stops and starts again. And I'm constantly thinking, if this stabilizes, I may feel a little better about it.

At that point, some roller coaster guru can come and say, if you really want it stabilized, why don't you get off the roller coaster when it stops next time? So I said, what do I need to do? I said, well, just focus on when it stops. When it stops, you get out and then you'll be in a stable ground, which is what your real place is on a stable ground. That's where you were before. Before you decided you want to have this unlimited fun on this roller coaster.

Because there is no fee today. There is no restriction how many times you can take it. You say, well, I'll basically take it as long as I can stay there. But in that goal, I forgot that what I'm seeking is stability. That's my true nature. That's what I'm daily living.

But in that quest for getting this unlimited fun in what I always thought is a great fun, but I did not go there because it cost so much. Now that my chance to do it free, I'm on a roller coaster constantly seeking for the stability which does not exist in roller coaster. Very nature of roller coaster is to go up and down. So some guru comes and said, just focus on yourself. When you see a little stability, that's where the roller coaster stops. And then you will find that stability which you had been seeking all throughout this roller coaster will be yours because it resides outside this roller coaster.

Bhagavan says the Santi Nirvana Paramam, that santhi which only gets when you are liberated from this rat of this limited being, trying to seek happiness and peace in this world outside. You will achieve that because your mind and intellect is now pure to experience the joy which resides in the self. And once you unite with that self, Matsangstham Adigacchati, you will achieve that state of mind. And then the last three verses which you've seen, which is 16, 17 and 18. And it said, what we tend to think is, well, I need to live my life as I'm living. But then I need to have like 15 minutes in the morning.

I'm going to meditate, you know, and then I've achieved this state of paramshanti. Well that absolutely is a false notion. To do a meditation, you have to prepare for doing meditation. So how do we prepare for it? The Bhagavan says that the yoga is not possible for people who leave life without any control. I live undisciplined life.

And then I say, then I sit down and do yoga. A lot of people have this strong notion that I am living this dynamic life of working for 18 hours a day. But because I have 15 minutes of meditation then I can go on for another 18 hours. Bhagavan clearly says that that's not the reality. You live a life which is hectic and uncontrolled. You will not be able to meditate at all.

Therefore it says: Na ati ashnatah tu yoga asti -- for one who eats too much, Yoga is not possible. In other words, if I'm indulging in sense gratifications, Yoga is not possible. It is also not possible for one who doesn't eat at all, who is completely avoiding any fulfillment for this body.

It clearly says that torturing my body and senses unnecessarily will not make me any more worthy of meditation than a person who lives a moderate, disciplined life. Na cha ati svapnashilasya -- one who is engaged in svapna (dreaming/sleeping).

Dreaming is only possible when you're sleeping. But I can be Svapnashila while I'm waking in this world also, because from the point of Vedanta, the svapna extends from my dream world into the waking world. The waking world is nothing but another glorified dream from Vedanta's perspective. Na cha ati svapnashilasya -- one who is sleeping too much, or not sleeping at all.

Jagrato naiva cha Arjuna -- or constantly awake in this world, more engaged in this world, not taking enough sleep. Anything which is extreme is to be avoided, because it will not give you the purity or the control over yourself to focus your mind.

It's very enlightening that this is not sacred knowledge you only learn from Bhagavad Gita. People learn this on their own when they want to achieve something. We say, "Tomorrow I cannot do this because I have to wake up early." "I'm not coming to that party, I'm not going to a late-night movie, if I'm serious about what I'm going to do the next day."

I saw two interviews on TV by two Bollywood stars whom I probably wouldn't think had ever gone to any school of philosophy -- both basically known for their good looks, like Akshay Kumar and John Abraham. In short interviews, the first thing they both said when asked "how do you do that?" was: "I live a very disciplined life." You wouldn't expect to hear that from a Bollywood star, but both said the only way to achieve and maintain their stardom was by living a very disciplined life. "I don't stay awake after 9 o'clock" or whatever.

"I go to sleep by that time, I wake up early." Akshay Kumar said his show had to be recorded at six o'clock in the morning -- that was the only time he would be available. He won't stay up late. He said, "I'm very disciplined."

"I do this exercise daily." And I heard the exact same thing from John Abraham's interview somewhere. I wouldn't really think they have great knowledge of Bhagavad Gita or that somebody told them. They themselves figured out that the only way to maintain success is by living a disciplined life. Anyone who is serious about success eventually finds out that it is only possible through moderation. So Bhagavad Gita says, if I'm not clear about that and think meditation will be a panacea that solves all my problems -- like saying "I take Lipitor, so I can eat anything I want" -- that's not a smart idea. Anytime a doctor gives me medication and says, "Neil, you have a cholesterol problem, here's the medication," the medication only works well if I also control my diet and make other lifestyle changes. In anything I want to achieve, moderation is the key. Bhagavan says, first of all, yoga is not for people who live an extreme life.

Then the positive message: Yukta Ahara Viharasya, Yukta Cheshtasya Karmasu, Yukta Svapnavabodhasya Yogo Bhavati Duhkhaha. Now you might ask: did I really forget why I'm doing this yoga? Why did I start all this in the first place? If I have to live this moderate life and give up all the fun I used to have at parties at night, why do I even start? You are doing it, my friend, to get rid of your duhkha.

All the sorrows which you have, you want to get rid of them. There's not a single moment in life where I can say, "This pain is great, it really feels good." Unless you've heard this joke -- it's pretty famous. Someone was banging his head against the wall.

Why are you banging your head against the wall? He said, because it feels good when I stop. Just to get that feeling of good. When you stop, you don't bang your head against the wall. You want to get rid of any pain that you have in your life, physical, mental, intellectual. You want to get rid of as quickly as possible in the easiest way.

Bhagavan says, Yukta Ahara Viharasya -- first, the person who is moderate in ahara, consumption of sense objects. Vihara means moving around, going on vacations, cruises. But sometimes that becomes more exhausting than work, doesn't it? Recreation also must be in moderation. I used to watch movies when I was a student because in those days that was the only entertainment -- sometimes three shows in a row: 12 to 3, then 3 to 6, then 6 to 9.
snippets.reflection:
The Gita's teaching on moderation in these verses is remarkably practical and timeless. "Naty-ashnatas tu yogo'sti na chaikantam anashnatah" - yoga is not for one who eats too much, nor for one who eats too little. The same applies to sleep, recreation, and all activities. This is not a call to austerity or self-denial, but to wisdom and balance. Interestingly, even successful Bollywood stars have discovered this principle through experience - that discipline and moderation are essential for sustained achievement.

We sometimes develop a dangerous misconception: "I live a hectic 18-hour workday, but my 15 minutes of meditation will fix everything." This is like saying, "I eat junk food constantly, but my daily vitamin will make me healthy." Bhagavan clearly states that an extreme, undisciplined life cannot be compensated by brief periods of meditation. The whole of life must become regulated - "yukta-ahara-viharasya, yukta-cheshtasya karmasu" - balanced in eating, recreation, and action.

The reward for this moderation is profound: "Yogo bhavati duhkhaha" - yoga becomes the destroyer of sorrow. Why are we undertaking this practice? Not to punish ourselves, but to eliminate the suffering that pervades our lives. Today, honestly assess one area of your life that is out of balance. Are you sleeping too much or too little? Eating mindlessly or obsessively? Working to exhaustion or avoiding necessary tasks? Choose one small adjustment toward moderation. Remember: every aspect of life either supports or undermines your capacity for inner peace.

snippets.title: Day 86: The Restless Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता |

यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया |

सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद् बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yathā dīpo nivātastho neṅgate sopamā smṛtā .

yatroparamate cittaṃ niruddhaṃ yogasevayā .

sukhamātyantikaṃ yattad buddhigrāhyamatīndriyam .
verseTranslations: The wise man who has conquered his mind and is absorbed in the Self is as a lamp which does not flicker, since it stands sheltered from every wind.

There, where the whole nature is seen in the light of the Self, where the man abides within his Self and is satisfied there, its functions restrained by its union with the Divine, the mind finds rest.
When he enjoys the Bliss which passes sense, and which only the Pure Intellect can grasp, when he comes to rest within his own highest Self, never again will he stray from reality.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. And that happiness can only come if we become detached from our attachment to this world of objects and beings. But we still have to work in this world. And therefore the simple definition given of a person who has achieved that detachment, whether you call him a yogi or a sannyasis, Anasritaha Karma, Falam Karyam Karautiya. One who acts in this world without depending on the fruits of actions, he is acting, but he is not dependent on what will come out of my actions. That anxiety is not there.

One who has achieved that state of mind control. He is a yogi or he is a sannyasi. That's as simple a definition. Then he says to achieve that state, obviously you have to go through several disciplines and practices. And all this is all about controlling your mind. Because all that we consider a happiness or unhappiness, sorrow or pleasure is all a mental state.

When that mental state is controlled, we can control whether we are in a happiness or unhappiness state. The practice given is called meditation. This meditation is not just a physical act of sitting down cross-legged and focusing on some idea, but regulating the entire life. We have seen the prerequisites of what needs to be done. It is about one who regulates his life in all aspects.

He does not eat too much, he does not eat too little, he does not sleep too much, he does not sleep too little. Even in his activities, he does not exert himself too much. In other words, everything in moderation. All that really means is you apply the appropriate amount of effort -- not too much, not too little. It's like tightening a bolt. If you tighten too much, it's a problem. If you don't tighten enough, it's a problem.

Only time it works perfectly is when it is appropriately tightened. So every activity of our life should be regulated to a point. But then your mind has to be focused or controlled and how do we control mind? And we have learned that the very nature of the mind, very definition of mind is mind is nothing but a flow of thoughts. Mind is like a river. Water does not make a river, but a flowing water in one direction makes a river.

So mind is nothing but the flow of thoughts -- in our case, flowing in many directions. These thoughts are channelized into many channels, and each channel assumes that at its end there is happiness. If we channelize them to one particular point where happiness really lies -- which scripture says is within yourself -- that exercise of reverting your mind's flow of thoughts from outward to inward is called meditation. To practice that, we have been given a prescription and detailed instruction.

Sit down erect so there is no discomfort in your body. There is no discomfort in the environment around you. And then focus your mind onto yourself. That peace which you experience during that inward journey is yourself. And as the meditators of all ages have said, once you experience that peace, you will like to experience that over and over again. And then with that constant practice, you reach a point where that peace become permanent.

The last thing we have seen is: Yada viniyatam chittam atmani eva avatishthate -- when the mind rests in the self. Once the mind has found its final destination, where the peace lies, it does not want to go anywhere. If somebody says, "Where do you want to buy a house in Richmond?" -- once I've decided the West End is the right place, I'm not going to look around in Mechanicsville or Chesterfield, because I have already decided that the right place is the West End. Once the mind decides that the real resting place where peace is, is in myself, it will not go anywhere else.

It's just the very nature of the mind. So it says, once that mind rests in the self, free from longing -- Nihsprihah sarva kamebhyah -- all the desires up till now were for what? Everything I have done since I understood who I am, till last night or this morning, is to get happiness, to feel happy, to get peace in life. And this peace is so elusive. The more you go after it, like a mirage,

the more it runs away from you. Once you find a place where it is not a mirage, you will establish yourself in that. Once you establish in that, there is no longing for any objects and desires. Then it is said he is united -- that is Yuktah. We are like lost children. We are lost in this sansar, this mela, and we are seeking our own place, where our family is, where we came from. When we get united with that place, we find peace.

A child will be lost in India festival and is crying profusely. No matter what you tell him, give me chocolate. Nothing works till find my parent. And as soon as he finds his parents nothing can attract him but that peace. When you find after that there is nothing else you will look for. So our nature is peace and therefore we are seeking peace.

If our nature is not peace, we wouldn't be seeking peace. My nature is health, therefore I am seeking health. So anything happens, I run to the doctor, run to whatever, fix me quickly, as quickly as you can. Everybody says antibiotics, read about antibiotics and all the perils of taking antibiotics. The first thing I go and ask my doctor is give me the antibiotics as quickly and as powerful as possible. I want to get rid of whatever that is not health as quickly as possible.

Because my real nature is health. My real nature is not unhealthy. So I am always seeking what my true nature is. My true nature is peace. And everything else in this world is giving me un peace. Once I unite with that peace, I am considered Yuktaha.

This simile used is just as in a windless room the flame of a lamp does not flicker, it remains steady. Yatra uparamate chittam nirdam yoga sevaya yatracha eva atmana tmanam pasyan atmani tushyade. So when the mind restrained by the practice of yoga attains quietude by when seeing the self by the self he satisfied by the self always seeking all our life is some satisfaction, some peace. We tried everywhere else but it was never complete. It may come for a for a while as I said. As soon as I get that, the key of my first BMW in my hand, a complete peace in my mind.

All that I want to achieve. And the next moment the agitation starts again. As soon as he tells me what the insurance would be for this guy. But once I found that piece where? By the self satisfied by the self. So yogi, once he practices this yoga to find his peace and he found it, he is now satisfied that the final state.

These four verses basically describe what yoga is all about. We have this whole notion about yoga being sitting down in a lotus position. But those are all practices to control your body, mind, and intellect. All agitations in my life come through my body, mind, and intellect. Either my body is not healthy, or my mind is not healthy.

Mind is okay, but ideas are not coming -- the intellect is struggling. Once those are controlled and peace comes, then I am a yogi. Sukham atyantikam yat tat buddhi grahyam atindriyam, vetti yatra na cha eva ayam sthitah chalati tattvatah. This is like somebody who has gone to Hawaii and is explaining the joy. "I had been to all these different destinations for vacation." He said, "No, no, Neil, forget about all of that."

You just go to Hawaii one time and that's the end of the story. You wouldn't like to go anywhere else. So he explained and see, when you go there, they have all these things. After that you never have to take a vacation anywhere else. Sukam Atyantikam Yattad When a yogi feels this infinite bliss, one who has experienced this bliss in his meditation, he said that's infinite bliss. That bliss is not something which comes and goes.

So what we worry about is: this is too much trouble in the first place. I can't wake up early in the morning as everybody says I should. Then I have to sit down in a particular place. Then I have to control my mind, which is not controllable in the first place. And then someday I'll find a little peace and it will go away, and I'll have to start all over again. But the real meditation -- once a person has experienced that infinite bliss -- can be grasped by the intellect. Buddhi grahyam atindriyam -- it's not something promised that can never be proved.

Swamiji used to say, "In our business there is no danger because we can bluff our way out and nobody can catch us." But no, Bhagavan said that's not true. You will be able to grasp this peace through Buddhi, the intellect. But that Buddhi is the pure Buddhi -- the intellect that is not clouded by Rajas and Tamas. We are also very smart at finding what is right and wrong for us. But all that right and wrong is colored by our vasanas.

What my Buddhi says is good for me or not good for me is all colored by my experiences, desires, and vasanas. The intellect which is pure will grasp that infinite happiness. Vetti yatra na cha eva ayam sthitah chalati tattvatah -- once Buddhi grasps that infinite peace, he will never be shaken from that ultimate reality. Tattvatah -- he will never be able to think the other way around. He will never be able to think happiness lies outside.

Because his Buddhi has grasped that the reality where the bliss is so that's a state which only you have to achieve one time. Once you achieve that, nobody will be able to shake you off that realization. Once you realize what is reality. Once you wake up from your dream and you realize what the reality is. No matter how much you convince yourself that no, no, no. The reality was the one which was experiencing the dream.

In my dream I was Bill Gates' boss. No matter how much I convince myself that I am actually Bill Gates' boss, that's not going to work. Because once my Buddhi has grasped that what I was experiencing was nothing but a dream, as a waker I will not be able to go back to that. In the same way, the Upanishad says that the waking world is a dream. We have assigned values to all these objects in our waking world as if they are happiness.

Once you wake up from this, you realize that there is no value outside for your own bliss or happiness. And from that you cannot be shaken off. Yam labdhva cha aparam labham manyate na adhikam tatah -- having experienced that, you will realize there is nothing else greater to be achieved. All my life, everything I have done is to find some peace, some happiness.

Well, here is ultimate happiness and ultimate bliss. So there is nothing to be gained if I suddenly wake up and realize that my forefathers used to own the entire real estate in Richmond.
snippets.reflection:
The beautiful simile in verse 19 - "yatha dipo nivata-stho nengate" - compares the controlled mind to a lamp in a windless place that does not flicker. Our minds currently flicker violently because the winds of desire constantly blow through them. One thought leads to another: "I'm chanting Rama, which reminds me of Ramlal who owes me money, which reminds me..." The cascading associations carry us far from our intended focus. But when we calm the winds of desire, even briefly, the flame of awareness becomes steady.

Verse 21 promises "sukham atyantikam" - infinite, never-ending bliss. This is not exaggeration but precise description. The happiness we experience from external achievements - getting the car keys to our first BMW - is real but fleeting. The next moment, worries about insurance arise. The bliss discovered in meditation is different in kind, not just degree. It is "buddhi-grahyam atindriyam" - graspable by the pure intellect but beyond the senses. It cannot be seen, touched, or heard, yet it is more real than any sensory experience.

The promise of verse 21 is crucial: "Sthitash chalati tattvatah" - once established in this truth, the yogi never strays from reality. This is like waking from a dream. No matter how vivid the dream was - even if you were Bill Gates' boss in it - once awake, you cannot convince yourself the dream was real. The waking state has superior claim to reality. Similarly, the one who has tasted this infinite bliss through meditation can never again believe that happiness lies in external objects. Today, sit quietly and ask: "What would it mean to find a happiness that never ends?" Let that question draw you inward.

snippets.title: Day 87: The Supreme Yogi
snippets.sanskrit:
यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः |

तं विद्याद् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम् |

सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः |
snippets.transliteration:
yaṃ labdhvā cāparaṃ lābhaṃ manyate nādhikaṃ tataḥ .

taṃ vidyād duḥkhasaṃyogaviyogaṃ yogasaṃjñitam .

saṅkalpaprabhavānkāmāṃstyaktvā sarvānaśeṣataḥ .
verseTranslations: Finding That, he will realise that there is no possession so precious. And when once established here, no calamity can disturb him.
This inner severance from the affliction of misery is spirituality. It should be practised with determination and with a heart which refuses to be depressed.
Renouncing every desire which imagination can conceive, controlling the senses at every point by the power of mind;
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. So those of you who remember, we were on chapter six two weeks ago and we discussed verses 25, 26, and 27. Chapter six is Dhyana Yoga. The first six chapters, as we have discussed many times, describe the "you" part of that.

"You are That" -- Thou art, Tattvamasi -- in the Upanishads. The "you" part is you and I, who we are. The first six chapters culminate into Dhyana Yoga: who I am, which I can't understand right now, I can reflect on and find through the self. This false notion -- "this is me, this body, mind and intellect" -- to undo this, I have to contemplate on that self. Once I find myself by myself and become content in myself, then my yoga is complete.

That's what we have seen. The verse says: Atmanam pashyan atmani tushyati -- seeing the self by the self,

I'm satisfied in myself. That's the goal of life. I want contentment, I want happiness which is everlasting. I looked at, I sought that outside. I finally find in myself. And once I find that in myself, I'm satisfied, content.

So the first six chapters told us who we are, what our shortcomings are, and how to overcome them, culminating in meditation. We came across a new definition of yoga in the last few verses: Duhkha samyoga viyoga is yoga -- disassociation from the association with sorrows is yoga. Right now we actually associate with our sorrows, and therefore we are sorrowful. I have an ache and pain in my leg and I think "I have pain." I start associating with this pain -- somebody pricks me and that's my pain.

But when a doctor or nurse is ready to give me an injection, I'm already prepared for that. I disassociate myself from that pain so I can tolerate it without any problem, because I have already disengaged and said, "That's not really pain, not something unnatural happening to me." That attitude of disassociating yourself from the association with pain -- pain exists, sorrows exist, but my association with that ends. Bhagavan says that's Yoga: Duhkha Samyoga Viyoga.

And therefore Duhkhena guruna api na vichalyate -- even when the greatest sorrows come from the outside world, they seem like the greatest sorrows from my perspective, but those are just the natural occurrences of this world. They happen just as the laws of nature predict. The yogi who has disassociated himself from sorrows is without any disturbance. He has found himself by himself and finds this infinite joy and happiness in that.

The next three verses go along with verse 24: Sankalpa prabhavan kaman tyaktva, manasaivendriyagramam viniyamya samanthatah. You have traveled that journey from ignorance about yourself to understanding what's not right in your internal instrument, the mind and intellect. Purifying it through Karma Yoga, contemplating on that self, I have come to this point: I have given up all the desire-prompted actions, all the desires prompted by the Sankalpa Shakti of my mind. I may have normal desires like "I'm thirsty and I want water." That's not Sankalpa Prabhavan Kama -- those are not born out of my fanciful imagination. I'm thirsty, so I need water.

But the Sankalpa Shakti in my mind is my mind projects a future, imaginary future and say if I do this then I can do this and then I will have this and then I'll gain this and then I'll be a millionaire. Well that's my Sankalpa Shakti. And what I do is before I start a plan to achieve that goal, my mind has already moved on to another goal. But I can also do this and then do this and then do this and then I can be a billionaire. So before even I start any concrete actions to achieve my goal my mind has erased that goal and gave me another goal. So I'm constantly chasing the goal which is not there.

By that time I start working on my goal. My goal has moved away. So I'm aimlessly moving. And you see that Sankalpa Shakti. All the desires prompted by this fanciful nature of my mind. When I give up asesata without leaving anything behind.

snippets.reflection:
A new definition of yoga emerges in these verses: "Duhkha-samyoga-viyogam yoga-samjnitam" - yoga is the disassociation from the association with sorrow. We currently associate with our sorrows so completely that we become them. "My leg hurts" becomes "I am in pain." Yet when a nurse prepares to give an injection, we instinctively disassociate - "This is expected, temporary, for my benefit" - and the same pain becomes bearable. The yogi extends this disassociation to all of life's inevitable sorrows.

Verse 24 addresses "sankalpa-prabhavan kaman" - desires born from the projecting power of the mind. Our Sankalpa Shakti is remarkable: it projects imaginary futures and convinces us that happiness lies there. "If I do this, then I can do that, then I'll achieve this, then I'll be a millionaire... no wait, I could also do this other thing and become a billionaire!" The mind creates goals, then erases them before we even begin working, replacing them with new fantasies. We are aimlessly chasing targets that keep moving.

Verse 23 offers essential encouragement: "Sa nishchayena yoktavyo yogo'nirvin-nachetasa" - yoga should be practiced with determination and without depression. The spiritual path requires resilience. Many give up quickly, saying "I tried meditation; it doesn't work for me." But how long did you try? A few days? Would you expect to master any skill - playing piano, speaking a language, running a marathon - in a few days? Today, renew your commitment to practice. Choose one sankalpa-born desire that you will consciously set aside - not forever, but for today. Notice how the mind protests, then settle it and return to presence.

snippets.reflection:
The word "shanaih shanaih" - gradually, gradually - in verse 25 offers tremendous encouragement. This is not a path of sudden transformation but patient cultivation. With a pure intellect (buddhya dhriti-grihitaya), you gradually withdraw the mind from its outward rushing and establish it in the self. The key is not to expect overnight results, but to trust the process and continue. Like learning to drive a car - initially overwhelming, eventually automatic - the practice of steadying the mind becomes natural through repetition.

Verse 26 acknowledges reality with compassion: "Yato yato nishcharati manash chanchalam asthiram" - wherever and whenever the restless, unsteady mind wanders, bring it back. This is not a verse of condemnation but of practical instruction. The mind WILL wander - that is its nature. Your job is not to prevent wandering but to notice it and return. Each return strengthens the faculty of awareness. Don't punish yourself for wandering; celebrate each return. You are training a wild horse, and every gentle redirection is progress.

The reward described in verse 27 is the purpose behind all this effort: "Prasanta-manasam hy enam yoginam sukham uttamam" - supreme bliss comes to the yogi whose mind is peaceful, whose rajas (restlessness) is subdued, who has become one with Brahman and is free from sin. The sins mentioned are the impurities of the internal instrument - the vasanas and tendencies that drive us toward wrong action. When these are purified through meditation, the yogi realizes that the individual self and the Supreme Self were always one. Today, practice this: when your mind wanders during any activity, gently whisper "return" and bring attention back. Do this ten times and notice how the quality of your experience changes.
