snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We had been discussing chapter six, Yoga of Meditation. So far we have seen up to verse 27 that the goal of meditation is to make the mind steady. The mind currently in my present situation is flickering and running away in many, many directions.

And therefore the whole idea of making the mind steady seems very, very difficult for me. So we have seen the practice how to meditate, how to make this mind steady, Choose a place which is conducive, make it a practice every day, make this as a habit, same place, same position, controlling your body from not disturbing you, make it most comfortable, sit down and focus your mind. Now this is where we find ourselves in difficulty focusing the mind on one goal and one target. We have heard this simile that the mind, when it is like a mind, like a lamp, when there is a wind in the room or in the place where the lamp is placed, the flame flickers. And depending on the nature of the wind, flame may flicker very heavily or may flicker just a little, depending on how much wind there is. The mind works in a similar way.

Depending on my vasanas, depending on the desires in my mind, this mind will be running after many, many thoughts and one thought will lead to the another. Swamiji used to say, I'm trying to chant Rama and the Rama. The word Rama reminds me of Ramlal who has borrowed money from me. And then we go on and on and on. But this obviously can be controlled, as we have seen that if you calm down this wind of desires, at least at the time of sitting in the meditation, that you have trained your mind not to think about other things and you focus on that one thought, then mind will be steady. And as we have seen that by a constant practice, the yogi can make his mind steady.

And once that mind becomes steady, he will Recognize the peace within himself from whatever the cause. The restless and the unsteady mind wanders away from that. Let him restrain it and bring it back under the control of the self alone by practice now it is becoming easier for me. I guess I am speaking for every seeker who is practicing that practice makes man perfect. We have heard this before. We have learned in our life that anything I continue to practice, it becomes easier.

Something which I practice over and over and over again. It reaches a point that there is no effort required. Something like driving a car. When I was first learning how to drive a car, obviously I had all kinds of problems. And I may have said this before that I used to complain to my cousins who were trying to teach me how to drive a car in Africa. I had gone from India.

I had never driven a car in India. I probably took some lessons in India before I was living for Zambia. And in India it was very easy to get a license. Nobody even bothered with it. I really knew how to drive, but I got a license now I went to Zambia. And then I really had to drive.

So learning from my cousins how to drive, they kept telling me, "Keep your car steady, keep your car steady." And I complained, "How can I keep it steady when I'm sitting on one side of the car? If the steering wheel was in the center, it would be much easier!" But that was just an excuse because I didn't know how to control the car. And then more and more I practice driving the car. It started becoming easier and easier.

And then I reached a point where driving a car requires no efforts. I sit down in the car, put the key in the ignition, can be thinking about every other thing except driving the car. But I will be driving properly in a right lane. And whatever the appropriate thing I have to do for driving the car. But I do not have to put any more efforts in. Comes automatically and naturally.

As soon as I sit down in the driver's seat, my mind takes over. My subconscious mind takes over how to drive this car. Meditation is like that. If I practice over and over and over again to steady my mind under one thought and one thought alone. As soon as I sit at the seat of meditation, my mind will know what to do and it will control itself automatically. And Bhagavan says that such a yogi experiences the supreme bliss, that peace which I had been seeking all my life.

And I had been trying to achieve that in many different ways. To acquire things, to make sure everything is secured, my future is secured, my Family's future is secured. However, I never experience that peace in my mind. Now at the seat of meditation, I can experience the supreme bliss. Bhagavan said, the supreme bliss verily comes to this yogi whose mind is quiet and peaceful. His passions are quietened.

Now he is free from sin. And we have seen the sin is nothing but impurities on my mind. Impurities are the impressions on my mind which makes me think that this I will do and that will make me happy. Once my mind is steady and is focused on one thought, who I am, what is myself, all these impurities are purified and I achieve that bliss. And the term used is Brahma Bhutam akalmasham. He becomes one with the Brahman all pervading self and he becomes free of all sins.

Continuing in this thought, the next three verses talks about the yogi who has with continued practice has made this as his own nature that the Yunjan Evam Sada Atmanam Yogi Vigada kalmashah. Again we are talking about in Yogi who has become freed from all his sins. Now we sometimes makes an argument that on one hand, the law of karma says that if I have done something, I have to pay for it. Or if I pay for it, in a sense, if it was a negative act, if it is a positive act, I will get the reward. And then here it says that by meditation I will become free of all sins. How do we reconcile the idea of the law of karma which says you cannot escape from your actions?

Here it says just by meditation I can become free from all my sins. Well, the law of karma simply says that my actions will have equal and appropriate reactions. If I've done something inappropriate, I will have to pay the consequences. However, the sins here are not the consequences of the actions. Sins are the impressions on my mind. A negative impression on my mind from any event or experience is a sin.

These negative impressions are the ones which are causing me to do more wrong things. I have seen somebody making money by illegal means. That impressions, that thought or the observation leaves a wrong impression that if I have to make money, it seemed like this is the only way to do it. That negative impression is a sin. Now that sin will make me act in an inappropriate manner. Then I will also try to achieve the wealth by what I thought was the only way you can achieve wealth by inappropriate means.

The wrong impression on the mind made me do the wrong things. Now I have to face the consequences of those wrong things. However, if I have cleaned up my mind from all these impressions, then I'm free of sins. I may still have to face consequences of past actions, but no more wrong actions will be generated from impressions on my mind. A yogi constantly controlling his mind reaches a level of purification where there are no negative impressions, and therefore there is no cause for him to react inappropriately. So Yunjan Evam Sada Atmanam Yogi Vikatha Kalma Sahar. The Yogi always engaging the mind. Thus in the practice of yoga, freed from sins, he now Sukena Brahmasp Samsparsam Atyantam Sukham Ashnate. He now easily enjoy that infinite bliss. Because his mind, no matter whatever is happening in his life, in his situations, he is constantly in the thought of that supreme Brahman that he is enjoying that bliss at every moment.

So he has become Brahma sans person. He is in touch with Brahman in all situation and therefore he is experiencing that bliss in all situation. Sukham Atyantam Ashnute and he enjoys this Sukham, this happiness which is infinite. I have tried in my life all other things, but I never got it. Scripture says that Yogi who meditates and makes his mind steady. Just by that simple act of making the mind steady, he will be in touch with the Brahman.

The supreme reality will be freed from all his limitations. So the yogi has now experienced the supreme bliss. What would be his vision? Sarva Bhutastham Atmanam, Sarva Bhutani Cha Atmani, Ikshate Yoga Yuktatma Sarvatra Samadarshanah. Now, with his mind harmonized and in touch with the supreme reality, he starts seeing that same reality residing in all beings, and also seeing all beings residing in that supreme reality. We had seen this paradox before in Bhagavad Gita: is Bhagavan within me, or am I in Bhagavan? Is God within me, the limited being, or am I, the limited being, in the God-self which is unlimited?

Both are correct. It depends on your viewpoint. Is the room space in the universal space, or is the universal space in the room? When you see the room space as an individual space, it is nothing but part of the universal space. But when you see the space in the room as part of the universal space, that universal space is in the room. I, the limited being, am in the self of the Bhagavan who is manifesting and pervading everywhere. But when I look at it from my limited perspective, I see that I, the limited being, have the presence of Bhagavan in me.

So I start seeing that he is in all the beings. I also see that all the beings are in that supreme self. Icsate Yoga Yukta Tatma. Thus the Yogi who is one with the yoga, one, the Yogi who has become one with his Self, he sees this Sarvatra Samadarshanaha everywhere He sees that unity. He sees this presence of the Lord equally in all beings and things. Same Lord which resides in Me is also residing in everything else that manifests in this world.

Such a vision makes this yogi become one with this world, acting as if this world is nothing but his own extension. Yo mam pashyati sarvatra sarvam cha mayi pashyati, tasya aham na pranashyami sa cha me na pranashyati. Bhagavan now says: Yo mam pashyati sarvatra -- when Lord Krishna in Bhagavad Gita refers to himself in the first person singular, Swamiji points out every time that he is not speaking as Devaki's son or Yashoda's son, but referring to himself as the supreme being pervading everyone. The yogi who sees Me everywhere -- anything I see, I recognize as nothing but Bhagavan's manifestation. Sarvam cha mayi pashyati -- I also see God's presence in everything. Nothing could have been possible without His presence.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal a seeming paradox about sin and karma. If the law of karma says we must face consequences of all actions, how can meditation free us from all sins? The key distinction is that sins here are not the consequences but the impressions (vasanas) that drive future wrong actions. Seeing someone make money illegally creates an impression that this is how wealth is gained. That impression is the sin - it will prompt future wrong action. When meditation purifies these impressions, no new wrong actions arise. You may still face consequences of past actions, but you stop generating new problematic karma.

Verse 29 describes the vision of unity: "Sarva-bhuta-stham atmanam sarva-bhutani cha atmani" - seeing the Self in all beings and all beings in the Self. This is not poetic metaphor but literal description of realized experience. Just as the space in one room is the same space as in every room, and all rooms exist within infinite space, the consciousness in you is the same consciousness in all beings, and all beings exist within that one consciousness. The apparent diversity is real at one level, yet underlaid by absolute unity.

The beautiful promise of verse 30 - "Tasyaham na pranashyami sa cha me na pranashyati" - "I am never lost to him, nor is he ever lost to Me" - assures us that this relationship with the Supreme is mutual. Once you see the Divine everywhere, the Divine is always accessible to you; once the Divine recognizes you as its own, that bond can never break. Today, practice seeing the same life force - the same consciousness - in three very different beings: a family member, a stranger, and a plant or animal. Can you sense the common thread of awareness that animates all three?

snippets.title: Day 90: The Restless Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः |

आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
sarvabhūtasthitaṃ yo māṃ bhajatyekatvamāsthitaḥ .

ātmaupamyena sarvatra samaṃ paśyati yo.arjuna .

arjuna uvāca .
verseTranslations: The sage who realises the unity of life and who worships Me in all beings, lives in Me, whatever may be his lot.
O Arjuna! He is the perfect saint who, taught by the likeness within himself, sees the same Self everywhere, whether the outer form be pleasurable or painful.
Arjuna said: I do not see how I can attain this state of equanimity which Thou hast revealed, owing to the restlessness of my mind.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter six, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. In chapter two, Sankhya Yoga, we learned how to differentiate between the self and non self. Self is that which is Ajaha, which is unborn and imperishable. Nayanam Chindanti Sastrani Nayanam Dhati Pavaka. That which cannot be destroyed by anything, by weapons or fire or water or air. That's the definition of the self.

Anything which does not fit into the definition is non self. So everything which I consider myself today does not fit into that definition. I was born, I have a birth date and I may have a death date. And everything which I know about me and my possessions fall into the same category. So it all falls into non self. So my world is populated by non self only.

All that I consider myself so far as me is also non self. My body has a birth and death. My mind has beginning and end. My intellect has beginning and end. So everything that I associate myself and considered to be me is non self. So now the search for the self.

How do I find myself? So we have learned up to chapter five how to purify the mind and intellect. In other words, how to prepare yourself for this search for running a marathon. You first have to prepare for it the whole period of training. So the second chapter onward we had this clear instruction how to prepare your mind. So once that mind is prepared, which we call Yoga Rudha, one who is now prepared to take on this journey for the search of the self.

So chapter six we started that journey. How to find the journey once the mind is prepared. When it becomes sinless, that the word we constantly keep using in every language that you wash your sins. In other words, the mind is cleared of all the impurities. We learn the mind is nothing but the thought channels. A thought occurs, second thought follows that same thought.

Third thought now follows the second thought. It is now creating a channel. Those channels are created which has become my mind and it is all going outwards. I'm thinking about something other than me now the same Mind I have to turn towards me the self. So everything I have learned so far is about non self. All my education, all my contemplation on what is good and what is bad, all that is about non self.

So now I have to turn towards myself, the self. That's chapter six, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation -- how to prepare yourself and position yourself so that you can start that inward journey. We have seen the clear instruction that once you have prepared your mind and purified it of all the sins, you start this journey of Dhyana Yoga. Constantly doing that search, you will come to a point where you will find that bliss.

From verse 28 onward, it says the yogi is always engaging the mind: Yunjan evam sada atmanam yogi vigata kalmashah -- one who is freed of all sins.

In other words all the impurities of the mind. Mind which has tendency to see wrong things or going in a wrong direction that I have now adjusted the mind focuses on the right thing, clearly sees this is non self and searching for the Self that Sukena Brahma sans Parsam. Very easily it enjoys the contact with the Brahman. He easily can understand what the Self is. So clear goal here is to do inward search about what is the self is all about. When do I consider that my search has yield some results?

The next one is Sarva Bhuta Stamatmanam Sarva Bhutani Chaatmani. When I start seeing that self which I'm searching as the real self, not the non self is not only residing in me, but residing in all beings searching for myself. In tone I found the eternal self which is residing all beings and Sarva Bhutani Ch' Aatmani and I see the all beings are in the Self. My standard example, all the houses, all the buildings, I see the space. But then I also see that all the buildings are in the space because the space is all pervading. I was searching for the space for my own room once I realized the nature of the self.

I realized that space is the same in all the buildings in the world. And all the buildings are nothing but in that all pervading self. Once that awareness takes place, then I realize I am now truly understand what the nature of the space is. Space is not something which I create as an architect, not something I can buy from Lowe's or Home Depot. I can only buy material to condition my space. Space is universal and all pervading.

Once that understanding takes place about the self Bhagavan said he will say sarvatra samadharsanaha. Now he can see the equality everywhere. Now he sees the connectivity everywhere. Yomam pashyati sarvatra sarvam chamay pashati tasya ahamna pranasyami sachamena pranashati. So here comes basically an assurance. Is it something that one time I understand in meditation that I have suddenly and then next day I go to work and I forget all about it?

Once you have that understanding of all pervading self, that connection with yourself will never get broken, will never be separated. Once I understood the nature of the space, the space is all pervading. These are all conditioning. The buildings we create, the things which are in the space, then my understanding of the space will never go away, no matter what I'm doing. Yomam pashyati sarvatya. The one who sees me everywhere, Sarvamchyamay pashyati.

All the being, all the things, he sees me in it. Now, as Swamiji says, every time Krishna uses the word "me," he's referring to this supreme self. The big "I" is what he is referring to. The conditioned "I" is the small "I," as we call it, and the big "I" is the unconditioned "I." So when Krishna says "me," he's referring to the unconditioned "I," which is all-pervading.

Yoma M. Pasade sir, one who sees me in all things and all things in me. Because now there is no differentiation between the self and the non self. Even the non self was nothing but the part of this. If something is all pervading, there is no space left for anything else to exist. It's only I'm limited. There is a space for other people.

If I buy all the real estate in Richmond, can you buy anything else? No, there's no nothing left for you to buy. It's only when I leave out a parcel and say I don't want that, then you can come and buy. That when I have recognized myself is all pervading, there is nothing left for anything else to exist. But now I have a vision now of the equality in this plurality. So yomam pasyati sarvatra sarvam chamayi pasyati tasya ahamna pranayami.

For him I never get separated. Once that vision takes place, you are never separated from it. Once I wake up from my dream, I never get separated from the waker. Both dreamer and waker are now connected to the waker. Dreamer also remembers that I am the waker I was dreamer, now I am a waker. Same dreamer is now waker.

The waker knows "I am the waker who was dreaming." Having woken up, I don't go back to the dreaming state. Once I'm established in my waking state, I never get separated from it till I go to sleep again. Similarly, once that understanding takes place that myself is nothing but the all-pervading self, I never get separated from myself. The verse says "sa cha me na pranashyati" -- and now comes the assurance from the all-pervading Lord: I will never get separated from him.

That relationship is dual relationship. I have relationship with him and he has relationship with me. It is not a one-sided love. If I liked her, but she never knew I exist -- I say, "I will never leave you," but she says, "I don't even know that you exist."

I, the conditioned self has now recognized that I'm nothing but the manifestation of the me of the supreme self. The supreme self knows that I am not conditioned in this body mind. So this relationship is mutual relationship. Both exist in their own perspective. The supreme self exists from a perspective of the macrocosm. And my conditioned self exists in a perspective of the microcosm.

The room space exists as a. We can be meeting here on Sunday morning. If I say room space does not exist, only universal space exists. Go and meet in a Louis Ginter garden same as meeting here. No, we have to come here. This is where we meet.

It does exist, but it is nothing but the manifestation of this supreme space. In the same way, my conditioned self exists as an ego identifying with this conditioning. But it clearly knows that this is purely an identification with conditioning, for the convenience of transacting with other conditioned selves. So the next verse says: Sarva bhuta sthitam yo mam bhajati ekatvam asthitah. Once we've established ourselves in this unity, having seen what the self truly is -- my search was to understand: if this body is my non-self, this mind is my non-self, this intellect is my non-self, then what is myself? I found that the consciousness which is not conditioned by this body, mind, and intellect is myself. That's why in meditation the whole goal is to not be aware of your body, not be aware of your thoughts or your intellect. Because intellect can become a hindrance in understanding. The more I consider that I'm pretty smart, the more I do dumb things. The more I give up my idea about my intellectual superiority,

the more I learn about myself. So Bhagavan said, the one who is Ekatvam asthitah -- the one who is now established in the unity of all things -- has realized that my conditioning and your conditioning are very different. You are not me and I am not you. You have your own limitations, I have mine. But the essence which makes me who I am, and the essence of who you are, is one and the same.

The self in you and self in I is one and the same. That unity I have found. We constantly search commonness. We come across a new person. We don't try to find how different we are from each other. First thing we try to find what is common among us.

I say, I am from Richmond. Oh, I am also from Richmond. Okay, we have one commonness we found. Then we gradually say, okay. Where do you come from? Well, I come from Surat.

Oh, I'm also from Surat. More we find commonness, more we feel comfort. Then we are not worried as much about the differences which we have. The differences drop more common things. We find the people whom we love, all the negative things about them. We don't pay attention to our children, our grandchildren.

They are mischievous, laugh it off. We feel good about it. We say, how cute it is. Somebody else do that to you. Because we found something common. So the first search for every human being or every being is to find commonness among ourselves.

Once we find more things common, more identification occurs. First in the college I saw her. Then I found out she takes the same chemistry class I do common. Then I found out she comes from the same town I come from. More things I found common, more I identify with her.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 32 offers a profound standard: "Atmaupamyena sarvatra samam pashyati" - one who sees equality everywhere through the analogy of the self is the supreme yogi. What is this analogy? I know that I want happiness and freedom from suffering. Through self-examination, I recognize that this same desire motivates every other being. Thus I understand others by understanding myself. This becomes the basis for true compassion: I would never do to others what I would not want done to me, and I naturally wish for others what I wish for myself.

Then comes Arjuna's honest doubt in verse 33, which mirrors the doubt of every sincere seeker: "I do not see how this yoga of equanimity can be maintained, owing to the restlessness of my mind." This is not a lack of faith but clear-eyed self-assessment. Arjuna has listened to all the teachings about steady minds and seeing sameness everywhere, and his experience tells him: my mind is not like that. It constantly chases finer things - Marriott over Super 8, not Seven-Eleven coffee once a better brand is discovered. How can such a mind ever become stable?

The beauty of this passage is that Arjuna voices what we feel but may be too embarrassed to admit. His honesty opens the door for Krishna's practical response. Today, be equally honest with yourself. Where do you find the teachings beautiful but impractical? What specific aspect of your restless mind seems most untameable? Write it down. Naming the obstacle is the first step toward addressing it. Remember, Arjuna is not rejected for his doubt - he is answered with understanding and solutions.

snippets.title: Day 91: The Supreme Yogi
snippets.sanskrit:
चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद् दृढम् |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः |
snippets.transliteration:
cañcalaṃ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavad dṛḍham .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

asaṃyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti me matiḥ .
verseTranslations: My Lord! Verily, the mind is fickle and turbulent, obstinate and strong, yea extremely difficult as the wind to control.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Doubtless, O Mighty One, the mind is fickle and exceedingly difficult to restrain, but, O Son of Kunti, with practice and renunciation it can be done.
It is not possible to attain Self-Realisation if a man does not know how to control himself; but for him who, striving by proper means, learns such control, it is possible.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation and Contemplation. So far we have seen in chapter 6 that Bhagavan has emphasized the quiet mind. The basis of all the practices is the mind. As long as you can control the mind, you can become a yogi. Bhagavan had said Samatvam Yoga Uchyate -- equanimity is yoga. In this chapter he also says Duhkha Samyoga Viyoga is Yoga.

The detachment from the attachment to pain is Yoga. We have a natural attachment to pain; our mind goes towards pain more than it goes towards other things. Another way to look at it: detachment from all objects which have the potential to give me pain. This is what we try to do in life -- avoid all the dangers, protect ourselves from any potential danger. But if you can detach yourself from all potential dangers, which actually includes all sense objects in this world -- all sense objects have equal capacity to give me pleasure as they have the capacity to give me pain.

So therefore, if I really want to detach myself from all pains, all potential dangers of getting pain, I have to avoid all sense objects. So in verse 27, Bhagawan has concluded his teachings. Prasantamanasamhi enam yoginam Sukha Muthamam. That supreme bliss which I am seeking all my life. I am looking for permanent happiness. I don't want temporary happiness, I want permanent happiness.

Bhagawan saying that happiness is available to a yogi who has achieved this supremely quiet mind. Upeti Santarajasam Brahmabhutam or Kalmasam. Supreme bliss comes to this yogi whose mind is peaceful, whose patience are quietened and he does not have any rajas in Brahma Bhutam or Kalmasam. He has become sinless. There is no impurity on his mind. It has become Brahman Brahma Bhutam.

He recognizes that his own self, the ego, is none other than Brahman. This synchronization of the ego with Brahman is the ultimate goal -- to achieve that final state of supreme happiness, permanent bliss. But the basis of all that is prasantamana. It all boils down to whether I can have this mind completely quiet, completely under control. In verses 28 through 32, Bhagavan has described the yogi who has achieved this state of becoming Brahman. He sees that self in all beings and all beings in the self.

He will have both perspective at the same time that he sees that consciousness in me. But I'm also in the consciousness. Pot space is within the spot, but pot is in the space also. That dual perspective, if I can have simultaneously, I can synchronize these two perspectives. Bhagavan said that comes only when the Yogi has achieved this Siddhi of quietening the mind and becoming Brahman. He sees sameness everywhere.

He never gets separated from the self, the self never gets separated from him. Once the pot space realizes that the space outside me is no different, then the space within me never gets separated from the main space. When my ego recognizes that myself, the consciousness in me, is none other than the consciousness everywhere. So right now we cannot imagine that consciousness can be anything outside living beings. But Bhagavad Gita time and again tells us that consciousness is all pervading. We are all existing within the consciousness.

This world is created out of that supreme self. There is no other material was available to create this universe other than the self alone. And because that yogi has achieved this state, he sees sameness of the self in all beings. Now he has achieved a different reason. Our vision right now is to live in this world by identifying the differences. So the way we transact in this world is if I can detect differences, then I can differentiate things one from another.

Table is not chair, chair is not table. Because they will both look completely different from each other. Different characteristics. But I can also see probably the sameness if both are made up of wood. That sameness when a person sees, Swamiji very cleverly puts it in the biblical term of that that person. Now because this is the sameness, he loves others as he loves his own self.

I don't see any difference between doing something for me or doing something for others. It's basically one and the same thing. Now I also won't do anything to others which I don't want others to do to me because of the sameness that I detect in all things and beings. Up till now I was seeing only differences and that's how I lived my life. By detecting differences and protecting myself from what I don't find conducive and then engaging myself in what I find conducive. But now I don't say anything conducive or unconducive.

But sameness is my central vision. And Arjuna has been very quietly listening to this and he has come to the conclusion that the basis of all this is Prasantamanah supremely peaceful mind. And therefore he actually verbalize doubt we have in our mind while learning Bhagavad Gita whether it is at all possible. Arjunava Yoyam Yoga TV this yoga that you just described which can be achieved only by quiet mind. Samyana Madhusudana of the sameness that you have described. The the yoga which you described which requires that I see sameness in everything and every being.

We discussed the importance of the words used in our scriptures. All the names used for Krishna or Arjuna are strategically placed. Madhusudana -- the slayer of the demon Madhu. In this life, we get attracted to things which are sweet for us, things which are nice and comfortable. But attraction in the end creates all my sorrows. If I don't get attracted to them in the first place, I won't have the problems they are capable of giving me.

Krishna as Madhusudana is the remover, the destroyer of this attraction to comfortable, pleasant things. But Arjuna says, "I don't see that happening. My mind always goes to finer things in life. I find Marriott is better, so I stay at Marriott, not at Super 8. This is the nature of my mind."

My mind always gravitates towards finer things and avoids painful, uncomfortable situations. I don't think that's going to change, because the very nature of the mind is ever-changing. The mind constantly flows in various directions, following whatever the sense organs report to it. For example, when I was only experiencing Seven-Eleven's coffee, my mind was satisfied with Seven-Eleven's coffee. I remember when we used to practice bhajans in our youth group, we'd invite a violin player named Subhas. As soon as he arrived, we had to send somebody to get his coffee from Seven-Eleven. We couldn't offer him coffee at home -- "Oh yeah, Subhas is here, go get his coffee from Seven-Eleven." Because for him 7 limits coffee was ultimate. The mind is chanchala -- as long as it has not experienced something better, it may stick to this. But as soon as it finds something better, it's going to move on to the next thing and then the next thing. Chanchalatva sthitim sthiram -- therefore I do not see this as a long-lasting situation, even if I practice everything that you taught me in this chapter about meditation.

Find a quiet place, sit down comfortably and focus on one point. Then once I focus on one point, if your mind runs away, bring it back. I may do it for 10 minutes, 20 minutes, 30 minutes. But what is after that? After that my mind is going to do exactly what it was doing before I sat down from meditation. So therefore, O Krishna, this is wonderful discourse.

But I don't think this is possible to achieve that permanent steadiness Prasantha Manasam which you have described in verse 27. This is a very bold and daring question because he's directly telling Krishna that this teaching is not practical. "It sounds very good, it has good aesthetics, it's pleasant to hear. But I don't see how to apply it in my life. I know how my mind works, and it's not going to stay in one place as you require."

I think every one of us without exception feels exactly the same. We practice meditation -- how many minutes? We count meditation in minutes! But Bhagavan said it has to be a permanent situation. Your mind should be steady all the time. Chanchalam hi manah Krishna, pramathi, balavad dridham -- he said, "I'm not giving you this argument just to make an argument."

"But I know the nature of the mind, my mind at least. Chanchalam hi manah Krishna -- this mind is always going in different directions. Pramathi -- it's very turbulent. Balavad dridham -- very strong and firm. Once my mind gets attached to an object, it's very difficult to remove it. If I start thinking about drinking coffee, I won't be able to concentrate on what I'm doing till I get a cup of coffee."

Because the mind is very strong. I have to get up and get a cup of coffee. You know, I can focus on whatever I was doing before. Then I put the coffee in that warmer I keep on my desk. Then I'll forget about it. After an hour I realized that I got up, went and got a cup of coffee.

The coffee was not really needed because I didn't even remember to drink it. But at that time the mind was so attached to the coffee that I had to go get a cup. Swamiji explains here that the word Krishna comes from the root Krish, which means to uproot. Krishna is the one who uproots all these attachments from my mind. So Bhagavan Ved Vyasa very strategically placed this name. Arjuna has not addressed Krishna as Krishna casually.

Chanchalam hi manah Krishna -- this mind is not only all over the place and going everywhere, but it's very turbulent, very difficult to control. And dridham -- when it gets attached to something, it's very difficult to disengage it. Vayoh iva su-dushkaram -- not just dushkaram (difficult), but su-dushkaram (very difficult). I consider control of this mind as difficult as controlling the wind. Right now we have a prediction of a hurricane hitting the upper east coast. All you can do is get out of its way.

There is nothing you can say will prevent the hurricane from hitting New York or Long island. Divert it towards the sea. None of that is in our power even though we are super power. Only thing you can do is get out of its way. So this mind is as difficult to control as wind. And therefore, O Krishna, I don't think it is possible.

Even if I control my mind temporarily, permanently it is not possible. Therefore this yoga is not practical." Bhagavan then answers this question. We can learn a technique of how to win an argument. If we are debating or negotiating and somebody makes a point, and you flatly reject it, that person will become even firmer in his opinion.

He'll say, "I don't agree with you," and that will continue. Nobody will win. So Bhagavan first agrees with Arjuna. He said, "You are right." The first thing you do is agree with your opponent. "No doubt, you are not wrong, Arjuna."

You are not making argument just for the sake of making an argument. But your argument is very, very valid. That mind is difficult to control. This is a very commonly known fact. Mind is not easy to control.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna's description of the mind in verse 34 is vivid and relatable: "Chanchalam hi manah Krishna pramathi balavad dridham" - the mind is restless, turbulent, strong, and obstinate. Once attached to an object, it clings stubbornly. You must get up for coffee, even if you forget to drink it afterward. Controlling such a mind seems "vayoriva su-dushkaram" - as difficult as controlling the wind. When hurricanes approach, all our technology is helpless; we can only step aside. Is the mind equally untameable?

Krishna's response in verse 35 is masterful. First, he agrees completely - "Asamshayam mahabaho mano durnigraham chalam" - without doubt, the mind is difficult to control. This is wise counsel for any disagreement: acknowledge the valid point before offering a different perspective. Then comes the prescription: "Abhyasena tu Kaunteya vairagyena cha grihyate" - through practice (abhyasa) and dispassion (vairagya), it can be mastered. Like circus animals trained to perform remarkable feats, like wild waters tamed by a dam to generate power, the very energy that makes the mind turbulent can be harnessed for spiritual awakening.

Verse 36 offers realistic assessment: "Asamyatatmana yogo dushprapa" - yoga is difficult for one with an uncontrolled self. But "vashyatmana tu yatata shakyo'vaptum" - for one who strives with a controlled self, using proper methods, it is attainable. The key is not extraordinary ability but consistent effort with the right approach. Today, choose one area where your mind is habitually uncontrolled - perhaps checking your phone, perhaps negative self-talk - and apply both abhyasa (repeatedly redirecting attention) and vairagya (reducing the pull of that habit). Small victories build the confidence that larger mastery is possible.

अर्जुन उवाच |

कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति |

एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

kaccinnobhayavibhraṣṭaśchinnābhramiva naśyati .

etanme saṃśayaṃ kṛṣṇa chettumarhasyaśeṣataḥ .
verseTranslations: Arjuna asked: He who fails to control himself, whose mind falls from spiritual contemplation, who attains not perfection but retains his faith, what of him, my Lord?
snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

 6.39 My Lord! Thou art worthy to solve this doubt once and for all; save Thyself there is no one competent to do so.

So we had been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. And obviously this is the conclusion of all the discussion we had about ourselves, who we are, what we consider ourselves to be, what we should be considering ourselves to be and how to get there. Right now I'm identified with this limited being called me, my body, mind and intellect. Chapter two said, your goal is to identify with the one which is imperishable. snippets.reflection:
Arjuna's question in these verses voices a universal anxiety: What if I try sincerely but fail? "Ayatih shraddhayopeto yogac chalita-manasah" - one who has faith and makes effort, yet whose mind wanders from yoga, "aprapya yoga-samsiddhim kam gatim Krishna gacchati" - failing to attain perfection, what becomes of him? This is not lack of faith but honest fear. Life is short, time runs out, and we know our minds are not fully under control.

The powerful metaphor of the torn cloud (chinnabhram) expresses this fear vividly: like a cloud broken apart by wind, neither giving rain nor rejoining the sky, does the unsuccessful yogi get destroyed, having gained neither worldly success nor spiritual perfection? "Ubhaya-vibhrashta" - fallen from both paths. This is the fundamental dilemma many face: if I pursue spirituality seriously, I may neglect my worldly duties and fail there; if I focus on the world, I make no spiritual progress. Can I afford to do both halfway?

The urgency of this question reflects real-life experience. Friends on both sides offer the same advice: "If you put as much time into business as you do into Gita classes, you'd be wealthy" or "If you put as much time into practice as you do into your profession, you'd be realized." Neither side seems wrong. Today, sit with this genuine question without rushing to answers: What is your deepest fear about the spiritual path? That you'll waste time? That you'll fail at both worldly and spiritual life? Articulating the fear clearly is the first step toward receiving Krishna's reassuring answer in the next verses.

snippets.reflection:
Krishna's response in verse 40 is profoundly reassuring: "Partha naiveha namutra vinashas tasya vidyate" - My dear child, there is no destruction for this person, either in this world or the next. "Na hi kalyana-krit kashchid durgatim tata gacchati" - one who does good never comes to grief. This is a universal guarantee: sincere spiritual effort is never wasted. Even if you do not reach the goal in this lifetime, the progress you make is preserved and continued.

The mechanism is explained in verses 41-42: the yoga-bhrashta (one fallen from yoga) either takes birth in a pure and prosperous family where conditions support continued practice, or - even more rarely - in a family of wise yogis where spiritual progress can resume immediately. The second birth is described as "durlabhataram" - more difficult to obtain. This reveals the value of being born into a spiritually oriented family; such a birth is the result of significant previous effort.

The concept of spiritual bank balance is illuminating. If you retire and move to another country, your wealth comes with you. Similarly, the development of your inner instrument - the purification of mind and intellect, the wisdom gained, the vasanas refined - transfers to your next life. This is why child prodigies exist: mathematical geniuses and musical virtuosos are not accidents but continuations of development from previous lives. Today, take comfort in this assurance. Every moment of sincere practice, every genuine attempt to control the mind, every act of selfless service is deposited in an account that can never be lost. What investment could be more secure?

snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation and we are coming to the conclusion of this chapter. We are also coming to the conclusion of the first segment of Bhagavad Gita. As we had discussed many times before, Bhagavad Gita is divided into three segments. First six chapters deal with who I am at this limited being as an individual. Next six chapters will deal with who that ultimate reality is. The last three chapters will deal with how you can synchronize these two.

So we are coming to the end of the first segment of Bhagavad Gita and what we have learned so far is in the chapter one we have learnt about our own situation, that our situation is not clear cut in life. Things don't come in life as clear as black and white. It comes in various shades of gray. That was the first chapter, Arjuna Vishada Yoga that confuses us. Chapter two gave us a thumbnail sketch the entire knowledge of Bhagavad Gita, Upanishada and Brahma Sutra. What is reality and what is perceived to be my reality?

Right now I consider myself to be mortal. I had a beginning and I'll have an end. And the elder Bhagwan said, your self is imperishable, immutable. We have come to this stage by passing through many, many experiences in different states of existence. Chapters three through five gave us instruction on how to optimize our performance in this life using the equipment we have -- dealing with the cards we are dealt.

How do you optimize your game? That was the topic of chapter third through fifth. And chapter six gave us the instruction how to now raise your plateau. I'm comfortable dealing in this sphere. How do I now go a step above that? You may be a local level politician going through the school board elections.

Then I want to do at the state level. Then I want to do at a national level. Well, how do I raise my plateau is the topic of chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga Yoga of meditation. All my focus right now is this body, this mind, this intellect and this world. Now how do I conduct transaction in this world and how do I optimize it? That's what we have learned.

Chapter six is, now that you have learned how to optimize your performance in this world, go to the next level of finding out what is the real nature of the self is there was meditation. We have learned in this process that there are two ways to get there. The one who gives up the fruits of actions is a Karma Yogi. The one who gives up the sense of agency -- "I am the doer" -- is a Sannyasi. Both reach the same goal of realizing the truth, the self. That changes my identification from this limited being to that unlimited self.

So we have elaborate discussion about how to meditate. And then we have come to the last portion of it where Arjuna had two doubts. First is we are talking about controlling our mind. My experience so far is mind is so fickle. Controlling it doesn't seem like an achievable goal. And Bhagavan said it can be done by Abhyasa in Vairagya, by constant practice, by forming a habit.

Once you form a habit, it becomes very easy, automatic. So that's Abhyasa and Vairagya. To form a habit in one sphere, you have to undo your habits in the other sphere -- that is Vairagya. You have to give up what you are attached to right now in order to do something else. Then Arjuna had the second doubt: "I sincerely try all these things, but then I run out of time."

Then what happens to all my efforts? Will that be all in vain? That I have lost on both hands? That I have not enjoyed my life here in the material world? And also I'm not making any progress in my spiritual evolution. In response to that, we have seen that the concept of reincarnation was reintroduced in this chapter.

Where I am today is the sum total of all my experiences before. What I'm doing with my total experiences now in my present today, that will make my future. This life is a continuum. This existence is a continuum. Whether I exist in this form or the other. When I was born, I was a baby.

I existed as a baby for a while, then as a teenager, then as a young man. But I exist all through this. So will you exist in your future state of existence we call a rebirth. And there he gives us assurance. Fruits of all your efforts will be with you. You will carry your bank balance.

If I retire from my practice here and leave the United States and go to India, what will happen to all my bank balance? It will come with you. It will be transferable. You can convert it into rupees. So all that we have done will come with us in our next life. That's the assurance.

So the last few verses which you have seen say that the Yogi who had been striving to achieve this but cannot come see, falls from his path for whatever reason, runs out of time, get distracted. He said then he will get a place in his next birthday in a conducive environment. Suchinam srimatam Gehei. He will take birth in the house of a pure and wealthy. So he will have conducive environment to pursue his path. This is what he will then go and fulfill all his desires.

Bhagavan guarantees that all your desires will be fulfilled sooner or later. As long as you have a strong desire to achieve something, to experience something, you will achieve it sooner or later. Most of the things I wanted to do in my 20s, I finally got it in 60s. So it takes that much time. But you will be the assurance is all your desires will be fulfilled. You will have time to exhaust them.

Then continue pursuing your path again. That if the Yogi had some desires left to pursue, but those who have no desire, they purely in the path of this yoga, but ran out of time. He said they will take birth in a home of a yogi where the utmost was conducive for him to start his journey right away, to continue on his path. And then the last few verses talks about what will happen once you take that next birth. Tatratam buddhi sahyogam labate Parva DEI kam. Parva dehikam in the last life, the knowledge which you have gathered through your efforts in yoga, in meditation, in a Karma yoga, whatever practice you have done.

This is also true for all our secular efforts. That's why we have talked about child prodigies, musical geniuses, mathematical geniuses. Our culture doesn't consider these an accident or random happening. It's a systematic evolution of that intellect to come to that point. Verse 43 describes what happens after a spiritually inclined person takes a new birth: "Tatra tam buddhi-samyogam labhate paurva-dehikam" - there, that person regains connection with the intelligence developed in the previous body. This explains the phenomenon we see: some people are inexplicably drawn to spiritual seeking from early childhood, while others with every advantage show no such inclination. The draw comes from within - from previous development - not from external circumstances alone.

The remarkable statement in verse 44 - "Purvaabhyasena tenaiva hriyate hy avasho'pi sah" - emphasizes that one is carried forward by previous practice, even against one's conscious will. Parents feared their son would lose his culture in a foreign land, but instead, more Gita classes flourish in America than in India. A father visiting from abroad, speaking little English, spontaneously finds friends who play Tinpathi because that is his vasana seeking expression. Your deeper tendencies will find their outlet regardless of external circumstances.

Verse 45 gives the long view: "Aneka-janma-samsiddhas tato yati param gatim" - perfected through many births, one finally reaches the supreme goal. This is not discouraging but realistic. We would not expect to master any great skill in a single attempt; why expect instant enlightenment? Today, reflect on your own spiritual tendencies. What aspects of the practice feel natural, as if you are remembering rather than learning? What draws you to these teachings? Trust that these inclinations are not random but reflect your soul's ongoing journey. Continue practicing with faith that nothing is lost and everything contributes to eventual attainment.

snippets.reflection:
As Chapter 6 concludes, Krishna offers a clear hierarchy in verse 46: the yogi is greater than the ascetic (tapasvi), greater than the scholar (jnani), and greater than the ritualist (karmi). This is not to demean any path, but to clarify that integrated spiritual practice - yoga in its full sense - surpasses partial approaches. One can torture the body without purifying the mind; one can accumulate knowledge without transforming behavior; one can perform elaborate rituals without developing inner awareness. The yogi combines right understanding with sustained practice and integration into daily life.

The final verse offers the ultimate teaching: "Yoginam api sarvesham mad-gatenantaratmana, shraddhaavan bhajate yo mam sa me yuktatamo matah" - of all yogis, the one who worships Me with faith, with the inner self absorbed in Me, is the most united with Me. This devotional culmination may seem surprising after detailed meditation instructions, but it reveals that the highest yoga is not merely technique but relationship. The peak of practice is not achieving a state but becoming intimate with the Divine.

These verses conclude the first section of the Bhagavad Gita - the six chapters exploring "who am I?" You have learned about your confusion (Chapter 1), your true nature (Chapter 2), the path of selfless action (Chapter 3), the means of purification (Chapter 4), the yoga of renunciation (Chapter 5), and now the yoga of meditation (Chapter 6). The next six chapters will explore "who is That?" - the nature of the Divine reality. But before moving on, let the teaching of these final verses sink in: become a yogi, and among yogis, become one whose heart is absorbed in the Supreme. What single practice can you commit to that integrates all you have learned in these first six chapters?

snippets.title: Day 96: Knowledge of the Divine
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः |

मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

jñānaṃ te.ahaṃ savijñānamidaṃ vakṣyāmyaśeṣataḥ .

manuṣyāṇāṃ sahasreṣu kaścidyatati siddhaye .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: Listen, O Arjuna! And I will tell thee how thou shalt know Me in my Full perfection, practising meditation with thy mind devoted to Me, and having Me for thy refuge.
I will reveal this knowledge unto thee, and how it may be realised; which, once accomplished, there remains nothing else worth having in this life.
Among thousands of men scarcely one strives for perfection, and even amongst those who gain occult powers, perchance but one knows me in truth.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions on how to live. We experience life's vicissitudes without a so-called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We have seen that the first six chapters described Jivatma, the conditioned self. The science which we are interested in is that of the self. What is the nature of my being?

That's the quest in learning Bhagavad Gita. The self -- in Sanskrit, Atma -- is what I'm trying to figure out. The first six chapters taught me what the conditioned self is called: Jivatma, what you and I call "myself."

This is me, this myself, this is yourself. That self is conditioned by my perception of who I am. The "I" that refers to my body, my mind, my intellect, and all the things I have achieved -- that's Jivatma in Vedanta. It is nothing but a conditioned self.

Conditioned by this body, mind, and intellect. Just as room space is space, just like the space outside -- but I call it "room space" because it's conditioned by the room. The room is made up of four walls, a floor, and a ceiling. If you take one of those away, it's no longer a room, but the space itself remains. Space was always here.

I created the conditioning. Now I call it room space. Similarly, I created the conditioning called "me" -- this body, this mind, this intellect -- and they called it Jiva Atma. Every conditioned being is a Jivatma. Who that is, we have discussed in detail in the first six chapters: who I am, how I act in this world, what the consequences of my actions are, and how I can avoid sorrow and unhappiness.

Karma Yoga culminated in meditation -- what some may call Raja Yoga. We started with Karma Yoga, then graduated to Dhyana Yoga, the yoga of meditation. Now we need to know: where do I go from here? I understood what Jivatma is. I need to now understand who Paramatma is.

Supreme self, space, room space, universal space -- I understood what the room space is, but my mind right now can't grasp what the universal space is. So I now need to graduate from room space to understanding the universal space. For that, I first start with understanding the conditioned self, the Jivatma, and then move toward the Paramatma, the supreme self. The next six chapters will tell us about Ishvara, the Lord Almighty, who is the creator of this universe and who is in control of all the Jivatmas.

All Jivatmas are functioning because of Ishwara, just as all room spaces in all the rooms in the world exist because of universal space. But right now I only understand the conditioned self. From Jivatma, I'm migrating to Paramatma. I may not understand Him in His essence, so I now need to come down to one level below -- to Him as the creator.

Him as the controller of all the beings -- that is whom we call Ishvara. My friends who know me may not know me as an architect, but my clients know me as one. They can only understand me through the relationship they have with me. I am the creation of the Creator. If I can understand my relationship with Him -- the creation and the Creator -- that's easier than finding out who He is in all His entirety.

So we'll start with Ishvara, the one who created this universe as I can perceive, feel, and touch it -- which is called Prakriti in Sanskrit. The one who is in control of the Prakriti is Purusha. The next six chapters will explore that. And it has to culminate into devotion for that Paramatma. For me to know someone in his or her entirety, I need to identify with him or her.

That identification becomes love. For me to know Paramatma, I need to devote myself to Paramatma. I need to start identifying with that Paramatma. That identification will become devotion. So these six chapters will culminate into 12th chapter Bhakti Yoga, the yoga of devotion. We started with Karma Yoga.

We graduated to Raja Yoga. We're now marching towards Bhakti Yoga, the yoga of devotion. So these first three verses -- Bhagavan, in the last verse of the previous chapter, set up the stage and said: the one who wants to know yoga, even out of just curiosity -- "I really want to know what yoga is all about" -- he's better than the Karma Kandi, the one who is simply doing rituals.

I'm a very religious person. I need to have my business run properly by Bhagavan's grace. Early morning, before I go to my job, I need to do the puja as quickly as I can. Before 8 o'clock, I do puja and run. I'm done with Bhagavan today.

Then I say, well, now things are getting even more hectic. I actually asked somebody in India, and I said, "What about puja?" He said, "I just go online and I have this website. You click on Ganpati Puja, the Ganpati Murti comes in, there is agarbatti on the side. You click on the agarbatti, it lights up. You click on the lamp, the lamp lights up. You click on the garland, garland comes on. You click on the aarti -- I can do it anywhere now. It's very, very easy."

So we say that's Karmakanda -- just performing rituals mechanically. "I decided that I have to do this to be on the good side of the Lord" -- that is a Karma Kandi. Bhagavan said, even one who merely wants to know yoga is better than a Karma Kandi. I may not have any interest in performing yoga, but if I want to know what yoga is, I'm at least better than that.

Then obviously, the yogi is said to be better than a Gnani, a Tapasvi, or even a Sanyasi. Because the yogi is the one who has given up everything in terms of the fruits of actions and is relying on the Lord to give him the Karma Phala. "I'll do my duty as His vehicle. I'm just a Nimitta Matra." My actions are there because I'm empowered by the Lord to do this. I can speak because I'm alive.

I'm alive because the consciousness is still functioning through this body. That consciousness belongs to the Supreme Consciousness. You and I are conscious of each other because the same consciousness functioning through me is functioning through you. If you had two incompatible programs, we wouldn't be talking to each other. Two computers don't talk to each other if one is on Windows and the other on a different system.

But we can, because the same consciousness is functioning through you and me. So Bhagawan said, the one who has given up his sense of "I am in control" and surrendered -- he's a yogi, and he's better than all of that. Now Bhagavan says Arjuna is all charged up and wants to know. The seventh chapter continues as Gnana Vignana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. So what is the difference?

We obviously had a discussion last time. Something which I know is Gnana. Something which I do not know is obviously ignorance. Then Vignana -- Visheshta Gnana -- is special knowledge.

Normal knowledge is: I know you people are in the room. That's knowledge because I can see it and vouch for it. The knowledge which I can perceive, feel, and touch through my senses is Gnana. But when we process that knowledge and come to another conclusion, that is Vignana. So the Swami Chidananda Bhagavad Gita which I have here --

It basically says Gnana requires sight -- in other words, the senses. Vignana is insight. Gnana requires tuition: for me to learn Bhagavad Gita, I had to go to Swami Chinmayananda.

Sight requires tuition. But the knowledge of what I learned requires intuition. Music is the one which I really understand well because I have a lot of difficulty learning that. I went to my teacher to learn that and he will say, Neel, do this sargam. You know, Subha says, it's too difficult. I know how to sing song.

I said, no, no, you need to do this sargam. And while I was doing it, it was so difficult. And then he told me that one day it will come naturally to you and you yourself will understand how to do it. And I didn't believe him. But it did happen exactly that way. Things which I couldn't learn while he was teaching me, but I know what to do came naturally to me.

At one point, when I was trying to practice it, I didn't need to make any effort to figure out what it is -- because it became my own knowledge. Intuitively, I knew what it was. I asked my nephew, who has been a prodigy since he was about six years old -- he can do any music he wants. I asked him, "Advaita, teach me how to do this."

He said, uncle, I don't know how to teach you. I myself do not know how I'm doing it. I just know how to do it. So the vignana is the intuitive knowledge. Once you gather the knowledge and absorbed it as your own, intuitively you use it for its right application is vignana. So Bhagavan says, sometimes it's translated as wisdom.

Wisdom is not something you sit down and decide to do. Wisdom is when somebody says something and you know what to do with it. It's an intuitive knowledge born out of the knowledge and experiences you have accumulated. And that wisdom you cannot claim as your own, because something in you has the ability to grasp that knowledge. When you're alive, you can do it. When you're dead, you can't be conscious of it.

Your consciousness is that entity which is the source of intuition. So Bhagavan said, "I will tell you now." Yogam yunjan, mad ashrayha, asansayam samagram mam, yatha jnasyasi tat shrunu. This is a promise to all beings who really want to know who they are. He said, "Now listen carefully, O Partha, because I'll tell you what the knowledge and the wisdom is." But here are the prerequisites.

With your mind clinging to me, taking refuge in me, and practicing Yoga, you will without any doubt know me in full. Three things. Bhagavan said, "I'm going to tell you what you need to know, but your mind should be focused on me." If I want to learn something, I obviously need to be focused on that.

I want to find out how my BlackBerry works -- I need to be focused on it. I still can't use all the features on my BlackBerry because I'm not focused enough.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna opens this chapter with three prerequisites for knowing the Divine: a mind clinging to the Supreme (mayyasaktamanah), taking refuge in Him (madasrayah), and practicing yoga (yogam yunjan). Today, examine which of these three areas needs your attention most. Is your mind scattered across countless worldly concerns, rarely resting on the deeper questions of existence? Do you truly take refuge in a higher purpose, or do you rely solely on your own limited efforts? How consistent is your actual practice of meditation and self-inquiry?

Consider Krishna's sobering statement that among thousands of people, scarcely one strives for perfection, and even among those who strive, few truly know Him in essence. This is not meant to discourage but to inspire urgency. Ask yourself: Am I among those rare seekers who genuinely pursue self-knowledge, or am I content with surface-level spirituality? The distinction between Jnana (knowledge gained through study) and Vijnana (wisdom through direct realization) is crucial here. Today, take one teaching you intellectually understand and consciously apply it in a difficult situation. Notice the gap between knowing and being.

What would it mean to move from tuition to intuition in your spiritual life? Just as a musician eventually plays without conscious effort, how might you internalize these teachings so deeply that right understanding becomes spontaneous?
