verseTranslations: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect and personality; this is the eightfold division of My Manifested Nature.
This is My inferior Nature; but distinct from this, O Valiant One, know thou that my Superior Nature is the very Life which sustains the universe.
It is the womb of all being; for I am He by Whom the worlds were created and shall be dissolved.
snippets.commentary:
Chapter 7, Gnana Vignana Yoga -- the Yoga of Knowledge and its Application, or Realization, or Wisdom. Whichever way we define the word Vignana: Vishishta Gnana, special knowledge. Knowledge becomes special when we apply it, so the application of knowledge is Vignana. At the end of the last chapter, Bhagawan gave a hint about what we'll be discussing here. He said that among the yogis, the one whose inner self merges with me and who worships me with faith is the greatest Yogi. First of all, in the last six chapters, Bhagawan told Arjuna to become a Yogi -- Sarva Sankalpa Sanyasi, Yoga Rudha Uchyati.

One who is completely devoid of all Sankalpa -- all fancies of the mind about what can give me happiness and where my happiness lies -- such a person is a yogi. So the advice from Bhagavan to Arjuna and all of us was: become a Yogi so that you can remove this parallax between "Tat" and "Tvam." In our understanding of "myself," I am this limited being -- this consciousness confined in this body, mind, and intellect is me. But Bhagavan says your consciousness is no different than the supreme Consciousness, which is all pervading. That parallax I have to remove. I see these two selves -- myself and the supreme Self. How do I remove this parallax and make them one? That is the goal.

So Bhagwan said to meditate on the supreme self. Right now we are meditating on the limited self. We are constantly in the state of Samadhi identifying with this limited being, and therefore I am in love with it. Everything I do, everything I accomplish, I am very proud of it. So Bhagawan said, that's because you are in constant Samadhi with this limited self. You now have to contemplate on your supreme self, which is God, Brahman, the Ishvara, whatever the name we give him.

The problem is we really have no idea about what that self is all about. We've heard about it; we have been given indications by Bhagavan in the second chapter. But how can I devote myself to it? To devote myself, I have to have devotion. Devotion is nothing but love for the Divine. And love is nothing but identification.

Identification only comes when I have complete understanding or knowledge about that thing or being. The more I know about that thing or being, the more I identify with it or him or her, and the more I love that person or thing or being. So to love the Divine, to devote myself to the Divine, I need to know the nature of that Divine. Bhagawan has devoted the entire Chapter 7 to this. For those who have reached that state of desire, Mumukshatvam -- I need to be one with that -- Bhagawan has given in the first three verses an introduction. These are the three qualities you are going to require to achieve this: Mind should be in love with me. Asakta -- who has the attachment, so mind should be attached to him.

The supreme -- here Bhagwan means the Supreme. Yogam yunjan -- who has become a Yogi, as has been described in the previous chapters. Sarvasankalpa Sanyasi. And Mat Ashrayaha -- who is taking refuge only in me, who knows that his liberation, his ultimate happiness lies in identifying with that Brahman only. There is no other source of long-lasting, everlasting happiness. All other things can give me temporary joy but not long-lasting happiness. Asansayam, without doubt I will tell you how you can achieve that. Bhagawan had given this indication, and the very first indication he gives us is where to find him in this world. We never see Bhagavan, never come across him in my transactions anywhere.

Where is he and what is he? This is the first verse each seeker can relate to and contemplate. Bhagawan said, you see me every day. Everything that you see, hear, touch, smell through your senses is nothing but me. Everything in this world is made up of these five great elements. But these five great elements do not create any experience unless there is a knower.

So to create the sense objects out of these five great elements, you need a Knower. And the knower is Manas, Buddhi, Ahankar. These five great elements create the sense objects, which are the knowables. The three -- Manas, Buddhi, Ahankar -- create the Knower, that which will know the sense objects. So corresponding to these five great elements, we have the five sense objects: Shabda, Sparsha, Rupa, Rasa, Gandha. But they all reside in my mind.

We know from physics that particles and atoms do not have color, shape, or smell on their own. But we see colors and smell fragrances. So this mind is the knower -- it creates the sense objects to enjoy. Iti me bhinna prakriti ashtadha. This world of knowables and knower, and the experiences and exchanges between them, creates this lower Prakriti, the Eightfold Prakriti of mine. So know that anything which you see, anything which you touch, anything which you hear, is nothing but me alone -- my manifestation only.

This is the very first exercise. One can do that every time he sees, he should remember that it is nothing but his manifestation and nothing. There is no other thing. And then he says, apara ayam ITI to anyam prakruti vidhi me param. So we may come to the conclusion. If I put all the things in this world together, then that's Bhagavan Bhagawan.

It is like if I have all the parts of Tesla in boxes or I can put a Tesla together. You need something else to make Tesla what Tesla is. So it says, apara ayam itutu annyam prakrutim vidhi me param. This is my lower Prakriti. Lower Prakrutin is the grosser manifestation. It is something which can be perceived by senses.

These five elements which we have described, I can perceive through my senses. Now the scientists may say, "Oh no, Neil, they were not knowledgeable enough. There are more than 100 elements." But these elements are related to sense perception. Space is the subtlest because we can only hear through space -- there is no other perception of space.

But Bhoomi is the grossest because it can have all five perceptions: Sabdha, Sparsa, Rupa, Rasa, Gandha. Bhumi has all five of them. Space is only one, Sabdha, and so on and so forth. So the more sense perception, the grosser the element is. Bhagwan said, this is my lower Prakriti which can be known through your senses.

Jivabhuta Mahabhaho yaya idam dharyate jagat. But by which this world is upheld -- this entire universe is sustained by that element -- that is my higher Prakriti. Viddhi me param: know that there is a higher Prakriti of mine which is sustaining both the knower and the knowable. The knower -- the mind, Buddhi, intellect -- and the sense objects are only possible if there is life in that knower, a living force.

That living force is something completely different than mind, completely different than intellect and the world of perception. Etad yonini bhutani sarvani iti upadharaya. This is the womb of all beings. These two prakritis -- the lower which is perceptible through my eyes and ears, and now we have additional means to perceive this world, like the telescope and the microscope.

So we have expanded our senses by adding those instruments. But no matter how far we can go, we will never be able to perceive anything without consciousness itself. Even a scientist who knows all about electrons and quarks -- the fundamental building blocks, at least as we know them -- can only know if he is conscious. Etad yonini bhutani sarvani iti upadharaya. These two prakritis together are the womb of all beings: the lower Prakriti, which is manifest and can be perceived through the senses and understood by the intellect; and the para, which is unmanifest. I do not know what the life force is all about. I do not know what consciousness is.

I know I am conscious. I am aware that I exist, but I cannot define it. No science has yet successfully defined consciousness. Being unmanifest, it cannot be described. This indescribable consciousness and the world of matter together constitute the womb of all things and beings, no matter what they are. Aham krtsnasya jagatah prabhavah pralayastatha. Now Bhagavan says, "I am actually slightly different than these two."

I'm not just the lower Prakriti. I'm not just the higher Prakriti, the womb of all beings. I am the source of both. I am the source of both the Prakritis -- the para and apara. Aham krtsnasya jagatah prabhavah pralayah. All knowables and knowers come out of me. They also merge in me.

It is something like the entire world of my dream coming out of my own mind, and also dissolving into my own mind. When I wake up, the dream world is gone. None of the knowers or knowables in my dream remain, because the mind is something higher than both. Bhagawan says, "I am the Brahman which projects itself as the Ishvara through Maya, which creates Prakriti and also creates the mind, Buddhi, and Ahankar." Know that I'm higher than both the para and apara Prakriti, and I am the substratum for the creation and dissolution of this universe.

In our science we know everything about Big Bang. And up to the few seconds after the Big Bang, we just do not know what was the singularity and what was before the Big Bang. That we probably will never know, at least in our lifetime. The Bhagavan said, you can know everything about your Buddhi. But beyond Buddhi it is very difficult to know. Matthaha parataram na anyat kinchi dasti dhananjaya.

That which is the source of both this world of my experiences and the experiencer -- there is nothing more than that. That which has created this life in me, that which I feel as myself -- there is nothing beyond that. In other words, there is nothing subtler than that. The grosser the element, the easier I can perceive it. The subtler it is, the more difficult it is for me. Then it comes to a point where it is imperceptible.

There is nothing subtler than that self, life itself, consciousness itself. This is obviously a very famous verse, a milestone verse: this consciousness, this entity which cannot be described, cannot be perceived, cannot be thought of, is the source of all things and beings. All things and beings are strung into it -- in other words, supported as this universe. This universe has laws, functions, and activity depending on Rajas, Tamas, and Sattva. But all that is only possible because of that entity called consciousness.

So the metaphor is about a pearl necklace, where I can see the pearls. The pearls are held in a particular formation.

And I know that there is something holding the pearls in that particular formation, but I do not see what it is. I know that if you take that element out, the pearls will fall apart and scatter all over the floor. Everything is in this formation, which we call the universe, because of that underlying principle which is holding it all together. Bhagavan is continuously giving indications about what you should think about when you work in this world.

Right now, my world is divided into I and the world, the two entities. But one is trying to bring them closer, to make that difference. What you are made up of, what the world is made up of, is one and the same thing. My body and my chair are made of the same material called the electron and quarks.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna reveals His Eightfold Prakriti: earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and ego. This is His lower nature (apara prakriti), while the life force that sustains everything is His higher nature (para prakriti). Today, as you move through the world, practice recognizing both. When you drink water, acknowledge it as Divine manifestation. When a thought arises in your mind, recognize even that mental activity as part of the Lord's Prakriti. The challenge is to see that not only the beautiful sunset but also your own ego, your intellect, your very sense of "I am this body" are all expressions of the same Divine energy.

Reflect on the profound statement: "I am the source and dissolution of the entire universe." Everything emerges from this one reality and returns to it. Like the analogy of a Tesla car, having all the parts does not make a working vehicle; something more is needed to bring it all together. What is that animating principle in your own life? Today, notice moments when you feel most alive, most conscious. That very awareness, that sense of being present, is a glimpse of the higher Prakriti.

Consider: If the same consciousness that functions through you also functions through everyone you meet today, how might that change the way you interact with the difficult coworker, the impatient driver, or the stranger on the street?

snippets.title: Day 98: Four Types of Seekers
snippets.sanskrit:
मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय |

रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययोः |

पुण्यो गन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ |
snippets.transliteration:
mattaḥ parataraṃ nānyatkiñcidasti dhanañjaya .

raso.ahamapsu kaunteya prabhāsmi śaśisūryayoḥ .

puṇyo gandhaḥ pṛthivyāṃ ca tejaścāsmi vibhāvasau .
verseTranslations: O Arjuna! There is nothing higher than Me; all is strung upon Me as rows of pearls upon a thread.
O Arjuna! I am the Fluidity in water, the Light in the sun and in the moon. I am the mystic syllable Om in the Vedic scriptures, the Sound in ether, the Virility in man.
I am the Fragrance of earth, the Brilliance of fire. I am the Life Force in all beings, and I am the Austerity of the ascetics.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 7, Gnana Vignana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. In the beginning, Bhagavan said, "I'm going to tell you who I am, and I'll tell you all about it without leaving anything behind." And then he basically said that what you see in this world is my Eightfold Prakriti.

We all claim that we have never seen Bhagavan before. We have never seen God. We have never known Him. Bhagawan says, "You know me every day, you meet me every day. You just don't recognize it." Because what you see is the Bhoomi, Apaha, Analaha, Kham, Vayuhu -- the five elements which make up the entire world of ours. It is nothing but my own manifestation.

Then he also included Manas, Buddhi, Ahankara. When we think about the five elements, we only think about the insentient world, the world of matter. We say, "Well, we are human beings, we are living beings." But no -- even my mind, my intellect, my ego. Bhagavan said, that's my Prakriti.

That's my own nature, you know, it's my own manifestation. So when you include all of that, that includes all the beings and things, there's nothing left behind. He said, that's nothing but me manifesting in my Eightfold Prakriti. You know me -- you just are not capable of grasping the totality of His expression. With that, he progressed and said, "Well then, let me explain to you that all these beings have come out of me. I am the source of all beings and I am the resting place for all beings."

There is nothing other than Him in this world, but in His manifestation as the Eightfold Prakriti, I don't see Him in His totality. So he proceeds further in verse seven to say how everything is connected. Right now we don't feel connected to anything. No matter how hard we try, we feel like I am an island in this universe.

By myself, I am so unique. Everything else is the world. All beings are part of the world. That's what we call Jagat. We complain in Hindi all the time, you know, Jagat. Because we consider ourselves to be so unique, we are not part of this Jagat.

We are not part of this world. Even though our intellect says I am part of this world, our heart doesn't agree. We feel outside of it. We are in the center of our own universe. When I see the world this way, I don't see connection.

How am I connected to the rest of the world? Verse 7 says: Mattah parataram na anyat kinchit asti dhananjaya. There is nothing that exists other than me. So how can you exist without me? From that one singularity, the whole plurality came out. Everything in the plurality is part of that.

If I am part of this world, I am part of that singularity. Therefore there is nothing other than me exist. You are no other than my own self. He said, "I am the common thread." The expression in English is "that's the common thread" -- the common thread in all these things and beings which keeps them together as the world.

The Self is the common thread. Even though right now I think "myself" is completely different than "yourself" and "herself" and "himself" -- that self remains constant in all beings. I am that common thread which keeps this universe together. The analogy, obviously, is sutre manigana iva -- in the pearl necklace, beads are all separate from each other.

But the thread keeps them together as a necklace. So I am that common thread. What is common in me and you? You also call it "myself" when you express yourself. That self, Bhagavan said, is the common thread among all beings. And then, obviously, for people like us who can't really understand without elaborate examples --

We can only relate to something when somebody gives an example about something we know. This may still remain abstract, but then he says, "Okay, let me explain to you how it works." So the next verse says: Raso aham apsu kaunteya prabhasmi shashisuryayoh pranavah sarva vedeshu shabdah khe purusham nrshu. In other words, "Now let me enumerate things you can understand." I am the liquidity in water. I am the radiance in moon and sun.

Whatever we think is the unique quality of that thing or being -- he said, that's because of me. Because I reside in that being or thing, it makes the thing what it is. What is dharma in Sanskrit? That which holds is dharma. As I always use the example: the dharma of sugar is sweetness. As long as it is sweet, it is sugar. It may look like sugar, it may feel like sugar, but if it doesn't taste like sugar, it's not sugar.

So the dharma of a thing or being -- what makes it what it is -- Bhagavan says that dharma is me. Because of that dharma, things and beings are what they are. Then he continues in the next verses: Punyo gandhah prithivyam cha tejash chasmi vibhavasau jivanam sarvabhuteshu tapash chasmi tapasvisu. "I am the sweet fragrance of this earth. I'm the radiance in fire, and I'm the life in all beings."

Very clearly he says, "I am the life in all beings." Tapash chasmi tapasvisu. In other words, anything which makes anybody what it is, is me. Living beings are living because of my presence in them. It's a profound statement which we all basically know. We have accepted: Bijam mam sarvabhutanam viddhi partha sanatanam.

Know that I am the source of all beings. I am the seed of all beings. The beings cannot exist without me. Buddhir buddhimatam asmi. I am the intellect in the intellectual, the brilliance in the brilliant.

So if I think that I am so smart, my ego says, "It's because of my intellect." Bhagavan says, "Mr. Ego, you have really nothing to do with it. I am the intellect in the intellectual, and I am the brilliance in the brilliant." And obviously, Balam Balavatam asmi Kama Raga Vivarjitam. Here is a very interesting point he makes: I am the strength in the strong.

I am the power in the powerful. But Kama Raga Vivarjitam -- that strength is devoid of desire or attachment. It is strength without any association with desire. We only desire strength if we can use it. Isn't there an expression: "What is the use of power if I can't abuse it?" So this is power without any desire to abuse it.

That's what we would call sattvic strength. So Bhagavan said, "I am the strength in the strong. But when the strong misuse that strength and hurt others, that's not me." So this is like, you know, He very conveniently keeps out of all the trouble we get into. "Hey Bhagavan, if you're giving this guy all this mighty power, he'll want to hurt us!" Bhagavan says, "I am the strength in him."

But I am not the one who is hurting you. Dharma Aviruddha, Bhuteshu Kamo Asmi Bharatarshapa. Now I say, okay, what happens to all these desires we have? He said, that's also me. But that is Dharma Aviruddha. We have always this argument.

Is the desire good or bad? You know, Vedantic discussion. We say, yeah, but that's also our desire. I said, well, I want to do good thing. Well, that's also desire. Well, I want to meet Bhagavan.

So if you see in our tradition, when Brahmacharis go to the guru, they first shave all their hair off. That basically indicates getting rid of all desires. You're a student now, you're a seeker. You shouldn't have any other desire. But they leave a Choti -- that indicates the Shastra Vasana, the desire for knowledge.

That Choti keeps him tied to the Sastra. Then when he becomes a Sanyasi, when that Choti is gone, when you reach a level, even attachment to the Sastra should be dropped. Because otherwise I just remain a pure Pandit. That's an attachment. It's a golden chain, Bhagawan. So even that has to be dropped.

So when he becomes a Sanyasi -- Sanyasi literally means one who has renounced -- he has renounced everything, all attachment. The Choti goes away. Even Shastra Vasana is not there. That too becomes bondage, so even that needs to go.

So where do these desires stand? Bhagwan said, "Desires are nothing but me. I am expressing through you as your desire." But that is Dharma Aviruddha -- not contrary to your Dharma. When you have a desire in accordance with your Dharma, that is legitimate. I am a doctor and I have a desire to help people, perform surgery, or practice my art of medicine. That's a Dharma-aligned desire.

That's not a desire which is wrong. Bhagavan said, "I am the desire in you which is in line with your Dharma." If I'm a father and I want to take care of my children, that's in line with my Dharma. If I'm a teacher and I want to make sure my students learn, that's a desire in line with my Dharma. If I am a postman and I want to deliver mail, that's in line with my Dharma. Where we get confused in our understanding of Vedanta is this: Vedanta doesn't say desire is something outside of this world.

We don't import it from somewhere. It's part of your nature, part of Bhagavan's nature. But it has to align with your Dharma, without any contradiction. I'm a treasurer in a bank, but I want to become the owner of the bank by dealing under the table? That's obviously contrary to my position. So Bhagawan says, "I am the strength in the strong, but without any attachment or desire to use this strength in a manner contrary to Dharma."

Therefore, Bhagavan Bhagavad Gita asks Arjuna to fight. Well, is it right or wrong? Bhagavad says, it is in line with your Dharma. You are the general of this army. All these people are relying on you. You have to use your strength to fight your battle.

So the very important point is: desires are natural as long as they are in line with your duties. I want to take care of my children -- that's in line with my Dharma. Ye chaiva Sattvika Bhava Rajasas Tamasash cha ye. Whatever beings are Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic -- we classify people and things into these categories by their own nature. We know, or at least we have learned from the Upanishads and Bhagavad Gita, that this world is made up of these three Gunas: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas.

Everything else we see is the permutation and combination of these three gunas. When I have four-color printing, I may have hundreds of colors on my picture, but they are nothing but the permutation and combination of the four colors. Therefore my printer will say "yellow is out," and I replace the yellow.
snippets.reflection:
"There is nothing higher than Me; all is strung upon Me as rows of pearls upon a thread." This image of the pearl necklace offers a powerful contemplation for today. We see individual beads and think they are separate, but an invisible thread holds them together as one necklace. What is the common thread connecting you to your family, your colleagues, even strangers you pass on the street? Krishna says it is the Self, the "I am" that each being experiences. Today, when someone speaks to you, try to sense that same thread of consciousness animating both of you.

Krishna then gives specific examples: "I am the fluidity in water, the light in sun and moon, the sacred syllable Om, the sound in ether, the virility in man, the fragrance of earth, the brilliance in fire, the life in all beings." These verses teach us to see the Divine not in abstract theology but in immediate experience. What makes water, water? Its wetness, its fluidity. What makes fire, fire? Its heat and brilliance. That essential quality, that dharma, which makes each thing what it is, is the Divine presence.

Today, practice this recognition exercise: For each element you encounter, ask "What is its essential quality?" and recognize that quality as a direct expression of the Divine. The sweetness in your morning fruit, the warmth of sunlight on your skin, the stability of the ground beneath your feet. Can you move through an entire day holding this awareness?

That which holds is dharma. As I always use the example: the dharma of sugar is sweetness. As long as it is sweet, it is sugar. It may look like sugar, it may feel like sugar, but if it doesn't taste like sugar, it's not sugar.

So the dharma of a thing or being -- what makes it what it is -- Bhagavan says that dharma is me. Because of that dharma, things and beings are what they are. Then he continues in the next verses: Punyo gandhah prithivyam cha tejash chasmi vibhavasau jivanam sarvabhuteshu tapash chasmi tapasvisu. "I am the sweet fragrance of this earth. I'm the radiance in fire, and I'm the life in all beings."

Very clearly he says, "I am the life in all beings." Tapash chasmi tapasvisu. In other words, anything which makes anybody what it is, is me. Living beings are living because of my presence in them. It's a profound statement which we all basically know. We have accepted: Bijam mam sarvabhutanam viddhi partha sanatanam.

Know that I am the source of all beings. I am the seed of all beings. The beings cannot exist without me. Buddhir buddhimatam asmi. I am the intellect in the intellectual, the brilliance in the brilliant.

So if I think that I am so smart, my ego says, "It's because of my intellect." Bhagavan says, "Mr. Ego, you have really nothing to do with it. I am the intellect in the intellectual, and I am the brilliance in the brilliant." And obviously, Balam Balavatam asmi Kama Raga Vivarjitam. Here is a very interesting point he makes: I am the strength in the strong.

I am the power in the powerful. But Kama Raga Vivarjitam -- that strength is devoid of desire or attachment. It is strength without any association with desire. We only desire strength if we can use it. Isn't there an expression: "What is the use of power if I can't abuse it?" So this is power without any desire to abuse it.

That's what we would call sattvic strength. So Bhagavan said, "I am the strength in the strong. But when the strong misuse that strength and hurt others, that's not me." So this is like, you know, He very conveniently keeps out of all the trouble we get into. "Hey Bhagavan, if you're giving this guy all this mighty power, he'll want to hurt us!" Bhagavan says, "I am the strength in him."

But I am not the one who is hurting you. Dharma Aviruddha, Bhuteshu Kamo Asmi Bharatarshapa. Now I say, okay, what happens to all these desires we have? He said, that's also me. But that is Dharma Aviruddha. We have always this argument.

Is the desire good or bad? You know, Vedantic discussion. We say, yeah, but that's also our desire. I said, well, I want to do good thing. Well, that's also desire. Well, I want to meet Bhagavan.

So if you see in our tradition, when Brahmacharis go to the guru, they first shave all their hair off. That basically indicates getting rid of all desires. You're a student now, you're a seeker. You shouldn't have any other desire. But they leave a Choti -- that indicates the Shastra Vasana, the desire for knowledge.

That Choti keeps him tied to the Sastra. Then when he becomes a Sanyasi, when that Choti is gone, when you reach a level, even attachment to the Sastra should be dropped. Because otherwise I just remain a pure Pandit. That's an attachment. It's a golden chain, Bhagawan. So even that has to be dropped.

So when he becomes a Sanyasi -- Sanyasi literally means one who has renounced -- he has renounced everything, all attachment. The Choti goes away. Even Shastra Vasana is not there. That too becomes bondage, so even that needs to go.

So where do these desires stand? Bhagwan said, "Desires are nothing but me. I am expressing through you as your desire." But that is Dharma Aviruddha -- not contrary to your Dharma. When you have a desire in accordance with your Dharma, that is legitimate. I am a doctor and I have a desire to help people, perform surgery, or practice my art of medicine. That's a Dharma-aligned desire.

That's not a desire which is wrong. Bhagavan said, "I am the desire in you which is in line with your Dharma." If I'm a father and I want to take care of my children, that's in line with my Dharma. If I'm a teacher and I want to make sure my students learn, that's a desire in line with my Dharma. If I am a postman and I want to deliver mail, that's in line with my Dharma. Where we get confused in our understanding of Vedanta is this: Vedanta doesn't say desire is something outside of this world.

We don't import it from somewhere. It's part of your nature, part of Bhagavan's nature. But it has to align with your Dharma, without any contradiction. I'm a treasurer in a bank, but I want to become the owner of the bank by dealing under the table? That's obviously contrary to my position. So Bhagawan says, "I am the strength in the strong, but without any attachment or desire to use this strength in a manner contrary to Dharma."

Therefore, Bhagavan Bhagavad Gita asks Arjuna to fight. Well, is it right or wrong? Bhagavad says, it is in line with your Dharma. You are the general of this army. All these people are relying on you. You have to use your strength to fight your battle.

So the very important point is: desires are natural as long as they are in line with your duties. I want to take care of my children -- that's in line with my Dharma. Ye chaiva Sattvika Bhava Rajasas Tamasash cha ye. Whatever beings are Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic -- we classify people and things into these categories by their own nature. We know, or at least we have learned from the Upanishads and Bhagavad Gita, that this world is made up of these three Gunas: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas.

Everything else we see is the permutation and combination of these three gunas. When I have four-color printing, I may have hundreds of colors on my picture, but they are nothing but the permutation and combination of the four colors. Therefore my printer will say "yellow is out," and I replace the yellow.
snippets.reflection:
"I am the eternal Seed of being; I am the Intelligence of the intelligent, the Splendour of the resplendent." When you feel proud of your intelligence or accomplishments, pause and consider: where does that intelligence come from? Krishna gently reminds us that the intellect and the intellectual both belong to Him. This is not meant to diminish your efforts but to shift your identification. The next time you solve a problem or have a creative insight, try thinking: "That intelligence flowing through me is the Divine expressing itself."

Krishna makes a crucial distinction about strength and desire: "I am the Strength of the strong, of them who are free from attachment and desire; and I am the Desire for righteousness." Notice that divine strength is without the craving to misuse it. Today, examine your own strengths and talents. Are you using them in alignment with your dharma, or are they mixed with selfish desire? The desire to care for your children, to excel at your profession, to serve your community, these are dharma-aviruddha, desires not contrary to righteousness. But the same strength twisted by ego becomes bondage.

The teaching that Sattvic, Rajasic, and Tamasic qualities all come from the Lord, yet He is not in them, is paradoxical but liberating. You are not your moods, your qualities, your changing states. Today, when you notice yourself becoming agitated (rajas) or dull (tamas), remember: these states arise and pass, but the witness of these states, that unchanging awareness, is your true nature. Can you rest in that witness position even briefly?

snippets.title: Day 100: Knowledge of the Divine
snippets.sanskrit:
त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत् |

दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया |

न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः |
snippets.transliteration:
tribhirguṇamayairbhāvairebhiḥ sarvamidaṃ jagat .

daivī hyeṣā guṇamayī mama māyā duratyayā .

na māṃ duṣkṛtino mūḍhāḥ prapadyante narādhamāḥ .
verseTranslations: The inhabitants of the world, misled by those natures which the Qualities have engendered, know not that I am higher than them all, and that I do not change.
Verily, this Divine Illusion of Phenomenon manifesting itself in the Qualities is difficult to surmount. Only they who devote themselves to Me and to Me alone can accomplish it.
The sinner, the ignorant, the vile, deprived of spiritual perception by the glamour of Illusion, and he who pursues a godless life - none of them shall find Me.
snippets.commentary:
We are discussing Chapter 7, Gnana Vignana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. In this chapter we have seen that the Lord says, "You complain that you don't know the Lord, that you have never seen God before."

But I pervade this universe with my Ashta Dha Prakriti. In my Eightfold nature, I manifest in this world, and you see me every day. That is Bhumiyapo anala kam vayuhu Manabuddhi Ahankar. That's my Eightfold Prakriti. And you see me every day.

This is my lower Prakriti. Lower means the grosser manifestation which you and I can perceive through our senses. But he said, higher than that is my higher Prakriti, which is not just the sum total of all this, but something which is the cause for this entire universe. Everything comes out of me and everything goes back into me. It stays in time and space in a particular shape or form or state temporarily, but eventually it goes back to its source, which is the self -- the self which is all-pervading. Therefore there is nothing other than myself.

Anything which you can see is nothing but myself. Therefore all the examples then given show that whatever you see is me. In the last verse, in the previous three verses we have seen, it says Ye chaiva Sattvika Bhava Rajasas Tamasash cha ye. Matta eveti tan viddhi na tv aham teshu te mayi. This world right now seems divided into three types of people, three types of things, three types of qualities. These are the qualities of my Maya. This illusion creates a world of plurality when only one exists -- the singularity -- and it does so by fooling my mind and intellect.

I see this plurality. And I say that this illusion which I see is because of the divine Prakriti called Maya. This Maya has three aspects: Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Sattva is pure knowledge or existence. Rajas is activity. And Tamas is inertia.

These three are absolutely required for anything to exist. The awareness that it exists, the activity, dynamism, and then inertia -- all three in different proportions, in different permutation and combination, create this world of plurality. So any being you see in this world -- whether Sattvik, Rajasik, or Tamasic -- they come from me, they are in me, but I am not in them. Now obviously, our whole life we've heard that Bhagavan is in every being. But now Bhagavan says they are in me, but I am not in them. When we discussed this verse, we used a simple analogy: the universal space says, "I'm not in the car, but the car is in me."

A car is traveling in space. The space inside the car -- is it in the car, or is it remaining where it is? The car is traveling in the space. We feel the space in the car; otherwise we wouldn't be able to sit in it. However, when the car moves from Hanover County to Henrico, it doesn't carry the Hanover County space to Henrico. Otherwise Henrico would have a surplus of space.

The space remains where it is. Even though in my perception it seems like the space is in the car, in reality the car is in the space. So even though it seems like Bhagavan is in me -- that's why I can speak, I can hear, I can walk -- actually I am in the Lord. As long as I keep connected with Him, I can do all of that.

So the next three verses. Verse 13: Mohitam na abhijanati mam ebhyah param avyayam.

All this elaborate explanation creates a confusion in our mind: "So if that's the case, why don't I feel the Lord's presence? All this is great, but I don't feel it." Because Bhagavan says this world is deluded by the three qualities of Maya -- Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas -- which create this magnificent projection of the world. We go to a cinema theater; we know it's just a screen and light is thrown on it. But we get caught up in the images, the storyline, and the acting.

We forget completely that what's in front of us is nothing but a white screen with light projected through a lens -- that magnificent projection. So it's even more confusing for us: what is real and what is unreal? Up till now, at least with the 2D world, we could say, "That's two-dimensional. My world is three-dimensional." Many years ago I went to Epcot Center, and that was the first time I'd seen a hologram. I was completely baffled.

The lady looked so real in the hologram, walking around giving a presentation. Luckily it was not full scale, so you could tell. But it's so real that our senses cannot differentiate between what is real and what is unreal. Same thing with Photoshop. Previously, when somebody sent me a picture, I knew what it was.

Now somebody sends me a picture and I don't know whether it's Photoshopped or real. I'm in a party, but I was never there -- because somebody photoshopped me into it. The more the world creates these magnificent projections, the more we get deluded. The more our senses are involved, the more it confuses us from differentiating the real from the unreal. So Bhagavan said that these three qualities of His Prakriti, projected through His Prakriti --

His Prakriti's nature is this divine Maya, the divine illusion which creates multiple entities out of one. This world is deluded by this -- Mam na abhijanati mam ebhyah param avyayam -- and therefore they do not know that I am the immutable source of all beings. It is as simple as this: Bhagavan said, "It's me. I created the confusion in your mind. I am the source of the confusion."

So we say, "Well then, why are we suffering? Bhagavan, why didn't you create a simple world where everybody understands that we are part of the Lord?" But in fact, we don't like simple things. The more confusing it is --

that's why we want 3D TV now. Up till now, we were happy with 2D TV. The more baffling it is, the more interesting. A magic trick that somebody can figure out is no longer magic -- I don't want to go see it.

But something I can't figure out? How does David Copperfield make the Statue of Liberty vanish? The whole United States tunes into the television set. More confusing, more interesting. That's what makes our life interesting. Bhagwan said, "That's what my Leela is."

We get caught in the play; we lose the sense of what is real and what is unreal. So the next verse: Daivi hi esha gunamayi mama maya duratyaya. This divine Maya of mine -- Maya is divine because, after all, it is the Lord's quality. He says, "This is my quality." But it is very difficult to overcome.

We know that when we go to see a magic show, almost 100% of the people in the audience know there is no real magic. He is not cutting this lady in half. But at the same token, we can't figure out how he did it. We actually had a magic show at Chinmaya Mission -- probably you may have seen this. It was a fundraiser, and they had all these acts.

One act was: they put Swamiji, Swami Dheerananda, into this box and rotated the box around. When you opened it, the Swamiji was gone and a young little kid in a swami dress came out. "Oh, what did you do? You made Swamiji a little kid!" Unfortunately, there were obviously two compartments and the guy switches around.

But Swamiji's saffron robe got stuck in the partition. So when the little kid comes out, we see the saffron robe, and the whole magic is gone. Everybody's laughing. We figured out Swamiji is right behind that curtain. This magic is only enjoyable as long as we can't figure it out. Once we figure it out, the magic is gone. Bhagavan says, "I am the greatest magician, so you can't figure out my Maya."

This threefold Maya of mine is difficult to overcome. With a simple mind and intellect, you're trying to figure out the Lord's Maya -- your mind and intellect are not capable. Bhagavan says, you can try all your life, generations after generations, to intellectually figure out the Lord's nature. You're not going to succeed.

Bhagawan says, Mama Maya Duratyaya -- it is very difficult to cross over. But then we say, "Okay, that's the end of this class. Let's close the book. Let's go home." Mam eva ye prapadyante mayam etam taranti te. Those who take refuge in me will cross over.

This Maya, we are all very anxious to find out. Well, the magician says, if you come and take, become my disciple, then you will figure out everything what I do. So when you go to the source and take refuge in him, if I really want to find out what David Copperfield does, I have to go and bow down and say, take me as your disciple. Let me know how you make this statue of Liberty vanishes. That's the purpose of my life. Okay, then I'll teach you.

Bhagavan says, Mama Maya Duratyaya -- it's very difficult to cross over if you just rely on your own intellect and mind. But if you take refuge in me -- in other words, start identifying with the self -- you will overcome that. That's the little escape hatch you have. Mam eva ye -- those who invoke me, or Bhajanti. Now, we basically think about singing Bhajans, like Swami Dheerananda.

It's not just the harmonium and tabla. Bhajanti means: anytime we have to do something, we have to invoke ourselves. When somebody asks me, "Neel, how did you do this?" -- "I did it all by myself." I had to invoke myself to do it. For something else you might say, "Well, no, I had a little help from this organization, but I still did it myself."

So I invoked the organization for some help, but I still myself is doing it. But she did it herself or something else. Well, they didn't do it, but he did it himself. Wherever there is something doing comes, there is some self involved in it. Whether it is myself, yourself, herself, themselves, itself, the self involved in it. In other words, in any activity you have to invoke self.

That self is the doer, whether it is myself or yourself or herself or himself. The self is the only doer. If there is no self involved, nothing happens. So we have to invoke the self. Now, the question is: with what instrument do we invoke it? To get the light in this room, I have to invoke electricity.

So I have to flip the switch, connect that to all the lights here and the lights come on.
snippets.reflection:
"The entire world is deluded by the three qualities (gunas) and does not recognize Me, who am beyond them and imperishable." This verse explains why spiritual realization seems so elusive. Like watching a captivating movie, we become so absorbed in the play of Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas that we forget we are the witness, not the movie. Today, notice how your moods shift throughout the day: clarity and peace (sattva), restlessness and ambition (rajas), heaviness and confusion (tamas). Can you observe these shifting states without being completely identified with them?

Krishna offers both a warning and a promise. The warning: "This divine Maya of Mine, consisting of the three gunas, is difficult to cross." The promise: "Those who take refuge in Me alone shall cross over this illusion." The key word is "alone" (eva). Half-hearted seeking, divided attention, keeping one foot in spiritual practice and both hands grasping worldly security, this approach will not work. The magician's tricks cannot be understood from the audience; you must become his disciple. Today, honestly assess: how much of your day is spent genuinely seeking truth versus being entertained by the magic show of Maya?

The verse about those who do not seek the Divine describes them as "deprived of spiritual perception by the glamour of Illusion." This is not a judgment but a diagnosis. The cure is Bhajanti, which means invoking the Self. Every action requires invoking some self: myself, yourself, itself. Today, consciously invoke the higher Self before important activities. Before a meeting, a difficult conversation, or creative work, pause and remember: "May the Divine intelligence work through me."

snippets.title: Day 101: The Material World
snippets.sanskrit:
चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन |

तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते |

उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम् |
snippets.transliteration:
caturvidhā bhajante māṃ janāḥ sukṛtino.arjuna .

teṣāṃ jñānī nityayukta ekabhaktirviśiṣyate .

udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me matam .
verseTranslations: O Arjuna! The righteous who worship Me are grouped by stages: first, they who suffer, next they who desire knowledge, then they who thirst after truth, and lastly they who attain wisdom.

Of all of these, he who has gained wisdom, who meditates on Me without ceasing, devoting himself only to Me, he is the best; for by the wise man I am exceedingly beloved and the wise man, too, is beloved by Me.
Noble-minded are they all, but the wise man I hold as my own Self; for he, remaining always at peace with Me, makes me his final goal.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 7, Gnana Vignana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. As we discussed, in Chapter 6 we learned how to meditate. In Chapter 7, he is teaching us what to meditate upon. In Chapter 6, we learned how to identify with the Supreme Self and detach ourselves from the limited self that I consider myself. In Chapter 7, Bhagavan is giving us the indications of how to think about the Supreme Being. We have seen his lower and higher nature.

The lower nature is what I can see, perceive, think in this world -- this is the lower Prakriti. So Bhagavan said, he is all-pervading, and anything which I see, I should see his presence in it. Anything which I consider conducive or not conducive is still manifestation of the same underlying reality. This Prakriti has three Gunas: Sattva, Rajas, Tamas. Whatever there is which is Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik, consider that all come from me, the supreme reality.

It is actually my mind which divides this world into three different categories. The world I see as Sattvik, the world I see as Rajasic, the world I see as Tamasic. That makes me think about positive emotions: where I feel happy, I feel that's a Sattvic world. The world which makes me agitated, I consider Rajasic. The world which confuses me is Tamasic for me. But no matter what world you are identifying with, that is your world and you are in the center of it.

But consider that comes from me. All sense objects in this world, whether they give you Sattvic experience, rajasic experience or Tamasic experience, they all come from me. But I am not in them, they are in me. In other words, there is no indication of supreme reality in them. I cannot find its presence in them in those sense objects. But note that all sense objects are in me.

In other words, without that supreme reality, without my consciousness, I will not be able to detect any of those sense objects. Therefore, all the sense objects in this world are actually in my consciousness. Consider that they are all present because of my presence as your own consciousness. Then Bhagawan explains why we cannot realize that. Because all people, all beings in this world are confused by this Maya. As we have discussed, Maya is that which is not, but appears to be.

The world of sense objects is actually created by my own mind. The impression I have of them is actually my impression only. I will never know what the reality is. When I look up into the sky, I see stars and moon and sun. What I see is my world -- the impression I see is the representation of this world in my mind.

I will never know what the reality is. So Bhagawan said, consider all that to be me. But you will never be able to cross this illusion that you have created about your world. This knowledge about the underlying reality is lost to me because I'm under the spell of Maya. I do not see the unity in the diversity of sense objects around me, because I consider myself an island by myself.

I am so unique that I'm different than this world. This notion about my uniqueness creates this duality about I and the world. Because that's the my illusion that the Maya's illusion. Even knowing, through intellectual appreciation, that my body, my mind, my intellect are part of this Prakriti -- this body is nothing but food modified.

But I never see my body as food modified. I always see my body as something very unique. Bhagwan said, that's the confusion created by Maya. Tribhir gunamayair bhavair ebhih sarvam idam jagat mohitam -- the entire Jagat, all beings, are confused by the three Gunas. But those who have some inkling about this underlying reality will pursue it.

That's basically I'm worshipping. I'm trying to find out and identify with the supreme self. I have inkling that there is something higher than me and that I am pursuing. So Bhagavan now tells us which types of people will try to identify with the supreme self. In the last verse we discussed, he said: who will not be aware of something greater than his own self? Na mam dushkritino mudhah prapadyante naradhamah, mayaya apahrita jnana, asuram bhavam ashritah. Those who are under the complete spell of Maya will only identify with the ignorance they have.

This ignorance that "I am by myself and the world is a completely different entity." Duskritina, Mudha -- people who are not yet evolved to the point of identifying with something higher than their limited self. They will not be able to understand this, and therefore they take refuge in their own ignorance: "I am who I am; the world is out there to get me."

In contrast, Bhagavan said there are people who have evolved from identifying with their limited self and have recognized an underlying unity in all sense objects. They see that everything is strung into the same reality.

Physics tells us the same thing -- that in this world there is one underlying energy. And in this world nothing is lost. No matter what incident or phenomenon is happening, we know that energy in this world remains constant. If you take a gallon of water and boil it until it all evaporates, that does not mean that the water is lost. The same amount of energy which was in the water -- the mass -- is now converted into something else. When you add all that up, it will come to exactly the same amount.

That's what we learned in high school physics. The Bhagawan said that you in this world there is nothing is really lost or gained. It just changes appearances. And those who have come to the realization that there is an underlying reality, they will pursue identification with that reality. And those people: Chaturvidha bhajante mam janah sukritino Arjuna. Contrast this with the last verse.

The wrongdoers, in essence, are acting in this world with the wrong notion that their own self is the only reality. Charvaka darshan: Bhasmi bhutasya dehasya punaragamanam kutah -- when this body is burnt, there is no coming back. So this life is the only life; enjoy as best as you can, no matter what you have to do. Rinam kritva ghritam pibet.

Those are Duskritina because they have a very narrow view about who they are, and therefore their actions are driven by that paradigm -- "I am by myself and have to make the most out of this life." Bhagavan calls them Maya Apahrita Jnana: their knowledge about the self and their connection with the higher self is lost because of the confusion created by Maya.

Chaturvidha bhajanti mam janah sukritina Arjuna. In contrast, the people of good deeds pursue me.

They try to identify with me in four different ways. Or you can say there are four different types of people who identify with me. This can also be one person in four different states of pursuing the supreme reality: Artah, Jijnasu, Artharthi, Gnani -- O Bharatarshabha, best of the Bharat clan. There are four types. The first is Artah, the one who is in distress and looking for help.

But there is a slight distinction people have made in understanding this verse. Bhagavan has called them Sukritina. Also, in the next two verses, he will attach the word Udara to them -- the noble people who are trying to understand why things are the way they are. We have seen that for people who are working only for themselves, all actions are binding. Any action which binds me is Dushkrita.

Any action which liberates me is Sukrita. So in the last verse, the wrongdoers -- all their actions were binding, getting more and more deeply into the bondage of their egos. In contrast, these people are Sukritina. All their actions are towards liberation from their false identification.

So this Artah may not be an average person in distress seeking Bhagavan's help -- "I'm in trouble, help me; I have back pain, please help me." He's trying to understand why there is distress in this world, why people are suffering, and he's seeking the Lord's guidance on how to alleviate that suffering. During the pandemic, a person may have been very safe in his house, in a location where he's not going to get infected.

But just watching people suffer, you may think, "Oh Lord, why are you not removing all this suffering and helping those in this pandemic?" Bhagavan said, that's the Artah -- a Bhakta who is pursuing me, disturbed by distress, seeking understanding.

The next is the Jijnasu. He wants to know how this world works, why there is suffering. It may be at a personal level -- when I'm in distress, I'm trying to find out why there is sorrow in my life.

What is it that I'm not doing right which makes me sorrowful? But at a greater level, the Bhakta is trying to understand why people are suffering and trying to find the answer. Bhagavan Buddha was not upset about his own situation. He was well protected in the palace, but he saw the suffering outside. He said, "I need to find the cause for this suffering." Bhagawan said, that's a Jijnasu.

Then the third type, Bhagawan said, is the Artharthi -- one who is seeking wealth. We all fall into that category. We do Lakshmi Puja on Diwali because we want to make sure the next year will be as good or better than the last. But this Artharthi is not seeking just for himself. These people are seeking wealth so that they can help others.

They want to create wealth for the betterment of society so that sorrows can be eliminated. And the last one is the Gnani, who has truly understood the relationship between his limited self and the Supreme Self. Bhagavan in the next verse says he is the best: Sa cha mama priyah. Out of these four, they are all selfless workers. They have gone through the first six chapters of Bhagavad Gita and learned the art of Karma Yoga.

They're working in this world for the greater good, but they still have questions: why is there suffering, where does it come from, what can I do to alleviate it? "Oh Lord, give enough so everyone can eat and nobody goes hungry."

But the Gnani understands that his own limited self is none other than the Supreme Self. They are one and the same, connected with each other, only separated by conditioning. Nitya Yukta -- constantly establishing their knowledge. No matter what I see outside, the Self is pervading all throughout this world. Whether people are suffering or enjoying, it is the same reality expressing itself. Eka Bhakti Vishishyate -- single-pointedly identified with that, because there is nothing else to identify with, once he has realized that his self is not different from the Supreme Self.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna identifies four types of devotees who turn to the Divine: the distressed (arta), the curious seeker of knowledge (jijnasu), the seeker of wealth (artharthi), and the wise one (jnani). Today, honestly identify which category best describes your current spiritual motivation. There is no shame in any of these; Krishna calls all of them "sukritina" (people of good deeds) and "noble." The distressed person who cries out to God in a hospital bed is on the same path as the philosopher seeking ultimate truth. The key is that all four are turning toward the Divine rather than away from it.

Yet Krishna makes clear that the jnani, the one who truly knows, is dearest to Him: "For the wise man I am exceedingly beloved and the wise man, too, is beloved by Me." This is not favoritism but natural law. The closer you come to understanding someone, the deeper your love becomes. The jnani has removed the veil of separateness and sees that "Vasudevah sarvam," Vasudeva is everything. This recognition creates single-pointed devotion (eka-bhakti) naturally, not through effort.

Reflect on your own journey: Have you moved through these stages? Perhaps you first came to spirituality during a crisis (arta), then developed curiosity about how life works (jijnasu), then sought divine help for worldly goals (artharthi). Each stage is valid and necessary. The invitation today is to ask: "What would it mean to move toward jnana, toward actually knowing rather than just believing?" One practice: Choose one teaching from the Gita and contemplate it deeply throughout the day, not just intellectually accepting it, but testing it against your actual experience.

snippets.title: Day 102: Four Types of Seekers
snippets.sanskrit:
बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते |

कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः |

यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति |
snippets.transliteration:
bahūnāṃ janmanāmante jñānavānmāṃ prapadyate .

kāmaistaistairhṛtajñānāḥ prapadyante.anyadevatāḥ .

yo yo yāṃ yāṃ tanuṃ bhaktaḥ śraddhayārcitumicchati .
verseTranslations: After many lives, at last the wise man realises Me as I am. A man so enlightened that he sees God everywhere is very difficult to find.
They in whom wisdom is obscured by one desire or the other, worship the lesser Powers, practising many rites which vary according to their temperaments.
But whatever the form of worship, if the devotee have faith, then upon his faith in that worship do I set My own seal.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 7, Gnana Vignana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. We have seen in Bhagavad Gita so far that Bhagavan taught us Gnana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge or Path of Knowledge. In Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, we learned that our self is immortal, imperishable -- though we consider ourselves to be mortal. So that was the path of knowledge revealing the nature of the self. Then from Chapters 3 to 5 we learned Karma Yoga, the Path of Action -- how we can transform our day-to-day actions into selfless activities and purify our mind and intellect. So Karma Yoga is to develop equanimity and purification of the mind.

That's the Path of Action. And in Chapter 6, Bhagavan taught us Dhyana Yoga, the Yoga of Meditation -- how we can shift our mind from identifying with this limited self (this body, this mind, this intellect that I consider to be my own self). In Chapter 2, we learned that the all-pervading, omniscient, ever-existing Self, which is of the nature of Sat-Chit-Ananda, is nothing but my own self as the universal Self. What I consider "myself" right now is conditioned consciousness -- the same consciousness conditioned by what I call body, mind, and intellect. So we learned how to shift this identification from the limited self to the higher Self through Dhyana Yoga by focusing the mind on the supreme Self.

At the end of Chapter 6, Bhagavan declared that the Yogi -- one who has tuned his mind to the Supreme Self, who has shifted identification from the limited self to the higher Self -- is greater than the Tapasvi (one practicing austerities), greater than the Jnani (one who has acquired knowledge through study of scriptures), and greater than the Karmi (one who acts in this world thinking that doing good is good enough). Bhagavan clarified that doing good is not good enough. You have to have the clear understanding that "myself" is not this limited self, but the limited self is nothing but the expression of the Supreme Self.

The three paths which are described in our system -- Karma Yoga, Gnana Yoga and Bhakti Yoga -- need to be practiced serially. Therefore, the Gita starts with Karma Yoga. Now in Chapter 7, Bhagavan is instructing us how to practice the Path of Bhakti, the path of devotion. But before I can start practicing Bhakti Yoga, I have to develop that identification with the supreme Self. Without knowing that supreme Self, I will not be able to focus my limited mind, which is right now fully identified with this limited self, onto that supreme self which is limitless.

So Bhagavan in the opening of this chapter gives Arjuna assurance: I will teach you. I will tell you how to do that. Bhagavan opens the chapter by saying Yogam yunjan mat ashrayah -- tune your mind to me. My mind right now is fully tuned with this body, identified with the limited self. That mind has to now identify with the Supreme Self.

He said, once you do that, you will come to know me. And he assured us that he will teach both the knowledge and its application -- Gnanam, the Knowledge, and Vignana, Vishishta Gnanam, its application in your life -- without leaving anything behind. Having known that, you will not have to know anything else. In other words, having known myself in its true nature, there will be no need to achieve, accomplish, or acquire anything to find that ultimate happiness -- the happiness which has no limitation. I do not want to be unhappy at any given time.

If you ask me, "When do you want to be happy?" -- it is not okay to be happy during weekdays but unhappy during weekends. I want to be happy all seven days of the week, 365 days of the year. Bhagwan says, having known that your self is not the limited self, you shall achieve that ultimate happiness. Why are people not achieving this knowledge? He said, Manushyanam -- out of thousands of human beings on this planet, someone will try to achieve this perfection.

We can now say billions of people -- out of billions, very few will try this method of achieving perfect happiness by identifying with the Supreme. And of those who are striving, there are very few. Out of billions, maybe a few hundred or a few dozen are trying this. And he says: Yatatam api siddhanam kashchin mam vetti tattvatah -- even those who are striving sincerely, only very few will achieve this perfection.

So this almost looks like Bhagavan is discouraging us. But Bhagavan is not discouraging us. Bhagavan is saying that it is an equal opportunity goal. Anyone can achieve this goal if they try in an appropriate manner. So Bhagavan then describes the people who are striving to achieve identification with the Supreme Self. He calls them my devotees, my Bhakti.

And he classifies those devotees into four categories. In general, he divided the entire human race into two categories. One, those who are striving for perfection. Those who are not striving for perfection. Those who are striving for perfection are trying to develop some kind of relationship with the Supreme. Others are simply considering that this world is where I can find my happiness.

"I work outside, I go and acquire things, I go and accomplish things, and that will give me happiness." This group of people is not even trying to develop any relationship with the Supreme. He called them Duskritina -- which does not mean they are evildoers, but they are working towards their happiness in a wrong way that will guarantee their failure. He defines the other group as Sukritina, people of good deeds. He says they are his devotees.

But they fall into four different categories, and therefore not all of them will achieve perfection. The first is Artah -- one who reaches out to the Supreme, developing some relationship with Him due to distress. There is sorrow in his life or her life, or there is sorrow all around. He wants to know how invoking God's grace will alleviate that sorrow.

We only invoke His grace when we feel helpless. "I can solve my own problem." It's only when we feel helpless that we seek help from the higher Self. They are my devotees, but they have a limited relationship -- they only seek my help when they feel helpless.

It's like my son when he was in college. He would only call me when he really needed something. Otherwise, he was happy doing whatever he was doing. We'd have to call him and say, "Bhai, you didn't call us all month." But when he needs something, he suddenly remembers, "My parents are there to take care of me. Let me call dad" -- and dad sends more money.

So that relationship is still of a son and a father. "My Father in heaven will take care of me when I really need Him." The next is the Jijnasu -- one who is curious about the nature of the Supreme. All scientists actually fall in that category, because they're trying to find that God equation, the equation which will reveal the nature of the Creator who created this universe. Out of curiosity about the nature of the self, the supreme, the ultimate reality, they are developing a relationship with Him.

Then the third, Bhagavan says, is the Artharthi. The entire wealth on this planet is created by the Supreme Being, and therefore He is the owner. When I need wealth to support myself, my family, my community, my nation, I seek His help.

On our dollar bill it says, "In God we trust." That Bhakta seeking wealth is an Artharthi. And the last one is the Jnani -- one who has developed this relationship with the Supreme by understanding His real nature, shifting identification from the limited self to the higher Self.

The higher Self is my true self; this limited self is just a reflection of it. Bhagavan said the Jnani is the one closest to Him. Udarah sarva evaite jnani tu atma eva me matam. All my devotees are noble people. They're people doing good deeds.

They are on the right path. I may start developing a relationship with Bhagavan because I feel distressed, but eventually I will progress to where I understand His true nature. It's like knowing somebody -- just knowing a little bit, we start liking them more. The closer we come, the more we know them in detail. Ultimately, we know that person almost in totality.

So Bhagawan said, all these devotees of mine are noble people. However, the Jnani I consider to be my own self. He is no different than me. Asthitah sa hi yuktatma mam eva anuttamam gatim. By steadfastly establishing his mind in me, he comes to me.

But then he says something which discourages many of us: Bahunam janmanam ante jnanavaan mam prapadyate, Vasudevah sarvam iti sa mahatma sudurlabhah. This Jnani has not become a Jnani overnight. After going through this journey of knowing the Supreme Self for many, many lives, he comes to understand the nature of the Supreme. And he realizes that there is nothing in this universe --

there is nothing in this Prakriti which is other than Vasudeva -- Vasudeva, the supreme, all-pervading Self. So Bhagavan said, "I told you in the beginning that Prakriti is my lower nature, my manifest nature which one can experience through the senses -- I can see, I can touch, I can feel. But other than this manifest nature of mine, there is a higher nature which is unmanifest, which you have to experience."

Only then will you come to know. So after many births of trying to seek unity in diversity, such a Jnani achieves the understanding that the supreme Self is everywhere. Sa Mahatma sudurlabhah -- such a great soul is very rare to find. So we come to the conclusion that this is not something I can easily achieve.

But come to think of it, there's nothing in this life we achieve in any other way. We have to start somewhere and then gradually make progress one step at a time. We have learned that in elementary school somebody asked me, what do you want to become? I want to become a doctor. It does not make you become doctor the next day. It took you a long time.

From elementary school to secondary school to high school to college, then medical school, then internship. All that effort you put for many, many, many years. And then you achieved this status as doctor. Such and such people recognize you as doctor. You practice your art of medicine. All that is only possible because of the journey you started from your kindergarten which ended into your internship in some hospital.

Bhagavan says bahūnām janmanāmante, the jñānī which you see today. As a knowledgeable person. He did not achieve the knowledge overnight. He put his efforts into it. So Bhagawan is encouraging us. No matter where we are in our journey, we keep making progress one step at a time.

But then the caution here is we may get distracted.
snippets.reflection:
"After many births, the wise one realizes Me, understanding 'Vasudeva is all.' Such a great soul is very rare to find." This verse can either discourage or inspire. The key is understanding that every journey, no matter how long, is completed one step at a time. You did not become a professional overnight; years of education and practice were required. Similarly, spiritual maturity develops through consistent effort across time. Today, rather than lamenting how far you have to go, appreciate how far you have already come. What spiritual insights do you now hold that you did not have five or ten years ago?

Krishna then addresses those whose knowledge is stolen by desires, who worship lesser powers. This is not a condemnation of diverse worship but an observation about limitation. If I worship only the god of wealth, I limit my vision to wealth. If I worship only health, my horizon stops there. Each deity represents a facet of the one Reality. Today, notice what you functionally worship through your time, attention, and energy. Is it career success, family security, social approval, physical pleasure? These are not wrong, but are they your ultimate goal, or stepping stones toward something greater?

The beautiful teaching that Krishna strengthens the faith of every sincere seeker, regardless of the form of worship, is profoundly inclusive. Whatever path genuinely draws your heart toward the sacred, pursue it with full conviction. The caution is to eventually recognize that all paths lead to the same summit. Today's practice: If you follow a particular tradition or form of worship, honor it fully while remaining open to the truth that others who worship differently are also reaching toward the same ultimate Reality.

snippets.title: Day 103: The Deluded
snippets.sanskrit:
स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते |

अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम् |

अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः |
snippets.transliteration:
sa tayā śraddhayā yuktastasyārādhanamīhate .

antavattu phalaṃ teṣāṃ tadbhavatyalpamedhasām .

avyaktaṃ vyaktimāpannaṃ manyante māmabuddhayaḥ .
verseTranslations: If he worships one form alone with real faith, then shall his desires be fulfilled through that only; for thus have I ordained.
The fruit that comes to men of limited insight is, after all, finite. They who worship the Lower Powers attain them; but those who worship Me come unto Me alone.
The ignorant think of Me, who am the Unmanifested Spirit, as if I were really in human form. They do not understand that My Superior Nature is changeless and most excellent.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 7, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. We have seen that Bhagavan said, consciously or unconsciously, we are all seeking the Lord. We are all seeking who we are, where we came from.

Some of us seek unconsciously and some consciously. Those who seek unconsciously obviously do not know where the answer is. Those who seek consciously are worshipping the Lord, the source of their being. We have seen that seekers can be classified into four types. Of these four, the Gnani is so firm in his conviction that his self is something other than the limited self. We need to find out what that is. But the journey from ignorance about the self to knowing the self takes its own effort.

Bahunam janmanam ante jnanavaan mam prapadyate. After many years of sincere seeking, the Gnani who is sincerely seeking his own self finds the truth. He comes to the conclusion: Vasudevah sarvam iti -- there is nothing other than the supreme reality. There is no separate world and there is no separate "I."

All that exists is Vasudeva. Anything that I see, touch, feel, or perceive is nothing but that one supreme reality alone. But Bhagavan said, why don't we all realize this? Kamaih taih taih hrita jnanah -- because of this desire and that desire, the knowledge which is inherently ours is taken away from us. And therefore we seek the fulfiller of that desire.

Who do I go and meet at a party? The one I think is going to be the most beneficial to me. Networking parties, I'm talking about. Somebody may come very lovingly and say, "Neil!" I say, "No, no, not right now. I need to go and talk to that guy, because that's where I think my benefit lies."

Even at a social party, we go say hello first to whoever we think is most important. With this desire and that desire, our sense of who we are is looted away. And then we seek the fulfiller of that desire. That's the Devata -- the one we consider the fulfiller. The object of our desire becomes the Devata we worship.

And Bhagavan says, whatever your desire and whoever your Devata, it eventually comes from me alone. Whatever you have faith in -- that entity, that source will fulfill your desire. "I make your faith even firmer." Where does the faith come from? Faith comes from my own attachment and understanding. My own consciousness, my own thinking, is only possible because the Supreme functions through me as consciousness. The same consciousness which allows me to think makes me think over and over in the same line of thinking.

It makes my faith firmer and firmer the more I think in that line. "Only science can give me the answer." The more I indulge in that thought, the firmer my faith becomes. "All these sadhus and swamis are nonsense." Swamiji himself said that's how he started -- "These guys are just bluffing their way." So the more we think in the same line, the firmer our faith becomes through our own consciousness. Bhagawan says, "I make their faith firm."

And then, the more they worship that Devata, the more they fulfill that desire sincerely. Whenever I apply myself in whatever field, the success comes from that field. Bhagavan said, wherever you apply yourself with faith, your desires will be fulfilled.

However, he said, all that comes from me alone. Sa taya shraddhaya yuktah tasya aradhanam ihate labhate cha tatah kaman maya eva vihitan hi tan. No matter where you think this profit came from, where you think this success came from, no matter who you think helped you -- Bhagavan said, that was your faith making you think it came from that source. However, because I am the all-pervading Lord, everything coming to you from these different Devatas is coming from me alone.

I am the only source. Those in business, you have several accounts and LLCs. You transfer money from here and there. Eventually, whose money is it? Yours. Anytime we go out and do something, Mina asks, "How are you going to pay for this?" I say, "Oh, that's for NBJS." She thinks the money is coming from NBJS, who is paying the rent here. "Then I don't have to worry about it." As long as you don't think it's coming from me -- but eventually it all comes from me, right?

At the time, I feel it didn't come from the Lord; it came from this Devata, this source. Bhagavan says all the sources eventually merge into me. Wherever you are, whatever Devata you are worshipping, wherever the results come from, they all come from me. Apply yourself in a field of productive potential and you shall get results. But know that all these results come from me. Antavattu phalam tesham tat bhavati alpamedhasam.

But the Alpa Medhas, those with limited intellect, get finite results. Antavattu -- which has an end. No matter how hard I try for something and get it, the joy will only last for a certain period of time. My standard example: buying a BMW. You bought the BMW, and that joy has ended. The pursuit has its own charm.

Once you reach the destination, the whole excitement of the journey has ended. Whatever Devatas you are worshipping, certainly you will get success in that field. But the results are finite -- they have a beginning and an end. I want to see a Broadway show I have never seen in my life. Next time I'm in New York, I want to see it.

But it has a beginning and an end. The show starts and ends. After that, I'm back to square one. Bhagawan said, these people with limited intellect think their destination lies in finite happiness. Therefore they pursue this field of finite happiness, and they get it.

Devan devayajo yanti mad bhakta yanti mam api. Those seeking small gains get small gains. The one who wants to hit the jackpot strives for that and reaches there sooner or later. Bhagavan said, the Bhaktas of various Devatas -- all of us who have this desire and that -- continuously pursue them. And because we put in our efforts, we get them.

But Bhagavan says, the one who seeks me finds me -- as simple as that. Gandhiji could have been the most successful barrister in South Africa and could have made all that money like the other Gujaratis at the time. But he wasn't happy with that finite result. We would have never heard about Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi. "Successful barrister, practiced in Durban and died." We would have had nothing to do with him.

But he wasn't going after the small results. He was going after what he thought rightfully belongs to his countrymen. So he became immortal. He got what he sought after. That's why I say be careful in what you think you want. You have this unlimited potential of realizing yourself.

But we are happy with small results in our life. Even in Sadhana, they say when you start meditating, Siddhis come to you, and you're pretty happy with that. A good example is Yoga. In this country, Yoga is only for the physical. Patanjali didn't write the Yoga Sutras just to make your body fit.

He wrote it to achieve the highest. But we are pretty happy with the little results we get. Therefore Bhagawan says they have a limited intellect regarding where their happiness lies. They pursue fields of action, fields of potential gain, and they get results. But those results have a beginning and an end. Inherently we are seeking infinite happiness, but we are applying ourselves in very small, finite fields of action and expecting to get infinite happiness.
