And therefore we oscillate between sorrow and happiness, sorrow and happiness. Mad Bhakta Yanti Mam Api -- only my worshipper, the one who has decided that these small gains are not good enough, who needs to find the ultimate truth that gives infinite happiness.

The last verse says: Avyaktam vyaktim apannam manyante mam abuddhayah.

Those with no intellect to understand the truth -- all of us who have no capacity to understand it. Because the intellect is the only instrument we use to understand things, and the intellect is a byproduct of ignorance. Ignorance creates this perception that "this limited being is me." This "me" -- the body, mind, and intellect -- is a product of Avidya, ignorance.

"This mind is me, this intellect is me." That intellect is now trying to find out who the Lord is. "I'm going to figure it out by reading Bhagavad Gita, then the Bible, then the Quran. In the end, I'll tell you who the Lord is." Bhagavan said, those Abuddhayah -- they think that the Avyakta, the unmanifest, has manifested. The Lord pervading everywhere whom we can't really see, who is the substratum without which this universe cannot exist, but who is not perceptible -- they think He manifests.

And therefore we have all these Bhajans about Bhagavan coming: "Maine aapko dekha, Bhagavan." And then we have stories about Bhagavan appearing. If Bhagavan can come stand in front of me while I am also standing here and the rest of the world is also standing -- where is that unmanifest?

Therefore he said, only the one without that understanding thinks the unmanifest can manifest. The unmanifest remains unmanifest. But I am seeking that, so I say, "Oh no, this is Bhagavan." I think one of the Bal Vihar children had probably seen pictures of swamis in his house.

So when Swami Dheerananda was here, the child came to our house and then went back and said, "Mom, God came to Meenanti's house!" Because to the little child, a Swami wearing a saffron robe is God. The picture he has seen is Bhagavan. "God came to Meenanti's house." What does Mama say? "No, no, that's not God. That's Swami Dheerananda."

For the child, the unmanifested God has manifested. The mother said, "No, no, that's just Dheerananda." We, in our limited intellect, think that God manifests as Jesus, as Krishna. But Bhagwan said, I remain unmanifest all the time. Param bhavam ajanantah mama avyayam anuttamam.

Knowing a guru, knowing a prophet, and thinking, "This is it." Swamiji said, "If that's the case, whoever went to a temple and saw the Murti would never have to find any truth -- he found Bhagavan! And anybody who found a guru would never have to do anything -- he already found the truth." He said, "No, they are just indications. The unmanifest remains unmanifest."

Our limited senses, mind, and intellect have no capacity ever to understand it.
snippets.reflection:
"The fruit that comes to men of limited insight is finite." This simple statement contains the key to understanding human dissatisfaction. We pursue finite goals expecting infinite satisfaction. The BMW brings joy, but it ends. The promotion brings pride, but it fades. The vacation provides relaxation, but we return to the same mind we left with. Today, examine your current pursuits: Are you investing tremendous energy in achieving something that, by its very nature, cannot provide lasting fulfillment? This is not to say you should abandon worldly goals, but recognize them for what they are, finite rewards from finite efforts.

Krishna distinguishes between those who worship lesser powers (devas) and those who worship Him directly: "They who worship the lesser Powers attain them; but those who worship Me come unto Me alone." The practical application is this: whatever you consistently give your attention to, you become. Worship of money makes you wealthy but not necessarily happy. Worship of fame makes you known but not necessarily at peace. Worship of the Supreme, the unchanging Reality behind all changing forms, leads to that same unchanging peace within yourself.

The verse about the ignorant thinking the Unmanifested has taken human form challenges our comfortable religious notions. If God is omnipresent, how can He be limited to any single form? This does not deny the value of divine incarnations or teachers but invites us beyond form-worship to essence-recognition. Today's contemplation: What if every person you meet is equally a manifestation of the Divine? Not just the saints and sages, but the confused, the suffering, even those who harm others? Can you glimpse the unmanifest presence wearing these countless disguises?

snippets.title: Day 104: Knowledge of the Divine
snippets.sanskrit:
नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः |

वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन |

इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत |
snippets.transliteration:
nāhaṃ prakāśaḥ sarvasya yogamāyāsamāvṛtaḥ .

vedāhaṃ samatītāni vartamānāni cārjuna .

icchādveṣasamutthena dvandvamohena bhārata .
verseTranslations: I am not visible to all, for I am enveloped by the illusion of Phenomenon. This deluded world does not know Me as the Unborn and the Imperishable.
I know, O Arjuna, all beings in the past, the present and the future; but they do not know Me.
O brave Arjuna! Man lives in a fairy world, deceived by the glamour of opposite sensations, infatuated by desire and aversion.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 7, Gnana Vignana Yoga, the Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom -- knowledge about the Supreme Self, contemplating on which we can attain wisdom. In this chapter, from verses 4 through 7, Bhagavan gave a thumbnail sketch of who the Lord is and what to meditate upon. First, he said his manifest Prakriti is Eightfold, available to us for perception through our senses -- everything we can think of, see, touch, and feel. All experiences of body, mind, and intellect are part of His manifested Prakriti. But then he said there is also His higher Prakriti, the para Prakriti.

In other words, that which is not available to us for cognition through our senses. Therefore it's called unmanifest -- not available to thinking through my mind, thinking through my intellect, or perceiving through my senses. The lower Prakriti is what I can interact with. The higher I cannot perceive.

But that higher is the basis of all manifestation, without which the world which you and I know will not exist. If I'm not conscious about my world, does the world exist? It only exists because I'm aware of it. The known only exists when the Knower is there. Because the Knower is there, the world of known things and beings exists. So therefore Bhagavan said, my Higher Prakriti is the one which is stringing all these manifestations together.

What you perceive, what I perceive, what he perceives, what she perceives -- when you put all perception together, it is a world of beings. That's His real nature. So from verses 4 through 7, we've seen the identity of the Lord, the Supreme, our Self, and how to contemplate on it. And then Bhagavan said you can perceive Him through anything which is the essence of anything.

Brilliance in the brilliant. Swamiji used to say, "I am the kick in whiskey." What is whiskey if there is no kick in it? It may look like whiskey, it may taste like whiskey, but if there is no kick, it's not whiskey. That which makes things and beings what they are -- that is who I am. Then he said that people who have no discriminating intellect to pursue this will never pursue it, never want to think about it.

But there are people who are pursuing an understanding of the very nature of the self and trying to get over their limitations. We have seen four types of devotees: Artah, Jijnasu, Artharthi, and Gnani. The Gnani is very close to me. He has come close to understanding what the self is all about. To Arjuna: therefore, become a Gnani.

Therefore, pursue the path of knowledge which makes you realize who you are. And then he also said that in our delusion, we sometimes think the unmanifest comes into manifestation. But the unmanifest never manifests -- we only feel it has. Bhagavan Vedvyasa makes this point very clear here, because we have all this fighting about different religions.

We say, "Our Bhagavan manifested as Krishna. Yours manifested as Christ, but mine is greater than yours." The very first ignorance is thinking the unmanifest comes into manifest. The unmanifest will never come into manifestation. Anyone who has used his intellect knows: every religion says God is omnipresent, omniscient, omnipotent.

Then how can your God be different than mine? If my God is omnipresent, there is no room for another God. Knowing this, why are we fighting about whose God is greater? Abuddhayah -- without using my intellect, I think the unmanifest God comes into manifestation as an incarnation, a prophet, a sage. Param bhavam ajanantah.

They are not aware of my real nature. My real nature is Avyayam -- immutable. Bhagavan created this world out of His own self because He has no other material available. Did He ever mutate into this world? He never mutated into this world. Therefore, one who does not know that His nature is immutable --

he is the one who is fighting about it. There is nothing higher than that. There is nothing beyond His existence. If you take Him out, nothing remains. If you put everything together, there is nothing but Him alone. But see, that's not available to all of us.

To perceive my own self is what I'm trying to understand. How can it be that difficult? It is difficult because: Na aham prakasah sarvasya yogamaya samavritah. I am not available to all because my real nature is veiled by Yoga Maya. This Yoga Maya, which creates the world of plurality out of these three gunas, confuses us so we can't see His real nature. Mudho ayam na abhijanati loko mam ajam avyayam.

Deluded by that Yoga Maya, I do not recognize its very nature, which is unborn and immutable. That is where our whole problem starts -- our sorrows and limitations. This Yoga Maya is the power with which He created this universe. The perception of plurality is because of this Yoga Maya. It is like when I'm dreaming: out of my own mental power, I create my own world and delude myself. I create my own world, but I -- the waker -- remain immutable. In that dream, the waking self remains unchanged.

I remain Ajah in my dream. I never take birth as Bill Gates, but I feel in my dream that I'm Bill Gates. So he said, that is not available to all. Nobody will ever know it. But this is not a statement to discourage us -- it is a statement for us to contemplate on.

He said it is available to those who contemplate His real nature and cross over this Maya, who see beyond it -- therefore the word Divya Drishti. I have one perspective about this world right now, and I can change my perspective when I get greater knowledge. Before I came to Richmond, I had one perspective. I thought, "Oh, Richmond is a very conservative southern town."

An old-boy network type of town. It seemed so far away in the south from Washington D.C. where I used to live -- it's only 100 miles, but I thought it was way down in the deep south. My company kept telling me, "You need to move to Richmond." Until I came here and recognized this is a pretty cosmopolitan town. The more knowledge I get, the better my perspective becomes.

It becomes more encompassing. So Bhagavan said, one who does not have this perspective will not know my nature. We will need a Divya Drishti to see His real nature in totality. Mudha means one who has not yet developed that perspective -- who doesn't yet see the totality of the Lord's nature.

Therefore, we learned from verses 4 through 7 how to see Him in totality. There is nothing separate from anything else. We are not islands by ourselves. We are connected in a way that we can never separate ourselves from each other. You can't have this class without any one of you. We need all of you, including myself, to have this class.

But if I miss that perspective, I am a Mudha. A father cannot be a father without a son or daughter. A daughter cannot be a daughter without father and mother. This interdependence we have right from birth is what we miss because of our ego. Then we say, "I am a self-made man." You couldn't even breathe on your own.

So Bhagavan said: Vedaham samatitani vartamanani cha Arjuna bhavishyani cha bhutani. "I know all beings of past, present, and future." But mam tu veda na kashchana -- "no one knows me." It's a real hide-and-seek game. The one at the top, with a greater perspective, sees everything, but we can't see Him.

Swamiji elaborates on why He knows everyone. It's like Krishna saying, "I know all beings in the past, present, and future, but no one knows me." It's like the space in Henrico County claiming tomorrow, "I know all the buildings in Henrico County past, present, and future." Because no building is possible without the inherent ingredient of space in it. From space's perspective, no building is unknown.

From a building's perspective, I only know the conditioned space. Therefore I think I'm limited. I have birth, I have death. I don't know what is the real nature of the space. I think the nature of the space is the room. So all of us, as soon as we take this identification, we forget the real nature of ourselves and take the identification of the conditioning.

But from the perspective of consciousness -- the same consciousness in me as in you, as in him, as was in my father, my grandfather, my ancestors 5,000 years ago -- the same consciousness. Therefore, from consciousness's perspective, it knew all beings in the past, present, and future. Because it never changed; it remained what it is. Beings and their conditioning came and went and will come and go, but the inherent ingredient, the entity which makes it all possible, remains the same. So we know God is omnipresent.

None of us somehow doubt it. That which is omnipresent, by its very nature, becomes omniscient. If I am all-pervading in this space, I know everything about it. So Bhagavan is omnipresent and therefore omniscient. But from a narrow perspective, if I try to understand Bhagavan, it will never be possible. Therefore He says, Mam tu veda na kashchana.

Because we try to personify Him as a limited entity. Therefore, North Indian Rama looks North Indian and South Indian Rama looks South Indian. The artist paints it in his imagination. We see Bhagavan in our imagination. We put all our conditioning on Him.

Therefore Bhagavan says, "No one knows me." We have to cross over these limitations of our mind and intellect. Therefore it's called transcendental meditation. Iccha dvesha samutthena dvandva mohena Bharata. What creates this confusion? Iccha and Dvesha -- likes and dislikes.

Sarvabhutani sammoham sarge yanti parantapa. All beings are deluded from the very moment of birth by likes and dislikes. Right from birth, the little baby knows what is comfortable and what is not. As soon as something is not comfortable -- the diaper is wet -- it starts crying. It has already taken on that conditioning. Per our scriptures, that baby has taken its conditioning --

because of past Vasanas, that body is taken. I take this particular state of existence -- that's what I wanted to experience. Why do I go to concerts and not to boxing matches? That's what I want to experience.

That's why I go to concerts, not wrestling matches. The one who goes to wrestling matches -- tell him to go to the opera! So you have taken on your conditioning based on what you like. Now you divide your world into the world you like and the world you don't like -- the world of your physical existence and the world of your emotions involved with your thinking.
snippets.reflection:
"I am not visible to all, for I am enveloped by the illusion of Yoga-Maya." This verse reveals why the spiritual search feels like hide-and-seek. The Divine is not hiding from us; we are veiled from seeing what is already everywhere present. Like someone searching for their glasses while wearing them, we seek what we already are. Today, instead of trying to "find" God or truth, try relaxing the very effort to seek. In moments of pure presence, without agenda or grasping, what remains?

"I know all beings in the past, the present and the future; but they do not know Me." From the perspective of space, all rooms are known because space pervades all rooms. But from the perspective of a single room, space seems confined to those four walls. Your consciousness, which seems limited to your body and mind, is actually the same universal consciousness that pervades all beings across all time. Today's exercise: When you meet someone, briefly consider that the awareness looking out from their eyes is the same awareness looking out from yours. Only the conditioning, the "room," is different.

The root cause of delusion is revealed: "Iccha-dvesha-samutthena," born of likes and dislikes. From the moment of birth, we divide the world into what we want and what we reject. This fundamental duality creates all suffering. Today, notice your automatic reactions of attraction and aversion. The morning coffee you crave, the traffic you despise, the praise you seek, the criticism you avoid. Can you observe these preferences without being completely controlled by them? Even brief moments of equanimity, accepting what is without demanding it be different, give a taste of freedom from the dvandvas (pairs of opposites).

snippets.title: Day 105: The Material World
snippets.sanskrit:
येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम् |

जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये |

साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः |
snippets.transliteration:
yeṣāṃ tvantagataṃ pāpaṃ janānāṃ puṇyakarmaṇām .

jarāmaraṇamokṣāya māmāśritya yatanti ye .

sādhibhūtādhidaivaṃ māṃ sādhiyajñaṃ ca ye viduḥ .
verseTranslations: But those who act righteously, in whom sin has been destroyed, who are free from the infatuation of the conflicting emotions, they worship Me with firm resolution.
Those who make Me their refuge, who strive for liberation from decay and Death, they realise the Supreme Spirit, which is their own real Self, and in which all action finds its consummation.
Those who see Me in the life of the world, in the universal sacrifice, and as pure Divinity, keeping their minds steady, they live in Me, even in the crucial hour of death."
snippets.commentary:
Just to remind us: the Bhagavad Gita is divided into three segments of six chapters each. In the first segment, we learned all about ourselves. The second chapter gave us a summary of who we are.

What we remember from the second chapter is that the self is immutable, imperishable. The "myself" which I consider "me" is immutable, imperishable. But we never fully grasped what that really means. Okay, someone who realizes that -- how would he act? How would he behave in this world? Will he be completely different from us?

We saw the characteristics of a Gnani, but that didn't show us anything different from what we do. So the next few chapters gave us how to analyze our actions and ourselves, and then recalibrate our actions to become more productive and effective. That first segment ended with Chapter 6 on meditation. Meditation is the means given to us to recalibrate this instrument called mind, body, and intellect.

Then this next segment of six chapters, from 7 to 12, is all about what that imperishable self is which we talked about in Chapter 2. That's why the first chapter of this segment, Chapter 7 -- Gnana Vignana Yoga -- is about having this knowledge of the Lord, that immutable self we learned about in Chapter 2.

But how can we make it Vishishta Gnana that we can apply? Therefore Chapter 7 describes in detail the Lord's nature and why we can't realize it in our day-to-day life. Bhagavan said, "I manifest in this world as the Eightfold Prakriti." That's something you and I can see -- "that's nothing but my own manifestation." Then he says, "There is nothing in this world which does not come out of me. Anything you can see, feel, touch, and perceive has come out of me and will dissolve in me."

And all this world of plurality, as we see it, is strung together. Nothing is independent, like an island in this universe -- which is hinting at us, because we think we are the island of the universe as "me" and everything else revolves around me. He said, "No, everything is strung like pearls in a necklace. I am that common thread. I pervade through this universe as the Eightfold Prakriti."

You are part of that Prakriti. The unmanifest is the common thread among all the manifestations which apparently look different from each other. "Why then are we not seeing that?" "Because you are under the spell of my divine Maya, which creates plurality out of singularity. As long as you are under that spell, you see yourself as different from this world." This Maya has three Gunas -- Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas -- and through their permutation and combination, it creates the infinite varieties of things and beings.

But as long as I can't overcome that Maya, I can't see the truth. In the last set of verses we saw: Iccha dvesha samutthena dvandva mohena Bharata. Because of this desire or that desire, I have divided this world into two -- the world I like and the world I don't like. Right from birth, I'm deluded about myself.

That immutable, imperishable self talked about in Chapter 2 -- I'm not recognizing it because of the duality my mind has created. My mind says, "This is me and everything else is the world." As long as I can't get out of that concept, Bhagavan said, I won't be able to realize the truth.

However, in the last three verses he says that those Gnanis who have erased this wrong notion of who they are -- their papas are all erased by this new line of thinking. Yesham tu antagatam papam jananam punya karmanam.

So there is hope. Bhagavan said this is not just a philosophical discussion. He's not just telling us, "You will never realize it." No, let's figure out what the problem was in the beginning. The problem was my wrong line of thinking: that I am different from this world. This notion that I am this limited being, and therefore I have all these problems.

Once I undo the thinking that I am this limited being, the limitation will be gone. Yesham tu antagatam papam -- those whose papas have come to an end. The classic definition of Papa is: a thought or impression which takes me away from myself, takes me away from my understanding that I am that immutable, imperishable self, and creates division between "I" and the world. As long as I am driven by the desires of the flesh, my thinking will be focused on how to fulfill those desires.

When I start thinking in the same line, it creates deep channels in my mind which guide subsequent thoughts into the same channel. This habit of following the same line of thinking to fulfill desires creates Papa -- because I just can't get out of the thinking that "this will make me happy." Last time I had a cup of coffee and it made me happy. This time it should do the same thing, and I continue. Bhagavan said, that creates your own notion of who you are.

How do I come out of it? He said, more and more I become introverted through the technique given in the previous chapter -- the meditation that "No, this is not me. The one who is getting happy with the Starbucks coffee is not me; it is someone other than myself." That line of thinking erases those channels created by my attempt to satisfy all the desires that body, mind, and intellect have created. The more I fulfill desires, the more new experiences create new channels of thinking, which create new Vasanas.

These Vasanas, the tendencies, create the same line of thinking and the same line of actions. I need to stop doing actions driven by the same line of thinking that is not giving me happiness. Even though I figured out last time that investing in the stock market was not good -- because everybody says, "Don't miss this cycle," I'm back again. You need to get out of that line of thinking.

Once you start meditating on what really makes you happy -- if I analyze my experience, was it the experience that made me happy, or something else? -- you come to the conclusion that no desire makes me happy. When I'm completely at ease, when I don't want anything -- I've already eaten my lunch, I don't have anywhere to go, and I can just sit down -- at least I still have a desire to watch TV, but even if I drop that, I'll probably be completely happy.

This new line of thinking creates the undoing of all those wrong channels in my mind. Now I have removed all the Papas. Papas are just the wrong line of thinking, the wrong Vasanas.

Yesham tu antagatam papam jananam punya karmanam. The method we learned in the first six chapters is Karma Yoga -- selfless actions. When I act in a manner that erases the thinking that "working to fulfill my desires makes me happy," I also realize the real happiness comes when I do something for others -- the true happiness we get when we do something for our children, our parents, our relatives, our friends.

Jananam punya karmanam -- they have changed their line of actions, therefore changed their line of thinking, therefore changed their tendencies. Now they are in a completely different realm of actions and thinking. Their Papas are all erased.

Te dvandva moha nirmuktah -- now they are out of this duality. "I'm not just working for me; I'm working for the whole of humanity, my town, my family." I keep expanding my identity until there is no duality between "I" and the world. Te dvandva moha nirmuktah -- this Dvandva is nothing but a delusion that you and I are different from each other.

That this world and I are two different entities is nothing but a delusion. Those who, by acting in the right manner, erase those lines of thinking which create delusion -- now Bhajante mam dridha vratah. Worshipping, we have seen, is an act of love. That love for the divine becomes so firm that I am firmly established in the thought that "I" and the world are nothing but part of the same all-pervading entity.

The next verse says Jara marana mokshaya -- and why am I doing all of this? Because the two things I'm afraid of in life are Jara (old age) and Marana (death). We had a Valentine's Day party yesterday, and you know what the topic was -- because we were all probably above 50 there.

"How do we get out of this problem of dying? The 10 tubes going through you..." Because we are afraid of Jara, old age -- when I will not be in control. I was reading about Ronald Reagan, when he was taking a walk and people said, "Good morning, Mr. President." He wouldn't recognize why people were calling him president. He didn't know he was a president. He just thought, "This guy is nice; he's greeting me."

That's all he could think. The thought that a person can reach that level, where he can't even recognize who he is -- it's pretty scary for all of us. Because all our life we took pride in being in control. I take care of myself. I take care of my family. I take care of my business.

"I take care of..." -- "I am in charge" is what makes me who I am. The very thought that I will not be in control is very, very disturbing. We want to get out of that. I want to exist, and death wipes me out. It just doesn't seem right.

Jara Marana Mokshaya -- for liberation from this thought of old age and death. Mam ashritya -- taking complete refuge in me means not Lord Krishna or Rama or Jesus, but in that immutable self. Taking complete refuge in identification with my immutable self. Just as I'm in complete control in a barber's chair -- the hair I let go and the hair I keep, I'm in complete control. The hair I let go, I don't get attached to.

"Please, please pack it up for me!" No -- I say, "Wipe it out clean as quickly as possible."
snippets.reflection:
"Those who act righteously, in whom sin has been destroyed, who are free from the infatuation of conflicting emotions, they worship Me with firm resolution." Sin (papa) here is defined not as breaking commandments but as any thought or action that reinforces the illusion of separation between self and the Divine. Each time you act from ego, from the belief that you are a separate, isolated being fighting against the world, you deepen those grooves of wrong thinking. Each time you act from dharma, recognizing your connection to the whole, those grooves begin to fill in. Today, before each significant action, ask: "Does this reinforce my sense of separation, or does it align me with something greater?"

The chapter concludes with the profound motivation for spiritual seeking: "liberation from decay and death" (jara-marana-mokshaya). This is not morbid but urgently practical. We all fear aging and death because our identity is bound to the body. The one who knows the Self as distinct from the body has nothing to fear, like someone in a barber's chair watching hair fall away without grief. Today, contemplate: What in you is actually subject to decay? Your body certainly. Your opinions and preferences, yes. Your memories and personality, these too change. But the awareness that witnesses all these changes, has that ever aged?

The final verses point to the culmination: knowing the Divine in all aspects of existence, as Adhibhuta (in all beings), Adhidaiva (as the cosmic principle), and Adhiyajna (as the sacred offering in every action). The promise is extraordinary: "Those who know Me thus, even at the hour of death, remain united with Me." Today, practice the recognition that every action, however mundane, can be a sacred offering. Washing dishes, answering emails, driving to work, when done with awareness of the Divine presence pervading all, these become Yajna, sacrifice, paths to liberation.

snippets.title: Day 106: The Imperishable
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

adhiyajñaḥ kathaṃ ko.atra dehe.asminmadhusūdana .

śrībhagavānuvāca .
verseTranslations: Who is it who rules the spirit sacrifice in many; and at the time of death how may those who have learned self-control come to the knowledge of Thee?

The Lord Shri Krishna replied: The Supreme Spirit is the Highest Imperishable Self, and Its Nature is spiritual consciousness. The worlds have been created and are supported by an emanation from the Spirit which is called the Law.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed discussion on Chapter 7, Gnana Vigana Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. And we'll be entering into the discussion of Akshara Brahma Yoga, Yoga of Imperishable Brahman. So starting from chapter one, we have seen our own situation, the condition we are in. We are fighting this battle of life, but we get confused about what is right action -- whether this is right or that is right, should I do this or should I do that?

Constantly I'm waffling between this or that and can't come to the right conclusion. So in chapter one, Arjuna kept arguing intellectually, but could not come to any conclusion. In chapter two, in the beginning he surrenders himself to Lord Krishna. Then comes the guidance. So the guidance comes as the revelation about the true nature of our self. So in chapter two, we learned that all that which I have thought about myself was erroneous.

Myself is immortal being. And therefore once I realign my understanding about who I am, everything else will fall in place in a very new pattern. Just like when we are traveling and encounter a new road pattern, we have to adjust to it. Unless you pay attention, you go back to the old way, and if you keep traveling the old road, you are going to run into some construction. So if I change the old way of thinking about who I am to the new way of thinking about who I am, then how I act will change completely. In chapter three, we learned the nature of actions, what actions are all about.

Actions are binding, but not the ones which are performed in the spirit of Yajna. So the escape hatch is that all my actions should be performed in the spirit of Yajna for the greater good, for the common good, which is Karma Yoga. So we learned that Karma Yoga is the way to act in this world. And then what is Karma Yoga was defined? If you give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions, that's Karma Yoga. So now my goal is: I have to act in this world, but I want to renounce actions.

So chapter four talked about how to renounce actions in knowledge. Knowing that I'm not the doer, I'll be able to renounce my actions. That renunciation of the sense of agency is sannyasa. In chapter five, we learned what Sannyasa is. Renouncing the anxiety of actions is Karma Yoga. Performing Karma Yoga, I become a Yogi -- I become so efficient in my actions that I realize I am not the doer at all.

And that is sannyasa. Once I renounce this sense of agency, then I have to identify with my true self. So in chapter six we learn the techniques of meditation -- how to give up the identity with the limited self, the conditioned self which I currently consider to be me, and how to align with the true self that we learned about in chapter two. That alignment is chapter six: the techniques of meditation on the self.

But now, how to meditate on the self? What is the subject of my meditation? We learnt that in chapter seven. There we learned that the nature of the true supreme self is twofold. One is Lower Prakriti and one is higher Prakriti. The lower is the one which I can experience, perceive, feel, touch and cognize and say this is it.

So the reality which I can perceive through my senses is the manifest world. The Bhagavan says that's my Lower Prakriti. Everything that you see, touch, feel is made up of my own self. The Asthatha Prakriti. That's his Eightfold which is Bhumi, Apaha, Kham, Analah, Vayuhu, Mana, Buddhi and Ahankar. All five great elements.

Mind, intellect and Ahankal, Ego. So there is nothing left. You take any entity in this world, and it will fall somewhere in this combination of eight -- start recognizing my Saguna Prakriti. This Prakriti has names and forms. But he says there is a higher Prakriti which is beyond this Saguna Prakriti -- the Nirguna Prakriti, which has no names, no forms, no colors, no attributes, no entity, no being.

He said that's my Higher Prakriti. That Prakriti is what I'm now trying to align myself with in my meditation, because I can already identify with the Saguna Prakriti. So we started our journey from "me" -- being the most selfish person, only thinking about "this is me." Then we expand our horizon and say, I'm a little better than that; I identify with my family.

I expand my horizon even more and say, no, no -- my community is also me, not just my family. Then I expand a little further and say, no, no, my nation is also me. Then I go even further -- Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam -- this planet is my home.

And then I say I'm going to go beyond that. And this cosmos is me. This gradually expanding my identification from this limited me to cosmic me. From a Saguna perspective is which I can do with my open eyes meditation. But then I have to go to the higher Prakriti that is beyond all the names and forms. Bhagawan says that's my imperishable nature.

That's Akshara Brahma. So chapter eight now attempts to explain what that higher nature is. In the last chapter, in the ending two verses, Bhagavan said that one who knows myself in its totality -- Adhibutam, Adhi Daivam and Adhiyagnam -- even at the time of death, even that becomes a glimpse. At the last minute this complete picture becomes clear to me: what is Saguna Prakriti?

What is Nirguna Prakriti? And what is this creation is all about? So now Arjuna obviously wants to know all the technical terms he heard in last chapter. So the chapter eight start with Arjuna's question. And as we have seen, he asked Bhagavan to define seven terms he has heard in his discourse. What is that Brahman which you are talking about?

Then what is Adhyatma Kim? We talked about actions we know. Without action I cannot even survive. I cannot maintain my body. Then what is Adhibhuta? You talked about Adhibhuta in the last chapter. Kim Proktam Adhi Daivam -- and what is called Adhidaivam? What is it that we call Adhi Daivam? Adi Yagna Katham Ko ata Katham -- what is Yajna and how does it work?

Adi Yajna is Dehe asmin Madhusudhana. We have discussed Madhu Sudhana, the slayer of Madhu. Madhu was a demon in our life -- that which feels very good is my enemy. I learned that in old age, the only taste that survives is sweet. I was talking to one of our friends who said, "I don't know why, but I never liked sweets in my life."

"And now in my old age I like nothing but sweets." Isn't it very simple? All your taste buds die as you grow older. The only ones that survive are the sweet taste buds. So the only thing I really taste is sweetness. Everything else is not very enchanting anymore.

The slayer of Madhu is Madhu Sudhana. O Madhu Sudhana, Prayana kale cha Katham Gneyo asi Niyatatma Bihi -- in the last verse of the last chapter, he said that even at the last moment, if you know this, know myself as Adhi Bhuta, Adhi Deva, Adi Yajna. How do I know even at the last minute? You tell me, how should I know? And how do I make sure that I will know? How do I live a self-controlled life? Niyatatma Bhi -- self-control so that I will know you at the last minute. He recognized that at least there is some exercise I have to do.

Not just relying on luck or chance that I will remember him at the last minute just because I named my son after him. In fact, he may distract me -- because "Rama, Rama, O Rama" went away from here to Austin, Texas. I'm glad that I have only one son, and his name is not after any Devta. Niraj! So Arjuna says, just let me know. All other six questions were relatively less important. What he really wanted to know about was the last minute -- that was the real question. How do I live a self-controlled life so that even at the last minute I will know your real self? And why is the last minute so important here? That's a milestone. When I decide that I'm going to take a vacation, that's a change -- from here I'm going there. Till that time, it doesn't matter; I'm here. Mawlik moving from here to Dallas, Texas.

The day he moves is a milestone. Till that, he is just Mawlik. So Prayana Kale Apicha -- because I know that I will have the transition from this self to that existence, how do I make sure that I go to the right place, to know you? The answer comes in the next two verses, which actually, if we wanted to discuss fully, could take six months. We'll do it in the next 10 minutes.

Aksharam Brahma Paramam. Very simple. Brahman is Akshara -- that which is imperishable is Brahman. Everything that I know in this world is perishable. Brahman is imperishable. That means anything which I can assign a beginning and end is not Brahman. Aksha Ra, that Akshay.

That which makes "I" revel in that form is Akshara. That's why the letters are called Akshara -- because they become real to us. So Saguna, from that perspective, is Akshara. But Paramam -- Aksaram Brahma Paramam -- that which is higher than Akshara is Brahman. So from that definition, that which is greater than Saguna, different than Saguna is Brahman.

So now I have to negate everything that I know and go beyond my knowledge. Therefore it is transcendental -- it cannot be learned through intellect, cannot be experienced through my mind. It is transcendental. Svabhava Adhyatma Uchyate.

They ask, what is Adhyatma? It is Svabhava -- the nature of your own self. That which makes me who I am is my Svabhava. Bhagavan Sankaracharya says that that which makes me who I am is Paramatma. When he resides in me, he is Pratyagatma.

And when that Pratyagatma identifies with this body, mind, and intellect, it becomes the Jiva. It is something between the Jivatma as I know myself and the all-pervading Paramatma. The part of him which is me is Pratyagatma. That is my svabhava; without that I cannot do anything. Therefore he says, when I know my own self, that is Adhyatma. Arjuna's seven questions in these verses reveal a fundamental human longing: to understand the ultimate nature of reality and our place within it. Before we can embark on any meaningful spiritual journey, we must first ask the right questions. Take time today to examine your own burning questions about existence. What is it that you truly want to know?

Krishna defines Karma here not as mere ritual, but as "Bhuta Bhava Udbhavakara"—that which creates improvement and brings beings into existence. This revolutionary definition transforms how we view our daily activities. Ask yourself: Are my actions today merely labor, or are they true Karma—creative endeavors that contribute to the betterment of myself and others?

The teaching that Brahman is "Akshara" (imperishable) while everything we can perceive is perishable invites deep contemplation. Consider making a list of what you cling to most tightly—possessions, relationships, achievements, identity. Recognize that all these fall within the realm of the perishable Lower Prakriti. This is not meant to create despair, but clarity. The practice is to hold these things lightly while turning your attention toward that which cannot be destroyed. In meditation today, try to shift your identification from the Saguna (with attributes) to the Nirguna (without attributes)—from the room space of your conditioned self to the infinite space of pure awareness. What would it feel like to expand your identification beyond "me" to family, community, nation, planet, and ultimately, the cosmos itself?

snippets.title: Day 107: Remembrance at Death
snippets.sanskrit:
अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम् |

अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम् |

यं यं वापि स्मरन्भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम् |

adhibhūtaṃ kṣaro bhāvaḥ puruṣaścādhidaivatam .

antakāle ca māmeva smaranmuktvā kalevaram .

yaṃ yaṃ vāpi smaranbhāvaṃ tyajatyante kalevaram .

So Bhagavan in verse 5 gives the same answer which he gave as a statement at the end of chapter 7.

From this body to somewhere else. From this existence to some other existence. Existence is not questioned. It is the state of existence which is questioned here. Whether will I remain in the same state of existence that I am? Will I retain my wisdom or will I retain my stupidity is the question.

One who even at the last minute recognizes the truth. He will come to know me. He will come to become one with me. There is no question about it. But by the time she had already pressed that button. So then she started reading all the opinions and the comments. They're all pretty bad. This is not a product for elderly. You can fall down also. It took me three times it broke down.

We said cancel that order as quickly as you can. Because they didn't guarantee anything. They only offered a free trial for 30 days. Bhagwan gave the guarantee. But realize that you will be looking for some support, watching some comments from other users. So he makes his supporting argument.

A statement of fact: whosoever you are thinking of at the time of leaving your body, that and that person alone you shall go to. Looking at our own context of life -- who do we meet in life? The people whom we think about most. We constantly think about a person. Then we obviously make a plan to meet. When my mother was alive, I was thinking about her the most. Every two years I was making a plan to go and see her.

Now I really have not. Even though I have my brothers and my nephews and nieces, it's not that much of a pressure on me to go to India anymore. Because I was thinking about my mother all the time. I was feeling guilty that I have left my mother at the age of 17 or 18. Never went home, never took care of her. So constantly was thinking about her.

And therefore my plans will be no other vacation. Go to India, stay with her for a few days. So Bhagavan said that it is a given: whatever is my constant thought becomes the last thought at the time of my journey. Where will you go for vacation? Not to a place you have never thought about. The vacation you are planning for the last six months -- you have checked all the brochures, checked out all the prices, checked out all the hotel accommodations available, researched all the places to visit. Then, at the time of your journey to take a vacation --

That's the ticket you buy and that's the place you end up going. Bhagavan says, one who is constantly thinking about me is the only one who will be thinking about me at the time of death to come to me. Therefore the next verse says, tasmat sarveshu kaleshu -- therefore at all times, mam anusmara, think about me. And then he says, Yudhyacha Swamiji says that this half sloka, if misunderstood, can bring down the entire generation.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna's guarantee in verse 5 is remarkable: "Whosoever at the time of death thinks only of Me... assuredly he will know Me." This is not about luck at the final moment, but about the power of lifelong habits of thought. The teaching "Yam yam vapi smaran bhavam" reveals a profound psychological truth—we become what we consistently think about. Examine your mental habits today: Where does your mind naturally drift when it is unoccupied? What do you think about first thing in the morning and last thing at night? These habitual thought patterns are shaping your inner trajectory. Just as you naturally plan vacations to places you have been researching for months, your consciousness will move toward whatever you have been contemplating most deeply.

The verse distinguishes between Adhibhuta (the perishable realm of matter) and the imperishable Self that Krishna represents. This is an invitation to shift your planning horizon. Most of our planning is short-term—this life, this career, this relationship. But these verses invite us to consider: What if you planned for your long-term existence across many lives? This week, practice the "mother meditation"—think of someone you love deeply, as the teacher spoke of thinking constantly about his mother. Notice how that consistent thought naturally creates action (visiting, caring, connecting). Now apply this same principle to your spiritual aspiration. What would it mean to think about the Supreme Self with that same consistency and devotion? Begin simply: set three reminders on your phone each day to pause and remember your true imperishable nature.

"Tasmat sarveshu kaleshu mam anusmara yudhya cha"—"Therefore meditate always on Me, and fight." Swamiji warns that this half-verse, if misunderstood, can bring down an entire generation. The key insight is that Krishna is not asking us to abandon our duties to sit in constant prayer. Rather, He asks us to fight the battle of life while maintaining remembrance of our true nature. This is the integration of action and awareness. Today, experiment with this teaching: Choose one routine activity—washing dishes, commuting, exercising—and practice holding a background awareness of your deeper Self while fully engaging in the task. Notice how this dual awareness affects both the quality of your work and your inner state.

Verse 9 offers a powerful word-picture for meditation on the Supreme: "Kavim Puranam Anusasitaram"—the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler of all; "Anor aniyamsam"—subtler than the subtlest atom; "Aditya varnam tamasa parastat"—brilliant like the sun, beyond all darkness. This is not a form to visualize, but qualities to contemplate. The Supreme is self-effulgent—it does not need anything else to reveal itself, just as your own awareness needs nothing external to be known to you. In your meditation this week, rather than trying to picture a form, rest in the quality of awareness itself. Notice that you are aware. That awareness is self-revealing. Can you find where that awareness ends? Can you locate its boundaries? This pathless investigation is the meditation Krishna recommends for those who would attain "the Supreme Purusha, the Resplendent One."

snippets.title: Day 109: Reaching the Supreme
snippets.sanskrit:
प्रयाणकाले मनसाऽचलेन

यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति

सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
prayāṇakāle manasā.acalena bhaktyā yukto yogabalena caiva .

yadakṣaraṃ vedavido vadanti viśanti yadyatayo vītarāgāḥ .

sarvadvārāṇi saṃyamya mano hṛdi nirudhya ca .
verseTranslations: He who leaves the body with mind unmoved and filled with devotion, by the power of his meditation gathering between his eyebrows his whole vital energy, attains the Supreme.

Now I will speak briefly of the imperishable goal, proclaimed by those versed in the scriptures, which the mystic attains when free from passion, and for which he is content to undergo the vow of continence.

These verses reveal a practical meditation technique: "Sarva dvarani samyamya"—close all the gates of the senses; "Mano hridi nirudhya"—draw the mind inward to the heart; "Murdhni adhaya atmanah pranam"—focus the vital energy in the head. This is not esoteric instruction reserved for advanced yogis—it describes what happens naturally when we truly withdraw attention from external stimulation. Consider how retreats work: by removing radio, television, and now phones, we close the gates of information that constantly agitate the mind. This week, create a mini-retreat for yourself. Set aside 20 minutes where you consciously close all "gates"—no phone, no conversation, no reading. Notice how when external input stops, awareness naturally turns inward and begins to settle in the "heart"—the center of your being.

The teaching about focusing pranas in the head during meditation has a practical interpretation for daily practice. When you sit for meditation, begin by noticing where you feel "alive" in your body—this is prana. Through breath awareness, gradually let go of awareness of your limbs, your torso, and gather your sense of aliveness into your head, particularly between your eyebrows. This is not about straining; it is about selective attention. Just as you can choose to feel the sensation in your left thumb right now, you can choose to center your awareness. The goal, as verse 11 states, is to glimpse "that imperishable state which the knowers of the Vedas speak of"—a state without limitation, without sorrow, of pure bliss. Your 20-minute meditation becomes a dress rehearsal for the ultimate letting go. What are you practicing? What are you becoming skilled at releasing?

snippets.reflection:
"Om iti ekaksharam Brahma"—Om, the single syllable, is Brahman. This verse introduces the most practical tool for meditation: the sacred syllable Om. Unlike complex visualizations or elaborate rituals, Om is simple, portable, and universally accessible. It represents all of creation, sustenance, and dissolution—past, present, and future—compressed into one sound. This week, practice the progression described: begin chanting Om aloud, then gradually soften it to a whisper, then to a mental repetition, then let even that dissolve into silent awareness. Notice how the sound carries your attention inward naturally. The instruction "Mam anusmaran"—"remembering Me"—reminds us that Om is not just a sound to repeat mechanically, but a symbol pointing to the all-pervading Self.

Verse 14 offers an extraordinary promise: "Ananya chetah satatam yo mam smarati nityashah, tasya aham sulabhah"—"To one who thinks of Me constantly with undivided mind, I am easy to attain." The word "sulabhah" (easy to attain) is striking. Usually we think of God-realization as the most difficult achievement. Krishna reverses this: for the devoted practitioner with one-pointed focus, it is natural and easy. The difficulty lies only in our divided attention. Examine your attention today: How many competing loyalties divide your mind? How many contradictory desires pull you in different directions? Verse 15 reveals the ultimate result: those who reach the Supreme "go no more to the misery and death of earthly life." This is not about escaping the world, but about completing the curriculum. Once perfection is gained, there is no need to return to the school of suffering. What would it mean to approach each day as if you were completing your final semester?
