snippets.transliteration:
ābrahmabhuvanāllokāḥ punarāvartino.arjuna .

sahasrayugaparyantamaharyad brahmaṇo viduḥ .

avyaktād vyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame .
verseTranslations: The worlds, with the whole realm of creation, come and go; but, O Arjuna, whoso comes to Me, for him there is no rebirth.
Those who understand the cosmic day and cosmic night know that one day of creation is a thousand cycles, and that the night is of equal length.
At the dawning of that day all objects in manifestation stream forth from the Unmanifest, and when evening falls they are dissolved into It again.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 8, Akshara Brahma Yoga Yoga of Imperishable Brahman this world which I live in has things and beings. Things have their production date or date of creation and will also have a date of destruction. Beings have their birth dates and will also have their death dates. Nothing in this world remains permanently. Everything is perishable, exists for a limited period in both time and space. But this ever changing reality which I experience as the world cannot exist unless there is an imperishable substratum.

And Bhagavan said in this chapter that Brahman is that imperishable reality. Brahman is the truth which makes all other relative truths possible. For example, I can say this room exists. That's a statement of truth. But it only exists because the another universal truth exists. That is the room space existed before this room was built.

It is right now here as room space and will remain space when this room will be destroyed. So based on that universal reality which I call space, the relative reality, what I call room space can exist. Bhagavan says the Brahman in a similar way exists. As Bhagawan Shankaracharya says, the principle that graces all bodies is their essential self. Any being will not be aware of his own self unless that principle, imperishable immortal principle is residing in that body. With that consciousness I become aware of my conditioning which I call my body, mind and intellect.

And then I'm aware of myself. So it is the self-knowing reality -- the very nature of Brahman -- which makes me aware of myself as that conditioned self. Right now I'm not aware of my supreme self that is imperishable, deathless, and birthless. But I'm aware of myself as this limited body, limited mind, limited intellect -- as Nil Bhatt -- because of that consciousness which is functioning through me.

So Bhagavan says that that consciousness is now making you aware of your own limitations and also making you aware of the existence of this world of perishable nature. As long as I am conditioned and identified with this body, mind, and intellect, I will have all the limitations of this body, mind, and intellect.

And therefore the sorrows, therefore unhappiness. And therefore I feel bound by these limitations. My goal is to liberate myself from my limitations, my unhappiness, my sorrows and attain a state of bliss where there never will be any sorrow, never will be any limitations and never will be any unhappiness. Bhagavan said, that can only happen when you identify with me, the imperishable, and not with the one who is conditioned by your body, mind, and intellect. As long as I remain aware of the limitations of the room, I will only be seeing the space as room space. But if I want to see this space as immortal --

If I never want to get this space destroyed, I'll be always afraid of what happens if someone destroys this building. If earthquake happens or a meteor falls on my property, well, it will be destroyed. Is the room space getting destroyed? But right now I'm more identified with the conditioning than the space itself. And therefore that fear of destruction. If my identification was not with the conditioning, just the space.

This is my land and this is my space, and I want to own this thing forever. But here's the thing: nothing can destroy the space itself. The only thing that can be destroyed is whatever you have built on that land. The space will never be destroyed. But as long as my identification is with that building on that land, I'll be afraid. When my identification goes beyond that, then I will not be afraid of the destruction of the building.

So Bhagavan said, one who identifies with me will come to attain me. Antakale cha mam eva kalevaram ya prayati sa mad bhavam yati na asti atra sansayah. There is no doubt that one who gives up this identification with body, mind, and intellect -- treating the leaving of this identification as the death -- and thinking about me alone, will come to me. There is no doubt about that. So the advice we have seen so far says: therefore, tasmat sarveshu kaleshu mam anusmara yudhya cha -- engage in this battle of life constantly remembering me as your true self.

Not this conditioned self as your true self, but me, the imperishable, who is making it possible for you to function. Fight this battle of life with that in mind, and you shall be liberated from these limitations. You will come to be one with me, and once you become one with me, after that there is no coming and going again. Mam upetya punar janma dukhalayam ashashvatam na apnuvanti.

Having attained me, there is no coming and going back to this house of pain we call this world. But now Bhagavan says, in a stark contrast to the ones who have identified with me and one who has become one with me. If you're striving to achieve that liberation but haven't reached that prerequisite qualification, then you will constantly come back and forth. So the next verse 16 says, A Brahma Bhuvanat lokah punaravartino Arjuna Mam upetya tu Kaunteya punarjanma na vidyate -- all the worlds up to the world of Brahmaji, Brahmaloka, are subject to birth and rebirth. Punara vartina -- constantly coming again and again, coming back to the same cycle.

One who reaches me, there is no rebirth for him. So what does that mean, reaching up to the world of Brahmaji? Brahmaji is the creator. As we know in our Hindu Trinity, Brahma is the creator, Vishnu is the sustainer and Shiva is the destroyer. This creation, sustenance, and destruction is constantly going on in this world. Brahma is the ultimate creator of this entire universe. In our concept of Hiranyagarbha in Vedanta, Brahma represents the ultimate creator -- the total mind and total intellect. I am the creator of my own world. You are the creator of your world, and she is the creator of her world. We create our world through our mind and intellect, depending on our desires and vasanas. Now, if I take this group and look at it as one -- individually we have our vasanas and desires, but we also have group vasanas and desires.

So we'll say, well, when are we going to have the Janmastami next? So everybody will say, well, I would like to have it on such and such and let's do this and let's do that. These common thoughts put together what we call it a planning, a group planning will have group activity. So that's a mind which is expanded from my mind to a group's mind. You can continue to expand this mind and intellect, including more and more people and beings into it. When you reach the ultimate limit of all the beings and things, all the minds and intellects put together -- that is Brahmaji, Brahma the creator.

When my identification rises from me to my family, to my neighborhood, to my community, I'm expanding my identity and including them as my own self. So I may be making progress in my spiritual evolution by expanding my identity, but until I reach that pre-qualifying limit, I still have to come back over and over again.

Well, it is something like this. If you are taking any licensing examination -- for those of you who are professionals who have to take the licensing exam, you probably know all about it. I took mine in this country when I came here in 1984, and I knew that it was going to be difficult because I had barely come here, had no experience in this country, and people had already warned me: it's going to take you a long time to get this license, simply because there were nine parts to the exam and you have to clear all nine parts to get a license.

So the firm I had joined initially a large firm, and there were at least about a couple of hundred people, at least at any given year, there are about 60 to 80 people taking exams. So they told me, "Take it easy, Neil. You just came to this country; it's going to take you eight to ten years before you can pass this exam." And I said, "What do you mean by that? I don't understand what you're saying. Why should it take so long?" They said, "Well, here is how it works."

"You'll take the exams and probably pass maybe two parts out of nine. Then you will come back next year and may pass another couple of parts, then come back the year after and may pass one or two." People who experienced this had formulated an average: it takes about six to ten years for somebody to get licensed as an architect in this country after graduating from architecture school. Because until you pass all nine parts -- and if you fail any one subject more than three times, you take all nine parts all over again. There were some people I knew who had already given up taking these licensing exams. I said, "Well, all you have to do is pass all nine parts and it will be fine." They said, "Yeah, that sounds easy, but it is not." That was obviously their perception.

So they go, take the exam, come back, take the exam and come back -- till you reach a point when the ninth part is cleared, then you get a license. And even after passing all nine parts and getting a license, you still have to maintain your continuing education to remain effective as an architect.

This is something like our spiritual journey. Bhagavan said that we are all pursuing our spiritual evolution as seekers, reaching from the level we are at right now to the next level as we make more progress. But at the time of death, if my evolution has not risen to the level where I can be liberated, I'll have to come back -- just as with the exams.

If I haven't cleared all nine parts, I have to come back next year to clear whatever parts are left. Same way, in our spiritual journey, things we have learned and things yet to be learned will decide how many times I have to come back. This is driven by my desires and vasanas. My desires will make me come back to that state, that stage where I feel comfortable that I can make progress from here. After I pass my high school graduation, I go to undergraduate school. I cannot just say, "After my high school graduation, leave me alone -- my education is finished."

To get to a doctorate level, I have to make my own efforts. So up to the world of Brahmaji. In the world of Brahmaji, you have the identification with this entire creation. And as Swamiji explains here that in the concept of gradual liberation, Karma Mukti, which is accepted in Vedanta, it basically says that karma with Upasana can lead you to the realm of Brahmaji. If you do your karma diligently with devotion to the Lord, you will reach a state of identification where you will feel the whole world is your own being and you reach the world of Brahmaji. Once reaching that, there is no coming back.

From that, you will just merge into the supreme Brahman.
snippets.reflection:
"A Brahma bhuvana lokah punar avartino Arjuna"—even up to the world of Brahma, all realms are subject to return. This teaching shatters any notion of a permanent heavenly destination short of complete liberation. The analogy of professional licensing examinations is illuminating: just as you must pass all nine parts to become a licensed architect, you must complete your entire spiritual curriculum to achieve liberation. Failing any part means returning to retake it. Consider your own spiritual "exam results": What subjects have you mastered? What areas still need work? Patience, forgiveness, non-attachment, selfless service—which of these do you still struggle with? Each challenge in life is an examination. Each failure is simply an invitation to return and try again until mastery is achieved.

The cosmic scale presented here—one day of Brahma equals a thousand yugas, approximately 4.32 billion years—puts our earthly concerns in perspective. Your current frustrations, achievements, and dramas are occurring within a cosmic blink. Verse 18 describes how all beings stream forth at the dawn of Brahma's day and dissolve back into the unmanifest at cosmic night. Your individual existence is part of this vast breathing rhythm of the universe. This week, practice holding this expanded perspective when you encounter stress or conflict. Ask yourself: "In the scale of Brahma's day, how significant is this problem?" This is not to dismiss your real concerns, but to loosen the grip of identification. The teaching points to the one place beyond this cosmic rhythm: "Mam upetya tu Kaunteya punar janma na vidyate"—reaching Me, there is no rebirth. What would it mean to identify with the eternal witness of this cosmic dance rather than being swept along as a participant?

snippets.title: Day 112: The Two Paths
snippets.sanskrit:
भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते |

परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः |

अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम् |
snippets.transliteration:
bhūtagrāmaḥ sa evāyaṃ bhūtvā bhūtvā pralīyate .

parastasmāttu bhāvo.anyo.avyakto.avyaktātsanātanaḥ .

avyakto.akṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim .
verseTranslations: The same multitude of beings, which have lived on earth so often, all are dissolved as the night of the universe approaches, to issue forth anew when morning breaks. Thus is it ordained.
In truth, therefore, there is the Eternal Unmanifest, which is beyond and above the Unmanifest Spirit of Creation, which is never destroyed when all these beings perish.
The wise say that the Unmanifest and Indestructible is the highest goal of all; when once That is reached, there is no return. That is My Blessed Home.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 8, Akshara Brahma Yoga Yoga of Imperishable Brahman as we have seen that we are trying to understand the nature of the supreme reality, so we have to do some heavy lifting here to understand the underlying concepts. In the beginning, we heard from Bhagavan that Brahman is imperishable, immutable, and self-knowledge is its nature. What is the nature of Brahman? It is self-knowledge. It does not require any other aid to understand it. It is self-effulgent.

It's very nature is self knowledge. With its creative force, it works to create things and beings. What his work is that which creates these things and beings. That Brahman which is imperishable, its nature is self knowledge. With its own creative force, it works to create things and beings. Then what is nature of the things and beings that Brahman has created?

Brahman is imperishable, but anything that is created by its creative force is perishable. That because the very act of creation gives it a birth date, it's now created. Something is created, therefore it will have its own life. Then it will get destroyed. It will have a limited shelf life as we call it, no matter how long. That is what makes those things and beings function as they are.

The Daivam is that same Brahman remaining within each created entity -- that Daivam makes the thing or being possible as a creation. And when these things and beings are reacting with each other, it's only possible because Brahman remains present as the Yajnam in all the activities -- that Supreme Being is present in every action. Therefore all activities are possible in this world of created beings. The analogy we have heard before is like my dream. I as the conscious being have experiences in my waking world.

The same experiences at night gets all jumbled up. My mind creates its own world. Out of my own mind, I create my own world. That mind by itself creates various entities, things and beings in My dream. Those entities are acting in the dream because I am in and through available to project the dream. But when I wake up, all those entities, things and beings are now unmanifest.

Till next time I go to sleep again and dream again. So this is what we have seen is how the overall cosmos is functioning at the level of Brahman. Him remaining supreme, unchangeable with his self knowledge, with his own creative force, he works to create these things and beings. These things and beings, their Gunana Dharma. I studied chemistry in Gujarati -- because I studied all throughout my school days and college days in Gujarati medium. In chemistry they used to ask us, "Padarthana Gunadharmanu Varnan karo" -- describe the characteristics and nature of this substance. So there are two things every substance has: Guna and Dharma.

Guna is the basic characteristics of that substance or a thing or a being. And Dharma is the nature of that substance depending on guna. So what is my Dharma is depending on my gunas. The gunas which I have as an entity creates my Dharma. So Guna and Dharma are related to each other. So Brahman creating things and beings.

Each thing and being has its own Dharma, Guna and Dharma. This Guna and Dharma continues to change as we acquire more impressions. So my guna before I went to architecture school has nothing to do with architecture. In fact, I was not even aware of what architecture is all about. So at that point my Dharma had nothing to do with architectural knowledge or practice. More I acquired the architectural knowledge.

My gunas changed, so my Dharma changed. So now I practice architecture. So Guna Dharma is constantly changing this evolutionary path a thing or being takes in the creation itself. So Bhagavan said that this creation is now guided by its own laws, where each thing and being is driven by their own Guna and Dharma. What will be my next state of existence? It depends on the gunas which I am creating through my experiences -- as a practicing architect or as a Bhagavad Gita student.

So my next state of existence can only be evolution from a present state. It cannot completely change overnight from where I am today. So that's the evolutionary path each thing and being in the creation takes. So from some stardust, my original evolution started and then that keeps changing. Gunanayana Dharma came to this level where I am today. I read in some one of these popular science books that our atoms in the body continues to change.

They are not the same atoms, because our body's cells change every few years. And they said it is possible that the atoms which existed in Shakespeare's body or Rama's body or Krishna's body have passed through my body at one point -- because there is a finite amount of energy, a finite amount of matter, and all things and beings are created out of that. The nature of this cosmos is that one thing changes into the shape and form of another and continues.

So where I am today is the product of my past -- from that stardust to who I am today. My future would be the product of my present plus my past. The advice then given to us is this: if you want to accelerate this evolution and not go through this gradual path of changing Guna and Dharma, you can directly relate to the Source. We have seen that Brahman is imperishable, immutable, and created this universe out of his own creative force as the efficient cause.

Material cause was the only thing available to Brahman, which is his own self. He created this universe out of his own self. And each creation has limited life. Creation remains perishable, but the underlying material which creates this universe remains imperishable. So either I can identify with my Guna and a Dharma today and then take a step next forward in the same path of my evolution, or I can short circuit this whole cycle and go straight to my source where I started. So that's the advice in this chapter.

At the time of death -- death is the end of this state of existence. The death of today will create tomorrow. At the time of this transition, whatever I think would be my next state of existence, that's what I will become. Bhagawan said, you can focus directly on the Source and become the Source. Up to Brahma Loka, the world of Brahma, everything has coming and going. As long as we are within the realm of this Prakriti -- which is made up of nothing but the total things and beings in this world -- I will keep recycling from one state of existence to another.

And we have said how long this will continue -- as long as Brahma is creating and dissolving. We see our own day and night in our day-to-day activities. Day is the active part of my life. Night is the inactive part of my life. Superimposing the same concept on Brahmaji, the total creator:

I am the creator of my world. You are the creator of your world. She is the creator of her world. When you put all things and beings together, all the ideas and vasanas and thoughts together create cosmic mind. The cosmic mind has the latency to create this cosmos. And that's called Hiranyagarpa, the golden embryo, which is all the possibilities of creating everything that is in this cosmos that continues to be go in the cycles of activity and inactivity.

When Brahma is actively creating, it's his day. When he takes rest and is inactive, it's night for him. We superimpose our experience: my day is activity, my night is inactivity. It's not so different now with nightlife, but 5,000 years ago they probably didn't have nightlife. So what is Brahma's day? Brahma's day is a thousand eons. So for thousand eons this activity of creation continues. Things changing from one thing to another to another. And then Brahmaji takes rest. All the things which he has created now goes into dormant state. Not destroyed, but in a dormant state.

Just as I, the architect, goes into dormant state from Friday to Sunday. But that doesn't mean the architect in me has died. Architect in me will wake up on Monday morning and start all over again. So all the ideas and thoughts and vasanas in this total mind go into hibernation, into a dormant state. How long does that last? Another thousand eons.

So we did some calculation the other day: 4.32 billion years is one day. A thousand of these makes 4.32 billion years, and you take two of them -- day and night -- that's 8.6-something billion years, one complete cycle. So when you think about your journey, this is what continues from day to night, day and night, from one state of existence to another. And if you as the entity are not really happy about it, then there is an escape hatch: take refuge in me, identify with the Source.

As long as I'm watching David Copperfield performing magic, it's wonderful to watch and get enchanted by it and then keep thinking, how does he do it? Till one day I show up when he is preparing for his show and say, I want to be your apprentice, sir. And he takes me and then he shows me and then I see how all these tricks are done and then all magic is gone. Now I'm not confused. Now when he's cutting the lady in half, I know exactly what he's doing. Till that time, I have to keep coming back. Till I reach Brahma Loka, the Creator's own world, I will be coming back into the same cycle. But then when I reach there and identify with the source, I will become one with that. So it gives us a scale. My quest in life to achieve happiness is not a short-term thing, even though I put it in short-term goals and long-term goals. But in the end I want happiness. If you just extend that quest to Brahma's day and night and work towards your goal, the only way to achieve that is to identify with the source. Avyakta d vyaktayaha Sarvaha prabhavanti aha Agame. So all those things in beings with all their guna and Dharma are in dormant state. When Brahmaj is inactive, which we consider as a dissolution. Pralaya, Vishnu, lying in a Kshira, Shira, Samudra, milky ocean.

There are no vasanas, pure Sattva, then there is no activity. If it is pure Sattva, there is no activity. Rajas and Tamas has to be there. So when you are in a pure state of Sattva, there is no activity. But all other things in being there in dormant state. All the other thoughts are in dormant state.

Just as when I go to sleep, all my thoughts about what I'm going to be doing next week are in dormant state. Not that I've forgotten anything about it. I'm just in dormant state. As soon as I wake up on Monday morning, we all come into being and becomes my work and my activity and my creation. Avyakta, vyaktaha, sarvaha prabhavanti ahaha made the arrival of the day. All those who were unmanifest now becomes manifest in all those who are manifest during the day.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce the concept of Guna and Dharma—the characteristics that define who we are and the duties that arise from them. The teaching that "where I am today is the product of my past" and "my future would be the product of my present" offers both responsibility and hope. You are not trapped by your current limitations; you are simply at one point on an evolutionary journey that stretches across lifetimes. The fascinating scientific observation that our atoms are constantly recycling—that atoms once in Shakespeare's or Krishna's body may have passed through yours—points to the material interconnectedness of all existence. This week, reflect on your own Guna-Dharma evolution: What qualities did you have ten years ago that have now transformed? What new capacities have emerged? What qualities are you currently cultivating that will shape your future self?

Verse 20 reveals there is something beyond even the unmanifest Prakriti from which creation emerges: "Paras tasmat tu bhavo anyo avyakto avyaktat sanatanah"—"Beyond this unmanifest is another Unmanifest, eternal, which does not perish when all beings perish." This is the ultimate goal—not just a better position within the cycle, but transcendence of the cycle itself. The analogy of watching a magician perform is apt: as long as you sit in the audience, you are enchanted by the illusion. But when you become the magician's apprentice and learn how the tricks work, the magic dissolves into understanding. Verse 21 promises: "Yam prapya na nivartante"—having reached this, one does not return. This is not a distant goal. The teaching offers a "short circuit": rather than evolving slowly through countless incarnations, you can go directly to the Source through knowledge and devotion. Today, ask yourself: Am I content to improve my position within the dream, or am I ready to wake up?

snippets.title: Day 113: Reaching the Supreme
snippets.sanskrit:
पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया |

यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः |

अग्निर्जोतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम् |
snippets.transliteration:
puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā .

yatra kāle tvanāvṛttimāvṛttiṃ caiva yoginaḥ .

agnirjotirahaḥ śuklaḥ ṣaṇmāsā uttarāyaṇam .
verseTranslations: *Now I will tell thee, O Arjuna, of the times at which, if the mystics go forth, they do not return, and at which they go forth only to return.

If knowing the Supreme Spirit the sage goes forth with fire and light, in the daytime, in the fortnight of the waxing moon and in the six months before the Northern summer solstice, he will attain the Supreme.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter eight, Imperishable Brahman. We are coming to the last concluding verses of this chapter. In chapter seven, we learned about the nature of the supreme as the Higher Prakriti and the Lower Prakriti. He said, my Lower Prakriti is Eightfold Prakriti which is manifest. My Higher Prakriti which supports this lower Prakriti. So that higher Prakriti is the imperishable Brahman, which is the substratum for this Lower Prakriti.

That which is manifest is supported by that which is Unmanifest. That Unmanifest is the Supreme Brahman, the Imperishable. So chapter eight is our quest to understand the imperishable Brahman. We've been discussing the nature of the Imperishable Brahman. In the beginning we have learned that the nature of that supreme reality is imperishable. He is self knowing and in his work is to create these things and beings.

That same supreme reality creates these things and beings as Prakriti -- the Lower Prakriti, out of his own self. So the world which we see is the manifest world, but it is supported by the Unmanifest. The Unmanifest is imperishable, but the world which it creates is perishable. Prakriti is infinite, just as Brahman is infinite. Prakriti is ever-existing, just as Brahman is ever-existing. But the creations within Prakriti are perishable, because the same entity which creates these things and beings will keep creating and destroying. Brahma, the Creator, while he is working -- that's his day.

When he's not working, that's his night. And we have seen that how long the Brahma's day is compared to hours. Then in the end we have talked about how can the individual ego, the individual entity which finds itself to be limited by these limitations of mind and intellectual, can rise above this limitations and reach the Supreme. Why I'm suffering through my limitations. And therefore there are Sorrows. If I was having no limitation, there will not be any sorrow.

So my quest in life is to get over all my limitations. So when I transit from one existence to another, my goal is always to get to a stage which has less limitations or no limitations. So we talked about the one who dies with that thought of imperishable in mind will lead the imperishable. One who dies with the goal of achieving something will get to that state of achievement. Those who worship Devas will go to Devas. Those who worship Brahman will go to Brahman.

Then we elaborately discussed how to get to that point where we can think about that goal. Verse 21, which was the last one we discussed, says: Avyakto Akshara iti uktah tam ahuh paramam gatim. That which is considered the unmanifest, imperishable -- that is your highest goal. They who reach it never again return. Yam prapya na nivartante. Everyone else has to come back because of some goal or other.

Some desire or other which is unfulfilled. And I want to fulfill it. I want to achieve their capabilities and then achieve that goal. So to achieve that, now I'm in a pursuit of happiness. Because my happiness is somewhere else. I have to come back to pursue my happiness.

But one who wants to achieve that happiness which is supreme, then he doesn't have to come back. And therefore it says that your goal is to achieve that unmanifest and imperishable that is considered the highest goal. They who reach it never again return. Bhagwan says, that is my highest abode. That's what my my abode is. All this time we had been discussing and thinking about what is the nature of the Lord and where does he reside.

He says, that is my abode and that's my nature. My nature is supreme, imperishable, unmanifest. My abode is that state of awareness -- that's where you will find me. So the next seven verses, which are the concluding verses, say: Purushah sa parah partha bhaktya labhyas tu ananyaya. Is it ever possible to achieve that state of oneness with the imperishable Brahman?

Right now I can achieve oneness with my own limitations -- "this is me." I can also relate to other things in the world and achieve oneness. But it is unthinkable right now to achieve oneness with the supreme imperishable Brahman. Bhagavan gives a guarantee here: it is achievable by Bhaktya labhyas tu ananyaya -- by single-pointed devotion. Single-pointed identification with that imperishable Brahman.

As long as I'm identified with something else, I cannot be identifying with that. As long as I'm identified with my body, my intellect there is no way that I can identify with him. So Bhagavan said, it is possible for Purusha, any person to achieve that by single pointed devotion. That's the only path.

Yasyantahasthani Bhutani. That single pointed devotion for what? That which is the indwelling for all beings. I am trying to achieve understanding about myself. But in that inward journey I have to realize that myself is not just limited to my limited self but it is the self of all the beings. Yesyanta sthani Bhutani.

That's the dwelling place for all beings. Yena sarvam idam tatam -- everything is pervaded by it. That entity with which I want to identify is the dwelling place for all beings and things. With single-pointed devotion, I'm identifying with that. We can very easily identify with people and things similar to us. We have difficulty identifying with people who are a little different from us.

They speak different language, they look different. It's a way I can overcome that. But then I have to identify with entire Jagat and it goes even beyond that and says there is nothing in this universe cosmos where the self is not pervaded. In my inward journey of meditation I have to understand and identify with that entity which does not leave anything out. If I say I love this, but I hate this, well, I have limited him. I created limitation for him and therefore my journey is incomplete.

So now Bhagavan said that I will explain to you how to reach there. And he said there are two paths. Yatra kale to anavrutyam avruttim chevayogina. Well, first qualification. You should be a Yogi.

You are the one who is striving to achieve this liberation that's given. But the striving alone will not guarantee that you will achieve liberation. Because the path you may take. He said he will explain the time and path while parting from this state of existence: one which is the path of return, and one which is the path of no return. We have been trying -- people have been trying -- but we continue to come back to the same world of sorrow.

Prayatha Yanti Tamkalam Vakyami Bharata Sabah. So I will let you know what path will lead you to no return. I also let you know what the path of return. So that's basically just an introduction to the next two verses. Next is Agnihi Jyotihi Ahaha, Shuklaha Shanmasa, Uttarayanam Tatra, Prayahata, Gachanti, Brahma, Brahma Vidojanaha. These two mantas are very, very difficult to understand because from a superficial translation it makes no sense whatsoever.

It says Agni, Jyoti, Ahaha -- fire, light, daytime -- Shuklaha, the bright fortnight, in six months of Uttarayanam. Tatra Prayata Gachanti Brahma, Brahma Vidojanaha -- one who goes through that path, they go to Brahman, the path of no return. The Yogi who knows Brahman goes through this path of light. So now, if we take this literally, that means people who die during these six months have a chance to get liberated, and the other six months have no chance. December 22 to June 21 you get liberation, and after June 22 to December 21 people have to return. That obviously makes no sense. Swamiji explains here that you have to remember the Gita is the essence of Upanishads. Sarva Upanishado Gavo, Dugdham Gopala Nandanam -- all Upanishads are cows, and Gopala Nandana (Krishna) has collected the milk and given it to you. He is the one who collected all the ideas and concepts from the Upanishads and put them in the Bhagavad Gita. You have to study the Upanishads to understand these concepts. These particular two verses about the path of Uttarayana and Dakshinayana are directly taken from the Prashna Upanishad. The Prashna Upanishad elaborately explains the path of Uttarayana and Dakshinayana.

It starts with explaining the creation of this universe -- that Prajapati himself became the sun and the moon. The sun represents energy; the moon represents matter. Then it also explains how the year is created, how a month is created, how a day is created -- one represents energy, the other matter. Anything during the day represents energy. We know that daytime is the domain of the sun -- sunlight, energy, activity. Nighttime is presided over by the moon -- its inactivity.

Darkness -- that's the path of the Moon. So the two paths were thought of as the path of energy and the path of matter; the path of the Sun. With Krama Mukti, the gradual liberation through Upasana and Karmas, you reach through the path of the sun to the Brahmaloka. We also know that we can gradually improve ourselves.

So the good actions are necessary. But we also know that doing good is not good enough. It has to be associated with knowledge. So that is the difference between the two parts. One who is doing good but with a goal of getting something good out of it -- that is the path of return. One who is doing good but without seeking anything in return, seeking only to liberate himself -- those selfless actions are the path of no return. These two are symbolically described in Upanishadic language as the Path of Uttarayana and the Path of Dakshinayana. Another way to look at it: when we face the sun in the morning, we are facing east. On your right side is south, and your left side is north. So the path of Dakshinayana is the sun rising from the east, going through the south, and setting in the west. The path of the north is the path of the rising sun.

And the path of the south is the path of the setting sun. So we are going from the rising sun to daytime, from the setting sun to nighttime. If we associate knowledge and the sacred with the path of the rising sun, that is the path of Uttarayana; the path of the setting sun is the path of Dakshinayana. "Bhaktya labhyas tu ananyaya"—the Supreme is attainable through single-pointed devotion alone. This verse addresses a common concern: Is liberation actually possible for ordinary people like us? Krishna answers emphatically: yes, but the key is "ananya"—undivided, exclusive devotion. This does not mean abandoning responsibilities; it means having only one ultimate allegiance while performing all duties. Examine your divided loyalties today. We easily identify with people similar to us but struggle with those who appear different. Yet the teaching says we must identify with "that in which all beings abide and which pervades the entire universe." This week, practice expanding your circle of identification. When you meet someone who seems very different from you, look for the common awareness that animates both of you. That shared consciousness is the Supreme Self dwelling equally in all.

Verses 23-24 introduce the symbolic paths of Uttarayana (northern course) and Dakshinayana (southern course). Rather than being literal astronomical timings for death, these represent mental and spiritual states. The path of "fire, light, daytime, bright fortnight" symbolizes the illuminated mind filled with knowledge. The opposite path represents the mind clouded with ignorance and attachment. The practical question becomes: What path is your mind currently traveling? Is it moving toward greater light, clarity, and selflessness (Uttarayana)? Or toward greater attachment, confusion, and self-centeredness (Dakshinayana)? The good news is that unlike the literal sun's path, your mental path can be changed at any moment through conscious choice. Today, notice moments when your mind moves toward darkness—worry, resentment, craving—and gently redirect it toward light. Each redirection is a practice run for the ultimate journey.

snippets.title: Day 114: The Imperishable
snippets.sanskrit:
धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम् |

शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगतः शाश्वते मते |

नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन |
snippets.transliteration:
dhūmo rātristathā kṛṣṇaḥ ṣaṇmāsā dakṣiṇāyanam .

śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate .

naite sṛtī pārtha jānanyogī muhyati kaścana .
verseTranslations: But if he departs in gloom, at night, during the fortnight of the waning moon and in the six months before the Southern solstice, then he reaches but lunar light and he will be born again.
These bright and dark paths out of the world have always existed. Whoso takes the former, returns not; he who chooses the latter, returns.*
O Arjuna! The saint knowing these paths is not confused. Therefore meditate perpetually.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter eight and we are coming to the conclusion of chapter eight. Akshara Brahma Yoga, Yoga of Imperishable Brahman. So let's see what we have seen so far in Bhagavad Gita. We are almost at the midpoint of Bhagavad Gita. The teachings in Bhagavad Gita are basically telling us that you are not this limited self; your real nature is the supreme Self. The journey from this limited self to the supreme self is the quest of human life.

So Bhagavan has indicated in chapter one what this limited life is like using Arjuna's situation, that the life is not clearly divided between good and evil, or situations which are black and white, but they come in various shades of gray. And to learn to deal with it is the wisdom. So Bhagawan gave Arjuna the guidance and encapsulated that guidance in Bhagavad Gita for the generations to come, so that we can use the same guidance given to Arjuna for our own lives. So Bhagavan had given Arjuna in the second chapter, a clear indication of what is reality and what is superimposition on the reality. Bhagawan said, we consider ourselves to be mortal beings, but we are immortal beings identified with mortal bodies. This identification is creating all the confusion.

So the goal of life is to get rid of this ignorance about the supreme Self. He defined a man of wisdom, Sthita Prajna -- the one who has balanced his mind and can see the situation clearly without getting tainted by it. Bhagawan gave that wisdom in a nutshell to Arjuna. We learned that what we consider ourselves to be is not really ourselves. We are not limited beings. We are immortal beings identified with mortal bodies. Bhagavan described a man of wisdom -- a Sthita Prajna who sees this clearly because of the purification of his internal instrument. He understands that the self is different than this body, mind and intellect, and the one who is not attached, who is desireless, will achieve this wisdom. The path was then given in the following chapters: how to act in this world without desires or attachment. Chapter three gave us Karma Yoga, with the simple indication that we have no control over the results of our actions, but we do have the right to act.

I have right to act, but I cannot anticipate a particular result. Therefore I should act without any anticipation or expectation -- that's the simple first step. The second step, in chapter four: Bhagavan said you should come to the understanding that the self is not the doer. The self that you call "I" is not participating in any activity. Activities are performed by the body, mind, and intellect -- matter reacting with matter. But the self is not involved.

Therefore in chapter five he says, you should give up the sense of agency -- "I am the doer." Everything is happening at the body level, at the mind level, at the intellect level, but "I" is not involved. I am not doing anything; "I" is not participating in any of these activities. Chapter six then culminated in Dhyana Yoga, the Yoga of Meditation.

How can I contemplate on the real self? Thoughts of the same species, of the same type, when directed towards the goal -- that is called meditation. Meditation is to constantly think about the Supreme Self that I am. My Atma is none other than the Paramatma; that thought held constantly is meditation. Bhagawan defined meditation, the path of meditation, and the techniques of meditation in chapter six.

The second segment of Bhagavad Gita, as we have discussed many times, is about the Supreme Self. The first segment was about Tvam, the "you" part of Tattvamasi. The next six chapters are all about Tat, that Supreme. We defined Tvam, which is right now identified as the little ego.

Tat is the Supreme Self. And if I have to contemplate on that, I need to understand the nature of the supreme self. So in seventh chapter we learned the two aspects of that supreme reality. One is the lower Prakriti, made of the Eightfold manifestation -- Bhumi, Apah, Analah, Vayu, Kham -- that which we can perceive through our senses is the representation of that lower Prakriti. Beyond this lower Prakriti is the Higher Prakriti, which becomes the knower of this lower Prakriti; the self in us becomes the knower, the unmanifest aspect of that self. Bhagavan said, my real nature is beyond these two, and that is veiled by Maya.

That real nature is not available to all of us because it is veiled by Maya. Bhagawan defined Maya as the total conditioning of Ishwara. When that Maya operates at my individual level, it becomes ignorance -- Avidya. This Avidya is not letting me cross Maya itself. So in chapter 8, Bhagavan has given us the means to overcome this Maya.

So we have started this chapter 8 with clear definitions of all these terms we come across. So we have learned that the supreme reality is veiled by Maya. And this projection of the multitude of beings and multitude of realities in physical world is projected through Maya. In the very first verse, Arjuna asked question which basically defines all these terms for us. These terms -- Adhi Yajna and others -- we want clarified for our understanding. If you want to contemplate on the supreme Self, then we need to understand the differentiation between Adhi Bhuta, Adhi Daiva, and Brahman. Brahman is the supreme reality, one without a second. Adhibhuta is the perishable nature of the reality which we experience.

And Adhi Daivam is my own Swabhava. When it operates through me, it becomes Adhi Devam. And Bhagawan in the end said that I alone am the Adhi Yajnam. All the experiences which you have at an individual level are experienced by none other than the supreme self -- because the Self is real. Everything else is nothing but superimposition on it. Therefore Bhagawan says you must identify with this supreme Self to get over this Maya, this superimposition. In the discussion of what happens at the time of departure from this level of existence, we have seen two terms: Antakala and Prayanakala. Antakala is my preparation time -- I have to prepare for this journey. This existence is limited, which is a given, but there will be another existence right after that.

So if I was not really satisfied with my current existence, then I'm obviously looking for a better existence next time. Bhagawan says, that better existence is dependent on how you prepare and how you end this existence. Whatever you are thinking at the time of your departure, that's the destination you will reach. So Bhagawan said, therefore think about me all the time -- that destination which holds the ultimate happiness that you are seeking.

That world without sorrow, without any limitations, without any conditioning. And we have seen that that world is only at the level of Brahman. All the lokas up to Brahma's world are subject to repeated return -- that's called the path of repeated return. We have seen that Maya has three aspects: Tamas, Rajas, and Sattva. Any existence is nothing but a permutation and combination of these three Gunas.

If I am at a level where Tamas is predominant, then I am at the level of complete ignorance. When I rise from that level to the next level, then obviously the Rajas increases and then Tamas reduces. If I rise even further, then the Sattva increases, Rajas diminishes and Tamas diminishes. I can go all the way up to the level of pure Sattva. But as long as I am in Rajas and Tamas, I have to come back to a level of existence which has beginning and end -- that is the path of repeated return. But there is also a path of no return: you have to cross this Prakriti, this Maya. When you cross this Prakriti, there is no coming back to mortal existence. That is the path of no return.

Those two paths are described in the last few verses. The confusion obviously was: is there a particular time, a particular moment, a particular method in which one can depart and not return, or return? Those two paths we have been discussing: Agnihi Jyotihi Ahah Shuklaha Shanmasa Uttarayanam Tatra Prayata Gachanti Brahma Brahma Vido Janaha. This path is called Devayana, the Divine path -- the path which leads to no return. The path of fire, light, daytime, bright fortnight, the six months of the northern solstice. Following this path, men who know Brahman go to Brahman -- the wise people who acquired this knowledge.

Therefore we are going through Gnana, Vignana, Yoga. Knowledge about my supreme self is Gnana. And applying it in my life to get over these limitations is Vignana. So Brahma says, the one who has applied this, he is following the bright path. And these are probably symbolically indicated in Upanishads or how our mind sees this world. So when our mind is cheerful, we associate with the bright and sunny atmosphere.

So there is a climate outside and a climate inside my mind. Those two are related to each other but not really connected. The climate outside may be very bright and sunny, but my mind inside may be very gloomy -- that will not let me enjoy the world outside. But if I can synchronize the two, then my mind is feeling the same bright atmosphere inside as is outside. And maybe that's what was indicated here.

I can keep my mind in the same bright atmosphere of knowledge and then leave this existence. Then I will achieve the state of Brahman, Brahma, Vidojanaha. People who know Brahman will always be following this bright path. And one who knows Brahman, he obviously is not going to desire for anything less than Brahman. If I have known that I own a billion dollar trust fund somewhere, obviously I want to achieve that and not go for a smaller gain in life. So we have known this ultimate goal of achieving that state of imperishableness.

They will follow the path of Brahman so that the path was identified Uttarayanam or Devayanam. In the contrast to that, the path which we typically associate with is labeled as Dakshinayanam or Pitrayanam. So the path of ancestors or the southern path. That path, in contrast to the previous one, is followed by people who are not aware of the nature of Brahman, who have not realized that there is an existence without any conditioning. As we have said, the conditioning at my individual level is Avidya. Ignorance about myself has created this conditioning through identification with body, mind, and intellect.

Identifying with walls, floor, and ceiling creates room space. I, the self, identifying with this body, mind, and intellect, create this Jiva as a limited entity existing in this pluralistic world. When I leave this body, this existence, with only the understanding that I'm a limited being trying to achieve a higher standard of living, then I'll reach that stage. But when I exhaust my Punya, I'll come back to start working at it again. That's basically the path of return -- I have to work for 50 weeks for two weeks of vacation. Once the two weeks vacation is over, I have to start working for another 50 weeks for two more weeks of vacation.
snippets.reflection:
The contrast between Shukla (bright) and Krishna (dark) paths in verse 26 is not about external circumstances but internal orientation. The Devayana (divine path) is followed by those who know Brahman—their actions arise from knowledge and selflessness. The Pitrayana (ancestral path) is followed by those doing good with the expectation of reward. Both paths involve good actions, but the motivation differs completely. This is a crucial distinction for daily practice: When you perform a kind act today, notice your subtle expectations. Do you anticipate gratitude, recognition, or future benefit? That expectation, however reasonable it seems, keeps you on the path of return. Practice performing at least one completely anonymous act of kindness each day—something no one will ever know about, not even your closest confidant. This trains the mind in truly selfless action.

Verse 27 delivers the chapter's practical conclusion: "Tasmat sarveshu kaleshu yoga-yukto bhava Arjuna"—"Therefore, at all times, be established in yoga." The saint who understands these two paths is never confused about priorities. He knows that doing good for personal gain, while not wrong, is simply insufficient for liberation. This week, audit your spiritual activities: Are you studying scripture to become more knowledgeable (ego enhancement) or to dissolve ignorance (liberation)? Are you meditating to feel calm (personal benefit) or to realize your true nature (transcendence)? Are you serving others to be recognized as a good person (reputation) or because you see the Divine in them (devotion)? There is nothing wrong with the first motivation in each pair, but it leads to the path of return. Only the second orientation leads to the path of no return. The teaching invites us to examine not just what we do, but why we do it.

snippets.reflection:
This concluding verse of Chapter 8 makes a revolutionary claim: the sage who truly understands these teachings "passes beyond all merit that comes from the study of scriptures, from sacrifice, from austerities, and from charity." This does not mean these practices are worthless—they are essential stepping stones. But knowledge of the imperishable Brahman transcends all accumulated merit. Merit (Punya) keeps you on the wheel; it earns you better circumstances for future births. But the goal is to step off the wheel entirely. Reflect on your spiritual resume: How much of your practice is oriented toward accumulating spiritual merit (better rebirth, divine favor, inner peace) versus dissolving the very illusion of a separate self that could accumulate anything?

The "Supreme Primeval Abode" mentioned in this verse is not a location in space but a state of awareness—the recognition that you have always been and will always be the imperishable Brahman wearing the temporary costume of your current identity. Chapter 8 has offered a complete teaching: from Arjuna's seven questions about ultimate reality, through the meditation techniques for realizing it, to the cosmic context of creation and dissolution, to the two paths of return and no-return. The chapter ends where it began—with the imperishable. As you conclude this study, ask yourself: What has genuinely shifted in my understanding? What am I now willing to let go of that I was clinging to before? What does it mean that my true Self—the awareness reading these words right now—is "Akshara," imperishable, and has been present before this body was born and will remain after it dissolves? Let this question accompany you not just in formal meditation, but through every moment of daily life.

snippets.title: Day 116: Royal Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् |

अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

rājavidyā rājaguhyaṃ pavitramidamuttamam .

aśraddadhānāḥ puruṣā dharmasyāsya parantapa .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: I will now reveal to thee, since thou doubtest not, that profound mysticism, which when followed by experience, shall liberate thee from sin.
This is the Premier Science, the Sovereign Secret, the Purest and Best; intuitional, righteous; and to him who practiseth it pleasant beyond measure.
They who have no faith in this teaching cannot find Me, but remain lost in the purlieus of this perishable world.
snippets.commentary:
We have started discussing chapter nine, which is the Raja Vidya Rajaguhiya Yoga, the Yoga of the Royal Knowledge and Royal Secret. This is in continuation of what we have discussed in the last two chapters, 7 and 8. In chapter 7 we have seen Gnana Vignana Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge, and Visishtha Gnana, which is applied knowledge -- or what we call wisdom. Wisdom is something we have gained through our own experience. As the saying goes, "Look at my gray hair. I didn't get this gray hair standing in the sun outside -- all this is experience." In other words, what I have learned through my experience became my own knowledge.

Somebody told me something that remained at the information level, then I applied it and it became my own knowledge. That's why in science college you have theoretical classes and then you go to the lab. The same thing you learned there -- that H2O makes water -- you go and experiment with it yourself, and you realize that's what happens. So the first thing we did after finishing the first six chapters was talk about who we are and how we purify our internal instrument by meditation, by all these sadhanas, selfless actions. Now the question is: what are we meditating upon? That is what we need to know. So from chapter seven onward, we started talking about self-knowledge -- knowledge about my own self, removing this paradox where I think "this is me" and still worry about what happens to me after death and what happened before my birth.

So the self-knowledge, the Gnana Vignana Yoga, tells us what is the nature of the Lord and how people approach it. In chapter seven we learned about the Chaturvida Bhakta -- the four types of devotees. Everyone wants to achieve that state of perfect happiness where there is no sorrow, no imperfection in my life. In four ways we approach that. Our quest for that perfectness is described as Aartha, Jijnasu, Artharthi, and Gnani. One is approaching him out of distress.

One is approaching because he wants to gain something. One is approaching out of curiosity -- is there a state of perfectness? And the last one approaches because out of his own intuition, he knows there is a state of perfectness. Then in the last chapter we discussed the imperishable Brahman. Yes, there is a state which is infinite, imperishable. At that state of existence, we call it Brahman -- that which pervades everywhere and everything.

My world right now is pervaded by my thoughts, you know, and my thoughts are right now limited. So my world is limited. I can think about the things only which I have experienced in the past, you know, or I heard about it from others or something which I have known from reading the books. But my thoughts are limited to that. Therefore my world is also limited to that. Beyond this world, I'm always afraid or curious.

What is beyond my thoughts? Before my birth, I can think about my life as far back as my childhood. I can think about my life in the future as far as I can think. So I had this guy trying to sell me an annuity, and he said this thing gives you lifetime income from whenever you start. I said, when can I start?

He said, you can start at age 70. I said, my lifetime may not be more than five or six years after that, so your lifetime income doesn't do much for me. He said, why do you say that? I said, by statistical data -- how many people in my family have lived beyond that?

So I know my future by observing what has happened in my family. So what is beyond that? That's where I get lost. So Bhagavan said that imperishable Brahman is the state of yourself. So in chapter eight we have discussed about the nature of that imperishable Brahman and how I as this limited being fit into that.

That as long as I identify with this limited intellect in mind, this instrument of ego, I constantly come back and forth because I'm hanging on to that identity. This me is where I am as long as I have that ego. Bhagavan says in the part of your Prakriti, he'll come back again and again taking another instrument of transaction with this world continuing in the same argument. Now chapter nine says, now we'll talk about the royal secret. Why is it a royal secret? Because it is already obvious to you, but you are not aware of it.

It's right there, but I can't see it. Therefore it's a secret. And it's a royal science, because "Royal" -- Rajan, Raja -- connotes supremacy. In a kingdom there is nothing higher than a king. In our case we have the president as the highest authority.

But he has many people to question him and tell him what he is not doing right. In those kingdoms, the Raja was never questioned. Even though he is not wearing clothes, nobody says the king is not wearing clothes. There was a supreme status. They say this Vidya is a Raja Vidya, the supreme knowledge.

Beyond that there is nothing to be known. That is self-knowledge. I know physics, I know chemistry, I know all these things, I know all the knowledge about arts and everything else. But Bhagavan says there is only one thing you need to know -- about yourself.

And there is nothing more to be known. Therefore it is the supreme knowledge in the self knowledge. So the first verse of this chapter starts with Bhagavan's profound statement: Idam tu te guhyatamam pravakshyami anasuya ve. I am going to tell you this. Gnanam Vignana sahitam yad Gnatva mokshyase asubhat.

I'm going to tell you this knowledge along with Visishtagnam -- along with its wisdom, its application. Knowing that, you will be freed from what? From Ashubha and Shubha. Shubha is auspicious, that which is good. Ashubha is not good for me.

Anything in your life which you consider not good, you'll be liberated from that. And we say, well, that's exactly what I was looking for all my life. Get rid of all the problems I have, Bhagavan, then I'll be doing your bhakti forever. Because right now I don't have time -- I'm just fixing my problems.

My total attention will be yours after that. Bhagavan says, idam tu te guhyatamam. This knowledge which is the deepest, most profound secret. Guhyatamam -- guhya means secret, tamam means most. I'm going to tell you. You know what is the supreme secret?

It's something nobody can figure out. That's a supreme secret. Other secrets you can figure out by asking someone, but this secret is right in front of you, yet you can't figure it out. Like a person in disguise walking around in a party you see in a movie.

Everybody sees him but nobody figures out who he is. And he said, I'm going to tell you this because you're anasuya ve. We have heard last time, you're a person who does not cavil or carp, who does not raise petty arguments or petty objections. Sometimes people come to a lecture to find out how smart the speaker is, to see whether he knows anything. Then they will find fault in it.

See, if you give an example and say, our life is short, but the sun is there forever, suddenly somebody says, well that's not true, the sun is not there forever. I can tell you how it works. But that was not the intention of the speaker in giving that analogy -- to give you a relationship. But because your purpose is only to see what the speaker does not know.

So you are carping at him, raising petty objections, pointing out petty faults and errors. Because you are not truly, genuinely interested in understanding. The person who is like that is obviously not going to learn, because his mind is not in learning things -- his mind is in finding out where the faults lie. So therefore he says, I'm going to tell you the deepest of secrets, the most profound secret. Because so far you have proved that you are a genuine seeker of this knowledge. You really want to find out how to get rid of sorrows from your life, how to readjust your thinking pattern so you can function right in this world. Having known the Gnanam vignana sahitam yad gnatva mokshyase asubhat -- after that you will get rid of all that is ashubha, sorrowful, not conducive in your life.

Bhagavan, that's what I've been looking for! If you can tell me, then after this, once I know: every time I buy a lottery, I'll be the winner. Every time I submit a proposal, I'll be the winner. Every time I put a contract on a property, I'll be the winner -- because you told me that after knowing this, there will not be any sorrow in your life.

You'll be just a winner. You'll never be a loser. Bhagavan said, that's not what it means. What it means is that after knowing this, you will not see anything happening in your life as inherently good or bad. Right now, my definition of good and bad is defined by what I want and what I want to reject. Everything which I want to reject is Ashubha. Everything I want is Shubha.

There is a story of a father who goes to visit his two daughters. One was married to a pot maker, another was married to a farmer. He went to the daughter married to the farmer and said, "What's happening?" She said, "Oh, this was a wonderful season, a lot of rains, and we are doing very well. Oh Lord, keep continuing doing that!" Then he goes to the other daughter's house, the one married to the pot maker. "So how are things going?" She said, "Pretty bad this year. There was no sun. It was raining all the time. We couldn't really bake any pots, so we are really not doing well. Hope the Lord does something and stops this rain." So the father thinks, "Oh Lord, please stop this rain so that my daughter will be happy." But what can a father do? Same situation -- one sees it as Shubha, the other sees it as Ashubha.

The Shubha and Ashubha, as we are saying, are projections of our mind. We create this Shubha and Ashubha in our life. Once I fix my perception of how to see the world, I may not find anything Ashubha in it.

There's this story in the Mahabharata. Yudhishthir and Duryodhan were both under the same teacher. The teacher said, "I have one test for both of you." He calls Yudhishthir first and says, "Go and find one bad person from this town." Yudhishthir goes off. Then he called Duryodhan and said, "Go and find one good person from this town." After a while, Yudhishthir comes back. The teacher asks, "Where is the bad person I asked you to bring?" He said, "I'm so sorry, but I couldn't find anybody bad in this town." Then Duryodhan comes back. "Where is the good person I asked you to bring?" He said, "I'm so sorry, but I couldn't find any good person in this town." Both have a different way of looking at the world.

One cannot find anything bad in this world other cannot find anything good in this world. I right now have divided my world into good and bad because of my attachment, my desires, my aspirations of what I want to achieve. When I achieve that, great. When I don't achieve that, the world is falling apart. Bhagavan said, having known this knowledge, there will not be Ashubha in your life.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna promises to reveal the "most profound mysticism" (guhyatamam) - knowledge combined with direct experience (jnana with vijnana) that liberates us from all that is inauspicious (ashubha). But this royal secret is only accessible to those who approach without caviling or carping (anasuya) - without petty objections or the desire to find fault. Today, examine your relationship with spiritual teachings: Do you approach them as a genuine seeker, or do you sometimes listen just to critique? The mind that seeks faults in the teaching never receives its nectar.

The chapter opens with a powerful reframe: what we label as "good" and "bad" (shubha and ashubha) are merely projections of our desires. Like the story of Yudhishthira who could find no bad person, and Duryodhana who could find no good person - each saw the world through the lens of their own nature. This week, when something "bad" happens, pause and ask: "Is this truly ashubha, or have I simply labeled it so because it conflicts with what I want?" Krishna says that knowing this knowledge removes all ashubha - not because circumstances change, but because our perception transforms.

Practice exercise: Each morning, set an intention to receive the day's teachings - from people, situations, and challenges - without immediately judging them as favorable or unfavorable. Notice how much mental energy is freed when you stop sorting experiences into "good for me" and "bad for me."

snippets.title: Day 117: The Divine Secret
snippets.sanskrit:
मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना |

न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् |

यथाकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान् |
snippets.transliteration:
mayā tatamidaṃ sarvaṃ jagadavyaktamūrtinā .

na ca matsthāni bhūtāni paśya me yogamaiśvaram .

yathākāśasthito nityaṃ vāyuḥ sarvatrago mahān .
verseTranslations: The whole world is pervaded by Me, yet My form is not seen. All living things have their being in Me, yet I am not limited by them.
Nevertheless, they do not consciously abide in Me. Such is My Divine Sovereignty that though I, the Supreme Self, am the cause and upholder of all, yet I remain outside.
As the mighty wind, though moving everywhere, has no resting place but space, so have all these beings no home but Me.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter nine, Rajavidya Rajaguhya Yoga, the royal secret. In the royal knowledge, we have seen up to chapter eight in which we have learned about ourselves -- who we are in this limited self, what is our goal, and how we can evolve out of it. Then we ask, but what do we meditate upon? What do we evolve into? We have said you have to evolve from this limited self, identifying with this limited being, to the infinite self, unlimited being -- and that's you. Meditate upon whatever we want to achieve, we meditate on that.

But unless I know the nature of that infinite self and my relationship with it, how can I meditate upon it? So in chapter eight we have seen imperishable Brahman, that entity which remains in existence all the time. Even when I perish or this world will perish, that substratum which creates this reality will always be there. So now chapter nine says, what is my relationship with that imperishable Brahman? He is the source, he is the resting place. But what is my relationship with that?

And so chapter nine says that is the royal secret. Right now I don't really see any relationship, even though I've heard through all these scriptures and books and religions. But I personally cannot feel any relationship with him. So what is my relationship? He said that is the royal secret.

You, knowing yourself, do not know what your relationship with yourself is. That is the deepest secret -- the most secret is that it's right there. Looking for my key all the time, and it's always in my pocket. That is the biggest secret. So that's the Raja Guhyam, and Raja Vidya.

Knowing this -- knowing how to know this secret -- is the supreme knowledge. Once I realize my key is in my pocket that time I have the joy of my life. Up till now I was so worried about where is my key, I'm going to be late for my meeting and all of that. Suddenly I realized that right here, that is the greatest knowledge I can have at that moment. Anything else, you tell me at that time and say, well let me tell you. The E is equal to MC square.

Look, I know I want my key. So when we get what we want to know is the supreme knowledge. So Bhagavan said, that's what I'm going to tell you in this chapter. So in the first three verses he gave the promise. And now he says, let me tell you what that secret is. So in verse four he says:

Mayatatam idam sarvam jagat avyaktamurtina. I am pervading this Jagat. This entire Jagat, this entire cosmos, this entire universe is pervaded by me in my unmanifest form. That which is illuminated is Jagat. That which is illuminated by my senses.

My Jagat is limited to that. That which I do not know is not part of my world. So Jagat is that which is illuminated by my senses. Your senses define your Jagat. Her senses define her Jagat. When you put everyone's Jagat together, that is the total Jagat.

Bhagavan said, I pervade this entire Jagat, whatever is illuminated by any being in this world. I pervade that in my unmanifest form. The manifest is something I can say, oh yeah, I have seen it, I have touched it, I have been there. But the unmanifest is something beyond my perception.

So Bhagavan said, this world of your perception is pervaded by me in my unmanifest form. Therefore you see the Jagat but do not see me, because I'm unmanifest. But I'm always there in anything you perceive, see, touch, or feel. Here is my nature: your entire Jagat is pervaded by me.

In my unmanifest form. That also includes myself -- I can perceive, feel, touch. But wait, if that's part of your Jagat, then I am pervading through that. In my unmanifest form. My mind -- I can feel my thoughts. Well then I am pervading in that also in my unmanifest form. My intellect.

So then I'm also pervading in the unmanifest form. Matsthani sarva bhutani. At least we understood that Bhagavan says he is in unmanifest form. Whatever you think of, right there, his presence is there. As long as I can consider something as part of my Jagat, Bhagavan is right there. So now I come to the conclusion:

Bhagavan resides in all of them. That's what all religions tell us. Bhagavan resides in you. The Lord resides in your heart. So you say, well, let's not get confused here. Okay, so what is my real nature?

Matsthani, sarvabhutani, nacha aham te su avasthitaha. All these beings or things which you see, perceive, touch, and feel as your Jagat -- they reside in me, but I am not in them. See, in the first line he said that he pervades this entire Jagat of yours in his unmanifest form. We put two and two together and said, therefore he is in all of them. But no -- "I am not in them, they are in me." My standard example: I buy a car and take it from Chesterfield County and bring it to Henrico County.

What if Chesterfield County claims that the space in Mr. Batue's car was Chesterfield County space? "Henrico County, you can't keep it there. Now you have extra space. Please return the extra space -- he took it with his car from Chesterfield County." Can I return that space in my car to Chesterfield County?

What happened to the space which was in my car when the car was in Chesterfield County? It remained in Chesterfield County. When the car came to Henrico County, the space in the car changed from Chesterfield to Henrico. The car moved through the space. So the conundrum is: is the space in the car, or is the car in the space? Obviously, if I cannot return the space from Henrico to Chesterfield -- "Oh, here is the extra space I brought with me" -- then obviously the car was moving in the space, not the other way around. So now the space can say, "All the cars are in me." But it also says, "I am not in them." Now you have the puzzle -- there is no separate space "in" my car. So Bhagavan says, Matsthani Sarva Bhutani -- all the things and beings you can think of are in me.

Your Jagat is whatever you can perceive, feel, think, and touch. Now everything I see, Bhagavan says he pervades in unmanifest form. In other words, he is not limited to your Jagat. If I only say that Bhagavan pervades the entire Jagat, I know the Jagat in manifest form, and Bhagavan is in unmanifest form.

The law of conservation says, in this world there is always the same amount of energy and matter. Whether it's in a form of a matter, form of energy. The total energy remains the same at any given time. So I can say, okay, the Bhagavan says he is unmanifest. So if I put sum it up, all the parts of my Jagat I know the Bhagavan. I say, no, they are in me, but I am not in them.

I am something beyond that. So he said, what is that relationship then? So Swamiji explains here is that it's a relationship less relations. Just as the space in the car and the space outside. There's really no relationship to the car. It's not because the car is here.

There is a space here. The car will move, the space will move. With is my perception that the space is in the car. Space was always here outside this door. When I brought my car and parked it, I perceived that space is in my car. Space never moved from anywhere to anywhere.

In a similar way, the classical example we learn in Vedanta is that of a snake and a rope. The existence of snake is very real. Is part of my Jagat, my world. When I see a snake, I perceive it. I can vouch for it that there is a snake here. And therefore it is part of my Jagat.

Now Bhagavan said, in unmanifest form, the rope was existing while I was seeing the snake in it. That snake could not have come into existence without the existence of the rope. So now the rope can say that I was always pervading through this entire snake in my unmanifest form while you were seeing the snake in me. Therefore the snake is in me. But I as the rope am not in the snake. The rope has no relationship to the snake whatsoever.

Snake cannot exist without that rope. But it takes the support of my ignorance, my perception. My perception created snake in my Jagat in my world. Because Jagat is only limited by my perception. That which I can illumine as world of plurality is my Jagat. Snake was part of my Jagat.

Without the rope, the snake could not have existed. And therefore rope was existing in its unmanifest form in the snake all the time. But it was never in the snake. Bhagavan said, all these beings are existing in me. In other words, without my existence, there is no existence for anything. Therefore they are in me.

But I, in my pristine nature, unlimited, formless, was never in any of these shapes and forms and colors which you see. So the next verse takes it further -- in case you think we got it all. Nachamatsthani Bhutani, Pashya Me Yogam Aishvaram, Bhuta Bhrit Na Cha Bhutastho Mamatma Bhuta Bhavanaha. Now he says that all these beings exist in me because we have seen the snake exists in the rope. But the rope is not existing in the snake. So now you think okay, the beings are in him.

But then he adds: these beings are also not existing in me. The beings which I am perceiving, seeing, touching, and feeling are part of my Jagat. But the Brahman who is pervading all this Jagat has nothing to do with that. The snake which was existing in the rope -- the rope can say, "It existed in me, but I am not in them." But now he goes further. If we think we got it correct and say, "Okay, so the snake was always in the rope," he says, no -- Nachamatsthani Bhutani.

Even though these beings are existing in me, there was never a time -- from the perspective of the one who knew the rope -- that the snake was existing in that rope. In my world there was a snake. But the next guy standing with his torchlight, who at least knew that it's a rope -- for him, there was no snake in his Jagat. The snake was only possible because of the rope, yet from his perspective, there was no snake ever in the rope.

So in reality, there is never a snake existing in the rope. The rope remained rope all the time -- before I created the snake in it and after I realized there is no snake. Therefore Bhagavan says: in your Jagat, you create this world through your perception. You create this world of plurality -- I exist, you exist, she exists, he exists.

And now I said, I am the center of my universe. The world revolves around me. You are in the center of your universe and the world revolves around you. So from my perspective, in my Jagat, beings exist. Because the Supreme Being exist. And that being pervades through all the beings in my Jagat.
snippets.reflection:
"All beings dwell in Me, but I do not dwell in them" (matsthani sarvabhutani na caham tesvavasthitah) - this paradox holds the key to understanding our relationship with the Divine. Like space that appears to be "in" a car but actually contains the car, we exist within the infinite consciousness, not the other way around. The space doesn't move when the car travels from one county to another - the car moves through unchanging space. Similarly, your true Self remains unchanging while the body-mind moves through experiences.

The analogy of the snake and rope illuminates this further: the snake (this world of multiplicity) cannot exist without the rope (Brahman), yet from the rope's perspective, no snake ever existed.
