Your limitations, your problems, your separate identity - these exist in the Divine like the snake exists in the rope. They are real to your perception but have no fundamental reality. This is the "relationless relationship" - we are intimately connected to the Divine (closer than close), yet the Divine remains untouched by our perceived limitations.

Contemplation for today: When you look at any object or person, remind yourself: "This exists in consciousness, not consciousness in this." Notice how this shifts your sense of what is fundamental and what is derivative. Where you once saw solid, separate objects, begin to sense the unmanifest presence that pervades and supports all that you perceive.

snippets.title: Day 118: Worship and Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम् |

प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः |

न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय |
snippets.transliteration:
sarvabhūtāni kaunteya prakṛtiṃ yānti māmikām .

prakṛtiṃ svāmavaṣṭabhya visṛjāmi punaḥ punaḥ .

na ca māṃ tāni karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya .
verseTranslations: All beings, O Arjuna, return at the close of every cosmic cycle into the realm of Nature, which is a part of Me, and at the beginning of the next I send them forth again.
With the help of Nature, again and again I pour forth the whole multitude of beings, whether they will or no, for they are ruled by My Will.
But these acts of mine do not bind Me. I remain outside and unattached.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter nine, Rajavidya Raja Guhya Yoga. So far we have seen that Bhagavan has indicated the relationless relationship of Jiva, Jagat and Paramatma. That's basically the topic of this discussion that Bhagawan started. So we are aware of our relationship with the Jiva to the Jagat, that I consider myself to be independent of the Jagat, the world. So the world I consider is an object, something other than me. But we still do not have any inkling about what our relationship with the Paramatma is.

The all pervading being. So Bhagavan clarified in the first six verses that his relationship to the Jagat is a relationless relationship. First he said, I am not in them, they are in me. The first conception we have from our childhood, learning from other teachers and religions, is that Bhagavan is within me, but I do not know who that Bhagavan is. Bhagavan clarified that I am not in them, I am not in the beings. So the first paradigm shift here is Bhagavan saying I am not in them.

The next thing he says is that they are in me. I pervade this entire Jagat Jagat which I can imagine and perceive in its infinity. Bhagawan said I am that infinite Jagat and all beings are in the Jagat. I am not in it, but it is in me. So Brahman Paramatma is the fundamental. Everything is an emergent reality.

The Jagat is emerging out of Paramatma, Jiva is emerging out of Jagat. So he clarified this relationship that I am fundamental, Jagat and Jivas are within me. But then he clarifies further saying but in reality, even they are not in me. So first we are conceived as the wind in the space, that the space is all pervading and infinite. From our perspective, the wind is finite and moving around within the space. In the same way all other elements which we see below, space, air, fire, water, earth, they're within space.

So space is the substratum for all things and beings to be in. That's our normal perception. The space is all pervading. Everything is within the space. Now Bhagavan is saying that he is beyond space and time. The Jagat is bound by space and time.

Bhagavan says, I am beyond space and time. So the Bhagavan is fundamental, infinite, all pervading, unchanging. Jagat is bound by space and time. And therefore it is changing, but is constantly changing with time. So the conundrum is: if the Jagat and Jiva came out of Brahman, the supreme reality, how did Brahman change? I see the manifest Jagat -- the manifest Prakriti which came out of Brahman, which is unmanifest -- so how did the unmanifest become manifest? That is the riddle we have to solve. So Bhagavan said, even they are not in me. This makes it clear that the Jiva and Jagat are apparent reality, not the fundamental reality. They appear to be in me, but they are also actually not in me.

And therefore we use this analogy of snake and rope. So that's the only way the two things can exist in the same state of manifest and unmanifest at the same time. Rope is unmanifest to the one who is afraid of snake. But someone who is aware of the rope, for him, the snake is not there. So these two are related, but have no real relationship. Snake and rope are related because without rope, the snake cannot exist.

But snake has no real reality other than the observer is creating this reality. You remove the observer, the snake and rope dichotomy goes away. So this Jagat and Jiva, which I see as two realities -- Bhagavan said that they do not really exist. They are created by my observations. It's my mind which projects space and time. Space and time are concepts of my mind.

When I am not aware of myself, in deep sleep, neither space nor time exists. When you wake up, only then can you say, "Nice sleep." But how long did I sleep? I will have no idea unless I look at the watch or clock. I went to sleep at such and such time, woke up at such and such time.

So I infer that I slept for as many hours. But a deep sleeper has no sense of time or space. So the Bhagavan said, jiva and Jagat are the conceptions of mind. But I, in reality is pristine without any change. But then Jeevan Jagat are very real for us. How do they come into existence?

Bhagawan now explains in the following verses. Sarvabhutani, Kaunteya, Prakritim, Yanti, Mamikam, Kalpakshaye, Punasthani, Kalpadau, Visrijami Aham. At the end of the Kalpa all beings, Sarva Bhutani, come back to my original nature, Prakriti. Prakriti we discussed in chapter seven is the fundamental manifest reality, also called Hiranyagarbha, also called Ishvara.

So Brahman with Maya is Ishvara. Brahman is the efficient cause. Maya is the material cause. Maya provides this material to create this Jagat. So this Maya is the fundamental Prakriti. From that fundamental Prakriti, the Prakriti which I see as pluralistic manifestation comes into existence.

This plurality goes back into that singular Prakriti at the end of Kalpa. We learned in last chapter that Brahmaji is one day is one Kalpa. Brahmaji is one day is 1000 Maha Yugas. One Mahayuga has four Yugas, Sathya, Treta, Dwapur and Kali. And we have calculated the one Kalpa is 4.3 billion years. So here Bhagavan says there is one cycle of creation.

The another cycle of dissolution is Brahmaj's night, which is equally as long as 4.3 billion years. The Bhagawan said, I create this Jagat at the beginning of my day and all that comes back to its original state at the end of the Kalpa. So the creation goes to the evolution as we perceive in our scientific observations. In our modern day, the universe came into existence, the Big Bang. It continues to expand, it continues to evolve, and at some point of time it will go back to its original state. Bhagavad said Sarvabhutani, all beings in this Jagat, Prakrutim, Yanthi, Mamikam, Kalpakshaya.

At the end of Kalpa they all come back to me in my Prakriti. Punahatani, Kalpada, Visrajami Aham. I recreate them at the beginning of the next Kalpa. This is very similar to our daily experience. During the day, I have all these ideas, all these goals, my to-do list. When I go to sleep, all those ideas are folded back into my consciousness. When I'm in deep sleep, I don't really feel anything.

I have no to-do list, no idea what I need to become, what I need to acquire, what I already accomplished. All those ideas are in a dormant state when I'm sleeping. The next morning when I wake up, exactly those same ideas will create my new day. I went to sleep as an architect; I wake up as an architect. A doctor who went to sleep as a doctor wakes up as a doctor. My problems from yesterday, unresolved?

They're still unresolved today. So we start from where we left off last night. Bhagavan said here in the case of the Srishti, at the individual level, my world starts at the beginning of the day or ends when I go to sleep at night. At the Samasthi level. At the end of Kalpa, the whole world goes to sleep. But all those Vasanas tendencies of all the beings are in a dormant state.

The new Kalpa will start with the old Kalpa. So nothing really changes. When the new Kalpa starts, the same cycle will start all over again. And so Bhagavan said, Prakrutim swam Avastabhya Vishrujami Puna Puna. This is unending cycle. The Brahmaji wakes up one day and then goes to sleep.

And then we are done with it. Brahmaji's life is considered a hundred years. One day and one night make up two Kalpas. Now multiply that by his hundred years. That Brahma then gets liberation, Moksha. The new Brahma takes over.

The new cycle starts all over again. So this is unending creation. My world comes out of my ideas and it dissolves into my nothingness. When I go to deep sleep, when I wake up, it starts all over again. This happens all throughout my life. When I die, everything gets merged into tendencies.

I will have no memory of my experiences, but I'll carry that fragrance with me of what I have experienced in this life, which will be the beginning of my next life. At an individual level and at Brahma's level, the entire Srushti is in that state. Bhagavan said, you can visualize this entire Jagat as your own self, just as you're visualizing yourself right now as a limited being. Bhuta Gramam Imam Kritsnam Avasam Prakriteh Vashat.

This cycle continues perpetually, because Brahman is beyond time. Time does not exist for Brahman. Time exists because we are perceiving events in space. Time is an interval between two events. If you remove all events, there is no time.

If I don't experience anything, there is no time. But I experience one event, then a second event -- this interval becomes time. This Bhuta Gramam Kritsnam, this entire group of beings, Avasham, without any choice -- as long as I have a tendency, I'm going to manifest that tendency. If I have desire, I'll act according to that desire. Visrijami Punah Punah, Avasam Prakriteh Vashat.

Because they are under the spell of Prakriti, the Maya. Therefore they do not have any choice but to act according to their own tendencies and vasanas. All beings are propelled to act according to their swadharma, according to their makeup of their own vasanas and desires. Even when they go into dormant state, those vasanas and desires remain in dormant state. When you wake up, those vasanas and desires come back again. And this cycle continues perpetually unless you get out of this cycle of becoming and doing.

Now the question Bhagavan answers here is: does that affect Brahman? Because he is the propeller, the prompter, the supporter of all this activity which is happening perpetually. Creation and dissolution are continuing. They cannot happen without the presence of Brahman. My day, my night, and my activity cannot happen unless I'm conscious of it.

As long as my consciousness is there, there will be a waking state for me, a dream state for me, a deep sleep state for me. The question is: is my consciousness getting affected by my experiences at an individual level? At the Samashti level, does Brahman get affected by these happenings? Bhagavan clarifies in this verse: Na Cha Mam Tani Karmani Nibadhnanti.

These actions of creation and dissolution which is only possible because I, the Supreme Consciousness is supporting it by using Maya. But the Maya is Brahma Shraya. It is supported by Brahman. There is no magician. You have to have magician to create magic. So that magic is supported by magician.

This Maya is supported by Brahman. But Brahman uses that Maya as the material to create this Jagat. Just as in my dream state, I create the experiences of my waking state as the material to create my dreams. No matter how weird a dream is, it is never based on something which you have not experienced before. It may be jumbled up of all the experiences. But all my dreams are based on my experiences, not on anybody else's experiences.

So Brahman creating this Maya as the material, creating this Jagat and then dissolving this Jagat into Prakriti again remain in its pristine state, unaffected by individual actions.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna describes cosmic cycles - at the end of each Kalpa (4.3 billion years), all beings return to Prakriti, and at the beginning of the next, they are sent forth again. This mirrors our daily experience: each night when you enter deep sleep, your entire world - your to-do list, your achievements, your worries - dissolves into dormant consciousness. Each morning, you wake up exactly where you left off. The architect who sleeps wakes as an architect; your unresolved problems remain unresolved. Understanding this cycle reveals something profound: nothing is truly lost or gained; everything is a manifestation from and dissolution back into the same source.

The crucial teaching in verse 9 is: "These actions do not bind Me" (na ca mam tani karmani nibadhnanti). Though Brahman is the support of all cosmic activity - creation, preservation, dissolution - it remains utterly unaffected, like the dreamer who creates an entire dream world yet wakes unchanged. Your consciousness similarly witnesses all your experiences - joy and sorrow, success and failure - without being touched by any of it. The witness is never the witnessed.

Daily practice: Tonight, before sleep, consciously notice how your entire world - relationships, responsibilities, identity - dissolves as you drift off. In the morning, observe how it all reconstructs. Ask yourself: "What remains constant through this daily creation and dissolution?" That unchanging awareness is your true nature, unbound by the cosmic dance of manifestation.

snippets.title: Day 119: Divine Grace
snippets.sanskrit:
मयाध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम् |

अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम् |

मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः |
snippets.transliteration:
mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram .

avajānanti māṃ mūḍhā mānuṣīṃ tanumāśritam .

moghāśā moghakarmāṇo moghajñānā vicetasaḥ .
verseTranslations: Under my guidance, Nature produces all things movable and immovable. Thus it is, O Arjuna, that this universe revolves.
Fools disregard Me, seeing Me clad in human form. They know not that in My higher nature I am the Lord-God of all.
Their hopes are vain, their actions worthless, their knowledge futile; they are without sense, deceitful, barbarous and godless.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter nine and what we have learned is that Bhagavan said, I am the source of all the things, all the beings, everything that you see. I am the source and I am also the final resting place for all things. Things come out of me and they will return back into me. There is nothing really that can exist without me. As we said in that classical example, a ghost cannot exist without the post. So from the post's point of view, the post can say the ghost came out of me. And once you realize there is no ghost, it also goes back into me.

At any given time the ghost has no modifications or it never changed into ghost. But my ignorance and my perception has created this perception of a ghost. In a similar way, Bhagavan says from me the whole Prakriti comes into existence. This world of plurality as you see, is because of my existence. If I'm not there, there is no world of plurality. This world as we know is I.

And the world only exists because the fundamental basic reality is the self. I know I exist because of myself. You know you exist because of yourself. She knows she exists because of herself. But we think these are different selves. Bhagavan says it's just me, myself reflecting through all of them.

But we don't recognize it because of Mogha Asha -- vain desires. I think I am the center of my universe. The world needs to revolve around my desires. I want things to be like this, I want the world to be like this, I want the market to do this when I invest. And therefore we do the wrong actions.

Because I have now considered this limited being as me, I now have my false desires. We know we have very little power over how things work in this world. But when we act, we forget what we know. Even buying a gallon of milk -- so many people do so many things to bring that gallon of milk to your nearest Martin's or Food Lion. Then, and only then, can you go and buy it. But I think that if I have $4 in my pocket, I'm the king and can buy that milk. That Mogha Asha creates this false notion that I am in control.

And Bhagavan says Mogha Jnana Vichetasaha -- because of this false knowledge that "this is me and I can change this world as I want," we create a false notion of control. Rakshasim Asuram Chaiva -- these people are of the nature of Rakshasa and Asura. Rakshasa is one who is predominated by the Rajasic nature. We have seen in Vedanta that nothing can exist in this world of time and space if it does not have these three qualities of Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas -- the fundamental classifications of the basic gunas.

For any effect to exist in time and space, you need Sattva, which is the awareness that this exists. Then there is the activity -- the intense activity we see at the atomic level, subatomic level, or even at the level of our daily experience. And then Tamas, the inertia for the thing to remain in its state as long as it can, until another force changes it. He said that those with the most Rajasic predominance are the Rakshasas, because they consider that their activity will give them control over their world. And the Asuras are the Tamasic ones, with the predominant quality of Tamas. They rely on inertia.

If I don't do anything, things won't change. Let's keep things as is, don't change it. Not realizing that the nature of this world is Samsara -- constantly changing. In that Samsara, I try to keep things inert, as is. That is the nature of the Asura. These two qualities make us forget the real nature of the self.

In contrast to that -- Mahatmanastumam Partha, Devim Prakritim Ashritaha. There is another group of people who do not fall into these two categories of Rajasic and Tamasic. The Rajasic and Tamasic are constantly interested only in material existence. They see their physical existence and say, "My goal in life is to maintain this existence and have as much pleasure from this world as possible" -- not realizing that this is a temporary existence in time and space. But my real existence is infinite, permanent, immutable -- in the nature of the self.

The other group of people, the Mahatmas, are great souls simply because they realize the nature of the self. Mahatmanastumam Partha, Devim Prakritim Ashritaha -- because they have taken refuge in the divine nature of the self, which is to recognize Sattva, the truth, that eternal truth which does not change with time. Everything in this world is relative truth. Somebody says, "What is it?" I say, "It's a day outside."

Well, that's a relative truth. It was not true at 4 o'clock in the morning. It will not be true at 8 o'clock at night. It is true only now in this time. So it's called a relative truth. But the truth which remains constant in any period of time is called Sattva, which I can say it was this 150 years ago.

It is now and it will be for eternity. That's the universal truth, the Sattva. Those who take taken refuge into this awareness of that immutable truth which is the nature of the self. My self is not this limited being which has started its life on day one time. When I was born and I'll die is time T2. And I want to make the most out of this life.

Between this span of T1 and T2 are those Asuras and Rakshasas. But one who says, "This is just a flicker in my existence. My existence was infinite before and will be infinite after. I want to achieve that sense back, not get bogged down with this limited being" -- those are the great souls. They identify not with the limited self, but with the higher self. Here is the example I have used many times, because I'm an architect.

The space in this room is a conditioned space. Right now my association with this space is room space conditioned by these walls, floor, and ceiling. But I also recognize that this space is universal space. It is here and it will be here, whether this building is there or not. The one who recognizes that myself will always be here, whether his body is there, mind is there, or intellect is there or not.

They are the great souls. Therefore they have taken refuge in the Daivi Prakriti -- this Sattva, predominantly Sattvic in nature. They recognize the ultimate truth about their own self. Bhajanti ananya manasaha. Therefore they devote themselves to me with a single-pointed mind.

Now obviously there are word connotations that come from our own experience in life. Bhajanti -- with that kirtan and all that, you know. Bhajanti ananya manasaha, satatam. So constantly they are doing this. But that's not possible in the literal sense. But we know that the Vedantic connotation of the word bhajanti means love. Love for the Divine is devotion. Love is nothing but identification.

The more I identify with someone, the more my love increases. The more I identify with the Divine. So ananya manasaha means without any other thought -- without any other thought that this limited being is me. I'm not an architect, I'm not a father, I'm not a son. All these are superimpositions on me.

Amitabh Bachchan never forgets when he plays the coolie that he is Amitabh Bachchan. He never forgets while doing all these roles he plays. I too play all these roles, but I forget and get identified with them. And I get carried away with them.

The Mahatma never gets carried away. So bhajantim Ananya Manasaha Gnatva Bhut adim avyam. Knowing that I am the source of all the beings imperishable. We typically see that the source get destroyed into you take a seed and seed becomes a tree. The seed is no more there. Now I can say, okay, now I want the seed back.

That's a perishable source of the tree. Bhagavan said, but I am the source of this universe. All the being but imperishable never get destroyed. Because the creation is a Maya Post never became ghost. Therefore it never had to go into any transformation into something else. So once you see the ghost, post doesn't go away.

It remains exactly what it was before. Bhagavan says, knowing that I am the immutable, imperishable source of all the beings. These Mahatmas wants to get back to their original self. At the immutable, imperishable self. They drop the identification with the limited. Playing this part very efficiently in this world.

But always the identification is with the higher self. Just as Amitabh Bachchan never forgets in Amitabh Bachchan. But he is a coolie at the time. You know, say, Satatam Kirtayantah maam Yatan taschadiravratah. So now what will be my attitude once I have recognized that this limited being is not me. This life is just a part I am playing for the time being.

Before I was born, I existed as the universal being. After that all existed as a universal being. Before this building was built, this space was here. And I can vouch for it because I live here long enough. Long before this building was here, this space was here. After the building is built, there's room spaces here.

And someday somebody will decide we can do better use of this land. And the building will be gone, but the space will be here. I am here, I was here and I will be here. That's the eternal truth. Bhagavan says Satatam Kirtayantah. Having known this, so what will be my actions?

Satatam constantly Kirtayantaha. I am singing the glory of that eternal self that I am my Lord, who functions through me as this limited being. Swamiji obviously said kirtan du Visival. We have a bhajan, you know, next week. So that's the kirtan. That's the only time we do kirtan Bhajan and kirtan Swamiji.

This singing, with equally crude and noisy instruments -- it has its own place, for that time only, to occupy the mind. Because at least at that time, my mind is focused on those songs and the verses and what they mean. At that time, I'm not thinking of anything else. Those who do any kind of art know this -- the mind has to be occupied with something.

And if it doesn't occupy, then it wanders away. One whose mind is constantly attached to that understanding that I am not this limited self, this universal self is manifesting in this world. There is nothing that can exist in this world without Him. And therefore there is no existence for anything else other than that. If God is all pervading, where are we? If we are here, then he is limited.

He cannot be all pervading. So if he is all pervading, there is no place for anyone else. All that I see is nothing but his manifestations. So now that constantly when I see anything in this world, the thought at the back of my mind says, that is nothing but the Lord's manifestation. Whether that is good, bad or ugly. See, we have no problem.

We see something very beautiful, nice, and divine -- "That's God's manifestation." Early morning the sun rises and we see, "O God!" But when we see darkness and evil and still see his presence in it -- that's where the real test is. Then my Kirtan, Bhagavan says, is complete, no matter what I encounter.

I know he pervades the entire universe and all its happenings. Nothing other than him can exist, and therefore there cannot be anything other than Him.
snippets.reflection:
"Fools disregard Me, seeing Me clad in human form" (avajnanti mam mudha manusim tanum asritam). The Divine pervades everything, yet we fail to recognize it because we expect something extraordinary. We look for God in temples and sacred texts while ignoring the consciousness that animates every being we meet. The Divine is not hiding - it is the most obvious reality, present in every eye that sees, every heart that beats. Our failure to perceive it comes from looking for the wrong thing in the wrong way.

Those caught in Mogasha (vain desires), Moghakarma (vain actions), and Moghajnana (vain knowledge) live as if they are the center of the universe, believing their limited efforts can secure lasting happiness. Dominated by Rajasic (restless activity) and Tamasic (inertia) tendencies, they remain blind to the Sattvic truth of their own divine nature. The Rakshasa nature says "I will acquire and control," the Asura nature says "I will resist all change" - both miss the recognition that the Self is already complete.

Self-inquiry for this week: Examine your primary operating mode. Are you driven by endless activity toward acquisition (Rajasic)? Or by resistance and avoidance (Tamasic)? Neither brings lasting peace. The alternative is to cultivate Sattva - the quality of awareness that recognizes the Divine presence in all. Today, practice seeing the same consciousness looking out from every pair of eyes you encounter. What shifts when you recognize that the one perceiving through you is perceiving through all?

snippets.title: Day 120: Royal Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः |

सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः |

ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते |
snippets.transliteration:
mahātmānastu māṃ pārtha daivīṃ prakṛtimāśritāḥ .

satataṃ kīrtayanto māṃ yatantaśca dṛḍhavratāḥ .

jñānayajñena cāpyanye yajanto māmupāsate .
verseTranslations: But the Great Souls, O Arjuna! Filled with My Divine Spirit, they worship Me, they fix their minds on Me and on Me alone, for they know that I am the imperishable Source of being.
Always extolling Me, strenuous, firm in their vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me continually with concentrated devotion.
Others worship Me with full consciousness as the One, the Manifold, the Omnipresent, the Universal.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter nine, Rajavidy Rajagohya Yoga. Yoga of Supreme Knowledge and Supreme Secret. So far we have seen the Bhagavan has revealed the supreme secret that I pervade everything in this Jagat. And this Jagat is supported by my Maya, my association with Prakruti. Prakruti produces all that is moving and unmoving. But I am not in the Prakriti.

I am not in the beings in the Prakriti. Those beings are in me. I am not in the Jagat, but Jagat is in me. In other words, my self supports the perception of the Jagat. So the Jagat exists as long as I perceive it. This world exists for me as long as I am conscious of it.

When I'm not conscious of this Jagat, then this Jagat does not exist for me. The same way from the Supreme Consciousness. As long as that Supreme Consciousness is aware of the Jagat, that Jagat exists. And therefore Bhagavan says that I am not in the Jagat, Jagat is in me. But then he also said that they are also not in me. The beings and things in this Jagat are also not in me.

In other words, the Jagat and the things and beings which I see in the Prakriti, they are not in the consciousness. The consciousness is not affected by this perceptions of the world outside. So Bhagawan created contradictory statements for us to understand. Relationless relationship with Bhagavan. We are related to Bhagavan, as close to him as we are to our own selves. Because this world is created out of Bhagavan's own self.

Therefore I cannot be further away from him than I am from my own self. And that's the secret which is the Supreme Secret. Even though I am as close to him as I am to my own self. But I never feel his presence. So Bhagawan said, to feel my presence you have to identify with me. People who do not identify with me.

Bhagawan is explaining in last verse, 12 he says Moga Asa, Mogha Karmanaha, Moga Gnana Vicheta sah. This is the reason why we are not experiencing his presence. Because we are distracted by our vain desires. Those desires prompt us to do vain actions. Because of our vain knowledge who we are, we consider this body, this mind, this intellect is to be me, this limited being to be me. I'm driven by my Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies.

As we have seen, this Maya is the root cause of the production of this Jagat. Jagat comes into existence out of Maya. Maya has three qualities. Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Therefore everything in this Prakriti. Prakriti is nothing but the representation of Maya to us.

So everything in this Prakriti has those three qualities, Satvarajas and Dhammas. Awareness, activity and inertia. To exist in space and time, it has to have activity and inertia. And Sattva is the awareness part of it. So everything in this Jagat has these three qualities. The permutation combination of these three qualities makes this plurality that we see like in a three color printing.

There are only three colors, but they create myriads of shades of color. We can create all kinds of pictures from the combination of those three colors. The same way, this Prakriti produces a variety of things and beings by permutation and combination of these three Gunas.

Bhagavan said that up to the level of human beings, people are just living by their instincts. All animals, plants, and aquatic life survive in the lap of Mother Nature.

They are aware of their own existence. But they are not aware of any other higher entity. Human beings are the only ones who have intellect. To realize that there got to be somebody higher than me, somebody greater than me to have the control over this world. Having that understanding, I still don't identify with him, because Rajas and Tamas dominate.

When Sattva is subdued by Rajas and Tamas, all my actions will be driven by those Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies. The Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies tell me that my happiness lies in this world out there. Therefore all my efforts to achieve that happiness which is my true nature. Just like water seeks its own nature, happiness is our true nature. So we constantly seek bliss and happiness.

And therefore we work in the world outside. We never complain about why I'm feeling good today. We always complain I'm not feeling good. Today because being good is my nature, being not feeling good is not my nature. Bhagavan said, you are not recognizing your nature because of your wrong knowledge about yourself. Mogha Gnana -- because of wrong knowledge, Vichetasaha -- my thinking is wrong about where my happiness lies.

I'm working outside in a Rajasic manner to acquire things, to achieve things, to get happiness. Or I say, "If I don't do anything, then I'll be happy" -- that's the Tamasic tendency. Because of these two aspects of my nature, which are predominantly Rajasic and Tamasic, I'm not identifying with him. Bhagavan said that when he takes the human form, people do not recognize him and they avoid him, ignore him. We know everything about our own self and other beings, but we don't know about the divinity which is common in all of us -- the consciousness which is the common factor, the one thread which ties everything together in this universe.

So therefore Bhagavan says Rakshasim Asuram Chaiva Prakritim Mohinim Shritaha -- by the nature of this Rajasic and Tamasic Prakriti, they are confused about their own self and about the divinity in all human beings.

In contrast, Mahatmanastumam Partha Devim Prakritim Ashritaha. In this path of evolution, everything evolves from Tamas to Sattva. Even in the evolution of our planet, we can see that first there was nothing but just inert matter.

Then came the organic life. Then gradually it evolved into more complex life, more intelligent life. So everything evolves from inertia to knowledge, from Tamas to Sattva. Some are in the path of evolution at Tamasic level, but they are on the path of their own evolution. So next step is Rajas to be Rajasic. So in our self unfoldment, Swamiji says that when you introspect and see what you find, if you find Tamasic quality, then replace it by Rajasic quality.

If you find Rajasic tendencies, replace them by Sattvic tendencies. So this is a conscious effort. As a human being, we have our freedom to choose how to behave. So Bhagavan said, those Mahatmas who have evolved to Sattva, even Mahatma has Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies. But they're subdued by Sattvic tendencies. In other cases, the Rajasic tendencies are subduing the Sattvic tendency.

Here the Sattvic tendencies are subduing the Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies. Devim Prakritim Ashritaha -- the Sattvic is considered the Devi, the divine quality, closer to reality. Bhajantim Ananya Manasaha -- knowing fully well that I am not this bundle of matter, not this mind, not this intellect. Even though I'm pulled by the tendencies of body, mind, and intellect.

I'm constantly reminding myself I'm part of this all pervading consciousness. My consciousness is same as consciousness in all other being. Bhajanti Ananya Manasa not having any other thought. Even though I'm functioning in the world like everybody else. But that thought is constant in my mind that I am the divine being at the core of my being. I am that supreme self, the all pervading consciousness.

Knowing that Gnatva Bhuta dim avyam I am part of that immutable self which is all pervading. So we have discussed this example before. The space in my car or my car is in this space. The car is in the space. Space is not in the car. The space seems divided in different cars in different rooms.

But it is not really divided. Otherwise the car cannot move in the space -- it would have Henrico space when it is in Henrico, Hanover space when it's in Hanover County. Gnatva Bhutadim Avyayam -- the self in me and the self in you are not two divided selves. The self in all beings is one.

The consciousness which makes the entire Jagat possible is undivided. It's not that my consciousness is different than your consciousness. Your equipment, my equipment are different. And therefore our manifest representations are different. So Bhagavan says Mahatma. One who has evolved to that level of understanding that the self is undivided and all beings are existing in that consciousness.

Bhajanti Ananyamanah he devotes himself to me without any other thought, constantly with a single pointed devotion. There is no other doubt. There is no other identification. Even though he realizes that he is an individual functioning as this body, mind, intellect. But that is only possible because the consciousness functioning. We know this body is inert because we have seen dead bodies.

Dead body cannot function when the consciousness is not there. Therefore we come to the conclusion that the body is inert. Body is nothing but made up of food which I have eaten all my life. But I am a conscious being. Therefore my real identity is the consciousness and not this body. This Mahatma has come to this level of understanding.

Therefore he is constantly devoting himself to that true self which is the consciousness. Satatam, Kirta, Yanthamam, Yatantaschadravrataha. He is constantly doing kirtan to me. He is constantly praising me. So we obviously kirtan, bhajan, kirtan. We hear these words in our day to day conversation.

In our culture, bhajan is when we are thinking about the Lord; kirtan is when we are praising the Lord. But here, the praise and thinking about the Lord carry a very different connotation. When I am praising the Lord, I am devoted to the Lord. Devotion is love for the Divine. Our love for the Divine becomes devotion, and love is nothing but identification. When I identify with something or someone, I love that thing or that person. I love my BMW because I identify with my BMW. When I identify with the Lord as my Lord, then I devote myself to Him. This devotion is nothing but my identification with the Lord. And therefore that kirtan -- kirtan is not that one Sunday afternoon or Saturday evening we get together, and Swamiji says, the noisy kirtan we do with equally noisy equipment.

Kirtan is a constant thought in my mind that I am not this limited being, and my Lord is not divided into separate beings. We all exist in his own being. We are only existing because he exists. I am only alive because the consciousness is functioning through me. When the consciousness will not be there, I will be purely as just a bundle of matter. They will call it dead body and get rid of it as quickly as possible.

Satatam Yatantascha Dridavrataha. They are constantly striving, because they will be pulled by this Prakriti to identify with it -- to identify with my body, to go out and get things, to fall in love with things and beings outside. I have to constantly remind myself; therefore it's Yatantaha.

So once you get this knowledge from the books or from a guru, you're not done with it. That's just the beginning. Now you have to constantly remember it with everything you do. Constant efforts are required for even Mahatmas. Dridavrataha -- they are steadfastly established in this knowledge. There is never a doubt that this is not true.

Some of us read this, then read another book, and start doubting whether this is right or that is right. One says there is Ishvara; another says there is no Ishvara. One path says there is no life after death.
snippets.reflection:
The Mahatmas (great souls) are distinguished not by external achievements but by their inner orientation. They have taken refuge in the Daivi Prakriti - the divine nature of Sattva, truth, and awareness. While functioning in the world like everyone else, they maintain unwavering recognition that their true identity is not the body-mind but the all-pervading consciousness. Like the actor Amitabh Bachchan who never forgets he is Amitabh while playing a coolie, the Mahatma never loses awareness of the Self while playing worldly roles.

"Bhajanti ananya manasah" - they worship with single-pointed mind, with no other thought. This is not about excluding worldly duties, but about the constant background awareness that "I am the divine being at the core of my existence." Such devotion is identification - the more you identify with something, the more you love it. The Mahatma identifies with the imperishable Self (bhutadim avyayam) that is the same in all beings. Just as the space in your car is not separate from space everywhere, consciousness in you is not separate from universal consciousness.

Krishna describes three approaches to this truth: seeing the Divine as One (ekatvena - Advaita), as separate Creator and creation (prthaktvena - Dvaita), or as present everywhere with many faces (bahudha vishvatomukham). Whatever your philosophical approach, if your goal is alignment with the Supreme, you will reach it. Practice this week: Whatever draws you spiritually - prayer, meditation, service, study - pursue it with drdha-vrata (firm resolve). The path matters less than the steadfastness with which you walk it.

snippets.title: Day 121: The Divine Secret
snippets.sanskrit:
अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाहमहमौषधम् |

पिताहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः |

गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत् |
snippets.transliteration:
ahaṃ kraturahaṃ yajñaḥ svadhāhamahamauṣadham .

pitāhamasya jagato mātā dhātā pitāmahaḥ .

gatirbhartā prabhuḥ sākṣī nivāsaḥ śaraṇaṃ suhṛt .
verseTranslations: I am the Oblation, the Sacrifice and the Worship; I am the Fuel and the Chant, I am the Butter offered to the fire, I am the Fire itself, and I am the Act of offering.
I am the Father of the universe and its Mother; I am its Nourisher and its Grandfather; I am the Knowable and the Pure; I am Om; and I am the Sacred Scriptures.
I am the Goal, the Sustainer, the Lord, the Witness, the Home, the Shelter, the Lover and the Origin; I am Life and Death; I am the Fountain and the Seed Imperishable.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter nine, Raja Vidya, Raja Guhya Yoga -- Yoga of King of Secrets and King of Knowledge. So from chapters one through six we have seen who I am and how I should work in this world with the Spirit of Yajna. Because those actions are not binding. All others are binding. Then we have looked in chapter seven, the lower nature of the supreme, that which is manifest all around me. And then in chapter eight we have seen his higher nature which is unmanifest, supporting all the beings.

The secret still is what is my relationship with him is the secret. Having known all that, I still cannot find how I can relate to Him. So now chapter nine gives us the indication of what is your relationship with the Supreme? The Bhagavan, the Almighty, my Creator. So in the beginning he said that my relationship to this Prakriti which you are part of it. I'm trying to find out my relationship with Him.

I already learned in chapter 8 that I'm nothing but a part of this manifest world. Therefore I'm nothing but a Prakriti. See, my relationship to this manifest world, Bhagavan said, is that of a relationship less relation. So he said that this entire Jagat of moving and unmoving is pervaded by me and presided by me, Adiyakshaina. I keep eye on it, but I don't take part in it. This Jagat is in me, but I'm not in them.

They are also not in. From my perspective, from the perspective of the supreme, this Jagat does not exist and therefore it is not in me. So therefore he says, this relationship of this Prakriti and the supreme is that of no relationship but a perceived relationship. Relationship which can be associated with each other but have no real association. This entire Jagat is pervaded by me and Chara Nachar, moving and unmoving. I send them forth by my Yoga Maya.

At the beginning of the cycle I send those multitude of beings. Same multitude of beings will merge into me at the end of the cycle. And again they will start all over again. Those who do not recognize this fact because of their limited understanding of the nature of the supreme, they try to find the perfection which truly belongs to the supreme through Mogasa, Moga Karma. By the vain desires and vain actions. I'm trying to achieve something which can only be achieved at the level of perfection.

I'm trying to achieve it with my little efforts here and there. Bhagavan says, therefore they cannot achieve it. But then there are others who recognize this fact that if my goal is that high, then I have to align myself with that high of an entity. The one who truly have these qualities. How do you do strategic planning? You align your capabilities with the opportunities.

When you combine the two, that's your strategy. But if I don't have capabilities and I just keep looking at opportunities, that's not really a strategy. My strategy in life is to get perfect happiness. I see opportunity there -- there's got to be somewhere, a state where I can be happy all the time. What I miss out on is: am I capable? So I am not really aligning these two. I have two different entities -- one who is very limited in capability, trying to achieve something which is highly unachievable through limited means. Bhagavan said that those who recognize this align themselves with the supreme. They focus single-pointedly to identify themselves with that supreme who is pervading everywhere.

And to do that, they use different methods. Different people use different methods. Once they recognize the fact that the perfect happiness is not achievable by actions in this world of Prakriti -- the world of objects, emotions and thoughts as shown in Swamiji's BMI chart -- this world can never give you the perfect happiness, no matter how hard you try. They align with the supreme, the work in this world. But their goal is aligned with the Mahatmas. Those great souls who realize that perfect happiness can only be found by aligning with one who is perfect. They achieve that in many different ways.

Some consider him to be only one -- the one that exists and nothing else can exist. And as we have seen in our three schools of thought, that's Advaita. I and him are no different from each other. I am under the spell of Maya. That's the only difference.

Some see it as divided into many. So at least it's more than one -- Creator and creation. These two, some believe, will never be able to coincide with each other. Creation will always remain creation, Creator will always remain Creator.

From that perspective also people can reach Him. Or I say bahudha vishvatomukham. He is everywhere, in everything I see. And every being I see is him alone. Every eye I see, every leg I see, every mouth I see -- it's all his expressions. Others see it that way, as we have seen in Vishishtadvaita.

He is the whole and what I see is just a part. I have a narrow perspective on life. Therefore I cannot see him in his complete glory. But wherever I see, I see his glimpse. That's Visheshta Advaita. So Bhagavan said, any which way you can approach me, it is all coming to me only.

Because I am everything. If you pay money to Chinmaya Mission, whether at this center or any other center, eventually it all goes to Chinmaya Mission. It really doesn't matter. Any efforts you put in aligning yourself with the supreme, in whatever manner -- whether it's Advaita, Dvaita, or Vishishtadvaita -- seeing him as father, mother, brother, supporter.

And therefore they will be successful as long as they align with me in any which way. Because that's all coming to me. Because I am the father of this entire Jagat -- Mata Dhata Pitamaha. As we have said, I am also mother, sustainer, grandfather. Vedyam, Pavitram, Omkaram. I am that which is indicated in the Vedas as the supreme reality, as Om, which encompasses all four states of existence.

Three which I am very aware which is my dream world, deep sleep and waking world. In the fourth one which supports all these three, he said that's indicated by Om. Therefore whatever is indicated in the Rukh Saam and Yajuho in these books of knowledge about his nature. Any which way you approach me is acceptable. You will reach me as long as your goal is to reach me. Gatihi Bharata Prabhuhu Sakshi Nivasah Bhagawan Vidyas uses the approach sometimes.

I tell our young architects: it has to be idiot-proof. Consider your contractor the greatest fool on this planet, and then do your documents. That way you will not make the mistake of him misunderstanding you. Make it so clear, so obvious that you hit the lowest denominator. Bhagavan through Vedavyasa doesn't want to leave anything out. In case you missed it in Pitahamasya Jagato Mata Dhata -- now he adds Gatihi.

I am the goal Bharata. I am the supporter Prabhu. I am the Lord Saksihi. Anything that is happening in this world, I am the witness. You may think that when you are doing something bad, nobody is seeing. But Bhagavan is watching that.

Because Bhagavan is every including your own self. It means you will know what you have done. Therefore I am always witness as you. I am the refuge when I am in trouble. I'm actually invoking my own capacity to overcome my difficulties. We have talked about many times.

Friend is a very special relationship. In any other relationship, I have to be correct in my behavior and approach for that relationship to work. But friends? Any which way we meet after a long time, they curse each other and do all the funny things, hit each other. A friend is one who supports you no matter how wrong you are.

Anytime I want to do something and I tell my friend Deepak, "I'm trying to do this," he says, "That's not a good idea." I say, "No, but that will be fun in the end." He says, "Okay, then if you really want to do it, let's go and do it." Just before exams, we did this all the time. I'd say, "Deepak, let's go see a movie." He'd say, "But tomorrow you have an exam." I'd say, "I think I can make it up." And in the end he would say, "Okay, then let's go." A friend will support you even when you are wrong, even if he knows you are going down the wrong path and going to suffer through it. Bhagavan says, "I am that friend. Anytime you do something wrong, I know."

I am telling you as your conscience. Still you want to do it? I am the beginning and the end. Sthanam -- also the place where you exist, the support. For anything to exist in space and time, you need inertia.

Bhagavan says, I am the Sthanam, that space where you exist. I'm also the treasure house. When I need knowledge -- O Bhagavan, O Saraswati Mata, Saraswati Puja. I want wealth -- Lakshmi Mata. I am afraid -- Hanuman Ji or Durga Mata. Whatever you want.

I am the treasure house of anything you want. We have discussed this concept before. I am the source, the seed. But very different than any other source which we know. Every other source will be depleted once you exercise it. That source will be depleted.

That's why worried about this. Fossil fuel will be depleted or any seed. Once you use that seed and the tree comes out, the seed is destroyed. Immutable seed, the tree will come out or whatever the product. I still remain intact. Therefore any method which you apply is still coming to me.

I am the one who bakes you as the sun. Aham Varsam, I rain down as rains. Nigruhani Utsradami I also hold and I also throw you out. I send you back Amrutham Chaya. None of us will ever have any experience of not existing. Not a single being has ever existed in this universe who has the experience of not existing.

We assume we will not exist because Gandhiji is not here, my father is not here. So it's an assumed position that I will not exist. However, you can't find one person in the entire history of the human race who can say, "Yeah, I know what it means to not exist." Because everyone is only there when they think they are existing. Amritam -- immortality. Cha Eva Mrityustra -- and also death.

The death which I see decaying every day. Death and decay which I see. I as a baby have died and become a toddler. Toddler died and became a boy. And boy died, became a young man. A young man died into the old man.

And now I think my next stage is not existing. I'm constantly seeing death. Bhagawan says that's also me. Sat, Asatya Aham Arjuna. O Arjuna in the head and Sat, that which is existing as real and also Asat that which is unreal. So Sat can be viewed in many different ways.

That which is temporary is Asat. That which is permanent is Sat. That which is cause is Sat. That which we see as effect is Asat. Everything in this world is nothing but an effect of a cause. The cause remains intact throughout all the variations and modifications of the effect. Standard examples we have seen are that of gold and gold bangles. I also use the example of space: space is Sat; all conditioned spaces -- room space, cathedral space, casino space -- are Asat.
snippets.reflection:
In these verses, Krishna declares: "I am the ritual, the sacrifice, the offering, the fire, and the act of offering" (aham kratur aham yajnah). He is not just one element of worship - He is every element. This reveals a profound truth: in any spiritual practice, the worshipper, the worshipped, and the act of worship are all expressions of the same reality. There is no separation between subject, object, and action. When you offer a prayer, who is praying to whom? The consciousness in you reaches toward... consciousness itself.

"I am the Father, Mother, Grandfather, Sustainer of the universe" (pitaham asya jagato mata dhata pitamahah). Whatever role you seek the Divine in, that role is fulfilled. "I am the Goal, the Supporter, the Lord, the Witness, the Abode, the Refuge, the Friend" (gatir bharta prabhuh sakshi nivasah saranam suhrt). Notice especially "suhrt" - the friend. A friend supports you even when you are wrong, unlike other relationships that demand correct behavior. The Divine is that friend who accompanies you through every mistake, never abandoning you.

Most remarkably, Krishna says: "I am the imperishable seed" (bijam avyayam). Unlike ordinary seeds that are destroyed when they sprout, the Divine remains unchanged though the entire universe emerges from it. This week, contemplate: What remains unchanged through all your life's transformations - childhood to adulthood, joy to sorrow, health to illness? That unchanging witness-awareness is the avyaya bija, the imperishable seed that is your true identity and the source of all.

snippets.title: Day 122: Worship and Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च |

त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा

ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं
snippets.transliteration:
tapāmyahamahaṃ varṣaṃ nigṛhṇāmyutsṛjāmi ca .

traividyā māṃ somapāḥ pūtapāpā yajñairiṣṭvā svargatiṃ prārthayante .

te taṃ bhuktvā svargalokaṃ viśālaṃ kṣīṇe puṇye martyalokaṃ viśanti .
verseTranslations: I am the Heat of the Sun, I release and hold back the Rains. I am Death and Immortality; I am Being and Not-Being.

Those who are versed in the scriptures, who drink the mystic Soma-juice and are purified from sin, but who while worshipping Me with sacrifices pray that I will lead them to heaven; they reach the holy world where lives the Controller of the Powers of Nature, and they enjoy the feasts of Paradise.

Yet although they enjoy the spacious glories of Paradise, nevertheless, when their merit is exhausted, they are born again into this world of mortals. They have followed the letter of the scriptures, yet because they have sought but to fulfill their own desires, they must depart and return again and again.
snippets.commentary:
In the beginning of Bhagavad Gita, the first six chapters, we have learned about ourselves as the Great Mahavakya from Upanishad Tattvamasi. That thou art that which you are seeking, that which is in control of this universe and my life. Who is that that I'm seeking is that you are that. So that paradigm shift about the one I'm seeking is not away from me, but my own self. And then we obviously have seen that the one which I consider myself me is just an equipment which I use to transact with this world. What I consider myself with this body, this mind, this intellect.

In chapter two we have this paradigm shift that that's not you. That's actually a vehicle you use to transact with this world. But you are imperishable, immutable, unborn, never dying. That's a paradigm shift we have learned in the in the second chapter then we also learned about the Karma Yoga act. I must as an individual in this world. So I do not perpetuate this ignorance I have about myself.

So we all learned about Karma Yoga. Selfless actions will purify my mind and intellect, the internal instrument so that I'll be able to see the reality as is where myself then the universal self has no duality. It is something similar to my room space. Right now I see is completely separated from the outside. But from another developer who wants to build a big building, this space is part of the space outside. And then obviously we have seen how to get the Karma Sanyas renunciation in actions by knowledge.

By knowing that I am not the doer, I can renounce my actions. I right now take the doership and ownership of my actions. Except I am not really ready to face the consequences. And when the consequences come, I blame other people. World was unfair, society is unjust. People don't recognize my contribution.

All of that is simply because of my lack of understanding that I am not the doer. I have very little capacity to act on my own. I'm just a part of this whole fabric which is called this universe. And I'm just this minute part which only can function when other parts function in its own way. So there's a Gnana Karma Sanyas Yoga. Once the knowledge takes place that I am not by individual and island who is capable of acting that I give up my ownership of my actions and I start accepting my role as a part in this whole. And then we obviously see in meditation, Dhyana Yoga how to now reflect and contemplate on myself so I can wipe this ignorance out of myself.

Those are the first six chapters we learned about ourselves. We are not with who think we are. Bhagavan said, you are part of my own self. The next three chapters, 7, 8, and 9, are about "That" -- we learned about "Tat" first. "Tat" means "That" -- we learned about That. Then we said, who is That which I'm seeking as the Lord of this universe?

Therefore Lord of my own self. Bhagavan gave his identity in the last three chapters saying I am who pervades in this entire universe in my unmanifest form, I am the source of this universe. I'll be the resting place for this universe. Everything comes out of me, everything dissolves in me. But we can recognize that. So this chapter Chapter 9 says Raja Vidya Raja Guya Yoga opened with a profound statement by Bhagavan said I manifest in this entire Jagat in my unmanifest form.

But people fail to recognize it out of their own ignorance. The world is full of Mudhas. They fail to recognize because of their own different identifications, notions, desires -- Mogha Asha, Mogha Karmaha. Bhagavan said you need the right equipment to recognize something which is unmanifest. There are radio waves in this room. I'm not sure now that they've all gone digital.

But think about how analog radio waves work. Radio waves are wireless. What are the waves which make my wireless phone work? To make them manifest, I need equipment. And when that equipment is fine-tuned and pointed in the right direction, it will manifest. Yesterday I was listening to one of these Gujarati Kathas by Ramesh bhai Oza.

And I said this Samsar. We are completely surrounded by this Samsar that is constantly changing by this Maya. We are trying to find its end. Where does this Maya end? They say all over vernacular language said Sansar. You have to cross this Sansar, this ocean of Sansar.

And for that you need a boat. He said that boat, Ramesh bhai, is your body, this mind, and this intellect. It's not an ordinary boat -- it's like a luxury liner. It is fully equipped with all that you need to cross over this ocean in a very luxurious way. But we fail to recognize the goal of this boat and direct it towards other things.

So we go in circles. Our scripture says that the ultimate goal of human life is to recognize your own self, your own reality, who you really are. In this evolution from a single-cell amoeba to where we are now, we are fully equipped to realize who we are. But we fail to recognize that. Why? Traividya mam somapaha puta papa yajnaih ishtva svargantim prarthayante.

Te punya masadya surendra lokam asnanti divyan divi deva bhogan. How does this work? It works as simply as this: wherever you put your effort, whatever your goal is, that is what you will achieve. What do I want to become? We ask our little children all the time, "What do you want to become when you grow up?" "Well, I want to be a fireman."

We never let him try to become a fireman. The parents say, "Oh no, okay, that's a great idea. But no, no, you're not becoming a fireman. We are not going to let you do that." The point is: we don't always put our efforts into what we truly want to achieve. We achieve whatever we actually put our efforts into.

Now here we're not talking about people who are completely deluded and don't know what they are doing. Here are the people who we consider ourselves to be like -- people who say, "Look, I really don't need to do anything more. I'm a good man doing good things. So what else do I need to do?" And I constantly say doing good is not good enough.

The knowledge about yourself and what you're trying to achieve is very important before you start any action. So here it says traividya. Those who are expert in three Vedas, those who have learned three Vedas -- they are knowledgeable people. They have jnana in the Vedas. They are somapaha -- puta papa.

Somapaha means one who has drunk that soma drink. The soma drink was offered into the Agni, and then as prasad, you take it in a small quantity at the end of the Yajna. It indicates that the ritual is over and I'm taking whatever came out of this Yajna. Just like when you go to the temple, at the end of the Aarti, Panditji is standing there distributing the Charnamrit. It basically indicates that the performing of the Puja is over. That's the conclusion of my actions.

And I'm taking whatever will come out of the action. They are also purified of the sins. They don't have any evil qualities. They are not evil doers. They are the Veda knowers. They have done the rituals as indicated in the Vedas.

They are free from sins. Yajnaih Ishtva Svargantim Prarthayante. Having performed this sacrifice of the Yajna, what does their desire say? They want to achieve heaven. Anything good we do -- what is the ultimate goal? I am doing this Puja, I am doing these actions.

In the end what we want is heaven. I can have all the good things in life and no sorrows. So Swarganti Parthayanti, the Purnya Masadya, Surendra Loka, Asnanti Divyan Divideva Bhagaana. So having earned all this merits of the good deeds they are doing the knowledge they have gathered from the Vedas. Vedas means the books of knowledge. So our Vedas are now expanded to many, many, many sciences.

Knowing all this, I perform actions in a field of my chosen field and ask for Swarga. O Lord, give me a situation where there is no sorrow ever, always there is happiness. So they achieve the Surendra Loka. The Loka of the Devas. The place of Devalok. And we have talked about there are various Lokas.

You know, from Go Loka to Brahma Loka. After all they are all in my mind. When I am in a complete control and happiness, I feel I am in heaven. Things are going right. Kids are doing fine job. Nobody is bothering me.

People are respecting me. Everybody is saying Neel, you are doing wonderful. Meena is not complaining. Surendra Loka Hatha Bhagawan says you reach that Surendra Loka. People achieve that state of Surendra Loka, Asnanti Divya Divideva Bhogan. They're enjoying all these divine pleasures which we learn in this Purana all the time.

These Apsaras are dancing. You know, somebody is doing this. Beautiful gardens, no drought anywhere. You enjoy all the Bhogas. But then I say tetam bhuktva swargalokam vishalam Enjoying these vast heavens and vast enjoyments in the heavens. Chine punya martha lo KE vishante.

But once those punyas are exhausted -- no matter how infinite you think they are -- consider Bill Gates, the wealthiest person in this world. You can still count his wealth, can't you? We can put a number to it. An expert CPA sits down, looks at his books, and comes up with "this is your wealth." It can be spent. It may take longer than my wealth, maybe a very long time, but it can be exhausted, and it will be exhausted at some point. Bill Gates' descendants, whoever they may be, will eventually not have anything.

I remember one Gujarati poem I heard is Sagaadi tami sa alamna bhik magda shariya sah alam who was the Mughal emperor. He said, I've seen his descendants begging in the street. Saga di tam es salam na bhik makta serhiye. So any wealth, no matter how infinite seem right now, will be exhausted in time. The same applies to you. Any amount of good deeds and good merits you have done to achieve these heavenly pleasures -- you will get them according to your efforts, according to your ability.

But once you reach there and enjoy those vast heavens, at some point they will exhaust, and you're back to square one. You're going to start from where you left off. Just like going on a vacation -- at the end of the vacation, you are back to square one, working for another 50 weeks to earn two weeks of vacation again. Evam Trayi Dharmam Anuprapanna Gatagatam Kama Kama Labhante. Thus, as described in the Vedas, they attain the state of going and coming.

I perform good actions, achieve heavens, come back, keep performing good actions, go back and coming back. Obviously we say well that's good enough for me. And Bhagawan says that's why we are stuck into it, no? Because we are so addicted to this heavens, addicted to the results of my good actions that we continue to go back and forth, go back and forth into it.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna describes people who are learned in the Vedas (traividya), who perform rituals correctly (yajnair ishtva), who are purified of sins (puta-papa) - yet they pray for heaven (svargati prarthayante). They achieve what they seek: divine pleasures in celestial realms. But here is the sobering truth - "kshine punye martya lokam vishanti" - when their merit is exhausted, they return to the mortal world. Even Bill Gates' wealth, though seemingly infinite, can be counted and eventually spent. So too, any accumulation of punya (merit), no matter how vast, will eventually deplete.

This is the cosmic trap: "gatagatam kama-kama labhante" - those driven by desires attain going and coming, an endless cycle of earning, enjoying, depleting, and returning. Like working 50 weeks for a 2-week vacation, then returning to work again, we strive for temporary heavens only to start over. We have a "luxury liner" of body-mind-intellect fully equipped to cross the ocean of samsara, yet we sail in circles, never reaching the far shore.

Honest self-assessment: What is the goal of your spiritual practice? Is it a better rebirth, a more comfortable life, heavenly rewards? These are legitimate desires, but Krishna invites you to something greater - liberation from the cycle itself. This week, examine your deepest motivations. Are you seeking temporary relief or permanent freedom? The practices may look similar externally, but the intention determines the destination. What would shift if your goal became not better experiences within the dream, but awakening from the dream altogether?

snippets.title: Day 123: Divine Grace
snippets.sanskrit:
अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते |

येऽप्यन्यदेवता भक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः |

अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च |

ananyāścintayanto māṃ ye janāḥ paryupāsate .

ye.apyanyadevatābhaktā yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ .

ahaṃ hi sarvayajñānāṃ bhoktā ca prabhureva ca .

Even those who worship the lesser Powers, if they do so with faith, they thereby worship Me, though not in the right way.
I am the willing recipient of sacrifice, and I am its true Lord. But these do not know me in truth, and so they sink back.
