And I'm just this minute part which only can function when other parts function in its own way. So there's a Gnana Karma Sanyas Yoga. Once the knowledge takes place that I am not by individual and island who is capable of acting that I give up my ownership of my actions and I start accepting my role as a part in this whole. And then we obviously see in meditation, Dhyana Yoga how to now reflect and contemplate on myself so I can wipe this ignorance out of myself.

Those are the first six chapters we learned about ourselves. We are not with who think we are. Bhagavan said, you are part of my own self. The next three chapters, 7, 8, and 9, are about "That" -- we learned about "Tat" first. "Tat" means "That" -- we learned about That. Then we said, who is That which I'm seeking as the Lord of this universe?

Therefore Lord of my own self. Bhagavan gave his identity in the last three chapters saying I am who pervades in this entire universe in my unmanifest form, I am the source of this universe. I'll be the resting place for this universe. Everything comes out of me, everything dissolves in me. But we can recognize that. So this chapter Chapter 9 says Raja Vidya Raja Guya Yoga opened with a profound statement by Bhagavan said I manifest in this entire Jagat in my unmanifest form.

But people fail to recognize it out of their own ignorance. The world is full of Mudhas. They fail to recognize because of their own different identifications, notions, desires -- Mogha Asha, Mogha Karmaha. Bhagavan said you need the right equipment to recognize something which is unmanifest. There are radio waves in this room. I'm not sure now that they've all gone digital.

But think about how analog radio waves work. Radio waves are wireless. What are the waves which make my wireless phone work? To make them manifest, I need equipment. And when that equipment is fine-tuned and pointed in the right direction, it will manifest. Yesterday I was listening to one of these Gujarati Kathas by Ramesh bhai Oza.

And I said this Samsar. We are completely surrounded by this Samsar that is constantly changing by this Maya. We are trying to find its end. Where does this Maya end? They say all over vernacular language said Sansar. You have to cross this Sansar, this ocean of Sansar.

And for that you need a boat. He said that boat, Ramesh bhai, is your body, this mind, and this intellect. It's not an ordinary boat -- it's like a luxury liner. It is fully equipped with all that you need to cross over this ocean in a very luxurious way. But we fail to recognize the goal of this boat and direct it towards other things.

So we go in circles. Our scripture says that the ultimate goal of human life is to recognize your own self, your own reality, who you really are. In this evolution from a single-cell amoeba to where we are now, we are fully equipped to realize who we are. But we fail to recognize that. Why? Traividya Mam Somapaha Puta Papa Yajnaih Ishtva Svargantim Prarthayante.

Te Punya Masadya Surendra Lokam Asnanti Divyan Divi Deva Bhogan. How does this work? It works as simply as this: wherever you put your effort, whatever your goal is, that is what you will achieve. What do I want to become? We ask our little children all the time, "What do you want to become when you grow up?" "Well, I want to be a fireman."

We never let him try to become a fireman. The parents say, "Oh no, okay, that's a great idea. But no, no, you're not becoming a fireman. We are not going to let you do that." The point is: we don't always put our efforts into what we truly want to achieve. We achieve whatever we actually put our efforts into.

Now here we're not talking about people who are completely deluded and don't know what they are doing. Here are the people who we consider ourselves to be -- people who say, "Look, I really don't need to do anything more. I'm a good man doing good things. So what else do I need to do?" And I constantly say doing good is not good enough.

The knowledge about yourself and what you're trying to achieve is very important before you start any action. So here it says traividya. Those who are expert in three vedas, those who have learned three vedas, they are knowledgeable people. They have jnana of the Vedas. They are soma paha -- puta papa.

One who has drunk that soma drink. The soma drink was offered into the Agni, and then as prasad, you take it in a small quantity at the end of the Yajna. It indicates that the ritual is over and I'm taking whatever came out of this Yajna. Just like when you go to the temple, at the end of the Aarti, Panditji is standing there distributing the Charnamrit. It basically indicates that the performing of the Puja is over. That's the conclusion of my actions.

And I'm taking whatever will come out of the action. They are also purified of the sins. They don't have any evil qualities. They are not evil doers. They are the Veda knowers. They have done the rituals as indicated in the Vedas.

They are free from sins. Yajnaih Ishtva Svargantim Prarthayante. Having performed this sacrifice of the Yajna, what does their desire say? They want to achieve heaven. Anything good we do -- what is the ultimate goal? I am doing this Puja, I am doing these actions.

In the end what we want is heaven. I can have all the good things in life and no sorrows. So Swarganti Parthayanti, the Purnya Masadya, Surendra Loka, Asnanti Divyan Divideva Bhagaana. So having earned all this merits of the good deeds they are doing the knowledge they have gathered from the Vedas. Vedas means the books of knowledge. So our Vedas are now expanded to many, many, many sciences.

Knowing all this, I perform actions in a field of my chosen field and ask for Swarga. O Lord, give me a situation where there is no sorrow ever, always there is happiness. So they achieve the Surendra Loka. The Loka of the Devas. The place of Devalok. And we have talked about there are various Lokas.

You know, from Go Loka to Brahma Loka. After all they are all in my mind. When I am in a complete control and happiness, I feel I am in heaven. Things are going right. Kids are doing fine job. Nobody is bothering me.

People are respecting me. Everybody is saying Neel, you are doing wonderful. Meena is not complaining. Surendra Loka Hatha Bhagawan says you reach that Surendra Loka. People achieve that state of Surendra Loka, Asnanti Divya Divideva Bhogan. They're enjoying all these divine pleasures which we learn in this Purana all the time.

These Apsaras are dancing. You know, somebody is doing this. Beautiful gardens, no drought anywhere. You enjoy all the Bhogas. But then I say tetam bhuktva swargalokam vishalam Enjoying these vast heavens and vast enjoyments in the heavens. Chine punya martha lo KE vishante.

But once those punyas are exhausted -- no matter how infinite you think they are -- consider Bill Gates, the wealthiest person in this world. You can still count his wealth, can't you? We can put a number to it. An expert CPA sits down, looks at his books, and comes up with "this is your wealth." It can be spent. It may take longer than my wealth, maybe a very long time, but it can be exhausted, and it will be exhausted at some point. Bill Gates' descendants, whoever they may be, will eventually not have anything.

I remember one Gujarati poem I heard is Sagaadi tami sa alamna bhik magda shariya sah alam who was the Mughal emperor. He said, I've seen his descendants begging in the street. Saga di tam es salam na bhik makta serhiye. So any wealth, no matter how infinite seem right now, will be exhausted in time. The same applies to you. Any amount of good deeds and good merits you have done to achieve these heavenly pleasures -- you will get them according to your efforts, according to your ability.

But once you reach there and enjoy those vast heavens, at some point they will exhaust, and you're back to square one. You're going to start from where you left off. Just like going on a vacation -- at the end of the vacation, you are back to square one, working for another 50 weeks to earn two weeks of vacation again. Evam Trayi Dharmam Anuprapanna Gatagatam Kama Kama Labhante. Thus, as described in the Vedas, they attain the state of going and coming.

I perform good actions, achieve heavens, come back, keep performing good actions, go back and coming back. Obviously we say well that's good enough for me. And Bhagawan says that's why we are stuck into it, no? Because we are so addicted to this heavens, addicted to the results of my good actions that we continue to go back and forth, go back and forth into it.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 22 contains one of the most reassuring promises in the Gita: "Tesham nityabhiyuktanam yoga-kshemam vahamy aham" - "For those who worship Me with single-pointed devotion, I personally carry their yoga (acquisition of what they lack) and kshema (preservation of what they have)." This is not about material prosperity but spiritual assurance: when you make the Divine your sole refuge, your spiritual welfare is guaranteed. You need not worry about whether you are progressing correctly - that responsibility shifts to the Lord.

Yet verse 23 adds nuance: even those who worship other deities with faith (shraddhayanvitah) are actually worshipping Krishna, though "avidhi-purvakam" - not in the proper manner. All sincere worship reaches the same destination, like tributaries flowing to the ocean. However, verse 24 warns: "na tu mam abhijananti tattvena" - they do not know Me in truth, and therefore "cyavanti te" - they fall back. The difference between temporary upliftment and permanent liberation lies in correct understanding, not just sincere feeling.

Practical inquiry: Examine where you place your deepest trust. Is it in your abilities, your relationships, your financial security? These are forms of worship too - whatever you depend upon most is your functional deity. Krishna invites you to shift that ultimate reliance to the imperishable Self. This week, when anxiety arises about outcomes, practice this surrender: "My part is to act with devotion; the yoga and kshema are not my burden to carry." Notice how this shifts your relationship with uncertainty from fear to trust.

snippets.title: Day 124: Royal Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
यान्ति देवव्रता देवान्पितॄन्यान्ति पितृव्रताः |

पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति |

यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत् |
snippets.transliteration:
yānti devavratā devānpitṝnyānti pitṛvratāḥ .

patraṃ puṣpaṃ phalaṃ toyaṃ yo me bhaktyā prayacchati .

yatkaroṣi yadaśnāsi yajjuhoṣi dadāsi yat .
verseTranslations: The votaries of the lesser Powers go to them; the devotees of spirits go to them; they who worship the Powers of Darkness, to such Powers shall they go; and so, too, those who worship Me shall come to Me.
Whatever a man offers to Me, whether it be a leaf, or a flower, or fruit, or water, I accept it, for it is offered with devotion and purity of mind.
Whatever thou doest, whatever thou dost eat, whatever thou dost sacrifice and give, whatever austerities thou practisest, do all as an offering to Me.
snippets.commentary:
Obviously we have seen, as Bhagavan said, a royal secret, a grand secret is something which is very close to us but we fail to recognize. Therefore it's a secret. So the first declaration in this chapter, Bhagawan says that even though I pervade this entire Jagat, the universe, this creation, in my unmanifest form, all the beings dwell in me, but I don't dwell in them. They are in me, but I'm not in them. Which is obviously quite contrary to what we typically have learned all our life through all religions saying, Bhagwan, the Lord is within you. Here he said, even though I pervade the entire universe in my unmanifest form, I do not dwell in them, they dwell in Me.

Then he even further clarifies in saying, but in reality, they are also not in me. In other words, if we can take it on its face value, if we say we are in him, obviously we are influencing his being. All my qualities of limitedness and imperfection will affect Him. And therefore he says, in reality, even they are not in Me. None of the qualities we see in this world, in the things and beings, Bhagavan Siddi does not exist in me. All the imperfections we see in this world, which we constantly wonder why Lord created this world like that.

And he says, it is not in Me. And then obviously we have continued to discuss this, the relationship of this creation and the Lord self. And he says, even though this world is created by my Maya, I am the efficient cause for this world and I am also the material cause for this world. And therefore everything comes out of me and everything goes back to me. Because there is no nothing other than him existed before this creation was created. Then nothing will exist after this creation will be dissolved.

All that was there was his own self. So Bhagavan said, the relationship, less relationship between the Prakriti, the world, the manifest world as we know, and the unmanifest self which he says pervades entire Jagat, is that of a non existent relationship. But we have created this relationship. So then we have understood that everything which we do is because of the Lord's presence. As long as I'm conscious, I can act in this world. So Bhagavan said that everything you do eventually comes to me.

I'm the only enjoyer. Consciousness is the only enjoyer in any being. Because only time we enjoy or suffer is when we are conscious about it. So we have seen that relationship. The Bhagavan says, everything comes out of me. Everything dissolves in me.

Everything is possible because of me. Everything can be done only with my presence. However, because of our desires and wrong identification with this limited self, we create our own world of actions and our own world of worship. Depending on my desires, I worship the Lord of my heart. I put my efforts into the field where I want success. Bhagavan says, those who apply their efforts to fulfill their desires will be blessed to get their desires fulfilled by me.

So then we have seen in detail that the worshipers of the Devas goes to the Devas. Worshipper of the Bhutas goes to Bhutas. Worshipper of the Pitrus go to the Pitras. Deva, as we say Diva is to illumine which relates to our senses. So whoever perceives the visual arts, excel in visual arts. Whoever perceives performing arts, excels in performing arts.

So we know in this world we can prove from our own experience that wherever I put my efforts, wherever I identify myself, that's the field I'll excel. That the success I will receive. Same way we see the Pitruloka, the cultural heritage of our ancestors. Those who value that and put efforts in that, they will achieve that. Bhutas we have seen is the physical sciences. Science of this manifest world is Bhuta.

Those who pursue that, they excel in that. But see, all these successes are finite in nature, exist in time and space. And once you achieve that success, enjoy the fruits of it. You to come back to pursue the next desire which you have and the next success you want. So this is the coming and going which Bhagavad Gita and Upanishad describe. We constantly achieve, things, enjoy it, come back, strive for something else, achieve that, come back, strive for something else.

But Bhagavan said, the one who worships me -- and we have seen, worship is devotion, devotion is love for the Divine, love is identification -- one who starts identifying with that eternal self will achieve me. That we have seen in the last three verses.

Verse 26 actually says Patram Puspam falam toyam Yomi bhakta prayachati Tadaham bhakt Apurhat asnami prayatat Manaha. Whatsoever my devotee offer me with devotion, I accept that. That's good enough for me. You really don't have to have elaborate resources to worship Lord. And as we discussed last time, it takes away any excuse that I may have. Look, I'm not strong enough.

I don't have enough strength or I don't have enough wealth. But once it is whatever you can offer from my own garden, whatever you can pluck and give it back to me, I'll be happy simply because I see your devotion. What he's looking for is your intention, your devotion and your attitude. So the next verse 27 says, Yat karosi yatasnasi yat johosi dadasiyat. Now here comes the prescription. We have seen in theory what is our relationship to the Lord?

What can we do to remove this parallax between myself and his self? And then we may have an excuse saying, but I'm not capable of doing so. There is a very simple method. And you will not need anything more than what you already have. All you have to do is change your attitude in what you do. Yat Karoshi -- whatever you do, no matter who you are: a cobbler, a weaver, a doctor, an engineer, a president -- whatever you are, whatever you are doing. Yat Ashnasi -- whatever you are receiving, eating. Swamiji always expands the view and says eating is not only what we eat through our mouth but anything we take in through our eyes, ears, and all the senses. Yat Juhoshi -- whatever you offer back to the world. Yat Dadasi -- whatever you give as charity. Yat Tapasyasi -- whatever discipline you are following. We all follow some discipline -- I have to get up in the morning, do this, do that.

We follow discipline to achieve anything. Whatever discipline you are following to achieve what you are pursuing -- it is that simple: do not do it for yourself. Right now we are doing it for ourselves. It is very clear in my mind why I am doing this.

Neil, why are you doing this? Well, because I want to do this. Neil, why don't you do this? Because I don't want to do that. It's as simple as that. So we know very clearly that all my actions are for me.

For me to achieve what I want. Bhagavan says, just change that attitude and have that attitude that I'm offering. All my actions, all my charities, all my disciplines, all that I'm receiving is to him. Because without his presence as the consciousness in me, none of these activities are possible in the first place. So who am I to take credit now when I say who am I? As I said I reside in my ego.

That "I" which resides in my ego -- if it gives up that "I" and says, "I'm only possible as long as this consciousness functions through me, and I do not know where this consciousness comes from; it must be my Lord's presence" -- then I offer all my actions to him. Bhagavan says, you will achieve myself. So that's a simple prescription. Do not change anything that you are doing except change your attitude that you're not doing it for yourself, you're doing it for him.

Therefore, when you enjoy something, he's the enjoyer. When you suffer, he's the sufferer. You achieve something, he's the achiever. When you fail somewhere, he bears the failure. Shubha Ashubha Phalaih Evam Mokshyase -- thus you shall be freed from this bondage of Shubha and Ashubha, this bondage of labeling things as "good for me" or "not good for me."

When something good for me happens, I'm very proud. When something good doesn't happen for me, I blame everybody else other than me. He should have done this. Why didn't he tell me that? Why didn't he do that?

We find everybody responsible except me. Also it creates negative impression on my mind. Well, next time I never want to do that. I went to this organization for volunteer my services and they were not appreciative at all. I will never do that again. So I lost a chance of doing something good in life.

That bondage which is created by the impressions on my mind -- by perceiving "this is good for me" and "this is bad for me" -- you will be freed from. You will then see clearly, without having a cataract in your vision. I went to the doctor a few weeks ago and he said, "Open your right eye." I could barely see anything, completely fuzzy. I said, "I'm fine."

He said, that's because your left eye is taking over. And he said, thank God you don't have cataract in both eyes. That's exactly what he told me. So you can imagine if you have a cataract in a vision in both your eyes, the world will be very fuzzy. And Bhagavan said, that's where we are Right now. Because if one eye we see Subha, other we see a Subha and we have a very distorted view of this world.

But once we are freed from that, you have 2020 vision of this world. And then you will be doing exactly what is appropriate at an appropriate time. And when you do that, you know what you will achieve? So you'll be freed from by changing your attitude about everything you do. From doing it for myself to doing it for his self, I will be freed from the bondage of this is good and this is bad. Whatever the results come from my actions, I'll say, lord, you gave me this Buddhi to do this and I did that.

Now this is what you are giving me as a prasad. I'm sure you know what you're doing. Then this must be good for me. I'm accepting it and I'm moving forward. Next step, Sannyasa, Yoga Yuktatma, Vimukto Mam Upeshasi. You will become Sannyasa and Yoga Yuktatma.

We have learned these terms in previous chapters that should I be a Sanyasi or should I be any yogi? He says sannyasi is the one who has given up the sense of agency. I am the doer that agency. One who gives up, he is called Sannyasi. Swamiji says, not the one who wears the saffron robe and has a long beard. One who has given up the sense of agency that I am the doer is a Sannyasi.

The yogi is the one who has given up the desire for the results of the actions. One who is given the Karma Phala is the yogi. You are established in Yoga if you have no particular desire for particular results. I will do my actions because I am not the Karma Faladatta. I am never the actor is never in control of its results. It's always somebody else.

You present a song, you present a performance. It's not who you are going to applaud. Other people are going to applaud or other people are going to throw stones at you.
snippets.reflection:
"Yanti deva-vrata devan" - those devoted to the devas (sense pleasures, arts) go to the devas; those devoted to the pitrs (ancestors, cultural heritage) go to the pitrs; those devoted to the bhutas (physical sciences) excel there. Wherever you place your devoted attention and effort, that is what you become. This is both warning and promise: you have complete freedom to choose your destination through where you invest your identification. The question is not whether you will reach your goal, but whether your goal is worthy of your infinite potential.

Verse 26 removes all excuses: "Patram pushpam phalam toyam" - a leaf, a flower, fruit, water - the simplest offerings are accepted when given with devotion. You need not be wealthy, learned, or specially qualified. What Krishna seeks is "bhaktya prayacchati" - the devotion behind the offering, not its material value. This demolishes the ego's protest that "I'm not ready" or "I don't have enough." You have enough right now to begin.

Verse 27 provides the complete prescription: "Yat karoshi yad ashnasi yaj juhoshi dadasi yat" - whatever you do, eat, offer, give, or practice as austerity - "tat kurushva mad-arpanam" - do it as an offering to Me. This is not about adding spiritual activities to your life; it is about transforming your entire life into spiritual practice. The cobbler stitching shoes, the executive closing deals, the parent changing diapers - all becomes worship when the attitude shifts from "I do this for myself" to "I offer this to the Divine."

This week's practice: Choose one routine activity - eating, commuting, working - and consciously offer it before, during, and after. Notice: when you act as an offering rather than as the doer seeking results, how does your relationship with success and failure change?

samo.ahaṃ sarvabhūteṣu na me dveṣyo.asti na priyaḥ .

api cetsudurācāro bhajate māmananyabhāk .

Neil, why are you doing this? Well, because I want to do this. Neil, why don't you do this? Because I don't want to do that. It's as simple as that. So we know very clearly that all my actions are for me.

For me to achieve what I want. Bhagavan says, just change that attitude and have that attitude that I'm offering. All my actions, all my charities, all my disciplines, all that I'm receiving is to him. Because without his presence as the consciousness in me, none of these activities are possible in the first place. So who am I to take credit now when I say who am I? As I said I reside in my ego.

That "I" which resides in my ego -- if it gives up that "I" and says, "I'm only possible as long as this consciousness functions through me, and I do not know where this consciousness comes from; it must be my Lord's presence" -- then I offer all my actions to him. Bhagavan says, you will achieve myself. So that's a simple prescription. Do not change anything that you are doing except change your attitude that you're not doing it for yourself, you're doing it for him.

Therefore, when you enjoy something, he's the enjoyer. When you suffer, he's the sufferer. You achieve something, he's the achiever. When you fail somewhere, he bears the failure. Shubha Ashubha Phalaih Evam Mokshyase -- thus you shall be freed from this bondage of Shubha and Ashubha, this bondage of labeling things as "good for me" or "not good for me."

When something good for me happens, I'm very proud. When something good doesn't happen for me, I blame everybody else other than me. He should have done this. Why didn't he tell me that? Why didn't he do that?

We find everybody responsible except me. Also it creates negative impression on my mind. Well, next time I never want to do that. I went to this organization for volunteer my services and they were not appreciative at all. I will never do that again. So I lost a chance of doing something good in life.

That bondage which is created by the impressions on my mind -- by perceiving "this is good for me" and "this is bad for me" -- you will be freed from. You will then see clearly, without having a cataract in your vision. I went to the doctor a few weeks ago and he said, "Open your right eye." I could barely see anything, completely fuzzy. I said, "I'm fine."

He said, that's because your left eye is taking over. And he said, thank God you don't have cataract in both eyes. That's exactly what he told me. So you can imagine if you have a cataract in a vision in both your eyes, the world will be very fuzzy. And Bhagavan said, that's where we are Right now. Because if one eye we see Subha, other we see a Subha and we have a very distorted view of this world.

But once we are freed from that, you have 2020 vision of this world. And then you will be doing exactly what is appropriate at an appropriate time. And when you do that, you know what you will achieve? So you'll be freed from by changing your attitude about everything you do. From doing it for myself to doing it for his self, I will be freed from the bondage of this is good and this is bad. Whatever the results come from my actions, I'll say, lord, you gave me this Buddhi to do this and I did that.

Now this is what you are giving me as a prasad. I'm sure you know what you're doing. Then this must be good for me. I'm accepting it and I'm moving forward. Next step, Sannyasa, Yoga Yuktatma, Vimukto Mam Upeshasi. You will become Sannyasa and Yoga Yuktatma.

We have learned these terms in previous chapters that should I be a Sanyasi or should I be any yogi? He says sannyasi is the one who has given up the sense of agency. I am the doer that agency. One who gives up, he is called Sannyasi. Swamiji says, not the one who wears the saffron robe and has a long beard. One who has given up the sense of agency that I am the doer is a Sannyasi.

The yogi is the one who has given up the desire for the results of the actions. One who is given the Karma Phala is the yogi. You are established in Yoga if you have no particular desire for particular results. I will do my actions because I am not the Karma Faladatta. I am never the actor is never in control of its results. It's always somebody else.

You present a song, you present a performance. It's not who you are going to applaud. Other people are going to applaud or other people are going to throw stones at you.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 28 promises liberation from "shubha-ashubha-phalaih" - the bondage created by labeling results as good or bad. Like having cataracts in both eyes, we see a fuzzy, distorted world when we constantly sort experiences into favorable and unfavorable. The sannyasa-yoga described here is not about external renunciation but internal freedom: sannyasi is one who gives up the sense of doership; yogi is one who gives up attachment to specific results. When both are achieved, you act with full engagement yet remain untouched by outcomes - not through suppression but through understanding.

"Samo'ham sarva-bhuteshu" (verse 29) - "I am the same to all beings." The Divine has no favorites. Like a parent whose love for all children is equal (even if one visits more often), Krishna's relationship with every being is identical. The difference we experience is not in His giving but in our receiving. "Ye bhajanti tu mam bhaktya, mayi te teshu chapy aham" - those who worship with devotion dwell in Him, and He in them. The intimacy is not one-sided; it is mutual. You are not reaching toward a distant God; you are recognizing the God who has never left.

Verse 30 offers radical hope: "Api chet su-duracharo" - even the worst sinner, if they worship with undivided devotion, should be considered righteous (sadhur eva). This is not endorsement of wrongdoing but acknowledgment that right resolve changes everything. Your past does not define your future; your present orientation does. Today, release any sense that you are disqualified from spiritual progress due to past mistakes. Ask: "Am I now, in this moment, rightly resolved toward truth?" That is the only question that matters.

snippets.sanskrit:

snippets.transliteration:
kṣipraṃ bhavati dharmātmā śaśvacchāntiṃ nigacchati .

māṃ hi pārtha vyapāśritya ye.api syuḥ pāpayonayaḥ .

verseTranslations: He shall attain spirituality ere long, and Eternal Peace shall be his. O Arjuna! Believe me, My devotee is never lost.
For even the children of sinful parents, and those miscalled the weaker sex, and merchants, and labourers, if only they will make Me their refuge, they shall attain the Highest.
What need then to mention the holy Ministers of God, the devotees and the saintly rulers? Do thou, therefore, born in this changing and miserable world, do thou too worship Me.
snippets.commentary:
So we are concluding chapter nine today. Chapter nine, Raja Vidya, Raja Guja Yoga. Yoga of Royal Knowledge and Royal Secret. And obviously the question last time, what is this secret? Well, we have discussed many times, the secret is, where does my happiness lie? All my life I was seeking one thing and one thing alone.

That is permanent happiness and permanent peace. I have tried everywhere, I have tried in getting knowledge, learning things in this world. I have tried in accomplishing things, achieving things, acquiring things in my relationships. But in the end, every happiness came with associated unhappiness. As we have learned through our life, anything which has the capacity to give me happiness has an equal capacity to give me unhappiness. In our relationships we know exactly: the closer you are, the more chances of getting hurt. Even though we know what we are looking for and look everywhere in our life, we can't find our happiness.

So that's the secret. And whatever makes me find that will be the knowledge which will be royal knowledge. So Brahmagnan is the secret. Unless you have the Brahmagnaan, you will never find this permanent happiness. And Brahma Vidya is the Raja Vidya. And Swamiji explains that why it is called Rajavidya.

Raja Vidya is something which is available to all. The road which is available to everybody, Rajmarg, anybody can pass through that road, not restricted. It is the Raja Vidya because it is available to all. So the Brahma Vidya is the Rajavidya because this knowledge is available to all. Brahma Ghana is the royal sacred. Because everyone has a birthright to know that knowledge.

And still none of us is capable of finding it easily. So Bhagavan said that that is the knowledge, that is the secret. I'm going to tell you which is Pavitram Ida Muthamam. It is the highest purifier. Once you wake up from your dream, the waking state is the highest purifier of your dream state. All your problems of the dream state go away.

So we have started learning that Brahmagna is the one secret I need to unlock. And the key is the Brahma Vidya. And therefore rest of the chapter is spent in describing what Brahman is, what is the nature of Brahman and what my relationship is with Him. So we have elaborately seen that there is nothing in this world which is other than Brahman. In his manifest form he becomes this Prakriti, this manifestation. Anything which I see is nothing but the manifestation of the same reality.

From science point of view, we have discussed the singularity at one time because of the Big Bang. It is now a plurality and someday it will recede back into singularity again. So the same entity which is pervading everywhere is the basis of this reality as we know. And then what is my relationship? You see it's a relationship less relation that all the qualities of Brahman are in me because I am his manifestation. I am nothing but that this world is created by the Creator out of his own self.

Because there is no other material was available to Him. Only available material to create this world was his own self. Because if you think that there is other material available then he obviously is not complete God. So we have to come to the conclusion that his self and this universe and myself is one and the same. But I just can't recognize it. That is the Avidy which we have to dispel.

So this knowledge will dispel that Avidya Bhagavan said and therefore it is Rajavidy. So we have learned the nature of the Brahman that everything is because of Brahman. Everything resides in Brahman but Brahman does not reside in it. In other words, my limitations are not in Brahman. My ignorance is not part of Brahman. The Creator with his power of Maya he creates this universe through the Mayapati.

He is the Lord of Maya, Lord of this illusion. But I am under the spell of Maya and therefore I'm in a Maya Jal. I'm in the web of Maya. I can't see it clearly what my self is. He said the Vidya which will take me there would be the Raja Vidya, that which dispels my ignorance about my own self. When I start seeing my relationship clearly with him then I will be Dharmaatma.

I'll be a righteous soul. So Bhagavan has talked about the why people can't see it because of the Moga Asa Mogha actions. I'll find my happiness here, I'll find my happiness there. And that's where we are confused. But the Mahatma, they single pointedly seek that happiness at the source of happiness which is the Brahman which is the Almighty Lord which is my own self. So what is my relationship with Him?

He is as close to me as my own self. But there is no special relationship he is with me. Because I am a Dharmatma and others are not good people. He says I am same to Samoham Sarva Bhulteshu. My relationship to them is same as my relationship to you, him, her, my relationship to my children. If they have my four children, that's exactly same.

But one is closer to me than another, because he identifies with me more, he writes to me more, he calls me up more, he comes to see me more -- so I have more relationship with him. The one who never calls me, never writes me, never comes to Thanksgiving dinner -- I have less relationship with him. But my relationship with all of them is exactly the same. Samoham Sarva Bhuteshu -- everything and every being is made up of me alone.

Therefore relationship is exactly same. Just as my relationship with my left leg and right leg exactly same. Even though I rely on my left leg more because right leg is broken. So Bhagavan says Samoham Sarva Bhuteshru and each one is the birthright to know this. But because we are deluded, therefore I don't recognize it. Just because I think that I have not done something right in my past that does not stop me from realizing this truth.

Durachara -- Su is a prefix meaning supreme. Su-Durachara means one who is the highest sinner. Even he has the right to realize me. Bhajate Mam Ananya Bhak -- once he single-pointedly identifies with me. Sadhu Eva Sa Mantavyaha Samyak Vyavasito Hi Saha -- once he is rightfully resolved, once he has completely realized what is the right way of living, what is his swadharma, then he should be considered a Sadhu.

Swamiji says this is Krishna's missionary zeal to expand the tent to its infinity. Everybody is in it, nobody left out. So once that person is rightly resolved, we must consider him as a good person. Forget about what his past is all about. And the next verse says why that is because Kshhipram Bhavati Dharmatma. Once you have a right resolve, you very soon will become what you resolved to become.

See, it's all about your conviction about what is right and what is wrong. What is the right action? What is the wrong action? What is the right way of living and what is the wrong way of living. This is the right way to live. You will become that in no time.

Bhagawan saswat shantim ni gachati. And you will achieve that in eternal peace. Peace which I had been seeking all my life and I have blamed everybody other than me. Children are not behaving to my expectations. Once you resolve rightfully where your Santi is, you will in no time achieve it. Satsvatsanti m ni gachadhi.

Such a person will achieve that eternal peace in no time. Kaunteya Pratijanihi Na Me Bhaktah Pranashyati. It is obviously a little pat on Arjuna's back. Because the Pandavas, at no time during their life, ever questioned their relationship with Krishna or their faith in Krishna. So in our case also, if I have complete faith in that Supreme Lord who is myself, then my peace lies there. Then Bhagavan says Na Me Bhaktah Pranashyati -- one who identifies with me will never be destroyed.

Never be destroyed in the sense that he will never lose his peace again. Once I have decided where my peace is and am rightfully pursuing it single-pointedly, Bhagavan said he will never go back to getting unhappy again.

The next verse has been difficult for people to translate and understand. Mam Hi Partha Vyapashritya Ye Api Syuhu Papayonayaha. Then he described: Striyo Vaishyah Tatha Shudrah Te Api Yanti Param Gatim. They also achieve my being.

They are the people who are born in Papayoni. Correct understanding can only be gained if we can define Papayoni correctly. That's where the problem is, right? Because he actually enumerated and gave examples of classes of people who are born in Papayoni. It is very loosely translated as "sinful birth." Well, then you have to define sin.

Sin we have defined as a negative impression on my mind which is damaging to my chances of getting peace. When my mind is agitated, no matter how much of a Gnani I am, I will not have peace. We know that when the mind is agitated with any negative impression, there is no peace. Papa is that which robs away my peace. So Papayoni is the environment which has the most chances of creating negative impressions on my mind. Environment is not something I control.

So if I am placed in that environment, it is not my fault. It is not something I have chosen; I happen to be in that environment. In modern day, we call it the disadvantaged class of people, or minority. In India, Jains have fought very hard to be classified as a minority, and they finally got the same status as Muslims and Christians who are considered minorities in India. It is not that they are saying, "We are bad, just consider us." No, they say, "We are disadvantaged because we are not the majority."

So Papayoni creates an environment which has more chances of putting negative impressions on my mind. Bhagavan said that people who do not have the privilege of being in the most pious and best environment -- and those people are Striya, Vaishya, Tatha Shudra -- in which society, in which time of history, do you think that women have had the same rights as men, including in 2016? We know they are always disadvantaged. It is not their fault. It is the society's fault if the way it is designed does not give them equal opportunity. There is a movie coming up, the Birth of a Nation.

It's about how and I have not seen anything. I just saw a clip on one of those talk show. They said that in the slavery days a black child and white child will be playing together till the age of about 11. About 11 they will decide that only now the black child has reached highest of his or her development. So he doesn't need to be sent to school or do anything about it. He can now start working.

White child will continue in his development of learning and going to school. So is that something you consider a Papa Yoni -- because the child is born in that yoni, or because the society is not giving him an opportunity? Bhagavan said: the society which has not given them the opportunity they deserve -- an opportunity rightfully theirs, which is their birthright -- we are not giving them that. Even though you are born in that class of people who are disadvantaged, you have equal right to achieve the highest potential. In those days, and even today, there are classes which are disadvantaged.

Striya, Vaishya, Tatha Shudra -- women, merchants, laborers -- by history, everybody can vouch for it that they never had equal rights.
snippets.reflection:
"Kshipram bhavati dharmatma" - one who is rightly resolved quickly becomes righteous. This is the transformative power of conviction. Once you truly decide on the direction of your life, the becoming follows swiftly. "Shashvat shantim nigacchati" - such a person attains eternal peace. Then Krishna makes a solemn declaration: "Kaunteya pratijanihi na me bhaktah pranashyati" - O Arjuna, proclaim this truth: my devotee never perishes. This is not just Krishna's promise; He asks Arjuna to declare it, making the disciple a witness and messenger of this assurance.

Verse 32 is often misunderstood. "Papa-yonayah" does not mean sinful by birth but disadvantaged by circumstance - those in environments that make spiritual pursuit more difficult. Women, merchants, laborers - in ancient society, these groups had fewer opportunities for formal spiritual study. Krishna's point is revolutionary: even those whom society has marginalized can attain the highest goal ("te'pi yanti param gatim"). The Gita democratizes liberation. Your birth, social status, education, or past mistakes do not disqualify you. As Swamiji says, this is "Krishna's missionary zeal to expand the tent to infinity" - everybody is included, nobody left out.

Verse 33 then asks: if even the disadvantaged can reach the Supreme, how much more easily can those with advantages - the learned, the devoted, the royal sages? "Anityam asukham lokam imam prapya bhajasva mam" - having come to this impermanent, joyless world, worship Me. This week, honestly assess: What excuses have you been making for not deepening your spiritual practice? Whatever they are - lack of time, education, purity, worthiness - Krishna has removed them. The question is no longer "can I?" but "will I?"
