snippets.reflection:
The final verse of Chapter 9 distills the entire teaching into four instructions: "Man-mana bhava" - fix your mind on Me; "mad-bhakto" - be My devotee; "mad-yaji" - sacrifice to Me; "mam namaskuru" - bow to Me. These are not four separate practices but one integrated orientation: complete absorption in the Divine through thought, feeling, action, and humility. The promise follows: "Mam evaishyasi" - you shall come to Me alone.

"Yuktvaivam atmanam mat-parayanah" - having thus united the self, with Me as your supreme goal. The Sanskrit "parayana" means ultimate destination, final refuge. When the Divine becomes your parayana - not one goal among many but THE goal that contains all others - liberation is assured. This is not about abandoning worldly responsibilities but about recognizing what they ultimately serve. The executive working to support family, the artist creating beauty, the scientist seeking truth - all activities can have mat-parayanah (the Divine as supreme goal) as their hidden foundation.

This verse appears again at the end of Chapter 18, framing the entire Gita's teaching. Chapter 9 reveals the royal secret: you are not separate from the Divine you seek. The path is simply the progressive removal of the illusion that you ever were separate. This week, make this verse your constant companion. When the mind wanders, return: "Man-mana bhava" - let my mind rest in You. When devotion wavers, remember: "mad-bhakto" - I am Your devotee, whether I feel it or not. When action becomes self-serving, redirect: "mad-yaji" - this is my offering. When pride arises, bow: "mam namaskuru" - I am not the doer; You are the source and goal of all.

snippets.title: Day 128: Divine Glories
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः |

यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम् |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

na me viduḥ suragaṇāḥ prabhavaṃ na maharṣayaḥ .

yo māmajamanādiṃ ca vetti lokamaheśvaram .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: Now, O Prince! Listen to My supreme advice, which I give thee for the sake of thy welfare, for thou art My beloved.
Neither the professors of divinity nor the great ascetics know My origin, for I am the source of them all.
He who knows Me as the unborn, without beginning, the Lord of the universe, he, stripped of his delusion, becomes free from all conceivable sin.
snippets.commentary:
So we completed chapter nine and we'll now be discussing chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga. In the first six chapters we learned about I, the limited being which is part of this Prakriti. Prakriti has three constituent parts: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas. Everything in this Prakriti is made up of these three Gunas; whichever has the predominance, that becomes my nature. Sattva is purity, Rajas is activity, and Tamas is inertia.

Everything in this Prakriti is made up of these three gunas, and we have learned the nature of Prakriti in chapter seven. Up to chapter six we learnt about us as the limited beings and the makeup of our beings. From chapter 7 onward, we are learning about the nature of the supreme, the Lord. In chapter seven we learnt about his lower natures. Bhagavan said this Ashtadha Prakriti: Bhumi, Apah, Analaha, Kham, Vayu, Mana, Buddhi, Ahankara.

The eight — five great elements, Mind, intellect, and Ahankara — are the nature of Prakriti, my lower nature. These are not different from me, but they are my lower nature in the sense of the grosser manifestation which you and I can perceive through our senses. We discussed Prakriti in chapter seven. Chapter eight said that in Prakriti, things are unmanifest in the beginning, then manifest in the middle, then unmanifest again. So Prakriti itself has two aspects.

One is manifest, one is unmanifest. There is unmanifest, Prakriti. There is manifest Prakriti. Bhagawan said, other than this unmanifest, there is another unmanifest which is my higher. Prakriti, which always remains unmanifest, is the support of all things and beings. So in chapter 8, Akshara Brahma Yoga, we learnt about this unmanifest nature of Purusha remaining unmanifest, it supports everything.

Bhagawan said that I'm the origin of all things and beings and I'm also the dissolution of all things and beings. I get confused about my being and therefore I'm not experiencing the very nature of the supreme. The very nature of the supreme is Sat-Chit-Ananda — Sat is existence, Chit is knowledge, and Ananda is happiness or bliss. So right now I'm not truly experiencing Sat. I know I exist, but I'm afraid I'll become non-existent. I'm not experiencing Sat fully.

I know something, but I don't know everything, so I'm not experiencing Chit either. And Ananda is my biggest problem. Happiness comes and goes. For a while I'm happy, and most of the time I'm just pursuing happiness.

So I'm trying to get out of the impermanent nature of Ananda into the permanent nature of Ananda, trying to find out where that permanent Ananda is. Bhagavan in the ninth chapter says that's the royal secret, the greatest secret: it is your very nature to be Sat-Chit-Ananda, but you are not experiencing it. That knowledge which connects me back to my real nature is the royal knowledge.

So that was chapter nine. At the end of chapter nine, Bhagavan said the only way one can experience this is Manmana Bhava. Make your mind focused on me. Offer yourself to me. Make me as your goal Yuktva Mat Parayanaha. In other words, completely identify with me and you will experience that Ananda which you are seeking.

Now how do I get to that level where I can completely identify with him is the subject of chapter 10. So it's called Vibhuti Yoga. Yoga of divine glories. I see, perceive, touch and feel this world of my experiences. But I break them all down into perishable things and beings. Anything which I see, I can say I understand this.

This is just a table. All this, I understand this. Well, I understand this is plant kingdom. So I break this down into the impermanent, perishable conglomeration of things and beings which by very nature they are impermanent and not divine. I don't consider them as divine. I don't say this table is divine.

I don't consider my colleagues as divine. Even when some wise person comes. But he is not Bhagavan. We have difficulty if somebody calls himself Bhagawan because we cannot associate the divinity with the objects of my perception. So how to change that and start seeing Divinity in everything I see and touch and feel is the subject of chapter 10. Therefore it is called Yoga of Divine Glory.

How to see this divinity, this divine glories in everything and being that I come across in the world of my experiences, my world of my perception. So Bhagavan starts this chapter without waiting for Arjuna to ask questions because he saw that he is enjoying it and he wanted to continue the theme which he started in chapter seven about the Prakriti. When he says, this Prakriti is nothing but my lower nature. Everything in this Prakriti Aa Sesah. There is nothing left in this Prakriti which is not divine. But we don't really see that way.

In fact, we divide this world into good and evil. We have some level of acceptance that good is divine. But we are difficult when it comes to bad and ugly. I can't associate divinity with it. This chapter will say that even that is only possible. Bad is only possible because of my presence and evil is only possible because of my presence.

There is nothing that can happen or exist in this world without me. So chapter opens with Bhagavan's statement says Bhuya Eva Mahabaho srunume paramam vacha yatta te aham Priyamanaya vakshyami Hita Kamya. I wish your welfare Hita Kamiya. Therefore I'm going to continue. And in last chapter I told you that this knowledge is available to all. And we discussed that verse which is very troublesome to discuss and say.

Those who are born in Papayonayaha Triya vaishya tathakshadraha. Even they have equal right when they come to me. If they focus their mind onto me. We discuss why Papayoni. Anything which takes me away from my identification with the supreme is sin. That which does not recognize my true potential which is Sat chit in Ananda is Papa.

It is the impurity on my mind which is right now not letting me see who I am. An environment which is more likely to create wrong impressions on my mind is Papa Yoni. Yoni is a collection of people which creates an environment that is similar for each other — a symbiotic relationship. It's like a satsang in reverse — bad company. If I'm put in that environment where I get more sinful impressions on my mind, I have less chance of rising out of it.

Even those people who are disadvantaged by their environment — those who are put in a society that does not give them the equal right to achieve what they try to achieve — can still rise above that. Triya Vaishya Tatakshudra. Interestingly, the Vaishyas never complained about this verse. Only two groups complain. Vaishya didn't say why we are included in it as well.

We are higher than you now. All business people are worshipped now, not Kshatriyas and Brahmanas. So Bhagawan says that at the time of Mahabharata, Vaishyas were not considered as high as the Brahmins and Kshatriyas. I heard when I was growing up. Which profession you are supposed to take?

Uttam Kheti Keti Farming. Madhyam Vyapa and Kanishta Nokri. The worst is you want to work for somebody is Kanishta. We all work for corporate and feel great about it. If you can't do farming then only you do Vaipa. So they were considered lower in that society.

Now today in India, if you tell someone to become a farmer — how many farmers are committing suicide? Why would you want me to do farming? But in that society, Kshatriyas were farmers. Janakaraj, when he was tilling his land, found Sita. Kshatriyas, the kings, were themselves landlords and farmers.

So those people in that environment had a great chance to uplift themselves by getting this knowledge. But others did not have those equal rights. Women, Vaishya, Kshudra. But even they can get this knowledge and come to me. But you are a Mahabaho. You are the mighty armed person who has all the opportunities and all the prerequisites to know this.

So Bhuya Eva Mahabaho again. Listen to my very important words. I think you have come to a level that you are understanding what I'm saying. Manmana Bhava Madh Bhakta Madhya ji Mam namaskaru. I heard Obama saying the other day, stay focused. Don't get distracted by the protesters.

Don't get distracted by your doubts in your mind. Bhagavan says Paramam vacha yate aham Priyamanaya. And I'm only telling those people who likes to listen to this type of knowledge. Vakshyami Hitakami Ayyaa. Because I wish welfare for you all. And therefore I'm telling you.

So what I'm telling you is what we had started in the last chapter saying. What is the royal secret? Aham Adhi Devanam Maharshinam Chasarva Sah. Neither the Devas in the heavens nor the great Rishis know my origin. What is the source of my being? Not on the great Rishis, not the Devas.

Because even in Puranas, Devas have their own limitations. Devas are considered pretty greedy. They want to have everything. Devas, they don't know. And Rishis, they are distracted by their own intellect. See, when we learn something, we get to a level where our intellect will become an obstacle.

We can't experience it because we keep doubting ourselves. So Bhagavan says, even they don't know. Because the source of the Deva and Rishis is me. Swami Dheerananda's very famous example. Batteries in the flashlight. If you're in a dark room and I have flashlight, I can see everything in the room.

But somebody says, what type of batteries are you using, Neil? I say, well, let me take it out. I take out the batteries. I put the batteries back. Light is back, but I can't see the batteries. I said, I don't know till tomorrow morning.

So the source of the light in the flashlight is the batteries. And therefore I cannot know through the light of the flashlight the type of batteries I'm using. Through my intellect, which is the Rishi, I cannot know the source of my being. I constantly try to contemplate through my intellect by deduction and inferences who I am. Bhagavan said, you will not know that the Rishis, our intellect, the knower, the seer in us is the Rishi. In the Devas are our sense perceptions.

To illumine something which is illuminated by my senses. So my senses are the Devas. Without them, the world is not existent for me. You remove the one sense of seeing. The world of sight is gone. You remove the hearing.

The world of sound is gone. You remove all five senses. The world is illuminated by my senses. So they are Devas through my senses. I am trying to find Bhagavan. I want to see Bhagavan.

I want to see the presence of Bhagavan. In the laboratory, when somebody dies, what happens? Where is that atma is going? The people have done experiments of people dying. And what is it that leaving they cannot find it simply because Bhagavan said, because I am the source of this Deva Dhanda, I am the source of your senses and your intellect. You will never be able to find me through this.

Because the instrument cannot find its own source. Bhagwan says, aham, Adhi Diwanam, Maharishi Nam Cha Sarvasa. I'm not available to any of those, to the sense perceptions or by intellectual inquiry. I'm only available by contemplation and identification. By identification that I will be able to find myself. Yom Ajam Anadim Chavaiyati.

One who knows that I am that I. Whichever way you apply it, when applied to the supreme, he is the God. Bhagawan says "I" — that includes everything.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna declares that neither the celestial beings (Devas) nor the great sages (Maharishis) can fully comprehend His origin, for He is the source of them all. This teaching invites us to a profound humility: the instruments we use to understand reality - our senses and intellect - are themselves products of that supreme reality. Just as batteries in a flashlight cannot illuminate themselves, our mind and senses cannot fully grasp their own source. Yet knowing Him as "unborn, beginningless, and Lord of the universe" liberates us from delusion and all conceivable sin.

Consider how you typically try to "figure out" the divine through analysis and reasoning. These verses suggest that intellectual understanding alone has limits - the knower cannot fully objectify its own source. Instead, Krishna offers this knowledge out of love ("priyamanaya" - to one who is dear) and for our welfare ("hitakamyaya"). Today, practice approaching spiritual understanding not as a puzzle to solve, but as a relationship to deepen. When you encounter something beyond your comprehension - a moment of unexpected grace, an inexplicable feeling of peace, the mystery of consciousness itself - instead of immediately trying to analyze it, allow yourself to simply rest in not-knowing.

Ask yourself: "How would my daily life change if I truly accepted that my mind cannot fully grasp its own source? What would it mean to approach the divine with the heart of a beloved, rather than only the intellect of an investigator?"

snippets.title: Day 129: The Source of All
snippets.sanskrit:
बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसम्मोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः |

अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः |

महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा |
snippets.transliteration:
buddhirjñānamasammohaḥ kṣamā satyaṃ damaḥ śamaḥ .

ahiṃsā samatā tuṣṭistapo dānaṃ yaśo.ayaśaḥ .

maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavastathā .
verseTranslations: Intelligence, wisdom, non-illusion, forgiveness, truth, self-control, calmness, pleasure, pain, birth, death, fear and fearlessness;
Harmlessness, equanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame and failure, all these, the characteristics of beings, spring from Me only.

The seven Great Seers,* the Progenitors of mankind, the Ancient Four,** and the Lawgivers were born of My Will and come forth direct from Me. The race of mankind has sprung from them. [* Mareechi, Atri, Angira, Pulah, Kratu, Pulastya, Vahishta. ** The Masters: Sanak, Sanandan, Sanatan, Sanatkumar.]
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. We have seen so far that Bhagavan is immanent as well as transcendental. Bhagavan is immanent because he resides in the hearts of all beings — Ishvara Sarva Bhutanam Hrideshe Arjuna Tishtathi. Ishvara is residing in the hearts of all beings, therefore immanent. But he's also transcendental because we do not recognize him.

This chapter started out by Bhagavan saying in the second verse, I am not known to anyone. Neither the Devas, the divine beings or the divine senses, know me, nor the Great Rishis know me. He is not known by the mind or the intellect. By applying the normal tools of my cognition, I cannot know Ishvara. Therefore he is transcendental. So these two aspects of Bhagavan we have to overcome, in a sense, to know Him.

We have to find altar of meditation. We have completed the first segment of Karma Yoga, culminated in a Dhyana Yoga to meditate upon that supreme Self, my true Self. But what to meditate upon is what we have been discussing since last three chapters 7, 8 and 9. And Bhagawan in various ways told us what his real nature is that I am all pervading. Everything is strung into me. There is no reality other than me.

But it's still difficult for us to meditate on those aspects of Bhagavan. So the Vibhuti Yoga, the glories of the Lord, are required to meditate upon, to focus on. Something which I can identify through the limited means that I have, is my mind and intellect. So in this chapter, the Bhagavan is giving us the Vibhuti, that which I can identify and vouch for his presence. It is something like when I am in a deep sleep at night and wake up suddenly if I really want to know whether the sun is outside or not. That means, is it a day or not?

When I open my windows and I see sunlight, I do not see the sun, but I see sunlight. The presence of sunlight tells me that sun has risen. The sun is there outside. I may not be able to see sun for various reasons. Maybe a building is blocking my view, maybe so bright that I cannot see it. But the very fact that I can experience the sunlight, it tells me that sun has risen.

In the same way, if I know the Vibhutis Sri Bhagawan says, if you can identify the qualities which emanate from me, which are my real qualities, then you should be able to vouch for my presence. The Lord resides in all hearts, in all beings, in all things. But I cannot vouch for it right now. So Bhagawan is giving us the tools to realize his presence. So in verse 3, Bhagavan concluded Yomam Ajam Anadim, Chaviti, Loka Maheshwaram. I am not known to the Devas.

I am also not known to the Rishis, the great sages. I am not known through intellect nor I am known through mind. However, if one knows that I am Ajam Anadim, I am the source of all being. I am birthless and beginningless. It is uncaused, caused, then it is birthless. There is nothing before me.

Therefore there is nothing is causing my existence. And also I'm beginningless because there's nothing before me. Loka Maheshwaram, the Lord of all the entire creation is there because of me. Because of the entity which is beginningless and birthless, the entire Jagat exists, the Bhagavan, the Lord Ishvara is the material cause and efficient cause for this Jagat. When he created this universe out of his own Maya, there was no other material available to him. From his own self, from his own qualities.

He provided the material as well as the knowledge, the efficient cause to create this Jagat. So the creation, if it all comes out of he is the Loka Maheshram. He is the Lord of all the beings. Lord is the one on whom my existence depends. So my Lord is my own consciousness. Without that, my existence as this limited being does not exist.

The day consciousness is not there, I will not be nil Bhatt. I'll be just a dead body. So Bhagavan said Asammudasam, the one who is not deluded by these appearances, he will be relieved of all the sins. In other words, all the ignorances, all the ignorant ideas that I have about myself as a limited being, I'll be liberated from. And then he enumerates those 20 qualities of the supreme Being, the divinity. These qualities in people, in things and beings, exist because of my presence. Those qualities are somewhat easy to understand.

Buddhi, Gnanam, Asamoha, Shamah, Satyam, Damaha, Shamaha. Buddhi is intellect, Nischayatmika Buddhi — that which decides what is right and wrong. So when I feel that I'm exhibiting my Buddhi because I can decide it is day and not night, that's my Buddhi. Bhagavan says that because of my presence in you, this Buddhi exists in you at the microcosm. This Buddhi I use for deciding what's outside in this world. Gnanam — this Buddhi now gives me knowledge of what is real and what is unreal.

Asammoha and non illusion. When I have Buddhi and I apply it to find out whether it is day outside or night, when I wake up, it gives me non illusion. Even though it was dark in my room, there is no difference between day and night in my room. But as soon as I open the window, I knew it's a day outside. That is because of my Buddhi that if there is sunlight outside, the sun has risen and therefore it is a day. So that created a Samohaha.

Non-illusion, no delusion, no confusion. Out of these three, I develop other qualities such as Kshama (forgiveness), Satyam (truth), Damaha (control of the Indriyas), and Shamaha (control of the mind). We've seen in Tattva Bodh that Shamah is Mano Nigrahaha, and Damaha is control of the senses such as eyes and ears. Now, if I see that somebody is not yet convinced that it's day outside — even though I have concluded that it is day — if my wife doesn't agree with me, then I forgive her.

I think she has not seen outside yet. Because of my knowledge, my Buddhi, my non-delusion, I can forgive other people who are still not at that level. She has not woken up completely. She cannot see the light outside — to her, it's still night. I can forgive her because of my knowledge.

If I have no knowledge, there will be confusion. We will be fighting about it. But because I have knowledge, I can have Kshama and I can vouch for the truth that it is day outside. I can control my actions and also my mind. All this emanates from the same source — my own consciousness at the vyashti, at the microcosm. I have all these exhibiting through me.

Because of that divinity, the consciousness functioning through me, I'm identifying with it. Sukham Dukham Bhavah Abhavah, Bhayam cha Abhayam eva cha. These are the pairs of opposites I have to deal with in this world — this world which I have created out of my own consciousness. In deep sleep, there was no world outside to deal with. There were no pairs of opposites.

There was no confusion about day or night. But as soon as I woke up and I have this Buddhi and Gnana exhibiting through me. Now I have to deal with this world outside which has pairs of opposites. So Kannadukha Bhava and Abhava. Existence and non existence, birth and death. Bhayam cha Bhayam Bhaya is a positive emotion which protects me from getting myself hurt.

If I have no Bhaya of jumping from a third floor window, then I'm going to hurt myself. So this fear of getting hurt is actually protecting me. So therefore it's a positive emotion. And Abhaya and fearlessness. Things which I am very sure about. I'll be fearless no matter what.

Somebody tells me that I do not exist. So things which I so sure about my existence, I'm fearless. Things which I'm not sure about my existence. After my death, I'm fearful. I have fear of death because I have no idea what will happen after my death. I'm fearless about my existence right now.

Because I know who I am and how I exist exist. So there's both fear and fearlessness emanating from my identification with my consciousness. Ahimsa, non injury, Samatha, equanimity, Tusthi, contentment, Tapaha, disciplines, austerity, Dhanam, charity, Yashaha, Fame and also Ayyashaha ill fame. All these I experience because of my identification with myself as my conscious conscious being. These 20 qualities are given as the glories of that supreme Lord. These are the basic qualities through which he manifests in this world through beings.

He resides in the hearts of all the beings. And when those beings identify with him, these positive qualities are exhibited through them. Then what about the opposites of this? Like Hinsa, Abudhi, Agnana, Samoha. It is nothing but non identification with the self. When I identify with the Divinity within me, all these positive qualities of the divinity will be manifesting through me.

When I'm not identifying with that divinity, then the lack of those qualities will be exhibiting. So the lack of qualities are not really any qualities. They are just lack of good qualities. Something similar to how there is nothing called cold — just a lack of heat. Heat I can identify as a form of energy, but cold has no form of energy.

It just lack of heat creates sensation of cold. Lack of Ahimsa creates Himsa. Lack of Buddhi creates Abuddhi — one who doesn't know anything. Lack of knowledge creates ignorance. So the negatives which we see in this world is because of non identification with the true self. Bhagavan said this entire Jagat is created by my own mind using my own self as the material.

My Maya is the material, therefore he is the Loka Maheshwaram. Without him no world is possible. Without you being conscious of your world, your world cannot exist. Without me being conscious of my world, my world does not exist. And therefore he, the Supreme Lord who is functioning through all beings as their consciousness. He is the Lord of all all the beings.

So he is justifying why he is Loka, Maheshwaram, Bhavanti, Bhava, Bhutana, Mata Eva, Pruthakvida. These varieties of expressions you see in this world through various beings with all these qualities in the various levels, this permutation combinations, all these 20 qualities creates this multitude of personalities in this world. Somebody has more Buddhi, somebody has more Kshama, somebody has more Ahimsa. All these manifestations in this world through beings. But anytime I see the expression of any of these qualities, I must know that divinity is present in that being. Bhavanti Bhava Bhutanam Mata Eva Prithak Vidhaha.

All these different kinds of qualities of being arise from me alone. Without that one common thread which we call it consciousness, life, none of these are possible. And therefore we should know when we see these qualities that the Lord is present. And therefore when we meet each other, when we see the exhibition of any of these qualities, we have to do Namaste that I see the divinity in you is emanating through you as kindness. All these qualities are nothing but the glories of the Lord and Bhagawan. Meditate on those glories.

These are your means, the tools for you to meditate on the divine self that you are. Then Bhagavan concludes by giving a complete picture of the creation. Maharsayah, Saptapurve, Chatvarohu, Manamahata, Madbhava Manasa Jata, Esam, Loka, Imah, Prajaha.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal twenty divine qualities that emanate from the Lord's presence: Buddhi (intellect), Jnana (wisdom), Asamoha (non-delusion), Kshama (forgiveness), Satya (truth), Dama (sense-control), Shama (mind-control), Sukha and Dukha (pleasure and pain), Bhava and Abhava (birth and death), Bhaya and Abhaya (fear and fearlessness), Ahimsa (non-injury), Samata (equanimity), Tushti (contentment), Tapa (austerity), Dana (charity), Yasha and Ayasha (fame and ill-fame). Each of these exists in beings only because of the divine presence within. When we see someone display wisdom, forgiveness, or fearlessness, we are witnessing the Lord's light shining through that individual.

The teaching also clarifies something crucial: negative qualities are simply the absence of these positive divine expressions. Just as cold is not a thing in itself but merely the absence of heat, ignorance is the absence of knowledge, cruelty is the absence of compassion. This understanding transforms how we view both ourselves and others - rather than seeing "bad" as a positive force, we recognize it as non-identification with our divine nature. Today, when you encounter any of these twenty qualities in yourself or others - a moment of genuine forgiveness, an act of charity, a flash of wisdom - pause and recognize: "This is divinity expressing itself."

Reflect on these questions: "Which of these twenty qualities do I most naturally express? Which ones feel distant from me? Can I see even difficult emotions like fear or the experience of loss as part of the divine tapestry of existence, present only because consciousness is present?"

snippets.title: Day 130: Divine Manifestations
snippets.sanskrit:
एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः |

अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते |

मच्चित्ता मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम् |
snippets.transliteration:
etāṃ vibhūtiṃ yogaṃ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ .

ahaṃ sarvasya prabhavo mattaḥ sarvaṃ pravartate .

maccittā madgataprāṇā bodhayantaḥ parasparam .
verseTranslations: He who rightly understands My manifested glory and My Creative Power, beyond doubt attains perfect peace.
I am the source of all; from Me everything flows. Therefore the wise worship Me with unchanging devotion.
With minds concentrated on Me, with lives absorbed in Me, and enlightening each other, they ever feel content and happy.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, the Lord's Vibhuti, that one which appears to be many is His Vibhuti. By his power of Yoga he appears to us as many. So you go to the jewelry shop, the gold is gold, but the Vibhuti of gold with all the jewelries you see, that's the glory of the gold you see in the jewelry shop. And the yogic power is the jeweler who is the yogic power, that efficient cause with which he creates many out of this one gold. So Bhagavan said that I am the source of all the beings in this chapter, but says not many people can realize that. Even the Rishis, Maharisis and the Devas Sura Ganaha, even they cannot recognize that.

The reason being that I am the source of even those who we consider to be the higher beings, such as Sura Ganaha and Mahari says, and therefore the effect cannot find its own source. All this Saptarisis, sanat, Kumaras and 14 Manus, they're all born out of my mind. In other words, anything which you consider is the source of your being, source of your human race or your existence, all came out of me, born out of my mind. And after that, all the progeny of those are also me. However, it appears to us as many because of our own ignorance about our own self. Now the goal is to unwind that clock from where we started and reached to this point of ignorance and remove that ignorance.

So, Aham Sarvasya Prabhavah, Matta Sarva Pravartate, Iti Matva Bhajante Mam Budhaha Bhava Samanvitaha — but one whose intellect is steady, Bhava Samanvitaha, they will see me as the source of all the beings. Everything is pervaded by me. With such understanding and such devotion, one who worships me, they obviously will get me. And then: Macchitta Madgat Pranah Bodhayantah Parasparam Kathayantash cha Mam Nityam Tushyanti cha Ramanti cha.

What we don't have in our life is contentment and delight. Our life is full of discontent and dejection. One of the Swamijis used to say, our life is like the cardiogram: unhappiness, unhappiness, little happiness, unhappiness, little happiness.

That's the story of our life. What we're seeking is exactly the contentment. I want to be satisfied, I want to be content. I want to have bliss. Then I want to enjoy my life. That's what we are looking for.

And everything we have tried so far in our life has its own limitation. So that is what we are lacking. Bhagavan says the only people who achieve this are Macchitaha — those whose mind is absorbed in me. In other words, I have come to the conclusion that the Lord is the source of all being. And we have seen from the logic of spirituality that this world was created by God, using the only material available to him, which is his own self.

You and I cannot be anything different than his own self. With that understanding, if my mind is resting in him always, anything I see, anything I feel, anything I touch is nothing but his self. Machittaha Madgat Pranaha — everything that is happening with my life, my Prana. Swamiji takes a much wider view of Prana: any experience which I have through my sense organs is nothing but his experience alone.

Because I have come to the firm conclusion that this world could not have been created out of anything but God's own self. There is no other material available to him to create this world but his own self. We constantly remind each other that you and I are nothing but the Lord's own self. It reminds me of a kind of practical joke. When I was in the Dallas group, a lot of Americans who were involved in what I do said, "Neel, I noticed something. You guys always say, 'Hari Om.'"

In Chinmaya Mission we meet each other and say, "Hari Om." But he heard it as "hurry home." He said, "I know now why you guys have a better family life. You remind each other constantly. Your wife must be waiting.

Neel, go home, otherwise you'll be in trouble. You remind each other, hurry home. Then you won't have any trouble." But the real meaning of Bodhayantaha Parasparam is that we constantly remind each other and enlighten others that there is no other self in you or in me but the same self. That's why Namaste means "I bow down to you" — the same self which is in me is in you.

Bodhayantaha Parasparam Kathayantash cha Mam Nityam — constantly speaking about me, constantly reminding ourselves in all our actions that everything happening in my life, every experience that I'm experiencing, is nothing but the Lord's glory alone. Tushyanti cha Ramanti cha — they're content and they're reveling in their own self. Swamiji makes an elaborate distinction between Kridanti and Ramanti. Krida requires an outside object to interact with — to play a ball or whatever. Ramanti is reveling in yourself; by yourself you're enjoying. That is Ramanti.

So the two things we always are lacking is this contentment and the joy. Bhagavan said, you can only get by your mind constantly focused on the self. All your activities are devoted to the self. Reminding, enlightening each other that we are the manifestation of the same Lord. And then Kathayanti cha — speaking about that will lead you to contentment and enjoyment. Dadami Buddhi Yogam Tam Yena Mam Upayanti Te.

Those who do what we have discussed in the previous verse — Bhagawan says, now what is my job? Tesham Satata Yuktanam Bhajatam Priti Purvakam Dadami Buddhi Yogam Tam Yena Mam Upayanti Te. I give them Buddhi Yoga. Those who are doing what we just discussed — constantly focusing their mind on the self, all their activities dedicated to the self, enlightening each other and speaking about it — they're content.

Because Bhagavan said, I give them Buddhi Yoga. Now, Buddhi Yoga is not this Buddhi that we know as part of Mana, Buddhi, Chitta, Ahankara. That Buddhi is used to decipher the world of objects. With this intellect I try to decide my experiences — whether this is right or that is right — and I come to a conclusion.

So that is the ordinary Buddhi. But this is Yogic Buddhi. Buddhi we associate with knowing something. Becoming firmly convicted about something is Buddhi. Waffling is the mind — I like, I dislike.

I know, I don't know, this or that. Once I decisively know, that's Buddhi. In this case, I now decisively know what my self is. There is no doubt left in my mind anymore. Up till now I had a doubt: what is my relationship with the Lord?

Is he really looking after me or not? Well, I'm doing his puja — does he know that I'm doing his puja? Therefore, make sure that we publish it in Bharadwani that I did Lakshmi Puja. "Lord, you know that it was published in Bharadwani. Now it's your responsibility." Bhagavan said, I give them that Buddhi which gives you that contentment and joy.

Te Yena Mam Upayanti Te. With that Buddhi Yoga they come to me. Our journey started from when we separated from ourselves by ignorance and started thinking, "This is me, this body is me, this mind is me, this intellect is me." And now at my age, I realize that not only this body which I was born with and then grew out of food, but the steel plate in my leg and the acrylic lens in my eye is also "me." No difference between the lens I was born with. I actually asked my ophthalmologist.

I said, doesn't it come with a lifetime warranty? He said, no, it doesn't. I said, how about this one? He said, this has a limited warranty too. All that I consider me turns out to be something I have borrowed from this world. Bhagavan said, once that awareness takes place that there is nothing but the self exists.

You know there is nothing but "I" that exists. That parallax is now removed between my lower self and the higher self. Tesham Eva Anukampartham Aham Ajnana Jam Tamah Nashayami Atma Bhavastho Jnana Dipena Bhasvata.

So now it seems like Bhagavan is doing all that very partially — only for those who put in all this effort. And he really doesn't care about people like us who are constantly busy with our business and our studies and our professions. But Bhagavan is ever compassionate, and all religions say that, including Christianity.

Bhagawan is never considered as one who is harshly judging people. He's ever compassionate, but he has his own limitations. Unless I seek his compassion, he does not have the power to shower his compassion on me. Let's say I have five children and four of them never talk to me — only one talks to me. My compassion is only revealed to the one who is constantly with me. The other four have never experienced my compassion because they never allowed me to show it to them.

Swamiji gives another example. That sun is always compassionate to give you sunlight. But as long as I keep the windows closed, he doesn't have any power to give you compassion. He has to patiently wait outside your window till you allow him to come inside your room by opening the windows. Then he can shower his compassion by giving you the light. It is us where we have to become worthy of his compassion.

So Bhagawan said, Tesham — those we just talked about, all the qualities they have achieved. Tesham Eva Anukampartham Aham Ajnana Jam Tamah. What has made me feel different from my own self, from God? My own ignorance. The self is self-effulgent. It has its own revelation. It becomes revealed to you by its own glory.

Myself, I'm always aware. Under whatever condition, I know I exist. That requires no intellectual conviction or intellectual argument about whether I exist or not. Everything else requires my intellectual conclusion. Am I an architect or a doctor? I come to the conclusion I cannot be anything but an architect.

I never went to medical school. So all these things which my upadhi requires — my intellectual conclusion that "this is who I am" — but "I exist" requires no intellectual argument. It reveals to me that I exist, in my awareness. So Bhagavan says, what has removed you from that revelation that yourself and the God-self are one? Your ignorance, created by identification with the non-self — my body, my mind, my intellect — that created an avarana, a veiling, over my understanding that I exist.

And that veiling once removed, no other efforts are required. Swamiji uses a very good example. I'm looking for my key in the room and the key is lying on the table. But the room is pitch dark. Obviously I can't find my key. But somebody with his compassion turned the lights on.

With that compassion of turning the light on, now the light shines on my key and I see my key. The person didn't have to produce a key. Just out of compassion, he removes the darkness in the room and I find my key. In the same way, Bhagawan said, the self was always dwelling in my own heart.

It is always revealing that I exist. But I consider that "I" to be this limited "I" — the existence which I feel all the time, I now take it for granted. It is talking about my body, my mind, my intellect, my achievement, my position, my relationship. That's "I." Bhagawan said, with the destruction of this ignorance by all the things which we have talked about, I remove that darkness by lighting up the Jnana Dipa, the light of knowledge, in your heart.

And you come to this revelation that my existence is of that supreme self.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the blessed state of those who truly understand Krishna's Vibhuti and Yoga: "Macchitta Madgata-pranah" - minds absorbed in Me, lives dedicated to Me. Such devotees enlighten each other (Bodhayantah parasparam), constantly speak of the divine (Kathayantah), and experience both contentment (Tushyanti) and joy (Ramanti). Notice how this spiritual path is not solitary - it involves mutual enlightenment and shared discourse. The greeting "Hari Om" or "Namaste" is not mere social courtesy but a constant reminder: the divine in me recognizes the divine in you.

The distinction between Kridanti (playing with external objects) and Ramanti (reveling within oneself) is profound. Our usual happiness depends on external conditions - we need something outside ourselves to enjoy. But the devotee described here experiences Ramanti - a self-contained joy that needs nothing external. This contentment comes from the firm conviction: "I am the source of all; from Me everything flows" (Aham sarvasya prabhavah). When this understanding moves from intellectual assent to lived experience, the endless seeking stops.

Today, practice "Bodhayantah parasparam" - mutual enlightenment. Share a spiritual insight with someone, or ask about their understanding. Notice how speaking about truth deepens your own grasp of it. And throughout the day, when happiness comes, ask: "Is this Krida - dependent on something external? Or can I touch that Ramanti - the joy of simply being?" What would it mean for your life to be truly "Madgata-prana" - your very life-breath dedicated to recognizing the divine in all?

snippets.reflection:
The Lord makes a remarkable promise here: "Dadami Buddhi-yogam tam" - I give them the Yoga of discrimination. This is not ordinary intellectual sharpness but a special faculty that connects us back to our source. And crucially, this gift comes to those who worship "Priti-purvakam" - with love, not mere duty. The image of the sun waiting patiently outside a closed window beautifully illustrates divine grace: it is ever-present, but we must open ourselves to receive it. God's compassion is unconditional, but our receptivity determines what we experience.

Arjuna's response reveals a transformed understanding. He addresses Krishna with profound titles: Param Brahma (Supreme Absolute), Param Dhama (Supreme Abode), Pavitram Paramam (Supreme Purifier), Purusham Shashvatam (Eternal Being), Adi-devam (Primal God), Ajam (Unborn), Vibhum (All-pervading). This is not flattery but recognition - Arjuna has moved from confusion to clarity, from seeing Krishna as merely his friend and charioteer to recognizing him as the Supreme Reality. Such recognition transforms relationship - we cannot treat casually what we truly revere.

Today, practice opening your windows to divine grace. Where have you kept the shutters closed - through doubt, distraction, or simply forgetting? The Buddhi-yoga promised here is not earned through effort alone but received through loving devotion combined with consistent practice. Ask yourself: "What would it look like to worship 'with love' rather than obligation? Where in my life am I seeking confirmation from the outside world rather than trusting the light of knowledge that dwells within my own heart?"

snippets.title: Day 132: Divine Glories
snippets.sanskrit:
आहुस्त्वामृषयः सर्वे देवर्षिर्नारदस्तथा |

सर्वमेतदृतं मन्ये यन्मां वदसि केशव |

स्वयमेवात्मनात्मानं वेत्थ त्वं पुरुषोत्तम |
snippets.transliteration:
āhustvāmṛṣayaḥ sarve devarṣirnāradastathā .

sarvametadṛtaṃ manye yanmāṃ vadasi keśava .

svayamevātmanātmānaṃ vettha tvaṃ puruṣottama .
verseTranslations: So have said the seers and the divine sage Narada; as well as Asita, Devala and Vyasa; and Thou Thyself also sayest it.
I believe in what Thou hast said, my Lord! For neither the godly nor the godless comprehend Thy manifestation.
snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

We had been discussing chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glory. In the first six chapters. Chapter two gave us the real indicator of who we are. The paradigm shift in chapter two was you are not the mortal being, but you are the immortal being having mortal equipment. As long as you identify with your mortal equipment, you are mortal. But if you identify with immortal being, you are immortal.

The quest of my life is to exist, and therefore the only remedy is to identify with the immortal being, not with the mortal equipment. The remaining segment of the first six chapters dealt with actions, because actions are the unit of my interface with this world. So the first six chapters give us the pluralistic view of the world and myself. The segment ended with Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Contemplation, Meditation. How do I now change my worldview from pluralistic to singularistic? The technique is meditation, but then what to meditate upon will be the next six chapters, 7 to 12, which is that "Tat" aspect of Tattvamasi.

There are four Mahavakyas we have seen before in the Upanishads. One is Prajnanam Brahma — Consciousness is Brahman. That's the very first. The next is Ayam Atma Brahma.

So if consciousness is Brahman, then my Atma is Brahman — my consciousness is Brahman. The next one says Tattvamasi — "That thou art," that which you are seeking as immortal existence is you, is your own self. And the last one is Aham Brahmasmi. Once that realization takes place, it's "Oh, I am that consciousness." The Gita is an elaboration on the third, which is Tattvamasi. So the "Tat" — that which I consider right now something other than me, Bhagavan is somebody other than me.

I know all my limitations, all my papas and punyas. Bhagavan has none of those. So he's something other than me. That is described in chapters 7 to 12. The seventh chapter was Jnana Vijnana Yoga — Yoga of Knowledge and its application. Vijnana is Vishishta Jnana, applied knowledge.

When it's applied, it becomes Vijnana. So in Jnana Vijnana Yoga we got a glimpse of reality — that there are two ways to look at it. One is the pluralistic view, the other the singularistic view. When we look at the pluralistic, it's called Prakriti, the world of the manifested universe.

As we know, where I exist, he exists, it exists, and everything else exists. That's the world of Prakriti. But that is my lower Prakriti, because you can perceive, feel, and experience it through your senses. Therefore it's the lower Prakriti. Other than that is my higher Prakriti, which is unmanifested.

The higher Prakriti cannot be perceived through your senses. So he said, there are two Prakritis. The source of all the beings and things in this world are these two Prakritis — these two natures, higher and lower. Whether you look at it from a singularistic way or a pluralistic way. That was chapter seven.

Chapter eight was Imperishable Brahman. How do I recognize that imperishable Brahman, that which is the source of all beings? He says, Aham Kṛtsnasya Jagadaha — I am the source of all the things and beings. How do I recognize that the self is imperishable? That is given in chapter 8. Chapter 9 was Rajavidya Rajaguhya Yoga, the Yoga of the Royal Secret.

The secret is the relationship — the "relation-less" relationship I have with that source. Bhagavan said, I am not in them, but they are in me. All the things and beings which we perceive, feel, touch, interact, and react with in this world — Bhagawan said, they are in me, I am not in them. Which is totally contrary to what we have heard all our life from our childhood.

Bhagavan is in every being. Bhagavan is in your heart, my heart, his heart. Bhagawan says, no, I am not anywhere. They are all in me, but I am not in them. He also turned around and said, but they are also not in me. So it is something for us to contemplate.

How can that relationship exist where he is not in me, but I am in him, but I am also not in him? So the analogy we had used before to understand this: space in a car. Is the space in the car, or is the car in the space? BMW or Mercedes — is the space in the car, or is the car in the space? We clearly know space is in the car. "We have already four people. We don't have space in my car."

But if that's the case, what happened to the space which was in the car when it was manufactured in Germany and sealed tight and transported to United States? What happened to the German space? Did I bring it with me or we left it in Germany? Well, the answer is obviously we didn't import space, we only imported the car. So car must be in this space. Space cannot be in the car.

Car moved in the space. And now if you consider that this space and the car are made up of the same entity called nothingness, then space can say, car is not in me. See, we have difficulty understanding this because we think this is solid world of matter and the space is no matter. But scientists have been trying to find a solid matter in this world and they have not been successful so far. First we thought that you need a matter atom. Then we found out atom is nothing but a hole of space.

There's nothing in it other than electrons and protons. The nucleus must be a solid material. They found out that's not solid either. We are yet to find any solid material anywhere in this universe. So if you consider that both the car and the space are made up of the same material, then space can say, "Car is not in me." So Bhagavan said, I am not in them, they are in me.

The beings as they perceive, they are in my own self. They are there because of me. If I am not there, they are not there. But they are also not there. Because I have never changed into these beings. Therefore they are also not in me.

That's my relation-less relationship with my Lord. How do I recognize it? As we discussed in chapter nine. But now I'm more confused. Arjuna said, "What do I contemplate? I cannot contemplate on nothingness."

As I said, in architecture, the first exercise was how to perceive space. So if you take space and remove everything out of this space, you cannot perceive space, only perceive space in the relationship of objects. There are two objects in architecture. We used to say we created three spaces. Two positive space and one negative space in between. And that's how you now perceive positive, negative, positive.

My senses are not capable. So Bhagavan said, I will tell you how you should contemplate on me. He said, Aham Sarvasya Prabhava, Mattaha Sarva Pravartate — start thinking first that I pervade everywhere, I am the source of all being. And Mattaha Sarva Pravartate, Iti Matva Bhajante Mam Budhaha Bhava Samanvitaha.

Thus, whoever contemplates on me is a wise person, one endowed with loving consciousness. He will start with this very notion that he is the source of all being. We will have great difficulty if the president of our country is not to our liking and we are told he is also Krishna's manifestation. Bhagawan said, you have to overcome that. If you don't overcome that, you have failed at the starting line.

You have to overcome that. Iti Matva Bhajante Mam Priti Purvakam Bhava Samanvitaha. With a loving consciousness — right now I divide my world into the world I love and the world I hate. Bhagawan says, if you want to know me, this world cannot be divided, because it's only me. I cannot hate part of me. I cannot love my right leg and hate my left leg.

So Bhagawan gave that thumbnail sketch of how people can come to Macchittaha Madgat Pranaha Bodhayantaha Parasparam. You try to do it by yourself — you may be motivated for a few days. After that you will recede into what you were doing before.

Therefore, it is very important to have Bodhayantaha Parasparam — reinforce this idea in each other. Satsanga, the glory of Satsanga. This cannot be done by yourself. Gita cannot be read in one sitting. You can't sit down and say, "I learned Gita." When Swamiji used to come, people would say, "Swamiji, we have gone through the Gita."

Swamiji used to say, "Has the Gita gone through you?" So it is very essential that we keep up our enthusiasm about knowing Bhagawan. We are very easy to drop off. Somebody once said, "I finally understood the difference between two worldviews." He said the basic difference is that one group starts with saying that human beings are basically bad, and you have to improve them. Their goal is: they start out bad, you have to improve them.

The other group says human beings are basically good; they are victims of situations, and we have to help them. That's the big difference in worldview. So they're very similar to what we say about the Hindu view and certain other religious views. Some religions start with the premise that the human being is a sinner who must be redeemed. Hinduism says the human being is an immortal, divine being, and you have to purify him if there is impurity on him.

So Bhagavan here says, whether you start from evil or good, there is a very good possibility of impurities superimposing on you and dampening your enthusiasm. The only way you can make sure is Parasparam Bodhayantaha — because we see our world through others' eyes. If others approve what you are doing, we feel good about it. No matter how sure I am that I am doing good, if others don't approve, I won't feel good about it.

Two people were working in a warehouse, painting the high trusses. They are lazily leaning against each other while painting. One fell down, so the other also fell down. Luckily they fell in a heap of garbage, so they were not hurt. They got up and looked at each other. One's face was completely dirty, the other's was miraculously clean.

The guy whose face was clean went to the bathroom, washed his face, then went to work. The guy whose face was dirty didn't bother — he went straight to work. Why? They looked at each other. The clean-faced guy said, "His face is dirty, mine must be dirty too." The dirty-faced guy said, "His face is clean, mine must be clean too. Let me go and start working."
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna now confirms his faith by citing authorities: the great sages, divine seers like Narada, Asita, Devala, and Vyasa have all declared this truth. His statement "Sarvam etat ritam manye" - "I accept all this as truth" - marks a crucial transition from hearing to believing. Yet Arjuna adds something profound: "Svayam eva atmana atmanam vettha tvam" - "You alone know Yourself by Yourself." No external authority can fully reveal the divine; ultimately, the Self knows the Self. Even the greatest teachers can only point; realization is direct and intimate.

The verse also highlights the importance of Satsanga - spiritual companionship. We see the world through others' eyes; if our companions approve of spiritual seeking, we feel encouraged. The story of the two workers who fell into garbage illustrates this perfectly - each judged his own face by looking at the other's. In spiritual life, we need fellow seekers who reflect back to us our higher nature, not our limitations. This is why "Bodhayantah parasparam" - mutually enlightening each other - is so essential. Alone, our enthusiasm fades; together, we sustain the fire.

Today, reflect on your sources of spiritual authority. Who are the "Naradas and Vyasas" in your life - the teachers, texts, and companions whose wisdom you trust? And recognize that while external confirmation matters, the ultimate knowing must come from within. Ask yourself: "Do I seek truth to genuinely understand, or merely to collect intellectual concepts? Who in my life supports my highest aspirations? Am I that kind of friend to others?"

snippets.reflection:
Arjuna's request here is deeply practical: "Tell me Your divine manifestations (Vibhutayah) by which You pervade these worlds." He understands the teaching intellectually but needs concrete pointers for meditation. His question "Katham vidyam aham" - "How shall I know You?" - acknowledges that knowing about God is different from experiencing God's presence. The formless is difficult to contemplate; the mind needs hooks, anchors, tangible reference points. This is not spiritual weakness but honest acknowledgment of how human consciousness works.

Most striking is Arjuna's declaration: "Truptir hi shrinvato nasti me amritam" - "I am never satiated listening to Your nectar-like words." This insatiable thirst for spiritual knowledge marks the true seeker. Unlike ordinary desires that diminish with fulfillment, spiritual hunger grows the more it is fed. Each insight creates capacity for deeper insight; each experience of truth creates longing for more. This is the nature of approaching the infinite - there is always more.

Today, practice Arjuna's approach: bring your honest questions to your spiritual practice. What specific pointers would help you recognize the divine in your daily experience? Notice whether your engagement with spiritual teachings feels like obligation or genuine thirst. If the fire seems dim, perhaps you need fresh fuel - new questions, new perspectives, renewed wonder. Ask yourself: "Am I approaching spirituality as a subject to master or a mystery to explore? What would it take to feel genuine, insatiable curiosity about the nature of reality?"

snippets.title: Day 134: Divine Manifestations
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः |

आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान् |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

ahamātmā guḍākeśa sarvabhūtāśayasthitaḥ .

ādityānāmahaṃ viṣṇurjyotiṣāṃ raviraṃśumān .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: So be it, My beloved friend! I will unfold to thee some of the chief aspects of My glory. Of its full extent there is no end.
O Arjuna! I am the Self, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning and the life, and I am the end of them all.
Of all the creative Powers I am the Creator, of luminaries the Sun; the Whirlwind among the winds, and the Moon among planets.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. So far, up to chapters one through nine, we came to one conclusion: that everything comes out of one single entity and everything is pervaded by him. Over and over Bhagavan said that you should focus on that entity which is permanent, that which never changes. Along with all the changes happening in this Sansar, everything is constantly changing — including my body, my mind, my intellect. But they're part of the Prakriti.

But as long as you identify with this unchanging reality which is all pervading and the source of all the beings, then thou shall be liberated from all your sorrows and limitations. So Arjuna, like all of us, says that I intellectually appreciate this. Many, many Rishis have said this, and now you are also telling me the same thing. But how do I contemplate upon that single entity is still not clear to me. Intellectually appreciating that he is everywhere is one thing, and when encounter a situation which is unconducive, to keep that thought steady in your mind is another thing. And that's why Arjuna said I am having difficulty.

I cannot conceptualize in my mind what is that all pervading entity is all about. You need to give me some pointers. Something which I can tangibly can relate to, which I can conceptualize in my mind, in my meditation, in my contemplation, where I can hang on to that entity as the divine entity, as the one all pervading entity. And then I may make some progress. So tell me all your glories without leaving anything behind, because I never get tired of listening to it. You tell me all these times.

So tell me what is it that I should be looking for in this universe which I can identify as your manifestation? Everything I see right now, even though I have understood, come very short of being divine. So what should I focus on? So in response to that, we have this next 22 verses which Bhagavan gives Various pointers to meditate upon. It is not very clear to us how to identify divinity. So Bhagavan said, you find divinity in everything that is best among their own spheres.

So Bhagavan starts his response by clarifying that we are not coming to any new conclusion now — that only the best is where I am, but not the rest. Verse 20 clearly makes a summary statement: let's not get deviated from what we already talked about, that I am the source of all the beings, Asheshena, without leaving anything out. But in some, this divinity may be more prominent to identify. So he says: Aham Atma Gudakesha Sarva Bhuta Ashayasthitah. Let's make it clear that I reside as the core of all the beings. There is no exception.

Just because we say the one is more manifesting divinity and other is not, that does not mean the other is devoid of my presence. So very first clarification is I reside in all the beings as the core of their beings. Aham adhisha madhyacha bhutanam anta evacha. I am the origin, Adi middle and the end of all the beings. All the beings are part of the Prakriti. They have beginning and end.

They come from somewhere. They exist in time and space for a while and then they end. But all the time the source of that being is me. I am the one who sustained them during their existence. And I am the one they dissolve into. That you should never forget, Bhagavanji, even in your contemplation, that there is no exception.

There is nothing which can exist without my presence. But your question was: what to contemplate upon? How can I conceptualize the divinity, the self, which is all pervading and immortal? So I'll give you the pointers. As Swamiji says, in the next 21 verses Bhagawan gave 75 pointers. It is like something obvious we can identify with.

When the lights are on in this room, we know the electricity is there. When lights were off, electricity was still here. It just was not available for my perception. The electricity always pervades in this room in all this electrical wiring. I can only prove when I show you the presence of it in some manifest form. So the manifest forms rest of the chapter talks about.

And because it is given to Arjuna in his time, we obviously walk through several of these Vedic and Puranic references. If Krishna were talking today, he would say, "I am the iPhone among all smartphones. I'm Google among all technology companies." We relate to things which are familiar to us, and therefore the analogies given are more in line with the culture at the time.

And what Arjuna can identify with — he starts out from the higher, then comes down to the level which in day-to-day life Arjuna can identify with. Adityanam Aham Vishnuh — among the Adityas, I am Vishnu. Aditi's sons are the Adityas. As Swamiji points out, Aditi is mentioned in the Rig Veda. Aditi means limitless. Aditi is the mother of all celestial beings.

Later, in Puranic time, Aditi was also shown as wife of Kashyap Rishi. But from the Vedic point of view, Aditi was the perennial mother, the primordial mother who gives birth to this universe. According to our scriptures and puranas, sometimes four Adityas are mentioned, sometimes six. But eventually they settled on 12 Adityas. When the word is used in the singular, it means Sun. When mentioned in the plural, it means the 12. The Adityas somewhat identify with the 12 months of the year; each one is in charge of one segment of the year. So among the Adityas, Bhagavan says I am Vishnu. Vishnu is all pervading. Vishnu means one who has long reach.

You can probably say that the one in charge of the longest day in the year is Vishnu. But basically, among all the celestial beings, what becomes very apparent to me is Vishnu because he is all pervading. Consider me as Vishnu among all Adityas. Jyotisham Ravihi Anshuman — among the luminaries in the sky, those objects or entities that are self-effulgent, I am the radiant Sun.

Sun is something obvious to us. But we can only relate to Sun. Among the luminaries in the sky, I am Sun. Marichihi Marutam Asmi among the winds, wind is air in different forms. It can be hurricane, it can be tornado, it can be storm or it can be a pleasant breeze. Marutas in plurality are in charge of all these different types of winds.

Now obviously in Vedic time, we were reliant on the natural forces. Natural forces are something we are trying to understand. So each natural force is a deity. We came to one conclusion that if there is an activity, there is somebody in charge of the activity. Activity cannot take place unless there is somebody guiding it. If I see an effect, there has to be a cause.

If I see a wind moving, there is A cause somebody is in charge. Somebody making sure that in this condition only this thing can occur. So marutas were in charge of winds. And each type of wind has a different maruta. The Marichi is among the best because it is the in charge of the pleasant breeze which we can enjoy. We are afraid of tornado, we are afraid of hurricane.

But we are very happy when this pleasant breeze is flowing. Among all the Marutas, Nakshatranam, Ahamshashi, Nakshatrana, the asterisms or constellations among them all the arrangement of stars in the sky. In Nakshatra, the moon appears to be traveling through these star clusters. So when I see the night sky, the asterisms are dimly lit, but the moon is brightly lit. He seems like the king of all these asterisms, traveling through all these Nakshatras as if he were the king of all the Nakshatras.

So therefore he says, among the Nakshatras, I am Shashi. He say, consider me as the sun. Night time I see moon. He says, consider me as moon. If it is windy, consider that my Maruta are working. But when you feel at ease, most at comfort, I am Marichi.

And among all the celestial beings, I am Vishnu. Without Vishnu, nothing can exist. So therefore, when you see anything, something which catches your imagination, something that can invoke these divine feelings in you, consider that my presence you are experiencing. The next verse says Vedanam Sama Vedo Asmi. Obviously, Arjuna was a product of a Vedic culture. We consider Vedas the basis of our culture.

If things cannot have a proof in Vedas, it is not true. Truth has to have basis in Vedas. And obviously we know there are four Vedas. Rug Veda, Sam Veda, Yajurveda and Tharva Veda. Sam Veda is most pleasant. Saam Veda is basically as we have heard all in poetry.

Rug Veda is in prose, Sama Veda in poetry. So listening to Sama Veda is most pleasant. Even today if you listen to our Panditji, he is Samavedi. When he chant, it really catches your attention. Chanting normally going on in temple, everybody is talking. You know, when he starts in a Sam Vedi chanting, everybody is quiet.

Something really unique, something which catches your attention, something which catches your mind is Sama Veda. Among all the Vedas, I am Sama Veda. Knowledge is in all Vedas. But something that can invoke the sense of divinity in your heart is when you have this beautiful Poetry sung in a proper raga. So if a Vedas discussion is going on and it is not interesting to me, Swamiji says it's like the Ghata Pata. You know, there's two pandits talking about this Vedic discussion.

They give examples: Ghata and Pata, Ghata and Pata. One who cannot get anything out of it says, "All this is Garbhat" — they are doing Garbhat. That's where the word Garbhat comes from. Because we cannot understand what they are talking about.

So it's Garbhat to us, even though they may be talking at the highest level. But even one who has no knowledge of Veda — if he listens to the Sama Veda, he will have that divinity experience in his heart. Bharu Bhagavan said, among Vedas, I am Sama Veda Devanam Asmi, Vasavah, Vasava Indra. Among the Devas, I am Indra.

We know Indra is the king of all the Devas. He is the mightiest, he is the wealthiest. He is the greatest kingdom Splendor. Deva Loka is supposed to be a place for enjoyment. Even the Devas have all these politics among themselves. Who is higher, who is lower.

They have as much jealousy as us. This is serial Kantosima. Indra's wife Paulami is the bad one and Santosima is the good one. One harasses people and one tries to save people. So among Devas, in other words, even if you reach to a level of goodness, your shortcomings will still be there. If I want to be happy and say, if I become a millionaire or a billionaire, I'll be happy.

All your shortcomings will be with you when you become billionaire. What is making me unhappy will make me unhappy. Then also just having wealth, just having accomplishment is not a remedy for any happiness or experiencing any divinity. But even when you consider that as the basis of divinity, I am among all Devasam Indra, most accomplished, the king of all. From a material wealth perspective, Indriyana Manasthyasmi. Even in the previous line, he also said among the Devasam Indra Deva means to Dev is to illuminate.

That which illuminates is the Deva.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna begins His enumeration with a crucial clarification: "Aham Atma Gudakesha sarva-bhutashaya-sthitah" - "I am the Self dwelling in the hearts of all beings." Before listing specific glories, He establishes the universal foundation: divinity is not only in the excellent but in all. He is the beginning, middle, and end of all beings - their source, sustenance, and dissolution. This prevents a common misunderstanding: that only special, excellent things are divine while ordinary things are not.

Then come the celestial manifestations: among the Adityas (sun-deities), He is Vishnu the all-pervading; among luminaries, the radiant Sun; among the Maruts (wind-gods), He is Marichi the gentle breeze; among the Nakshatras (stars), He is the Moon. Notice the principle: in each category, Krishna identifies with what is most prominent, most beneficial, most capable of evoking awe. When you look up at the sun, you are seeing divine glory. When a pleasant breeze refreshes you, that is Marichi - divine comfort made tangible.

Today, practice this cosmic vision. When you see sunlight streaming through a window, recognize it as Krishna's glory. When wind touches your face, feel the divine presence. The examples may seem archaic - we no longer worship the Adityas - but the principle is timeless. In whatever catches your attention and evokes wonder, the divine is more visibly present. What are the "Suns" and "Moons" in your life - those things that illuminate, that you cannot help but notice? Can you begin to see them as pointers to their source rather than ends in themselves?

रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम् |

पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम् |

vedānāṃ sāmavedo.asmi devānāmasmi vāsavaḥ .

rudrāṇāṃ śaṅkaraścāsmi vitteśo yakṣarakṣasām .

purodhasāṃ ca mukhyaṃ māṃ viddhi pārtha bṛhaspatim .
verseTranslations: Of the Vedas I am the Hymns, I am the Electric Force in the Powers of Nature; of the senses I am the Mind; and I am the Intelligence in all that lives.
