Among the priests, know, O Arjuna, that I am the Apostle Brihaspati; of generals I am Skanda, the Commander-in-Chief, and of waters I am the Ocean.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. So far, up to chapters one through nine, we came to one conclusion: that everything comes out of one single entity and everything is pervaded by him. Over and over Bhagavan said that you should focus on that entity which is permanent, that which never changes. Along with all the changes happening in this Sansar, everything is constantly changing — including my body, my mind, my intellect. But they're part of the Prakriti.

But as long as you identify with this unchanging reality which is all pervading and the source of all the beings, then thou shall be liberated from all your sorrows and limitations. So Arjuna, like all of us, says that I intellectually appreciate this. Many, many Rishis have said this, and now you are also telling me the same thing. But how do I contemplate upon that single entity is still not clear to me. Intellectually appreciating that he is everywhere is one thing, and when encounter a situation which is unconducive, to keep that thought steady in your mind is another thing. And that's why Arjuna said I am having difficulty.

I cannot conceptualize in my mind what is that all pervading entity is all about. You need to give me some pointers. Something which I can tangibly can relate to, which I can conceptualize in my mind, in my meditation, in my contemplation, where I can hang on to that entity as the divine entity, as the one all pervading entity. And then I may make some progress. So tell me all your glories without leaving anything behind, because I never get tired of listening to it. You tell me all these times.

So tell me what is it that I should be looking for in this universe which I can identify as your manifestation? Everything I see right now, even though I have understood, come very short of being divine. So what should I focus on? So in response to that, we have this next 22 verses which Bhagavan gives Various pointers to meditate upon. It is not very clear to us how to identify divinity. So Bhagavan said, you find divinity in everything that is best among their own spheres.

So Bhagavan starts his response by clarifying that we are not coming to any new conclusion now — that only the best is where I am, but not the rest. Verse 20 clearly makes a summary statement: let's not get deviated from what we already talked about, that I am the source of all the beings, Asheshena, without leaving anything out. But in some, this divinity may be more prominent to identify. So he says: Aham Atma Gudakesha Sarva Bhuta Ashayasthitah. Let's make it clear that I reside as the core of all the beings. There is no exception.

Just because we say the one is more manifesting divinity and other is not, that does not mean the other is devoid of my presence. So very first clarification is I reside in all the beings as the core of their beings. Aham adhisha madhyacha bhutanam anta evacha. I am the origin, Adi middle and the end of all the beings. All the beings are part of the Prakriti. They have beginning and end.

They come from somewhere. They exist in time and space for a while and then they end. But all the time the source of that being is me. I am the one who sustained them during their existence. And I am the one they dissolve into. That you should never forget, Bhagavanji, even in your contemplation, that there is no exception.

There is nothing which can exist without my presence. But your question was: what to contemplate upon? How can I conceptualize the divinity, the self, which is all pervading and immortal? So I'll give you the pointers. As Swamiji says, in the next 21 verses Bhagawan gave 75 pointers. It is like something obvious we can identify with.

When the lights are on in this room, we know the electricity is there. When lights were off, electricity was still here. It just was not available for my perception. The electricity always pervades in this room in all this electrical wiring. I can only prove when I show you the presence of it in some manifest form. So the manifest forms rest of the chapter talks about.

And because it is given to Arjuna in his time, we obviously walk through several of these Vedic and Puranic references. If Krishna were talking today, he would say, "I am the iPhone among all smartphones. I'm Google among all technology companies." We relate to things which are familiar to us, and therefore the analogies given are more in line with the culture at the time.

And what Arjuna can identify with — he starts out from the higher, then comes down to the level which in day-to-day life Arjuna can identify with. Adityanam Aham Vishnuh — among the Adityas, I am Vishnu. Aditi's sons are the Adityas. As Swamiji points out, Aditi is mentioned in the Rig Veda. Aditi means limitless. Aditi is the mother of all celestial beings.

And then in Puranic time, Aditi was also shown as wife of Kashyap Rushi. But from the Vedic point of view, Aditi was the perennial mother, the primordial mother which gives birth to this universe. According to our scriptures and puranas, somewhere four Adityas are mentioned, somewhere six. But eventually they settled on 12 Adityas. If the word is used in the singular, it means Sun.

When mentioned in the plural, it means 12. The Adityas somewhat identify with the 12 months of the year; each one is in charge of one segment of the year. So among the Adityas, Bhagavan says I am Vishnu. Vishnu is all pervading. Vishnu means one who has long reach.

You can probably say that the one in charge of the longest day in the year is Vishnu. But basically, among all the celestial beings, what becomes very apparent to me is Vishnu because he is all pervading. Consider me as Vishnu among all Adityas. Jyotisham Ravihi Anshuman — among the luminaries in the sky, those objects or entities that are self-effulgent, I am the radiant Sun.

Sun is something obvious to us. But we can only relate to Sun. Among the luminaries in the sky, I am Sun. Marichihi Marutam Asmi among the winds, wind is air in different forms. It can be hurricane, it can be tornado, it can be storm or it can be a pleasant breeze. Marutas in plurality are in charge of all these different types of winds.

Now obviously in Vedic time, we were reliant on the natural forces. Natural forces are something we are trying to understand. So each natural force is a deity. We came to one conclusion that if there is an activity, there is somebody in charge of the activity. Activity cannot take place unless there is somebody guiding it. If I see an effect, there has to be a cause.

If I see a wind moving, there is A cause somebody is in charge. Somebody making sure that in this condition only this thing can occur. So marutas were in charge of winds. And each type of wind has a different maruta. The Marichi is among the best because it is the in charge of the pleasant breeze which we can enjoy. We are afraid of tornado, we are afraid of hurricane.

But we are very happy when this pleasant breeze is flowing. Among all the Marutas, Nakshatranam, Ahamshashi, Nakshatrana, the asterisms or constellations among them all the arrangement of stars in the sky. In Nakshatra, moon appears to be travelling through this star clusters. So when I see at night the sky, the asterisms are dimly lit, but the moon is brightly lit. He seems like the king of all these asterisms. He is traveling through all these Nakshatras, you know, as if the king of all the Nakshatras.

So therefore he says, among the Nakshatras, I am Shashi. He say, consider me as the sun. Night time I see moon. He says, consider me as moon. If it is windy, consider that my Maruta are working. But when you feel at ease, most at comfort, I am Marichi.

And among all the celestial beings, I am Vishnu. Without Vishnu, nothing can exist. So therefore, when you see anything, something which catches your imagination, something that can invoke these divine feelings in you, consider that my presence you are experiencing. The next verse says Vedanam Sama Vedo Asmi. Obviously, Arjuna was a product of a Vedic culture. We consider Vedas the basis of our culture.

If things cannot have a proof in Vedas, it is not true. Truth has to have basis in Vedas. And obviously we know there are four Vedas. Rug Veda, Sam Veda, Yajurveda and Tharva Veda. Sam Veda is most pleasant. Saam Veda is basically as we have heard all in poetry.

Rug Veda is in prose, Sama Veda in poetry. So listening to Sama Veda is most pleasant. Even today if you listen to our Panditji, he is Samavedi. When he chant, it really catches your attention. Chanting normally going on in temple, everybody is talking. You know, when he starts in a Sam Vedi chanting, everybody is quiet.

But something that can invoke the sense of divinity in your heart is when you have this beautiful Poetry sung in a proper raga. So if the Vedas discussion is going on, if it is not interesting to me, Swami says the Ghata pata Gadabada. You know there's two pandas talking about this Vedic discussion.

They give example a Ghata and a pata, Ghata and a pata. One who cannot get anything out of it say all this. They spell Gaddapada garbhat. They are doing garbat. That's where the garbhat words come from. Because we can understand what they are talking about.

So it's a garbhat to us. Even though they may be talking at the highest level. But even the one who has no knowledge of Veda, he listens to the Sama Veda. He will have that divinity experience in his heart. Bharu Bhagavan said, among Vedas, I am Sama Veda Devanam Asmi, Vasavah, Vasava Indra. Among the Devas, I am Indra.

We know Indra is the king of all the Devas. He is the mightiest, he is the wealthiest. He is the greatest kingdom Splendor. Deva Loka is supposed to be a place for enjoyment. Even the Devas have all these politics among themselves. Who is higher, who is lower.

They have as much jealousy as us. This is serial Kantosima. Indra's wife Paulami is the bad one and Santosima is the good one. One harasses people and one tries to save people. So among Devas, in other words, even if you reach to a level of goodness, your shortcomings will still be there. If I want to be happy and say, if I become a millionaire or a billionaire, I'll be happy.

All your shortcomings will be with you when you become billionaire. What is making me unhappy will make me unhappy. Then also just having wealth, just having accomplishment is not a remedy for any happiness or experiencing any divinity. But even when you consider that as the basis of divinity, I am among all Devasam Indra, most accomplished, the king of all. From a material wealth perspective, Indriyana Manasthyasmi. Even in the previous line, he also said among the Devasam Indra Deva means to Dev is to illuminate.

That which illuminates is the Deva.
snippets.reflection:
These verses bring divine manifestations closer to human experience. Among the Vedas, Krishna is the Sama Veda - scripture set to music, the most beautiful and captivating. Among the senses, He is the Mind (Manas) - that which coordinates all perception. Among living beings, He is Consciousness (Chetana) itself. The principle is clear: whatever has the capacity to move the heart, to coordinate, to bring awareness - that is where the divine is most evident.

The mention of Sama Veda is particularly instructive. While all Vedas contain truth, Sama Veda captures attention through melody. Even those who cannot understand Sanskrit feel something when they hear Sama Vedic chanting - the divine speaks through beauty. Similarly, among priests Krishna is Brihaspati (the most eloquent), among generals He is Skanda (the most skilled), among waters He is the Ocean (the most vast). Excellence in any field - eloquence, strategy, expansiveness - these are divine signatures.

Today, notice what captures your attention. When you hear music that moves you, recognize: this is Sama Veda, divine beauty speaking. When you witness someone coordinating complex activities skillfully, see Skanda - divine intelligence in action. When you encounter vastness - the ocean, the sky, a great idea - feel the presence of something beyond ordinary limits. Ask yourself: "What has naturally captured my devotion, even before I called it spiritual? Can I now recognize that spontaneous attraction as the divine calling me home?"

snippets.title: Day 136: Divine Glories
snippets.sanskrit:
महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम् |

अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः |

उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम् |
snippets.transliteration:
maharṣīṇāṃ bhṛgurahaṃ girāmasmyekamakṣaram .

aśvatthaḥ sarvavṛkṣāṇāṃ devarṣīṇāṃ ca nāradaḥ .

uccaiḥśravasamaśvānāṃ viddhi māmamṛtodbhavam .
verseTranslations: Of the great seers I am Bhrigu, of words I am Om, of offerings I am the silent prayer, among things immovable I am the Himalayas.
Of trees I am the sacred Fig-tree, of the Divine Seers Narada, of the heavenly singers I am Chitraratha, their Leader, and of sages I am Kapila.
Know that among horses I am Pegasus, the heaven-born; among the lordly elephants I am the White one, and I am the Ruler among men.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. Bhagavan, in the beginning of the chapter, made two basic points. First: all these divine qualities which you see in beings — such as Buddhi, Jnana, Asamoha, Samata, Ahimsa, Dana, Bhaya, Abhaya — all these qualities emanate from me. Because of my presence in them, they manifest these qualities. So whenever you see these qualities, know that I am present in that being. And then he said: Aham Sarvasya Prabhavah, Mattaha Sarva Pravartate.

There is nothing that is not based in me. I am the source of all things and beings, and everything proceeds from me. So Bhagawan has made it very clear that there is nothing which is devoid of him. But Arjuna obviously wanted examples in his world which he can relate to. So that's what he said: Keshu Keshu Bhaveshu Chintyo Asi Bhagavan Maya.

In what different forms that I see in this world can I worship as your presence? If I have to find examples of divinity which are worthy of worship, tell me — how do I find them, how do I recognize them, and how do I approach them? Therefore, Bhagavan said: when you see anything which is best among that category, consider that worthy of worshipping. Excellence is worthy of worshipping. Yogah Karmasu Kaushalam — proficiency is worshipable. Anything which is efficient and proficient.

Bhagawan said, consider that is my manifestation. It is worthy of worship. So therefore, Bhagavan has been giving various examples of best among those categories. And we have seen so far as Swamiji explains that Bhagawan started with Vedic examples based rooted in the culture of Vedic period. And then he has given some examples which are common between Vedic and Puranic period. And then he has been giving examples from Puranic period.

In other words, he's covering all that Arjuna has experienced, ancestral, past, folklore. And then Also the day to day world where I'm trying to find divinity. I try to find divinity in my great culture. Also try to find divinity in the folklore which I've heard from people. And I also try to find divinity in my world. Verses 27, 28, 29 continues in that tradition.

We are seeing more Puranic examples. Ucchaihshravasam Ashvanam Viddhi Mam Amritod Bhavam — among the horses, Ucchaihshravas, which came out of the endeavor of finding nectar. It is the story of churning the milky ocean to find the nectar of immortality. But byproducts of that effort we can call Riddhi and Siddhi. Swamiji explains here that this churning of the ocean is nothing but churning your own mind.

One side is bad and other side is good thoughts. Bad thoughts and good thoughts are churning your mind. What comes out of it are the byproducts I call Riddhi and Siddhi. When we try to achieve the final goal of liberation or immortality or ultimate happiness, whichever you want to call it, we are constantly churning our mind to find that ultimate happiness. In that process we achieve some accomplishments. Those are Siddhi and Riddhi.

We get these along our pursuit of happiness. We have not got the happiness yet, but we get some things which are byproducts of the pursuit. So me buying a BMW, or Albany and Maulik going to Hawaii — you people went to Hawaii and I bought a BMW X5 Hybrid over the weekend. So we covered two bases of my Vedantic journey. Now you have to go to Starbucks to complete the third leg of it. All that is in pursuit of happiness.

That's why I want to go to Hawaii. That's why I want to buy BMW. But that is not the end goal. Bhagavan says the end goal is to find the nectar. The nectar is endless happiness without any break in it. That is what we call immortality.

That is also what we call liberation. So this churning of the ocean — Viddhi Mam Amritod Bhavam. This flying horse came out of the pursuit of happiness as an excellent achievement from the pursuit of finding something else. They were not looking for a flying horse; they were looking for nectar. But what came out? A flying horse — the best among the horses.

We become excellent in our profession. But that actually was not the goal. I wanted to make more money. Then I became very proficient in my profession. We consider, unfortunately, that this is the goal. But that never was my real goal.

My goal was to be happy. But I sometimes become so enamored by my own achievement that I just stop right there, thinking "I'm the best." So Bhagavan said, among horses, Uche Shravaha, the flying horse which came out of the journey of ocean, Airavatam, Gajendrana both came out of the same pursuit. The white elephant with many tusks came out. Airavat and Cheshrava, the flying horse came. They both came in same pursuit of finding nectar.

The airavat was given to Indra, but horse was given to Daitya. But both came out as excellent examples of something you can accomplish by your pursuit of finding nectar. Bliss Naranamcha, Naradhipah among men. I am the king among man. When somebody becomes as powerful as one can be, he is called king. Airavat is an example among elephants, Uchesa among horses.

So in all living beings you find example of excellence. In our culture the king is considered divine representation. Not only in our culture, but all Western cultures also King was considered divine. He is the one who is supporting the whole kingdom by his own action. Therefore he is considered divine. Anything that is excellent among man, among animals, among beings of any kind considered to be my manifestation is worthy of worshipping.

Because the original question was Keshu, Keshu, Chabhesu. So Bhagavan is giving him various examples. Ayudhanam Aham Vajraha. Not only beings but things. Among the weapons and Vajra. Vajra was conceived by Indra as the weapon which can kill the demon Vritrasur.

He was the snake in a human form. The snake is generally considered poisonous. So something which is poisonous and in stopping my progress bad thoughts in my mind. So Vhtrasu is my negative tendencies. And to kill that I need a weapon which is powerful and effective. So here Indra to kill Vritrasur wanted Vajra, the ultimate weapon to kill this demon who was stopping the course of rivers.

So he was someone who was stopping the progress. So Vritrasur could only be killed by something which is very pious and self-sacrificing. So Indra found that Dadhichi is the right candidate. He had all the positive qualities, selfless in his endeavors. And when Dadhichi was approached, he agreed to give up his body. His bones were then used to make this Vajra.

The meaning of this metaphor is if you have to kill the negative tendencies of your mind, you have to sacrifice. Selfless sacrifice is the only sure weapon to kill the negativity in your mind. Of all the weapons to kill your negativity Bhagwan said, I am Vajra Denunam Asmi Kamaduk among cows. The milch cow was also described in chapter three in verse 10 where Bhagavan said Sahayagna prajasrustva Purvacha Prajapati Anena Prasi vistadvam ishacha asthu isht Kama dhak. In the beginning Prajapati said, I have created Praja in the same time Yajna. This Yajna will be your Kamadhenu.

This Yajna will be your cow which fulfills all your desires. So the Kamadenu is something which has the capacity to fulfill all your desires. According to the Puranas, Vasishtha had this Kamadhenu. This cow could give whatever you desire, like a genie in an Arabic tale. Whatever you desire, the genie can present.

Bhagavan said Kamadhenu is your cooperative endeavor — your Yajna spirit. When you work together, when you combine the resources of your community, of your family, of your country, then you can get whatever you want. In our culture, the cow is sacred because the cow supports life. In olden days, the cow provided everything. Cow provided milk for sustaining bodies.

Cow also provided bullocks to till the land. Cow also provided cow dung as a source of fuel. That cow dung was also used as building material to plaster the floors. The cow has the ultimate giving capacity — it can sustain life. And therefore the cow is considered sacred. But among all cows Bhagavan said, I am Kama Dhuk.

I am Kama Dhenu which has capacity to fulfill all desires. And as Bhagawan said in chapter three, Kama Dhenu is your Yajna spirit. When you work selflessly and work together, you can fulfill all your desires. Prajanascha Asmi Kandarpah — among the progenitors, I am that instinct to create progeny. This instinct, Bhagavan said, is divine.

Normally any sexual instinct we consider it to be negative, not good. Our culture clearly says that's divine. Anything which is natural has to be divine. So this instinct to further your progeny is a divine instinct. Attraction for the opposite sex is put in beings by Bhagavan for a reason and therefore it is divine. Swamiji used to say that if you don't get attracted by opposite sex, go and see a doctor.

There's something wrong with you. That is something natural and divine. It is how you use it, how you Manage it makes it either divine or devilish. Kandarpah is that innate attraction for the opposite sex in you. I am that. Sarpanam Asmi Vasukihi.

We have discussed two types of snakes: Sarpa and Naga. Sarpa is the unhooded snake. The hooded snake is Naga. Snakes like pythons and other garden snakes. And they are not many times poisonous. Python can kill you, but it's not poisonous.

There's a Naga Panchami day at least in Surat where I grew up. All these guys will bring cobra in in their little basket. And my mother will offer milk and give some donation. Naga cobra is poisonous. But Bhagavan said even that poisonous instinct in beings is also divine. Because there is no other source for this poisonous instinct than God alone.

Everything in this world, even though it seems negative from our perspective, when you change the perspective it becomes natural and necessary. I very recently read an article, I think in the New York Times, saying forest fires are necessary for the survival of the forest. Now that was a complete revelation to me. Because every time I see forest fire in California on the TV I say why can't they do something?

Can they not figure out how to stop this thing? Or what is the purpose of this? And it really opened my eyes. That article said without forest fire, forest cannot survive because the undergrowth will be so dense the trees won't survive. The forest fires clean up the forest every year now, obviously out of control. Anything creates disasters.

And most of the forest fires are man made or man created. They are not naturally created. So anything which I see negative may have been over manipulated by someone. But the actual phenomenon, whether it seems negative or positive from my perspective, is natural and divine. So therefore Bhagawan says Sarpanam Asmi Vasukihi. Among serpents, I am Vasuki. Vasuki is the smallest snake on Shiva's finger.

Vasuki was also used as the rope in churning the ocean. And Vasuki selflessly volunteered to become that rope for churning the ocean. Among snakes, Vasuki is the one who gives his services selflessly for the common good. Anantascha Asmi Naganam — and among Nagas, I am Ananta. Ananta means endless. Another name is Ananta Shesha Naga.

We have seen Vishnu lying on the Shesha Naga in slumber, Lakshmi Ji massaging his feet, a lotus coming out of his navel, and Brahma Ji sitting on it. So this thousand-hooded snake is nothing but my mind — a thousand different desires in a thousand different directions. With that capacity when it is associated with Tamas and Rajas, it has creative urge.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce the sacred syllable OM and silent prayer (Japa) as divine manifestations. Among words, Krishna is "Ekam Aksharam" - the one imperishable syllable, OM. Among offerings, He is Japa-yajna - the sacrifice of repetition, the silent turning of the mind toward the divine. Among immovable things, He is the Himalayas - stable, majestic, pointing upward. Each pointer reveals something about recognizing the divine: the simplest sound, the quietest practice, the most enduring presence.

The examples also include the Ashvattha (sacred fig tree) whose roots grow downward and branches upward - a symbol of the world rooted in the divine; Narada among divine seers - the eternal wanderer spreading divine names; Chitraratha among Gandharvas - celestial musicians; Kapila among Siddhas - the philosopher who founded Sankhya. Excellence takes many forms: wisdom, devotion, artistry, philosophical depth. In whatever domain someone achieves mastery, there the divine presence shines more brightly.

Today, practice the simplest of these manifestations: OM and Japa. Take a few moments to chant OM - not as technique but as recognition that this primordial sound contains all sounds. Or practice silent repetition of a divine name, noticing how Japa naturally calms and focuses the mind. When you see mountains or large trees, let them remind you of stability and aspiration. Ask yourself: "What is my 'Himalaya' - the stable, immovable foundation in my life? What is my 'Japa' - the quiet, persistent practice that keeps turning my mind toward truth?"

snippets.title: Day 137: The Source of All
snippets.sanskrit:
आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक् |

अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम् |

प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम् |
snippets.transliteration:
āyudhānāmahaṃ vajraṃ dhenūnāmasmi kāmadhuk .

anantaścāsmi nāgānāṃ varuṇo yādasāmaham .

prahlādaścāsmi daityānāṃ kālaḥ kalayatāmaham .
verseTranslations: I am the Thunderbolt among weapons; of cows I am the Cow of Plenty, I am Passion in those who procreate, and I am the Cobra among serpents.
I am the King-python among snakes, I am the Aqueous Principle among those that live in water, I am the Father of fathers, and among rulers I am Death.
And I am the devotee Prahlad among the heathen; of Time I am the Eternal Present; I am the Lion among beasts and the Eagle among birds.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. Bhagavan, in the beginning of the chapter, made two basic points. First: all these divine qualities which you see in beings — such as Buddhi, Jnana, Asamoha, Samata, Ahimsa, Dana, Bhaya, Abhaya — all these qualities emanate from me. Because of my presence in them, they manifest these qualities. So whenever you see these qualities, know that I am present in that being. And then he said: Aham Sarvasya Prabhavah, Mattaha Sarva Pravartate.

There is nothing that is not based in me. I am the source of all things and beings, and everything proceeds from me. So Bhagawan has made it very clear that there is nothing which is devoid of him. But Arjuna obviously wanted examples in his world which he can relate to. So that's what he said: Keshu Keshu Bhaveshu Chintyo Asi Bhagavan Maya.

In what different forms that I see in this world can I worship as your presence? If I have to find examples of divinity which are worthy of worship, tell me — how do I find them, how do I recognize them, and how do I approach them? Therefore, Bhagavan said: when you see anything which is best among that category, consider that worthy of worshipping. Excellence is worthy of worshipping. Yogah Karmasu Kaushalam — proficiency is worshipable. Anything which is efficient and proficient.

Bhagawan said, consider that is my manifestation. It is worthy of worship. So therefore, Bhagavan has been giving various examples of best among those categories. And we have seen so far as Swamiji explains that Bhagawan started with Vedic examples based rooted in the culture of Vedic period. And then he has given some examples which are common between Vedic and Puranic period. And then he has been giving examples from Puranic period.

In other words, he's covering all that Arjuna has experienced, ancestral, past, folklore. And then Also the day to day world where I'm trying to find divinity. I try to find divinity in my great culture. Also try to find divinity in the folklore which I've heard from people. And I also try to find divinity in my world. Verses 27, 28, 29 continues in that tradition.

We are seeing more Puranic examples. Ucchaihshravasam Ashvanam Viddhi Mam Amritod Bhavam — among the horses, Ucchaihshravas, which came out of the endeavor of finding nectar. It is the story of churning the milky ocean to find the nectar of immortality. But byproducts of that effort we can call Riddhi and Siddhi. Swamiji explains here that this churning of the ocean is nothing but churning your own mind.

One side is bad and other side is good thoughts. Bad thoughts and good thoughts are churning your mind. What comes out of it are the byproducts I call Riddhi and Siddhi. When we try to achieve the final goal of liberation or immortality or ultimate happiness, whichever you want to call it, we are constantly churning our mind to find that ultimate happiness. In that process we achieve some accomplishments. Those are Siddhi and Riddhi.

We get these along our pursuit of happiness. We have not got the happiness yet, but we get some things which are byproducts of the pursuit. So me buying a BMW, or Albany and Maulik going to Hawaii — you people went to Hawaii and I bought a BMW X5 Hybrid over the weekend. So we covered two bases of my Vedantic journey. Now you have to go to Starbucks to complete the third leg of it. All that is in pursuit of happiness.

That's why I want to go to Hawaii. That's why I want to buy BMW. But that is not the end goal. Bhagavan says the end goal is to find the nectar. The nectar is endless happiness without any break in it. That is what we call immortality.

That is also what we call liberation. So this churning of the ocean — Viddhi Mam Amritod Bhavam. This flying horse came out of the pursuit of happiness as an excellent achievement from the pursuit of finding something else. They were not looking for a flying horse; they were looking for nectar. But what came out? A flying horse — the best among the horses.

We become excellent in our profession. That actually was the goal. I want to make more money. Then I became very proficient in my profession. We consider unfortunately that is the goal. That never was my goal.

My goal was to be happy. But I sometimes become so Enamored by my own achievement that I just stop right there, that I'm the best. So Bhagavan said, among horses, Uche Shravaha, the flying horse which came out of the journey of ocean, Airavatam, Gajendrana both came out of the same pursuit. The white elephant with many tusks came out. Airavat and Cheshrava, the flying horse came. They both came in same pursuit of finding nectar.

The airavat was given to Indra, but horse was given to Daitya. But both came out as excellent examples of something you can accomplish by your pursuit of finding nectar. Bliss Naranamcha, Naradhipah among men. I am the king among man. When somebody becomes as powerful as one can be, he is called king. Airavat is an example among elephants, Uchesa among horses.

So in all living beings you find example of excellence. In our culture the king is considered divine representation. Not only in our culture, but all Western cultures also King was considered divine. He is the one who is supporting the whole kingdom by his own action. Therefore he is considered divine. Anything that is excellent among man, among animals, among beings of any kind considered to be my manifestation is worthy of worshipping.

Because the original question was Keshu, Keshu, Chabhesu. So Bhagavan is giving him various examples. Ayudhanam Aham Vajraha. Not only beings but things. Among the weapons and Vajra. Vajra was conceived by Indra as the weapon which can kill the demon Vritrasur.

He was the snake in a human form. The snake is generally considered poisonous. So something which is poisonous and in stopping my progress bad thoughts in my mind. So Vhtrasu is my negative tendencies. And to kill that I need a weapon which is powerful and effective. So here Indra to kill Vritrasur wanted Vajra, the ultimate weapon to kill this demon who was stopping the course of rivers.

So he was someone who was stopping the progress. So Vritrasur can be only be killed by something which is very pious and self sacrificing. So Indra found the Dhiji is the right candidate. He has all the positive qualities selfless in his endeavors. And when the Dichi approached, he agreed to give up his body. And then his bones were used to make this Vajra.

The meaning of this metaphor is if you have to kill the negative tendencies of your mind, you have to sacrifice. Selfless sacrifice is the only sure weapon to kill the negativity in your mind. Of all the weapons to kill your negativity Bhagwan said, I am Vajra Denunam Asmi Kamaduk among cows. The milch cow was also described in chapter three in verse 10 where Bhagavan said Sahayagna prajasrustva Purvacha Prajapati Anena Prasi vistadvam ishacha asthu isht Kama dhak. In the beginning Prajapati said, I have created Praja in the same time Yajna. This Yajna will be your Kamadhenu.

This Yajna will be your cow which fulfills all your desires. So the Kamadenu is something which has capacity to fulfill all your desires. And as for Purana, Vasisthta had this Kamadhina. Vasistha had this cow. This cow which can give whatever you desire like a genie in other Arabic tale. Whatever you desire, genie can present.

Bhagavan said, kamadhanu is your cooperative endeavors Yajna spirit. When you work together, when you combine your resources of your community, of your family, of your country then you can get whatever you want. Dhienuna masmikamadu. In our culture cow is sacred because cow supports life. In olden days cow provided everything. Cow provided milk for sustaining bodies.

Cow also provided bullocks to till the land. Cow also provided cow dung for source of fuel. That cow dung was also his building material to plaster the floors. The cow has ultimate giving capacity that it can sustain life. And and therefore cow is considered sacred. But among all cows Bhagavan said, I am Kama Dhuk.

I am Kama Dhenu which has capacity to fulfill all desires. And as Bhagawana said in chapter three, Kama Denu is your Yajna spirit. When you work selflessly and work together you can fulfill all your desires. Prajanastya Asmi Kandarpah among the progenitor. I am that instinct to create progeny. This instinct, Bhagavan said, is divine.

Normally any sexual instinct we consider it to be negative, not good. Our culture clearly says that's divine. Anything which is natural has to be divine. So this instinct to further your progeny is a divine instinct. Attraction for the opposite sex is put in beings by Bhagavan for a reason and therefore it is divine. Swamiji used to say that if you don't get attracted by opposite sex, go and see a doctor.

There's something wrong with you. That is something natural and divine. It is how you use it, how you Manage it makes it either divine or devilish. Prajanas chasmi Kandarpaha. Kandarpah is that innate attraction for the opposite sex in you. I am that Sarpanam Asmi Vasukihi.

We have discussed two types of snakes, Sarpa and naga. Sarpa is the unhooded snake. Hooded snake is Naga. Snakes like pythons and other garden snakes. And they are not many times poisonous. Python can kill you, but it's not poisonous.

There's a Naga Panchami day at least in Surat where I grew up. All these guys will bring cobra in in their little basket. And my mother will offer milk and give some donation. Naga cobra is poisonous. But Bhagavan said even that poisonous instinct in beings is also divine. Because there is no other source for this poisonous instinct than God alone.

Everything in this world, even though it seems negative from our perspective. When you change the perspective it becomes natural and necessary. I very recently read an article I think in New York Times. Forest fires are necessary for the survival of the forest. Now that was complete revelation to me. Because every time I see forest fire in California on the TV I say why can't they do something?

Can they not figure out how to stop this thing? Or what is the purpose of this? And it really opened my eyes. That article said without forest fire, forest cannot survive because the undergrowth will be so dense the trees won't survive. The forest fires clean up the forest every year now, obviously out of control. Anything creates disasters.

And most of the forest fires are man made or man created. They are not naturally created. So anything which I see negative may have been over manipulated by someone. But the actual phenomenon, whether it seems negative or positive, my perspective is natural and divine. So therefore you say Sarpanam Asmi Vasukihi. Among serpents and Vasuki Vasukhi is the smallest snake on Shiva's finger.

Also used as the rope in churning the ocean. And Vasuki also selflessly volunteered to become that rope which are on the ocean among snakes. And Vasuki who gives his services selflessly for the common good. Anantahacha Asminagana. And among Nagam Ananta Ananta endless. Another name of Ananta Nageshanahaya.

We have seen Vishnu lying on the sheshanag in a slumber. Lakshmi Ji massaging his feet and Lotus coming out of his navel and Brahmaji sitting on it. So this thousand hooded snake is nothing but my mind. It is thousand different desires in thousand different directions. With that capacity when it is associated with Tamas and Rajas, it has creative urge.
snippets.reflection:
These verses present perhaps the most challenging of Krishna's identifications: "Prajanah cha asmi Kandarpah" - I am the creative desire in beings (Kandarpa/Kama). The procreative instinct, often seen as unspiritual or base, is here declared divine. Anything natural, placed in beings for a purpose, partakes of divinity. The issue is never the instinct itself but how it is expressed - controlled or compulsive, sacred or profane. Similarly, Krishna is Vajra among weapons - the thunderbolt that destroys negativity - and Kamadhenu among cows - the wish-fulfilling power of cooperative endeavor (Yajna).

Even more striking: "Sarpanam asmi Vasuki" - among serpents, I am Vasuki, who selflessly served as the churning rope when gods and demons sought nectar. And among the hooded serpents (Nagas), I am Ananta (the endless one) upon whom Vishnu rests. The serpent represents the mind with its thousand desires moving in every direction; when this same energy supports the divine (as Ananta supports Vishnu), it becomes sacred. What seems dangerous becomes the very vehicle of the divine.

Today, contemplate the divinization of natural instincts. That drive you feel - for creation, for union, for achievement - is not inherently unspiritual. The question is: does it serve the whole or only the ego? Vasuki volunteered for service and was honored; Ananta supports the divine in rest. Can your desires become like Vasuki - offered in service? Like Ananta - supporting divine presence rather than chasing endless wants? Ask: "What instincts do I judge as 'unspiritual'? Can I see them instead as divine energy awaiting proper direction?"

snippets.title: Day 138: Divine Manifestations
snippets.sanskrit:
पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम् |

सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन |

अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
pavanaḥ pavatāmasmi rāmaḥ śastrabhṛtāmaham .

sargāṇāmādirantaśca madhyaṃ caivāhamarjuna .

akṣarāṇāmakāro.asmi dvandvaḥ sāmāsikasya ca .
verseTranslations: I am the Wind among purifiers, the King Rama among warriors; I am the Crocodile among the fishes, and I am the Ganges among rivers.
I am the Beginning, the Middle and the End in creation; among sciences, I am the science of Spirituality; I am the Discussion among disputants.
Of letters I am A; I am the copulative in compound words; I am Time inexhaustible; and I am the all-pervading Preserver.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. As we have seen, Arjuna, after listening to the whole discourse from Bhagavan on the nature of the Supreme Self, said, "But I need to know more." So in verse 18 he says: Vistarena Atmano Yogam Vibhutim cha Janardana, Bhuyah Kathaya Triptir hi Shrinvato Nasti Me Amritam. "Tell me again in detail, O Janardana, your Yoga power and your immanent glory, because I do not feel satisfied hearing your life-giving, nectar-like speech." In other words, he said, give me some examples. So Bhagavan said: Divya hi Atma Vibhutayah — my glories are divine.

Pradhanyataha Kuru Shreshtha Na Astyantah Vistarasya Me. There is no end to this glory, but I can give you some prominent examples. So Bhagavan clearly clarified to Arjuna: I'm going to give you some prominent examples. They do not constitute my entire glory, but they will give you some idea of where to see my presence. So we have been seeing many examples, right from the Vedic period to the Puranic period. And Bhagavan is now even coming down to our day-to-day experiences.

Pavanaha Pavatamasmi — something which we experience in phenomenal nature. Everything and every being is nothing but my own self, because he said everything proceeds from me and I am the source of all things and beings. There is no other thing which has created this universe. When we see an effect, there have to be two causes.

One is the efficient cause — somebody who knows how to make that thing come into existence. And one is the material to create that thing. Take pizza: we need a pizza maker and pizza ingredients. So if you see pizza here, you can't simply say, "Well, the pizza just appeared here. We are Chinmaya Mission, we are divine people. We don't need to order pizza."

Pizza just appears here. We know that an intelligent person will not believe that. He knows that if there is pizza there, there is a pizza maker and he had the ingredients for the pizza. So the same way, if this world exists, there is the material cause and efficient cause. Material cause is something which we have difficulty understanding. We think if Bhagavan knows everything, obviously he knows how to create this world.

The problem is where did he find the material? How do we create something? I'm an architect, so I can create buildings. Because I know how to design building. Just knowing how to create building doesn't create building. I need to have materials.

Go to Home Depot or Lowe's to buy that material. Ask Home Depot, "Where do you get materials?" "We get them from our suppliers." So you can go up to the source of the material, where it came from. In this case, if we find the source of the material which Bhagavan used to create this Jagat, you can always say that Bhagavan found the material from X. Then X becomes greater than the Bhagawan who created it.

Go to X and say, "Where did you get the material?" "From Y." Then Y becomes greater than X because he had the original material. Ask Y, "Where did you get the material?" "Z had the material," and then Z becomes greater than Y. So this exercise is futile because we cannot get to the ultimate source of the material. You have to come to the conclusion that Bhagavan himself was the source of the material.

In Bhagawan, there's only one thing which he did not have to buy, borrow, or steal — that is his own self. Everything we acquire in this world, we bought from somebody, borrowed from somebody, or took from somebody. But one thing I never had to acquire is my own self.

That which I call "I." I did not acquire it from anywhere. I didn't buy from anywhere. So that's the only material available to Bhagavan. So he created this Jagat using his knowledge of creating this universe as an efficient cause. And he also used the material available to him with his own self. So he became the material cause and the efficient cause for this universe.

Therefore he said, everything proceeds from me and I am the source of all things. However, that is not something for us to easily understand. So give me some examples of glories. It may be difficult to find glory in something which is average. But we can find it in something which is really excellent. If you have a water jug and you put just a little salt in it, and you taste it, you won't know that there is salt in it.

But if there's a lot of salt in it and you taste it, you know there's salt in it. The Bhagawan has been giving several prominent examples. Sarjanam, Adihicha, Antacha, Madhyamcha Evam, Aham, Arjunah. In the creation for anything which is created and the beginning, the middle and the end, there is no other material to create anything, to sustain anything or destroy anything. The same material which was used to create this Jagat, everything in Jagat in this universe is also created by the same original material.

So Bhagawan said, any creation you see in this world, I am the beginning, the middle and the end. In verse 33 he says, Aksaranam Akaro Asmi. In the previous verse he said, among all the sounds, I am the one syllable, Om. Because Om is the primordial sound. That is the sound which is the most basic sound out of which all the other variation of sounds come into existence. As I said, it's like three color printing.

There are only three cartridges in your printer. But when you print a picture, permutation combination of those three colors created this wonderful picture which is a variety of colors. So A-U-M is like the source of all the sounds. Om is the sum total of all the sounds that we hear in this world. Out of Om, the first sound is A. A signifies creation, U signifies sustenance, and M signifies dissolution. So when you close your mouth, it's Ma. I heard Anup Jilotra telling a joke.

He was teaching a female student. He said she would do Sa-Re-Ga-Ma, but when it comes to Ma, she would skip it. He said, "Why are you skipping Ma?" She said, "Ma, I have to close my mouth so my lipstick gets spoiled." So Ma — you are closing your lips, signifying the dissolution. A comes from your belly, signifying creation. Aksaranam Akaro Asmi. Among the letters, I am A. Swamiji also explains that in every language, the alphabet starts with A, and without a vowel you cannot make any word. And Swamiji explains that in Sanskrit there is a preponderance of the A sound. Therefore it is such a sweet-sounding language. Among the compound words in Sanskrit, I am Dvandva.

Those of us who have learned a little bit of Sanskrit know there are several types of compound words. I know only one very well: Bahuvrihi Samasa. Yasya Kantah Nilah — whose neck is blue? Neela Kantha. That's a Bahuvrihi Samasa. So two words, Neela and Kantha, when you combine them become Neelakantha. That's what I remember from my 8th standard Sanskrit. In this, Neela is actually almost like an adjective.

It does not have the same value as Kantha. Neela is just the attribute of that Kantha. But in Dvandva Samasa, when two words are used, they both retain their own identity. Sita-Ram — Sita and Ram both maintain their own identity, their own importance. Therefore Dvandva is considered the most prominent Samasa. Bhagavan says among the compound words, I am Dvandva — that which retains the value of both.

Swamiji explains here that some commentators have commented that it also may be indicating the Self and non-Self. So this entire world of ours is made up of something which we call the Self — that is me — and something which is not me, which is the non-Self. In Vedanta, this body, mind, and intellect are non-Self. They are not really permanent. "I" am permanent — the "I" feeling is permanent. This beautiful combination of Self and non-Self which we see in our Jagat — the Self remains the Self, and still the non-Self retains its own identity as a plurality in this world.

So therefore Bhagawan says: among compound words, I am Dvandva. Aham Eva Akshayaha Kalaha. I am that ever-existing time. He said among the reckoners, among the measures, I am time. Everything we know is defined in space and time. Indian philosophers have given more importance to time.

They say time is fundamental, and space is an emergent quality of time. So Bhagawan said, I am time. Among all the ways we measure things, I am time. In all measurement, time is the most important one. He said I am that infinite time.

It seems like to us that it is flowing and going. But time remains constant. It's our experiences that change. Our experience of time starts with one event followed by a second event. If there's only one event, there is no time. When only the first event occurs, there is no time.

We measure time between two events. Therefore, Swamiji says the measure of time in English is called "second," not "first." There is no "first" in time — only seconds. So here he says I am that infinite time, not the finite time perceived through your senses. Dhata Aham Vishwato Mukaha — and I am also the Karma Phaladata. I am also the supporter, the dispenser of all your experiences.

I experience as long as I'm alive, as long as I'm conscious. So my consciousness is the dispenser of all my thoughts and experiences. Dhata Vishwato Mukaha — facing everywhere, that Self which is in me. Facing everywhere and getting experience of everything is the same self in you. That Self is facing everywhere, gaining all the experience outside. So when you put it together, Bhagavan is everywhere.

No matter where you see, he is there. The next verse says Mrityuh Sarva Harascha — I am death among all that takes things away from you. You can lose things in an accident. You can lose things in various ways in life.

We lose money in the stock market. But you see, you're still left with something. I may lose money, but I'll have my health. I may be out of health, but I'm still alive. So there's something left. I lost something, but when I die, I lose everything.

There's nothing left for me. Therefore, I am death — it takes away everything from you. You cannot take anything with you. Therefore it's Mrityu Sarva Haraschaham — the greatest taker, who takes everything that you think is yours. Udbhavascha Bhavisyatam. The translation in the book is slightly confusing. It says, "I am the prosperity of those who are to be prosperous."

Swamiji clarifies that's not really the appropriate interpretation of Udbhava. Udbhava means to come into existence. "I am the source of all that is coming to be in the future." Not only am I the source of all things and beings in the present that you see, but I am also the source of everything that will come into existence in the future. In other words, past, present, and future are just concepts of my mind. There is only one existence, and it exists all the time.

And therefore anything which is created in that existence is nothing but the expression of the same supreme reality which is all-pervading, everlasting, omnipresent, omniscient. Kirtihi Shri Vakcha Narinam Smriti Medha Dhriti Kshamah. All women can take some pride here. All the good qualities listed are feminine. Bhagawan says I am these feminine qualities. Fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness and forgiveness. All these qualities are manifest in people because of my presence.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the divine in language, knowledge, and time itself. Among letters, Krishna is "A" (Akara) - the first sound, present in every vowel, essential for all speech. Among compound words, He is Dvandva - the type that preserves the equal identity of both components (like "Sita-Ram" where neither subsumes the other). This points to the coexistence of Self and non-self, spirit and matter, maintaining their distinct identities while unified. Among sciences, He is Adhyatma-vidya - the science of the Self, supreme among all knowledge because it reveals the knower behind all knowing.

Most profound is "Aham eva akshayah kalah" - "I am inexhaustible Time." Time seems to devour everything, yet Krishna identifies with that which makes all experience possible. Without time, there is no before and after, no change, no experience. The measure of time in English is "second" (not "first") because time only appears when there is a second event to mark against the first. This infinite, unchanging Time is not what we measure with clocks but the eternal present in which all moments arise.

Today, practice awareness of these subtle divine presences. When you speak or write, recognize that the vowel "A" underlies your words - language itself carries divine essence. When you learn anything, ask: does this knowledge reveal or obscure the knower? The science of Self (Adhyatma-vidya) is supreme because all other knowledge is useless if we do not know who is knowing. Most importantly, notice Time - not as minutes passing but as the unchanging awareness in which all events occur. Can you touch that "inexhaustible Time" behind your moment-to-moment experience?

snippets.title: Day 139: The Infinite One
snippets.sanskrit:
मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम् |

बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम् |

द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् |
snippets.transliteration:
mṛtyuḥ sarvaharaścāhamudbhavaśca bhaviṣyatām .

bṛhatsāma tathā sāmnāṃ gāyatrī chandasāmaham .

dyūtaṃ chalayatāmasmi tejastejasvināmaham .
verseTranslations: I am all-devouring Death; I am the Origin of all that shall happen; I am Fame, Fortune, Speech, Memory, Intellect, Constancy and Forgiveness.
Of hymns I am Brihatsama, of metres I am Gayatri, among the months I am Margasheersha (December), and I am the Spring among seasons.
I am the Gambling of the cheat and the Splendour of the splendid; I am Victory; I am Effort; and I am the Purity of the pure.
