So in verse 18 he says: Vistarena Atmano Yogam Vibhutim cha Janardana, Bhuyah Kathaya Triptir hi Shrinvato Nasti Me Amritam. "Tell me again in detail, O Janardana, your Yoga power and your immanent glory, because I do not feel satisfied hearing your life-giving, nectar-like speech." In other words, he said, give me some examples. So Bhagavan said: Divya hi Atma Vibhutayah — my glories are divine.

Pradhanyataha Kuru Shreshtha Na Astyantah Vistarasya Me. There is no end to this glory, but I can give you some prominent examples. So Bhagavan clearly clarified to Arjuna: I'm going to give you some prominent examples. They do not constitute my entire glory, but they will give you some idea of where to see my presence. So we have been seeing many examples, right from the Vedic period to the Puranic period. And Bhagavan is now even coming down to our day-to-day experiences.

Pavanaha Pavatamasmi — something which we experience in phenomenal nature. Everything and every being is nothing but my own self, because he said everything proceeds from me and I am the source of all things and beings. There is no other thing which has created this universe. When we see an effect, there have to be two causes.

One is the efficient cause — somebody who knows how to make that thing come into existence. And one is the material to create that thing. Take pizza: we need a pizza maker and pizza ingredients. So if you see pizza here, you can't simply say, "Well, the pizza just appeared here. We are Chinmaya Mission, we are divine people. We don't need to order pizza."

Pizza just appears here. We know that an intelligent person will not believe that. He knows that if there is pizza there, there is a pizza maker and he had the ingredients for the pizza. So the same way, if this world exists, there is the material cause and efficient cause. Material cause is something which we have difficulty understanding. We think if Bhagavan knows everything, obviously he knows how to create this world.

The problem is where did he find the material? How do we create something? I'm an architect, so I can create buildings. Because I know how to design building. Just knowing how to create building doesn't create building. I need to have materials.

Go to Home Depot or Lowe's to buy that material. Ask Home Depot, "Where do you get materials?" "We get them from our suppliers." So you can go up to the source of the material, where it came from. In this case, if we find the source of the material which Bhagavan used to create this Jagat, you can always say that Bhagavan found the material from X. Then X becomes greater than the Bhagawan who created it.

Go to X and say, "Where did you get the material?" "From Y." Then Y becomes greater than X because he had the original material. Ask Y, "Where did you get the material?" "Z had the material," and then Z becomes greater than Y. So this exercise is futile because we cannot get to the ultimate source of the material. You have to come to the conclusion that Bhagavan himself was the source of the material.

In Bhagawan, there's only one thing which he did not have to buy, borrow, or steal — that is his own self. Everything we acquire in this world, we bought from somebody, borrowed from somebody, or took from somebody. But one thing I never had to acquire: that is my own self.

That which I call I. I did not acquire it from anywhere. I didn't buy from anywhere. So that's the only material available to Bhagavan. So he created this Jagat using his knowledge of creating this universe as an efficient cause. And he also used the material available to him with his own self. So he became the material cause and the efficient cause for this universe.

Therefore he said, everything proceeds from me and I am the source of all things. However, that is not something for us to easily understand. So give me some examples of glories. It may be difficult to find glory in something which is average. But we can find in something which is really excellent. If you have a water jug and if you just a little salt in it and you taste it you won't know that there is salt in it.

But there's a lot of salt in it. And you taste it, you know there's salt in it. The Bhagawan has been giving several prominent examples. Sarjanam, Adihicha, Antacha, Madhyamcha Evam, Aham, Arjunah. In the creation for anything which is created and the beginning, the middle and the end, there is no other material to create anything, to sustain anything or destroy anything. The same material which was used to create this Jagat, everything in Jagat in this universe is also created by the same original material.

So Bhagawan said, any creation you see in this world, I am the beginning, the middle and the end. In verse 33 he says, Aksaranam Akaro Asmi. In previous verse he said, in all the sounds and then one syllable, Om. Because Om is the primordial sound. That is the sound which is the most basic sound out of which all the other variation of sounds come into existence. As I said, it's like three color printing.

There are only three cartridges in your printer. But when you print a picture, permutation combination of those three colors created this wonderful picture which is a variety of colors. So this aa and M is like the source of all the sounds that we hear in this world is the sum total of all the sounds. The Om out of which the first sound is a. U in Ma signifies creation, O signifies such stance and Ma signifies. So when you close your mouth, it's a ma. I heard Anup Jilotra telling a joke.

He was teaching a female student. He said, she will do saregami when it comes to maa, she will skip this ma. He said, why are you skipping Ma? He said, ma, I have to close my mouth so my lipstick gets spoiled. So Ma, you are closing your lips signifying the destruction. Aa comes from your belly.

So that's a creation. Aksaranam akaru asmi. Among the letters I am a. Swamiji also explains that every language, the Alphabet starts with A and without a vowel you cannot make any word. And Swamiji explains that in Sanskrit there is a preponderance of a sound. Therefore it is so sweet sounding language. Among the compound words in Sanskrit, I'm Dwandva.

Those of us who have learned a little bit of Sanskrit, there are several compounding words. I know only one very well. Bahubri samas, yasyakantaha nilaha, Sahneela Kantaha whose neck is blue and Neela kanta, that's a Bahuri samas. So two words, Neela and Kanta, when you combine it With Neel Kant. That's why I remember from my 8th standard Sanskrit that is called Bahu Brahi Samas. Neela is actually almost like an adjective.

It does not have same value as Kantha. Nila is just the attributes of that Kanta. But as Dvanga samas used two words, they both retain their own identity. Dita, Ram, Sita and Ram both maintain their own identity, their own importance. Therefore Dhvandva is considered the most prominent samas. Bhagavan says among the compound words I am Dhvandva that which retains the value of both.

Swamiji explains here that some commentators have commented that it also may be indicating the self and non self. So this entire world of ours is made up of something which we call it self that is me and something which is not me, which is non self. In Vedanta, this body, mind, intellect are non self. They are not really permanent. I am permanent, I feeling is permanent. This beautiful combination of self and non self which we see in our Jagat where self remains the self and still non self retains its own identity as a plurality in this world.

So therefore it says Dwandva amongst compound words. I'm Dwandva Aham Eva Akshayaha Kalaha. I am that ever existing time. For he said among the reckoners, Kalaitam kalaham among the measures, I am time. Everything we know is defined in space and time. Indian philosophers have given more importance to time.

They say time is fundamental. Space is an emergent quality of time. So in that he said, I am the time. Among all the reckon how we measure things, I am time. In all the measurement, time is the most important one. He said I am that infinite time.

It seems like to us it is flowing and going. But time remains constant. It's our experiences change. Our time starts with the experience of any event followed by the second event. If there's only one event, there is no time. The first event occurs, there is no time.

We measure time between the two events. Therefore, Swamiji says the measure of time in English is second, not first. There is no time second. So here he says I am that infinite time, not that perceived through your senses as finite time. Dhata aham Vishwato Mukaha and I am also the Karma Falada. I am also the supporter, the dispenser of all your experiences.

I experience as long as I'M alive as long as I'm conscious. So my consciousness is the dispenser of all my thoughts and experiences. Daata Viswato Mukaha Facing everywhere that self which in me. Facing everywhere and getting experience of everything is the same self in you. Facing everywhere, gaining all the experience outside. So when you put it together, Bhagavan is everywhere.

No matter where you see, he is there. Next verse says mrtyuhu Sarva harascha. I am death among all that takes things away from you. You can lose things in some accident. You can lose things by losing something. Various ways we lose things in life.

We lose money in stock market. But you see that still you will be left with something. I may lose money, but I'll have my health. I'm out of health, but I'm still alive. So there's something left. You know, I lost something, but when I die, I lost everything.

There's nothing left for me. Therefore, once I am the death, it takes away everything from you. You cannot take anything with you. Therefore it's a Mrityo Sarva Haraschaham, the greatest taker to take everything that you think is yours. Udbhavastcha Bhavish. The translation in the book is slightly confusing which says, I am the prosperity of those who are to be prosperous.

Swamiji clarifies that's not the really appropriate interpretation of Udbhava. Udbhava means to come into existence. I am the source of all that is coming to be in existence in future. Not only I am the source of all things and beings in present that you see, but I am also the source of everything that will come in existence in future. In other words, past, present and future are just concepts of my mind. There is only one existence and it exists all the time.

And therefore anything which is created in that existence is nothing but the expression of the same supreme reality which is all pervading, everlasting, omnipresent, omniscient, Kirtihi Sri wakcha, NRI nam smruti medha, dhrutikshamah. All women can take some pride here. All the good qualities are feminine. It says that I am the feminine qualities. Fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness and forgiveness. All these qualities are manifest in people because of my presence.
snippets.reflection:
Here Krishna makes His most challenging identification: "Mrityuh sarva-harash cha aham" - "I am death, the all-devouring." Death takes everything we think is ours; nothing survives its grasp. Yet even this ultimate loss is divine manifestation. Why? Because death reveals what is truly ours (consciousness, which survives) versus what was only borrowed (body, possessions, relationships). The all-devouring one is also the great teacher of impermanence and detachment.

Equally striking are the feminine qualities Krishna claims as His own: Kirti (fame), Sri (prosperity), Vak (speech), Smriti (memory), Medha (intelligence), Dhriti (firmness), and Kshama (forgiveness). All these are grammatically feminine in Sanskrit, and Krishna says these positive qualities manifest in people because of His presence. This teaching dignifies the feminine principle - the qualities that nurture, remember, articulate, persist, and pardon are divine signatures. Wherever you see these qualities - in any person of any gender - you see the Lord.

Today, contemplate your relationship with death and loss. Rather than avoiding the thought, recognize: every moment something dies - a breath, an experience, a version of yourself. Can you see this continuous dying as divine teaching, constantly showing you what is essential versus what is passing? And notice the feminine qualities - in yourself, in others, in the world. When someone speaks wisdom, demonstrates memory, shows intelligence or forgiveness - these are not merely personal virtues but manifestations of the divine feminine. Ask: "How does my relationship with impermanence change if I see death as divine teacher rather than enemy? Which feminine qualities do I most need to cultivate?"

snippets.title: Day 140: Divine Glories
snippets.sanskrit:
वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनञ्जयः |

दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम् |

यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन |
snippets.transliteration:
vṛṣṇīnāṃ vāsudevo.asmi pāṇḍavānāṃ dhanañjayaḥ .

daṇḍo damayatāmasmi nītirasmi jigīṣatām .

yaccāpi sarvabhūtānāṃ bījaṃ tadahamarjuna .
verseTranslations: I am Shri Krishna among the Vishnu-clan and Arjuna among the Pandavas; of the saints I am Vyasa, and I am Shukracharya among the sages.
I am the Sceptre of rulers, the Strategy of the conquerors, the Silence of mystery, the Wisdom of the wise.
I am the Seed of all being, O Arjuna! No creature moving or unmoving can live without Me.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter 10, and we are coming to its conclusion. So far we have seen that Bhagavan has been hammering on the same idea which has been discussed many times before in the Bhagavad Gita: that I am the source of all things and beings. The central theme of the Bhagavad Gita is that there is unity in diversity. Even though we see this world as a world of plurality — each individual different from each other, each thing different from each other — there is an unseen thread running through all things and beings, because they all come from the same source.

So there is similarity, there is something common to all. That's basically Bhagavan's theme. All throughout the Bhagavad Gita, he has been explaining that in various ways. And we have seen in the beginning of this chapter, Bhagawan reiterated: Aham Sarvasya Prabhavah Matta Sarva Pravartate — I am the source of all beings and everything proceeds from me. It is something like a scientist would say: everything started from the Big Bang in our universe, and everything which we see in this universe came from the Big Bang.

So when you and I are nothing but the product of the Big Bang — when there was nothing but hydrogen and helium, and now we have all this complex universe that we are trying to understand. If somebody comes out and says, "That's all good, but explain to me how I can see evidence of the Big Bang in the universe," then people can start explaining: what you see in the galaxies — the hydrogen, the microwave radiation — it all comes from that original source. But you still have to give some examples. So here Arjuna says the same thing: I understood that everything comes from that supreme reality, You, the supreme reality.

Many sages in the past have said the same thing, and you are also now saying it. I'm not doubting those sages, nor do I have any doubt in you. But can you give me some examples in my life where I can feel your presence in the world of objects and beings? That's what Bhagawan has given — these examples, somewhat reluctantly. "Alas, I explained all of this, but you still want to know." It's like we all can learn the Bhagavad Gita and say that God is everywhere.

God has no form, God is not a man, he's not a woman. But that doesn't end it. I still want Bhagavan's Darshan, because we are stuck with our perception of reality. Our perception is limited by our mind, intellect, and senses. We also want to see Bhagavan in the image which we have created in our mind. Arjuna says the same thing.

Show me evidence of your presence in my world. Bhagavan has given these 54 examples, starting from Vedic entities to Puranic ones, then natural phenomena and everything else you can think about, including some negative ones — Dandaha Damayatam Asmi, and among all the cheating and gambling. He wanted to convey to Arjuna: I am not just in the good; everything that's seemingly evil in your world also exists only because I exist.

And then the last few verses are the conclusion of this chapter, where Bhagawan says: I have exhausted the examples which I can give you, but there is not really any end to this discussion. You can't continue to say, "Just give me one more example, just give me one more example."

So he says: Yat cha Api Sarva Bhutanam Bijam Tat Aham Arjuna — whatever is the source of anything, I am that. Because anything in this world, as we have described, is an effect. When I see something which I can perceive through my senses, it's an effect. There has to be a cause, there has to be a source. You see a child — you know there are parents for that child.

A child cannot exist without parents. So the parents are the source of the child. We see a pizza — we know there is a pizza maker somewhere. So everything we know has a source. And right now our conclusion is that everything has different sources. Wood comes from somewhere, steel comes from somewhere else.

Then all this comes together and we build buildings. Bhagawan here says that whatever you see in this world is a being. "Being" means that which has existence, that which comes into being, which comes into existence in this space and time. I am the source, no matter what you see. Yat cha Api Sarvabhutanam Bijam, Tad Aham Arjuna. I am the primordial cause for all things and beings.

We understand this analogy of a seed and anything which comes out of it — a tree, an animal, a human being from a seed. But in that case, the seed is destroyed. After that manifestation is completed, when the tree comes into existence, that seed is gone. But in this case, that seed is immutable. It remains as the support for that manifestation.

So that cause remains as support for the effect. There are three laws of causation, Swamiji teaches. One of them says: if you remove the cause from the effect, the effect does not remain. You remove the cause from this universe, which is the Supreme Being, and the universe does not remain. The gold is the cause for the gold ornament.

You remove the gold from the gold ornament, and the gold ornament does not remain. Na Tad Asti Vina Yat Syat Maya Bhutam Characharam. Without me, the moving or unmoving cannot exist in this world. Just as if we remove the gold, the gold ornament cannot exist. So Bhagawan has basically concluded that all these examples are given for you to understand and to train your mind to start seeing things as they are.

They're all made up of the same material. This universe has one source. Eventually you can trace down the source to that one entity which remains immutable — the uncaused cause. There is no source for that cause. If you find a source for that cause, you can go further and find that source. So at one point in time, there will be a cause which has no cause.

So therefore Bhagavan said, I am that cause. And without that, nothing can exist. You remove that from this universe — it's like in my dream. My own thoughts are the source of my dream. But when I go into deep sleep, that dream cannot exist.

Because without my mind, which is the source, the dream cannot exist. Bhagawan here says the conclusion of all my examples is: I am the ultimate cause. I am the ultimate source of all things and beings. No thing, moving or unmoving, can exist without me. This is the very efficient way in Vedanta to explain that everything is included — when you say "moving and unmoving," all sentient beings and all inert things are included. Nothing can exist without my presence.

There is no end to my Vibhuti. You cannot count all the manifestations. If you want to catalog all the manifestations of physical world, in this physical world, even that's not possible. So now we have in our science all this Webb telescope so we can see as far as possible. But let's say you want to catalog all the galaxies and all the stars in this universe. No matter what kind of a telescope you will have.

There are billions and billions of stars and millions and millions of galaxies. It's almost impossible. And by the time you catalog all of them, the new galaxies are formed and new stars are born, new old stars. It's a continuous change. Therefore, in Sanskrit it's called Jagat universe. But Jagat is that which is constantly changing.

Something which is constantly changing, there is no end to its manifestation. If it's constantly changing, you cannot count it. But by the time you catalog what you have known, new things come into existence. We were in high school, we thought, if I learn this physics and chemistry, then I'll be good at it. Well, physics and chemistry keeps changing in my own lifetime, so even that is not possible. Na antah asti mama divyanaam vibhuti nam paranti.

But there is no end to the divine glories, the physical manifestation of myself. But I told you some in detail just because you asked for it. Now you can figure out rest by yourself. Basically you teach somebody how to think, then the person can think himself rather than spoon feeding him. Give them example and then a person can learn on his own how to detect that. If you figure out if you are working in a jewelry shop and you figure out how to test a gold ornament, whether it is gold or not, once you have one example, you can then apply that on any other example.

So taking all these 54 examples, you have seen the method that anything which you see which has some excellence, that's because of the presence of that Lord. Now I told you all that you should be able to detect this. But in conclusion I can tell you. Yat Vibhuti mat satvam Srimat urjitam eva va tattat eva avagatschatvam mama tej ansa sambhavah. Whatever you see in this world, the world of your experiences, as Swamiji says that Jagat is not just the physical world which is changing outside the world of my experiences, world of my perception that is changing constantly, whatever in your perception, in your experience, you see as Vibhuti mat which has glory or its own excellence, Sattvam existence Sat is which is real, asat which is unreal. So Sattvam one context purity also that which has existence Srimat prosperous And Urjitam energetic.

So anything which you see in this world, in nature, in society, in your community, in your family, where you see these qualities, you should know that they are all coming from me alone. Tatta Eva Avagacvam Mama Teja Ansa Sambhavam. It's coming into existence because iota of my being. So don't consider that if I add up all this manifestation someday with some supercomputer and add it up, that will be Bhagavan. He said no, no, that will be just an iota of my being. Swamiji gives a very good example that my mind has all the capabilities.

But once in a while it gets confused or deluded by some random thought. And then it goes into a wrong direction. It creates this scenario which is unrealistic. That doesn't mean I completely have lost all my ability to think. My 99% of my ability is still valid. But right now it's dormant.

It's covered by the one delusion. But when that one delusion is removed, 100% of my ability will be back. So Bhagavan is Satchitananda is ever pure. But this manifestation, the Prakriti, the world of plurality comes into existence by just one part which creates this disturbance which they call the Hiranyagarva cumulative Vasanas. Of all the beings and things which are in this universe, that one portion is now creating a new world. So when I go to sleep, my world comes to an end.

In a deep sleep there is no world. I don't exist, world does not exist. But my Vasras are there in dormant form. That dormant vasanas will find the appropriate condition. My body has rested fully. I will wake up and they will all come back and manifest and create my own world.

In case of Ishvara also, Ishwara remains as pure as Brahman. But all the cumulative asanas of of the Jagat are still in a dormant form.
snippets.reflection:
In a remarkable personal touch, Krishna declares: "Vrishninam Vasudevah asmi, Pandavanam Dhananjayah" - "Among the Vrishnis, I am Vasudeva (Krishna himself); among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna." Krishna identifies with Himself and with His devoted friend! This is not ego but demonstration: divinity is present in the one who knows and the one who seeks to know. Among sages, He is Vyasa (compiler of the Vedas); among poets, Ushanas (Shukracharya). The capacity to organize wisdom and the capacity to express beauty - both are divine expressions.

The verse "Yat cha api sarva-bhutanam bijam tat aham" is the chapter's essence: "I am the seed of all beings." Unlike an ordinary seed that is destroyed when the plant emerges, this divine seed remains - it is the immutable support for all manifestation. "Na tat asti vina yat syat maya bhutam chara-acharam" - nothing moving or unmoving can exist without Me. This is not arrogance but ontological fact: remove the cause from the effect, and the effect cannot remain. Remove gold from the ornament, and the ornament vanishes.

Today, contemplate yourself as both the beloved (like Arjuna) and the manifestation of the divine (like Vasudeva). You are not merely a seeker but also that which is sought - the divine expresses through your very seeking. And see everything around you as effects whose cause is the same divine presence. The chair, the tree, the stranger on the street - all exist only because they are supported by that "seed" which is never destroyed. Ask yourself: "If I am the Arjuna in Krishna's enumeration - chosen, beloved, identified with - how does that change my sense of spiritual worthiness? Can I see myself as both seeker and sought?"

snippets.title: Day 141: The Source of All
snippets.sanskrit:

यद्यद्विभूतिमत्सत्त्वं श्रीमदूर्जितमेव वा |

अथवा बहुनैतेन किं ज्ञातेन तवार्जुन |
