There is no source for that cause. If you find a source for that cause, you can go further and find that source. So at one point in time, there will be a cause which has no cause.

So therefore Bhagavan said, I am that cause. And without that, nothing can exist. You remove that from this universe — it's like in my dream. My own thoughts are the source of my dream. But when I go into deep sleep, that dream cannot exist.

Because without my mind, which is the source, the dream cannot exist. Bhagawan here says the conclusion of all my examples is: I am the ultimate cause. I am the ultimate source of all things and beings. No thing, moving or unmoving, can exist without me. This is the very efficient way in Vedanta to explain that everything is included — when you say "moving and unmoving," all sentient beings and all inert things are included. Nothing can exist without my presence.

There is no end to my Vibhuti. You cannot count all the manifestations. If you want to catalog all the manifestations of physical world, in this physical world, even that's not possible. So now we have in our science all this Webb telescope so we can see as far as possible. But let's say you want to catalog all the galaxies and all the stars in this universe. No matter what kind of a telescope you will have.

There are billions and billions of stars and millions and millions of galaxies. It's almost impossible. And by the time you catalog all of them, the new galaxies are formed and new stars are born, new old stars. It's a continuous change. Therefore, in Sanskrit it's called Jagat universe. But Jagat is that which is constantly changing.

Something which is constantly changing, there is no end to its manifestation. If it's constantly changing, you cannot count it. But by the time you catalog what you have known, new things come into existence. We were in high school, we thought, if I learn this physics and chemistry, then I'll be good at it. Well, physics and chemistry keeps changing in my own lifetime, so even that is not possible. Na antah asti mama divyanaam vibhuti nam paranti.

But there is no end to the divine glories, the physical manifestation of myself. But I told you some in detail just because you asked for it. Now you can figure out rest by yourself. Basically you teach somebody how to think, then the person can think himself rather than spoon feeding him. Give them example and then a person can learn on his own how to detect that. If you figure out if you are working in a jewelry shop and you figure out how to test a gold ornament, whether it is gold or not, once you have one example, you can then apply that on any other example.

So taking all these 54 examples, you have seen the method that anything which you see which has some excellence, that's because of the presence of that Lord. Now I told you all that you should be able to detect this. But in conclusion I can tell you. Yat Vibhuti mat satvam Srimat urjitam eva va tattat eva avagatschatvam mama tej ansa sambhavah. Whatever you see in this world, the world of your experiences, as Swamiji says that Jagat is not just the physical world which is changing outside the world of my experiences, world of my perception that is changing constantly, whatever in your perception, in your experience, you see as Vibhuti mat which has glory or its own excellence, Sattvam existence Sat is which is real, asat which is unreal. So Sattvam one context purity also that which has existence Srimat prosperous And Urjitam energetic.

So anything which you see in this world, in nature, in society, in your community, in your family, where you see these qualities, you should know that they are all coming from me alone. Tatta Eva Avagacvam Mama Teja Ansa Sambhavam. It's coming into existence because iota of my being. So don't consider that if I add up all this manifestation someday with some supercomputer and add it up, that will be Bhagavan. He said no, no, that will be just an iota of my being. Swamiji gives a very good example that my mind has all the capabilities.

But once in a while it gets confused or deluded by some random thought. And then it goes into a wrong direction. It creates this scenario which is unrealistic. That doesn't mean I completely have lost all my ability to think. My 99% of my ability is still valid. But right now it's dormant.

It's covered by the one delusion. But when that one delusion is removed, 100% of my ability will be back. So Bhagavan is Satchitananda is ever pure. But this manifestation, the Prakriti, the world of plurality comes into existence by just one part which creates this disturbance which they call the Hiranyagarva cumulative Vasanas. Of all the beings and things which are in this universe, that one portion is now creating a new world. So when I go to sleep, my world comes to an end.

In a deep sleep there is no world. I don't exist, world does not exist. But my Vasras are there in dormant form. That dormant vasanas will find the appropriate condition. My body has rested fully. I will wake up and they will all come back and manifest and create my own world.

In case of Ishvara also, Ishwara remains as pure as Brahman. But all the cumulative asanas of of the Jagat are still in a dormant form.
snippets.reflection:
The chapter concludes with a teaching that shatters our usual way of thinking about God and world. After 54 examples, Krishna says: "Na antah asti mama divyanam vibhutinam" - there is no end to My divine glories. And then the stunning finale: "Vishtabhya aham idam kritsnam ekamshena sthito jagat" - I support this entire universe with a single fragment of Myself. All we see - every star, every being, every atom - is sustained by just a portion of the divine. The infinite remainder lies beyond our comprehension entirely.

This teaching serves two purposes. First, it prevents worship of manifestations as the ultimate - no matter how glorious something appears, it is only a fragment pointing to the whole. Second, it instills appropriate awe - if this vast, incomprehensible universe is merely one-fraction, what must the whole be? Like a single thread of a tapestry that goes on forever, what we experience is real but partial. Our task is not to catalog all divine manifestations (impossible) but to recognize the principle: wherever there is excellence, beauty, power, or truth, there is divine presence.

Today, let this teaching reshape your perception. Look at everything you consider magnificent - towering mountains, brilliant minds, acts of extraordinary love - and remember: this is one fragment. The divine is not exhausted by any manifestation, no matter how grand. This should humble us (we cannot fully grasp the whole) and liberate us (we need not search elsewhere - the fragment before us is enough for recognition). Ask yourself: "If everything glorious I have ever witnessed is only a fragment, what does this tell me about seeking 'more' versus appreciating what is present? How would my life change if I truly saw each moment as a window onto the infinite?"

snippets.title: Day 142: The Cosmic Form
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया |

एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

bhavāpyayau hi bhūtānāṃ śrutau vistaraśo mayā .

evametadyathāttha tvamātmānaṃ parameśvara .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna said: My Lord! Thy words concerning the Supreme Secret of Self, given for my blessing, have dispelled the illusions which surrounded me.
O Lord, whose eyes are like the lotus petal! Thou hast described in detail the origin and the dissolution of being, and Thine own Eternal Majesty.
I believe all as Thou hast declared it. I long now to have a vision of thy Divine Form, O Thou Most High!
snippets.commentary:
We have started discussing Chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan, the Vision of the Cosmic Form. Up till now in Bhagavad Gita, we have learned that all of us are trying to liberate ourselves from our sorrows. In the very first chapter, we defined our condition. From my perspective, life is full of sorrows and joys, but they don't come as cleanly defined as we would like them to be. Sorrows come with a little joy, and joys come with a little sorrow.

Everything that is positive comes with a little negative, and everything negative has some positive in it. The very first chapter defined our condition. To get out of this, we are trying all our means to overcome these limitations. In the first five chapters, we define who we are and from what perspective we are seeing our life, and therefore why we have these limitations. We have seen that we are defining ourselves by our accomplishments, our relationships, our abilities, and also our limitations.

From that perspective, when I see the world, I'm a minuscule being and the world is out there to get me. The vast world out there is the Karma Falada -- the field of my activity -- and I have very limited control over what comes out of my actions. In that situation, I constantly try to find what is right and what is wrong, what is appropriate and what is inappropriate, but I can't find a clear definition. From chapter two onwards, we have seen why that perspective is not correct.

That perspective -- me looking at myself from a very narrow angle -- is creating all this confusion. If I change the perspective about who I am, which Bhagavan clarifies in chapter two, I learn that you are not who you think you are. This mortal self is not you but your equipment. My body, my mind, my intellect -- these are my equipment, but not me. I consider them to be me and associate all their limitations as my limitations. Up to chapter five, we learned what that equipment is all about and how using it in this world effectively will get me to where I want to be, which is a state of complete bliss. Then we learned the art of meditation in chapter six -- how to meditate upon that other self which I have not experienced yet, but which is my real self.

So the quest from chapter 7 onward is to define that Self -- the self which I have not yet identified with, but identification with which will end all my sorrows and limitations. We have learned that that self is the Almighty, all-pervading self. That self is none other than the self which I consider to be myself, the one self which constantly reminds me that I exist. That self is the same self as the self outside. But the change of perspective is what I need.

So how do I get to that was the topic of chapter 10. How do I now start identifying with that higher self? By seeing that self in everything and every being. In chapter 10, the Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories, we have learned that Bhagavan says there anything glorious, splendid, powerful, wonderful, you see in this world. Consider that is that because of me, the self in it. So the theme of chapter 10 was that I am the origin and dissolution of all the being.

Aham Sarvasya prabhavaha matthaha Sarva Prabhartate. When you take that statement -- that everything is pervaded by me -- it basically tells me that everything is one and the same. Nothing is different from I, because the I pervades everywhere. There is no space left. If you say I pervades only in sentient beings, then it is a different story. But this I pervades everywhere.

Aham Atma guda kesa sarva asyas thetah. I'm seated in the hearts of all beings. I'm the core of all beings and things. So we have learnt and have an intellectual appreciation. Now, the knowledge in our life comes from three different sources. One is Pratyaksa Pramana.

You can keep telling me that it is night outside. You are hallucinating where I personally can see. That's the Pratyaksha Parama. I infer where there is smoke, there is fire. So chapter 10 gave me all the inferences. How can I claim that there is electricity in this room?

I said, don't you see the lights are on? That means electricity is on. It's an inference -- it does not say that I can see electricity. All my knowledge about electricity comes from inferences: the heater is on, lights are on, air conditioning is working. But my Pratyaksha Pramana will be when I put my finger in that outlet. No words are necessary. No description is necessary. That's Pratyaksha Pramana -- seeing is the closest I can come. So our Shastra, the Sankhya philosophy, accepts three sources of knowledge.

First, Pratyaksha Pramana -- perception through my senses. Second, inference -- from my observation, I deduce that this must be the truth. And third is testimony -- somebody comes and tells me what it is. Most of our knowledge about Bhagavan comes from testimony only, so far. My parents told me Bhagavan is like that.

All religions tell me Bhagavan is all-pervading. Swamiji even said Bhagavan is all-pervading. Who am I to doubt him? So I'm relying totally on testimony right now about Bhagavan, from a lineage of all the gurus. They are telling us that the Atma is the Paramatma.

Who am I to question them? I have complete faith in them, in the testimony. How does a judge ever decide what is right and what is wrong? Who is guilty, not guilty. He relies strictly on testimony, because he is hardly ever there at the scene of crime. Only in some very unique case does he happen to be there. Otherwise, he never has any other means of knowledge other than testimony. That's why the oath is taken: truth and nothing but the truth. So I can rely on testimony if I trust the testimony. So far we have trusted the testimony of Bhagavan. Aham Atma Guda Kesas Sarva -- that is his testimony. He says so, and unless we doubt him, we don't have any reason to doubt him. So we say okay, that's fine. Then he said, "If you don't believe me just on my word, look everywhere around you and see all this power and glory. That power and glory will not be there if I am not there." So anytime I see something splendid.

Anytime you go out into nature, something awesome strikes you. Right away you have that sense of awe about the divine in nature. How wonderful this nature is! Because this exists, there must be God. Because nature has laws, there must be a lawgiver. And because the laws are implicitly followed, there must be a law enforcer.

We have never met him. But we know if I jump from the 14th floor window, Mother Earth will receive me. As Newton figured out. But that's still not good enough for me to vouch for his presence. What I want is seeing is believing. So Vishwarupadarshan is the final experience all of us are seeking.

In spite of my complete faith in Bhagavad Gita and Swami Chinmayananda, the only time I can come and tell you Bhagavan exists is if I experience him. Therefore, now Arjuna says Mat Anugrahaa Paramam Guhiyam Adhyatma Sangin Matanughaya Paramam. Out of your great compassion for me -- not that I was deserving, not that I did something special. A mother does something for a child not because the child is deserving, but out of complete compassion. Yat Paya Uktam -- out of great compassion for me, you have given me this secret knowledge about the self. You told me about what the Self is all about.

In chapter two you told me that you are not that mortal being. You are the immortal being. All beings are immortal. The self in them is immortal. All bodies are destroyable, perishable. But the self in those bodies is immortal.

You told me this great secret, which can only be transmitted when there is a great teacher and a very eligible student. Otherwise the secret remains secret. Teachers may come and tell you, but you will never learn. My delusion is gone by this discourse. This knowledge that you have given me out of your great compassion for me.

So that confusion about who I am and what my duty is -- am I a soldier, a general? Or am I a brother, a grandson, and a student? What is more important, my duty as a general or my duty as a family man? That delusion is gone. The field of action changes, but I, the actor, remain the same.

So depending on the field of action, I should be working accordingly. I can think about architecture when that is my field. I can't start giving clients a discourse about Bhagavad Gita -- they will go away! The delusion is gone. I now know what is right and what is wrong.

However, Bhava Apyayo hi Bhutanam Srutao Vistara Shomaya. Let me also tell you what I understood so far. That Bhava Apya origin and dissolution of beings in Bhutanam Sruta Vistara Somaya. I heard in detail which you told me Kamala Patraaksa Mahatmyam Apicha Avyam that it is the eternal self which is the origin and dissolution. Ishvara the Lord is the resting place and the source of all the beings. Also Mahatmyam Apicha Abhyam.

Then also your great glories. Then I heard you the Isvara. I heard Your glories. He addresses Krishna Kamalapatra as one who is lotus eyed. Now obviously in our culture lotus eyed is considered beautiful. But there is another implication here.

That you are seeing this world as a lotus eyed. In other words, the lotus remains pure no matter what the condition of its being. You the self remain unattached to all this prakriti that you have in detail described to me how this world functions. But you remain completely detached of that. I understood that part also. I understood who I am, what my duty is.

Now I also understood your nature as the Ishwara and how you remain detached from all the workings of this Prakriti. Evam etad yatha ATH tvam atmanam parameshwara. Thus you have described Eva metat. So be it or so it is. Evam eta yatha atma as you said what we just discussed that you are the source of all the beings and you are the dissolution of all the beings. That includes myself as well.

You describe to me that you are the source of all the beings. You are the dissolution of all the beings. However, Drastu mitchami -- I want to see it. I understood. There is no question anymore about the teaching. However, I want to see it for myself. The sense of sight is the most dear to us, because seeing is believing. I may close my eyes and I may hear my granddaughter. But that doesn't mean that she is here. Somebody put recording. I want to see what I'm hearing is correct or something else I'm hearing. That's why I want to have the direct experience.

Only then can I vouch for it that your nature is such. I am understanding and accepting, with no doubt, the testimony you have given. And all of this -- including Narad Muni, Kavi Ushna, and all the people we have talked about -- is testimony I've taken for granted. As for inference, you told me to see everywhere in this world as you. I also understood that. But I still need my direct experience. Pratyaksha Pramana. Drastumi Chami Terupam Ayeshwaram -- I want to see that splendid form of yours where everything is included in it. Right now I only have a very narrow perspective. When we look at photographs of any building, we are only seeing a part of it.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna declares that his delusion is gone after hearing Krishna's teachings, yet he still yearns to see the cosmic form directly. This reveals a profound truth about spiritual growth: intellectual understanding, while necessary, is not the same as direct experience. Consider the three sources of knowledge mentioned in these verses - perception (pratyaksha), inference (anumana), and testimony (shabda). Most of our spiritual knowledge comes from testimony - what teachers, scriptures, and traditions tell us. But like Arjuna, we long for that direct perception, that moment when "seeing is believing."

Reflect today on the gap between what you intellectually know and what you have actually experienced. You may understand that all beings share the same consciousness, but do you feel it when interacting with a difficult colleague or a stranger on the street? Arjuna's honesty is instructive - he does not pretend to have realized what he has only understood conceptually. Practice this honesty with yourself: Where in your spiritual journey are you relying purely on faith and testimony? What would it mean to move from hearing about the unity of existence to actually perceiving it?

As a daily exercise, when you encounter any moment of excellence or beauty today - a sunset, a kind gesture, a moment of insight - pause and ask yourself: "Am I merely inferring the divine here, or can I directly perceive the source behind this manifestation?" Let this question bridge the gap between knowledge heard and wisdom realized.

snippets.title: Day 143: Universal Vision
snippets.sanskrit:
मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्विनौ मरुतस्तथा |
snippets.transliteration:
manyase yadi tacchakyaṃ mayā draṣṭumiti prabho .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

paśyādityānvasūnrudrānaśvinau marutastathā .
verseTranslations: If Thou thinkest that it can be made possible for me to see it, show me, O Lord of Lords, Thine own Eternal Self.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Behold, O Arjuna! My celestial forms, by hundreds and thousands, various in kind, in colour and in shape.

Behold thou the Powers of Nature: fire, earth, wind and sky; the sun, the heavens, the moon, the stars; all forces of vitality and of healing; and the roving winds. See the myriad wonders revealed to none but thee.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 11, the Vishwarupadarshan, the cosmic form of the Lord. In the beginning of chapter 11, Arjuna said: Anugrahaya, out of your compassion for me, you gave me this deepest secret about the Self and showed me how to experience that and meditate on it. However, that's not sufficient for me to understand the nature of the self which you have described. He said, my delusion is dispelled -- the delusion about myself. When he started in the first chapter saying, "I cannot kill these people even if I get killed," Bhagavan said in the second chapter that the self cannot be killed.

The self in you is imperishable, immutable. The self in you is the same self in everyone else. So one who thinks he is a slayer and one who thinks he is slain -- both are wrong, because it is like within myself: I cannot be both slayer and slain of my own self. Arjuna said, now I'm very clear. My confusion about what my self is, that is gone. However, I'm still at a level where I cannot comprehend the unity of all beings.

I understand. I can also experience my own self. I'm very aware of myself. I can now theoretically understand that as my self is imperishable, your self is also imperishable. However, that oneness of the self is beyond my understanding. If you really look at this point of the Bhagavad Gita, we are exactly at the same level -- all of us who have been sincerely seeking to understand the nature of the self.

All this is intellectually understood. But when it comes to realizing, myself and yourself is one and the same understanding falls apart from experience. My experience is very different in day to day life. I know everything about myself and how I feel, but I cannot relate to yourself and how you feel. Therefore, Arjuna said, I am very clear. You have also explained to me how the things come into being and how they perishes all comes out of the same self and perishes back into the same self.

It is very clear to me. However, this oneness of the Lord, the glory of the supreme Self -- to be perceived as one and not as many -- is beyond my control right now. And that's the hurdle in the path of my realization. Right now I'm in a constant samadhi about myself. This conditioned self which I think is me requires no effort to realize. It's automatic knowledge. As soon as a baby is born, he or she knows "this is me" and everyone else is someone else.

So that's an automatic knowledge. We're conditioned by that. The conditioned self has conditioned us to think who we are. The knowledge given to us by the sages telling us that no, this conditioned self is not the only nature of yourself. Yourself is omnipresent, omnipotent and omniscient. You're just conditioning it and making it limited yourself.

Once you let go of those limitations, you will identify with the Supreme Self. And that's where Arjuna says, I have a difficulty. I can't experience that. I want to experience that form of the self -- your form. You claim to know that supreme form of the self. I know this limited form of the self; you know the supreme form.

I need to see that to get over the hurdle. So he said, drastumi chami te rupam aishwaram purushottamam. O Lord of all the beings. Purushottam, I want to say that form of yours where everything is included in one. I see myself as separate. The world is separate.

The world of plurality is very easy for me to comprehend. But I want to see all in its totality. That if you think that it is possible for me to see. So Bhagavan said, okay, I think you are ready for it. You come to that level of understanding that the only barrier left is your own intellect. The only barrier left is your own conditioning.

You have accepted fully that my self and the selves of others are one and the same. By inference, we have come to the conclusion that we cannot be anything but part of the same self. If the Lord created this universe out of his Self -- no other material was available to him, and both the universe and the Lord exist -- then the material for this universe is the Lord's Self. If my self is created out of the Lord's Self, then my self and his self cannot be different. So is the case for everything else which I see.

However, that oneness which I should feel -- which I am feeling in my own body, in my own limited self -- I have complete oneness there. There is never an argument about the left hand versus the right hand, no argument about the right eye versus the left eye. If one is weak, the other takes over. You don't even realize when that happens, because there's a complete oneness in it. But that's not happening with my family members or my community members. If someone is suffering, to some extent I will help, but not to the extent that I would help myself.

Arjuna said, let me see that oneness with all beings. In Verse 5, Sri Bhagavan Vacha Pashame Partharu Pani Satasa Athah Sahastra Saha Nana Vidhani Divyani Nana Varana Krutinicha. Krishna says: I will let you see my form which has hundreds and thousands of forms in it, various types of divine shapes and colors. In my own being you will see hundreds and thousands of forms -- the forms which you have seen till now and forms which you have not seen -- in a flash, all at once. So you will see hundreds and thousands of forms, various colors, various types, and various shapes. And in the next verse he says Pashya, Aditya, Rudra, Asvinau, Marutahata, Bahuni, Adristha, Purvani, Pasha, Acharyani, Bharada.

He said, not only will you see the forms you are familiar with, but you will also see forms you are not familiar with. Not only the forms and beings which you want to see in one, but also the divine beings which you have been worshipping as someone other than this world. All these deities they were worshiping in Vedic times -- Aditya (Surya), Rudra (basically Shiva, the aspect of destruction in the Trinity), Vasu, all these various deities of nature, Maruta the wind God -- all the gods which you have been worshipping, you will see them also in the same being. Currently your understanding is that this is Mrityu Lok. We are the mortal beings, and the divine beings are separate. So we worship the divine beings as mortals.

And they seem to be completely different from myself and the selves of the people in the mortal world. But Bhagavan says, when you see them -- those divine beings -- all will be part of the one self, my own self, your own self. And you will see all that. Then Bahuni Adrishta Purvani -- even things you never imagined or thought about before, Sacchara and Achara, the moving and unmoving beings, you will see as one self. Yacha Anya Drastum Ichasi -- he says, here in this one location, everything is complete without leaving anything out. The whole universe centered in one being, including all the moving and unmoving.

As I said, you will see all these things, plus whatever else you desire to see. Because, you see, we always have a conception of divinity. A Hindu will say, when Bhagavan appears, in what form will he come? Either Rama or Krishna or Shiva -- and that too in the same form as we have been seeing in calendars and pictures. If he comes in a different form, we don't accept him as Bhagavan. He has to have the mukut and all those things. So, whatever you want to see, you will see in myself.

However, the technical difficulty is that you won't be able to see it with your natural eyes. Natu maam shakya seydrastum anay neva swachakshusa Divyam dadami teksuhu pashame yogameshwaram. No matter how much we are taught to look at the world differently, unless we change our way of seeing things, we'll always go back to seeing what we were seeing before. To learn new things and to look at this world in a different way, we have to change our perception. So Divyam dadami tejaksho -- I'm giving you this divine vision, meaning I'm going to change your way of seeing things.

The way of my seeing things right now may be well, I am this and you are that. After about two generations we call ourselves, we are Indians and they are Americans. Somebody says, are you not American also? You're an American citizen. You had been living here for like 30 years. No, no, I'm an Indian or I'm an American, but I'm Indian.

Till I change my perception of seeing myself as part of this country, as an American, I will never be able to see myself as part of it. Nothing changes, but my perception about seeing things changes. That perception change is very much required. Go outside right now. The way you see this world, no matter how much I tell you to see it as one -- we can say the space is in the room, or the room is in the space. I can continue seeing this space in the room until I start visualizing that the space is everywhere, including in this room. And that visualization has to change.

The perception has to change to see what Arjuna wanted to see. So now Swamiji says, what is it that stands between my perception and the unity of myself and yourself? There are two things. One is, I am separated from you by the space between us. This conditioned self and that conditioned self have a space between them.

So as soon as we have this perception of space, we create this world of plurality. This space, just like anything that we can imagine, is an imaginary thing. Is there space in existence? When you put two things, a space is created between two things. If you remove both, there is no space. Space can only be seen in relationship to the objects we perceive.

How much space is between you and me can only be defined by first defining where you and I are. If you remove "you" and "I," there is no space to be measured. So this space is a conception of my mind. Once I conceived of myself as an entity separate from you as an entity, the space was created. And then the second thing which separates myself and others is time.

I met such and such person yesterday, but he's not here today. So I'm separated from him by time. My father lived in a different time. I'm living in a different time. I'm separated by time.

From Einstein onward, we know time is nothing but a concept of our mind. Time depends on the position of the observer. When we say we are seeing the same thing at the same time, it depends on where you and I are. We see the stars at night and say, "That star is doing this right now." But we know the light takes many, many years to come here. So what we see today actually existed many years ago, but we consider it "now."

We consider that in the past. We consider what we'll see tomorrow is in future. Now all this thing is dependent on my station point in life. My time is defined by my conditioning.
snippets.reflection:
In these verses, Krishna promises to show Arjuna forms "by hundreds and thousands, various in kind, in colour and in shape" - including the Adityas, Vasus, Rudras, Ashvins, and Maruts. But crucially, Krishna warns that Arjuna cannot see this with his ordinary eyes - a divine vision (divya chakshus) must be granted. This points to a fundamental limitation we all face: our programmed way of seeing the world keeps us trapped in duality. We are conditioned from birth to see "I" as separate from "the world," and this conditioning acts like a filter that obscures unity.

Consider how your perception creates your reality. The same situation can be seen as a threat by one person and an opportunity by another - nothing changes except the way of seeing. Krishna is essentially telling Arjuna: "I will change your paradigm, not the world itself." What paradigms or mental filters are you currently looking through? How might your relationships, work, and daily experiences transform if you could truly see through a lens of interconnection rather than separation?

Today, practice shifting your perspective intentionally. When you see individual objects - trees, cars, people - try to also perceive the space that contains them all. When you notice differences between yourself and others, simultaneously recognize what you share: consciousness, the desire for happiness, the experience of being alive. This practice of holding both perspectives - the many and the One - is the beginning of developing that "divine sight" Krishna speaks of.

snippets.title: Day 144: Arjuna's Terror
snippets.sanskrit:
इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम् |

न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा |

सञ्जय उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
ihaikasthaṃ jagatkṛtsnaṃ paśyādya sacarācaram .

na tu māṃ śakyase draṣṭumanenaiva svacakṣuṣā .

sañjaya uvāca .
verseTranslations: Here in Me living as one, O Arjuna, behold the whole universe, movable and immovable, and anything else that thou wouldst see!
Yet since with mortal eyes thou canst not see Me, lo! I give thee the Divine Sight. See now the glory of My Sovereignty."
Sanjaya continued: "Having thus spoken, O King, the Lord Shri Krishna, the Almighty Prince of Wisdom, showed to Arjuna the Supreme Form of the Great God.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan. We discussed that after listening to the glories of the divine, we, at least as seekers, understand how to see divinity in the world of plurality with respect. But at the same token, we all have the exact same issue: even though I can intellectually appreciate this, even though I can see the argument about the unity of all things, that's not my personal experience. My personal experience is something other than that. I do feel very clearly separated from the world as an entity. And that's exactly Arjuna's opening question.

Basically saying that I am completely satisfied with your explanation. Out of your compassion, you give it to me, you explain to me your glory. I also understand that you are the source of everything and you will be the resting place for everything. However, I want to see all that into one. All that vision I need to see. It is a one unified vision where I feel that oneness with this world.

With that request, Bhagavan said, yes, I can show you that because you are ready. A seeker reaches a point where he really wants to know -- and that's where Arjuna is now. Krishna is saying, you are at that point where I can show you this. However, no matter how hard you try, you will not be able to see this with your normal eyes. In other words, the way you are trained or programmed to see this world as separate individuals will not allow you to see the unity. We are programmed right from our birth: this is me, this individual limited being is me, this body and mind-intellect is me.

Our psyche is programmed to see that way. As long as we see the waves in the ocean as individual waves, not part of the ocean, we won't see the unity. Unless you change the perspective, the perception, the paradigm, you will not be able to see the unity. Therefore, you will not be able to see this with your normal eyes. I have to give you a divine Drashti -- divine eyes, another way of looking at this world than you are used to. The same thing can be seen by two different people, and one person sees something in it while the other person sees something else. It all depends on my perspective, on how I see things. You know those riddles: what do you see in this picture? Do you see a glass, or do you see two people facing each other? It depends on whether you're seeing the negative space or the positive space. So Bhagavan said, I need to change your way of seeing, and so I will give you a Divya Drashti.

And we obviously know that at the same time, when Arjuna gets Divya Drashti, Sanjaya automatically gets it too, because he already had the divine vision given to him -- the ability to see what's happening on the battlefield of Kurukshetra. Not only can he see what's happening physically on the battlefield, he can also peer into the minds of the people who are fighting that battle. So he can see what Arjuna sees. He can also feel what Arjuna feels. And he can narrate all of this to his audience. So Bhagavan fulfilled his promise and told Arjuna, I will let you see the cosmic form.

In other words, seeing this entire cosmos as one. Right now, we see the entire cosmos as, at a minimum, two: I and the cosmos. Even though I theoretically know that myself is not outside this cosmos or this world, when I become an observer, I exclude myself from the observed, which is the world. That perception was created the day I was born, when the first thought "this is me" arose. The I, the ego, was born and associated with this limited being. It excluded me from everything else which I observe as an observer.

And to remove this, I need to first remove the I-ness. So the different perception which Bhagavan is giving him is to combine all these things into one. As we say, the only thing which divides us is the space between you and me, and the time between me and others. Take these two concepts out of my perception, and the world becomes one entity. If there are droplets of water on my table, each droplet has its own existence because it is divided from the other droplet by space.

But we know they came out of the same glass of water. Once the identification with the droplet is developed, two droplets become individuals, and they are apart from each other. Bhagavan said, I need to change your perception. It's not that I'm going to change the world -- I'm going to change your perception. With this normal, programmed perception of yours, you will never be able to see oneness.

Therefore, temporarily, I want to take this limitation away from you. As long as I'm programmed to see this space as room space, I will have difficulty combining it with the universal space outside. But if I change my perception and look at it from outside, then I can combine them. A good example would be: we are walking down Knuckles Road and you can see the trees all separated. You go a little further up to a bird's eye view, and the streets start coming together. When you are at 15,000 feet in an airplane flying from Richmond Airport and look down at Richmond, it looks like one big entity -- everything becomes part of it. Right now from ground level, everything is individual. Every building has its own identity, every street has its own identity, every lamp post has its own identity. Just go to 15,000 feet above and have a view -- all these merge into one complex. You go even further up, and all things merge into completely one.

Bhagavan is taking Arjuna into that 25,000-foot view of this cosmos. So then what Arjuna saw, Sanjaya saw through Arjuna's eyes and mind. What follows is Sanjaya's honest attempt to tell Dhritarashtra what Arjuna is experiencing. Verses 9, 10, and 11 say: Evamuktva tatvarajan Maha Yogeshwaro Harihi Darsaya Maa Saparthaya Paramam Rupam Aishwaram. Having said that Arjuna will not be able to see this with his normal perception, that his perception must change, and that Krishna will help him do that -- now, having said this, O Rajan, O King, the Maha Yogeshwara Hari, because he was the Lord of the Yogas, could do that for Arjuna.

Right now I'm connected with my world, with my limited perception, but the Lord of Yoga can change my connection. Maha Yogeshwara Harihi -- Hari is one who removes ignorance. He is the Yogi who can connect this mundane state of existence with that universal state. He is the Lord of Yoga. He showed Arjuna -- Dasaya Masparthaya Paramam Rupam Aishwaram -- the supreme form of his being.

Basically, this just confirmed that Krishna fulfilled his promise to Arjuna to show him the cosmic form. The next verse is Sanjaya's quick attempt to paint what he is seeing through Arjuna's eyes for Dhritarashtra. So he says Anek Vaktra Nayanam Anek Adhut Darshana. When we are overwhelmed by something, we can't really go into detail about what's happening. "Oh, I think there's chaos here. People are running around."

Think of the description of 9/11 -- in the first few hours there is panic, fear, the cloud, the smoke coming out. People are running in the streets. Nobody knows what's happening. But generally, this is what I can say. The first journalist has to narrate to the world what's happening, and if it's on radio and not on TV, he can only describe impressions. So Sanjaya says Anek Vaktra Nayanam: I see many mouths and many eyes.

Anek Adbhut Darshanam -- there are so many wonderful sights. Adbhut means something which I have not seen normally. In this one form of the Supreme Being, I see many mouths, many eyes, and many wonderful sights. Anek Divya Abharanam -- many divine ornaments. Divya Aneko Yata Yudham -- and many divine weapons uplifted.

Obviously he's seeing the whole thing on the battlefield, so the first thing that comes to his mind is the weapons. Many mouths, many hands, many wonderful sights, many different types of clothes, and many different weapons lifted. People are ready to kill each other, but there are not separate people here. One being, in his Supreme form -- I see all of that all at once.

Divya Mallya Ambaradharam -- he continues because he doesn't know where to start and where to end. He said, many mouths, all of this, and not only that, but I'm seeing Divya Mallya Ambaradharam. Typically the things we notice: divine garlands, divine clothes. Divya Gandhanulaipanam -- with very divine fragrance. All the lepas, the pastes you apply. Obviously in our culture there is a lot of paste-applying, so very different types of paste.

Sarva Ascharimayam Devam Anantam Vishwato Mukham -- everything is so fascinating. There's nothing normal about it. I can't say, "Remember last time we went to such-and-such, and it was something similar." I can't do that. There is no experience I can relate to this vision of the Supreme. That's why he is grabbing a word from here and a perception from there and just throwing it at Dhritarashtra, saying, "That's what Arjuna is experiencing right now."

I don't know whether you can comprehend or not. Divya Mallya Ambaradharam Sarva Aschariyamayam Devam Anantam -- this divine vision is Anantham, infinite. It's not something I can say starts here and ends here. Arjuna wanted to see the cosmic form in Krishna. He says, show me your cosmic form. Krishna obviously is finite.

He stands here and Arjuna stands here and the army is all around him. It's not that this vision is limited to the form of Krishna, however tall he was. This is infinite. What Arjuna is seeing is infinite. There is no end to it. There is no beginning he can see.

There is no end he can see. All he sees is hundreds and thousands of mouths, legs, clothes, malas, lamps, weapons, and wonderful sights. Everything is fascinating. I have nothing I can explain to you. Anandam Vishwa Tomukham -- facing all sides. Vishwa, the cosmos, is facing everywhere. In other words, this is something that cannot be limited to Krishna's being.

This vision is beyond any perception that we have ever had. As we have been discussing in Bhagavad Gita, the simple quest in life for any being is to exist. This is the basic instinct. What we want to preserve out of everything else is our existence. Therefore, this fear of death -- that my existence is temporary, that it began at my birth (time T1) and will end at my death (time T2).

And as I always say, those two events are hypothetical. Nobody has ever experienced their own birth and death. But I have come to this conclusion from inferences, Anumana. I have seen other people being born and I have seen other people dying. Therefore, I have come to the conclusion that my existence is temporary. Remember the very old song.

Maybe Anil will remember. Ae zindagi ki mele e zindagi ki melee Dunyame kam nahonge upsource. Hum nahonge upsource. I wish I will be there, but I will not be there. All this wonderful world will continue and I wish I would be there, but I will not be there. That's my biggest fear.

That's my essential quest in life to exist. And then we heard from Bhagavan in last few chapters.
snippets.reflection:
These verses mark the pivotal moment when Krishna grants Arjuna the divine vision and Sanjaya begins narrating what unfolds. Krishna declares: "Here in Me living as one, O Arjuna, behold the whole universe, movable and immovable." The key insight is that we normally see ourselves as observers separate from what we observe. The moment the ego was born in us - that first thought of "this is me" - we excluded ourselves from everything else. To see unity, this sense of separation must temporarily dissolve.

Think about how you constantly position yourself as an observer of life rather than a participant in its wholeness. When watching news of a disaster, do you feel "that is happening to them, not me"? When celebrating another's success, is there a subtle sense of "their gain, not mine"? This observer-observed split is the fundamental illusion Krishna is removing from Arjuna's perception. The divine vision combines all things into one - not by changing the world, but by changing the way of seeing.

For today's practice, experiment with dissolving the observer-observed boundary. When you look at a tree, instead of thinking "I am seeing the tree," try experiencing "seeing is happening." When in conversation, rather than "I am listening to you," sense simply "listening is occurring." This subtle shift - from "I" doing something to simply experiencing awareness itself - offers a glimpse of what it means to see the universe "living as one" within the divine. Notice what changes when you are no longer the separate observer but simply awareness witnessing itself.

snippets.title: Day 145: Return to Grace
snippets.sanskrit:
अनेकवक्त्रनयनमनेकाद्भुतदर्शनम् |

दिव्यमाल्याम्बरधरं दिव्यगन्धानुलेपनम् |

दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता |
snippets.transliteration:
anekavaktranayanamanekādbhutadarśanam .

divyamālyāmbaradharaṃ divyagandhānulepanam .

divi sūryasahasrasya bhavedyugapadutthitā .
verseTranslations: There were countless eyes and mouths, and mystic forms innumerable, with shining ornaments and flaming celestial weapons.
Crowned with heavenly garlands, clothed in shining garments, anointed with divine unctions, He showed Himself as the Resplendent One, Marvellous, Boundless, Omnipresent.
Could a thousand suns blaze forth together it would be but a faint reflection of the radiance of the Lord God.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 11, Vishwarupadarsha Yoga of Cosmic Form. So far we have seen in Bhagavad Gita that the quest for each individual is to understand who Bhagavan is. We try in different ways to conceptualize Bhagavan. And we typically hear that people want to see Bhagavan as a person. But all philosophers basically tell us Bhagavan is not a person -- he's not a man, he's not a woman, he's not it, he's not he, he's not she. So how one can conceptualize Bhagavan is a riddle.

If you see the Abrahamic religions, they forbid any picture of God. What God looks like is not possible to depict. Therefore they say, do not draw. Do not create an image which can falsify the image of God in your mind. Our religion, on the other hand, makes a very daring attempt to describe Bhagavan. So chapter 11, by Bhagavan Ved Vyas, is a great attempt to describe what Bhagavan would look like if you ever have his darshan.

So far we have seen that Arjuna said: I have understood everything you have said -- that Aham Aksaram Brahma Paramam, I am that imperishable being, I am the source of things and beings. I have no doubt. He said Etat Atha -- that means, so be it. I understood, no question about it. I'm convinced that this is what your nature is, that you are the source of all beings. But how do I contemplate upon you?

How do I meditate upon you? Because you told me: meditate on myself, and you will become myself. So Bhagavan Ved Vyas takes us on Arjuna's journey and asks, how does he see it? Arjuna makes a request, and Bhagavan grants it and says, okay, I will show you my total form that nobody has seen before. But you won't be able to see it with your natural vision. I have to give you a divine vision.

I'll give you a divine perspective. With your perspective today, you will not be able to understand this. The things themselves don't change -- but when we change our perspective, we see things in a very different light. Things we have only seen from one narrow perspective suddenly look different.

So right now we are seeing the world from our narrow perspective of I, the limited being. Then conceptualize what would be that greater self. We are part of the plurality. We want to experience singularity. Bhagavan Krishna told Arjuna, I will change your vision. And Bhagavan Bedya has already given that divine vision to Sanjaya.

Sanjaya can see everything that is happening on Kurukshetra. And whatever Arjuna sees, he sees too. So Sanjaya saw the form and described it to Dhritarashtra, as we have seen in the last few verses. He confirmed: yes, Krishna granted this vision to Arjuna. He said Anek Vaktra Nayanam, Anek Adbhut Darshanam, Aneka Divya Abharanam. Everything I see in my world is included in it.

I see various types of dresses, various types of ornaments, various types of fragrances. All that he is saying is Anek vaktra Nayanam. As we have discussed last time, if I take the concept of space out of my mind by some magic, then everything will lump into one. All hands will be of that one big body of a person. And all hands are his, all mouths are his, all eyes are his. Because now I'm seeing it from my world's perspective.

We always see things from our own perspective. We see things based on what we already know. So if I have to describe something which you have not seen before, I can only describe it from the perspective of what you already know. Do you know where Short Pump is? I don't know where Short Pump is. Do you know where that Walmart is?

Okay, well, that's Short Pump. You need a reference point you already know to get you to Walmart, and then you can put together in your mind what that place should look like. So now, as Bhagavan is giving Arjuna this vision, Sanjaya is putting together in his mind what he has seen in his world: many mouths, many hands, many different types of dresses, many different types of fragrances. Aneka Divya Abharanam.

Then he says, Divya, Mallya, Ambar, Dharam, same thing. Whatever I have seen in my world, I Now see in that form and Sarva ascharimayam Devammanantam everything is very wonderful and infinite. I cannot describe what it is from our perspective. When we try to put together things in one vision, it looks really infinite. We try to find out how wide this universe is. We have to simply say it's infinite.

Because we can't really imagine it. We see the stars, we see the moon. But what is the nature of the cosmic infinite, Anant? Now, if I really take my gaze from my world to the outer world, then he says what you see is Yadibaha Divi Surya Sahasrasya Bhavet Yukpat Uthita. In my world, I see one sun rising every morning, and I know the splendor of that sun.

That splendor is incomparable. In my world, there's nothing I can compare to the sun's splendor. When we design light, designing a surgery room, we have to mimic the sunlight. So you have to come close to the sunlight from your artificial light. You are still only talking about the sunlight. As we experience this far away from sun.

But to experience the sun where it is and to look at it directly -- it's splendid. We can hardly look at it. Now imagine that all the space between all the stars is removed, and all the stars, all the suns in this cosmos, all come together. The splendor of that entity -- all the thousands of stars together! We can look at the sky and look at the stars because they're so far away. By the time the light comes to us, it's so feeble that they look like twinkling stars.

But if they all come together -- because you have removed space and time from your mind -- they all come together at the same time. Therefore, Divi Surya Sahasrasya Yadi Bhaha: if thousands of suns were rising in the sky, if you can imagine that -- Sadrushi Sat Bhasah Tasya Mahatmanaha -- even that cannot describe the splendor of that great being, that Mahatma. Because he is the stars, he is the moon, he is everything that we can think of. Therefore, we cannot draw his picture.

Because everything that I can imagine as part of this cosmos, Bhagavan said, it is me. Then this is my Eightfold prakriti that includes everything they can think of. Bhoomi apah analaha kam vayuhu mana buddhi ahanka. So space is part of that manifestation, everything else I can imagine. Now, if I say that I have Bhagavan's darshan, all that darshan has to come together in one. Therefore it is not possible.

But what we try to do as human beings is personify all that divinity in one person. So therefore he said, Bhagavan, I'm seeing this vision in your body. Even in our life, what we do is take all the divinity that we can think of or we have imagined, and we assign that to one person. We want to see it all in one person. So therefore we say, "Bhagavan, I see all that in Swami Chinmayananda," somebody says. "I saw all that in Bhagavan Rajneesh," somebody else says. Because we gather all that conceptualization of divinity and want to see it in one person.

And then we get disappointed because a person by very nature cannot have all the attributes of that entire divinity. But if we change our perspective, then we will be able to see that. So Bhagavan said, yadibaha divi Surya Sahastrasya Bhavet yukpat Uthita Sadrushi saa saad Bhasah Tasya mahat manah. The splendor of that being which represents totality is like thousands of suns. You cannot describe it. Tatra Ekastam, Jagat Krishnam, Pravibhaktam, Anekata -- it's all centered into one.

Because that's what Arjuna asked for. I want to see all that centered into you, all in one. Right now I see them as Pravibhakta, different parts. I know this cosmos exist as nature, as Lord's manifestation, but in different parts I can manage. I can manage to understand. It is your world, his world, her world, my planet, different planets.

There are different parts of his manifestation. From my narrow perspective, I can understand it. But now he says, Tatra Ekastam is centered into one Jagat Krushnam. The entire Jagat Jagat includes everything. Jagat includes your physical cosmos as well as your emotional cosmos and your intellectual cosmos. Everything that you can think of that the greatness of our Hinduism, it has included in Astra, Prakriti, mind, intellect and ego.

Without that, your world is not complete. If I can put all this together, one person and what that vision would be, that's what Arjuna is seeing right now. In that Mahatma Deva Devashya Sari re. Arjuna saw in the body of the God of Gods. Krishna is no longer a person. Dhritarashtra can relate to who he knew as the king of Yadavas or Pandava's ally.

But now he says he's a Deva Devasya, the God of all the gods. So he said, I see the Maruta and I see Rudras, all these Devas, all the deities which he is the God of all those deities. Everything that we have imagined, who has the control over this world, he has control over all of them. Deva Deveshary, Pandavahatada, Pandava Arjuna. Arjuna saw in the body of that God of gods this splendor of thousands of suns blazing at the same time. So what could be the reaction of Arjuna Vishma Yavista overcame by the wonderment?

He's completely dumbfounded. Rustiroma is here standing on hands. I don't know if the English translation of in our language it's very well used. Goosebumps is the only thing come to my mind in English. He's having goosebumps. He's completely dumbfounded looking at this.

He asked for it, but did not know what to expect. Now he's seeing in the body of the God of Gods, because all that vision is personified in one person. Ristiroma Dhananjaya Dhananjaya again Arjuna Pranasya Silasadvam. Once you have that experience, as soon as you see him in his true nature -- Pranamya Sirasadevam -- as soon as he realized the nature of this total being, he is completely surrendered. We don't surrender right now because we don't think this is all true, even though we kind of learn and all that.

But when it comes to our life, we say, no, no, I have better control. I have people come to me and say, stop coming to class. They think it was actually giving them less motivation to do things in the world. So right now our motivation in working in the world is that we don't have much trust in him. We don't think he can take care of it. I really need to look out for myself, look out for number one.

That used to be a mantra when I came to this country. Somebody said, think about number one. Number one is you -- start from thinking about yourself first, then comes everybody else. Your family, your children, and so on. Start from you, take care of yourself first and then go to others. But here Arjuna realized that he is nobody compared to what he is seeing. He is insignificant in relation to this cosmic form.

So Pranaam Sirasa Devam Dandavat Pranam -- he does full prostration. Pranamya Sirasadevam. Once you have understood the greatness of who you are relating to, you are completely surrendered to him.
snippets.reflection:
Sanjaya attempts to describe the indescribable: countless eyes and mouths, mystic forms innumerable, divine ornaments, celestial weapons, and a radiance compared to a thousand suns blazing simultaneously. This famous verse - "divi surya sahasrasya" - has inspired countless seekers because it points to something beyond ordinary comprehension. When we try to imagine even one sun's full brilliance (which we cannot look at directly), multiply that by a thousand, and realize this still falls short of the divine splendor.

The teaching here is about the limitations of description and the necessity of direct experience. Sanjaya can only use references Dhritarashtra knows - ornaments, weapons, forms, colors - to describe what transcends all categories. Similarly, when we speak about ultimate reality, we can only point toward it using familiar concepts. This is why the vision cannot be transmitted through words alone; it must be experienced. Notice how your own spiritual understanding may be limited by the concepts and images available to you.

Today, try this contemplation: Imagine removing all the space between every object in your visual field - all the stars, all beings, all things compressed into one point of infinite density. What would remain? The "thousand suns" metaphor suggests pure, undifferentiated radiance - consciousness itself before it manifests as particular forms. When you see any light today - sunlight, a lamp, a candle - let it remind you that this visible light is merely a pale reflection of the light of awareness that illuminates all your experiences. Ask yourself: What is the light by which I see this light?

Thereupon Arjuna, dumb with awe, his hair on end, his head bowed, his hands clasped in salutation, addressed the Lord thus:
Arjuna said: O almighty God! I see in Thee the powers of Nature, the various creatures of the world, the Progenitor on his lotus throne, the Sages and the shining angels.
