Arjuna makes a request, and Bhagavan grants it and says, okay, I will show you my total form that nobody has seen before. But you won't be able to see it with your natural vision. I have to give you a divine vision.

I'll give you a divine perspective. With your perspective today, you will not be able to understand this. The things themselves don't change -- but when we change our perspective, we see things in a very different light. Things we have only seen from one narrow perspective suddenly look different.

So right now we are seeing the world from our narrow perspective of I, the limited being. Then conceptualize what would be that greater self. We are part of the plurality. We want to experience singularity. Bhagavan Krishna told Arjuna, I will change your vision. And Bhagavan Bedya has already given that divine vision to Sanjaya.

Sanjaya can see everything that is happening on Kurukshetra. And whatever Arjuna sees, he sees too. So Sanjaya saw the form and described it to Dhritarashtra, as we have seen in the last few verses. He confirmed: yes, Krishna granted this vision to Arjuna. He said Anek Vaktra Nayanam, Anek Adbhut Darshanam, Aneka Divya Abharanam. Everything I see in my world is included in it.

I see various types of dresses, various types of ornaments, various types of fragrances. All that he is saying is Anek vaktra Nayanam. As we have discussed last time, if I take the concept of space out of my mind by some magic, then everything will lump into one. All hands will be of that one big body of a person. And all hands are his, all mouths are his, all eyes are his. Because now I'm seeing it from my world's perspective.

We always see things from our own perspective. We see things based on what we already know. So if I have to describe something which you have not seen before, I can only describe it from the perspective of what you already know. Do you know where Short Pump is? I don't know where Short Pump is. Do you know where that Walmart is?

Okay, well, that's Short Pump. You need a reference point you already know to get you to Walmart, and then you can put together in your mind what that place should look like. So now, as Bhagavan is giving Arjuna this vision, Sanjaya is putting together in his mind what he has seen in his world: many mouths, many hands, many different types of dresses, many different types of fragrances. Aneka Divya Abharanam.

Then he says, Divya, Mallya, Ambar, Dharam, same thing. Whatever I have seen in my world, I Now see in that form and Sarva ascharimayam Devammanantam everything is very wonderful and infinite. I cannot describe what it is from our perspective. When we try to put together things in one vision, it looks really infinite. We try to find out how wide this universe is. We have to simply say it's infinite.

Because we can't really imagine it. We see the stars, we see the moon. But what is the nature of the cosmic infinite, Anant? Now, if I really take my gaze from my world to the outer world, then he says what you see is Yadibaha Divi Surya Sahasrasya Bhavet Yukpat Uthita. In my world, I see one sun rising every morning, and I know the splendor of that sun.

That splendor is incomparable. In my world, there's nothing I can compare to the sun's splendor. When we design light, designing a surgery room, we have to mimic the sunlight. So you have to come close to the sunlight from your artificial light. You are still only talking about the sunlight. As we experience this far away from sun.

But to experience the sun where it is and to look at it directly -- it's splendid. We can hardly look at it. Now imagine that all the space between all the stars is removed, and all the stars, all the suns in this cosmos, all come together. The splendor of that entity -- all the thousands of stars together! We can look at the sky and look at the stars because they're so far away. By the time the light comes to us, it's so feeble that they look like twinkling stars.

But if they all come together -- because you have removed space and time from your mind -- they all come together at the same time. Therefore, Divi Surya Sahasrasya Yadi Bhaha: if thousands of suns were rising in the sky, if you can imagine that -- Sadrushi Sat Bhasah Tasya Mahatmanaha -- even that cannot describe the splendor of that great being, that Mahatma. Because he is the stars, he is the moon, he is everything that we can think of. Therefore, we cannot draw his picture.

Because everything that I can imagine as part of this cosmos, Bhagavan said, it is me. Then this is my Eightfold prakriti that includes everything they can think of. Bhoomi apah analaha kam vayuhu mana buddhi ahanka. So space is part of that manifestation, everything else I can imagine. Now, if I say that I have Bhagavan's darshan, all that darshan has to come together in one. Therefore it is not possible.

But what we try to do as human beings, we personify that reason in one person. So therefore he said, bhagavan, I'm seeing this vision in your body. Even in our life, what we do is all the divinity that we can think of or we have imagined of. We assign that to one person. We want to see that in one person. So therefore we say, bhagavan, I see all that in Swami Chinbananda somebody says, I saw all that in Bhagavan Rajneesh, somebody says, because we gather all that conceptualization of divinity into one person, we want to see that in one person.

And then we get disappointed because a person by very nature cannot have all the attributes of that entire divinity. But if we change our perspective, then we will be able to see that. So Bhagavan said, yadibaha divi Surya Sahastrasya Bhavet yukpat Uthita Sadrushi saa saad Bhasah Tasya mahat manah. Splendor of that being which represents totality, heirs of thousands of sons. You cannot describe it. Tatra Ekastam, Jagat Krishnam, Pravibhaktam, Anekata, it's all centered into one.

Because that's what Arjuna asked for. I want to see all that centered into you, all in one. Right now I see them as Pravibhakta, different parts. I know this cosmos exist as nature, as Lord's manifestation, but in different parts I can manage. I can manage to understand. It is your world, his world, her world, my planet, different planets.

There are different parts of his manifestation. From my narrow perspective, I can understand it. But now he says, Tatra Ekastam is centered into one Jagat Krushnam. The entire Jagat Jagat includes everything. Jagat includes your physical cosmos as well as your emotional cosmos and your intellectual cosmos. Everything that you can think of that the greatness of our Hinduism, it has included in Astra, Prakriti, mind, intellect and ego.

Without that, your world is not complete. If I can put all this together, one person and what that vision would be, that's what Arjuna is seeing right now. In that Mahatma Deva Devashya Sari re. Arjuna saw in the body of the God of Gods. Krishna is no longer a person. Dhritarashtra can relate to who he knew as the king of Yadavas or Pandava's ally.

But now he says he's a Deva Devasya, the God of all the gods. So he said, I see the Maruta and I see Rudras, all these Devas, all the deities which he is the God of all those deities. Everything that we have imagined, who has the control over this world, he has control over all of them. Deva Deveshary, Pandavahatada, Pandava Arjuna. Arjuna saw in the body of that God of gods this splendor of thousands of suns blazing at the same time. So what could be the reaction of Arjuna Vishma Yavista overcame by the wonderment?

He's completely dumbfounded. Rustiroma is here standing on hands. I don't know if the English translation of in our language it's very well used. Goosebumps is the only thing come to my mind in English. He's having goosebumps. He's completely dumbfounded looking at this.

He asked for it, but did not know what to expect. Now he's seeing in the body of the God of God because he's all that vision is personified in one person. Ristiroma Dhananjaya Dhananjaya again Arjuna Pranasya Silasadvam. Once you have that experience, as soon as you see him, Chamatkar I may not believe anything about when he does Chamatkar, he takes out a Rolex watch and gives you namaskar right there. So Pranamya Sirasadevam, as soon as he realized the nature of this total being is surrendered. We don't surrender right now because we don't think this is all true, even though we kind of learn and all that.

But when it comes to our life, we say, no, no, I have better control. I have people come to me and say, stop coming to class. I think it was actually giving him less motivation to do things. So right now our motivation in working in a world is we don't have much trust in him. We don't think he can take care of it. I really need to look out for myself, look out for number one.

That used to be a mantra when I came to this country. Somebody has started and said, think about number one. Number one is you start from thinking about you first, then comes everybody else. Your family, your children, your. Start from you take care of yourself first and then go to. But here he said he realized that he is nobody with whom he is relating to what he is seeing Nobody.

So Pranaam is Sirasa Devam Dandavat Pranam Only the South Indians do that Dandavat Pranayama Punjabi is doing Mathotic they just put the head on and Gujaratvi yeah Pranamya Sirasadevam, Once you have understood the greatness of who you are relating to, you are completely surrendered to him.
snippets.reflection:
In these verses, Arjuna sees the entire universe with its manifold forms "all embraced in One" - the supreme Lord. His response is immediate and visceral: dumb with awe, hair standing on end, head bowed, hands clasped in salutation. He sees all the powers of Nature, the various creatures, the Progenitor Brahma on his lotus throne, the Sages, and the shining angels. Notice the dramatic shift: the moment Arjuna truly perceives Krishna's nature, spontaneous surrender arises. He does not decide to bow; bowing happens naturally.

This points to why we do not surrender in daily life - we have not truly seen. We may intellectually accept spiritual teachings, but when push comes to shove, we still believe we have better control, that we need to "look out for number one." Arjuna's goosebumps and spontaneous prostration show what happens when intellectual understanding becomes direct perception. The teaching suggests that true surrender is not an act of will but a natural response to genuine recognition of the divine.

Reflect today on your relationship with surrender. When you say "Thy will be done" or "I trust the universe," is it genuine recognition or merely words? Notice the situations where you grip tightly, trying to control outcomes. Ask yourself: What would I need to truly see for surrender to arise spontaneously? Consider that perhaps you are not lacking in willingness to surrender but in the clarity of perception that makes surrender the obvious and natural response. Practice today by consciously acknowledging your limitations in even small matters - traffic, weather, others' moods - and notice if a sense of release naturally follows this honest recognition.

snippets.title: Day 147: Universal Vision
snippets.sanskrit:
अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं

किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च

त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं
snippets.transliteration:
anekabāhūdaravaktranetraṃ paśyāmi tvāṃ sarvato.anantarūpam .

kirīṭinaṃ gadinaṃ cakriṇaṃ ca tejorāśiṃ sarvato dīptimantam .

tvamakṣaraṃ paramaṃ veditavyaṃ tvamasya viśvasya paraṃ nidhānam .
verseTranslations: I see Thee, infinite in form, with, as it were, faces, eyes and limbs everywhere; no beginning, no middle, no end; O Thou Lord of the Universe, Whose Form is universal!
I see thee with the crown, the sceptre and the discus; a blaze of splendour. Scarce can I gaze on thee, so radiant thou art, glowing like the blazing fire, brilliant as the sun, immeasurable.
Imperishable art Thou, the Sole One worthy to be known, the priceless Treasure-house of the universe, the immortal Guardian of the Life Eternal, the Spirit Everlasting.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarsha Yoga of Cosmic Form. As we have seen so far, in the beginning, Arjuna made the request saying that my delusion is gone now. Out of compassion, you explained to me that you are the source of all beings. You are the resting place of all beings. Nothing exists which is away from you. Everything I see is the manifestation of you alone.

So now my delusion is gone about what is right and what is wrong. However, I would like to see that form of yours in its totality in one place. In the previous chapters we have seen his Prakriti Astada Prakruti. So you can say you can experience, you are seeing it every day. His Eightfold Prakriti, you are experiencing and seeing every day. But I still can't see it in one place.

I basically see as the plurality what I want to see as one entity. That's basically what we are all struggling with. Intellectually, we understand what Bhagavad Gita says. But when it comes to day-to-day life, it is very difficult to comprehend. So Arjuna said, my delusion is gone. I understand, but I want to see it, I want to experience it.

And in response, Bhagavan said that if you wish to, I will show you, but you will not be able to see it from your present way of looking at the world, from your present eyes. You will not be able to see it the way you see the world right now -- it will remain divided. Because right now I see my world as I, an individual, and everything else as individual entities. If I see it that way, I will never be able to see the unity in them. If I change my perspective and see it from the singularity's point of view, and include myself in it, then I'll be able to see it.

That's you have to change your perspective. So I'll give you that perspective. Divyam Dadami te Chakshuhu. I'll give you that vision and then you will be able to see. Having said that, he showed the Swarupa, and Sanjaya was the witness. He confirmed that, yes, Yogeshwara Krishna showed Arjuna his Virat Swarupa. And Sanjaya described on his own what Arjuna saw: Aneka Vaktra Bahu -- many mouths and many hands, as if thousands of suns were blazing in the sky at the same time. It is so resplendent and difficult to see. He also showed us Arjuna's reaction: having seen that, Arjuna -- Pranamya Shirasa Devam -- as soon as he saw who Krishna in his real form is, he basically completely surrendered to him. And then what he said is this.

Now we are discussing from verse 15 onward. As we have discussed before, the Bhagavad Gita is generally in Anushtup Chanda. But these verses are in Trishtup Chanda, because there is more to describe. So these are much longer verses, with more words packed into each verse. This is beautiful poetry, a prayer describing the nature of the Supreme Being. From Arjuna's perspective, when he sees that Swarupa, he sees things which are common to his experiences. When we go to any other town -- like we went to New York and I say I'll go to Manhattan -- what am I going to say?

I'm going to see the buildings, 911 memorial, One World Tower, because that's the world I see is what Manhattan is all about. So now what Arjuna sees in that Swarupa is what he is familiar with. He says, pasyami Devan Tava Deva, Deva Sarvantatham Bhuta Visesanga O Deva. He doesn't say Krishna anymore, but O resplendent Being. I see in your body all the other Devas. In this Puranic culture, we have assigned deities to each force of nature, and those resplendent beings, the Devas -- he said, I see in your body all of them.

Pasyami Devan, Tava Deva Dehe. In your body I see them all. Tatha Bhuta Visesa Sangana, various groups of other beings. Brahmanam Isam, Kamala, Sanastha -- and I see the Lord Brahma. Swamiji looks at it both ways. He said, this could mean Lord Brahma, or it could mean Brahma and Isha -- Brahma and Shiva -- Kamala Sanastha sitting on the lotus. I see the whole creation in you, and I see the Creator himself.

You are the creation and you are the creator. I see everything all in one. Tatahu Rishis Cha Sarva -- and I see all the rishis. It's like everything is flashing through his eyes. Everything he has learned about divinity in this world is flashing at the same time. And also Uragan Cha Divyan -- and I see also the divine serpents.

Swamiji points out here that this is one of the techniques poets use -- to take you to the most sublime level and then bring you all the way down to the lowest of the low. So I see all the divine beings, including the Lord Creator himself, but also all the serpents. The entire universe, from the lowest of the low to the highest of the high -- I see in your body at one time. And then he says Aneka Bahu Udar Vaktra Netra. Sanjaya has already described that before to Dhritarashtra.

Now Arjuna himself says: I see infinite hands. Bahu -- hands, Udara -- stomachs, Vaktra -- mouths, Netra -- eyes. Pasyami tvam Sarvato Anantarupam: I see you facing everywhere. He is now realizing that this is not something he will be able to describe. Infinite mouths, infinite hands, infinite eyes. As we have discussed earlier, once you take the space out of our world and keep all the beings lumped as one...

Right now I have two hands and you have two hands. But when you are together there are many hands. All the hands in this world are his hands. All the legs in this world are his legs. All the mouths in this world are his mouths. He is experiencing that.

But then he says, anywhere I see -- you know, like a 360-degree movie projected all over. You are focused on one side, and what happened to the other side? Still the same movie, just different parts. But we can't describe where that movie starts and where that picture ends. We actually went to the 9/11 memorial. They have a presentation on three sides.

When people enter, they start putting their strollers against those walls as if they're just walls. Then someone comes and moves all of them because the movie is going to play on all three sides. Then we are focusing on one wall and realize, oh, there are details I'm missing on this side. And then, what about that side? We realized we will never be able to capture all three sides at the same time. It's beyond my capacity to see all three sides at once.

So Arjuna is experiencing something at a much grander scale and says, I will not be able to describe everything that I can see. Pasyami tvam Sarvato Anantarupam -- I see you everywhere with infinite forms. There is no end to what I see in you. Naantam Namadhyam Napunah Ta Adim -- we have learned this before in previous chapters.

Bhagavan himself said: I don't have any beginning, I don't have any end. I am the resting place of everything. Now Arjuna tells him: Bhagavan, I see you as you are -- no end, no beginning, no origin. Pasyami Vishweshvara Vishwaroopa -- he is accepting the fact that you are the Lord of all the universe, and this is your Vishwaroopa.

This is your infinite form. What I'm experiencing now is your real nature: you are beginningless, you have no middle and no end. Wherever we stand is the ever-present. Whatever we left behind is our past. What we have not yet experienced is our future.

But if we experience all of it at the same time, there is no beginning, no end, no past, no future. So he's seeing everything in his present. You are the Lord of the whole universe and I am seeing your Vishwaroopa. Kiritinam Gadhinam Chakrinam Cha -- as Swamiji explains here, Arjuna is now recognizing that what he's seeing is the divine form he always perceived as the Lord. Kiritinam Gadhinam Chakrinam Cha Tejo Rashim Sarvato Diptim Anantam: I see you with the crown, the club, and the discus -- the universal form of Vishnu with his four hands holding a lotus, a club, a discus, and a conch.

And then he is wearing the crown. Only one who has complete control of his self can wear the crown. Vishnu is the only one who has complete control of the self. Therefore he wears the crown, which means he has the authority. We wear the crown temporarily. Whenever I feel I am in authority, I wear my crown. But that only lasts for a limited period of time. My authority slips away before I even realize. My authority is like the cardboard crown in a drama. While I'm on this drama stage, I have that cardboard crown. As soon as I'm off this stage, the crown is gone. Vishnu carries that authority all the time. That's why he wears the crown. So he holds the lotus which signifies purity and knowledge. And then he has a conch to wake you up from your ignorance. If you don't listen to the call for waking up, then he uses his club, the gada, to shape you up. And if you shape up, all well and good. If not, the chakra will annihilate you, just destroy you. So that's how the creation and maintenance continue. Bhagavan gives you all the chances to shape up. If you don't shape up, time will take care of you.

So Arjuna sees that form as the totality. Kiritinam Gadhinam Chakrinam Cha Tejo Rashim Sarvato Diptim Anantam -- a mass of radiance. Sarvato Diptim -- blazing everywhere. In the previous verses, Sanjaya says it is like a thousand suns blazing in the sky. Here Arjuna says Tejo Rashim Sarvato Diptim Anantam -- everywhere it's blazing. And Swamiji explains that what he's seeing is not the light of any sun, but the light of the self, the consciousness, that which illumines everything. Anant Diptim -- infinite teja.

So he is experiencing resplendence of the self. Pasyami tvam Durniriksham Samantha. But it is difficult to see. It is difficult to perceive the light of consciousness itself. Through the light of my consciousness, I understand everything. I see all these things -- Kiritinam Gadhinam Chakrinam Cha -- the crown, the club, the discus. But seeing the consciousness itself, your splendid being, is difficult to see directly. From the light of my consciousness, I can describe everything. But describing my consciousness itself is not possible. So Dur Niriksham -- I cannot grasp it. Dur Niriksham Dipta Anala Arka Dyutim Aprameyam.

That light is blazing all around like fire and sun, and it's incomprehensible. He comes to the conclusion that what he is seeing is undefinable. At the same time, whatever I want to see, I'll see in it. In any museum or gallery, we go and look at the pictures.

Every visitor will see something different. Even in our world, we see what we want to see. We'll never see the things we do not want to see. As soon as we see something which is not conducive, we will run away from it. Many years ago, when I first started working on a forensic lab and medical examiner's office, the first time I met with them they shared statistics about how many people go through an autopsy, how many people die. And the statistics showed something like one in four persons goes through an autopsy.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna declares three profound realizations: he sees the Lord everywhere with "no beginning, no middle, no end"; he sees the radiance that is difficult to gaze upon, "glowing like blazing fire, brilliant as the sun, immeasurable"; and he recognizes Krishna as "Imperishable, the Sole One worthy to be known, the priceless Treasure-house of the universe, the immortal Guardian of the Life Eternal." The vision reveals that what we normally see as limited forms with clear boundaries - a beginning here, an end there - are actually expressions of something without any such limits.

Consider how we normally perceive everything with boundaries: this person started here and will end there, this project has a deadline, this relationship has a history. We carve up reality into manageable pieces. But Arjuna now sees that these boundaries are imposed by our minds, not inherent in reality itself. The crown, scepter, and discus he sees represent complete authority (crown), the power to shape (scepter), and the wheel of time and action (discus) - symbols that Krishna is not merely present in the universe but is its controller, sustainer, and essential nature.

For your practice today, look at something you consider "complete" - a finished task, a relationship that ended, a chapter of life that closed - and contemplate: Where exactly did it begin? What conditions led to those conditions? Trace backward and notice how the "beginning" dissolves into endless prior causes. Then trace forward: How does what ended continue to influence the present? See how "no beginning, no middle, no end" applies even to ordinary experiences. This contemplation can soften the rigid boundaries we place on life events and open us to sensing the continuous, beginningless, endless flow of existence.

snippets.title: Day 148: Arjuna's Terror
snippets.sanskrit:
अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य-

द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि

अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति
snippets.transliteration:
anādimadhyāntamanantavīryam anantabāhuṃ śaśisūryanetram .

dyāvāpṛthivyoridamantaraṃ hi vyāptaṃ tvayaikena diśaśca sarvāḥ .

amī hi tvāṃ surasaṅghā viśanti kecidbhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti .
verseTranslations: Without beginning, without middle and without end, infinite in power, Thine arms all-embracing, the sun and moon Thine eyes, Thy face beaming with the fire of sacrifice, flooding the whole universe with light.
Alone thou fillest all the quarters of the sky, earth and heaven, and the regions between. O Almighty Lord! Seeing Thy marvellous and awe-inspiring Form, the spheres tremble with fear.
The troops of celestial beings enter into Thee, some invoking Thee in fear, with folded palms; the Great Seers and Adepts sing hymns to Thy Glory, saying All Hail.'
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, and we'll now be discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan, the cosmic form of the Divine. In the last chapter, Arjuna had asked Krishna: tell me how I should feel your presence, the presence of the divine, the presence of that all-pervading self, and how I can meditate upon that. In response, Bhagavan gave him various examples of excellence in this world from various walks of life -- applicable to Arjuna and also to us -- showing that from our day-to-day life, from our cultural backgrounds, from our spiritual quest, we find examples all around us of excellence and can feel the Lord's presence. As we discussed in chapter 10, anytime I see excellence, my mind recognizes it as God's blessings, the grace of God. In other words, divinity is evident in excellence. Bhagavan gave various examples for Arjuna and said, when you see this, it will remind you of my presence in all things and beings. I'm not limited to those excellent manifestations, but that's where you will find it easier to experience my presence.

And now that Arjuna has heard that, he says: I'm still not experiencing that oneness, the oneness which you talk about throughout this discourse. I have intellectually appreciated it and come to the conclusion that that's what it is -- that there is one singular entity pervading this entire universe, which is you, the Supreme Self. But I need to have that experience. I would like to experience that oneness. This, as Swamiji explains, is similar to how we scientifically make any concept or theory our own knowledge. First I need to gather all the evidence and data.

And then, once I have gathered all the data and evidence, I need to demonstrate that the phenomenon exists. I gather all information about how water is formed. In chemistry class, two molecules of hydrogen and one molecule of oxygen can create water. But at some point, I want to see the demonstration -- in the lab, I create that situation and then see how hydrogen and oxygen create water. In a similar fashion, Arjuna has now understood, but he wants to see a demonstration. So the chapter starts with Arjuna Vacha.

Arjuna said: Mat Anugraha Ya Paramam Guhyam Adhyatma Sangnitam Yat Tvaya Uktam Vachasthena Moho Ayam Vigato Mama. With your compassion for me, you have given me this secret knowledge. And as you have said, the self is indestructible, imperishable. One who considers himself to be the slayer or the slain -- in both cases, he is wrong. There is nothing to grieve over in the changes which take place in this world, including death, because death is not the end of existence. It is only the end of existence in the form of this body.

So Moho Ayam Vigato Mama -- by this discourse of yours, you have given me the secret knowledge. Bhavapyayo Hi Bhutanam Shrutao Vistaraso Maya Tvattah Kamala Patraksha Mahatmyam Api Cha Avyayam -- I have also heard the origin and destruction of beings, O lotus-eyed Krishna, from you, and also your inexhaustible greatness. I heard the greatness of the self, the supreme Brahman, that which is not limited by anything.

And therefore my delusion is gone. I understand it clearly now. Evam Etat Yatha Attha Tvam Atmanam Parameshwara Drashtum Icchami Te Rupam Aishwaram Purushottamam. However, I would like to see that form as you described yourself -- that oneness in this world of plurality. I have understood that you pervade the entire universe and therefore there is no existence separate from you.

However, at this time I cannot see that, and I would like to see that. I would like to experience that oneness of yours. Manyase Yadi Tat Shakyam Maya Drashtum Iti Prabho -- if you think it is possible for me to see that divine form, then, O Lord of Yogas, show me that imperishable form which includes everything in this world. I would like to see that complete form of yours where everything is in yourself.

It is easier for me to see your presence in this world of plurality. As Swamiji explains, it is easier for me to see gold in gold jewelry. I can take one look at it, experience the gold in it, then pick up another piece. As long as the excellence is there, in other words, the gold is apparent and not covered by something -- the gold is manifested in the jewelry -- I can see the gold in it. So it is easier to see the divinity in the world of plurality for us. What is not possible for us generally is seeing all the plurality in that one single entity. I can imagine that God is in you. God is in me, God is in He, God is in she. If my mind and intellect has achieved that level of purity, level of understanding, then I start seeing the divinity in all beings.

And therefore, in our culture, when we meet each other, we say, namaste, Namah te, I bow down to you. I'm not bowing down to the limited self which is standing in front of me. Because I may have my own opinion about that person, but I still do. Namaste to all of the people I meet, at least culturally. That's what we should be doing or we are doing. Who we are bowing down to is the divinity in that person that I recognize.

The divinity in me and divinity in you is the same. So I respect the divinity in you. I bow down to you with that recognition. My transaction with you would be always of very friendly, very congenial, and not adversarial. Because I have recognized that myself and yourself has one thing in common, that consciousness, the divinity which makes me who I am. The same divinity, the same consciousness is within you.

What I have trouble imagining or perceiving or seeing is that the whole divinity is one, and you and I are in it. And we have heard in Bhagavad Gita before, Bhagavan says, I am not in them, they are in me. The car is in the space, the space is not in the car. When I see a car which was built in Germany, there was space inside. When it was in Germany, there was German space. And they seal it tight and then transport that car to United States. Now the car is here, the space is still intact which was sealed in Germany. Now, whether the space in the United States is the German space or American space in the car -- obviously the answer is simple. The space inside the car is American space. So what happened to the German space which was in the car when it was sealed tight in Germany? The answer obviously depends on our way of seeing space.

As long as I see the space in the car, I have difficulty imagining what happened to that German space. When it came to America, the space was inside the car. The car was never opened till it came here. Well, it should still be German space in it, right? But if I start seeing that the space was not in the car, but the car was in the space, then I do not have any difficulty. The car was traveling in the space. And therefore wherever the car is, that country's space is in that car, because the car is traveling in the space. For me to imagine that, I have to first have a perception of space as a totality without any gap. If German space is one space and American space is another space, I will have difficulty. But if I can imagine a homogeneous, continuous, universal space, now I can see everything is in it. So what you and I have difficulty in recognizing is the unity between myself and yourself and herself, and also the objects in this room -- this is because of the distance between us. I am here and you are there, you are there and she is somewhere else.

What is separating us from each other is the space. What is separating me from my father is the time. My father lived up to 1975 and I'm here today in 2014 thinking about it. So we are separated from each other by time. So there are two things which creates this world of plurality for me, and that is space and time. We have also heard from sages and scientists that this concept of space and this concept of time is creation of my mind.

So one can say, well, what is the distance between here and D.C.? It's too long a journey. And somebody else will say it's too close, it's only a two hour drive. So my mind creates the valuation of whether it's too far or too close -- that's the conception of space in my mind. Same thing with time. If somebody says I'll be back in half an hour, well, is it too soon for me or too long for me? I can't wait for half an hour.

You need to be back here in 10 minutes. Because my conception of time is different than his conception of time. For him half an hour is too short, and for me half an hour is too long. Well, anytime somebody goes to India for a vacation and when they come back, and if I ask that person, so how was your vacation? The answer is it was great, but it was too short. And I say, how long were you there?

He said four weeks. For me, that's too long a time. I only go there for a week or two. So for me a two weeks vacation is good enough, but for them four weeks is too short, because when you are enjoying yourself, four weeks seems too short. But if you were suffering because of the heat or monsoon and all the other things which we normally complain about, you'll say, boy, it was too long. I tried, and then I finally was ready to get out.

So even time is a concept of my mind. If these two concepts of my mind are wiped out, then I will see the world completely differently. If the concept of space is wiped out from my mind, then I will see you and I and everyone in this room come together as one entity. There is no space between us. We are all joined together and we will be one entity with different limbs, but we are all together. Swamiji uses a very good analogy in his commentary.

There is a toy maker making toys from clay. And he has various toys and various dolls: elephant, tiger, baby and a bird. And then he decided, no, this is not good. I need to use this clay for something much larger, more sellable. He takes all those dolls and compresses them into one ball of clay.

And when he compressed them together, what he has done is taken all the space away from each other. Previously they were sitting on a table or in a display box as separate entities. Once he gathers them and lumps them into one, now it's a big lump of clay. At the same time, I can see the face of the elephant on the surface of that lump. I also see the baby's smile. I also see the tiger's face. What is taken away from each other is the space. The same way, the events in my life have a time value -- it was in my past, or it is in my present, or it will be in my future. My childhood is in my past. My youth is in my past. My old age is in my present.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the cosmic form as filling all space between heaven and earth, with the sun and moon as eyes, and a face beaming with sacrificial fire "flooding the whole universe with light." Arjuna observes that all three worlds tremble with awe and fear at this vision, while celestial beings enter into the Lord - some invoking Him in fear with folded palms, while Great Seers and Adepts sing hymns saying "All Hail." This shows that even enlightened beings respond to ultimate reality with reverence and wonder.

The key teaching here involves space and time as mental constructs that create our experience of separation. Swamiji's analogy of the toymaker is illuminating: when clay dolls - elephant, tiger, baby, bird - are compressed into one ball, all the space between them disappears, yet traces of each remain visible on the surface. Similarly, what separates you from your father is time; what separates you from your neighbor is space. Remove these mental constructs, and all beings merge into one entity. This is not philosophy but a description of actual perception when the divine vision is granted.

For today's practice, work with your perception of space. When you see a friend, recognize that the "distance" between you is a concept in your mind. When you remember someone who has passed, notice that the "time" separating you is also a mental construct. Experiment with the feeling of closeness to someone physically far away, or connection to an ancestor long gone. What changes when you treat space and time not as absolute barriers but as perspectives that can shift? This is the beginning of understanding how Arjuna could see "the whole universe, movable and immovable" within a single form.

snippets.sanskrit:

रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं

नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं

rudrādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyā viśve.aśvinau marutaścoṣmapāśca .

When I see Thee, touching the Heavens, glowing with colour, with open mouth and wide open fiery eyes, I am terrified. O My Lord! My courage and peace of mind desert me.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, and we'll now be discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan, the cosmic form of the Divine. In the last chapter, Arjuna had asked Krishna: tell me how I should feel your presence, the presence of the divine, the presence of that all-pervading self, and how I can meditate upon that. In response, Bhagavan gave him various examples of excellence in this world from various walks of life -- applicable to Arjuna and also to us -- showing that from our day-to-day life, from our cultural backgrounds, from our spiritual quest, we find examples all around us of excellence and can feel the Lord's presence. As we discussed in chapter 10, anytime I see excellence, my mind recognizes it as God's blessings, the grace of God. In other words, divinity is evident in excellence. Bhagavan gave various examples for Arjuna and said, when you see this, it will remind you of my presence in all things and beings. I'm not limited to those excellent manifestations, but that's where you will find it easier to experience my presence.

And now that Arjuna has heard that, he says: I'm still not experiencing that oneness, the oneness which you talk about throughout this discourse. I have intellectually appreciated it and come to the conclusion that that's what it is -- that there is one singular entity pervading this entire universe, which is you, the Supreme Self. But I need to have that experience. I would like to experience that oneness. This, as Swamiji explains, is similar to how we scientifically make any concept or theory our own knowledge. First I need to gather all the evidence and data.

And then, once I have gathered all the data and evidence, I need to demonstrate that the phenomenon exists. I gather all information about how water is formed. In chemistry class, two molecules of hydrogen and one molecule of oxygen can create water. But at some point, I want to see the demonstration -- in the lab, I create that situation and then see how hydrogen and oxygen create water. In a similar fashion, Arjuna has now understood, but he wants to see a demonstration. So the chapter starts with Arjuna Vacha.

Arjuna said: Mat Anugraha Ya Paramam Guhyam Adhyatma Sangnitam Yat Tvaya Uktam Vachasthena Moho Ayam Vigato Mama. With your compassion for me, you have given me this secret knowledge. And as you have said, the self is indestructible, imperishable. One who considers himself to be the slayer or the slain -- in both cases, he is wrong. There is nothing to grieve over in the changes which take place in this world, including death, because death is not the end of existence. It is only the end of existence in the form of this body.

So Moho Ayam Vigato Mama -- by this discourse of yours, you have given me the secret knowledge. Bhavapyayo Hi Bhutanam Shrutao Vistaraso Maya Tvattah Kamala Patraksha Mahatmyam Api Cha Avyayam -- I have also heard the origin and destruction of beings, O lotus-eyed Krishna, from you, and also your inexhaustible greatness. I heard the greatness of the self, the supreme Brahman, that which is not limited by anything.

And therefore my delusion is gone. I understand it clearly now. Evam Etat Yatha Attha Tvam Atmanam Parameshwara Drashtum Icchami Te Rupam Aishwaram Purushottamam. However, I would like to see that form as you described yourself -- that oneness in this world of plurality. I have understood that you pervade the entire universe and therefore there is no existence separate from you.

However, at this time I cannot see that, and I would like to see that. I would like to experience that oneness of yours. Manyase Yadi Tat Shakyam Maya Drashtum Iti Prabho -- if you think it is possible for me to see that divine form, then, O Lord of Yogas, show me that imperishable form which includes everything in this world. I would like to see that complete form of yours where everything is in yourself.

It is easier for me to see your presence in this world of plurality. As Swamiji explains, it is easier for me to see gold in gold jewelry. I can take one look at it, experience the gold in it, then pick up another piece. As long as the excellence is there, in other words, the gold is apparent and not covered by something -- the gold is manifested in the jewelry -- I can see the gold in it. So it is easier to see the divinity in the world of plurality for us. What is not possible for us generally is seeing all the plurality in that one single entity. I can imagine that God is in you. God is in me, God is in He, God is in she. If my mind and intellect has achieved that level of purity, level of understanding, then I start seeing the divinity in all beings.

And therefore, in our culture, when we meet each other, we say, namaste, Namah te, I bow down to you. I'm not bowing down to the limited self which is standing in front of me. Because I may have my own opinion about that person, but I still do. Namaste to all of the people I meet, at least culturally. That's what we should be doing or we are doing. Who we are bowing down to is the divinity in that person that I recognize.

The divinity in me and divinity in you is the same. So I respect the divinity in you. I bow down to you with that recognition. My transaction with you would be always of very friendly, very congenial, and not adversarial. Because I have recognized that myself and yourself has one thing in common, that consciousness, the divinity which makes me who I am. The same divinity, the same consciousness is within you.

What I have trouble imagining or perceiving or seeing is that the whole divinity is one, and you and I are in it. And we have heard in Bhagavad Gita before, Bhagavan says, I am not in them, they are in me. The car is in the space, the space is not in the car. When I see a car which was built in Germany, there was space inside. When it was in Germany, there was German space.

And they seal it tight and then transport that car to United States. Now the car is here, the space is still intact which was sealed in Germany. Now, whether the space now in the United States is the German space or American space in the car, obviously the answer is simple. The space inside the car is American space. So what happened to the German space which was in the car when it was still tight in Germany? The answer obviously is in our way of seeing space.

As long as I see the space in the car, I have difficulty imagining what happening to that space which was German space. When it came to America, the space was inside the car. Car was never opened till it came here. Well, it should have been a German space in it. But if I start seeing that the space was not in the car, the car was in the space, then I do not have any difficulty. Car was traveling in the space.

And therefore wherever the car is, that country space is in that car, because car is traveling in the space. For me to imagine that, I have to first have a perception of a space as a totality without any gap. A German space is one space, an American space is another space, I will have difficulty. But if I can imagine a homogeneous, continuous, universal space, now I can see everything is in it. So what you and I have difficulty in recognizing the unity between myself and yourself and herself, and also the objects in this room is because of the distance between us. I am here and you are there, you are there and she is somewhere else.

So my mind creates the valuation whether it's too far or too little, that the conception of space in my mind, same thing. If somebody says I'll be back in half an hour, well, is it too soon for me or too long for me? I can't wait for half an hour.

You need to be back here in 10 minutes. Because my conception of time is different than his conception of time. For him half an hour is too short, and for me half an hour is too long. Well, anytime somebody goes to India for a vacation and when they come back, and if I ask that person, so how was your vacation? The answer is it was great, but it was too short.
