If the concept of space is wiped out from my mind, then I will see you and I and everyone in this room come together as one entity. There is no space between us. We are all joined together and we will be one entity with different limbs, but we are all together. Swamiji uses a very good analogy in his commentary.

There is a toy maker making toys from clay. And he has various toys and various dolls. Elephant, tiger, baby and a bird. And then he decided, no, this is not good. I need to use this clay for something much larger, more sellable. He takes all those dolls and compresses them into one ball of clay.

And when he compressed them together, what he has done is taken all the space away from each other. Previously they were sitting on a table or in a display box as separate entity. Once he gathers them and lumps them into one. And now a big lump of clay. At the same time, I can see the face of the elephant on that surface of that lump. Also see the baby smile.

Also see the tiger's face. What is taken away from each other is the space. The same way the events in my life has a time value of it was in my past, or it is in my present, or it will be in my future. My childhood is in my past. My youth is in my past. My old age is in my present.
snippets.reflection:
In these verses, Arjuna witnesses hosts of beings - Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, divine healers, the Winds, demons and saints alike - all gazing at the cosmic form in amazement. Then comes a shift: Arjuna begins to feel overwhelmed and terrified. Seeing the stupendous form with myriad faces, innumerable eyes and limbs, and "terrible jaws," he confesses: "I am terrified. My courage and peace of mind desert me." The vision that began with wonder now reveals its awe-inspiring and fearsome aspect.

This is a crucial teaching about spiritual growth. We often approach the divine expecting only comfort, beauty, and peace. But the complete vision includes what we might call the "terrible" aspects - destruction, death, the dissolution of everything we hold dear. Arjuna wanted to see totality, and totality includes both creation and destruction, both the pleasant and the fearsome. His terror is the natural response of the ego when it confronts something that completely transcends its capacity to control or even comprehend.

Today, reflect on what aspects of reality you resist seeing. Do you avoid thinking about death? Do you turn away from suffering in the world? Do you prefer a "nice" spiritual path without difficult truths? Arjuna's experience suggests that mature spirituality requires facing the full picture - not just the comforting divine but also the destroyer, not just light but also the consuming fire. Ask yourself: What would it mean to accept that the same consciousness that creates also destroys? That the God you pray to for protection is also the power behind everything that threatens you? Sitting with this paradox, without resolving it too quickly, is itself a spiritual practice.

snippets.title: Day 150: The Cosmic Form
snippets.sanskrit:
दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि

अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राः

वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति
snippets.transliteration:
daṃṣṭrākarālāni ca te mukhāni dṛṣṭvaiva kālānalasannibhāni .

amī ca tvāṃ dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ sarve sahaivāvanipālasaṅghaiḥ .

vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇā viśanti daṃṣṭrākarālāni bhayānakāni .
verseTranslations: When I see Thy mouths with their fearful jaws like glowing fires at the dissolution of creation, I lose all sense of place; I find no rest. Be merciful, O Lord in whom this universe abides!
All these sons of Dhritarashtra, with the hosts of princes, Bheeshma, Drona and Karna, as well as the other warrior chiefs belonging to our side;
I see them all rushing headlong into Thy mouths, with terrible tusks, horrible to behold. Some are mangled between thy jaws, with their heads crushed to atoms.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan Yoga, the Cosmic Form. We all want to know Bhagavan. But Bhagavan says, if I show you my Roop, it may not be as pleasant as you think. So Arjuna asked for it and he got what he wished for. Both concepts of space and time are wiped out from his mind. Now he sees this entire Jagat without any space, and also without any time difference. So first he described what he saw and said, I see that everything is within you. I see with many mouths, many hands, many stomachs, many legs. In other words, all the legs and all the mouths which I consider to be individually assigned to individual are all yours. I see them all into you.

He also saw everything that he has ever encountered in his life. Devas, all the deities -- I see all of them in you. So he described what he sees. Then he also sees the condition of other beings looking at this great form: all these people are entering into you. Some are fearful and some are praising your glory. Those who have not comprehended the reality are fearful of it. When we are not sure about the outcome of our actions in life, we are fearful. Those who are wise enough to not get perturbed by whatever the outcome is, they are blissful and praising the Lord because they have accepted everything. So I see those wise people are praising you, but others are entering into you in fear. And then he says, I also see you as Vishnu. I see you as that Almighty Vishnu. Kiritinam Gadinam, Chakri Namcha. With all your attributes, I see you. But then he says, I also don't see any middle, end or beginning. And all the space between the heavens and earth is filled with you alone. Up till now what I considered nothingness -- there is no such thing as nothingness anymore. Everything is you and you alone.

So I see you all around me and everything in you. And now I also see how the world is looking at you, how the other beings react. He still keeps himself out of this. He is an observer observing an object. His experience is all objective. Right now he is describing what's happening to others.

This is how we observe our world. We keep ourselves out of it and then say, oh, he is not doing exercise, he is going to be suffering, he is smoking, he is going to have cancer. We keep ourselves out of it. We look at the world and see how they are doing and how they are feeling and how they are behaving. So up to now he is looking at everything and saying, everybody is entering into you. Some are fearful, some are praising you.

I see the deities, I see everything into. You are filling all the spaces. But then he starts having the other side of the experience. It's not all wonderful -- life has its positive moments and negative moments. And when you focus on one, you can always give a biography of a person showing how great he was and how accomplished he was.

Every funeral I go to, I realize there is not an average person in this world. Everyone says how great the person was, what he accomplished, and how loving he was. I have never heard somebody say, "He was such an average person. He didn't really accomplish much in his life. He was a terrible husband, a cruel father." Because we focus on what is good in that person, we highlight all the goodness in him.

So up till now Arjuna was only focusing on the divinity. Then he sees Brahma seated on the lotus. All the deities are praising, all the vasavas and maruts and everybody is praising. And they are all dumbfounded just looking at this great. They're looking in wonderment. Even the wise person also gets awed by the nature.

Even people like Einstein, who are pure scientists -- he could not figure out what God's game is all about. That's why he said, "God doesn't play dice." He had complete faith that God wouldn't be doing something random. He had faith in God's laws of nature, that we can figure them out. This world is very predictable from our perspective; there's nothing unpredictable in this world, really. With that predictability, we can plan our life. I'll get up at 6 o'clock and then I'll do this, then I'll be at class at 10. We can plan that because it's predictable. Everything you can predict from when I leave my house. The unpredictable part is what will happen during that period. And once we look at that, we start getting fearful.

Well, you can get in an accident. You are at Times Square walking around and somebody just drives a car onto the sidewalk. It's unthinkable, unpredictable. Unpredictable things do occur. So there is positive and there is negative. From our perspective, from our relative world, there is positive and negative.

Now Arjuna, from his perspective, says what is also not so pleasant. He says: Nabhas Sprisham Diptam Anek Varnam Vyattananam Dipta Vishala Netram Drashtva Hi Tvam Pravyathitantaratma Dhritim Na Vindami Shamam Cha Vishno. Having seen your form touching the sky, inflaming with many colors, your open mouth and fiery eyes -- I am shaken up inside. I have no courage, no peace.

Up till now, I had a place in this world where I had staked myself and said, "This is where I am, and this is who I am in relationship to the world." The moment I feel insignificant anywhere -- in my organization, in my society, in my community, in my family -- I start getting depressed. We keep our balance by having that self-assessment of ourselves as an important being. The moment we drop that, we become completely fearful. We do not know where we stand. That's why when people retire, they often lose their sense of what is important. Roger Ailes ruled Fox channel for a long time. As soon as he was disgraced and ousted, he died within a year. Had he still been at Fox, he probably would have continued for another 10 years.

People lose their bearings in life and therefore lose their stability. So he said, Dhritim Na Vindami Shamam Cha Vishno -- I do not see what I can do. I don't think I'm capable of anything, and I have no peace because of that. Danshtra Karalani Cha Te Mukhani -- now he gives the other side of the coin. Up till now, he was talking about all existence, seeing everything existing in you. I see that everything is existing in you and everything is supported by you. But now he says Danshtra Karalani Cha Te Mukhani Drashtva Eva Kala Anala Sannibhani -- I see in your mouth these terrible teeth, fearsome teeth, and fire blazing in your mouth. Disho Na Jane -- I don't see the directions. I do not see my place in life; I do not see my place in this universe. Up till now, I had a complete sense of who I am and where I am. In my family, there is a placement -- I know who I am. I know who I am in my community. I know who I am in my company. I know who I am as a citizen. There is a bearing I can describe. I'm at 1537B Knuckles Road. I can tell you how to come to me. There is a complete sense of placement and direction.

I am such-and-such in the community. So I had a complete sense of my worth and my place in this universe. But once I see the mortality -- that everything is rushing towards you, and so am I -- that changes everything. Right now, I see my life in a static picture. I always see myself as existing now. It's a static picture in my head. Everybody else sees me getting old. It's very hard for you to imagine yourself to be growing and deteriorating. You have to constantly remind yourself, you know, I can't do that anymore. I have to keep telling myself, I'm an old man. Because I don't see myself as an old man. I have to remind myself.

The other day I was reading something. Some psychoanalyst says that the difference between a normal person and a psychopath is that a psychopath has to be reminded that certain behavior is not acceptable. A normal person naturally knows what is acceptable behavior in a society. A person suffering from that mental condition who becomes a sociopath or psychopath does not have that natural bearing. Somebody has to constantly tell him, "This is not acceptable, this is not acceptable." Only then can he function in society. So Arjuna said, having seen this mortality -- that everything is rushing towards you, that there are terrible teeth and blazing fire in your mouth, that you are the resting place of everything, that all names and forms, including mine, will be destroyed in you -- therefore, I do not know what my place in life is.

I am fast-forwarding my life right now. Normally, I see my life one frame at a time. Therefore, it is a static picture I am seeing. I see every moment as one frame at a time. I have forgotten the last frame, and I don't know the next frame. It's a static picture, and I consider that as my existence.

But fast-forward my life. We have DVR, obviously -- we record all the shows. Sometimes I say, "Meena, you have 24 episodes of this Satyameva Jayate. When are we going to get rid of them?" She says, "Oh, no, no, I'll finish. I'll do speed watching." I had heard of speed reading, but speed watching! Fast-forward for three minutes and the whole show is done. A person's whole episode is over in two minutes. If our life is fast-forwarded, the eulogy at the end of your life tells the story. Somebody will give your entire life in two minutes: he was born in Surat, went to high school here, then went to architecture school, went to Africa, then taught Bhagavad Gita, and died. Entire life summarized in two minutes or less. When you fast-forward your life, the only thing you see is that you are rushing towards your death. That's all you're doing every moment. And we have to keep reminding ourselves -- we have birthday celebrations to say, "This is not bad so far."

So he said, I do not know where I stand. Disho Na Jane Na Labhe Cha Sharma. Having seen my mortality and insignificance, I can't find any peace. What is the purpose of my life? We completely realize that all I consider to be my abilities are of no value when you are sick. And I have explained this before -- when you are sick, you can tell me anything about anything, but I'm not listening right now. I just can't feel good about anything. I have a fever of 105 and you want to talk to me about Bhagavad Gita? Forget about it right now. I can't find any bearing. And Arjuna said, I'm in that situation. I can't find it.

So he said, Prasida Devesha Jagannivasa -- be gracious to me, O Lord of the universe. This is, Swamiji says, the true surrender. Intellectually saying "Bhagavan, tera tujhko arpan, kya lage mera" -- intellectual surrender really means nothing, because you still think "I am surrendering." That ego is still very much there. "I am good, I am doing puja, I am doing meditation." That "I" is so solidly there that the surrender is of not much value.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna now sees the fearsome mouths with terrible jaws "like glowing fires at the dissolution of creation" and cries out: "I lose all sense of place; I find no rest." Even more disturbing, he sees all the sons of Dhritarashtra, Bhishma, Drona, Karna, and warriors from both armies rushing headlong into these terrible mouths, "some mangled between Thy jaws, with their heads crushed to atoms." The cosmic vision has revealed not just abstract unity but the concrete reality that everyone Arjuna knows is heading toward destruction.

This is the point where intellectual understanding becomes visceral. We all know that everyone dies, but Arjuna is seeing it happen - not as a future event but as a present reality from the cosmic perspective. The verse about losing "all sense of place" is particularly significant. Our sense of identity depends on knowing our place - in family, society, time. When we see that this placement is temporary and that we are all rushing toward the same dissolution, our ordinary bearings disappear. This is terrifying for the ego but liberating for the seeker who is ready.

For today's practice, try Swamiji's exercise of "fast-forwarding" your life. Imagine someone giving your eulogy - your entire life summarized in two minutes. What remains significant from this perspective? What falls away as trivial? Then extend this to everyone you will interact with today: each person you see is also moving toward their end. This is not meant to be morbid but to shift priorities. What conflicts would dissolve if you truly saw the temporary nature of all positions and identities? What kindness would become more natural? Let the awareness of universal mortality open compassion rather than despair.

snippets.title: Day 151: Universal Vision
snippets.sanskrit:
यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः

यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गा

लेलिह्यसे ग्रसमानः समन्ताल्-
snippets.transliteration:
yathā nadīnāṃ bahavo.ambuvegāḥ samudramevābhimukhā dravanti .

yathā pradīptaṃ jvalanaṃ pataṅgā viśanti nāśāya samṛddhavegāḥ .

lelihyase grasamānaḥ samantāl- lokānsamagrānvadanairjvaladbhiḥ .
verseTranslations: As rivers in flood surge furiously to the ocean, so these heroes, the greatest among men, fling themselves into Thy flaming mouths.
As moths fly impetuously to the flame only to be killed, so these men rush into Thy mouths to court their own destruction.
Thou seemest to swallow up the worlds, to lap them in flame. Thy glory fills the universe. Thy fierce rays beat down upon it irresistibly.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, and we'll now be discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan, the cosmic form of the Divine. In the last chapter, Arjuna had asked Krishna: tell me how I should feel your presence, the presence of the divine, the presence of that all-pervading self, and how I can meditate upon that. In response, Bhagavan gave him various examples of excellence in this world from various walks of life -- applicable to Arjuna and also to us -- showing that from our day-to-day life, from our cultural backgrounds, from our spiritual quest, we find examples all around us of excellence and can feel the Lord's presence. As we discussed in chapter 10, anytime I see excellence, my mind recognizes it as God's blessings, the grace of God. In other words, divinity is evident in excellence. Bhagavan gave various examples for Arjuna and said, when you see this, it will remind you of my presence in all things and beings. I'm not limited to those excellent manifestations, but that's where you will find it easier to experience my presence.

And now that Arjuna has heard that, he says: I'm still not experiencing that oneness, the oneness which you talk about throughout this discourse. I have intellectually appreciated it and come to the conclusion that that's what it is -- that there is one singular entity pervading this entire universe, which is you, the Supreme Self. But I need to have that experience. I would like to experience that oneness. This, as Swamiji explains, is similar to how we scientifically make any concept or theory our own knowledge. First I need to gather all the evidence and data.

And then, once I have gathered all the data and evidence, I need to demonstrate that the phenomenon exists. I gather all information about how water is formed. In chemistry class, two molecules of hydrogen and one molecule of oxygen can create water. But at some point, I want to see the demonstration -- in the lab, I create that situation and then see how hydrogen and oxygen create water. In a similar fashion, Arjuna has now understood, but he wants to see a demonstration. So the chapter starts with Arjuna Vacha.

Arjuna said: Mat Anugraha Ya Paramam Guhyam Adhyatma Sangnitam Yat Tvaya Uktam Vachasthena Moho Ayam Vigato Mama. With your compassion for me, you have given me this secret knowledge. And as you have said, the self is indestructible, imperishable. One who considers himself to be the slayer or the slain -- in both cases, he is wrong. There is nothing to grieve over in the changes which take place in this world, including death, because death is not the end of existence. It is only the end of existence in the form of this body.

So Moho Ayam Vigato Mama -- by this discourse of yours, you have given me the secret knowledge. Bhavapyayo Hi Bhutanam Shrutao Vistaraso Maya Tvattah Kamala Patraksha Mahatmyam Api Cha Avyayam -- I have also heard the origin and destruction of beings, O lotus-eyed Krishna, from you, and also your inexhaustible greatness. I heard the greatness of the self, the supreme Brahman, that which is not limited by anything.

And therefore my delusion is gone. I understand it clearly now. Evam Etat Yatha Attha Tvam Atmanam Parameshwara Drashtum Icchami Te Rupam Aishwaram Purushottamam. However, I would like to see that form as you described yourself -- that oneness in this world of plurality. I have understood that you pervade the entire universe and therefore there is no existence separate from you.

However, at this time I cannot see that, and I would like to see that. I would like to experience that oneness of yours. Manyase Yadi Tat Shakyam Maya Drashtum Iti Prabho -- if you think it is possible for me to see that divine form, then, O Lord of Yogas, show me that imperishable form which includes everything in this world. I would like to see that complete form of yours where everything is in yourself.

It is easier for me to see your presence in this world of plurality. As Swamiji explains, it is easier for me to see gold in gold jewelry. I can take one look at it, experience the gold in it, then pick up another piece. As long as the excellence is there, in other words, the gold is apparent and not covered by something -- the gold is manifested in the jewelry -- I can see the gold in it. So it is easier to see the divinity in the world of plurality for us. What is not possible for us generally is seeing all the plurality in that one single entity. I can imagine that God is in you. God is in me, God is in He, God is in she. If my mind and intellect has achieved that level of purity, level of understanding, then I start seeing the divinity in all beings.

And therefore, in our culture, when we meet each other, we say, namaste, Namah te, I bow down to you. I'm not bowing down to the limited self which is standing in front of me. Because I may have my own opinion about that person, but I still do. Namaste to all of the people I meet, at least culturally. That's what we should be doing or we are doing. Who we are bowing down to is the divinity in that person that I recognize.

The divinity in me and divinity in you is the same. So I respect the divinity in you. I bow down to you with that recognition. My transaction with you would be always of very friendly, very congenial, and not adversarial. Because I have recognized that myself and yourself has one thing in common, that consciousness, the divinity which makes me who I am. The same divinity, the same consciousness is within you.

What I have trouble imagining or perceiving or seeing is that the whole divinity is one, and you and I are in it. And we have heard in Bhagavad Gita before, Bhagavan says, I am not in them, they are in me. The car is in the space, the space is not in the car. When I see a car which was built in Germany, there was space inside. When it was in Germany, there was German space.

And they seal it tight and then transport that car to United States. Now the car is here, the space is still intact which was sealed in Germany. Now, whether the space now in the United States is the German space or American space in the car, obviously the answer is simple. The space inside the car is American space. So what happened to the German space which was in the car when it was still tight in Germany? The answer obviously is in our way of seeing space.

As long as I see the space in the car, I have difficulty imagining what happening to that space which was German space. When it came to America, the space was inside the car. Car was never opened till it came here. Well, it should have been a German space in it. But if I start seeing that the space was not in the car, the car was in the space, then I do not have any difficulty. Car was traveling in the space.

And therefore wherever the car is, that country space is in that car, because car is traveling in the space. For me to imagine that, I have to first have a perception of a space as a totality without any gap. A German space is one space, an American space is another space, I will have difficulty. But if I can imagine a homogeneous, continuous, universal space, now I can see everything is in it. So what you and I have difficulty in recognizing the unity between myself and yourself and herself, and also the objects in this room is because of the distance between us. I am here and you are there, you are there and she is somewhere else.

What is separating us from each other is the space. What is separating me from my father is the time. My father lived up to 1975 and I'm here today in 2014 thinking about it. So we are separated from each other by time. So there are two things which creates this world of plurality for me, and that is space and time. We have also heard from sages and scientists that this concept of space and this concept of time is creation of my mind.

So one can say, well, what is the distance between here to D.C. and so on. So it's too long a journey. And somebody will say it's too close, it's only two hour drive. So my mind creates the valuation whether it's too far or too little, that the conception of space in my mind, same thing. If somebody says I'll be back in half an hour, well, is it too soon for me or too long for me? I can't wait for half an hour.

You need to be back here in 10 minutes. Because my conception of time is different than his conception of time. For him half an hour is too short, and for me half an hour is too long. Well, anytime somebody goes to India for a vacation and when they come back, and if I ask that person, so how was your vacation? The answer is it was great, but it was too short. And I say, how long were you there?

He said four weeks for me, too long a time. I only go there for a week or two. So for me a two weeks vacation is good enough for them four weeks is too short, because when you are enjoying their four weeks seems too short. But if you were suffering because of the heat or monsoon and all the other things which we normally complain about, if I'm suffering. I'll say, boy, it was too long when I tried. And then I finally was ready to get out.

So even time is a concept of my mind. If these two concepts of my mind are wiped out, then I will see the world completely differently. If the concept of space is wiped out from my mind, then I will see you and I and everyone in this room come together as one entity. There is no space between us. We are all joined together and we will be one entity with different limbs, but we are all together. Swamiji uses a very good analogy in his commentary.

There is a toy maker making toys from clay. And he has various toys and various dolls. Elephant, tiger, baby and a bird. And then he decided, no, this is not good. I need to use this clay for something much larger, more sellable. He takes all those dolls and compresses them into one ball of clay.

And when he compressed them together, what he has done is taken all the space away from each other. Previously they were sitting on a table or in a display box as separate entity. Once he gathers them and lumps them into one. And now a big lump of clay. At the same time, I can see the face of the elephant on that surface of that lump. Also see the baby smile.

Also see the tiger's face. What is taken away from each other is the space. The same way the events in my life has a time value of it was in my past, or it is in my present, or it will be in my future. My childhood is in my past. My youth is in my past. My old age is in my present.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna uses two powerful metaphors to describe what he sees: rivers flooding furiously into the ocean, and moths flying impetuously into flame "only to be killed." Both images share a common quality - the movement is irresistible and ends in dissolution of individual identity. The river does not choose to merge with the ocean; the moth does not choose to enter the flame. This is the inherent nature of manifestation returning to its source. Then Arjuna sees the Lord "swallowing up the worlds, lapping them in flame" with glory filling the universe.

The river metaphor is particularly instructive. A mighty river like the Ganges has its own identity, its own name, its own course through the landscape. People build cities on its banks, write poems about it, worship it. Yet eventually, inevitably, it disappears into the ocean and loses all separate identity. From the ocean's perspective, there is no Ganges - only water that briefly took a particular form and path. This is true of every individual life, every civilization, every world.

Today, contemplate your life as a river. Where did "you" really begin? In your birth? Your parents' meeting? The formation of Earth? Trace the current of your existence backward and find no true beginning. Now follow it forward - where does "you" end? In death? In the memories others hold? In the effects of your actions rippling outward? See how the boundaries of your identity are not as fixed as they appear. The practice is not to become nihilistic but to recognize that you are already part of the ocean taking the temporary form of a river. Living from this recognition brings both humility and freedom.

snippets.title: Day 152: Arjuna's Terror
snippets.sanskrit:
आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

तस्मात्त्वमुत्तिष्ठ यशो लभस्व
snippets.transliteration:
ākhyāhi me ko bhavānugrarūpo namo.astu te devavara prasīda .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

tasmāttvamuttiṣṭha yaśo labhasva jitvā śatrūn bhuṅkṣva rājyaṃ samṛddham .
verseTranslations: Tell me then who Thou art, that wearest this dreadful Form? I bow before Thee, O Mighty One! Have mercy, I pray, and let me see Thee as Thou wert at first. I do not know what Thou intendest.

Lord Shri Krishna replied: I have shown myself to thee as the Destroyer who lays waste the world and whose purpose is destruction. In spite of thy efforts, all these warriors gathered for battle shall not escape death.
Then gird up thy loins and conquer. Subdue thy foes and enjoy the kingdom in prosperity. I have already doomed them. Be thou my instrument, Arjuna!
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We had been discussing chapter 11. We have seen Arjuna's description of what he is seeing, and we have discussed so many times in the last few weeks. What he has seen is everything that he can perceive in this world, all coming together as one, this plurality which is separated from each other. Now he sees that as one singularity. He also sees all the divine beings which he has just heard of in his Vedic training or from the cultural training.

He sees all of them -- Brahma, Vishnu, Mahesh -- all of them merged into this one entity. But he also sees that all these beings are rushing towards the mouth of that supreme being and getting dissolved, disappearing into it. And he comes to this realization that just as the river water is rushing towards the ocean -- intuitively, with inherent nature, not that somebody is propelling it or forcing it, but by its inherent nature. The river water runs from the mountaintops through the plains to the ocean. Just as the moth instinctively rush towards its death into the flame, river rushes towards the ocean, loses its identity. Mighty river, like Ganges or Yamuna or even Patomak or James, once it disappears into the ocean, there is no identity of the river of its own.

It just becomes part of the ocean. It seems that is the true nature of the river and the moth. So he sees that all the beings are without any hesitation, they're rushing towards the mouth of this great being and disappearing into it. And then he sees that this great being is seemingly enjoying this act of all these beings disappearing into his mouth, some get stuck. He makes sure that nobody is left out when we do some task. And we are so happy about it, that we are so proud of that.

In the end we try to inspect and say, is there anything left? That's basically equivalent to licking up what's going into his mouth -- making sure that all these beings are getting dissolved into his own being.

And now Arjuna says, I don't understand any of this. Akyahi me ko bhavan ugrarupaha -- tell me, O being with a very fierce form. Namostu te deva or prasida -- if you want to ask somebody who you are and that person is not smaller than you, you better be a little respectful first.

He does ask and say, I want to know who you are. But first, Namostute devara prasida -- you are the supreme Lord, so I bow down to you, have mercy on me, because I don't understand. I am not capable of understanding who you are. And vignatum ichami bhavantam adyam -- I have completely and clearly recognized that you are the Adi being. You are the original being. All beings are nothing but the manifestation of you.

They come from you, they go into you. But you are that original Bhavantam adyam. You are that original being. Vignatum ichami -- I want to know, which in normal terms we say, I want to know God. I know he is the supreme being.

At least from my childhood religious training I understood that he controlled this world. Vigna tam ichami bhavanta madhyam -- even after having this global vision, the cosmic vision, our intellect is not capable of understanding it. Nahi prajanami tavapravratyam -- also, I have no idea why you are doing this activity which I see right now. Isn't that something we ask all the time? I don't know why Bhagawan does this thing, why there is a tsunami, why there is an earthquake, or why Bill Gates and Steve Jobs are successful and not every IT person in this country. I do not know what you are doing, Bhagwan.

I hope you know what you are doing. Basically Arjuna puts it in his word very respectfully saying I want to know you O supreme Being. I clearly recognize you are the original being, but I also don't understand what you are engaged in right now. I see all these beings going into your mouth and getting crushed. He has also seen -- we have seen -- that all Kauravas are going into his mouth, as well as all the great kings on both sides.

See, anytime we have a vision, we focus on something closer to our own situation. Anytime you have a dream, the dream is always something related to what you were thinking about in the last week or so.

So even when he sees this whole cosmic vision, he focuses on the Kauravas going into his mouth. All the kings from the Kauravas as well as the kings from our side, going into his mouth. He says, I don't understand what you are engaged in right now.

And in response to that, Bhagavan says, Kalo'smi -- I am time. Lokaksha Kruta Pravrad daha -- I am engaged in destroying this world. I can see the world from both perspectives.

Either I can see it from a constructive perspective or a destructive perspective in nature. Actually both simultaneously keeps going on. Something gets destroyed, something gets built. I can fix my perspective only on the destruction part and say why this thing is happening. I can look at the statistics in the newspaper and say how many people die every day and say oh God, billions of people die. I don't know whether millions or billions, but I'm sure there are plenty because every several seconds there's somebody dies in the United States.

I read somewhere about how many people die every day, and if I look at that and say God, why do you do this? This many people dying every day. Don't you have better things to do than just killing? Right now Arjuna is just seeing this destruction going on. So Bhagavan's answer is also exactly that. Kalaha Asmi, I am all devouring time.

I was born in 1948. In 2012, I'm an old man, but sometime in the 2000-somethings I won't be around. That's what Lokakshaya krita pravadha means. You're seeing me destroying this world. As you know, the world as I know right now, is actually rushing towards its own destruction. All my friends and relatives and all of them, one after the other, they're all rushing towards their own death.

Kalavasmi lokaksha Kruta Prabhradha. From your perspective, Arjuna, I am that all devouring time. Right now what you are seeing is I am engaged in destroying these worlds. Lokan sama hartum iha pravrutaha ruteapi tvamna Bhavishyanti swarve e avasthitaha pratyanikeshi odaha. Even without you -- now coming down very personally to Arjuna -- Arjuna had said, I don't want to engage in this war. The whole purpose of this divine vision Arjuna wanted to have was connected to all the philosophy Bhagavan gave him in the second chapter about why he should engage in this war. Bhagavan had said, look, whoever takes birth will die.

Beginning they unmanifest, they will manifest for a while, they will unmanifest in the end. So you don't worry about it. Whatever the little role you are given in this drama, you take part and take credit for it and you don't worry about who's going to die and who's going to survive. But Arjuna was not clear. So he said, well let me see this entire vision now. He sees the entire vision and then he says I don't understand what are you doing?

And Bhagawan basically said, don't worry about it, I am time. I'm going to destroy everything in time. Whether you take part in it or not. Even without you, none of the warriors in front of you shall live. Whether you take part in this war or not is immaterial. Their destiny is to die in time.

Whenever their time will come, they will die. Because I am that all devouring time. Tasmat Utestha Yashola Basva -- all you have to do is take credit for it. Everybody says Bill Clinton was the best president in his time. We all thrived and our country has this surplus we never had seen in all these times before. And George Bush came and completely messed it all up.

But I'll tell you what, if George Bush was the president at the time when the technology bubble was blowing up, he would have the same credit. He just happened to be at that time a president. And we can blame Obama all we want. About 8% or 9% unemployment. But even if Bill Clinton is today, he would have the same problem. Because this thing is driven by this cycle, cosmic cycle, economic cycles, whatever the cycle you want to call it, you just happen to be there.

And if you're a smart person, you do your part and take credit. Become that instrument in this giant will of Dharma. So therefore Bhagavan said, look, all these people are already killed by me. Without your help also they will get killed. You just saw that every being is rushing towards their death in my mouth. Get up Yashola Basra and get the fame that you deserve.

Jitva Satrun Bhangshvarajam Samruddham -- get victory over your enemies and enjoy the kingdom. Maya Evey Thai Nihitaha Purva Meva -- I have already killed all these people before you decided to start this war. Nimittamatram Bhava Savya Sachin -- so you just become the Nimitta Matra.

If somebody gives you credit and says, why don't you become our group's leader and do this petition to such and such?

It's not that the guy who is making a petition is the only guy who came up with the idea or we are just giving him a credit. Look we can all go and talk. You become our leader. Arjuna, I'm just giving you this opportunity. To become the Nimitt Matra because you deserve it. We always choose a person who has the best capabilities or the best qualification to become the representative of our group.

We try to elect the best person who could be our president by looking at his qualifications. So becoming a Nimitta Matra is also something to be very proud of. That somebody has given us a chance considering us to be worthy of it. So when Bhagavan said, you become Nimitta Matra for something, you should take great pride in it and get up and do it. Swamiji says, in this case it is Arjuna. But in our case also, we get this chance all the time.

Bhagavan gives us the ability, capability, and opportunity to do something at our level in this world. And Bhagavan saying the same thing, look, I have already done this thing. It will be done whether you take part in it or not. But you have this opportunity. Why don't you take this chance and become Nimitta Matra? Become the instrument in my hand and take the credit and enjoy the credit.

Bhagavan said to Arjuna, same thing. These people are killed. You just do your part. You had been trained for these wars, stand up for the right cause. Take your credit and enjoy the fruits. Dronam Chabism Cha Jayadratham cha Karnam Tatha Anyanabi Yodavira Maya Hatam Stumhi Jahimam Vyatista.

Nobody gives us this kind of guarantee before we start anything. "Neil, go and do this. You are going to win it. Don't worry about it. I already took care of it." Once in a while somebody does it for us too.

Our father comes and says, "Beta, don't worry about it. I already talked to him. They are going to hire you," right? So Bhagavan said, look, you are worried about a few of them. Whether you admit it or not, you think, how can I fight in front of these great warriors such as Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, and Karna?

Bhagavan specifically mentions them and says I have already killed them.
snippets.reflection:
These verses contain one of the most famous declarations in the Gita: "Kalo'smi" - I am Time. When Arjuna asks who this terrible being is and what his intention is, Krishna reveals himself as "the Destroyer who lays waste the world." Then comes the practical instruction: "Gird up thy loins and conquer... I have already doomed them. Be thou my instrument (nimitta matra)." The warriors will die whether Arjuna fights or not; his participation does not determine the outcome but gives him the opportunity to fulfill his dharma.

The concept of "nimitta matra" - being merely an instrument - is revolutionary. We typically think our actions determine outcomes. But Krishna suggests that from the cosmic perspective, outcomes are already determined by the flow of time and karma. Our role is not to determine results but to participate fully and righteously in the unfolding. This is not fatalism but freedom from the anxiety of results. A surgeon operates with full skill; the outcome depends on many factors beyond her control. Her job is excellent action, not guaranteed results.

For today's practice, approach one significant task with the attitude of "nimitta matra." Do your absolute best while inwardly acknowledging that you are an instrument, not the ultimate doer. Notice how this shifts your relationship to anxiety and pressure. Ask yourself: In what areas of life am I exhausting myself trying to control what time will ultimately determine anyway? Where can I be a more willing instrument, doing excellent work while leaving results to the larger flow?

snippets.sanskrit:

अर्जुन उवाच |
