In the end we try to inspect and say, is there anything left? That's basically equivalent to licking up what's going into his mouth -- making sure that all these beings are getting dissolved into his own being.

And now Arjuna says, I don't understand any of this. Akyahi me ko bhavan ugrarupaha -- tell me, O being with a very fierce form. Namostu te deva or prasida -- if you want to ask somebody who you are and that person is not smaller than you, you better be a little respectful first.

He does ask and say, I want to know who you are. But first, Namostute devara prasida -- you are the supreme Lord, so I bow down to you, have mercy on me, because I don't understand. I am not capable of understanding who you are. And vignatum ichami bhavantam adyam -- I have completely and clearly recognized that you are the Adi being. You are the original being. All beings are nothing but the manifestation of you.

They come from you, they go into you. But you are that original Bhavantam adyam. You are that original being. Vignatum ichami -- I want to know, which in normal terms we say, I want to know God. I know he is the supreme being.

At least from my childhood religious training I understood that he controlled this world. Vigna tam ichami bhavanta madhyam -- even after having this global vision, the cosmic vision, our intellect is not capable of understanding it. Nahi prajanami tavapravratyam -- also, I have no idea why you are doing this activity which I see right now. Isn't that something we ask all the time? I don't know why Bhagawan does this thing, why there is a tsunami, why there is an earthquake, or why Bill Gates and Steve Jobs are successful and not every IT person in this country. I do not know what you are doing, Bhagwan.

I hope you know what you are doing. Basically Arjuna puts it in his word very respectfully saying I want to know you O supreme Being. I clearly recognize you are the original being, but I also don't understand what you are engaged in right now. I see all these beings going into your mouth and getting crushed. He has also seen -- we have seen -- that all Kauravas are going into his mouth, as well as all the great kings on both sides.

See, anytime we have a vision, we focus on something closer to our own situation. Anytime you have a dream, the dream is always something related to what you were thinking about in the last week or so.

So even when he sees this whole cosmic vision, he focuses on the Kauravas going into his mouth. All the kings from the Kauravas as well as the kings from our side, going into his mouth. He says, I don't understand what you are engaged in right now.

And in response to that, Bhagavan says, Kalo'smi -- I am time. Lokaksha Kruta Pravrad daha -- I am engaged in destroying this world. I can see the world from both perspectives.

Either I can see it from a constructive perspective or a destructive perspective in nature. Actually both simultaneously keeps going on. Something gets destroyed, something gets built. I can fix my perspective only on the destruction part and say why this thing is happening. I can look at the statistics in the newspaper and say how many people die every day and say oh God, billions of people die. I don't know whether millions or billions, but I'm sure there are plenty because every several seconds there's somebody dies in the United States.

I read somewhere about how many people die every day, and if I look at that and say God, why do you do this? This many people dying every day. Don't you have better things to do than just killing? Right now Arjuna is just seeing this destruction going on. So Bhagavan's answer is also exactly that. Kalaha Asmi, I am all devouring time.

I was born in 1948. In 2012, I'm an old man, but sometime in the 2000-somethings I won't be around. That's what Lokakshaya krita pravadha means. You're seeing me destroying this world. As you know, the world as I know right now, is actually rushing towards its own destruction. All my friends and relatives and all of them, one after the other, they're all rushing towards their own death.

Kalavasmi lokaksha Kruta Prabhradha. From your perspective, Arjuna, I am that all devouring time. Right now what you are seeing is I am engaged in destroying these worlds. Lokan sama hartum iha pravrutaha ruteapi tvamna Bhavishyanti swarve e avasthitaha pratyanikeshi odaha. Even without you -- now coming down very personally to Arjuna -- Arjuna had said, I don't want to engage in this war. The whole purpose of this divine vision Arjuna wanted to have was connected to all the philosophy Bhagavan gave him in the second chapter about why he should engage in this war. Bhagavan had said, look, whoever takes birth will die.

Beginning they unmanifest, they will manifest for a while, they will unmanifest in the end. So you don't worry about it. Whatever the little role you are given in this drama, you take part and take credit for it and you don't worry about who's going to die and who's going to survive. But Arjuna was not clear. So he said, well let me see this entire vision now. He sees the entire vision and then he says I don't understand what are you doing?

And Bhagawan basically said, don't worry about it, I am time. I'm going to destroy everything in time. Whether you take part in it or not. Even without you, none of the warriors in front of you shall live. Whether you take part in this war or not is immaterial. Their destiny is to die in time.

Whenever their time will come, they will die. Because I am that all devouring time. Tasmat Utestha Yashola Basva -- all you have to do is take credit for it. Everybody says Bill Clinton was the best president in his time. We all thrived and our country has this surplus we never had seen in all these times before. And George Bush came and completely messed it all up.

But I'll tell you what, if George Bush was the president at the time when the technology bubble was blowing up, he would have the same credit. He just happened to be at that time a president. And we can blame Obama all we want. About 8% or 9% unemployment. But even if Bill Clinton is today, he would have the same problem. Because this thing is driven by this cycle, cosmic cycle, economic cycles, whatever the cycle you want to call it, you just happen to be there.

And if you're a smart person, you do your part and take credit. Become that instrument in this giant will of Dharma. So therefore Bhagavan said, look, all these people are already killed by me. Without your help also they will get killed. You just saw that every being is rushing towards their death in my mouth. Get up Yashola Basra and get the fame that you deserve.

Jitva Satrun Bhangshvarajam Samruddham -- get victory over your enemies and enjoy the kingdom. Maya Evey Thai Nihitaha Purva Meva -- I have already killed all these people before you decided to start this war. Nimittamatram Bhava Savya Sachin -- so you just become the Nimitta Matra.

If somebody gives you credit and says, why don't you become our group's leader and do this petition to such and such?

It's not that the guy who is making a petition is the only guy who came up with the idea or we are just giving him a credit. Look we can all go and talk. You become our leader. Arjuna, I'm just giving you this opportunity. To become the Nimitt Matra because you deserve it. We always choose a person who has the best capabilities or the best qualification to become the representative of our group.

We try to elect the best person who could be our president by looking at his qualifications. So becoming a Nimitta Matra is also something to be very proud of. That somebody has given us a chance considering us to be worthy of it. So when Bhagavan said, you become Nimitta Matra for something, you should take great pride in it and get up and do it. Swamiji says, in this case it is Arjuna. But in our case also, we get this chance all the time.

Bhagavan gives us the ability, capability, and opportunity to do something at our level in this world. And Bhagavan saying the same thing, look, I have already done this thing. It will be done whether you take part in it or not. But you have this opportunity. Why don't you take this chance and become Nimitta Matra? Become the instrument in my hand and take the credit and enjoy the credit.

Bhagavan said to Arjuna, same thing. These people are killed. You just do your part. You had been trained for these wars, stand up for the right cause. Take your credit and enjoy the fruits. Dronam Chabism Cha Jayadratham cha Karnam Tatha Anyanabi Yodavira Maya Hatam Stumhi Jahimam Vyatista.

Nobody gives us this kind of guarantee before we start anything. "Neil, go and do this. You are going to win it. Don't worry about it. I already took care of it." Once in a while somebody does it for us too.

Our father comes and says, "Beta, don't worry about it. I already talked to him. They are going to hire you," right? So Bhagavan said, look, you are worried about a few of them. Whether you admit it or not, you think, how can I fight in front of these great warriors such as Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, and Karna?

Bhagavan specifically mentions them and says I have already killed them.
snippets.reflection:
Having heard Krishna declare "I am Time" and "I have already killed them," Arjuna responds with trembling, prostration, and choked voice. Sanjaya notes he was "overwhelmed with awe, bowing down again and again." Then Arjuna speaks: "It is natural that the world revels and rejoices when it sings the praises of Thy glory; the demons fly in fear and the saints offer Thee their salutations." He is processing the vision intellectually while still emotionally shaken.

Notice the different responses to the divine revelation: demons flee in fear, saints offer salutations, and the world rejoices in singing praises. How we respond to truth depends on our nature and readiness. The same reality that terrifies the unprepared becomes a source of devotion for the mature seeker. Arjuna stands at the threshold - shaken but not fleeing, overwhelmed but still present and engaged. This is the response of a genuine seeker: neither running away nor pretending everything is fine.

Reflect today on how you respond to difficult truths. When you encounter the reality of impermanence, do you flee into distraction? When you see the suffering in the world, do you turn away or remain present? The spiritual path is not about achieving a state where nothing disturbs you but about developing the capacity to remain present with whatever arises. Practice today by staying with one uncomfortable truth for just a few minutes longer than you normally would. Notice the impulse to flee and gently remain. This builds the capacity that allows transformation.

snippets.title: Day 154: The Cosmic Form
snippets.sanskrit:
कस्माच्च ते न नमेरन्महात्मन्

त्वमादिदेवः पुरुषः पुराणस्-

वायुर्यमोऽग्निर्वरुणः शशाङ्कः
snippets.transliteration:
kasmācca te na nameranmahātman garīyase brahmaṇo.apyādikartre .

tvamādidevaḥ puruṣaḥ purāṇasa- tvamasya viśvasya paraṃ nidhānam .

vāyuryamo.agnirvaruṇaḥ śaśāṅkaḥ prajāpatistvaṃ prapitāmahaśca .
verseTranslations: How should they do otherwise? O Thou Supremest Self, greater than the Powers of creation, the First Cause, Infinite, the Lord of Lords, the Home of the universe, Imperishable, Being and Not-Being, yet transcending both.
Thou art the Primal God, the Ancient, the Supreme Abode of this universe, the Knower, the Knowledge and the Final Home. Thou fillest everything. Thy form is infinite.

Thou art the Wind, Thou art Death, Thou art the Fire, the Water, the Moon, the Father and the Grandfather. Honour and glory to Thee a thousand and a thousand times! Again and again, salutation be to Thee, O my Lord!
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 11, Viswarupadarshan Yoga of the Cosmic form of the Lord. We have seen so far that Arjuna learned from Bhagavan first the nature of the limited self. What is the nature of this conditioned self? He learned that the self is immortal. The conditionings are perishable. The conditionings -- this body, this mind, this intellect -- are perishable.

But the self is imperishable. And therefore, while working in this world, keep that self in mind, identify with that self. But that is not very naturally happening to people. So Bhagavan talked about how to act in this world, addressed Arjuna, that you should act in this world in the spirit of Yajna. You will be then gradually detach yourself from this ego and will be able to identify with yourself. So then obviously Arjuna wanted to know the nature of that imperishable self.

So from chapter seven, Bhagavan said, I am the source of all the beings and things. Aham krutnasya jagadah prabhavaha pralayah t -- I am the source and dissolution of all things and beings in this world. So that's my relationship to you: I am the source of all the beings, and therefore also the source of you. And then he says, matthaha parataram na asti kincit anyat asti dhananjaya -- there is nothing higher than me.

There is nothing higher than this self. Therefore you should identify with the self. But Arjuna obviously was not ready to take this on its face value. The Bhagavan said, I am the source of all the beings and all the things. He wanted to know more. So he said, I want to know in detail your glories.

Because he is still identifying with Krishna as Krishna, and himself as Arjuna. How can Krishna be the Lord of all the beings? Arjuna, identifying with his limited self, is speaking from his ego's perspective and projecting his world. Krishna is speaking from his identification with the Supreme. He said, I am the source of all the beings. So Arjuna said, explain to me in detail, because I actually love hearing about your great glories, all the powers of this omnipresent, omniscient being.

So in chapter 10 we have a detailed description of Bhagavan saying that you can see my glory in everything that is splendid, wonderful, strong -- anything where you can find something which catches your eye.

That's me at the core of all beings. I am the sweetness in sugar, I am the light in sun, I am the liquidity in water. And even he says Dyutam, Chalaya, Tamasmi, even I am the gambling and the fraudulence. Even that also somebody can only cheat you if he is alive and conscious and consciousness is working through him. Everything that you see in this world, the core of all beings and things, is me and me alone. Nothing other than me exists.

Arjuna heard all that, but he's still not satisfied. He's still not grasping the whole idea of the omniscience and omnipotence of the Lord -- how the Lord can be everywhere. So he says, I want to see it. I have no doubt; you said this and also many others have said so before you. So I have no doubt about it. I take it for granted that what you are saying is correct.

Because time and again, sages after sages from generations have come and confirmed that this is the truth. So I am not doubting it now. You, Krishna, telling me so, I have no doubt -- but I want to see it. And therefore in chapter 11 we see that Krishna grants him this great vision of totality, where Arjuna can see all at once -- the past, present and future, an entire universe in one glimpse. And what he sees is that up till now the things which he has been seeing as different entities are all merged into one.

They're all part of the one entity. Therefore he describes and says, I'm seeing that you have thousands of mouths and thousands of hands and thousands of legs and thousands of stomachs. Because every stomach is yours, every hand is yours, every mouth is yours. So I see now all of them as part of the one entity. I'm seeing wonderful sights -- all these forms and colors and all the deities, things which I have not seen before, I have not even imagined before. I'm seeing all of them.

So he's enchanted by that form. But then he sees the other side of it. Other side of creation is always destruction. This is the other side of it. He sees that now all those beings which I see existing in him also rushing towards his mouth to get destroyed. Every name and form in this world is helplessly rushing toward its own destruction within the self which is supporting it.

So he starts getting really nervous about it that everyone is rushing towards your mouth to get destroyed. And I see the great people, the great heroes are helplessly rushing towards your mouth and getting destroyed. And that vision really terrified him. We had this notion about Bhagavan as one who is compassionate, serene, and creative. But the destructive aspect -- we never focus on that. Arjuna, while listening to all the discourses before, all the glories, all the splendid descriptions given --

I am the light in the sun. I am the fragrance in flower. So he was expecting it will be all well and good. Once I see the totality, it will be wonderful. My mind will be at peace. And after that there will be no problem.

But he sees the other side of it. He says everything is getting destroyed. Every name and form is getting destroyed in the being of that great Mahatma, the great person, the Purusha, the one entity. So he says, I'm terrified. I can't find my place in life. I don't know where I am and I'm losing my bearing.

So tell me, who are you and what are you up to? Because I have never imagined your form like this. See, only in our culture, in our religion, we have terrible forms of God also -- Kali and Shiva doing Tandava and Rudra and Pralaya. But in most cases we want to see him as a very calm, serene, and peaceful God. But when you want to understand God in totality, Bhagavan says, you have to know this also.

So he sees this destruction happening. Bhagavan says, I am the world-devouring time. Kalo'smi -- I am that time which devours everything. Within time, all names and forms will be destroyed. Everything dissolves into time. Things exist in time, get destroyed by time.

I am that all-devouring time. What you are seeing right now is my form which devours all names and forms. What are you up to right now? I'm engaged in destroying the world as you know it. The world as you and I know it is already getting destroyed by Bhagavan. Every second, every millisecond, it's constantly getting destroyed.

My reality yesterday is no longer my reality today. My reality today will no longer be my reality tomorrow. So it's constant, constantly destroying my world. And I am on the other end, constantly trying to keep my world in a status quo. I want to keep it exactly as I like. I think I'm right now in a better situation.

Let's keep it that way. So we have a tug of war between Bhagavan and me. I try to keep it; he wants to destroy it. So when I see his all-destroying power, I ask, why are you doing this? He says, my purpose is clear: I am the time who devours everything.

And right now you are seeing me destroying the world. As you know, and directly addressing. Arjuna said you were afraid that you will kill all these people. You thought that you are so powerful that you will kill all these people. Therefore you were afraid of taking part in this war. He said, I have already killed them all.

From our perspective, we are all alive and trying to survive. But Bhagavan says, there's time. I have already killed all of you -- for whatever time it is, you are going to be killed by time. No matter how many cryogenic clinics open in Richmond -- there is one opened, I guess, recently.

The time may be in years, maybe in millennia. But you will be destroyed by time. I've already destroyed you as the name and form you exist. I already killed you. Whether you take part in this game or not. You think that you don't want to take part in destroying these people?

These people are already destroyed, because as we learned, what will get destroyed is the conditioning. Only the self is immaculate, permanent, without any limitations. So these people are already destroyed as they exist -- whether they are Karna, Bhishma, or Jayadratha. Even though they seem invincible from your perspective, and they have powers so much greater than yours.

But they are killed by me. So my advice to you, Arjuna, is take charge of your life. Do what you were trained to do. Do what you thought was the purpose of your life. To establish the rule of justice and punish the people who are evil doers. I have already killed them.

You take the credit and then enjoy this kingdom. And that's where Bhagavan stopped. Then Sanjaya now takes a chance to tell Dhritarashtra what's happening. Sanjaya Vacha -- etatshrutva vachanam Kesavasya Krutanjalir vaipamanaha Kiriti namaskritva Bhuya evaha Krishnam Sagadgadam Bhitebhitaha Pranamya. He's giving a running commentary. He says, having heard these words from Krishna --

That I already killed all of them. I am the one who devours everything. I am the one who kills. You just take the credit and enjoy the victory. Only you can take credit or enjoy victory if you take part in it. If I don't take part, there is no chance.

There is 100% chance of me losing if I don't buy a lottery ticket. Guaranteed 100% chance of not winning the lottery. That's at least the surest outcome I can say. But if I think I have a chance to win 1 in 10 million, I have to buy a lottery ticket. I have to take part in it. So Bhagavan said, I already decided who the winner is.

You go ahead and buy a lottery ticket if you think you can. But if you don't take part, you will have no chance to win this thing. So Arjuna, therefore get up and do your duty. Result is decided by me. But you have a duty to perform your actions, for which you are trained, which you thought is the purpose of your life. And you must pursue that.

Having heard this, Sanjaya said that this Kiriti, the crowned one, Krutanjali Vepamanha -- his folded palms trembling, because he is still shaken up by this vision of all death and destruction happening constantly in this great self. The self remaining what it is, the names and forms are created in it and getting destroyed all the time. Namaskritva -- having prostrated to him -- Bhuya Eva Aha Krishnam -- he said the following words. He is choked with emotions, choked with the realization of what the self is all about. Up till now, I was in control of my life.

I thought I can control it. I have accomplished things. I have acquired abilities and promises. I suddenly realized that those things are of no value unless there is a support from the Almighty. The consciousness functioning through me. I may be the best architect, but if I'm in a coma, it doesn't do any good to anybody.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna now offers a prayer of deep recognition: Krishna is "greater than the Powers of creation, the First Cause, Infinite, the Lord of Lords." He declares Krishna to be "the Primal God, the Ancient, the Knower, the Knowledge and the Final Home... the Wind, Death, Fire, Water, the Moon, the Father and the Grandfather." This comprehensive list shows Arjuna seeing Krishna not as one god among many but as the source and essence of all divine principles and natural forces.

The teaching here is about the relationship between the many and the One. We worship different aspects of divinity - some pray to a nurturing mother aspect, others to a powerful protector, still others to wisdom or prosperity. Arjuna's vision reveals that all these are expressions of one reality. Wind, Death, Fire, Water - seemingly separate forces - are all manifestations of the same supreme consciousness. This does not diminish the deities but reveals their ultimate unity.

For today's practice, notice the divine in multiple forms throughout your day. See consciousness in the sustaining power of your breath (Vayu), in the natural limits and endings you encounter (Yama), in the transformative fire of your digestion and passion (Agni), in the flowing adaptability of water. Instead of thinking "this is different from that," practice seeing each as a face of the same underlying reality. When you say "namaste" to someone, recognize you are bowing to the same consciousness that looks out through your own eyes. This practice of seeing unity in diversity is the practical application of Arjuna's vision.

snippets.title: Day 155: Universal Vision
snippets.sanskrit:
नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते

सखेति मत्वा प्रसभं यदुक्तं

यच्चावहासार्थमसत्कृतोऽसि
snippets.transliteration:
namaḥ purastādatha pṛṣṭhataste namo.astu te sarvata eva sarva .

sakheti matvā prasabhaṃ yaduktaṃ he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakheti .

yaccāvahāsārthamasatkṛto.asi vihāraśayyāsanabhojaneṣu .
verseTranslations: Salutations to Thee in front and on every side, Thou who encompasseth me round about. Thy power is infinite; Thy majesty immeasurable; thou upholdest all things; yea, Thou Thyself art All.
Whatever I have said unto Thee in rashness, taking Thee only for a friend and addressing Thee as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend!' in thoughtless familiarity, no understanding Thy greatness;
Whatever insult I have offered to Thee in jest, in sport or in repose, in conversation or at the banquet, alone or in a multitude, I ask Thy forgiveness for them all, O Thou Who art without an equal!
snippets.commentary:
As we have been discussing last few times, that now that Arjuna has seen this cosmic form of the Lord, in other words, his mind has comprehended the unity of this plurality, this world which seemingly is divided among this plurality of things and beings, is actually strung by the same entity which manifests as this plurality, beings and things come out of the same reality and dissolve into the same reality. That reality is what he's facing right now. So he's now offering his prayer, his adoration to that. And he has said, you are everything -- Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna. Anything that I can think of, any being my mind can perceive, is nothing but you alone; all I see is you. And therefore he says, my salutations to you, my salutations to you a thousand times. I salute you from your front, I salute you in your back, I salute you at your side, because you are everywhere. Wherever I turn around, I see you.

If we come to the conclusion that this world is nothing but the Lord's manifestation, then obviously when we turn around, we see him. Just like this classical story -- maybe it's folklore -- that Nanak went to Kaaba and was sleeping with his feet towards Kaaba. The Maulvi comes and says, you idiot, what are you doing? He said, oh, is that what I'm doing? Well, then move my leg to where the Kaaba is not. The Maulvi in anger moves his leg. Wherever he turns it, he sees Kaaba moving around with it.

So basically saying God is everywhere, because God is everything, therefore God is everywhere. So he said, therefore. Now, whatever I see when I say I bow down in the front, in the back and the rear, whatever I see in front of me, whatever I see in the side of me is nothing. But you and I recognize that in our culture we say namaste -- Namah te -- I bow down to you. Not you as a person, but you the self, which is no other than myself. Once we find that commonality, we obviously can't have animosity or jealousy. But we just give lip service. Namaste -- we never understood.

So obviously we don't get the benefit of that. But if we develop any commonality with anybody -- somebody says, "Sunil, which university did you go to?" "Oh, I'm also from Baroda." Then we start feeling comfortable right there. Then he says, "Which year were you?" The more we find we have in common, the more we like each other, the more we fall in love with each other.

In other words, we find more identification with that person. So here now he is finding that everything that he knows is now him. So he is offering his salutation. Then he suddenly realizes that maybe when he was not aware of this fact, he may have insulted people. He may have insulted people who he should actually be respecting. In this case, obviously, he superimposes all of that onto Krishna, because Krishna is the one who showed him this Vishwaroop.

So he identifies what he is seeing as Krishna's self. I, Arjuna, am seeing Krishna's self as this great cosmic being who is everywhere and everything. Therefore, Hare Ram Hare Krishna -- which is Swami Prabhupada's movement -- they call it Krishna consciousness. The lineage from Shankaracharya speaks of consciousness, self-consciousness. Myself and yourself is one and the same. Prabhupada comes from a different lineage, which is a dualistic school of thought. They look at the Bhagavad Gita the same way except with a slightly different twist: they will say, let my consciousness right now -- ego consciousness -- identify with the Krishna consciousness.

Then I become one with Krishna, the Krishna, not that historical Krishna but the universal being. So here Arjuna sees the same way as this is the Krishna's great cosmic form. I have known Krishna from my childhood as Devaki's son, Yashoda's son, my cousin -- but look at his greatness. Sakha Ithimatva Prasabham Yad Uktam -- not knowing your greatness, I may have addressed you disrespectfully. This may not be appropriate for a great being like you.

When I came to this country, this was the biggest problem I had. Here, everybody called everybody by first name. Obviously, I was trained in India. And I said, "Oh, Neil, you can call..." I say, he's the president of our company of 200 people. I am not going to call him David. "No, no, it's okay, call him David."

But very difficult for us to do that -- how can I say? Even today, after living here for 30 years, I have a client named Charles McFarlane, and obviously we call him Charles. He's about my age, so much younger than me. His father is 80-something and he used to be our senator, Granger McFarlane. But he's also part of this project which I'm doing. So Charles will say, "Call my father."

Everybody called him Granger. I said, I'm not going to do that. I call him Mr. McFarlane and call Charles, Charles. That's how I make the distinction. So now Arjuna, realizing this, says, I must have done something not right -- I called you Sakha.

So ajanata mahimanam avedam -- not that I want to disrespect you, but I did not know your greatness, that you are that all-pervading being. See, till we come to see God, we are not one with him, and therefore we always say, "Oh God, you are so almighty." We never say, "O my own self, which is almighty." Because who is seeking this relief from pain and unhappiness? Actually, the sufferer right now is none other than my ego. Something happens -- who gets hurt?

So who needs liberation? My ego can never be the God's self. So my ego says oh forgive me Lord. So here Arjuna says, O forgive me. In not knowing your greatness, I must have called you Sakha, Yadava, Krishna, whatever. Maya pramadat pranayana vapi -- pramadat, out of my lethargy in understanding you. I could have realized what I'm realizing today had I given enough thought to it. But it never occurred to me that I should put enough effort to know you.

So pramada pranayana vapya -- therefore I must have done this thing out of love for you. I liked you, I loved you. I just did not know your greatness. Therefore I could not give you the due respect which you deserve.

Just continuing that -- Yacha avaha sartham asat krutosi vihara sayya asana bhujanesho -- while we were together, roaming around, sleeping in the same room, eating dinner, whatever, eating things together, I must have done things disrespectfully to you. Eko athwa api achyuta tat tamaksam tat kshamaye tvam aham aprameyam -- or when we were just alone, I must have done that. So he says, in any situation -- he's just enumerating what situations he must have done this in, whether in company or when they were together with other people.

Sometimes I say oh, it's okay that you insulted me because nobody was here. That's not good that you did that in front of my friend. Maybe I did it alone. But I may have done it even in front of other people. All of the tat shamaye. Please forgive me O Aapramayyam.

Because you are immeasurable. Basically, when an individual recognizes the Lord's greatness, in a sense we come to recognize that we are powerless in this world. And everything that we have achieved is because of his presence. Then all the credit we have taken, the ego we have developed -- all that, we feel so bad about it. I must have done all of this, O Lord, out of my own ignorance. But please forgive me. Then he says why the Lord should forgive him.

Let me tell you why you should forgive me. Because I know and I now recognize that you are Pitasi Lokasyachara Acharasya. You are the father of this entire Jagat made up of chara and Achara. That means everything. Then nothing you can leave behind in it. You are the most respectful, worshipable Guru Gariyan.

You are the greatest teacher of all. I did not know all this. You may take some blame for that -- you are the greatest guru, and living with you, I still didn't learn all this. But you are the father of all the beings. Na tvat samo asti abhyadhikah.

There is no one greater than you. I now recognize your almighty power. I thought he is powerful and he is powerful and she is powerful, and I was running after them. But I realized, when I divide this world into plurality again -- none of them have independent power. You are the powerhouse of everything.

In these three worlds. These three worlds can be defined in many different ways. One is obviously Swarga Lok, Patal Lok, and this Lok -- or Swarga, Nark, and Prithvi Lok. But three Lokas generally in Vedanta mean: my waking world is one world, in which I have all these people who are more powerful than I am, and I'm trying to gain their favor.

I'm trying to be in their company. Anytime we see somebody -- the president comes, everybody says, "Mr. President, very glad to see you, sir." The president says, "Very glad to see you also." He moves on because there are 5,000 people in a day he probably tells that to. We put the picture in our office.

"Neil with Obama." Obama probably doesn't care. There are thousands of pictures like that. "Pretty close relationship." We all have pictures with Swamiji. "We were very close to Swamiji."

Was Swamiji close to us? But that's our ego basically tells us to do. But this also our way of showing respect. There is none greater than you. So in my waking world I have thought there are many. But none has power of their own.

They all derive power from you. So you are the greatest of all in my waking world. Same is true for my dream world. I derive power in my dream world because I am conscious. I am self aware in my dream. And my own mind creates my own world.

Even there, none greater than you. And when I'm in deep sleep, there is no one. I'm completely ignorant. In my deep sleep there is no thought. In deep sleep, you are the only one who takes care of me at the time. None greater than in these three worlds.

In the last verse we see Tasmad -- therefore. Pranamya Pranidhaya Kayam -- therefore I bow down, bending my body. Prasadaye Tvam Aham Isham Idyam -- seeking your forgiveness, O adorable Lord. Now knowing your greatness, I adore you. We have learned what adoration is.

Intensive form of love. Intensive love is intense identification. I am now bowing down to you with my body, with my mind, and with my intellect. Pita Eva Putrasya -- just as the father forgives his son, no matter what the son does, once he says, "Dad, I'm sorry," that's the end of the story. No matter how bad it was. Okay my son, don't do it ever again. But I'm letting you go.

And son knows that that trick works all the time. He said, because there's a love between the father and the son. No matter what it is, he forgives you. So you should do that. You are the father of the whole universe. That's another relationship where forgiveness comes very easy.

You and your friend are really mad at each other. And the other friend, you know, Neil, I'm so sorry I did that. That's the end of the story. Let's go see a movie together. It's a very different relationship. And then when you're in love, when somebody is beloved to you, no matter what differences you have.

And you're mad at each other, as soon as one person says, "I'm sorry," that's the end of the story.
snippets.reflection:
Having recognized Krishna's true nature, Arjuna becomes acutely aware of how he has treated Krishna casually in the past. He recalls addressing him familiarly as "Krishna," "Yadava," "Friend" - calling him by first name, joking with him, perhaps even insulting him in jest during meals or leisure. "Whatever insult I have offered to Thee in sport or in repose... alone or in a multitude, I ask Thy forgiveness." This is the natural response when we suddenly realize the divine was present all along in what we treated as ordinary.

This teaching applies directly to our relationships. The same consciousness that Arjuna saw in Krishna's cosmic form is present in every person we encounter. How do we treat the divine when it appears as our spouse, our child, our colleague, the stranger at the store? The casual disrespect, the thoughtless words, the failure to truly see the other - Arjuna recognizes these as offenses against the divine itself.

Today, bring awareness to how you treat the people closest to you - precisely because familiarity often breeds carelessness. Notice when you dismiss, interrupt, or fail to fully see someone you interact with regularly. Arjuna's recognition that Krishna was "O Thou Who art without an equal" applies to the unique, irreplaceable consciousness in each person. Practice pausing before responding to a family member or close friend, and silently acknowledge: "The divine is present here." Notice how this small recognition changes the quality of your interactions.

When I came to this country, this was the biggest problem I had. Here, everybody called everybody by first name. Obviously, I was trained in India. And I said, "Oh, Neil, you can call..." I say, he's the president of our company of 200 people. I am not going to call him David. "No, no, it's okay, call him David."

But very difficult for us to do that -- how can I say? Even today, after living here for 30 years, I have a client named Charles McFarlane, and obviously we call him Charles. He's about my age, so much younger than me. His father is 80-something and he used to be our senator, Granger McFarlane. But he's also part of this project which I'm doing. So Charles will say, "Call my father."

Everybody called him Granger. I said, I'm not going to do that. I call him Mr. McFarlane and call Charles, Charles. That's how I make the distinction. So now Arjuna, realizing this, says, I must have done something not right -- I called you Sakha.

See, till we come to see God, we are not one with him, and therefore we always say, "Oh God, you are so almighty." We never say, "O my own self, which is almighty." Because who is seeking this relief from pain and unhappiness? Actually, the sufferer right now is none other than my ego. Something happens -- who gets hurt?

snippets.reflection:
Arjuna appeals to three relationships where forgiveness comes naturally: "as father to son, as friend to friend, as lover to his beloved." Then he makes his request: "I rejoice that I have seen what never man saw before; yet I am overwhelmed with fear. Please take again the Form I know." He asks to see Krishna with "the crown, the sceptre and the discus" - the familiar four-armed Vishnu form he grew up venerating. The cosmic vision, while revelatory, is more than he can bear.

This reveals something important about spiritual growth: we can only integrate as much truth as we are prepared to hold. Arjuna's request is not weakness but wisdom - he knows his limits. The cosmic vision showed him ultimate reality, but he needs to return to a form he can relate to, worship, and live with. Similarly, moments of profound spiritual insight often need to be followed by integration into ordinary life.

Reflect today on your own capacity to hold truth. Have you had experiences or insights that were overwhelming? How did you integrate them? Notice the balance between reaching for expanded awareness and respecting your current capacity. What "gentle form" of the divine can you relate to in daily life? What practice or image or relationship helps you connect with the sacred in a sustainable way? Honor both the aspiration for ultimate truth and the need for forms that support your current stage of development.

snippets.title: Day 157: Return to Grace
snippets.sanskrit:
किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रहस्तं

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

न वेदयज्ञाध्ययनैर्न दानैर्-
snippets.transliteration:
kirīṭinaṃ gadinaṃ cakrahastaṃ icchāmi tvāṃ draṣṭumahaṃ tathaiva .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

na vedayajñādhyayanairna dānaira- na ca kriyābhirna tapobhirugraiḥ .
verseTranslations: I long to see Thee as thou wert before, with the crown, the sceptre and the discus in Thy hands; in Thy other Form, with Thy four hands, O Thou Whose arms are countless and Whose forms are infinite.

Lord Shri Krishna replied: My beloved friend! It is only through My grace and power that thou hast been able to see this vision of splendour, the Universal, the Infinite, the Original. Never has it been seen by any but thee.
Not by study of the scriptures, not by sacrifice or gift, not by ritual or rigorous austerity, is it possible for man on earth to see what thou hast seen, O thou foremost hero of the Kuru-clan!
snippets.commentary:
So far we have discussed chapter 11. As we always try to remind ourselves, this chapter is all about the cosmic form of the Lord. Cosmic form of the Lord means the cosmic form of my own self -- the self which I know since I became aware of myself as this "me." When that paradigm shifts and I see that as the all-pervading self, that's the paradigm shift that happened for Arjuna. We learn all this through the scriptures and religions and philosophy -- that there is a unity in this diversity -- but it is very hard to comprehend. And therefore we crave to have that experience of that unity.

And Arjuna vocalizes our urge to see that unity to Krishna and said, I understand all that, but I want to experience it. I want to see that form of yours, O Supreme Lord, that I can understand all of that. And Bhagawan said, I'll show you. You won't be able to see it through your normal perception. The normal perception we have is I and the world exists. And therefore there is a duality.

There is a constant struggle between I and the world, where I define myself as me and the world as everything else. And then this world we divide into two: the world which I like and the world which I don't like. So our whole life pursuit is to align with the world which I like and avoid the world which I don't like. Vedanta says, all of life, the pursuit is to avoid what is unpleasant and to gain what is pleasant. And this pursuit creates the friction, and that creates more unhappiness, more dissatisfaction, because almost everyone around me is trying to do the same thing. And then we are in competition to get out of that race. If I can get that vision of oneness, then I can have that everlasting peace that I am seeking.

So Bhagavan showed this roop to Arjuna. And Arjuna sees this world without any space and time. The dividing factor between I and the world is the space and time. And once that is taken off, I see this world as one entity ever strung into each other by a common thread. But this is an overwhelming picture for Arjuna. So he said, I'm delighted to see this, but at the same time I am completely overwhelmed and I'm fearful.

So oh Lord, show me your form which is much gentler and which I am most comfortable with, which is that of Vishnu. We want to see Bhagavan in a form which is most comfortable to us, as we have discussed last time. So he says, show me with your form with the Kiritinam Gadinam, Chakrinam Hastam, with the crown and mace and Chakra which I'm so familiar with. Right from my childhood I've seen Vishnu's pictures and anytime somebody says, have you seen cosmic form? All of us say, oh yes, yeah, I've seen Bhagavad Gita pictures and you know, Shiva. Sure, because we have seen all the paintings of Shiva.

So we had a familiarity. We have formed an image of God in our head, and any image other than that -- the whole understanding that this Almighty is nothing but the source of all these beings and is all these beings -- is not really a comforting thought. Therefore, very conveniently, we divide the world into good and bad. Everything good happening is divine; bad happening is evil. Tsunami is evil, earthquake is evil. But in reality, it's all part of the whole phenomenon called this world. There's nothing evil or good about it.

Arjuna asked for that, and then Bhagavan said in his response -- Maya prasannena tava Arjuna, Idam Rupam Param Darsitam, Atma Yogat -- the last verse which we have seen. He said, I showed you the supreme form of mine graciously, because you are my devoted student, a friend, and a devotee. With my Yoga, with my power of changing your perception, I have showed you my form. Not that this form was never available. It is always available to those who can see it. Radio waves are always here for those who can tune into them -- the fact that we're not tuning into them doesn't mean they're not there. The form was always there. Arjuna did not have the capacity to see it. But my yoga gave you that perception which was Tejomayam Vishwam, Anantam, Adyam, Yanme tvad anyena Drishta Purvam -- the splendid and all-encompassing Vishwam, all-pervading infinite form which you have seen and not seen by any other before. Now, there are some saying that's not true -- Krishna already showed it to Yashoda. This is not an argument about the Puranas saying, who saw it first?

The point is that no one in this state of mind, state of evolution, state of understanding has seen this thing. If I say, "Well, I actually saw it while driving down to work yesterday" -- well, that's not true, not going to happen. Because then I won't be able to drive, because I lose that whole perception of the road, my car, and me as separate. I can't have these two together -- the perception of me and this world as separate, and the perception of me and the world as one and the same -- both at the same time.

Therefore I say, nobody has seen it before you, you remaining you. Arjuna has seen this form. And then why this is not seen by others? Because others are trying to see this by the means which they find most convenient and appropriate. We are also trying to find that source of happiness which has infinite power to make us happy. So we try our own way.

We say we will have the best education. We want our children to be the happiest in this world. What are we going to do? We're going to make sure they go to the best schools, we'll make sure they have the best health care, will make sure they will have the best desk. But do they really turn out to be the best as we see it? Because what they are looking for, or let's put it this way, we think we have done the best for them to make them happy.

Does it make them happy? In fact, half the time what we have done to make them happy makes them most unhappy. But that's the only means which we know to transfer happiness to someone else.

Na Veda Yajna Adhyayanair Na Danair Na Cha Kriyabhir Na Tapobhir Ugraih. All others are trying in this world -- by the Veda, by Dhyana, by learning Vedas. We want to learn. When I was a teenager and I see people talking about Bhagavad Gita and I used to say, I understand nothing, but someday I really want to know what they're talking about.

So we want to get the knowledge which we think the others have. So we learn Veda, Yajna, all the things which we think is good. With doing Dana, I remember in my childhood when Surat, when there is eclipse, everybody comes out in a street and then the beggars come and they know that now there's a big business time because people are doing dana at that time. Because if you do that it multiplies so many times. So Dana -- we obviously value the importance of charity. We have this notion that doing Dana, I get the merits, and that merit will earn me the vision of that source of infinite happiness, the Lord.

Yajna, Dhyana, Dana, Kriyabhi. Now actions -- obviously they translate as rituals, because religious actions in the traditional sense means ritual. I have to do this Archana or I have to do this Puja because that gives me merits, or do austerities or fasts. This many on this day, that many on that day -- all this. We are doing it to ultimately find that source of happiness which is infinite. I want that unconditioned happiness, unending happiness.

And I want to do that by gaining this. Bhagavan very clearly says, na veda na kriyabhi na tapobhi. It's not that Bhagavan is condemning this. Somewhat in a putting-it-down tone, I said this -- that's not the intention. Those are the means to prepare your mind and intellect to a level where he will shine through. We have discussed that a seeker's job is only to do the Antahkarana Shuddhi.

As per our Vedanta, our job is simply to make our Antahkarana -- the internal instrument, which is mind and intellect -- to clean it up, make it ready for his reflection into it. Because right now it is so clouded with all the layers of our vasanas on it that the reflection is not clear. We have seen in Vedanta that three types of impurities can be there. The first is like smoke in front of a mirror. You can't see the reflection because there is smoke in front of the mirror.

Well, it is very easy to dispel the smoke. But then there is the dust layer on the mirror. And third, we say, just as in the womb the fetus is enveloped in matter -- which is even more difficult. Our job with this mind and its impurities is simply to clean up the impurities. All this we have discussed is actually just for the Antahkarana Shuddhi.

Veda, Dhyana, Yajna, Tapa, Dana, Kriya -- all that is for Antahkarana Shuddhi. If you are doing it for Antahkarana Shuddhi, it will gain its results. This is all I have to do, and I'm done with it. And therefore he says, you are not getting it through these alone. So Bhagavan says, evam rupah sakya aham nrloke --

this form of mine is not possible to be seen in this world of man. Drastum tvad anyena kuru pravira -- Arjuna is Kuru Pravira, the best among the Kurus. It is not possible in this world for anyone other than you to see this by these means alone, because these are the means and not the end -- which we normally confuse as the end. The next verse we just saw is Ma te vyatha. This is a verse which shows what state Arjuna was in. Ma te vyatha cha vimudhabhavah --

Don't be disturbed and don't be fearful. I can see clearly on your face that you are disturbed, overwhelmed, and fearful by looking at this terrible form of mine. Drishtva rupam ghoram idrik mama idam -- having seen such a terrible form of mine. See, again, somewhere in the translation it says "terrific form." But it says Ghoram, which means terrible. Whether it is terrible or terrific -- who decides that?

From our point of view something may be terrible. From some other perspective it is terrific when somebody is taking those pictures of tsunamis from a distance from some satellite and then we are seeing those such a terrific form of tsunami. But guy at that whatever the beach where the tsunami is coming in Japan or wherever that is, it's a terrible form of tsunami. So he says, having seen this terrible form of mine -- because you are seeing it as a jiva, as a limited being, trying to comprehend this overwhelming nature of the self -- it's a terrible form. Vyapetabhih pritamanah -- with your fear dispelled, get your fear out, and pritamanah, have a loving nature again. Punastvam tadeva me rupam idam prapashya.

And now see this form which will remove your fear -- a loving form. Now comes a little bit of a controversy. When Bhagavan came back from his Virat Swarupa, what form did he show? Arjuna had asked for Kiritinam Gadinam Chakrinam Hastam -- you know, Vishnu Roop. But Bhagavad Gita really doesn't say that. Some commentaries have said Bhagavad Gita simply says he came back to his original gentle form as Vasudev Krishna.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna grants Arjuna's request to see a gentler form, then makes a remarkable statement: "Never has it been seen by any but thee... Not by study of the scriptures, not by sacrifice or gift, not by ritual or rigorous austerity, is it possible for man on earth to see what thou hast seen." This seems to negate all spiritual practice - if study, sacrifice, charity, and austerity cannot grant this vision, what can? The answer lies in what these practices prepare us for rather than what they directly achieve.

The teaching here parallels success in any field. Going to architecture school does not guarantee becoming a successful architect - many graduates never practice. The training is necessary but not sufficient. What is also required is devotion and the grace of opportunities. Similarly, spiritual practices purify the mind and prepare us, but the actual vision comes through grace - it cannot be demanded or earned.

For today's practice, examine your relationship to spiritual effort. Are you treating practices as transactions - "I did this much meditation, so I deserve that much peace"? Or are you doing practices for their own sake, to purify and prepare, while remaining open to grace? The vision comes through grace, in its own time, to those who have prepared and remained humble. Today, do your practices with full effort and zero expectation. Offer the effort itself as worship, and release all claims to results.

snippets.title: Day 158: The Cosmic Form
snippets.sanskrit:
मा ते व्यथा मा च विमूढभावो

सञ्जय उवाच |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
mā te vyathā mā ca vimūḍhabhāvo dṛṣṭvā rūpaṃ ghoramīdṛṅmamedam .

sañjaya uvāca .

arjuna uvāca .
verseTranslations: Be not afraid or bewildered by the terrible vision. Put away thy fear and, with joyful mind, see Me once again in My usual Form."

Sanjaya continued: "Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Lord Shri Krishna showed Himself again in His accustomed form; and the Mighty Lord, in gentle tones, softly consoled him who lately trembled with fear.
Arjuna said: Seeing Thee in Thy gentle human form, my Lord, I am myself again, calm once more.
snippets.commentary:
So far we have discussed chapter 11. As we always try to remind ourselves, this chapter is all about the cosmic form of the Lord. Cosmic form of the Lord means the cosmic form of my own self -- the self which I know since I became aware of myself as this "me." When that paradigm shifts and I see that as the all-pervading self, that's the paradigm shift that happened for Arjuna. We learn all this through the scriptures and religions and philosophy -- that there is a unity in this diversity -- but it is very hard to comprehend. And therefore we crave to have that experience of that unity.

And Arjuna vocalizes our urge to see that unity to Krishna and said, I understand all that, but I want to experience it. I want to see that form of yours, O Supreme Lord, that I can understand all of that. And Bhagawan said, I'll show you. You won't be able to see it through your normal perception. The normal perception we have is I and the world exists. And therefore there is a duality.

There is a constant struggle between I and the world, where I define myself as me and the world as everything else. And then this world we divide into two: the world which I like and the world which I don't like. So our whole life pursuit is to align with the world which I like and avoid the world which I don't like. Vedanta says, all of life, the pursuit is to avoid what is unpleasant and to gain what is pleasant. And this pursuit creates the friction, and that creates more unhappiness, more dissatisfaction, because almost everyone around me is trying to do the same thing. And then we are in competition to get out of that race. If I can get that vision of oneness, then I can have that everlasting peace that I am seeking.

So Bhagavan showed this roop to Arjuna. And Arjuna sees this world without any space and time. The dividing factor between I and the world is the space and time. And once that is taken off, I see this world as one entity ever strung into each other by a common thread. But this is an overwhelming picture for Arjuna. So he said, I'm delighted to see this, but at the same time I am completely overwhelmed and I'm fearful.

So oh Lord, show me your form which is much gentler and which I am most comfortable with, which is that of Vishnu. We want to see Bhagavan in a form which is most comfortable to us, as we have discussed last time. So he says, show me with your form with the Kiritinam Gadinam, Chakrinam Hastam, with the crown and mace and Chakra which I'm so familiar with. Right from my childhood I've seen Vishnu's pictures and anytime somebody says, have you seen cosmic form? All of us say, oh yes, yeah, I've seen Bhagavad Gita pictures and you know, Shiva. Sure, because we have seen all the paintings of Shiva.

So we had a familiarity. We have formed an image of God in our head, and any image other than that -- the whole understanding that this Almighty is nothing but the source of all these beings and is all these beings -- is not really a comforting thought. Therefore, very conveniently, we divide the world into good and bad. Everything good happening is divine; bad happening is evil. Tsunami is evil, earthquake is evil. But in reality, it's all part of the whole phenomenon called this world. There's nothing evil or good about it.

Arjuna asked for that, and then Bhagavan said in his response -- Maya prasannena tava Arjuna, Idam Rupam Param Darsitam, Atma Yogat -- the last verse which we have seen. He said, I showed you the supreme form of mine graciously, because you are my devoted student, a friend, and a devotee. With my Yoga, with my power of changing your perception, I have showed you my form. Not that this form was never available. It is always available to those who can see it. Radio waves are always here for those who can tune into them -- the fact that we're not tuning into them doesn't mean they're not there. The form was always there. Arjuna did not have the capacity to see it. But my yoga gave you that perception which was Tejomayam Vishwam, Anantam, Adyam, Yanme tvad anyena Drishta Purvam -- the splendid and all-encompassing Vishwam, all-pervading infinite form which you have seen and not seen by any other before. Now, there are some saying that's not true -- Krishna already showed it to Yashoda. This is not an argument about the Puranas saying, who saw it first?

The point is that no one in this state of mind, state of evolution, state of understanding has seen this thing. If I say, "Well, I actually saw it while driving down to work yesterday" -- well, that's not true, not going to happen. Because then I won't be able to drive, because I lose that whole perception of the road, my car, and me as separate. I can't have these two together -- the perception of me and this world as separate, and the perception of me and the world as one and the same -- both at the same time.

Therefore I say, nobody has seen it before you, you remaining you. Arjuna has seen this form. And then why this is not seen by others? Because others are trying to see this by the means which they find most convenient and appropriate. We are also trying to find that source of happiness which has infinite power to make us happy. So we try our own way.

We say we will have the best education. We want our children to be the happiest in this world. What are we going to do? We're going to make sure they go to the best schools, we'll make sure they have the best health care, will make sure they will have the best desk. But do they really turn out to be the best as we see it? Because what they are looking for, or let's put it this way, we think we have done the best for them to make them happy.

Does it make them happy? In fact, half the time what we have done to make them happy makes them most unhappy. But that's the only means which we know to transfer happiness to someone else.

Na Veda Yajna Adhyayanair Na Danair Na Cha Kriyabhir Na Tapobhir Ugraih. All others are trying in this world -- by the Veda, by Dhyana, by learning Vedas. We want to learn. When I was a teenager and I see people talking about Bhagavad Gita and I used to say, I understand nothing, but someday I really want to know what they're talking about.

So we want to get the knowledge which we think the others have. So we learn Veda, Yajna, all the things which we think is good. With doing Dana, I remember in my childhood when Surat, when there is eclipse, everybody comes out in a street and then the beggars come and they know that now there's a big business time because people are doing dana at that time. Because if you do that it multiplies so many times. So Dana -- we obviously value the importance of charity. We have this notion that doing Dana, I get the merits, and that merit will earn me the vision of that source of infinite happiness, the Lord.

Yajna, Dhyana, Dana, Kriyabhi. Now actions -- obviously they translate as rituals, because religious actions in the traditional sense means ritual. I have to do this Archana or I have to do this Puja because that gives me merits, or do austerities or fasts. This many on this day, that many on that day -- all this. We are doing it to ultimately find that source of happiness which is infinite. I want that unconditioned happiness, unending happiness.

And I want to do that by gaining this. Bhagavan very clearly says, na veda na kriyabhi na tapobhi. It's not that Bhagavan is condemning this. Somewhat in a putting-it-down tone, I said this -- that's not the intention. Those are the means to prepare your mind and intellect to a level where he will shine through. We have discussed that a seeker's job is only to do the Antahkarana Shuddhi.

As per our Vedanta, our job is simply to make our Antahkarana -- the internal instrument, which is mind and intellect -- to clean it up, make it ready for his reflection into it. Because right now it is so clouded with all the layers of our vasanas on it that the reflection is not clear. We have seen in Vedanta that three types of impurities can be there. The first is like smoke in front of a mirror. You can't see the reflection because there is smoke in front of the mirror.

Well, it is very easy to dispel the smoke. But then there is the dust layer on the mirror. And third, we say, just as in the womb the fetus is enveloped in matter -- which is even more difficult. Our job with this mind and its impurities is simply to clean up the impurities. All this we have discussed is actually just for the Antahkarana Shuddhi.

Veda, Dhyana, Yajna, Tapa, Dana, Kriya -- all that is for Antahkarana Shuddhi. If you are doing it for Antahkarana Shuddhi, it will gain its results. This is all I have to do, and I'm done with it. And therefore he says, you are not getting it through these alone. So Bhagavan says, evam rupah sakya aham nrloke --

this form of mine is not possible to be seen in this world of man. Drastum tvad anyena kuru pravira -- Arjuna is Kuru Pravira, the best among the Kurus. It is not possible in this world for anyone other than you to see this by these means alone, because these are the means and not the end -- which we normally confuse as the end.
