Don't be disturbed and don't be fearful. I can see clearly on your face that you are disturbed, overwhelmed, and fearful by looking at this terrible form of mine. Drishtva rupam ghoram idrik mama idam -- having seen such a terrible form of mine. See, again, somewhere in the translation it says "terrific form." But it says Ghoram, which means terrible. Whether it is terrible or terrific -- who decides that?

From our point of view something may be terrible. From some other perspective it is terrific when somebody is taking those pictures of tsunamis from a distance from some satellite and then we are seeing those such a terrific form of tsunami. But guy at that whatever the beach where the tsunami is coming in Japan or wherever that is, it's a terrible form of tsunami. So he says, having seen this terrible form of mine -- because you are seeing it as a jiva, as a limited being, trying to comprehend this overwhelming nature of the self -- it's a terrible form. Vyapetabhih pritamanah -- with your fear dispelled, get your fear out, and pritamanah, have a loving nature again. Punastvam tadeva me rupam idam prapashya.

And now see this form which will remove your fear -- a loving form. Now comes a little bit of a controversy. When Bhagavan came back from his Virat Swarupa, what form did he show? Arjuna had asked for Kiritinam Gadinam Chakrinam Hastam -- you know, Vishnu Roop. But Bhagavad Gita really doesn't say that. Some commentaries have said Bhagavad Gita simply says he came back to his original gentle form as Vasudev Krishna.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna speaks with gentleness: "Be not afraid or bewildered by the terrible vision. Put away thy fear and, with joyful mind, see Me once again in My usual Form." Sanjaya describes how the "Mighty Lord, in gentle tones, softly consoled him who lately trembled with fear." Then Arjuna, seeing Krishna's human form again, says: "Seeing Thee in Thy gentle human form, my Lord, I am myself again, calm once more." He has returned to normal perception after the overwhelming cosmic experience.

This return to normalcy is essential. The vision showed Arjuna ultimate reality, but he must live in the relative world, fight the battle, and fulfill his dharma. Spiritual experiences, however profound, must be integrated into daily life. Someone who remains permanently in cosmic consciousness cannot function in the world. The path involves expansion followed by integration, insight followed by application.

Reflect today on how you integrate spiritual insights into ordinary life. Have you had experiences of expanded awareness that you then had to bring back to mundane reality? How did that transition feel? The teaching suggests this is natural and necessary. The goal is not to escape ordinary life permanently but to transform how we engage with it. After touching the cosmic vision, Arjuna will fight the same battle, but with transformed understanding. What insights from your spiritual practice can you bring more fully into your daily activities, relationships, and challenges?

snippets.title: Day 159: Universal Vision
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

नाहं वेदैर्न तपसा न दानेन न चेज्यया |

भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

nāhaṃ vedairna tapasā na dānena na cejyayā .

bhaktyā tvananyayā śakya ahamevaṃvidho.arjuna .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: It is hard to see this vision of Me that thou hast seen. Even the most powerful have longed for it in vain.
Not by study of the scriptures, or by austerities, not by gifts or sacrifices, is it possible to see Me as thou hast done.
Only by tireless devotion can I be seen and known; only thus can a man become one with Me, O Arjuna!
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter 11, Viswarupadarsana Yoga -- the Yoga of Revelation of the Cosmic Form. We have seen in this chapter that Bhagavan showed his cosmic form. So what does that mean? The cosmic form is that form which includes all the forms in this cosmos, in this world, in this Jagat. All the forms at one place, from past, present, and future.

So that negates time. If there is no past, present and future, there is no time. If there is only one entity, one supreme being, then there is no time. I don't require any time to meet myself. I am always there, so there is no time required. It is when I have to meet somebody else, then I have to have time.

The two, it requires time and we can say we'll meet at 10 o' clock every Sunday morning. So as long as there are more than one, there will be time. If there's only one, there is no time. So in this cosmic form, everything is crunched into one. Past, present, future. There is no time also.

If there is one, there is no space. If there is one dot, the dot doesn't require any space. Instead of two dots, there is a distance between the two and there's space between the two. The space is created only when there are two. So in this, all forms are in one. Therefore there is no space also.

Because all forms are within that one form, that one form now becomes the form, the cosmic form. And therefore there is no space. So the space and time are both negated. In cosmic form, to have any form, what you require is space and time. Without space and time, there is no form. So the actual vision that Arjuna had was that of a formless space, supreme being.

But then he describes all these beings in it: I see Brahma, I see Vishnu, I see all the Siddhas, I see all Rakshasas, I see Dhritarashtra's sons. So in the supreme, all the probabilities -- infinite probabilities, the infinite amount of forms you can imagine -- you can create in that infinite.

It is something like if one of my clients comes to me and says, "Neil, here is a piece of land. Design a building." I say, "But what kind of a building? What do you want to use it for?" If you leave everything up to me, I have infinite possibilities -- what I can design, what type of building I can design.

There I can say, it can be a hospital, it can be a jail. It can be an office building, a multi-storied office building. Maybe it's a single-story office building. No, no, it can be residential. Well, maybe multi-story. Infinite possibilities.

To really design a building, I have to eliminate all other possibilities and narrow it down to one. It can't be a hospital because it's not possible here, not needed here. It cannot be a jail because we have no authority to imprison anybody. I have to come down to negate everything until only one choice remains, and that becomes my choice. So for any form, it's necessary that you negate all other forms.

So when I say, let's say Prakashji comes to the room and I see Prakashji -- what I have to do is negate all 7 billion people on this planet. All remaining 7 billion people are not that; that's Prakashji. So to create a form from a probability of infinite probabilities in the supreme, I have to negate all other probabilities. Here, Arjuna can see whatever he wants to see. So is the case with us, because we see from a narrow perspective, we negate things, and it comes down to a particular form. So here Bhagavan showed Arjuna the supreme form which is formless but has infinite probabilities and possibilities of forms.

So that was the reason. And therefore Arjuna could see things which are delightful and those which are frightful. When it comes to the delightful, when we think about God as divine, it is very pleasant. But when we think about God who is also responsible for -- or also enabling -- the evil in this world, that is very frightful. Therefore we say, Bhagavan, I don't want to see that part of yours. Show me something which I can live with.

So that's what we have seen so far. Arjuna requested, put me back where I was before. So Bhagavan showed him the same Swarupa as Vasudeva, as Vasudeva's son which he was before as his charioteer. And then Bhagavan told him, look, this form of mine which you have seen -- which has all the forms included from past, present, and future -- is very difficult to see. It is auspicious but very difficult to see. And therefore nobody has seen it before.

You have seen it simply because of my grace -- Atma Yogat. By my yoga I could make you see this. But it is not possible to see through all the other preparations. Learning Veda, Dhyana, Yajna -- these are means but not the goal. You cannot achieve the goal by just preparing for it. Na aham vedena tapasa na danena ijyaya shakya evam vidho drastum -- as you have seen me, it is not possible through study of Vedas or austerities or charities or even sacrifices.

It almost looks like Bhagavan is discouraging us -- none of this is going to be helpful. But Bhagavan is actually making a statement of fact. We can learn from this verse the secret of success in anything. Can I become a successful architect just by going to architecture school? Many of my classmates are in the United States.

They all went to the same school. We all got the architecture degree. None of them are practicing architecture. They're successful in what they are doing. They own motels, they own gas stations and big houses and many cars. But they're not practicing architecture.

So just by going to architecture school, I cannot become a successful architect. So is the case with doctors, engineers. What makes a person a successful professional? The first thing is his devotion to the profession. He has to be devoted to his profession. When I came to this country -- big recession time, 1982, huge recession -- I was in Houston.

Pipe drafting was a big thing there because of all the oil companies. And people said, forget about architecture, do pipe drafting, you will make a lot of money. And I said, there's one thing I will not do, and that is leave architecture. I'll find jobs somewhere. Even drafting in architecture is acceptable, but not pipe drafting. So unless you are devoted to a profession -- that's the first requirement -- but even that doesn't make me successful as a designer of buildings, because I need the grace of my clients.

I may be the best architect on this planet, but if there is no client that I can convince to let me design his or her building, then I won't be able to design. So to become a successful architect who can design a building and construct it, I need the grace of my clients. The ultimate thing I need is grace from the one from whom I am seeking that work, that achievement. But to get there, I have to do a lot more. I can't really just come out and say, "I'm devoted to architecture, give me work."

That's also not possible. You have to train yourself continuously. So that you become proficient and efficient. Then somebody will see that you are capable of doing so. So Bhagavan said, two things I require. One is your devotion to your goal.

And then grace from whoever is the fruit giver. Whoever is responsible to give you that work or that achievement. So Bhagavan says, Na aham vedair tapasa na danena ijyaya shakya evam vidho drastum drishtavanasi mam yatha -- you have seen me, but I am not possible to be seen through all these things alone. We think that preparing ourselves is good enough. But when it is not good enough, what you require is: Bhaktya tu ananyaya shakya aham evam vidho Arjuna jnatum drastum cha tattvena praveshtum cha parantapa.

It is not possible by just preparation. If you are devoted to me -- Bhaktya tu Ananyaya -- by single-minded devotion, it is possible. Bhagavan has given you the secret. What you really require is single-pointed devotion. And devotion, as we have discussed many times, is nothing but love for the divine. And love is nothing but identification.

I love someone because I identify with that person. Because I identify with this class. I like to discuss Bhagavad Gita. You like to discuss Bhagavad Gita. I love people who come to this class. So this identification is love.

I don't love my neighbour's child. As much as I love my own child. I identify with my child, my son. So love is nothing but pure identification. Without identification you cannot love anything or any being. So love for the divine is devotion.

But I cannot love the divine without knowing the divine. And therefore Bhagavan spent the last five chapters defining what the divine is, culminating in this Vishwaroop Pradarshan. So Bhagavan says it is possible. And then Bhagavan gives the steps of that vision: Jnatum drastum cha tattvena praveshtum cha parantapa.

First you have to know. For identifying with anyone. I need to know that person. I have to know that person. I can't fall in love with a girl who I never met. I have to know her first.

So jnatum -- knowing first. In our studies we say the first is Shravanam -- listen to the scriptures, listen to the nature of the Lord. This is what we are doing. We are listening from Bhagavan. Then you will see me.

Then you will know me. You will see me in my essence. Wherever I look, I see you. So that's the vision -- Drastum. In our path, through Mananam (reflection), I create a perception of what I have learned. Bhagavan's form is like that.

And then I reflect on it. Have you seen calendar pictures of Vishwarup Darshan? The painters created those iconic images we've all seen -- Bhagavan with many heads and many arms and fire coming out of his mouth. Of course, painters have their limitations. But if you have listened to the five chapters carefully and then you reflect on it, then Bhagavan says, you will see me in my essence.

The last stage is Praveshtum -- then you will identify with me. Pravesham is to become one, to enter into that self. Right now, I am in my limited being. I'm completely identified with this body, this mind, this intellect.

My identification is so complete that there is no real rivalry between my right hand and left hand, my right leg and left leg. That is complete identification with this limited self -- i.e., praveshtum, entered into that "me." Bhagavan says, if you reflect on that Vishwaroop, then you will also enter into that. You will identify with that supreme as you identify with your limited self right now. Here the operative word is Ananya Bhakti.

With single minded devotion, you shall be able to know me. You shall be able to see me. You shall be able to enter into me. The last word he gives us how to do that. So first he says, this vision is not possible without my grace. But it is possible if you are single mindedly devoted to me.

But how can I develop that single-minded devotion? Bhagavan answers in the last verse of this chapter. Mat Karma Krit -- the very first thing he says is, do everything for me. Continue doing everything you're doing right now. You think you're doing it for you, you're doing it for your family, you're doing it for your country. He says, just think -- it's all me.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna now reveals the secret: "Only by tireless devotion can I be seen and known; only thus can a man become one with Me." The word used is "ananya bhakti" - single-pointed, exclusive devotion. This is followed by a progression: know Me (jnatum), see Me (drastum), and enter into Me (praveshtum). These correspond to the traditional steps of shravana (hearing), manana (reflection), and nididhyasana (meditation/absorption). Knowledge comes first, then vision, then complete identification.

The key insight is that devotion (bhakti) is not mere emotion but deep identification. We love what we identify with - our children, our work, our country. Love and identification go together. To develop devotion to the divine requires knowing the divine (hence chapters 7-10 describing Krishna's nature), then seeing the divine in the world (the vision of chapter 11), and finally entering into complete identification where the sense of separation dissolves entirely.

For today's practice, work with the concept of "ananya" - single-pointed, without another. Examine where your devotion currently goes. Most of us are devoted to many things: comfort, success, approval, security, pleasure. These divided devotions scatter our energy. What would it mean to have all these secondary devotions organized under one primary devotion - to truth, to the divine, to consciousness itself? Begin by noticing when you serve lesser gods throughout the day. Each choice for immediate gratification over deeper truth is a moment of divided devotion.

There I can say, it can be a hospital, it can be a jail. It can be an office building, a multi-storied office building. Maybe it's a single-story office building. No, no, it can be residential. Well, maybe multi-story. Infinite possibilities.

To really design a building, I have to eliminate all other possibilities and narrow it down to one. It can't be a hospital because it's not possible here, not needed here. It cannot be a jail because we have no authority to imprison anybody. I have to come down to negate everything until only one choice remains, and that becomes my choice. So for any form, it's necessary that you negate all other forms.

So when I say, let's say Prakashji comes to the room and I see Prakashji -- what I have to do is negate all 7 billion people on this planet. All remaining 7 billion people are not that; that's Prakashji. So to create a form from a probability of infinite probabilities in the supreme, I have to negate all other probabilities. Here, Arjuna can see whatever he wants to see. So is the case with us, because we see from a narrow perspective, we negate things, and it comes down to a particular form. So here Bhagavan showed Arjuna the supreme form which is formless but has infinite probabilities and possibilities of forms.

So that was the reason. And therefore Arjuna could see things which are delightful and those which are frightful. When it comes to the delightful, when we think about God as divine, it is very pleasant. But when we think about God who is also responsible for -- or also enabling -- the evil in this world, that is very frightful. Therefore we say, Bhagavan, I don't want to see that part of yours. Show me something which I can live with.

So that's what we have seen so far. Arjuna requested, put me back where I was before. So Bhagavan showed him the same Swarupa as Vasudeva, as Vasudeva's son which he was before as his charioteer. And then Bhagavan told him, look, this form of mine which you have seen -- which has all the forms included from past, present, and future -- is very difficult to see. It is auspicious but very difficult to see. And therefore nobody has seen it before.

You have seen it simply because of my grace -- Atma Yogat. By my yoga I could make you see this. But it is not possible to see through all the other preparations. Learning Veda, Dhyana, Yajna -- these are means but not the goal. You cannot achieve the goal by just preparing for it. Na aham vedena tapasa na danena ijyaya shakya evam vidho drastum -- as you have seen me, it is not possible through study of Vedas or austerities or charities or even sacrifices.

It almost looks like Bhagavan is discouraging us -- none of this is going to be helpful. But Bhagavan is actually making a statement of fact. We can learn from this verse the secret of success in anything. Can I become a successful architect just by going to architecture school? Many of my classmates are in the United States.

They all went to the same school. We all got the architecture degree. None of them are practicing architecture. They're successful in what they are doing. They own motels, they own gas stations and big houses and many cars. But they're not practicing architecture.

So just by going to architecture school, I cannot become a successful architect. So is the case with doctors, engineers. What makes a person a successful professional? The first thing is his devotion to the profession. He has to be devoted to his profession. When I came to this country -- big recession time, 1982, huge recession -- I was in Houston.

Pipe drafting was a big thing there because of all the oil companies. And people said, forget about architecture, do pipe drafting, you will make a lot of money. And I said, there's one thing I will not do, and that is leave architecture. I'll find jobs somewhere. Even drafting in architecture is acceptable, but not pipe drafting. So unless you are devoted to a profession -- that's the first requirement -- but even that doesn't make me successful as a designer of buildings, because I need the grace of my clients.

I may be the best architect on this planet, but if there is no client that I can convince to let me design his or her building, then I won't be able to design. So to become a successful architect who can design a building and construct it, I need the grace of my clients. The ultimate thing I need is grace from the one from whom I am seeking that work, that achievement. But to get there, I have to do a lot more. I can't really just come out and say, "I'm devoted to architecture, give me work."

That's also not possible. You have to train yourself continuously. So that you become proficient and efficient. Then somebody will see that you are capable of doing so. So Bhagavan said, two things I require. One is your devotion to your goal.

And then grace from whoever is the fruit giver. Whoever is responsible to give you that work or that achievement. So Bhagavan says, Na aham vedair tapasa na danena ijyaya shakya evam vidho drastum drishtavanasi mam yatha -- you have seen me, but I am not possible to be seen through all these things alone. We think that preparing ourselves is good enough. But when it is not good enough, what you require is: Bhaktya tu ananyaya shakya aham evam vidho Arjuna jnatum drastum cha tattvena praveshtum cha parantapa.

It is not possible by just preparation. If you are devoted to me -- Bhaktya tu Ananyaya -- by single-minded devotion, it is possible. Bhagavan has given you the secret. What you really require is single-pointed devotion. And devotion, as we have discussed many times, is nothing but love for the divine. And love is nothing but identification.

I love someone because I identify with that person. Because I identify with this class. I like to discuss Bhagavad Gita. You like to discuss Bhagavad Gita. I love people who come to this class. So this identification is love.

I don't love my neighbour's child. As much as I love my own child. I identify with my child, my son. So love is nothing but pure identification. Without identification you cannot love anything or any being. So love for the divine is devotion.

But I cannot love the divine without knowing the divine. And therefore Bhagavan spent the last five chapters defining what the divine is, culminating in this Vishwaroop Pradarshan. So Bhagavan says it is possible. And then Bhagavan gives the steps of that vision: Jnatum drastum cha tattvena praveshtum cha parantapa.

First you have to know. For identifying with anyone. I need to know that person. I have to know that person. I can't fall in love with a girl who I never met. I have to know her first.

So jnatum -- knowing first. In our studies we say the first is Shravanam -- listen to the scriptures, listen to the nature of the Lord. This is what we are doing. We are listening from Bhagavan. Then you will see me.

Then you will know me. You will see me in my essence. Wherever I look, I see you. So that's the vision -- Drastum. In our path, through Mananam (reflection), I create a perception of what I have learned. Bhagavan's form is like that.

And then I reflect on it. Have you seen calendar pictures of Vishwarup Darshan? The painters created those iconic images we've all seen -- Bhagavan with many heads and many arms and fire coming out of his mouth. Of course, painters have their limitations. But if you have listened to the five chapters carefully and then you reflect on it, then Bhagavan says, you will see me in my essence.

The last stage is Praveshtum -- then you will identify with me. Pravesham is to become one, to enter into that self. Right now, I am in my limited being. I'm completely identified with this body, this mind, this intellect.

My identification is so complete that there is no real rivalry between my right hand and left hand, my right leg and left leg. That is complete identification with this limited self -- i.e., praveshtum, entered into that "me." Bhagavan says, if you reflect on that Vishwaroop, then you will also enter into that. You will identify with that supreme as you identify with your limited self right now. Here the operative word is Ananya Bhakti.

With single minded devotion, you shall be able to know me. You shall be able to see me. You shall be able to enter into me. The last word he gives us how to do that. So first he says, this vision is not possible without my grace. But it is possible if you are single mindedly devoted to me.

But how can I develop that single-minded devotion? Bhagavan answers in the last verse of this chapter. Mat Karma Krit -- the very first thing he says is, do everything for me. Continue doing everything you're doing right now. You think you're doing it for you, you're doing it for your family, you're doing it for your country. He says, just think -- it's all me.
snippets.reflection:
The chapter concludes with a comprehensive instruction: "He whose every action is done for My sake, to whom I am the final goal, who loves Me only and hates no one - only he can realize Me." This single verse summarizes the entire path: Mat-karma-krit (actions for Me), Mat-paramah (I as supreme goal), Mad-bhaktah (devoted to Me), Sanga-varjitah (free from attachment), Nirvairah (without enmity toward any being). These five qualities together describe the integrated spiritual life.

Each quality connects to the vision Arjuna has just witnessed. When you see that all beings are within the divine, acting for God means acting for the good of all. When you see that nothing exists outside the divine, making God your supreme goal means aligning with ultimate reality. Loving God only does not mean hating the world but loving the divine in and through the world. Freedom from attachment follows naturally when you see the temporary nature of all forms. And hatred toward any being becomes impossible when you recognize all beings as expressions of the One.

For your practice today, take these five qualities as a checklist. As you go through your day, ask: Is this action offered to the divine or serving my ego? Is my goal in this moment ultimate truth or temporary gain? Am I relating to this person with love for the divine presence in them? Am I attached to this outcome or free? Do I harbor enmity toward anyone? Do not expect perfection, but use these as orientation points. Each time you remember to check, you strengthen the pathways of spiritual awareness.

snippets.title: Day 161: The Path of Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

ये त्वक्षरमनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं पर्युपासते |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

ye tvakṣaramanirdeśyamavyaktaṃ paryupāsate .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna asked: My Lord! Which are the better devotees who worship Thee, those who try to know Thee as a Personal God, or those who worship Thee as Impersonal and Indestructible?
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Those who keep their minds fixed on Me, who worship Me always with unwavering faith and concentration; these are the very best.
snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

What is my purpose and destiny? So we had been discussing chapter one, Arjuna's Grief -- Arjuna Vishada Yoga. This is a contradictory term: Vishada and Yoga. Grief cannot be in Yoga; we are always in Yoga. But when we are in grief, this is the one time we really align ourselves to our own self, seeking an answer: how do I get out of this grief?

So grief also is one form of Yoga. In fact, it aligns you more to your own reality than when times are good, when we are more outwardly seeking things outside. When we are in grief, we seek inward and ask, how do I get out of this sorrow and find peace? So therefore this chapter is also called Yoga -- the Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. And the grief basically started with his looking at his situation.

So far we have seen that Dhritarashtra was curious about what's going on, out of his ignorance about the situation.

Curiosity is the manifestation of ignorance. Unless we are ignorant, we cannot be curious. We can only be curious about something we are ignorant about. We cannot be curious about something we already know. So Dhritarashtra, being ignorant about what's going on, was curious about what's happening at the battlefield of Kurukshetra, so he asked Sanjaya. And then what we have seen is Sanjaya's narration.

Sanjaya first narrated what Duryodhan was doing. Duryodhana has gauged his situation, came to the conclusion we may not have enough resources. And then Bheeshma declared the war by blowing his own conch. And once he blew his conch, everybody blew their own conch. Now we have seen that the situation is such that everybody blew their own conches. And there was so much sound, there was so much chaos that everybody was trembling with fear.

Now we are coming back to what Arjuna is doing. The last three verses say Vyavasthitan, Dhrushtva, Dhartarashtra, and Kapidhvajah. Having seen this -- the army of Duryodhana, Dhritarashtra's side, the Kaurava army assembled in the battlefield -- Kapidhvajah, the one whose flag has a monkey, Hanuman. Basically, Hanuman is a symbol of air, Marutasya putrah.

So basically his symbol says: my chariot flies like wind -- that powerful chariot, that's his symbol. So the one whose symbol is Kapidhvajah, Arjuna -- pravritte shastra sampate dhanuh udyamya pandavah. He saw that the people are ready to discharge their weapons, war is declared, everybody is anxious. And as I said, always the first person has to do something. One person blows the conch, everybody blows conches. The first person shoots an arrow, everybody starts shooting.

Nobody has shot the arrow yet, but everybody is anxious to discharge their weapons. So Arjuna also picks up his Gandiva. And then he says, Hrishikesham tada vakyam idam aha Mahipate -- O King. Sanjaya is addressing Dhritarashtra. Now that Arjuna has seen this army assembled in front of him, ready to discharge weapons, he has picked up his Gandiva. Basically, he's ready.

He probably wants to be the first one to shoot an arrow -- picks up the Gandiva. But then, as any good commander, he wants to make sure he has a complete understanding of what's going on. So then he says -- he said the following sentence to Hrishikesha Krishna, the one with the short hair. Now this is a half verse. This is where Sanjaya stops. Then we go straight to Arjuna.

So sometimes we hear Sanjaya's commentary; sometimes Sanjaya just puts it directly so we can listen to what Arjuna is saying or Krishna is saying. Arjuna uvacha: Senayoh ubhayoh madhye ratham sthapaya me Achyuta -- O Achyuta, another name of Krishna meaning one who never fails you -- take my chariot and station it right in the middle of the two armies.

This is basically something any general would do. When we are ready to attack Iraq or Iran, we say, "Oh, we know they have WMDs." Well, we have the satellites to figure it out. We concluded that Saddam Hussein has all those WMDs -- weapons of mass destruction.

And now therefore we are ready to attack him. Similarly, Arjuna said, well, let me be in a position where I can gauge the complete situation of who I have to fight so that I can strategize accordingly. Anxious soldier, anxious warrior, very confident, ready to discharge his arrow. He just wants his chariot to be in a proper location. And as Swamiji says, he shows his confidence. He says may ratham my ratha.

So he is a commander who is ready to give his command and do his duty. Yavat etan niriksheham. Why I wanted to do that because I would like to see Yudhung kaman, avasthitaan, which generals, which warriors are assembled in the other army. Obviously they didn't have satellite pictures. You have to have eye contact to figure out what's happening. So you need a station point where your perspective is panoramic, where you can see everybody.

So therefore it's a put me in a position where I can panoramically see who are assembled here. Duryodhana has already done that. Duryodhana went through who are on the other side. We haven't heard from Arjuna. Now Arjuna says I want to say Kair maya saha yuddhavyam asmin ranam samuddya me who are desirous of fighting at the eve of this battle. Eve of the battle, at just the beginning of this battle.

Let me know with whom I must fight, who I'm going to fight. Yotsyamanam aveksheham ye ete atra samagatah Dhartarashtrasya durbuddher yuddhe priyachikirshavah. He shows his disgust for the people who are in their wrong notion. Yotsyamanam avekshe aham -- because I would like to observe those who are assembled. Ye ete atra samagatah -- they're assembled here. Dhartarashtrasya durbuddheh priya chikirshavah -- who are here to fight, wishing to please in battle the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.

They are pleasing somebody who has an evil mind -- Duryodhana. They are not really using their own judgment about what is right and wrong. They just want to please somebody, whether he is wrong or right, just because he is in power, just because he is someone they need to align with. So I want to see who those people are.

Verse 24 onward is Sanjaya Vachana. We are getting back to Sanjaya: Evam uktva Hrishikesham Gudakesha Bharata senayoh ubhayoh madhye sthapayitva rathottamam.

Just as he said, Krishna established the chariot thus addressed by Gurakesha. Just as instructed by Arjuna. Shikesha situated the best of the chariots between the two armies. This is where the turning point is. Here is how he sees what the situation is. Sometimes in our ignorance we are very comfortable in what we are doing because we do not know the rest of the story.

So we are very gung-ho on doing something. It is suddenly when we have the complete picture that what I'm doing is not just truly good -- it can also affect people. Go ahead and have this gas pipeline or whatever. The fracked gas looks very good. But it's when you have the complete picture of how many people get affected by it, what the effect on the natural resources is --

Then you start questioning whether that is the right thing to do or the wrong thing to do. Till Arjuna did not have the clear picture, he was very gung-ho: "I want to fight this battle. I'll kill those people who are aligning with this Durbuddhi." We will see what happens.

We completed chapter 11, Vishwarupa Darshan. Now we have started discussing chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga.

So we have learned so far in Bhagavad Gita about our limited self -- in the first portion, up to chapter five. Then it culminated into Dhyana Yoga. Once you know about the makeup of your being, you have to contemplate upon who I am. Everything we learned in that portion says that what I have considered myself to be so far is not me. Everything I considered as me -- this body, this mind, this intellect, my accomplishments, my relationships -- all this I considered to be me.

And it turned out it is not me. I is something other than all these things. So contemplate upon the idea about who I am, that I am something other than this body, other than this mind, other than this intellect. And in that contemplation, what I find is myself. When I negate all the things which I currently consider as me, but turned out to be my equipment, my achievement, my accomplishment, my relationship, you negate all of that. And then what is left is Me.

And that I is no different than the Supreme I. That's what we learned in that segment of Bhagavad Gita. So the next segment, which we embarked on learning was to know about the nature of the Supreme Self and how I can relate myself to the Supreme Self. So we have learned that his nature is imperishable, immutable, all pervading, omnipresent, omniscient. And everything in my world that I know is strung into him like the beads and necklace. So that segment, after discussing the nature of the self, ended with chapter 11 which showed the totality of that vision.

If I have that identification not with the limited self but with the greater self, what will be my vision of that Supreme Purusha, the Ultimate Being? Everything will be included in it. Once I have that understanding of the relationship between my limited self and that supreme self, it has to culminate in devotion toward the Supreme Self. Once I identify with the supreme self, I'll be devoted to that supreme self. So the next chapter is Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of devotion.

But most of us really get scared by the very word bhakti. Because unlike Gnana and Karma, where I have some control, I have control over actions. At least I know that when I want to act, I will have the ability to act. It will be my will to engage in actions, so I can motivate myself to act. There is something I can do about it. Same way with knowledge -- I think I have some control; I can learn when I want to know.

If I think I'm ignorant about something and I really want to become knowledgeable, there are means available to me. If I can engage in it, then obviously I will get the knowledge. So with Gnana and Karma, we feel somewhat comfortable because we have something to say about it, some way to engage. But when it comes to bhakti, we are completely lost. Bhakti is an emotional response, and emotions are not something I have control over.

That's what I learned all my life that why did you do that, Neil? Because I couldn't control my emotions. I cried in public or I got angry in public. Emotions are something we are afraid that we may not have control over. So bhakti is an emotional response to something or someone I identify with. When I identify with someone, my emotional response is to like him or her or it.

So that's an emotional response and that we are very unsure about. That's what we get afraid of. Everybody says love God. Every religion says love God. Every teacher says, you should love God. But how should I love God?

Nobody has been very clear about this -- love does not come because I try hard. Trying to love someone is a very difficult thing. "Neil, you should love him." "But I don't like him." So we are very unsure about how to engage ourselves in Bhakti Yoga. Therefore, many teachers have defined Bhakti in different ways. There is a very authoritative book called Narada Bhakti Sutra.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna's question in these opening verses cuts to the heart of spiritual seeking: Should I worship the Divine with form or without form? Krishna's answer reveals that those who fix their minds on Him with unwavering faith and concentration are the "very best" devotees (yuktatamah). This teaching invites us to examine our own approach to the sacred. Bhakti, as explained here, is not merely an emotional sentiment but an alignment of the entire being toward the Divine. The word "satatayukta" (ever-steadfast) suggests that true devotion is not occasional temple visits or periodic prayers, but a continuous orientation of consciousness.

Consider today: Where does your mind naturally gravitate when left unoccupied? What occupies your thoughts in the spaces between tasks? These moments reveal where your true devotion lies. The teaching suggests that genuine spiritual progress begins when we consciously redirect this natural flow of attention toward something higher. Try this practice: At three different moments today, pause and notice where your attention has wandered. Without judgment, gently bring it back to an awareness of the Divine presence, whether you conceive of it as a personal God or an all-pervading reality.

Ask yourself: What form of the Divine feels most accessible to me right now? Is it the personal God I can speak to, or the vast, formless consciousness behind all existence? Krishna teaches that both paths are valid, but the personal path may be easier for those of us still identified with our bodies. What small step can you take today to strengthen that connection?

snippets.title: Day 162: The Ideal Devotee
snippets.sanskrit:
सन्नियम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वत्र समबुद्धयः |

क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम् |

ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः |
snippets.transliteration:
sanniyamyendriyagrāmaṃ sarvatra samabuddhayaḥ .

kleśo.adhikatarasteṣāmavyaktāsaktacetasām ||

ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi saṃnyasya matparaḥ .
verseTranslations: Subduing their senses, viewing all conditions of life with the same eye, and working for the welfare of all beings, assuredly they come to Me.
But they who thus fix their attention on the Absolute and Impersonal encounter greater hardships, for it is difficult for those who possess a body to realise Me as without one.
Verily, those who surrender their actions to Me, who muse on Me, worship Me and meditate on Me alone, with no thought save of Me,

So we are very gung-ho on doing something. It is suddenly when we have the complete picture that what I'm doing is not just truly good -- it can also affect people. Go ahead and have this gas pipeline or whatever. The fracked gas looks very good. But it's when you have the complete picture of how many people get affected by it, what the effect on the natural resources is --

Then you start questioning whether that is the right thing to do or the wrong thing to do. Till Arjuna did not have the clear picture, he was very gung-ho: "I want to fight this battle. I'll kill those people who are aligning with this Durbuddhi." We will see what happens.

We completed chapter 11, Vishwarupa Darshan. Now we have started discussing chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga.

So we have learned so far in Bhagavad Gita about our limited self -- in the first portion, up to chapter five. Then it culminated into Dhyana Yoga. Once you know about the makeup of your being, you have to contemplate upon who I am. Everything we learned in that portion says that what I have considered myself to be so far is not me. Everything I considered as me -- this body, this mind, this intellect, my accomplishments, my relationships -- all this I considered to be me.

And it turned out it is not me. I is something other than all these things. So contemplate upon the idea about who I am, that I am something other than this body, other than this mind, other than this intellect. And in that contemplation, what I find is myself. When I negate all the things which I currently consider as me, but turned out to be my equipment, my achievement, my accomplishment, my relationship, you negate all of that. And then what is left is Me.

And that I is no different than the Supreme I. That's what we learned in that segment of Bhagavad Gita. So the next segment, which we embarked on learning was to know about the nature of the Supreme Self and how I can relate myself to the Supreme Self. So we have learned that his nature is imperishable, immutable, all pervading, omnipresent, omniscient. And everything in my world that I know is strung into him like the beads and necklace. So that segment, after discussing the nature of the self, ended with chapter 11 which showed the totality of that vision.

If I have that identification not with the limited self but with the greater self, what will be my vision of that Supreme Purusha, the Ultimate Being? Everything will be included in it. Once I have that understanding of the relationship between my limited self and that supreme self, it has to culminate in devotion toward the Supreme Self. Once I identify with the supreme self, I'll be devoted to that supreme self. So the next chapter is Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of devotion.

But most of us really get scared by the very word bhakti. Because unlike Gnana and Karma, where I have some control, I have control over actions. At least I know that when I want to act, I will have the ability to act. It will be my will to engage in actions, so I can motivate myself to act. There is something I can do about it. Same way with knowledge -- I think I have some control; I can learn when I want to know.

If I think I'm ignorant about something and I really want to become knowledgeable, there are means available to me. If I can engage in it, then obviously I will get the knowledge. So with Gnana and Karma, we feel somewhat comfortable because we have something to say about it, some way to engage. But when it comes to bhakti, we are completely lost. Bhakti is an emotional response, and emotions are not something I have control over.

That's what I learned all my life that why did you do that, Neil? Because I couldn't control my emotions. I cried in public or I got angry in public. Emotions are something we are afraid that we may not have control over. So bhakti is an emotional response to something or someone I identify with. When I identify with someone, my emotional response is to like him or her or it.

So that's an emotional response and that we are very unsure about. That's what we get afraid of. Everybody says love God. Every religion says love God. Every teacher says, you should love God. But how should I love God?

Nobody has been very clear about this -- love does not come because I try hard. Trying to love someone is a very difficult thing. "Neil, you should love him." "But I don't like him." So we are very unsure about how to engage ourselves in Bhakti Yoga. Therefore, many teachers have defined Bhakti in different ways. There is a very authoritative book called Narada Bhakti Sutra.
snippets.reflection:
These verses present a profound truth about the spiritual path: the abstract, formless approach to the Divine (Avyakta) brings "greater hardships" (kleso adhikatarah) for those who identify with the body. Krishna is not discouraging the path of formless meditation, but acknowledging a practical reality. The phrase "dehavadbhir" (for the embodied ones) points to our current condition: we are deeply identified with this physical form, its sensations, its desires, its limitations. To leap from this embodied identification directly to the formless Absolute is like asking someone who has never swum to cross an ocean. The verse about surrendering all actions to the Lord ("sarvani karmani mayi sannyasya") offers a more accessible doorway.

The key teaching here is "sarvabhutahite ratah"—being engaged in the welfare of all beings. True devotion expresses itself not in withdrawal from the world but in compassionate engagement with it. When you serve others seeing them as expressions of the Divine, every interaction becomes worship. This transforms ordinary life into a spiritual practice. Notice how different this is from devotion as mere ritual or sentiment.

Today, practice this: Before each significant interaction, silently acknowledge that the person before you is an expression of the same consciousness that animates you. Whether it is a colleague, a family member, or a stranger, let your actions toward them be offerings to the Divine. At the end of the day, reflect: How did this shift in perspective change the quality of your interactions? Where did you find it easy, and where did resistance arise?

snippets.title: Day 163: Steps to Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात् |

मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय |

अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम् |
snippets.transliteration:
teṣāmahaṃ samuddhartā mṛtyusaṃsārasāgarāt .

mayyeva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṃ niveśaya .

atha cittaṃ samādhātuṃ na śaknoṣi mayi sthiram .
verseTranslations: O Arjuna! I rescue them from the ocean of life and death, for their minds are fixed on Me.
Then let thy mind cling only to Me, let thy intellect abide in Me; and without doubt thou shalt live hereafter in Me alone.
But if thou canst not fix thy mind firmly on Me, then, My beloved friend, try to do so by constant practice.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? So far we had been discussing the Bhakti Yoga chapter 12, and there are 20 verses in this chapter. It's a pretty small chapter because there is not much to tell you. Everything that has to be told is already told in the chapters before. So as we have discussed, from chapter six to ten we saw the Bhagavan's Vibhuti, his glory, his identification, how to find him in this manifest world. We saw in chapters 6 to 10 where he said, I am in the fragrance of flower, I am the sweetness of honey, I am even in the cheating power of the cheats.

Whatever you can think of is the essence of a thing or a being. The Dharma of that being or a thing is me. A thing only exists because of its inherent quality to be its own Dharma. We are human beings because we have the basic qualities necessary for a human being. You take that away, you are no more a human being. If a person looks like Michael Jackson, you go near, but he doesn't move, we know it's just a Madame Tussauds Museum statue. That's not Michael Jackson. Because that statue does not have the inherent qualities required to be Michael Jackson. So that which makes you you, and I I, and it it -- Bhagavan said -- is me. We have seen that from chapter six to ten, and from that we should have developed a devotion to the Lord. But obviously that's not that simple.

So Arjuna asked Bhagavan in chapter 11, "I understood all of it, but I want to experience it -- I can't experience it." So with Lord's grace, he gets a divine vision to comprehend this oneness in this manifest world, which is what we had been talking about. We just can't connect with that on our own. And Arjuna gets connected to that where he sees this manifest world as nothing but one being with many mouths, many hands, many legs, and many things happening. With that understanding, one should develop the devotion to that being, that one supreme Being who is nothing but my own self. So chapter 12 is the Yoga of devotion.

Once you contemplated who I am, realize the nature of the supreme and realize that myself and the supreme selves are not two different selves. I must instantaneously develop identification with that supreme self, which we call it a love for the Divine devotion. So this chapter is about all the Bhakti Yoga, how to unite with yourself by devotion. And we had been talking about various paths to attain that oneness with the Supreme. And we have talked about three different three distinct paths. Karma Yoga, Bhakti Yoga, Gnana Yoga.

And we always get confused because of our cultural baggage. We have understood bhakti as something which happens in a temple or during bhajan time. "I'm not that kind of bhakta. I don't really wear a mala and keep doing kirtan all day. I'm not a bhakta like that." So here is our chance to understand what bhakti really is.

So the chapter opened with Arjuna's two obvious questions. Should I be devoted to you in the form which I have seen -- you as Krishna or Rama or Shiva, Jesus, whatever -- whom I have now recognized as divine, while I'm a mortal, and put my faith into that one manifestation to achieve oneness? Or, as others discussed in the Vedas and Upanishads, should I worship that being which is Nirguna, Nirakara -- no qualities, no shape and form -- that all-pervading being in its unmanifest form?

And obviously Bhagavan's answer was: one who gives his mind to me and has me as the supreme goal and does it with faith, he comes to me quicker. But the others who want to devote to the unmanifest, if they can do the following -- Samniyamya indriyagramam, all the senses under control, equanimous to all, where they can see the equanimity in this entire manifest world, where they can see that underlying thread in this world of plurality and diversity which binds this entire universe -- that thread which we already discussed in previous verses.

Sutre eva, Maniganaha eva -- just as a thread in a necklace of beads -- we can see that underlying unity. And then, Sarvabhutahite rataha, I'm constantly engaging myself in the welfare of all beings. Not just my group of people, my family, my people -- while other people can go wherever -- but Sarvabhuta hite rataha, the welfare of all.

Then he also comes to me, Bhagavan said. And then obviously the question is, which one is better? Should I devote to a particular deity whom I feel closest to and most inspired by? And Bhagavan said, both are fine.

But Kleso adhikatarasteham -- those who devote to the unmanifest, it's a harder path. There are more obstacles on the way. For Dehavadbhih, those who are attached to the body, the first qualification required is to have Samniyamya indriyagramam -- all the senses under control. But if I'm not at that level and still have attachment to these senses and the body, no matter how intellectually I consider myself non-dualistic, that attachment to duality will bring me down. And therefore Bhagavan says for them it is more difficult if you are Dehavadbhih.

Not just the indweller of the body, but one who is attached to this body. I never understood the meaning of samadhi -- they talk about it in meditation and all this. But one time Swami Tejomayanda explained it to me in one simple term. He was not addressing just me, but an audience.

But I got it. He said, "You are in a state of samadhi all the time -- a samadhi with reference to your body." There is never a time where I am not identified with my body. Nobody has to wake me up and say, "Neil, that's not you, that's you." I'm always in a state of samadhi with reference to my body. That's actually Dehavadbhih.

I'm attached to this body. For me, clinging to this body as the ego-I and then trying to establish myself into the supreme unmanifest -- Bhagavan says Kleso adhikatarasteham, for them there are lots of difficulties. Therefore he said, the easy path is Mayyeva mana adhatsva. Give your mind to me and then do everything for me.

And I will become your savior -- to save you from this ocean of samsara, this ocean of experiences which seems infinite. I don't see the end of it. So many times I thought I got it. We told Bhagavan, "Oh Lord, just give me this, just give me a green card and I'll be fine."

Oh Lord, give me a green card. Because the green card these days takes about eight to ten years. I have somebody with me who has been here like six years now. I applied for his green card about three years ago, and we are renewing for the third time. So believe it or not, his prayer to the Lord is what?

"Oh Lord, give me a green card." After that I'm taken care of, right? Green card lets you stay here, do whatever you want to do. And as soon as you get the green card -- what? "Oh Lord, find me the right partner."

So now I can settle down. And then it continues. Many, many times we thought there was an end to these difficulties, that once I get past this sorrow I'll be done. But the moment we get there we realize, no, no -- the infinite experiences which give me joys and sorrows never end.

It never comes with pure joy. What I really want to achieve is a state where there is no sorrow. But this Samsara -- Samsarati -- the constantly changing life of mine, these infinite experiences, I don't see the end of it. One thing ends, a new thing starts.

Bhagavan says, for those who have given their mind to me and have supreme faith in me, I become their savior. They are not capable by themselves of crossing this ocean of infinite experiences -- infinite experiences in a finite world. I will be the savior for them, to save them and take them to the other side.

Where there is no sorrow, where there is pure happiness -- what you are looking for. There is no ignorance about who I am, there is no death, there is no end of me.

There is no ignorance and there is no sorrow. So it's all about the mind -- that's what we figured out. Bhagavan never said give me your intellect and body. The intellect is nothing but a memory bank of my experiences; I think I know based on only my experiences. But the mind takes flight into the unknown and keeps on going.

There is a story about a Sankalpa Shali -- one who can't control his imagination. I'd heard a story in my childhood about a Brahmin's son who makes his living by getting bhiksha, alms. One day he got more bhiksha than he could consume. He said, "Well, today was a good day and I got a lot of this bhiksha. I cannot consume all of it."

"So what I'm going to do is take the part which is left and sell it and make some money. Then what I'm going to do with that money? Well, I'll buy this and then I'll do this little business. Then I'll make more money, and then I will find a worthy partner. Then I'll get married."

"And then I will have children, and then children will come to me." And in his excitement he kicked -- he kicked that pot which had the flour in it, broke it, and it was all gone. His flight of imagination took him away, and he lost everything he was dreaming about. So Bhagavan said, that quality of the mind which we have seen is Sankalpa Shakti.

You need to curb that and put it in me. Nivasishyasi mayyeva ata urdhvam na samshayah. Fix thy mind in me, place thy intellect in me too. See, right now we are so dependent on our own intellect. Doubt comes to the mind. Almost everybody who learned Bhagavad Gita has said, "All this is great, but I don't think you can succeed if you just continue like this."

"You have to have passion and drive, then only you can succeed in life. So learn this, but don't get hung up on it." Why? Because we are relying on our own intellect, which is nothing but a bank of finite experiences that tells us what succeeds and what doesn't. We have seen people like Steve Jobs and say, "That's why they are succeeding -- I should be like that." Bhagavan said, no, don't rely on your intellect.

It will misguide you, because it does not have the capacity to go beyond the realm of your experiences. What you are trying to cross is the realm of your experiences. How can you rely on your intellect for that? You need to plug into the global database, the cosmic database. If I don't know anything, what do I do?

I go on Google and see if I can find it. If I find it on Google, I'm fine. That entire database of the supreme intellect, that cosmic intelligence, I need to rest in that. I have to rest my intellect into that. Plug into not only my hard drive which is my intellect to the cloud computing connected to that Bhagavan. Not only give your mind to me but rest your intellect into me.

Realize that there is a guide who will guide me once I put faith in him.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna's promise in verse 7 is breathtaking: "I rescue them from the ocean of life and death" (mrityu-samsara-sagarat). The image of samsara as an ocean is powerful—endless waves of experience, joy and sorrow rising and falling, with no shore in sight. We have all felt this: the moment we achieve one goal, another desire arises. Green card leads to wanting a partner; partnership leads to wanting children; children bring new anxieties. The cycle seems infinite. Yet Krishna offers Himself as the rescuer for those whose minds are "fixed on Me" (mayy-avesita-cetasam).

The practical instruction in verse 8 is remarkably direct: "Let thy mind cling only to Me, let thy intellect abide in Me." This is not passive wishing but active engagement. The mind must be placed (adhatsva) in the Divine; the intellect must be established (nivesaya) there. As the teaching explains, our intellect is like a personal hard drive with limited data from our finite experiences. Devotion means plugging into the "cosmic database"—trusting a wisdom greater than our own accumulated knowledge. When doubt arises about decisions, ask: Am I relying solely on my limited experience, or am I open to guidance from a higher intelligence?

Verse 9 offers compassionate encouragement for those who struggle: "If thou canst not fix thy mind firmly on Me, then try to do so by constant practice" (abhyasa-yogena). This is the path for most of us. Practice today by setting three reminders on your phone. When each reminder sounds, pause whatever you are doing and consciously place your attention on the Divine for just one minute. Notice how the mind resists, wanders, returns. This is abhyasa yoga—patient, persistent practice without expectation of immediate perfection.

snippets.title: Day 164: Dear to the Lord
snippets.sanskrit:
अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव |

अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः |

श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
abhyāse.apyasamartho.asi matkarmaparamo bhava .

athaitadapyaśakto.asi kartuṃ madyogamāśritaḥ .

śreyo hi jñānamabhyāsājjñānāddhyānaṃ viśiṣyate .
verseTranslations: And if thou are not strong enough to practise concentration, then devote thyself to My service, do all thine acts for My sake, and thou shalt still attain the goal.
And if thou art too weak even for this, then seek refuge in union with Me, and with perfect self-control renounce the fruit of thy action.
Knowledge is superior to blind action, meditation to mere knowledge, renunciation of the fruit of action to meditation, and where there is renunciation peace will follow.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of Devotion. In our scriptures, generally there are three paths prescribed: Karma Yoga, Gnana Yoga, and Bhakti Yoga. Most people consider Bhakti Yoga to be the easiest path because it requires no special training, no special arrangement. You can just go and worship the Lord.

You go to the temple, you sing bhajans. So most people feel it is more comfortable and much easier to practice Bhakti Yoga than Karma Yoga or Gnana Yoga. That's our general understanding. But it turns out Bhakti Yoga is the most difficult path to follow, because Bhakti is the emotional response to something we adore or something we worship. Devotion, as we have discussed before, is nothing but love for the divine. Narad Ji defines Bhakti in his Narad Bhakti Sutra as Sa Tasmin Premarupa -- it is of the nature of love. It is the nature of immortality. Yat labdhva puman siddho bhavati -- once a person achieves that Bhakti, becomes established in Bhakti Yoga, that person becomes Siddha, accomplished. Amritva bhavati -- he becomes immortal. And Tripto bhavati -- he becomes completely satisfied.

So to achieve that state is not very simple. So what we find actually is it is easier for me to practice Karma Yoga. Karma Yoga is something related to my actions. I consider it is in my control. How I act in this world is something I can control. So Karma Yoga is related to my organs of actions and how I perform my actions in this world which I consider I have some control over it.

At least I can attempt to practice Karma Yoga. And then Gnana Yoga is related to the intellect -- acquiring knowledge. That again I find is something in my control. I can make a choice that I want to learn this or that. If I want to learn about physics, I can make a resolve, go to the physics department, learn physics.

So knowledge is something I find within my choice to pursue, just as actions are within my choice to pursue. But Bhakti is related to the mind. It's an emotional response. Nobody can say, "I'll fall in love in 2025." You cannot plan falling in love.

It really does not go by your planning or your calendar. The love will only come if I know the divine. And therefore, we have gone through five chapters in this segment, from the 7th through the 11th, to know the Supreme Lord. In chapters 10 and 11, Bhagavan has given Arjuna all the required information -- chapter 10 gave all the Vibhutis in the manifest world, then chapter 11 gave him the total representation of his nature. If you have been equipped with that level of knowledge, then Bhakti actually becomes an automatic response. However, it is still related to the mind.

And therefore Bhagavan starts this chapter by saying, fix your mind onto me. No matter what amount of knowledge I may have intellectually or how much activity I have performed, it is the mind which decides my next destination. It is the mind which will have the desire to explore new things. So Bhagavan said, attach your mind to me.

We have seen in the last few verses that Bhagavan has clarified: focusing your mind on one particular form is the easiest way to do it. That does not mean Bhagavan is simply saying idol worship is all you have to do.

So we discussed last time whether idol worship is acceptable or not. It is one form, one means to achieve bhakti. Most of the time when we consider Bhakti, we think simply: "He is going to the temple and singing bhajans, so that's the sum total of bhakti." And Bhagavan said, that's not true. It is your mind that matters, not the activity of going to the temple, not the singing.

Swamiji used to say, bhajans with noisy instruments -- that's not Bhakti. Bhakti is where the mind penetrates the nature of the Lord and fixes itself to that form. Bhagavan said, the first requirement is: fix your mind onto me. Your mind and intellect should be firmly established in that supreme knowledge. That's what we've been learning throughout these last five chapters.

Nothing exists other than his self. What I see through my senses is his lower nature. What I do not see but feel as my own existence, my own consciousness, is his higher nature. I cannot vouch for any other person's consciousness, but I can vouch for my own -- because I feel I exist, and that nobody can take away from me. This consciousness cannot be displayed in any other way than when I act outside. Then you can say, "He's speaking, he's talking, he's alive."

So that is the higher nature. The consciousness which makes this inert equipment function in this world is the higher nature. If you understood these two, then "focus your mind onto me, constantly think about me" does not mean you have to drop everything and start thinking about him. But whatever you think, in the back of your mind you should know that he is the enabler of this thought. Without his presence, without this consciousness, this mind cannot even run away in different directions. At least you should have that as a background thought.

Just as in music you have the Shruti playing in the background -- nobody pays attention to the Shruti. But the moment you miss the Shruti, you are done with your bhajan. If you pay attention to the Shruti, the entire music falls in place. Once you miss it, everything is haywire. Our Shruti should be that I am that Satchitananda -- this consciousness is me.

But when we miss that and ignore that, the music of our life falls apart. Bhagavan said, therefore Mayy aveshita mana, and then Buddhi niveshaya -- place your intellect into me. So now that intellectually we appreciate that Bhagavan is everywhere, that there is nothing that exists without Bhagavan, that everything I see is Bhagavan alone -- now my intellect reminds me every time I transact in this world.

Then no matter what I think about, the party I'm dealing with is nothing but his own representation. And Bhagavan said, if you keep that in mind, you will never be able to do anything wrong. You will not be able to perform any crime. And therefore he says, Nivasishyasi mayyeva ata urdhvam na samshayah. If you constantly keep this thought in your mind and have your intellect constantly remind you that whatever you are dealing with in this world is nothing but his Prakriti, then you will come to me. You will reside in me.

There is no doubt about it. So Bhagavan has clearly clarified: Bhakti is all about mental control, having the mind focused on the supreme reality. We find that actually very difficult, because we all have admitted that controlling the mind is not that easy.

So Bhakti is actually a destination. You start your journey from Karma Yoga. If you have no other training in spirituality and somebody says this is the path, then the easiest path is Karma Yoga, because you can control your actions. When you purify mind and intellect through action, your intellect becomes ready for knowledge. Then once you get knowledge, you really have to do nothing.

You don't have to do anything. Bhakti will reveal itself automatically in your mind. It's like when you fell in love -- you didn't even realize when you fell in love. You started knowing about her at some point, and you didn't realize when it happened.

There is no timeframe -- you can't say on such and such date I fell in love. I went to a music teacher when I was in my late 40s, and I kept saying, "Subhashi, I really have trouble understanding what you are saying. I understand it, but I don't feel it. You're telling me I'm out of rhythm, but I don't know when I'm out of rhythm."

When I stopped going to class, at some point I started understanding it -- I'm out of scale, I'm out of rhythm. And when that happened, I cannot pinpoint when the knowledge of scale and rhythm came. There is no timeline for it. But it was because of the music classes I took. This is what happens when knowledge matures into skill. So Bhagavan said, all you have to do is purify your mind and intellect.

Put your mind and intellect in me and this will happen automatically. Once you achieve Bhakti, as Narad Muni said, it is Amrita Swarupa. You will have no fear of death. You will feel Tripta -- completely satisfied. You will have nothing more to achieve in this world. But Bhagavan is very kind and said there are alternates.

If you don't think that is possible for you even after going through the last five chapters, then he said, if you are not capable of controlling your mind, just perform Abhyasa Yoga. Abhyasa Yoga is simply to keep reminding yourself that you are deviating from what you have learned and to try to bring the mind back to its goal. It's constant practice. Practice makes you perfect. By practice, you can train wild animals in a circus.

So obviously you can train your mind. If wild animals can be trained, your mind can be trained -- it's a matter of how much practice you put in. Bhagavan says, just keep practicing. But somebody like me says, "Bhagavan, even that's really difficult. I get so distracted by my thoughts that I even forget to remember that I have to bring my mind back to where it should be."

And Bhagavan has already said in chapter seven that all my devotees are Udaraha -- noble people. No matter what level they are, Udara Sarvaivaithi, they are all good people performing good actions. No matter how incomplete they are, no matter how incapable they are of realizing their own self.

But they're good people. At whatever level you are -- whether at a kindergarten level or a high school level -- you can start your journey towards your goal. Abhyase api asamarthosi matkarma paramo bhava. Then perform actions for me. But keep in mind that you are doing it for the Lord.

In the sense that if I have come to realize that there is nothing but the Lord alone, then whoever I serve, I'm serving him. In your profession, when you serve your clients, keep in mind that the client is nothing but his own representation. You serving him is serving the Lord. You serve other people -- they are also forms of the same Lord.

And therefore I'm serving Him. So keep that thought in mind: I am performing all actions for him only. Madartham api karmani kurvan siddhim avapsyasi -- even just by performing actions for me, you can achieve that perfection. You don't have to meditate. You don't have to do any kind of tapas.

But keep performing your actions for me alone, and keep in mind that you're not doing it for yourself. This limited self has to be removed from the equation. Now I want welfare of all beings. But even that is not possible for some. You are so self-focused that you can't think about anybody but yourself.

"What I'm doing is for myself" or "I am the doer" -- the ego is so strong. Bhagavan says, Atha etad api ashakto asi -- if you are even incapable of doing so -- then Kartum madyogam ashritah sarva karma phala tyagam. If you cannot perform all actions for me, perform actions for whatever purpose you were performing before -- for accomplishing things, achieving respect in society, your big bank balances, all that.

Continue doing the same thing you are doing. But give up the anxiety for the fruits.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal Krishna's extraordinary compassion as a teacher. He offers a descending ladder of practice for aspirants at different levels. Cannot fix your mind on the Divine? Practice concentration (abhyasa). Cannot practice concentration? Perform actions for His sake (mat-karma). Cannot even do that? Simply renounce the fruits of action (sarva-karma-phala-tyagam). The teaching meets us exactly where we are. Verse 12 presents a remarkable hierarchy: "Knowledge is superior to blind action, meditation to mere knowledge, renunciation of the fruit of action to meditation, and where there is renunciation peace will follow." The culmination is telling—peace (shanti) comes immediately (anantaram) from letting go of attachment to results.

This is profoundly practical wisdom. Most of our mental suffering comes not from our actions themselves but from our anxious attachment to their outcomes. We plan for the green card, then the partner, then the children, then their education, then their success—an endless chain of anxiety about future results. Krishna does not ask us to stop acting or even stop planning. He asks us to release the grip of anticipation, to act fully while holding outcomes lightly.

Today, choose one task that normally causes you anxiety about results—perhaps a work presentation, a difficult conversation, or a creative project. Before beginning, consciously offer both the action and its outcome to something greater than your ego. Perform the task with full engagement, but notice when the mind starts calculating results. Each time it does, gently return to the present action. At day's end, reflect: Did this shift bring any measure of peace? The teaching promises it will—not eventually, but "anantaram," immediately.

snippets.title: Day 165: The Path of Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च |

सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः |

यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः |
snippets.transliteration:
adveṣṭā sarvabhūtānāṃ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca .

santuṣṭaḥ satataṃ yogī yatātmā dṛḍhaniścayaḥ .

yasmānnodvijate loko lokānnodvijate ca yaḥ .
verseTranslations: He who is incapable of hatred towards any being, who is kind and compassionate, free from selfishness, without pride, equable in pleasure and in pain, and forgiving,
Always contented, self-centred, self-controlled, resolute, with mind and reason dedicated to Me, such a devotee of Mine is My beloved.
He who does not harm the world, and whom the world cannot harm, who is not carried away by any impulse of joy, anger or fear, such a one is My beloved.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 12. This is Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of devotion. As we had been discussing, the Bhagavad Gita is the science of self-improvement. We started out with the first section of the Bhagavad Gita to understand who we are, how our body, mind, and intellect function, and how we can perform the most effective actions. That segment ended with meditation.

Once you understood what is myself and what is not myself, you have to contemplate on it, meditate on it -- to move this identification from this limited self, which is very natural to us ("you consider this is me"), to that supreme Me, the self which is all-pervading. And then we have seen the Lord's nature. Once you identify with the self, what is the nature of that self? What do I need to meditate on?

So in chapters seven through eleven, we have seen the nature of that self, that all-pervading self, and that segment ended in Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of devotion. The identification with that supreme self is devotion to that supreme self. We have many times discussed this: devotion is love. And divine love is nothing but identification. Identification only comes by finding our common traits, our common ground. Our common ground with the supreme self is: I want happiness -- unlimited happiness, unlimited existence, and unlimited bliss.

This is what I'm looking for in my life. Scripture says the only way you can achieve it is once you identify with that self. So Bhakti Yoga is the yoga of devotion -- how to achieve that identification. We have seen there are two ways of meditating upon the supreme: either with form or without form. And Bhagavan said, with form is easier for one who is associated with the body, one who is more attached to this body, this limited ego.

It's easier to identify with the Lord with the form, whatever form that you and I can assign for our own personal God. And then he says, what is devotion? He said, devotion is the complete surrender of my mind to Him. Right now, my mind is surrendered completely to my ego. My mind and intellect have identified completely with my ego. And therefore I am one with my ego.

My identity is my ego. And therefore all the limitations of my mind and intellect are now the limitations of myself, as identified with the ego. The sorrows I'm experiencing in life, the unhappiness I'm experiencing -- these are because of these limitations. My inner self is seeking complete happiness, unending happiness, unbound happiness. But I am identified with my ego, and therefore the limitations of my mind and intellect are creating unpleasant situations.

So to get out of this situation, the only way I can achieve that perfect happiness is by identifying with that supreme self -- the self which is residing in me, residing in you, residing in him, residing in her, and in everything that we perceive, think, and consider as our world.

Therefore, Bhagavan in the last seven verses of this chapter, starting from verse 13, enumerates the qualities of a true devotee -- a true Bhakta who has surrendered his or her mind and intellect to the supreme self. Now the mind and intellect have become instruments of the supreme Self, the Lord we have seen.

In the last two verses we discussed -- verses 13 and 14 -- Bhagavan has enumerated 11 qualities of a true devotee: Adveshta Sarvabhutanam, Maitrah, Karuna evacha, Nirmamah, Nirahankara, Samaduhkha-sukhah, Kshami. He hates no creature, he is friendly to all beings, he's compassionate, he has no ego, he has no sense of attachment, he is balanced in pleasure and pain. Santushtah satatam yogi, yatatma, dridha-nishchayah. He is ever content, steady in meditation about who he is.

He is self-controlled and possesses firm conviction, with mind and intellect dedicated to the supreme self. Bhagavan says, such a person is my Bhakta, and he is dear to me.

Continuing the same description of the true devotee, Bhagavan describes in verse 15: Yasmat na udvijate Lokah -- he by whom the world is not agitated. If my presence makes the world around me agitated, then obviously there is something I need to correct in myself.

We have experienced this all the time. Some people can just enter a room and suddenly the room is in a positive, joyful mood. They bring that joy, that enthusiasm, that excitement into the room. And some people come in and there is gloom and doom. We have experienced this with our day-to-day acquaintances and friends. But most profoundly, we have experienced this in the presence of a Mahatma.

I have experienced this in the presence of Swami Chinmayananda, where people used to sit for hours, including myself, without doing anything -- just sitting in front of him and watching him. It gives you such peace in your mind that you just don't want to leave. When Swamiji would come, all the devotees would get together. Those who were close to him would get a chance to be with him, just be in his room. And Swamiji would be doing whatever he was doing.
