He'd be watching tennis -- Swamiji used to love watching tennis after lectures. Somebody would have taped the Wimbledon matches or whatever tournament, and he would be watching that. And other people would just be watching Swamiji, feeling peace.

In the very early days of my exposure to spirituality, my mentor at the time was a chief architect where I used to work as an intern architect.

After the first year of architecture school, during a vacation, he took me to Sant Mota in Surat. At the time I didn't understand much, but because my chief architect told me I should come with him, I went along. Somebody asked Sant Mota a question: "How do we know that a person we are meeting is a true saint? Because he could be a cheat, just putting up a show and deceiving people."

And Sant Mota said, there is only one test for it. If in his presence you feel peace, he is a true sadhu or sanyasi. If in his presence your mind gets agitated, consider that person not a genuine saint. At that age -- I was only about 17 -- I couldn't understand how that could be. But over the years I've experienced that in the presence of a Mahatma, peace prevails in your mind. Automatically, he projects his peace into your mind and into everyone around him.

So Bhagavan said, Yasmat na udvijate Lokah -- he by whom the world is not agitated. His presence brings peace and joy to the people around him and the world around him. We have heard that in the presence of Lord Buddha and such Mahatmas, even animals would sit down in front of them and feel peace. Lions and tigers have been calmed by Lord Buddha. Lokat na udvijate cha yah -- neither does he agitate the world, nor can the world agitate him.

So these are the qualities you find in a true devotee of the Lord: in his presence you will experience joy, and the agitation in your mind will not affect him. Sometimes everything is going well at home. But as soon as I come from my office, I create agitation in the house, because I bring my agitation from the office into the home.

And now my household, which was peaceful without me, is agitated because of my presence. That's why we typically have that threat to our children: "Well, you just wait -- dad is coming." That means there will be turmoil and agitation in the house. "So you behave and don't add any more agitation to his agitation." We put so much burden on our children to calm down their parents.

Obviously I'm joking. So Bhagavan said that my devotee is such a person who brings peace to this world and does not get agitated by this world. Harsha, Amarsha, Bhaya, Udvega Muktah -- free from elation, envy, fear, and anxiety. Such a person, Bhagavan says, Yah sa cha me priyah -- he is closer to me. This does not mean that Bhagavan is partial to him.

Rather, he feels the peace prevailing in the supreme self as his own peace, and therefore he is closer to him. Continuing in the same vein, the next two verses form the third segment of the qualities of a true devotee: Anapekshah, Shuchih, Dakshah, Udasinah, Gatavyathah. So far in the previous stanzas we have seen about 14 characteristics of a true devotee. In this stanza we see six more.

Anapekshah -- he is free from all wants. He has no expectation from this world. Now these are very difficult concepts for you and me to understand, because we live in a world where expectation, anticipation, and performing to someone's expectations are a normal part of our vocabulary -- in the business world, in our regular world. But what we are talking about here is our internal world.

We are not talking about the world outside, where I deal with my peers, my superiors, my enemies, and my competitors. That's the world my ego has created. The world we are concerned about is the world of my inner self. For that inner self, there is no real enemy, no real competitor, because the same self which is pervading the entire Jagat is also residing in me.

And I'm trying to get in contact with that. Once I am in touch with that, Bhagavan said, you will have no Apeksha. I am satisfied by my own self, and therefore I have no other expectation from the world. Up till now, my expectation was that the world will make me happy. My children will grow up and do this and that, and they will make me happy.

My wife will do this and that will make me happy. My friends will do this and that will make me happy. I have mortgaged my happiness with all the people I know, but have not left anything for me to do. So now I have no control over my happiness -- I have to rely on the people with whom I've mortgaged it. They have to do something to make me happy.

My children have to perform well in their studies or in their sports or whatever I expect them to do. My wife has to perform according to my desires. My friends have to behave the way I want. When they do that, I'll be happy. So I mortgage my happiness. And therefore I have Apeksha -- expectations from the world to make me happy.

Bhagavan says my devotee is Anapekshah. There is no expectation because he is the reservoir of his own happiness. Shuchih -- someone who is devoted to the Lord cannot be filthy and dirty, both in his own mind and intellect, and also in his surroundings. He will live a clean life, both inside and out.

When your mind is clean you automatically will make your environment around you clean. It has a reverse effect also. When my environment around me is clean it will calm my mind down and my mind will be clean too. Dakshah -- there is no laziness in him.
snippets.reflection:
These verses begin Krishna's portrait of the ideal devotee, and the qualities are striking: "Adveshta sarvabhutanam"—incapable of hatred toward any being. Not merely controlling hatred, but being constitutionally incapable of it. "Maitrah karunah"—friendly and compassionate. "Nirmamah nirahankarah"—free from possessiveness and ego. "Samadukhha-sukhah"—balanced in pain and pleasure. These are not commandments to follow but descriptions of what naturally emerges when the mind is surrendered to the Divine. The devotee does not struggle to be compassionate; compassion flows naturally when the ego-barrier dissolves.

Verse 15 offers a powerful diagnostic: "He who does not harm the world, and whom the world cannot harm" (yasmat na udvijate lokah, lokat na udvijate ca yah). The teaching illustrates this beautifully with the example of Sant Mota's test for a true sadhu: if you feel peace in someone's presence, they are genuine; if you feel agitated, they are not. Consider: What effect does your presence have on others? When you enter a room, does the atmosphere lighten or tense? This is not about being artificially pleasant but about the natural radiation of an untroubled mind.

For today's practice, focus on the quality of "kshami"—forgiveness. Identify one person toward whom you hold resentment, however small. You need not contact them or resolve the situation externally. Simply sit quietly and consciously release the grip of that resentment. Notice how the mind wants to justify holding on—"But they really did wrong me." Acknowledge that and release anyway. True forgiveness is not about condoning actions but about freeing your own mind from the prison of grievance. Observe: Does this release bring any taste of the peace Krishna describes?

snippets.title: Day 166: The Ideal Devotee
snippets.sanskrit:
अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः |

यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति |

समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः |
snippets.transliteration:
anapekṣaḥ śucirdakṣa udāsīno gatavyathaḥ .

yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati .

samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ .
verseTranslations: He who expects nothing, who is pure, watchful, indifferent, unruffled, and who renounces all initiative, such a one is My beloved.
He who is beyond joy and hate, who neither laments nor desires, to whom good and evil fortunes are the same, such a one is My beloved.
snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga, Yoga of Devotion. The first six chapters described Karma Yoga -- the Yoga of action -- teaching us who we are as individuals, how our actions function, and how we can make our actions more efficient. We have seen two definitions of Yoga: Samatvam Yoga Uchyate and Yogah Karmasu Kaushalam. The equanimity of mind is Yoga, and the dexterity in action is also Yoga.

You can only be dexterous in your actions if your mind is quiet. That was the technique we learned in the first six chapters. And at the end of those chapters we had Dhyana Yoga, the Yoga of Meditation. Bhagavan said, I consider a Yogi to be higher than even a Gnani, even a Tapasvi. So he said, "You become a Yogi, Arjuna." Arjuna asked, "How do I become a Yogi?"

He said, offer your mind and intellect to me, focus your mind and intellect on me, synchronize your mind and intellect with me, and you become a Yogi. Bhagavan has defined the perfect Bhakta as the one who offers his mind and intellect and considers him to be the supreme goal. Now here we discussed that Bhagavan, the supreme self which is pervading everywhere, is the same self that you consider yourself. Right now I consider myself to be identified with this body, mind, and intellect. Bhagavan said, when you tune your mind and intellect to me, align with me, and identify with me, you become my Bhakta.

So that's the definition of Bhakta we learn upfront in this chapter: Mayy arpita manobuddhih -- one who has offered his mind and intellect to me. Swamiji used to joke about it: in all our temples, the Bhagavans are standing there with the hand extended, hoping that some Bhakta will come someday and offer his mind and intellect. "I'll fix it and give it back to him." But he says they're all unemployed, because no Bhakta ever goes to offer his mind and intellect.

They go and offer coconuts and flowers and prasad, but nobody is interested in giving their mind or intellect to Bhagavan. So Bhagavan has defined in this chapter: the devotee is the one whose mind is fixed on him and whose intellect is aligned with him.

We started this chapter with Arjuna's question about the two types of Bhaktas: one who considers God to be manifested in a particular form and worships him as his goal, and one who considers God to be Nirakara -- without any attributes, only all-pervading. Which one is better, which one is closer to him? And Bhagavan said, both are closer to me.

But for somebody who considers himself to be embodied, who identifies with his body as himself, it is very difficult to focus on God without any attributes. Therefore, it is much easier for you, Arjuna, to focus on someone or something you consider as the representation of the supreme reality. In this case, Bhagavan said, focus on me, Krishna, as the representation of the supreme reality -- see the entire divinity in that person. Swamiji explains: just as we assign our entire patriotic feelings to the flag of our country. When that flag is raised in the stadium during the Olympic medal ceremony, all citizens of that country feel elated because that flag represents their entire identification with their country.

Bhagavan said, in the same way, when you can see the entire supreme reality represented in one person or one form, then it is easier for you to worship through that one. Then Bhagavan has given us choices: if you cannot offer your mind and intellect to me, at least do Abhyasa, constant practice. There are two ways to interpret this. One is to constantly keep trying to offer your mind and intellect to Bhagavan. The other is to learn about the nature of God through the scriptures, so that you come to realize what the supreme reality is and then offer yourself to it. If even that is not possible, offer all your actions to me -- work for me.

Surrender to me, and I'll take care of everything. It's like when you work for a large company. Whatever you do in your position, you're actually doing it for the company. When you go to a meeting with your client, you don't say "I am such and such." You say, "I represent such and such company." The entire power of that company is behind you.

Nobody knows better than me, because I used to work for large companies. The last firm I worked at had 2,100 people. So when I represented myself as from that firm, they obviously knew I represented a 2,100-person firm. When I left that firm and started my own, I had five people. When I'd say I'm NBG Architecture, first I'd have to explain what NBG Architecture is, who owns it, and how it came into existence. Then I'd say, "I'm the same person you used to meet."

Because the power of that company is what you're representing. The larger the company, the more power you have behind you. So if you identify with this limited mind and intellect, you're projecting the limited power of this mind and intellect. But if you identify with that universal mind and intellect, then when you work in the world outside, you're projecting the power of the supreme. Bhagavan said, do all your actions for me. Consider me as your employer and then work in this world, and you will have the supreme power behind you to be successful in everything you do.

If even that is not possible, then give up the anxiety for the fruits of your actions. Karma Phala Tyaga -- that will give you peace instantaneously. All those other things may not give you peace instantaneously. But this one thing -- if you give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions -- will give you peace right away. Na Chirat -- immediately you will get this peace.

So therefore Bhagavan in the end said, Karma Phala Tyaga is the greatest devotion to me. In other words, you have given up the sense of ownership -- "I am the doer" and "I control my destiny." Once you have given that up, all your anxiety will be gone and you will be aligned with me. The greatest devotee is the one who gives up the anxiety for the fruits of actions.

In the last few verses, from verse 13 onwards through verse 19, Bhagavan has been defining the perfect devotee, the perfect Bhakta.

These qualities described for the perfect devotee are no different than the Muni we saw in chapter two. The qualities are exactly the same, just presented in a different way. These are the very qualities for which Bhagavan considers such a person as his Bhakta. And Swamiji categorized these qualities into six categories. After every verse, Bhagavan says Sa me Priyah -- such a devotee is closer to me, is dear to me.

When he says "dear to me," Bhagavan is not being partial -- "if you have this quality, I like you; if you don't, I don't like you." Rather, that person is identifying much more closely with the supreme. The qualities we have been seeing from verse 13 onward start with Adveshta Sarvabhutanam Maitrah Karunayevacha -- he does not hate anyone in this world. Now that is something we find very difficult, because we hate many things and many beings in this world. "I hate cockroaches and I hate snakes."

Bhagavan said, you may not want to associate with them, you may want to stay away from them, but you do not hate them. It's not like Parashurama saying, "I'm going to make this earth Nakshatri -- no Kshatriyas on this planet." You are not going to say, "I'll make this earth without cockroaches" -- because they have survived the longest. As we know, we will be gone, but they will still be there. Bhagavan said, one who does not hate anyone -- and then we have seen several more qualities.

And then we come to the verse: Yasmat na udvijate Lokah. This is a very important verse. Lokat na udvijate cha yah -- one who is not disturbed by others, and who does not disturb the world outside. My behavior, my presence should not agitate others, nor should I be agitated by others.

I used to work for a company.

I had moved to Dallas from another company, WZMH. They gave me a project and said there was already a project manager, but they were looking for a replacement. So they gave me that project. I went to the first meeting and the contractor said, "Neil, I'm glad that you are going to be the project manager now. The last project manager we had was a guy named Howard Johnson."

He said, "He may not say anything, he may not do anything, but as he walks into the room, everybody gets tense and agitated. Something about the way he handled people -- it just didn't make people comfortable." The contractor told me, you shouldn't be that type of person. People should feel calm and comfortable in your presence.

I remember another incident. My chief architect, where I was interning as a first-year architecture student, was the one who introduced me to Swami Chinmayananda.

He also took me to another saint, Sant Mota. He was somehow on a mission to introduce me to all great sages. I kept telling him, "Padna, I have no interest in spirituality." But anyway, he introduced me to Sant Mota, who founded the Mauna Mandir. His concept was that you stay alone in a room for as long as you can.

People would sign up for one day, two days, one week, one month. The condition was that you just go there and do whatever you want to do -- chant, read Bhagavad Gita, read even a novel if you want to. But you are not connected with the world outside. No phones, no newspapers. Take whatever books you want to take.

But other than that, you stay there. People used to come from all over the world to sign up for that Mauna Mandir. I'm not sure whether it's still there or not. But he was called Sant Mota, and when Padna took me to him, somebody asked Mota a question. I was only 17 years old. "I hear all about some being fake sadhus and some being genuine teachers."

"How do we differentiate between a fake guru and a real guru?" He said, "What I say is very simple. If you come to that person and you feel peace in your mind, he is a true Sadhu. If in his presence you get agitated, consider him to be not right for you."

I still remember that answer after all these years. It is such a profound statement. And I'll tell you what we experienced ourselves in the presence of Gurudev. No matter how many questions you had, no matter how you went thinking, "I'm going to talk to Swamiji and tell him that these people are doing this to me" -- you go there, and you forget everything. You forgot what you were going to complain about.

People used to just sit in front of Swamiji for hours. Swamiji would keep doing whatever he was doing. He was actually watching tennis in those days -- Swamiji always liked to watch tennis because he was a tennis player. People would record all those Wimbledon matches, and when Swamiji was relaxing, he would watch tennis.

We will have like 15, 20 people just sitting there for hours without any words exchanged.
snippets.reflection:
"Anapekshah"—free from expectations. This single quality from verse 16 strikes at the root of much human suffering. We have "mortgaged our happiness," as the teaching says, to external conditions and other people. My children must perform well for me to be happy. My spouse must behave a certain way. My colleagues must recognize my worth. We have distributed the keys to our peace among countless others who may never use them as we wish. The true devotee, having identified with the inexhaustible Divine, becomes "the reservoir of his happiness." This is not cold detachment but the deepest security—happiness that does not depend on the world's cooperation.

Verse 17 describes one who "neither laments nor desires" (na socati na kankshati). This is freedom from the two movements that torment the mind: grief over the past and craving for the future. The devotee lives fully in the present moment, where the Divine actually dwells. Notice the phrase "shubha-ashubha-parityagi"—one who has renounced both good and bad fortune as defining experiences. This does not mean indifference to ethics but freedom from being psychologically tossed by favorable and unfavorable circumstances.

Verse 18 points to equanimity toward "friend and foe, honor and dishonor, heat and cold, pleasure and pain." Practice this today with one pair of opposites. Choose something you typically react to strongly—perhaps praise and criticism. When either comes, pause before the automatic reaction. Notice the mind wanting to expand with praise or contract with criticism. Can you remain "samah"—even—in both? This is not suppression but observation. The goal is not to stop feeling but to stop being unconsciously driven by feeling. At day's end, journal about what you noticed in these moments of attempted equanimity.

snippets.title: Day 167: Steps to Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येन केनचित् |

ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते |
snippets.transliteration:
tulyanindāstutirmaunī santuṣṭo yena kenacit .

ye tu dharmyāmṛtamidaṃ yathoktaṃ paryupāsate .
verseTranslations: Who is indifferent to praise and censure, who enjoys silence, who is contented with every fate, who has no fixed abode, who is steadfast in mind, and filled with devotion, such a one is My beloved.
Verily those who love the spiritual wisdom as I have taught, whose faith never fails, and who concentrate their whole nature on Me, they indeed are My most beloved."
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We've been discussing chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga. Devotion is love for the Divine. Love is nothing but identification. The more we identify with someone, the more we like that person.

When identification becomes complete, we say we fell in love with that person. So Bhakti is nothing but the love for the Divine. Love cannot occur without knowledge of that person or knowledge of that thing. So in this case, loving God is not possible without knowing God. Knowledge is as important as my desire to love God. The knowledge about God, the knowledge about the Supreme Being, is what we had been learning from Bhagavan.

In the last five chapters, from chapter 7 through 11, Bhagavan elaborated the nature of the Supreme. In chapter seven he says, there is nothing greater than Me. And then he explains that everything you see is nothing but me -- the Prakriti you see is nothing but my lower Prakriti, my lower nature, the manifest Prakriti. So he has described his lower Prakriti as the manifest world which we see.

We complain that we have not seen Bhagavan. But Bhagavan said, you see me every day. You deal with me every day. You just do not know that you are dealing with Bhagavan, because there is nothing other than me in this world. Then he described many aspects of this Prakriti -- how we can identify his presence in Prakriti, which we saw in chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga: anything excellent you see in this world, consider that to be my presence.

I am the strength in the strong, the intelligence in the intellect, the fragrance in the flower. Everything that right now I consider to be something other than me -- Bhagavan said -- is me, the supreme alone. Right now, my identification is so complete with this limited self. I consider this body, mind, and intellect to be me.

This identity is so complete that loving myself is very easy. In spite of all my shortcomings that I am aware of, I never hate myself, because the identification is so complete that I'm in love with myself. But once again, the quest in life is to change this identification from this limited self to the supreme self. For that to happen, I obviously need to know Bhagavan. As we have seen in the last five chapters, Bhagavan has been telling us the nature of the supreme.

In chapter 11, just before this chapter, Bhagavan demonstrated that everything comes out of me and everything merges into me -- whether you consider it good, bad, or ugly. It's easy for us to associate divinity with something pristine and sattvic. But it's very difficult for our mind to associate divinity with something that doesn't align with us, that is not conducive to our comfort.

Therefore, in this chapter, Bhagavan, while explaining Bhakti, describes the nature of the perfect devotee. From the beginning of this chapter we saw Arjuna's question: which is better? One who worships the manifest Prakriti, the manifest nature of God, or those who worship the supreme without any attributes?

Because in the end we have learned that he does not have any form. He is not a man, not a woman, not it, not she, not he -- he's everything. Without any form, it is very difficult for us to grasp his nature. That higher Prakriti, Bhagavan said, is very different from the manifest Prakriti which you see. But to focus on that higher Prakriti, my mind may not be capable. Bhagavan said, for those who consider themselves identified with this body -- the embodied ones who consider "this is me" --

As we said, our identity is so complete with this body, mind, and intellect. Nobody has to tell me "this is me" or "that's me" -- the rest is the world outside. For one who considers himself thus, to focus his mind on the unmanifest is very difficult. Klesha Adhikatarah Tesham -- for them the difficulty is much greater.

So for them it is easier to focus on one form that they find divine. Ramakrishna, or Gurudev Swami Chinmayananda -- in his presence, you don't have to figure out what God looks like. Many children in our neighborhood, when Gurudev came to our house, would say, "God came to Bhatt's house." Because we easily associate divinity with such a person. Bhagavan said, this may be easier for you, Arjuna. At your level, the easiest way to worship me is to give your mind and intellect to me. In other words, synchronize your mind and intellect with me. As we discussed last time -- WWKD, What Would Krishna Do in this situation? Like the Christian bracelets that say WWJD.

It's for teenagers who are facing peer pressure -- should I smoke or not smoke? You say, think about it. Look at the bracelet: WWJD. What would Jesus do in this case? Synchronize your mind and intellect with me. Give your mind and intellect to me and make me the supreme goal.

I'll take care of everything. If that is not possible, Bhagavan gives another option: constant practice or constant learning of the nature of the Lord from the scriptures. If that is not possible, give me all your actions -- work for me and do all your actions for me. My employer is Lord Krishna. Everything I do is for him.

If even that is not possible, then just do Karma Phala Tyaga -- don't expect anything from what you do. In the end he said, Karma Phala Tyaga is the greatest of all because it gives you peace instantaneously. As soon as you give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions, your mind will stop agitating. Most of my agitations are about the fruits -- fear of what will happen in the future.

Bhagavan said, once you give that up, peace will come automatically. Therefore it is greater than anything. So Bhakti is like an HOV lane on the highway. It takes you to your destination much quicker than other paths -- Karma Yoga, Gnana Yoga, Dhyana Yoga. Those are slower paths.

There are several entry points you can have. Either you are ready and give your mind to me. If you're not ready, keep practicing. If not, keep working for me. If not, just give up the fruits of actions and you will be my Bhakta. And then in the last few verses, starting from verse 13, we've seen the nature, the characteristics, the qualities of a perfect devotee.

All our preconceived notions about a bhakta -- that he has given up everything and is just doing nothing but bhajans all day long. And as Swamiji used to say, with those noisy accompaniments -- no, that's not bhakti. A Bhakta is the one who has these qualities. So Bhagavan has given the litmus test of who is a perfect devotee. And Swamiji enumerates 36 qualities of a perfect devotee, starting from Adveshta Sarvabhutanam Maitrah Karunayevacha. One who does not hate anyone.

As I said, it is so difficult for us to even have that concept, because so many things in this world we don't like. As long as you have identification with this body, mind, and intellect -- within the realm of this body, this mind, this intellect -- anything which is not conducive to the body, I'll hate. "It's too hot, it's too cold" -- because it's not conducive to my body. When I used to live in Nairobi, you didn't need air conditioning or heating.

The city by nature is perfectly air-conditioned -- the temperature remains between 65 and 75 all throughout the year. So I found that very conducive, a good city to live in. Until we found out that Meena and my son Neeraj both had asthma because of the high altitude. So for me it was very conducive.

For them it was completely not conducive. So Bhagavan says, as long as you identify with this body, mind, and intellect, there will be things that are mentally conducive and sometimes mentally not conducive, intellectually conducive and intellectually not conducive. But one who is not identified with these limitations -- for him it becomes possible to worship God without any form. A true Bhakta reaches that point.

So we have been seeing these qualities from the last few verses. Samah shatrau cha mitre cha tatha mana apamana yoh, shitoshna sukha duhkheshu samah sanga vivarjitah. One who no longer considers this body and intellect to be me, but rather my equipment. For him, his relationships are neutral in all aspects. Nobody is truly my friend and nobody is truly my foe. But there is a Vyavaharik (transactional) relationship I will have.

The people who help me are my friends. The people who hinder me are my enemies. But that's a Vyavaharik, transactional relationship. But at the core of my being, I remain equanimous to them. As long as I identify with my mind, there will be honor and dishonor.

Obviously, we architects put our buildings out for all to see. They say that doctors bury their mistakes; we put ours out for the world to see. The buildings I don't like, I avoid passing by. The ones I like, I make sure to pass by -- because at the intellectual level, honor and dishonor is what I perceive.

But you see, for the true Bhakta, both are equal. Shitoshna sukha duhkheshu -- at the body level, hot and cold. That does not mean I don't feel hot. Somebody asked Swamiji Gurudev, "Why is it that you always go in the best car?" Because people would go to pick up Swamiji at the airport.

Someone has a Mercedes or BMW or Lexus. There are people who have Toyotas. "You don't go in those cars." Swamiji said, "I'm not stupid. If the best car is available, which is more reliable and not going to break down on the way, why should I take a chance and go in an old Subaru that may break down on the highway?"

So when it is available to me to mitigate discomfort at the body level, I will do it. But if it is not available, I persevere and continue. Shitoshna sukha duhkha -- Agamapayinah, Anityah -- they come and go. I remain constantly at peace because Samah Sanga Vivarjitah -- I remain constantly in a state of equanimity because I'm not attached to any of these worlds of mine.

Physical, mental, intellectual. Tulya ninda stutih mauni -- Tulya ninda stutih means equanimous to criticism and praise. Because no matter what you do, somebody will praise the same act and somebody will criticize that same act. The Supreme Court takes a decision on those abortion pills. Democrats are rejoicing -- "They did the right thing."

Republicans are saying, "What is this court doing?" So Ninda and Stuti, criticism and praise -- both I consider to be not about my actions alone but a reflection of their mental environment. Somebody will like what I say because it is conducive to them. Somebody will criticize what I say because it is not conducive to them. Therefore, a true devotee of the Lord -- in other words, one who has identified himself with the supreme -- remains at peace in all situations. Mauni -- he becomes silent, not just physically or at the speech level.

At the mind level, I may be silent but fuming inside. And that's very dangerous. You can end up in trouble if you don't vocalize your anger, don't vocalize your ideas, don't vocalize what's going on in your mind. But this is silence at the mind level.

When Mauni, the true devotee, becomes silent at the mind level -- that is true silence. Santushtah yena kenachit -- content with this or that, content with whatever comes.
snippets.reflection:
These concluding verses of Chapter 12 offer the culminating portrait of the beloved devotee. "Tulya-ninda-stutih"—equal to censure and praise. The teaching observes that no matter what we do, some will praise and some will criticize. The same Supreme Court decision causes Democrats to rejoice and Republicans to despair. This recognition can liberate us from the exhausting effort to please everyone. The devotee understands that praise and blame reflect the mental state of others more than objective truth about ourselves. "Mauni"—one who has become silent, not merely at the level of speech but at the level of mind. This inner silence is the fruit of true devotion.

"Santushto yena kenacit"—content with whatever comes. "Aniketah"—without a fixed abode. This does not mean homelessness but freedom from psychological dependence on any particular place, possession, or circumstance for one's sense of security. The devotee is at home everywhere because the Divine is everywhere. "Sthira-matih"—steady-minded. The mind that has found its anchor in the infinite does not sway with every passing wind of circumstance.

The final verse (20) brings it all together: those who pursue this "dharmy-amritam" (immortal righteousness) with "shraddha" (faith), making the Divine their supreme goal, are "ativa me priyah"—exceedingly dear to the Lord. Bhakti, we learn, is like an HOV lane on the highway of spiritual progress—it takes us faster to our destination than other paths. Today, choose one quality from these verses that feels most distant from your current state: Is it contentment? Silence of mind? Equanimity toward praise and blame? Freedom from fixed attachments? Do not judge yourself for the gap, but use it as a compass pointing toward growth. What one small step could you take today in that direction?

snippets.title: Day 168: The Field
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

kṣetrajñaṃ cāpi māṃ viddhi sarvakṣetreṣu bhārata .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna asked: My Lord! Who is God and what is Nature; what is Matter and what is the Self; what is that they call Wisdom, and what is it that is worth knowing? I wish to have this explained.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: O Arjuna! The body of man is the playground of the Self; and That which knows the activities of Matter, sages call the Self.
I am the Omniscient self that abides in the playground of Matter; knowledge of Matter and of the all-knowing Self is wisdom.
snippets.commentary:
We concluded chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga, Yoga of Devotion. Now we'll be starting discussion on Chapter 13, the Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of differentiation between the field and its knower. So far we have seen the two segments of the Bhagavad Gita which discussed "tat" and "tvam" from the Mahavakya Tattvamasi. The first six chapters we learned about "tvam." The next six chapters we learned about "tat." Now we will be discussing the correlative verb "asi," the connections between the two and how to differentiate between the two. Therefore it's called Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of the field and its knower.

In other words, how to differentiate between what I am not and what I am. There is a granth written by Bhagavan Shankaracharya, or at least attributed to him, called Drig Drishya Viveka, which is similar in nature but more logically explained. Drig Drishya Viveka -- discrimination between the seer and the seen. Who is the seer and what is seen? If we can differentiate, then we know them both. So the same way, here it says Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga -- how to differentiate the field from its knower.

So that's the theme of this chapter. In other words, we will be learning how to navigate through Maya. Maya is the entity which creates this confusion for me, who I am and what is my real nature. Maya creates this illusion of plurality where the only singularity exists. One exists, but it appears to be many. So the chapter now discusses this aspect of Maya in detail.

Swamiji explains here that in this chapter, suddenly after devotion, Krishna took up a theme which is completely different, and therefore some interpolator has added this one verse. The very first verse, Arjuna Uvacha, does not appear in previous commentators' commentaries. Bhagavan Shankaracharya did not comment on the first verse; he starts from the second verse. Same with Jnaneshwari -- it also starts from the second verse. Because it seemed like Bhagavan had suddenly taken up a different topic, somebody thought it appropriate to add a connector between what was discussed so far and what would be discussed next. What we will be discussing is actually the continuation of the theme.

Bhagavan started this theme in chapter seven and chapter eight. In chapter seven he talked about the Eightfold Lower Prakriti and the Manifest Prakriti. Then in chapter eight he talked about the imperishable Brahman. Chapters nine, ten, and eleven were somewhat of a distraction from the theme because Arjuna kept asking questions. He wanted to know in what different forms to think about Bhagavan, so Krishna gave the Vibhuti Yoga.

Then he wanted to know Bhagavan in his totality, so Krishna gave him the Vishwarupadarshan. And then obviously it culminated in Bhakti Yoga. So Bhagavan picked up that theme again from chapters 7 and 8. In chapter 13, we want to continue the theme of how to differentiate between the Jiva and Paramatma and what is their connection. As we have learnt in that great statement: that which you are seeking, and you who consider who you are, are one and the same. But right now I don't see the connection.

Once I know the nature of both, then I will be able to connect them. So that's basically the theme of chapter 13, Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga. The very first verse, Arjuna Uvacha, basically gives you what we're going to discuss in this chapter. As we've discussed many times, the best presentation is when you first tell them what you're going to talk about, then tell them what you are talking about, and then tell them what you told them.

Summarize it, put an agenda up front, make the presentation, and then summarize. So here the first verse attributed to Arjuna says: Prakritim Purusham cha eva, Kshetram Kshetrajnam eva cha, etat veditum icchami, Jnanam Jneyam cha Keshava. These are the things I want to understand clearly. We pick up the themes from chapters 7 and 8. Prakritim Purusham -- I want to know Prakriti and Purusha. We have discussed these before; we need to brush up our knowledge of what Prakriti and Purusha are. And also Kshetra Kshetrajna, the field and its Knower. You talked about the field of my actions. This world currently is clear to me -- this is the field of my actions.

For me it is very simple. I am the actor and this world is the field of my actions. So I am the knower of the field of my actions. But when it comes to knowing who I am, I have to go further. So we will talk about that. Kshetram Kshetrajnam eva cha, etat veditum icchami, Jnanam Jneyam cha Keshava -- I also want to know what is knowledge and what is to be known.

So we clarified by this first verse what we'll be discussing. To know myself, I have to be very clear about what is Prakriti and what is Purusha, what is manifest and what is unmanifest. I also need to know what is the field of my activity and who is the actor. I also want to know what is knowledge and what is to be known. Just simple curiosity -- "I want to know" -- doesn't mean anything.

I need to know what is there to be known. So Arjuna asked this question to put the agenda forward for this chapter, saying we want to know about these things.

The next verse is where it changes the paradigm for us. Idam shariram Kaunteya, Kshetram iti abhidhiyate -- this body, O Kaunteya, is called the field. Completely different than what I thought all along.

We thought that this world is the field, and I as this limited being am the knower of this world. I know my world, I know my field -- my field of profession, field of activity. So right now I have considered this body to be the knower, this me, this limited being, to be me. But Bhagavan said no, this body itself is the field. This field which I consider to be the world, and this body, mind, intellect which I consider to be me --

He said no, this body belongs to the field, the Prakriti. The knower is somebody different than that. This body is called the field. He who knows is called the Kshetrajna. One who knows this body is the Kshetrajna. Once I have established what the field is, the one who knows the field is the knower.

So from the perspective of the world, the "I" is the seer of this world. When I see colors and forms, my eye is the seer and the world is the seen. When it comes to my eye, the mind is the seer and the eye is the seen. When I observe what is happening to my eye, who is seeing? My mind is seeing my eye. So I took a step backward and put the seer in the field of the seen. And if I keep receding, then everything that I consider today to be me will belong to the field of Prakriti.

That which I consider to be me so far is my mind, my body, my intellect. That's what I define myself to be. But when seen from the perspective of what do I know, I know about my body. If I know my body, then I am the the knower. Somebody other than my body. Same goes for my mind.

I'm very aware that my mind is upset. So I am the knower of my mind. My mind is not calm today. Somebody sees the mind to be not calm or calm -- there is some other entity which is seeing the mind. That same entity also can judge whether my intellect is sharp or dull.

I don't know about it. So there is somebody other than this body, mind and intellect who is the knower. One who knows all these three. So in short, Bhagavan says the body is the field. The one who knows that is considered to be the knower. That's basically simple.

But because of my identification, I always considered this to be the seer. As I give the example that my eye can see but only with the aid of my glasses. So I consider the glasses to be as important as my eye. If I want to read without glasses, I cannot read. So glasses are as important for me to read as my eye is. But I don't consider my eye and glasses in the same category.

Because I know I can go to LensCrafters and get replacement glasses in one hour. The eye, at least today, is not that easy to replace. Someday it will probably be as simple. Till that time, I consider the eye to be something very special -- part of me without which I cannot see. But glasses I can replace.

But if I can now learn that even the eye can be replaced anytime, then I will also put the eye in the same category as my glasses. Sometimes the instruments through which we see, we identify with so closely that we forget the differentiation between the seer and the seen. So Bhagavan changes this paradigm and says this body is the field through which the seer is functioning to manifest.

Electricity needs all these lamps and gadgets. Electricity is present in this room -- we can vouch for it because the lights are on, the air conditioning is on.

But remove both the air conditioning and the light, and we will not know whether electricity is in the room or not -- until you put a finger in that outlet. So the seer is present, but its presence is felt through the equipment. The knower is only there as long as the knowables are there. If there's nothing to be known, the knower is not needed. The proverbial question -- whether a tree falling in the jungle makes a sound or not -- unless there's somebody to listen to that sound, the world of sound does not exist.

And unless there are objects, no knower can exist. In my deep sleep, there is no knower because the world does not exist for me. Therefore there is no knower. If there are no knowables, the knower does not exist. So if you remove the knowables from the knower, Bhagavan says, what remains is pure knowledge -- not knowledge of something, but knowledge by itself, which we call pure awareness.

Right now I exist as something. Then everything else follows -- as Neel, as an architect, as a father, as a community member, whatever it is. But I have to attach something to "I exist." And if you remove all of them, what remains is simply "I exist." So the knower and the known go together.

So it says, idam shariram Kaunteya, Kshetram iti abhidhiyate. This body is to be known as the field, and the one who knows the body is the knower of the field. Now these are the arguments for us to navigate through Maya so that you can contemplate on the nature of the self. You can start to contemplate: okay, if this body is not me, who knows this body?

The next verse says, Kshetrajnam cha api mam viddhi, sarva-kshetreshu Bharata. Once we have discussed that this body is the field and the knower is the Kshetrajna, then we may have another confusion -- that in my body I am the field and my consciousness is the knower.

In your body, the same thing for you. There are so many knowers in this world, as many beings are there that many knowers are there from our perspective from just learning the second verse. So Bhagavan clarifies this.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses introduce the revolutionary insight that "idam shariram" - this very body - is the field (kshetra), not just the external world. Krishna declares that there is only one Knower (kshetrajna) in all fields. Today, contemplate this paradigm shift: you have always considered your body, mind, and intellect to be "you" - the knower. But what if they belong to the field of the known? Spend a few moments simply observing your body sensations, your thoughts, your emotional reactions. Notice that there is something aware of all these - that awareness itself is the true Knower.

The verse states "kshetra-kshetrajnayor jnanam yat taj jnanam matam mama" - the knowledge of both field and Knower is true wisdom. This week, practice asking yourself throughout the day: "Who is aware of this experience right now?" When you notice your breath, who notices? When you feel an emotion, who feels aware of that feeling? This inquiry is the beginning of navigating through Maya - the confusion between what you are not and what you truly are.

As a practical exercise, sit quietly for five minutes each morning. Let your attention rest on the simple sense of "I exist" before any thought of being a particular person with particular roles. Can you touch that pure sense of existence-awareness before the mind adds labels? This is the doorway to understanding the Knower of the field.

snippets.title: Day 169: The Knower
snippets.sanskrit:
तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक्च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत् |

ऋषिभिर्बहुधा गीतं छन्दोभिर्विविधैः पृथक् |

महाभूतान्यहंकारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च |
snippets.transliteration:
tatkṣetraṃ yacca yādṛkca yadvikāri yataśca yat .

ṛṣibhirbahudhā gītaṃ chandobhirvividhaiḥ pṛthak .

mahābhūtānyahaṃkāro buddhiravyaktameva ca .
verseTranslations: What is called Matter, of what it is composed, whence it came, and why it changes, what the Self is, and what Its power - this I will now briefly set forth.
Seers have sung of It in various ways, in many hymns and sacred Vedic songs, weighty in thought and convincing in argument.

The five great fundamentals (earth, fire, air, water and ether), personality, intellect, the mysterious life force, the ten organs of perception and action, the mind and the five domains of sensation;
snippets.commentary:
We have started discussing chapter 13, Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of knowing the difference between the field and its knower. We are basically learning how to navigate through Maya. As we have seen before, we have four great Vedas: Rig, Sama, Yajur, and Atharva. Each one gave us one great statement which summarizes the entire philosophy of who I am. At the end of the Vedas is a section called Vedanta, literally "end of Vedas," which consists of the Upanishads. The Upanishads discuss who we are, what our relationship is to that Almighty, and whether I have an existence before and after my death. Each one has argued this point logically and came to a logical conclusion about what the truth is, summarized in one great statement in each Veda.

So in Rugveda from Ayutary Upanishad, we get Prajnaam Brahman. In the end, he says, the real truth is that the consciousness alone is that Almighty, all pervading self. From this Sama Veda in Chandogya Upanishad came Tattvamasi, that thou art, you are that that which you are seeking as the Supreme Lord is your own self. From the Atharva Veda came I am Atma Brahman. After the inquiry about what the self is, it says, my self is Brahman. The self which I consider to be myself is Brahman.

So that comes from the Atharva Veda's Mandukya Upanishad. The last one is Aham Brahmasmi, "I am Brahman." The final realization that Brahman is none other than my own self comes from the Yajurveda, from the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. The Gita, as we have seen, is Bhagavan Krishna's collection of all those ideas from the Upanishads, put into one discourse called the Bhagavad Gita. So we have been discussing the Bhagavad Gita, learning the essence of these great statements.

Many commentators have said, as we have discussed many times before, that Tattvamasi is the statement which the Gita elaborates upon. We have learned so far about "tat" and "tvam" in the first 12 chapters. For six chapters we learned about "tvam," that is, you and I as limited beings. That segment culminated in Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. Once I know who I am as a limited being, now I have to contemplate upon who I am.

The next six chapters we discussed about that, that Almighty, the Supreme. What is the nature of that? And that culminated into Bhakti Yoga, Yoga of devotion. Once I know myself in that Almighty, I will have nothing but devotion for that self. Once I identify with someone, I will be in love with that person. I love something when I know something.

Once I know the nature of the Supreme, then only can I develop devotion for it. So chapter 12 was Bhakti Yoga, Yoga of Devotion. Chapter 13 now connects the two. "That thou art" -- that correlative verb "art" is what we are now discussing: how to make the connection between this limited self which I consider to be myself, and that which is the Almighty, all-pervading. As we have discussed in Self Unfoldment and before, this self which I consider "me" is a conditioned self, conditioned in my body. And I consider this to be my body.

This is a gross body which I consider to be my body which is perceived by everybody else. Everybody can see how tall I am, how short I am, how old I am. But then there is a subtle body which I am very aware. You may have inkling about it, but you can't perceive it. That's my mind and intellect. That's like a software in this hardware called body.

But both of these exist because of the third body, called the causal body, which is the cause for these two to come into existence. These two cannot come into existence if there is no cause for them. These two came into existence as they are. Why are you not so powerful? Why are you not so smart? That's because this is what the cause considered the most appropriate form to transact all the desires and vasanas which I have. So that's the causal body.

The causal body is nothing but the leftover tendencies and vasanas from my past experiences. For example, from my past experience of buying a house in this area -- if I made a mistake last time, don't do that again. Next time when I buy a house, I look for a good school district because that's more important. Let's find which has the best resale value. Don't fall into the trap of "this is the most economical area."

You need to find something where the resale value is more important. All these are my past impressions from last time, when I made a mistake. The same way, Bhagavan says that this body and this mind are also ordered by me, custom designed by me. Like when you go online and fill out which color car you want, what shape, what size, what brand, and you put together a customized package. I heard somewhere that at Starbucks, there are like 5,400 or so different varieties of coffee you can order -- you can customize your coffee. It's the same way I have customized this existence of mine which I call my limited self.

Total impressions of my past experiences and tendencies created these two bodies. Subtle body and gross body. That's at my micro level. The total tendencies and impressions of all the beings and things in this Jagat, this universe create the total causal body. And in Sankhya philosophy it's called Mola Prakriti. The original nature of this Prakriti, Mula Prakriti.

In Vedanta, we call it Maya. That means "ya ma sa maya" -- that which is not, but appears to be, that is Maya. These limitations on me -- as my body, my mind, my intellect -- are not actually there. There are no limitations on myself apart from my mind, my intellect, my body. But it appears to have this limitation.

I feel these limitations when I think about myself. That's because of Maya. Maya is nothing but my identification with this body, with this mind, with this intellect. As long as that identification is there, all the limitations of my body, mind, and intellect will be there. Once I get out of that identification, those limitations only remain for the body, for the mind, for the intellect -- but not for me. Swami Vivekananda used to say, "I as a Swami have all the problems."

"But I as I have no problem." I as an architect have all the problems, all limitations. But when I remove all those, the "I" which remains has no problem because it has no limitation. How to migrate from this limited "I" and its identification to that unlimited "I" -- that is what we'll be discussing from chapter 13 through 18. And therefore the last chapter, chapter 18, will culminate in Moksha Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of liberation and renunciation.

So we started discussing chapter 13. We have indicated that the very first verse, Arjuna Uvacha, is not in many texts, but it is very appropriate that it was interpolated by some commentator. Arjuna said, "I want to know the nature of these things." What are the things he wants to know? Prakriti -- I want to know the nature of Prakriti.

I want to know the nature of Purusha also. In addition, I want to know Kshetra and Kshetrajna -- what is the field and who is the knower of the field. I want to know what is knowledge and what is to be known. So these are the topics we'll be discussing going forward. snippets.reflection:
These verses enumerate the 24 constituents of the field: the five great elements (earth, water, fire, air, ether), the ego (ahamkara), intellect (buddhi), the unmanifest (avyaktam), the ten sense organs, the mind, and the five sense objects. Krishna emphasizes that this teaching is not new - it has been sung by seers in various hymns and validated through the Brahma Sutras. Today, take inventory of what you normally consider "yourself." Your physical body made of elements, your sense of individual identity, your reasoning faculty, your perceptions - all these belong to the field, not to the Knower.

Reflect on how you have "customized" your existence through past impressions and tendencies (vasanas). Like ordering a custom car with specific features, your body, mind, and intellect have been shaped by accumulated experiences. This is not cause for guilt but for understanding - these are borrowed equipment from Prakriti. The question becomes: if all this is borrowed, who is the borrower? Spend time today noticing how you identify with your personality traits, your intellectual capabilities, your physical characteristics. Can you see them as equipment rather than essence?

As a daily practice, when you wake up tomorrow, before getting out of bed, mentally list the components of your "field": your body lying there, your mind starting to generate thoughts, your intellect planning the day. Then ask: "Who is aware of this entire field awakening?" Rest in that awareness for a moment before beginning your day.

You need to find something where the resale value is more important. All these are my past impressions from last time, when I made a mistake.
