snippets.reflection:
Verse 7 completes the description of the field by including its subtlest modifications: desire (iccha), aversion (dvesha), pleasure (sukham), pain (dukham), the aggregate body (sanghata), consciousness reflected in matter (chetana), and fortitude (dhriti). Notice how even your desires and aversions belong to the field - they are experiences happening within you, not the essence of who you are. Today, when desire arises for something pleasant or aversion arises toward something unpleasant, practice labeling it: "This is a modification of the field." You are the witness of these movements, not their slave.

Verses 8-9 begin listing the twenty qualities that constitute true knowledge (jnana): humility (amanitvam), unpretentiousness (adambhitvam), non-violence (ahimsa), forgiveness (kshanti), uprightness (arjavam), service to the teacher (acharya-upasanam), purity (shaucham), steadfastness (sthairyam), self-control (atma-vinigrahah), dispassion toward sense objects (vairagyam), absence of egoism (anahamkara), and seeing the defects in birth, death, old age, and disease. These are not mere moral prescriptions - they are the natural qualities that emerge when one begins to dis-identify from the field. Which of these qualities do you find easiest to cultivate? Which most challenging?

This week, choose one quality from this list to consciously practice. If you choose humility, notice whenever the ego seeks recognition. If you choose non-violence, observe subtle forms of aggression in thought and speech. Keep a small journal noting when you succeeded and when you forgot. This is the practical work of knowledge.

snippets.title: Day 171: Prakriti and Purusha
snippets.sanskrit:
असक्तिरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु |

मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्तिरव्यभिचारिणी |

अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम् |
snippets.transliteration:
asaktiranabhiṣvaṅgaḥ putradāragṛhādiṣu .

mayi cānanyayogena bhaktiravyabhicāriṇī .

adhyātmajñānanityatvaṃ tattvajñānārthadarśanam .
verseTranslations: Indifference, non-attachment to sex, progeny or home, equanimity in good fortune and in bad;
Unswerving devotion to Me, by concentration on Me and Me alone, a love for solitude, indifference to social life;
Constant yearning for the knowledge of Self, and pondering over the lessons of the great Truth - this is Wisdom, all else ignorance.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter 13. First we saw the definition of the Kshetra. The Kshetra is defined as everything that I can see, perceive, and think -- that is my field. The knower is the next subject of discussion. In the last few verses, we have been seeing the qualities of a seeker who wants to know. These qualities need to develop, or will develop, in the seeker because of his Mumukshutva, his desire to liberate himself from this limitation. All the qualities we are seeing are attributes which become the cause for that revelation. The last quality we saw was Putra-dara-griha-adishu.

One should be non-attached, not identifying with the putra, dara, griha, and so on. That which we commonly consider as something I need to be attached to, something I need to be identified with -- here Bhagavan says you should not be identified with it. Nityam cha sama-chittatvam ishta-anishta-upapattishu -- one becomes equanimous in all situations, whether ishta or anishta, whether conducive or non-conducive. In other words, we have been given a pointer: because we have defined the Kshetra as that which I can perceive, and the Kshetrajna as that which is not the field but the knower. Right now, my identification with my family and my possessions creates this notion that they are part of me. Therefore, the prescription here is: you need to develop non-identification.

It did not say "do not have a relationship with them." They are my relationships. Putra, dara, griha -- all these are my relationships, my possessions, my acquisitions, my achievements. All these I should see as something other than me. With my identification remaining with the Self, I can now relate to them.

That right relationship forms the right sort of dharma for the relationship. I follow that dharma without identifying myself with it -- that is basically the prescription. And therefore it will remain the same all the time, because you realize these are my relationships, and relationships are constantly changing. No matter what the situation is, I remain constant in my identification and see the relationship developing and changing.

Sometimes the situation may be ishta -- something which I think is conducive to me. And sometimes it is not. When children come to us, we consider that as ishta. But when they want to move away from you, we don't consider that ishta.

But knowing that it is for their own good, we feel good about letting them go. If I have not understood the concept that I need to let the children go for their own good, I will be in the path of their progress. That close identification may cause a person not to achieve his or her full potential. So non-identification is very necessary. Bhagavan says, whether the condition is ishta or anishta, conducive or non-conducive, remain equanimous.

Then we continued into a few more qualities which Bhagavan says are very essential to understand the nature of the knower. Who is it that is perceiving? "Me" is this mind and intellect, and then the ego it creates. The prescription here is given because, if I have developed the other qualities we discussed, then as Swamiji says, you have conserved lots of energy -- mental energy, intellectual energy. Now you have to apply that somewhere, so that it has its own field of action.

So the next verse is: Mayi cha ananya-yogena, bhaktih avyabhicharini. I take all this identification I have right now in this world -- which grounds my personality, grounds my self-esteem, grounds my identity about who I am. You take all this away from me, and I forget I'm an architect.

I forget I have a house, and I'm nothing. My grounding in this world is because of my identification with my family, my friends, my organizations, my accomplishments, my profession. Now, up till now you heard that -- take all that away from you. Where can all that energy which I had been putting into identification go? Bhagavan says: Mayi cha, ananya-yogena.

You now shift all that identification to Me. There, I have an identification. Here, I have a relationship. Previously I thought my identification is my relationship, and my relationship is my identification. Because I identify, I have a relationship.

Take the identification part and assign it to Me. Just leave the relationship. So Ananya means "none other." Identification with none other -- and then relating to the world as the field of your activity, the field of your actions, the field of performing your duties. Bhagavan says this will relieve you from that burden. Bhaktih avyabhicharini -- devotion, love for the divine.

We talked about taking this identification. And assigning to the one supreme entity. Who I consider my own self. Which is other than this body, this mind, this intellect. Everything that I know right now is not that. Move all that identification to that.

And it should be Ananya -- no other identification lingers around. Somebody says, "Are you faithful to your wife?" "I'm very faithful, except that I have a couple of love affairs." Is he really faithful? The very fact that you have other affairs means you are not faithful.

But people do convince themselves that they are faithful because they are "taking care of things." Bhagavan said that kind of identification with Me will not be very helpful. Therefore, bhakti avyabhicharini. Vyabhichari, in our normal context, refers to someone doing something which is disloyal to his own relationship or his own duties.

We do that to gain something frivolous. We perform that act for a momentary pleasure -- no real relationship, but just to get some pleasure for the time being. That is called vyabhichara.

We can relate that to our identification with the Supreme. "Are you devoted to Bhagavan?" "I am very devoted to God. However, this is very important to me. This relationship is very important. Well, first is my wife and then my Bhagavan."

Your bhakti should be avyabhicharini -- for no small gain will you shift your identification even for a moment to something other than Me. You'll be constantly identified with Me, and then functioning in this world. We have seen Swamiji's standard example of an actor performing his part on the stage. He's never truly identified with the role.

He's truly identified with himself, knowing fully who he is. He's performing his role very effectively -- that's the only reason he can perform his role effectively. Because he knows he is not the beggar that he is playing; he has a house in Beverly Hills.

Therefore he can act the beggar so effectively. If he forgets he is an actor who is a multimillionaire, he will not be able to perform that act. So Bhagavan said you will be more effective in your relationships. Your bhakti with Me should be avyabhicharini -- never leaving that for small, petty gains.

We identify with things for our small pleasure, small gain in this world, and Bhagavan said that's what prevents you from realizing yourself. Mayi cha ananya-yogena. Swamiji says this is like a new word coined by Krishna in Bhagavad Gita: Ananya Yoga. Nowhere in the earlier scriptures does the word Ananya Yoga appear. But Krishna, in rejuvenating this whole knowledge, is coining new words. Ananya Yoga -- union with none other.

My union with Him is so firm that there is no other identification. Vivikta-desha-sevitvam. So now, if I am the only one in this room, am I by myself? Am I in solitude or in company? Well, of course, Neel, you're in solitude because there's nobody else here. He said, vivikta-desha-sevitvam.

I should be practicing to be in solitude, not loneliness. As Swamiji points out, you don't want to be lonely -- you want to be in solitude. So everybody said, "Well, that means what I had been thinking all along -- this is not going to work. I want to work my profession, have family, friends, all that, and then I'm trying to understand Bhagavad Gita."

Bhagavad Gita itself says go into solitude, then only you will know. Bhagavan said, not really. Solitude is when I identify with that Self that alone exists. Then nothing exists other than that. I am never really in another's company. Everything else is nothing but my own manifestation.

Everything else is nothing but my own Leela. Then obviously I'm in complete solitude. When I'm here by myself, everything I do is just me. I say something, I hear that. But it's solitude because it's all me. That's why I said, in Surat when I was growing up, there was a Maun Mandir for a saint.

In the Maun Mandir, you don't even have to take Bhagavan's name when you go there. You just go into that room -- Maun Mandir, they called it -- and do whatever you want. You can take the books of your profession and read them.

You can take a radio or you can take anything -- there are no conditions. But you can take books, any type of books, and you can read there. The point is, you are by yourself. Whatever I do is echoing my own thoughts, echoing my own self. I'm in complete solitude because I'm identifying with nothing other than me alone. That sense of being, establishing yourself in it, creates this solitude.

The world is going around me, but it's like a dream, and therefore I'm in complete solitude. Vivikta-desha-sevitvam, aratih janasamsadi -- and he develops a distaste for the company of other people. Obviously, once I'm identified with Him, I see everything else is just a temporary relationship. So I will not be craving for their company; I'll be craving to be in my own Self. I may have relationships and therefore duties to perform.

I get together with them, I talk to them, but I'm always in my solitude. I'm not craving for their company because my identification is gone. What do we really crave for? We identify with someone and say, "I really need to go and see my mom," or "I need to go and see such and such," only because we have an identification. Once the identification is shifted from this field to the knower of the field, obviously there is no craving for this field. So Bhagavan continues.

Now he says, what is the purpose of all these things? Adhyatma-jnana-nityatvam, Tattva-jnana-artha-darshanam. For the purpose of knowing the Tattva, that knowledge which I am seeking. As we say, my true nature is Sat, Chit, and Ananda. The Chit is seeking the knowledge. But right now it is gaining knowledge which is actually in my way. To know my true knowledge, I need to do all that which is prescribed in these few verses.

Now I will build a Tattva-jnana-artha-darshanam. I can see the light at the end of the tunnel. I can see what my goal is. Swamiji explained that even when we go to the station and ask, "Which is the train to Madras?" -- that's because the train is not in Madras right now, but it is going to Madras. So right now I may not be there, but I see the goal for my being, where my identification will be established.

That's why Tattva-jnana-artha-darshanam -- I will know the essence of the knowledge about me. Adhyatma-jnana-nityatvam -- constancy of Self-knowledge. See, in our case we get a glimpse of who I am, but then we constantly shift and identify with something else which is also temporary. At no time do we have a constancy of identification about who I am, what I am.

At some point I thought I'm a very good student. At some point I thought, well, I'm a very good worker. My identification keeps shifting to different roles and accomplishments, never constant.
snippets.reflection:
These verses complete the enumeration of knowledge with profound instructions: non-attachment to family and possessions (asakti), equanimity in favorable and unfavorable circumstances (sama-chittatvam), unswerving devotion to the Lord (ananya-yoga bhakti), love of solitude (vivikta-desha-sevitvam), and constant pursuit of Self-knowledge (adhyatma-jnana-nityatvam). The key teaching here is the difference between relationship and identification. Krishna does not ask you to abandon your family (putra, dara, griha) but to stop identifying with them. Your spouse, children, and home are relationships to be honored through dharma - but your sense of self should not depend on them.

The concept of "ananya-yoga" - union with none other - is revolutionary. Right now, your identity is scattered across many identifications: profession, family, achievements, possessions. What if all that energy of identification were gathered and redirected toward the Supreme? This is not abandonment of worldly duties but a shift in where you anchor your sense of self. Reflect today: what would your life look like if you maintained all your relationships and responsibilities, but your fundamental identity rested in the unchanging Self rather than changing circumstances?

Verse 12 declares: "This is knowledge; whatever is contrary to this is ignorance." As a practice, examine your mental and emotional reactions today. When you feel disturbed, ask: "Which quality of knowledge am I forgetting right now? Am I attached when I should be witnessing? Am I craving company when I could rest in inner solitude?" This discrimination between knowledge and ignorance is itself the path.

snippets.title: Day 172: The Field
snippets.sanskrit:
ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वामृतमश्नुते |

सर्वतः पाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम् |

सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम् |
snippets.transliteration:
jñeyaṃ yattatpravakṣyāmi yajjñātvāmṛtamaśnute .

sarvataḥ pāṇipādaṃ tatsarvato.akṣiśiromukham .

sarvendriyaguṇābhāsaṃ sarvendriyavivarjitam .
verseTranslations: I will speak to thee now of that great Truth which man ought to know, since by its means he will win immortal bliss - that which is without beginning, the Eternal Spirit which dwells in Me, neither with form, nor yet without it.
Everywhere are Its hands and Its feet; everywhere It has eyes that see, heads that think and mouths that speak; everywhere It listens; It dwells in all the worlds; It envelops them all.
Beyond the senses, It yet shines through every sense perception. Bound to nothing, It yet sustains everything. Unaffected by the Qualities, It still enjoys them all.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter 13, Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of differentiation between the field and its knower. The quest in our life is to know: is there an entity which knows that I exist? I know I exist as this body because of identification with this body. I exist as my mind and I exist as my intellect. But is there existence beyond this existence of body, mind, and intellect? That's the quest in our life, which is what we call immortality.

After this body is destroyed, mind is destroyed, intellect is destroyed, will there be existence? We have been learning from Bhagavan. From chapters one through twelve, we have learned that yes, there is something which remains in existence even when these three are not existent. That we called our Supreme Self. And this we call a limited self. Through all of it, we have learned one thing and one thing alone.

Bhagavan continues to say that no matter which way you look at it, it is My existence alone. Even this limited existence is none other than My own existence. Everything which you see is nothing but Me alone. In chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, the Divine Glories, Bhagavan said that everything you see in this world is Me, but My presence can only be felt in perfection. Everybody can be a singer, but I only recognize the good singing. When somebody is singing in perfect shruti, that's when I enjoy the music.

Bhagavan said, that's where you will recognize My presence. But in the same chapter he came back and said that all these qualities which are contradictory to each other that you see in this world -- they're all Mine. It is not that I am in fear but not in fearlessness. In chapter 10, verses 4 and 5, he defined: Buddhi, Jnana, Asammoha, Kshama, Satyam, Dama, Shamah, Sukham, Dukham, Bhava, Abhava, Bhaya, Abhaya -- they all contradict each other. Ahimsa, Samata, Tushti, Tapa, Dana, Yashah, Ayashah -- bhavanti bhava bhutanam matta eva prithagvidhah. They manifest in people in different ways.

But they're all my qualities. I am the efficient cause. And all the qualities and things and beings which you see are the effects. Depending on the equipment, the effect may be different. We have been discussing this classical example of electricity involved. Depending on the bulb, the manifestation will be different.

But all the manifestations are of the same source. We have been learning that everything which I see -- the hunted and the hunter -- both are expressions of the same entity. But he said, not only the hunter and the hunted. The savior of the hunted from the hunter is also Me. The hunter is exhibiting the lower qualities; the savior is exhibiting the higher qualities. That is the only difference.

There is none that is not Me. We want to divide our world into divine and devilish -- this is good, this is bad. But He continues to tell us that that's not the case. The world, as you see it, is My own expression. So in chapter 13, we are going a step further.

In chapter 10 he said all qualities are Mine -- Yasha, Apayasha, fear, fearlessness. Now he says there is a difference between the two, which is what this chapter is all about. Kshetra, Kshetrajna. The field is this Jagat, the world of my experiences.

And there we included everything that we know -- my body, my mind, my intellect, Idam Shariram. The 24 expressions of Prakriti that he included in Idam Shariram. Then he describes the modifications of them, the modification-expressions as we experience them. All these are expressions of the field with the vikaras. Vikaras are the modifications -- elements in their own form.

When they come together with each other -- all these 24, which are seen as 10 senses, five sense objects, mind, intellect, buddhi, and five great elements -- when they interact with each other, what comes out are the vikaras, the modifications which we experience. They are part of this field.

They are inherent in the field and cannot be avoided. As that famous Gujarati poem says: Sukha-Dukha mana mein nahin, ghata satya gadhiya. They are embodied in the field itself -- the very expression of the self that cannot be avoided. As long as we are part of this world, they will be there. But then it says you can recognize the knower who is distinctly different from the field.

We have seen these 20 qualities which are the qualities of the Knower. As we saw previously, there are divine qualities and devilish qualities. The divine ones express the higher self; the others express the lower self. But both belong to the same Supreme Being. Here we are going a little further in our analysis to ask: what is it that makes me unhappy? He said, that's part of the Prakriti.

As long as I am bound by this Prakriti -- in other words, as long as I'm identified with this body, this mind, this intellect -- these are bound to occur. It cannot be avoided no matter how hard you try. We have all these mitigating plans. Invest in your 401(k)s. Well, no, put it in mutual funds. Then no, put some in bonds. Eventually we realized that there was no really foolproof formula.

No matter what you do, you are going to lose somewhere and win somewhere, as long as you keep an equal mind. That's what they say about monthly contributions -- even-mindedly, no matter where the market is, you put your 401(k) in. As long as you have that discipline.

In the end, you will be the winner. Bhagavan says the same thing: even-mindedly, you keep doing your work, no matter what the circumstances are. Then you will be the winner. In the end, you will be okay.

So we have seen these qualities of the field, and now we know what the field is. The Knower we have defined by 20 qualities. These qualities can be considered as prerequisites to recognize the Self. On the other hand, these are actually the qualities of the Knower himself. When the Knower is shining through you, all these qualities which we have been learning for the last few weeks will be exhibited.

When you see these qualities, recognize that this is the manifestation of the Knower who is distinctly different from the field. Attachment is created by Prakriti. But detachment is created by the Knower. Therefore, all of us who came here -- our parents were too attached to us as children. But they gladly, even though they were sad that we were going to leave their home, let us come.

Probably they knew we would never go back, and we would probably not write to them on a monthly basis. But their true love for you, which is the expression of the Knower, overcame attachment which wants to keep you with them. "Let him make his own progress as an individual." So these qualities we have been looking at are the Knower's qualities. One set binds you to this Prakriti; the other liberates you from this Prakriti. But the field is no different than the Knower.

Field is also my expression. And in verse 12 we saw Etaj jnanam iti proktam -- "This is what is called knowledge." In the end he defined knowledge as Adhyatma jnana nityatvam -- constant awareness about the Self. Being constantly aware that I am not this limited being.

This limited being is an instrument through which I function. The knower is defined by two qualities: Adhyatma jnana nityatvam and Tattvajnana-artha-darshanam. These are the two basic definitions we came across here. Tattvajnana-artha-darshanam means keeping the goal in mind -- why do I really want to know the truth? The goal should be clear in my mind.

Unless I have a goal in mind, I won't have the enthusiasm. It is like if I am working hard all year, I need to have some goal. What am I going to achieve at the end of the year? Well, when my review comes, maybe my supervisor will recognize I have been working hard. You need to have a goal, the end game, so that you have enthusiasm to pursue the path. So if I consider all these 20 qualities as my prerequisites and want to develop them, I need to have a goal in mind. And the more clear I have the goal in mind, the easier it becomes.

These qualities will then manifest by themselves because my goal is now the correct goal. This is called knowledge. Bhagavan said, everything contrary to that is Ajnanam -- ignorance. Everything contrary to these qualities is ignorance about my own self. He told us: Yaj jnatva amritam asnute -- having known this knowledge, you will attain immortality.

Because the mortality is in reference to this body, this mind, this intellect. As long as I am not identified with them, those mortalities are not mine. Body and mind have their mortality. They are my equipment, and they will have their own use. And once their use is complete, I will have no use for them.

The immortality I seek is beyond this mortal being. Having known which you will attain that immortal Brahman: Anadi mat-param Brahma na sat tan nasat ucyate. So we want to be immortal. He said no, that doesn't happen that way. No being can be immortal.

As long as you are a being, there will be birth and death. But that immortality is neither a being nor a non-being. It's not that because it's not a being, it has no existence. He said it is neither a being nor non-being. It is not a being because it does not have any qualities of a limited being. Therefore it cannot be defined by shape, color, form, or need.

Therefore it's not a being, but also not non-being. It's not non-existent -- it exists, and therefore it's also not non-being. And then we have seen the verse which says: now I need to know what is to be known. I know what knowledge is. But what is to be known -- that which is neither a being nor a non-being?

We have seen this description before in chapter 11, the Vishvarupa. "I see thousands of mouths and thousands of hands and thousands of eyes." As we have also discussed, in the Purusha Suktam of the Rig Veda it is: Sahasra-shirsha Purushah, Sahasrakshah, Sahasrapat -- thousands of heads, thousands of eyes, thousands of feet. Once again he repeats: Sarvatah pani-padam -- everywhere the hands and legs; Tat sarvatah akshi-shiro-mukham -- everywhere the eyes, heads, and mouths.

All hands and legs are His. All eyes and heads and mouths are His. Sarvatah shruti-mat loke -- all the ears are His. Sarvam avritya tishthati -- He remains pervading all, pervading everywhere.

Even though He does not have any qualities, He pervades all the ears, all the hands, all the mouths, all the heads -- everything that I can think of, He's pervading all. Sarva-indriya-guna-abhasam -- He is shining through all the senses. His presence is felt through the senses. When I can see, I know I'm alive.

When I can hear, I know I'm alive. The proof of my existence is that it's shining through my senses. As long as my eyes are seeing and my mouth is speaking, people can vouch for it -- "I think he's okay." When it is not, then simply, life is gone. He is shining through all the indriyas.

Sarva-indriya-vivarjitam -- but He is devoid of all indriyas. Here comes the conundrum. This is taught in dichotomies because we cannot understand the subtlety of it. We try to explain, but we can't fully explain. Therefore we have to explain in pairs of opposites -- like saying neither night nor day, pointing to something beyond both.
snippets.reflection:
Now Krishna describes what is to be known (jneyam) - that Brahman which, when known, grants immortality. The description is deliberately paradoxical: "na sat tan nasad ucyate" - It is neither being nor non-being. It has hands and feet everywhere, eyes and heads everywhere, ears everywhere, yet It is beyond all senses. It sustains everything yet is unattached. It is without qualities yet experiences all qualities. These paradoxes are not logical contradictions but pointers to a reality that transcends the either/or categories of the mind.

Contemplate the teaching that your true Self "shines through every sense perception" (sarvendriya-gunabhasam) yet is "beyond the senses" (sarvendriya-vivarjitam). When you see, there is seeing happening - but the awareness that knows "I am seeing" is not itself seen. When you hear, there is hearing - but the awareness that knows "I am hearing" is not itself heard. Today, during ordinary activities, try to catch glimpses of this: the Knower that is present in all knowing but is never itself an object of knowledge.

As a practical exercise, sit with a candle flame or look at any object. Notice the seeing. Then ask: what is aware of the seeing? You cannot see it, yet without it, no seeing would be known. This is what the verse means by "sustains everything yet is unattached" - your awareness supports every experience yet remains untouched by any experience. Rest in this recognition even briefly, and you touch the immortal.

snippets.title: Day 173: The Knower
snippets.sanskrit:
बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च |

अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम् |

ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
bahirantaśca bhūtānāmacaraṃ carameva ca .

avibhaktaṃ ca bhūteṣu vibhaktamiva ca sthitam .

jyotiṣāmapi tajjyotistamasaḥ paramucyate .
verseTranslations: It is within all beings, yet outside; motionless yet moving; too subtle to be perceived; far away yet always near.
In all beings undivided, yet living in division, It is the upholder of all, Creator and Destroyer alike;
It is the Light of lights, beyond the reach of darkness; the Wisdom, the only thing that is worth knowing or that wisdom can teach; the Presence in the hearts of all.
snippets.commentary:
We have seen in this chapter that in verse number three, Bhagavan has given us a formula for liberation. He basically says that knowledge of the field plus the knowledge of the knower of the field equals knowledge of the Supreme Self. To find this enlightenment, Bhagavan said you need to know both -- the field of experiences and the experiencer. In the same verse, he told us that the Kshetrajna is only one. "I am the Supreme Lord, the experiencer in all the fields. I am the knower in all the fields." As we have discussed before, the consciousness is one and all-pervading, but it manifests through the equipment which we call body, mind, and intellect.

We feel that this consciousness is within me. But in the last few verses, Bhagavan has described that consciousness as all-pervading. I feel it is within me because it is within and without all things and beings. All things and beings are in the consciousness, but we feel the consciousness is within me. Very similar to our analogy of space -- we think the space is in the room, but actually the room is in the space. We have been given a detailed explanation about the Kshetra.

So we have seen the definition of Kshetra from verse 6 to 7. What is the field of experience? It says this body is the field, which includes the five great elements, all the way up to the modifications of mind, up to fortitude, the dhriti. So everything that I consider as part of my world is included in the field of experiences. And then from verse 8 through 12, Bhagavan has described qualities to be developed, starting from humility, Amanitvam, ending with Tattvajnana-artha-darshanam -- the goal of knowing the knower of the field. What is the purpose of having this knowledge that Bhagavan has described?

And these qualities are the means to achieve the knowledge. So Bhagavan called developing these qualities or having these qualities "knowledge." Anything other than that is ignorance. The opposite of all those qualities is ignorance. All these things are limiting me -- this showing off, this high opinion about myself.

Because of that, when I hurt other people knowingly or unknowingly, that's the expression of ignorance. So anything other than these 20 qualities, Bhagavan called it ignorance. And then Bhagavan has described what is to be known in very contradictory terms. Starting from verse 13: Anadi mat-param Brahma. That Brahman which needs to be known is beginningless, and na sat tan nasat ucyate -- it is neither being (sat) nor non-being (asat).

It is also not nothing. So in these contradictory terms, Bhagavan has been explaining the nature of the supreme Brahman that is to be known. That is the goal of knowledge. We came to the last verse we have discussed: Bahir antas cha bhutanam acharam charam eva cha. That supreme Being is within and without all beings.

It is easier for us to think that He is within me and within all the sentient beings. Very, very difficult for me to imagine that He is also outside of me. It appears to be within me, but actually my equipment is within this supreme consciousness. Space seems to be within the room, defined by its conditionings -- four walls, ceiling and floor. But actually space was always here and it will always remain here, even when you remove these conditionings.

Even though this equipment I call myself is identified with the body, mind and intellect, and it seems to be the container for this consciousness -- actually, it is within the consciousness. Acharam charam eva cha -- so it is not just limited to the beings but also things, whether moving or unmoving, within and outside. However, I have no direct experience of this.

So Bhagavan says it is because Sukshmatvat tad avijneyam -- it is so subtle that it is not easy to know. Things which are within the capabilities of my senses, I can perceive them. So I can see the visible light. Light is a form of electromagnetic wave, and within the capabilities of my eyes I can see the visible light.

But any other electromagnetic wave beyond that, I'm not capable of seeing. Radio waves are all over in this room, but I'm not capable of detecting them. But with the right equipment, they can be detected. They are so subtle that my senses are not capable of grasping them. That does not mean they do not exist. Bhagavan says Sukshmatvat tad avijneyam -- because the supreme Self, the supreme consciousness which is everywhere, it is not known to us because of its subtlety. Durastham -- for those who are ignorant about its nature, it is too far to find right now.

It is very overwhelming for me to even think that consciousness is everywhere. Therefore it is too far for me. But it is also very close -- Antike cha tat -- to those who understand its very nature. So one who understands its very nature through experience, for him it is so close because it cannot be any further than my own self. How far am I from my own self? There is no distance to be measured there. I am who I am, where I am. If that "I am" is the same as the supreme Consciousness, if that understanding takes place, Bhagavan said, it is very, very close to you.

It is far for the people who have not understood its real nature, but very close to the people who understood its nature. Bhagavan continues in the next verse and says, Avibhaktam cha bhuteshu vibhaktam iva cha sthitam -- even though it is indivisible, undivided, ever present, all pervading, it also appears to remain in people as divided selves. This is something similar to the space we have discussed. Even though the space is indivisible -- space cannot be divided, cannot be cut, cannot be separated, cannot be made into pieces -- I feel it is divided among all the rooms and buildings and huts and whatever type of containers that I can imagine in this world.

So space is divided into small box, big box, small house, big house. However, its very nature is indivisible. So these days, repurposing the old building is a big trend. Because as we, as we call the greenest building is the one which is not built. The second greenest building is one which is repurposed, which is existing. When you repurpose the building, it's always old, really messy.

But if you are trained in that profession, then you will visualize the space without all the distractions you have from the existing walls and floors and ceilings. Then you figure out that if I can combine all this space and repurpose it, I can make it useful for whatever the purpose. We are using this building because the space is always indivisible. It is I as the architect who put those divisions in it. So Bhagavan says for all the people who feel that the consciousness within them -- He remains as the knower within them, but He remains the same for everyone. Avibhaktam -- never gets divided, never gets polluted, never gets tainted, never gets affected by all the qualities of all those things and beings.

But He remains as He is, though appearing to be divided in beings. Bhuta-bhartru cha taj jneyam -- He is the supporter of all. When I exist in my present state, He is the supporter of my existence. I exist because I'm conscious. My consciousness is the supporter of my existence. Bhuta-bhartr -- the sustainer of all beings. So the same supreme Being which has no qualities, neither Sat nor Asat.

When He sustains this world, He becomes Vishnu, Bhuta-bhartr. When He devours that, when that existence ends, He is the devourer. When the time of Pralaya comes, He devours the whole world, and it goes back into that unmanifest state -- so He is Grasisnu, the devourer. He is also the devourer of all things and beings. When I die, my consciousness associated with this limited self will not be there. So He is the devourer of my existence as it exists today.

Prabhavisnu cha -- when I come into existence in a new form or when I came into existence in this form, He was the generator. Without that awareness that I exist, I do not exist. That awareness started right from my birth. The very first breath you take, you realize "I am." Bhagavan said, Taj jneyam Grasisnu Prabhavisnu cha -- that which is to be known is the sustainer of this universe and all things and beings.

He is also the devourer of all things and beings. He is also the generator of things and beings. Taj jneyam -- you need to know that. So if I cannot know that right now, then the question would be whether that is because of darkness. The things which are unavailable to me, I consider that to be ignorance. Bhagavan addresses this in the next verse.

No, that is not the case. Jyotisham api taj jyotih -- It is the light of all lights. You know, the sun is self-effulgent. But to see the sunlight I have to be conscious. If I'm not conscious, the sun does not exist for me.

Sunlight does not exist for me. Therefore my consciousness is actually the illuminator of the sun which is self-effulgent. Tamasah param ucyate -- beyond darkness. Where there is knowledge, there cannot be ignorance. Where there is light, there cannot be darkness. Therefore this Self which is aware of its own self -- it is the light of all lights. It is the source of all knowledge.

It is the source of all my experiences. Jnana-gamyam -- it resides in all hearts in a very special way. Not just that it stays there as an inactive entity -- in a very special way it participates in all its activities, all that person's activities. So Hridi sarvasya vishthitam -- He stays in the hearts of all, at the core of my consciousness, my intellect, my mind. Jnanam Jneyam Jnana-gamyam -- knowledge, that which is to be known, and also the means to that knowledge. So all three, Bhagavan said, is one and the same -- the supreme Self. The knowledge, the purpose of knowing, and the means for the knowledge is the supreme Self. Iti kshetram tatha jnanam jneyam cha uktam samasatah -- so Bhagavan is concluding the topic saying, look, I told you in the beginning we're going to talk about Kshetra, Jnanam, and Jneyam.

We'll talk about the knowledge and what is to be known. I explained to you what the Kshetra is. I also explained what Jneyam is. Jneyam is that which pervades everywhere, but it seems like it's divided into all things and beings. I also explained what Jnanam is -- what is knowledge?

Knowledge that enables me to know the supreme Self is true knowledge. Therefore we have seen those 20 qualities from Amanitvam to Tattvajnana-artha-darshanam, and I also explained to you what is to be known. My devotees, knowing these, will come to my being. As we have said in the beginning, Bhagavan has given this formula: the knowledge of the field plus the knowledge of the knower of the field equals the knowledge of the supreme Self. Now I've told you what is the goal. The goal is to know the Supreme Self, and the formula is to know the Kshetra and also know who is the knower of the Kshetra.

What is my field of experiences and who is the experiencer? Once you have understood both, then you are my bhakta -- you have dissolved your individuality in that supreme Self. So mad-bhava ayopapadyate -- the one who has surrendered his individuality, one who has surrendered his sense of agency. Once I realized that what I considered to be "me" was actually my ego. When I considered myself as the knower of my experiences, the experiencer, the perceiver, feeler, thinker -- all these actually refer to my ego.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the supreme paradox: That which is to be known is "within all beings yet outside" (bahir antas cha bhutanam), "motionless yet moving" (acharam charam eva cha), "far away yet near" (durastham chantike cha tat), "undivided yet appearing divided" (avibhaktam cha bhuteshu vibhaktam iva cha sthitam). It is the Creator, Sustainer, and Destroyer - and the "Light of all lights, beyond darkness" (jyotisham api taj jyotih tamasah param). This is the formula Krishna promised: knowledge of field plus knowledge of Knower equals knowledge of the Supreme.

The analogy of space is illuminating here. Space appears to be inside the room, but actually the room is in space. Space appears divided by walls into rooms, but space itself is never divided. Similarly, consciousness appears to be "inside" your body, but actually your body-mind exists within consciousness. Consciousness appears divided among beings, but it remains ever undivided. Today, experiment with this shift in perspective: instead of feeling that awareness is inside you, sense that you (body, mind, thoughts) are arising within awareness.

Verse 18 declares that this Supreme is "seated in the hearts of all" (hridi sarvasya vishthitam) - not as an inactive presence but participating in all activities. This is the witness (upadrashta), the permitter (anumanta), the supporter (bharta), and the enjoyer (bhokta). Notice today that your every action has a witness. When you eat, something knows you are eating. When you work, something knows you are working. This knowing presence is not far away in some heaven - it is "nearer than near," the very core of your being.

snippets.sanskrit:
इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः |

snippets.reflection:
Krishna now reveals the relationship between Prakriti (Nature) and Purusha (Spirit): both are beginningless (anadi). All modifications (vikaras) and qualities (gunas) arise from Prakriti alone. Prakriti is the cause of all action through body and senses (karya-karana-kartritva), while Purusha is the cause of experiencing pleasure and pain (sukha-duhkhanam bhoktritva). This is a crucial discrimination: your body acts, your mind thinks, your senses perceive - all this is Prakriti at work. But the sense of "I am experiencing this" - that witnessing presence - is Purusha.

Reflect on this division of labor in your own experience. When your hand moves, it is Prakriti moving. When your mind worries, it is Prakriti worrying. But the awareness that knows "my hand is moving" or "my mind is worrying" - that is the Purusha principle. The Purusha never acts; it only witnesses. Today, notice how naturally you attribute actions to yourself: "I am walking," "I am thinking," "I am feeling." Can you shift to recognizing: "Walking is happening and I am aware of it," "Thinking is happening and I am aware of it"?

The practical implication is liberating: if you are not the doer, you need not carry the burden of doership. Your body-mind will continue to act according to its nature and karma, but you - as awareness - can witness without being crushed by the weight of endless doing. This is not passivity or irresponsibility; it is acting from clarity rather than compulsion. As an exercise, perform one routine task today with full attention but with the inner attitude: "Prakriti is doing this; I am the witnessing presence."

We have been discussing Chapter 13, Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of Discrimination between the Field and its Knower. So far in this chapter, Bhagavan has described the Kshetra -- that this body is the Kshetra, which includes not only the external instruments but also the internal instruments: mind, Buddhi, Chitta, Ahankara, and all their modifications. The Kshetrajna is Paramatma alone. The Supreme Lord, the God, the Almighty, the all-pervading consciousness is the Kshetrajna in all the fields. Then he said, "I'm going to tell you what is Jnanam, Jneyam, and Jnana-gamyam" -- what is knowledge, what is to be known, and how.

Then he explained how Purusha and Prakriti are related to each other. Purusha and Prakriti intertwine and create this world which we experience. Both are beginningless; both are aspects of Ishwara. In our cosmology, we have Purusha and Prakriti -- both beginningless, but controlled by Ishwara. Ishwara is the Mayapati.

Ishvara is in charge of Maya. Brahman with Maya becomes Ishwara, and Ishwara is the Mayapati -- with his Maya, he controls both Prakriti and Purusha. Purusha is the knower. The attributes of Purusha we have seen are Sat, Chit, and Ananda -- Sat (existence), Chit (knowledge), and Ananda (bliss). These are the attributes of Purusha, the knower.

Prakriti has three Gunas: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas. Purusha has no Gunas; Prakriti has three Gunas. Purusha is sentient, conscious. But the interaction between the two creates this world that we experience. That's basically what we have learned so far. The last verse we saw says: Purushah Prakriti-sthah hi, bhunkte Prakriti-jan gunan.

When seated in Prakriti, when intertwined with the Prakriti, it experiences all the gunas of the Prakriti. Karanam Guna, Sangasya Sad Asat, Yoni Janmasu. What I'm experiencing today is because of my attachment to the gunas of the Prakriti.

Because as the Purusha adopted all the Gunas so Purusha coming in contact with the Prakriti. All the gunas of the Prakriti are superimposed on the Purusha Purushas. All the attributes get superimposed in the Prakriti. So Prakriti experience the Satchit and Ananda. That's why we experience the sense of existence. And also we experience Sukha and Dukha as we have seen in this everywhere.

Prakriti on the other hand becomes sentient. Therefore my body becomes sentient, inert body becomes sentient. My mind knows and I also feel that Ananda or Sukharga. So he said Purusha Prante, Prakti. That's the reason we come into being. So we have like three bodies.

The Purusa as my soul has the same nature as the Brahman which is of Sat, Chit and Ananda. So this Sat aspect gives me the sense of existence. The Cheetah aspect gives me the sense of knowing. That's why I know myself, I know the world around me. I know my relationships that comes from that. And Ananda that I experience Sukhendukha in my life.

So this reflection is in my internal instrument. This internal instrument is right now not clean enough. It is also reflecting all other things of Prakriti. So this is more like if I am sitting in a dark room and suddenly light comes on and I see there are mirrors all around me. In that mirror not only I see myself but I also see everything in the room. Now not only I recognize myself in in the mirror but I also recognize everything in the room and I start identifying with them.

So the internal instrument not only reflects the Purusha, it also reflecting the world of objects. All the sensory perceptions we get, we get the sensation through our senses on the internal instrument. The internal instrument is like a mirror or like a film in a camera. It captures everything which comes to it whether it's a Purusha or the world of objects. It captures all the images. That sensation creates perception in the mind.

Then the mind asks the intellect to interpret and it creates conception. That's how we conceive thoughts, we conceive ideas, we conceive things outside. So Bhagawan Shankaracharya says it is the Brahman reflecting in your internal instruments become your individual ego. But I don't recognize it the same as Ishvara. Purusha with the Upadi of Maya becomes Ishwara Purusha with the Upadi of ignorance. In my case same Purusha superimposed by the ignorance, he becomes Jiva, the individual soul conditioned consciousness in case of Lord, unconditioned consciousness superimposed by Maya, by creativity.

Why Bhagavan creates the world? Because it is the very nature of that Purusha. So with that we'll go to the next verse. So next verse says, even though I see that as the cause for my birth in this Sansar, but this supreme Purusa in me, the reflection of the Brahman which I consider to be my limited self, also can be seen as Upadrista, Anumanta, Chabharta, Loka, Maheshwaraha, Paramatma, Iticha, opi Uktaha, dehe Ashmin, Purushah, Paraha, that Purushahaparaha, the supreme Purusha. In this body, the same supreme being which is everywhere, also in the same body. I call myself a Jiva.

An individual ego also is called Upadrasta, the onlooker. Because it is not really taking any part in the activities of my body, mind and intellect. This gross body, this subtle mind and intellect, they're functioning all the time. They are empowered by consciousness, consciousness not taking part in it. Therefore it is also called Upadrasta, onlooker, anumantacha. So that onlooker does not really discriminate between the good activity or bad activities.

But when my mind is thinking something higher, something nobler, something greater, he also becomes permitter. He allows me to act in that particular manner which will help me in my evolution. When I act in that manner, he becomes Bharata, the supporter of my activities and my evolution. He also becomes Bhokta. He also become the enjoyer of those actions. So this Purusha in me is a witness.

He also permits all the things which I do, good or evil. But when it is good, it allows me to grow, then also makes me enjoy those fruits of actions. He is also called Maheshwarah because he is no different than the Great Lord himself. Therefore he is also called Maheshwara. Maheshwara the Great Lord himself and Paramatma in the supreme soul. But looking from the different perspective, when I grow out of my ignorance that I am this body, I am this mind intellect, then I see him as the same Lord Paramatma.

I see him as Maheshwara, the Great Ishwara. So there is no difference between the Lord outside and Lord within me. Therefore, Bhagawan Shankaracharya says this should not be accepted. That Jiva and Paramatma are two different entities. It is one and the same, seen from two different perspectives, one through the lens of ignorance and Other through the lens of knowledge. Sa evam vitti purusam prakritim cha gunaihi saha sarvatha vartamano PI nasabuyo abhijayate.

Such a person who knows Purusha and Prakruti in their real nature, he knows that nature Purusha is satchit and Ananda. It never gets tainted by Prakruti's gunas. But Prakruti's gunas are superimposed on the Purusha when it comes in contact with it. We have heard example in Brahma sutras that if you take an iron ball and put it in fire, each will give its own gunas to the other. So the fire which is red hot, now the ball looks red hot. So the fire attributes are now on the iron ball.

And the fire which was formless, now you can see the round shape. Because that ball was round, you see the red hot ball of iron. So each gives its own attributes to the other when they come in contact with each other. So in this case also that we have seen that the Prakrudin Purusa gives each other their own attributes. One who knows that that they remain separate. They seem to be associated with each other.

They seem to be taking each other's gunas, but they remain separate Gunehi Saha including the gunas, Sarvatha, Varsamanoapi. No matter what situation or condition that person is, he doesn't take the next board. And this is somewhat of a difficult concept because it basically says all my actions in the past and present and future get nullified when I get this knowledge. So there are some technical arguments made here that what happens to the actions which I have performed in the past which are Sanchita Karma? So the actions are three types. Sanchida Karma, Agami Karma and Prarabdha Karma.

Prarabdha Karmas are which I am experiencing right now. The past actions mature today as my circumstances. I went to architecture school. I'm an architect now. That's a Prarabdhyakarna. So if a Gnani becomes knowledgeable about this, do all his karmas get nullified?

And the answer is no. He will continue to experience the Prarabdha Karma which I have matured now in this life. So you will still live this life. But then this Sanchita Karma which accumulated actions which are not yet matured, they get roasted so they never will fructify. And Agame Karma, which I will perform now onward, will have no Meaning because it does not create any more vasanas in me. We have realized that I am not this limited being.

And therefore I don't associate any of the gunas of the body, mind and intellect, even though body, mind and intellect continue to function as they were before. Therefore, these verses say, such a person, at the end of the exhaustion of this life, he will not take the birth again. So I'll leave it to you how you take it. But that's exactly what this verse says. The next verse says how people achieve the state of knowledge, that all the accumulated actions get burned. Prarabdha Karma means nothing because I don't really see myself as the enjoyer, sufferer, as a limited being.

And no actions in the future will make and any difference. Some highly qualified seekers, seekers of liberation, seekers of ultimate happiness, those who are highly qualified, they will achieve this by contemplation.
snippets.reflection:
These verses explain the mechanism of bondage and liberation. When Purusha (consciousness) is "seated in Prakriti" (prakritistho), it experiences the gunas born of Prakriti. Attachment to these gunas (guna-sanga) is the cause of birth in good or evil wombs (sad-asad-yoni-janmasu). Yet this same Purusha in the body is called the Witness (upadrashta), the Permitter (anumanta), the Supporter (bharta), the Enjoyer (bhokta), the Great Lord (Maheshvara), and the Supreme Self (Paramatma). The one who truly knows Purusha and Prakriti with their gunas "is not born again" (na sa bhuyo 'bhijayate).

The image of iron in fire is instructive: when iron enters fire, it takes on the qualities of fire (red, hot, glowing), and fire takes on the form of iron (round, if a ball). Yet iron remains iron and fire remains fire. Similarly, when consciousness associates with Prakriti, each seems to take on the other's qualities - consciousness seems to act and suffer, matter seems to be aware. But in reality, neither has changed its essential nature. Today, notice how you attribute consciousness to your body ("my body feels tired") and how you attribute material qualities to yourself ("I am heavy, I am old"). Can you begin to untangle these superimpositions?

Verse 24 promises liberation to one who knows this: "sarvatha vartamano 'pi" - in whatever condition one may live. You do not need to change your circumstances; you need to change your understanding. The question for reflection: If liberation depends on knowledge, not on external conditions, what is stopping you right now from knowing yourself as the witnessing Purusha rather than the acting Prakriti?
