When seated in Prakriti, when intertwined with the Prakriti, it experiences all the gunas of the Prakriti. Karanam Guna, Sangasya Sad Asat, Yoni Janmasu. And attachment to the Gunas is the cause for the birth in good or not so good wombs. In other words, the existence which I experience right now in this life is because of my attachment and avidya to the Gunas in my past life. Maybe two years before or before my birth. What I'm experiencing today is because of my attachment to the gunas of the Prakriti.

Because as the Purusha adopted all the Gunas so Purusha coming in contact with the Prakriti. All the gunas of the Prakriti are superimposed on the Purusha Purushas. All the attributes get superimposed in the Prakriti. So Prakriti experience the Satchit and Ananda. That's why we experience the sense of existence. And also we experience Sukha and Dukha as we have seen in this everywhere.

Prakriti on the other hand becomes sentient. Therefore my body becomes sentient, inert body becomes sentient. My mind knows and I also feel that Ananda or Sukharga. So he said Purusha Prante, Prakti. That's the reason we come into being. So we have like three bodies.

The gross body which everybody can see. The subtle body which is the internal instrument, the mind Buddhi Chitta Nahanka and the causal body which is the cause for both these bodies to come into existence. Which is my left Tor Vasanas, leftover desires which is what we learned in this previous chapter. The leftover impressions and desires prompt me to take birth in this particular situation. So these two bodies come into existence because of the past Karma Bhagavan Sangha is Sat Karma Janyam. Because of your good actions you achieve this gross and subtle body in this life.

And then he said, how this Pratibimba I think Jina, your question was is there anything reflecting? And Bhagavan Sankaraja Satupa directly answered that question saying Sthula Sarira Abhimani Jiva Namakam Brahmaprati Bambam Bhavati Sa Eva Jivaha Prakritya Swasmat Iswaram Binnat Vena Janati. So it says that the reflection of Brahman, the all pervading Almighty consciousness which is immutable undividable. Its reflection occurs in the internal instrument of that being. That being now receives the impressions reflection of the Brahman. And that is called Jiva.

Now this Brahman as the Purusha reflecting in the internal instrument of individual ego is called Jiva. So it's called Jivaatma atma. The self or the soul, it's called Jiva atma. This Jiva by nature of ignorance consider itself to be different from the Ishvara. This is where we not experience the almightiness of Ishvara. The consciousness which we have is nothing but the Buddhist all pervading Purusha's consciousness.

The Purusa as my soul has the same nature as the Brahman which is of Sat, Chit and Ananda. So this Sat aspect gives me the sense of existence. The Cheetah aspect gives me the sense of knowing. That's why I know myself, I know the world around me. I know my relationships that comes from that. And Ananda that I experience Sukhendukha in my life.

So this reflection is in my internal instrument. This internal instrument is right now not clean enough. It is also reflecting all other things of Prakriti. So this is more like if I am sitting in a dark room and suddenly light comes on and I see there are mirrors all around me. In that mirror not only I see myself but I also see everything in the room. Now not only I recognize myself in in the mirror but I also recognize everything in the room and I start identifying with them.

So the internal instrument not only reflects the Purusha, it also reflecting the world of objects. All the sensory perceptions we get, we get the sensation through our senses on the internal instrument. The internal instrument is like a mirror or like a film in a camera. It captures everything which comes to it whether it's a Purusha or the world of objects. It captures all the images. That sensation creates perception in the mind.

Then the mind asks the intellect to interpret and it creates conception. That's how we conceive thoughts, we conceive ideas, we conceive things outside. So Bhagawan Shankaracharya says it is the Brahman reflecting in your internal instruments become your individual ego. But I don't recognize it the same as Ishvara. Purusha with the Upadi of Maya becomes Ishwara Purusha with the Upadi of ignorance. In my case same Purusha superimposed by the ignorance, he becomes Jiva, the individual soul conditioned consciousness in case of Lord, unconditioned consciousness superimposed by Maya, by creativity.

Why Bhagavan creates the world? Because it is the very nature of that Purusha. So with that we'll go to the next verse. So next verse says, even though I see that as the cause for my birth in this Sansar, but this supreme Purusa in me, the reflection of the Brahman which I consider to be my limited self, also can be seen as Upadrista, Anumanta, Chabharta, Loka, Maheshwaraha, Paramatma, Iticha, opi Uktaha, dehe Ashmin, Purushah, Paraha, that Purushahaparaha, the supreme Purusha. In this body, the same supreme being which is everywhere, also in the same body. I call myself a Jiva.

An individual ego also is called Upadrasta, the onlooker. Because it is not really taking any part in the activities of my body, mind and intellect. This gross body, this subtle mind and intellect, they're functioning all the time. They are empowered by consciousness, consciousness not taking part in it. Therefore it is also called Upadrasta, onlooker, anumantacha. So that onlooker does not really discriminate between the good activity or bad activities.

But when my mind is thinking something higher, something nobler, something greater, he also becomes permitter. He allows me to act in that particular manner which will help me in my evolution. When I act in that manner, he becomes Bharata, the supporter of my activities and my evolution. He also becomes Bhokta. He also become the enjoyer of those actions. So this Purusha in me is a witness.

He also permits all the things which I do, good or evil. But when it is good, it allows me to grow, then also makes me enjoy those fruits of actions. He is also called Maheshwarah because he is no different than the Great Lord himself. Therefore he is also called Maheshwara. Maheshwara the Great Lord himself and Paramatma in the supreme soul. But looking from the different perspective, when I grow out of my ignorance that I am this body, I am this mind intellect, then I see him as the same Lord Paramatma.

I see him as Maheshwara, the Great Ishwara. So there is no difference between the Lord outside and Lord within me. Therefore, Bhagawan Shankaracharya says this should not be accepted. That Jiva and Paramatma are two different entities. It is one and the same, seen from two different perspectives, one through the lens of ignorance and Other through the lens of knowledge. Sa evam vitti purusam prakritim cha gunaihi saha sarvatha vartamano PI nasabuyo abhijayate.

Such a person who knows Purusha and Prakruti in their real nature, he knows that nature Purusha is satchit and Ananda. It never gets tainted by Prakruti's gunas. But Prakruti's gunas are superimposed on the Purusha when it comes in contact with it. We have heard example in Brahma sutras that if you take an iron ball and put it in fire, each will give its own gunas to the other. So the fire which is red hot, now the ball looks red hot. So the fire attributes are now on the iron ball.

And the fire which was formless, now you can see the round shape. Because that ball was round, you see the red hot ball of iron. So each gives its own attributes to the other when they come in contact with each other. So in this case also that we have seen that the Prakrudin Purusa gives each other their own attributes. One who knows that that they remain separate. They seem to be associated with each other.

They seem to be taking each other's gunas, but they remain separate Gunehi Saha including the gunas, Sarvatha, Varsamanoapi. No matter what situation or condition that person is, he doesn't take the next board. And this is somewhat of a difficult concept because it basically says all my actions in the past and present and future get nullified when I get this knowledge. So there are some technical arguments made here that what happens to the actions which I have performed in the past which are Sanchita Karma? So the actions are three types. Sanchida Karma, Agami Karma and Prarabdha Karma.

Prarabdha Karmas are which I am experiencing right now. The past actions mature today as my circumstances. I went to architecture school. I'm an architect now. That's a Prarabdhyakarna. So if a Gnani becomes knowledgeable about this, do all his karmas get nullified?

And the answer is no. He will continue to experience the Prarabdha Karma which I have matured now in this life. So you will still live this life. But then this Sanchita Karma which accumulated actions which are not yet matured, they get roasted so they never will fructify. And Agame Karma, which I will perform now onward, will have no Meaning because it does not create any more vasanas in me. We have realized that I am not this limited being.

And therefore I don't associate any of the gunas of the body, mind and intellect, even though body, mind and intellect continue to function as they were before. Therefore, these verses say, such a person, at the end of the exhaustion of this life, he will not take the birth again. So I'll leave it to you how you take it. But that's exactly what this verse says. The next verse says how people achieve the state of knowledge, that all the accumulated actions get burned. Prarabdha Karma means nothing because I don't really see myself as the enjoyer, sufferer, as a limited being.

And no actions in the future will make and any difference. Some highly qualified seekers, seekers of liberation, seekers of ultimate happiness, those who are highly qualified, they will achieve this by contemplation.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna now reveals the multiple paths to Self-knowledge: some realize the Self through meditation (dhyana), some through the yoga of knowledge (Sankhya), some through the yoga of action (Karma Yoga), and others simply through hearing from teachers and worshipping with faith (shrutva anyebhya upasate). The beautiful promise is that even those without direct knowledge, if they are "devoted to what they have heard" (shruti-parayanah), cross beyond death. This is enormously encouraging - the path is available to all, regardless of intellectual capacity or spiritual attainment.

Verse 27 summarizes the entire teaching: wherever any being exists, movable or immovable (sthavara-jangamam), know it to be born from the union of Field and Knower (kshetra-kshetrajna-samyogat). This is like the observer effect in quantum physics - the particle manifests when observed. Similarly, the world of experience arises when consciousness (Knower) and matter (Field) come together. Today, look around at everything you see - people, animals, plants, objects. Each one exists because of this union. The same consciousness that looks through your eyes is present in all these forms.

As a practical exercise, choose one of the four paths mentioned for deeper exploration this week. If meditation suits you, set aside time for silent sitting. If you are intellectually inclined, study the distinction between Purusha and Prakriti more deeply. If action is your nature, practice Karma Yoga by offering your work as worship. If devotion calls to you, simply listen to the teachings with faith and let them transform you. All paths lead to the same recognition: you are not the Field but the Knower of the Field.

snippets.title: Day 177: The Knower
snippets.sanskrit:
समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम् |

समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम् |

प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः |
snippets.transliteration:
samaṃ sarveṣu bhūteṣu tiṣṭhantaṃ parameśvaram .

samaṃ paśyanhi sarvatra samavasthitamīśvaram .

prakṛtyaiva ca karmāṇi kriyamāṇāni sarvaśaḥ .
verseTranslations: He who can see the Supreme Lord in all beings, the Imperishable amidst the perishable, he it is who really sees.
Beholding the Lord in all things equally, his actions do not mar his spiritual life but lead him to the height of Bliss.
He who understands that it is only the Law of Nature that brings action to fruition, and that the Self never acts, alone knows the Truth.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing chapter 13, Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of discrimination between the field and its Knower. This is the most analytical chapter in the Bhagavad Gita. It literally summarizes the whole philosophy of Vedanta. The goal of this chapter is to differentiate between the self and the non-self, the field and its knower. What we have seen so far is that Bhagavan has clearly defined the field and clearly defined who the knower of the field is.

We know that every being has his or her own consciousness. But we consider that to be different from each other. In the very beginning of the chapter, Bhagavan changed that paradigm and said the Kshetrajna is only one -- the pure Consciousness, the Supreme Self. The Supreme Being is the Kshetrajna in all the fields. He is the Knower of the field in all the fields. This is where we have to reconcile the parallax that we have -- we consider the Knower of the field in me, the Knower that I am, to be different from the Knower in other people.

Bhagavan basically started this chapter with that premise: the Knower is only one. In previous chapters, Bhagavan described his nature. In chapter 7 he describes that he has a lower Prakriti and a higher Prakriti. The lower Prakriti is the manifest world that we see. The higher Prakriti is the unmanifest consciousness which functions through this Prakriti. We discussed that Bhagavan as Ishwara is both the efficient cause and the material cause for this world -- the creation as we perceive it through our senses.

This world is a creation which I can perceive through my senses and vouch for -- it exists, the world exists. These are existences I can vouch for, and the creation is an effect. I myself am an effect; the world is an effect. So there has to be a Creator. We have come to the conclusion that there must be one Creator who created this universe, including my own self, including my own being. That Creator did not have any other source of material.

He could not buy, borrow, or steal material from any other source. Therefore, the only material available to him was his own self. He created this Jagat out of his own self, and so is my own being. Therefore, myself cannot be separate, cannot be different from his self, because the material provided for this Jagat is nothing but the Bhagavan's own self. In Sankhya philosophy, we have seen it described in a different way.

Purusha and Prakriti. Purusha is the efficient cause and Prakriti is the material cause. Prakriti provides the material. Purusha is the consciousness agency which provide the efficient cause. Then we have discussed the Vedanta goes one step further. It says both the efficient cause, which is Purusha and Prakriti which is the material cause, are expression of the same entity, Brahman.

This Prakriti is created out of Maya. In appearance only -- no actual mutation took place in the self of that great Paramatma. But it appears to have mutated into this Prakriti, the world of plurality. We have understood this intellectually. If you take that argument, there is no difference between your Atma -- which you consider your consciousness, different from the Paramatma -- and the Supreme Being. Now what we are discussing is how that Supreme Being relates to the Prakriti. The last few verses we have seen are concluding verses, because in the verses before this, we saw how to recognize the Paramatma which is immutable, which is neither Sat nor Asat.

Some recognize this through Dhyanam, some through Karma Yoga, some through just listening. Depending on your own capabilities, you can choose the path most appropriate for you to recognize that myself, the Atma which I consider my own being, is the same as Paramatma. Bhagavan now concludes this topic by saying: Yavat sanjayate kinchit, satvam sthavara-jangamam. Wherever you see any creation in this Jagat, know that the field and its knower have come together. Without the knower and the field coming together, there is no creation. It is like in quantum physics.

They say the particle only exists when somebody detects it. Unless there is an observer, the particle may be in the form of a probability wave. As soon as there is a detector, either individual or mechanical, the particle will manifest as a particle. So unless there is a knower, there is no field. And if there is a field, there has to be a knower of that field. The two exist in mutual existence.

So Bhagawan said, whenever there is a creation, both have to be there. Efficient cause and material cause. They both have to be present in that creation. So no O Bharatara Sabha, wherever there is creation, there are both material cause and efficient cause. Purusha Efficient cause, Prakriti material cause. However you should know.

Bhagavan said Samam sarveshu bhuteshu tishthantam parameshvaram -- seeing the supreme Lord equally present in all beings. Right now, because of my own Ahankar, this Aham-kartr Ahankar which says I am so unique that the paramatma in me is very unique compared to all other beings. The atma in all other beings -- dismissing the animals to be inferior, and even the worms to be inferior to anything else. So this notion that I have, this inflated evaluation of my own self, is a myth. This myth has to go away for me to recognize the paramatma. The myth which I have created in my own mind that I am unique and everybody else is just normal, that we are normal beings of this world.

But I myself am very unique. One who sees the same Atma, same paramatma as the atma in all beings -- Vinashyatsu avinashyantam yah pashyati sah pashyati. Right now I am seeing this world through my physical senses, through my eyes, through my understanding based on my limited sense perception. The sense perception has created the conception in my mind about what the world is and what my being is. But after getting the wisdom of this reality, Bhagavan said, one who starts seeing that immutable, imperishable paramatma -- which is the Purusha functioning as the knower of the field.

The knower in each field is not different from the knower in other fields. So he does not see this atma to be destructible in any being. Yah pashyati sah pashyati -- one who sees that indestructible atma in all perishable things and beings, he truly sees. I see things and beings all around me which are perishable in the sense that they have a beginning date and an end date.

Everything that I see in the world, including the stars and galaxies, all have a beginning date and end date. The world around me is constantly changing. I myself am constantly changing. My body is changing, my mind is changing, my intellect is changing. But I am the witness of these changes in me.

So I must be different than the changes which are occurring in me, the same way the world which is changing requires a changeless knower. The knower of this universe must be changeless, just as I remain changeless throughout my existence as this limited being from my childhood to these old days. He said, one who sees that is the wise person. Samam pashyan hi sarvatra samavasthitam ishwaram na hinasty atmanatmanam tato yati param gatim. One who sees Ishwara pervading all beings, the same Ishwara everywhere -- he does not destroy the Self by the self, and therefore he achieves the higher state of existence.

He becomes one with That. We have seen this before. We learned in chapter 6, verse 5: Uddharet atmana atmanam na atmanam avasadayet -- lift yourself by yourself, don't let yourself fall. So we already learned, at least six chapters ago, that there are two selves in me.

One which is identified with this limited being -- the limited self which is conditioned consciousness. That limited self is constantly getting guidance from the higher Self which is the paramatma. My own conscience, my own antaratma, which guides me all the time. I know before I do anything whether it is right or wrong. My antaratma will tell me. My conscience will tell me whether I'm on the right path or not.

I know this market is very hot and everybody is putting money in it. Maybe I should back out. But I'm not going to back out because I don't want to lose out. What if market continues to go up? Even though my antaratma said this is not the right way to go about in this market. I'll go and do it anyway.

Bhagavan is saying that you have let yourself down by your own self, by not listening to the higher Self. Bhagavan has advised us: don't let your lower self fall by not listening to your higher Self. The constant guidance from the higher Self is there. I'm always connected, even though I am not aware of it -- just as the conditioned space in the room is always connected with the universal space outside. There was never a division between the room space and the space outside. It is only in my mind that I see it as limited space.

Therefore I call it "room space." All the things which I consider the attributes of the room space are actually attributes of the conditioning of the room -- the walls, the length, width, height, whether the room is clean or dirty. I call it "room space," but what I'm describing is the conditioning of that room. The same way, Bhagavan said, when I identify with this conditioning, the knower of the field appears to become limited.

That is the aham-kartr, the ahankar. When it reflects the consciousness, it itself thinks it is consciousness. That consciousness is now reflecting the limitations of the conditioning in the body, mind and intellect -- just as the room space appears to reflect the limitations of the room: how wide it is, how long it is, how tall it is. All those are attributes of the conditioning, not of the space.

So Bhagavan says: Samam pashyan hi sarvatra samavasthitam ishwaram -- one who sees this Ishwara pervading all knowers of these fields, he does not destroy the higher Self by the lower self. By completely identifying with the lower self, I'm literally disassociating myself from the higher Self. If I completely identify myself as the body, mind, intellect and say "this is it" -- Rinam kritva ghritam pibet yavaj jivet sukham jivet.

Even if you incur debt, drink ghee, live happily -- after this body is burnt, there is no coming back. So live as comfortably as you can by whatever means. There is one type of philosophy which is Charvaka Darshan, one of the schools of thought in our Indian philosophy. But once again, if you are abiding by that thought, then you have completely negated the existence of the higher Self. You have disassociated yourself from the higher Self.

You are not recognizing the existence of the higher Self. That is killing your higher Self by identifying with the non-self. This ego is not the Self -- it is a thinking entity. This thinking entity is inert and cannot think unless it is energized by the Purusha's presence, the sentience in me. But the ego starts thinking, "These are the qualities of mind, and therefore I am the Almighty for my world and I do not need any higher guidance."

He says such a person kills the higher Self by the lower self, and he does not see the real truth. One who does not do that achieves the higher state of existence. Prakritya eva cha karmani kriyamanani sarvashah -- one who sees that all actions are being performed within the Prakriti, by the Prakriti alone, and the Atma is the non-doer.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the vision of the wise: one who sees the Supreme Lord equally present in all beings (samam sarveshu bhuteshu), the Imperishable amidst the perishable (vinashyatsu avinashyantam) - "he alone truly sees" (sa pashyati). Such a person, seeing the Lord equally everywhere, "does not destroy the Self by the self" (na hinasty atmanatmanam) and attains the supreme goal. The one who sees that all actions are performed by Prakriti alone, and that the Self is the non-doer (akartaram), truly sees.

The phrase "does not destroy the Self by the self" recalls Chapter 6: "Let a person lift himself by himself; let him not degrade himself." Your lower self (ego identified with body-mind) can either serve or obstruct your higher Self (the witnessing consciousness). When you completely identify with the ego and deny the higher dimension, you "kill" your higher Self. When you recognize the ego as a useful instrument while anchoring your identity in awareness, you "lift" yourself. Reflect today: in what ways do you habitually "destroy" your higher nature by over-identifying with the limited self?

Verse 30 provides the practical key: see that all actions are performed by Prakriti alone (prakritya eva cha karmani kriyamanani sarvashah). Your body moves, your breath flows, your thoughts arise - all this is Prakriti functioning according to its nature. The Self merely witnesses without acting. Today, choose one activity - perhaps brushing your teeth or preparing a meal - and observe it with this understanding: "Prakriti is performing this action. I am the witnessing presence." Notice how this shift brings a natural ease and freedom to action.

snippets.title: Day 178: Knowledge and Ignorance
snippets.sanskrit:
यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति |

अनादित्वान्निर्गुणत्वात्परमात्मायमव्ययः |

यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
yadā bhūtapṛthagbhāvamekasthamanupaśyati .

anāditvānnirguṇatvātparamātmāyamavyayaḥ .

yathā sarvagataṃ saukṣmyādākāśaṃ nopalipyate .
verseTranslations: He who sees the diverse forms of life all rooted in One, and growing forth from Him, he shall indeed find the Absolute.
The Supreme Spirit, O Prince, is without beginning, without Qualities and Imperishable, and though it be within the body, yet It does not act, nor is It affected by action.
As space, though present everywhere, remains by reason of its subtlety unaffected, so the Self, though present in all forms, retains its purity unalloyed.

Right now, because of my own Ahankar, this Aham-kartr Ahankar which says I am so unique that the paramatma in me is very unique compared to all other beings. The atma in all other beings -- dismissing the animals to be inferior, and even the worms to be inferior to anything else. So this notion that I have, this inflated evaluation of my own self, is a myth. This myth has to go away for me to recognize the paramatma. The myth which I have created in my own mind that I am unique and everybody else is just normal, that we are normal beings of this world.

But I myself is very unique. One who says the same Atma, same paramatma is atma in all beings. Vinasyatsu or Vinasyantam Yah Pasyati sah Pashyati. Right now I am seeing this world through my physical senses, through my eyes, through my understanding of my limited sense perception. The sense perception has created the conception in my mind about what the world is and what my being is. But after getting the wisdom of this reality, Bhagavan said, one who starts seeing that, that immutable imperishable paramatma which is the Purusha functioning is the knower of the field.

In each field is not different from each other or each other. Knowers in this field. So he does not see this atma to be destructible in any being. Yah Pashyati Sah Pashyati Manu sees that indestructible atma in all perishable things and beings. I see things and beings all around me which are perishable in a sense. It has beginning date and end date.

Or anything that which I see in the world, including the stars and galaxies. They all have beginning date and end date. Changing the world around me is constantly changing. I myself is constantly changing. My body is changing, my mind is changing, my intellect is changing. But I am the witness of these changes in me.

So I must be different than the changes which are occurring in me the same way the world which is changing. The knower of this universe must be changeless just as I remain changeless throughout my existence as this limited being from my childhood to these old days. He said, one who sees that he is the wise person. Sammam paschenhi sarvatra sam avasthitam ishwaram na hinashyati atmanaatmanam tatoyati paramgatim. One who sees Ishwara exists pervading an all being, a same Ishwara. He does not destroy the self by by the self and therefore he achieves the higher state of existence.

He becomes one with that. We have seen this before. We Learned in chapter 6 in verse 5 Bhagawan I said uttarat atmana tmanam na tmanam ausaade. Lift yourself by yourself, don't let yourself fall. So we already learned at least six chapters ago. There are two selves in me.

One which is identified with this limited being, the limited self which is conditioned consciousness. That limited self is constantly getting the guidance from the higher self which is the paramatma. My own conscience, my own antaratma which guides me all the time. I know before I do anything whether it is right or wrong. My antaratna will tell me. My conscience will tell me whether I'm on a right path or not.

I know this market is very hot and everybody is putting money in it. Maybe I should back out. But I'm not going to back out because I don't want to lose out. What if market continues to go up? Even though my antaratma said this is not the right way to go about in this market. I'll go and do it anyway.

The Bhagawan saying that you have let yourself down by your own self, not listening to the higher self. The Bhagawan has advised us that don't let your lower self fall by not listening to your higher self with constant guidance from the higher self. Because I'm always connected even though I am not aware of it. Just the conditioned space in the room is always connected with the universal space outside. There was never a division between the room space and the space outside. It is only in my mind that I see that as limited space.

Therefore I call this room space. All the things which I consider the attributes of the room space are actually those attributes are of the conditioning of the room, the walls, the length, width, height, the contamination or the room is clean or dirty. I call it A room space. But what I'm describing is the conditioning of that room. The same way Bhagavan said. When I identify with this conditioning, the node of the field becomes limited.

That is the ahamkartru, the ahankar. When it reflects the consciousness, it itself think it is consciousness. That consciousness is now reflecting the limitations of the condition in the body, mind and intellect. Just as the room space is now reflecting the limitations of the room. How wide it is, how long it is, how tall it is. All those are attributes of the conditioning, not of the space.

So Bhagwante samam pashanhi sarvatra sam avasthitam Ishwaram. One who sees this Ishwara pervading all knowers of these fields. He does not destroy the higher self by the lower self. By completely identifying with the lower self, I'm literally disassociating myself from the higher self. If I completely identify myself as the body, mind, intellect and say this is it. Runam krutva gurutumbibet yavad jeevet Sukam jeevet.

Even if you incur death, drink ghee, live happily. After this body is burnt, there is no coming back. So leave as comfortably as you can by whatever means. There is one type of philosophy which is Charvak Darshan, one of the schools of thought in our Indian philosophy. But once again if you are abiding to that thought then you have completely negated the existence of the higher self. You disassociated yourself with Sahara self.

You are not recognizing the existence of the higher self. That is killing your higher self by yourself identifying with the non self. This ego is not the self. This thinking entity. This thinking entity is inert and cannot think unless it is energized by the Purusha's presence, the sentience in me. But the ego starts thinking.

These are the qualities of mind. And therefore I am the Almighty for my world and I do not need any higher guidance. He says such a person kills the higher self by the lower self and he does not see the real truth. One who does not do that, he achieves the higher state of existence. Prakruti evacha Karmani Kriyamanani Sarvasah. One who sees that all actions are being performed within the Prakriti by the Prakriti and Atma.
snippets.reflection:
These verses bring a sublime vision: when one perceives the diverse existence of beings as rooted in One and spreading forth from That alone (ekastham anupashyati, tata eva cha vistaram), one attains Brahman. The Supreme Self, being beginningless and without qualities (anaditvat nirgunatvat), though dwelling in the body, neither acts nor is tainted (na karoti na lipyate). Just as space, being all-pervading and subtle, is not affected by what it contains (akasham nopalipyate), so the Self, though present in all bodies, remains pure (atma nopalipyate).

The space analogy is profound and practical. Consider the space in a dirty room versus a clean room, a prison cell versus a temple. The space itself is never dirty or clean, imprisoned or sacred - these are qualities of the containers, not the space. Similarly, your awareness witnesses angry thoughts and peaceful thoughts, noble actions and ignoble actions, but awareness itself is never angry or peaceful, noble or ignoble. It simply illuminates whatever arises. Today, practice holding this recognition: "I am like space - present everywhere in my experience, yet untouched by any experience."

The practical test is simple: can you be aware of a difficult emotion without becoming that emotion? Can you witness a disturbing thought without being disturbed? This is not suppression or denial - the emotion is fully felt, the thought is clearly seen - but you recognize that you are the space in which these arise, not the contents. When you truly see this, you touch the imperishable amidst the perishable, the unchanging amidst the changing.

snippets.title: Day 179: Prakriti and Purusha
snippets.sanskrit:
यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः |

क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवमन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा |
snippets.transliteration:
yathā prakāśayatyekaḥ kṛtsnaṃ lokamimaṃ raviḥ .

kṣetrakṣetrajñayorevamantaraṃ jñānacakṣuṣā .
verseTranslations: As the one Sun illuminates the whole earth, so the Lord illumines the whole universe.
Those who with the eyes of wisdom thus see the difference between Matter and Spirit, and know how to liberate Life from the Law of Nature, they attain the Supreme."
snippets.commentary:
In studying the Bhagavad Gita, we have seen that it is divided into three parts describing Tattvamasi -- "That thou art." "Thou," that is you as you are; "That," which is the Lord you are seeking. They both are one and the same. In the first six chapters, we talked about "you" as we are today. In the next six chapters, we talked about the identity of the Lord. But how do we reconcile that they both are one and the same? From chapter 13 onward is an explanation of how these two are one and the same.

Myself and this Supreme Self are not two different selves, but just one and the same. Chapter 13 started by asking how this differentiation comes in our perception, in our understanding of "I" and the world -- the duality created between myself and everything other than what I consider myself. In chapter 13, we have seen Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga -- the differentiation created in my understanding between the field and its knower. The differentiation right now is very clear: I am the knower of the world that I know, and the world is my field of actions. This chapter takes it one notch higher and says: Idam Shariram Kaunteya, iti Kshetram.

This which I consider as the knower right now is actually part of the field. This body is the field, and one who knows the body is the knower. So we took it to one more subtle level. The definition I know intuitively is that I am the knower and the world is my field. But now I have included my body as part of the world, and "I," the knower, remains something other than this body. Then we also include the mind and intellect and all my emotions into it.

All the vikaras, the modifications of this field, all my emotions, my experiences -- all go into it. Then what is left, the one who is aware of everything, is the knower. The field is where all the activity is taking place. We have also defined it in a different way: Prakriti and Purusha. Now we know there are two entities which constitute my world. My world is the world of matter, the field in which all the activity is taking place.

The one who knows and feels the results and reactions of this activity -- at my micro-cosmic level, when I'm identified with this field, with what I consider my body, my mind, my intellect -- the one who is aware of this and identifying with it becomes the enjoyer or sufferer of the activities performed by my mind, my intellect, and my body. The same applies to all bodies, minds, and intellects.

Bhagavan said both the field and the knower of the field are beginningless. You can think about when this started. The question, obviously and legitimately, is: why and when?

When did this ignorance about myself start -- the ignorance that I am not the Supreme Self? And why? The answer is given in a way that requires more contemplation. It basically says they both are beginningless. There's no beginning where one day Bhagavan says, "Let there be Prakriti and let them suffer through it." They're beginningless because they are the very nature of the Lord. Both Prakriti and Purusha are the nature of the Lord, as we have seen in the previous chapter: "My higher Prakriti and my lower Prakriti." My lower Prakriti is the manifest world, and my higher Prakriti is the one which supports this lower Prakriti and makes it function.

In this chapter, we have seen it in different ways. Purusha is the subtler, higher, unmanifest self. And Prakriti is the most manifest self. Both are beginningless because they are the very nature of the Supreme, the Brahman. Anything which has a cause becomes an effect. Every effect has its qualities.

These qualities make it perishable, and therefore it remains in time and space for a limited duration. As long as qualities are attributed to something, it has a cause and a timeline. But something which is beginningless obviously cannot have any qualities. Therefore Brahman does not have any qualities, and therefore it has no cause.

If there is no cause, it is beginningless. If Prakriti and Purusha are the two aspects of the Supreme, they both are beginningless. We started with this basic understanding. Then he said, if that's the case, then obviously all hands are His, all mouths are His. Anywhere or any place where a thing or a being comes into existence, it is because of the union between these two -- Prakriti and Purusha. Creation only takes place when Prakriti and Purusha, the field and its knower, come together. If there is no knower, there is no field.

And if there is no field, there is no knower. As long as I consider myself a living being -- as long as, one, I have this body, mind, and intellect, and two, I'm aware of it. If I'm not aware of it, do I really exist? Therefore the question: do you really exist in deep sleep? I know I exist in the waking world.

I know I exist in a dream as a dreamer. But do I really exist in my deep sleep? I'm not aware of myself -- or am I? I am very aware of myself even though I'm not aware of my body, mind, and intellect. Therefore I wake up and say, "I had a good sleep." If I were not aware of myself, I wouldn't be able to say that.

Therefore I say I exist even in my deep sleep. I exist as a waker, I exist as a dreamer, and I also exist as a deep sleeper. As this limited ego, I consider myself. Then Bhagavan takes us to the path where he says: what is knowledge and what is to be known? What is to be known is seated in the hearts of all the beings and all things.

The core of our being is our awareness about our self -- that is to be known. Who is it that is aware of my being? That which leads me to that knowledge is the knowledge. Everything else other than that is ignorance. We have seen those several qualities -- Amanitvam, Adambhitvam. Those qualities lead me to know the knowable in my heart.

Those qualities will take me to knowing the Self, which will make me aware that my self is no different from yourself, herself, and himself -- it is the one Self. Once that understanding takes place, Bhagavan said, one achieves the supreme state. How can I get over my limitations? How can I be perennially happy? That state, Bhagavan said, you will achieve when you understand that this self in me is the self seated in all hearts, moving or unmoving.

That is the core, the essence of all beings. Bhagavan said that many people have recognized this Self through many different paths -- Dhyana Yoga, Karma Yoga, Jnana Yoga, Bhakti Yoga. There are various paths. People have attained knowledge about their own self and in turn gained knowledge of the Paramatma. But some may not even be capable of following any path.

Just having faith in somebody's words, they have attained this. Just having that faith -- because my guru told me, or such and such person told me -- and having pursued that, they also achieved it.

The last few verses address the test: how can I consider that I have come to know this? Samam pashyan hi sarvatra, sama-avasthitam Ishwaram. One who starts seeing that the Ishwara, my Lord, is sitting equally in all hearts, is present everywhere equally -- and therefore I'm not negating the Supreme Self by my small self. Right now, I've already negated it.

I only consider "this is me." Nothing other than this I consider me -- "that's not me, that's not me, that's not me." But once I say "this is all me," I'm not negated, even though I'm aware of this limited self. I'm also aware that this extension of the world is nothing but me alone. Just as in the example we have seen, the conditioned room space was never separated from the space outside. Right now I'm aware of the conditioned space and I say, "This is room space."

But if I also have the understanding that room space and space are one and the same, then I truly have knowledge of space. The last few verses expand on this idea that I'm constantly aware of both my existences -- my existence as this limited ego, the conditioned self as this body, mind, and intellect, and at the same time, my existence as the Supreme Self.

The last few verses say: Anaditvat nirgunatvat, Paramatma ayam avyayah, sharira-stho 'pi Kaunteya, na karoti na lipyate. This Paramatma, this Self at its greater level, is beginningless and devoid of all qualities. My limited self has a beginning and an end -- I was born and I will die.

Or you can say wherever my ego started, many births ago. Once I realize that this conditioned self is none other than that which is beginningless and nirgunatvat -- I have all the qualities right now: nice person, not so nice. All these are qualities of my body, mind, and intellect, which I perceive one way and the world perceives another way. But He said these qualities are not the qualities of myself. These are qualities of my conditioning, the Prakriti. Prakriti, my manifest self, has the qualities.

But my real Self, which is knowing this Prakriti, has no qualities. Because, as Bhagavan said, the Self has no cause and therefore it is beginningless. And because it is beginningless and has no cause, it cannot have any qualities that make it limited. Knowing that the Paramatma is immutable, imperishable, beginningless, and quality-less -- and so is the nature of myself -- therefore, though it is seated in my heart, in this body, as the propeller for this body to perform actions, it is not doing anything.

No actions are being performed by myself. All actions are performed by the qualities of the Prakriti. In Gujarati there is a saying: "Prana Prakriti saathe jaay" -- the Prana and the Prakriti both go together. Nothing goes first, nothing goes later. In other words, my inherent nature will not change no matter what happens.

I cannot suddenly become interested in boxing or wrestling because my inherent nature is not to be in that. Bhagavan said: Sharira-stho 'pi Kaunteya -- even though it seems he is seated in this heart and propelling this body, mind, and intellect to act, the acts are only performed by this body, mind, and intellect and belong to them alone. As long as the conditioned self is identifying with them, it suffers and enjoys. When that identification is removed, there is no suffering or enjoyment because of the actions of this body. Therefore he says: Na karoti -- he is not doing anything. Na lipyate -- he is not affected by it.

The next verse says: Yatha sarvagatam saukshmat, akasham na upalipyate, sarvatra avasthito dehe, tatha atma na upalipyate. Just as space -- and I use this analogy very conveniently as an architect -- because of its subtle nature, space is never tainted. It says Akasha, space, is all-pervading yet never affected.
snippets.reflection:
The chapter concludes with a powerful analogy and promise: "As the one sun illuminates the entire world, so the Lord of the field illuminates the entire field" (yatha prakashayaty ekah kritsnam lokam imam ravih, kshetram kshetri tatha kritsnam prakashayati). Just as one sun lights up all objects without being affected by what it illuminates, so the one Consciousness lights up all experiences in all beings. Those who perceive with the eye of wisdom (jnana-chakshusha) the difference between Field and Knower, and know the liberation of beings from Prakriti, attain the Supreme (yanti te param).

This solar analogy deserves deep contemplation. The sun does not choose what to illuminate - it shines equally on palaces and slums, on saints and sinners. Your awareness is similar: it illuminates every thought, every sensation, every emotion without discrimination. The sun does not become the objects it lights; awareness does not become the experiences it illuminates. Spend time today with this recognition: there is a light in you that has illuminated every experience of your life, yet has never been changed by any experience. This light is your true nature.

The final verse gives the key to liberation: see with wisdom the difference between Field and Knower (kshetra-kshetrajnayor evam antaram). This entire chapter has been preparing you for this discernment. As a concluding practice for this chapter, sit quietly and review: What is my field? My body, senses, mind, emotions, thoughts, memories, identifications. Who is the Knower? That which is aware of all these yet is none of these. Rest in this discrimination. This is not mere philosophy; it is "bhuta-prakriti-moksham" - the liberation of your being from the bondage of matter. Those who know this, says Krishna, attain the Supreme.

snippets.title: Day 180: The Three Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः |

मम योनिर्महद् ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम् |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

idaṃ jñānamupāśritya mama sādharmyamāgatāḥ .

mama yonirmahad brahma tasmingarbhaṃ dadhāmyaham .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna continued: Now I will reveal unto the Wisdom which is beyond knowledge, by attaining which the sages have reached Perfection.
Dwelling in Wisdom and realising My Divinity, they are not born again when the universe is re-created at the beginning of every cycle, nor are they affected when it is dissolved.
The eternal Cosmos is My womb, in which I plant the seed, from which all beings are born, O Prince!
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 13 and started discussing chapter 14. So in the last chapter we have very exhaustively discussed the relationship of the nature and the knower of the Nature, the Prakriti and Purusha, the field and its knower, that we have seen that both are Anadi, both are beginningless. But all these activities take place in Prakriti. The self remains inactive, it becomes a witness, but its very presence makes it possible. All the activities, this field and its Knower, when come together, then only a creation comes into place. If there is a field but there is no knower, or the knower but there is no field, both cannot exist because field of the Knower only exists because there is a field and the field only exists because the Knower is there.

So this superimposition of the field on its knower creates this world of plurality as we know it. But it never really explained to us why this plurality -- in other words, why this variety. We know that the Prakriti is beginningless. We know the Purusha is beginningless. There is no difference in Prakriti here or Prakriti there, no difference between over here and over there.

Then what is it that causes all this world of plurality, the variations and modifications that we see -- that I am different from you, and you are different from the next person? This chapter deals with that aspect. Prakriti is all-pervading and everywhere, and so is the Knower. But it is the qualities of this Prakriti that create this variety, as we know. So this chapter, the Yoga of Gunas, now talks about the nature of Prakriti. We have seen that there is no activity taking place in the Knower, the self. All the activities, all the Karmas, are the cause and the effect of Prakriti. The very nature of things and beings creates this activity and this variety.

So that will be discussed in this chapter. The chapter opens with Lord Krishna's declaration one more time. As he has done many times before, he says parambhuyaha pravakshami Gnananam Gnanamuttamam -- I'm going to tell you, I shall again declare to you the supreme knowledge, Gnananam Gnanamuttam, the best among all knowledge. What it really means is that we need to constantly keep repeating what is important, what is real and what is unreal. In the last chapter, in a very broad brush, we have seen that how we can disassociate ourselves as the knower from the field that included my body, mind and intellect. That was the paradigm shift for us, that this body, mind and intellect is part of the field. One who knows this body, mind and intellect is the knower of this field.

That knower is the self. That self is pervading equally among all the beings. However, it never explained -- if that's the case, if the knower is the same, pervading everywhere -- why there is a variety, why I am who I am and you are who you are. So this chapter says, if I know why I am who I am right now, if I have a guide to analyze my own self, I can introspect and say: what makes me who I am? At times I'm a nice person, at times I'm a very angry man.

And at times I'm not so nice. What makes me nice or not so nice at various times? If I can have a guide to use as a path to introspect myself, maybe I will have a better chance to understand myself as I exist as the jiva, as the individual ego -- and then can transcend that individual ego to identify with the self which is all-pervading in all of us. Therefore, this knowledge is the most important knowledge among all the knowledges, because it allows you to introspect your own self.

Yat gnatva munayha sarve param siddham ita gataha. Anytime you have to sell something to somebody, you have to make sure that there is proof.

You can't say that nobody has ever heard this before -- you are the first guinea pig I'm going to try this out on, and let's see if it works. This knowledge was used by many munis. Yat gnatva -- knowing this knowledge, they attain the param siddhim, the highest supreme achievement. The phrase "after going from here" is sometimes complex and can be misleading.

If you don't read between the lines, the first phrase is "ita gathaha" -- after going from here. So we might come to the conclusion that this knowledge will be only beneficial after I die, that while I'm here, it may not be possible for me to gain that knowledge. Then "yad ginatva munay ha" -- all the Munis who, knowing this, have achieved the supreme state. And we all know that we started out by asking, what is the supreme state?

We are looking for the supreme state where there is no limitation. For me, I am right now suffering from my limitations. I want to get out of these limitations so that I can have eternal bliss. So am I qualified for this? And this verse can be misguiding when it says "munihi sarve" -- so we think this knowledge is only for the Munis.

Our picture of a Muni is, as Swamiji says, a guy who is in his 70s and 80s, somewhere in the Himalayas with a white beard, surviving on just whatever he can gather. Nothing to do with the world. But Swamiji tried to explain to us that a Muni is one who is contemplating within his mind. One who is contemplating about the self in his own mind is a Muni. One who is a seeker of this knowledge is a Muni. As this knowledge becomes more and more clear to him -- yad gatva -- as this knowledge becomes clearer to him, he gets closer and closer to his goal.

Once this knowledge becomes his own, he achieves that final state where there are no limitations. Itaha kathaha -- after having gone from here. "Gone from here" means from this state of my understanding that this is me, that this body, mind and intellect is me, and the workings of my body and mind are my doings, and I am the enjoyer and sufferer. Once that understanding has changed -- that body, mind and intellect are part of the field, and I am just the observer who makes this body, mind, and intellect function.

So Itah kath -- going from this stage of identifying with the conditioned individualized ego, which we have seen in the field and its knower. The knower which identifies with the field becomes the individualized ego. The knower which identifies with my body, my mind, my intellect becomes me, the jiva. Once that identification is detached and I see myself as every other self, I become free from that. Itha gath -- the Munis have come to understand this.

The next verse says Idam gnanam upashitya mama sa Dharmyam Agathah. So we have two entities right now in our understanding.

One is me, who is eternally suffering -- because anytime I think I have achieved what I want, something else comes along that is higher than that. Something gets out of my control. I think I have control of all the situations, then suddenly something gets out of control. We figure out everything is going right.

And suddenly we hear that our son is not doing well. Somehow I make sure that side is taken care of. Then we figure out the economy has shifted. We try to manage things within our control, but constantly something is getting out of our control. Then we know that there is someone who has control over everything, one who never has to worry about anything.

He doesn't have to compete for jobs with anybody. He is the Lord of all these beings. This creates a complete division -- I and him are separate. But my goal is to constantly become him, because my goal is to become without any limitations, without any sorrows.

So I'm constantly trying to go from what I am to what he is. And Bhagavan says, Idam Gnanam Upashatya -- one who has taken refuge in this knowledge. The knowledge which he has not given us yet, but he's going to give it to us. He has given us a broad brush understanding of how things work. But how to get from here to there, we don't know yet.

But he says, idam Gnanam Upasatya mama sa Dharma Agathah. One who has taken refuge in the knowledge, they become one with me. Their dharmas have become what my dharmas are. My dharmas are limited. Right now his dharmas are unlimited. From this limitedness to unlimitedness, Bhagavan said, those munis who have understood this knowledge and became one with that knowledge have become one with me.

Sadharamyam Agatha API na upa jayante Pralayena Vihanticha. This is a broad statement for somebody like us who is worried about the next paycheck. It says that they do not take birth even at the time of creation. We are saying, look, forget about the creation and Pralaya -- I am worried about what's happening tomorrow. But he says, there's such a person Sargiya Pina upa Jayante Pralay na Vyatanti character.

And he doesn't get destroyed at the time of Pralaya. Because we are also pretty long term planners. So we say, okay, I mean I do all of that. But then again I'll take a birth and I'll go back to the same thing all over again. I'll realize that I'm that unlimited being. But then I'll take a birth again and then I'll start from scratch all over again.

Bhagavan said, no -- once you have realized who you are, there is no birth or death for you. Then you might ask, if everybody realizes this, obviously there is no creation and there is no Pralaya, so why are we going through all of this? He says, this is self-knowledge. This is for you to get out of the misery which you are going through. You are not worried about what the others are doing.

We are not taking over his job of creating and destroying. I am only concerned about me. If the job market is bad and we have 10 of our friends who are out of a job, including yourself, who are you most worried about getting a job for? Yourself, right? Good luck to all of you, but once I get a job, I'm alright. Others may be doing whatever they are doing. Bhagavan may have whatever goal he has in this cycle of creation and dissolution.

I need to get out of this misery. The one who has understood this will never have to take birth again or die again.

Swamiji explains this in a logical, philosophical manner. He says the world keeps on going the way it is, but I understand that this Prakriti is an illusion.

The creation is a trick of my mind. If there is a lump of clay or Play-Doh, I make the shape myself and assign value to it -- that it is a doll, or it's an elephant, or whatever it is. Nothing has changed in the clay itself. But my mind has now assigned a value that it's a creation created by me and I have given a name and form to it. Now if I don't assign the name and form to it and keep seeing the clay as it is, there is no creation taking place.

Now when I take that clay elephant I made and destroy it back into a lump of clay, that elephant is destroyed. If I had taken credit for that creation and assigned a name and form to it, then yes, something was destroyed. But if I never assigned a name and form to it, it has remained what it was before -- a lump of clay. Prakriti remaining Prakriti, and Purusha remaining Purusha.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses reveal a profound truth: the same Supreme Knowledge (jnananam jnanam uttamam) that liberated the ancient sages is available to you right now. Krishna declares that those who truly understand this teaching attain "mama sadharmyam"—they become one with the Divine nature itself, beyond the cycle of creation and dissolution. Consider today: What would it mean to know yourself not as this body, mind, and intellect, but as the eternal witness? The teaching tells us that Prakriti (Nature) is the cosmic womb and Purusha (Spirit) is the seed-giving father—together they produce all beings. You are that union of the manifest and unmanifest.

Reflect on the clay and elephant analogy from the teaching: when you mold clay into an elephant shape, the clay never changes—only your perception assigns name and form. Similarly, the world of plurality you experience is your mind's creation upon the unchanging Brahman. Today, practice seeing past the "elephant" to the "clay"—look at the objects, people, and situations around you and ask: What is the unchanging substratum beneath all these changing forms? When you truly see that all variety arises from the same source, the fear of birth and death naturally dissolves. What "names and forms" are you most attached to? Can you begin to see the one consciousness that animates all?

snippets.title: Day 181: Bondage of Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः |

सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसम्भवाः |

तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम् |
snippets.transliteration:
sarvayoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ .

sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisambhavāḥ .

tatra sattvaṃ nirmalatvātprakāśakamanāmayam .
verseTranslations: O illustrious son of Kunti! Through whatever wombs men are born, it is the Spirit Itself that conceives, and I am their Father.
Purity, Passion and Ignorance are the Qualities which the Law of nature bringeth forth. They fetter the free Spirit in all beings.
O Sinless One! Of these, Purity, being luminous, strong and invulnerable, binds one by its yearning for happiness and illumination.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 13 and started discussing chapter 14. So in the last chapter we have very exhaustively discussed the relationship of the nature and the knower of the Nature, the Prakriti and Purusha, the field and its knower, that we have seen that both are Anadi, both are beginningless. But all these activities take place in Prakriti. The self remains inactive, it becomes a witness, but its very presence makes it possible. All the activities, this field and its Knower, when come together, then only a creation comes into place. If there is a field but there is no knower, or the knower but there is no field, both cannot exist because field of the Knower only exists because there is a field and the field only exists because the Knower is there.

So this superimposition of the field on its knower creates this world of plurality as we know it. But it never really explained to us why this plurality -- in other words, why this variety. We know that the Prakriti is beginningless. We know the Purusha is beginningless. There is no difference in Prakriti here or Prakriti there, no difference between over here and over there.

Then what is it that causes all this world of plurality, the variations and modifications that we see -- that I am different from you, and you are different from the next person? This chapter deals with that aspect. Prakriti is all-pervading and everywhere, and so is the Knower. But it is the qualities of this Prakriti that create this variety, as we know. So this chapter, the Yoga of Gunas, now talks about the nature of Prakriti. We have seen that there is no activity taking place in the Knower, the self. All the activities, all the Karmas, are the cause and the effect of Prakriti. The very nature of things and beings creates this activity and this variety.

So that will be discussed in this chapter. The chapter opens with Lord Krishna's declaration one more time. As he has done many times before, he says parambhuyaha pravakshami Gnananam Gnanamuttamam -- I'm going to tell you, I shall again declare to you the supreme knowledge, Gnananam Gnanamuttam, the best among all knowledge. What it really means is that we need to constantly keep repeating what is important, what is real and what is unreal. In the last chapter, in a very broad brush, we have seen that how we can disassociate ourselves as the knower from the field that included my body, mind and intellect. That was the paradigm shift for us, that this body, mind and intellect is part of the field. One who knows this body, mind and intellect is the knower of this field.

That knower is the self. That self is pervading equally among all the beings. However, it never explained -- if that's the case, if the knower is the same, pervading everywhere -- why there is a variety, why I am who I am and you are who you are. So this chapter says, if I know why I am who I am right now, if I have a guide to analyze my own self, I can introspect and say: what makes me who I am? At times I'm a nice person, at times I'm a very angry man.

And at times I'm not so nice. What makes me nice or not so nice at various times? If I can have a guide to use as a path to introspect myself, maybe I will have a better chance to understand myself as I exist as the jiva, as the individual ego -- and then can transcend that individual ego to identify with the self which is all-pervading in all of us. Therefore, this knowledge is the most important knowledge among all the knowledges, because it allows you to introspect your own self.

Yat gnatva munayha sarve param siddham ita gataha. Anytime you have to sell something to somebody, you have to make sure that there is proof.

You can't say that nobody has ever heard this before -- you are the first guinea pig I'm going to try this out on, and let's see if it works. This knowledge was used by many munis. Yat gnatva -- knowing this knowledge, they attain the param siddhim, the highest supreme achievement. The phrase "after going from here" is sometimes complex and can be misleading.

If you don't read between the lines, the first phrase is "ita gathaha" -- after going from here. So we might come to the conclusion that this knowledge will be only beneficial after I die, that while I'm here, it may not be possible for me to gain that knowledge. Then "yad ginatva munay ha" -- all the Munis who, knowing this, have achieved the supreme state. And we all know that we started out by asking, what is the supreme state?

We are looking for the supreme state where there is no limitation. For me, I am right now suffering from my limitations. I want to get out of these limitations so that I can have eternal bliss. So am I qualified for this? And this verse can be misguiding when it says "munihi sarve" -- so we think this knowledge is only for the Munis.

Our picture of a Muni is, as Swamiji says, a guy who is in his 70s and 80s, somewhere in the Himalayas with a white beard, surviving on just whatever he can gather. Nothing to do with the world. But Swamiji tried to explain to us that a Muni is one who is contemplating within his mind. One who is contemplating about the self in his own mind is a Muni. One who is a seeker of this knowledge is a Muni. As this knowledge becomes more and more clear to him -- yad gatva -- as this knowledge becomes clearer to him, he gets closer and closer to his goal.

Once this knowledge becomes his own, he achieves that final state where there are no limitations. Itaha kathaha -- after having gone from here. "Gone from here" means from this state of my understanding that this is me, that this body, mind and intellect is me, and the workings of my body and mind are my doings, and I am the enjoyer and sufferer. Once that understanding has changed -- that body, mind and intellect are part of the field, and I am just the observer who makes this body, mind, and intellect function.

So Itah kath -- going from this stage of identifying with the conditioned individualized ego, which we have seen in the field and its knower. The knower which identifies with the field becomes the individualized ego. The knower which identifies with my body, my mind, my intellect becomes me, the jiva. Once that identification is detached and I see myself as every other self, I become free from that. Itha gath -- the Munis have come to understand this.

The next verse says Idam gnanam upashitya mama sa Dharmyam Agathah. So we have two entities right now in our understanding.

One is me, who is eternally suffering -- because anytime I think I have achieved what I want, something else comes along that is higher than that. Something gets out of my control. I think I have control of all the situations, then suddenly something gets out of control. We figure out everything is going right.

And suddenly we hear that our son is not doing well. Somehow I make sure that side is taken care of. Then we figure out the economy has shifted. We try to manage things within our control, but constantly something is getting out of our control. Then we know that there is someone who has control over everything, one who never has to worry about anything.

He doesn't have to compete for jobs with anybody. He is the Lord of all these beings. This creates a complete division -- I and him are separate. But my goal is to constantly become him, because my goal is to become without any limitations, without any sorrows.

So I'm constantly trying to go from what I am to what he is. And Bhagavan says, Idam Gnanam Upashatya -- one who has taken refuge in this knowledge. The knowledge which he has not given us yet, but he's going to give it to us. He has given us a broad brush understanding of how things work. But how to get from here to there, we don't know yet.

But he says, idam Gnanam Upasatya mama sa Dharma Agathah. One who has taken refuge in the knowledge, they become one with me. Their dharmas have become what my dharmas are. My dharmas are limited. Right now his dharmas are unlimited. From this limitedness to unlimitedness, Bhagavan said, those munis who have understood this knowledge and became one with that knowledge have become one with me.

Sadharamyam Agatha API na upa jayante Pralayena Vihanticha. This is a broad statement for somebody like us who is worried about the next paycheck. It says that they do not take birth even at the time of creation. We are saying, look, forget about the creation and Pralaya -- I am worried about what's happening tomorrow. But he says, there's such a person Sargiya Pina upa Jayante Pralay na Vyatanti character.

And he doesn't get destroyed at the time of Pralaya. Because we are also pretty long term planners. So we say, okay, I mean I do all of that. But then again I'll take a birth and I'll go back to the same thing all over again. I'll realize that I'm that unlimited being. But then I'll take a birth again and then I'll start from scratch all over again.

Bhagavan said, no -- once you have realized who you are, there is no birth or death for you. Then you might ask, if everybody realizes this, obviously there is no creation and there is no Pralaya, so why are we going through all of this? He says, this is self-knowledge. This is for you to get out of the misery which you are going through. You are not worried about what the others are doing.

We are not taking over his job of creating and destroying. I am only concerned about me. If the job market is bad and we have 10 of our friends who are out of a job, including yourself, who are you most worried about getting a job for? Yourself, right? Good luck to all of you, but once I get a job, I'm alright. Others may be doing whatever they are doing. Bhagavan may have whatever goal he has in this cycle of creation and dissolution.

I need to get out of this misery. The one who has understood this will never have to take birth again or die again.

Swamiji explains this in a logical, philosophical manner. He says the world keeps on going the way it is, but I understand that this Prakriti is an illusion.

The creation is a trick of my mind. If there is a lump of clay or Play-Doh, I make the shape myself and assign value to it -- that it is a doll, or it's an elephant, or whatever it is. Nothing has changed in the clay itself. But my mind has now assigned a value that it's a creation created by me and I have given a name and form to it. Now if I don't assign the name and form to it and keep seeing the clay as it is, there is no creation taking place.

Now when I take that clay elephant I made and destroy it back into a lump of clay, that elephant is destroyed. If I had taken credit for that creation and assigned a name and form to it, then yes, something was destroyed. But if I never assigned a name and form to it, it has remained what it was before -- a lump of clay. Prakriti remaining Prakriti, and Purusha remaining Purusha.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce the three gunas—Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas—as the fundamental qualities that bind the imperishable Self to the perishable body. Krishna states clearly: "nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinam avyayam"—these gunas fetter the free Spirit in all beings. Yet here is the subtle trap revealed in verse 6: even Sattva, the most luminous and pure quality, creates bondage through "sukhasangena" (attachment to happiness) and "jnanasangena" (attachment to knowledge). Notice today how your pursuit of clarity, health, and understanding—all sattvic qualities—can themselves become chains. Do you cling to your "good" states? Do you feel superior when you are clear-headed and peaceful?

The teaching reveals that you are the Divine Father's seed planted in Nature's womb—"aham bijapradah pita." Every being, regardless of their apparent form or station, shares this sacred origin. Today, look at every person you encounter and recognize them as your sibling, born of the same cosmic parents. More practically, use these verses as a diagnostic tool: When you feel light, clear, and healthy, recognize Sattva at work. But ask yourself—am I attached to this pleasant state? The goal is not to maximize Sattva but to recognize the witness who observes all three gunas without being bound by any. What would it feel like to appreciate happiness without grasping it?

snippets.title: Day 182: Rising Above
snippets.sanskrit:
रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम् |

तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम् |

सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत |
snippets.transliteration:
rajo rāgātmakaṃ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam .

tamastvajñānajaṃ viddhi mohanaṃ sarvadehinām .

sattvaṃ sukhe sañjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata .
verseTranslations: Passion, engendered by thirst for pleasure and attachment, binds the soul through its fondness for activity.
But Ignorance, the product of darkness, stupefies the senses in all embodied beings, binding them by chains of folly, indolence and lethargy.
Purity brings happiness, Passion commotion, and Ignorance, which obscures wisdom, leads to a life of failure.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga, the Yoga of Trigunas. We had just completed the Kshetrakshatragna Vibhaga, the differentiation between the field and its knower. We have seen that this world of ours is made up of two things. One is the field and its knower. In my case, I the knower of my world. And then we have also seen at the macro level, it's a Purusha and Prakriti, two entities which makes this manifest world apparent to me.

Prakriti is the nature, the manifest world, and Purusha is the unmanifestation which is making this Prakriti animated. So this understanding of Purusha and Prakriti -- now we can use it to our advantage. As Bhagawan says, we can only understand it if we know the nature of this Prakriti. Prakriti, even in our vernacular language, refers to anybody's inherent qualities and nature -- that's his Prakriti. Also in Gujarati they say -- I'm sure it's in other languages too.

Pranayani, Prakruti, Sathya Jay, that this breath and my quality, they go together, they remain embedded in me. So knowing this Prakriti can certainly be a big help in my spiritual quest of knowing myself. So this chapter talks about Gunatraya, the three Gunas of the Prakriti. Prakriti is me as this body, mind and intellect. This world as I see it is all-pervading, just as the nature of Brahman is. And as we have said, both the Purusha and Prakriti are beginningless because both are the nature of Brahman, which is beginningless.

Something which is beginningless in whatever format it is presented remains beginningless. Therefore, Prakriti is beginningless. Purusha is beginningless. In my quest of understanding myself, myself is beginningless. Where did I create this misunderstanding that I'm limited and I'm going through these ups and downs in my life? I'm Going through these sorrows and happiness, the spurts of little happiness and then long period of pursuit of happiness.

Bhagavan said that understanding this nature of this Prakriti will be helpful. Bhagawan said, I am the Mahat Yoni Brahman. I, the Brahman in the form of a Prakriti is the womb of all the beings. No being or thing can come into existence unless the Purusha and Prakriti come together. So see, anywhere you see a thing or being coming into existence, consider that as the union of the Purusha and Prakarati, that unmanifest and manifest coming together creates a new creation. Wherever there is a birth taking place, consider that it is coming from my womb, the universal womb.

And then you say, I am the Sid giver, Father. Prakriti is the womb and Purusha is the father. Therefore, in our all vernacular language is Mother Nature, Mother Earth. And Bhagavan is Pita. Bhagavan is my father. Prakriti is my mother, comes directly from this verse from Bhagavad Gita.

So this nature, Mother Nature, when it comes to me, creates this body, mind and intellect. When I was born, what I was born with is this body, which continues to grow and decay. I was born with this mind and intellect, which at the rudimentary level grew into who I think I am today. If I know the nature of this Prakriti, it will help me understand who I am. So the next three verses tell us the nature of Prakriti. Swattam Rajah, Tama, iti, Gunaha, Prakriti, Sambhavah.

The three Gunas which we see in this world, in almost everything that we can observe, are Sattva, rajas and Tamas. They are born out of Prakriti. This manifest world becomes manifest because of these Gunas. Take these three gunas away and there is no world -- only the unmanifest remains. So what is the first? Sattva -- purity, awareness, knowledge, luminosity.

A thing comes into existence for me when I become aware of it. We went on a cruise about two years ago and realized at the last minute that we needed some cash. So I went to the ATM, but it was Sunday and my car just wouldn't work. So I finally called my client in Baltimore -- Mike, can you have $300 in cash for me? I'll give you a check when I come there. So anyway, he had three crisp $100 notes ready for me in an envelope. I went there, collected it, gave him a check and went on the cruise. We never used that money. It was sealed in that envelope when we came back, and we forgot all about it. Those $300 never existed for us for all this time.

Because we had forgotten about it. Then one day we opened it -- $300 in it. We are suddenly $300 richer. They did not exist for us until then. Then one day Mina said, I gave you that $200. What did you do with it?

Well I said I have it. I'll give it back to you if you want. That money came into existence when I became aware of it, when Mina became aware of it. Till that time it did not exist. Sattvam -- unless you are aware of this world, the world does not come into existence for you.

So it is for her, for him, and everybody else. When we all become unaware of this world, it ceases to exist for us. So Sattva is the first quality of Prakriti. In this nature, we are aware of each other and therefore we exist for each other. Next is Rajas and third is Tamas. We have heard it many, many times before.

But he said they are Prakriti Sambhavah. These gunas are born out of Prakriti. My Prakriti is that I become aware of my world. This experience of this world creates passion and desires in me. Passion creates desire, desire creates actions, actions create reactions. And my world continues with cause and effect.

Somebody comes and says you should be investing money right now because the market is down. Then suddenly my desire to make money kicks in -- Neel, you need to do something! And I start doing things. That creates another chain reaction when the market drops. So Rajas is the activity which is the nature of cause and effect. My interaction with this Prakriti, because of my passion, creates activity.
