This activity creates the experience of joys and sorrows. I pat my back and say I'm so smart -- when everybody was thinking this way, I was doing that. Then when things go bad, I say, well, people really cheated me, they should have told me. And then Tamas -- inertia. If we don't have inertia, we don't even exist.

For something to exist in time and space, it has to have inertia. It has to remain in that condition in time and space for others to experience it. I am real because I have inertia -- I remain in that state in time and space for others to experience me. So the inertia is the essential part of Prakriti. Tamas is the very essential quality of Prakriti.

Just as Sattva and rajas. If you take one of the three out, Prakriti does not exist. Sattva cannot exist if there is no rajas and Tamas. There is nothing to be aware of. Rajas cannot exist if there is no inertia. But because there is inertia, Tamas, all three continue to work with each other.

So this Tamas is the nature of inertia, which at my level I relate to as my sleep, deep sleep. When I really don't want to do anything, somebody says, oh, let's go and have a party. Forget about it, I'm not in the mood today -- I'm overwhelmed by Tamas. If I'm very sleepy and you tell me to do something, forget about it. Right now all I want to do is sleep.

That means I am overwhelmed by Tamas, and all I want to do is go back to my basic nature. Iti Gunaha Prakruti Sambhavaha -- they are part of Prakriti. They are the nature of Prakriti, embedded into it. Swamiji says they are not like qualities of a material where you can say, if I test in the lab I will find Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas. They are actually the moods of my mind when I interact with this Prakriti.

So sometimes my mind is overwhelmed by Sattva. Things start getting clearer to me. I tried very hard yesterday, couldn't figure it out. This morning it suddenly came to me -- an aha moment, a Eureka moment. That is predominant Sattva. Then Rajas -- now I've figured out, I need to do something. And Tamas -- this is enough.

I need to go to sleep. There is always a time -- no matter how dynamic a person is, he has to take rest. Ithiguna Prakritisam Nibadnanti Mahabhaho Dehe Dehi nam Avyayaam -- this imperishable self, the Purusha, the Brahman which is imperishable, is now bound by this perishable body through these three gunas. The Purusha comes in contact with the Prakriti and gets attached to it. So this dehi in me, my consciousness which is of all-pervading, imperishable nature -- once it attaches to this body, mind and intellect and enjoys the gunas, it gets bound.

So now I consider this is me, the body; this is me, the intellect. This is only possible because the consciousness tells me that's who I am. This imperishable one is now bound in this body by these three gunas. Tatra satvam nirmalatva Prakasakam anamayam Sukha sangena badnati gnana sangena cha anagaha -- my mind, under the influence of these three gunas, binds me to this body, this mind, and this intellect.

So what is the nature of it? Now I want to unbound myself so that I can realize my imperishable self. That's the quest we have. So that I will have infinite happiness, unlimited happiness which I'm seeking. So I have to unbound myself. So I have to see what is binding me and how.

So the first is Sattva. Tatra Sattva nirmalatva Prakashakam annamayam. The nature of Sattva is prakashakam -- suddenly things become clearer to me. Before I walk into this room at night, it's dark. Nothing is clear about what's in the room. Suddenly I switch the light on.

Everything becomes completely clear because it is luminous. That's the nature of Sattva in my chitta, in my mind. When Sattva prevails, things start getting clearer to me. So it's the nature of luminosity. And annamayam -- eat some sattvic food. You tell Panditji this: the pure ghee, you know, cholesterol and all -- that's good for you, that's Sattva.

So purity is of the nature of health. When I am completely in tune with myself, I feel healthy and I feel aware. Everything seems nice, which is the experience of happiness and joy. That's what binds me to this Prakriti.

When I feel I am in command and I understand things, I am enjoying this knowledge. When I learn something, it binds me to knowledge and the happiness of getting knowledge. Sukha sangena badnati -- it binds me to happiness. Gnana sangena cha anagaha.

Sattva binds me to knowledge and happiness. It's still a bondage. No matter how golden the chain is, it's still a bondage. Therefore, many other saints have argued about this. The Vedantin says this, and we say harina janato Muktina magya. Whoever among the Gujarati fellows can understand -- he says God's people do not want this liberation.

They want birth after birth. So that I enjoy your bhakti. Because if I'm not there, how can I enjoy your bhakti? Therefore Harina Jina Muktina Mangi Mangi Jana Vi Janavata. I want birth after birth so that I can devote myself to you. Bondage to this Sattva?

This experience of my devotion to my Lord is giving me happiness and ecstasy. I don't want to give it up. Just keep me in this state. Don't take me to the next one. Otherwise I will lose this ecstasy. This is bondage to Sattva, even for a man of dynamic personality who worked 18 hours a day.
snippets.reflection:
These verses expose the mechanics of Rajas and Tamas with surgical precision. Rajas is "ragātmakam"—born of passionate attachment—and binds through "trishna" (thirst) and "karma-sangena" (attachment to action). How often do you feel compelled to act, to achieve, to acquire? That restless drive is Rajas at work. Tamas, born of ignorance, binds through "pramada" (heedlessness), "alasya" (laziness), and "nidra" (sleep). Verse 9 summarizes beautifully: Sattva attaches you to happiness, Rajas to action, and Tamas—by covering knowledge—attaches you to heedlessness. Today, trace your actions back to their source: Are you acting from clarity, compulsion, or avoidance?

The teaching uses the example of forgotten money—$300 sealed in an envelope that "did not exist" until awareness revealed it. This illustrates Sattva's essential nature: things come into existence for you only when you become aware of them. Similarly, the whole world exists for you only through your awareness. But notice also the Rajasic trap described: setting a goal of $100,000, achieving it, yet still remaining unsatisfied, always chasing the next thing. Today, examine one goal you are pursuing: Is it Sattva seeking knowledge, Rajas seeking endless activity, or Tamas seeking escape? Can you find the witness who observes all three without being pulled by any? Remember—even the bliss of devotion (as the teaching notes about those who seek "birth after birth" to enjoy bhakti) is a form of bondage.

snippets.title: Day 183: Beyond the Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत |

सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते |

लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा |
snippets.transliteration:
rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata .

sarvadvāreṣu dehe.asminprakāśa upajāyate .

lobhaḥ pravṛttirārambhaḥ karmaṇāmaśamaḥ spṛhā .
verseTranslations: O Prince! Purity prevails when Passion and Ignorance are overcome; Passion, when Purity and Ignorance are overcome; and Ignorance when it overcomes Purity and Passion.
When the light of knowledge gleams forth from all the gates of the body, then be sure that Purity prevails.
O best of Indians! Avarice, the impulse to act and the beginning of action itself are all due to the dominance of Passion.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga. So we have seen so far that these three gunas are born out of Prakriti. They are actually the nature of Prakriti. The nature gets it from Maya, as Vedanta says. Then Bhagavan Sankaratabodha says three Gunatmika Maya. This Maya has three gunas.

That which is not but appears to be -- that is Maya. So this Maya, which creates the illusion that this world is real, does so through these three qualities which bind our mind. How do we see a hologram? The question is, is the hologram real? A hologram has its own reality. However, it is not what it appears to be.

If I see a hologram of a woman, hologram is real, but the woman is not. So from that perspective, is this Prakriti real? Prakriti is very real, but it is not what it appears to be. We have all learnt in physics by this time that the atom which appears to be solid and no real solid matter in it whatsoever, but it is very real from my perspective because it is a relative reality. So Bhagavan says in this chapter that all the beings which are born in this world are basically are born from the womb of Mother Nature, Prakriti. And I, this consciousness, I, the self, supreme self, Purusha is, is the seed giving father.

The entire Prakriti and entire creation that we know is born of the same entity, the self. The Purusha is the father and the Prakriti. The nature as we know is the mother. This Prakriti has three gunas which bind the Purusha into the Prakriti. This union between the Prakriti and Purusha happens because of the three gunas in the Prakriti. And when that occurs, a being is born.

An ego is conditioned. Consciousness is conditioned, as we have seen in this analogy, a room space. When a building is built, it binds this space into it and the association creates a room Space. The same way Bhagavan said Purusha came in contact with Prakriti, a conditioned ego is born. Three gunas we have seen is Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Classic classification we heard over and over again.

Sattva is the nature of purity, light, knowledge, illumination, Rajas activity, passion, attachment and Tamas, ignorance, inertia. And then we have seen how each one binds this consciousness, which is pure and pristine in its nature. Once it comes in association with the Prakriti, it binds itself to the Prakriti and creates a new conditioned being. So verses 9, 10 and 11 give us this relationship. Sattva binds you to happiness. This embodied one, this consciousness which feels embodied in myself, is bound by the nature of this field. We have seen this field -- Idam sariram Kshetram ITI abhidhya.

This body is the field. This field, with its three qualities, binds the consciousness in me. Sattva binds through happiness -- something happens, I figure it out, I come to know, I enjoy that experience. Rajas binds through activity -- the passion, the attachment creates desires, creates activity. And the more I do, the more I achieve, the more I get bound. More and more I do, as I'll give an example.

When I left India, I had one very clear goal: if I make a hundred thousand rupees, I'll go back to India and start practicing architecture there. In Ahmedabad, I made a hundred thousand rupees long, long, long ago. I'm still outside India. Rajas binds you to activity -- the more we do, the more I want to do. And then Tamas -- ignorance, inertia. All three are absolutely necessary for this Prakriti to exist.

Just as whatever ingredients bind the hologram into a form which I perceive must be there, so the next three verses summarize what we have already seen. Sattva sukhe Sanjayati Rajah Karmani Bharata Gnanam avrutya tu tamah pramade sanjayatu. Sattva binds to happiness and pleasure. Rajas binds to actions. And this knowledge about the self -- the very fact that I call myself "I," but I'm not aware of what that is, I can't define it. As we have seen in this example: everything I use to define myself turns out to be something related to myself, but not me. My name, my relationship, my profession, my achievements, my losses -- whatever that is, it's not me. What is it that does not let me figure out who I am?

Tamas. Gnanam Avritya tu Tamah Pramade Sanjayati -- by pramad, heedlessness. My own self tells me who I am, but this pramada, this heedlessness, says no, it cannot be. Swamiji used to say, I come here every year. Because when Swamiji was alive, he used to come every year to the United States for Yagna. Some of us were standard devotees -- we were always there.

He said, I'm glad that you guys are not listening to me. I come here, give you my knowledge, and on the last day I gather it and go back. That way you keep me in business -- because otherwise, once you understood, you'd have no need for me. This Tamas -- even though we hear, even though we understand, even though our conscience tells us this should be right, we say, "But I don't think so, because not everybody else is doing it."

So we get deluded by that -- Tamas, Pramade Sanjayati. So here is how he says that pure consciousness is bound into the Prakriti. Now, further analysis of how these three gunas work. These three gunas are inherent in all of Prakriti. Tamas is not a negative quality of Prakriti -- it is the very essential nature of Prakriti.

For an atom to remain in solid state, for me to recognize the atom, atom has to have certain inertia in it for me to see it as an atom. If I can start seeing it as electron and proton and neutron, the world will disappear because there is no solid matter around. So the inertia, the Tamas is the essential quality of Prakriti. So is the rajas and so is the Sattva. Because we have tendency to classify with the higher, lower and middle. So we say, well, this is higher, this is lower.

For Prakriti there is nothing like higher or lower. But what really matters is the right balance. How does one particular quality of this Maya bind me? Rajas Tamah Abhi Bhuyam Satvam Bhavati Bharata. One guna may be predominant at any given time, and the other two will be subsidiary. How we recognize a thing or being depends on what the predominant quality is.

For example, yesterday Sanchan -- normally he's a very nice guy, but I don't know what happened to him yesterday. In other words, normally he has this predominance of being nice, but once in a while the not-being-nice predominates. Any guna can obviously have predominance over the others. When Sattva predominates over Rajas and Tamas, then the experience of Sattva happens. Right now, if I want to understand something, I focus on it, I close all my activity down.

Then the knowledge takes place, and we say Sattva is predominating -- everything is now clear to me. Raja satvam tamasteva tamah sattvam rajasthadha. Each one, when it predominates the others, makes that quality more apparent. We may have any dish, and if there is more salt, we'll say it's a salty dish. There may be a little sugar in it and all other things.

But whatever is predominating, we call it that -- it's salty, it's sweet. Even a sweet dish has lots of other ingredients and other tastes in it. At times Sattva predominates, at times Rajas, and at times Tamas -- in all beings, at least in human beings. Our mind, associating with the Prakriti, picks up whatever qualities attach most, and that's what defines our experience. All of us go to downtown Richmond and we come back and describe it.

All of us will have different description. Somebody like me will say, you know, the buildings are like this. Each one will come back with a different impression. Because it is my mind associating with it, my mind experiencing this world of objects. Whatever the qualities I pick up is what my mind predominates. There are times when I'll be dominated with Sattva.

There are times rajas, there are times tamas. But the other two at that time are existing in a subsidiary role. And the next verses tell us what happens -- and when I should recognize that I am under the influence of Sattva. Sarva dwareshu dehe asmin prakash upajayate -- if there's a light coming out of all the gates of my body. The navadvare puree dehi -- the body has nine gates. Basically we're talking about sense perception, the gnanendriya, the five senses of perception.

Out of all these five gnanindriya, when there is a light of knowledge emitting, then I should know that gnanam yada tada vidya vibruddham satvam ITI uta. I'm seeing clearly, I'm hearing clearly, I'm tasting the right things -- when I'm having the experience of knowledge, the experience of light, then it is indeed the experience of Sattva. It may be known that Sattva is predominant. There are times we are very clear about everything -- there is no confusion in our mind, no strong passion or desire to act, but simply to know. This is fairly logical, and we all have experienced that.

Somebody says, Neel, I waved at you so many times when I was passing by, but you didn't acknowledge me. Oh, I didn't see you. My eye was not having any experience of knowledge -- in other words, the mind wasn't there, and there was no way to acknowledge what I was seeing. All spouses know this. Meena will get mad and say, I don't like the insult.

She says, I've been telling you for the last two minutes and you're not paying attention. No, no, I was paying attention, but I was doing something. It happens to me almost three or four times a week. Because my mind is somewhere else, she's continually telling me what happened, and then after about two minutes she realizes, I don't think he listens to anything that I say. No knowledge is taking place.

So that's not Sattva. That's obviously my passion for something taking my mind away. And it is so important for my mind to be there in everything. Once in a while I miss the verses which I chant, because within that fraction of a second my mind goes someplace else while I'm chanting, and I'm desperately seeking which verse I was on. Each verse ends with Guru Venama -- was I on the second verse?

Was I on Guru Vai Namah, the third verse, or Guru Veh Namah? Because for a fraction of a second your mind lost it, lost the connection. If that happens, it's not Sattva which is chanting -- it is Rajas that predominated, because something took over. Lo Baha Pravruti Arambha -- now this is a very Indian concept, because it's difficult for any Westerner to understand Pravritti Arambha. The urge to start something, to initiate action -- that's not Sattva. Karmanam Asamaha Spriha Rajasya Jayante Vivruddhe Bharata -- these arise when Rajas is predominant.

If this is happening, remember -- Bhagavan said, I'm going to give you this knowledge which is so profound that, having known it, you will get rid of all your bondage and liberate yourself. Here is what he's telling us: how to diagnose yourself, what your situation is. Otherwise, my mind constantly tells me, "Neel is a very nice guy. He's a very Sattvic person." But he said, you have to do self-diagnosis, and you have to do it this way.

The first sign is that there is knowledge coming out of all the gates. It didn't say only one gate or the other -- all the gates.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal a crucial insight: the gunas are constantly competing for dominance. "Rajas tamash cha abhibhuya sattvam bhavati"—Sattva prevails only by overcoming Rajas and Tamas, and likewise each guna rises by suppressing the others. This is not a static battle but a dynamic interplay happening moment to moment in your mind. Verse 11 gives a powerful diagnostic: "sarvadvāreshu dehe asmin prakāśa upajāyate"—when light (knowledge) streams through ALL the gates of your body (the senses), then Sattva is predominant. Notice the emphasis on ALL gates—partial clarity is not true Sattva. When you are truly sattvic, your seeing, hearing, tasting, touching, and smelling all convey clear knowledge.

The teaching illustrates this with everyday examples: waving to someone who doesn't acknowledge you, speaking to a spouse who doesn't hear, losing track of which verse you're chanting. These lapses reveal that your mind has been pulled elsewhere—Rajas or Tamas has taken over. Verse 12 lists the symptoms of Rajas: "lobhah" (greed), "pravritti" (the urge to act), "ārambhah" (initiating actions), "aśamah" (restlessness), and "spriha" (desire). Today, conduct an honest self-diagnosis: When do ALL your senses convey clear knowledge? When do you find yourself compulsively starting new projects or feeling unable to rest? Remember—this is not about judging yourself but about developing viveka (discrimination). The one who can accurately diagnose which guna is predominant is already beginning to stand apart from all three.

snippets.title: Day 184: The Three Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च |

यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत् |

रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते |
snippets.transliteration:
aprakāśo.apravṛttiśca pramādo moha eva ca .

yadā sattve pravṛddhe tu pralayaṃ yāti dehabhṛt .

rajasi pralayaṃ gatvā karmasaṅgiṣu jāyate .
verseTranslations: Darkness, stagnation, folly and infatuation are the result of the dominance of Ignorance, O joy of the Kuru-clan!
When Purity prevails, the soul on quitting the body passes on to the pure regions where live those who know the Highest.
When Passion prevails, the soul is reborn among those who love activity; when Ignorance rules, it enters the wombs of the ignorant.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of the three gunas. We have concluded that these are the qualities of Prakriti. These three gunas make the Prakriti what it is. These three gunas come from Maya. Ishwara, in control of Maya, creates Prakriti through Maya. That which is not then appears to be there.

This world of plurality appears to be there. In reality, there is only singularity exist. This Maya creates this Prakriti by three gunas, the Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. So everything in this Prakriti has these three gunas. If you take the basic building block of our universe as the atom, the atom obviously has inertia. It has activity, and it has some awareness.

From my perspective, the atom remains in its space and time because of inertia. If the atom doesn't remain in space and time, there's nothing you can do about it. We also know that even though it looks inactive, it has extreme activity inside -- the electron swirling around the neutron or proton within the nucleus. So there is Rajas, and there is Tamas, which is inertia. Tamas keeps the atom in its shape and its existence in space and time. The atom also knows what to do when another atom comes in contact with it, which creates this Prakriti.

So right from the basic building block to ourselves, these three gunas are existent. We obviously are not really concerned about the Prakruti as the universe right now. We are concerned about the Gunas which are manifesting in my internal instrument. Because the goal of my spiritual quest, as we all learned over and over and over again, is cleansing my internal instrument, which is the mind and intellect. This mind and intellect, when in action, will obviously manifest one guna or another as more predominant.

My mind and intellect is nothing but the impressions of my experiences and the transactions in this world. This experience, living its impression, will either make my thoughts more Satwik, more Rajasic, or more Tamasic. Under the sway of these experiences with the world outside, my internal instrument is constantly transforming from one predominance to another. And that's where we have seen why we should be aware of these gunas. Once I understand how my mind comes under the sway of these gunas, I may be able to train my mind in a manner that will be more beneficial in my spiritual evolution -- in my journey from this limited being to the unlimited being.

And therefore we are also concerned that this life is not long enough.

I'm trying to attain something but my body doesn't give cooperation and it falls apart prematurely when I have not achieved my goal. The verses we have been seeing say this is a continuity. This life is nothing but one link in a chain -- the continuity of links which is your existence. And as this limited being, my existence is more at the subtle instrument level than at the external instrument level. This external instrument will die and perish when it has run its course. The internal instrument will continue.

It has gathered experience from the past lives, gathering experience in this life and will continue into the next. So the question is, what happens when I leave this body? The last three verses deal with that. And as Swamiji says, Hinduism is the only faith that very systematically deals with the afterlife -- whereas most other faiths and most other schools of thought in this world do accept that there is a life after this life. So the verses you have seen address: what happens?

What will be my destination when I leave this station of life? The first verse says, what happens if my mind is in a sattvic mood? Yada sattve pravruddhe tu pralayam yati deha bhrit -- uttama vidam lokan amalan pratipadyate. If my mind is in a sattvic mood of predominance at the time of my leaving, I will reach the world of the highest. I will go to an environment which will aid my journey from this limited being, the Jiva, to the higher being.

So what happens at the time of my death? I may be comatose, I may be in pain, so my mind cannot consciously think about anything.

But remember what happens when you go to deep sleep. Last night when you went to sleep -- you're not necessarily in the same mood every night, nor even aware of when you went to sleep. But the next morning when you wake up, you're basically the same person who went to sleep the night before. As Swamiji explains, an architect going to sleep is not going to wake up as a surgeon the next morning just because the night before he was watching ER. He's going to wake up as an architect, because all his life he has accumulated the experiences of an architect. His mind has predominantly become an architectural mind.

So when I wake up the next morning, no matter what show I saw on TV last night, my mind will start where I left off. It may be that at the time of death I am not aware. But the subtle tendencies which my mind has gathered will take me to that world. We don't remember experiences -- even something about what I did in my childhood.

I don't remember what happened in my youth -- a few things here and there we remember. But the tendencies we gathered made me who I am today. My across-the-street neighbor used to take me to Gita class. I really had no interest whatsoever, but because I couldn't say no, I went with her.

That Gita class led me to Gita class today. So the tendencies we gather -- we may not remember anything about them, but the experience of gathering those tendencies creates the sattvic mood or rajasic mood or tamasic mode, and we carry on. So it says one who dies with a sattvic predominance of mind will go to the world of the highest. The Puranas say it is Brahmaloka -- a place of abundant happiness, very little sorrow or no sorrow, and abundance of creativity. The world of creativity.

Somebody who revels in creativity and gets joy out of that creativity. The next verse says Rajasi pralayam gatva Karma sangi su jayate. If all my life experience was rajasic -- in business and whatever else -- obviously when I die, my mind is still in that mode. I'm not carrying any memories of the experiences, but I'm carrying the tendency of those experiences with me. Maybe the last 15 days of my life I'm completely comatose.

But that just the connection with the body is disconnected. Mind in its own remain in its own health. And when it leaves, it carries those tendencies with it. So what I'm going to do is look for an environment where I can exhaust my vasanas -- my tendencies for being active. So I may be born in a businessman's house. Karma sanghi su Jayate.

Such a person gets an environment, a world of action, where he can exhaust his vasanas for actions. The Lord is very compassionate. The Lord of this universe, my own Lord, is very compassionate -- He only gives me what I want. If I want knowledge and creativity and awareness about myself, He will give me that. If I want actions, He will give me that too -- He will give me an opportunity to exhaust my vasanas. Tatha pralinas tamasi mudha yonishu jayate.

But if for some reason all my experience of life has been Tamas, then I'll go to the mudha yoni. And Swamiji basically explained that mudha yoni is one which is not aware of anything -- the animal kingdom and plant kingdom. Now obviously we are animals as well, but we are somewhat evolved in that we are aware of things. But if I am not really comfortable progressing in this world, sometimes I may be put in a position where I can be more comfortable in a simpler environment.

What is the right thing to do then? Change that environment. Go back to where I feel comfortable, so I can start my progress appropriately from there. I don't know about here, but in India they sometimes will put you back in the fifth grade and say, well, let's put him back in the fourth grade because that will be the most comfortable. See, it's not a punishment. The Lord never punishes you for your own actions.

You only punish yourself for your own actions. Once the mudha yoni is what I'm most comfortable with, Bhagavan says, go back, start all over again from there and go further. And the next verse says Karmanaha sukritasya ahuhu satvikam nirmalam phalam. So what am I supposed to do? Am I just simply programmed, and by chance the experiences I'm having in this world will make me either Tamasic, Rajasic, or Sattvic? You do have a choice.

Very little, but you have a choice. And the choice is Karmanaha sukritasya ahuhu satvikam nirmalam phalam -- the result of good action is pure and Sattvic. Rajasa tu phalam dukkham -- the result of Rajas is dukkham, sorrow. And I'll tell you, we have difficulty accepting that. If that's the case, we'll all stop acting.

But remember, we are not in a business class. We are not in any kind of social reform class. We are in a class to reform our own mind. In your own mind, you can try it yourself -- put in a spreadsheet what you have done and what the final outcome was of that action. In the end, there will be more pain than what you gained out of that action. Oh boy, that was a project from hell.

But we were dying to get that project. Because in the end this interaction with this world create frictions and the frictions create pain. The result is always more pain and little happiness. And therefore Vedanta also calls this world Dukkhalaya -- the house of pain. Now this is not to discourage people from doing what they are doing. This is for you to know, for your mind, what is good.

For my mind to remain in equanimity -- if I attach myself to this world, there is nothing but pain. If I attach to good actions, selfless actions, Karma Yoga, the results are sattvic and pure. Tamas Agnanam Tamasah phalam -- very obvious. If I am completely in Tamas, what is the result? So you decide what you should do.

The only thing you have in your hand is your own actions. Nahi kashchit kshanam api jatu tishthati akarma krit -- you cannot stand for any minute without acting. Good actions will lead to a Sattvic environment. So, of course, everyone wants to do that. Sattvat Sanjayate Jnanam -- so what happens when I do good actions?

Well, people praise me and say Neel is a good person. No, he said, that's not your goal -- that's actually a detriment to you. The more people praise you, the more your ego gets hardened, and the more criticism you attract. Durijan Niire Rakhi Angan Kuti Chabai Binapani bin Sabana Nirmal kare Sadh. Sattvat Sanjayate Jnanam -- but why?

I'm doing good actions because I want sattvic thoughts and a sattvic mood. And what's the result of that? I'll have knowledge -- knowledge about my own self, what my goal is, and how to get there. Sattvat Sanjayate Jnanam Rajaso Lobha Eva Cha -- he said, do you mean to say this man of action that everybody talks about is not good? This dynamic man of action, if he's driven by his own gains, the result will be greed.

Lobha -- greed. We had this hedge fund manager Rajaratnam, who was a billionaire. He must have come with $8 in his pocket from India. He was a multi-billionaire. But where is he today? Why do you need all those billions and then still have to do something which is illegal?
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the profound consequences of which guna predominates at the moment of death—and, by extension, throughout life. Verse 13 lists Tamas symptoms: "aprakāśa" (absence of light), "apravritti" (inactivity), "pramāda" (heedlessness), and "moha" (delusion). But the teaching goes deeper: verses 14-15 explain that one who dies in a sattvic state reaches "uttamavidām lokān amalān"—the pure worlds of those who know the Highest. One who dies in Rajas is reborn "karmasangishu"—among those attached to action. One who dies in Tamas enters "mūdhayonishu"—the wombs of the deluded. This is not punishment but natural consequence—like an architect who, regardless of what TV show he watched last night, wakes up still an architect because that is what his mind has become through accumulated tendencies.

The teaching offers compassionate wisdom here: the Lord gives each soul exactly the environment it needs to exhaust its vasanas (tendencies). If you crave activity, you get an active life. If you crave knowledge, you get opportunities for wisdom. This is Lord's compassion, not punishment. Today, ask yourself honestly: What tendencies am I cultivating? If you were to die tonight, what would the predominant texture of your mind be—clarity, restlessness, or dullness? The beautiful news is that you have choice: "karmanah sukritasya āhuh sāttvikam nirmalam phalam"—the fruit of good action is pure and sattvic. Right now, in this moment, you can choose actions that cultivate Sattva. What one small choice can you make today that moves your baseline toward clarity and knowledge?

snippets.title: Day 185: Bondage of Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम् |

सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च |

ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः |
snippets.transliteration:
karmaṇaḥ sukṛtasyāhuḥ sāttvikaṃ nirmalaṃ phalam .

sattvātsañjāyate jñānaṃ rajaso lobha eva ca .

ūrdhvaṃ gacchanti sattvasthā madhye tiṣṭhanti rājasāḥ .
verseTranslations: They say the fruit of a meritorious action is spotless and full of purity; the outcome of Passion is misery, and of Ignorance darkness.
Purity engenders Wisdom, Passion avarice, and Ignorance folly, infatuation and darkness.
When Purity is in the ascendant, the man evolves; when Passion, he neither evolves nor degenerates; when Ignorance, he is lost.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of the three gunas. So far, in the first six chapters we learned about the conditioned consciousness -- "I". In the next six chapters we learned about the Supreme Consciousness. From conditioned consciousness to the supreme Consciousness is the journey which we all are taking. So to help that journey, in the last chapter we have defined what is the field and who is the knower and what is the differentiation between the two. So we have said that the I, the knower, know the field which is this body, mind and intellect.

I know my body, I know my mind, I know my intellect, therefore they are my field. And I, the knower, am the knower of the field. And the field cannot be the knower, and the knower cannot be the field. Now, in this chapter we are learning about the qualities of the field. So we are taking it a step at a time to understand how I can take this journey from this conditioned consciousness which I consider "I" -- or in Vedanta called Jiva, the limited self -- to the supreme self which is my true nature. And therefore the quest in life is always to achieve that balance where there is no sorrows, no limitations, nothing that will create unhappiness, a perfect happiness.

And because there is no unhappiness, it cannot be called happiness, but just a bliss. So we have seen this and then we say these gunas. The Prakriti has three gunas. The field which is part of the Prakriti has three gunas. These gunas bind the knower to the field. Those are the attractions which create bondage between the Purusha and Prakriti, the knower and the field, and create identification.

This identification is because of these gunas. And those three gunas we have seen as Sattva rajas and Tamas. My awareness about this field is Sattva; the activity, the passion for something I like, is Rajas; and then ignorance is Tamas. These three bind me. So how do I get out of these three? Or is one of them helping me to get out of this conditioned consciousness to supreme consciousness?

So we have seen that Sattva gives knowledge, Rajas gives activity. And the byproduct would be greed -- one activity leads to another and to another and another, and there's no end to it. So that creates greed and Tamas creates inertia. So now we have to transcend from one to another. So one, the lowest we can see is inertia from our perspective.

These are the qualities of my mind right now. These are the qualities of the field. In this field the body is obviously completely inert. By its very nature it just cannot do anything but to exist. Just like we have seen, the atom has inertia and therefore it exists. As long as the inertia is there, atom exists as an atom.

Once you disturb the inertia, the Rajas will explode into atomic energy. Body is nothing but inertia. But the mind and intellect have all three. The Rajas, Tamas and Sattva. So these are the qualities of my mind which I'm most interested in. And that depending on the quality of my mind, if it is Sattva, it has a knowledge.

Prakash, Gnaan -- if it is Rajas, I'm active with new projects, new activity. And inertia -- don't want to know anything, don't want to do anything. So the verses you have seen now tell me what happens if one guna or another is predominant in my mental zone. Urdhvam Gacchanti Sattvasthaha -- those who are established in Sattva. If my mental quality is predominantly Sattva, Urdhvam Gacchanti -- I go higher. "Higher" and "lower" are obviously concepts of my mind.

I'm going towards my goal -- going from the conditioned consciousness to supreme consciousness, to unconditioned consciousness. This conditioning which is binding me, my goal is to get rid of it and become one with the unconditioned supreme consciousness. That which leads me to my goal, I consider higher. So Urdhvam Gacchanti Sattvasthaha -- the Sattvic mode of my mind will lead me towards my goal of unconditioning this conditioning. Then, Madhye Tishthanti Rajasaha -- those whose mental zone is predominantly Rajasic.

They remain in the middle. Neither are they going up nor are they going down. They remain in a status quo. Just like in our election -- we ended up where we started. The Rajasic do a lot of activities.

But in the end if you see the sum total, the result is the same. If you can look at all the activities we have done in life. All we have done is to create security for ourselves, stability for ourselves, some kind of a protection that we remain in a good condition. And in the end it all comes down to the same thing. Every few years we have to go through the same thing over and over and over again. So they basically remain in the same state they are in.

Neither are they making progress upward nor going downwards. Neither are they unburdening themselves from their bondages nor creating more bondage -- they are in the same state. Jaghanya gunavrittisthaha adho gacchanti tamasaha. But those who are abiding in the lower qualities of Tamas, they go down. Obviously we are talking about human beings, about the human mind.

The human mind which has evolved for activity and knowledge to understand the world around it. The more it understands, the higher it goes. The more it gets entangled into this world, the more it remains where it is. The more it doesn't want to know, the more it goes down -- down in the sense of a situation where no more knowledge is necessary to survive, just the basic knowledge of "I exist and I survive" is good enough. They go down into that state of existence.

In the next verse we have seen: na anyam gunebhya kartaram yada drashta anupashyati. Why did we look at that verse? To introspect. In the spiritual quest, introspection is the most important aspect of our practice. You have to constantly introspect and see what is there in your mental zone. And if I find any impurities, I need to remove them -- that is antahkarana shuddhi.

And then once I remove the impurity, the purity itself will reveal what is right and wrong. If I introspect and find myself to be in the tamasic zone, my next goal is to become Rajasic. Going from Tamasic to Sattvic is not an easy journey -- you have to go through Rajasic first. That's why the Bhagavad Gita says, the people who are doing good for the wrong reason -- let them do it, do not stop them. If I'm giving a donation to make my name, I'm at least better than the one who is not giving at all.

That's why the Bhagavad Gita says let them do it, for whatever the motivation. But you need to make progress. So he said, if I am in a tamasic zone, let me make sure that at least I'm active. If I'm in an active zone, I need to slow down and understand why I'm doing it. That introspection leads me to what will be the remedy, to what my next efforts should be.

And therefore the next verse says this is not enough. Generally we understand, well, if I go from tamasic to rajasic to sattvic, I'm done -- because now I'm remaining in the sattvic guna. So I want to keep getting that praise over and over again.

In other words, you get attached to happiness. The joy which comes out of knowledge, the joy which comes out of doing good, binds me to this. It does not let me leave. We have a saying in our architecture: what happens to the old architects? They don't die, they just wither away. They continue working till they drop dead in the studio.

The real goal for the conditioned self is to go beyond the gunas. And how do you go beyond gunas? Na anyam gunebhya kartaram -- there is no other doer in my life other than my own gunas. Only the gunas are the doers for everything which I am doing, accomplishing, and losing.

Yada drashta anupashyati -- one who starts seeing this, that all my actions are driven by the modes of my mind. Only when my mind wants to see Skyfall does it act on that desire. Meena says, read this chapter, it's so nice. But in my mind, I'm going to see a Bond movie. Right now you can say whatever you want -- I'm not in the mood right now.

So who drives me to the Bond movie? Who brings me here to Gita class? My own gunas. If I can recognize my mind as the doer and say, all that I do is driven by the quality of my mind as thought -- whatever my thought, my action will be driven by that. So all my actions I should assign clearly to my mind. All the gunas are doing what they do. Na anyam -- there is no other. You can say, well, I was forced by society.

Well, I really didn't want to go see a movie, but they insisted. We used to do that when I was in college. I really didn't want to go just before the exam, but all my room partners said, Neel, come on. I blame my room partners for why I went to see a movie just before the day of the examination. But if I had no tendencies, I wouldn't have gone.

One who sees that -- Yada drashta anupashyati -- one who starts seeing that all my actions are driven by my mind and the qualities of my mind. Gunebhyash cha param vetti -- and he says there is someone higher than these gunas, someone much higher than my mind, who also sees the limitations of my mind. "Well, I shouldn't have gone to see a movie just before the exam."

The "I" who says "I shouldn't have" is different from the "I" who went to see a movie. Gunebhyah param vetti -- one who knows that there is one who is above these gunas. Mad Bhavam sa adhigacchati -- identify with that. I really don't need to take any credit or blame for my actions. My mind was in that mood and I did that. However, I am not my mind. My mind is just a field in which my consciousness functions.

That consciousness never took part in any of the action. If my identification takes place that way, Bhagavan says, Mad Bhavam sa adhigacchati -- he attains my being. We have seen the supreme consciousness. Unconditioned by the limitations of body, mind and intellect, he becomes one with me. As Swamiji says, he doesn't become Krishna with flute and peacock feather.

He becomes one with that unconditioned consciousness. He now starts identifying with the room space analogy. Once the space leaves its identification with the walls, floor and ceiling -- remaining within the room -- it identifies now with the space outside. I'm none other than this universal space. Gunaan etan atitya trin dehi deha samudbhavan -- this dehi, one who considers "this is me, this body, this mind is me," is created by these gunas.

These verses map the spiritual trajectory of each guna with striking clarity. Verse 18 declares: "ūrdhvam gacchanti sattvasthāh"—those established in Sattva rise upward toward liberation. "Madhye tishthanti rājasāh"—the rajasic remain in the middle, neither ascending nor descending, like a person running endlessly on a treadmill. "Adho gacchanti tāmasāh"—the tamasic descend into lower states of existence. Yet the teaching reveals a crucial truth often missed: even Sattva is bondage. The joy of knowledge, the pleasure of doing good, the praise of others—all these can become golden chains. As the teaching notes, "what happens to old architects? They don't die, they just wither away"—attached to creativity until the end.

The prescription becomes clear: use introspection to diagnose your current state, then systematically work upward. If you find yourself in Tamas—unwilling to know or act—the remedy is not to leap directly to Sattva but to first become Rajasic, to become active. If you find yourself in Rajas—compulsively doing but not understanding why—slow down and seek clarity. But even when you reach Sattva, don't stop there. Verse 19 points beyond: "nānyam gunebhyah kartāram yadā drashtā anupashyati"—when the seer recognizes that ONLY the gunas act, and perceives That which is beyond the gunas, he attains the Divine nature. Today, practice this: observe your actions and say, "My gunas are doing this, not I." The one who can make this distinction has begun the journey beyond all three. What guna is predominant in you right now? What is the appropriate next step upward?

snippets.reflection:
Verse 19 contains the pivotal teaching of this chapter: "nānyam gunebhyah kartāram"—there is NO doer other than the gunas. When you truly see this, everything shifts. That moment when you said something hurtful? Your gunas were acting. That burst of creative brilliance? Your gunas again. The one who SEES this—the "drashta" (witness)—stands apart from all action. And Krishna promises: "gunebhyash cha param vetti madbhāvam so adhigacchati"—one who knows the Self as beyond the gunas attains My nature. This is not becoming Krishna with flute and peacock feather, as Swamiji clarifies, but becoming one with unconditioned consciousness itself.

Verse 20 reveals what transcendence brings: freedom from "janma-mrityu-jarā-duhkhaih"—birth, death, old age, and sorrow. The embodied self, once it transcends the three gunas that caused physical existence, "amritam ashnute"—tastes immortality. Arjuna then asks the practical questions we all ask (verse 21): How do I recognize such a person? How does he behave? How did he get there? Today, practice the essential shift: When you catch yourself saying "I did this" or "I felt that," pause and reframe—"The gunas did this; the gunas felt that." Notice how this creates space between you and your experience. The teaching uses a powerful example: "The one who says 'I shouldn't have gone to the movie before the exam' is different from the one who went." Who is that witness in you? Can you find and rest in that awareness today, even for a moment?

snippets.title: Day 187: Beyond the Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते |

समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

udāsīnavadāsīno guṇairyo na vicālyate .

samaduḥkhasukhaḥ svasthaḥ samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: O Prince! He who shuns not the Quality which is present, and longs not for that which is absent;
He who maintains an attitude of indifference, who is not disturbed by the Qualities, who realises that it is only they who act, and remains calm;

Who accepts pain and pleasure as it comes, is centred in his Self, to whom a piece of clay or stone or gold are the same, who neither likes nor dislikes, who is steadfast, indifferent alike to praise or censure;
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of the three gunas. So far in Bhagavad Gita, you have learned about ourselves in the first six chapters -- who we are as limited beings, how we function, how we can make the most out of our actions, and how we can be most efficient. And we learned that working without any attachment or expectation is actually the best method to gain the most out of your life and most out of your actions. To become the most proficient and efficient, the basic requirement is not to get too attached to whatever you are doing. This is completely contrary to what we think.

We think the more passionate I am, the better I will be. Bhagavad Gita says it's the other way around. The less you are attached to what you are doing, the more efficient you would be, the more successful you would be. So this is what we learned in the first six chapters. That's called Karma Yoga. How to act in this world as a limited being and to get the most out of your life is Karma Yoga.

Then we focused on who you are in reality -- that you are not this body, you are not this mind, you are not this intellect. So Dhyana Yoga, contemplating upon that supreme self -- the self that I am beyond this limited self -- we have learned this in the next set of chapters, culminating in Bhakti Yoga, the devotion to that self. Unless I identify with something higher, I cannot detach from the lower. To resign from my job, I have to find another job before I resign. If I'm a smart person, I don't resign before getting the next job.

You have to find a better job before you can resign from your current one, which you either hate or at least don't love as much. This limited self, even though I'm comfortable -- it's not the best situation I'm in. I'm not always happy, I'm not always achieving what I'm trying to achieve. So I'm trying to see something better than what I have today, something which can give me permanent happiness. Bhagavan said, identify with that self which is capable of giving you permanent happiness. That's Bhakti Yoga.

Bhakti Yoga is truly to identify with that which has no limitations. As long as I'm identified with this limited being, there is no chance, ever in eons to come, that I'll achieve my goal of being perfectly happy. But once you identify with that supreme self -- then the question becomes, what is the difference between the limited self and the higher self, and how to go beyond those limitations? So the last chapter we talked about Kshetra-Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga.

What is the field and who is the knower? The knower is always someone other than the field. If I know something, that means it's an object. If I know my limited self, the limited self is an object, and I, the knower, am knowing the limited self. So there we identified that this body -- Idam Sareeram Kaunteya Etat Kshetram Iti Abhidhiyate -- this body is the field.

This body includes all my experiences, my mind, my thoughts, modifications of my moods -- all that is the field. But one who is witnessing it is the witness. So now, how do I go beyond this? We have been learning in this chapter what is binding this unlimited self to the limited self. And we came to the conclusion that it is the three gunas of the Prakriti. This Prakriti, the manifest world, has three basic qualities.

The three ingredients which make it a pluralistic world, now projecting as a plural world. We know from science that there was nothing but singularity before the Big Bang, and then this world of cosmos came into existence. I was just reading Stephen Hawking -- some dialogue with somebody. And somebody asked him, so what was before the Big Bang?

And he said, nothing. Nothing before the Big Bang. But there was something -- because, as we say, something cannot come out of nothing. So there was something, but that something was not as divided as we perceive it right now. We also learned about cause and effect.

That effect can be nothing but the cause modified. This cosmos cannot be anything but the singularity modified. So Bhagavan said that you have to understand what is binding you to this worldview of pluralistic world. And you are at the center of your own world. I'm in the center of my world. Everything relates to me.

If I remove myself from this world, the world disappears. When I'm not there, that world does not exist. What's happening in Syria right now does not exist for me, because I'm not there. But what's happening here -- I'm very much involved, it all relates to me. Once I remove this limited self out of this equation, the pluralistic world does not exist.

These three gunas are binding this infinite to this limited self. Gunas as we have learned, also means ropes. These three ropes are binding you to this limitedness. We are not giving up our limitedness, but expecting infinite happiness, unlimited existence. We all think that we are going to exist forever. We have learned in Mahabharata that Yaksha asked you this direct question.

What is the most wonderful you find about human beings? The most wonderful, most amazing thing is that everyone knows he's going to die. But they all live like they're never going to die. We cannot think about ourselves as non existing. Existence is my real nature. But I also know that this life as I know will end sooner or later.

How can I get out of this fear of mortality, this fear of unhappiness? Bhagavan said, you need to get rid of these three binding ropes. You have this great wealth of Sat, Chit, and Ananda, but you just don't have the password to that account. Somebody says, Neel, your great grandfather left great wealth in a Swiss account -- the only problem is we don't have the account number. So we know that we are Satchitananda.

We just don't know the key to it. So Bhagavan said, know that these three are binding you. Once you get out of these three, you will achieve that state where you are immortal, always blissful, and all-knowing. So we have learned that these three gunas are binding -- they are Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas. Sattva binds you with happiness, Rajas by activity, and Tamas by laziness or inactivity.

So the ultimate prescription was Guna tita Bhava -- go beyond these three gunas. Arjuna obviously says, okay, all this is well and good, but how can one get to that point? The last verse we have seen says Kair lingais trin gunan etan atito Bhavati prabhu -- how can anyone go beyond these three gunas? Once he achieves that, what will be his behavior? Katham cha etan trin gunan ativartate.

How can I understand that this is possible? Give me some indications -- like a litmus test -- that if I see this, it means that person has gone beyond the three gunas. And also, if that is possible, if somebody has already done that, then tell me the recipe for how to get there. Now we know that Bhagavan has been talking about it throughout the Bhagavad Gita. But Arjuna one more time asks this question to make it very clear that this is the goal of life.

So Bhagavan answers in the following verses, and it's really very unique. Verse 22 -- this is something we really want to contemplate. What is his answer? Prakasham cha Pravritim cha Moham eva cha Pandava Na dveshti sampravrittani -- he did not say that these gunas will disappear once you become Nirguna, Gunatita. He does not hate when these three gunas are present. Prakasham cha Pravritim cha Moham -- these are the effects of these three gunas.

Prakash -- light, knowledge, clear-headedness. We clearly understand what's going on. Things are very clear, no confusion. That's the effect of Sattva. When my mind and intellect are in Sattva Guna, everything is crystal clear. I don't need somebody's advice.

I know what is right and what is wrong. Pravritti -- activity, I'm busy. That's the effect of Rajas. And Moha -- delusion. I don't understand what's going on, I don't know whether they're right or wrong. Moha is the effect of Tamas.

When these are present in my personality, in my mind, I don't hate them. Up till now we were thinking that when somebody says Guna Tita Bhava, it means I will not have those gunas at all. Bhagavan makes it very clear: these gunas will remain as they are. Just because you became Sthita Prajna, the world is not going to change. Neither the quality nor the nature of your body, mind, and intellect are going to change.

If I am a weakling, it's not overnight going to change just because I have become a Gnani. The body will have its own Dharma -- it will be exactly what it was before realization and after realization. The mind will have its own Dharma. It has been with you for eons; it has its own personality.

It's not going to change. Neither is the intellect overnight going to become Einstein. We know these are my equipment and I have to live with their limitations. But I, at the core of my being, seeing that happening in my mind and intellect, remain a witness. And I don't hate that. "Why am I in this mood?" is not a question. This is how I react when things happen this way.

This is my nature. Na nivrittani kankshati -- he also does not desire them when they are not present. When I am in a sattvic mood, things are very clear, and I'm very happy about my own clarity. Then when I lose that sattvic mood and get into Rajasic or Tamasic territory, I hate that -- I want to be back to my serene, clean, clear state of mind. Bhagavan says that's not how it works, and therefore you shouldn't be desirous of clinging to those states. Many people say, I was meditating, the very first day it was very good, but from the second day onward nothing really happened.

The more you desire and grasp, the more it will stay away from you. In Gujarat there is a saying: one who is asking for it, things go away from them; and one who says "I don't need it," people will come to you. The more you say "I don't need it," the more people offer; the more you say "I want it," the more people take away from you. So Bhagavan says, when the effects of these three gunas are present, don't hate them. Understand that these are the common experiences for everyone. Na nivrittani -- when something is absent, when I was enjoying my activity, I was very busy, and now I'm not -- accept it as is.

So the acceptance is the mark of a true Gnani. One who accepts his reality as it is -- that is Bhagavan's answer to Arjuna's question: what are his qualities? His qualities are that he accepts things as they are. He does not hate them if they are happening; he does not desire them if they are not happening. Now this is very difficult for us to accept, because as soon as we talk about somebody, we say, I don't know, he has been talking about all this, but then the other day this thing happened and he reacted this way. He reacted this way because this is how he was made up through all his life.

But you do not know how that incident affected him. Once, at the core of your being, you become a witness.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna's answer to Arjuna's question is revolutionary and often misunderstood. Verse 22 does NOT say the gunas disappear for the enlightened one. Rather: "prakāsham cha pravrittim cha moham eva cha... na dveshti sampravrittāni na nivrittāni kānkshati"—when light (Sattva), activity (Rajas), or delusion (Tamas) are present, he does not hate them; when they are absent, he does not crave them. This is radical acceptance. The liberated one still experiences all three gunas—clarity fades into restlessness, restlessness into dullness—but he neither clings to the pleasant states nor pushes away the unpleasant ones. He remains "udāsīnavat āsīnah"—seated like one indifferent, unmoved by the gunas' play.

Verse 24 paints the portrait of such equanimity: "sama-duhkha-sukhah svastah"—equal in pain and pleasure, established in the Self. "Sama-loshta-ashma-kānchanah"—to whom a clod of earth, a stone, and gold are the same. "Tulya-priya-apriyah"—equal toward the pleasant and unpleasant. "Tulya-nindā-ātma-samstutih"—the same whether criticized or praised. This is not suppression or indifference but a fundamental shift in identity. Today, test yourself: When you are in a sattvic, clear state, do you grasp at it, fearing its loss? When you feel dull or agitated, do you fight against it? Practice letting each state arise and pass without the second layer of reaction—without craving the good or hating the bad. Notice: the one who can observe both pleasant and unpleasant states with equanimity is already beyond both. That witness is your true nature.

snippets.title: Day 188: The Three Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः |

मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते |

ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
mānāpamānayostulyastulyo mitrāripakṣayoḥ .

māṃ ca yo.avyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate .

brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāhamamṛtasyāvyayasya ca .
verseTranslations: Who looks equally upon honour and dishonour, loves friends and foes alike, abandons all initiative, such is he who transcends the Qualities.
And he who serves Me and only Me, with unfaltering devotion, shall overcome the Qualities, and become One with the Eternal.
For I am the Home of the Spirit, the continual Source of immortality, of eternal Righteousness and of infinite Joy."
snippets.commentary:
Okay, so I will be discussing the last four verses of chapter 14. Chapter 14 is the Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga. We have discussed and basically found so far that in this Prakriti, this manifest world, everything has these three gunas, which are the signature of Prakriti: Sattva -- the light, the knowledge, the awareness; Rajas -- the activity; and Tamas -- inertia. These three gunas bind this supreme self, which has no limitations, to this limited being. These qualities belong to my body, mind and intellect. Once the consciousness attaches to this, it takes upon itself all the limitations of Prakriti.

So I, the ego, am right now conditioned by this body, mind, and intellect. Therefore I have all the limitations of body, mind, and intellect. Therefore I go through sorrows and happiness, pleasant and unpleasant experiences, conducive and unconducive situations. Because each entity by itself has its own priorities and its own situations. The world remains the world -- one person sees it as very positive, the other sees it as very negative.

Depending on their own conditioning, one who goes beyond these three gunas will be beyond all these conflicts and sorrows. So what we have seen is that these three gunas also belong to my mind. It is my mind which is sometimes sattvic, sometimes rajasic, or sometimes tamasic. Depending on the qualities of my mind, I'll see this world as Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. My experiences will be driven by the moods of my mind.

So if I can get over this, if I can introspect and vigilantly monitor the moods of my mind, I will be able to rise above the situations I am facing. The situation remains the same, but I can change the mood of my mind, and that will change my reaction to the situation. But the ultimate goal is to go beyond the three gunas all the time. So the verse we have seen: udasina avad asino gunaihi yo na vichalyate -- one who is indifferent to these gunas and does not get swallowed by them. Guna vartanta iti eva avatishtati na ingate.

What is happening in this world is nothing but the play of the gunas. Gunas are the ones acting in this world. Guna guneshu vartante iti matvaa na sajjate -- knowing that what is happening is the gunas of my senses and the gunas of this world of objects reacting with each other. When I have an experience, it is an interaction between the gunas of my senses, my body, my mind, and the gunas of the objects. So when I come across a conducive situation, I feel happy.

In an unconducive situation, I'm not happy -- but the one who knows that the self that I am does not get disturbed by it remains steady. This verse 23: Guna vartanta iti eva avatishtati na ingate -- knowing that these are all the play of the gunas only, and nothing to do with me the self, he does not move from his state of bliss. He is always in the state of bliss as the self. When we hear what's happening in Tahrir Square in Egypt, does it really make me so upset that I couldn't sleep at night?

I may have my opinion whether they're good or bad for the world, but that's all it is -- I'm a third-party observer. If I can do the same thing for everything happening to me in my own "Tahrir Square," then I will be the same way. That's all it's saying.

So now, Arjuna had asked three questions. One: what are the marks of a person who has gone beyond the gunas?

This is exactly similar to chapter two, where he asks, what are the qualities of a person who is Buddhi-sthita, established in wisdom? Same thing here: how do I know that person has gone beyond the gunas? Then, how does he move around and talk in this world? And lastly, how did he do it? The one who is beyond the gunas, knowing that this is the play of gunas only, does not get disturbed.

That's the mark of him. What will be his behavior? We have seen in the following verses: Sama dukha sukhaha svasthaha sama loshta ashma kanchanaha tulya priya apriya dhiraha tulya ninda atma samstutih. We have seen this in Bhagavad Gita before -- the quality of a person whose Buddhi is established in the supreme self and not in this limited self. When things occur in this life, such a person sees that it's this ego reacting with the world outside, and therefore Sama dukha sukhaha -- whether the condition is conducive or non-conducive, he remains the same.

He sees that we don't have big riots when seasons change. From spring we move to fall and then winter. We don't have riots in the streets about that. Why? Because we accept that's how nature is. After spring, fall has to come, and after fall, winter has to come.

We adjust to it. In our life, we are not accepting this -- we always want a hundred percent happiness all the time, and therefore we get all disturbed. But the person who knows this, just like I know that fall will come after spring and winter will come after fall, knows that after every happy occasion there is something unhappy, non-conducive. Those of you educated by Indian TV know this all the time, right? So Sama dukha sukhaha svasthaha.

He remains Svasthaha -- balanced, not affected by Sukha or Dukha. Knowing this is a temporary interaction between the gunas of myself as body, mind, intellect, and the world. When the economy is doing well, we are all very happy -- everybody talks about the party, about how much money they made in the stock market. Now we all talk about, I don't know what Obama is doing.

Why doesn't he think about me? That's the nature of this world. Sama loshta ashma kanchanaha -- he also sees no greater value in one thing of this world than another. Now does that mean that if somebody asks for one rupee, he gives away a thousand-dollar note? No. A transaction in this world is a transaction between me, the limited being, and the world. That is what is called Vyavahara.

And Vyavahara should be appropriate to the situation. However, such a person doesn't see one transaction as inherently more important than another. Swamiji gives an example: when you were a little kid, a game card -- one was more valuable than the other. I grew up in India, so we used to have Parle bottle tops. There was a value to each one -- a Parle cap had greater value than a certain other brand, right?

Anybody remember that? In those days, your wealth was those bottle tops, and if somebody took them away from you, it was devastating. But when you grow out of it, all those bottle tops are worth nothing to you. One who sees the world that way knows that each thing has its own value in that particular transaction at a particular time. Therefore we say, you may have a styrofoam cup and somebody has a gold cup. Both are thirsty and going to a lake -- which one is more valuable than the other?

As long as there is an emptiness which can fetch water -- for me, that's all that counts. At that moment, the value of gold and the value of styrofoam is exactly the same, depending on which can fetch more water. So sama loshta ashma kanchanaha -- he does not give greater value to one or the other, knowing that the value only belongs to the exchange or the utility in that particular transaction. Tulya priya apriya -- this one, obviously, we all can use.

He remains the same when something comes which is dear to me or not dear to me, because it is not in my control. We struggle through in this economy, go through interviews and proposals, and we come out and everybody says, Neel, you really did a fantastic presentation. I feel so good -- until I hear that my competition got the project. Things will come to you by their own nature. They are not depending on my efforts alone; they're coming to me by their own nature.

And I react to that as my right or my misfortune, depending on what is coming to me. You can really see it: I say, boy, Neel, you did so good -- but when you don't, I think you should have prepared a little better. Neel, I think this time you were not really ready; you should have prepared more. Whether it's good or bad.

What happened? Suddenly my success now defines whether I was good or not. We were reading about Steve Jobs. He threw away all the rules of business -- no focus groups, no surveys, nothing. "What do people know about what they want? I will tell them what they want." So he worked completely contrary to other people's business models, as taught in Harvard and everywhere else.

And his is the most successful company. So now we say, let's look at the Steve Jobs model, how he built the company. You have to remain the same whether people are praising you or not. They praise you simply because it is the nature of the world, not yours. And then the next verse says Mana apamana yoho tulyaha tulyo mitraha aripaksha yoho. Continuing the same teaching.

Bhagavan says such a person who has gone beyond the gunas is acting in this manner. He is working in this world as a normal person, but in his mind, he sees all this as a temporary occurrence -- nothing that he controls. His duty is to act according to dharma in each situation. Mana apamana yoho -- this is obviously very important to us because we get hurt very easily. Mana and apmana -- honor and dishonor -- are at our mental level.

This is truly at our mind's level. Sometimes the person who is telling you something had no intention of insulting you or hurting you. But you take it that way because your mental state was such that you received it that way. If I'm supremely confident, people say something critical and I think, don't worry about it. But if I'm already shaky, then somebody says, Neel, you're not doing well.

Then I collapse right there. So it is not the world, but my mind that decides whether this is mana or apmana. He is so established in himself that whatever comes from the world, he just takes it at face value and moves on. Mitraha aripakshayoho -- this is another important quality. These are my friends and these are my enemies.

My relationship may be different with each person, but my inner stance toward them should remain the same. That does not mean that when enemies are attacking your country, you say, well, we'll receive you the same way we receive our allies. At that time, your Vyavahara -- your appropriate action -- is to protect your country. But just as Gandhi said, I hate the British government but not the British people. It's not the person you are reacting to, but the action you are reacting to. Therefore, tulya mitra aripaksha -- equal toward friend and foe.

Aripaksha -- the foes, the enemies. Mitra -- friend. We all know this. Sarva Arambha parityagi -- we have seen it before, and this is the most difficult one. He gives up all endeavors, all efforts. Sarva Arambha parityagi -- this sounds like complete death.

If I stop doing everything, it's a complete death. I will stop all my endeavors and efforts when I die. Swamiji explained that's exactly what they're asking you to do.
snippets.reflection:
These concluding verses answer Arjuna's final question: How does one transcend the gunas? Verse 25 continues the portrait: "mānāpamānayoh tulyah"—equal in honor and dishonor, "tulyo mitrāri-pakshayoh"—the same toward friend and foe. Then comes the challenging phrase: "sarvārambha-parityāgī"—one who has abandoned all undertakings. This sounds like death itself! But the teaching clarifies: it means giving up the SENSE of personal doership, not the actions themselves. Continue to work, but know that the gunas alone act while you remain the witness. Verse 26 then gives the method: "mām cha yo avyabhichārena bhaktiyogena sevate"—one who serves Me with unwavering devotion transcends the gunas and becomes fit for union with Brahman.

The chapter's final verse (27) reveals Krishna's ultimate identity: "brahmanah hi pratishthā aham"—I am the abode of Brahman, "amritasya avyayasya cha"—of immortality and imperishability, "shāshvatasya cha dharmasya"—of eternal dharma, "sukhasyaikāntikasya cha"—and of absolute bliss. This is where the journey ends—or rather, where the illusion of journey dissolves. Today, practice "sarva-ārambha-parityāga" in a practical way: choose one activity and perform it completely, but without the sense that "I am doing this." Let the hands move, let the mind think, but rest as the awareness in which all this happens. Notice how this does not diminish the quality of action—often it improves it, as you noted from the Karma Yoga teachings. The one who has nothing to prove, nothing to gain, acts with perfect freedom. Can you taste that freedom today, even in one small task?

snippets.title: Day 189: The Cosmic Tree
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा

न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

adhaścordhvaṃ prasṛtāstasya śākhā guṇapravṛddhā viṣayapravālāḥ .

na rūpamasyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na cādirna ca sampratiṣṭhā .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna continued: This phenomenal creation, which is both ephemeral and eternal, is like a tree, but having its seed above in the Highest and its ramifications on this earth below. The scriptures are its leaves, and he who understands this, knows.

Its branches shoot upwards and downwards, deriving their nourishment from the Qualities; its buds are the objects of sense; and its roots, which follow the Law causing man's regeneration and degeneration, pierce downwards into the soil.

In this world its true form is not known, neither its origin nor its end, and its strength is not understood, until the tree with its roots striking deep into the earth is hewn down by the sharp axe of non-attachment.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga. And now we will be starting discussion of Chapter 15, Purushottam Yoga -- Yoga of the Supreme Purusha. In Chapter 13 we have seen the difference between the field and its knower. The Prakriti is the field, and the one which is aware of the field is the knower of the field. So at my individual level, we have learned that this body is the field.

The one who is aware of the body is the knower of the field. So the body is part of the Prakriti. But I, the knower is part of the Purusha, the manifestation of Purusha in me. This Purusha which is imperishable, right now I consider it to be perishable because it is identified with this perishable body. To make this connection between the Purusha and Prakriti at both my individual level and at the universal level, we learned in chapter 14 that the Purusha is the father of all the beings and Prakriti is the womb of all the beings in this world. So Prakriti is the mother and Purusha is the father.

Any being which is born at any place, to any womb -- Bhagavan said, consider this great Prakriti as the womb and I am the seed-giving Father. We see the variety of beings and things in this world; that variety is explained by these three Gunas, the three binding ropes which bind this imperishable Purusha to this perishable manifestation. This variety of things and beings are created by the permutation and combination of these Gunas, the three modes of material nature. This variety of things and beings around me create my Sansaar. My relationship with these things and beings is my Sansaar.

This Sansaar is ever changing Samsaratiyeti Sansaar. That which is constantly changing is Sansaar. Sansaar does not remain same. That which was there a minute ago has already changed. It has already passed. So we constantly are struggling with this ever changing Sansaar.

This Sansaar continues to grow. When I was just a single person and a student, my Sansaar was limited to me and my parents. Then you get married -- so now you have become two. Your problem plus her problem, and then we have children. So not only my problem, her problem, but also his problem. A few years ago when I used to go to India, I used to have only three houses to visit -- my three brothers.

Now when I go there, it is not only my brother's houses but their children -- they are married, their in-laws. So by the time I'm done, the 15 days are just gone, just meeting with all their relatives. Because my Sansaar has grown. Bhajagovindam says: "Bala tat krida sakthah, taruna tat taruni sakthah, vruddha tavat chinta sakthah." When I was a child, I was engaged in plays and toys. When I was a young man, I was engaged in chasing girls. When I became an old man, I'm just overwhelmed by worries.

I said well why would that be? You should be relieved. So I was actually looking forward to an old age. Because I thought the old age means my children will be married. I will have no worries then I will be completely free. Now that I have become an old man, I realize how true that verse was.

Not only did I have to worry about myself, my family, my children, but also their children. So my Sansaar has grown so large. To detach from the Sansaar is increasingly becoming more and more difficult as the Sansaar grows. So this chapter opens up with the allegory of this Sansaar. It says: Urdhvamulah adhah shakham ashvattham prahuhu avyayam, Chandamsi Yasya Parnani, Yastam Veda sa Veda vit -- describing this Sansaar by using this allegory where it is like an upside-down tree. Now this allegory has been used in the Upanishads. In the Katha Upanishad, in the sixth portion, the Lord of death Yama indicates to Nachiketa that this Sansaar is like the upside-down tree.

The roots are in heaven and it is spreading in this world below. So my Sansaar right now is like that Urdhvamuna. Its source is up above. We always say anything which is higher say up Bhagavan kaha Upar. So this world as we see Bhagavad Gita and the Upanishad say the source is Apa. Source is somewhere beyond my perception.
