Urdhvamuna adas Sakaha all the branches are below. That which I see growing is here in my world. I see its effect, I don't see the cause. So in our normal tree, roots are not perceivable. They are not perceived. They are below under the ground.

But we see the trunk and we see the branches. And these branches continue to grow. And this Sansaar is like that. As we have learned a few lectures ago, the return in farming is thousand fold. So traditionally the farmers were the richest people. Even the kings were farmers.

Janakaraja found Sita while tilling the land, because farming was the most profitable business, most rewarding business. You sow one seed and a thousand come out. So the growth is exponential in anything in nature. The tree grows exponentially. My Sansaar is like that -- it grows exponentially beyond my control.

I do one action and it creates a thousand reactions. The allegory of the tree shows this: one action generates a thousand connections in my Sansaar. And its source is Apaba Urdhvamulaha Adasakaha. I see the branches of my Sansaar here below. Prahuhu Abyam the wise people talk about this tree of Sansaar is something which has the roots above the branches below Chandansi, Yasya, Panani.

The Vedas are its leaves. This verse about the Vedas being the leaves needs explanation because the connection is not immediately obvious. We have seen the commentaries by various scholars. Swamiji explains here that Bhagavan Sankaracharya says the tree is explained as Ashvattha. Because when you break down the word Ashvattha, it becomes "that which does not remain the same tomorrow."

Therefore this tree of Sansaar is explained as Asvathaha. And therefore that which promotes growth to this tree is the Vedas. The knowledge of Vedas, the instructions in Vedas, when followed by a person, his Sansaar grows healthily. By knowing this Sansaar and Prakriti, I more and more grow my Sansaar here. So these Vedas, the knowledge grows this tree of Sansaar in my life, in yours, in his Chandansi, Yasya, Pranani, Yastam, Vedasa, Veda Vid. And he who knows, he is a Veda knower.

One who knows both the roots and the branches of this tree, he knows the entire tree. So when I look at the tree I already know because I am a Veda knower of the trees that the roots are below in the ground. So There is a knowledge about where the roots are for the tree that makes my knowledge of the tree complete. So right now my knowledge of my Sansaar is incomplete. Because I only know what I see. So I only believe that what I see is the reality beyond my perception.

I don't see there is reality. The other day we are explaining myth to Meda and say myth is something, a made up story to explain something. And she said okay then my English homework is a myth because it's made of stories in it. So we consider that seeing is believing. Everything I see as real is real. Everything else is myth.

And therefore our knowledge is incomplete about this tree of Sansaar. I will know this tree of Sansaar completely when I know the roots, what the source of this tree of Sansaar is. That's why we are lacking for one side. So therefore I say one who knows this, he knows the Vedas. Vedas explain both the cause and effect. The roots and its tree.

So one who knows both is the Veda knower. Not the one who is only rooted in the Prakriti or this world. Only Yastam Vedasa Vedavid. Such a person knows the Vedas. Adhacha Urdhvam Prasuta Tashishaka, Guna Pravruddha, Vishe Pravalaha. So our Sansaar is now described using this allegory of a tree.

So that we understand how my world works. We talked about Prakriti in detail in last chapter but we have still stopped at. But these are the Gunas which are binding me and I need to go beyond these Gunas. Now we are learning about this Sansaar which is constantly changing. And how can I liberate myself from this Sansaar root? The cause for this is the Purusha.

Unless there is consciousness, there is no Sansaar. How this Sansaar is rooted in this consciousness is what I'm trying to understand. That this tree grows in my world. Adha Cha Urdham, Prasuta Tashya Shah. Its branches are up and also below my world of ideas. Prakriti in the lower world where I live in.

But I also have ideas about the higher nature. So my ideas go both ways. They go up and they go down. I think about mundane thing but I also think about the sacred things. So my branches of my Sansaar is spreading in both directions in my Prakriti in my day to day life. But also what is beyond my day to day life.

Guna Pravrudha, Vishaya pravalaha. These branches are nourished by the Gunas. They get more and more entangled into this prakruti. Bound by these Gunas I get more and more entangled in my world here because of the Gunas, my vasanas, my tendencies bind me to this world. My tendency is the music. So I somehow will always have to have some kind of a musical event because my Gunas is binding me.

So these Gunas are binding me into this world below. Guna pravruddha, vishaya pravalaha and the sense objects are the buds. So the sense objects have the potential to grow my Sansaar. If I see something which is of my liking, then my Sansaar will grow in that direction. As we have seen, given opportunity, I have these latent tendencies. And when the right environment is given to me, those tendencies will play out -- first as desires and then as actions.

So if I don't have a chance, if there is no field then those tendencies will remain dormant. So I may be the nicest person if there is no opportunity given to me to get bribed. I have never taken a bribe in my life, but I may have a tendency to take a bribe which was never given an opportunity. The sense objects are buds. This opportunity presenting itself will then grow that tendency in me as desire and into actions. So the sense objects are the buds which have the capability to grow my Sansaar in the direction of my tendencies, depending on whether I'm sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic.

The sense objects will grow my Sansaar in that direction. Adaachar mulani anusanthatani and while I am functioning in this world bound by these Gunas, I am also developing my roots in this prakrit in this world. When we first moved to Richmond, because we moved from Northern Virginia, we were pretty active there. You know, we were running all these classes and all my friends, they say, Neil, it's not too far, only two hours. So anytime we have an event, you come down to Northern Virginia. So first about few months we did that, you know, they will have a music party and they will call me and we go down there, we will have music party, we call them and they come down here.

Gradually we started having roots here in Richmond. You know, we have friends here, our own group, and we have classes. So now that we have grown our roots here in Richmond, we gradually get detached from those Northern Virginia friends. Now they call me and I say, yeah, but I don't have time -- I have activities here, I have classes here, so I can't come.
snippets.reflection:
The Ashvattha tree described in these verses presents a powerful mirror for self-examination. Notice how the word "Ashvattha" itself means "that which does not remain the same tomorrow" - reminding us that our entire world of relationships, possessions, and circumstances is in constant flux. Yet we keep planting our roots deeper into this ever-changing soil, establishing ourselves in jobs, cities, and social circles as if they were permanent. Consider today: where have you been growing roots that bind you more tightly to the impermanent? The verse tells us that the Vedas - knowledge itself - are the leaves that nourish this tree. Even our learning can become an attachment that expands rather than liberates us.

The remedy offered is remarkably specific: "asanga-shastrena dridhena" - with the strong weapon of non-attachment, cut this tree. This is not about abandoning responsibilities, but about loosening the grip of identification. Try this practice: at the end of each day, identify one thing you clung to - an opinion, an outcome, a preference - and consciously release it. Ask yourself: "What would remain of me if this were taken away?" The one who truly knows this tree, says Krishna, is the knower of the Vedas. True wisdom is not just understanding your world, but understanding its source and your relationship to that source.

snippets.title: Day 190: The Supreme Self
snippets.sanskrit:
ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं

निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा

न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः |
snippets.transliteration:
tataḥ padaṃ tatparimārgitavyaṃ yasmingatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ .

nirmānamohā jitasaṅgadoṣā adhyātmanityā vinivṛttakāmāḥ .

na tadbhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅko na pāvakaḥ .
verseTranslations: Beyond lies the Path, from which, when found, there is no return. This is the Primal God from whence this ancient creation has sprung.

The wise attain Eternity when, freed from pride and delusion, they have conquered their love for the things of sense; when, renouncing desire and fixing their gaze on the Self, they have ceased to be tossed to and fro by the opposing sensations, like pleasure and pain.
Neither sun, moon, nor fire shines there. Those who go thither never come back. For, O Arjuna, that is my Celestial Home!
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 15. We have seen in last two chapters the nature of Prakriti. Chapter 15 is Purushottami Yoga, Yoga of the Supreme Purusha. So now we are learning about the nature of Purusha. So the chapter begins with explaining the tree of Sansar. That Sansar which I find it very real and that which I consider is the real reality is explained in the first three verses.

So it's a Urdhvamoolaha Adashakaha. The allegory used is of a tree because it exponentially growing. Just like a tree grows over a period of time. So this tree of my Sansar is growing exponentially. But its real picture given here is Urdhvamoolaha. The source of this tree is up above and the branches are below and the leaves are below.

This tree of Sansar is growing in this world with the branches spreading all over. The more I know about this Sansar, the more this tree grows. The more I know about things and beings, the more my Sansaar grows -- networking more people. The more people I know, the more my network grows. The more people I have relationships with.

My network grows in this world. The Veda -- the knowledge -- increases my Sansaar, and as my Sansaar increases, I start developing roots, not knowing what my real source is, because the source is unavailable for me to see. So I develop roots here. The more actions and experiences I have, the more roots grow here. So the actions are creating new channels in this world and then establishing me in this Sansar.

I start thinking this is where I come from. I cannot find my real source. So I consider this Sansar as my source. So my roots are now growing in this world. And Bhagavan said that Naarupam Ashya iha Tatha Upalambita. Its overall form is not available to me.

I cannot figure out how this Sansaar started and how I got entangled into it. Naantah Nachadhi Nacha Samprateshta. I cannot figure out where it started, where it's going to end, and how it is rooted in this world. Asvattam Enam Suvirudamulam -- if you want to know the overall picture, we have learned before: one who knows both, he is the Veda Vida. One who knows the source and the Sansaar.

One who knows the Purusha and Prakriti together is the Veda Vit -- he is the knower of the Vedas. We know only part of it, like the Karmakanda, the actions. What we do in this world, we are aware of it, but we consider ourselves to be Gnani. But one says that's only partial knowledge. That's what is actually binding me to this world.

Because I don't have complete knowledge. Veda describes both the Purusha and Prakriti. Therefore one who knows both is the Veda Vida. To become a Veda knower, you have to go beyond this perception of Prakriti. Only with the weapon of non-attachment can I understand what is binding me to this world.

What will release me from this world and give me the overall picture is detachment. Therefore, with that weapon of detachment, firmly cut this tree. Tathaha Padam Tat Parim ar Gita Vyam Yasmin Gadhana Nivardanti Bhuyah. This statement comes over and over again in our scriptures. Tasmin Gada na Navaratanti Bhuyaha. One who goes there, he never comes back.

Because this life is just one small part of our existence. Our existence is infinite. It started when the world started and will continue till the world ends. This life is just a small sliver of my existence. So I'm trying to resolve all my issues during this lifetime.

But you say it will be nothing but a continuation. End of this life will not be the end of anything. End of the life will be just a milestone. Move on to the next mile. But if I really want to resolve all that I want to resolve in this life, I need to go to a place where I don't have to come back again and again to resolve my issues. My issues are I'm trying to avoid unhappiness.

I'm trying to go beyond sorrows. He said that can only happen if you go to a place where there are no sorrows or where there is no mortality. That place, that goal should be sought. Right now I'm seeking goals which are temporarily giving me happiness. My accomplishments, my acquirements, all these things are giving me happiness, but temporarily. So he said, if you want to go there, then you have to seek that goal.

Now what is that goal? Tamevacha Adhyam Purusam Prapadyam Yat Pravrutvicha, Prasuta Purani. Then now I seek refuge in that primeval Purusha, that original source from which stream forth all the ancient activity. The real source of this activity, the Sansar, is the Purusha. Unless I'm conscious about my Jagat, my Jagat does not exist. Unless you are conscious, your Jagat, your Jagat does not exist.

This world exists as it is because we are aware of it. Bhagavan said from that source, the consciousness is the source from which all the activity started. My Jagat comes into being as soon as I become aware of it. If I'm not aware of it, it does not exist for me. So Bhagavan said that seek that place from which all the activities started, that consciousness. So he said, now my goal is that I seek refuge in that primeval Purusha from which all the activities have started.

So we have defined the goal. We have defined the Sansar. The Sansar seem like roots are here. As we say, wherever we settle down, we form our roots. So now that I'm in Richmond, my roots are in Richmond. I have forgotten all about my previous roots.

People come from Northern Virginia. I don't have time for them. I come from India, but I go back and I feel uncomfortable there. All your formative years in your life were here. And suddenly you feel uncomfortable because you are detached from those roots. The things which we used to find so common, we can find anymore because we keep changing where we establish ourselves.

But once you establish yourself into your original source source, then you will not have to move around. We establish the goal that I need to take refuge in that primeval Purusha, the original source. And my original source, as I know is, everything that I know is because I'm aware of it. My consciousness is the source of all my experiences. My entire Jagat exists because I'm conscious. So I want to take refuge in that.

So then the next verse gives us the qualifications to be achieved -- or, when will I be able to achieve that state? It says: nirmana moha, jita sangha dosha, adhyatma nitya, vinivratta kamah, dvandvaihi vimuktaha, sukha dukha sangaihi gacchanti amudhaha padam avyayam tat. The six qualifications given here are something similar to what we have learned before, all throughout the Bhagavad Gita. And we have concluded already: not possible. We right away said, this is not possible for us. So we move on to the next chapter.

So first is Nirmana Moha -- the one who is free from pride and delusion. Mana and Moha: both relate to my assessment of my situation, and typically my assessment is overly liberal about myself. So Bhagavan said, Moha -- that over-assessment of myself -- creates the delusion about my importance. Once I have the correct assessment of myself, then I will not have the delusion. So Mana, my importance -- I can say, without me the world cannot function, my company cannot function.

I don't know what will happen if I'm not there tomorrow. This society cannot function unless I do this. That wrong perception that I am so important creates the situation which makes me unhappy. In the end all this impurities because of the attachment. My attachment creates the false perception. As we said, the people we like, no matter what they do, it's okay.

The same event if you watch on Fox News will be completely different than if you watch on MSNBC. The country is divided into two: those who watch Fox News and those who watch MSNBC. This is because of Sangha -- attachment. That attachment creates dosha, a false perception of reality. So maybe you have to watch CNN instead.

So it is my attachment which is creating false perception which is creating dosha in my perception. Therefore Jita Sanga Dosha 1 is victorious over attachment and the stain which comes with it. Adhatma nityaha established in the self. Our mind obviously have to have something to attach to. Our mind cannot stay without any object to think about. Mind does not exist if you don't think about anything.

Therefore, in deep sleep there is no mind because there are no objects. In my deep sleep, I don't exist. In deep sleep, the world does not exist. The mind does not exist in deep sleep. As soon as I wake up, the mind rises because all the things which I associate with come into its perception -- my house, my car, my family, my work, my job.

Very first moment in the mind is active. So all this talk about jita sangha do saha I say not going to happen. Because more I try to avoid attachment, I get attached more. So Bhagavan said then you have to create an attachment which is so powerful that no other attachment can touch you. That attachment with your own self Adhyatmanity. Constantly remembering that I'm not this body, not this mind, not this intellect.

These are my equipment. This world is temporary but myself is permanent. That constant churning in your mind will give you the ability to detach from Other things. So adhyatma nitya -- then you are free from desires. My memory bank is the root cause of all the problems. That's why when we see somebody, we don't see him or her as they are right now.

Right now we remember everything. Our encounter with that person in the past. If the memory bank said the encounter was good, the person is good. The memory encounter wasn't that pleasant. The person is not good. So this memory bank creates ideas and then it creates a desire and the mind starts longing for it.

If we stop power of this memory bank to guide our perceptions, Bhagwanji will see things as they are. If I can judge a person from the day I'm looking at him it will be very different than all the baggage of all my experiences with him before. If you judge him from what he does today then it will be a very different perception. Even the person who is a big criminal. But once he resolved to be good, he should be considered good. Because he should be judged on what he's doing today not what he has done in the past.

But we obviously cannot function that way. We have to find all his resume, what he did in the past, and then only can we judge people. Bhagavan said, vinivrutta kamaha -- if you don't do that, there won't be any desire to do anything which is not appropriate. Dvandvai vimuktaha -- we have learned this over and over again. It is the most difficult concept to understand: being beyond pairs of opposites.

That does not mean the pairs of opposites go away. Pairs of opposites remain as they are. Sukha du kha mana apman they all remain exactly where they are. Winter and summer all those things remain. But I become indifferent to them. That's a dvandvai hi vimuktaha.

Just like in the last chapter we have learned what is the first quality of a guna titaha. He's a Gunatidha one he does not despise when the gunas are present. Also he does not long for them and they are not present when Tamas is there and despise and seek sattva. But I take them as they are and not get attached to them. So therefore he said dhvandvayihi vimukta he is not affected by one or the other.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal both the destination and the qualifications needed to reach it. "Yasmin gata na nivartanti bhuyah" - having gone there, one never returns. This is not a place in space but a state of being where the cycle of seeking, finding, losing, and seeking again finally ends. The primeval Purusha from which all activity has sprung forth is described as the ultimate refuge. Today, notice how much of your energy goes into seeking temporary refuges - in accomplishments, relationships, entertainment - only to find yourself seeking again tomorrow. What would it mean to seek refuge in the source itself?

The qualifications listed - freedom from pride and delusion (nirmana-moha), victory over attachment (jita-sanga-dosha), constant abidance in the Self (adhyatma-nitya), freedom from desires (vinivrtta-kamah), and liberation from the pairs of opposites (dvandvair-vimuktah) - may seem impossibly high. But verse six offers hope: that supreme abode is not illumined by sun, moon, or fire, because it is self-luminous. Your own awareness is that light. Practice this: when you feel buffeted by life's dualities - praise and blame, success and failure - pause and ask: "Who is aware of both? Who remains unchanged?" That unchanging witness is a doorway to the place from which there is no return.

snippets.title: Day 191: Two Purushas
snippets.sanskrit:
ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः |

शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः |

श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च |
snippets.transliteration:
mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ .

śarīraṃ yadavāpnoti yaccāpyutkrāmatīśvaraḥ .

śrotraṃ cakṣuḥ sparśanaṃ ca rasanaṃ ghrāṇameva ca .
verseTranslations: It is only a very small part of My Eternal Self, which is the life of the universe, drawing round itself the six senses, the mind the last, which have their source in Nature.
When the Supreme Lord enters a body or leaves it, He gathers these senses together and travels on with them, as the wind gathers perfume while passing through the flowers.
He is the perception of the ear, the eye, the touch, the taste and the smell, yea and of the mind also; and the enjoyment of the things which they perceive is also His.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 15, Purushottam Yoga, Yoga of the Supreme Purusha, the Supreme Being. In chapter 15, we have started out by realizing that my own source -- when I look at my life story, when I look at where I came from and what my world is -- it seems like Bhagavan says it's an upside-down tree. It seems like my source is somewhere up above. I right now cannot perceive where it is. Somewhere beyond my cognition, somewhere beyond my understanding, is my source. Urdhva Mulaha Adhah Sakaha.

My source is somewhere up above, but the branches and the leaves are in this world. And then it also seems like my roots are now getting established in this world. This is how I see myself and my world. I cannot find my source somewhere beyond my cognition, somewhere beyond my understanding. The self which I considered me has a source which I cannot recognize. And then we have seen that Bhagavan said that the perception of that is unavailable.

Knowledge of my source, of that supreme Being is unavailable to most of us. But those who have achieved that sense of equanimity, nirmoha nisanga, those qualities which you have seen, jita sangha do saha, who have got over this evil of attachment, all these qualities which they have achieved, to them it is available the self which is immutable, imperishable. They recognize that the self in me is the self everywhere. Self in me, the self in everyone else. There is no other existence other than my own self. However, at this time it is not available to me and I have become the individualized ego.

It refers to my body, my mind, my intellect. So the verses which we have seen say, how did that happen? The ones who have the knowledge about the self, they know that the source -- that Urdhva Mulaha, that source -- is in a place where there is no sun shining, no moon shining, no light of fire there. But once reaching that state, no one ever comes back. I particularly, right now, cannot see that as my world or myself. So how did that come about?

This ignorance came about. So Verse seven says: Mama Eva Amsha Jiva Loke Jiva Bhutah Sanatanah. An eternal portion of mine, establishing in this world of beings, associating itself with the world of beings, becomes a Jiva -- Jiva Bhutah. When I associate myself with the India Association, I become one of the members of the India Association, just like every other member. I associate myself with Chinmaya Mission; I become a Chinmaya Mission member just like all other members.

So when this Supreme also associates with the Jiva Loka, the Prakriti, he becomes one of the Prakriti. He becomes one of them. He becomes the Jiva Bhuta, associating with the world of beings. As we know, we have learned in chapter 13 that Bhagavan told Arjuna: "Idam shariram kaunteya kshetram iti abhidhiyate." This body is considered to be the field, which is the Prakriti. And the one who knows this field is the knower of the field. So at my individual level, this field, the Prakriti, is the body.

One who knows is the knower. Knower is the Purusha. Purusha functioning through the Prakriti. We have seen in the 14th chapter the qualities of the Prakriti. The Prakriti has three gunas. These gunas bind this Purusha to the Prakriti Satvaraja Santamas.

So right now myself, the consciousness in me, is bound by this body, mind and intellect -- by the qualities, the gunas of the body, mind and intellect. Now our goal in this chapter is to understand the nature of the Purusha. Therefore we are going through this exercise of knowing: what is the nature of the Prakriti? What is the nature of the Purusha? So how did this ignorance come about? That is basically our goal.

So he said, Bhagavan said Mama Eva asa a portion of mine eternal portion. Because once we say, the portion may be separated from that whole or something which once it gets separated, maybe get destroyed. This portion eternal of mine. Something which cannot be divisible but seem to be divided. We have seen the classic example of this space outside the room. Space is indivisible.

No matter how much we try, you cannot divide the space. However, it does seem divided between this room and that room -- this space, the kitchen, the bathrooms. And because of the conditioning, in a similar manner, the supreme being, even though indivisible, seems like a portion of it is divided from it and now, associated with the Prakriti, becomes a jiva. Once it is now associated with Prakriti and becomes a jiva, Bhagavan said: Manah Shashthani Indriyani Prakriti Sthani Karshati.

Once abiding in this Prakriti, it attracts or obtains the five senses and the manas. So now it has its own identity as this limited self, associated with those six things it obtained, which we call jiva. Those six are considered the internal instrument, or Antahkarana. Bahishkarana is this body; Antahkarana, the six things. The Jiva, that consciousness, acquired its own equipment. And the next verse says, what is now the relationship with that equipment which is obtained by the portion of the jiva? So for example, in this case, this room space is acquired.

The length and breadth and height of this room, this nature of this wall, floor and ceiling, they would define this room. And I'm leasing this room. In the lease I write down, this room is 20ft by 14ft. So many square feet has height of 8ft. Total volume is this. That's how the rent is decided.

But it is defined by what? By the wall, floor and ceiling. So now the Jiva defines itself as a limited being by the mind and the five senses, the six. So that's its equipment to function with the other jivas. It's called antahkarana. Next the verse says: Sariram Yat ava apnuthi, Yaatschaapi utkramati, Ishvaraha.

So this consciousness is now the Ishvara of my self. My consciousness is the Lord of my being. As long as I am conscious, I can speak, I can hear, I can touch, I can smell, I can taste. All this is possible only because of the consciousness in me. And therefore consciousness is my Lord. This Lord, when it obtains the body -- this gross body is something different from the mind and senses which we are describing. It obtained this body as a vehicle, where it requires one.

I have software, but my computer is now broken. All I need is new hardware. Now when it obtains a body, Yat chapi utkramati. When it leaves the body, it takes this subtle body with it. Now five senses, not the sense organs, the senses. I can see only when the mind is there.

So sometimes we are gazing but not seeing. We have all heard this before. We are hearing but not listening. Because although the equipment is functioning properly, the translator -- the mind -- is not there. The experiencer, the mind, is not there. This experiencer, the translator, is the internal instrument.

This verse says, when this Ishvara, the consciousness, right now, conditioned by this mind and senses, it leaves this body and obtains the body what it does. Grihitva etani samyati vayu gandha nivashayat. Just as air moves from one place to another, it carries the fragrance of the things which it touches, it carries with it. So that's why sometimes the air smells good when the air freshener. And if there is a toilet not properly cleaned, that smell also come through. Air does not discriminate.

It carries all of whatever comes with it. In the same way, the Ishvara, the consciousness, when it leaves this body or obtains a new body, it carries these six like a fragrance. Not in any fashion an actual experience, not in any fashion an actual sense organ, but just the fragrance of what it has experienced, it carries with it. Therefore, when we move from one body to another, Bhagavan says, what carries those vasanas? Vasa Gandha -- fragrance, vasanas. This collective accumulation of my experiences is the tendencies. So this verse clearly says how the jiva was created.

The eternal portion, one portion of this whole supreme being identifying with this mind and intellect, becomes a jiva, conditioned consciousness. Now this conditioned consciousness, its own identity. Now it wants to exercise its desires and vasanas through a body. As long as it acquires the body, it unbundles the vasanas and start functioning. So some child, right from the beginning, shows a tendency for music, a tendency for dance, a tendency for mathematics, whatever that is. And some show a tendency for boxing -- because those vasanas are carried with it, at least according to our shastras.

So when it leaves one body and obtains another, the body is like a temporary abode. The jiva takes over the body and uses it as long as it is functional. When the body is no longer functional, it moves on to the next one, carrying those vasanas -- those collective experiences and tendencies -- with it. The next verse says: Shotram Chakshuhus parsanam charasanam granam evacha Adhisthaya Manishchayam, vishaya anupasevate. So what happens when the jiva takes a new body? This jiva, the conditioned consciousness, having its own tendencies, unbundles those tendencies and uses this body to fulfill those desires, acting in the field which is appropriate for this.

So Bhagavan said: Shrotram -- presiding over the ear; Chakshuh -- the eyes; Sparshanam -- the touch with the skin; Rasanam -- taste; Ghranam -- smell; and also the mind. This consciousness, presiding over these five senses and the mind, now enjoys -- Vishayan Upasevate. He now enjoys the sense objects. I somehow want to go and get some music and enjoy it. You want to go and get ESPN and enjoy the sport. Depending on your vasana.

The last verse says: Utkramantam sthitam va api bhunjanam va gunanvitam, vimudha na anupashyanti, pashyanti gnana chakshushah. Utkramantam -- while leaving; sthitam -- while it is staying in this body; api bhunjanam va gunanvitam -- or enjoying by association with the gunas. This consciousness in me, which is the Lord of my being, I do not recognize if I'm ignorant about it. I'm not recognizing that the one who is enjoying is someone other than my body. The one who is thinking is something other than my mind.

One who has the knowledge is something other than my intellect. I as the deluded person. Deluded in a sense that I do not have sense of reality. Deluded doesn't mean something. Someone who does not have sense of reality is deluded. So when David Cooperfield shows us that the Statue of Liberty is disappearing, we are not stupid, but we are deluded by his trick, by his illusion.

So one who is deluded doesn't know how that thing is happening. David Copperfield and his staff know exactly how it is happening, because they have Gnana Chakshu. They know exactly how this thing is being done. We, on the other hand, the television viewers, do not know it. Therefore to us it's a wonderment how this thing is happening.

The one who is not educated in this -- Vimudha Na Anupashyanti -- does not see that the Ishvara, the enjoyer of all this, is the consciousness in me. Consciousness in me is the controller of the senses, mind, and all these transactions taking place in my life. Pashyanti Gnana Chakshushah -- but one whose eyes of knowledge are opened, one who has understood how this thing is working, he sees this. And therefore, what he seeks as his goal -- even when he was deluded, even when I'm deluded right now, still the motive, my goal, is that I want peace.
snippets.reflection:
"Mamaivamsho jivaloke jivabhutah sanatanah" - an eternal portion of Myself becomes the jiva in this world of beings. This is one of the most profound declarations in the Gita. You are not separate from the Divine; you are an eternal fragment that has become conditioned by association with mind and senses. Like space confined by walls becoming "room space," your infinite nature has taken on the appearance of limitation. The beautiful metaphor of wind carrying fragrance illustrates how the subtle body - your accumulated tendencies and impressions - travels from life to life, just as breeze carries the scent of flowers. Consider: what fragrances are you cultivating? What vasanas will your consciousness carry forward?

The verse says this Ishvara (the Lord within) presides over the ear, eye, touch, taste, smell, and mind, enjoying sense objects through them. This means that every experience you have is actually the Divine experiencing through you. Today, try this contemplation: as you see, hear, taste, touch, or smell anything, remind yourself that consciousness is the true experiencer, not the sense organs. The deluded do not recognize this truth - they think the body-mind is the enjoyer. But the wise, with the eye of knowledge (jnana-chakshusah), see that the same consciousness that animates you animates all beings. What would change in your interactions today if you truly saw every person as an eternal portion of the same Divine?

snippets.title: Day 192: The Highest Truth
snippets.sanskrit:
उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम् |

यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम् |

यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम् |
snippets.transliteration:
utkrāmantaṃ sthitaṃ vāpi bhuñjānaṃ vā guṇānvitam .

yatanto yoginaścainaṃ paśyantyātmanyavasthitam .

yadādityagataṃ tejo jagadbhāsayate.akhilam .
verseTranslations: The ignorant do not see that it is He Who is present in life and Who departs at death or even that it is He Who enjoys pleasure through the Qualities. Only the eye of wisdom sees.
The saints with great effort find Him within themselves; but not the unintelligent, who in spite of every effort cannot control their minds.
Remember that the Light which, proceeding from the sun, illumines the whole world, and the Light which is in the moon, and That which is in the fire also, all are born of Me.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 15, Purushottam yoga, yoga of the Supreme Spirit, the Supreme Purusha. We have talked about Prakriti. The Prakriti has three aspects, the Sattva, rajas and Tamas. And this permutation combination of the Sattva, Rajas and Tamas create this multiplicity in this world. When we associate with it, it creates a sansar I in the world. In that relationship, we get lost.

And that relationship creates either the conducive experience or not conducive experience. Some gives us joy and some gives us unhappiness. So that's our Sansar. In that Sansar, we try to understand through various ways, to understand what gives me happiness, how can I achieve the permanent happiness. So, as we have seen before, our entire life is divided into two pursuits. One is to achieve happiness and other is to avoid unhappiness.

So this chapter starts with saying, well, let's understand how your Sansar starts. In the first place, place, it seems like it is rooted here, but its source is up above. Up above, in other sense, there's something which is beyond my perception, something which is beyond my understanding. From that source, this sansar grows and it is nourished by the Veda, the leaves and branches. The more I know about this sansar, more it grows, more I know about any subject, it becomes more and more complex. And even though my knowledge grows, my insecurity increases.

That there may be even a lot more that I do not know. The more we know about the atom, the less we know about the reality of what the atom actually is. In physics, when knowledge was limited, people could say, "Well, I have understood everything and there is nothing more to be known." But the more we know, the more complex it becomes. This Sansaar is like that. This Sansaar is the theme of all scriptural advice and practices.

So this chapter tries to make this very clear to us: remaining in the Sansaar, getting attached to the Sansaar, will never give us what we seek. So the very first advice in this chapter says, with the strong axe of detachment, cut this tree of Sansaar. Detach yourself from this Sansaar. This is the only way to achieve that permanent happiness which you are seeking. And then we have discussed what is the nature of that self.

If I detach from this sensa, what am I getting attached to? You are getting attached to that supreme self. Having gone there, non returns. Once you have achieved that identification, there won't be any delusion. You will never come back to this ignorance. So as we had seen before, this Maya is created out of ignorance.

Maya is called Maya because it gives an appearance of something that which is not. I always give the example of David Copperfield, and I thought he must have disappeared somewhere. But he was in the news a few days ago. He was in a courtroom explaining how the illusion works. So this is the first time he has had to give the secret out in open court -- how he does that illusion -- because somebody got hurt. So it is an illusion.

But till we know how it happens, it's a mystery for us. So this Sansaar is like that illusion -- even though it seems so real, we all come to understand from the scriptures that it is an illusion. It is the Maya, and we want to get out of this illusion. Once we understand, then anytime David Copperfield performs his act, we will not be in much confusion. We know what's happening there. If you have that vision of both at the same time, you've got it made.

So therefore, the one who understands both -- one who can see this Sansaar and the source of Sansaar -- he knows what the reality is. To get out of this ignorance in which we think this Sansaar is so real, you have to develop some mental capabilities. And we have seen those qualities: Nirmana moha, Jita sanga dosha.

One who is beyond the pride and whatever the opposite of that. And also jita sangha do saha who has a victory over attachment. We are trying to achieve that. But then we also want to understand what is the nature of myself. Then what is it that now considers that I as I am? And what is the relationship between the supreme self?

So we have learned that Mama Evamsha Jiva Loke Jiva Bhutah. The world of individual beings, where each one considers himself or herself to be an individual. We all consider ourselves to be a very complete individual, independent of each other. That's our general understanding. We think that I am by myself and the world is out there to compete with me. It's actually the other way around.

I am there because the world is there. But that's never clear in our mind. So when one makes the connections, there's an all-pervading supreme self which acts as the source of all beings. When it comes to me as the individual, only a portion of that self associates with this mind and intellect. It basically, as we have seen, draws the five senses and mind from the Prakriti.

So everything that I consider myself right now belongs to the Prakriti. My mind, my intellect, my body. And we have seen previously in detail how this works. That the body is made of the grossified element. The five elements which has come into it gross forms. So you can identify them as five different elements.

And also we know where it comes from and where it goes. We know that the body is made of food. It's very simple for us to really follow this food chain. When I digested, it became my body. When I die, the same body will become food for somebody else. And the cycle continues.

What is not simple for us is to understand the subtle body. We always thought that my consciousness, my mind and my intellect are the thinkers who think. So we consider that as our real self, which is driving this body to do what it does. The distinction made here is that those are also part of the Prakriti, the inert nature. Nature is inert in all forms. It becomes sentient by association with the consciousness.

Just like we know for sure that my eye cannot see. I know now very much. I know more about eye than I'm supposed to know. You know it basically no different than my glasses. So at least previously I had a God's given lens inside. Now I have both acrylic lenses on both sides and they are shifted.

The guy said, don't worry about it. So it is no different than any other thing which breaks down in my house, my clothes or whatever. You can repair it and make it good again. So this body, mind and intellect are from this inert world. It becomes sentient only when it is associated with the consciousness. As long as I am aware, my eye can see.

And I am not aware of what's happening around my eye cannot see. We are seeing but not registering that what is there. Or we are hearing but not listening. Because the mind is not there. And the mind itself also cannot do anything, because it is made up of inert material.

Vedanta says that before these five elements were grossified, those five elements existed in their primordial state, which they call tanmatra. From these tanmatras, the mind and intellect are made. Those are still inert equipment, just like our body. But when the consciousness shines on that mind and intellect, then mind and intellect become capable of interpreting the experience which is happening. Only when consciousness is present and aware can I see and can my mind interpret -- even when I am alive. But when I am in deep sleep, the mind and intellect are in a dormant state because consciousness is not available to them.

Therefore the mind cannot interpret any experience in deep sleep. Therefore I wake up and say "I don't know what happened." That "I don't know" and "I know" is my entire world. So the avidya is the root cause of my confusion about who I am. Avidya is part of Maya. So that avidya -- "I don't know" -- will associate with the Purusha, which is all knowledge.

That portion of me comes to say "I know." And that "I know" creates the notion that I, the individual, know. So now I have created an entity called jiva. That jiva -- the consciousness identifying with the mind and intellect, considering itself to be an entity by itself, which is capable of knowing. So that jiva, when associated with the atma, which is the pure consciousness, is called jivatma. Mind and intellect identifying itself as an entity, associating with the consciousness, creates jivatma.

This jivatma remains intact as long as the conditionings are there. The standard example: the room space. The space was always here. But this very fact that space was here attracted somebody to build a building. Some developer who has an idea to create a building sees this space and says, "I can build a building here." So this space, by its very existence, attracted walls and floor and ceiling into this space. Now it has created a room space -- now it's the conditioned space.

So as long as this conditioning remains, the room space remains. This mind and intellect, once they come in association with the consciousness, identify with the limited consciousness which is reflecting through them and become a jivatma. This jivatma experiences this world through those five senses and the mind. Then we have seen that when this self leaves this body, one thing is sure -- we have seen people dying. So it follows that I will die too.

So what happens at the time of death is always a mystery to us. Bhagavan clarifies here that what happens here is that jivatma will leave this body carrying the fragrance with it off all the experiences and tendencies, all the fragrance of the mind and intellect which it has experienced through the senses, it will go with it. So Atmabodha actually describes the subtle body. What dies is only the gross body. The subtle body leaves as jivatma because it is constantly identifying with the consciousness which is all-pervading. It's like a mobile home or a car.

The space inside the car is identified with the car, but it's not actually different from the space outside. It can move from here to Hanover County, and still the car space remains -- it moved from Germany to the United States, and it's still the same car space. But now we know from our overall perspective, it's not the same space when it is here versus there. If the space belonged to Henrico, it's the space belonging to Henrico; if in Hanover, it belongs to Hanover. But because the conditioning is moving, and the space is omnipresent.

Wherever the conditioning moves, the identification moves with it. This jivatma associating with all pervading consciousness. When it moves from one body to another, it still identifies itself as an entity that is called a subtle body living so. So subtle body is the only thing which survives my death. And that subtle body is described in atma bodha. There are 17 elements: five pranas, ten senses -- pancha prana, dasha indriya -- that's 15.

Then mind and intellect make 17. These 17 remain as a subtle body -- not exactly the way we understand today. So not my physical eye is going to go, but the capacity and ability to remember that experience will go along with it, and that will then start its journey again. When I look at this experience, I think that when I die, my existence will end. So the verses we have seen say: Utkramantam sthitam va api bhunjanam va gunanvitam, vimudha na anupashyanti, pashyanti gnana chakshushah.
snippets.reflection:
These verses draw a stark contrast between the deluded and the wise. The ignorant (vimudha) do not perceive the Self even as it departs at death, dwells in the body, or enjoys experiences through the gunas. Like watching a magic show without understanding the mechanism, we remain mystified by life's appearances. But those with the "eye of knowledge" (jnana-chakshusah) see the truth. The yogis who strive with purified minds perceive the Self established within themselves, while those with unprepared minds, despite their efforts, cannot perceive it. Ask yourself honestly: am I striving with a prepared mind, or am I expecting results without the inner work?

Verse 12 offers a magnificent contemplation: the light of the sun that illumines the whole world, the light in the moon, the light in fire - all proceed from the Supreme. This is not poetic metaphor but a profound teaching about the nature of reality. Every light you see is borrowed light, reflecting that one original consciousness. Practice this today: when you see sunlight streaming through a window, when you notice moonlight, when you see a flame - pause and remember "tat tejo viddhi mamakam" - know that brilliance to be Mine. Let every source of illumination become a reminder that your own awareness, which makes all perception possible, is that same divine light manifesting through you.

snippets.title: Day 193: The Cosmic Tree
snippets.sanskrit:
गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा |

अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः |

सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो
snippets.transliteration:
gāmāviśya ca bhūtāni dhārayāmyahamojasā .

ahaṃ vaiśvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṃ dehamāśritaḥ .

sarvasya cāhaṃ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo mattaḥ smṛtirjñānamapohanañca .
verseTranslations: I enter this world and animate all My creatures with My vitality; and by My cool moonbeams I nourish the plants.
Becoming the fire of life, I pass into their bodies and, uniting with the vital streams of Prana and Apana, I digest the various kinds of food.
I am enthroned in the hearts of all; memory, wisdom and discrimination owe their origins to Me. I am He Who is to be realised in the scriptures; I inspire their wisdom and I know their truth.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 15, Purushottama Yoga, Yoga of the Supreme Being. And so far we have seen Bhagavan saying that everything that you see, everything that you can perceive, and everything that you can experience is nothing but me. In the last few verses we have seen he said: the light which is from the sun, which illumines this entire world of yours, is nothing but my light -- it comes from me alone. The light from the moon which nourishes the plants is nothing but my own light. And the fertility in this soil which supports all the beings on this planet is nothing but me. My mind, my intellect, which is aware of this world --

That awareness comes from him. And this world which I experience also comes from him. Then he says, not only that this being is supported by me, but all this functions within the sentient beings which makes them living beings. I support those functions. Aham Vaishva Narobhatva Prani Namdha Masridha. Residing in the bodies of all the beings, I digest these four types of food.

Basically, as I said, our ancestors were fond of classification, so they always have some classification. Foods are of four types. And once you look at what the four types of foods are, there's nothing left out. So any food that a being can eat, it gets digested. Bhagavan said, by me residing in this body as this eternal fire, this internal fire. So everything I see, everything I hear, everything I experience -- there is really nothing other than the Lord.

And this somewhat, if you really think logically fits into the normal belief, a normal declaration in all religion that the God is omnipresent. Once something we have taken as omnipresent, there is no room left for anything else. So if we say that God is omnipresent in this world, then there is no room for you and I as an individual other than God. As we have discussed so many times from the physics perspective, if I say I am omnipresent in my chair, there is no room for anything else or anybody else. So now everything in this chair has to be me. Whether it's my leg, it's my hand, my torso, whatever, it's all me.

So Bhagavan said, I am omnipresent. And therefore all the experiences illumined by your consciousness is nothing but me alone. So we have so far seen Bhagavan is giving his identity. What is the identity of the supreme Being? That there is none other than that being exist. So the last verse 14 we say prani nam deha masirithah prana pana samayukta Pachami annam Chaturvedam.

I can see at the macro level that the Lord is everywhere. At the micro level, the Lord is also in my body. This body, mind and intellect come from this world. This world is nothing but his expression. But the functions within me -- which I think differentiate me from the insentient world called matter -- make me consider myself as something completely different than matter.

That's why my body is so spatial. Because I don't think it's a matter. I consider that's me. But that me from the matter to me is because of these functions which makes me a living being. These pranas and apanas, all these activities happening in my body. And Bhagawan says that also I control by living in your body.

In the next verse it says, Sarvasya chaham Hrudhisan niveshtah matthaha smriti gnanam upo hanamcha vedeshcha sarve ham eva vedyo vedantakrut veda Videva chaham. So what is my relationship to the Lord now? He said, I am residing in the hearts of all beings. How do I know? This great Lord is everywhere, and that may overwhelm my intellect. I am a seeker seeking my experience or realization of my Lord. Now he says, the light of the sun is me, the light of the moon is me.

I am the fertility in the earth. Then we give up and say, I will never be able to reach him. Somebody says, "Neil, if you want to do something, why don't you call up the President?" If you tell me to call a project manager, I can think about it. But make a cold call to the President of the United States, Barack Obama?

That really doesn't sound like a practical thing to do. So we say, well, if Bhagavan is so supreme, then there is no way that I'll ever be able to get connected with him. So now Bhagawan said, no, that's not the truth. The truth is I'm residing in the hearts of all beings. Sarvasenni, Vistaha, Matthaha, Smrutihi, Gnanam and Upohanam. Because I'm residing in the hearts of all beings.

And because of me they have a memory. Because of me they have knowledge. And because of me they have forgetfulness or ignorance. Everything which I know today is because of my consciousness. I'm aware of my experiences, so it becomes my memory. I'm aware of what I have learned.

So my memory has become my knowledge. If somebody says what month comes after January? Well, I learned in kg, it's February. That's nothing but my memory. I consider that as my knowledge. But it's actually my memory.

All this, Bhagavan said, comes from me. I will only remember if I'm conscious. Without that, I won't. But more important than this knowledge is also forgetfulness. If I remember everything that happened, there won't be any room for me to learn anything new. The IT guys were telling me, "Neil, our server is really getting to capacity now."

We had been in business for 12 years and we keep piling all this data on it. I think it's a time for you to change the server. It's 80% capacity you really have to have. So I said, well, I'll tell you what. We can't really afford a new server right now. Purge all the old projects which are done five years ago.

I don't need them anymore. Purge them so I can put new projects onto my server. Forgetfulness is the gift from God to us. If we don't forget, we will not be able to learn anything new. All the bad memories of our childhood literally get erased from us. That's why we also recall our childhood as so good.

My college days were so good. Because the bad memories are erased. What you remember is all the fun you had. Now there are some bad memories that remain there. But most of it get erased. So I had a nice childhood when I was growing up.

Because the Bhagavan has given a gift of forgetting things which is not useful to you. Forgetting things which removes all the unnecessary ignorance out of your mind. So you can fill that void with new knowledge. Sarvasya Chaham Rudhisa Nivestaha. I am residing in the hearts of all. So we obviously in my heart Bhagavan is here.

Swamiji makes it clear. And obviously you and I can logically say "heart" is not that physiological organ literally pumping the blood. It is the core of my being. What I consider "me" is my heart. What is at the heart of Richmond city?

What is at the heart of this community? What I consider the core of my being. Bhagavan said, I reside there. The core of my being is my awareness about me. My awareness about me, makes me who I am. That has these good qualities about compassion, charity, love.

But once I decide in there, when my God is invoked then I will have this good quality manifest. When I am in a divine mood, then I will have love, compassion, charity, all the good qualities. When I am forgetting about my Lord, my being, then I will have all the negative qualities. Because those negative qualities are the product of my ignorance. I hate somebody, I'm evil to someone. All these things are because of the lack of my connection with my core of my being, my heart, my Lord who makes me who I am.

So Bhagavan says, Sarvasyacham, Hrudhi Sanniveshtah. I am residing in all the beings at the core of their heart. When I am really aware of myself, I can only manifest my divine qualities -- love, compassion, charity. Whatever the good qualities we think of. It's only when I'm devoid of those connections that I will have jealousy, hatred. He said, Matthaha Smritih.

Because of me is the memory. Because of me is the knowledge. Because I'm aware of myself, I have a memory. Because I'm aware of myself, I have a knowledge. And because I'm aware of myself, I have forgetfulness. I am also our ignorance.

I am as much aware of my knowledge as I am aware of my ignorance. "Neel, do you know medicine?" "No, I know nothing about it." "Do you know architecture?" "Yes, tell me all about it." I am aware of my knowledge. I am also aware of my ignorance.

Bhagavan said, it's all because of my presence in you, the consciousness. I reside in you as your being. I am the Vedas and I am that needs to be known. I am the author of the Vedanta and knower of the Vedas. Now Vedas, as we have seen, they are our scriptures. What do they represent?

They represent knowledge. The knowledge compiled by the sages becomes Veda. This knowledge encompass everything. Utilitarian knowledge as well as the divine knowledge, secular as well as sacred. Now the secular knowledge obviously also come from my awareness. I learn things and I use it.

I am all this knowledge that is out there. And I am only the one to be known. And Veda in the end says what? The only thing to be known is your own self. Once you realize yourself, there is nothing more to be known. Having reached that place, we have learned that no one comes back.

That's what Veda says. That's what Vedanta said. In the end of Veda, the section which deals with the Upanishads and the knowledge about yourself is called Vedanta. So who gave this knowledge of the self to the Rishis? Bhagavan said, I did. And therefore there is no authorship in our Vedas of who wrote this Vedanta.

There is no authorship because it is a revealed knowledge. That is what is remembered. So I can say I thought about it many times. Honestly, I can tell you, I give some examples in my lectures. And I really sometimes feel good that I really thought about really neat example. Then I read Swamiji's commentary and I find the exact same example in it.

I said, how did that happen? I thought, I thought about it. What I really forget is I'd been listening to Swamiji since I was 16 years old. So all this thing which I think, I'm thinking fresh, new is literally come from what I heard since I was 16 year old. Now, I may not have understood the time, I may not have got the gist of it at the time, but things stay with you. Then we are really churning on that idea.

Things come out and now you think, I invented this idea. And therefore in Hinduism there is no originality. The only originality is with him. Everything else we do is just relearn. So Bhagavan says, therefore I am the author of Vedanta. Now I am the one to be known.

Everything which I can consider is the quest of my life. If Bhagavan said, is me, know that I am at the core of your being. So how difficult would it be for you to know your core of your being? Not that difficult, Bhagavan said, as long as you turn your gaze towards yourself. So these verses are obviously very contemplative verses and not really intellectual verses, but contemplative verses. But going back to our understanding of what is real, what is unreal, what is transitory or temporary, and what is permanent.
snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the Supreme Person as the sustainer of all existence at every level - cosmic, earthly, and personal. Krishna declares that He enters the earth and sustains all beings with His energy, becomes the moon (Soma) and nourishes all plants with life-giving essence, and as the digestive fire (Vaishvanara) within all living beings, digests the four kinds of food. This teaching dissolves the boundary between sacred and mundane. The very act of digestion happening in your body right now is a divine function. The next time you eat, consider: the fire that transforms food into energy is not merely a biological process but the Lord functioning within you through prana and apana.

Verse 15 is especially intimate: "Sarvasya chaham hridi sannivishto" - I am seated in the hearts of all beings. From Me come memory, knowledge, and their removal. This means your capacity to remember, to know, and even to forget is a divine gift. Forgetfulness, often seen as a flaw, is actually a blessing - it allows old wounds to heal and makes room for new learning. The verse concludes by stating that the Lord is what is to be known through all the Vedas, is the author of Vedanta, and the knower of the Vedas. Today, reflect: if the Supreme dwells in my heart as the source of all my knowing, how far do I need to search? Turn your attention inward, to the very awareness that makes all experience possible, and recognize that the goal of all seeking is already present as the seeker.
