Swamiji makes it clear. And obviously you and I can logically say "heart" is not that physiological organ literally pumping the blood. It is the core of my being. What I consider "me" is my heart. What is at the heart of Richmond city?

What is at the heart of this community? What I consider the core of my being. Bhagavan said, I reside there. The core of my being is my awareness about me. My awareness about me, makes me who I am. That has these good qualities about compassion, charity, love.

But once I decide in there, when my God is invoked then I will have this good quality manifest. When I am in a divine mood, then I will have love, compassion, charity, all the good qualities. When I am forgetting about my Lord, my being, then I will have all the negative qualities. Because those negative qualities are the product of my ignorance. I hate somebody, I'm evil to someone. All these things are because of the lack of my connection with my core of my being, my heart, my Lord who makes me who I am.

So Bhagavan says, Sarvasyacham, Hrudhi Sanniveshtah. I am residing in all the beings at the core of their heart. When I am really aware of myself, I can only manifest my divine qualities -- love, compassion, charity. Whatever the good qualities we think of. It's only when I'm devoid of those connections that I will have jealousy, hatred. He said, Matthaha Smritih.

Because of me is the memory. Because of me is the knowledge. Because I'm aware of myself, I have a memory. Because I'm aware of myself, I have a knowledge. And because I'm aware of myself, I have forgetfulness. I am also our ignorance.

I am as much aware of my knowledge as I am aware of my ignorance. "Neel, do you know medicine?" "No, I know nothing about it." "Do you know architecture?" "Yes, tell me all about it." I am aware of my knowledge. I am also aware of my ignorance.

Bhagavan said, it's all because of my presence in you, the consciousness. I reside in you as your being. I am the Vedas and I am that needs to be known. I am the author of the Vedanta and knower of the Vedas. Now Vedas, as we have seen, they are our scriptures. What do they represent?

They represent knowledge. The knowledge compiled by the sages becomes Veda. This knowledge encompass everything. Utilitarian knowledge as well as the divine knowledge, secular as well as sacred. Now the secular knowledge obviously also come from my awareness. I learn things and I use it.

I am all this knowledge that is out there. And I am only the one to be known. And Veda in the end says what? The only thing to be known is your own self. Once you realize yourself, there is nothing more to be known. Having reached that place, we have learned that no one comes back.

That's what Veda says. That's what Vedanta said. In the end of Veda, the section which deals with the Upanishads and the knowledge about yourself is called Vedanta. So who gave this knowledge of the self to the Rishis? Bhagavan said, I did. And therefore there is no authorship in our Vedas of who wrote this Vedanta.

There is no authorship because it is a revealed knowledge. That is what is remembered. So I can say I thought about it many times. Honestly, I can tell you, I give some examples in my lectures. And I really sometimes feel good that I really thought about really neat example. Then I read Swamiji's commentary and I find the exact same example in it.

I said, how did that happen? I thought, I thought about it. What I really forget is I'd been listening to Swamiji since I was 16 years old. So all this thing which I think, I'm thinking fresh, new is literally come from what I heard since I was 16 year old. Now, I may not have understood the time, I may not have got the gist of it at the time, but things stay with you. Then we are really churning on that idea.

Things come out and now you think, I invented this idea. And therefore in Hinduism there is no originality. The only originality is with him. Everything else we do is just relearn. So Bhagavan says, therefore I am the author of Vedanta. Now I am the one to be known.

Everything which I can consider is the quest of my life. If Bhagavan said, is me, know that I am at the core of your being. So how difficult would it be for you to know your core of your being? Not that difficult, Bhagavan said, as long as you turn your gaze towards yourself. So these verses are obviously very contemplative verses and not really intellectual verses, but contemplative verses. But going back to our understanding of what is real, what is unreal, what is transitory or temporary, and what is permanent.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce the crucial distinction that gives this chapter its name. There are two Purushas in the world: the perishable (kshara) comprising all beings, and the imperishable (akshara) - the unchanging witness within. But beyond both stands the Supreme Person (Purushottama), the Paramatma who pervades the three worlds and sustains them. Consider this carefully in your own experience: your body-mind complex is clearly perishable - it changes moment to moment. But there is something in you that notices these changes, that remembers being young, that fears death - this is the imperishable self, still conditioned by its association with the perishable. The Purushottama is beyond even this duality.

The analogy of space helps illuminate this: room space is imperishable relative to the walls, floor, and ceiling that define it. But remove those boundaries, and "room space" as a concept disappears into the infinite space that was always there. Similarly, when conditioning is removed, your individual self (jivatma) is recognized as the universal Self (Paramatma). Krishna declares: "Because I transcend the perishable and am higher than the imperishable, I am celebrated in the world and in the Vedas as Purushottama." Today, practice observing your experience through these three lenses: what is changing (kshara), what witnesses the change (akshara), and what makes both possible - the ever-present awareness that is neither limited nor unlimited, but simply IS.

snippets.title: Day 195: Two Purushas
snippets.sanskrit:
यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम् |

इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ |
snippets.transliteration:
yo māmevamasammūḍho jānāti puruṣottamam .

iti guhyatamaṃ śāstramidamuktaṃ mayānagha .
verseTranslations: He who with unclouded vision sees Me as the Lord-God, knows all there is to be known, and always shall worship Me with his whole heart.
Thus, O Sinless One, I have revealed to thee this most mystic knowledge. He who understands gains wisdom and attains the consummation of life."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 15, Purushottama yoga, yoga of the Supreme Purusha. We have heard these terms before in Bhagavad Gita and Vedanta, Purusha and Prakriti. We understood from this discussion that the Prakriti is the manifest. Anything that which I can see, touch, feel and vouch for its existence is Prakriti, including my thoughts, my ideas. Because other people may not be able to vouch for, I can vouch for it that they exist. Anything that exists in the realm of my perception, feeling in thoughts is a Prakriti.

But that which supports this Prakriti or awareness is the Purusha. I am aware of this Prakriti because I am alive. If I am not alive, this body cannot perceive whether it is day or night. So that conscious principle in me is a Purusha. That's what we understood. The Prakriti is changing every minute, every second.

At a micro level, my body. My body has been changing every minute. I may not realize it till I see my pictures from five years ago. One good thing about these pictures on a website, we never change it. So I have a picture which was taken in 2003 on my website and anywhere else. So when the people come in contact with you in person, they get shocked.

Neil, you know, look a little different. Well, I never realized it. But other people who say it or when we see our picture, we realize this is constantly changing. What it was yesterday is not today. So that falls into the category of a perishable things and beings. This body is perishable.

But this body is supported by something which remains constant. This change I'm noticing in my body because something remains constant. That constant factor is gauging the change. I used to look like this. I used to have all dark hair, all my beard was dark. That one who notices the change remains constant.

That the support for this change. Change can only takes place if there is something constant. So in my life, I, the consciousness, I, the awareness is constant. So when we remember Our childhood memories we don't think that that was something a different person. I remember this happened to me I remember that I remain constant. Everything else about me keeps changing.

So at my micro level, there are two Purushas, two "me." One is perishable, which is the body, mind and intellect. One is imperishable, which is the one who is aware of these changes -- the one who is afraid of death. Otherwise, why would I be afraid if there is not someone watching and saying, "Looks like this body is going to go out"? People ask me all the time now, "Neil, what's your plan?" I said, "What do you mean, what's my plan?" He said, "We're talking about retirement." I said, "I have no plan, because I feel the way I felt when I started NBG Architecture the very first day. I'm the same person." "You're going to be qualified for Medicare in a couple of months, so I'm sure you have some plan." And at that time I started thinking, oh, is that so?

Statistically, Indians don't really last longer than somewhere about the early 70s. That's 65 -- I probably have less than 10 years. If I have less than 10 years, I haven't even planned what I'm going to do. Because I never feel old. That "I" at my level is always imperishable.

We started out this chapter by saying that when I think about myself, it seems like my source is somewhere unknown up above, but my life is all here, spread all around. The same way, now I look at it: when Bhagavan talked about the nature of the Supreme Being, everything that you see, perceive and feel is nothing but my expression. Right now I'm only worried about me. I'm not worried about whether you're going to retire or she is going to retire or he's going to retire -- what am I going to do? I'm also not worried about whether you people will be around when I die. After I die, I'm only worried about what will happen to me. So at my level, Bhagavan said, in this Loka, Dvau Purushau -- there are two Purushas in this world.

In my world there are two Purushas. One which is perishable, that I see. Bhagavan said, nothing that you see is other than me. I only exist and pervade everywhere. Everything you see, touch, feel and perceive is nothing but my expression -- including the perception of my own body, mind and intellect, which is deteriorating. I can't remember even my employee who has just left me three days ago. "She used to work here." Because the memory is not now as good as it used to be.

So I see this perishable me, which is also the Purusha. And I also see the imperishable one who doesn't think about retirement even now. Dvau Imau Purushau -- in this loka of mine, in this world of mine, there are two Purushas. One is perishable, one is imperishable. Does the world end here for me? Beyond these two, there is a supreme Purusha.

Right now that supreme Purusha I really have no connection with. So therefore I'm only worried about this Purusha. The one I feel is imperishable. Whatever I feel is still as young as when I used to be a little child. Bhagawan said that beyond these two there is a Purusha which transcends both the imperishable and perishable. And the example which we have seen is this room space is imperishable.

Room, walls, floor and ceiling is perishable. We are doing some renovation next door. So we say I'll move this wall here and do this because that's perishable. But we know that the space itself is imperishable. In relationship to the wall, floor and ceiling, this space is imperishable. But if we remove this walls, floor and ceiling out of the equation, what happens to this imperishable space?

It's not even imperishable anymore. If there is no perishable things in this world, the word imperishable means nothing, right? Because it is imperishable compared to perishable thing. Long-lasting battery, short-lasting battery. Lifetime warranty -- but whose lifetime? The battery's life, or the manufacturer's life?

Or that company's life? All of our contractors, we ask them we need 10 year warranty or 15 year warranty. 20 years warranty guy gladly give. 5 years from now you'll try to call him and say we have problem, we need you to. The phone number is out of service. So the lifetime warranty we get is not your lifetime, it's the lifetime of the company.

As long as companies, the warranty is good. But all these things are relative. But if you take the relationship out, what remains is absolute which you cannot really compare in this world. So this Purusha, one is perishable, this body one is imperishable. Which is conditioned by this body, mind and intellectual. But if you remove the conditioning, what remains is absolute Purusha which is neither perishable nor imperishable but ever existing.

And that Bhagavan said is by nature. So he said Uttamahapuru Sahatu Annyaha Paramatma ITI Udahrutah. We heard the word Paramatma. What does paramatma means? My atma is imperishable compared to my self. The body, mind, intellect.

But if I don't have this body, mind, intellect, that atma is absolute. Therefore it is param Atma. Not in reference to this. Our idea is that imperishable. Bhagavad Gita said that I'm imperishable. Even if I die, I'll be nil bhatt somewhere.

Bhagavan said Paramatma, it will be part of the infinite. Therefore that supreme being which forms this being as me is a paramatma. Swamiji gives a very nice example. Even within a room space there is a pot space. The space in the coffee cup is room space. The space remains in the room.

But when I even remove the room, the whole room space becomes so. When we take these layers out of identification, this is my mind, this is my body, this is my intellectual. They have their own identity and then I have my identity. The I which is my mind, my body, my intellect. When you remove in this I, what remains is just an absolute self. My atma, not conditioned by my limitations is Paramatma.

Your lokatriyam Avishya Bibhartya via Ishvaraha. That Paramatma is supporting the three worlds I live in my three worlds. Waking dream and deep sleep. My waking world is different. My dream world is different and my deep sleep world is different. I, the conditioned self is going through all these three experiences in my life.

But the condition self is supported by whom? This room space is bigger, smaller, depending on where I put the walls here. But supported by what? By the universal space. This is a part of that universal space. Yasmaat Aksharam Atito Aham Aksarat Apicho Uttamah.

Therefore Bhagavan's Yasmat Aksharam Adith. This self is even beyond imperishable. This self in me is much greater than this perishable Me. That's what we take some solace in learning Bhagavad Gita that even if I die, I will not die. Bhagavan said, but that self is even beyond Aksharaha. Beyond this imperishableness.

Imperishable as we have seen is only reference to the perishable. So let's say my life is hundred years. But there are things here which are 5000 years old. Compared to me, that thing has existing forever. But this time frame, when we completely remove the scale from our mind, what remains is absolute existence. No past, no present, no future.

So Bhagavan said, Yasmat Aksharam Atitah -- beyond imperishable and perishable. I am even supreme beyond this perishable and imperishable. Atah Asmi Loke Cha Vede Cha Prathitah Purushottamah. We had been hearing this word Purushottama. What is that Purushottama? He said, because my real nature -- I the Lord, the Ishvara -- and I say Lordship is that which supports my existence. That is my Lord.

That's when we call King a Lord. Because my existence as the commoner is because of his grace. He allows me to do that. That's why he's the Lord. In this case my Lord is him. Because my existence is because of him.

Therefore in this world I am called Purushottama in the Vedas. Purushottama is described in Vedas as the one which is beyond perishable and imperishable. And also the scholars and poets in this world has sung its glory as something beyond perishable and imperishable. And therefore Bhagavan said, I am called Purushottama. Therefore this chapter was called Purushottama Yoga. Yoga of Purushottama.

Right now I am completely yoked with this perishable and imperishable Purusha. I am very aware this is perishable me. I also know this body is going to die. But I have complete identification with it. I also have some solace because I had been learning Bhagavad Gita for many, many, many years. That something within me is imperishable.

Bhagavan said, but I am Purushottama. I am beyond this perishable and imperishable. Therefore I am called Purushottama. My own self, when it drops its relationship with this body, mind and intellect, this world, this perception, this feeling, these thoughts -- it becomes Purushottama. Yo Mam Evam Asammudhah Janati Purushottamam -- who knows his self as Purushottama? One who is Asammudhah, one who is undeluded. We, whether we like it or not, are deluded -- fooled by the illusion that you are different from me and she is different from he.

No matter how hard we try, this conditioning is so complete that we will not be able to get out of it. R. Bhagavan said there is a state for a Gyani to go beyond this illusion or delusion that he sees all the time that his relationship is with the Purushottama and not with this Purusha. Sarva Vid Bhajati Maam Sarva Bhavena Bharata.
snippets.reflection:
The chapter concludes with both a promise and a proclamation. "Yo mam evam asammudho janati purushottamam" - whoever knows Me thus, without delusion, as the Supreme Person, knows all there is to be known. This is not intellectual knowledge but direct recognition. The word "asammudha" (undeluded) is key - our usual state is one of delusion, convinced that we are separate individuals competing with other separate individuals. The sage who sees through this illusion recognizes that the same Purushottama that animates his being animates all beings. Such a person, says Krishna, worships Me with his whole being (sarva-bhavena). This is not partial devotion squeezed between other activities, but total orientation of life.

Verse 20 calls this teaching "guhyatamam shastram" - the most secret of all scriptures. Why secret? Not because it is hidden, but because it can only be understood by a prepared mind. Krishna promises that one who truly understands this becomes wise (buddhiman) and has accomplished all that needs to be accomplished (kritakritya). Imagine that - nothing more to achieve, nothing more to become. This is the consummation of human life. Today, carry this question: What if my deepest identity is not the struggling person I take myself to be, but the Purushottama itself, temporarily playing the role of this individual? How would that change what I pursue, what I fear, and how I treat others who are equally expressions of that same Supreme Person?

snippets.title: Day 196: Divine Qualities
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम् |

तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

ahiṃsā satyamakrodhastyāgaḥ śāntirapaiśunam .

tejaḥ kṣamā dhṛtiḥ śaucamadroho nātimānitā .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna continued: Fearlessness, clean living, unceasing concentration on wisdom, readiness to give, self-control, a spirit of sacrifice, regular study of the scriptures, austerities, candour,
harmlessness, truth, absence of wrath, renunciation, contentment, straightforwardness, compassion towards all, uncovetousness, courtesy, modesty, constancy,
Valour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, freedom from hate and vanity; these are his who possesses the Godly Qualities, O Arjuna!
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 15 and we'll be discussing chapter 16 now. And so far in Bhagavad Gita, we have seen in the first six chapters who we are as the limited beings. Then the next six chapters we have seen, what is the nature of of the Lord, the one, the Bhagavan which I'm seeking? In the last three chapters, which is chapter 13, 14 and 15, we had been seeing how to differentiate the two and how to go from one to the other, from manhood to godhood. So the first thing we have learned in chapter 13 is how to differentiate between the field and its knower. Because right now we have a confusion about what is field and what is knower.

I, the knower, think the world is the field. Even your body, mind and intellect which you consider you, is actually part of the field. One that knows this field is the Knower. So you've seen the differentiation between the knower and the field. We also come to the conclusion in that chapter. The knower is only one.

Whether it knows to you, knows through me, knows through him, knows through her, Knower is only one. The field has many expressions, which we call Prakriti. The variety of manifestations in the Prakriti creates individuality. The same knower, functioning through these different manifestations, creates the individuality we call ego. Each ego thinks he or she is the Knower, while the knower remains one. So now the question arises for a seeker who is sincere: if the Knower is one, why is my knowledge different from your knowledge, and your knowledge different from his knowledge?

In the last chapters we have seen the qualities of the Prakriti -- the 3 Gunas. The Prakriti has these three qualities: Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Depending on the permutation and combination of these three gunas in that particular individual, and as the light of consciousness shines through that equipment, the result will be according to the nature of that equipment. So these three gunas create various perception of the reality. Reality Remaining the same, you see differently and I see it differently. Something which is quite obvious to you becomes soul intriguing for me. And something so intriguing to you becomes so obvious to me.

That's because of the nature of our equipment. So to reach that transcendental self which we have seen in chapter 15, the Purushottama -- we've seen there are three levels of recognizing the all-pervading self. The first level is the perishable one which we can identify as myself, yourself, this world, my children, your children, my family, your family. We see that as a perishable world -- they come into being and will go away. But because we have come to the conclusion that there is only one entity which exists, which is the omnipresent Lord, even these transitory manifestations are also nothing but his self.

And therefore we call it the perishable Purusha, Kshara Brahman. Next, the Akshara -- the one who knows these changes are happening in me, in you, in him, in her -- is the imperishable self. So I know that my body is decaying, my mind is losing its grip, my intellect is fading. But the one who knows these changes are happening is the imperishable in me. Therefore we call it the conditioned imperishable self. This body is the outward expression, which is perishable.

One who knows this body is decaying is the imperishable self. But we learnt in the last chapter that the Supreme Being transcends both the perishable and imperishable. And therefore he is called Purushottama -- Supreme Purusha, Supreme Being. Because the qualifications of perishable and imperishable are invalid at that point. Knowledge is only in reference to ignorance. I can say my knowledge of the English language started when I was in fifth standard, because in reference to that knowledge, I was ignorant. Before my fifth standard, I was ignorant about English.

But if there is no ignorance ever, the knowledge has no meaning. Or if there is no knowledge to be known, the ignorance has no meaning. Ignorance about my own tail has no meaning because I don't have a tail. So when you remove the both perishable imperishable, what remains is the Supreme Being, the Purushottama. Having understood this intellectually, we have a difficulty grasping these ideas. So now the chapter 16 starts with the qualifications required to purify your mind and intellect to reach the level of clarity so that the knowledge of the supreme self shines through automatically.

It also talks about what is right now stopping this knowledge -- what are the impurities which are veiling this truth from me. My own self is not very evident to me right now. My own self, I'm seeing through my colored glasses of identification with my body, mind and intellect. I do recognize I exist. I do recognize that no one else has to come and convince me that I exist. But that existence I can only perceive in terms of my body, mind and intellect.

Just as I know the space exists, and I can perceive this space as room space. But only as long as the walls, floor and ceilings are there can I perceive room space. You remove all objects from this world -- perception of space is very difficult. So right now I do recognize myself, but in the context of my body, mind and intellect. I want to transcend this relationship.

How do I transcend? By purifying my internal instrument -- Antahkarana, mind and intellect. Antahkarana Shuddhi, purity of mind and intellect. So in Vedanta, the whole of mankind is divided into three categories. People who are divine -- those who have developed the divine qualities of mind and intellect -- are called Devas. Those who have demonic qualities, which bring you down to this world and bind you to this world, are called Asuras. Then there are the completely ignorant, completely indifferent about what is good and bad, called Rakshasas. And the goal of Bhagavad Gita is to help everyone.

So the goal of Bhagavad Gita is just like our president said: "I'm not only the president of the 51% who voted for me. I'm also the president of the 49% who did not vote for me. I'm the president of 100% of Americans. My goal as president is to help each and every American, whether they voted for me or not." So Bhagavad Gita is like that. See, normally we say Bhagavan will only help you if you pray to him.

Bhagavan will only help if you do good things. But Bhagavan says, my goal is to help all of you -- whether you are divine, you are Asura (demonic), or you are Rakshasa. Now, the completely ignorant ones -- there is no help readily available for them.

They have to go through the adversity of nature to destroy this mold in which their mind and intellect is right now imprisoned -- to break that mold so they can get out of it. So that's why we say about some criminal, we can understand why they did this. But then the law of society, the law of nature, or the law of some divine force will break their mold for them. There is no advice given in this chapter for them, but the rest of us either fall into demonic or divine qualities. This chapter gives us guidance.

So the purpose of this chapter is the topics we have already discussed before. We have indication in chapter seven and chapter nine about people who have the knowledge will understand this, but people with the deluded intellect will not understand that. Now we have a chance to elaborate on them and see what are the qualities I can introspect in myself which I need to cultivate more and one which I need to negate. So the chapter starts with Sri Bhagavan Oacha Bhagavan directly comes out and gives this knowledge without any introduction to it. Abhayam Sattva Sansuddhi Gnana Yoga, Vivasthidhi Dhanam Damasta Yagnascha Swadhyayavam. We have seen this in first three verses that 26 divine qualities are enumerated for you and I to use it as the litmus test.

How many of these do I have? Now, most of us write it off: well, these are for saintly people, not for me. However, if you carefully look at it, all of these are in you. You practice all 26 of them in your daily life at some level. But now it is our turn to look at these qualities. And what we have latently is our ability to cultivate them, so that they become my own personality.

So the first one I say is Abhayam -- fearlessness. Now we know where fear comes from. Out of ignorance -- when I am not comfortable about a situation, I am fearful. One time I took the Chamberlain exit. Somehow I thought I'm going towards VCU. I ended up on the other side.

And as I drove further I started getting more and more nervous about how can I take a short turn. Why I never been to that neighborhood ever before. Getting lost in West End is no big deal. I get lost in West End sometime, try to take a shortcut and then can't find a way out of that neighborhood. But I'm comfortable because I know this neighborhood, other side of Chamberlain Avenue. I did not know, so I was fearful.

Fear comes from ignorance. Therefore when someone who doesn't look like me, doesn't talks like me, does not dress like me, I am fearful of him. So Bhagavan says Abhayam, the first quality to be developed is Abhayam. And Abhayam comes from that basic understanding that no matter what the outward expression of the thing or being is, it is Lord's expression. So how far that expression is from me, as far as I am from my own self, there is nothing to fear in this world. So Bhagawan said Abhayam is the first quality a seeker develops.

We have heard that Alexander, going back, wanted to take a saint with him and said, "Well, you come with me. Are you not afraid of me? I can kill you!" The saint replied, "You can't take anything from me and you can't do anything to me. So I'm not afraid of you, no matter who you are." He had nothing to lose. If I have no fear of losing anything, nobody can make me afraid of him or her.

So Bhagavan said, Abhayam -- the first quality a seeker develops is fearlessness, and that comes naturally to me if I have purity of my mind and intellect. Sattva Samshuddhi -- purity of heart. As we had heard before, these qualities are obviously linked to each other. One cannot be developed without others being developed. Without the purity of heart, fearlessness does not come. If I don't have purity of heart, I'll always be fearful of others -- that they will take advantage of me.

People are going to walk over me if I don't behave this way. They will misunderstand me. All this fear is actually my own inbuilt fear of how incomplete I am. The more I know I'm incomplete, the more fearful I become. The more fearful I become, the more arrogant I will become. Therefore we see that people who have achieved a lot become more and more humble.

One of my friends had an encounter with Amitabh Bachchan. A whole group of actors were stranded at a New Jersey airport. Amitabh Bachchan was one of them, and he was telling me -- now this is obviously what I heard from him -- he said all these guys are jumping up and down about why they were stuck. He said Bachchan was peacefully sitting on one side. They were saying, "Well, put me in a five-star hotel" and all that.

Bachchan ended up in my friend's motel in a comfort suite. And he said he was so happy and peaceful.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses present twenty-six divine qualities beginning with abhayam (fearlessness) and sattva-samshuddhi (purity of heart). Krishna teaches that fear arises from ignorance - when we do not understand a situation or person, we become fearful. True fearlessness emerges when we recognize that all beings, regardless of outward appearance, are expressions of the same divine presence. As the teaching illustrates, the more we know ourselves as unlimited, the less we have to lose, and the less we fear. Consider: What situations or people trigger fear in you? Can you trace that fear back to ignorance or unfamiliarity? Today, when fear arises, pause and remind yourself that nothing external can diminish your true Self.

The qualities listed here - ahimsa (non-injury), satya (truthfulness), daya (compassion), kshama (forgiveness), and others - are not exotic virtues reserved for saints. They already exist within you at some level; the work is to consciously cultivate them so they become your natural personality. Choose one quality from these verses to practice intentionally today. If you select arjavam (straightforwardness), notice moments when you are tempted to be indirect or manipulative, and choose honesty instead. If you select mardavam (gentleness), observe how you speak to those around you and soften your tone. Write down at the end of the day: How did practicing this quality change my interactions? What resistance did I encounter within myself?

snippets.title: Day 197: Demonic Qualities
snippets.sanskrit:
दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च |

दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता |

द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन्दैव आसुर एव च |
snippets.transliteration:
dambho darpo.abhimānaśca krodhaḥ pāruṣyameva ca .

daivī sampadvimokṣāya nibandhāyāsurī matā .

dvau bhūtasargau loke.asmindaiva āsura eva ca .
verseTranslations: Hypocrisy, pride, insolence, cruelty, ignorance belong to him who is born of the godless qualities.
Godly qualities lead to liberation; godless to bondage. Do not be anxious, Prince! Thou hast the Godly qualities.
All beings are of two classes: Godly and godless. The Godly I have described; I will now describe the other.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 16, Daiva Asura Sampada Vibhaga Yoga -- Divisions of Divine and Devilish Estates. We are all hung up on "estate" these days, because the Republicans want the highest value of the estate you can pass on to your children without any taxes. That's because we consider this estate as something which I have acquired and accumulated. Something which is rightfully acquired becomes mine, and everything associated with it I consider to be my estate. Now this estate I want to preserve, because I want to pass it on to my children even after I die. Therefore, I don't want the government to take it away.

Bhagavad Gita says that the only estate you will take with you is the quality of your mind and intellect. We have seen in previous chapters and in Vedanta in general that death is only for the body. The mind and intellect remain intact, identifying as an individuality by their own conditioning. The only goal in life, scriptures tell us, is to uncondition myself from this conditioning, so that Mama Atma -- myself, which I consider "me" -- is without any conditioning and becomes the Paramatma, the supreme self. The only difference between myself and the supreme self right now is that myself is conditioned by these limitations -- my body, my mind, my intellect. The body, I know, has its own limitations.

It was born at a time T1 and will die at time T2. That I consider my death. What I do not know about is the nature of my mind and intellect -- when it was born, when will it die? Our scriptures tell us that the death of the body is not the death of the mind and intellect. And therefore, to uncondition this mind and intellect is the goal of my life.

Therefore the scriptures say the only responsibility a seeker has is to purify his antahkarana. This Antahkarana Shuddhi is the goal of all the practices, all the learnings that we have. So this antahkarana is my mind and intellect. The nature of my mind and intellect will decide what kind of wealth I have accumulated over my existence as this mind and intellect. And this wealth is nothing but my experiences and my tendencies. So that the experiences are good and I have developed the good qualities. My experience was bad and I developed bad qualities that became my estate.

So the nature of this estate is now defined into two categories. First, that which brings me closer to my supreme self, the Paramatma. The qualities which take me closer to my unconditioned self are called divine estate. Second, the qualities which bind me to this world -- to these limitations and therefore to the sorrows and unhappiness associated with limitations -- are considered devilish estates. Divine is something which is beyond my conditioning.

Devilish is something which is tying to my conditioning. So this chapter defines those two estates which I have. And all of us have some divine and some devilish estates. You know, just like viz. How about your portfolio? There are some good stocks in my portfolio.

But then there are some really, really bad ones. Same way my mind and intellect has some divine tendencies and some devilish tendencies. But therefore we have heard that the Mahabharata war is a war in my mind and intellect. Few good thoughts are fighting too many bad thoughts, but few good thoughts. If they are aligned with the self, the Paramatma, the Sri Krishna, then the war will be won between these good and bad tendencies in my heart. Now what can I do proactively is to introspect regularly and constantly and see what is the nature of my mind and intellect.

Am I more on a divine side or am I on the devilish side? Am I gathering more divine qualities or am I gathering more devilish qualities? I will be only able to do that if I understand what is divine and what is devilish. Now it has nothing to do obviously with Hinduism or any particular scripture or any particular faith. These divine qualities are universal qualities no matter which faith I belong to or which scripture I study. Because this divine quality is Thou shall not kill non injury, compassion.

All that we have learned is nothing which I need to be taught. It is something that comes to me naturally. Even as cave people, human beings knew that something which I have gathered with my efforts, nobody should take away from me. And therefore a good person will not do the same to others. If I don't want somebody to take away from my efforts, I also shouldn't be taking away from somebody else's efforts. So that became one virtue for a good person.

Then there are all the others which I don't want others to do to me. I don't want somebody to hurt me. I don't want somebody to kill Me, I don't want somebody to cheat me. So now my good virtues are. I will not cheat anybody. I will not kill anybody.

I will not hurt anybody. One of the criteria of a good seeker is defined in Vedanta as: just as, even in my sleep, I can never think about hurting myself -- even when I am completely deluded, I can't think about hurting myself -- a true seeker, even while in his conscious state, will never think about hurting anybody else.

So the good virtues are nothing so sacred or exotic to us. Good virtues are universal -- accepted by all cultures, all faiths, and people of all caliber of intellectual levels. But we need to remind ourselves time and again so that we can introspect. So the first three verses which we had seen in chapter 16 define those 26 virtues which are divine.

In other words, if I develop those 26 in my internal instrument, mind and intellectual. I will get closer to my supreme self. My mind and intellect's true nature is pristine. That it has an ability to see the reality as is. It is what I have acquired and superimposed on it as my estates have clouded that ability. Therefore, we consider the little children are divine.

Little children are the reflection of God, because they see reality as it is. They don't really have biases. I never had a chance to see a little baby growing, because as I told you, I have only one son, and for up to three years I didn't even know how he was growing up -- he was with my in-laws.

But now my granddaughter has given me a chance to see that how a little baby grows from time of her birth to where she is right now, 15 months old. And I could say that gradually she's developing personality. She's developing likes and dislikes. Things which she consider is good for her and things not good for her. Previous to this, her stage is 15 months. She was completely oblivious about.

She knows what is good and what is bad, and that's about it. So our mind and intellect, its very nature, is pristine -- it can see through to the reality as it is. But this coloring of my likes and dislikes, which I have acquired, has created this veil or tint on it. So now I'm seeing this world through my tinted glass.

So which tint is good and which tint is not good -- that is what we had been discussing. The first 26 virtues which we have seen are universal virtues which, once developed, will purify the mind and intellect, bringing them to their own pristine nature. So I can see the reality of myself as it is. I start seeing that this Self is nothing

But the Paramatma is the supreme self, just conditioned by my own limitations. Then the next three verses talks about which qualities which are really binding me to these limitations. So the verse four says Dhambah, Darpah, Abhimanaha, Chakrodah, Parushyam. You assume the good virtues. Now what are the vices? What are the bad qualities I can develop by my likes and dislikes which can be harmful?

First is Dhambha hypocrisy to some respect. If you really introspect, we all do some kind of a Dhamba, something which I am not. I am trying to show enhancing your resume, Neil, is absolutely necessary in this world. You have to say how great you are. You fake it till you make it. So when I came to this country, I obviously came from Africa and in somewhat of a trained by British system where an architect cannot write his name larger than 2 inches anywhere in the world.

So our sign boards cannot have the names more than 2 inches tall. You cannot market, you cannot go and advertise. People are supposed to come to me for design and I'm not supposed to go to them. So I was in Houston, I obviously did not have a job. And one of the person who had a contracting company, he was trying to help me. So he gave me a little project, tiny little project.

He said, but Neil, we need a building permit and you don't know the system here, so I'll come with you to the Houston City hall and help you out. So we were standing in a line for the building permit application, and just before me is a Hispanic lady who wanted to extend her house. She was asking this guy and said, but I want a building permit to add this bedroom to my house. And the guy said, do you have plans? No, I don't have plans. Do you have an architect?

Well, you need to get the plans drawn so that we can give you a building permit. My friend standing next to me said, neil, tell her that you're an architect. Neil, tell her that you're an architect. You can draw that plan for her. And I tell her, but how can I do that? She doesn't know me unless somebody introduce her to me.

I can go and tell her that I'm an architect, that's okay. And he'll just go and give you a card. I don't have a card, you know, and he got so mad at me. You're never going to make it in this country. He said, this country, you need to walk as if you're the only architect ever walked on this earth there is nobody as great as you are. That was my first lesson in American marketing.

Now we would consider a Dhamba. I know in my heart there are a lot of good architects. Much better than I am. At least I know where I am. But if I make that as my obsession to show the people it becomes a negative quality. First devilish quality.

Is Dhambha showing something other than who I am. Nobody as good as I am. That's an arrogance which is obviously over estimation of my own capabilities or evaluation of myself. Then nobody can cheat me. And that's the guy who gets cheated very easily. I kept telling him this is not right for you.

And he kept saying oh no, no. I've done so many businesses. I keep telling you you're going to get hurt on this project if you don't listen to me. He certainly was the easiest target to get hurt by others. Abhimanaha, these are the qualities even though I consider the helpful to me are actually most hurtful to me. Even when we are watching television or a movie only characters we like in them are one.

Who are the nice guys? We don't like the villains. All the people who are very arrogant and pompous. So how can we like in real life if we are like that? How can we expect other people? And in the end, in all the movies and television who get hurt, those villains get hurt.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 4 names six demonic qualities: dambha (hypocrisy), darpa (arrogance), abhimana (self-conceit), krodha (anger), parushyam (harshness), and ajnana (ignorance). Notice how these qualities are interconnected - when I feel incomplete within myself, I become arrogant to compensate; when I project something I am not, I live in hypocrisy; when my inflated self-image is challenged, I respond with anger and harshness. The teaching reminds us that the person who has achieved much often becomes more humble, while the one who feels lacking becomes more defensive. Today, honestly examine: Where do I project qualities I do not actually possess? Where does my self-conceit create friction with others? When someone questions my competence, how do I react?

Krishna offers Arjuna reassurance in verse 5: "Do not grieve, O Pandava, you are born with divine qualities." This same assurance extends to anyone sincerely engaged in self-inquiry. The very fact that you are studying these teachings, examining your own nature, and seeking liberation indicates the presence of divine tendencies within you. Yet verse 6 reminds us that both divine and demonic qualities exist in varying degrees within everyone. Rather than labeling yourself or others as wholly good or bad, use this teaching as a mirror. Ask yourself each evening: Did my actions today move me toward liberation (freedom from limitation and sorrow) or toward bondage (deeper identification with my limited ego)? Keep a simple tally and watch the pattern over a week.

snippets.sanskrit:
