verseTranslations: The godless do not know how to act or how to renounce. They have neither purity nor truth. They do not understand the right principles of conduct.
They say the universe is an accident with no purpose and no God. Life is created by sexual union, a product of lust and nothing else.
Thinking thus, these degraded souls, these enemies of mankind - whose intelligence is negligible and whose deeds are monstrous - come into the world only to destroy.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 16, Deva Asura Sampat Vibhag Yoga, Yoga of Divine and Devilish Estates. So as per some of the commentators, this chapter from 16 onwards, except 16, 17, 18 are elaboration on the ideas which are already discussed in Bhagavad Gita previously. But now we are elaborating on those ideas so that we can understand and apply in our daily life. The idea which we have seen earlier in the Bhagavad Gita is that the soul is divine, your self is divine. But the imposition on the self by all the layers which you have acquired through interactions with the Prakriti is hiding that self from you. I can't recognize myself right now because of all the layering on this pristine self.

So we have talked about who I, the individual, am. We talked about who the pristine self is. Now we are talking about what created this layering. In chapter 15 we talked about the Supreme Purusha. The Purushottama is beyond perishable and imperishable. This body is perishable.

The self is imperishable. The equipment which I have to transact with this world, this body, this mind, this intellectual are perishable. But the one who is supporting this equipment using this equipment is imperishable. Then Bhagawan said that I am even higher than them both the conditioned self in me which I consider my soul, my self is imperishable and perishable self that I condition myself, my body, my intellect are the two perishable me and imperishable me. Beyond this is the Supreme Me which transcends both Me the perishable and Me the imperishable. Those are the ideas we have seen in chapter 15.

And then in chapter 15 we also learned how that all pervading, imperishable became an individual soul. It's a portion of mine which is as eternal as my real self. When associated with this world of Prakriti then acquires five senses in mind then it enjoys the world of objects through those five senses and then gathering those experiences it creates its own personality. Now, while interacting with this Prakriti, I gain both types of experiences -- experiences which are conducive and experiences which are non-conducive. The tendencies which I acquire become my wealth. So when we say "my wealth" in our day-to-day life, it is all that I earned and acquired.

Now that has become my estate, it's my portfolio. So this chapter says I as the individual going through the variety of experiences from the day my soul started as an individual till today has acquired lots of impressions and built its own personality which has become my wealth, my estate. That estate has divine qualities but also some devilish qualities. And as these verses now will describe, what are the differences between the two? So the chapter opens with the first three verses which defines all the divine qualities or 26 qualities we have seen in first three verses. These are similar to the verses we have seen before where the Kshetra Gna was described by 20 qualities.

Kshetra was defined very elaborately in that chapter where Kshatragna was just given the qualities Amanittam oddam bitvam ahinsaakshantihi arjavam acharya upasana. Because the divine can only be expressed through its own expressions. Outside my physical appearance can be described by my mind, can only be read through my actions. Expressions of my mind, through my speech, my actions. So the divine is defined only by its expressions. And expressions we have seen in Kshatragna the Amani tum vadu.

Their similar qualities are here now described as divine qualities of a being, a person. The my estate then rest of the chapter now focuses on the devilish qualities or demoniac qualities. The reason for that is for us to know that the unique thing about ourselves is: it's very easy for me to detect divine qualities in me. Also, it is very easy for me to detect devilish qualities in others. My own devilish qualities I'm either completely unaware of, or even if I'm aware of them, I have justification for them.

But my divine qualities I'm very aware of and I can detect very easily. Well, I'm a very honest person. I'm a straightforward person. All that I others see me other way around. So you ask Meena, my opinion about myself is very different than my opinion about myself. We constantly see the demonic qualities in other but divine qualities in us.

On the other hand, when I have to judge myself -- am I a divine being or a demonic being? -- I'll always say, maybe, I'm not sure, I'm not divine. So we are completely confused about what our real nature is all about. So now Bhagavan clearly defines these qualities. Divine, as we said, is very easy to identify. But demonic is difficult when it comes to me.

It's very easy for me to say that's not a good quality in others. But the same behavior when I do, I will have a justification for it. So Bhagavan now goes into elaboration of why these qualities should be detected within yourself, how to detect them, and then how to avoid them. Verse 4 gave us in brief the devilish qualities. He said: Dambhah Darpah Abhimanah Cha Krodhah Parushyam Eva Cha Agnanam Cha Abhijatasya Partha Sampadam Asurim. These qualities are born out of your Asuric Sampat.

What you have acquired is not your real nature. This Sampat is not your real nature. So as most of us at my age say, "We came from India with $8 in our pocket. Everything I have here, I acquired from the United States by working here." So we were born with pristine nature, the self without any quality. And we acquired all these qualities -- of what?

So, Dambha -- hypocrisy; Darpa -- arrogance. Now there are subtle differences between them, even though we feel they all basically fall into the same behavior pattern. Dambha, hypocrisy: something which I am not, but I'm projecting. I'm not a very religious person, but outwardly I try to come across as a religious person. Darpa -- arrogance, I don't care. Abhimana -- self-conceit, a greater opinion about oneself.

Abhimana. Krodha -- anger. Then Parushyam -- harshness, whether physical harshness or mental harshness. Agnanam -- ignorance. Bhagavan says, the more I associate with this world of materialistic Prakriti, the more I lose my identity with my true self. Agnanam -- they are Abhijatasya Partha Sampadam Asurim. They are born out of your devilish estate.

The qualities which you acquire from this world by attaching yourself to the materialistic values. So in simple obviously it is defined as divine qualities are one which are spiritual and devilish quality ones which are materialistic. So Swamiji explained that the whole humankind can be divided into two those who are more divine and those who are more demonic. And then he also goes into the third kind called Raksasis. Now obviously Sid is here so you have to be careful in defining this in historical terms. But Asuras and Raxasas were probably tribes at one point of time or Asura is actually one of the gods.

Then there was a split. So people who followed Asura went to Iran, and those who remained stayed here. But as far as the ideas here: there are people who have more divine qualities or predominant sattvic qualities, who are closer to their real self. Those with more materialistic tendencies, who give more emphasis to enjoying the material pleasures, they are called Asuras. And Rakshasas are considered those who are completely ignorant about either. They are at the animalistic level, left on the lap of Mother Nature.

They don't have self efforts to improve themselves. So Bhagawan said here that these are the qualities which are considered demonic. Dhamba, Darpa, Abhimana, Krodha, Parushyam and Agnanam. And then rest of the chapter elaborates on the behavior and the verse 5 says Devi Sampadvi Mokshaya. Why should I be focusing on the divine? Because it will liberate you from your bondage.

Bondage with the identification with your limited self. Right now I consider myself to be the limited being. The limitedness is creating all the sorrows in my life. I'm not powerful enough, I'm not tall enough, I'm not strong enough. All those things which is stopping me to enjoy the unbroken happiness is because of my bondage to this limitedness. Once it is Devi Sampath Vimokshaya is for liberating you from your bondage.

Nibandhaya Asuri Mata Asuri is considered to be binding you to this limitedness. Masuchaha Sampadam daibim Abhijato Asi Bandava. But O Pandav, you don't worry, O Arjuna, don't worry. You are born with divine qualities. And last time we had discussion about whether Bhagavan said that because you are a royal prince. It does not say anything about royal prince here.

It simply says you are born with divine qualities. Bhagavan just assured him that just the behavior you have exhibited in your life. I assure you that you are born in divine qualities. As Swamiji says that we all can be assured that we have divine qualities. The very fact that on a Sunday morning you are learning Bhagavad Gita because of the divine quality. Giving assurance to seekers that if you are sincere about Liberating yourself, you need to have some courage.

As I said, we have easy detection of a divine quality. But when it comes to our judgment, we are not sure whether we are divine or not. So here is an assurance that because you are exhibiting divine qualities that you are divine. So the Master Chaha, do not worry. I look back on my life and I see a lot of mistakes I made and now I am worried about whether this is my exhibition of my devilish qualities. The very fact that you're interested in liberating yourself tells you that you are exhibiting the divine quality.

Continue in a path of your journey for seeking your liberation. Now start making statements. Dvav Bhuta Sargo Loki Asmin Deva Asura Evacha Devo Vistarasahaprakhtaha Asuram Partha Meshrunaho. There are two types of beings in this world, Divine and demonic. Divine we have talked about at length in the previous chapters in Bhagavad Gita we have been talking about these divine qualities of the Supreme Being manifesting through all beings. We have been describing in detail.

Bhagawan said, so now I'll just focus on Asuri. I'm going to tell you Asuri in detail now. So rest of the chapter now focus on the behavior of Asuri. Prakriti Pravritimcha Nivruttimcha Janana Vidhu Asuraha. Very first manifestation of demonic qualities. I do not know what should be done and what should not be done, what is the right thing to do, what is not right thing to do, what I should be engaging into and what I should refrain from, what I should stay away from if I can decide that Bhagavan said, this is the first quality of your demonic estate.

No Saucam, there is no purity. Purity at the physical level, mental level, intellectual. Now Socham na cha API acharaha na satyam tesu vidyate. Those people with demonic qualities, they do not know what to do, what not to do. They neither have purity nor right conduct. They do not know the truth.

All these things are the manifestation of demonic qualities. So now we can start looking at ourselves and say, is that something I should be detecting in myself and correcting? And with that, I'll stop here because the rest is a continuation of this discussion. We are discussing chapter 16, Deva Asura Sampath Vibhaga Yoga -- Yoga of Divine and Devilish Qualities, or Estate, or Wealth. We have started learning Bhagavad Gita from Lord Krishna, where he first gave us this scenario of Arjuna -- that Arjuna is a broken-down hero, a person who has all the strength, all the valor, all the training to fight his situations.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 7 identifies the first sign of demonic tendency: not knowing pravritti (what to engage in) and nivritti (what to refrain from). This confusion about right action was precisely Arjuna's condition in Chapter 1. The teaching clarifies that such confusion is not a personal failing but the natural result of an impure mind - one lacking saucha (cleanliness), achara (right conduct), and satya (truth). When you find yourself unable to decide what is right, recognize this as a signal to purify your inner instrument through study, reflection, and disciplined practice. Ask yourself today: In what areas of my life am I genuinely confused about right action? What impurities - desires, fears, attachments - might be clouding my discrimination?

Verses 8-9 describe those who believe the universe has no underlying truth (asatya), no foundation (apratishtha), and no governing intelligence (anishvara) - that everything arose by chance from the union of opposites. Krishna calls such people alpa-buddhayah (of small intellect) and ugra-karmanah (of fierce actions). This is not condemnation but diagnosis: when I see no sacred purpose in existence, I treat life - mine and others' - as expendable. Notice how your worldview shapes your behavior. When you act as if only material success matters, what becomes of your compassion, patience, and honesty? Today, consciously affirm: "There is a deeper order to existence. My actions have consequences beyond what I can immediately see." Observe how this shift in perspective changes your choices, even in small matters.

snippets.title: Day 199: Following Scripture
snippets.sanskrit:
काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः |

चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः |

आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः |
snippets.transliteration:
kāmamāśritya duṣpūraṃ dambhamānamadānvitāḥ .

cintāmaparimeyāṃ ca pralayāntāmupāśritāḥ .

āśāpāśaśatairbaddhāḥ kāmakrodhaparāyaṇāḥ .
verseTranslations: Giving themselves up to insatiable passions, hypocritical, self-sufficient and arrogant, cherishing false conception founded on delusion, they work only to carry out their own unholy purposes.
Poring anxiously over evil resolutions, which only end in death; seeking only the gratification of desire as the highest goal; seeing nothing beyond;
Caught in the toils of a hundred vain hopes, the slaves of passion and wrath, they accumulate hoards of unjust wealth, only to pander to their sensual desire.
snippets.commentary:
We are discussing chapter 16, Deva Asura Sampath Vibhaga Yoga -- Yoga of Divine and Devilish Qualities, or Estate, or Wealth. We have started learning Bhagavad Gita from Lord Krishna, where he first gave us this scenario of Arjuna -- a broken-down hero, a person who has all the strength, all the valor, all the training to fight his situations. But under the burden of the circumstances, he broke down and did not know what to do and what not to do. So Bhagavan told him that the only cure for your condition is to correct your understanding about what is right and what is wrong, what is permanent and what is impermanent. Since the second chapter, it clearly says that your mistake is that you are identifying with your limited self and looking at all the other people through their limited equipment.

But they are imperishable when it comes to the soul. Their real being is imperishable, just as yours. So that was the correction Bhagavan wanted Arjuna to make the identification from this limited to unlimited. In Bhagavad Gita, the journey is to change your identification from the limited being that I think I am to the unlimited soul that I actually am. Everything we have discussed so far in Bhagavad Gita is towards that goal -- changing my identification from the limited self to the unlimited self.

So entire Bhagavad Gita up to chapter 15 has described that unlimited self and how to identify with that. And in chapter 16 now we are discussing what is that which is binding me to their limited self. So as we have discussed, the first three verses told us about the qualities of the divine being or the divine estate. As we transact in this world, we are going to acquire wealth, we also accumulate other wealth. Respect, recognition, appreciation, and on the other side, disgust, criticism, all that also we accumulate along with accumulating the wealth which is generally our normal endeavor in life. So these become our estate.

Some are divine and some are devilish. Something which are acquired is pure and something we are called impure. So Bhagavan gave us the first 26 qualities of the divine estate. And then in the fourth verse he gave another six qualities of the devilish estate. So he said, the divine is quite obvious. Most of us recognize divinity when we see it.

And as we have discussed last time, it is easier for us to find divinity in us. For my mind to detect good quality in me is easy, very difficult for my mind to detect the negative tendencies in me, but it is very easy for my mind to see negative tendencies in others. That person is very hypocritical. Well, he is doing it for ego only. We can very clearly recognize it, but it is very difficult for us to recognize in ourselves. So this chapter takes upon itself to describe in detail what would be the behavior of a person who is predominated by negative tendencies, which in this case we call asuric tendencies.

So when we see this behavior in others, it is easier to detect. But when I do something similar, I consider that as well very, very minor or well, this is the way the life works. If I don't do it, then people will trample over me, I'll be a doormat. So my behavior I can justify saying that's how you survive in this world. But Bhagavan makes it very clear that if you detect this type of behavior, this behavior is very negative for your evolution, for your goal of liberation. So he said there are two types of one helps you to liberate yourself from the limitation.

Other will be binding you to this limitation. The more you try to satisfy your desires to get happiness through material goals, the more you will be binding yourself to these limitations. Pravrittim nivrittim cha janah na viduh asurah. The first indication is that the person does not know what to get engaged in and what to stay away from. I do not know what to do and what not to do -- which is what Arjuna's situation was in the very first chapter.

He did not know what is right for him. Bhagawan is not saying the Arjuna is asura, but the behavior he exhibited was clearly of asuric tendency. So something in him which was not allowing him to decide what is right and what is wrong. But once I know that that's a negative tendency Pravrittimcha nivruttimcha janahanna vidhu asuraha those who have the predominant qualities, they will not know what to do, what not to do. Na saucam, na apiyacharah na satyam teshu vidyate they will not have purity, cleanliness also na satyam teshu vidyate. They will not be able to tell the truth.

And Swamiji explains here that it is not to put them down that Bhagavan is saying this. It's actually somewhat of a pity for them that they're incapable of doing so. They're incapable of living an honest life, incapable of telling the truth. Because they're so afraid that telling truth will put them in trouble. In our daily life we call it white lie. Because you know, telling truth is going to put me in trouble.

Well, you really don't want to say what you really think about. They will say generally around looks good. So that basically is my incapacity to tell the truth. These people, when look at overall life, they are just not capable of telling truth because of their desire to protect what they consider is giving them happiness. And then he continues. Asatyam a pratishtam te jagat ahuhu Anishwaram.

This statement relates to what we have learned so far in Bhagavad Gita. In Bhagavad Gita we have learned that the nature of the self is Sat chit in Ananda that Sat is ever existing. We also learned that Sat truth is something which is consistent in all three periods of time. In the past, in the present and future. Something which was true in past has to be true today and will also be true tomorrow. So that is considered Sathya.

But that which is not consistent, something which was true yesterday, which is not true today. At some point it was true. Everybody agreed with each other. Other will all fall down at the edge of the earth. But now we know that that's not true. So that was not true.

Now what we know was true then even though we did not know it. It is true today and will remain true tomorrow. The people with asuric tendencies, they think that this world is asat. In a sense it is impermanent. It came in existence by chance and will perish. That means it's not permanent or pratish.

It just by chance occurring. It happened Te jagat ahuhu an ishwaram. And there is no controller. There is no central authority who govern the laws of nature. Their view is it all came about by an accident. Will remain in this situation for a while and will disappear.

There is no basis for this world to exist. There is no fundamental substratum which supports this universe. Universe came in Existence by accident will get destroyed by accident, basically. Or pratishtham te jagat ahu Anishwam. This is the worldview, Swami is a materialistic view. When I try to analyze the truth in this nature through pure physical science, only then obviously the only thing I can find is these two came together by some accident.

These elements came together by accident and then it happened this. Then other things happened by accident and then this happened this. So starting from the Big Bang, we can say Big Bang occurred. Why it occurred we don't know. But it's an accident. It occurred and after that it started expanding and then hydrogen became helium.

And all this is just an accident without any basis. Anishwaram There is no controller who is controlling the laws of nature. Aparaha paraha sambhutam. By coming together two opposites. Kim annyat kaama haithu kam. So the progeny or the continuing of this life on this planet came out by just accident.

By coming two together and for the only purpose fulfilling desire. There was no master plan, there is no underlying truth, there is no substratum. But it just all chance occurring. This is the view of the materialistic atheistic people. They have no faith in any underlying reality for this world. Etam drastim avastabya nastaatmanaha alpa buddhayaha.

Obviously this is a direct criticism from the Gitacharya that these people are wrong. They are seeing this from a very narrow perspective because they are viewing this world from a very narrow perspective. So when I see my life as a living being and I just analyze from a chemical perspective, electrical perspective, this is just a pure machine. It came together and it is pumping blood through the pumping action. And I can define everything in a mechanical term, in a physical term, in a chemical term, and say this is me. But what is it that keeping all the systems together, I really don't have an answer.

Simply saying it's just all working together. Physics came together, science came together. So basically you can see this life either as something divine which is supporting it, or simply say this is all just chance occurring. There is a book I have read called Brief History of Almost Everything. It's a fantastic book. It explains right from the Big Bang to where we are today in a very succinct manner.

His conclusion is that we as human beings existing on this planet is almost a chance. That one in a million odds that happen thing and it happened and continue happening and we are still existing. But anything could have gone wrong and we wouldn't have been here. So basically you're saying that maybe just a chance that we have become who we are. So here Bhagavan is saying that these people are looking at the world from a material perspective, analyzing what's happening from a material perspective. They're coming to the conclusion it's just chance occurring.

Why I am not tall enough and other guy 7ft tall is just a chance occurring. So Bhagavan said that having such view Nast Atmanah they are destroying their own self because they are negating their own self. They are not even recognizing that there is underlying reality. Called myself Alpa Buddhaya. They have intellect they are obviously analyzing. They are using all the faculties to understand this world.

But from a very narrow perspective. Alpam Buddha Fools it basically says very narrow perspective. Prabhavanti Ugrakarmanah Shayaya Jagato Ahitah. So the actions are very harsh because they are not recognizing the underlying unity of our things and being. You can take example of vegetarianism. The one underlying theme of vegetarianism is that every life has right to survive and live.

So you have to inflict as little harm to a life to support yourself. But if I don't have that view, then obviously killing other animals may be justified. So Bhagawan said that because they have a narrow perspective, their actions are harsh. Shaya Jagato Ahithaha because of the misunderstanding of how this universe work, they are the enemies of the world for its destruction. You can relate to our green movement about saving the planet. Now obviously there are a lot of people coming out saying all this thing is a hoax.

We really don't need to preserve anything. This planet will preserve itself. In fact, I just read that somebody written a book that actually the global warming will be very good for farming. There are more warmer weather and it will make people rich. So you can look at it from any perspective and your perspective will decide how you're going to act in this world.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 10 describes those driven by dushpuram kamam - insatiable desires. The key word is "insatiable." A natural desire (I am thirsty, I drink water) is fulfilled and ends. But obsessive craving (I must have more, bigger, better) can never be satisfied because it arises from an inner emptiness that no external object can fill. The verse also mentions asuchi-vratah - impure resolves, actions taken without consideration of their ethical consequences. Examine your desires today: Which are simple needs that can be met and released? Which are obsessions that keep growing regardless of what you acquire? Choose one insatiable desire and ask: What inner lack am I trying to fill with this external pursuit?

Verses 11-12 paint a vivid picture: those bound by hundreds of ropes of hope (asha-pasha-shataih baddhah), slaves to desire and anger (kama-krodha-parayanah), accumulating wealth through unjust means (anyayena artha-sanchayan). Notice the progression - endless hoping leads to attachment, attachment to frustration, frustration to unethical action. The teaching uses the powerful image of being "bound by hundreds of ropes." Each unfulfilled desire is another rope. Each resentment is another knot. Today, identify one "rope" that binds you - perhaps an expectation about how someone should treat you, or an attachment to a particular outcome. Practice releasing it, not through suppression but through understanding: "This hope is creating my bondage. I can act appropriately without being imprisoned by the result."

snippets.title: Day 200: Divine Qualities
snippets.sanskrit:
इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम् |

असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि |

आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया |
snippets.transliteration:
idamadya mayā labdhamimaṃ prāpsye manoratham .

asau mayā hataḥ śatrurhaniṣye cāparānapi .

āḍhyo.abhijanavānasmi ko.anyo.asti sadṛśo mayā .
verseTranslations: This I have gained today; tomorrow I will gratify another desire; this wealth is mine now, the rest shall be mine ere long;
I have slain one enemy, I will slay the others also; I am worthy to enjoy, I am the Almighty, I am perfect, powerful and happy;
I am rich, I am well-bred; who is there to compare with me? I will sacrifice, I will give, I will pay - and I will enjoy. Thus blinded by Ignorance,
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 16, Deva Asura Sampada Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of divine and devilish qualities. And we have seen that these are the qualities of my mind. Even though it seems like it is describing two sets of different people, one are divine and one are devilish. And as if we are dividing this world again into divine and devilish. The purpose of these qualities to be described in Bhagavad Gita is to understand our own mind. Our own mind has this both qualities, the divine and devilish, depending on which one we promote, either we'll be liberated or will be bound more and more into this world of limitations.

So the last verse we had seen last time says Asa Pasas Satayi Baddhaha, the person who is not knowledgeable enough about what will liberate him and what will bind him by depending on this notion that the sense enjoyment is the only purpose of life. By hook or crook, I should achieve what I want. They will be more and more bound by unlimited desire, Asha Pasa, bound by this bondage of desires. You know, satay, that means innumerable desires. And therefore they will do anything which is either appropriate or inappropriate. They will try to achieve, acquire, hoard things which they think will give them the happiness by even illegal means.

Inappropriate means continuing in the same dialogue as we have seen, Bhagavan now describes what will be the tendency or the thinking of these people. Swamiji says there's not really much to elaborate on it. Just as we have seen that the first three verses which describe the divine quality, there is not really much to be discussed about. These are universal qualities. Even cavemen knew what is right and wrong. Somebody should not take the food which I have acquired with my labor.

Therefore, if I do that to others, it will be wrong. I don't want somebody to kill me, and therefore killing somebody is bad. These are universal values which every human being from the dawn of the civilization know. In the same way, the tendencies and thinking of a devilish mind that we are going to be discussing also don't require much explanation. Why? Because we all have experienced this at some point or other, at some level or other. Except that at that time, I did not know that my thinking was going to create more unhappiness for me.

When I was thinking about that, I was thinking I'm doing this to get more happiness, for financial security. I put more and more money into the stock market, and as it grows I get the statement every month -- it made 8%, then next month 10%. Feeling pretty good. Except when it collapsed. Didn't have the courage to open up your statement. But while I was doing that, I thought, I'll get this and then I'll also get this, and therefore I'll be completely secured. We didn't think it through -- we work all our lives so hard.

I have not come across a single person who says, "I really need to work hard in my life, but I'm enjoying it." Everybody thinks the same thing. What I was thinking all the time was: Idam Adya Maya Labdham -- I have gained this today. Today I can say I have this. I reconcile my statement of what my assets are at the end of the year, for taxes or whatever. "Boy, that's pretty good." Or, "Well, at least I have this."

And then what is my next thought? Imam Prapsye Manoratham -- I have this, but I will also get this. What if the financial planner says, "Okay, well you need to have this to retire at the age of such and such. This many times your current income -- you will need this, and therefore you need to do the following." So you start planning. The first time a financial planner, a friend of ours coming to Chinmaya Mission in Dallas --

I was pretty young at the time. I was like 30 something. And he looked at them and said you need million something dollar to retire. I don't think I'll ever have a million dollar. At the time I was probably making like $35,000 a year and the guy was trying to tell me I need million dollar to retire. You forget about it, okay?

I'm going to work till I die. No planning required. Because when you see that I have this, I need to achieve this or work hard. Neel, you have to have at least this much when you retire. I have this right now. This is a common thinking.

Nobody will label that as devilish. Bhagavan says that's the quality which binds you to this world of constant changes and disappoints you more times than you think it will. Idham asti idam API me bhavishyati punardhanam. And this wealth shall also be mine in the future. It's simple planning. I acquired this, and I'll work a little hard and do this project, then invest here, and then I'll get that.

Bhagavan says that may be okay for planning purposes, but when that becomes your obsession, then it has a sure capacity for failure. You should be planning. I can never forget this thing in my life. I bought my first house in Dallas, Texas in 1984, just before the election. I guess it was the Reagan second election. And they told me that after the election the prices will go so out of control that you won't be able to buy.

So you should buy before the election. Says, okay, you buy this house, $150,000 minimum, it will have 5% appreciation. You have compounded 5% for 10 years. The value of this thing will be this. Oh boy, that's pretty good. They say that's guaranteed 3 to 5%.

It may go up and it's guaranteed. I sold that house, the one which I bought in 1984, in 2000. Now you apply that formula, 150,000. Should have been at least $350,000, right? I sold it for $10,000 more than what I bought in 1984. And as if I have not learned the lesson yet, I bought a house in Northern Virginia where they say it was Dallas.

You know, that's an oil dependent economy. It goes down or it goes up. We are federal government dependent economy. Guaranteed 20% appreciation every year. You can look at it last five years and you will see it. I bought a house again in 1988, Northern Virginia, in Fairfax.

And again I said, well, they say 20%. I'm going to be on 5%. Okay, at least I'm safe. I projected in about 10 years, eight years, five years. I bought it in 1988, sold it in 1996 for exactly $6,000 more than what I had bought for. I made $6,000 after eight years owning that house in Fairfax, Virginia.

We plan, but what will come out of my actions is not guaranteed. Bhagavan said, there's nothing wrong in planning. That's not in a devilish pursuit. What devilish pursuit is, if this doesn't happen by hook or crook, I will make somebody a Scapegoat and get my money. So therefore it says Idamasti Idham Apimi Bhavishati Punardhanam. This is mine and this will also be mine.

That which I have projected at a 5% appreciation that shall also be mine in 10 years. I can say this is what I have. This is its value today. What will happen 10 years from now only he knows. And whoever after 10 years has to buy this house knows. So it is the attitude of my mind makes the same thing either divine or devilish.

I took care of this competition. Obviously in those days they were enemies and they were killing each other. But in a normal day to day even they say I never have killed anybody. So I never said I killed this person. But we do mentally all the time. I killed this competition.

He was trying to be the VP of the company. But I really manipulated. I went around and talked to all the other bosses and I really pushed him down. And now I got the promotion as vp. That's I who killed him for that purpose. So Asaomaya Hataha Satrahu who was my enemy who is in the path of my happiness.

My enemy is the one who is obstructing me to be united with my happiness. I killed this person, initiator Aparanape and the others who I think will be on my way, I will kill them too. It always gives me a kick. Anytime I read this Rasi Bhavishya we get this South Carolina Sati magazine and only thing I read is honestly the horoscope. Because I have nothing to do with all these businesses in South Carolina. Only thing I can relate to is that last page which says your monthly horoscope.

And this guy constantly warns me. At least the Aries who I am, you know, born in that sign. Be careful about the people around you. They may be planning to harm you. Now what do you think? My thinking would be well look at Meena, Pourvi, Neeraj, little Medha.

They must be all planning something against me or my employees or my friends. This is just insecurity. We bank on people's insecurities. Because if you don't take these annuities the market may go down. You will have no security when you are retiring. You need a guaranteed income.

Annuities will give you this guaranteed income. He fails to tell you that those annuities cost lot more than any other investment you would do. They are making money in your insecurities. What will happen when I return If I don't have money they say okay we'll take care of it. But we'll take part of your money and put it in our pocket and make you feel good that you will have the guaranteed income. I took care of this computation, this enemy, even the others I'll take care of them too.

Therefore I will be secured. When I'm doing this, my state of my mind is I am the Lord of my being. I take care of myself. Not only I take care of myself, I take care of all people around me. What would happen to them had I not been doing what I am doing. All these people are dependent on me.

Bhogihi and I'm enjoying it. All these efforts which I'm putting and gaining this I have got that I'll be getting. I'm the Lord of lord is on whom my existence is dependent on. So in the feudal system whether you live or die, the way you live is dependent on the Lord. He decides how much money there was no unions and nobody decides how much to give it to the workers. He decides whatever he has to give.

So therefore he's the Lord and you're the commoner. Ishwara Same he decides how this world is going to function. So when I decide that I am the Lord of my Sansar I decide in old Indian system the head of the house will tell how everyone should leave in that house. I think that I control everybody and everything. Bhogi and I'm enjoying the fruits of my actions. I'm a successful one.

What you have accomplished in your profession and it's admirable and what you accomplished in your wealth and it's all admirable. Guy doesn't know the other side of the story. What I not accomplished and where I have failed. It is okay for others to think about that. When I start thinking about my own accomplishments that's where the problem starts. It's perfectly okay for us to admire the people who accomplished some great things such as Isaac Newton or Bill Gates or Steve Jobs.
snippets.reflection:
These verses expose the inner monologue of the ego-driven mind: "This I have gained today; tomorrow I will get more. This wealth is mine; more shall be mine soon. I have defeated this enemy; I will defeat others. I am the lord, the enjoyer, successful, powerful, happy. I am rich and well-born - who is equal to me?" Read these statements slowly and notice which ones resonate uncomfortably with your own thought patterns. This is not about shame but honest recognition. When we reconcile our assets, review our accomplishments, or compare ourselves favorably to others, we are walking the edge of this mindset. The teaching does not condemn planning or achievement - it warns against the intoxication that comes when success inflates the ego rather than humbling it.

Verse 15 reveals the final delusion: "I will sacrifice, I will give, I will enjoy" - even spiritual and charitable acts become corrupted when performed for ego-gratification. The person described here makes donations to see their name on plaques, performs rituals to impress others, and serves the community for recognition. Examine your own generous acts: Do you give anonymously, or do you need acknowledgment? Do you serve quietly, or do you need others to notice? Today, perform one act of kindness or generosity that no one will ever know about. Notice what resistance arises when your ego cannot claim credit. This practice reveals how deeply ajnana (ignorance) has penetrated even our noblest intentions.

snippets.title: Day 201: Demonic Qualities
snippets.sanskrit:
अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः |

आत्मसम्भाविताः स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः |

अहंकारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः |
snippets.transliteration:
anekacittavibhrāntā mohajālasamāvṛtāḥ .

ātmasambhāvitāḥ stabdhā dhanamānamadānvitāḥ .

ahaṃkāraṃ balaṃ darpaṃ kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca saṃśritāḥ .
verseTranslations: Perplexed by discordant thoughts, entangled in the snares of desire, infatuated by passion, they sink into the horrors of hell.
Self-conceited, stubborn, rich, proud and insolent, they make a display of their patronage, disregarding the rules of decency.
Puffed up by power and inordinate conceit, swayed by lust and wrath, these wicked people hate Me Who am within them, as I am within all.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 16, the Evasura Sampada Vibhaga Yoga. The divine and devilish qualities are the estates. This is the only estate you and I will carry with us when we die. All other estates will remain. But these qualities or tendencies of my mind, which are both as some divine tendencies and some devilish tendencies, I will carry that as my estates and I'll start from there. You've seen so far that this divine tendencies will liberate me from my limitations.

The veilings on my mind which is right now is not letting me see the reality as is that myself and the supreme self is one and the same. On the other hand, the devilish qualities or the aspheric tendencies which in reality all it means is it binds me to this manifest world and therefore I will be more covered with ignorance from my own self. And therefore it is very important for me to understand what are these qualities. So in the beginning we have learnt about all the divine qualities and they are universal as we have said. So therefore there is not really much explanation needed. I should treat others just as I would like others to treat me.

Such divine qualities in if I practice it will liberate me from my limitations. But more and more I get bound to this world of manifestation. This is me and this is the world. This I want and this I want to avoid. It binds me more and more to this world. And therefore it is very important to understand how this thing works.

So we have seen so far that asuric tendencies make people believe that there is nothing more to this world than enjoy the sense gratification or satisfying the desires that I have, the lust that I have, and who knows, because I cannot see what was before my birth and I cannot see what was after my birth. Well, let's just consider this life is the only life that I have. And therefore let's make the most out of this life by by hook or crook. So I have now come to the conclusion that hoarding more and more wealth will make me happy. I will achieve that by any means, any unjust means. Even though I know this is not right, I will go ahead and do it anyway.

And once I get into that mode of mind, my situation would be that I will be constantly worried. Chintama Aparimayamcha AP I'll be overwhelmed by the worries. I'm always worried about things which I don't have. Once I acquire it, I'll be always worried about how to safeguard it. Because just as I took it away from somebody, somebody will take it away from me. So this mode of mind will be constantly be engulfed by these worries.

But then at the same token my ego will start rising into its power and start thinking look, I have acquired this. These are the natural tendencies of my ego. Once I accomplish something, I start thinking nobody else could have done it but I did. The last few verses which we have seen describe this mode of mind. Even success is something that is very difficult to digest or to become worthy of, because success can intoxicate you with wrong thoughts.

Instead of getting you to a higher level by whatever you learned or achieved, it sometimes brings you down. And if you fall into that category, what happens is what we have seen in the last few verses, which basically says: Adhyah Abhijanavan Asmi -- "I am rich." Once I have acquired wealth because I thought that's my security, that will give me happiness, I now forget why I acquired this wealth. It starts giving my ego a boost -- "Look, I am rich." So now I'm associating myself with my riches.

I start thinking I am my car, my car is me. I expand my identity not just to me as the body, mind and intellect, but now to all the possessions that I have. So my identity is incomplete without my possessions. Me minus my possessions is nothing. Now therefore I think: "I am rich." Abhijanavan Asmi -- "I am well-born." And Konyo Asti Sadrusho Maya -- "Who is there who is like me?"

These are the side effects of success. Success is something obviously very necessary for you to do what you need to do. But if that success only associate with why I wanted to achieve this then it's not really that big of a problem. But when I start associating with my ego then all these side effects will kick in. So now what I'm doing, even the thing which I'm doing good instead of giving me good results give me actually wrong results. So Yakshe Dashyami Modishya I am making the sacrifice.

Sacrifice is something you make so that you become more humble. But now I'm making sacrifice which makes me more arrogant. That look I am making sacrifice. Other people are not doing it. I am giving this donation. Donation is something is for you to get rid of more of your ego.

But it actually gives you boost your ego more that I am making donation. So the things which are supposed to be giving you the right results now start giving you the wrong results. Bhagavan said that this Asurik Sampath is. You need to be very careful in understanding that what are its evil effect on your mind and yourself. Once you are deluded. They get these wrong results even from the right actions.

Anek Chitta Vibranta Mohajal Samavrataha. Why all these things happening to them? Because they are Anek Chitta Vibhranta. They are bewildered by many fancy. They have all different kinds of fancies about what they are going to achieve, what their capabilities are. And I can also do that.

I tell all the time that if you are in one profession you always like to start thinking that something associated with it also I can do it. Most architects start getting into development and investment and real estate and all that. Because everybody comes to ask me how to do this. Why don't I do myself and also make money? In the end every architect who has tried has failed. Because that's not your really expertise or nature.

You're good at something -- that's why you became something. But this fancy of mine which says, "I can do this, I can also do this. I have achieved this, I can also accomplish this." Moha Jala Samavritah.

Because they are entangled into the snare of Moha delusion. This moha is simply my mind just cannot see the value of things and being as they are. So I start associating more and more values where they don't belong. Including on my own self, my own abilities. So I'm completely entangled into it. Prasaktaha kama Bhageso.

We know how the addiction works. Once I get something, I want to get it again and again. My Starbucks example, first time I had the Starbucks coffee. It's not an addiction. The second time and a third time and after that, how can you live without it? Prasaktaha kama Bhagesha.

Once I start enjoying the sense gratification more and more I get addicted to it. Patanti Naraki Ashucha. These unclean minds, people with the unclean intentions, they fall into the Naraka hell. When things don't go right for us and we start worrying about it and start losing sleep over that. It's falling into hell. Other people may think you are doing very well but you ask yourself how you are doing.

"Are you enjoying, Neil?" Because 18 things are going right in my life, but these two are not letting me enjoy those 18 things which are going right for me. So where am I living? Not in heaven, but in hell. From an outsider's perspective, I may be doing very well. Therefore you read these stories about people like the hedge fund manager.

There'd be billions, not even millions and still they are suffering through. He is under investigation, going to jail. If money was the only object which was going to make him happy, he wouldn't be living in this situation. Patanti Naraki Asuchao with that unclean intentions, pursuing the goals of satisfying their desires instead of giving them joy which they were seeking from those endeavors, they fall into this hell. Atma Sambhavitah Stabdaha. Now other people can see, but I think he's doing wrong.

He's going to get hurt by this thing. But I don't see myself. I'm suffering but I'm still continuing. In Gujarat there is a saying, a gambler who is losing, he puts double the stake. He thinks the next time I can make it up. And this is really true.

Stock market, forget about gambling. Stock market people put money, the stocks go down. He think, oh now this is the time to get in. He puts more money into it. There was a company I was designing a headquarter in Charlottesville called Value America. I don't know any of you remember, but 2000, it was a rising company.

Internet bubble at the peak. And they hired me to design their headquarter in like June or July. And they had 600 people. And then they told me that by December we had thousand people. So they were designed with 1000 people. This building has to be completed by end of next year or so.

We are rushing to do that. And then just before the end of the year in December, I get a call and say, Neil, send your invoice as quickly as possible because tomorrow the company may not be there. So anyway, the company was in a stock market. And then by the time I got involved, 15. And then when they called me it was about like $4 and say, got to be this good. No matter how much $4 will at least put $4,000.

I put thousand shares at $4, I said, I have seen that all the setup and those computers and all that is more than what they are saying. Well, the $4, then it eventually became 20 cents and eventually become zero. Even though I knew things are going down, I thought there's got to be a better deal. snippets.reflection:
Verse 16 describes the state of being aneka-chitta-vibhrantah (bewildered by many fancies) and moha-jala-samavritah (entangled in the net of delusion). This is the scattered mind that chases multiple desires simultaneously, convinced that each new acquisition will finally bring fulfillment. The verse warns that such minds, addicted to sense pleasures (prasaktah kama-bhogashu), fall into naraka - not a place but a state of constant anxiety, dissatisfaction, and inner torment. Reflect honestly: How many "fancies" are you currently pursuing? How scattered is your mental energy? The teaching suggests that even worldly success, when pursued obsessively, becomes its own hell. Today, practice simplification: identify one desire you can release, one pursuit you can let go of, to reduce the chaos of competing wants.

Verse 17 reveals how even sacred acts become corrupted: the wealthy and proud (dhana-mana-madanvitah) perform sacrifices in name only (nama-yajnaih), motivated by ostentation (dambhena) and without proper understanding (avidhi-purvakam). Verse 18 identifies those who, filled with ego, power, arrogance, lust, and anger, actually hate the divine presence within themselves and others (mam atma-para-deheshu pradvisantah). This hatred of the Self manifests as disregard for one's own conscience and dismissal of others' good intentions. Ask yourself: When has success made me more arrogant rather than more grateful? When have I ignored my inner voice because it conflicted with my desires? When have I dismissed good advice because it came from someone I felt superior to? These are the subtle ways we "hate" the divine within.

snippets.title: Day 202: The Three Gates
snippets.sanskrit:

snippets.reflection:
Verses 19-20 describe the consequence of persistent demonic tendencies: birth after birth in environments that reinforce those same qualities. This is not divine punishment but natural law - whatever tendencies we cultivate, we become expert in; whatever path we follow, we continue along. Just as a person who builds a career in one field becomes increasingly specialized in that domain, someone who practices cruelty, hatred, and delusion becomes increasingly skilled at those patterns. The teaching warns that such souls, never recognizing their divine nature (mam aprapya), sink to lower and lower states (adhamam gatim). Examine your own "expertise": What patterns have you become increasingly skilled at through repetition? Are they patterns that liberate or bind? Today, consciously interrupt one negative pattern before it runs its usual course.

Verse 21 offers the most practical guidance in this chapter: "Trividham narakasya idam dvaram" - there are three gates to hell: kama (lust/obsessive desire), krodha (anger), and lobha (greed). These three are the root destroyers of the Self. Notice how they interconnect: desire, when obstructed, becomes anger; desire, when fulfilled, becomes greed for more. The cycle is self-perpetuating. Krishna's prescription is simple: "tasmad etat trayam tyajet" - therefore, abandon these three. Today, keep a mental note each time you feel the pull of obsessive wanting, the heat of anger, or the grasping of greed. Do not judge yourself - simply observe. At day's end, review: Which gate did I approach most often? What triggered it? What would it mean to turn away from that gate rather than enter?
