snippets.reflection:
Verse 22 offers the positive counterpart to the previous warning: one who is freed from the three gates of darkness - lust, anger, and greed - naturally acts for their own highest good (acharaty atmanah shreyah) and attains the supreme goal (param gatim). This is liberation not as escape from the world but as freedom within it - the ability to act wisely without being driven by compulsion. Notice that Krishna does not say such a person has no desires, never feels irritation, or wants nothing. Rather, they are vimuktah - freed from being controlled by these forces. Today, practice this freedom in one small area: when desire arises, acknowledge it without acting on impulse; when irritation surfaces, feel it without speaking harshly; when greed whispers "more," recognize the voice without obeying. This is the beginning of liberation.

Verse 23-24 establish scripture (shastra) as the guide for determining what should and should not be done (karya-akarya-vyavasthitau). When we act merely from desire (kama-karatah), we achieve neither perfection (siddhi), nor happiness (sukham), nor the supreme goal. This teaching acknowledges our tendency to rationalize - "I know what is right for me" - while being driven by hidden motives. Scripture serves as an objective standard, a wisdom accumulated over millennia, that can check our self-deception. Practically, this means: before major decisions, consult the teachings; when confused about right action, return to the principles you have studied. Ask yourself today: In what area of life am I acting purely from personal desire while convincing myself it is right? What would the scriptural wisdom - non-injury, truthfulness, non-attachment - counsel in that situation? Let this chapter's teaching be your compass when your own judgment is clouded.

snippets.title: Day 204: Three Types of Faith
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna asked: My Lord! Those who do acts of sacrifice, not according to the scriptures but nevertheless with implicit faith, what is their condition? Is it one of Purity, of Passion or of Ignorance?
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Man has an inherent faith in one or another of the Qualities -Purity, Passion and Ignorance. Now listen.
The faith of every man conforms to his nature. By nature he is full of faith. He is in fact what his faith makes him.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing the Bhagavad Gita, starting from chapter one, Arjuna Vishada Yoga. The Gita opens with Dhritarashtra. Dhritarashtra, as we have discussed, is our state of mind. Right now we live in the Dhritarashtra state. We are blind to our reality, the supreme reality, the real reality. We are blind to the truth that I am part of that supreme being, and instead we live in the world of Mamakaha -- I and mine.

So that's basically how the Bhagavad Gita started: this is our problem. All our problems start with that one misunderstanding that I am this limited being, that Mamakaha is my world, I and mine is my world. And then I separate the rest of the world as something other than me. The next few verses focus on Duryodhana -- the Duryodhana in us.

This Duryodhana represents the thief in us -- the part that wants to take away something which belongs to somebody else and make it mine. I want it so badly that I will use any means to get it. All over our day-to-day life we see inequality in our society, because obviously there is wealth which is common to all, given by God, natural. Yet somebody hoards so much and doesn't leave enough for the others.

So the Duryodhana in us wants this thing so badly. He knows it's not his, but he wants it. And therefore he is always very anxious, because he has decided: I need to have it. I know it is not mine, but I need to have it for my own happiness, to make myself complete.

This sense of incompleteness started with our state of Dhritarashtra. Because we are blind to our reality, we make ourselves limited to this self, and that I-and-mine creates incompleteness. That incompleteness has created a thief in us -- I want to take away from others and make it mine so that I will feel complete. That's what Duryodhana felt all his life: I need all this kingdom for myself. He was already given half the kingdom after the first match of chess, and now he wants all of it.

So his mental state is that of any thief who is trying to steal something away from somebody else. One, he is insecure -- when you are trying to steal something, you wonder: is somebody watching me? So there is insecurity, and then fear. Obviously you are fearful, you are insecure. That's why you want to make sure you get what you want by any means.

So there are three things in that mentality: I want this so badly that I'll be willing to do anything; I'm insecure; and I'm fearful. The next few verses we have seen are just describing this. The first six verses said:

Look at the Pandava's army -- it looks pretty well protected. Great warriors on their side. He is basically going to Drona and saying, these are all your Shishyas. Arjun, son of Drupada, Drishtadharamna, who is now commanding the army. So I'm not sure that we are totally protected having somebody like Drona with us, because his shishyas are on the other side. That's a fear in him.

So he describes all that he feels are the weak points from looking at the other side. And now he realizes that he may have gone overboard. When somebody is in that state, he wants to cover both bases.

On one side he feels insecure. On the other side he feels very powerful -- I have all the shrewdness and smartness and strength to do it. So first he looked at his insecurity and his weaknesses, seeing the other side as powerful. Now he's looking at it differently: no, no, I can do it. So from verse 7 onwards, he now looks at his strength.

Asmakamtu Visishtaye Tani Bauda Dwijottama. Obviously he's addressing Drona, and he said Dvijottama. We have discussed before: Dwijottama, Dwija, Brahmin. Brahmin is considered twice born. One is a physical birth, and the second is a birth in this knowledge of who you are, which starts at the time of Upanayam when the Guru gives a mantra in his ear. Then he goes to the Gurukul to get that education and becomes established in this knowledge.

That's why it's called Dwij -- because the first is just a physical birth for a limited being, and the second birth is where he takes birth as a wise person.

So therefore they are called Dwijaha. Drona, being a Brahmin, is Dwijaha. But he said Dwijottama -- you are the best among the Brahmins. Now this could have been the best compliment in a normal situation.

But in this situation it is not because we know or at least the society knew at the time. Brahmins are soft hearted. They are not fighting type. They are not war mongerers. They are not the ones who can be in the situation. They want to avoid this type of conflict.

We have seen that that's how Karna was caught by Parasuram. Karna went to Parasuram because he realized that other than Drona, Parasuram could teach him what the other Pandavas were learning. Parasuram had taken a vow that he would not teach any Kshatriya, because he wanted to eliminate Kshatriyas from this planet. He would not teach this art of warfare to any Kshatriya.

So Karna goes there as a Dvija, as a Brahmin. He disguises himself as a Brahmin -- lies that he is a Brahmin.

And then obviously he was a good student. One day, the teacher was sleeping with his head in Karna's lap. A bumblebee comes and sits on Karna's thigh. He realizes that if he moves, his Guru will be disturbed, and he does not want to make his Guru uncomfortable at all.

The Guru is in a deep sleep. This bumblebee bores through his flesh and blood is oozing out of that wound. He tolerates all that pain but does not move a muscle, so that his Guru won't be disturbed in his sleep. The blood comes running down his thigh, under the Guru's head.

The Guru wakes up because of the warm blood he feels. He sees what's happening, realizes what has occurred, and Karna says, I'm fine. But the Guru was angry. He said: you lied to me. You are not a Brahmin. A Brahmin would not have been capable of tolerating this kind of pain. You are a Kshatriya who lied to me.

And then obviously, as the story goes, Karna asked for forgiveness and all of that. But Parasuram said: you will have this knowledge, but it will not come handy to you when you really need it in the battlefield. You will lose this knowledge.

The relevance here is that Dvija is not a positive compliment when you are in a war. So Duryodhana reminds Drona: look, I know you are a great teacher and a great archer and a great warrior, but in the end you are a Dvija -- so don't be soft-hearted here.

It's actually his fear that maybe this guy will go soft-hearted and will not fight this battle. Sangartam tan bravi mi te -- therefore I am going to now describe to you who are the great warriors on our side. Don't go soft-hearted on me.

We have also great people on our side. You don't need to worry about it. You just do your job. Bhavan Bismast Chakranastha starting with you Bhavan, you who are on our side so that we feel that we are protected. Bhavan, you Bisma, Karna, Krupastha, Samitin, Jaya and Krupacharya who are victorious. All these people have good track record of resume of winning battle.

Asvathama, Vikranscha, Somadatt, Tatha, Evacharya and then all others like Asvathrama. Last time we have seen Kurupacharya is Dronacharya's brother in law and Aswathrama is Dronacharya's son. So Swamiji says here or we can't have in one family all this bravery and valor. So he's obviously making it up a little more than what he should be. But whatever it is, these are all great warriors. Swathama was more like Duryodhana.

He was Duryodhana's best friend and was basically looking for this: if he stays with Duryodhana and Duryodhana wins the war, then he will have a kingdom of his own. Drona and Drupada were friends and they probably learned together at some Guru's place. Drona goes to Drupada asking for some favor to make him a Raja somewhere, and Drupada insults him.

That's where their animosity started. So the long story all weaved into it. But in the end basically Duryodhana said these are all people, the great people on our side and not only the main characters but Anyeche, Baha, Bahasuraha, Madharte, Tyakta, Jeevitaha and there are many others on our side who are ready to give up their life for me. Many, many brave people are on our side. In other words, they're committed to fight this war. Yudwijotama, I'm not sure about you but I'm sure about everybody else.

They are committed to fight. So let's do the right thing here. Nana Sastra Praharanaha, Sarve, Yuddha, Visharadaha. Not only they are ready to fight for me but they are equipped with various types of weapons. So we are well equipped. We have a human capital, we have technology.

So let's not worry about it. Yudda Visaradaha they are expert in warfare. This verse obviously confuses everybody -- why "Apar Yaptam," insufficient? Now every translation I have seen does say "insufficient," even though it seems that "unlimited" is more appropriate here. I had asked Swamiji one time: Swamiji, all this translation, where does that come from?

And Swamiji says we don't get involved in this because you need a Sanskrit pandit to translate this. He says there are Sanskrit pandits in Kashi who have translated the Bhagavad Gita after thorough discussion, and that's the translation we use. So even the Chinmaya Mission translation does not really come from Chinmayananda and the Swamis -- it actually came from Pandits who decided on the translation. So we have to take it as it is and say Apar Yaptam in our vernacular languages.

Apariyapta is insufficient. He's saying it's insufficient. Now remember, his mentality is that of a thief. He always feels that he is incomplete. No matter how much that person has, he will always feel there is something more he should have.

And therefore his vision about what we have is never that we are sufficient. We have plenty, so why even be fighting this battle? But even the army he sees as insufficient. All these people who went on Pandava's side -- they actually should have been on my side, and then it would have been much better. And my army is protected by Bheeshma, because he knew that Bheeshma has taken a vow that as long as he lives, he will guard the throne of Hastinapur.

Whoever is in Hastinapur, he will be protecting him. He also knows that Bheeshma has Ichamrityu -- he will only die if he wants to die. As long as Bheeshma is alive, he is protected. So on one hand, he knows that as long as Bheeshma is on his side, he obviously does not have to worry. But at the same token he thinks: if I had more, then I would have felt a little better about it.

So he said: Apariyaptam Tadasnakam Balam Vishna Bhirakshitam -- our strength protected by Bhishma still feels a little insufficient. Whereas on the other side, Pariyaptam twidam Etesham Balam Bhima Bhirakshitam -- they are protected by Bhima. And then last time, Sid or somebody pointed out that this is not correct. Bhima was not the commander; the commander was changing every day in this army.

If you read the Mahabharata -- and I have never read it, so I'm not an authority on this.
snippets.reflection:
These opening verses reveal a profound truth: "As is the faith, so is the person" (yo yacchraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ). Krishna teaches that our faith is not merely what we intellectually believe, but the deep orientation of our entire being - it arises from our svabhava, our inherent nature shaped by past experiences and tendencies. This faith, whether sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic, colors everything we perceive and pursue. When Arjuna asks about those who worship with faith but set aside scriptural guidance, Krishna does not condemn them. Instead, he reveals that faith itself is the defining factor of who we become.

Take time today to honestly examine: What do you truly have faith in? Not what you think you should believe, but what actually drives your decisions when no one is watching. When faced with a difficult choice, what conviction do you fall back on? Consider keeping a "faith journal" this week - note the moments when your deepest convictions reveal themselves, whether in moments of stress, temptation, or quiet reflection. Ask yourself: Does my faith lead me toward light and clarity (sattva), toward restless ambition (rajas), or toward confusion and inertia (tamas)? Remember, awareness of our current state is the first step toward transformation.

snippets.title: Day 205: Food and Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान्यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः |

अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः |

कर्षयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः |
snippets.transliteration:
yajante sāttvikā devānyakṣarakṣāṃsi rājasāḥ .

aśāstravihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ .

karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṃ bhūtagrāmamacetasaḥ .
verseTranslations: The Pure worship the true God; the Passionate, the powers of wealth and magic; the Ignorant, the spirits of the dead and of the lower orders of nature.
Those who practise austerities not commanded by scripture, who are slaves to hypocrisy and egotism, who are carried away by the fury of desire and passion,
They are ignorant. They torment the organs of the body; and they harass Me also, Who lives within. Know that they are devoted to evil.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 17, Sraddha Traya Vibhaga Yoga, three types of sraddha. The chapter opened with Arjuna's question: if someone has not understood the Sastras, or even having understood, he sets aside the prescription in the Shastras, but has faith in what he thinks is right and is pursuing his faith -- does that faith be considered Sattvik, Rajasik, or Tamasic?

That's a simple question, simply because in the last chapter, the clear advice by Krishna is to follow the prescriptions of the Sastras in deciding what to do and what not to do. And as we have seen, Sastras literally means the collective wisdom of your culture, your society, your ancestors. So unless I really rely on the wisdom of my ancestors, I will have no foundation to decide what is right and wrong. Any profession, any science -- you build on what has already been tried and true and proven in the labs or in workshops, and then say, now where do I go from here?

So the clear prescription was not to ignore the wisdom of your ancestors, your civilization, your culture, and then decide what is right and wrong for you. It's not saying that you don't think yourself, but think based on the tried and true wisdom. When we go to high school and learn chemistry and the teacher says H2O makes water, well, you have to have some faith in him. Unless you have faith, you will not learn, because you have faith in the teacher that you will accept that and then you will prove yourself going to the lab. So the prescription was follow the Sastras and decide what to do and not to do. Arjuna's question is, if someone completely sets aside the prescription in Sastras for lack of knowledge or lack of faith in the Sastras, but he has a faith in something he believes in, does that faith to be classified as Sattvik Rajasik or Tamasic?

Because as we have seen, everything can be classified Sattvik, Rajasik, or Tamasic. Bhagavan said: I'll tell you, it's not a one-label-fits-all type of answer. Your faith will be as you are. My faith will be as per my experiences. Every time I walk into the airport, I'm absolutely sure the plane will be on time -- if the last few times I went there the plane was on time, I'll say it will be on time. But if the last few times I'd been going there it was always late, what will be my faith? Chances are my flight will be delayed.

So anytime I'm going to India, what I do is I leave about six hours of gap between when I go from Richmond to New Jersey airport and New Jersey to Mumbai. We have no faith that the flight from Richmond to New Jersey will take me in time. They say, keep a two-hour gap. No, no -- six hours gap.

You don't want to miss an international flight. That's my faith in our airline based on my experience. And then the other people may have other things. So Bhagavan said that your faith is Sattva Anurupa. It in accordance with your own self, your own core of your being, core of your mind. So my faith will be what my experiences are.

Faith is something that comes intuitively to you, more like a tendency. Why do I like music? I don't know -- that's my tendency. But the more I follow my tendency, the more I will be following that path. The more I have faith in the Gita, the more Gita I will read; the more I read the Gita, the more faith I have in it.

So the two are wedded together. The more faith I have, the more I will pursue that path. The more I pursue that path, the more my faith increases. So Bhagavan said, it is the individual who decides whether he will have faith which is Sattvik, Rajasic, or Tamasic, depending on the tendencies of his mind. Yajante Sattvika Devan -- so if the overall makeup of my mind is Sattvik, what will I do?

Well, I will follow Sattvic beings. I will strive to pursue or worship divine beings. My role models depend on my tendencies. If I am pursuing wealth, my role model is Bill Gates. If I want to be a great leader, my role model will be Mahatma Gandhi. If I want to be spiritual, my role model will be Swami Chinmayananda.

Depending on my faith, my role model would be different. That's as simple as that. So Bhagavan said: Sattvika Yajante Devan -- one whose makeup is Sattvik, predominantly Sattvik. These are not exclusive qualities of one person, one thing, or one being. Everything is made up of some combination of Sattvik, Rajasik, and Tamasic.

But if my mental makeup is predominantly Sattvik, I will be pursuing the Deva, the divine beings, Yaksa, Rakshansi, Rajasaha, those who are Rajasik will pursue or worship Yakshas and Rakshasas. From the Puranas we have the descriptions of Devas and Yakshas and Rakshasas, but it's simply told here is Sattvik will follow the divine beings, Rajasik will follow the one which has wealth and power. Yaksas are supposed to be wealthy beings. There is a story in Mahabharata 1 where Yudhishthir goes to this lake when he wants to drink water. That lake was controlled by a Yaksha. Yaksha said, you can't drink water till you answer all my questions.

If you answer all my questions, I'll let you take water. In other words, he was the controller of that lake. He was wealthy enough to control his lake. These days people own islands because they're wealthy. So the Yaksa that the wealthy beings, and as Swamiji points out here in Purana, I say they're Kubera's brothers or cousins. So they're wealthy beings or Rakshasa's immense power.

There are stories in Puranas about Rakshasas' immense power. In other words, even in society there will be people who are Sattvic and people who are wealthy and powerful. So if my tendency is Rajasic, then I will be pursuing the wealthy and powerful. If my quality is Sattvik, I'll pursue the divine being. Preta Bhuta Ganas -- the others who have Tamasic qualities will pursue the Preta and Bhuta. We obviously know from our vernacular languages that Preta and Bhuta are the dead spirits.

Now in this society, if there are three people pursuing the same goal of making a million, the one with a Sattvik tendency will say: let's find some creative way which will help the society and at the same time create the wealth -- and that's how I'll make my million. The Rajasik will say: let's destroy my competition or take over someone else, and I'll get my million. And the last one will say: let's pursue the lottery, buy the Mega Millions. All three have the same goal, but all three have a different avenue to reach there.

Now all three are working hard to achieve the same goal -- making a million. The Sattvic person is working very hard to achieve his goal creatively. The Rajasic is working just as hard but competitively. The Tamasic is also working hard but relying on chance. Their means are different, depending on where their faith is. The one who's pursuing the lottery has complete faith that he cannot get a million in any other way -- this is the only way he can make a million.

The one who wants to employ himself in a business has complete faith he can succeed that way. And the Sattvic person has complete faith that if he creates something good for society, he will also benefit from it. Depending on your own experiences, your mental makeup is made. That mental makeup now defines where I have the faith in. That faith will lead me into my actions.

So Bhagavan said these faiths cannot be labeled simply because someone is not following Sastra. He may not know the Sastras but has Sattvic tendencies -- he will follow Sattva. He may not know Sastras but has Rajasic tendencies -- he is following Rajasik. And he may not know Sastras because he's Tamasic -- he's following Tamas.

So Preta and Bhuta are the dead spirits. In other words, normal society will consider that to be a non-starter. Somebody says, well Neil, why don't you buy a lottery? I never won anything in my life. Let's not waste my dollar.

At least I have a dollar. After that I won't have a dollar. But somebody has the faith and says, well, I have $10, I'll put nine of them in the lottery. I'm pretty much against the lottery, by the way, because we're taxing the people who can afford the least in the society. They say lottery is good for education, it will reduce your taxes. No -- it's a tax on the people who cannot afford that tax. Most lottery tickets are bought by people who can least afford it.

But they are following their faith. Asastra vihitam ghoram tapyante ye tapo janaha. Now I have my faith that this is how I can pursue my goal. My faith is dependent on my experiences.

So now I'm pursuing my goal vigorously because I'm as sincere as anybody else. But I'm pursuing it in a field which I think is the most conducive for me to achieve that -- not knowing what is right or wrong because I did not take time to find out. I'm working very hard. As I said last time, I want to go to New Jersey, but I'm driving as fast as I can on I-95 south just because I didn't take time to figure out whether New Jersey is north or south, without knowing what is right or wrong from the tried and true wisdom of my society.

If I had just taken the directions from AAA or a GPS, it would tell me New Jersey is to the north. But I didn't take it. I didn't want to take that time. They're working very hard. They are pursuing these austerities vigorously. Dambha ahankara sanyuktaha -- because they're filled with dambha, hypocrisy.

And ahankara, ego -- nobody knows better than I do. So who are they to tell me that New Jersey is to the north? I know it's got to be this way. Ahankara sanyuktaha, Kama raga balanvitaha -- they are propelled to do this by what? Kama, desire, and raga, attachment.

Kama and raga are propelling my actions, and I think my happiness lies there. My goal is to achieve happiness, just as everybody else's is. But I think my happiness lies in these actions, where others are saying no -- that's where you have the danger that you probably will be unhappy. We tell our kids: don't do that. But at that time the child does not think he is going to get hurt.

But if he listens to you -- you as an elder person have learned from your own experience that jumping from that second floor is going to get you in trouble. A young person, at the age of 8 or 9 or 10, thinks he can do anything he wants. Propelled by that desire and attachment, he wants to show off to his friend that he can jump from the second story. We have seen that in our childhood. Hypocrisy and arrogance, the ego filled with that and propelled by attachment and desire.

And they are putting vigorous actions in the fields which they consider appropriate for them. Karshayantaha Sarirastham bhutagramam a Chaitasaha. This is a description of someone who has completely ignored the advice from the Sastras. We read the Bhagavad Gita every Sunday -- what do we do after that? The Bhagavad Gita says one thing, but that's not really what we follow.

So now we fall into this category. Knowing fully well, we set aside the prescription in the Shastra. We are propelled by our desire and our attachments, and also we are dambha ahankara sanyukta.
snippets.reflection:
These verses present a sobering warning about misguided worship and extreme practices. Krishna describes those who, driven by hypocrisy (dambha), ego (ahankara), desire (kama), and attachment (raga), perform harsh austerities not prescribed by scriptures. Most striking is the statement that such people "torment the organs of the body" and "harass Me also, Who lives within" - revealing that when we abuse our body-mind complex through extreme or misguided practices, we are actually disrespecting the Divine that dwells within us. The sattvic worship Devas (divine beings representing light and wisdom), the rajasic pursue Yakshas and Rakshasas (representing wealth and power), while the tamasic follow spirits of the dead.

Examine your own spiritual practices and the role models you follow. Who are your "Devas" - the ideals and beings you worship through your attention and energy? If you seek wealth above all, your role model might be a billionaire; if wisdom, perhaps a sage; if power, perhaps a political figure. Today, notice when ego or the desire to show off enters your spiritual practice. Do you meditate to genuinely purify the mind, or partly to feel superior to others? Do you practice austerities that honor the body as a temple, or do you engage in extreme behaviors driven by pride or self-punishment? Ask yourself: Are my practices nourishing the Divine within, or harassing it?

verseTranslations: The food which men enjoy is also threefold, like the ways of sacrifice, austerity and almsgiving. Listen to the distinction.
The foods that prolong life and increase purity, vigour, health, cheerfulness and happiness are those that are delicious, soothing, substantial and agreeable. These are loved by the Pure.
Those in whom Passion is dominant like foods that are bitter, sour, salty, over-hot, pungent, dry and burning. These produce unhappiness, repentance and disease.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Shraddha Traya Vibhaga Yoga, yoga of three types of faith. We have seen in the last chapter, when Bhagavan ended the chapter, he gave the advice to Arjuna: do everything in life according to the advice given in the scriptures or by the sages. That's how you will acquire more divine qualities. And these divine qualities are liberating -- they will liberate you from your limitations which are creating sorrows in life.

If you do not follow that, you may incur more negative tendencies which will be more binding. They bind you to this material world. So Bhagavan said that follow the scriptural advice when you decide what to do and what not to do in this world. So obvious question Arjuna had was that what about the people who never had a chance to refer to scriptures? Either by their own choice, that they didn't think it was important, or they never had an opportunity to learn scriptures. And we can imagine in that society, probably the larger mass of people were not allowed to even learn scripture.

Arjuna had a very logical doubt: what happens to all those people? They are working in this world with faith. They have a faith that this is the right way to live life, which will give them happiness. Because at the end of the day, as we have discussed, the goal of life is to be happy. No matter who we are, our goal in life is very simple.

We all want to be happy. If I look at my entire life, it is divided into two pursuits: one is to achieve happiness, and the other is to avoid unhappiness. Bhagavan said we are all working toward the same goal. But those who do not listen to the advice in the scriptures, the books of knowledge, teachers, wise people, ancestors -- they suffer by developing wrong tendencies. Those who follow the advice from the wise people, because they've gone through that and come to the conclusion this is the right way to act, will benefit from that and acquire the divine, liberating tendencies.

Arjuna said: the people in this world, working in their field, in their life, with faith but having no knowledge of what is prescribed in the scriptures -- as I said, either by choice (they decided it's not worth it) or they never had a chance. So what is the nature of their sraddha? They have sraddha too -- that this is where I'll get my happiness in life. Is it Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic? Because if it is just out of my ignorance, one would say that is tamasic. Bhagavan said it is all of the above.

It can be any of the three. If you have not referred to the scriptures but still have faith, your faith can be of any of these three, and at any given time it can be one or another. It is predominantly whatever my personality is -- my faith will be according to my personality. As the faith, so is the person. As the person, so is the faith.

So it's a symbiotic relationship. Whichever field I choose to work in, I eventually become an expert in that. I go to architecture school, work in architecture field. More I work in that field, more I get knowledge. More my tendencies become to work in that field. And after about 30 years you become an expert in that field.

At that point somebody says, you made a mistake, Neil, you should have gone to medical school -- you would have made lots of money. Yeah, I'd want to switch overnight but can't do it because my tendencies are now firmly established in the field I've been working in all my life. Bhagavan says the same thing happens with your shraddha. Whatever shraddha you have, you will continue to pursue that path and have similar experiences. And it will make your shraddha even firmer.

The firmer your shraddha becomes, the more it becomes your nature, your personality. That's how you can identify or label a person as a Sattvic person, a Rajasic person, or a Tamasic person, depending on the predominant nature of their personality. Bhagavan said their faith can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. And then he said that depending on their personality, everything they do will be guided by that faith. The food they eat, the disciplines they practice, the charities they do -- all will be guided by their personality, whether Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic.

And therefore he said, now we'll discuss in detail what these are. So we have seen the verse: Ahara Tu Api Sarvasya Trividho Bhavati Priyaha. We have to pay attention to the words. Here all he's saying is that ahara, the food, also becomes dear to these people in three different ways. Depending on your personality, your faith, your tendencies, you will like one type of food or another. He did not say that these foods are inherently Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic.

These qualities depend on the mood of your mind. We all know that there are times you like to eat some chatpata, spicy food. And times you really want to stay away from it. Early morning somebody says have idli dosa for breakfast. But we went to the South and there, early morning, the breakfast comes -- idli dosa. And I said, are you serious that you want me to eat idli dosa at this hour?

I thought it's lunchtime. No, in the breakfast also idli dosa. So depending on my mood, I like one type of food or another. Yajna, tapah, tatha danam -- not only food is driven by the mood of my mind. These sattvic, rajasic and tamasic qualities are not inherent in the things we see in this world.

They're actually the qualities of my mind -- the moods of my mind. That mind will decide whether something is sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic. So depending on my mood, I will decide what I like. Bhagavan said even the food you like will be dependent on the mood of your mind. Whether sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic. Even the efforts you make.

Yajna -- traditionally we call that havan, which we do with fire and put offerings in it. Basically all your life you're doing yajna by putting your efforts, offering your actions in this yajna of your life. That will also be determined by the mood of your mind. The disciplines which you follow -- tapas, austerities -- not just sitting with folded legs. Everything you do to discipline yourself is basically tapas.

If you have to run a marathon, you have to do tapas for that, right? You have to train for that. That's your tapas. That will be determined by the mood of your mind -- whether sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic.

Where do I make charities when I give something back to society? He says that will also depend on the mood of my mind. Some people will donate toward hospitals and health care. Some toward a sports complex. Whatever you think is dear to your heart, that's where you are going to make charities. Bhagavan said everything in your life will be driven by your faith, your conviction -- whether it is sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic.

Your life will be driven by that. And therefore he said, let's talk about how that affects you. Ayuh sattva bala arogya sukha priti vivardhanah rasyah snigdhah sthira hrdya aharah sattvikapriyah. You really have to be very careful in reading this verse. First of all, it says that if the mood of my mind is sattvic, what do I want to get out of my life? My sattvic mood will say that I want Ayuh -- I want to prolong my life through my efforts.

I want to live a pure life, a long life. Bala, strength -- doesn't mean I want to be like Hercules, but means I don't have to be dependent on others for help. Arogya, health. Health is my real nature. I don't wake up any morning and say, I don't know why I'm feeling so good -- let me call my doctor, there's got to be something wrong. Because that's my nature, my real nature. I take it for granted. My health is my nature.

It's when I'm not healthy that I notice. Whatever it is, let's take care of it, because it's not my real nature. So Bhagavan said sukha, priti -- I want to be comfortable. Nobody wants to be uncomfortable.

I want to choose the food which will make me comfortable. Priti doesn't mean falling in love with somebody. Priti means something that makes me feel good. So I decide what my goal is in eating food first. My goal in eating food is to have ayuh, sattva, bala, arogya, sukha, and priti.

And I want to eat the food which promotes this kind of health. So that's the mood of my sattvic mind. And therefore the food he or she chooses would be rasyah, snigdhah, sthira, hrdya. Snigdhah doesn't mean oily with lots of calories. It means fresh, substantial, has nutritional value. Hrdya means agreeable, which works with my system, which I can digest.

Rasyah, snigdhah, sthira, hrdya. So either I'm living to eat, or eating to live, is the question. Here he says the sattvic person will first decide what they want to get out of food. This is the purpose of eating: I want to increase my ayuh, sattva, my purity, my strength, my health, my comfort and my mood. So let's find out which food will be agreeable for me to do that.

And we find that rasyah, snigdhah, sthira, hrdya -- the fresh foods, pure food, healthy food -- are the ones which will give me that. Therefore sattvic people like this type of food. That's all Bhagavan said here. He did not say eat this or don't eat this, or that people who eat other foods are not good. He said because your goal of life is to increase these types of qualities, you will choose that type of food.

In the next verse he says katva amla lavana atyushna tikshna ruksha vidahinah, ahara rajasasya ishta duhkha shoka amaya pradah. This type of food rajasic people like -- bitter, sour, salty, overly hot, pungent, dry, burning. But in the end he says the result would be this. See, in the first verse he said what the sattvic goal is. The sattvic person decided what their goal is first, then chose the food. The rajasic person decided the food I like, that's why I'm going to eat it.

Then Bhagavan said the result would be duhkha, shoka, amaya pradah. This food gives you duhkha, discomfort. Anybody who went to a party, had a good dose of hors d'oeuvres, and then dinner at 10:30 -- tell me, was that the best night you had? It was uncomfortable. I'll tell you what, I didn't sleep well that night.

I wish I had controlled myself. Shoka, grief, and amaya, disease. Katva, amla, lavana, atyushna, tikshna, ruksha, vidahinah -- bitter, sour, salty, extremely hot, pungent, dry, burning. Now Bhagavan didn't say this food is bad. He also did not say don't eat this food.

He said the result of this food will be duhkha, shoka, amaya pradah. These foods will result in discomfort, grief and disease. But he said when I'm in a rajasic mood, I don't really have time to think about my food. So whatever is tasty, I will eat that. In a rajasic mode, it's not that one group of people only eat this and another group only eat that. When I am in a sattvic mood I'll be very careful about what I'm eating. When I'm in a rajasic mood I'll say I don't really care -- I'm on a one-day trip, whatever.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce a fascinating principle: even something as basic as food preference reveals the texture of our mind. Krishna describes how sattvic foods are "rasyah snigdhah sthira hrdya" - juicy, wholesome, substantial, and pleasing to the heart - and they promote longevity, purity, strength, health, and cheerfulness. Rajasic foods are bitter, sour, salty, overly hot, pungent, and dry, leading to discomfort, grief, and disease. Notice that Bhagavan does not command "eat this, not that" - rather, he reveals that our food preferences mirror our mental state, and our food choices reinforce that state.

This week, practice mindful eating as a spiritual discipline. Before each meal, pause and ask: "Am I eating to live, or living to eat?" Notice your cravings - are you reaching for fresh, nourishing foods that promote vitality (sattvic), or for stimulating "comfort foods" loaded with spices and calories (rajasic)? When in a hurry, do you grab whatever is available without thought (tamasic)? The teaching here is not about rigid dietary rules, but about using food as a mirror for self-knowledge. Try one meal this week eaten in complete silence, savoring each bite, noticing how different foods affect your energy and mental clarity. Remember: your body is the vehicle for spiritual growth, and how you fuel it reflects - and shapes - your inner state.

snippets.title: Day 207: Om Tat Sat
snippets.sanskrit:
यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत् |

अफलाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते |

अभिसन्धाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत् |
snippets.transliteration:
yātayāmaṃ gatarasaṃ pūti paryuṣitaṃ ca yat .

aphalāṅkṣibhiryajño vidhidṛṣṭo ya ijyate .

abhisandhāya tu phalaṃ dambhārthamapi caiva yat .
verseTranslations: The Ignorant love food which is stale, not nourishing, putrid and corrupt, the leavings of others and unclean.
Sacrifice is Pure when it is offered by one who does not covet the fruit thereof, when it is done according to the commands of scripture, and with implicit faith that the sacrifice is a duty.
Sacrifice which is performed for the sake of its results, or for self-glorification - that, O best of Aryans, is the product of Passion.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Shraddha Traya Vibhaga Yoga, three types of sraddhas. Culturally we are obsessed with classifications, so we classify everything. In this case, Arjuna asked the question: if somebody does not have any guidance from the Sastras -- either voluntarily rejected or not available -- but he still has faith and is working, propelled by his faith, what type of faith is that? Bhagavan says: as the man, so is his faith; also, as the faith, so is the man. Both have a very synergistic relationship.

My faith and who I am are basically very closely related to each other. And therefore this chapter is all about explaining the types of faith one can develop. If I have a goal to be one type of a person or other, I should examine what type of faith do I have? Or I should at least see that what type of faith will lead me to the goal which I want to achieve. So therefore the whole discussion about the three types of faith, and obviously it was quite anticipated after learning 16 chapters of Bhagavad Gita, that these three types of faith correspond with the three qualities of Maya, Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Everything can be the Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasic.

Once again we have to remember that nothing we have discussed ever said that one quality can be exclusive of other two. The one quality always comes with the little shades of the other two. But it is the predominance of my personality or my faith makes me who I am. The worship people do are also depending on their faith. Sattvicas will worship the Devas -- in other words, to get the illumination of their mind. They want the light of knowledge in their internal instruments. The Rajasic wants to achieve wealth, prosperity, something they think will give them infinite happiness. But we know it is transitory.

The goal is the same for all of us: liberation from our sorrows and unhappiness. We should examine whether my path is the one which will lead me to that goal. And therefore the discussion. Even the likes and dislikes of people depend on their personality, their faith. The type of food I like depends on which mood my mind is in.

So when I'm in a sattvic mode, the type of food I like will be what we discussed. Sighnaha rasaha, that which promotes health. When I'm in rajasik mood, something which tastes good and when I'm tamasik mood, whatever is available now, this mood continues to change in our day to day life. Also, at times I would love to listen to Jagjit Singh's ghazal. But there are times I shut him off -- this is not the time.

I'm sometimes driving for like a couple of hours. You normally think that I'll be putting Jagjit Singh ghazal or two hours. I never listen to it. I want to listen to Bloomberg or CNBC or something which keeps my mind alert about this world. Because I'm not in a mood of listening to music. So mood of my mind determines what I like and dislike.

This mood continues to change. But my goal is to make sure the predominance of my mind is in the one or the other which I am currently convinced that which gives me the liberation from my sorrow. And therefore this elaborate discussion about these three faiths: aphalakankshi bhih yajnaha. We have seen what they worship, what types of likes and dislikes they have and therefore what they receive, the ahara, what they eat, what they receive through their senses. Type of music I like. All that is depending on the mood of my mind.

So now it says what type of yajna, the actions. Yajna basically is a sacrifice. When we sacrifice something we are offering to someone. Every action of mine in this world is my Yajna, my offering to this world. But whether I'm offering with expectations or no expectations is what makes that action either a yajna or a normal action.

So Aphalakankshi bhih Yajnah Vidhidrishtah ya ijyate Yastavyam eveti manah samadhaya sa Sattvikah. That yajna or sacrifice which is offered without desire for fruits and performed as per the ordinance -- in other words, done methodically. I can do something haphazardly or I can do something methodically. Both will have different results. You know, when I first went to architecture school, the first thing they teach you -- well, they don't teach you, actually, you have to learn on your own.

In those days we used to have drawing boards. You put a paper on it and then you have T-squares and set squares -- those of you in engineering understand. For the first two months, I never understood how to do that, because nobody ever tells you how to align this paper. So you haphazardly start something and it never really comes out right. One day I had to ask my seniors. One of my friends, who was a senior student -- I said: you know, Gupta, this never comes out right. All my borders are always off.

He said: Neil, let me tell you how to do it. First thing, you set your board correctly. Then make sure your seat is comfortable so you can reach everything. Then align your paper to your T-square, not to your board. And that was like an eye-opener to me -- oh, that's why his drawing comes out better than mine.

Because when I was putting the effort before, without Vidhi Purvakam, I had never tried to find out what is the right method, or at least had no knowledge of it. Once I found out the right method, then I realized why it is so important. Before you start, make sure everything is correct -- drawing board is stable, my seat is stable, nothing is falling apart, everything is aligned. Now things work out much better than before.

So Bhagavan said, one who is doing Vidhi Purvakam -- Vidhi Drishtah, Yastavyam Eveti Manah Samadhaya Sa Sattvikah -- with the firm faith that sacrifice is a duty. Why am I doing it? Because we always say: well, if I don't have any desire for fruits, then there is no motivation -- why would I be doing anything? If I say you go to work but there is no expectation for a paycheck at the end of the month, what is the motivation? Bhagavan said, it's the other way around. The paycheck should be the byproduct of your actions, and you have to be absolutely certain it will be there, because you have faith in the law of karma.

The law of karma says your actions will be rewarded appropriately. One of the persons I interviewed long, long, long time ago when I was in Nairobi -- I would never forget him. I never hired him, but I still never forget him. I asked him: what salary do you expect? And he said: whatever you think is appropriate is good for me. And then he added: I believe that whatever I'm worth, I'll get paid, whether by this employer or the next one.

You may underpay me today, but my next employer will recognize my worth and will pay me for it. I will never forget him. A complete faith in his ability, and that his worth will be paid for. Bhagavan said, if you have that faith then only motivation you have to do your work is that this is my duty. That duty boundness is your motivation. I am a human being and therefore this is my duty. I'm a part of this community, therefore this is my duty.

I'm part of this nation as a citizen. Therefore this is my duty. You take a role upon yourself and then see what your duty is and see whether you're performing those duties. And all your actions, because of the role you've taken, now motivate you to perform them. When you become a father, when you become a mother -- previously you were just a guy.

Now you are a husband and then you are a father. Your duties continue to evolve and see whether you are motivated by those additional duties which you have taken upon yourself by taking this role. Bhagavan says the one who is performing these Yajnas in this world, performing sacrifices, offering their actions -- first of all, no predetermined expectation for the results. The results will be there. If I put actions, results will be there.

But what that would be I do not know. Because the results are always in future. Actions are always in present. Results are always in somebody's control. Because if I act in this world, the world will react. So it's in control of the world.

Actions are always in my control. With that understanding I will not dissipate my energy in worrying about the results but use all my energy into my actions. Therefore my actions will be better. And therefore my results will be better. I have figured out my duty is this and also took some guidance. Therefore, you become the first-time mom -- all those books, and then you take seminars. That's why I'm so fascinated. When my son Neeraj was born, I was completely unprepared for everything. When he was born I was working in my office because my father in law called me and said I think they had taken Meena to whatever the room. You can come as quickly as you can. I took no hurry part very seriously.

So by the time I reached there, he was already born. If you take guidance, then you will do things right. And obviously Meena never let me forget that, even today. So that is the result of my lack of Vidhi Purvakam. And then with a complete faith that this is what I want to do because this is my duty. And see such an action is satvikaha.

Such a yajna is Sattvic Yajna. All my actions -- if I define and say Aphalakankshi, in other words no predetermined result -- I have decided: I go for an interview, and all the time I remember my job is to just go and present myself. Whether they select me or not is their problem. So I come back and Jackie asks: so how was the interview? The interview is always good -- it is the result you have to worry about.

So aphalakankshi, vidhi drishta -- sattvic actions and yajnas are like that. Don't have any expectations. Do it because that's your duty and then be firm that that's what you want to do. Abhisandhaya tu phalam -- the next verse contrasts with this. In the first one we are doing it simply because it is my duty. I don't have a predetermined notion of what results will be, and I'm firmly established in that action.

Abhisandhaya tu Phalam -- the next one is similar but with a slight difference. In the first one, I had no expectations. Here, I want to make sure that if I do this, I want to get this thing out of it. Before I make a donation, I ask: what kind of recognition will your organization give me? Can I get a seat on your board, or what other things are you going to do for us? Any action where I want to have a predetermined result -- that is Abhisandhaya tu Phalam. Dambhartham api cha eva yat -- I'm doing it because I want to show off. Let me give a concert where I'm going to show off how good a singer I am.

Ijjyatai Bharata Sreshta Vidhirajasam There are only two motivation I have in performing these actions. One is I want to show off and acquire something which is predetermined. Therefore that motivates me.
snippets.reflection:
These verses complete the teaching on food and introduce the three types of yajna (sacrifice or action). Tamasic food is described as "yatayamam gatarasam puti paryusitam" - stale, tasteless, putrid, and leftover - reflecting a careless, inert approach to life. But the heart of this section lies in understanding sattvic versus rajasic action. The sattvic yajna is performed "aphalakankibhih" (without desire for fruits), following proper method (vidhi-drsta), with the firm conviction that "this is my duty" (yastavyam eva). The rajasic yajna, by contrast, is performed "abhisandhaya tu phalam dambhartham" - with expectation of results and for the sake of showing off.

Reflect on your motivations at work and in service. When you take on a project, do you first calculate "what's in it for me?" (rajasic) or do you recognize it as your duty and trust that appropriate results will follow (sattvic)? Krishna's teaching here connects to the law of karma: if you have faith that your worth will be recognized - if not by this employer, then by another - you can focus entirely on excellence rather than anxiety about rewards. This week, choose one task and approach it purely as duty, without mental bargaining about recognition or reward. Notice how this shifts your energy and the quality of your work. Ask yourself: "Am I performing this action to show off my abilities, or because it genuinely needs to be done?"

snippets.title: Day 208: Three Types of Faith

देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम् |

अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत् |

vidhihīnamasṛṣṭānnaṃ mantrahīnamadakṣiṇam .
