Bhagavan says the one who is performing these Yajnas in this world, performing sacrifices, offering their actions -- first of all, no predetermined expectation for the results. The results will be there. If I put actions, results will be there.

But what that would be I do not know. Because the results are always in future. Actions are always in present. Results are always in somebody's control. Because if I act in this world, the world will react. So it's in control of the world.

Actions are always in my control. With that understanding I will not dissipate my energy in worrying about the results but use all my energy into my actions. Therefore my actions will be better. And therefore my results will be better. I have figured out my duty is this and also took some guidance. Therefore, you become the first-time mom -- all those books, and then you take seminars. That's why I'm so fascinated. When my son Neeraj was born, I was completely unprepared for everything. When he was born I was working in my office because my father in law called me and said I think they had taken Meena to whatever the room. You can come as quickly as you can. I took no hurry part very seriously.

So by the time I reached there, he was already born. If you take guidance, then you will do things right. And obviously Meena never let me forget that, even today. So that is the result of my lack of Vidhi Purvakam. And then with a complete faith that this is what I want to do because this is my duty. And see such an action is satvikaha.

Such a yajna is Sattvic Yajna. All my actions -- if I define and say Aphalakankshi, in other words no predetermined result -- I have decided: I go for an interview, and all the time I remember my job is to just go and present myself. Whether they select me or not is their problem. So I come back and Jackie asks: so how was the interview? The interview is always good -- it is the result you have to worry about.

So aphalakankshi, vidhi drishta -- sattvic actions and yajnas are like that. Don't have any expectations. Do it because that's your duty and then be firm that that's what you want to do. Abhisandhaya tu phalam -- the next verse contrasts with this. In the first one we are doing it simply because it is my duty. I don't have a predetermined notion of what results will be, and I'm firmly established in that action.

Abhisandhaya tu Phalam -- the next one is similar but with a slight difference. In the first one, I had no expectations. Here, I want to make sure that if I do this, I want to get this thing out of it. Before I make a donation, I ask: what kind of recognition will your organization give me? Can I get a seat on your board, or what other things are you going to do for us? Any action where I want to have a predetermined result -- that is Abhisandhaya tu Phalam. Dambhartham api cha eva yat -- I'm doing it because I want to show off. Let me give a concert where I'm going to show off how good a singer I am.

Ijjyatai Bharata Sreshta Vidhirajasam There are only two motivation I have in performing these actions. One is I want to show off and acquire something which is predetermined. Therefore that motivates me.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe tamasic sacrifice and introduce the beautiful teaching on threefold tapas (austerity). Tamasic yajna is "vidhihinam" (without proper method), "mantrahinam" (without sacred intention), "adaksinam" (without appropriate offering), and most importantly, "shraddha-virahitam" (devoid of faith) - it is mere ritual going through the motions. But then Krishna reveals three levels of genuine tapas: physical (sharira tapa) includes worship of the Divine, respect for teachers and the wise, purity, straightforwardness, celibacy, and non-violence. Verbal tapas (vak tapa) is speech that is "anudvegakaram" (non-agitating), true, pleasant, beneficial, and includes study of scriptures.

The teaching on speech is particularly practical: your words should be truthful AND pleasant AND beneficial - not just one or two of these qualities. Many pride themselves on "brutal honesty" while causing harm, or speak sweetly but without truth. This week, before speaking, especially in difficult conversations, pause and ask: "Is what I am about to say true? Is it pleasant (or at least not agitating)? Is it beneficial to the listener?" Practice the discipline of svadhyaya (self-study) by reading even a few verses of sacred text daily. Also examine your physical tapas: Do you show genuine respect to teachers and elders, or is it merely formal? Is there violence in your actions, even subtle forms like impatience or carelessness with others' time and feelings?

snippets.title: Day 209: Food and Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
मनः प्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः |

श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः |

सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत् |
snippets.transliteration:
manaḥ prasādaḥ saumyatvaṃ maunamātmavinigrahaḥ .

śraddhayā parayā taptaṃ tapastattrividhaṃ naraiḥ .

satkāramānapūjārthaṃ tapo dambhena caiva yat .
verseTranslations: Serenity, kindness, silence, self-control and purity - this is austerity of mind.
These threefold austerities performed with faith, and without thought of reward, may truly be accounted Pure.
Austerity coupled with hypocrisy or performed for the sake of self-glorification, popularity or vanity, comes from Passion, and its result is always doubtful and temporary.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Shraddha Vibhaga Yoga, three types of Shraddha. We are coming to the concluding portion of the Bhagavad Gita, and some of us who started from chapter one and have gone through all 16 chapters may start wondering: what about the people who never get a chance to learn the Bhagavad Gita? We are fortunate that we get a chance to learn the Bhagavad Gita one way or another. But what about the people who never thought about learning it or never had a chance? The thought does come to our mind: how do they live their life in a manner which is appropriate? A similar question Arjuna asked in the beginning of this chapter.

Arjuna says: I learned from you all this knowledge which you have given me, and I have Shraddha. But how about the people who have never gone through the scriptures or had the guidance from the scriptures? They also have Shraddha -- everyone has Shraddha in something, that we know. So how is their Shraddha helping them, or how do you classify their Shraddha? What kind of Shraddha is that, without any basis or guidance from any guru or scriptures?

And Bhagavan said each person has a Shraddha according to his or her mental makeup. It as simple as that. Whatever my mental makeup is that will decide what type of things I will be convinced will give me happiness. Bhavan said that there are three types of Shraddha you find in people. One is Sattvik, other is Rajasic, third is Tamasic depending on the texture of the person's mind. We know that texture of our mind changes as the circumstances change.

So depending on my circumstances and the basic nature of my mind, my mind will be either in a Sattvic mode or in a Rajasic mode or a Tamasic mode. But with practice I can control mood of my mind. Even when these circumstances are not conducive, Bhagavan said, that becomes your predominant nature. Some people, no matter what it is, get angry. Some people, no matter what situation has come, enter the room and people will be all agitated. But that is because that is your basic nature.

Your basic nature is what is predominantly the life you are living and how you are reacting to the situations. And that makes up your mental texture. And as your mental texture, so is your faith. And as your faith, so will be your mental texture. So we'll go back and forth between who I am, what I have faith in, what my faith in what make me who I am. So what are the three types of Shraddha?

And this Shraddha is so powerful that it will lead your life. It will guide your life. Wherever I have my conviction that this is right. This is what will give me happiness. It will pursue that path. So our life is not really divided.

What I do in one aspect of my life does not affect the other aspect of my life. Even though we think, well, I compartmentalize my life -- my professional life is different from my personal life -- in reality there is nothing like that. Who you are will permeate through the entire life that you live, whether it is personal, professional, social, or sacred.

So Bhagawan said that that's very important. That you control the texture of your mind. Because that will exhibit your qualities no matter what you are doing. And therefore he said that even to something as simple as Ahar food also you will pursue according to the mental makeup of yours. So in the beginning we had talked about three types of people. What type of food they will like.

That is, something which will give nourishment, is life-giving, promotes health. When you're Rajasic, you will like something which is tasty, feel-good food, comfort food. As soon as the word "comfort" comes, you know it's not really healthy. There is a restaurant in downtown that specializes in comfort food. I finally realized it's all loaded with calories.

That's why it's good. I don't know why Bhagavan made it that way -- why can't comfort food be healthy? I always question why fried food is not the healthiest food. So up till now people have been saying low-fat milk, skim milk, low fat.

I just read article in New York Times said the whole milk is now rising in popularity. Because now the research says the whole milk is actually healthier than your skim milk. Still he said the American association, whatever the doctors recommend that you should have the low calorie diet. But the low calorie diet is gradually losing its glitter. So Bhagavan said that the person with Sattvic mood will find something which is nourishing and health giving. Rajesh will find something which tastes good and comfort food and it's a tamasic.

Will get anything that is available. Does not matter whether it is good or bad. Then we said even the Yajna they perform in a broader sense. All my efforts are basically offered in the Yajna of my life. My life is a Yajna and I am offering all my efforts into it to achieve something good. Bhagawan saying the Yajna is for the greater good.

Even when I consider that I'm doing something for the greater good it will be all as per my mental makeup. Even though I may have good intentions, I may end up doing something which may not be helpful to others. The road to hell is paved with good intentions -- I think the Rolling Stones or somebody said that. So sometimes, even though I have good intentions, my mental makeup will make me put efforts in a place where I feel right. They may not be right.

Therefore he says the Sattvik will put efforts where it is. He has figured out what is the right way to put actions. With faith, with guidance that he will put his effort. When I buy furniture, I'm so impatient. Let's not worry about the instructions. Let's start putting it together.

Halfway I realize that I missed a couple of steps. I have to go back and undo it. Bhagavan said the sattvic person will find out the right way to do it first. Whatever he does, he'll follow the proper method. A rajasic person will say let's get it done. Right or wrong, let's just get it done.

Because I want a result instantaneously -- that which gives me a result instantaneously, that's what I want to do. You don't have patience to go through this step by step, or Vidhi Purvakam. So because we want instantaneous results, I sing a song and people who are just like me, who don't know what music is, say: great, you are doing very well. That's what I was looking for.

So that's Rajasic Yajna -- without any method but with a result, a fruit, in mind. And then the last one we have seen: Yajna where I don't even have faith in it, but it's supposed to be done as per society's norm, or people think I'm not doing right, so let's do it anyway. It's like a factor of safety before an exam -- go to the temple. I know that's not really going to help, but you might as well do it because there is no harm. Just as a factor of safety, maybe let's go to the temple and say: Bhagavan, take care, tomorrow I have an exam. Without faith, without any method, without any reason -- that Yajna, Bhagavan says, is Tamasic Yajna.

Then we came to the Tapas.

This faith affects ahara, yajna, tapa, and dana. So now we came to the Tapas part. Tapas, austerities, or as we loosely translate it, the disciplines which we follow. We discipline ourselves so that we can get some benefit out of it. We exercise routinely for our good health. I want to run a marathon -- I have to prepare myself.

So when we started this discussion, Bhagavan described three types of Tapas. First is at the physical level, next is Tapas at the speech level, and third is Tapas at the mental level, the thoughts level. So at the physical level:

In my activities, Bhagavan described worship of the Devas, Dwijah, Prajnah, and Guru -- deities, divine beings, twice born, wise people, and your guru. Ahimsa and Shaucham are considered Sharira Tapas. All of us, at some level or other, try to do that in our activities.

Next, speech: whatever I speak is non-agitating to others, it is truth but sweet-sounding truth, and it is beneficial to others. That's Tapas at the speech level.

And then Tapas at the mind level, where my mind is silent and not creating unnecessary noise in the background. At the thought level, my thoughts are disciplined. My thoughts are always about my highest goal, which is to achieve that oneness with God, as we call it. But in reality, what we are looking for is unbroken happiness.

When I achieve a state where my happiness remains permanent -- it's not temporary, it's not coming and going -- Bhagavan said that's at the thought level. We know that most of us try at the physical level. The majority of people will fall into a category where they are trying their Tapas at the actions level. Where we fail is at the speech level, because we think that saying something is not hurting anybody.

I'm Ahimsa-minded, but I say things that will hurt other people. "I'm not hitting him, I'm not hurting him -- I'm just saying things." We hear this in the media all the time these days. But Bhagavan said that's also very harmful, and therefore very important to watch. So the majority will stop at the physical level of Tapas in actions, but fail to do it at the speech level.

Then out of the remaining, there are few who try hard to be at the speech level, but most of us fail at the thought level. Because I think nobody knows what I'm thinking. Nobody has any clue what I'm thinking. Only my outward actions and my speech are the things people are noticing or judging me from. Most of our lives we're doing things for others to judge us by, right? That's why I said all marketing works very well.

Because all these people in marketing psychology figured out we never think about what this will look on me. We're only thinking about what it looks on others. So when we look at Tom Cruise wearing a suit which looks good on him, so I think it looks good on him, it should look good on me. So we try to judge ourselves by reflecting in the mirror of the society. And we think that what I am thinking in my mind nobody knows. And therefore we fail to do Tapas at the thought level.

But Bhagavan said all three, when performed together, will yield the good results. So the next verse says: Shraddhaya Paraya Taptam Tapah Trividham Naraihi Aphalakankshi Bhih Yuktaihi Sattvikam Parichakshate. A man with firm devotion -- Shraddhaya Paraya -- with firm faith, when a person is practicing all these three Tapas -- Trividham, all three -- and Aphalakankshi, he has no particular gain in mind. When I'm doing Tapas also, I shouldn't be expecting a particular result, because I must have complete faith in the Karma Phaladata -- that if I put my efforts, the results will be there.

So I constantly hear from my staff: Neil, I don't think that when we come on Sunday and work, anybody is appreciating it. I said, but I don't even know that you came on Sunday. Did you put down your timesheet that you were here on Sunday?
snippets.reflection:
These verses complete the teaching on tapas by introducing the most subtle and important level: mental austerity (manasa tapa). Krishna describes it as "manah prasadah" (serenity of mind), "saumyatvam" (gentleness), "maunam" (silence or contemplation), "atma-vinigrahah" (self-control), and "bhava-samsuddhih" (purity of intention). This is the deepest discipline because, as Krishna notes, most people may discipline their actions and even their speech, but fail at the level of thought - believing that "no one knows what I'm thinking." Yet inner noise eventually corrupts both speech and action. Sattvic tapas is performed with supreme faith, without desire for reward; rajasic tapas is done for "satkaramana-pujartham" - for honor, respect, and praise - and its results are "chalam adhruvam" (unstable and temporary).

This week, practice the discipline of mental silence. Set aside even five minutes daily to simply observe your thoughts without engaging them. Notice: Is your mind predominantly serene or agitated? When you perform good actions, is there a hidden desire for recognition? The teaching reveals that rajasic tapas - discipline performed for applause - yields only temporary, unstable results. Ask yourself honestly: "Would I still practice this discipline if no one ever knew about it?" Also examine bhava-samsuddhih (purity of intention): even if your actions appear sattvic and your speech is controlled, what is the quality of your underlying motivation? True mental austerity means your inner world matches your outer presentation.

snippets.title: Day 210: Austerity
snippets.sanskrit:
मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः |

दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे |

यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः |
snippets.transliteration:
mūḍhagrāheṇātmano yatpīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ .

dātavyamiti yaddānaṃ dīyate.anupakāriṇe .

yattu pratyupakārārthaṃ phalamuddiśya vā punaḥ .
verseTranslations: Austerity done under delusion, and accompanied with sorcery or torture to oneself or another, may be assumed to spring from Ignorance.
The gift which is given without thought of recompense, in the belief that it ought to be made, in a fit place, at an opportune time and to a deserving person - such a gift is Pure.
That which is given for the sake of the results it will produce, or with the hope of recompense, or grudgingly - that may truly be said to be the outcome of Passion.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Sadhatraya Vibhaga yoga, yoga of three types of faiths. We had been learning in Bhagavad Gita that our goal in life is to find ultimate happiness. And one thing we have noticed in our life is that I only can feel happy when my mind is happy. So the goal is to keep this mind in a happy mode. And for that I have to purify my mind, purify my mind and intellect, which is an internal instrument to achieve the ultimate goal of liberation, liberation from my limitations. Right now, the limitations which I have create sorrows and anxieties and regrets.

So to become ultimately happy, I need to get out of my limitations. These limitations exist right now because of my identification with this body, mind, and intellect. Mind is the tool I use to decide whether I am happy or unhappy. So my first goal is to purify my mind, so it remains in a happy mode -- the Mana Prasadah.

So we have seen in this chapter that as my mind, so is my personality, my faith. Bhagavan said that there is someone who has no guidance from the scriptures or from a guru, or from any wise person. But each one of us has faith that I will achieve happiness one way or other. And then wherever my faith is that my happiness lies, those are the pursuit I'll pursue. So Arjuna asked Bhagavan, what kind of a faith is that? Bhagavan said, this faith can be of three different kinds.

This faith can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. Depending on your mind being Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic, you will be convinced your happiness lies in those types of endeavors. So Bhagavan said: your faith, your mental texture -- as the faith, so is the person; as the person, so is the faith. It is very important for me to understand what is making me unhappy, what makes my mind unhappy. And therefore this chapter helps us understand how Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas affect my life.

So the first thing we have seen: Bhagavan said that everything you do in life will be controlled by your mental makeup -- the type of food you like, the type of food you will take, the yajnas which you perform, all the effort you put for the greater good.

But that greater good also include myself. So therefore, all my actions which I perform are basically to achieve their ultimate goal of becoming happy. So those actions which I offer as my sacrifice to get my happiness is my yajna. See, those yajnas will be also of three different types. Sattvik, rajasik and tamasic. So we have seen that the ahara, the sattvik people will eat what is good for them.

And nutritious. Rajasic people will eat whatever is pleasant, whatever feels good. And Tamasic will take whatever is available. Yajnas -- Sattvic people will perform without any expectations for the fruits; the Rajasic will have a goal in mind, what they want to get out of these efforts; and the Tamasic just doesn't care. Then we talked about tapas, austerities -- but in our life we call it discipline.

I have to discipline myself to do this. I was just reading this morning. Now, the new research says that not doing exercise is as bad as smoking cigarettes every day. I better be careful because I'm the one who obviously does not get motivated for exercise that easily. So now I say, oh, I need to exercise. That's something I'm telling myself.

I need to perform to be in a good shape. I want to be in good shape because I want to be healthy. I want to be healthy because that makes me happy. So ultimately, all the tapas which we do, all the disciplines which we practice, are for my happiness. Bhagavan said Tapas is performed at three different levels: you perform at your physical level in your actions, you perform at your speech level,

And you perform at the mental level. So the actions level, My actions should be helping others and not harming others. All my activities, I keep in mind that my actions are for the greater good. Once I take care of the greater good, I am already included in it. Because any action performed by any one person in this universe affects the entire universe. We know that we are all connected with each other.

If one person in family is unhappy, it makes the whole family unhappy. So we know that that why I should be performing this for greater good. Because it ultimately will affect me if someone is suffering. That suffering will eventually come down to me. The bhagavan said that the tapas are performed at three different levels. My activities should be such that it is for the greater good, then at the speech level, my speech should be such that it is truth but pleasant sounding truth.

All we husbands have a good idea of this. When your wife says, how do I look -- do you really want to be truthful? You can be truthful, but it has to be pleasant-sounding. Satyam Vada, Priyam Vada. Bhagavan said your speech should be not only truthful and pleasant, but also beneficial.

If I tell somebody a truth, it has to be for his or her benefit, not just because I want to be Satya Vadi Harishchandra. So that's at the speech level. And then at the mental level -- I may be acting in a manner that looks so Sattvic, I may be speaking so softly and nicely, but if there is noise in my mind which is completely different from my actions and my speech, it will eventually affect my speech and my actions. Therefore, at the mental level, this tapas is what Bhagavan is describing.

Now when I'm performing, it can also be the same three categories of Sattvik, rajasic and tamasic. Again, my tapas is for not for getting anything out of it, but it is something I need to do. So that's the purification of your internal instrument. My tapas is to purify my internal instrument so that I can experience that happiness in my mind. And the last thing we are seeing is the Dana. Charity is our general idea is it is to help others.

In reality, charity is to help yourself. Therefore, Swami Vivekananda said: if you find somebody who is worthy of helping, when you help, thank him for giving you the opportunity to help -- so that you can help yourself. Dhanam is for me to purify my mind and control my ego. Dana gives me the opportunity to purify my mind by giving away things which are in abundance with me. Dana is also a social phenomenon to keep the equilibrium in society. We know that in any given society there will be income inequality.

People are not born with the same resources and therefore there will be inequality. And if I happen to be the one who is fortunate enough to have more than what I need, it becomes my duty and it becomes my means to purify my mind by doing charities. So charities are strictly for me and not for others. So when the I perform charities, I must be very clear why I'm performing these charities. So there Bhagavan said that these charities can be seen as three types. Again, Sattvik Rajasik or Tamarsic.

The first one says Datavyam. The very first requirement for appropriate Sattvic Dana, which will give you the most result of what you're looking for. What you're looking for in your life is to purify your mind to a point that it is always in a sunny, bright mood and you're always happy. You do not want to be grouchy and unhappy, complaining and regretful. So to keep my mind in that mode, I'm performing all of this -- I'm eating the right food, doing the right yajna, doing the right tapas.

When I do also, I have to keep in mind I'm doing it for me and therefore I should know how to make these charities. So the first requirement is Datavyam Iti -- I see a cause and realize there is no other way but for me to help. You are going on a road and you see a little child just about to get hit by a car. You don't sit down and say: is this going to be a Sattvic act or Rajasic? Is it going to be Tamasic?

At that point you have no other thought than I need to help that child get him or her out of the harm's way. So when you do a charity and you have that attitude, it has to be done, it has to be done then that's the right charity. And when you give, you are not obliging that person -- actually, you should thank him: you are obliging me by giving me a chance. If there's no one to help, who are you going to help? When we were at the old temple, we were having this annadhanam, because every Sunday people would come there. But if you are feeding people who are already fed, that is not Annadhanam -- it is just a party you are having.

Every week we all get together. When a person needs food and you give him food, that's Annadhanam. If a person is already fed, you can't give him food and call it charity. Deshe kale cha patre cha ta danam sattvikam smrutam -- when it is given at the right time, at the right place, to the right person.

So if I want to help somebody and that person is sitting in a group of his friends, and I go and say: you told me that you need help --

Here is my hundred dollars which you asked for. You are insulting him in front of his friends and family. He didn't want other people to know his problems. He came to you to ask for help, and now you're helping him at the wrong place. Wrong place, wrong time.

You should also not help somebody who you know does not need any help. Sometimes people say: I don't get a chance to do all this social work. I want to do social work, but people are not making me president of this organization. You shouldn't worry about it. Bhagavan says Patra -- only help someone who really needs help and is seeking help.

When you find that opportunity, take that opportunity that is God's given to you. Consider that as God's blessing that you came across this opportunity to help that person and therefore you're helping. Bhagawan says that's a Sattvik dharam. You're not expecting anything out of it. Just like the example of a child in a harm's way. When you help that child you're not expecting anything, not even thank you from anybody.

At that point your only thought is I need to get that child out of the harm's way. It's the exact same emotion you should have when you give somebody any help: that person needs help, and I have the means -- I need to help that person. Bhagavan says that's Sattvic Dana.

Yatu pratyupakarartham phalam uddishya va punah diyate pariklistam tadanam rajasam smrutam. In contrast to that, the gift which is given in view of receiving something in return -- phalam uddishya. I'll make this donation so I can get this tax benefit.

And at least people will think that he is a good donor. I am doing these charities so it will help my business. So all companies say "we are connected, we give back" -- all that is actually just marketing.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe tamasic tapas and introduce the profound teaching on dana (charity). Tamasic austerity is performed "mudha-grahena" (with foolish stubbornness), involving self-torture or harming others - discipline without wisdom or proper understanding. But the verses on dana reveal a transformative truth: sattvic giving is "datavyam iti" - done with the conviction that "this must be given," to one who cannot reciprocate (anupakarine), at the right place, time, and to the right recipient. Rajasic giving, by contrast, is "pratyupakarartham" (expecting something in return) or "pariklistam" (given grudgingly). Swami Vivekananda captured this beautifully: when you find someone worthy of help, thank them for giving you the opportunity to purify your own mind.

Reflect deeply on your relationship with giving. When you donate or help someone, do you calculate the tax benefit or social recognition? Do you give reluctantly, feeling the pinch? The sattvic giver experiences the spontaneous urgency of "datavyam iti" - like seeing a child about to be hit by a car, where helping is not a choice but an imperative. This week, practice giving with complete anonymity - help someone who cannot possibly repay you, without anyone knowing. Notice how this feels different from publicized charity. Also examine: Do you give at the right time and place (not embarrassing the recipient), to those who genuinely need help (not just those who can acknowledge you)? Remember, dana purifies the giver more than it helps the receiver.

snippets.title: Day 211: Om Tat Sat
snippets.sanskrit:
अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते |

ॐतत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः |

तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः |
snippets.transliteration:
adeśakāle yaddānamapātrebhyaśca dīyate .

OMtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ .

tasmādomityudāhṛtya yajñadānatapaḥkriyāḥ .
verseTranslations: And that which is given at an unsuitable place or time or to one who is unworthy, or with disrespect or contempt - such a gift is the result of Ignorance.
'Om Tat Sat' is the triple designation of the Eternal Spirit, by which of old the Vedic Scriptures, the ceremonials and the sacrifices were ordained.
Therefore all acts of sacrifice, gifts and austerities, prescribed by the scriptures, are always begun by those who understand the Spirit with the word Om.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Sadhatraya Vibhaga yoga, yoga of three types of faiths. We had been learning in Bhagavad Gita that our goal in life is to find ultimate happiness. And one thing we have noticed in our life is that I only can feel happy when my mind is happy. So the goal is to keep this mind in a happy mode. And for that I have to purify my mind, purify my mind and intellect, which is an internal instrument to achieve the ultimate goal of liberation, liberation from my limitations. Right now, the limitations which I have create sorrows and anxieties and regrets.

So to become ultimately happy, I need to get out of my limitations. These limitations exist right now because of my identification with this body, mind, and intellect. Mind is the tool I use to decide whether I am happy or unhappy. So my first goal is to purify my mind, so it remains in a happy mode -- the Mana Prasadah.

So we have seen in this chapter that as my mind, so is my personality, my faith. Bhagavan said that there is someone who has no guidance from the scriptures or from a guru, or from any wise person. But each one of us has faith that I will achieve happiness one way or other. And then wherever my faith is that my happiness lies, those are the pursuit I'll pursue. So Arjuna asked Bhagavan, what kind of a faith is that? Bhagavan said, this faith can be of three different kinds.

This faith can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. Depending on your mind being Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic, you will be convinced your happiness lies in those types of endeavors. So Bhagavan said: your faith, your mental texture -- as the faith, so is the person; as the person, so is the faith. It is very important for me to understand what is making me unhappy, what makes my mind unhappy. And therefore this chapter helps us understand how Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas affect my life.

So the first thing we have seen: Bhagavan said that everything you do in life will be controlled by your mental makeup -- the type of food you like, the type of food you will take, the yajnas which you perform, all the effort you put for the greater good.

But that greater good also include myself. So therefore, all my actions which I perform are basically to achieve their ultimate goal of becoming happy. So those actions which I offer as my sacrifice to get my happiness is my yajna. See, those yajnas will be also of three different types. Sattvik, rajasik and tamasic. So we have seen that the ahara, the sattvik people will eat what is good for them.

And nutritious. Rajasic people will eat whatever is pleasant, whatever feels good. And Tamasic will take whatever is available. Yajnas -- Sattvic people will perform without any expectations for the fruits; the Rajasic will have a goal in mind, what they want to get out of these efforts; and the Tamasic just doesn't care. Then we talked about tapas, austerities -- but in our life we call it discipline.

I have to discipline myself to do this. I was just reading this morning. Now, the new research says that not doing exercise is as bad as smoking cigarettes every day. I better be careful because I'm the one who obviously does not get motivated for exercise that easily. So now I say, oh, I need to exercise. That's something I'm telling myself.

I need to perform to be in a good shape. I want to be in good shape because I want to be healthy. I want to be healthy because that makes me happy. So ultimately, all the tapas which we do, all the disciplines which we practice, are for my happiness. Bhagavan said Tapas is performed at three different levels: you perform at your physical level in your actions, you perform at your speech level,

And you perform at the mental level. So the actions level, My actions should be helping others and not harming others. All my activities, I keep in mind that my actions are for the greater good. Once I take care of the greater good, I am already included in it. Because any action performed by any one person in this universe affects the entire universe. We know that we are all connected with each other.

If one person in family is unhappy, it makes the whole family unhappy. So we know that that why I should be performing this for greater good. Because it ultimately will affect me if someone is suffering. That suffering will eventually come down to me. The bhagavan said that the tapas are performed at three different levels. My activities should be such that it is for the greater good, then at the speech level, my speech should be such that it is truth but pleasant sounding truth.

All we husbands have a good idea of this. When your wife says, how do I look -- do you really want to be truthful? You can be truthful, but it has to be pleasant-sounding. Satyam Vada, Priyam Vada. Bhagavan said your speech should be not only truthful and pleasant, but also beneficial.

If I tell somebody a truth, it has to be for his or her benefit, not just because I want to be Satya Vadi Harishchandra. So that's at the speech level. And then at the mental level -- I may be acting in a manner that looks so Sattvic, I may be speaking so softly and nicely, but if there is noise in my mind which is completely different from my actions and my speech, it will eventually affect my speech and my actions. Therefore, at the mental level, this tapas is what Bhagavan is describing.

Now when I'm performing, it can also be the same three categories of Sattvik, rajasic and tamasic. Again, my tapas is for not for getting anything out of it, but it is something I need to do. So that's the purification of your internal instrument. My tapas is to purify my internal instrument so that I can experience that happiness in my mind. And the last thing we are seeing is the Dana. Charity is our general idea is it is to help others.

In reality, charity is to help yourself. Therefore, Swami Vivekananda said: if you find somebody who is worthy of helping, when you help, thank him for giving you the opportunity to help -- so that you can help yourself. Dhanam is for me to purify my mind and control my ego. Dana gives me the opportunity to purify my mind by giving away things which are in abundance with me. Dana is also a social phenomenon to keep the equilibrium in society. We know that in any given society there will be income inequality.

People are not born with the same resources and therefore there will be inequality. And if I happen to be the one who is fortunate enough to have more than what I need, it becomes my duty and it becomes my means to purify my mind by doing charities. So charities are strictly for me and not for others. So when the I perform charities, I must be very clear why I'm performing these charities. So there Bhagavan said that these charities can be seen as three types. Again, Sattvik Rajasik or Tamarsic.

The first one says Datavyam. The very first requirement for appropriate Sattvic Dana, which will give you the most result of what you're looking for. What you're looking for in your life is to purify your mind to a point that it is always in a sunny, bright mood and you're always happy. You do not want to be grouchy and unhappy, complaining and regretful. So to keep my mind in that mode, I'm performing all of this -- I'm eating the right food, doing the right yajna, doing the right tapas.

When I do also, I have to keep in mind I'm doing it for me and therefore I should know how to make these charities. So the first requirement is Datavyam Iti -- I see a cause and realize there is no other way but for me to help. You are going on a road and you see a little child just about to get hit by a car. You don't sit down and say: is this going to be a Sattvic act or Rajasic? Is it going to be Tamasic?

At that point you have no other thought than I need to help that child get him or her out of the harm's way. So when you do a charity and you have that attitude, it has to be done, it has to be done then that's the right charity. And when you give, you are not obliging that person -- actually, you should thank him: you are obliging me by giving me a chance. If there's no one to help, who are you going to help? When we were at the old temple, we were having this annadhanam, because every Sunday people would come there. But if you are feeding people who are already fed, that is not Annadhanam -- it is just a party you are having.

Every week we all get together. When a person needs food and you give him food, that's Annadhanam. If a person is already fed, you can't give him food and call it charity. Deshe kale cha patre cha ta danam sattvikam smrutam -- when it is given at the right time, at the right place, to the right person.

So if I want to help somebody and that person is sitting in a group of his friends, and I go and say: you told me that you need help --

Here is my hundred dollars which you asked for. You are insulting him in front of his friends and family. He didn't want other people to know his problems. He came to you to ask for help, and now you're helping him at the wrong place. Wrong place, wrong time.

You should also not help somebody who you know does not need any help. Sometimes people say: I don't get a chance to do all this social work. I want to do social work, but people are not making me president of this organization. You shouldn't worry about it. Bhagavan says Patra -- only help someone who really needs help and is seeking help.

When you find that opportunity, take that opportunity that is God's given to you. Consider that as God's blessing that you came across this opportunity to help that person and therefore you're helping. Bhagawan says that's a Sattvik dharam. You're not expecting anything out of it. Just like the example of a child in a harm's way. When you help that child you're not expecting anything, not even thank you from anybody.

At that point your only thought is I need to get that child out of the harm's way. It's the exact same emotion you should have when you give somebody any help: that person needs help, and I have the means -- I need to help that person. Bhagavan says that's Sattvic Dana.

Yatu pratyupakarartham phalam uddishya va punah diyate pariklistam tadanam rajasam smrutam. In contrast to that, the gift which is given in view of receiving something in return -- phalam uddishya. I'll make this donation so I can get this tax benefit.

And at least people will think that he is a good donor. I am doing these charities so it will help my business. So all companies say "we are connected, we give back" -- all that is actually just marketing.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe tamasic giving and introduce the sacred formula "Om Tat Sat" - the triple designation of the Eternal Spirit (Brahman). Tamasic dana is given "adesha-kale" (at the wrong place and time), "apatrebhyah" (to unworthy recipients), "asatkrtam" (without respect), and "avajnatam" (with contempt) - it demeans both giver and receiver. But then Krishna offers a powerful tool for transformation: "Om Tat Sat" - by which the Vedas, Brahmanas, and sacrifices were ordained from the beginning. Om represents the transcendental reality beyond all parts; those who understand the Spirit begin all acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity by uttering Om, remembering that all manifestation is ultimately one.

The teaching of Om is profoundly practical. Even if your faith is currently rajasic or tamasic, beginning any action with the remembrance of Om - the ultimate unity behind all diversity - can gradually purify and transform that faith toward sattva. This week, experiment with this ancient practice: before beginning any significant action (work, conversation, meal, or practice), pause and silently invoke Om, remembering that you and all beings are manifestations of one reality. Notice how this shifts your relationship to the action and to others involved. Also examine your giving: Have you ever given in a way that embarrassed the recipient or showed contempt? True giving preserves dignity and arises from respect for the Divine in the other person.

snippets.title: Day 212: Three Types of Faith
snippets.sanskrit:
तदित्यनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः |

सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते |

यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
tadityanabhisandhāya phalaṃ yajñatapaḥkriyāḥ .

sadbhāve sādhubhāve ca sadityetatprayujyate .

yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ saditi cocyate .
verseTranslations: Those who desire deliverance begin their acts of sacrifice, austerity or gift with the word 'Tat' (meaning 'That'), without thought of reward.
'Sat' means Reality or the highest Good, and also, O Arjuna, it is used to mean an action of exceptional merit.
Conviction in sacrifice, in austerity and in giving is also called 'Sat.' So too an action done only for the Lord's sake.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Sraddhatriya Vipaga Yoga, and what we have seen so far in this chapter and in the Bhagavad Gita is that we have heard that our body is what we eat, our mind is what we think, and what we think is dependent on our faith, dependent on what we are convinced of or convicted of. So thinking is driven by our convictions. And therefore who I am is all about my convictions. So who I am is depending on my faith. And therefore this chapter elaborates what are the types of faiths a person can have? Then we have broadly classified, just as everything else, in three categories.

Faith can be Sattvic, faith can be Rajasic, faith can be Tamasic, and depending on that, I may be a Sattvic person, a Rajasic person or a Tamasik person, and my understanding of that will help me how do I change my faith so that my thinking changes, so my behavior changes, my mind changes and ultimately gives me the result which I'm looking for, which is in the end is to achieve happiness. You're all looking for one and one thing alone is to get out of our limitations and sorrows. So Bhagavan has described in this chapter the three types of faith and how it controls our Ahara, our Yagna, our Tapa and our Dana. As we have seen last time, it is what we take from this world, how we interact and connect with this world, how we discipline ourselves for what we want and then what we give back to this world, all dependent on my faith. And therefore my goal obviously is to make my faith more Sattvic. If I detect that I have Tamasic faith, I want to make it more Rajasic.

If I detect I'm more Rajasya, make it Sattvik. Eventually I can get to my goal of achieving that happiness. So now our question was: well, I may or may not have that capability, and I may be all filled with Rajasic faith and not be able to change that. The last three verses we have seen say there is one way of mitigating that. There is a threefold indicator of that transcendental reality, the ultimate reality, the one unifying entity which binds us all, which is indicated in the Sastras as Om Tat Sat. Om is the transcendental form of the Lord that I have learned in the previous chapter. The Astadha Prakrithi, Eightfold manifest Prakriti of the Lord.

So everything which I see and perceive and feel is basically nothing but his manifestation. But then I come to the conclusion, maybe if I put everything together that's Lord, or if I put all the parts together, will it make a machine? The question is how you put it together. So all this part putting together does not still make the identity of the Lord. That is something beyond that. Lower Prakriti and higher Prakriti.

I have all these parts and say if I put all this together, it will be the whole. No, it has to be in a particular manner. Then only that machine functions as it's supposed to be functioning. All these parts, I have to put it together and perceive it in a way that it will reveal the Lord's identity. And that's the transcendental part, is how to see this whole in a manner that I can see Him. I see this world in its parts, but I can't put it together as his identity.

That's the Aum, a transcendental part. Om is the indicator of that. And if I can remember that -- that all that I see, perceive, and experience put together -- I will never be able to fully understand the Lord through parts alone. But Om points to that reality beyond the parts. My faith may be rajasic, it may be even tamasic, but remembering Om will transform it into sattvic faith. That's basically a way out given to us by these last three verses.

Om Tat Sat iti nirdeshah brahmanah trividhah smritah. These are the three indicators of that supreme reality. I know all the parts right now, but I can't put together the machine. I can't put together its real identity. So Aum is the one indicator. Tat we have seen is another indicator.

That is that that which I constantly keep referring to the God, the Lord, that entity other than this which I can perceive, feel, touch and vouch for it, that it exists. That which I cannot vouch for, that it exists, does exist, but beyond my perception. So that's Tat and Sat, the existence or the truth. Truth is that which exists in all periods of time. In other words, it was true yesterday, it is true today and it will be true tomorrow. That is Sat.

So these are the three indicators. And Bhagavan said that those who are Brahmavadina -- those who are completely convinced about the existence of that ultimate reality. Just like Mudivad (capitalism), Samajvad (socialism) -- because they're convinced that this is the only way to help the society. Vaad means I'm completely on the side of that.

Those who are completely convinced that Brahman is the only reality -- they will start all their activities by uttering Om. Utterance means remembrance. It's an indication to me that Om is the ultimate reality. I may be perceiving a difference between you and me right now, and therefore I may have developed a liking or disliking for you.

But Om is the ultimate reality which manifests as me, which manifests as you. As long as I have that thought in the beginning, whatever I do afterwards will be purified. Om Iti Udahritya Yajna Dana Tapaha Kriyaha -- we have discussed all that in the previous verses. The activities we are performing in this world:

We receive from the world, we interact with the world, we connect with this world, we prepare ourselves for how to interact with the world, and then we give back to the world. First, those who are Brahmavadina.

We see that those who are seeking liberation have come to the conclusion that there is no way that in my present state of limitedness the ultimate goal of infinite happiness is possible. I have come to that clear understanding that no matter how hard I try with my mind and intellect and body that unbroken happiness is not possible at all. It's only possible if I can identify with that. That which is unlimited. That which has no limitations.

That which has no sorrows, that which has no competition, that which is all-pervading. People who are seeking moksha -- and we are all Moksha Kankshi, believe it or not -- we want liberation from anything which we think is our limitation.

All of us who are aware of our limitations and are not happy with them -- if you're happy with your limitations, you're not a Moksha Kankshi. If I have some limitations but think this is good enough, then I'm not seeking liberation. But we all have one limitation we cannot stand: running into a situation which makes me unhappy. Therefore I'm constantly trying to avoid the things which create sorrows and want to pursue the things which give me happiness.

So at least I want to get rid of the limitations that run me into situations which give me unhappiness. Bhagavan says those Moksha Kankshi who want to get rid of those limitations will start all their activities -- the same yajna, tapa, dana kriyaha -- with Tat. Tat anabhisandhaya phalam yajna tapah kriyaha. They have come to the conclusion that if I remember Him as the Karma Phaladata, He is the giver of the fruits. So I leave the results to Him and do all my activities, trusting that He will give me the result that will lead to liberation.

We have learned that as Karma Yoga. The last one: sad bhave sadhu bhave cha sad iti etat prayujyate, prashaste karmani tatha sat shabdah partha yujyate. Sat is used in the sense of reality. Sat, as we have said is only that can be proven true in all three phases. In the past, in the present, in the future. Everything else is unreal. It existed one point of time in time and space, another period of time.

It has no existence whatsoever. It's completely gone. Just like a film on a screen or a hologram. It exists in my perception for a period of time. So the lamp is shut off. The word sat is used in the sense of reality and also for goodness.

Now we are coming back to the world which you and I know -- not transcendental unlimitedness, but the world of good and bad. Our world is divided by good and bad. Bhagavan said the real and the good is indicated in this world as Sat. As we say, there are values and there are universal values.

There are values may be applicable to me in this situation which may not be applicable in other situations. Well, those are transitory values. I work for a company and what are the values of the company? It only applies to me as long as I am there. But there are values which applies to me whether I'm working or not. Whether I'm working for this company or not or that company or not.

Those are universal values. Therefore we have said even before the civilization started, human beings knew what is right and what is wrong. Even before any religious were established, they knew what is good and what is bad. Those universal good and those universal truths are indicated as Sat. It is not dependent on any culture, not dependent on any beliefs -- those are the universal good and universal reality. So Bhagavan said, the word Sat is used in this sense of reality and of goodness. And also, Partha:

The word is used in the sense of auspiciousness. Anything which is good is auspicious. And therefore you start that work, same thing, yajna pohadana kriya with that word sat. Then may this be auspicious. May this act of mine be of goodness and of kindness and of reality. So you start with sat.

So obviously in the Sikh tradition, the word Sat is given the most importance: Sat Sri Akal, that Sat which is Akal, which is timeless, no beginning, no end. So that Sat is uttered: yajne tapasi dane cha sthitih sat iti uchyate. Therefore, if I am one who is clearly aware of good and bad in this world -- I divide my world into this is good and this is evil, this is good for me, this is bad for me -- then I should start all my activities with Sat. Bhagavan says yajne tapasi dane cha -- the activities remaining the same.

Whether it is my tamasic faith, my rajasic faith, or the sattvic faith, it is what my mind tells me is good, I'm gonna do. No matter how much I tell you this is good for you, as long as your mind does not tell you it is good, you will not be able to follow. Everybody says, do this. Okay, okay, I'll think about it. But the thinking part never comes, because I have already decided it is not worth thinking about. So Bhagavan said -- and that's what yajne tapasi dane cha sthitih means:

To be steadfast in my yajna, dana, and tapa. I do some yajnas, but only occasionally -- some sacrifice here and there. But occasionally I'm not steadfast. I sometimes get all excited and say, I think we should all do some charity or some kind of community service. We organize this, and then after about two weeks, everything gradually dies down.
snippets.reflection:
These verses explain "Tat" and "Sat" - completing the sacred formula. "Tat" (That) is uttered by those seeking liberation (moksha-kankibhih) who perform yajna, tapas, and dana without attachment to results (anabhisandhaya phalam). They remember that the fruits belong to "That" - the Supreme, the Karma Phaladata (giver of fruits). "Sat" signifies reality, goodness, and auspiciousness - it represents universal truth that transcends all cultures and beliefs, the values that were known even before civilizations and religions were established. Krishna teaches that steadfastness (sthiti) in yajna, tapas, and dana is itself called Sat.

The distinction between Tat and Sat offers practical wisdom. Use "Tat" when you need to surrender the fruits of action - remembering that results belong to That which is beyond your control. Use "Sat" when you need grounding in universal goodness - what is true, beneficial, and auspicious regardless of circumstance. This week, when anxious about outcomes, silently invoke "Tat" to release attachment. When uncertain about whether an action is right, invoke "Sat" and ask: "Is this aligned with universal truth and goodness?" Also examine your steadfastness: Do you enthusiastically begin charitable projects only to abandon them after initial excitement fades? Sthiti (steadfastness) in your practices is itself a form of Sat. What one practice can you commit to maintaining with unwavering consistency?
