That which has no sorrows, that which has no competition, that which is all-pervading. People who are seeking moksha -- and we are all Moksha Kankshi, believe it or not -- we want liberation from anything which we think is our limitation.

All of us who are aware of our limitations and are not happy with them -- if you're happy with your limitations, you're not a Moksha Kankshi. If I have some limitations but think this is good enough, then I'm not seeking liberation. But we all have one limitation we cannot stand: running into a situation which makes me unhappy. Therefore I'm constantly trying to avoid the things which create sorrows and want to pursue the things which give me happiness.

So at least I want to get rid of the limitations that run me into situations which give me unhappiness. Bhagavan says those Moksha Kankshi who want to get rid of those limitations will start all their activities -- the same yajna, tapa, dana kriyaha -- with Tat. Tat anabhisandhaya phalam yajna tapah kriyaha. They have come to the conclusion that if I remember Him as the Karma Phaladata, He is the giver of the fruits. So I leave the results to Him and do all my activities, trusting that He will give me the result that will lead to liberation.

We have learned that as Karma Yoga. The last one: sad bhave sadhu bhave cha sad iti etat prayujyate, prashaste karmani tatha sat shabdah partha yujyate. Sat is used in the sense of reality. Sat, as we have said is only that can be proven true in all three phases. In the past, in the present, in the future. Everything else is unreal. It existed one point of time in time and space, another period of time.

It has no existence whatsoever. It's completely gone. Just like a film on a screen or a hologram. It exists in my perception for a period of time. So the lamp is shut off. The word sat is used in the sense of reality and also for goodness.

Now we are coming back to the world which you and I know -- not transcendental unlimitedness, but the world of good and bad. Our world is divided by good and bad. Bhagavan said the real and the good is indicated in this world as Sat. As we say, there are values and there are universal values.

There are values may be applicable to me in this situation which may not be applicable in other situations. Well, those are transitory values. I work for a company and what are the values of the company? It only applies to me as long as I am there. But there are values which applies to me whether I'm working or not. Whether I'm working for this company or not or that company or not.

Those are universal values. Therefore we have said even before the civilization started, human beings knew what is right and what is wrong. Even before any religious were established, they knew what is good and what is bad. Those universal good and those universal truths are indicated as Sat. It is not dependent on any culture, not dependent on any beliefs -- those are the universal good and universal reality. So Bhagavan said, the word Sat is used in this sense of reality and of goodness. And also, Partha:

The word is used in the sense of auspiciousness. Anything which is good is auspicious. And therefore you start that work, same thing, yajna pohadana kriya with that word sat. Then may this be auspicious. May this act of mine be of goodness and of kindness and of reality. So you start with sat.

So obviously in the Sikh tradition, the word Sat is given the most importance: Sat Sri Akal, that Sat which is Akal, which is timeless, no beginning, no end. So that Sat is uttered: yajne tapasi dane cha sthitih sat iti uchyate. Therefore, if I am one who is clearly aware of good and bad in this world -- I divide my world into this is good and this is evil, this is good for me, this is bad for me -- then I should start all my activities with Sat. Bhagavan says yajne tapasi dane cha -- the activities remaining the same.

Whether it is my tamasic faith, my rajasic faith, or the sattvic faith, it is what my mind tells me is good, I'm gonna do. No matter how much I tell you this is good for you, as long as your mind does not tell you it is good, you will not be able to follow. Everybody says, do this. Okay, okay, I'll think about it. But the thinking part never comes, because I have already decided it is not worth thinking about. So Bhagavan said -- and that's what yajne tapasi dane cha sthitih means:

To be steadfast in my yajna, dana, and tapa. I do some yajnas, but only occasionally -- some sacrifice here and there. But occasionally I'm not steadfast. I sometimes get all excited and say, I think we should all do some charity or some kind of community service. We organize this, and then after about two weeks, everything gradually dies down.
snippets.reflection:
This concluding verse delivers the chapter's most sobering message: "Asraddhaya hutam dattam tapas taptam krtam ca yat, asad ity ucyate partha na ca tat pretya no iha" - whatever is offered, given, or practiced WITHOUT FAITH is called "Asat" (unreal, the negation of Sat), and has no significance here or hereafter. This is not about the object of faith, but about the presence of faith itself. Actions performed mechanically, rituals gone through without conviction, charity given without heart - all are rendered meaningless. Faith (shraddha) is the essential ingredient that transforms ordinary action into spiritual practice.

This verse invites deep self-examination: How much of your daily life is performed with genuine faith versus mere habit or obligation? Do you pray with conviction or recite words mechanically? Do you work with purpose or simply go through the motions? The teaching is both challenging and liberating - it is not the elaborate nature of your practice that matters, but the quality of faith behind it. A simple act done with complete faith surpasses grand gestures performed without heart. This week, choose one small daily action - perhaps your morning routine, a work task, or a family interaction - and infuse it with conscious intention and faith. Ask yourself before beginning: "Do I truly believe in the value of what I am about to do?" If not, either find that faith or reconsider the action. Remember: shraddha is the foundation upon which all spiritual transformation is built.

snippets.title: Day 214: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

tyājyaṃ doṣavadityeke karma prāhurmanīṣiṇaḥ .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna asked: O mighty One! I desire to know how relinquishment is distinguished from renunciation.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: The sages say that renunciation means forgoing an action which springs from desire; and relinquishing means the surrender of its fruit.
Some philosophers say that all action is evil and should be abandoned. Others that acts of sacrifice, benevolence and austerity should not be given up.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 17 and we concluded chapter 17. Now we'll be starting chapter 18, Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. This is the last chapter in Bhagavad Gita, basically a revision or summary. We are going to review all that we have discussed so far in Bhagavad Gita up to chapter 17. From chapter two through 17 -- chapter one was the introduction, setting the stage, telling us what situation we are in.

We are in Arjuna's situation. We face this battle of life and in that we come across situations which are not clear cut. So that was the scenario. And then Bhagavan gave us the whole discourse about why we are so confused. We are confused because of our basic fault -- as the Christians would call it, a basic sin -- or basic misconception about ourselves, about who we are. We consider this mortal being to be me, whereas the "I" that I truly am is imperishable.

We learnt that once you change that paradigm -- that this is not me. This body, mind and intellect is not me. The "I" that I truly am is the owner of this body, mind and intellect. This body, this mind, my intellect -- they are the equipment I use to transact with this world. The mortality is for the body, mind and intellect, particularly for the body. In this life, the body will survive from birth to death and then it will decay.

But the mind and intellect will continue their journey till they give up their own attachment and identification. So we have learned in the first six chapters that the basic technique for detaching oneself from this limited self and then attaching to the supreme self is Karma Yoga. We have seen that there are two aspects of Karma Yoga. One is doing actions without any expectations for the fruits, and the second is to act for the greater good. So these are the two main things we have learned. They equate to Tyaga and Sannyasa.

So we have heard these two words, Tyaga and Sannyasa, over and over again in this discourse. We constantly talk about giving up, abandonment -- and what to give up is what we have to learn. Chapter three said Karma Phala Tyaga is the Tyaga. What you need to give up is the expectations of a particular result from your actions. Then later chapters 4 and 5 talk about renouncing actions in knowledge. Right now I consider myself the doer and therefore I expect the results. Then I become the enjoyer and the sufferer.

If I give up the doership, then the sufferer and enjoyer also goes away. As long as I consider I am the doer, all the results are binding to me. Because I take the responsibility, I take the ownership of my actions. Then the results which comes in future. Actions are always in present. Results are always in future.

No matter what a time lag is. By the time I speak and you hear and you respond, there is a time lag. It may be a fraction of a second but there is always a time lag. So the actions are always in present, results are always in future. The future is one which I do not have a control over. I only have control of the present.

I can only live in present. I can only act in present. So how do I make myself more efficient? In present is what we have learned in those chapters. Give up the expectations of the fruits. Because I do not have any control over what the fruits would be.

I am not the judge of what the rewards of my action should be, even though I have expectations. Karma Phala Datta is always someone else. Whether we consider the Almighty or the world. I go for an interview for a project. All I can do is make presentation.

The result is always in the hand of the selection committee who I have no control over. But all I can do is make myself as efficient and proficient and effective as possible. The Bhagavan said, if you do not think about the results, you will be more efficient. You are not wasting your energy into thinking about what will come out of actions. Then when we talked about the second set of chapters where we have described the Bhagavan's identity, who the Bhagavan is. Then we say Bhagavan has two aspects.

One is Purusha, which is the substratum for all things and beings. What we call "myself," you call "yourself," he calls "himself," she calls "herself," it calls "itself" -- that Self is the Purusha, which is permeating through all things and beings as existence. And then there is the manifest aspect of the Prakriti which is the myriads of forms and names and colors. And it's constantly changing. We have come to learn that that's because of the Maya.

This Prakriti is the manifest world of plurality, is a product of Maya. Maya is that which is not, but appears to be that. In Newtonian physics, the atom looks so solid, but on further investigation, you found there is no solid material in atom at all. There is nothing that we have found so far which is solid in atom, but it does act as a very solid material. Therefore, I can punch this table. If I punch this table, it will hurt because it is very solid.

This, which appears to be real, but it is not, is the product of Maya. And this Maya has three gunas. As we have discussed, this Maya is supported by the three constituent parts, the Sattva, rajas and tamas. The purity, the reality, the truth; Rajas, which is the activity; and Tamas, which is inertia. To remain as an entity in space and time, inertia is needed -- it has to remain as it is for you and I to perceive it. Sattva, Rajas and Tamas are the three aspects which govern our life as part of the Prakriti.

So we have now five things we obviously have to focus on. Tyaga and Sannyasa are the means to achieve the ultimate happiness that I am seeking. And then, what is binding me to this world? This identification which I have with this body, mind, intellect is because of the three Gunas of Prakriti -- Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas. So this chapter combines all the concepts which we have learned in various chapters into one cohesive teaching on how one should use this knowledge to make your life better and achieve your final goal of liberating yourself from unhappiness and sorrows. Just as we have seen previously, Arjuna time and again asked questions to make sure that he understood correctly.

In chapter eight, he said, these are the following terms. You said Brahman, you said Dharma, you said Karma, you said Adhyatma, you said Adhi Devata. Explain to me all this in detail. Then we had this whole discussion in chapter eight. Now in this chapter, he starts with saying, let's make sure that I understood correctly that you use two terms, tyaga and sannyasa. They both seem the same thing. When somebody says, "give up drinking coffee," and then I say, "I renounce coffee" -- both seem one and the same thing. I'm just not drinking coffee. There's got to be a difference. Otherwise you won't be talking about Tyaga and Sannyasa in two different contexts. So I would like to know. So the chapter starts with Arjuna saying Sanyasasya Mahabaho tattoom ichami veditum.

I want to know about Sannyasa in its essence. And also I want to know about tyaga in its essence. I want to know what is Tyaga and what is Sannyasa. He addresses Krishna with two different Hrishikesha and Keshini Sudhana. Krishna has various names depending on how you see him. So one is Keshini Sudhana, the slayer of demon Keshini.

So for those who have read Mahabharata or Bhagavadpura, Keshani was a demon was sent to kill Krishna in the form of a horse and Krishna slayed him by splitting him into two. So one who basically separates ignorance from knowledge is Keshini Sudhana. He is also called Hrishikesha. Hrishikesha has several meanings. One is "one who has control over the senses," the master of the senses.

Another meaning is "one who has short hair." So Arjuna addresses him saying Krishna Hrushiki, explain to me what is the difference between Tyaga and Sannyasa so that I am not confused. He talked about giving up things and also renouncing things. If we reflect back, we have talked about how Tyaga is Karma Fala Tyaga, and giving up the sense of agency that I am the doer is Sannyasa. We discussed that previously in the Bhagavad Gita. But Krishna now answers it slightly differently and he says Sri Bhagavanu vacha kamyanam Karmanam Nyasam sanyasam kabayo viduhu Giving up desire prompted actions.

Kavi means sage or poet, in Gujarati and in many vernacular languages. So in Gujarati we say, where the sun cannot shine, the poet can take his imagination there. The Kavis in the Vedic time are the people who saw the truth and then put it in poetic language. In the Rig Vedas and Sama Vedas, those who had the vision of the truth are the Kavis.

Many Kavis say that giving up desire prompted actions is sannyasa. Desire prompted actions only come in place if it is driven by my ego. If I think I am the doer and therefore I want something out of my action, so those actions are prompted by my self interest. By my ego are the desire prompted actions. So if I give up the sense of agency as the doer, there won't be any desire-prompted actions. All actions become for the greater good.

And that's where we have the concepts of offering all the actions to the Lord. If I come to the conclusion, as we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita that all actions are performed by this body, mind and intellect and the qualities of the body, mind and intellect. Because, why am I not the biggest wrestler in town? It is because I don't have the equipment. I don't have the body to wrestle. Everything which I do in life is depending on what equipment I have.

What is the proper apparatus I have? I like to sing because I have been given a voice which is appropriate for singing. If it was not, I would have no desire to sing. I don't have desire to dance. Because the apparatus is not right. So Bhagavan says that all actions are performed by the quality of your equipment and your senses, which are part of this Prakriti.

But I consider them to be my actions by misconception that this is me. If I correct that conception then all actions will not be for me. And therefore they will not be desire prompted. So he says Sannyasa is simply giving up the desire-prompted actions. Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa Sarvakarma Falat Tyagam Prahuhu Tyagam Vichakshanah Vichakshanah. Wise people who have observed how this world works and how the actions are performed.

And how the results of the actions are affected by our expectations. You see, those people have said Sarvakarma Falatyagam. Not some -- not just giving up the fruits for actions which are of no value. But for all the actions which I perform, I give up the expectation for the fruits. And we have discussed in detail in chapter three what is Karma Faladhyyagam. Karma Falat Yaga is simply not to expect a particular result.

Result will come in the law of nature. Once I perform action, there will be a reaction. As in physics we say it will be equal and opposite.
snippets.reflection:
Arjuna opens this final chapter with a profound question that resonates deeply with our daily struggles: What is the difference between tyaga (relinquishment) and sannyasa (renunciation)? Krishna's response reveals a liberating truth - sannyasa is giving up desire-prompted actions, while tyaga is surrendering the fruits of all actions. This distinction is crucial for modern life. We cannot abandon all actions, but we can transform our relationship with them. The key insight is that the Karma Phala Datta (giver of results) is always someone other than the doer. When we truly understand this, the anxiety about outcomes naturally dissolves.

Consider today: What desire-prompted actions are you performing simply because your ego demands certain results? Can you identify one action where you are acting not from genuine duty but from the expectation of recognition, reward, or control over outcomes? The Gita suggests that even good actions bind us when we cling to their fruits. Practice this: Before your next significant action, pause and ask yourself - "Am I doing this because it needs to be done, or because I want something specific from it?" This simple inquiry begins the process of transforming ordinary work into a path of liberation.

As an exercise, choose one task today and perform it with complete attention but zero attachment to how it will be received or what it will produce. Notice the difference in your inner experience - the lightness that comes from acting without the burden of expectation.

snippets.title: Day 215: Types of Action
snippets.sanskrit:
निश्चयं शृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम |

यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत् |

एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च |
snippets.transliteration:
niścayaṃ śṛṇu me tatra tyāge bharatasattama .

yajñadānatapaḥkarma na tyājyaṃ kāryameva tat .

etānyapi tu karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā phalāni ca .
verseTranslations: O best of Indians! Listen to my judgment as regards this problem. It has a threefold aspect.
Acts of sacrifice, benevolence and austerity should not be given up but should be performed, for they purify the aspiring soul.
But they should be done with detachment and without thought of recompense. This is my final judgment.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. This is a constant theme in our discussion: that to enjoy something, you have to give up something. So all throughout Bhagavad Gita you hear these two words, Tyaga and Sannyasa. Our normal connotation is that if I give up something, I have lost something. But Upanishads and Bhagavad Gita constantly tell us, to gain something you have to give up something. You are giving up something because you want to gain something.

When Upanishads like Isha Vasya Upanishad say "Isha vasyam idam sarvam" -- that this world is pervaded by that one single entity. Everything in this world, Jagatyam jagat, that which you see in this Jagat, is all pervaded by the same Ishvara, the same entity. Tena tyaktena bhunjita -- you protect that entity within you by detachment. If you attach to something else, you'll be detached from your own self.

So the main theme of Bhagavad Gita is that you should give up all attachments to enjoy the bliss which you're seeking. That perennial happiness that you're seeking can only be enjoyed by giving up the attachments to the world of plurality. So we have been discussing these two terms from chapter two onward -- Tyaga and Sannyasa. This chapter opened with Arjuna saying, I want to understand these two terms Tyaga and Sannyasa in detail so there is no confusion. What is Tyaga and what is Sannyasa?

We have talked about Tyaga and Sannyasa as if they're the same thing. Giving up something and renouncing something. I give up my Samsara or I renounce my Samsara. But as we discussed last time, giving up coffee is Tyaga. I will not drink coffee from tomorrow. That doesn't mean that my attachment to coffee is gone.

I will have a lingering thought of coffee. Renouncing is completely detaching yourself from the thought of coffee. So that's renunciation. So Bhagavan explains here in very simple terms: Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasah Sanyasam Kavayo Vidhu. The sages who have realized the truth in their meditation and contemplation then give out that truth in poetry.

In the richas, in Vedas they are called kavis. Those who have written poetry. These sages have said that Karmanam Nyasam it is sannyasam. Giving up the desire prompted actions is sannyas. You don't have to give up your clothes. You don't have to shave your head.

You don't have to run away from this world. Bhagavad said the giving up Karmanam Kamya Naam. But then what is tyaga? He says Sarvakarma Farad Tyagam Prahu Tyagam Vichakshanah. Wise people say that giving up the anxiety for the fruits of actions is tyaga. That I have given all my worries to the Karma Phala Datta.

Karma Phala Datta is always somebody other than the one who is acting. I am always the actor in the present. I act, result comes in future is always in somebody else's hand, not in mine. If something which I don't have any control over to worry about it is seems silly. But we do that all the time. So Bhagavan said that one who has given up that anxiety of the fruits of actions is the tyagi.

And then he said some people say that all actions are imperfect. There is not a perfect action in this world. Everything will have a main result and a side effect. Something which is good will always have some imperfection in it or something not good attached to it. And something which is evil will also some good attached to it. Climate change may be disastrous to one region.

It helps other region. I was watching one of those TV channel. Whatever that fish is migrating upward. So now there were less production in USA but more production in Canada. So what is lost for the USA is gain for the Canada. So there's always something which is contrary to what a popularly understood the result of the action is.

So Bhagavan said that some people say therefore give up all actions because they are all imperfect. They will never give you perfect results. Your goal is to get the perfect happiness in life by working in this world. But even good actions will not give you the perfect happiness. That's what we say in this class. Doing good is not good enough.

That still binds you to those good results. You feel good about doing something, you want to continue doing it. Then the world doesn't let you do it and now you're mad. So some people say therefore give up all actions. But Bhagavan says no. My opinion is you should not give up Yajna Dana Tapaha Karma -- the actions of yajna, dana, and tapa.

And then we have this confusion about what Yajna, Dana, and Tapa are for. I'm doing it for others, I'm sacrificing, I'm giving to somebody else, I'm doing charity for others. So this verse clarifies that for you. Nischayam Srunume Tatra Tyagay Bharatar Sabha, Tyagohi Purusha Vyagraha Trivedha Sampra Kirti Tah. Listen to me conclusively what Tyaga is.

Tyagahi Trividha Sampra Kirti Tah. Tyaga is also of three types. Two things are very common in our discussion in Bhagavad Gita. One is Tyaga and Renunciation. Second is Trigunas, satv, Rajas and Tamas. So Bhagawan said, let me tell you conclusively what Tyaga is.

And also you should know that Tyaga is also of three types of it can be classified in the same way we have classified Ahara Yagna Tapa. All this in previous chapter Tag also can be classified in three. And Swamiji points out that Bhagavan addresses Arjuna as Purusha Vyagara, a tiger among men, boosting his morale that you can do it. Yajna Dana Tapaha Karman Karyam Eva Tat, Yagna Dana Tapahachayeva Pavanani Manishina. Here comes why Dana is for you and not for others. He said Yajna, Dana, and Tapa Karma should not be given up, because Yajna, Dana, and Tapa are the purifiers even for the wise.

But actually there is no word "even" in the Sanskrit here; it simply says "for the wise people." Also, continuing education -- in any profession that we are in, unless you continue your education, you get stale. So when I was going for my eye surgery, when I subluxated eye lens, my cataract done four years ago, my lens has moved out. It's actually 90 degree. So obviously I didn't feel anything. But everybody who told me what it is pretty scary situation.

So I told my first surgeon that I think I want to go with somebody who has a lot of experience, who looks like me with gray hair. He said, no, no, no, Neil, don't do that. Because they are all stale, their knowledge is all outdated, you know, to go with somebody who's fresh, who has the latest knowledge. So I go to the next guy and ask him how many years of experience? How many surgeries you have done? I said, I'll go with the stale guy, the guy whose knowledge is 10 years old.

So I went with a guy who said I do it routinely for everybody, like six surgery in a month like this. So we also can say that a wise person can veer off from his knowledge. He has to constantly be on his toes to keep his mind pure. So he said this will only help wise people who are constantly doing this to keep their knowledge pristine. If you're doing yajnadanand tapa and you have no intention of getting any benefit out of it for you, then obviously it's not going to be of any value. But it will help people who are wise enough to know the value of this.

That keeping my mind and intellect pure, I need to constantly be working on it because there are lots of temptations out there in this world. And when I slip from my wisdom, nobody will know. Therefore I have to be constantly vigilant about keeping my mind and intellect -- which is my internal instrument -- pure, so that the knowledge can shine through. So therefore he says, yajna dana tapaacha pavanani manishinam. So wise people, they constantly do yajna dana and tapa to keep their internal instrument pure. So he said, this is for you to keep yourself pure so that the knowledge will always be with you.

Etan apitu karmani sangam tyaktva falanicha kartabyan ITI me partha nischitam matam uttamam. And now he says that I'm going to give you my final opinion. This is my best and final opinion. So there is no confusion. So up till now Bhagavan said, I'm not the first one to tell you. Many sages have come and told you that.

Now I'm telling you same knowledge. Here he comes and tells Arjuna, this is my best and final opinion for you. Because he realized that Arjuna is probably at a point where he will listen to me more than Vedas and Upanishads. He said, I'm telling you itana pito carmani sangam tyaktva falanicha. Even these actions of yajna danan tapa should be done with sangam tyaktva by giving up attachment and falanicha and giving up fruits. So two things we constantly hear, you have to detach and you have to give up.

Detach from that which is not real, that which is of not any use. So there are now lots of seminars on how to keep your house healthy and happy. And their claim is to give up everything which you don't use. Take out everything from your house which you have not used in last three years, last five years, keep it out and keep what you really need. And that will make you happy. So Bhagavan said, sangam tyaktva, detach from things which are of no value to you in this world.

The objects which cannot give you happiness. Be detached from that and fala nature and also detached from the expectations for the fruit. Because even doing good, when I have an expectation of something good coming out of, ties me to the anxiety. The Bhagavan said, yajna dana and tapa should be done for one simple reason. To purify your mind and intellect, your internal instrument. Because that's all you as a seeker has to do.

Rest of it Bhagavan has to do. It's like all you have to do is eat digestion. I don't have to worry about it. He needs to take care of it. Same way Bhagavan said, all you have to do is keep your mind and intellect pure. I'll take care of it.

So therefore it's a you do not worry about your actions. Give up the attachment to your actions. Whether I could do it or not, did I do it right or not? Let's not get attached to it. Do for purifying your mind and intellect without any attachment and any expectations from your actions. Even expectation this will purify my mind can become a burden.

You do for your simple motive of finding that ultimate happiness. Bhagawan says, rest, I will take care of it. Therefore he says, karthiya Bhyanidi, do all these actions as I prescribed. Partha nischitam matam uttam. This is my best and final opinion. Do actions which are purifying your mind.

And that means which we consider the punya Karma. Papa, Karma are the ones which are giving negative impressions on our mind. They should be avoided anywhere. But the ones which I am doing it to earn punya even they should be done without attachment, without an expectation for the fruits. Bhagawan says that's my best and final opinion. We had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sanyasa Yoga.

We have seen the conclusion of Bhagavad Gita. The last verse we had discussed is said Sarva Dharman parityajya Mamekam Sharanam Braja Ahamtwa Sarva Pape bhy moksha Shyamima Sucha. That's the conclusion. That's the essence of the entire Bhagavad Gita.
snippets.reflection:
Krishna delivers his "best and final opinion" in these verses: yajna (sacrifice), dana (charity), and tapa (austerity) should never be abandoned because they are pavanani manishinam - purifiers even for the wise. This is a revolutionary teaching. We might think that highly evolved souls no longer need spiritual practices, but Krishna insists that even wise people require continuous purification of their internal instruments. It is like continuing education for any profession - without it, even experts become stale. The practices of sacrifice, giving, and discipline are not just for beginners; they are lifetime companions on the spiritual journey.

The profound insight here is that yajna, dana, and tapa are ultimately for you, not for others. When you give charity, the primary beneficiary is your own mind and heart being purified. When you practice austerity, your internal instrument becomes clearer. Krishna's instruction is precise: perform these actions sangam tyaktva phalani cha - without attachment and without expectation of results. Even the expectation that "this practice will purify my mind" can become a subtle burden.

Reflect today: What is your relationship with your spiritual practices? Do you perform them with a scorekeeper's mentality, tracking progress and expecting results? Or can you engage in service, giving, and discipline simply because they need to be done? Try this exercise: Perform one act of generosity today with absolutely no expectation - not even the expectation of feeling good about it. Give anonymously if possible, and observe what happens in your inner world when no one knows and no result is anticipated.

snippets.title: Day 216: Knowledge and Doers
snippets.sanskrit:
नियतस्य तु संन्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते |

दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत् |

कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन |
snippets.transliteration:
niyatasya tu saṃnyāsaḥ karmaṇo nopapadyate .

duḥkhamityeva yatkarma kāyakleśabhayāttyajet .

kāryamityeva yatkarma niyataṃ kriyate.arjuna .
verseTranslations: It is not right to give up actions which are obligatory; and if they are misunderstood, it is the result of sheer ignorance.
To avoid an action through fear of physical suffering, because it is likely to be painful, is to act from passion, and the benefit of renunciation will not follow.
He who performs an obligatory action, because he believes it to be a duty which ought to be done, without any personal desire to do the act or to receive any return - such renunciation is Pure.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga. The very title implies that liberation will only come from renunciation. In other words, something which we are holding on to is binding us. If we let go of whatever is binding us, we'll be released. And as we have discussed many times before, this chapter is a summary of the entire Bhagavad Gita's teachings so far. All throughout these chapters which we had been discussing, there is one central theme: that either Sannyasa (renunciation) or Tyaga (abandonment) is the key to this liberation. So the chapter opened with Arjuna's question: what is Sannyasa and what is Tyaga?

And Krishna explained that Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa Iti Sannyasa -- giving up all the desire-prompted activity is Sannyasa, and Sarvakarma Phalatyagam -- giving up the desire for the fruits of actions is Tyaga. And then Krishna took up the theme of Tyaga as the most important thing because at our level, Sannyasa is probably not possible. Giving up all desire-prompted activities is probably not possible at our level because everything we are doing right now is prompted by some desire. Even the things which I consider I'm doing as community work or selfless activities -- when you go to the root cause of why you're doing it, there is some desire which is prompting you to do that. There are people who are involved in a lot of organizations which are community-activity based.

We know they're very active as long as they have a position -- president or chairperson or board member. And suddenly they lose that position and the person disappears from that organization. All those were supposed to be selfless activities. It was helping the community, it was helping the people it was intended for, but it was not truly selfless for the person performing it. It was not directly benefiting them in terms of monetary gain, but there was something which was feeding their ego. Bhagavan constantly says Tyaga is giving up attachment to the fruits of actions.

And that is something which at our level we can understand and we can practice. So he takes up the theme of Tyaga and says, there are philosophers who say that all actions should be given up. Because they say any action which you perform binds you to its results, whether good or bad. Good binds you to good results, bad binds you to bad results. When you're bound by the good results, you want them to be repeated over and over and over again. I want to be successful again and again and again.

I go to Las Vegas and experience beginner's luck. First time I go to the slot machine and win some money. So I think that's how it works. Next time also it should work the same way. So we get bound by this good result. And then sometimes we lose our shirt in Las Vegas and want to avoid that.

So we are bound by the results. And therefore some philosophers, Bhagavan says, says all actions must be given up. You will never be bound by anything. But Bhagawan said, that's probably not possible for us anywhere. Therefore, he says, I recommend the second opinion which says yajna dana, tapah should not be given up. Yajna the offerings, dana the charity and tapas the discipline, austerities, which is what at our level we can relate to it as what we do as yajna is all our efforts in this life is a yajna.

All that we give back to this world as our results of our efforts is adana. And whatever we do to discipline ourselves is the tapas, Bhagwan said, that should not be given up. So the definitive advice from Krishna, as we have seen so far, he says, this is my best in the firm opinion that yajna dhana, tapa should not be given up. And then obviously he says, how to look at this tyagaha? So now our central theme of Bhagavad Gita as we have seen is Krishna's doctrine is the tyaga. And the tyaga defined is Sarva Karma, Falatyaga, Sarvakarma akhila.

Without living any actions, whether it is desire prompted or selfless. In both cases, do not be in anticipation of a particular result. Because as we have seen, even in doing the selfless actions, if we are bound to the Karma phala, then it is binding your ego. So Bhagavan said, perform this yajna dhana tapa but without attachment and without the expectation for the fruits of actions. Swamiji defines attachment as ego plus egocentric Desire is attachment. I have ines and minus, then I have a desire.

So when I come in contact with an object that can satisfy the desire, I'm attached. And I these days constantly talk about how we are attached to a grandchild. You know, because our ego says that's my grandchild. And also it is enchanting. Rather it's fulfilling, enchanting. So we are attached to.

So attachment is ego plus egocentric desire. And as long as that ego and egocentric desires are there, there will be an expectation for fruits of actions. So we are already worried. She is only 20 months old. We are worried what will happen when she grow up. Will she be smart enough to do all these things?

Will she be doctor or an architect? Or will she be something else? Will be artistic or athletic? We're already looking at the results of our efforts in raising her up at overload. The Bhagavan says as long as these two are there, it will be a problem. So he said, perform all this yajnadana and tapa but without attachment in expectation for the results.

So now I think I'm doing the tyaga. I'm giving up some things and then feel good about it that I gave up this thing. Let's see what kind of tyaga is that. So the next three verses says Niyatasyatu sanyasah Karmano na upopady. What should not be given up? He said: obligatory duties.

Those which are the Niyata Karmas should never be given up. So we have learnt in the previous chapter there are three types of karmas. Something which you do daily -- you are not obliging anybody by doing so. Then Niyata Karma, obligatory duties. I'm a doctor, I'm an architect.

I'm a father, I'm an employer. All those roles which I'm playing, it comes with its own duties. They are Niyata Karma. Those are my Niyata Karmas. I have to fulfill their duties. Then Naymithya Karma are special duties, special occasion, special situations.

These days, at least once in a while I find time from my routine and go see Dan in the hospital. That was not in my routine before, neither was it required that I go to MCV before Dan was admitted there. It's now a special condition which created a duty for me. So then Namittya Karma -- Bhagavan says none of this should be given up. It is not recommended that you give up your obligatory duties. Muha Tasha Parityagaha Tama Saha Pari Kirti Taha. Say I have given up all these duties, Niyata Karma -- I'm a father but I don't want to take care of my family.

I think it is binding me, so I'm going to give it up -- because I'm confused whether I'm supposed to be doing it or not. Bhagavan says that is Tamasic Tyaga. You have given up something, but it is Tamasic -- out of delusion, out of ignorance about your duty. If I give up something because it gives me bliss in my ignorance -- say, I don't file my taxes for five years, nobody finds out, and I'm at complete bliss that I didn't pay any taxes -- that's Tamasic Tyaga. Or I don't go for voting.

This is Tamasic Tyaga, out of delusion that it is not my duty. "I did not know I was supposed to file taxes? Well, I didn't file them. I did not know that my vote counts, so I didn't vote." Bhagavan says that's Tamasic Tyaga. So do all your obligated duties, but Bhagavan said, without attachment and without fixation on results.

So first thing Bhagawan said is if I give up something because of my ignorance my delusion that this is my duty it's not a tiag which is going to give me any good benefits or any more liberation. It actually binds me more to the ignorance and its consequences. Ignorance of law is not an excuse. When I came from Africa. Very first week when you start driving you're driving on a right side or left side. Your brain is not wired yet so you end up going in the wrong sense.

Luckily there was no more traffic. I said I'm sorry sir but I did not know that's not an excuse my friend. You're going to get killed if you drive on the wrong side. So bear in mind that we drive on the right side not on the wrong side. Bhagavan said that's a Tamasic tyaga. I give up my duties out of delusion or ignorance -- that is Tamasic. Dukkham Itiyevayat Karma Kayakya Bhayat: I need to do this.

But it is too hard when it snows and there is a foot of snow in my front door. I have to keep my office entrance clear. So when the people come to my office, they don't fall. But it's too hard and there's nobody else to help me. Kayaklesa Bhayat Tyajet -- because of the fear of the pain to this body, I give up that action.

Bhagavan says sakrutva rajasam tyaga. That's the Raja Sikhtyaga. I'm giving up something I am not doing something which I should have done. I clearly know that's my duty. To keep the entrance to my house and office clean is my duty so that nobody else can get hurt by coming to my home or my office. But out of that fear that it's going to hurt my body or hurt me something, I avoid doing it.

Bhagavan says it is certainly tyaga, but it is a Rajasic tyaga because it creates agitation in my mind. Sometimes the things you don't do give you more agitation than the things you do. My standard example is calling my mother. My mother expects me to call every week. But I end up calling every couple of months. And then what happens is when I don't call her and as the time goes by I start feeling guilty.

But I don't get around calling her. It makes me feel even more guilty. It's still I do it that day. You know, I at least called today. I talked to her for five minutes. Okay, now I'm good for a week.

Well, the week passes by. Second week, third week and I then start feeling guilty again. So this dagger of not doing my duty because it's going to disrupt something I'm doing here because of the time change. Obviously we have to either call her or call her in the morning or in the evening, late night. And then that's within my clashing, my routine. And I give up that so that it does not disturb my routine.

Now it gives me pleasure. Sakrutva rajasam tyagam naivat yaga Phalam labhed. There is no benefit I'm getting out of not doing that action. So it did not benefit me at all of saving that time for not calling. It actually gave me more troubles and more agitations. Had I taken those five minutes to call her, it would have given me peace.

For next five days at least. So Bhagawan said that if you're giving up something by fear of it's going to hurt you, it's going to discomfort you, it's going to disrupt your activities.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce the threefold classification of tyaga that illuminates our daily choices. Tamasic tyaga is abandoning obligatory duties out of delusion or ignorance - like not filing taxes because you did not know it was required, or not voting because you think it does not matter. Rajasic tyaga is avoiding duties because they seem painful or inconvenient - the fear of physical discomfort or disruption to your routine causes you to neglect what needs to be done. The striking example given is avoiding a call to an elderly parent because it disrupts your schedule, only to suffer more from lingering guilt than the five minutes the call would have taken. Sattvic tyaga, the pure form, is performing obligatory duties because they must be done, without personal desire and without craving results.

The teaching on niyata karma (obligatory duties) is particularly relevant. These are the duties that come with our roles - as parent, professional, citizen, or community member. Krishna declares that giving up these duties out of confusion is tamasic, and avoiding them out of fear of difficulty is rajasic. Neither approach yields the benefit of true renunciation. Only when we perform our duties with the attitude "karyam iti eva" - simply because they must be done - do we experience sattvic action.

Ask yourself today: What obligatory duty am I currently avoiding? Is it because of genuine confusion about whether it is my responsibility (tamasic), or because it seems too hard or inconvenient (rajasic)? Identify one duty you have been postponing and perform it today with the simple understanding that it needs to be done. Notice how completing it releases the mental burden that avoiding it had created.

snippets.title: Day 217: The Final Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते |

न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः |

अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम् |
snippets.transliteration:
na dveṣṭyakuśalaṃ karma kuśale nānuṣajjate .

na hi dehabhṛtā śakyaṃ tyaktuṃ karmāṇyaśeṣataḥ .

aniṣṭamiṣṭaṃ miśraṃ ca trividhaṃ karmaṇaḥ phalam .
verseTranslations: The wise man who has attained purity, whose doubts are solved, who is filled with the spirit of self-abnegation, does not shrink from action because it brings pain, nor does he desire it because it brings pleasure.
But since those still in the body cannot entirely avoid action, in their case abandonment of the fruit of action is considered as complete renunciation.
For those who cannot renounce all desire, the fruit of action hereafter is threefold - good, evil, and partly good and partly evil. But for him who has renounced, there is none.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. We are at the end of Bhagavad Gita. We have discussed 17 chapters. This is like making a work plan for ourselves. What is work strategy?

Work strategy is capabilities plus opportunity. So we've seen our capabilities in chapter two: that this self is indestructible, only the body is destructible. And then we have seen what our opportunities are. If we can align with that supreme self -- versus identifying with this limited being called the Ego, this body, mind and intellect -- then I have a chance to achieve my goal of perennial happiness, unlimited happiness. Right now, because I am identified with this limited self, my happiness is also limited. There are limited capabilities, limited opportunities, therefore limited outcomes.

But I do have an opportunity to align myself with the unlimited self, the unconditioned self. Then my opportunities will be unlimited. Therefore I will have the unlimited happiness. That's what we have learned so far in Bhagavad Gita. Now we are making a work plan. So right from the beginning of this chapter we have seen that Arjuna asked question about what is renunciation Tyaga.

From the overall discourse we have come to the conclusion that the only way to achieve the then Moksha, the liberation is by giving up things, not acquiring things by Tyaga and Sannyasa only. So Arjuna wanted to know what is the difference between the Tyaga and Sannyasa? And Bhagavan made it very clear in a very simple term that Karma Phala Tyaga is Tyaga. When I have no desire for particular result from my action, that's Dhyaga. And when I have no sense of agency, I have no desire for desire prompted actions, that's Sannyasa. When I give up the desire prompted action, it's Sannyasa.

And then it seemed like Bhagavan was veering off on a tangent into a discussion about actions. It seemed like we started the discourse on Sannyasa and Tyaga, but now we are talking about action. In earlier verses we discussed what constitutes actions. There are five constituent parts of any action: Adhishtana (the body or seat of action), Karta (the doer), the organs of action, all the functions of the organs of action and perception, and then the presiding deity -- the five elemental forces. These five have to come together for any action to come into existence. If any one of them is missing, the action will not take place. If the body is not there, there won't be any action. If the ego is not there, there will also not be any action. So we have learned that action requires these five constituent parts.

And now we'll be talking about what is the anatomy of action. So the question is why Bhagavan is moving from discussion on sannyas and tyaga into actions. If you remember, in chapter four, after learning Sankhya Yoga and Karma Yoga, we talked of Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga. This sannyasa from the actions is only possible by knowledge about who is the actor, who is the doer. Right now the sannyas is not possible for me as long as I'm identified with the doer.

If I think I am the doer, giving up action is not possible. Should I give up all the actions? As it seems that action is the root cause of all my problems. Action may be appropriate, inappropriate. It gives either a good, bad or somewhere in between result. Why not I get out of completely and say, well let me not act and therefore there wouldn't be any consequences.

By very nature that we are living entities, it's not possible. We have learned that in previous chapters and in this chapter there is not even for a moment that we can stay without action. Nahi Kastchat Kshanama PI Jatu Tishtadhya Karma Krut. The signature of life is action. So as long as I'm alive, I'll be acting. So giving up action is not the solution.

Then what is the solution? The solution is to renounce actions in knowledge. If I take ownership of my actions, then I'm bound by my actions. It is more like filing bankruptcy. If I have a company and I have taken ownership of the company and I have done everything that is supposed to be done, and I end up with a huge debt. What is my out from there?

The American law says the only way you can get out of it, file for chapter 11. First you file for chapter 11. Say let me reorganize myself. So everything I have done right now is null and void. Nobody can come, no creditor come and ask for anything for me. And if that doesn't work out, I can reconstitute myself.

I file for complete bankruptcy. At that point, I disown everything that I owned in that company. I'm no more responsible for the functioning of the company nor for the assets. I'm not the owner of the assets and I'm also not responsible for the debt. Now I'm completely free and clear from that. Therefore, we have the limited liability companies.

We want to compartmentalize our responsibility. So Bhagavan said, you can do this. You can file for bankruptcy in your actions. If you disown your actions, if you say I am not the doer then you are not responsible for any of our actions. If I realize that I am not the doer -- the "I" which I consider "I" right now is actually the conditioned self, the conditioned ego that is identified with this body, mind and intellect, and therefore I feel responsible for it.

Well, if you're a doer, then as you have learned, out of the five constituent parts of the action, one is the Karta, the doer. That doer is as much involved in the action as the other four. So Bhagavan said, the only way to get out of it is to realize who the actor is. Which is what Gnana Karma Sannyasa is about. I, as an "I" without any superimposition on it. Superimposition is I am an architect.

Well, that's a superimposition on I. I am a father, another superimposition. I am a brother, another superimposition. If I remove all the superimpositions, what remains as "I" -- is that "I" really a doer? That is the "I" I'm concerned about, the one that wants to be happy. So Bhagavan said that we need to understand what constitute actions. Then also now we have to understand where our misunderstanding is.

So from these previous verses we have concluded this action belongs to Prakriti, the manifest world. We also learned in chapter 13: Prakriti is the cause for Karya and Karana -- action and the instruments of action. But Purusha, Sukhadu Khana Boktrutvi Hetuhu Uchyate -- Purusha is the enjoyer of Sukha and Dukha. My nature, and the nature of the world of objects, creates this action.

Because I have a vasana for singing, I go to music concert. So this is the interaction between the world of objects and my vasanas. They are all part of this Prakriti. But I, the self is not really involved in it. I as an I has no vasanas, no conditioning. And therefore it's not involved.

If I fail to recognize, Bhagavan said, then you are the doer. As an ego, you're fully involved and vested in that and you will bear the results of it. Tatra evam sati kartaram tmanam kevalam Tu yaha pashati akrut buddhihe. Whose Buddhi is not trained in thinking finer points about what is right and what is wrong, what is reality and what is non reality. Sa pasyati durma tehi. Such a person's mind is perverted.

Perverted in essence is not seeing the reality as it is and getting affected by the wrong notion of what reality is. Dhurma tehi akrad buddhi. Why these words are used? Because he says, because you are seeing. Tatyaam siddhi kartaram atmanam kevalam to yahu consider atma itself to the doer. One who sees that atma is the doer, he's wrong.

Because he does not have the finer intellect to realize what is right and wrong. Also he is influenced by wrong mati. His mind is tilted, polluted by vasanas, his intellect is clouded and therefore he does not see who the doer is. Because we elaborately analyzed and came to the conclusion that the action is only taking place in the realm of the Prakriti and the Purusha is not involved at all. The universal Purusha is not involved. We have used this example over and over again.

The space in this room is not participating in any activity of this room. But because we are identifying it with the walls, floor and ceiling, it becomes a room space. Now it is all the qualities of this room. Height, length, breadth; polluted air or clean air; light or darkness. All that is associated with this room is actually the conditioning superimposed in the space which was always here, is here and will always remain here. When you remove this building, the space will go back to its original condition.

But it was unpolluted, pristine space. That space is not taking part in any of the activity of this room. The same way, the self in me which enables me to do all these activities, when it is seen as unconditioned, is not taking any part in them. But it seems like it's taking part, because I'm identifying it with my mind, my intellect and my body. Now I'm thinking that the conditioned self is the only self and that he's the doer.

That notion is wrong and therefore we are suffering. So this verse clearly says you need to differentiate between who is the doer and who are you. Are you the conditioned self, the ego? Or you are the unconditioned self, that which is imperishable, indestructible. Yasya na aham kruta bhavah buddhi Yasya na lipya de hatwh iman lokan hanti na ni badyade. So we are coming back to what we want to know.

How should I act in this life? He said, you act as you have to. Because once you understand that yasya naham kuta bhavaha once you realize that I, the self is not the doer, not taking any part in action, I'm just a saxichaitanya. I'm just the enabler. Welfare check comes to the person who is receiving welfare. That check will enable that person to go and buy whatever necessities he has.

What he buys is entirely up to that person. We have heard complaints about people on welfare. Use the welfare checks to go and buy beer or whatever, the alcohol versus buying food. But because that is according to him, welfare department only sends you a check, enables you to buy things in your grocery store. After that, it is entirely up to you how you use that. This life in me is enabling me to act.

But it's not taking part into what field I'm acting in. That comes from my vasanas, my mental makeup, my intellect capabilities in my body. That's how I find my field. So Bhagavan said, yasya na aham kruta bhavah. One with his finer intellect came to the conclusion that I am not the doer. Such a person Buddhi Yasyana Lipyate whose intellect is not clouded by all the experiences of my life.

So right now my Buddhi is clouded by what I experienced. Experiences press on my mind, and that impression creates what I consider to be reality. So next time when I encounter the similar situation, I'll use that as a reference point and then act accordingly. Some people who start investing in one field get successful in first venture. He continues to do that and he has more positive attitude.

Next guy who does the same thing but fails the very first time, he'll have a negative impression of what to do in that field.
snippets.reflection:
The portrait of a true tyagi in verse 10 is striking: one who neither hates disagreeable work nor is attached to agreeable work, who is sattvic in nature, wise, and whose doubts have been cut asunder. This person has transcended the common trap of dividing work into "what I like" and "what I avoid." For most of us, work becomes a burden precisely because we have strong preferences. But the wise person understands that all work comes through the gunas of Prakriti, and the real self is merely the witness. The practical implication is profound: since we cannot completely give up actions while living in a body (verse 11), the path to freedom lies in giving up attachment to results.

Verse 12 presents a sobering truth: for those who do not practice tyaga, actions produce three types of results after death - agreeable, disagreeable, or mixed. But for the sannyasi who has truly renounced, there is no fruit at all. This is the ultimate freedom - not escaping action but escaping the bondage of results. Like filing for bankruptcy frees you from corporate debts by dissolving ownership, disowning the sense of doership frees you from karmic bondage.

Today, observe your reactions to different tasks. Notice when you approach work with enthusiasm because you like it, or with resistance because you find it disagreeable. Can you identify the underlying attachments? Practice approaching one pleasant task and one unpleasant task with the same equanimity - neither grasping at the enjoyable one nor pushing away the difficult one. This is the beginning of becoming medhavi (wise) and chinna-samshaya (free from doubt).

snippets.title: Day 218: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे |

अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम् |

शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः |

adhiṣṭhānaṃ tathā kartā karaṇaṃ ca pṛthagvidham .

snippets.reflection:
These verses reveal the five causes that must combine for any action to occur: adhishthana (the body or seat of action), karta (the doer or ego), karana (the various instruments or sense organs), the diverse functions of these instruments, and daivam (destiny or the presiding cosmic forces). This teaching from Sankhya philosophy dissolves the illusion that "I alone" am the doer. Consider: if any one of these five factors is absent, the action cannot happen. If the body is not present, if the ego is not engaged, if the instruments are not functioning, if the circumstances do not align - the action simply will not occur. This means our individual contribution is just one-fifth of the equation.

The insight becomes even more liberating when we realize that these five causes apply equally to right and wrong actions, to actions of body, speech, and mind. The mechanism of action is neutral - it is our identification with it that creates bondage. Like understanding that electricity powers both the heater and the air conditioner without preference, understanding the mechanics of action helps us stop taking personal credit or blame for outcomes that depend on factors far beyond our control.

Reflect on a recent accomplishment you feel proud of. Now analyze: What was the role of your body and its health? What instruments and skills were involved? What circumstances had to align? What cosmic factors - timing, luck, the cooperation of others - contributed? Honestly assess how much was truly "you" versus the coming together of these five factors. This contemplation naturally reduces ego and opens the door to genuine humility and freedom from the burden of being the sole doer.

snippets.reflection:
Verse 16 delivers a sharp rebuke: one who sees the Self alone as the doer, not understanding the five factors of action, is akrita-buddhi (of immature intellect) and durmati (of perverted understanding). This is strong language because the error is so consequential. When I believe "I am the sole doer," I take full ownership of results I do not fully control, creating unnecessary suffering. The solution in verse 17 is equally powerful: one whose intellect is not tainted by the notion "I am the doer" (naham-krita-bhava) does not kill even when killing, and is not bound by actions. This is not a license for violence but a statement about the nature of liberated action - when ego is absent, karma does not stick.

Verse 18 presents the complete anatomy of action through two triads. First, the impulse to action: jnana (knowledge), jneya (the object to be known), and parijnata (the knower). Second, the action itself: karana (instrument), karma (action), and karta (doer). Understanding these components helps us see how we get pulled into activity. Knowledge of a coffee shop creates the knower who desires coffee, prompting action through the instruments of body and mind. By understanding this mechanism, we gain the ability to interrupt automatic patterns.

Today, when you feel compelled to act - especially in response to a strong desire or aversion - pause and identify: What is the knowledge driving this? What am I seeking to know or obtain? Who is the knower that wants this? What instruments will be employed? This brief analysis creates space between stimulus and response. In that space lies freedom. Practice this with one desire today and notice how understanding the mechanics of action naturally loosens its grip on you.
