snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. As we have discussed before, the whole exercise in Bhagavad Gita is to renounce actions in knowledge. We have figured out that actions are the cause for all my frictions and unhappiness in life. Any action which I perform, whether good, bad or ugly, will have its result. And the result will be either conducive, not conducive, or somewhere in between -- mixed. And in this chapter, Bhagavan clarifies that this only applies to those who have not given up expectation for the fruits of actions.

In this chapter we learn the definition of a Tyagi: one who gives up Karma Phala Tyaga is a Tyagi. The one who gives up all the desire-prompted actions is a Sannyasi. I can only give up all my desire-prompted actions if I have no desires. At this point, it does not seem that I can reach that point where I hold no desire. So then the question is: how can I solve this conundrum?

On one hand it says the only way you can be free is if you have no desires. On the other hand, it clearly seems that living without desires is not possible. It seems like there is something we are missing in this equation. If both are true, then there has to be some kind of parallax which I have to remove so I can see the truth as it is. This is something which we have learnt in Vedanta: that the same thing can be seen in two different lights.

A rope can be seen as a rope if I'm clear about what it is. But it can also give rise to fear that it's a snake. So the same thing, depending on my mental association, can appear as a rope or as a snake. Similarly, because I can't reconcile these two -- on one hand Gita keeps telling me to live without any desires and on the other hand I see that desires are unavoidable -- it seems like there are two different kinds of people: one who cannot live without desires and one who has no desires.

So to understand that, we have obviously taken this study of Bhagavad Gita. And now we are coming to the conclusion that there are two I. The one I is a conditioned I which is conditioned by my body, my mind, my intellect, associated with my body, my mind, intellect and therefore that I has all the limitations of my body, my mind and intellect. But then there is one "I" which is always there. No matter what the condition of this body, mind, intellect -- the body was a baby, then it was a child, then a young man, then an adult, and now it's the old man -- that "I" remained the same. So there must be a differentiation between the I which I consider I when I think about my body, my mind, my intellect and that which has no conditioning.

When I remove all the conditioning, I will not be there as this conditioned "I," but that "I" will still remain. As we learnt in Bhagavad Gita chapter 2, that "I" is indestructible. The metaphor we use all the time is the room space. Room space is conditioned by its limitations of the size and shape and the type of air in it. Right now once this walls, floor and ceilings are gone the space will remain what it is. So we have learnt in chapter 13 that there is a field and it's knower. As long as there is field, I as the knower will limit myself as the knower of the field. So in this chapter we have started our journey by saying let me define what is Tyagi and what is Sannyasi.

The Tyagi does not give up the Karmaphalas, because Karmaphalas are not in his hand. Karma Phala Datta -- someone other than me -- gives me the fruits of my actions. But I want to influence that outcome by my desires. That I want this particular outcome.

That if I give up influencing the outcome by my desires then I will be Karma Falathyagi. If you know this, then the next thing you need to know is that any kind of results which come from your actions are not binding to you. Because you did not expect any result out of it. Whatever comes you accept with the Prasad Buddhi. Just like when you go to the temple and you accept Prasad, you don't really are choosy about what comes in your prasad. Whatever Panditja gives you, accept it with love.

When whatever comes out of my actions is the result, I should accept that. Just as I accept Prasad from Bhagavan. If I develop this sense, Bhagavan said, you will be a Tyagi. Once you disassociate from this limited "I," you will not have desires. That higher "I" will not have desires. The smaller "I" will have desires. The body will have its own demands, mind will have its own demands and intellect will own demands.

The one who is overseeing the three will have no demands whatsoever. It is now up to me to identify either with the lower "I" or the higher "I." So we have learned from the beginning that giving up actions is not possible. Therefore, whatever action you perform should be ordained action. Those even when I am performing, I should be not attached. It should be performed without any Ra, without any asakti, without any expectation and any attachment.

I should be performing this action without attachment. That's the advice we've heard so far. Then Bhagavan got into the discussion of what action is, because we need to understand it. We understood that action has five components. Unless those five come together, action never takes place.

In these five components, one is Karta, the actor. You have to have an actor or an action to come into being. And that's the only one I have control over. Then I need to now define who the Karta is. And that once I figure out, then I will be able to figure out whether I am the sufferer, the enjoyer of my actions or not. Because the Karta is the Bhokta of all the actions.

So in the following _Verses_ we have seen that one who considers that this self is the doer, he does not see the truth alone. Because the truth is the self is not acting at all. In all these actions which I am performing, the self remains as just a witness. Because actions are performed by the gunas of my body, mind and intellect. The nature of my mind, nature of my intellect and nature of my body decide what type of actions I'll perform. When the conducive objects come in my way, I get tempted to act and then I act.

Gnanam, gneam, parignata, Trivedaha, Karma, Chodana. These are the propellers of my actions. Gnanam, knowledge, Gnayam the knowable and Pariganatha the knower. So this is basically going back to chapter 13. In chapter 13 we are seeing there is a field and its knower. So when this gnanam, when there is a knowledge of the field occurs, that's the knowledge.

Once I figure out this is the field of my activity and I identify it, then the knower comes into being. As long as I'm aware of the field, I become the knower of the field. So this three when the knower of the field identifies the field and when that knowledge takes place the gnanam that becomes the propeller of my action. Starbucks is the field of my knowledge. Passing by I identify Starbucks.

The field of knowledge is there and my knowledge has taken place -- the Starbucks is there. I as the knower of the field will have the desire to have a cup of coffee. That knowledge of the field by the knower is the propeller of action. As long as I'm identified as the knower of the field constantly associating with the field that knowledge will create the impulse in me to act in this world. So that's clearly Bhagawan said you should understand that the knower of the field minus the field is just the knower.

Knowledge of the field minus the field is just the knowledge. So that knowledge is I exist in my deep sleep. I have no other knowledge but I still know that I exist. So when I wake up and somebody asks what kind of sleep? You say I had a very nice sleep. I said I don't know, I just had a good sleep.

There is no other experience but just I exist in the experience. Bhagavan said, know how these actions work. When the field comes in contact with the knower of the field when knowledge takes place that knowledge will be the propeller of your action. And then he says Karanam Karma Karta ITI Trivedha Karma Sangrah what will preserve the action? Three things to come together. Karanamdhi instrument of action.

I see a nice house in a good neighborhood. I really want to buy this house. But then I figure out: do I have the means to buy the house? If I don't have the means, all that good idea about that house and my desire to buy it remains just a dream. I will only put that into action if I have the means to perform that action -- that is Karanam.

When I have the Karana -- the means, the equipment to perform this action -- then we need the Karta, the doer. If there is no doer, I may have all the means and all the desires, but if I am not available to perform that action, then it won't come into existence. So these two have to come together. The Karanam and Karta have to come together for Karma to take place. We are analyzing what the impulse of action is, and how action comes into being, because at the end of this discussion we're going to find out what control I have over my actions.

We are coming to the conclusion that the person that I really have control over is the Kartha. If I don't have that doership Bhav that notion that I am the doer then no action really takes place. So that I, which we call it the conditioned I Jivatma is thinking that he is the doer. Not only is thinking he is the doer, he is the only doer. When I perform any action and it is successful I feel that I did it and I did it all by myself. There was no help from anybody else.

This is where Bhagavan says you are going wrong. That you think you are the doer and you are the only doer. If I think that I have the control over my actions and I perform my actions then obviously I have a particular result in mind. Because I think I'm performing it correctly. I'm performing right field. The result must be X, Y or Z.

We forget that for any action I have to perform the field of action has to be appropriately configured to drive from my home to here. The whole field of action which is my road from my house to here has to be completely clear. All traffic lights have to work perfectly. All other drivers should drive in the proper lanes. Unless all that come in property configuration I wouldn't be able to come here in time. So when I consider that I did everything myself to come here in time, I'm actually wrong.

There are so many people have to do so many things for me to be here on time.
snippets.reflection:
These verses introduce the threefold classification of knowledge based on the gunas. Sattvic knowledge perceives the One immutable Reality in all diverse beings - seeing the undivided in the divided (verse 20). Rajasic knowledge sees beings as separate and unrelated, perceiving manifold distinct entities everywhere (verse 21). This distinction has immediate practical implications. When we have sattvic knowledge about our own body, our hand rushes to help our aching leg without negotiation - there is complete unity. But with rajasic knowledge about the world, we see others as fundamentally separate, requiring permission, contracts, and boundaries for any cooperation.

The key insight is that our type of knowledge determines our type of action. If I see the world as a collection of separate, competing entities (rajasic knowledge), my actions will naturally be self-protective and acquisitive. If I perceive the same consciousness animating all beings (sattvic knowledge), my actions become naturally harmonious and selfless - like the seamless coordination within my own body. The knower, the knowledge, and the knowable are the propellers of action. Transform the knowledge, and the actions transform automatically.

Examine your perception today: When you interact with family, colleagues, or strangers, what do you fundamentally see? Separate beings competing for limited resources? Or the same life force expressing through different forms? Choose one interaction today and consciously shift to sattvic perception - see the other person as another expression of the same consciousness that animates you. Notice how this shift in perception naturally changes the quality of your interaction, making it more easeful and compassionate.

snippets.title: Day 221: The Final Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहैतुकम् |

नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम् |

यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहंकारेण वा पुनः |
snippets.transliteration:
yattu kṛtsnavadekasminkārye saktamahaitukam .

niyataṃ saṅgarahitamarāgadveṣataḥ kṛtam .

yattu kāmepsunā karma sāhaṃkāreṇa vā punaḥ .
verseTranslations: But that which clings blindly to one idea as if it were all, without logic, truth or insight, that has its origin in Darkness.
An obligatory action done by one who is disinterested, who neither likes nor dislikes it, and gives no thought to the consequences that follow, such an action is Pure.
But even though an action involve the most strenuous endeavour, yet if the doer is seeking to gratify his desires, and is filled with personal vanity, it may be assumed to originate in Passion.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. We had been discussing that this renunciation is of the actions which we are performing. Renouncing the actions will liberate me. And then we have also seen that all actions cannot be renounced. Therefore, the actions which are helping me in purifying my internal instrument, the Antahkarana, those actions must be performed. And Bhagavan said, even for the wise people, even one who has achieved this knowledge -- if they stop performing these actions, there is the danger of getting pollution on their mind and intellect, or getting Tamas clouding over the mind and intellect again.

So they also continue these actions. It's like continuous maintenance. You have to continue to act in the manner which purifies our internal instrument, the Antahkarana. Your actions should be for the purpose of purifying mind and intellect, so they remain in a Sattvic, clean mode where you can see the reality as it is all the time. And those actions must be performed in the right attitude and the right manner.

Then we have also discussed that actions are prompted by knowledge -- I know something which I either like or dislike, and I come to the conclusion that that's the field of my action. So knowledge is the propeller of action. The knowledge, the knower, and that which is to be known are the three propellers of action that propel you to act in this world. The last three verses analyzed knowledge, showing that even knowledge can be of three different types. Like everything else we have discussed in Bhagavad Gita and Vedanta, things can be classified broadly into three categories: Sattvic, Rajasic, and Tamasic. Because these are the qualities of Maya.

This world is nothing but the projection through Maya. So everything in this world can be classified into these three categories. Knowledge can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. Sattvic knowledge is the one which makes me see the unity in diversity -- I can see the same immutable reality pulsating through all beings and things. That knowledge which makes me see that is the Sattvic knowledge, the pure knowledge. The knowledge which makes me see the plurality -- that this world is made up of innumerable various things and beings unrelated to each other -- is called Rajasic, because it divides my world into "I" and "the world." I am separate from this world.

And this world is also not a one entity but conglomeration of various beings and things. That's Rajasic knowledge. And that creates again another division of the world: things which I like and things which I do not like. And then the third we have seen is Tamasic knowledge, which is a very narrow focus on a view or a philosophy. One may say, "this is reality." In Sanskrit we say kupamanduk, like the frog in a well.

For that frog, the well is the world. There is nothing beyond that. Obviously we know that is because of the frog's ignorance about the rest of the world. The same way, if we hold a view that this is real and everything else that other people tell me or believe is wrong, then it's Tamasic knowledge. It's out of delusion, out of confusion, out of ignorance that I hold that view. That's Tamasic knowledge.

Bhagavan said it is important for us to know what type of knowledge we have, because my actions will be guided by the views I hold because of my knowledge. We have seen the example that because I have a complete sattvic knowledge about my own self, when it comes to my body, the actions are completely synchronized. That when there is a pain in our leg, my hand and arm rush there to help that. That's because the knowledge is purely sattvic about myself that I pervade through this entire body. There is a unity in this diversity of limbs I have in my body.

And therefore my actions are also sattvic. There is no permission to be granted to the hand to go and massage the leg, which is if I have the similar reason for the rest of the world, my action will be exactly like that. So the next three verses say actions can also be classified -- depending on what propelled them -- into Sattvic, Rajasic, and Tamasic. Niyatam Sangarahitam: that action which is done with the attitude that it needs to be done, and therefore I'm doing it. My hand does not ask permission because it needs to be done.

If I will have the same view, if there's any pain anywhere, I just won't be able to stop myself to go and help. But right now I divide my world. "Well, that's all happening in Egypt, so it's not my problem. We are fine here. Let me call my brothers and sisters in India -- well, they are doing fine."

So I think we are okay. Because I don't feel that connection, that unity with the people who are suffering or people who need help. Bhagavan said, one who does this action -- the action which is ordained -- does it without attachment. There are no likes or dislikes.

There is no particular attachment in the left leg versus right leg. Even though my right leg is probably broken and needs more care. But I see them completely unattached manner. My actions are ordained. In a sense, I feel compelled to act by my nature and my instinct because of the oneness I feel with that entity. Without any attachment, there is no particular reason that I want to help that person or want to do that action.

It just needs to be done. I don't have a particular love for that action or hate for their action. And there is no expectation of a particular result to come out. Such an action is considered satwik. That's because it will create the bliss internally for me in my internal instrument. Once I perform that action, there is no agitation.

There is no lingering thought, why did I do it? Was that the right thing to do or not? There is no after effect of my action and therefore it is sattvic. So there is a bliss inside. As Bhagavan said, the harmony outside the field in which I'm acting, there is also no agitation. Because I read something, the people I'm working with, there is no agitation with them.

They also feel harmony. And we know that when we are in some kind of community action where you really don't have anything to gain but just want to help out, you feel harmony there. With other actions, you don't feel harmony. That's because they fall into the next category -- Rajasic action. Most of our actions unfortunately fall into this category.

First of all, it's done because it's prompted by my desire. I want to get something out of it, therefore I'm doing it. Their desire prompted action. I want to gain something out of it. Why did you join this organization?

Well, it's good networking. It's a Rotary Club or a Lions Club or something. It's supposed to be just for community development. But what does the marketing guy say? "If you really want to be successful, you should join your local Rotary Club or a Lions Club or something." So you have a networking.

By the way, some people may get benefit. That's a side effect of my joining. My main goal was to get a networking. I actually did a leadership metro course in 2003. It's pretty prestigious -- a lot of CEOs and presidents and all that.

It's basically for developing leadership in the area. But you ask them what the incentive is, and they say, "Well, you will get to know all the CEOs and presidents in this town. Good networking tool for your business." Now, by the way, if somebody is doing that and helping the community, it is still good enough. The people who are doing these actions for the wrong reasons but having a right effect on society -- let them do it, don't stop them.

But it is not helping the person who is doing it. So that's action which is prompted by desire. And again, it is also done with an ego. I am doing it, you know, nobody else was ready, but I said nobody else could have done it. But I said I can do that. So kriyate Bahula Yasam and it requires lots of efforts.

Something which does not come naturally to you obviously requires lots of effort. The guy who is trained singer, when he sings, how much effort does he have to put nothing he naturally because he's trained. All his systems are wired for it. His vocal cords are trained for that. And he just comes out and sings and goes away. Somebody like me, somebody says, neel, you have to perform on such and such.

Well, I have to practice and make sure that I understand lots of effort because it does not come naturally to me. So Bahula Yasam all our actions which are prompted by desire and done with ego require lots of efforts. And that's where we have a fatigue. When I say the burnout factor, you know, well, I had been helping this community for a long time. Well, volunteers make sure they don't get burned out. If they're truly volunteering, they will never get burned out.

They get burned out because there was something other than just helping was involved. Well, people are not giving me credit for what I'm doing. That feeling makes you burn out of what you are doing. Bhagavan said they are doing it with lots of effort, and therefore there is fatigue, there is a burnout factor, there is disharmony and agitation within. Sattvic action creates bliss within and harmony outside.

Rajasic actions create agitation inside and disharmony outside. "I wanted to do it, but he is now doing it. I wanted to be the president of this organization. Even though I don't get anything out of it, nobody pays me for that -- but now he is doing it." So there is agitation, disharmony.

Therefore these actions are called Rajasic. Swamiji makes a very good point that even the great political leaders, great social workers, and great leaders in the business world all fall into Rajasic action at the best of their behavior or the best of their intentions. Because the same action can be Tamasic -- one which looks Rajasic but could be Tamasic. He says Rajasic actions are clearly better than Tamasic. You now just have to graduate from Rajasic to Sattvic to get the bliss which you're seeking, the happiness which you are looking for.

You have to transcend Rajasic into Sattvic. But be careful -- what you consider Rajasic may actually be Tamasic. So the next verse says what Tamasic action is: those actions are first of all prompted by delusion. I want to do this because I do not know what is the right thing to do.
snippets.reflection:
These verses classify actions themselves according to the three gunas. Sattvic action is niyatam (ordained/obligatory), performed sangam rahitam (without attachment), araga-dveshatah (without likes or dislikes), and aphala-prepsuna (without desire for results). Rajasic action is driven by desire (kamepsuna), performed with ego (sahamkarena), and involves bahula-ayasam (great effort/strain). The contrast is illuminating: sattvic action flows naturally and creates inner bliss and outer harmony, while rajasic action requires tremendous effort and creates internal agitation and external discord.

The description of rajasic action in verse 24 deserves special attention. When work is desire-driven and ego-centered, it demands great effort. This explains burnout in volunteers and professionals alike - when we work for recognition, position, or personal gain, we become exhausted because we are fighting against the natural flow. Swamiji points out that even great social workers and business leaders, at their best, often operate at the rajasic level. The challenge is to graduate from rajasic to sattvic action.

Today, examine the effort level in your activities. Where does work feel like a struggle, requiring you to push through resistance? This may indicate rajasic motivation - desire for results or ego investment. Where does action feel effortless, almost doing itself? This points toward sattvic action. Choose one task that feels burdensome and ask: What am I really seeking from this? Can I perform it simply because it needs to be done, without attachment to how others receive it or what it produces? This shift from "I want" to "this needs doing" transforms the entire experience.

snippets.title: Day 222: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अनुबन्धं क्षयं हिंसामनपेक्ष्य च पौरुषम् |

मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः |

रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः |
snippets.transliteration:
anubandhaṃ kṣayaṃ hiṃsāmanapekṣya ca pauruṣam .

muktasaṅgo.anahaṃvādī dhṛtyutsāhasamanvitaḥ .

rāgī karmaphalaprepsurlubdho hiṃsātmako.aśuciḥ .
verseTranslations: An action undertaken through delusion, and with no regard to the spiritual issues involved, or the real capacity of the doer, or to the injury which may follow, such an act may be assumed to be the product of Ignorance.
But when a man has no sentiment and no personal vanity, when he possesses courage and confidence, cares not whether he succeeds or fails, then his action arises from Purity.
In him who is impulsive, greedy, looking for reward, violent, impure, torn between joy and sorrow, it may be assumed that in him Passion is predominant.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga. Just to remind ourselves what we have seen so far: in the beginning, Arjuna made a request -- I want to know what is Sannyasa and what is Tyaga? Because we had been talking about renunciation. This chapter is called Liberation through Renunciation. So the obvious answer is renouncing actions.

And how do we renounce actions and what type of actions can we renounce or should we renounce is the gist of this chapter. So the first thing Bhagavan said is Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa Iti Sannyasa -- giving up all the desire-prompted actions is Sannyasa. It's as simple as that. If I can give up all desire-prompted actions so that I'm truly driven by my duties, the joy of working, and whatever is appropriate for me to do, then I am a Sannyasi. But that may or may not be possible. So the next teaching is Sarvakarma Phala Tyaga Iti Tyaga.

If you give up all the Karma Phala, the desire for the fruits of action, then it's Tyaga. So Bhagavan starts with Tyaga because that may be more appropriate for us. So then he describes that even tyaga can be of three different types. So now the entire chapter takes up the aspect of actions -- which is what is binding us. Actions in our day-to-day life, what we call work, are becoming a burden for us. That's why we all want to retire.

All our planning for is what retirement. That's because we are not enjoying the work. So Bhagawan said let's understand what tyaga is. So then we have seen that the tyaga also can be of three types of you can give up something which is you're appropriately giving up because of sattvic reasons or rajasic reasons or tamasic reasons. Then we said the tyaga we talked about of actions. So what type of actions should be given up and what should not be given up?

We said the yajna dana tapa, this type of actions must be performed. So even the yajnas can be of three types. Sattvik, Rajasika, Tamasik, Dana also can be of three types. SattVik, Rajasik and tamasic. The disciplines which we follow can also be three types. Sattvik, rajasik, tamasik.

In other words, everything is tied to each other. How we think, how we behave and what the results come to us, they're all tied to each other. Our thinking is not sattvic, then obviously our actions will not be sattvic and therefore our results will not be satwik. So if we understand this mechanism of actions, then maybe we will be able to liberate ourselves from this burden of work. In India, at least in the 60s that I can remember, the first thing people would ask is, "So where are you working?" Oh, I just got a job in government.

I think it's a perfect job. I'll tell you, I hardly have to work. The definition of good job in many times in India was the job in which I did the least amount of work is a good job. Now is it really what I'm looking for in a job? I remember when I went to Zambia. I took a job at the building department in the government of Zambia.

So my chief architect, first day in orientation said, we have a requirement that in a year you should at least do three drawings. And I said, are you serious? He said, no, at least you should have three drawings in a year. So that was a government standard of your performance. Our basic understanding right now is that action is a burden. Actually, as long as I can get out of the actions, then I'll be happy.

So renouncing action is the goal of our life. But how to renounce action is the theme of this chapter. So we say even yajna dana tapas, which needs to be done also should be done in a manner that it liberates you and not binds you. So yagnas can be of three types, Dhyana can be of three types, and tapas can be of three types. And we all know sometimes we do charity. But that makes you unhappy.

Instead of making you feel joy about giving, it makes you unhappy. That's because our attitude towards giving had something not right about it. So Bhagavan said, you should examine this thing in all things you do, whether it's sattvik, tamasic or rajasik, and see what is appropriate for you. Then we said, okay, Karma. Now let's understand what is the nature of Karma. And I said: Karma, Karana, Karta.

These are the three constituent parts of any action. Any action will have an action, a doer, and an instrument of action. And that requires knowledge. Gnanam, Gneyam, Parignata -- these are the three constituent parts: the knowledge, that which is to be known, and the knower. If we understand the mechanism of these actions and how the knowledge takes place, then we should be able to work better.

So then we have looked at how the knowledge takes place and how the action is related to it. So then we have been looking at and say, okay, now if knowledge also can be of three types. Some knowledge is Sattvic, some is Rajasic and some is Tamasic. Something I come to believe without any reason or rhyme could be tamasic. So knowledge also can be Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. I should be very careful.

Even I consider myself a more knowledgeable person. I need to examine whether my knowledge is appropriate or Sattvik or Rajasik or Tamasakya. Obviously, before whoever figured it out that earth is round, people had knowledge the earth is flat. But it was not really a knowledge based on any basis, but just a regular observation that looks like earth is flat. So sometimes what is quite obvious may not be the truth. So I need to be constantly vigilant about it.

So my knowledge also should be examined whether it is Rajasik, Tamasik or Sattvik. Then Karma, which I am performing, also can be Rajasic, Tamasic or Sattvik, depending on the knowledge which I have, is whether Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. So these are all tied together in every aspect of my life. I should be examining whether this is the most appropriate way to behave. So then the verses which we'll be saying today they about Karta, Karta. I consider myself the doer.

Now am I a Sattvik doer, a Rajasic doer, a Tamasic doer? Then we find out that it's not a consistent that I am not always a Sattvic doer, I'm not always a Rajasik doer. I'm not always a Tamasik doer. At times I'm Sattvik, at times I'm Rajasik, at times I'm Tamasik. However, I must examine that and make sure that I do not become predominantly Tamasic or Rajasic. Because the results of Tamas and Rajas, as we have seen, are nothing but pain in the end.

The only thing which liberates you is sattva, the pure knowledge. When I start seeing things as they are, that's where the liberation comes in. Anytime I have bias of my own, then I'm bound by my own bias. More and more people realizing that more they limit themselves to one viewpoint or one group of people, they're binding themselves to limitations. The more they open up, they become more liberated and make more progress. So the verse 26 says Mukta Sangha Anahamvadi Dhruti Utsa Samanvitah Siddhi Asidyo nirvikaraha karta satvika uchate.

If I am a doer and I consider myself the person performing this action, well, let's see in what attitude I perform it. Mukta Sangha -- free from attachment. Am I really too attached to this action? If somebody lets me do it, great. If I don't get a chance to do this, am I okay? Or is the world going to come apart if I don't get a chance to do this? Unattached. Anahamvadi -- he does not have the ego that "I am the doer."

I am the only one who can do it. I can do this so that we know that if I can do it, the others can also do it. However, I can put the best efforts if I want. Dhruti Utsa Samanvitah -- I think this, at least from my life, is the most important part. Whether you are successful or not successful in what you are pursuing. Again dhruti persistent firmness.

This is what I want to do. When I came to this country, I kept giving my life's example because that's all I know is my life. When I came to this country, I met some architects who had been here 10 years before I had come. So I asked their advice and said what should I do? I need to get registration as a licensed architect in this country. They forget about it.

It's not really worth it. It will take you 10 years. There are better professions with your architectural training. You can be a pipe draftsman or something which will give you a better compensation. And I say, I'll tell you honestly, the only thing I know is architecture. So I need to pursue architecture.

Whether there are good chances in this country or not. I have to continue find my niche because I don't know anything better. But I say only thing I know is doing architecture. So Dhruti -- if you want to be successful in architecture, stay with architecture. Don't buy a gas station; don't open up a hotel.

Dhruti is the most important aspect of any actions we will perform. If you are yourself not firm about it, people will recognize right away that you are not serious about it. And the next quality, which I learned from my guru Swami Chinmayananda, is Utsaha -- enthusiasm. Swamiji had a unique quality: he would infuse enthusiasm in anybody he met. Everybody in front of him was like Swamiji we can do this and Swamiji we can do that. That's a unique quality that you can inspire people to be enthusiastic about what they are doing.

And again, if you are not enthusiastic, everybody else will be also the same way. The most important aspects of any doer are Dhruti and Utsaha -- Samanvitah Siddhi Asidyo Nirvikaraha. Having done all that, the result is not in my hand. I may be the best person, I may be the best firm. But the world may have different needs and the world may react differently. And therefore it may not be a successful action.

And I should be unattached to that. Do not get affected by it. We are human beings, we have emotions. We may feel slightly bad about it, but you have to move on from that. It should not affect your personality that now I'm rejected one time, I will not try next time. In fact, continue trying to persistently keep going back and back to the same organization or efforts to be successful.

Persistence pays off. Siddhi Asidyo Nirvikarah karta satvikochate. Such an actor, such a doer is considered Sattvik. He may be successful, he may not be successful. He may be appreciated. He may not be appreciated.

But he knows that he's pursuing this with all his zeal and all firmness. So that's such a doer is Sattvik the next one. Ragi Karma Phala prepsuhu lubdaha in Satmakaha Asuchi Harshoka Anvitah karta Rajasah Parikertita. However, when we are in that mode, we don't recognize it. Unfortunately, it's a ragi attached sometimes with a good virtue. He's very passionate about it.

Passion is something which can be very tricky to recognize whether it is positive or negative. The same passion, it is based on your dhruti then it is positive.
snippets.reflection:
After classifying knowledge and action, these verses turn to the actor. The sattvic doer (verse 26) is mukta-sanga (free from attachment), anaham-vadi (without ego-assertion), endowed with dhriti (steadfastness) and utsaha (enthusiasm), and nirvikara (unchanged) in success or failure. This portrait challenges our usual understanding of success. The sattvic actor is not passive but combines firmness with detachment - persistently pursuing goals without being shattered by setbacks or inflated by achievements. Dhriti and utsaha - persistence and enthusiasm - are highlighted as essential qualities for any endeavor.

The rajasic doer (verse 27) is driven by passion and greed for results, capable of violence and impurity, and swings between elation and sorrow based on outcomes. This describes most of us in our professional lives - attached to outcomes, devastated by failure, euphoric in success. The symptoms are clear: harsha-shoka-anvita, constantly oscillating between joy and sorrow based on external circumstances. This emotional volatility is the signature of rajasic doership.

Reflect on your own tendencies: When you undertake projects, how do you respond to success and failure? Does achievement make you think "I did this" while failure makes you defensive or depressed? True dhriti (steadfastness) means continuing your efforts regardless of immediate results. True utsaha (enthusiasm) comes from the work itself, not from anticipated rewards. Today, notice one moment when your mood shifts based on results - a compliment lifts you, a criticism deflates you. This is rajasic reactivity. Practice returning to center: "I did what was needed; the result belongs to the field of action, not to me."

snippets.title: Day 223: Types of Action
snippets.sanskrit:
अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकोऽलसः |

बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं शृणु |

प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये |
snippets.transliteration:
ayuktaḥ prākṛtaḥ stabdhaḥ śaṭho naiṣkṛtiko.alasaḥ .

buddherbhedaṃ dhṛteścaiva guṇatastrividhaṃ śṛṇu .

pravṛttiṃ ca nivṛttiṃ ca kāryākārye bhayābhaye .
verseTranslations: While he whose purpose is infirm, who is low-minded, stubborn, dishonest, malicious, indolent, despondent, procrastinating - he may be assumed to be in Darkness.
Reason and conviction are threefold, according to the Quality which is dominant. I will explain them fully and severally, O Arjuna!

That intellect which understands the creation and dissolution of life, what actions should be done and what not, which discriminates between fear and fearlessness, bondage and deliverance, that is Pure.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga. Just to remind ourselves what we have seen so far: in the beginning, Arjuna made a request -- I want to know what is Sannyasa and what is Tyaga? Because we had been talking about renunciation. This chapter is called Liberation through Renunciation. So the obvious answer is renouncing actions.

And how do we renounce actions and what type of actions can we renounce or should we renounce is the gist of this chapter. So the first thing Bhagavan said is Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa Iti Sannyasa -- giving up all the desire-prompted actions is Sannyasa. That's as simple as it is. If I can give up all desire prompted actions so that I'm truly driven by my duties, the joy of working and whatever is appropriate for me to work, then I am a sannyasi. But that may or may not be possible. So the next is Sarvakarma Falat Tyaga Iti Tyaga.

If you give up all the Karma Phala, the desire for the fruits of action, then it's Tyaga. So Bhagavan starts with Tyaga because that may be more appropriate for us. So then he describes that even tyaga can be of three different types. So now the entire chapter takes up the aspect of actions -- which is what is binding us. Actions in our day-to-day life, what we call work, are becoming a burden for us. That's why we all want to retire.

All our planning for is what retirement. That's because we are not enjoying the work. So Bhagawan said let's understand what tyaga is. So then we have seen that the tyaga also can be of three types of you can give up something which is you're appropriately giving up because of sattvic reasons or rajasic reasons or tamasic reasons. Then we said the tyaga we talked about of actions. So what type of actions should be given up and what should not be given up?

We said the yajna dana tapa, this type of actions must be performed. So even the yajnas can be of three types. Sattvik, Rajasika, Tamasik, Dana also can be of three types. SattVik, Rajasik and tamasic. The disciplines which we follow can also be three types. Sattvik, rajasik, tamasik.

In other words, everything is tied to each other. How we think, how we behave and what the results come to us, they're all tied to each other. Our thinking is not sattvic, then obviously our actions will not be sattvic and therefore our results will not be satwik. So if we understand this mechanism of actions, then maybe we will be able to liberate ourselves from this burden of work. In India, at least in the 60s that I can remember, the first thing people would ask is, "So where are you working?" Oh, I just got a job in government.

I think it's a perfect job. I'll tell you, I hardly have to work. The definition of good job in many times in India was the job in which I did the least amount of work is a good job. Now is it really what I'm looking for in a job? I remember when I went to Zambia. I took a job at the building department in the government of Zambia.

So my chief architect, first day in orientation said, we have a requirement that in a year you should at least do three drawings. And I said, are you serious? He said, no, at least you should have three drawings in a year. So that was a government standard of your performance. Our basic understanding right now is that action is a burden. Actually, as long as I can get out of the actions, then I'll be happy.

So renouncing action is the goal of our life. But how to renounce action is the theme of this chapter. So we say even yajna dana tapas, which needs to be done also should be done in a manner that it liberates you and not binds you. So yagnas can be of three types, Dhyana can be of three types, and tapas can be of three types. And we all know sometimes we do charity. But that makes you unhappy.

Instead of making you feel joy about giving, it makes you unhappy. That's because our attitude towards giving had something not right about it. So Bhagavan said, you should examine this thing in all things you do, whether it's sattvik, tamasic or rajasik, and see what is appropriate for you. Then we said, okay, Karma. Now let's understand what is the nature of Karma. And I said: Karma, Karana, Karta.

These are the three constituent parts of any action. Any action will have an action, a doer, and an instrument of action. And that requires knowledge. Gnanam, Gneyam, Parignata -- these are the three constituent parts: the knowledge, that which is to be known, and the knower. If we understand the mechanism of these actions and how the knowledge takes place, then we should be able to work better.

So then we have looked at how the knowledge takes place and how the action is related to it. So then we have been looking at and say, okay, now if knowledge also can be of three types. Some knowledge is Sattvic, some is Rajasic and some is Tamasic. Something I come to believe without any reason or rhyme could be tamasic. So knowledge also can be Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. I should be very careful.

Even I consider myself a more knowledgeable person. I need to examine whether my knowledge is appropriate or Sattvik or Rajasik or Tamasakya. Obviously, before whoever figured it out that earth is round, people had knowledge the earth is flat. But it was not really a knowledge based on any basis, but just a regular observation that looks like earth is flat. So sometimes what is quite obvious may not be the truth. So I need to be constantly vigilant about it.

So my knowledge also should be examined whether it is Rajasik, Tamasik or Sattvik. Then Karma, which I am performing, also can be Rajasic, Tamasic or Sattvik, depending on the knowledge which I have, is whether Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. So these are all tied together in every aspect of my life. I should be examining whether this is the most appropriate way to behave. So then the verses which we'll be saying today they about Karta, Karta. I consider myself the doer.

Now am I a Sattvik doer, a Rajasic doer, a Tamasic doer? Then we find out that it's not a consistent that I am not always a Sattvic doer, I'm not always a Rajasik doer. I'm not always a Tamasik doer. At times I'm Sattvik, at times I'm Rajasik, at times I'm Tamasik. However, I must examine that and make sure that I do not become predominantly Tamasic or Rajasic. Because the results of Tamas and Rajas, as we have seen, are nothing but pain in the end.

The only thing which liberates you is sattva, the pure knowledge. When I start seeing things as they are, that's where the liberation comes in. Anytime I have bias of my own, then I'm bound by my own bias. More and more people realizing that more they limit themselves to one viewpoint or one group of people, they're binding themselves to limitations. The more they open up, they become more liberated and make more progress. So the verse 26 says Mukta Sangha Anahamvadi Dhruti Utsa Samanvitah Siddhi Asidyo nirvikaraha karta satvika uchate.

If I am a doer and I consider myself the person performing this action, well, let's see in what attitude I perform it. Mukta Sangha -- free from attachment. Am I really too attached to this action? If somebody lets me do it, great. If I don't get a chance to do this, am I okay? Or is the world going to come apart if I don't get a chance to do this? Unattached. Anahamvadi -- he does not have the ego that "I am the doer."

I am the only one who can do it. I can do this so that we know that if I can do it, the others can also do it. However, I can put the best efforts if I want. Dhruti Utsa Samanvitah -- I think this, at least from my life, is the most important part. Whether you are successful or not successful in what you are pursuing. Again dhruti persistent firmness.

This is what I want to do. When I came to this country, I kept giving my life's example because that's all I know is my life. When I came to this country, I met some architects who had been here 10 years before I had come. So I asked their advice and said what should I do? I need to get registration as a licensed architect in this country. They forget about it.

It's not really worth it. It will take you 10 years. There are better professions with your architectural training. You can be a pipe draftsman or something which will give you a better compensation. And I say, I'll tell you honestly, the only thing I know is architecture. So I need to pursue architecture.

Whether there are good chances in this country or not. I have to continue find my niche because I don't know anything better. But I say only thing I know is doing architecture. So Dhruti -- if you want to be successful in architecture, stay with architecture. Don't buy a gas station; don't open up a hotel.

Dhruti is the most important aspect of any actions we will perform. If you are yourself not firm about it, people will recognize right away that you are not serious about it. And the next quality, which I learned from my guru Swami Chinmayananda, is Utsaha -- enthusiasm. Swamiji had a unique quality: he would infuse enthusiasm in anybody he met. Everybody in front of him was like Swamiji we can do this and Swamiji we can do that. That's a unique quality that you can inspire people to be enthusiastic about what they are doing.

And again, if you are not enthusiastic, everybody else will be also the same way. The most important aspects of any doer are Dhruti and Utsaha -- Samanvitah Siddhi Asidyo Nirvikaraha. Having done all that, the result is not in my hand. I may be the best person, I may be the best firm. But the world may have different needs and the world may react differently. And therefore it may not be a successful action.

And I should be unattached to that. Do not get affected by it. We are human beings, we have emotions. We may feel slightly bad about it, but you have to move on from that. It should not affect your personality that now I'm rejected one time, I will not try next time. In fact, continue trying to persistently keep going back and back to the same organization or efforts to be successful.

Persistence pays off. Siddhi Asidyo Nirvikarah karta satvikochate. Such an actor, such a doer is considered Sattvik. He may be successful, he may not be successful. He may be appreciated. He may not be appreciated.

But he knows that he's pursuing this with all his zeal and all firmness. So that's such a doer is Sattvik the next one. Ragi Karma Phala prepsuhu lubdaha in Satmakaha Asuchi Harshoka Anvitah karta Rajasah Parikertita. However, when we are in that mode, we don't recognize it. Unfortunately, it's a ragi attached sometimes with a good virtue. He's very passionate about it.

Passion is something which can be very tricky to recognize whether it is positive or negative. The same passion, it is based on your dhruti then it is positive.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 28 completes the portrait of the tamasic doer: ayukta (undisciplined), prakrita (vulgar), stabdha (obstinate), shatha (deceitful), naishkritika (malicious), alasa (lazy), vishadi (despondent), and dirgha-sutri (procrastinating). This is a catalog of self-defeating tendencies that prevent meaningful action. The combination is revealing - laziness paired with obstinacy, deceit with procrastination. These qualities feed on each other, creating a downward spiral that keeps one trapped in inertia and ineffectiveness.

Verses 29-30 shift to buddhi (intellect), the guiding faculty that determines which actions to pursue. Sattvic buddhi knows pravritti (what should be done) and nivritti (what should be avoided), karya (duty) and akarya (non-duty), bhaya (what to fear) and abhaya (what not to fear), bandha (bondage) and moksha (liberation). This discriminative capacity is the cornerstone of wise living. Without clear buddhi, even good intentions lead to confused actions. The sattvic intellect serves as an internal compass, consistently pointing toward what truly matters.

Examine your own buddhi today: How clear is your discrimination between what binds you and what liberates you? We often know intellectually what we should do but find ourselves doing the opposite. This gap indicates the need to strengthen sattvic buddhi through consistent practice. Ask yourself: In the decisions I face today, can I clearly see which choice leads toward freedom and which toward bondage? Make one choice today based purely on this discrimination - not on what feels good or what others expect, but on what your purified intellect recognizes as the path to liberation.

snippets.title: Day 224: Knowledge and Doers
snippets.sanskrit:
यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च |

अधर्मं धर्ममिति या मन्यते तमसावृता |

धृत्या यया धारयते मनःप्राणेन्द्रियक्रियाः |
snippets.transliteration:
yayā dharmamadharmaṃ ca kāryaṃ cākāryameva ca .

adharmaṃ dharmamiti yā manyate tamasāvṛtā .

dhṛtyā yayā dhārayate manaḥprāṇendriyakriyāḥ .
verseTranslations: The intellect which does not understand what is right and what is wrong, and what should be done and what not, is under the sway of Passion.
And that which, shrouded in Ignorance, thinks wrong right, and sees everything perversely, O Arjuna, that intellect is ruled by Darkness.
The conviction and steady concentration by which the mind, the vitality and the senses are controlled - O Arjuna! They are the product of Purity.
snippets.commentary:
We've been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. The goal is liberation and the tool is Sannyasa. Liberation is always from some bondage, and normally we think the bondage is always imposed by someone else. But in this case, Bhagavad Gita says the bondages are imposed by my own self. I myself have imposed these bondages on me by identifying with this material body, this material self -- the equipment which I use to transact with this world. I falsely understood it to be me.

And now all the limitations of this instrument have become my limitations. Sorrows and unhappiness are just the product of these limitations. And therefore, if I need to find ultimate happiness and ultimate liberation from sorrows and unhappiness, I need to get rid of the bondages. So this chapter says this liberation can only come from Sannyasa. The only means available to us is Sannyasa. So then, what is Sannyasa? We learn it is Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa.

All you have to do is simply give up the desire prompted actions. This we found is not easy. So the means again given is Tyaga. Give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions and over a period of time you will develop Sannyasa. Once you give up the anxiety of the fruits of action, work in this world and you will develop that understanding of who you are and you will overcome the limitations that you have. That basically what we understood in the gist of the entire Bhagavad Gita.

So now this chapter summarizing our endeavor, pursuing this path of Tyaga and then ultimately getting Sannyasa, examining all the qualities that we have acquired by just associating with this Prakriti. We have this long history of associating with this Prakriti. All this time the only thing I could associate with is my material nature. Therefore all the qualities of the Prakriti became my qualities. And we have learnt in Vedanta that this Prakriti has three basic Gunas, Satvarajas and Tamas. So everything associated with me is tainted by these three gunas.

My goal is to go beyond these three gunas and liberate myself from this identification of this Prakriti. So therefore, we have examined what makes me attached to this work. And the first thing came the Gnana. The knowledge that the Prakriti exists and I'm aware of it, makes me identify with it. It's like somebody says, why are you climbing this mountain? If I did not know it is there, I would never have any need to climb that mountain.

But because it is there, I have to now climb it. Because I'm aware of the Prakriti, I identify with that recruitment because I'm aware of the world of my liking. I identify with the world which I like. Also I'm aware of the world of my dislike. And again, I identify with that world for avoiding it. So my entire pursuit in life becomes pursuing that which I like and avoid that which I don't like.

In all cases, what is common is my knowledge about that field of activity. The first thing you need to say, what is the Gnana? The Gnana, what you consider Gnana at this time is of the Prakriti. Therefore it falls into these three categories of Sattvik, Rajasic and Tamasic. Just as the nature of the Prakruti has these three gunas, so we've seen the knowledge is also Sattvic, Rajasik and Tamasic. Then he said, now the next person involved in this action is the Karta.

One who considers that I exist and I do things. He said, that person again is tainted by the three gunas of the Prakriti because of the identification of the Prakriti. So the Karta can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. Now you put the two together. Knowledge and I as the doer both have tendencies which are Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic.

The final product which comes out -- actions -- will also be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. All these we are evaluating and understanding so that we can introspect and see where we fall in this category, where our actions fall. Because one thing we have learned is that the gradual progression is from Tamasic to Rajasic to Sattvic. Once I have purified my mind and intellect, the only obligation I have as the seeker of the truth is to purify my internal instrument, Antakarana, my mind and intellect. Once mind and intellect is pure, the knowledge will shine through by itself, there will be no effort required. Therefore, we keep hearing the term praptasyaprapti.

This knowledge which I'm seeking about myself is already available to me. It's already with me. I'm just not seeing it because I'm so engrossed in the knowledge of this world that I'm completely oblivious about the knowledge about myself. Once I get rid of this knowledge which is falsely coloring my personality as Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic, the true knowledge will shine through. To know this and to negate the qualities which are binding, gradually rise from Tamasic to Rajasic to Sattvic. Once I reach that sattvic tendencies and my mind and intellect are purified, the knowledge will shine through.

If this room is dark, my key is in this room. Only thing I require is turn the lights on. It will be very easy for me to find where my keys are. So Bhagawan said that this knowledge is within yourself. You already have it and therefore nothing new you will find. There is no new accomplishments to be made.

There is no new achievements to be achieved. But finding your own self would be like finding the keys in your pocket and becoming aware of it. Therefore, the word is realization. All I am doing is becoming realized about my own self. So if you examine Gnana Karta, Karma, then Bhagwancha Buddhi, which is a guiding factor. I see the objects or the field of actions in this world, then knowledge takes place.

Mind decide whether it is like or unlikable. Finding guidance from the intellect, then intellect will tell you how to act in this world. So therefore Buddhi is to be evaluated as whether it is Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. So we have looked at the Buddhi also. Now all of that is only useful if I'm consistently pursuing my path of evolution from Tamasic to Rajasic to Sattvik. Because anything if I do once in a while is of not great value.

Something which I do consistently, then it will have positive effect for me to become an expert in anything, I have to continuously work in that field. Once in a while I do something, it becomes hobby. That's why I'm not so good. But somebody who does it consistently, he becomes good at it. So Bhagavan said Dhruti is a very important factor in becoming successful and getting rid of unhappiness and sorrows -- the limitations of this body and intellect, the bondages. To get rid of them and to work consistently -- that consistency is what we have seen as Dhruti. And Dhruti can also be classified into three types.

Each one of us who is seeking happiness is consistently trying to be happy. See, it's not that nobody will be blamed for not trying to be happy. So if you ask anybody in this world, no matter what his position is, what his caste is, what his creed is, what's the goal of your life? Have you ever tried to be happy? And the answer is, of course I'm trying. Every day, every minute of my life, I'm trying to be happy.

I'm very consistent in finding my happiness. But how many of us are successful? The statistics are not so good. The Bhagawan says, that's because this dhruti with which you're finding your happiness also comes in three varieties. Drutya, Yaya, Dharayate Manah, Prana, Indriya, Kriya Yogena or Vyabicharynya Dhruti Sapartha Satviki. Swamiji says, and many commentators believe that Dhruti is very loosely translated in English language.

Because the essence of the word Dhruti cannot be translated without understanding it. Dhruti is fortitude -- in other words, grit, an inner strength, a force from my inner personality which will not let me give up. The things which I consider are important to me. I'm trying to achieve something. We know this world will throw some obstacles in my path. It will all dependent on how strong I am in pursuing my goal.

When I encounter great difficulties, I'll evaluate my situation. My Buddhi will say, I don't think it's worth it. We will weigh the pros and cons of this situation and say, what are my risk and reward here? Depending on what I come up with, I say, well, it's not worth pursuing it. Or I'll say, well, risk is not that great. Reward may be great, let's pursue it.

Prabhagawan said, that's Buddhi. Beyond this Buddhi, there is an inner strength which no matter what the circumstances are, will make me pursue my path. Bhagawan says that dhruti. He said that dhruti also can be of three types. The first one is Dhruti, which by the power of yoga will control my manah, Pranaha and Indriyaha. That inner force which by the power of yoga.

Because I had been pursuing this path and I have seen the glimpse of my own self, I know that all the things which I associate with this Prakriti is temporary. And therefore it will allow me to control my mind, my vital functions and my senses. We know how the world of actions works. Senses go out and get the information about the objects in this world. Mind decides whether it wants to pursue it or not. Intellect will guide the mind whether it is worth performing that action or not.

My tendency will override whatever my Buddhi will tell me to do. The Bhagavan says that force from my inner self which will let me control my mind. I control the mind, I control my senses. It also control my intellect. So Bhagavan said that Dhrutti which allows me to control my mind, vital functions and senses is Satvik Dhruti. I'm firmly established in what is the truth.

And therefore it is allowing me to pursue my path to stay connected with my truth is the Satvik Dhruti. Next one is Yayatu Dharma Kama, Artha Dharayate, Arjunah, Prasangayana, Falakangsi, Dhruti, Sapaarta Rajasi. This one we can relate to very easily. The Bhagavanta Dhrutti which is allowing me to pursue my Dharma, Artha and Kama by Prasangena by attachment. Attachment to my Dharma, attachment to my Kama and attachment of Artha Falakaan. Because I want to get something out of it.

I am pursuing my Dharma as whatever you put it, as an architect, as a father. Because I want results out of that. So I'm firmly pursuing my path of being an architect. I want to continue practicing it. Why I want something out of it. I'm attached to my Dharma.

Most people, if you take their profession away from them, they feel completely lost. They don't know who they are. But once it went, I am pursuing my path of Dharma Orthayanaka. The four goals of life we have learned in our scriptures, Dharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha. The waiting vow is also. There are four steps you take will do things which is in line with my Dharma.

Whatever my Swadharma, whatever is my duties, I'll follow them. I will only be able to sustain my Dharma if I have enough wealth. Narayana also sustained this world by the power of Lakshmi. Take the Lakshmi away from Narayana. Narayana cannot sustain this world. So if I want Artha -- acquiring wealth -- and Kama -- I want to fulfill my desires.

These three I'm consistently pursuing my life driven by Prasanga and Falakangshi. Because I'm attached to this three. And I want to get results out of them. And Swamiji says the Bhagavan leaves out moksha because typically we are not really interested in moksha simply because I think the happiness will be in pursuing these three.
snippets.reflection:
These verses complete the classification of buddhi and introduce dhriti (fortitude). Rajasic buddhi imperfectly understands dharma and adharma, what should be done and avoided (verse 31) - it has some discrimination but inconsistently applied. Tamasic buddhi, shrouded in darkness, mistakes adharma for dharma and sees everything in reverse (verse 32). This is perhaps the most dangerous state - not ignorance that knows itself as ignorance, but ignorance that believes itself to be knowledge. When wrong seems right and right seems wrong, one is deeply lost.

Verse 33 introduces sattvic dhriti - the unwavering steadfastness that maintains control over mind, prana, and senses through yoga. Dhriti is more than willpower; it is the inner force that keeps one on the path despite obstacles. Swamiji emphasizes that dhriti cannot be adequately translated - it combines fortitude, grit, persistence, and inner strength. This quality enables one to continue when the intellect calculates that the effort is not worth it. Beyond rational assessment lies dhriti, which says "this is my path, and I will walk it."

Reflect on your own dhriti: When obstacles arise, what keeps you going? Is it stubbornness (tamasic), desire for results (rajasic), or genuine commitment to the path regardless of outcomes (sattvic)? Today, identify one area where your resolve has weakened. Rather than forcing yourself through willpower alone, connect with the deeper "why" - the yoga that naturally sustains effort. Sattvic dhriti does not come from gritting your teeth but from being established in truth. When your path aligns with your deepest nature, persistence becomes effortless.

And that which clings perversely to false idealism, fear, grief, despair and vanity is the product of Ignorance.
Hear further the three kinds of pleasure. That which increases day after day delivers one from misery,

So this chapter says this liberation can only come from Sannyasa. That is the only means available to us is Sannyasa. So then what is Sannyasa we learn is Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa.

All you have to do is simply give up the desire prompted actions. This we found is not easy. So the means again given is Tyaga. Give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions and over a period of time you will develop Sannyasa. Once you give up the anxiety of the fruits of action, work in this world and you will develop that understanding of who you are and you will overcome the limitations that you have. That basically what we understood in the gist of the entire Bhagavad Gita.

So now this chapter summarizing our endeavor, pursuing this path of Tyaga and then ultimately getting Sannyasa, examining all the qualities that we have acquired by just associating with this Prakriti. We have this long history of associating with this Prakriti. All this time the only thing I could associate with is my material nature. Therefore all the qualities of the Prakriti became my qualities. And we have learnt in Vedanta that this Prakriti has three basic Gunas, Satvarajas and Tamas. So everything associated with me is tainted by these three gunas.

My goal is to go beyond these three gunas and liberate myself from this identification of this Prakriti. So therefore, we have examined what makes me attached to this work. And the first thing came the Gnana. The knowledge that the Prakriti exists and I'm aware of it, makes me identify with it. It's like somebody says, why are you climbing this mountain? If I did not know it is there, I would never have any need to climb that mountain.

But because it is there, I have to now climb it. Because I'm aware of the Prakriti, I identify with that recruitment because I'm aware of the world of my liking. I identify with the world which I like. Also I'm aware of the world of my dislike. And again, I identify with that world for avoiding it. So my entire pursuit in life becomes pursuing that which I like and avoid that which I don't like.

In all cases, what is common is my knowledge about that field of activity. The first thing you need to say, what is the Gnana? The Gnana, what you consider Gnana at this time is of the Prakriti. Therefore it falls into these three categories of Sattvik, Rajasic and Tamasic. Just as the nature of the Prakruti has these three gunas, so we've seen the knowledge is also Sattvic, Rajasik and Tamasic. Then he said, now the next person involved in this action is the Karta.

One who considers that I exist and I do things. He said, that person again is tainted by the three gunas of the Prakriti because of the identification of the Prakriti. So the Karta can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. Now you put the two together. Knowledge and I as the doer both have tendencies which are Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic.

The final product which comes out -- actions -- will also be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. All these we are evaluating and understanding so that we can introspect and see where we fall in this category, where our actions fall. Because one thing we have learned is that the gradual progression is from Tamasic to Rajasic to Sattvic. Once I have purified my mind and intellect, the only obligation I have as the seeker of the truth is to purify my internal instrument, Antakarana, my mind and intellect. Once mind and intellect is pure, the knowledge will shine through by itself, there will be no effort required. Therefore, we keep hearing the term praptasyaprapti.

This knowledge which I'm seeking about myself is already available to me. It's already with me. I'm just not seeing it because I'm so engrossed in the knowledge of this world that I'm completely oblivious about the knowledge about myself. Once I get rid of this knowledge which is falsely coloring my personality as Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic, the true knowledge will shine through. To know this and to negate the qualities which are binding, gradually rise from Tamasic to Rajasic to Sattvic. Once I reach that sattvic tendencies and my mind and intellect are purified, the knowledge will shine through.

If this room is dark, my key is in this room. Only thing I require is turn the lights on. It will be very easy for me to find where my keys are. So Bhagawan said that this knowledge is within yourself. You already have it and therefore nothing new you will find. There is no new accomplishments to be made.

There is no new achievements to be achieved. But finding your own self would be like finding the keys in your pocket and becoming aware of it. Therefore, the word is realization. All I am doing is becoming realized about my own self. So if you examine Gnana Karta, Karma, then Bhagwancha Buddhi, which is a guiding factor. I see the objects or the field of actions in this world, then knowledge takes place.

Mind decide whether it is like or unlikable. Finding guidance from the intellect, then intellect will tell you how to act in this world. So therefore Buddhi is to be evaluated as whether it is Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. So we have looked at the Buddhi also. Now all of that is only useful if I'm consistently pursuing my path of evolution from Tamasic to Rajasic to Sattvik. Because anything if I do once in a while is of not great value.

Something which I do consistently, then it will have positive effect for me to become an expert in anything, I have to continuously work in that field. Once in a while I do something, it becomes hobby. That's why I'm not so good. But somebody who does it consistently, he becomes good at it. So Bhagavan said Dhruti is a very important factor in becoming successful and getting rid of unhappiness and sorrows -- the limitations of this body and intellect, the bondages. To get rid of them and to work consistently -- that consistency is what we have seen as Dhruti. And Dhruti can also be classified into three types.

Each one of us who is seeking happiness is consistently trying to be happy. See, it's not that nobody will be blamed for not trying to be happy. So if you ask anybody in this world, no matter what his position is, what his caste is, what his creed is, what's the goal of your life? Have you ever tried to be happy? And the answer is, of course I'm trying. Every day, every minute of my life, I'm trying to be happy.

I'm very consistent in finding my happiness. But how many of us are successful? The statistics are not so good. The Bhagawan says, that's because this dhruti with which you're finding your happiness also comes in three varieties. Drutya, Yaya, Dharayate Manah, Prana, Indriya, Kriya Yogena or Vyabicharynya Dhruti Sapartha Satviki. Swamiji says, and many commentators believe that Dhruti is very loosely translated in English language.

Because the essence of the word Dhruti cannot be translated without understanding it. Dhruti is fortitude -- in other words, grit, an inner strength, a force from my inner personality which will not let me give up. The things which I consider are important to me. I'm trying to achieve something. We know this world will throw some obstacles in my path. It will all dependent on how strong I am in pursuing my goal.

When I encounter great difficulties, I'll evaluate my situation. My Buddhi will say, I don't think it's worth it. We will weigh the pros and cons of this situation and say, what are my risk and reward here? Depending on what I come up with, I say, well, it's not worth pursuing it. Or I'll say, well, risk is not that great. Reward may be great, let's pursue it.

Prabhagawan said, that's Buddhi. Beyond this Buddhi, there is an inner strength which no matter what the circumstances are, will make me pursue my path. Bhagawan says that dhruti. He said that dhruti also can be of three types. The first one is Dhruti, which by the power of yoga will control my manah, Pranaha and Indriyaha. That inner force which by the power of yoga.

Because I had been pursuing this path and I have seen the glimpse of my own self, I know that all the things which I associate with this Prakriti is temporary. And therefore it will allow me to control my mind, my vital functions and my senses. We know how the world of actions works. Senses go out and get the information about the objects in this world. Mind decides whether it wants to pursue it or not. Intellect will guide the mind whether it is worth performing that action or not.

My tendency will override whatever my Buddhi will tell me to do. The Bhagavan says that force from my inner self which will let me control my mind. I control the mind, I control my senses. It also control my intellect. So Bhagavan said that Dhrutti which allows me to control my mind, vital functions and senses is Satvik Dhruti. I'm firmly established in what is the truth.

And therefore it is allowing me to pursue my path to stay connected with my truth is the Satvik Dhruti. Next one is Yayatu Dharma Kama, Artha Dharayate, Arjunah, Prasangayana, Falakangsi, Dhruti, Sapaarta Rajasi. This one we can relate to very easily. The Bhagavanta Dhrutti which is allowing me to pursue my Dharma, Artha and Kama by Prasangena by attachment. Attachment to my Dharma, attachment to my Kama and attachment of Artha Falakaan. Because I want to get something out of it.

I am pursuing my Dharma as whatever you put it, as an architect, as a father. Because I want results out of that. So I'm firmly pursuing my path of being an architect. I want to continue practicing it. Why I want something out of it. I'm attached to my Dharma.

Most people, if you take their profession away from them, they feel completely lost. They don't know who they are. But once it went, I am pursuing my path of Dharma Orthayanaka. The four goals of life we have learned in our scriptures, Dharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha. The waiting vow is also. There are four steps you take will do things which is in line with my Dharma.

Whatever my Swadharma, whatever is my duties, I'll follow them. I will only be able to sustain my Dharma if I have enough wealth. Narayana also sustained this world by the power of Lakshmi. Take the Lakshmi away from Narayana. Narayana cannot sustain this world. So if I want Artha -- acquiring wealth -- and Kama -- I want to fulfill my desires.

These three I'm consistently pursuing my life driven by Prasanga and Falakangshi. Because I'm attached to this three. And I want to get results out of them. And Swamiji says the Bhagavan leaves out moksha because typically we are not really interested in moksha simply because I think the happiness will be in pursuing these three.
snippets.reflection:
Rajasic dhriti (verse 34) persistently pursues dharma, kama, and artha - duty, desire, and wealth - but prasangena and phalakankshi, with attachment and craving for results. This describes most dedicated professionals: persistent and hardworking, but bound by attachment to outcomes. Swamiji notes that Bhagavan leaves moksha out of the rajasic list because we typically are not interested in liberation - we believe happiness lies in successfully pursuing duty, desire, and wealth. Tamasic dhriti (verse 35) clings to sleep, fear, grief, depression, and pride - a stubbornness that perpetuates suffering rather than overcoming it.

Verse 36 introduces the final element: sukha (happiness/pleasure), which also comes in three types. Krishna promises that with proper practice (abhyasa), one can find happiness that ends all suffering (duhkhantam). This is crucial - the Gita does not dismiss our pursuit of happiness but redirects it. Every being seeks happiness; the question is what kind and through what means. Understanding the threefold nature of happiness helps us choose wisely.

Examine your persistence today: What keeps you going in your work and relationships? Is it attachment to results (rajasic) or something deeper? When you pursue Dharma, is it from genuine understanding or from social pressure? When you seek wealth, is it from need or greed? The rajasic person is not wrong to pursue these goals but remains bound by attachment. Today, practice holding your goals more lightly. Continue your efforts with full commitment, but experiment with releasing the grip on specific outcomes. Notice whether this loosening actually improves or diminishes your effectiveness.

snippets.title: Day 226: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
यत्तदग्रे विषमिव परिणामेऽमृतोपमम् |

विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगाद्यत्तदग्रेऽमृतोपमम् |

यदग्रे चानुबन्धे च सुखं मोहनमात्मनः |
snippets.transliteration:
yattadagre viṣamiva pariṇāme.amṛtopamam .

viṣayendriyasaṃyogādyattadagre.amṛtopamam .

yadagre cānubandhe ca sukhaṃ mohanamātmanaḥ .
verseTranslations: Which at first seems like poison but afterwards acts like nectar - that pleasure is Pure, for it is born of Wisdom.
That which as first is like nectar, because the senses revel in their objects, but in the end acts like poison - that pleasure arises from Passion.
While the pleasure which from first to last merely drugs the senses, which springs from indolence, lethargy and folly - that pleasure flows from Ignorance.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. We had been discussing all throughout the chapter that this renunciation is about the sense of doership. Right now I have this sense of doership which makes me a doer. Therefore I am bound by my own actions. But once you renounce that doership in knowledge that my true self is not the doer and therefore it's all related to the actions which I perform in this life. So we have seen the entire chapter discussing the quality of actions and how the actions are performed.

It also says that if I'm not attached to my actions, if I do not have ego and my Buddhi is not tainted, then even if I kill, I do not kill and I'm not bound by my actions.
