So the bondage is because of my doership in all the actions that I perform. So therefore we have seen the physiology of action and the three things are important. Knowledge of the field actor and then the act of acting which is action itself. These three we have discussed in detail that they are affected by the qualities of the Prakriti. Prakriti we normally translate in English as nature.

So you can apply that. What is the nature of my knowledge, nature of my actions and nature of my own self will affect the outcome of this actions. And we have seen because they are part of the Prakriti, they are affected by the Sattva Rajasav Thomas. So the knowledge can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. The Karta can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. Therefore the actions will be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic.

And then we have seen that this is driven by the Buddhi and Dhruti. What kind of actions I will perform is dependent on my Buddhi. So I have a Sattvic Buddhi. I will be performing Sattvic actions because Buddhi is the guiding factor. Buddhi as we have seen is the Reservoir of all my experiences in memory that creates my tendencies. The Buddhi will finally decide whether it's to be done or not to be done based on what I have considered it to be.

My duties, my past experiences, the outcomes which I had in the past -- the Buddhi, depending on my past experiences and their outcomes, can be Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic. No action can be successful unless there is dhruti, fortitude, persistent efforts. So what kind of a Dhruti I have will also be affecting my outcome of my actions. So we have seen that dhruti, the fortitude or grit can also be of three types. Even the person who is trying to rob a bank, he also need the fortitude.

You know, he may fail. One time he goes there first time he figures out that this is not the right time. He goes back again and again till he finds the right time to rob the bank. So this Dhruti also can be of a Rajasik, Satvik or Tamasic. We have seen that these five are connected -- three causes of actions and two supporters: the Buddhi and Dhruti, which make the action possible.

They all can be Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasic. Now you can see the permutation combinations of all this. There are myriads of variations of actions that we see in this world. But the reason we all act is one and the same. We all want happiness. So this Sukha which comes out of these actions can also be of three types.

Now Sukha can be translated in English as "comfortable" -- I'm comfortable, I'm a Sukhi. I'm a Dukhi -- unhappy or not comfortable. So Sukha is either comfort or joy or happiness. Any of these words can be associated with the word Sukha. In Sanskrit there are two words: Sukha and Ananda. What is the difference between Sukha and Ananda is what we obviously were trying to figure out. But in this case it says Sukha is the goal for all my actions.

Because Sukha I associate with happiness. Comfort I associate with happiness. The word Sukha originated from the word for the space for the axle in a chariot. "Su" means good, "kha" means space. Sukham -- good space for the axle of the chariot. Duhkham -- not so good space. In other words, if the hole in that chariot wheel is perfectly round, it is Sukham.

If it is not perfectly round, it is Duhkham. The ride will be comfortable if the axle is perfectly balanced in its space and there is no room for it to wobble. Then your ride will be comfortable. So that comfortable ride is associated with Sukham. Duhkham will be a not very comfortable ride because the space for the axle is not perfect.

So this sukhum is associated with comfort that I experience in life. So the comfort actually relates to the outside environment. If temperature is right in this room, it is comfortable. Temperature is too high or too low, somebody will start complaining. So it relates to the outside condition. My happiness or my comfort is dependent on the outside environment.

That Sukham is generally associated with your outside conditions. I was watching one of these interviews with Bill Gates and somebody asked him, "Do you relate your wealth with happiness?" And he said, "Yes, I think wealth does give happiness. I don't have to worry about health care costs or anything like that." He right away related that to other people's problems, because their conditions are not as comfortable as his.

It is because of his wealth that he didn't have to worry about the normal things people have to worry about. So Sukha is typically about the outside condition. Joy or Ananda is the state of mind. Happiness is a state of mind. It can exist in a Sukhi or Dukhi condition. The outside condition may not be comfortable, but I may still be happy.

Sukha and Duhkha, when they relate to the body, mind, and intellect, are obviously related to the outcome of my efforts. So this verse defines three types of Sukha which are the results of my actions. Sukha also can be of three types. I'm acting in this world so that my life is comfortable and I achieve happiness. Why do you want to be comfortable?

Because I want to be happy. In the end it's all about happiness. We know happiness is a state of mind. Somehow if my mind feels that it's the perfect condition then it will be happy. Till that time it will keep complaining. I may have the best car, but that's not the car I wanted.

I wanted something else. Well, I'm not really happy. Sukham Tvidanim Trividham Shrunu Me Bharatarshabha. Listen, Sukha can be of three types. Sukha is also not common to all. Our standard example is smoking.

That which gives Sukha to one person, gives the guy sitting next to him discomfort. So Sukha is also personal, depending on my tendencies and my likings and my dislikings. Abhyasad Ramate Yatra Duhkhantam Cha Nigacchati. But if you practice properly, this Sukha can lead to the end of Duhkha. If you figure out what is the cause of your Duhkha and work towards it, Sukha leads to the end of Duhkha. That's all this verse says. The verse says there are three types of Sukha.

And if you're intelligent enough to find out what is the cause of your Duhkha, then you can end that Duhkha. But my problem is something else, and I'm working on something else. It's like having a stomach ache but hitting my head. If the cause of my Duhkha is something else but I keep trying to fix other things, it will not help.

Therefore he said Abhyasat Ramate Yatra Duhkhantam Cha Nigacchati. With constant practice of figuring out what Duhkha is and how to avoid it, Bhagavan Buddha finally figured out what the cause of all these Duhkhas in this world is. He said, well, no matter what the situation, everybody's unhappy -- somebody's sick, somebody's old, somebody's poor. And he finally found one universal cause for all Duhkha. He said desire is the cause for all Duhkha. If you get rid of desire, all Duhkha will go away.

So Bhagavan said, you should understand the nature of Sukha also. Just because it is comfortable, it will not give you happiness. Yat Agre Visham Eva Pariname Amritopamam Tatsukham Sattvikam Proktam Atma Buddhi Prasadajam. Every word is important here to understand. So it says that Sattvic Sukha is that which is compared to poison (Visham) in the beginning -- so difficult, like climbing Mount Everest. I don't know why people do it.

I have never figured it out. Something which you consider Sukha, and if you want to achieve that, you have to go through hell. The road to heaven passes through hell. Bhagavan said that which is in the beginning like poison but in the end like nectar -- that is Sattvic Sukha.

But where does it come from? It says Atma Buddhi Prasadajam. It comes as a Prasad from your Buddhi which is established in yourself. One who has realized his own true nature -- that Buddhi will give you a Prasad. As we use the word Prasad in our day-to-day language, when you go to the temple and do puja, at the end there is a Prasad. Now this Prasad is not really guaranteed by my efforts.

Because it's up to the pujari -- whatever the Prasad, whether I get a banana or a mango. Meena said that her eye was on the mango. But then the pujari asked the first person, "Whatever fruit you want, take one from here." That person took the mango. If you are given a choice, it's not really Prasad. Prasad is to be given.

Swamiji used to say, you go to the temple and just accept the Prasad. Prasad is to be given, never taken. Prasad is something which is not in my control. It comes as a result of my efforts automatically. So that Prasad of integrating my Buddhi with the truth -- what comes out of it is the Prasad of that integration.

So the Buddhi which is established in the self, which gives you Prasad in the form of Sukha and bliss -- Bhagavan says that's Sattvic Sukha. But to get to that point was like poison. All the efforts that you put in to figure out what your true self is, going through all the experiences in life. When Buddha went through all these experiences in his life, he went from one teacher to another. He left his kingdom, left his wife, left his child, meditated for years. Finally, under the Bodhi tree, he realized what the real nature of the truth is.

Then he achieved the bliss. Bhagavan said that the Sukha which is obtained after vigorous efforts gives the most satisfaction. Because if you earned your Sukha, then that will give you the most happiness. If you have come to that final point of integrating your mind and intellect so that they recognize yourself, that Sukha will be permanent. And therefore it is Sattvic. In contrast to that: Vishayendriya Samyogat Yat Tad Agre Amritopamam, Pariname Visham Iva Tat Sukham Rajasam Smritam.

But that which is very pleasant in the beginning, because it is born out of contact of sense organs with the sense objects -- nice silky clothes, a nice bed -- those things give you happiness because of the contact of the sense organs with the sense objects, which feels like nectar in the beginning.
snippets.reflection:
These verses present the profound teaching on the three types of happiness. Sattvic sukha (verse 37) is like poison in the beginning but nectar in the end - it arises from atma-buddhi-prasada, the clarity and grace of an intellect established in the Self. The metaphor is perfect: spiritual discipline, study, and self-inquiry can feel arduous initially, but they lead to lasting fulfillment. Rajasic sukha (verse 38) is the opposite - like nectar at first when senses contact sense objects, but poison in the end. This describes most worldly pleasures: immediately gratifying but ultimately depleting.

The word sukha itself is revealing - it originally meant "good space" for the chariot axle, creating a smooth, comfortable ride. Duhkha is "bad space" - a rough, uncomfortable journey. Sukha relates to external conditions, while ananda (bliss) is an inner state independent of circumstances. We constantly confuse the two, seeking lasting happiness through adjusting external conditions rather than establishing inner stability.

Today, observe your pursuit of happiness: Are you seeking sattvic sukha that builds over time, or rajasic sukha that provides immediate gratification but leaves you emptier than before? Notice one pleasure you regularly pursue and honestly assess its trajectory - does it lead to greater peace or greater craving? Challenge yourself to choose one sattvic practice that feels difficult now - meditation, study, discipline - and commit to it not for immediate pleasure but trusting that it becomes like nectar over time. The teaching promises that what seems like poison initially transforms into lasting fulfillment.

snippets.title: Day 227: Types of Action
snippets.sanskrit:
न तदस्ति पृथिव्यां वा दिवि देवेषु वा पुनः |

ब्राह्मणक्षत्रियविशां शूद्राणां च परन्तप |

शमो दमस्तपः शौचं क्षान्तिरार्जवमेव च |
snippets.transliteration:
na tadasti pṛthivyāṃ vā divi deveṣu vā punaḥ .

brāhmaṇakṣatriyaviśāṃ śūdrāṇāṃ ca parantapa .

śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca .
verseTranslations: There is nothing anywhere on earth or in the higher worlds which is free from the three Qualities - for they are born of Nature.
O Arjuna! The duties of spiritual teachers, the soldiers, the traders and the servants have all been fixed according to the dominant Quality in their nature.
Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, as well as uprightness, knowledge, wisdom and faith in God - these constitute the duty of a spiritual Teacher.
snippets.commentary:
Chapter 18, Moksha Sanyasa Yoga. This is obviously the last chapter in our studies of Bhagavad Gita. So we had been systematically studying Bhagavad Gita. The goal of that is to figure out how I should act in this world so that I can get the maximum happiness. So we have first understood who we are in the Bhagavad Gita as individuals, how we function in this world. And then we have also talked about who is that?

Who has the control over this entire universe and therefore also over my life. We are coming to the end portion of the Bhagavad Gita. We are synthesizing this knowledge about who we are at the individual level. What is my relationship with this world and the Supreme Being? But the bottom line still remains, how can I be happy? So in this chapter we are analyzing the factors affecting my actions and the outcome of my actions.

So in the beginning, Arjun asked what is sannyas and what is thyaga? Because in all this discussion I picked up these two words which ultimately lead to happiness, ultimately leads you to liberation, freedom from all the sorrows and unhappiness. So I want to understand these two concepts so I can find out how I can act in this world. Number one, very simply said, giving up all desire prompted actions is Sanyas. If you can reach a point where you don't have to do anything to satisfy your desires, then you are a sannyasi. That can only happen when I have exhausted all the desire.

There is no desire left. Therefore I don't have to act for my desires. That can only happen if I have no ego and no individual identification. Sarva Karma Falatyagama stagger. That seems like the goal one can strive for that I can probably work on Tyaga part. But because the Tyaga can be misunderstood, giving up, abandoning something can be misunderstood.

We went into discussion about this. Tyaga also can be of three types. This Prakriti has three qualities, so anything associated with the Prakriti will have the same Triguna. We used the example before that every gold ornament will have the same ingredient of gold. Gold ornaments also come in different carats -- 18 carat versus 16 carat, 12 carat, 24 carat.

What that means is something else is mixed into the gold. You cannot make an ornament out of pure gold; they have to add zinc. The proportion of that metal can change, but every gold ornament will have both gold and zinc, which makes it more malleable, more workable. It is the proportion which makes it 12 carat vs 18 carat vs 24 carat. Prakriti is also like that.

The first thing that comes to mind is I should give up all my actions. So we reaffirmed that action cannot be given up by anybody. It is not possible for a living being to completely abandon all actions. Therefore, now we need to understand what actions are to be abandoned. In the beginning, Bhagawan gave an indication -- desire prompted actions. So what actions should I perform?

Yajna Dana Tapa should not be given up at any cost. The actions which are purifying your mind and intellect, they should be performed. And then we talked about the anatomy of action, because we are going to be focused on actions all our life. We are going to be focusing on how I should act in the right manner and what actions are to be abandoned. We looked at three propellers of actions.

The knowledge, Gnanam, Gnem, Parignatha -- the knowledge, the knower, and the knowable. We also looked at Karanam, Karma, Karta, iti, Trivedha, Karma, Sangraha. Action only comes into existence if these three are there: the instrument of action, the doer, and the action itself. Then we analyzed that Gnana, Karma, and Karta also can be of three types.

Anything which is part of the Prakriti will have the same three ingredients in different proportions. Gnana, Karma, and Karta also come in three types. We also discussed Buddhi and Dhruti -- the foundation of any action, my intellect and my fortitude. These basically make any action possible, or rather, success in any action possible. Even those two can come in three different varieties.

And in the end our goal was to get Sukham, happiness or Ananda. See this Sukha also can be three types. Sattvik, Sukha, which is at the beginning seems like a poison. But in the end it is like a nectar. Work hard to get somewhere. But when you get there, there is joy there.

So that's a Sattvik sukha. It seems good in the beginning, but in the end it gives pain. That's Rajasik sukha. So the pleasures in life which we pursue, they are like Rajasik sukha. It gives you some joy, but in the end it gives you unhappiness. Even going on vacation -- every time you come back, you say, "I'm tired, I can't do anything."

I need a vacation from my vacation, you know. So every pleasure which we seek in the end it ends them into some kind of a misery. So the Bhagawan says, that's Rajasik sukha. It starts as very pleasant, ends in unpleasantness. And Tamasik sukha? It is not enjoyable in the beginning, and also not enjoyable in the end.

Scratching, for example -- when we start, it's not really that pleasant. And after you are done with it, it is also very painful. This is why Bhagavan said that's Tamasik sukha. And then we are coming to the segment where Bhagavan said, therefore now understand that everything in this Prakriti is made up of these three gunas. So human beings are also affected by these three gunas. These three gunas affect all the people we come across and ourselves.

And based on those gunas, they can be also classified into Sattvik, Rajasic and Tamasic. But we may get confused. The Bhagawan makes it clear that it is not possible for anything or any being in this Prakriti to be without these three gunas. All three gunas have to be present for a thing or being to exist in space and time. For something to exist in space and time, it has to have inertia. Without inertia, the thing simply cannot persist -- otherwise it vanishes the moment it's created.

Somebody gave an example -- I think it was Swamiji who gave a story of Brahmaji when he first created human beings. They were all completely Sattvik. As soon as Brahmaji created them, they all went back to their true nature. Brahmaji was really baffled.

How can I keep this thing stable? The inertia tamas makes things remain in this time and space. But the thing also cannot remain what it is. And it rajast with activities. We now know from science that even atom which seems stable has intense activity in it. All electrons are circling around that neutral proton.

And the thing needs to know that it exists, which is Sattva. So Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas -- I exist, I act, and I remain in my place. These three are absolutely necessary for anything or any being to be in existence. So the verses which we are coming to now clarify: Na tad asthi prithivyam va divi deveshu va punah Sattvam prakritei muktaha yat yabhi sha tribhirgunaihi -- on this earth and also in the heavens among Devas, there is not a single being who is free from all these three gunas. Thinking of yourself without these three gunas is not possible. But at the same time, we keep hearing Bhagavan say Guna teet Bhava Arjuna.

We probably understood that I should go beyond this guna, so I should get rid of all three gunas. Bhagawan said that is not possible. You can stop identifying with this Guna. So my mind is working in Tamasic mode or Rajasic mode. I should be able to introspect and say it's my mind which is a rajasic mode. If I can make him go to Sattvic mode, it will be more comfortable.

But if I identify with my mind, am I obviously identifying with my mind and intellect? So you can be Gunateet only if you are not identifying with your limited self. Bhagavan said, be clear that these three gunas are present in all beings -- divine beings and also the mortals on this planet. They all are affected by these three gunas. And therefore all humanity and all beings can be classified into Sattvik, Rajasik, and Tamasik depending on their predominant qualities. Brahman, Kshatriya, Vishyam, Shudranamcha, Parantpa, Karmani, Pravibakthani, Swabhava, Prabhavai Gunai.

This is basically a clarification for all of us who have this confusion about what is this caste system. Bhagavan created Brahman, Vishyanshudra and therefore now you are bound by this divisions. It clearly says that Karmani, Pravibakthani, Swabhava, Prabhavai Gunaihe. Their duties are divided among this Brahmakshatriya, Vaishna Sudra for their own nature, Prabhavayi Gunai hi. According to their own nature, their duties are determined for Brahma, Vaishya, Kshudra and Kshatriya. So it is your own nature which makes you Brahman or Kshatri or Shudra or Vaishya.

Bhagavan makes it clear here: it is not by birth, not by association, not by caste, creed, or color, but by the texture of your mind and intellect. Your gunas will make you the Brahma, Kshatriya, Vishya, or Sudra. Shamah, Damah, Tapaha, Shaucham, Kshantihi, Arjamam, Evacha, Gnanam, Vignanam, Astikyam, Brahma Karma, Swabhavajam. First he said their duties in life are attributed to them according to their own nature. You have to give a person work or his place in your company, in your society and community based on what his aptitude is. That's why before going to college you take an aptitude test. Even in a company, two engineers come.

One may be more research oriented and other may be more practical oriented. You put them in right place. In our profession it is much more clearer that we are all architects. But some are more design oriented so they can design, some more creative. Some are more technical minded so they can put things together in a building a little better. And some are more into administrative.

Make sure that things are done right. So we used to have three divisions in companies. There used to go to design department, Production department and Construction Administration department. Suppose more glamorous because it's creative. But depending on your aptitude, you end up going from one to the another. Sometimes, even if you don't have the aptitude, you think, "Because design is more glamorous, I want to go there."

But then you would be miserable because you won't be able to perform your task properly. Eventually you end up going where your aptitude is whether you like it or not. Bhagawan said that the duties are distributed among them according to their own gunas. Now how do I know what gunas Bhagavan says know what Brahmana's qualities are? Shamaha, control over the mind, mental control, Shamah Dhammah, physical control, control over your senses, Tapaha austerity. Any discipline which you follow, Shaucham, purity, Shantihi, forgiveness, Arjvam, straightforwardness.

Whatever it is, you can see clearly: Gnanam, Vignanam -- knowledge and also applied knowledge, the application of knowledge. Astikyam -- faith in the underlying truth that this world has its basis. We have learnt in Bhagavad Gita before that those people who are of devilish qualities think there is no basis in this world. The Bhagawan says Astikyam, that faith in the underlying truth, the underlying reality in this nature -- Brahma Karma Swabhavajam. This comes naturally to Brahmins. In other words, the people who have these qualities are the Brahmins. Now, say you identified that you are that person.

You ask him to run a business. Obviously he is not good at it. So you can't really put somebody in charge of something he is not good at.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 40 makes a universal declaration: nothing in this world, neither on earth nor among the celestial beings, is free from the three gunas born of Prakriti. This is both humbling and liberating. Humbling because no one can claim to be beyond these qualities while living in a body. Liberating because it means we should not despair at finding these tendencies in ourselves - they are the nature of existence. The goal is not elimination but transcendence through dis-identification.

Verses 41-42 begin describing the four varnas based on svabhava-prabhava-guna - qualities born of one's own nature. This is not a birth-based caste system but a recognition that people have different temperaments and aptitudes. The Brahmana qualities are listed: shama (serenity), dama (self-control), tapa (austerity), saucha (purity), kshanti (forgiveness), arjava (straightforwardness), jnana (knowledge), vijnana (applied wisdom), and astikyam (faith in the underlying reality). These are not inherited but developed through inner work.

Reflect honestly: Which qualities from the Brahmana list do you embody naturally, and which require effort? The teaching is not that everyone should become a Brahmana but that everyone should discover and fulfill their own svadharma (inherent nature). Today, identify one quality from this list that you want to develop. Rather than forcing it, ask: What in my life is obstructing this quality? Shama (serenity) is obstructed by constant stimulation. Arjava (straightforwardness) is obstructed by fear of consequences. Address the obstruction, and the quality naturally emerges.

snippets.title: Day 228: Knowledge and Doers
snippets.sanskrit:
शौर्यं तेजो धृतिर्दाक्ष्यं युद्धे चाप्यपलायनम् |

कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यं वैश्यकर्म स्वभावजम् |

स्वे स्वे कर्मण्यभिरतः संसिद्धिं लभते नरः |
snippets.transliteration:
śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam .

kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam .

sve sve karmaṇyabhirataḥ saṃsiddhiṃ labhate naraḥ .
verseTranslations: Valour, glory, firmness, skill, generosity, steadiness in battle and ability to rule - these constitute the duty of a soldier. They flow from his own nature.
Agriculture, protection of the cow and trade are the duty of a trader, again in accordance with his nature. The duty of a servant is to serve, and that too agrees with his nature.
He who dedicates his actions to the Spirit, without any personal attachment to them, he is no more tainted by sin than the water lily is wetted by water.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 18 and we have so far analyzed the actions, knowledge and the actor. Now, as we have seen, everything is kind of classified into three classes depending on the qualities of the actions, knowledge or the actors. Now we are going into the classification of human beings. We also classified the Sukha, the happiness or the pleasure which comes from your actions. Actions are performed for as we said and discussed many times for two purposes only. One is to gain happiness and other is to avoid unhappiness.

There are actions we perform simply to make sure that there is no sorrow. Your retirement planning for avoiding sorrow in the future, when I'm not working, I'm not able to work. I need planning for my retirement. That's for avoiding unhappiness. But I am accumulating money to buy a BMW to get happiness. So there are two reasons we work in this world.

We have identified those. The happiness that comes out of these actions can also be either sattvic happiness. It may take very painful efforts in the beginning, but in the end it will be like nectar. Or it will feel like nectar now, but in the end it turns out to be more painful. Or the last one we have seen is something which in the beginning it is painful, in the end also painful. But I do it because I think that's the only way I can get some comfort.

So now why people act in this manner? The next few verses which we will see said, we are all driven by our qualities. So Bhagavan vastu, pravartate, Beings and things in this world are driven by their own qualities. So if you ask me to go for football match, no matter how hard you try, unless there is some other temptation you give, I won't go to football match. As I said when I was in Dallas, we will have all the social party football matches. The temptation was all the socializing and the food and friends.

Football was least of my concern because it's not in my nature. But you have a music party. I will stay hungry if I need to sing. Obviously you can't really sing with a full stomach. So I'll be the last one to eat while everybody has left. Because I want to make sure that I am at my best when my turn comes to sing.

So I'm sacrificing something for which my own nature says it's pleasurable. So the next few verses it says. nastih prathivyam vyam va divi deveshu va punah sattvam prakruti jai Muktam Yadebhi sat tribhirgunaih. Now first thing they say, well, if I understood all that, I'm going to get rid of all the Tamas. I'm going to get rid of all the Rajas. I'll be just Sattvik.

Bhagavan said, it is really not possible that there is no being on this earth or again in the heaven. It's our conception that we are the mortal beings on this planet earth and they are immortal beings or devas are in the heaven. These Devas, even you know, Purana says they also have their qualities. Some devas are angry, some manipulate, some do this, you know, that's all the Pura Puranic stories. So it says, there is no being, whether a human being or a divine being, Deva, who is totally liberated from the three qualities. One cannot get rid of these three qualities totally.

Because once you liberate from these Gunas, you're out of the Prakriti, you're out of Maya. These three gunas are the characteristics of Maya, the Prakriti, the manifest world. As long as you are part of the manifest world as a being, these three has to be there. All these three has to be there to make you a being in this world. Therefore, Bhagavan said, there is no being on this planet or anywhere else in this universe who can be liberated completely from these three gunas. The day you transcend all three gunas, there is no Gita class, there is no you, there is no I.

Only the supreme self who was never tainted by this Prakriti remains. So the next verse says Brahmana, Kshatriya, Vaishyam, Shudranamcha, Parantapa, Karmani, pravibhaktani, svabhava, prabhavaih, gunaih. This is not a social commentary on Indian caste system. Bhagavad Gita was written before the caste system had been polluted by social thinking and historical influences. So this is not a social commentary. Let's not get confused with what happened in India over the last few thousand years regarding the caste system or Varanashram. It simply says Brahmanakshatriya, Vishyam, Shudranamcha, Parantapa Karmani, Pravibhaktani, svabhava, Prabhaivi Gunehi.

Whatever the predominant quality in a being, their karmas are assigned accordingly. If my aptitude is to sing, but then you say no, there is no singing here. You're going to dance today. Obviously that's not really something I can do. And that happens to me all the time. We go to a party and then everybody starts dancing.

And I'm the one who has no real interest at all. But why you are not dancing? Because I don't like dancing. That's why I'm not dancing. So Bhagavan said that each one's actions karma is assigned as per the predominant Gunas. The Brahman, Rakshatriya, Vaishyam or Rakshudra.

Now these classifications are not based on what we understand today; they are based on the Gunas. And we tend to conveniently forget that Bhagavan has already said in the Bhagavad Gita: Chaturvarnam, Maya Shrushta Guna, Karma, Vibhaga Saha. Depending on their gunas, their qualities and their actions, I have created four types of people in this world. I'm not a Brahmin and you are not a Shudra. Everybody in this country of 250 million people or so has equal right.

The citizens I'm talking about has equal right to be a president of this country. How many in this class wants to be a president of this country? We have no desire to be that. We have no qualities to become one. Does that mean I don't have a right to become a president? You have every right to become a president.

The other day we were at the India festival and Tim Kaine came. Obviously we kind of know him from our association all these years. So we took Medha and had a picture with Tim Kaine. And I said, "Senator Kaine, this is the newest member in our family -- the future senator of Virginia." From his perspective, a child can only aspire to become another senator. But Medha will become exactly what her Guna Karma is. So Bhagavan said, the Prakriti has created four types of beings at least in the human race with their qualities and their actions are assigned accordingly.

I told you, in our architecture firm we're all architects. We come out of architecture college. But then some have a design tendency on the technical side, some are more on the nitty gritty type -- construction and details. And some are purely management. Now if you take one type and assign them the other's work, it's always a disaster. So even though we have abolished the system of design department, production department, we still assign work according to their tendencies.

Does that mean we are discriminating? No, we are just trying to make people more comfortable in their ability to produce work. So Bhagavan says Brahmanakshatriya Vishaam Sudranam Chaparantapa Karmani Pravibhaktani. So Bhava prabhavaih gunai hi. All these people have own tendencies and the work is distributed in the society according to their qualities born of their own nature, not just somebody instilled by force. There is a lot of social injustice in this world, but that's not what Bhagavad Gita is about.

Bhagavad Gita makes a statement of facts. How we understand these facts and utilize -- or misuse -- them is a matter of our shortcomings and ignorance. So the next verse says Shamah damah Tapaha Shaucham shanti arjavam Gnanam Vignanam Astikyam Brahma Karma svabhavajam Long list. These are the qualities of the scholarly class thinking class in any society whether it is Indian, tribal or somewhere in some distant planet. More evolved society than human beings. Every society in this age or in Rama's age was divided by people who have tendency to be more thinking, contemplating type, knowledge oriented. Those people who have these qualities -- serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, and also uprightness, knowledge, realization of what is right and wrong.

Realization of what is my true self and what is my non-self. Belief in God -- Brahma Astikyam -- having faith that there is some higher self than this limited self. The Astikyam, Brahma Karma, Svabhavajam -- these are the qualities of the Brahmanas. It does not say the one who was born in a Brahmana family or falls into a Brahmana caste. It simply says that the group of people in any society who have these qualities fall into this type of activity because of their evolution in their intellectual pursuit.

What I know in architecture today is a lot more than I knew in the 1970s. My constant working in that field has given me more and more knowledge. Does that mean that because we should have equal rights, I have to give up my knowledge and act like the guy who comes out of architecture school?

No, this is with my own effort I have achieved a status which is higher than the guy who comes out of architecture school today. So by their own efforts and evolution the people have achieved the state where they have developed these qualities. And we have seen all we are doing is working in our inner equipment through our actions. There are some actions which purify my inner equipment. There are some actions which will pollute my inner equipment. If my actions were consistently to purify my inner equipment I would have developed these qualities.

And those who have done that, they are the Brahmanas. In any society, the next category we discuss is Sauryam Tejo Dhrutihi Daksham Yudde Chapyapalayanam Dhanam Ishwara Bhavasta, Kshatram Karma Svabhavajam. There are people who are scholarly and who have, through the evolution of their mind and intellect, reached a point of serenity and clarity where they can see things as they are. Therefore, in all our Puranas, the king has to go to the Rajguru and ask for advice. Because the king, in his passion, may not see what is right or wrong -- whether to attack that next territory or not. He goes to the Rajguru and asks his counsel.

The Rajguru, because he's not attached, can see things as they are and say, "This is good for you," or "This is not good for you." This is right or wrong. Because he's devoid of the passion with the King. So the next group of people in any society are the Kshatriyas. We know by now that the Brahmanas do the scholarly work.

Kshatriyas do the political work and protection and administering the country or the kingdom. So their qualities should be prowess, splendor, firmness, dexterity. And also not fleeing from battle -- the battle of life. Some of us run away from any situation when it is threatening, and some will face it head on. The quality of Kshatriya is to face that situation head on. Generosity, lordliness, leadership.

Today we call it leadership qualities. I was part of this leadership Metro Richmond group and so was Rajesh. We want to develop leaders in this community so that they can take this community to the next level. I attended one of the seminars and the guy said something which really I thought was pretty neat. He said, do not work in your business, you have to work on your business. See, my staff works in my business.

I need to be constantly working on my business in a sense that I. I need to have foresight.
snippets.reflection:
The qualities of Kshatriyas (verse 43) include shaurya (valor), teja (brilliance), dhriti (steadfastness), dakshya (skill), apalayana (not fleeing from battle), dana (generosity), and ishvara-bhava (lordly bearing or leadership). For Vaishyas (verse 44): agriculture, cattle-rearing, and trade. For Shudras: service. This framework recognizes that different temperaments are suited to different contributions. The key teaching is svabhava-jam - these duties arise from one's own nature, not external imposition.

Verse 45 delivers the crucial promise: sve sve karmani abhirata samsiddhim labhate narah - devoted to one's own duty, a person attains perfection. This is revolutionary: perfection (siddhi) comes not from abandoning your field for a supposedly higher one, but from complete dedication to whatever naturally suits you. A devoted janitor attains the same spiritual perfection as a devoted scholar. The path to liberation is through work, not around it.

Examine your relationship with your work today: Are you doing what naturally suits your temperament, or are you in a field chosen for prestige, family pressure, or financial considerations? If you cannot change your external circumstances, can you change your internal orientation? Even within unsuitable work, find the aspect that aligns with your nature. The teaching promises that wholehearted dedication to one's own dharma - whatever that may be - leads to samsiddhi, complete fulfillment. Where in your current work can you bring more wholehearted presence today?

snippets.title: Day 229: The Final Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम् |

श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् |

सहजं कर्म कौन्तेय सदोषमपि न त्यजेत् |
snippets.transliteration:
yataḥ pravṛttirbhūtānāṃ yena sarvamidaṃ tatam .

śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt .

sahajaṃ karma kaunteya sadoṣamapi na tyajet .
verseTranslations: Man reaches perfection by dedicating his actions to God, Who is the source of all being, and fills everything.
It is better to do one's own duty, however defective it may be, than to follow the duty of another, however well one may perform it. He who does his duty as his own nature reveals it, never sins.
The duty that of itself falls to one's lot should not be abandoned, though it may have its defects. All acts are marred by defects, as fire is obscured by smoke.
snippets.commentary:
Chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga. Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. We have discussed what this chapter is all about. You can see it as a summary or the final recommendations. You can see it like a summary of a long report. You're trying to make sense out of it without reading the whole thing.

If you just read a summary before the full report, you might hear different interpretations about what's right. Similarly here, if you just read chapter 18 by itself, it probably won't make any sense to you. But if you read the entire Bhagavad Gita from chapter one through 17 and then read chapter 18, it should make sense to you. So what we have discussed so far is in Bhagavad Gita, the recommendations are made for your betterment, for your growth, for your happiness in general.

We have realized that in this world there are people who are different from each other. But each one is striving for the one and the same goal, which is to achieve happiness. Not only just the happiness in a finite term, but infinite term. I want to get happiness which never ends. So we all learned who we are at this limited self, what is our identity, what when we identify with the supreme, and how can we remove this parallax between the limited self and unlimited self to achieve that infinite happiness. So this chapter now brings it back to our attention that what we have discussed.

So what we have discussed so far is working in this world is absolutely necessary. In this world you will not be able to stand still without acting anything because of our experiences, that anytime I get involved in something and there are conflicts and there are frictions, and therefore it creates unhappiness. Maybe I should stay away from all these things. But that's not the answer, because you just cannot stay without doing anything. So therefore understand what action is all about. You should not give up actions, but act in accordance with the advice in the Sastra, which says that there are actions which are forbidden.

It is not that you and I have to invent the will all over again every time. We have the wisdom of our ancestors, our civilization, our culture which tells you that stay away from this. This is not going to help you. Just like you tell a child, don't put finger in the fire, you're going to get burnt. Don't put finger in the electrical outlet, you'll get shot. You don't have to try it out to see whether it works or not.

So the Nishiddha Karma are forbidden -- so that you don't get burnt, you don't get completely destroyed. Now what is left is Nityaattachment and you shall achieve your goal of getting happiness. That's basically a simple advice in the beginning. But then the question occurs that we are all of different temperaments and we all have different goals.

We act in different fields. Is it really applied to all of us or only apply to the great evolved people who have understood all this philosophy of life? And Bhagavan come to the conclusion, a guideline that no. It applies to all of you. Whether you are at the top of the pyramid or at the bottom of the pyramid in the society. Therefore, we have discussed the four types of people.

This classification which we have just learned in previous verses says there are four types of people. They are defined by their own nature, their own gunas. It does not say that because you are a Brahmana, these gunas are yours. Rather, because you have these gunas, you'll be considered a Brahmana. You should consider yourself a Kshatriya because you have the following gunas: bravery, valor, brightness, lordliness.

Not the other way around. It's not "because you are a Kshatriya, you should have these qualities," but "because you have these qualities, you are a Kshatriya." And similarly, because you have certain qualities, you are a Vaishya or a Shudra. It did not say that one class is more important than the other. He said it's applicable to all of you.

The advice given in Bhagavad Gita, whether you are at the lowest rank, at the Shudra level or the Brahmin level, it all will apply to you. So last time somebody asked me, can you make a reference to the Purusha Sukta in Riga Veda. So in Purusha Sukta the same idea is explained. Purusha Sukta starts with Sahastra, Sirisa, Purushaha, Sahastraksha, Sahastrapad. This Purusha is envisioned, is the universal being. If the entire creation is one being, then how will you view it?

Or the sage who saw this universe as one being, he saw him as a being with thousands of eyes and thousands of legs and thousands of mouths. Very similar to what we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita in that vishwarupadas in chapter 11. So he said, this Purusha is everywhere. Sabhumim, Visvatovratva, atyatistha dash Angalam. He's enveloping the entire universe and is spreading in all ten directions. We have discussed before eight cardinal directions.

Northwest, east, south, northwest, southwest, southeast and northeast. Then eight up and down, 10, he's extending in all 10 directions. And then the question asks, what about his limbs? Brahmano mukha Asita. The first time you hear this Brahmano, Ashya Mukha, Asith, Brahmanas are his mouth. This universal being in his self is envisioned as what coming out of his mouth is Brahmanas.

So Brahmana, the knowledge speech, what we see is Brahmana, Asya Mukham, Asith, Bahuhu, Rajanya, Kritaha. His arms are made up of Rajanya, Kshatriyas, Uru tadasyat, Vaishyah. His thighs are made up of Vaishyas and Padyam Shudrajaya and his feet are made up of Shudras. The shudras constitute his feet, Vaisyas constitute his thighs, Kshatriyas constitute his arms and Brahmanas his mouth. This being cannot be complete if any one of them. You remove the complete picture of the Supreme Being.

It cannot be complete if you just take the Brahmanas and say other three are not necessary. He is who he is because all four parts. And then it continues and says Nabya Asid Antariksha. His navel forms the space between the heaven and the earth. Sishnav dyo Samovar Tathaha, his head sustained in heaven. Padma Bhumir Disaha, your feet are sustaining the earth.

Nakshatra, Tatha, Lokan Akalbayan and his ears the directions. So basically this one single entity is viewed as encompassing every part of the society, every part of our universe. Brahmanas are his mouth, Kshatriyas are his hands, arms and Vaishyas are his thigh. And shudras are his feet. He's supported by Shudras and Vaishyas. But it is part of the same entity.

So it's not the intention of the writer of this Purushaktam to put anyone down or so. But basically saying this system just cannot function unless there are all four types of people at any given time, at any given place, in any given society. So therefore we have discussed in this that there are four types of people. You may fall in any one of them depending on your qualities. If you find your qualities to be of service, your Shudra and as we said, entire service sector now today can be part of Shudras. Because we are serving.

Serving is the nature of Shudras. Creating wealth is the nature of Vaishyas. If you put the Vaishyas where the Rajanya is supposed to be, that happens. What is happening in USA now? So Bhagawan said that each one has own quality. And when you try to mix each other without understanding, it may create issues and problems.

But if you understand yourself and where you stand, at least at your level -- this Bhagavad Gita is for self-unfoldment, for individual self-development. So the next four verses, from 45 through 48, are actually the essence of how to be successful. If we forget the entire message of Bhagavad Gita but understand these four verses, contemplate on them, and practice them, Bhagavan guarantees that you will be a happy person and a successful person. These verses are applicable to all four classes of people. Not just for the Brahmins, and not just for Kshatriyas or Vaishyas, but even Kshudras, all four of them.

If they can stick to this formula of success, then success is guaranteed. That's basically what these four verses are all about. Verse 45, which we have seen, says: devoted to one's own duty, a man attains perfection. Perfection here should not be taken in the ordinary sense. It is the realization that now I have realized what my true self is. Whatever the field you're practicing, if you stay within your own nature, you will achieve perfection in that. If I'm a sweeper, if I focus into it, I'll achieve perfection. I always wonder -- all these people who have a garbage collection company, I mean, at some point the guy had some interest in garbage collection, right? Before he became a big businessman with lots of trucks running around all over Richmond.

You can't suddenly get interested in garbage collection. I actually had a client one time with one of these recycling businesses. Just passing through his yard -- all junk all around it. Then you go to his office, which is air-conditioned, a nice little office, nice little conference room. But just going through that yard made me realize that this guy must really feel comfortable in this environment. Therefore, he can be a successful businessman trading in this recycling business.

Bhagavan said, wherever you feel comfortable, according to your own dharma. If you follow the actions. If you perform actions in your own field of interest. Sansiddhim Labate Naraha person gets success. That's as simple as that. If I try to do something which is not my nature, I may get some success here and there.

But I'll never get full success. I tried developing some hotels and lost my shirt. But designing hotels I do very well. So after I lost all my investment, I said, let me go back to what I do best. Keep designing for other people. I can give advice to other people.

Where to build hotels, what is the right location, what will work, what will not work. I tried to do it myself. The Bhagavan said, if you stay within your realm of interest, of your own nature, success is guaranteed. You will achieve success. Swag karma nirataha Siddhim Yatha Vindha di tatsurana. But how that happens?

Bhagawan said, I'll tell you now how working in the field of your own interest, one can get. Siddhi -- perfection, success, expertise. And we find in this world all kinds of experts. Every time I come across a new challenge in my profession, something which I never heard about -- somebody says design something and it requires something so unique -- how do I figure this thing out?

And then I realize that there are experts even in disaster recovery. Suddenly you find that there are experts in this world who deal with that type of disaster which we have never thought about. How can you have experts in that field when the disaster only occurs once in a while? Because there are people who find their niche and they become experts because they pursue the field of their interest. So Arjuna asks, "How do they do it?" Bhagavan says, "I will explain to you now." So the next three verses.

This simply says how you should view your own field of interest.
snippets.reflection:
These verses form what Swamiji calls the "formula for success" applicable to all people regardless of their station. Verse 46 reveals how work becomes worship: sva-karmana tam abhyarchya - by worshipping through one's own work, the one from whom all beings arise and by whom all this is pervaded, a person attains siddhi. This transforms every action into a sacred offering. The mechanic worships through perfect repairs; the teacher through patient instruction; the parent through loving care. No action is too mundane when offered to the Source.

Verse 47 repeats the earlier teaching: better is one's own dharma, though imperfect, than another's dharma well-performed. Svabhava-niyatam karma kurvan napnoti kilbisham - performing action determined by one's own nature, one incurs no sin. Verse 48 adds a crucial insight: sahajam karma - innate or natural work - should not be abandoned even if it has defects, because sarvarambha hi doshena - all undertakings are covered with defects as fire is covered by smoke. No work is perfect; waiting for perfect conditions means never acting.

What is your sahajam karma - the work that naturally suits you? Today, release the perfectionism that prevents wholehearted engagement. Accept that your work will have defects (like smoke accompanies fire) and offer it anyway. The defects belong to the work; liberation belongs to the attitude. Practice this: before beginning your next task, consciously dedicate it to the Source from which your abilities arise. During the work, stay present rather than projecting to results. After completion, release it - let the outcome unfold without grasping.

snippets.title: Day 230: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
असक्तबुद्धिः सर्वत्र जितात्मा विगतस्पृहः |

सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे |

बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्यात्मानं नियम्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
asaktabuddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigataspṛhaḥ .

siddhiṃ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me .

buddhyā viśuddhayā yukto dhṛtyātmānaṃ niyamya ca .
verseTranslations: He whose mind is entirely detached, who has conquered himself, whose desires have vanished, by his renunciation reaches that stage of perfect freedom where action completes itself and leaves no seed.
I will now state briefly how he, who has reached perfection, finds the Eternal Spirit, the state of Supreme Wisdom.
Guided always by pure reason, bravely restraining himself, renouncing the objects of sense and giving up attachment and hatred;
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasi Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through renunciation, renunciation of actions. Up till now we have discussed the nature of actions, the nature of actors -- that is, you and I -- and the nature of knowledge. Knowledge that propels my desires, and my desires prompt me to act. And I go and act in this world outside. So we have analyzed how we function in this world. We came to the conclusion that depending on the texture of my mind and intellect, whether it is Sattvik, Rajaseek or Tamasvik that's dependent on my tendencies.

If my tendencies are Sattvik, I will have Sattvik desires and I will do Sattvik actions. If they are Rajasik, the same applies, and Tamasic appropriately. So my tendencies are driving my actions. And from these actions come reactions from the world, and I react to those, and they become my further actions. This cycle continues as long as I have the sense of doership and Bhokta Bhava, which is the sense of enjoyership.

I am the doer and I'm the enjoyer. And therefore we have analyzed in detail what is the nature of the action, what is the nature of the actor, and what is the nature of knowledge. So the prescription we have seen in the last verse we had been discussing says Sahajam Karma Kaunteya, do the actions which come naturally to you? Because after analyzing all these actions we get confused. Maybe the only Sattvic actions should be done.

I should give up all the Rajasic and Tamasic actions. But that's not possible for any one of us, because what we don't have control over is our tendencies. The tendencies came from my past experiences. I do not have any control over my past. I have control over my present, and I don't have any control over my future.

But my present actions can determine what my future will be. I can control the present to shape my future. So therefore Bhagavan says after knowing all this, that the actions and actors can be Satvika, Raja, Sikh and Tamastik and their consequences, the results of those actions. So what am I supposed to do, Bhagavan? Bhagavan said, sahajam Karma Kaunteya.

You do the actions which come naturally to you at this time, because you have these accumulated vasanas and tendencies which you cannot get rid of overnight or just because you read Bhagavad Gita for half an hour in the morning. So Bhagavan said, do the actions which come naturally to you -- Sahajam Karma Kaunteya -- not the ones which I find to be the best actions to perform in this field or environment, but that which comes natural to me due to the tendencies of my mind and my intellect. Sadosham Api Na Tyajet. Now, I come to the conclusion that my desire is to do designs for buildings. But then the clients come to me.

Their projects may have some defects. I had clients who had tobacco companies. I have casinos as my client, and I even had a strip club as my client. In 2001, we were in our downtown Brook Binder building and there was a strip club on Brook Road. They called us up and said, "Somebody recommended your name and we need your help doing some modifications to our club because there are some code violations." So my staff who fielded the phone came to me and said, "Neil, this is a problem."

"I don't think you're going to allow it." I said, "Of course I'm going to allow it. The client is a form of God." Gandhiji said, Grahaka Iti Bhagavan -- the customer is God's representative. I said, our job is to fix the code violations. Go and find out what the code violations are, figure out what needs to be done, give them the appropriate drawings, and make sure the code violations are mitigated. What he does is between him and his Bhagavan.

What I do is between I and my Bhagavan. My Bhagavan says, your job as an architect to make sure if a client comes to you to get his building more in line with the local codes, you need to help him. Even actions with defects should not be given up. Because imagine if all architects say, "Well, we are not helping any strip clubs anymore" -- what happens? It will be a building full of fire violations, code violations, dangerous for the society. So Bhagawan said, even if your actions seem to have defects, because they come naturally to you, they should not be given up.

Sarva Arambahi Doshena Dhumena Agnihi Ava Vritaha -- all actions (arambha in this case means actions). Swamiji clarifies what is considered arambha: I'm doing it because I want to do it, to fulfill my desire. Any arambha will have its own defects. Any medication will have its own side effect. Any action prompted by your desire will have its own side effects.

So Bhagavan said that's given that the nature of any action. Therefore even if you find that something you are doing out of your nature and find a fault in it, you should not give up. Because every action if you analyze will have its own defects. Dhumena agnihi ava vritaha -- just as every fire will have smoke. Some fires may have more smoke, some may have very little. But there is smoke, because there is no combustion that we know of in our day-to-day life which is hundred percent combustion. Therefore there will be smoke.

But that does not mean that you give up lighting fire when you need it. Therefore you should continue to perform actions which comes naturally to you even though they may have defects. Now, if I work in this world in that manner, what should I expect? What happens is that when you are aligning your actions with your nature, the ego pressure will reduce. All the problems we see in our life come from egocentric actions. But when I do something which comes naturally to me, there will not be any ego pressure.

And therefore you will gradually become asaktabuddhehe -- your intellect will become unattached. When you do something which comes naturally to you, there is very little ego involved in it. And therefore you don't get attached to that. Sarvatra -- your intellect becomes unattached in all actions that you perform which come naturally to you.

Because now your intellect is not attached, it's not creating more vasanas. Where we create more vasanas is when we get polluted by the experience in the field. For example, I go to the mall and all I want to do is buy one thing. But while I'm there, I get affected by the environment.

I went with a list of 10 items and I came back with 18 items. That's how the environment affects us. If I'm consciously working in tune with my own nature, then I will be least affected by the environment. Therefore I will have the least creation of new vasanas, and the pressure of new vasanas will be at a minimum.

So I will be Jitatma -- I will have control over myself. Now anytime we say "the self," we mean my mind, my intellect, and my senses. So Jitatma Vigataspruhaha -- one becomes without any desires. This may be very difficult for us to grasp.

But the more you function in line with your nature, the more you get success in that field. And you have less and less desire to do things which are not in line with your nature. So therefore you become Vigataspruhaha -- without any additional desires. I'm exhausting my past vasanas which created my tendencies, which put me into this field of activities. I'm exhausting my past vasanas by doing so.

And therefore I'm getting least and least attached to my actions. And when I exhaust those vasanas, I'll have less and less desires. Because I'm only focused on the what I like. Niskarima siddhiyam paramam sanyasena adigachati. What was my final goal is to renounce actions. But right now, because of my past vasanas and the vasana pressures and my tendencies, I cannot renounce them.

So Bhagavan said, go ahead and act in this field which is in tune with your true nature. By doing so you will get less and less the sense of doership and sense of enjoyership. And therefore you will not take credit or blame for those actions. You will say, "This is what I do, this is what I wanted to do, and I did it. What came out of it was not in my hand." More and more you give up that sense of doership.

Actions become non-actions because you're not taking any credit for them. If you act on behalf of your company and things go completely wrong -- but you did it exactly as per the company's policies and what your job description calls for -- would you be totally worried about that?

That's the company's problem. Why did they have this wrong policy? They asked me to do this. I, as a project manager or the VP, did it. Those happen to be the wrong policies. As long as you thought that you took the decision and were guiding the company's policy, then you are in trouble.

But you are working on behalf of the company. What you do is strictly the company's liability. Even though Bhagavan has given us all these capabilities, we take the responsibility and therefore we suffer for it. So Bhagavan said, when you reach a point where your actions become natural, you are not taking the credit or blame for them. You offer everything to him who has given you this talent.

So Bhagavan said, as long as you recognize that most of your ability to function in this world has come in spite of you, that sense will give you Naishkarmya Siddhi -- you will reach a state of actionlessness. And if you think about it, that's what we were trying to do in the first place! I was working towards my retirement, right? All this 401k and all that I'm putting together for my retirement -- an actionless state. Naishkarmya Siddhim Paramam -- he achieves the highest state of actionlessness. And therefore, Sanyasena Adhigacchati.

And therefore he renounces all the sense of doership and enjoyership and achieves the highest state of complete bliss. The next verse says Siddhim Prapto Yatha Brahma Tata Apnoti Nibodhame Samase Naivakante Nishtha Gnanasya Yapara. We have come full circle. We have understood who we are, how we work in this world. And we also got the prescription of Bhagavan. So now Bhagavan said, okay, now that he understood all of that.

Now if you follow this advice, then what will happen? Siddhim Prapto yatha Brahma Tatha Apnoti Nibodhame ultimate goal was to reach the state of infiniteness. One with the Supreme Self. Why do I want to be one with the supreme self? Because the limited self is not giving me joy and happiness. Therefore I want to transcend it.

It's not that I'm doing a favor to the Supreme. I'm joining his party. This state is not giving me joy and happiness which I'm looking for. So I want to achieve a state which can give me joy and happiness. And at that state, by all accounts we have seen is the only one state, the state of the Supreme Being. So everyone is knowingly or unknowingly trying to achieve that.

We are failing and then going in circles. The Bhagavan says, let me tell you, it's a very simple and clear path. Act according to your nature. Do not do anything which is contrary to your nature. Because that will complicate your life, will create more unnecessary vasanas, unnecessary desires and then unnecessary actions.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 49 describes the ultimate state: asakta-buddhi (unattached intellect), jitatma (conquered self), vigata-spriha (free from longing) - such a person attains through sannyasa the supreme perfection of naishkarmya-siddhi, the state of actionlessness. This does not mean inactivity but rather action that leaves no karmic residue. When actions flow naturally from one's dharma without ego-driven attachment, they become like a hobby - full of engagement but without the burden of "I am doing this for that result."

Verses 50-51 begin describing the path to Brahman. The process starts with buddhya vishuddhaya yukto - endowed with purified intellect, controlling the self with dhriti (steadfastness), abandoning sense objects, and casting aside raga-dvesha (attachment and aversion). This is the practical instruction: purify the intellect, establish control, renounce sensory preoccupation, and release the grip of likes and dislikes.

Today, examine your attachments and aversions: What are you currently pursuing (raga)? What are you currently avoiding (dvesha)? These twin forces keep us bound to the wheel of karma. The instruction is not to become indifferent but to vyudasya - cast aside the compulsive quality of attachment and aversion. You can still have preferences without being driven by them. Practice with one attachment today: notice it, acknowledge it, but do not act from its compulsion. Notice one aversion: face it rather than automatically avoiding it. This is the beginning of jitatma - conquering the self.

snippets.title: Day 231: Types of Action
snippets.sanskrit:
विविक्तसेवी लघ्वाशी यतवाक्कायमानसः |

अहंकारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं परिग्रहम् |

ब्रह्मभूतः प्रसन्नात्मा न शोचति न काङ्क्षति |
snippets.transliteration:
viviktasevī laghvāśī yatavākkāyamānasaḥ .

ahaṃkāraṃ balaṃ darpaṃ kāmaṃ krodhaṃ parigraham .

brahmabhūtaḥ prasannātmā na śocati na kāṅkṣati .
verseTranslations: Enjoying solitude, abstemiousness, his body, mind and speech under perfect control, absorbed in meditation, he becomes free - always filled with the spirit of renunciation.
Having abandoned selfishness, power, arrogance, anger and desire, possessing nothing of his own and having attained peace, he is fit to join the Eternal Spirit.

And when he becomes one with the Eternal, and his soul knows the bliss that belongs to the Self, he feels no desire and no regret, he regards all beings equally and enjoys the blessing of supreme devotion to Me.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. So far we have seen that we are the product of our past and therefore we have tendencies, likings, and dislikings. All the discussion so far was about Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas -- this is Sattvik, this is Rajasik, and so on. So the natural tendency is to think, "Well, I'll pick the best which I can find. This looks like Sattva, so I'll just do Sattvik things only."

But our tendencies and our desires and the coloring of our mind won't let us do that. So the advice from Bhagavan is Sahajam Karma kontea sadoshena PI Natya Jat. Do the actions which come naturally to you -- those which are in line with your own personality, your tendencies, your likings, your dislikings. Do those actions even though you find them to have defects. Because I have learned 17 chapters of Bhagavad Gita now, and suddenly I find that most of my actions are Rajasik.

That's your nature right now that comes naturally to you. That's where the Bhagavad Gita started. Bhagavan said to Arjuna, you are a warrior. The Rajasic action is your nature in the Kshatriya. You can't give it up right now, run towards jungle to meditate, because that will be against your tendencies in nature. That will actually create more harm to your path of evolution than help you.

It won't purify your mind, pollute your mind and confuse your mind. So Sahajam Karma kaun teja sadoshana pen Natya Jat. Do not give up the actions which come naturally to you. Even though you find some defects, they are not perfect. And then Bhagavan said that by doing so you will purify yourself and consolation given to Sarvarambahi kadushena dumena agnihi ava vritaha all actions, no matter how pure you see them have some defects. There is always a side effect to even the best medicine you can take.

The Bhagavan said Any actions which you have to perform in accordance with your nature even if you find the faults in it, continue. Because every action will have its own defects. But then what do I do with it? The only thing you can do is perfect your attitude towards your actions. Actions by nature has their own pluses and minuses but you can change your attitude towards your actions. So the next few verses which we have seen say Asakta Buddhi -- the first thing you do is detach your intellect from your actions.

Asaktabuddhi Sarvatra Jitatma Vigataspruhaha -- I'm doing these things because they come naturally to me. As I said, Gita class is a Kamya Karma for me, because I like to do it, it is my desire to do it. So if it comes naturally to you, do it. But Bhagavan said, Asaktabuddhehe -- detach your mind and intellect from those actions.

Sarvatra Jitatma -- have self-control over your desires, your likings, and dislikes. I'm doing it, but I may not have any control of the outcome. I may not be allowed to do these things; the environment, the situation may not allow me. I need to be content with that, without attachment. I want to do it, but if there is no opportunity to do it, I'll continue with what is available to me.

The goal here is to achieve a state of Naishkarmya Siddhi -- whatever I do, I do not feel that I'm doing it. As I said, when we are working on our hobbies, it's not work. I'm putting in lots of effort, but I don't consider it work because that's my hobby. The other day Krishna told me, "I'm going to call you. We're going to practice together."

Because when we are not practicing, it's not really working. "When are you going to call me?" "Well, Saturday I'm not available," because that becomes work for me. Naishkarmya Siddhi is like this: when everything I do becomes my hobby, I become actionless. It's all basically in line with my nature.

Paramam Sanyasena Adhigacchati -- such a person achieves the highest level of renunciation. By doing the things which you are supposed to do, you can achieve sannyasa. The definition of sannyasa is giving up the sense of agency. Not giving up things and beings, but giving up the sense of agency -- "I am doing it" and "I am enjoying it." When you give that up, you are a sannyasi.

Bhagavan said, if you do all the things in line with your nature, you will never have that sense of agency, nor will you even notice that you are enjoying it. You get so engrossed in the stuff which you do for your hobby that neither you are aware that you are putting lots of efforts into it, nor whether it's painful or enjoyable. Music practice was the most painful thing I had when I was going to my teacher's classes for that little time. But it was still what I wanted to do. So whether it was a pain or a joy, I never noticed it. This is something I want to do.

That Bhagavan says -- in that state you are neither aware that you are the doer nor aware that you are the enjoyer. When you achieve that state, you have achieved sannyasa. With that the next verse says Siddhim prapto yatha brahma tatha apnoti nibodame sama se nay kaunteya nista gnana seya yapara. Now I'll tell you in brief how to reach Brahman, having achieved that siddhi -- the Naishkarmya Siddhi.

Now everything comes naturally to me. I do everything naturally. I don't have any anxiety about whether I'm enjoying or suffering through it, or whether good will come out of it. I just enjoy doing it. Therefore I'm doing it. He said, achieving that siddhi in your actions and achieving sannyasa through that -- how you can then achieve Brahman, I will tell you now.

So now comes the prescription or the detailed guidance of how to achieve that. The verse we have seen after that is Buddaya visuddaya Yuktah dhruti atmanam niyam yucha. First thing is Buddaya Vishuddaya -- you have to purify your intellect. My intellect is right now polluted by my ego.

My ego says I am always right, even though everybody else says otherwise. My intellect says I am the smartest among all. So Buddhaya Vishuddaya -- the purified intellect will see things as they are. The intellect is purified by not having ego polluting it. Dhruti Atmanam -- be firm in your own self. This is what I want to do. This is what I like to do.

And this is where I am putting my efforts. Dhruti Atmanam firm in your own self. What is my true nature? I know what I really like. I was just listening to NPR yesterday and some guy who was a lawyer and has a nice corporate practice, he gives up and becomes a LEGO artist. I don't know whether anybody heard that.

In other words, he makes complex form of lions and stuff. He's basically an artist whose work is now displayed all these places. But he gave up the job and became a LEGO artist. And LEGO company provides him free logos. When they have a new LEGO comes out in thousands and he creates whatever. He said that the worst day as an artist is better than the best day as a lawyer.

For me, therefore I did it. He found what he likes. He followed Bhagavad Gita without reading it. I want to do this no matter what the outcome may be. But this is what I like. Buddaya Visuddhaya Having purified my intellect, what is my true nature?

Our intellect typically gets polluted by worrying about what others will think of us. And therefore we make choices accordingly. We choose our profession -- at least in my time it was very simple. You didn't have to figure out what you like. If you don't get admission in medicine, go to chemical engineering. Chemical engineering doesn't work out? Go to mechanical engineering. Mechanical doesn't work out? Electrical. Then civil. And if you are completely out of all that, go to architecture. You didn't have to figure out what you like.

You just figured out what the social scale was. Bhagavan said that's a perfect recipe for disaster for you. Dhruti Atmanam Niyamyacha Sabdayati Visayam Tektva Ragadveso, vidashyacha sabdadi sound, etc. In other words, all the sense objects from outside which is polluting your mind and intellect. You are not getting disturbed by this. I wish I can become an artist but there is no money in it.

Doctors make more money, so let me go to medicine even though I hate that profession. There was one guy on Kaun Banega Karorpati. He had just done his internship, and Amitabh Bachchan asked him, "So after that, what next?" He said, "What do you mean?"

"Don't you want to do MD or MS or something?" He said, "Yeah, I can do MD or MS, but I'm not interested in it." "Why are you not interested in furthering your career?" He said, "I don't like medicine. My parents wanted me to go to medicine. That's why I went to medicine."

But I want to be an IAS officer. I've seen IAS officers. I've seen what they do and their power and their influence. And that's what I want to be. So I did what my parents wanted me to do. Now I'm going to do what I want to do.

And how do I achieve this purified intellect and self-control? Vivikta Sevi, Laghvashi -- now comes the discipline or guidance for how you can find out what you really like. How do you find out what your true nature is? How do I align my actions with my own nature? Vivikta Sevi -- solitude. Solitude is something we think about.

We are all afraid of loneliness. I'll tell you -- when we were young, if on Saturday you had no invitation to go to any party, we didn't know what to do. "Neil, what are you doing over the weekend?" "So Neil, how was your weekend?"

I said, "It's always the same. My weekends are always the same." "Which party did you go to?" If you don't get invited to a party, you don't know what to do with your life. That weekend you're completely lost. Learn to be happy with yourself.

Find a way that you can enjoy solitude. That you think, thank God nobody is now here. I can be by myself and enjoy my time. I'm sure most of your parents went through that. But solitude is a practice to figure out how you can enjoy yourself by yourself. Laghvashi -- eating but little. Other texts say: eat as much as you would take your medicine.

Your medication -- you never take more than what your doctor says you should take. One tablet means one tablet. That's what the doctor said, right? Not, "Well, the doctor says one, but I'm a little more aggressive about it, so I'm going to take three at a time." Take only what you need. Your food should be just like that -- only what you need. The texts elaborately describe that a quarter of your belly should be filled with food, a quarter left for water, and half left for air.

That much you should eat -- Laghvashi -- because you know that when you're overstuffed, you're uncomfortable and the mind is not available for anything else. Laghvashi Yata-Vak-Kaya-Manasaha -- control over your speech, body, and mind. Swamiji explains here that vak (speech) includes all organs of action. It's an indicator: all the organs of action should be in control.

It does not say stop them -- just keep them in control through moderation. Kaya -- body. The body is the gross form of my mind.
snippets.reflection:
These verses provide the complete prescription for Self-realization. Verse 52 lists the practices: vivikta-sevi (cultivating solitude), laghvashi (eating lightly), yata-vak-kaya-manasa (controlling speech, body, and mind), dhyana-yoga-para (devoted to meditation), and vairagyam samupashrita (established in dispassion). These are not random austerities but a coherent program for purifying the instrument through which we perceive reality. Notice the emphasis on moderation - laghu (light) eating, yata (controlled) faculties - not extreme suppression.

Verse 53 lists what must be abandoned: ahamkara (ego), bala (force/power), darpa (arrogance), kama (desire), krodha (anger), and parigraha (possessiveness). Casting these off, one becomes nirmama (without "mine-ness") and shanta (peaceful), qualifying for Brahma-bhuyaya - becoming one with Brahman. Verse 54 describes the result: Brahma-bhuta (established in Brahman), prasannatma (serene-minded), neither grieving nor craving, equal toward all beings, and attaining supreme devotion.

The path is clear but challenging. Today, practice vivikta-seva - cultivating moments of solitude, even briefly. Examine your laghu-ashi - are you eating more than needed? Practice yata-vak - restraint in speech before responding. These small adjustments accumulate. Also examine: where does ahamkara (ego) drive your actions? Where does parigraha (possessiveness) create suffering? Identify one instance of each today and consciously release it. The promise is profound: through consistent practice, one attains prasannatma - a naturally serene mind that neither grieves loss nor craves gain.

snippets.title: Day 232: Knowledge and Doers
snippets.sanskrit:
भक्त्या मामभिजानाति यावान्यश्चास्मि तत्त्वतः |
