सर्वकर्माण्यपि सदा कुर्वाणो मद्व्यपाश्रयः |

चेतसा सर्वकर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः |
snippets.transliteration:
bhaktyā māmabhijānāti yāvānyaścāsmi tattvataḥ .

sarvakarmāṇyapi sadā kurvāṇo madvyapāśrayaḥ .

cetasā sarvakarmāṇi mayi saṃnyasya matparaḥ .
verseTranslations: By such devotion, he sees Me, who I am and what I am; and thus realising the Truth, he enters My Kingdom.
Relying on Me in all his action and doing them for My sake, he attains, by My Grace, Eternal and Unchangeable Life.
Surrender then thy actions unto Me, live in Me, concentrate thine intellect on Me, and think always of Me.

So we have detailed analysis of these three, the action, the actor, and the knowledge. We have seen that all of these three are driven by the texture of my mind. My mind has either a sattvic, Rajasic or tamasic tendencies that will make me either a sattvic actor, Rajasic actor, tamasic actor, that will drive me to the sattvic actions, rajasic actions or tamasic actions. Okay, Now I have figured out what my natural field of action is. But how should I act so that I'll get the benefit of that?

The next thing is Asaktah Jitatma -- without attachment and without any expectation. We have seen there are only two paths: either to become a sannyasi or a yogi. Yogi is the one who gives up Karma Phala, the desire for fruits of action. So I've found the field of my actions.

I need to leave it to them their duties to perform diligently. I will perform my duty diligently. The Bhagavan said, perform your actions without attachment expectations in the field which comes naturally to you. Doing so, you will develop devotion for me. You will align your thoughts with the one who empowers you to do these actions. So therefore he said, become one with me.

Offer everything to me. And the last few verses which you have seen. He says, bhaktiya mam abhijanati yavat na aschasmi tatvatah tatomam tattvato gnatva visatei tad anantharam. Just by acting in this manner of offering everything to him. As we have seen in detail the previous verses, once I decided the field of my actions, I decided that I am not really the one who empowers me to act. The consciousness functioning through me as my life empowers me to act.

I'll be only able to conduct Gita classes as long as I'm alive. The day I drop dead, Gita classes will be history. That's because my consciousness in me allows me to understand Bhagavad Gita. So the empowering authority is something other than me. That which connects the electricity in this room is the empowering authority for the electricity. We have lights, we have air conditioning.

Right now we are pretty happy. Things are working fine. But when they first rented the place, the electricity wasn't there. He thought, "I am the Almighty for this place." Calls me up and says, "Not working."

I said, I think the machine is not working. Electricity is not connecting through Dominion Virginia Power. Dominion Virginia Power is the final authority that the electricity comes here. I have a limited power to turn the switch on and off when I need that. But in that limited power, I start thinking because it is always there. I think I am in control and I can turn this thing on and off.

It is only when the power goes out I realize I am just a Nimitta Matra. Virginia Power decides whether I have electricity or not. As long as that electricity is functioning through this space, I can control this space. When Dominion Virginia Power connection is disconnected, no matter how many times I turn the switch on and off, nothing happens. Bhagavan said, you need to recognize this fact that you are connected to me as the supreme consciousness which is functioning through you. If you keep that in mind all the time, they will make sure that that connection never gets disconnected.

See, when I design buildings, most buildings have normal electricity connection. And then when there is power outage, the connection goes out. But I designed the emergency shelter. Actually medical examiner's office in downtown. Well, you can't have the power go out during emergency. That is the time when there's a disaster.

That's the time that office becomes most active. They may have all these disaster victims coming to this place. Those pathologists have to work overnight to deal with them. So you need to have a dual power system for that. We connected that building from two different grids. So even though one grid is out, the other grid is connected.

They will never be out of that electrical connection. That's where you will have this permanent connection. Bhagavan said, if you want eternal happiness, you need to make sure that your connection to me is always connected. And for that, you have to offer everything that you do to me. Remembering constantly that I can only do this because he's functioning through me. With that attitude, you will develop devotion for him.

You will be constantly attached to him. So we both have to have that dual connection. Bhagavan has to have connection with me and I have to have connection with him. That connection when developed, we call it devotion. It's one that devotion takes place. Bhakti mam Avijanati Yavatna Asha asmi Tattvatahara Tatotam tattvoto Gnatva visate tat Anantaram.

By devotion he knows me in essence. Once I become identified completely with someone or something, I know that thing or being in its essence or his essence. He forthwith enters into me the supreme. Once I completely identify myself with the supreme self, I enters into him. In other words, I become one with that supreme being. Sarvakarmani API sada Kurvanaha mat vyapaasrayah mat prasadat avapnothi Saswatam padam avyayam.

The process took place. I gave up identification with my ego. I chose the field of my actions. I started working in the field of my actions without any expectations and offered all my actions to him. Now with that connection I have identified completely with him. So now my life is doing all actions always taking refuge in him with his grace.

Now I have not become happy with my efforts. I have become peaceful and happy with his grace. This space is properly conditioned and lit up right now -- by the grace of Dominion Virginia Power. When their grace is taken away from me, the lights will go away and the air conditioning will go away. As long as I recognize that the lights and air conditioning are not because of me -- not because I'm paying the bills, but because of their grace in connecting electricity to this space -- then I will be fine.

Then I'll develop that devotion to Dominion Virginia Power. As soon as the bill comes, pay the bill. Bhagavan said, one who becomes one with me, with this root of actions he has become one with me and therefore he achieves that Saswatam Padam avyayam.
snippets.reflection:
These verses describe the culmination of the spiritual journey through devotion. Verse 55 declares: bhaktya mam abhijanati - through devotion one knows Me in essence, and knowing Me thus in truth, immediately enters into Me. This is not intellectual knowing but direct realization through love. The analogy of complete identification applies - just as we intimately know those we deeply love, complete devotion to the Divine yields complete knowledge of the Divine.

Verse 56 offers remarkable assurance: sarva-karmani api sada kurvano - even while always performing all actions, one who takes refuge in Me attains by My grace the eternal, imperishable abode. This is the Gita's liberating promise: you do not need to abandon action for liberation. Continue your duties, but mat-vyapashraya - take refuge in the Divine. Mat-prasadat - by grace, not solely personal effort, comes the eternal state. Verse 57 summarizes: mentally surrender all actions to Me, keep Me as your supreme goal, practice buddhi-yoga, and constantly fix your mind on Me.

The practical instruction is clear: maintain your connection to the Source through all activities. Like staying connected to the power grid while using electricity for various purposes, stay connected to the Divine while engaging with the world. Today, practice mat-chitta - keeping the Divine in your awareness through activities. Before each task, briefly remember the Source of your abilities. During activities, occasionally pause and reconnect. This is not adding a spiritual practice to your day but infusing your entire day with spiritual awareness. The promise is that this constant remembrance, combined with offering all actions, leads to the eternal abode - by grace.

snippets.reflection:
These verses present both the promise and the warning. Verse 58: mat-chitta - with mind fixed on Me, you will overcome all obstacles by My grace. But aham-karat na shroshyasi - if through ego you will not listen, you will perish. The choice is stark: surrender and be carried across all difficulties, or cling to ego and be destroyed. Verse 59 addresses Arjuna's specific situation: if through ego you think "I will not fight," your resolution is vain - Prakriti will compel you. This applies universally: we cannot escape our nature through willful avoidance.

Verse 60 drives the point home: svabhava-jena nibaddha - bound by your own karma born of your nature, what you do not wish to do through delusion, you will do helplessly. This is not fatalism but psychological truth. Our vasanas (tendencies) are powerful forces that will express themselves. The question is not whether to act but whether to act consciously or be driven unconsciously. Arjuna cannot avoid being a warrior; his nature will assert itself. Better to fight consciously with understanding than to fight unconsciously driven by repressed instincts.

Examine where ego-resistance is preventing you from doing what needs to be done. What are you avoiding through willful stubbornness that your nature will eventually force you to face? The teaching suggests that surrender is not weakness but wisdom - recognizing that fighting against our fundamental nature is futile. Today, identify one area where you are resisting something that aligns with your dharma. Ask: Is my resistance protecting something valuable, or is it merely ego avoiding what feels threatening? Often what we resist most persistently is exactly what we need to embrace.

snippets.title: Day 234: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
ईश्वरः सर्वभूतानां हृद्देशेऽर्जुन तिष्ठति |

तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत |

इति ते ज्ञानमाख्यातं गुह्याद्गुह्यतरं मया |
snippets.transliteration:
īśvaraḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ hṛddeśe.arjuna tiṣṭhati .

tameva śaraṇaṃ gaccha sarvabhāvena bhārata .

iti te jñānamākhyātaṃ guhyādguhyataraṃ mayā .
verseTranslations: God dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna! He causes them to revolve as it were on a wheel by His mystic power.
With all thy strength, fly unto Him and surrender thyself, and by His grace shalt thou attain Supreme Peace and reach the Eternal Home.
Thus have I revealed to thee the Truth, the Mystery of mysteries. Having thought it over, thou art free to act as thou wilt.
snippets.commentary:
Discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga -- Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. We are at the conclusion of Bhagavad Gita, and in this chapter Bhagawan has stated a few simple facts which we already know. We have discussed them before and also experienced them in our life. Something as simple as this: in this world, people have different temperaments. Not all people are alike. Each one has his or her own temperament. Depending on that temperament, he may be good at one thing or another. Everybody is not good at everything, but depending on your temperament, you may be good at something.

And also this temperament will make you like some things and dislike other things. So this temperament is your own nature or your personality. Therefore, because in this world the different people have different personalities, different temperaments, they do different things. Some are good at scholarly pursuits and some are good at doing heroic things and some are good at creating wealth and some are just happy serving others, you may find yourself to be somewhere in this spectrum. Not everybody likes same type of coffee. Some like strong, some like very mild.

Others may be somewhere in between. So you will find yourself somewhere in the spectrum of temperament. Some are very sattvic, some are very tamasic and most of us are somewhere in between. Therefore find out what your real nature is. Bhagawan said this is a fact that each one has his or her own qualities and temperaments. So depending on your temperament, now you have to find the field of activity which is appropriate for you.

So earlier in chapter three, Bhagavan said Swadharma Nidhanam Shreya Paradharma Bhayavahah -- working in your own nature is better, because another's dharma is frightening. If you try to do something against your nature, it will be very frightening. You will always be a fish out of water. You are a very artistic person and you want to run a business -- you will be a fish out of water.

You will not feel comfortable. So therefore find your own Dharma and then work in it. So in this chapter again he reminds us what is good for you. So he said that Sriyan Swadharmo Vigunaha, Paradharma, Swanushti daat. Your Dharma alone is good for you, even though it has faults. It may not be as pristine as others, but this is what your nature is and it is good for you.

And therefore Sahajam, Karma, kaunteh. So find the field of activities which come naturally to you. Do the activities which come naturally to you. You shall not incur any sin in doing so. You shall not incur any sin. Continue doing what you like, what comes naturally to you.

And do not worry about whether I'll incur any sin or I'll incur any wrong tendencies. We have learnt in the previous chapter that no matter what your tendencies are and what activities you are performing, you start with Om Tatsat, purify them. So in chapter 17 we have learned that no matter what your Saddha is, whether it is Sattvic, whether it is, whether it is Raja Sikh, whether it is Tamasic, you are acting in that manner. But rather than worrying about whether it is Sattvik, Rajasik, or Tamasik, do whatever is natural to you. But whatever you do, start with Aum. Every activity which you do, remember him, that he is almighty and all pervading.

Verse 61 reveals a profound truth: ishvara sarva-bhutanam hrid-deshe - the Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, causing them to revolve as if mounted on a machine (yantra) by the power of Maya. This image combines divine immanence with the mechanical quality of conditioned existence. The Lord is not distant but intimately present in every heart, yet Maya creates the illusion of separate, automatic beings driven by their programming. We are simultaneously divine at core and conditioned at the surface.

Verse 62 delivers the instruction: tam eva sharanam gaccha sarva-bhavena - go to Him alone for refuge with your whole being. The result: tat-prasadat param shantim sthanam prapsyasi shashvatam - by His grace you will attain supreme peace and the eternal abode. Verse 63 concludes Krishna's teaching: I have declared to you this knowledge, the most secret of all secrets. Reflect on it fully, then do as you wish (yathecchasi tatha kuru). This final freedom is remarkable - after all instruction, the choice remains with Arjuna.

The teaching honors your autonomy while pointing to the truth. Today, contemplate the reality that Ishvara dwells in your heart right now - not as a visitor but as the very core of your being. The sense of being a separate mechanism driven by forces beyond your control is Maya's creation. Beneath that programming lies the Lord. Take refuge there - not as an escape from life but as a grounding that transforms how you engage with life. And remember: after receiving all teaching, the choice remains yours. What will you choose today?

snippets.reflection:
These verses contain the Gita's supreme teaching. Verse 64 establishes the context: because you are dear to Me, I will speak for your welfare the most secret of all. Verse 65 gives the complete instruction: man-mana bhava mad-bhakto mad-yaji mam namaskuru - fix your mind on Me, be My devotee, worship Me, bow to Me. The promise: mam evaishyasi satyam - you shall come to Me truly, I promise you, for you are dear to Me. This is love speaking to love.

Verse 66 is the charama-shloka, the ultimate verse: sarva-dharman parityajya mam ekam sharanam vraja - abandoning all dharmas, take refuge in Me alone. Aham tva sarva-papebhyo mokshayishyami - I shall liberate you from all sins; do not grieve. This is not abandonment of ethical conduct but transcendence of all limited identifications. Every role we play comes with its dharma - parent, professional, citizen. These are necessary but partial. The instruction is to ultimately take refuge in the One beyond all roles.

This is the heart of surrender: not passive resignation but active trust in the Source of all. The promise "I shall liberate you from all sins" addresses our deepest fear - that our past mistakes have permanently damaged us. They have not. Grace is more powerful than karma. Today, practice this surrender: acknowledge the various dharmas you carry, the roles and their obligations. Then, beneath all these, find the One to whom they are all offered. Say inwardly: "I take refuge in You alone." Notice the peace that comes when the burden of being the sole doer is released. Ma shuchah - do not grieve.

Do not try to compare yourself with others and don't try to copy them. You find your own bearings, what is good for you, what you like.

Continue functioning, but keep the Lord in mind -- that he is Almighty. He is making me do all these things and therefore I am offering everything I do to Him. Tamevasharanam gacha. Take refuge in that Ishvara, that Almighty, all-pervading consciousness. Sarva bhavena Bharata -- in all your being, with all your thoughts, whether thinking about your professional life, your relationships, everything.

While you are thinking, put him in the center of it -- all these things are only possible because of Him. Take refuge in him that you are the ones who is enabling me to function in this world as an individual. Tat Prasada paramsanthim Sthanam prapsi Saswatam. If you take refuge in him with all your being, with all your thoughts, no matter what that is, offer it to him that I can only think this way because of you. I can only act this way because of you. Once you start assigning all credits to him, then you are relieved.

You have no responsibilities. So in the end Bhagavan said this individualized ego which is identifying with this body, mind and intellect and taking credit for what I'm doing, thinking that I'm the doer. If you just keep that aside, do everything that you are doing right now exactly as you are doing. Because you are doing it as per your nature. You are propelled by your nature to do it. If you try to resist your nature, it creates distortion, a kind of mental disease.

So keep doing what you are doing. Just keep in mind Tamevasharanam Gacha, Sarva Bhavya Bharata. Just take refuge in Him. Make your identification with him versus this limited body, mind and intellect. Tat prasadat paramshantin sthan praapasi Saswatam. The grace is when the identification is complete then I obviously become one with him, his qualities become my qualities.

I start thinking, "I now have access to his capacities." You joined a company a day before, and from the next day onwards you're part of the company -- all the resources of the company are yours. You take the brochure of the company and go to a new client and say, "I represent IBM." All of IBM's resources are your resources. But before that, a day before, when you had not joined the company yet, you didn't have that brochure from IBM.

You are just an individual. You can say, "I can do this," and that doesn't really mean much. Once you attach yourself to the resources of the Great, all his resources become your resources; all the qualifications of that company become your qualifications. Once you identify with him and take refuge in him Tat Prasad with his grace you will achieve that Santisthanam Propyasi Sastvatam. You will find that eternal peace and a firm abode. All you have to do is just take refuge in him and continue doing what you are doing as per your own nature.

Itite Gnanam Akhyatam Guhyat Guhyatram Maya Vimrushyat Ashe. We have discussed this thing in detail from chapter two onward. We have analyzed every point. In the end I came down and told you: just follow your own Dharma, your own nature. You will not incur any sin.

Do not worry about what other people are doing, do not copy them. Your welfare is in following your own Dharma and giving up your ego and attachment. And I will take care of everything else. I told you this very secret of knowledge. "Secret" means it was hidden from you. It was right there but hidden from you.

Because of my own likes and dislikes, my vasanas, my ignorance, I was not able to see this. I took that coverings away from you so that you can see the knowledge as is. I told you in its entirety. Vimrushya Etit Asena. Reflect on it in its totality. Don't take a verse here and there from Bhagavad Gita.
snippets.reflection:
These verses address the transmission of knowledge. Verse 67 specifies to whom this teaching should NOT be given: na atapaskaya (one without discipline), na abhaktaya (one without devotion), na ashushrusha (one unwilling to serve/listen), and one who abhyasuyati (cavils or finds fault). This is not exclusion but wisdom - teaching reaches only those prepared to receive it. Forcing spiritual knowledge on unprepared minds creates neither understanding nor transformation.

Verses 68-69 describe the supreme service: teaching this knowledge to sincere devotees is the highest form of worship, and no one is dearer to Krishna than one who shares this wisdom. This is the concept of jnana-yajna - the sacrifice of knowledge. Swami Chinmayananda embodied this teaching through the study group movement, recognizing that teaching multiplies understanding both for teacher and student.

Consider: What knowledge have you received that is meant to be shared? Not everyone is ready - verse 67's criteria apply. But among those who show discipline, devotion, and willingness to learn, you have something to offer. Today, reflect on one insight from your spiritual journey that has genuinely helped you. Identify one person in your life who might benefit and is ready to receive. The teaching need not be formal - a conversation, a recommended reading, a shared practice. The Gita promises that sharing wisdom with ready students is the highest devotion. What will you share, and with whom?

snippets.title: Day 237: The Final Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
अध्येष्यते च य इमं धर्म्यं संवादमावयोः |

श्रद्धावाननसूयश्च शृणुयादपि यो नरः |

कच्चिदेतच्छ्रुतं पार्थ त्वयैकाग्रेण चेतसा |
snippets.transliteration:
adhyeṣyate ca ya imaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃvādamāvayoḥ .

śraddhāvānanasūyaśca śṛṇuyādapi yo naraḥ .

kaccidetacchrutaṃ pārtha tvayaikāgreṇa cetasā .
verseTranslations: He who will study this spiritual discourse of ours, I assure thee, he shall thereby worship Me at the altar of Wisdom.
Yea, he who listens to it with faith and without doubt, even he, freed from evil, shall rise to the worlds which the virtuous attain through righteous deeds.
O Arjuna! Hast thou listened attentively to My words? Has thy ignorance and thy delusion gone?
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. This is the last chapter in Bhagavad Gita, and Bhagavan has given his final advice to us. It boils down to Sreyan Swadharma Vigunaha Paradharma Swanashti da. Your own Dharma is better for you than other dharma. And therefore he says, Sahajam Karma Kamateja Sadosham Abhiyana Tej. These are the two basic facts.

He pointed out to us that your welfare is in staying within your Dharma, whatever Dharma you have acquired through your own choice. My dharma as an architect -- I chose it myself. I decided to go to architecture school and therefore I became an architect. Bhagavan said, your welfare is in your Dharma. Don't try to practice something other than what you're good at. Then there was Sahajam Karma Kaunteya.

Do what comes naturally to you. Because of all your experiences and vasanas and tendencies and your training, there are few things in life which comes easier for you. And others don't stay with what comes naturally to you, even though other things look more glamorous, more glorious. But you say, even if your Dharma, you found it Sadosha Mapi, even there are some defects in it or not very perfect. Do actions in your own field which come naturally to you. There are the only two things he said, doing so you will overcome all your obstacles and you will never incur sin.

Working in the field which come naturally to you, keeping your own goal in mind that I'm doing it to get my ultimate happiness. But once you will never incur sin. Sin, as we have discussed, is a negative impression on my mind which creates agitations. All we are looking for in life is peace. Give me peace of mind. Peace of mind only comes when the mind is tranquil.

Because the mind will only be tranquil if you're working according to your own Dharma. And then he said the final advice after completing his entire discourse: now you do whatever you think is right for you. He gave you the complete choice one more time and said, let me summarize what I told you. Manmana Bhava mad Bhaktaha Madhya ji Mam namaskuruhu. In other words, Krishna said, if you want to summarize the entire teachings of Bhagavad Gita in half a verse, this is it.

To get the happiness which you are looking for, fix your mind onto me -- me, the all-pervading almighty self which is also your self. Focus your mind on that mad Bhaktah worship that identify with that Madhya Ji. Offer all your actions to me. Offer all your actions to the highest goal which you have when you go to the first grade. I'm learning this and that.

Because eventually I want to become a doctor. My granddaughter was telling me yesterday, I have two inventions I want to release before I became a doctor. So there is an ultimate goal in mind. That ultimate goal is to find perfect happiness. Perfect happiness is only there if my mind is tranquil. Bhagawan said, Madhya Ji, offer everything to me Maam namaskurohu and take refuge in me.

Then he clarified say Sarva Dharma and parity. Aham TVA Sarva Papebiha Moksa Kshya minasucha. Right now you think that you are incomplete. You have lots of baggage -- all your incompleteness and sins, the things which you have not done right. "I have not done this thing right in my life."

Bhagawan said, no, you cannot correct yourself on your own. But if you take refuge in me, I can correct that. Sarva Dharman Parityajya. And we have discussed this Sarva Dharman. Every role that I take, it comes with its own Dharma.

Every role a drama actor plays, it comes with its own requirement. Now if I start identifying with each role, then I'll get confused. I will have a nervous breakdown. I will have a personality disorder. I don't know who I am. Am I a king or a pauper?

Because I play so many different roles. The Bhagawan says, in your life, you take on too many of these roles. All those roles come with their own Dharma. My Dharma as a father. My Dharma as an architect. My Dharma as a husband.

My Dharma as a citizen of this country. My Dharma as an employer. All those Dharmas -- if I get bogged down into them and think that they will give me my happiness, then I'll be completely shattered. I do not really know which role is more important than others. Keep working in that dharma when you are there.

When you are an architect, act as an architect. When you are father, act as a father. But at the end of the day, you realize that you are something other than all the roles which you play. An actor in Beverly Hills knows that he is something other than the roles he plays. So Bhagawanja Sarva Dharma and Paritya Jya. At the end of the day, give up.

All those dharmas are not yours. But they belong to the roles which you play. While you're playing that role, you can't give up those dharmas. But once you're out of that role, leave those dharmas with that role and focus on who you are. Who is there One constant in all these roles which has its own dharma. So Bhagawan says, ma makeam sharam Braja.

Identify with that one single entity which is pervading through all the roles which you play. Ahamtva Sarva Pape bihamoksik Shami Mashu chah. Once you identify with that, all the limitations you have in each one of those roles are of no consequence because it only belongs to the role. You may not have played the role correctly. Fine, let's move on to the next one. One movie gets flopped, the actor doesn't get shattered.

He moves on to another one, waiting for the next hit. Don't get caught up in any of those roles as that's the only thing which is mine. And if I fail there, I have failed in it. Bhagavan said, you don't worry. Once you take refuge in your own self, everything will be alright. Now that you have learnt this knowledge, don't just sit back and relax.

That's not where your duty ends. You have to do your part. Now that you were privileged enough to know what is right, you also have an obligation to teach others what is right. And I, the parent, was a son at one point of time. And I got the advice from my parents and they told me what is right and wrong. I made my life right or wrong according to that.

And now I learned after my experience what is right and wrong. I have an obligation to pass on that knowledge to my children. Ya Imam paramam guhiyam mad bhakteshu abhi dashyathi bhakti mai param kutva Mama eva isyati asansaya. He said, there is one who declares this, teaches this knowledge of mine to my devotees, not to the people who are not interested in it, but those who are inspired themselves to make their life better, make their life appropriate, remove all the negatives from their life, but they still do not know how to do it. When you find those enthusiastic students, that's what you want to teach them. Therefore I said, the one who teaches this sacred knowledge of mind to my Bhakta, those who are devoted to this knowledge, Bhakti mai param kutva maam eva Eshyati asansayaha.

I consider that he is worshipping me. Bhagavan said, you don't have to come to my temple every day and put $1 in the Aarti or to do anything special. The greatest devotion we can offer to our teacher is to carry the torch of his knowledge. That's why we do Pada Puja. Because the platform on which my Guru is standing that the platform which I worship, that knowledge is important. Bhagawan said, one who spread this knowledge of mine which I gave it to you, to others, I consider him to be my devotee and therefore he will come to me without any doubt.

He will become one with me or Sansayah. No other thing needed. Bhagavan said, you just continue. You learn this knowledge, practice it, and then pass it on to the others. That Bhagavan said, I consider to my greatest devotion. So basically it encourages all of us, whatever little we have learned from Bhagavad Gita.

There is an obligation to impart the knowledge to someone else who is curious to know. He may not have the right frame of understanding, but he wants to know. You have an obligation to give him that knowledge. Bhagawan says, Nachatasmat manushesu kaschinmi priyakrutamaha. None other than that person who carries this torch of knowledge is dearer to me than him. He is the closest to me because he's carrying forward the mission that I have -- that I want to correct the misunderstanding in people.

You were confused, Arjuna. I gave you this discourse so that you can now act in your life correctly. Now you have an obligation to do that to someone else who you will find it in the same situation. And I consider that as my worship that you have appreciated what I have given you. And such a person is dearer to me. Some other people may come and other things for me, but they are of lesser value than you carrying forward my mission.

Bhavita Nachame tasmat anyaha Priyatara Bhuvi, not only now, but even in future, there won't be anyone who is dearer to me than the one who is spreading this knowledge to make this world better and spreading the right knowledge. So Swamiji points out here that we have this misconception in our Hinduism -- that we obviously don't convert people, we don't encourage people to come to our fold. In fact, we discourage people: "If someone has to be Hindu, you can't become a Hindu unless you're born Hindu." Swamiji says Sri Bhagawan clearly points out that that's not part of our culture.

We do not want forced conversion. We don't want to tell people who have not yet understood to believe in this knowledge. Give him his own time. Because forced conversion, forced imposition, never works in reality anywhere. Therefore you say, find people who are willing to understand this and give this knowledge. That's your obligation.

So that's a kind of missionary work. They never said that this knowledge should never be given out to anybody, or that it should not be given to people who are not from this class or the other. Simply: find the right person, the right group of people who are anxious to make their lives better. Give this knowledge to them. I'll consider that the greatest devotion to me. And he said, such a person is dear to me not only now, but this will never change.

It's not that right now I'm telling you this, but in the future it may be something different. It will hold true throughout history: whoever spreads his teacher's knowledge is the greatest devotee, and that is the greatest Guru Dakshina one can give to his teacher.

Now, let's say you consider that you are not capable of spreading this knowledge -- you don't have the resources, you don't have the temperament, you don't consider yourself worthy of doing so. But if you just listen to this: Adhyeshyate Cha Imam Dharmyam Samvadam Avayoho. This dialogue of ours, this sacred dialogue which deals with who you are in reality and who you are not, how to act in this world so that you can achieve your ultimate goal.

This dialogue which we had, which is sacred, even if you just study that listening is slightly different than studying one who studies this.
snippets.reflection:
These verses address studying and listening to the Gita. Verse 70: one who studies this dharmya-samvada (sacred dialogue) worships through jnana-yajna (knowledge-sacrifice). Verse 71: even one who merely listens with shraddha (faith) and without anasuya (fault-finding) becomes liberated and reaches the auspicious worlds of the righteous. Verse 72 is Krishna's final question to Arjuna: Have you listened with one-pointed mind? Has your delusion born of ignorance been destroyed?

The distinction between studying and listening is significant. Studying is active engagement - reading, contemplating, discussing. Listening is receptive - allowing the teaching to enter without immediate analysis or judgment. Both are valid paths. The key qualifier for listening is shraddha (faith) and absence of anasuya (carping criticism). Coming to spiritual teachings looking for flaws prevents any transmission. Coming with openness allows transformation.

How do you engage with spiritual teachings? Are you a student - actively working with the material, questioning, applying? Or a listener - receptively allowing wisdom to seep in? Both have value. Today, try the approach less natural to you. If you typically analyze, simply listen without judgment. If you typically receive passively, actively wrestle with one teaching. And honestly ask yourself Krishna's question: Has your ignorance-born delusion been dispelled? If confusion remains, that is honest and workable. But if there is pretense of understanding without genuine transformation, that is the real obstacle.

snippets.title: Day 238: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

सञ्जय उवाच |

व्यासप्रसादाच्छ्रुतवानेतद्गुह्यमहं परम् |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

sañjaya uvāca .

vyāsaprasādācchrutavānetadguhyamahaṃ param .
verseTranslations: Arjuna replied: My Lord! O Immutable One! My delusion has fled. By Thy Grace, O Changeless One, the light has dawned. My doubts are gone, and I stand before Thee ready to do Thy will.
Sanjaya said: Thus have I heard this rare, wonderful and soul-stirring discourse of the Lord Shri Krishna and the great-souled Arjuna.
Through the blessing of the sage Vyasa, I listened to this secret and noble science from the lips of its Master, the Lord Shri Krishna.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyasa Yoga. Yoga of Liberation through renunciation. Liberating yourself from all that is binding you. What is binding me is my limitations. I'm limiting myself by associating with my body, mind and intellectual. So in the end, Bhagavan Samara says, sarva Dharma Parityajya Maam Ekam Sharanam Praja.

Give up your dependence on your body, mind and intellect as the source of your happiness. That eternal happiness which you are seeking, you are right now dependent on your body, mind and intellect. I'll gain through my power, I'll gain through my intellect. I'll gain through my manipulating the others. Bhagavan said, give up all those and just take refuge in me, the source, the self, the consciousness. And I will take care of all your sins.

All the things which you have as negative impressions, I will take care of. I will wipe them out and make you clean so that you can experience the joy which is your nature. This is praptasya pravtvi. This is something which we already have. All we have to do is clear that which is veiling that happiness. So we concluded the discourse on Bhagavad Gita.

Bhagavan also said who you should not be teaching this knowledge to. One who does not have any discipline. One who does not have any devotion towards this knowledge. One who has no sense of service to others -- in other words, someone so self-centered. Such a person will not be able to learn anything from you because he's so self-centered.

Then lastly he said, the one who cavils at this knowledge or at me -- if I do not have any faith in any idea, I will never be able to learn. In Gujarati, when a child is crying for a long time, they say "Asu ragda tyanay" -- "Ragada" means "raga tana," pulling. "Why are you pulling all these ragas?" You know why they said that? There was a kind of contempt against the people who perform classical music and go on and on.

So when somebody has no appreciation for classical music, they associate it with babies crying: "Why are you doing ragada?" That's cavilling towards that art -- having no respect for it. Sometimes, you know, people go for a dance program and say, "So how was it?" "The same old South Indian dancing all the time." Because they were looking for Bollywood dancing, and it turned out to be a Kathak classical dancing concert.

Because they have no appreciation for the art. I have seen the Ghatapata -- the discourse about Vedanta where they use the analogy of the pot. Ghata Pata, Ghatapada -- in Bombay they say "Garbhad Karta," right? Ghatapata became "Gadbar." No appreciation for that discussion or discourse. Now such a person -- if you try to teach him the same thing, one who says "Garbhad" -- you try to teach him Vedanta, it will not work.

One who says "Vairu Ragda," he will not learn music. He has no appreciation for it. So Bhagavan says such a person, you should not be teaching this Bhagavad Gita. He has to come to a level where he has disciplined himself. He has devotion for this knowledge and he has a sense of service. In essence, he does not think about his own good but sees oneness with others.

That's how we do service. We can only serve somebody whom we revere, appreciate, or love. For one who has none of this for this knowledge, you should not be teaching that to him. On the other hand, Bhagavan said, if you have learned this knowledge -- by God's grace you got this chance to learn this precious knowledge from your teacher -- you should share it with others. Do not be self-centered.

If you're a Christian who comes and asks me, that's fine. You don't just become a scholar; share this with others. This is the concept of franchising, right? You have a concept and give it to others. That's how it grows into a huge multinational. Otherwise selling burger, how can that be a big business?

It is the simplest thing in the world. Take a bun and put a patty in between. Put little lettuce, tomato and ketchup, you're done. But it's a multinational entity. Because the concept of franchising. Somebody asked Einstein, is there anything baffles you in this world?

He said, the concept of compound interest. Somebody demonstrated to me: if you get one penny the first day, then it doubles the next day, and you keep doubling pennies -- versus I give you a million dollars right away -- which one in 20 years will be greater? He demonstrates that the doubling pennies will be worth millions of dollars. The compound interest. So compounding this knowledge for the greater good of society -- it is every student's duty to share this with others.

Those who are interested and are worthy. So therefore Bhagavan said, such a person will certainly will come to me now. Teaching this subject which you have learnt, you become master at it. After a while you become one with that subject. If you learn music, then continue teaching music. You will become a master of it.

Because you are practicing more and more and more by every time you teach to somebody else. So Bhagavan says, such a person will certainly come to me. He will become me in a sense he will attain that oneness he is seeking with his own supreme self. So Bhagavan is actively asking you to go out and teach others. How did Swami Chinmayananda become a Jagat Guru? By introducing the idea of the study group.

If he had just said "come to my lecture," we would have gone to his lectures and left. I did that for a long time. I met Swamiji when I was 17 years old. First I just went to his lectures, because in India I did not know about study groups. When I came to the USA, the first series I attended in 1983, I had no idea about study groups. But Swamiji said at the end of the Gita Yajna that those of you who are interested must now attend a study group. And I said, "What is a study group?"

So Gaurang Nanavati from Houston called me up because I had filled out that form. I had no interest really in joining a study group, because I was thinking, "Who else other than Swami Chinmayananda can teach me this?" But because Swamiji said it, I had that little Shraddha -- I must go. And that's how I went to a study group. This is where I started truly learning Bhagavad Gita, not from Swamiji's lectures.

So the idea of these study groups has made Chinmaya Mission a great organization in sharing this knowledge. The idea came from Bhagavan Sri Krishna: share your knowledge. Bhagavan said, such a person will certainly achieve the goal he's seeking. Then he said, there is no one in this world who is closer to me than the one who is teaching this Bhagavad Gita with Shraddha, with having supreme faith in me, in this knowledge.

You cannot teach something if you are not convinced about it. You can only convince others. If you are convinced about it with conviction. One who teaches this Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan says, I don't think there's anyone who is dearer to me, anyone who is nearer to me than that person. Because he came closest to the goal of becoming one with that universal self. So Bhagavan has glorified the teachers and the teachings.

And then he said, Adhyeshyate Cha Imam Dharmyam Samvadam Avayoho Gnana Yagnena Tena Aham Ishtaha Syam Iti Me Matihi. Now the student -- is there anything beneficial in just learning? One who studies this dialogue of ours about Dharma. This dialogue, Bhagavad Gita, all 18 chapters of it -- this is a dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna. So Krishna is telling Arjuna: this, our dialogue about Dharma.

What is right, what is wrong, what is real, what is unreal. Who studies such a person? I consider that such a person is worshipping me through Gnani Yajna. He may not be a Krishna Bhakta. He may not be doing Sri Krishna, Shranham, Sri Krishna, Shrana, Sri Krishna. He may not be going to the temple at all.

He may not bow down at Krishna's statue in the temple. But Bhagavan said -- it is not that I will consider or not consider -- it is my conviction that such a person is worshipping me through Gnana Yajna. So the student who is studying Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan said, is directly worshipping me. And we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita previously: how do you serve your teacher?

By living the ideal the teacher teaches is the best service to your teacher. Your teacher teaches you music and you don't do anything about it. But just keep giving him fees and never learned music. Is that a service to him? It may make his living. But he is not very proud of you.

But my teacher teaches me something and I excel in it. And then propagate that knowledge even further. He will be very proud when he hears about you. Even today, if you go and tell Gaurangbhai that you went to Neelkant's class -- you know why? He is my teacher. When he hears that, he knows that after all these years, Neelkant is still into Bhagavad Gita, has not given up.

That's a service to your teacher. So Bhagavan said, such a person, I'll consider that he's serving me directly. He's worshipping me directly through Gnana Yoga word Yajna Signifies sacrificial fire is invoked and devotees are offering oblations in it. You see here, the fire of knowledge is kindled by your studies and you are offering your ignorance into it. Up till now what I considered me and now no, it is not me. So my ignorance about myself, which in common language we call ego is what we are offering into this Gnar Yajna.

Therefore, Bhagavan said, I am convinced, I'm convicted that such a person is worshipping me through Gnan Yajna. So the student is glorified here. Then the next verse says, okay, but what about somebody who is not even studying? We have heard this before -- there is a difference between reading and studying. Swamiji explained: you read a newspaper.

You really have no other interest but to get some information what's going on? So you are reading newspaper, but you study your subject. I have to study because I want to know the knowledge. So not just reading Bhagavad Gita. So just chanting Bhagavad Gita may or may not do much good to you. But studying Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan said, I'm convinced that you are worshipping me through Gnani Yajna.

But what if I'm not studying? Shraddha Vaan Anasuyash Cha Shrunuyat Api Yo Naraha. A person who is listening to this knowledge -- he may not be studying intently, he may not be reading Bhagavad Gita. But he's listening to the discourse about Bhagavad Gita, about the knowledge of Bhagavad Gita from a Sadguru.

But you have to have faith in it. You're not just listening to find out what it is all about. With Shraddha -- when we listen to somebody like the Dalai Lama or Sri Sri Ravi Shankar or somebody in whom we have Shraddha -- we are intently listening to what he's saying. We're trying to understand the message behind it. That's Shraddha Vaan Anasuya. He's not listening to find out what is wrong in it.

As we had heard before, Max Muller and those scholars were given grants by European powers to go and study Sanskrit -- to find out what all this "garbage" was that they were teaching their people, and then tell them that it was all wrong. That's Anasuya -- cavilling at that knowledge. But if you are not doing it for that reason -- and it turns out that Max Muller became probably the greatest scholar because he probably had the real intention, even though his sponsors may not have -- then such a person who is just listening to this discourse about Bhagavad Gita, the knowledge of Bhagavad Gita, So Api Muktaha -- he also will get liberated.
snippets.reflection:
Verse 73 is Arjuna's triumphant response: nashto moha smritir labdha - my delusion is destroyed, my memory is restored. By Your grace, I stand firm with doubts dispelled. I shall do Your bidding. This is the complete transformation from chapter one's paralyzed, despairing warrior to a clarity-filled instrument ready for action. Smritir labdha - memory restored - refers to remembering his true nature, which ignorance had obscured.

Verses 74-75 shift to Sanjaya, the narrator, who expresses his own wonder: through Vyasa's grace, I heard this secret yoga directly from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga. This acknowledges the lineage of transmission - from Krishna to Arjuna, witnessed by Sanjaya through Vyasa's blessing. Knowledge flows through prepared channels, each receiving according to their capacity.

Arjuna's transformation is available to each of us. The starting point - confusion, paralysis, conflicting duties - is universal. The path - listening with attention, receiving with faith, contemplating with discrimination - is accessible. The destination - nashto moha, smritir labdha - is the same: delusion destroyed, true nature remembered. Today, ask yourself: What delusion still clouds my understanding? What truth about myself have I forgotten? The Gita promises that with sustained engagement and grace, the clouds part. Gata-sandeha karishye vachanam tava - doubt-free, I shall act according to truth. This is the goal: not escape from action but action rooted in clarity.

snippets.title: Day 239: Types of Action

snippets.transliteration:
rājansaṃsmṛtya saṃsmṛtya saṃvādamimamadbhutam .

tacca saṃsmṛtya saṃsmṛtya rūpamatyadbhutaṃ hareḥ .

verseTranslations: O King! The more I think of that marvellous and holy discourse, the more I lose myself in joy.
As memory recalls again and again the exceeding beauty of the Lord, I am filled with amazement and happiness.
Wherever is the Lord Shri Krishna, the Prince of Wisdom, and wherever is Arjuna, the Great Archer, I am more than convinced that good fortune, victory, happiness and righteousness will follow.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyas Yoga. We have come to the final concluding portion where Bhagavan has concluded his portion. Arjuna has confirmed that he is now completely in control of himself. His delusion is gone. He regained his memory. In other words, what is right and what is wrong, what needs to be done and what's to be avoided and what his real self is.

I'm now ready to do whatever you have asked me to do. In other words, I'm now ready to follow your instruction in Bhagavad Gita, which I have learnt so far from you. So I will now fight this war. Basically, when we are deluded and somebody gives advice and we are now ready to face the challenges of life, then we say, don't worry, I'm now ready. I will fight this battle. That's where Arjuna is now.

And the only other two people who are participating in this was Sanjaya, sitting in Dhritarashtra's palace. Dhritarashtra, the blind king, who is somewhat a cause for this conflict. Had he done what needed to be done for him as a king, we wouldn't have the situation of these two armies facing each other. Because of his blindness, his ignorance about what is right and wrong, the situation led to this battle of the war. So he's sitting in his palace. Sanjay, his charioteer or the personal assistant, had narrated what was going on between the Krishna and Arjuna.

As we had discussed before, this was only possible because Bhagavan Ved Vyas, in his last-ditch effort to stop this war, goes to Dhritarashtra and says, "You need to stop this. For you to see what's happening, I can give you a divine vision. This will lead to a disaster for the Kauravas." But Dhritarashtra was not comfortable, so he said, "I do not want this vision. Give it to my secretary; he can narrate it to me." And that's how Sanjaya got the divine vision, so he could see everything while sitting in the palace.

For all practical purposes, Sanjaya became the first telecaster who narrated what was happening in a distant place. He was given this vision so that he could not only see what was happening there, but also hear what Krishna and Arjuna were talking about, and even see in their minds what they were thinking. So now, since Arjuna has concluded, Sanjaya gives the final comments. The last five verses are Sanjaya's -- he is the third party. Arjuna was involved in it completely.

He was the recipient of this knowledge. Knowledge was directly given to him. Krishna was the giver of the knowledge, and he obviously had not only Arjuna but everyone's betterment in mind. Sanjaya is the third party, looking at the situation, and now gives his version of what he has seen.

So the next five verses which conclude Bhagavad Gita -- Sanjaya said: Ithi Aham Vasudevashya Parthasyacha Mahatmanah Samvadam Imam Ashrausham Adbhutam Romaharshanam. He said, "This is me witnessing the dialogue between Vasudeva and Partha." Krishna is called Vasudeva because he is the son of Vasudeva -- Vasudevasutam Devam, Devaki's son. He's also called Vasudeva because he is the Deva of the Vasavas.

The Vasavas, as we learned in chapter 10, are the deities of the seasons. There are eight seasons, and each season has its own presiding deity. As we have said, in our culture everything is personified, and nothing can really work in a chaotic situation. Everything has its own order. If there is order, we absolutely know there is a controller -- without any laws or enforcing agency, there cannot be any order. Since in nature there is a perfect order, there have to be lawmakers and law enforcers. The enforcing deities for these seasons are the Vasavas, the Vasus.

These eight Vasus are controlling the eight seasons. As we may have discussed before, the six seasons we commonly know are summer, winter, monsoon, and then subsets like spring and fall -- so there are six seasons. Where are the other two? The other two are in our mind: happiness and unhappiness.

So two micro seasons and six macro seasons make eight, with their presiding deities. All Vasus are Vasavas, and the Deva of the Vasus is Vasudeva. So he is the Deva of all the seasons -- in other words, the Deva of all the seasons in our life. He is the presiding deity, Vasudeva, the consciousness. All these eight seasons are perceived by me because consciousness is functioning through me.

So this is the dialogue between Vasudeva and Mahatmana Partha -- High-Souled Arjuna. Arjuna is called "High-Souled" here not because he was Krishna's cousin or Pandu's son, but because he is a normal man who faced the challenges of life and broke down -- yet he had the courage to listen to the right advice and rise to the situation. Therefore he is high-souled: not because he was perfect, not because he had no faults, but because he had the normal faults of a normal person and the courage to overcome them. So Sanjaya said, "The dialogue between the supreme self, the sacred, and the normal man Partha -- listening to this, I am so thrilled that I am having goosebumps."

What have I experienced so wonderful? He said this was an incredible dialogue which he never thought he would be able to witness in his life. And then he continues: Vyasa Prasadat Shrutavan Etat Guhyam Aham Param Yogam Yogeshwarat Krishnat Sakshat Kathayatah Svayam. "I had the good fortune of listening to this dialogue because of Vyasa Prasadat. I was not capable of listening to it on my own. I would never have been able to see what Krishna and Arjuna were talking about. It was possible for me to hear because of the grace of Vyasa." We have seen why Vyasa gave him the divine vision, and therefore he could listen to it.

Any experience which I feel is incredible in my life, I always think it came to me by somebody's grace -- in this case, Vyasa's grace. He said, Yogam Yogeshwarat Krishnat Sakshat Kathayatah -- this dialogue which describes the yoga, I heard directly from the mouth of Yogeshwara Krishna. We have learned before that Krishna is Yogeshwara -- he is the Lord of Yoga, the perfect Avatara. There was never a time he was not connected with his supreme self. He was always a man walking on this earth, yet always connected with his supreme self. One who is connected with his supreme self is a Yogi.

Krishna is Yogeshwara. He is the Lord of all yogis, because there was never a time in his life, from the time he was born till he left, when he was not connected to his supreme self. Sanjaya says, "I heard from a person who is Yogeshwara, from his mouth directly." In other words, it's not that this was something completely new to him.

Growing up in Vedic culture as the minister or private secretary of the great king, he had heard these things before. But now he heard directly from the Lord himself, the one who is one with the supreme self. So this now completely clarifies any doubt he ever had in his mind. This is now his direct knowledge. He experienced directly what the Lord has said. The next verse says: Rajan Samsmritya Samsmritya Samvadam Imam Adbhutam Keshava Arjunayoho Punyam Hrishyami Cha Muhurmuhuhu.

"I keep remembering what I have just experienced, over and over again. The more I think about it, the more joy it gives me -- to know that the self is immutable, imperishable. More and more I remember, and it gives me great strength and great joy, that I have heard from the great soul what reality is." So Sanjaya is trying to impress upon Dhritarashtra: you are not facing somebody mortal -- your sons are facing someone who is the Lord himself, who has direct knowledge. And he will be on Arjuna's side.

Tat Cha Samsmritya Samsmritya Rupam Atyadbhutam Hareho Vismayo Me Mahan Rajan Hrishyami Cha Punaha Punaha. "Not only did I hear the dialogue between the two, but I also saw his Virat Rupa, his cosmic form. I've seen your sons going into his mouth and getting crushed. I have seen these Mahatmas praising him, some in fear and some in awe." That wondrous vision -- Tat Samsmritya Hareho -- that wonderful, magnificent form, he keeps remembering over and over again. And he is wonderstruck.

"I am completely wonderstruck about that vision. O Rajan, Hrishyami Cha Punaha Punaha. I rejoice again and again just remembering the Lord's complete form." And I know that the victory will be on the side of the truth. Obviously all the good people who knew what is right, including Drona, Bheeshma, Sanjaya, Vidur. But they could not be on the Pandava side because of the Niti Shastra at that time, if you have eaten somebody's salt, in other words, if you're obliged by somebody, you have to be on their side, no matter how wrong he is.

Therefore they cannot be on the Pandavas' side. But they are making every effort to see whether Dhritarashtra changes his mind. He is the one person who has complete control to stop this war right then and there. But as we have said, he has already confessed he is very comfortable in his blindness, in his ignorance. He does not want to come out of his comfort zone of what he knows. This is basically where we are at some level -- clinging to something familiar.

We are afraid of change. That's why from one generation to another there is always a generation gap. In my old age, I am so comfortable in what I do. I get completely baffled by all this technology and social media. And so we need support from somebody younger who can guide us.

That's a source of wonder for me. The last verse is the complete conclusion of what Sanjaya has learned. But this is not merely Sanjaya's opinion -- it is a direct teaching for us on how to live life. It says: Yatra Yogeshwara Krishna Yatra Partha Dhanurdharaha Tatra Shri Vijaya Bhutihi Dhruvah Nitihi Matir Mama. Where there is Yogeshwara Krishna -- he didn't simply say just Krishna.

Where there is Krishna, where there is Arjuna -- Yatra Yogeshwara Krishna -- where there is the Lord of Yoga, the Lord Krishna. And what does that mean for us? That person is the one who is always one with his supreme self. That Yogeshwara Krishna is present in our consciousness. When we invoke our consciousness, our divine vision -- the sacred in us, the divine in us -- along with Yatra Partha Dhanurdharaha, where there is Arjuna with his bow and arrow ready to fight -- not lying on the ground as was the case in the first chapter. When we face challenges in this life, we have the tools to fight this battle.

But we get dejected and put our tools down and say I'm not ready. So we cannot win that battle and therefore there cannot be any success. World will be what it is. You will be facing this battle of life no matter how sacred and pious you are. Because that's the nature of the world. What you have to be is Dhanurdhara Partha -- not just Partha, but Dhanurdhara Partha. Partha is a common man like you and I.

The only difference is he's ready to fight. So when you are ready to fight the challenges of life -- but not just with your ego saying, "I can take care of myself" --
snippets.reflection:
The Gita concludes with Sanjaya's joyful declaration. Verses 76-77: repeatedly remembering this wonderful, sacred dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I rejoice again and again. Recalling that supremely wondrous form of Hari, great is my amazement, and I rejoice repeatedly. The teaching has not just informed Sanjaya but transformed him. He cannot stop thinking about it, and each remembrance brings fresh joy and wonder.

Verse 78 is the Gita's triumphant conclusion: yatra Yogeshvara Krishna yatra Partho dhanurdharah tatra shrir vijayo bhutir dhruva nitir - wherever is Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, and Arjuna, the archer with bow ready, there are fortune, victory, prosperity, and firm righteousness. This is the promise and the formula. When higher wisdom (Krishna/Yogeshvara) combines with prepared, committed action (Arjuna/Dhanurdhara), success is assured.

This final verse is your daily practice in condensed form: Invoke the Lord of Yoga in your heart - the wisdom, the guidance, the connection to the Supreme. Then take up your bow - bring your skills, your preparation, your readiness to act. Together, these ensure victory - not necessarily the victory your ego envisions, but the victory of dharma, the triumph of what is right. Today, bring both elements to whatever challenge you face: yogeshvara (higher guidance) and dhanurdhara (capable readiness). Neither alone is sufficient - passive wisdom without action, or frantic action without wisdom, both fail. United, they are invincible. This is the Gita's final teaching: connect to the Source, prepare yourself, act decisively. Shri, vijaya, bhuti, and dhruva niti will follow.
